Information about Project Gutenberg (one page)

We produce about two million dollars for each hour we work.  The
fifty hours is one conservative estimate for how long it we take
to get any etext selected, entered, proofread, edited, copyright
searched and analyzed, the copyright letters written, etc.  This
projected audience is one hundred million readers.  If our value
per text is nominally estimated at one dollar, then we produce 2
million dollars per hour this year we, will have to do four text
files per month:  thus upping our productivity from one million.
The Goal of Project Gutenberg is to Give Away One Trillion Etext
Files by the December 31, 2001.  [10,000 x 100,000,000=Trillion]
This is ten thousand titles each to one hundred million readers,
which is 10% of the expected number of computer users by the end
of the year 2001.

We need your donations more than ever!

All donations should be made to "Project Gutenberg/IBC", and are
tax deductible to the extent allowable by law ("IBC" is Illinois
Benedictine College).  (Subscriptions to our paper newsletter go
to IBC, too)

<-- p. 723 -->

<centered><point26>I.</point26></centered>

<hw>I</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>. <sn>1.</sn> <def>I, the ninth letter of
the English alphabet, takes its form from the Ph\'d2nician,
through the Latin and the Greek. The Ph\'d2nician letter was
probably of Egyptian origin. Its original value was nearly the
same as that of the Italian I, or long <xex>e</xex> as in
<xex>mete</xex>. Etymologically I is most closely related to
<xex>e</xex>, <xex>y</xex>, <xex>j</xex>, <xex>g</xex>; as in
d<xex>i</xex>nt, d<xex>e</xex>nt, b<xex>e</xex>verage, L.
b<xex>i</xex>bere; E. k<xex>i</xex>n, AS. c<xex>y</xex>nn; E.
th<xex>i</xex>n, AS. <?/<xex>y</xex>nne; E. domin<xex>i</xex>on,
don<xex>j</xex>on, dun<xex>g</xex>eon.</def>
   In English I has two principal vowel sounds: the long sound,
as in <xex>p\'c6ne</xex>, <xex>\'c6ce</xex>; and the short sound,
as in <xex>p<icr/n</xex>. It has also three other sounds:
(<xex>a</xex>) That of <xex>e</xex> in <xex>term</xex>, as in
<xex>thirst</xex>. (<xex>b</xex>) That of <xex>e</xex> in
<xex>mete</xex> (in words of foreign origin), as in
<xex>machine</xex>, <xex>pique</xex>, <xex>regime</xex>.
(<xex>c</xex>) That of consonant <xex>y</xex> (in many words in
which it precedes another vowel), as in <xex>bunion</xex>,
<xex>million</xex>, <xex>filial</xex>, <xex>Christian</xex>, etc.
It enters into several digraphs, as in <xex>fail</xex>,
<xex>field</xex>, <xex>seize</xex>, <xex>feign</xex>.
<xex>friend</xex>; and with <xex>o</xex> often forms a proper
diphtong, as in <xex>oil</xex>, <xex>join</xex>, <xex>coin</xex>.

<p>See <xex>Guide to Pronunciation</xex>, <sect/<sect/
98-106.</p>

<note>The dot which we place over the small or lower case
<ex>i</ex> dates only from the 14th century. The sounds of I and
J were originally represented by the same character, and even
after the introduction of the form J into English dictionaries,
words containing these letters were, till a comparatively recent
time, classed together.</note>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>In our old authors, <it>I</it> was often used
for <it>ay</it> (or <it>aye</it>), yes, which is pronounced
nearly like it.</def>

<sn>3.</sn> <def>As a numeral, I stands for 1, II for 2,
etc.</def>

<hw>I-</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>prefix.</pos> <def>See
<er>Y-</er>.</def>

<hw>I</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>pron.</pos>
<wordforms>[<pos>poss.</pos> <er>My</er> <pr>(?)</pr> or
<er>Mine</er> <pr>(<?/)</pr>; <pos>object.</pos> <er>Me</er>
<pr>(?)</pr>. <plu>pl. <pos>nom.</pos> <plw>We</plw>
<pr>(<?/)</pr>; <pos>poss.</pos> <plw>Our</plw> <pr>(?)</pr> or
<plw>Ours</plw> <pr>(<?/)</pr>; <pos>object.</pos> <plw>Us</plw>
<pr>(?)</pr>.</plu>]</wordforms> <ety>[OE. <ets>i</ets>,
<ets>ich</ets>, <ets>ic</ets>, AS. <ets>ic</ets>; akin to OS. &
D. <ets>ik</ets>, OHG. <ets>ih</ets>, G. <ets>ich</ets>, Icel.
<ets>ek</ets>, Dan. <ets>jeg</ets>, Sw. <ets>jag</ets>, Goth.
<ets>ik</ets>, OSlav. <ets>az'</ets>, Russ. <ets>ia</ets>, W.
<ets>i</ets>, L. <ets>ego</ets>, Gr. <?/, <?/, Skr.
<ets>aham</ets>. <root/179. Cf. <er>Egoism</er>.]</ety> <def>The
nominative case of the pronoun of the first person; the word with
which a speaker or writer denotes himself.</def>

<hw>I*am`a*tol"o*gy</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[Gr.
<?/, <?/, medicine + <ets>-logy</ets>.]</ety> <fld>(Med.)</fld>
<def>Materia Medica; that branch of therapeutics which treats of
remedies.</def>

<hw>I"amb</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[Cf. F.
<ets>iambe</ets>. See <er>Lambus</er>.]</ety> <def>An iambus or
iambic.</def> <mark>[R.]</mark>

<hw>I*am"bic</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>a.</pos> <ety>[L.
<ets>iambicus</ets>, Gr. <?/: cf. F. <ets>iambique</ets>.]</ety>
<sn>1.</sn> <fld>(Pros.)</fld> <def>Consisting of a short
syllable followed by a long one, or of an unaccented syllable
followed by an accented; <as>as, an <ex>iambic</ex>
foot</as>.</def>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>Pertaining to, or composed of, iambics; <as>as,
an <ex>iambic</ex> verse; <ex>iambic</ex> meter. See
<er>Lambus</er>.</as></def>

<hw>I*am"bic</hw>, <pos>n.</pos> <sn>1.</sn> <fld>(Pros.)</fld>
<sd>(a)</sd> <def>An iambic foot; an iambus.</def> <sd>(b)</sd>
<def>A verse composed of iambic feet.</def>

<note><hand/ The following couplet consists of iambic
verses.</note>

<q>Thy gen- | ius calls | thee not | to pur- | chase fame
In keen | <qex>iam-</qex> | <qex>bics</qex>, but | mild an- |
agram.</q>
<qau>Dryden.</qau>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>A satirical poem (such poems having been
anciently written in iambic verse); a satire; a lampoon.</def>

<hw>I*am"bic*al</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>a.</pos>
<def>Iambic.</def> <mark>[Obs. or R.]</mark>

<hw>I*am"bic*al*ly</hw>, <pos>adv.</pos> <def>In a iambic manner;
after the manner of iambics.</def>

<hw>I*am"bize</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>v. t.</pos> <ety>[Gr.
<?/.]</ety> <def>To satirize in iambics; to lampoon.</def>
<mark>[R.]</mark>

<hw>I*am"bus</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos>; <plu>pl. L.
<plw>Iambi</plw> <pr>(#)</pr>, E. <plw>Iambuses</plw>
<pr>(#)</pr></plu>. <ety>[L. <ets>iambus</ets>, Gr. <?/; prob.
akin to <?/ to throw, assail (the iambus being first used in
satiric poetry), and to L. <ets>jacere</ets> to throw. Cf.
<er>Jet</er> a shooting forth.]</ety> <fld>(Pros.)</fld> <def>A
foot consisting of a short syllable followed by a long one, as in
<xex><acr/m\'bens</xex>, or of an unaccented syllable followed by
an accented one, as <xex>invent</xex>; an iambic. See the Couplet
under <er>Iambic</er>, <pos>n.</pos></def>

<hw>\'d8I*an"thi*na</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos>; <plu>pl. L.
<plw>Ianthin\'91</plw> <pr>(#)</pr>, E. <plw>Ianthinas</plw>
<pr>(#)</pr></plu>. <ety>[NL., fr. L. <ets>ianthinus</ets>
violet-blue, Gr. <?/; <?/ violet + <?/ flower.]</ety>
<fld>(Zo\'94l.)</fld> <def>Any gastropod of the genus
<spn>Ianthina</spn>, of which various species are found living in
mid ocean; -- called also <altname>purple shell</altname>, and
<altname>violet snail</altname>.</def> <altsp>[Written also
<asp>janthina</asp>.]</altsp>

<note><hand/ It floats at the surface by means of a raft, which
it constructs by forming and uniting together air bubbles of
hardened mucus. The Tyrian purple of the ancients was obtained in
part from mollusks of this genus.</note>

<hw>I*a`tra*lip"tic</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>a.</pos> <ety>[Gr.
<?/; <?/ physician + <?/ belonging to the <?/ or anointer, fr.
<?/ to anoint: cf. F. <ets>iatraliptique</ets>.]</ety>
<def>Treating diseases by anointing and friction; <as>as, the
<ex>iatraliptic</ex> method</as>.</def> <altsp>[Written also
<asp>iatroleptic</asp>.]</altsp>

<mhw>{ <hw>I*at"ric</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <hw>I*at"ric*al</hw>
<pr>(?)</pr>, }</mhw> <pos>a.</pos> <ety>[Gr. <?/ healing, fr.
<?/ physician, fr. <?/ to heal.]</ety> <def>Of or pertaining to
medicine, or to medical men.</def>

<hw>I*a`tro*chem"ic*al</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>a.</pos> <def>Of
or pertaining to iatrochemistry, or to the iatrochemists.</def>

<hw>I*a`tro*chem"ist</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[Gr.
<?/ physician + E. <ets>chemist</ets>.]</ety> <def>A physician
who explained or treated diseases upon chemical principles; one
who practiced iatrochemistry.</def>

<hw>I*a`tro*chem"is*try</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos>
<def>Chemistry applied to, or used in, medicine; -- used
especially with reference to the doctrines in the school of
physicians in Flanders, in the 17th century, who held that health
depends upon the proper chemical relations of the fluids of the
body, and who endeavored to explain the conditions of health or
disease by chemical principles.</def>

<hw>I*a`tro*math`e*mat"ic*al</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>a.</pos>
<def>Of or pertaining to iatromathematicians or their
doctrine.</def>

<hw>I*a`tro*math`e*ma*ti"cian</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos>
<ety>[Gr. <?/ physician + E. <ets>mathematician</ets>.]</ety>
<fld>(Hist. Med.)</fld> <def>One of a school of physicians in
Italy, about the middle of the 17th century, who tried to apply
the laws of mechanics and mathematics to the human body, and
hence were eager student of anatomy; -- opposed to the
<xex>iatrochemists</xex>.</def>

<hw>I*be"ri*an</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>a.</pos> <def>Of or
pertaining to Iberia.</def>

<hw>I"bex</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos>; <plu>pl. E.
<plw>Ibexes</plw> <pr>(#)</pr>, L. <plw>Ibices</plw>
<pr>(#)</pr></plu>. <ety>[L., a kind of goat, the chamois.]</ety>
<fld>(Zo\'94l.)</fld> <def>One of several species of wild goats
having very large, recurved horns, transversely ridged in front;
-- called also <altname>steinbok</altname>.</def>

<note><hand/ The Alpine ibex (<spn>Capra ibex</spn>) is the best
known. The Spanish, or Pyrenean, ibex (<spn>C. Hispanica</spn>)
has smoother and more spreading horns.</note>

<hw>\'d8I*bi"dem</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>adv.</pos>
<ety>[L.]</ety> <def>In the same place; -- abbreviated
<xex>ibid.</xex> or <xex>ib.</xex></def>

<hw>I"bis</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[L.
<ets>ibis</ets>, Gr. <?/; of Egyptian origin.]</ety>
<fld>(Zo\'94l.)</fld> <def>Any bird of the genus <spn>Ibis</spn>
and several allied genera, of the family <spn>Ibid\'91</spn>,
inhabiting both the Old World and the New. Numerous species are
known. They are large, wading birds, having a long, curved beak,
and feed largely on reptiles.</def>

<note><hand/ The sacred ibis of the ancient Egyptians (<spn>Ibis
\'92thiopica</spn>) has the head and neck black, without
feathers. The plumage of the body and wings is white, except the
tertiaries, which are lengthened and form a dark purple plume. In
ancient times this bird was extensively domesticated in Egypt,
but it is now seldom seen so far north. The glossy ibis
(<spn>Plegadis autumnalis</spn>), which is widely distributed
both in the Old World and the New, has the head and neck
feathered, except between the eyes and bill; the scarlet ibis
(<spn>Guara rubra</spn>) and the white ibis (<spn>G. alba</spn>)
inhabit the West Indies and South America, and are rarely found
in the United States. The wood ibis (<spn>Tantalus
loculator</spn>) of America belongs to the Stork family
(<spn>Ciconid\'91</spn>). See <er>Wood ibis</er>.</note>

<hw>-i*ble</hw> <pr>(?)</pr><def>. See <er>-able</er>.</def>

<hw>-ic</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>. <ety>[L. -<ets>icus</ets>, Gr. <?/:
cf. F. -<ets>ique</ets>.]</ety> <sn>1.</sn> <def>A suffix
signifying, in general, <xex>relating to</xex>, or
<xex>characteristic of</xex>; <as>as, histor<ex>ic</ex>,
hygien<ex>ic</ex>, telegraph<ex>ic</ex>, etc.</as></def>

<sn>2.</sn> <fld>(Chem.)</fld> <def>A suffix, denoting that the
element indicated enters into certain compounds with its
<xex>highest valence</xex>, or with a valence relatively higher
than in compounds where the name of the element ends in
-<xex>ous</xex>; <as>as, ferr<ex>ic</ex>,
sulphur<ex>ic</ex></as>. It is also used in the general sense of
<xex>pertaining to</xex>; <as>as, hydr<ex>ic</ex>,
sod<ex>ic</ex>, calc<ex>ic</ex></as>.</def>

<hw>I*ca"ri*an</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>a.</pos> <ety>[L.
<ets>Icarius</ets>, Gr. <?/, fr. <?/, the mythic son of
D\'91dalus, who, when flying from Crete on wings cemented with
wax, mounted so high that the sun melted the wax, and he fell
into the sea.]</ety> <def>Soaring too high for safety, like
Icarus; adventurous in flight.</def>

<hw>Ice</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[OE. <ets>is</ets>,
<ets>iis</ets>, AS. <ets>\'c6s</ets>; aksin to D. <ets>ijs</ets>,
G. <ets>eis</ets>, OHG. <ets>\'c6s</ets>, Icel.
<ets>\'c6ss</ets>, Sw. <ets>is</ets>, Dan. <ets>iis</ets>, and
perh. to E. <ets>iron</ets>.]</ety> <sn>1.</sn> <def>Water or
other fluid frozen or reduced to the solid state by cold; frozen
water. It is a white or transparent colorless substance,
crystalline, brittle, and viscoidal. Its specific gravity (0.92,
that of water at 4\'f8 C. being 1.0) being less than that of
water, ice floats.</def>

<note><hand/ Water freezes at 32\'f8 F. or 0\'f8 Cent., and ice
melts at the same temperature. Ice owes its cooling properties to
the large amount of heat required to melt it.</note>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>Concreted sugar.</def>

<au>Johnson.</au>

<sn>3.</sn> <def>Water, cream, custard, etc., sweetened,
flavored, and artificially frozen.</def>

<sn>4.</sn> <def>Any substance having the appearance of ice;
<as>as, camphor <ex>ice</ex></as>.</def>

<cs><col>Anchor ice</col>, <cd>ice which sometimes forms about
stones and other objects at the bottom of running or other water,
and is thus attached or <xex>anchored<xex> to the ground.</cd> --
<col>Bay ice</col>, <cd>ice formed in bays, fiords, etc., often
in extensive fields which drift out to sea.</cd> -- <col>Ground
ice</col>, <cd>anchor ice.</cd> -- <col>Ice age</col>
<fld>(Geol.)</fld>, <cd>the glacial epoch or period. See under
<er>Glacial</er>.</cd> -- <col>Ice anchor</col>
<fld>(Naut.)</fld>, <cd>a grapnel for mooring a vessel to a field
of ice. <au>Kane</au>.</cd> -- <col>Ice blink</col> <ety>[Dan.
<ets>iisblink<ets>]</ety>, <cd>a streak of whiteness of the
horizon, caused by the reflection of light from ice not yet in
sight.</cd> -- <col>Ice boat</col>. <sd>(a)</sd> <cd>A boat
fitted with skates or runners, and propelled on ice by sails; an
ice yacht.</cd> <sd>(b)</sd> <cd>A strong steamboat for breaking
a channel through ice.</cd> -- <mcol><col>Ice box</col> <or/
<col>chest</col></mcol>, <cd>a box for holding ice; a box in
which things are kept cool by means of ice; a refrigerator.</cd>
-- <col>Ice brook</col>, <cd>a brook or stream as cold as ice.
<mark>[Poetic]</mark> <au>Shak</au>.</cd> -- <col>Ice cream</col>
<ety>[for <ets>iced cream<ets>]</ety>, <cd>cream, milk, or
custard, sweetened, flavored, and frozen.</cd> -- <col>Ice
field</col>, <cd>an extensive sheet of ice.</cd> --
<mcol><col>Ice float</col>, <col>Ice floe</col></mcol>, <cd>a
sheet of floating ice similar to an ice field, but smaller.</cd>
-- <col>Ice foot</col>, <cd>shore ice in Arctic regions; an ice
belt. <au>Kane</au>.</cd> -- <col>Ice house</col>, <cd>a
close-covered pit or building for storing ice.</cd> -- <col>Ice
machine</col> <fld>(Physics)</fld>, <cd>a machine for making ice
artificially, as by the production of a low temperature through
the sudden expansion of a gas or vapor, or the rapid evaporation
of a volatile liquid.</cd> -- <col>Ice master</col>. <cd>See
<cref>Ice pilot</cref> (below).</cd> -- <col>Ice pack</col>,
<cd>an irregular mass of broken and drifting ice.</cd> --
<col>Ice paper</col>, <cd>a transparent film of gelatin for
copying or reproducing; <xex>papier glac\'82<xex>.</cd> --
<col>Ice petrel</col> <fld>(Zo\'94l.)</fld>, <cd>a shearwater
(<spn>Puffinus gelidus</spn>) of the Antarctic seas, abundant
among floating ice.</cd> -- <col>Ice pick</col>, <cd>a sharp
instrument for breaking ice into small pieces.</cd> -- <col>Ice
pilot</col>, <cd>a pilot who has charge of a vessel where the
course is obstructed by ice, as in polar seas; -- called also
<altname>ice master</altname>.</cd> -- <col>Ice pitcher</col>,
<cd>a pitcher adapted for ice water.</cd> -- <col>Ice plow</col>,
<cd>a large tool for grooving and cutting ice.</cd> <-- <col>ice
sculpture</col> = a sculpture carved from a block of ice, often
used for decorating restaurants. <col>ice show</col> an
entertainment consisting of ice skaters performing figure-skating
on a sheet of ice, usually in an arena, often accompanied by
music. --> -- <col>Ice sludge</col>, <cd>bay ice broken small by
the wind or waves; sludge.</cd> -- <col>Ice spar</col>
<fld>(Min.)</fld>, <cd>a variety of feldspar, the crystals of
which are very clear like ice; rhyacolite.</cd> -- <col>Ice
tongs</col>, <cd>large iron nippers for handling ice.</cd> --
<col>Ice water</col>. <sd>(a)</sd> <cd>Water cooled by ice.</cd>
<sd>(b)</sd> <cd>Water formed by the melting of ice.</cd> --
<col>Ice yacht</col>. <cd>See <cref>Ice boat</cref> (above).</cd>
-- <col>To break the ice</col>. <cd>See under
<er>Break</er>.</cd> -- <col>Water ice</col>, <cd>a confection
consisting of water sweetened, flavored, and frozen.<-- also
called Italian ice --></cd></cs>

<hw>Ice</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>v. t.</pos> <wordforms>[<pos>imp.
& p. p.</pos> <er>Iced</er> <pr>(?)</pr>; <pos>p. pr. & vb.
n.</pos> <er>Icing</er> <pr>(?)</pr>.]</wordforms> <sn>1.</sn>
<def>To cover with ice; to convert into ice, or into something
resembling ice.</def>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>To cover with icing, or frosting made of sugar
and milk or white of egg; to frost, as cakes, tarts, etc.</def>

<sn>3.</sn> <def>To chill or cool, as with ice; to freeze.</def>

<hw>Ice"berg`</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[Prob. of
Scand. origin; cf. Dan. <ets>iisbierg</ets>, Sw.
<ets>isberg</ets>, properly, a mountain of ice. See <er>Ice</er>,
and <er>Berg</er>.]</ety> <def>A large mass of ice, generally
floating in the ocean.</def>

<note><hand/ Icebergs are large detached portions of glaciers,
which in cold regions often project into the sea.</note>

<hw>Ice"bird`</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos>
<fld>(Zo\'94l.)</fld> <def>An Arctic sea bird, as the Arctic
fulmar.</def>

<hw>Ice"bound`</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>a.</pos> <def>Totally
surrounded with ice, so as to be incapable of advancing; <as>as,
an <ex>icebound</ex> vessel</as>; also, surrounded by or fringed
with ice so as to hinder easy access; <as>as, an
<ex>icebound</ex> coast</as>.</def>

<hw>Ice"-built`</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>a.</pos> <sn>1.</sn>
<def>Composed of ice.</def>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>Loaded with ice.</def> \'bd<xex>Ice-built</xex>
mountains.\'b8

<au>Gray.</au>

<hw>Iced</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>a.</pos> <sn>1.</sn>
<def>Covered with ice; chilled with ice; <as>as, <ex>iced</ex>
water</as>.</def>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>Covered with something resembling ice, as sugar
icing; frosted; <as>as, <ex>iced</ex> cake</as>.</def>

<cs><col>Iced cream</col>. <cd>Same as <xex>Ice cream<xex>, under
<er>Ice</er>.</cd></cs>

<hw>Ice"fall`</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <def>A frozen
waterfall, or mass of ice resembling a frozen waterfall.</def>

<au>Coleridge.</au>

<hw>Ice"land*er</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <def>A native,
or one of the Scandinavian people, of Iceland.</def>

<hw>Ice*lan"dic</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>a.</pos> <def>Of or
pertaining to Iceland; relating to, or resembling, the
Icelanders.</def>

<hw>Ice*lan"dic</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <def>The
language of the Icelanders. It is one of the Scandinavian group,
and is more nearly allied to the Old Norse than any other
language now spoken.</def>

<hw>Ice"land moss`</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>. <fld>(Bot.)</fld> <def>A
kind of lichen (<spn>Cetraria Icelandica</spn>) found from the
Arctic regions to the North Temperate zone. It furnishes a
nutritious jelly and other forms of food, and is used in
pulmonary complaints as a demulcent.</def>

<hw>Ice"land spar`</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>. <fld>(Min.)</fld> <def>A
transparent variety of calcite, the best of which is obtained in
Iceland. It is used for the prisms of the polariscope, because of
its strong double refraction. Cf. <er>Calcite</er>.</def>

<hw>Ice"man</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos>; <plu>pl.
<plw>Icemen</plw> <pr>(<?/)</pr>.</plu> <sn>1.</sn> <def>A man
who is skilled in traveling upon ice, as among glaciers.</def>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>One who deals in ice; one who retails or
delivers ice.</def>

<-- The Iceman Cometh (Title of a book) -->

<hw>Ice" plant`</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>. <fld>(Bot.)</fld> <def>A plant
(<spn>Mesembryanthemum crystallinum</spn>), sprinkled with
pellucid, watery vesicles, which glisten like ice. It is native
along the Mediterranean, in the Canaries, and in South Africa.
Its juice is said to be demulcent and diuretic; its ashes are
used in Spain in making glass.</def>

<-- 
 Ice skate = a shoe with a metal runner (called a blade) attached
to permit the wearer to glide on ice -->
 Ice-skater  = one who skates on ice wearing an ice skate; esp.
an athlete who performs athletic or artistic movements on a sheet
of ice, wearing ice skates; including speed skater and figure
skater -->

<-- p. 724 -->

<hw>Ice"quake`</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <def>The crash or
concussion attending the breaking up of masses of ice, -- often
due to contraction from extreme cold.</def>

<hw>Ich</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>pron.</pos> <def>I.</def>
<mark>[Obs.]</mark>

<au>Chaucer.</au>

<note><hand/ In the Southern dialect of Early English this is the
regular form. Cf. <er>Ik</er>.</note>

<hw>Ich*neu"mon</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[L., fr.
Gr. <?/, lit., the tracker; so called because it hunts out the
eggs of the crocodile, fr. <?/ to track or hunt after, fr. <?/
track, footstep.]</ety> <sn>1.</sn> <fld>(Zo\'94l.)</fld>
<def>Any carnivorous mammal of the genus <spn>Herpestes</spn>,
and family <spn>Viverrid\'91</spn>. Numerous species are found in
Asia and Africa. The Egyptian species(<spn>H. ichneumon</spn>),
which ranges to Spain and Palestine, is noted for destroying the
eggs and young of the crocodile as well as various snakes and
lizards, and hence was considered sacred by the ancient
Egyptians. The common species of India (<spn>H. griseus</spn>),
known as the mongoose, has similar habits and is often
domesticated. It is noted for killing the cobra.</def>

<sn>2.</sn> <fld>(Zo\'94l.)</fld> <def>Any hymenopterous insect
of the family <spn>Ichneumonid\'91</spn>, of which several
thousand species are known, belonging to numerous genera.</def>

<note><hand/ The female deposits her eggs upon, or in, the bodies
of other insects, such as caterpillars, plant lice, etc. The
larva lives upon the internal tissues of the insect in which it
is parasitic, and finally kills it. Hence, many of the species
are beneficial to agriculture by destroying noxious
insects.</note>

<cs><col>Ichneumon fly</col>. <cd>See <er>Ichneumon</er>,
2.</cd></cs>

<hw>Ich`neu*mon"i*dan</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>a.</pos>
<fld>(Zo\'94l.)</fld> <def>Of or pertaining to the
<spn>Ichneumonid\'91</spn>, or ichneumon flies.</def> --
<def2><pos>n.</pos> <def>One of the
<xex>Ichneumonid\'91</xex>.</def></def2>

<hw>\'d8Ich`thy*op`te*ryg"i*um</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos>
<ety>[NL., fr. Gr. <?/, <?/, a fish + <?/ a fin.]</ety>
<fld>(Anat.)</fld> <def>The typical limb, or lateral fin, of
fishes.</def>

<hw>\'d8Ich`thy*or"nis</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos>
<ety>[NL., fr. Gr. <?/, <?/, a fish + <?/ bird.]</ety>
<fld>(Paleon.)</fld> <def>An extinct genus of toothed birds found
in the American Cretaceous formation. It is remarkable for having
biconcave vertebr\'91, and sharp, conical teeth set in sockets.
Its wings were well developed. It is the type of the order
Odontotorm\'91.</def>

<hw>Ich"thy*o*saur</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[Cf. F.
<ets>ichthyosaure</ets>.]</ety> <fld>(Paleon.)</fld> <def>One of
the Ichthyosaura.</def>

<hw>\'d8Ich`thy*o*sau"ri*a</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n. pl.</pos>
<ety>[NL. See <er>Ichthyosaurus</er>.]</ety> <fld>(Paleon.)</fld>
<def>An extinct order of marine reptiles, including Ichthyosaurus
and allied forms; -- called also
<altname>Ichthyopterygia</altname>. They have not been found
later than the Cretaceous period.</def>

<hw>Ich`thy*o*sau"ri*an</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>a.</pos>
<fld>(Paleon.)</fld> <def>Of or pertaining to the
Ichthyosauria.</def> -- <def2><pos>n.</pos> <def>One of the
Ichthyosauria.</def></def2>

<hw>\'d8Ich`thy*o*sau"rus</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos>;
<plu>pl. <plw>Ichthyosauri</plw> <pr>(#)</pr></plu>. <ety>[NL.,
fr. Gr. <grk>'ichqy`s</grk>, <grk>-y`os</grk>, a fish +
<grk>say^ros</grk> a lizard.]</ety> <fld>(Paleon.)</fld> <def>An
extinct genus of marine reptiles; -- so named from their short,
biconcave vertebr\'91, resembling those of fishes. Several
species, varying in length from ten to thirty feet, are known
from the Liassic, O\'94litic, and Cretaceous formations.</def>

<hw>-ics</hw> <pr>(?)</pr><def>. A suffix used in forming the
names of certain sciences, systems, etc., as
acoust<xex>ics</xex>, mathemat<xex>ics</xex>,
dynam<xex>ics</xex>, statist<xex>ics</xex>, polit<xex>ics</xex>,
athlet<xex>ics</xex>.</def>

<note><hand/ The names sciences ending in <xex>ics</xex>, as
<xex>mathematics</xex>, <xex>mechanics</xex>,
<xex>metaphysics</xex>, <xex>optics</xex>, etc., are, with
respect to their form, nouns in the plural number. The plural
form was probably introduced to mark the complex nature of such
sciences; and it may have been in imitation of the use of the
Greek plurals <?/, <?/, <?/, <?/, etc., to designate parts of
Aristotle's writings. Previously to the present century, nouns
ending in <xex>ics</xex> were construed with a verb or a pronoun
in the plural; but it is now generally considered preferable to
treat them as singular. In Greman we have <xex>die
Mathematik</xex>, <xex>die Mechanik</xex>, etc., and in French
<xex>la metaphysique</xex>, <xex>la optique</xex>, etc.,
corresponding to our <xex>mathematics</xex>,
<xex>mechanics</xex>, <xex>metaphysics</xex>, <xex>optics</xex>,
etc.

<q><qex>Mathematics have</qex> for their object the consideration
of whatever is capable of being numbered or measured.</q>
<qau>John Davidson.</qau>

The citations subjoined will serve as examples of the best
present usage.

<q>Ethics is the sciences of the laws which govern our actions as
moral agents.</q>
<qau>Sir W. Hamilton.</qau>

<q>All parts of knowledge have their origin in
<qex>metaphysics</qex>, and finally, perhaps, revolve into
<qex>it</qex>.</q>
<qau>De Quincey.</qau>

<q><qex>Mechanics</qex>, like pure <qex>mathematics</qex>, may be
geometrical, or may be analytical; that is, <qex>it</qex> may
treat space either by a direct consideration of its properties,
or by a symbolical representation.</q>
<qau>Whewell.</qau>
</note>

<-- p. 725 -->

the jaundice.</def>

<hw>\'d8Ic"tus</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[L., fr.

etc.</def>

<hw>I"cy</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>a.</pos>
<wordforms>[<pos>Compar.</pos> <er>Icier</er> <pr>(?)</pr>;
<pos>superl.</pos> <er>Iciest</er>.]</wordforms> <ety>[AS.
<ets>\'c6sig</ets>. See <er>Ice</er>.]</ety> <sn>1.</sn>
<def>Pertaining to, resembling, or abounding in, ice; cold;
frosty.</def> \'bd<xex>Icy</xex> chains.\'b8 <au>Shak</au>.
\'bd<xex>Icy</xex> region.\'b8 <au>Boyle</au>. \'bd<xex>Icy</xex>
seas.\'b8 <au>Pope</au>.

<sn>2.</sn> <def>Characterized by coldness, as of manner,
influence, etc.; chilling; frigid; cold.</def>

<q><qex>Icy</qex> was the deportment with which Philip received
these demonstrations of affection.</q>
<qau>Motley.</qau>

with ice.</def>

<hw>Id</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <fld>(Zo\'94l.)</fld>
<def>A small fresh-water cyprinoid fish (<spn>Leuciscus
idus</spn> or <spn>Idus idus</spn>) of Europe. A domesticated
variety, colored like the goldfish, is called
<altname>orfe</altname> in Germany.</def>

<hw>Ide</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <fld>(Zo\'94l.)</fld>
<def>Same as <er>Id</er>.</def>

<hw>-ide</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>. <fld>(Chem.)</fld> <def>A suffix used
to denote: <sd>(a)</sd> The <xex>nonmetallic</xex>, or
<xex>negative</xex>, element or radical in a binary compound;
<as>as, ox<ex>ide</ex>, sulph<ex>ide</ex>,
chlor<ex>ide</ex></as>. <sd>(b)</sd> A compound which is an
<xex>anhydride</xex>; <as>as, glycol<ex>ide</ex>,
phthal<ex>ide</ex></as>. <sd>(c)</sd> Any one of a series of
derivatives; <as>as, indogen<ex>ide</ex>, glucos<ex>ide</ex>,
etc.</as></def>

<hw>I*de"a</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos>; <plu>pl.
<plw>Ideas</plw> <pr>(#)</pr></plu>. <ety>[L. <ets>idea</ets>,
Gr. <?/, fr. <?/ to see; akin to E. <ets>wit</ets>: cf. F.
<ets>id\'82e</ets>. See <er>Wit</er>.]</ety> <sn>1.</sn> <def>The
transcript, image, or picture of a visible object, that is formed
by the mind; also, a similar image of any object whatever,
whether sensible or spiritual.</def>

<q>Her sweet <qex>idea</qex> wandered through his thoughts.</q>
<qau>Fairfax.</qau>

<q>Being the right <qex>idea</qex> of your father
Both in your form and nobleness of mind.</q>
<qau>Shak.</qau>

<q>This representation or likeness of the object being
transmitted from thence [the senses] to the imagination, and
lodged there for the view and observation of the pure intellect,
is aptly and properly called its <qex>idea</qex>.</q>
<qau>P. Browne.</qau>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>A general notion, or a conception formed by
generalization.</def>

<q>Alice had not the slightest <qex>idea</qex> what latitude
was.</q>
<qau>L. Caroll.</qau>

<sn>3.</sn> <def>Hence: Any object apprehended, conceived, or
thought of, by the mind; a notion, conception, or thought; the
real object that is conceived or thought of.</def>

<q>Whatsoever the mind perceives in itself, or as the immediate
object of perception, thought, or undersanding, that I call
<qex>idea</qex>.</q>
<qau>Locke.</qau>

<sn>4.</sn> <def>A belief, option, or doctrine; a characteristic
or controlling principle; <as>as, an essential <ex>idea</ex>; the
<ex>idea</ex> of development.</as></def>

<q>That fellow seems to me to possess but one <qex>idea</qex>,
and that is a wrong one.</q>
<qau>Johnson.</qau>

<q>What is now \'bd<qex>idea</qex>\'b8 for us? How infinite the
fall of this word, since the time where Milton sang of the
Creator contemplating his newly-created world, -
\'bdhow it showed . . . 
Answering his great <qex>idea</qex>,\'b8 -
to its present use, when this person \'bdhas an <qex>idea</qex>
that the train has started,\'b8 and the other \'bdhad no
<qex>idea</qex> that the dinner would be so bad!\'b8</q>
<qau>Trench.</qau>

<sn>5.</sn> <def>A plan or purpose of action; intention;
design.</def>

<q>I shortly afterwards set off for that capital, with an
<qex>idea</qex> of undertaking while there the translation of the
work.</q>
<qau>W. Irving.</qau>

<sn>6.</sn> <def>A rational conception; the complete conception
of an object when thought of in all its essential elements or
constituents; the necessary metaphysical or constituent
attributes and relations, when conceived in the abstract.</def>

<sn>7.</sn> <def>A fiction object or picture created by the
imagination; the same when proposed as a pattern to be copied, or
a standard to be reached; one of the archetypes or patterns of
created things, conceived by the Platonists to have excited
objectively from eternity in the mind of the Deity.</def>

<q>Thence to behold this new-created world,
The addition of his empire, how it showed
In prospect from his throne, how good, how fair,
Answering his great <qex>idea</qex>.</q>
<qau>Milton.</qau>

<note><hand/ \'bdIn England, Locke may be said to have been the
first who naturalized the term in its Cartesian universality.
When, in common language, employed by Milton and Dryden, after
Descartes, as before him by Sidney, Spenser, Shakespeare, Hooker,
etc., the meaning is Platonic.\'b8</note>

<au>Sir W. Hamilton.</au>

<cs><mcol><col>Abstract idea</col>, <col>Association of
ideas</col></mcol>, <cd>etc. See under <er>Abstract</er>,
<er>Association</er>, etc.</cd></cs>

<syn>Syn. -- Notion; conception; thought; sentiment; fancy;
image; perception; impression; opinion; belief; observation;
judgment; consideration; view; design; intention; purpose; plan;
model; pattern. There is scarcely any other word which is
subjected to such abusive treatment as is the word
<xex>idea</xex>, in the very general and indiscriminative way in
which it is employed, as it is used variously to signify almost
any act, state, or content of thought.</syn>

<hw>I*de"al</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>a.</pos> <ety>[L.
<ets>idealis</ets>: cf. F. <ets>id\'82al</ets>.]</ety>
<sn>1.</sn> <def>Existing in idea or thought; conceptional;
intellectual; mental; <as>as, <ex>ideal</ex>
knowledge</as>.</def>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>Reaching an imaginary standard of excellence;
fit for a model; faultless; <as>as, <ex>ideal</ex>
beauty</as>.</def>

<au>Byron.</au>

<q>There will always be a wide interval between practical and
<qex>ideal</qex> excellence.</q>
<qau>Rambler.</qau>

<sn>3.</sn> <def>Existing in fancy or imagination only;
visionary; unreal.</def> \'bdPlanning <xex>ideal</xex> common
wealth.\'b8

<au>Southey.</au>

<sn>4.</sn> <def>Teaching the doctrine of idealism; <as>as, the
<ex>ideal</ex> theory or philosophy</as>.</def>

<sn>5.</sn> <fld>(Math.)</fld> <def>Imaginary.</def>

<syn>Syn. -- Intellectual; mental; visionary; fanciful;
imaginary; unreal; impracticable; utopian.</syn>

<hw>I*de"al</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <def>A mental
conception regarded as a standard of perfection; a model of
excellence, beauty, etc.</def>

<q>The <qex>ideal</qex> is to be attained by selecting and
assembling in one whole the beauties and perfections which are
usually seen in different individuals, excluding everything
defective or unseemly, so as to form a type or model of the
species. Thus, the Apollo Belvedere is the <qex>ideal</qex> of
the beauty and proportion of the human frame.</q>
<qau>Fleming.</qau>

<cs><col>Beau ideal</col>. <cd>See <er>Beau ideal</er>.</cd></cs>

<hw>I*de"a*less</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>a.</pos> <def>Destitute
of an idea.</def>

<hw>I*de"al*ism</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[Cf. F.
<ets>id\'82alisme</ets>.]</ety> <sn>1.</sn> <def>The quality or
state of being ideal.</def>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>Conception of the ideal; imagery.</def>

<sn>3.</sn> <fld>(Philos.)</fld> <def>The system or theory that
denies the existence of material bodies, and teaches that we have
no rational grounds to believe in the reality of anything but
ideas and their relations.</def>

<hw>I*de"al*ist</hw>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[Cf. F.
<ets>id\'82aliste</ets>.]</ety> <sn>1.</sn> <def>One who
idealizes; one who forms picturesque fancies; one given to
romantic expectations.</def>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>One who holds the doctrine of idealism.</def>

<hw>I*de`al*is"tic</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>a.</pos> <def>Of or
pertaining to idealists or their theories.</def>

<hw>I`de*al"i*ty</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos>; <plu>pl.
<plw>Idealities</plw> <pr>(<?/)</pr>.</plu> <sn>1.</sn> <def>The
quality or state of being ideal.</def>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>The capacity to form ideals of beauty or
perfection.</def>

<sn>3.</sn> <fld>(Phren.)</fld> <def>The conceptive
faculty.</def>

<hw>I*de`al*i*za"tion</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos>
<sn>1.</sn> <def>The act or process of idealizing.</def>

<sn>2.</sn> <fld>(Fine Arts)</fld> <def>The representation of
natural objects, scenes, etc., in such a way as to show their
most important characteristics; the study of the ideal.</def>

<hw>I*de"al*ize</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>v. t.</pos>
<wordforms>[<pos>imp. & p. p.</pos> <er>Idealized</er>
<pr>(?)</pr>; <pos>p. pr. & vb. n.</pos> <er>Idealizing</er>
<pr>(?)</pr>.]</wordforms> <sn>1.</sn> <def>To make ideal; to
give an ideal form or value to; to attribute ideal
characteristics and excellences to; <as>as, to <ex>idealize</ex>
real life</as>.</def>

<sn>2.</sn> <fld>(Fine Arts)</fld> <def>To treat in an ideal
manner. See <er>Idealization</er>, 2.</def>

<hw>I*de"al*ize</hw>, <pos>v. i.</pos> <ety>[Cf. F.
<ets>id\'82aliser</ets>.]</ety> <def>To form ideals.</def>

<hw>I*de"al*i`zer</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <def>An
idealist.</def>

<hw>I*de"al*ly</hw>, <pos>adv.</pos> <def>In an ideal manner; by
means of ideals; mentally.</def>

<hw>I*de`a*log"ic</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>a.</pos> <def>Of or
pertaining to an idealogue, or to idealization.</def>

<hw>I*de"a*logue</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos>
<ety>[<ets>Idea</ets> + -<ets>logue</ets>, as in
theo<ets>logue</ets>: cf. F. <ets>id\'82ologue</ets>.]</ety>
<def>One given to fanciful ideas or theories; a theorist; a
spectator.</def> <mark>[R.]</mark>

<au>Mrs. Browning.</au>

<mhw>{ <hw>I*de"at</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <hw>I*de"ate</hw>
<pr>(?)</pr>, }</mhw> <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[LL. <ets>ideatum</ets>.
See <er>Idea</er>.]</ety> <fld>(Metaph.)</fld> <def>The actual
existence supposed to correspond with an idea; the correlate in
real existence to the idea as a thought or existence.</def>

<hw>I*de"ate</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>v. t.</pos> <sn>1.</sn>
<def>To form in idea; to fancy.</def> <mark>[R.]</mark>

<q>The <qex>ideated</qex> man . . . as he stood in the intellect
of God.</q>
<qau>Sir T. Browne.</qau>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>To apprehend in thought so as to fix and hold in
the mind; to memorize.</def> <mark>[R.]</mark>

<hw>I`de*a"tion</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <def>The faculty
or capacity of the mind for forming ideas; the exercise of this
capacity; the act of the mind by which objects of sense are
apprehended and retained as objects of thought.</def>

<q>The whole mass of residua which have been accumulated . . .
all enter now into the process of <qex>ideation</qex>.</q>
<qau>J. D. Morell.</qau>

<hw>I`de*a"tion*al</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>a.</pos>

<q>Certain sensational or <qex>ideational</qex> stimuli.</q>

<hw>I"dem</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>pron. <or/ adj.</pos>
<ety>[L.]</ety> <def>The same; the same as above; -- often
abbreviated <altname>id.</altname></def>

<hw>I*den"tic</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>a.</pos>
<def>Identical.</def> <mark>[Obs.]</mark>

<au>Hudibras.</au>

<hw>I*den"tic*al</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>a.</pos> <ety>[Cf. F.
<ets>identique</ets>. See <er>Identity</er>.]</ety> <sn>1.</sn>
<def>The same; the selfsame; the very same; not different;
<as>as, the <ex>identical</ex> person or thing</as>.</def>

<q>I can not remember a thing that happened a year ago, without a
conviction . . . that I, the same <qex>identical</qex> person who
now remember that event, did then exist.</q>
<qau>Reid.</qau>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>Uttering sameness or the same truth; expressing
in the predicate what is given, or obviously implied, in the
subject; tautological.</def>

<q>When you say body is solid, I say that you make an
<qex>identical</qex> proposition, because it is impossible to
have the idea of body without that of solidity.</q>
<qau>Fleming.</qau>

<cs><col>Identical equation</col> <fld>(Alg.)</fld>, <cd>an
equation which is true for all values of the algebraic symbols
which enter into it.</cd></cs>

<hw>I*den"tic*al*ly</hw>, <pos>adv.</pos> <def>In an identical
manner; with respect to identity.</def>
\'bd<xex>Identically</xex> the same.\'b8 <au>Bp. Warburton</au>.
\'bd<xex>Identically</xex> different.\'b8 <au>Ross</au>.

<hw>I*den"tic*al*ness</hw>, <pos>n.</pos> <def>The quality or
state of being identical; sameness.</def>

<hw>I*den"ti*fi`a*ble</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>a.</pos>
<def>Capable of being identified.</def>

<hw>I*den`ti*fi*ca"tion</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos>
<ety>[Cf. F. <ets>identification</ets>.]</ety> <def>The act of
identifying, or proving to be the same; also, the state of being
identified.</def>

<hw>I*den"ti*fy</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>v. t.</pos>
<wordforms>[<pos>imp. & p. p.</pos> <er>Identified</er>
<pr>(?)</pr>; <pos>p. pr. & vb. n.</pos> <er>Identifying</er>
<pr>(?)</pr>.]</wordforms> <ety>[Cf. F. <ets>identifier</ets>.
See <er>Identity</er>, and <er>-fy</er>.]</ety> <sn>1.</sn>
<def>To make to be the same; to unite or combine in such a manner
as to make one; to treat as being one or having the same purpose
or effect; to consider as the same in any relation.</def>

<q>Every precaution is taken to <qex>identify</qex> the interests
of the people and of the rulers.</q>
<qau>D. Ramsay.</qau>

<q>Let us <qex>identify</qex>, let us incorporate ourselves with
the people.</q>
<qau>Burke.</qau>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>To establish the identity of; to prove to be the
same with something described, claimed, or asserted; <as>as, to
<ex>identify</ex> stolen property</as>.</def>

<hw>I*den"ti*fy</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>v. i.</pos> <def>To
become the same; to coalesce in interest, purpose, use, effect,
etc.</def> <mark>[Obs. or R.]</mark>

<q>An enlightened self-interest, which, when well understood,
they tell us will <qex>identify</qex> with an interest more
enlarged and public.</q>
<qau>Burke.</qau>

<hw>I*den"tism</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[See
<er>Identity</er>.]</ety> <fld>(Metaph.)</fld> <def>The doctrine
taught by Schelling, that matter and mind, and subject and
object, are identical in the Absolute; -- called also the
<altname>system <or/ doctrine of identity</altname>.</def>

<hw>I*den"ti*ty</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos>; <plu>pl.
<plw>Identities</plw> <pr>(#)</pr></plu>. <ety>[F.
<ets>identit\'82</ets>, LL. <ets>identitas</ets>, fr. L.
<ets>idem</ets> the same, from the root of <ets>is</ets> he,
that; cf. Skr. <ets>idam</ets> this. Cf. <er>Item</er>.]</ety>
<sn>1.</sn> <def>The state or quality of being identical, or the
same; sameness.</def>

<q><qex>Identity</qex> is a relation between our cognitions of a
thing, not between things themselves.</q>
<qau>Sir W. Hamilton.</qau>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>The condition of being the same with something
described or asserted, or of possessing a character claimed;
<as>as, to establish the <ex>identity</ex> of stolen
goods</as>.</def>

<sn>3.</sn> <fld>(Math.)</fld> <def>An identical equation.</def>

<hw>I"de*o-</hw> <pr>(?)</pr><def>. A combining form from the Gr.
<?/, an <xex>idea</xex>.</def>

<hw>I`de*o*gen"ic*al</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>a.</pos> <def>Of or
relating to ideology.</def>

<hw>I`de*og"e*ny</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos>
<ety>[<ets>Ideo-</ets> + -<ets>geny</ets>, from the same root as
Gr. <?/, birth: cf. F. <ets>id\'82og\'82nie</ets>.]</ety>
<def>The science which treats of the origin of ideas.</def>

<hw>I*de"o*gram</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos>
<ety>[<ets>Ideo-</ets> + -<ets>gram</ets>; cf. F.
<ets>id\'82ograme</ets>.]</ety> <sn>1.</sn> <def>An original,
pictorial element of writing; a kind of hieroglyph expressing no
sound, but only an idea.</def>

<q><qex>Ideograms</qex> may be defined to be pictures intended to
represent either things or thoughts.</q>
<qau>I. Taylor (The Alphabet).</qau>

<q>You might even have a history without language written or
spoken, by means of <qex>ideograms</qex> and gesture.</q>
<qau>J. Peile.</qau>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>A symbol used for convenience, or for
abbreviation; <as>as, 1, 2, 3, +, -, <?/, $, <?/, etc.</as></def>

<sn>3.</sn> <def>A phonetic symbol; a letter.</def>

<hw>I*de"o*graph</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <def>Same as
<er>Ideogram</er>.</def>

<mhw>{ <hw>I`de*o*graph"ic</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>,
<hw>I`de*o*graph"ic*al</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, }</mhw> <pos>a.</pos>
<ety>[Cf. F. <ets>id\'82ographique</ets>.]</ety> <def>Of or
pertaining to an ideogram; representing ideas by symbols,
independently of sounds; <as>as, 9 represents not the word
\'bdnine,\'b8 but the <ex>idea</ex> of the number
itself</as>.</def> -- <wordforms><wf>I`de*o*graph"ic*al*ly</wf>,
<pos>adv.</pos></wordforms>

<hw>I`de*o*graph"ics</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <def>The
system of writing in ideographic characters; also, anything so
written.</def>

<hw>I`de*og"ra*phy</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <def>The
representation of ideas independently of sounds, or in an
ideographic manner, as sometimes is done in shorthand writing,
etc.</def>

<hw>I`de*o*log"ic*al</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>a.</pos> <ety>[Cf.
F. <ets>id\'82ologique</ets>.]</ety> <def>Of or pertaining to
ideology.</def>

<hw>I`de*ol"o*gist</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <def>One who
treats of ideas; one who theorizes or idealizes; one versed in
the science of ideas, or who advocates the doctrines of
ideology.</def>


<-- idealogue n. one who adheres to an ideology -->

<hw>I`de*ol"o*gy</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos>
<ety>[<ets>Ideo-</ets> + -<ets>logy</ets>: cf. F.
<ets>id\'82ologie</ets>.]</ety> <sn>1.</sn> <def>The science of
ideas.</def>

<au>Stewart.</au>

<sn>2.</sn> <fld>(Metaph.)</fld> <def>A theory of the origin of
ideas which derives them exclusively from sensation.</def>

<note><hand/ By a double blunder in philosophy and Greek,
<xex>id\'82ologie</xex> . . . has in France become the name
peculiarly distinctive of that philosophy of mind which
exclusively derives our knowledge from sensation.</note>
<au>Sir W. Hamilton.</au>

<-- a set of theories and beliefs about sociopolitical goals and
methods to attain them; in common usage, such a set of beliefs so
strongly held by their adherents as to cause them to ignore
evidence against such beliefs, and thus fall into error -- hence
a negative trait; contrasted to pragmatism, and distinct from
idealism -->

<hw>I`de*o-mo"tion</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos>
<fld>(Physiol.)</fld> <def>An ideo-motor movement.</def>

<hw>I`de*o-mo"tor</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>a.</pos>
<ety>[<ets>Ideo-</ets> + <ets>motor</ets>.]</ety>
<fld>(Physiol.)</fld> <def>Applied to those actions, or muscular
movements, which are automatic expressions of dominant ideas,
rather than the result of distinct volitional efforts, as the act
of expressing the thoughts in speech, or in writing, while the
mind is occupied in the composition of the sentence.</def>

<au>Carpenter.</au>

<hw>Ides</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n. pl.</pos> <ety>[L.
<ets>idus</ets>: cf. F. <ets>ides</ets>.]</ety> <fld>(Anc. Rom.
Calendar)</fld> <def>The fifteenth day of March, May, July, and
October, and the thirteenth day of the other months.</def>

<q>The <qex>ides</qex> of March remember.</q>
<qau>Shak.</qau>

<note><hand/ Eight days in each month often pass by this name,
but only one strictly receives it, the others being called
respectively the day before the <xex>ides</xex>, and so on,
backward, to the eightth from the <xex>ides</xex>.</note>

<hw>Id"i*o-</hw> <pr>(?)</pr><def>. A combining form from the
Greek <?/, meaning <xex>private</xex>, <xex>personal</xex>,
<xex>peculiar</xex>, <xex>distinct</xex>.</def>

<hw>Id"i*o*blast</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos>

<fld>(Bot.)</fld> <def>An individual cell, differing greatly from
its neighbours in regard to size, structure, or contents.</def>

<hw>\'d8Id`i*o*cra"sis</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos>
<ety>[NL.]</ety> <def>Idiocracy.</def>

<hw>Id`i*oc"ra*cy</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos>; <plu>pl.

<mhw>{ <hw>Id`i*o*crat"ic</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>,

<hw>Id"i*o*cy</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[From
<ets>idiot</ets>; cf. Gr. <?/ uncouthness, want of education, fr.
<?/. See <er>Idiot</er>, and cf. <er>Idiotcy</er>.]</ety>
<def>The condition or quality of being an idiot; absence, or
marked deficiency, of sense and intelligence.</def>

<q>I will undertake to convict a man of <qex>idiocy</qex>, if he
can not see the proof that three angles of a triangle are equal
to two right angles.</q>
<qau>F. W. Robertson.</qau>

<hw>Id`i*o*cy*cloph"a*nous</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>a.</pos>
<ety>[<ets>Idio-</ets> + Gr. <?/ circle + <?/ to appear.]</ety>
<fld>(Crystallog.)</fld> <def>Same as <er>Idiophanous</er>.</def>

<hw>Id`i*o*e*lec"tric</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>a.</pos>
<ety>[<ets>Idio-</ets> + <ets>electric</ets>: cf. F.
<ets>idio\'82lectrique</ets>.]</ety> <fld>(Physics)</fld>
<def>Electric by virtue of its own peculiar properties; capable
of becoming electrified by friction; -- opposed to
<xex>anelectric</xex>.</def> -- <def2><pos>n.</pos> <def>An
idioelectric substance.</def></def2>

<hw>Id"i*o*graph</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[Gr. <?/
autographic; <?/ one's own + <?/ to write.]</ety> <def>A mark or
signature peculiar to an individual; a trade-mark.</def>

<-- p. 726 -->

<mhw>{ <hw>Id`i*o*graph"ic</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>,
<hw>Id`i*o*graph"ic*al</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, }</mhw> <pos>a.</pos>
<def>Of or pertaining to an idiograph.</def>

<hw>Id`i*ol"a*try</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos>
<ety>[<ets>Idio-</ets> + Gr. <?/ to worship.]</ety>
<def>Self-worship; excessive self-esteem.</def>

<hw>Id"i*om</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[F.
<ets>idiome</ets>, L. <ets>idioma</ets>, fr. Gr. <?/, fr. <?/ to
make a person's own, to make proper or peculiar; prob. akin to
the reflexive pronoun <?/, <?/, <?/, and to <?/, <?/, one's own,
L. <ets>suus</ets>, and to E. <ets>so</ets>.]</ety> <sn>1.</sn>
<def>The syntactical or structural form peculiar to any language;
the genius or cast of a language.</def>

<q><qex>Idiom</qex> may be employed loosely and figuratively as a
synonym of language or dialect, but in its proper sense it
signifies the totality of the general rules of construction which
characterize the syntax of a particular language and distinguish
it from other tongues.</q>
<qau>G. P. Marsh.</qau>

<q>By <qex>idiom</qex> is meant the use of words which is
peculiar to a particular language.</q>
<qau>J. H. Newman.</qau>

<q>He followed their language [the Latin], but did not comply
with the <qex>idiom</qex> of ours.</q>
<qau>Dryden.</qau>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>An expression conforming or appropriate to the
peculiar structural form of a language; in extend use, an
expression sanctioned by usage, having a sense peculiar to itself
and not agreeing with the logical sense of its structural form;
also, the phrase forms peculiar to a particular author.</def>

<q>Some that with care true eloquence shall teach,
And to just <qex>idioms</qex> fix our doubtful speech.</q>
<qau>Prior.</qau>

<q>Sometimes we identify the words with the object -- though be
courtesy of <qex>idiom</qex> rather than in strict propriety of
language.</q>
<qau>Coleridge.</qau>

<q>Every good writer has much <qex>idiom</qex>.</q>
<qau>Landor.</qau>

<q>It is not by means of rules that such <qex>idioms</qex> as the
following are made current: \'bdI can <qex>make nothing</qex> of
it.\'b8 \'bdHe <qex>treats</qex> his subject <qex>home</qex>.\'b8 
<qex>Dryden</qex>. \'bdIt is that within us that <qex>makes
for</qex> righteousness.\'b8 <qex>M</qex>.<qex>Arnold</qex>.</q>
<qau>Gostwick (Eng. Gram. )</qau>

<sn>3.</sn> <def>Dialect; a variant form of a language.</def>

<syn>Syn. -- Dialect.</syn> <usage> -- <er>Idiom</er>,
<er>Dialect</er>. The <xex>idioms</xex> of a language belong to
its very structure; its <xex>dialects</xex> are varieties of
expression ingrafted upon it in different localities or by
different professions. Each county of England has some
peculiarities of <xex>dialect</xex>, and so have most of the
professions, while the great <xex>idioms</xex> of the language
are everywhere the same. See <er>Language</er>.</usage>

<mhw>{ <hw>Id`i*o*mat"ic</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>,
<hw>Id`i*o*mat"ic*al</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, }</mhw> <pos>a.</pos>
<ety>[Gr. <?/.]</ety> <def>Of or pertaining to, or conforming to,
the mode of expression peculiar to a language; <as>as, an
<ex>idiomatic</ex> meaning; an <ex>idiomatic</ex>
phrase.</as></def> -- <wordforms><wf>Id`i*o*mat"ic*al*ly</wf>,
<pos>adv.</pos></wordforms>

<hw>Id`i*o*morph"ic</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>a.</pos>
<def>Idiomorphous.</def>

<?/ of peculiar form; <?/ peculiar + <?/ form.]</ety> <sn>1.</sn>
<def>Having a form of its own.</def>

<sn>2.</sn> <fld>(Crystallog.)</fld> <def>Apperaing in distinct
crystals; -- said of the mineral constituents of a rock.</def>

<hw>Id`i*o*mus"cu*lar</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>a.</pos>
<ety>[<ets>Idio-</ets> + <ets>muscular</ets>.]</ety>
<fld>(Physiol.)</fld> <def>Applied to a semipermanent contraction

<hw>Id`i*o*pa*thet"ic</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>a.</pos>
<def>Idiopathic.</def> <mark>[R.]</mark>

<mhw>{ <hw>Id`i*o*path"ic</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>,
<hw>Id`i*o*path"ic*al</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, }</mhw> <pos>a.</pos>
<ety>[Cf. F. <ets>idiopathique</ets>.]</ety> <fld>(Med.)</fld>
<def>Pertaining to idiopathy; characterizing a disease arising
primarily, and not in consequence of some other disease or
injury; -- opposed to <xex>symptomatic</xex>,
<xex>sympathetic</xex>, and <xex>traumatic</xex>.</def> --
<wordforms><wf>Id`i*o*path"ic*al*ly</wf>,
<pos>adv.</pos></wordforms>

<hw>Id`i*op"a*thy</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos>; <plu>pl.
<plw>Idiopathies</plw> <pr>(#)</pr></plu>. <ety>[Gr. <?/; <?/
proper, peculiar + <?/, <?/, to suffer: cf. F.
<ets>idiopathie</ets>.]</ety> <sn>1.</sn> <def>A peculiar, or
individual, characteristic or affection.</def>

<q>All men are so full of their own fancies and
<qex>idiopathies</qex>, that they scarce have the civility to
interchange any words with a stranger.</q>
<qau>Dr. H. More.</qau>

<sn>2.</sn> <fld>(Med.)</fld> <def>A morbid state or condition
not preceded or occasioned by any other disease; a primary
disease.</def>

<hw>Id`i*oph"a*nous</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>a.</pos>
<ety>[<ets>Idio-</ets> + <?/ to appear.]</ety>
<fld>(Crystallog.)</fld> <def>Exhibiting interference figures
without the aid of a polariscope, as certain crystals.</def>

<hw>Id"i*o*plasm</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos>
<fld>(Biol.)</fld> <def>Same as <er>Idioplasma</er>.</def>

<hw>\'d8Id`i*o*plas"ma</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos>
<ety>[NL., fr. Gr. <?/ proper, peculiar + <?/ a form,
mold.]</ety> <fld>(Biol.)</fld> <def>That portion of the cell
protoplasm which is the seat of all active changes, and which
carries on the function of hereditary transmission; --
distinguished from the other portion, which is termed
<xex>nutritive plasma</xex>. See <er>Hygroplasm</er>.</def>
<-- any modern equivalent?  The chromosome/ Genome? -->

<hw>Id`i*o*re*pul"sive</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>a.</pos>
<ety>[<ets>Idio-</ets> + <ets>repulsive</ets>.]</ety>
<def>Repulsive by itself; <as>as, the <ex>idiorepulsive</ex>
power of heat</as>.</def>

<hw>Id`i*o*syn"cra*sy</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos>; <plu>pl.
<plw>Idiosyncrasies</plw> <pr>(#)</pr></plu>. <ety>[Gr. <?/; <?/
proper, peculiar + <?/ a mixing together, fr. <?/ to mix
together; <?/ with + <?/ to mix: cf. F. <ets>idiosyncrasie</ets>.
See <er>Idiom</er>, and <er>Crasis</er>.]</ety> <def>A
peculiarity of physical or mental constitution or temperament; a
characteristic belonging to, and distinguishing, an individual;
characteristic susceptibility; idiocrasy; eccentricity.</def>

<q>The individual mind . . . takes its tone from the
<qex>idiosyncrasies</qex> of the body.</q>
<qau>I. Taylor.</qau>

<mhw>{ <hw>Id`i*o*syn*crat"ic</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>,
<hw>Id`i*o*syn*crat"ic*al</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, }</mhw>
<pos>a.</pos> <def>Of peculiar temper or disposition; belonging
to one's peculiar and individual character.</def>

<hw>Id"i*ot</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[F.
<ets>idiot</ets>, L. <ets>idiota</ets> an uneducated, ignorant,
ill-informed person, Gr. <?/, also and orig., a private person,
not holding public office, fr. <?/ proper, peculiar. See
<er>Idiom</er>.]</ety> <sn>1.</sn> <def>A man in private station,
as distinguished from one holding a public office.</def>
<mark>[Obs.]</mark>

<q>St. Austin affirmed that the plain places of Scripture are
sufficient to all laics, and all <qex>idiots</qex> or private
persons.</q>
<qau>Jer. Taylor.</qau>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>An unlearned, ignorant, or simple person, as
distinguished from the educated; an ignoramus.</def>
<mark>[Obs.]</mark>

<q>Christ was received of <qex>idiots</qex>, of the vulgar
people, and of the simpler sort, while he was rejected, despised,
and persecuted even to death by the high priests, lawyers,
scribes, doctors, and rabbis.</q>
<qau>C. Blount.</qau>

<sn>3.</sn> <def>A human being destitute of the ordinary
intellectual powers, whether congenital, developmental, or
accidental; commonly, a person without understanding from birth;
a natural fool; a natural; an innocent.</def>

<q>Life . . . is a tale
Told by an <qex>idiot</qex>, full of sound and fury,
Signifying nothing.</q>
<qau>Shak.</qau>

<sn>4.</sn> <def>A fool; a simpleton; -- a term of
reproach.</def>

<q>Weenest thou make an <qex>idiot</qex> of our dame?</q>
<qau>Chaucer.</qau>

<ety>[<ets>Idio-</ets> + <ets>thermic</ets>.]</ety>
<def>Self-heating; warmed, as the body of animal, by process
going on within itself.</def>

<mhw>{ <hw>Id`i*ot"ic</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <hw>Id`i*ot"ic*al</hw>
<pr>(?)</pr>, }</mhw> <pos>a.</pos> <ety>[L. <ets>idioticus</ets>

<mark>[Obs.]</mark>

<au>Blackwall.</au>

by idiocy; foolish; fatuous; <as>as, an <ex>idiotic</ex> person,

<hw>Id`i*ot"ic*al*ly</hw>, <pos>adv.</pos> <def>In a idiotic

Gr. <?/ belonging to a private man, private. See
<er>Idiot</er>.]</ety> <def>A dictionary of a peculiar dialect,
or of the words and phrases peculiar to one part of a country; a
glossary.</def>

<hw>Id"i*ot*ish</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>a.</pos> <def>Like an
idiot; foolish.</def>

<hw>Id"i*ot*ism</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[F.
<ets>idiotisme</ets>, L. <ets>idiotismus</ets> the way of fashion
of a private person, the common or vulgar manner of speaking, Gr.
<?/, fr. <?/ to put into or use common language, fr. <?/. See
<er>Idiot</er>.]</ety> <sn>1.</sn> <def>An idiom; a form, mode of
expression, or signification, peculiar to a language.</def>

<q>Scholars sometimes give terminations and <qex>idiotisms</qex>,
suitable to their native language, unto words newly invented.</q>
<qau>M. Hale.</qau>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>Lack of knowledge or mental capacity; idiocy;
foolishness.</def>

<q>Worse than mere ignorance or <qex>idiotism</qex>.</q>
<qau>Shaftesbury.</qau>

<q>The running that adventure is the greatist
<qex>idiotism</qex>.</q>
<qau>Hammond.</qau>

<hw>I"dle</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>a.</pos>
<wordforms>[<pos>Compar.</pos> <er>Idler</er> <pr>(?)</pr>;
<pos>superl.</pos> <er>Idlest</er>.]</wordforms> <ety>[OE.
<ets>idel</ets>, AS. <ets>\'c6del</ets> vain, empty, useless;
akin to OS. <ets>\'c6dal</ets>, D. <ets>ijdel</ets>, OHG.
<ets>\'c6tal</ets> vain, empty, mere, G. <ets>eitel</ets>, Dan. &
Sw. <ets>idel</ets> mere, pure, and prob. to Gr. <?/ clear, pure,
<?/ to burn. Cf. <er>Ether</er>.]</ety> <sn>1.</sn> <def>Of no
account; useless; vain; trifling; unprofitable; thoughtless;
silly; barren.</def> \'bdDeserts <xex>idle</xex>.\'b8

<au>Shak.</au>

<q>Every <qex>idle</qex> word that men shall speak, they shall
give account thereof in the day of judgment.</q>
<qau>Matt. xii. 36.</qau>

<q>Down their <qex>idle</qex> weapons dropped.</q>
<qau>Milton.</qau>

<q>This <qex>idle</qex> story became important.</q>
<qau>Macaulay.</qau>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>Not called into active service; not turned to
appropriate use; unemployed; <as>as, <ex>idle</ex>
hours</as>.</def>

<q>The <qex>idle</qex> spear and shield were high uphing.</q>
<qau>Milton.</qau>

<sn>3.</sn> <def>Not employed; unoccupied with business;
inactive; doing nothing; <as>as, <ex>idle</ex>
workmen</as>.</def>

<q>Why stand ye here all the day <qex>idle</qex>?</q>
<qau>Matt. xx. 6.</qau>

<sn>4.</sn> <def>Given rest and ease; averse to labor or
employment; lazy; slothful; <as>as, an <ex>idle</ex>
fellow</as>.</def>

<sn>5.</sn> <def>Light-headed; foolish.</def> <mark>[Obs.]</mark>

<au>Ford.</au>

<cs><col>Idle pulley</col> <fld>(Mach.)</fld>, <cd>a pulley that
rests upon a belt to tighten it; a pulley that only guides a belt
and is not used to transmit power.</cd> -- <col>Idle wheel</col>
<fld>(Mach.)</fld>, <cd>a gear wheel placed between two others,
to transfer motion from one to the other without changing the
direction of revolution.</cd> -- <col>In idle</col>, <cd>in vain.
<mark>[Obs.]</mark> \'bdGod saith, thou shalt not take the name
of thy Lord God <xex>in idle<xex>.\'b8</cd></cs>

<au>Chaucer.</au>

<syn>Syn. -- Unoccupied; unemployed; vacant; inactive; indolent;
sluggish; slothful; useless; ineffectual; futile; frivolous;
vain; trifling; unprofitable; unimportant.</syn> <usage> --
<er>Idle</er>, <er>Indolent</er>, <er>Lazy</er>. A propensity to
inaction is expressed by each of these words; they differ in the
cause and degree of this characteristic. <xex>Indolent</xex>
denotes an habitual love to ease, a settled dislike of movement
or effort; <xex>idle</xex> is opposed to <xex>busy</xex>, and
denotes a dislike of <xex>continuous</xex> exertion.
<xex>Lazy</xex> is a stronger and more contemptuous term than
<xex>indolent</xex>.</usage>

<hw>I"dle</hw>, <pos>v. i.</pos> <wordforms>[<pos>imp. & p.
p.</pos> <er>Idled</er> <pr>(?)</pr>; <pos>p. pr. & vb. n.</pos>
<er>Idling</er> <pr>(?)</pr>.]</wordforms> <def>To lose or spend
time in inaction, or without being employed in business.</def>

<au>Shak.</au>

<hw>I"dle</hw>, <pos>v. t.</pos> <def>To spend in idleness; to
waste; to consume; -- often followed by <xex>away</xex>; <as>as,
to <ex>idle</ex> away an hour a day</as>.</def>

<hw>I"dol</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[OE.
<ets>idole</ets>, F. <ets>idole</ets>, L. <ets>idolum</ets>, fr.
Gr. <?/, fr. <?/ that which is seen, the form, shape, figure, fr.
<?/ to see. See <er>Wit</er>, and cf. <er>Eidolon</er>.]</ety>
<sn>1.</sn> <def>An image or representation of anything.</def>
<mark>[Obs.]</mark>

<q>Do her adore with sacred reverence,
As th' <qex>idol</qex> of her maker's great magnificence.</q>
<qau>Spenser.</qau>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>An image of a divinity; a representation or
symbol of a deity or any other being or thing, made or used as an
object of worship; a similitude of a false god.</def>

<q>That they should not worship devils, and <qex>idols</qex> of
gold.</q>
<qau>Rev. ix. 20.</qau>

<sn>3.</sn> <def>That on which the affections are strongly (often
excessively) set; an object of passionate devotion; a person or
thing greatly loved or adored.</def>

<q>The soldier's god and people's <qex>idol</qex>.</q>
<qau>Denham.</qau>

<sn>4.</sn> <def>A false notion or conception; a fallacy.</def>

<au>Bacon.</au>

<q>The <qex>idols</qex> of preconceived opinion.</q>
<qau>Coleridge.</qau>

<hw>I*dol"a*ter</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[F.
<ets>idol\'83tre</ets>: cf. L. <ets>idololatres</ets>, Gr. <?/.
See <er>Idolatry</er>.]</ety> <sn>1.</sn> <def>A worshiper of
idols; one who pays divine honors to images, statues, or
representations of anything made by hands; one who worships as a
deity that which is not God; a pagan.</def>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>An adorer; a great admirer.</def>

<q>Jonson was an <qex>idolater</qex> of the ancients.</q>
<qau>Bp. Hurd.</qau>

<hw>I"dyl</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[L.
<ets>idyllium</ets>, Gr. <?/, fr. <?/ form; literally, a little
form of image: cf. F. <ets>idylle</ets>. See
<er>Idol</er>.]</ety> <def>A short poem; properly, a short
pastoral poem; <as>as, the <ex>idyls</ex> of Theocritus</as>;
also, any poem, especially a narrative or descriptive poem,
written in an eleveted and highly finished style; also, by
extension, any artless and easily flowing description, either in
poetry or prose, of simple, rustic life, of pastoral scenes, and
the like.</def> <altsp>[Written also <asp>idyll</asp>.]</altsp>

<q>Wordsworth's solemn-thoughted <qex>idyl</qex>.</q>
<qau>Mrs. Browning.</qau>

<q>His [Goldsmith's] lovely <qex>idyl</qex> of the Vicar's
home.</q>
<qau>F. Harrison.</qau>

belonging to idyls.</def>

<hw>I. e.</hw> <def>Abbreviation of Latin <xex>id est</xex>, that
is.</def>

<hw>If</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>conj.</pos> <ety>[OE.
<ets>if</ets>, <ets>gif</ets>, AS. <ets>gif</ets>; akin to
OFries. <ets>ief</ets>, <ets>gef</ets>, <ets>ef</ets>, OS.
<ets>ef</ets>, <ets>of</ets>, D. <ets>of</ets>, or, whether, if,
G. <ets>ob</ets> whether, if, OHG. <ets>oba</ets>,
<ets>ibu</ets>, Icel. <ets>ef</ets>, Goth. <ets>iba</ets>,
<ets>ibai</ets>, an interrogative particle; properly a case form
of a noun meaning, doubt (cf. OHG. <ets>iba</ets> doubt,
condition, Icel. <ets>if</ets>, <ets>ef</ets>, <ets>ifi</ets>,
<ets>efi</ets>), and therefore orig. meaning, on condition
that.]</ety> <sn>1.</sn> <def>In case that; granting, allowing,
or supposing that; -- introducing a condition or
supposition.</def>

<q>Tisiphone, that oft hast heard my prayer,
Assist, <qex>if</qex> \'d1dipus deserve thy care.</q>
<qau>Pope.</qau>

<q><qex>If</qex> thou be the Son of God, command that these
stones be made bread.</q>
<qau>Matt. iv. 3.</qau>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>Whether; -- in dependent questions.</def>

<q>Uncertain <qex>if</qex> by augury or chance.</q>
<qau>Dryden.</qau>

<q>She doubts <qex>if</qex> two and two make four.</q>
<qau>Prior.</qau>

<cs><mcol><col>As if</col>, <col>But if</col></mcol>. <cd>See
under <er>As</er>, <er>But</er>.</cd></cs>

<hw>I' faith"</hw> <pr>(?)</pr><def>. In faith; indeed;
truly.</def>

<au>Shak.</au>

<hw>Ig`a*su"ric</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>a.</pos> <ety>[See
<er>Igasurine</er>.]</ety> <fld>(Chem.)</fld> <def>Pertaining to,

<def>An alkaloid found in nux vomica, and extracted as a white

<hw>Ig"loo</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <sn>1.</sn> <def>An

<sn>2.</sn> <fld>(Zo\'94l.)</fld> <def>A cavity, or excavation,

<hw>Ig"ne*ous</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>a.</pos> <ety>[L.
<ets>igneus</ets>, fr. <ets>ignis</ets> fire; allied to Skr.
<ets>agni</ets>, Lith. <ets>ugnis</ets>, OSlav.
<ets>ogne</ets>.]</ety> <sn>1.</sn> <def>Pertaining to, having
the nature of, fire; containing fire; resembling fire; <as>as, an
<ex>igneous</ex> appearance</as>.</def>

<sn>2.</sn> <fld>(Geol.)</fld> <def>Resulting from, or produced
by, the action of fire; <as>as, lavas and basalt are
<ex>igneous</ex> rocks</as>.</def>

<hw>Ig*nes"cent</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>a.</pos> <ety>[L.
<ets>ignescens</ets>, p.pr. of <ets>ignescere</ets> to become
inflamed, fr. <ets>ignis</ets> fire: cf. F.
<ets>ignescent</ets>.]</ety> <def>Emitting sparks of fire when
struck with steel; scintillating; <as>as, <ex>ignescent</ex>
stones</as>.</def>

<hw>\'d8Ig"nis fat"u*us</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>; <plu>pl. <plw>Ignes
fatui</plw> <pr>(#)</pr></plu>. <ety>[L. <ets>ignis</ets> fire +
<ets>fatuus</ets> foolish. So called in allusion to its tendency
to mislead travelers.]</ety> <sn>1.</sn> <def>A phosphorescent
light that appears, in the night, over marshy ground, supposed to
be occasioned by the decomposition of animal or vegetable
substances, or by some inflammable gas; -- popularly called also
<altname>Will-with-the-wisp</altname>, or
<altname>Will-o'-the-wisp</altname>, and
<altname>Jack-with-a-lantern</altname>, or
<altname>Jack-o'-lantern</altname>.</def><-- thought to be caused
by phosphine, PH3, a sponaneously combustible gas. -->

<sn>2.</sn> <def>Fig.: A misleading influence; a decoy.</def>

<q>Scared and guided by the <qex>ignis fatuus</qex> of popular
superstition.</q>
<qau>Jer. Taylor.</qau>

<hw>Ig*nite"</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>v. t.</pos>
<wordforms>[<pos>imp. & p. p.</pos> <er>Ignited</er>
<pr>(?)</pr>; <pos>p. pr. & vb. n.</pos>
<er>Igniting</er>.]</wordforms> <ety>[L. <ets>ignitus</ets>, p.p.
of <ets>ignire</ets> to ignite, fr. <ets>ignis</ets> fire. See
<er>Igneous</er>.]</ety> <sn>1.</sn> <def>To kindle or set on
fire; <as>as, to <ex>ignite</ex> paper or wood</as>.</def>

<sn>2.</sn> <fld>(Chem.)</fld> <def>To subject to the action of
intense heat; to heat strongly; -- often said of incombustible or
infusible substances; <as>as, to <ex>ignite</ex> iron or
platinum</as>.</def>

<hw>Ig*nite"</hw>, <pos>v. i.</pos> <def>To take fire; to begin
to burn.</def>

<hw>Ig*nit"i*ble</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>a.</pos> <def>Capable of
being ignited.</def>

<ets>ignition</ets>.]</ety> <sn>1.</sn> <def>The act of igniting,
kindling, or setting on fire.</def>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>The state of being ignited or kindled.</def>

<au>Sir T. Browne.</au>

<hw>Ig`no*bil"i*ty</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[L.
<ets>ignobilitas</ets>: cf. F. <ets>ignobilit\'82</ets>.]</ety>
<def>Ignobleness.</def> <mark>[Obs.]</mark>

<au>Bale.</au>

<hw>Ig*no"ble</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>a.</pos> <ety>[L.
<ets>ignobilis</ets>; pref. <ets>in-</ets> not +
<ets>nobilis</ets> noble: cf. F. <ets>ignoble</ets>. See
<er>In-</er> not, and <er>Noble</er>, <pos>a.</pos>]</ety>
<sn>1.</sn> <def>Of low birth or family; not noble; not
illustrious; plebeian; common; humble.</def>

<q>I was not <qex>ignoble</qex> of descent.</q>
<qau>Shak.</qau>

<q>Her royal stock graft with <qex>ignoble</qex> plants.</q>
<qau>Shak.</qau>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>Not honorable, elevated, or generous;
base.</def>

<q>'T but a base, <qex>ignoble</qex> mind,
That mounts no higher than a bird can soar.</q>
<qau>Shak.</qau>

<q>Far from the madding crowd's <qex>ignoble</qex> strife.</q>
<qau>Gray.</qau>

<sn>3.</sn> <fld>(Zo\'94l.)</fld> <def>Not a true or noble
falcon; -- said of certain hawks, as the goshawk.</def>

<syn>Syn. -- Degenerate; degraded; mean; base; dishonorable;
reproachful; disgraceful; shameful; scandalous; infamous.</syn>

<hw>Ig*no"ble</hw>, <pos>v. t.</pos> <def>To make ignoble.</def>
<mark>[Obs.]</mark>

<au>Bacon.</au>

<hw>Ig*no"bly</hw>, <pos>adv.</pos> <def>In an ignoble manner;

<hw>Ig`no*min"i*ous</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>a.</pos> <ety>[L.
<ets>ignominiosus</ets>: cf. F. <ets>ignominieux</ets>.]</ety>
<sn>1.</sn> <def>Marked with ignominy; in curring public
disgrace; dishonorable; shameful.</def>

<q>Then first with fear surprised and sense of pain,
Fled <qex>ignominious</qex>.</q>
<qau>Milton.</qau>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>Deserving ignominy; despicable.</def>

<q>One single, obscure, <qex>ignominious</qex> projector.</q>
<qau>Swift.</qau>

<sn>3.</sn> <def>Humiliating; degrading; <as>as, an
<ex>ignominious</ex> judgment or sentence</as>.</def>

<au>Macaulay.</au>

<hw>Ig`no*min"i*ous*ly</hw>, <pos>adv.</pos> <def>In an
ignominious manner; disgracefully; shamefully;
ingloriously.</def>

<hw>Ig"no*min*y</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos>; <plu>pl.
<plw>Ignominies</plw> <pr>(#)</pr></plu>. <ety>[L.
<ets>ignominia</ets> ignominy (<ets>i</ets>.<ets>e</ets>., a
deprivation of one's good name); <ets>in-</ets> not +
<ets>nomen</ets> name: cf. F. <ets>ignominie</ets>. See
<er>In-</er> not, and <er>Name</er>.]</ety> <sn>1.</sn>
<def>Public disgrace or dishonor; reproach; infamy.</def>

<q>Their generals have been received with honor after their
defeat; yours with <qex>ignominy</qex> after conquest.</q>
<qau>Addison.</qau>

<q>Vice begins in mistake, and ends in <qex>ignominy</qex>.</q>
<qau>Rambler.</qau>

<q><qex>Ignominy</qex> is the infliction of such evil as is made
dishonorable, or the deprivation of such good as is made
honorable by the Common wealth.</q>
<qau>Hobbes.</qau>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>An act deserving disgrace; an infamous
act.</def>

<syn>Syn. -- Opprobrium; reproach; dishonor.</syn>

<hw>Ig"no*my</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos>
<def>Ignominy.</def> <mark>[R. & Obs.]</mark>

<q>I blush to think upon this <qex>ignomy</qex>.</q>
<qau>Shak.</qau>

<hw>Ig`no*ra"mus</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[L., we
are ignorant. See <er>Ignore</er>.]</ety> <sn>1.</sn>
<fld>(Law)</fld> <def>We are ignorant; we ignore; -- being the
word formerly written on a bill of indictment by a grand jury
when there was not sufficient evidence to warrant them in finding
it a true bill. The phrase now used is, \'bdNo bill,\'b8 \'bdNo
true bill,\'b8 or \'bdNot found,\'b8 though in some jurisdictions
\'bdIgnored\'b8 is still used.</def>

<au>Wharton (Law Dict. ). Burn.</au>

<sn>2.</sn> <plu>(pl. <plw>Ignoramuses</plw>
<pr>(<?/)</pr>.)</plu> <def>A stupid, ignorant person; a vain
pretender to knowledge; a dunce.</def>

<q>An <qex>ignoramus</qex> in place and power.</q>
<qau>South.</qau>

<hw>Ig"no*rance</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[F., fr. L.
<ets>ignorantia</ets>.]</ety> <sn>1.</sn> <def>The condition of
being ignorant; the want of knowledge in general, or in relation
to a particular subject; the state of being uneducated or
uninformed.</def>

<q><qex>Ignorance</qex> is the curse of God,
Knowledge the wing wherewith we fly to heaven.</q>
<qau>Shak.</qau>

<sn>2.</sn> <fld>(Theol.)</fld> <def>A willful neglect or refusal
to acquire knowledge which one may acquire and it is his duty to
have.</def>

<au>Book of Common Prayer.</au>

<cs><col>Invincible ignorance</col> <fld>(Theol.)</fld>,
<cd>ignorance beyond the individual's control and for which,
therefore, he is not responsible before God.</cd></cs>

<hw>Ig"no*rant</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>a.</pos> <ety>[F., fr. L.
<ets>ignorans</ets>, <ets>-antis</ets>, p.pr. of
<ets>ignorare</ets> to be ignorant. See <er>Ignore</er>.]</ety>
<sn>1.</sn> <def>Destitute of knowledge; uninstructed or
uninformed; untaught; unenlightened.</def>

<q>He that doth not know those things which are of use for him to
know, is but an <qex>ignorant</qex> man, whatever he may know
besides.</q>
<qau>Tillotson.</qau>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>Unacquainted with; unconscious or unaware; --
used with <xex>of</xex>.</def>

<q><qex>Ignorant</qex> of guilt, I fear not shame.</q>
<qau>Dryden.</qau>

<sn>3.</sn> <def>Unknown; undiscovered.</def> <mark>[Obs.]</mark>

<q><qex>Ignorant</qex> concealment.</q>
<qau>Shak.</qau>

<q>Alas, what <qex>ignorant</qex> sin have I committed?</q>
<qau>Shak.</qau>

<sn>4.</sn> <def>Resulting from ignorance; foolish; silly.</def>

<q>His shipping,
Poor <qex>ignorant</qex> baubles! -- on our terrible seas,
Like eggshells moved.</q>
<qau>Shak.</qau>

<syn>Syn. -- Uninstructed; untaught; unenlightened; uninformed;
unlearned; unlettered; illiterate. -- <er>Ignorant</er>,
<er>Illiterate</er>. <xex>Ignorant</xex> denotes want of
knowledge, either as to single subject or information in general;
<xex>illiterate</xex> refers to an ignorance of letters, or of
knowledge acquired by reading and study. In the Middle Ages, a
great proportion of the higher classes were
<xex>illiterate</xex>, and yet were far from being
<xex>ignorant</xex>, especially in regard to war and other active
pursuits.</syn>

<q>In such business
Action is eloquence, and the eyes of the <qex>ignorant</qex>
More learned than the ears.</q>
<qau>Shak.</qau>

<q>In the first ages of Christianity, not only the learned and
the wise, but the <qex>ignorant</qex> and <qex>illiterate</qex>,
embraced torments and death.</q>
<qau>Tillotson.</qau>

<hw>Ig"no*rant</hw>, <pos>n.</pos> <def>A person untaught or
uninformed; one unlettered or unskilled; an ignoramous.</def>

<q>Did I for this take pains to teach
Our zealous <qex>ignorants</qex> to preach?</q>
<qau>Denham.</qau>

<hw>Ig"no*rant*ism</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <def>The
spirit of those who extol the advantage to ignorance;
obscuriantism.</def>

<hw>Ig"no*rant*ist</hw>, <pos>n.</pos> <def>One opposed to the
diffusion of knowledge; an obscuriantist.</def>

<hw>Ig"no*rant*ly</hw>, <pos>adv.</pos> <def>In a ignorant
manner; without knowledge; inadvertently.</def>

<q>Whom therefoer ye <qex>ignorantly</qex> worship, him declare I
unto you.</q>
<qau>Acts xvii. 23.</qau>

<hw>Ig*nore"</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>v. t.</pos>
<wordforms>[<pos>imp. & p. p.</pos> <er>Ignored</er>
<pr>(?)</pr>; <pos>p. pr. & vb. n.</pos>
<er>Ignoring</er>.]</wordforms> <ety>[L. <ets>ignorare</ets>;
pref. <ets>in-</ets> not + the root of <ets>gnarus</ets> knowing,
<ets>noscere</ets> to become acquainted with. See <er>Know</er>,
and cf. <er>Narrate</er>.]</ety> <sn>1.</sn> <def>To be ignorant
of or not acquainted with.</def> <mark>[Archaic]</mark>

<q>Philosophy would solidly be established, if men would more
carefully distinguish those things that they know from those that
they <qex>ignore</qex>.</q>
<qau>Boyle.</qau>

<sn>2.</sn> <fld>(Law)</fld> <def>To throw out or reject as false
or ungrounded; -- said of a bill rejected by a grand jury for
want of evidence. See <er>Ignoramus</er>.</def>

<sn>3.</sn> <def>Hence: To refuse to take notice of; to shut the
eyes to; not to recognize; to disregard willfully and
causelessly; <as>as, to <ex>ignore</ex> certain facts; to
<ex>ignore</ex> the presence of an objectionable
person.</as></def>

<q><qex>Ignoring</qex> Italy under our feet,
And seeing things before, behind.</q>
<qau>Mrs. Browning.</qau>

<hw>Ig*nos"ci*ble</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>a.</pos> <ety>[L.
<ets>ignoscibilis</ets>, fr. <ets>ignoscere</ets> to pardon,
lit., not to wish to know; pref. <ets>in-</ets> not +
<ets>gnoscere</ets>, <ets>noscere</ets>, to learn to know. See
<er>In-</er> not, and <er>Know</er>.]</ety>
<def>Pardonable.</def> <mark>[Obs.]</mark>

<au>Bailey.</au>

<hw>Ig*note"</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>a.</pos> <ety>[L.
<ets>ignotus</ets>; pref. <ets>in-</ets> not + <ets>gnotus</ets>,
