<hw>I*gua"na</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[Sp.
<ets>iguana</ets>, from the native name in Hayti. Cf.
<er>Guana</er>.]</ety> <fld>(Zo\'94l.)</fld> <def>Any species of
the genus <spn>Iguana</spn>, a genus of large American lizards of
the family <spn>Iguanid\'91</spn>. They are arboreal in their
habits, usually green in color, and feed chiefly upon
fruits.</def>

<note><hand/ The common iguana (<spn>I. tuberculata</spn>) of the
West Indies and South America is sometimes five feet long. Its
flesh is highly prized as food. The horned iguana (<spn>I.
cornuta</spn>) has a conical horn between the eyes.</note>

<hw>I*gua"ni*an</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>a.</pos>
<fld>(Zo\'94l.)</fld> <def>Resembling, or pertaining to, the
iguana.</def>

<hw>I*gua"nid</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>a.</pos>
<fld>(Zo\'94l.)</fld> <def>Same as <er>Iguanoid</er>.</def>

<hw>I*gua"no*don</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos>
<ety>[<ets>Iguana</ets> + Gr. <?/, <?/, a tooth.]</ety>
<fld>(Paleon.)</fld> <def>A genus of gigantic herbivorous
dinosaurs having a birdlike pelvis and large hind legs with
three-toed feet capable of supporting the entire body. Its teeth
resemble those of the iguana, whence its name. Several species
are known, mostly from the Wealden of England and Europe. See
<xex>Illustration</xex> in Appendix.</def>

<hw>I*gua"no*dont</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>a.</pos>
<fld>(Paleon.)</fld> <def>Like or pertaining to the genus
Iguanodon.</def>

<hw>I*gua"noid</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>a.</pos>
<ety>[<ets>Iguana</ets> + -<ets>oid</ets>.]</ety>
<fld>(Zo\'94l.)</fld> <def>Pertaining to the
<spn>Iguanid\'91</spn>.</def>

<hw>Ih*lang`-ih*lang"</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos>
<ety>[Malayan, flower of flowers.]</ety> <def>A rich, powerful,
perfume, obtained from the volatile oil of the flowers of
<spn>Canada odorata</spn>, an East Indian tree.</def>
<altsp>[Also written <asp>ylang-ylang</asp>.]</altsp>

peculiar dress worn by pilgrims to Mecca.</def>

<hw>Il`e*o*c\'91"cal</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>a.</pos>

<hw>Il`e*o*col"ic</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>a.</pos>
<fld>(Anat.)</fld> <def>Pertaining to the ileum and colon;
<as>as, the <ex>ileocolic</ex>, or ileoc\'91cal, valve, a valve
where the ileum opens into the large intestine</as>.</def>

<hw>\'d8Il"e*um</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[L.
<ets>ile</ets>, <ets>ileum</ets>, <ets>ilium</ets>, pl.
<ets>ilia</ets>, groin, flank.]</ety> <sn>1.</sn>
<fld>(Anat.)</fld> <def>The last, and usually the longest,
division of the small intestine; the part between the jejunum and
large intestine.</def> <altsp>[Written also <asp>ileon</asp>, and
<asp>ilium</asp>.]</altsp>

<sn>2.</sn> <fld>(Anat.)</fld> <def>See <er>Ilium</er>.</def>
<mark>[R.]</mark>

<note><hand/ Most modern writers restrict <xex>ileum</xex> to the
division of the intestine and <xex>ilium</xex> to the pelvic
bone.</note>

<hw>\'d8Il"e*us</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[NL., fr.
Gr. <?/, <?/, fr. <?/ to roll up.]</ety> <fld>(Med.)</fld> <def>A
morbid condition due to intestinal obstruction. It is
characterized by complete constipation, with griping pains in the
abdomen, which is greatly distended, and in the later stages by
vomiting of fecal matter. Called also <altname>ileac, <or/ iliac,
passion</altname>.</def>

<hw>\'d8I"lex</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[L., holm
oak.]</ety> <fld>(Bot.)</fld> <sd>(a)</sd> <def>The holm oak
(<spn>Quercus Ilex</spn>).</def> <sd>(b)</sd> <def>A genus of
evergreen trees and shrubs, including the common holly.</def>

<hw>Il"i*ac</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>a.</pos> <ety>[L.
<ets>Iliacus</ets>, Gr. <?/. See <er>Iliad</er>.]</ety>
<def>Pertaining to ancient Ilium, or Troy.</def>

<hw>Il"i*ac</hw>, <pos>a.</pos> <ety>[Cf. F. <ets>iliaque</ets>.
See <er>Ileum</er>, and cf. <er>Jade</er> a stone.]</ety>
<sn>1.</sn> <fld>(Anat.)</fld> <def>Pertaining to, or in the

<ex>iliac</ex> artery</as>.</def> <altsp>[Written also
<asp>ileac</asp>.]</altsp>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>See <er>Ileac</er>, 1.</def> <mark>[R.]</mark>

<cs><col>Iliac crest</col>, <cd>the upper margin of the
ilium.</cd> -- <col>Iliac passion</col>. <cd>See
<er>Ileus</er>.</cd> -- <col>Iliac region</col>, <cd>a region of
the abdomen, on either side of the hypogastric regions, and below
the lumbar regions.</cd></cs>

<hw>l"i*ad</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[L.
<ets>Ilias</ets>, <ets>-adis</ets>, Gr. <?/, <?/ (sc. <?/), fr.
<?/, <?/, Ilium, the city of Ilus, a son of Tros, founder of
Ilium, which is a poetical name of Troy.]</ety> <def>A celebrated
Greek epic poem, in twenty-four books, on the destruction of
Ilium, the ancient Troy. The Iliad is ascribed to Homer.</def>

<hw>Il`i*o*pso"as</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos>
<fld>(Anat.)</fld> <def>The great flexor muscle of the hip joint,

<hw>\'d8Il"i*um</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[See

<mhw>{ <hw>Il*kon"</hw>, <hw>Il*koon"</hw> <pr>(?)</pr> }</mhw>,
<pos>pron.</pos> <ety>[See <er>Ilk</er>, and <er>One</er>.]</ety>

<hw>Ill</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>a.</pos> <wordforms>[The regular
comparative and superlative are wanting, their places being
supplied by <xex>worse</xex> <pr>(<?/)</pr> and <xex>worst</xex>
<pr>(<?/)</pr>, from another root.]</wordforms> <ety>[OE.
<ets>ill</ets>, <ets>ille</ets>, Icel. <ets>illr</ets>; akin to
Sw. <ets>illa</ets>, adv., Dan. <ets>ilde</ets>, adv.]</ety>
<sn>1.</sn> <def>Contrary to good, in a physical sense; contrary
or opposed to advantage, happiness, etc.; bad; evil; unfortunate;
disagreeable; unfavorable.</def>

<q>Neither is it <qex>ill</qex> air only that maketh an
<qex>ill</qex> seat, but <qex>ill</qex> ways, <qex>ill</qex>
markets, and <qex>ill</qex> neighbors.</q>
<qau>Bacon.</qau>

<q>There 's some <qex>ill</qex> planet reigns.</q>
<qau>Shak.</qau>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>Contrary to good, in a moral sense; evil;
wicked; wrong; iniquitious; naughtly; bad; improper.</def>

<q>Of his own body he was ill, and gave
The clergy <qex>ill</qex> example.</q>
<qau>Shak.</qau>

<sn>3.</sn> <def>Sick; indisposed; unwell; diseased; disordered;
<as>as, <ex>ill</ex> of a fever</as>.</def>

<q>I am in health, I breathe, and see thee <qex>ill</qex>.</q>
<qau>Shak.</qau>

<sn>4.</sn> <def>Not according with rule, fitness, or propriety;
incorrect; rude; unpolished; inelegant.</def>

<q>That 's an <qex>ill</qex> phrase.</q>
<qau>Shak.</qau>

<cs><col>Ill at ease</col>, <cd>uneasy; uncomfortable; anxious.
\'bdI am very <xex>ill at ease<xex>.\'b8 <au>Shak</au>.</cd> --
<col>Ill blood</col>, <cd>enmity; resentment.</cd> -- <col>Ill
breeding</col>, <cd>want of good breeding; rudeness.</cd> --
<col>Ill fame</col>, <cd>ill or bad repute; as, a house of
<xex>ill fame<xex>, a house where lewd persons meet for illicit
intercourse.</cd> -- <col>Ill humor</col>, <cd>a disagreeable
mood; bad temper.</cd> -- <col>Ill nature</col>, <cd>bad
disposition or temperament; sullenness; esp., a disposition to
cause unhappiness to others.</cd> -- <col>Ill temper</col>,
<cd>anger; moroseness; crossness.</cd> -- <mcol><col>Ill
turn</col>. <sd>(a)</sd> <cd>An unkind act.</cd> <sd>(b)</sd>
<cd>A slight attack of illness</cd>. <mark>[Colloq. U.S.]</mark>
-- <col>Ill will</col></mcol>, <cd>unkindness; enmity;
malevolence.</cd></cs>

<syn>Syn. -- Bad; evil; wrong; wicked; sick; unwell.</syn>

<-- p. 728 -->

<hw>Ill</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <sn>1.</sn>
<def>Whatever annoys or impairs happiness, or prevents success;
evil of any kind; misfortune; calamity; disease; pain; <as>as,
the <ex>ills</ex> of humanity</as>.</def>

<q>Who can all sense of others' <qex>ills</qex> escape
Is but a brute at best in human shape.</q>
<qau>Tate.</qau>

<q>That makes us rather bear those <qex>ills</qex> we have
Than fly to others that we know not of.</q>
<qau>Shak.</qau>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>Whatever is contrary to good, in a moral sense;
wickedness; depravity; iniquity; wrong; evil.</def>

<q>Strong virtue, like strong nature, struggles still,
Exerts itself, and then throws off the <qex>ill</qex>.</q>
<qau>Dryden.</qau>

<hw>Ill</hw>, <pos>adv.</pos> <def>In a ill manner; badly;
weakly.</def>

<q>How <qex>ill</qex> this taper burns!</q>
<qau>Shak.</qau>

<q><qex>Ill</qex> fares the land, to hastening ills a prey,
Where wealth accumulates and men decay.</q>
<qau>Goldsmith.</qau>

<note><hand/ <xex>Ill</xex>, like <xex>above</xex>,
<xex>well</xex>, and <xex>so</xex>, is used before many
participal adjectives, in its usual adverbal sense. When the two
words are used as an epithet preceding the noun qualified they
are commonly hyphened; in other cases they are written
separatively; as, an <xex>ill</xex>-educated man; he was
<xex>ill</xex> educated; an <xex>ill</xex>-formed plan; the plan,
however <xex>ill</xex> formed, was acceptable. Ao, also, the
following: <xex>ill</xex>-affected or <xex>ill</xex> affected,
<xex>ill</xex>-arranged or <xex>ill</xex> arranged,
<xex>ill</xex>-assorted or <xex>ill</xex> assorted,
<xex>ill</xex>-boding or <xex>ill</xex> boding,
<xex>ill</xex>-bred or <xex>ill</xex> bred,
<xex>ill</xex>-conditioned, <xex>ill</xex>-conducted,
<xex>ill</xex>-considered, <xex>ill</xex>-devised,
<xex>ill</xex>-disposed, <xex>ill</xex>-doing,
<xex>ill</xex>-fairing, <xex>ill</xex>-fated,
<xex>ill</xex>-favored, <xex>ill</xex>-featured,
<xex>ill</xex>-formed, <xex>ill</xex>-gotten,
<xex>ill</xex>-imagined, <xex>ill</xex>-judged,
<xex>ill</xex>-looking, <xex>ill</xex>-mannered,
<xex>ill</xex>-matched, <xex>ill</xex>-meaning,
<xex>ill</xex>-minded, <xex>ill</xex>-natured,
<xex>ill</xex>-omened, <xex>ill</xex>-proportioned,
<xex>ill</xex>-provided, <xex>ill</xex>-required,
<xex>ill</xex>-sorted, <xex>ill</xex>-starred,
<xex>ill</xex>-tempered, <xex>ill</xex>-timed,
<xex>ill</xex>-trained, <xex>ill</xex>-used, and the like.</note>

<hw>I' ll</hw> <pr>(?)</pr><def>. Contraction for <xex>I
will</xex> or <xex>I shall</xex>.</def>

<q><qex>I'll</qex> by a sign give notice to our friends.</q>
<qau>Shak.</qau>

<hw>Il*la"que*ate</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>v. t.</pos>

<hw>Il*la"tion</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[L.
<ets>illatio</ets>, fr. <ets>illatus</ets>, used as p.p. of
<ets>inferre</ets> to carry or bring in, but from a different
root: cf. F. <ets>illation</ets>. See 1st <er>In-</er>, and
<er>Tolerate</er>, and cf. <er>Infer</er>.]</ety> <def>The act or
process of inferring from premises or reasons; perception of the
connection between ideas; that which is inferred; inference;
deduction; conclusion.</def>

<q>Fraudulent deductions or inconsequent <qex>illations</qex>
from a false conception of things.</q>
<qau>Sir T. Browne.</qau>

<hw>Il"la*tive</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>a.</pos> <ety>[L.
<ets>illativus</ets>: cf. F. <ets>illatif</ets>.]</ety>
<def>Relating to, dependent on, or denoting, illation;
inferential; conclusive; <as>as, an <ex>illative</ex> consequence
or proposition; an <ex>illative</ex> word, as <xex>then</xex>,
<xex>therefore</xex>, etc.</as></def>

<cs><col>Illative conversion</col> <fld>(Logic)</fld>, <cd>a
converse or reverse statement of a proposition which in that form
must be true because the original proposition is true.</cd> --
<col>Illative sense</col> <fld>(Metaph.)</fld>, <cd>the faculty
of the mind by which it apprehends the conditions and determines
upon the correctness of inferences.</cd></cs>

<hw>Il"la*tive</hw>, <pos>n.</pos> <def>An illative particle, as
<xex>for</xex>, <xex>because</xex>.</def>

<hw>Il"la*tive*ly</hw>, <pos>adv.</pos> <def>By inference; as an
illative; in an illative manner.</def>

<hw>Il`le*git"i*ma*cy</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <def>The
state of being illegitimate.</def>

<au>Blackstone.</au>

<hw>Il`le*git"i*mate</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>a.</pos> <sn>1.</sn>
<def>Not according to law; not regular or authorized; unlawful;
improper.</def>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>Unlawfully begotten; born out of wedlock;
bastard; <as>as, an <ex>illegitimate</ex> child</as>.</def>

<sn>3.</sn> <def>Not legitimately deduced or inferred; illogical;
<as>as, an <ex>illegitimate</ex> inference</as>.</def>

<sn>4.</sn> <def>Not authorized by good usage; not genuine;
spurious; <as>as, an <ex>illegitimate</ex> word</as>.</def>

<cs><mcol><col>Illegitimate fertilization</col>, <or/
<col>Illegitimate union</col></mcol> <fld>(Bot.)</fld>, <cd>the
fertilization of pistils by stamens not of their own length, in
heterogonously dimorphic and trimorphic flowers.</cd></cs>

<au>Darwin.</au>

<hw>Il`le*git"i*mate</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>v. t.</pos>
<wordforms>[<pos>imp. & p. p.</pos> <er>Illegitimated</er>
<pr>(?)</pr>; <pos>p. pr. & vb. n.</pos>
<er>Illegitimating</er>.]</wordforms> <def>To render
illegitimate; to declare or prove to be born out of wedlock; to
bastardize; to illegitimatize.</def>

<q>The marriage should only be dissolved for the future, without
<qex>illegitimating</qex> the issue.</q>
<qau>Bp. Burnet.</qau>

<hw>Il`le*git"i*mate*ly</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>adv.</pos>
<def>In a illegitimate manner; unlawfully.</def>

<hw>Il`le*git`i*ma"tion</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos>
<sn>1.</sn> <def>The act of illegitimating; bastardizing.</def>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>The state of being illegitimate;
illegitimacy.</def> <mark>[Obs.]</mark>

<q>Gardiner had performed his promise to the queen of getting her
<qex>illegitimation</qex> taken off.</q>
<qau>Bp. Burnet.</qau>

<hw>Il`le*git"i*ma*tize</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>v. t.</pos>
<def>To render illegitimate; to bastardize.</def>

<hw>Il*le"sive</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>a.</pos> <ety>[Pref.
<ets>il-</ets> not + L. <ets>laedere</ets>, <ets>laesum</ets>, to
injure.]</ety> <def>Not injurious; harmless.</def>
<mark>[R.]</mark>

<hw>\'d8Il*li"ci*um</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[So

allurement.]</ety> <fld>(Bot.)</fld> <def>A genus of Asiatic and
American magnoliaceous trees, having star-shaped fruit; star
anise. The fruit of <xex>Illicium anisatum</xex> is used as a
spice in India, and its oil is largely used in Europe for
flavoring cordials, being almost identical with true oil of
anise.</def>

immeasurable; infinite; immense; vast.</syn>

<hw>Il*lit"er*a*cy</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos>; <plu>pl.

<hw>Ill"ness</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[From
<er>Ill</er>.]</ety> <sn>1.</sn> <def>The condition of being ill,
evil, or bad; badness; unfavorableness.</def> <mark>[Obs.]</mark>
\'bdThe <xex>illness</xex> of the weather.\'b8

<au>Locke.</au>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>Disease; indisposition; malady; disorder of
health; sickness; <as>as, a short or a severe
<ex>illness</ex></as>.</def>

<sn>3.</sn> <def>Wrong moral conduct; wickedness.</def>

<au>Shak.</au>

<syn>Syn. -- Malady; disease; indisposition; ailment.</syn>
<usage> -- <er>Illness</er>, <er>Sickness</er>. Within the
present century, there has been a tendency in England to use
<xex>illness</xex> in the sense of a continuous disease, disorder
of health, or sickness, and to confine <xex>sickness</xex> more
especially to a sense of nausea, or \'bdsickness of the
stomach.\'b8</usage>

<def>Illuminative.</def>

<hw>Il*lu"mi*nate</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>v. t.</pos>
<wordforms>[<pos>imp. & p. p.</pos> <er>Illuminated</er>
<pr>(?)</pr>; <pos>p. pr. & vb. n.</pos> <er>Illuminating</er>
<pr>(?)</pr>.]</wordforms> <ety>[L. <ets>illuminatus</ets>, p.p.
of <ets>illuminare</ets>; pref. <ets>il-</ets> in +
<ets>luminare</ets> to enlighten, fr. <ets>lumen</ets> light. See
<er>Luminous</er>, and cf. <er>Illume</er>, <er>Illumine</er>,
<er>Enlimn</er>, <er>Limn</er>.]</ety> <sn>1.</sn> <def>To make
light; to throw light on; to supply with light, literally or
figuratively; to brighten.</def>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>To light up; to decorate with artificial lights,
as a building or city, in token of rejoicing or respect.</def>

<sn>3.</sn> <def>To adorn, as a book or page with borders,
initial letters, or miniature pictures in colors and gold, as was
done in manuscripts of the Middle Ages.</def>

<sn>4.</sn> <def>To make plain or clear; to dispel the obscurity
to by knowledge or reason; to explain; to elucidate; <as>as, to
<ex>illuminate</ex> a text, a problem, or a duty</as>.</def>

<-- p. 729 -->

<hw>Il*lu"mi*nate</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>v. i.</pos> <def>To
light up in token or rejoicing.</def>

<hw>Il*lu"mi*nate</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>a.</pos> <ety>[L.
<ets>illuminatus</ets>, p.p.]</ety> <def>Enlightened.</def>

<au>Bp. Hall.</au>

<hw>Il*lu"mi*nate</hw>, <pos>n.</pos> <def>One who enlightened;
esp., a pretender to extraordinary light and knowledge.</def>

<hw>\'d8Il*lu`mi*na"ti</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n. pl.</pos>
<ety>[L. <ets>illuminatus</ets>. See <er>Illuminate</er>, <pos>v.
t.</pos>, and cf. <er>Illuminee</er>.]</ety> <def>Literally,
those who are enlightened; -- variously applied as follows:
-</def>

<sn>1.</sn> <fld>(Eccl.)</fld> <def>Persons in the early church
who had received baptism; in which ceremony a lighted taper was
given them, as a symbol of the spiritual illumination they has
received by that sacrament.</def>

<sn>2.</sn> <fld>(Eccl. Hist.)</fld> <def>Members of a sect which
sprung up in Spain about the year 1575. Their principal doctrine
was, that, by means of prayer, they had attained to so perfect a
state as to have no need of ordinances, sacraments, good works,
etc.; -- called also <altname>Alumbrados</altname>,
<altname>Perfectibilists</altname>, etc.</def>

<sn>3.</sn> <fld>(Mod. Hist.)</fld> <def>Members of certain
associations in Modern Europe, who combined to promote social
reforms, by which they expected to raise men and society to
perfection, esp. of one originated in 1776 by Adam Weishaupt,
professor of canon law at Ingolstadt, which spread rapidly for a
time, but ceased after a few years.</def>

<sn>4.</sn> Also applied to: <sd>(a)</sd> <def>An obscure sect of
French Familists.</def> <sd>(b)</sd> <def>The Hesychasts,
Mystics, and Quietists;</def> <sd>(c)</sd> <def>The
Rosicrucians.</def>

<sn>5.</sn> <def>Any persons who profess special spiritual or
intellectual enlightenment.</def>

<hw>Il*lu"mi*na`ting</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>a.</pos> <def>Giving
or producing light; used for illumination.</def>

<cs><col>Illuminating gas</col>. <cd>See <er>Gas</er>,
<pos>n.</pos>, 2 <sd>(a)<sd>.</cd></cs>

<hw>Il*lu`mi*na"tion</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[L.
<ets>illuminatio</ets>: cf. F. <ets>illumination</ets>.]</ety>
<sn>1.</sn> <def>The act of illuminating, or supplying with
light; the state of being illuminated.</def>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>Festive decoration of houses or buildings with
lights.</def>

<sn>3.</sn> <def>Adornment of books and manuscripts with colored
illustrations. See <er>Illuminate</er>, <pos>v. t.</pos>,
3.</def>

<sn>4.</sn> <def>That which is illuminated, as a house; also, an
ornamented book or manuscript.</def>

<sn>5.</sn> <def>That which illuminates or gives light;
brightness; splendor; especially, intellectual light or
knowledge.</def>

<q>The <qex>illumination</qex> which a bright genius giveth to
his work.</q>
<qau>Felton.</qau>

<sn>6.</sn> <fld>(Theol.)</fld> <def>The special communication of
knowledge to the mind by God; inspiration.</def>

<q>Hymns and psalms . . . are framed by meditation beforehand, or
by prophetical <qex>illumination</qex> are inspired.</q>
<qau>Hooker.</qau>

<hw>Il*lu"mi*na*tism</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos>
<def>Illuminism.</def> <mark>[R.]</mark>

<hw>Il*lu"mi*na*tive</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>a.</pos> <ety>[Cf.
F. <ets>illuminatif</ets>.]</ety> <def>Tending to illuminate or
illustrate; throwing light; illustrative.</def>
\'bd<xex>Illuminative</xex> reading.\'b8

<au>Carlyle.</au>

<hw>Il*lu"mi*na`tor</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[L., an
enlightener, LL. also, an illuminator of books.]</ety>
<sn>1.</sn> <def>One whose occupation is to adorn books,
especially manuscripts, with miniatures, borders, etc. See
<er>Illuminate</er>, <pos>v. t.</pos>, 3.</def>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>A condenser or reflector of light in optical
apparatus; also, an illuminant.</def>

<hw>Il*lu"mine</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>v. t.</pos> <ety>[Cf. F.
<ets>illuminer</ets>. See <er>Illuminate</er>.]</ety> <def>To
illuminate; to light up; to adorn.</def>

<hw>Il*lu`mi*nee"</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[F.
<ets>illumin\'82</ets>. Cf. <er>Illuminati</er>.]</ety> <def>One
of the Illuminati.</def>

<hw>Il*lu"mi*ner</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <def>One who,
or that which, illuminates.</def>

<hw>Il*lu"mi*nism</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[Cf. F.
<ets>illuminisme</ets>.]</ety> <def>The principles of the
Illuminati.</def>

<hw>Il*lu`mi*nis"tic</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>a.</pos> <def>Of or
pertaining to illuminism, or the Illuminati.</def>

<hw>Il*lu"mi*nize</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>v. t.</pos>
<wordforms>[<pos>imp. & p. p.</pos> <er>Illuminized</er>
<pr>(?)</pr>; <pos>p. pr. & vb. n.</pos> <er>Illuminizing</er>
<pr>(?)</pr>.]</wordforms> <def>To initiate the doctrines or
principles of the Illuminati.</def>

<hw>Il*lu"mi*nous</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>a.</pos> <def>Bright;
clear.</def> <mark>[R.]</mark>

<au>H. Taylor.</au>

<hw>Il*lure"</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>v. t.</pos> <ety>[Pref.
<ets>il-</ets> in + <ets>lure</ets>.]</ety> <def>To deceive; to
entice; to lure.</def> <mark>[Obs.]</mark>

<q>The devil insnareth the souls of many men, by
<qex>illuring</qex> them with the muck and dung of this
world.</q>
<qau>Fuller.</qau>

<hw>Ill`-used"</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>a.</pos> <def>Misapplied;
treated badly.</def>

<hw>Il*lu"sion</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[F.
<ets>illusion</ets>, L. <ets>illusio</ets>, fr.
<ets>illu</ets>dere, <ets>illusum</ets>, to illude. See
<er>Illude</er>.]</ety> <sn>1.</sn> <def>An unreal image
presented to the bodily or mental vision; a deceptive appearance;
a false show; mockery; hallucination.</def>

<q>To cheat the eye with blear <qex>illusions</qex>.</q>
<qau>Milton.</qau>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>Hence: Anything agreeably fascinating and
charning; enchantment; witchery; glamour.</def>

<q>Ye soft <qex>illusions</qex>, dear deceits, arise!</q>
<qau>Pope.</qau>

<sn>3.</sn> <fld>(Physiol.)</fld> <def>A sensation originated by
some external object, but so modified as in any way to lead to an
erroneous perception; as when the rolling of a wagon is mistaken
for thunder.</def>

<note><hand/ Some modern writers distinguish between an
<xex>illusion</xex> and <xex>hallucination</xex>, regarding the
former as originating with some external object, and the latter
as having no objective occasion whatever.</note>

<sn>4.</sn> <def>A plain, delicate lace, usually of silk, used
for veils, scarfs, dresses, etc.</def>

<syn>Syn. -- Delusion; mockery; deception; chimera; fallacy. See
<er>Delusion</er>. <er>Illusion</er>, <er>Delusion</er>.
<xex>Illusion</xex> refers particularly to errors of the sense;
<xex>delusion</xex> to false hopes or deceptions of the mind. An
optical deception is an <xex>illusion</xex>; a false opinion is a
<xex>delusion</xex>.</syn>

<au>E. Edwards.</au>

<hw>Il*lu"sion*a*ble</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>a.</pos> <def>Liable
to illusion.</def>

<hw>Il*lu"sion*ist</hw>, <pos>n.</pos> <def>One given to
illusion; a visionary dreamer.</def>

<q>Truth from <qex>illusive</qex> falsehood to command.</q>
<qau>Thomson.</qau>

<hw>Il*lu"sive*ness</hw>, <pos>n.</pos> <def>The quality of being

<hw>Il*lus"tra*ble</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>a.</pos> <def>Capable
of illustration.</def>

<au>Sir T. Browne.</au>

<hw>Il*lus"trate</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>v. t.</pos>
<wordforms>[<pos>imp. & p. p.</pos> <er>Illustrated</er>
<pr>(?)</pr>; <pos>p. pr. & vb. n.</pos> <er>Illustrating</er>
<pr>(?)</pr>.]</wordforms> <ety>[L. <ets>illustratus</ets>, p.p.
of <ets>illustrare</ets> to illustrate, fr. <ets>illustris</ets>
bright. See <er>Illustrious</er>.]</ety> <sn>1.</sn> <def>To make
clear, bright, or luminous.</def>

<q>Here, when the moon <qex>illustrates</qex> all the sky.</q>
<qau>Chapman.</qau>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>To set in a clear light; to exhibit distinctly
or conspicuously.</def>

<au>Shak.</au>

<q>To prove him, and <qex>illustrate</qex> his high worth.</q>
<qau>Milton.</qau>

<sn>3.</sn> <def>To make clear, intelligible, or apprehensible;
to elucidate, explain, or exemplify, as by means of figures,
comparisons, and examples.</def>

<sn>4.</sn> <def>To adorn with pictures, as a book or a subject;
to elucidate with pictures, as a history or a romance.</def>

<sn>5.</sn> <def>To give renown or honor to; to make illustrious;
to glorify.</def> <mark>[Obs.]</mark>

<q>Matter to me of glory, whom their hate
<qex>Illustrates</qex>.</q>
<qau>Milton.</qau>

<hw>Il*lus"trate</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>a.</pos> <ety>[L.

distinguished; illustrious.</def> <mark>[Obs.]</mark>

<q>This most gallant, <qex>illustrate</qex>, and learned
gentleman.</q>
<qau>Shak.</qau>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>That which illustrates; a comparison or example
intended to make clear or apprehensible, or to remove

<sn>3.</sn> <def>A picture designed to decorate a volume or

<hw>Im"age</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[F., fr. L.
<ets>imago</ets>, <ets>imaginis</ets>, from the root of
<ets>imitari</ets> to imitate. See <er>Imitate</er>, and cf.
<er>Imagine</er>.]</ety> <sn>1.</sn> <def>An imitation,
representation, or similitude of any person, thing, or act,
sculptured, drawn, painted, or otherwise made perceptible to the
sight; a visible presentation; a copy; a likeness; an effigy; a
picture; a semblance.</def>

<q>Even like a stony <qex>image</qex>, cold and numb.</q>
<qau>Shak.</qau>

<q>Whose is this <qex>image</qex> and superscription?</q>
<qau>Matt. xxii. 20.</qau>

<q>This play is the <qex>image</qex> of a murder done in
Vienna.</q>
<qau>Shak.</qau>

<q>And God created man in his own <qex>image</qex>.</q>
<qau>Gen. i. 27.</qau>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>Hence: The likeness of anything to which worship
is paid; an idol.</def>

<au>Chaucer.</au>

<q>Thou shalt not make unto thee any graven <qex>image</qex>, . .
. thou shalt not bow down thyself to them.</q>
<qau>Ex. xx. 4, 5.</qau>

<sn>3.</sn> <def>Show; appearance; cast.</def>

<q>The face of things a frightful <qex>image</qex> bears.</q>
<qau>Dryden.</qau>

<sn>4.</sn> <def>A representation of anything to the mind; a
picture drawn by the fancy; a conception; an idea.</def>

<q>Can we conceive
<qex>Image</qex> of aught delightful, soft, or great?</q>
<qau>Prior.</qau>

<sn>5.</sn> <fld>(Rhet.)</fld> <def>A picture, example, or
illustration, often taken from sensible objects, and used to
illustrate a subject; usually, an extended metaphor.</def>

<au>Brande & C.</au>

<sn>6.</sn> <fld>(Opt.)</fld> <def>The figure or picture of any
object formed at the focus of a lens or mirror, by rays of light
from the several points of the object symmetrically refracted or
reflected to corresponding points in such focus; this may be
received on a screen, a photographic plate, or the retina of the
eye, and viewed directly by the eye, or with an eyeglass, as in
the telescope and microscope; the likeness of an object formed by
reflection; <as>as, to see one's <ex>image</ex> in a
mirror</as>.</def>

<cs><col>Electrical image</col>. <cd>See under
<er>Electrical</er>.</cd> -- <col>Image breaker</col>, <cd>one
who destroys images; an iconoclast.</cd> -- <mcol><col>Image
graver</col>, <col>Image maker</col></mcol>, <cd>a sculptor.</cd>
-- <col>Image worship</col>, <cd>the worship of images as
symbols; iconolatry distinguished from idolatry; the worship of
images themselves.</cd> -- <col>Image Purkinje</col>
<fld>(Physics)</fld>, <cd>the image of the retinal blood vessels
projected in, not merely on, that membrane.</cd> -- <col>Virtual
image</col> <fld>(Optics)</fld>, <cd>a point or system of points,
on one side of a mirror or lens, which, if it existed, would emit
the system of rays which actually exists on the other side of the
mirror or lens.</cd></cs>

<au>Clerk Maxwell.</au>

<hw>Im"age</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>v. t.</pos>
<wordforms>[<pos>imp. & p. p.</pos> <er>Imaged</er> <pr>(?)</pr>;
<pos>p. pr. & vb. n.</pos> <er>Imaging</er>
<pr>(?)</pr>.]</wordforms> <sn>1.</sn> <def>To represent or form
an image of; <as>as, the still lake <ex>imaged</ex> the shore;
the mirror <ex>imaged</ex> her figure.</as></def> \'bdShrines of
<xex>imaged</xex> saints.\'b8

<au>J. Warton.</au>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>To represent to the mental vision; to form a

<q>Condemn'd whole years in absence to deplore,
And <qex>image</qex> charms he must behold no more.</q>
<qau>Pope.</qau>

<hw>Im"age*ry</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[OE.
<ets>imagerie</ets>, F. <ets>imagerie</ets>.]</ety> <sn>1.</sn>
<def>The work of one who makes images or visible representation

\'bdPainted <xex>imagery</xex>.\'b8

<cs><col>Imaginal disks</col> <fld>(Zo\'94l.)</fld>, <cd>masses
of hypodermic cells, carried by the larv\'91 of some insects
after leaving the egg, from which masses the wings and legs of
the adult are subsequently formed.</cd></cs>

<hw>Im*ag"i*nant</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>a.</pos> <ety>[L.

<hw>Im*ag"i*na*ry</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>a.</pos> <ety>[L.
<ets>imaginarius</ets>: cf. F. <ets>imaginaire</ets>.]</ety>
<def>Existing only in imagination or fancy; not real; fancied;
visionary; ideal.</def>

<qex>Imaginary</qex> ills and fancied tortures?</q>
<qau>Addison.</qau>

<cs><col>Imaginary calculus</col> <cd>See under
<er>Calculus</er>.</cd> -- <mcol><col>Imaginary expression</col>
<or/ <col>quantity</col></mcol> <fld>(Alg.)</fld>, <cd>an
algebraic expression which involves the impossible operation of
taking the square root of a negative quantity; as,
<mathex><root/-9</mathex>, <mathex>a + b <root/-1</mathex>.</cd>
-- <mcol><col>Imaginary points</col>, <col>lines</col>,
<col>surfaces</col></mcol>, etc. <fld>(Geom.)</fld>, <cd>points,
lines, surfaces, etc., imagined to exist, although by reason of
certain changes of a figure they have in fact ceased to have a
real existence.</cd></syn

<syn>Syn. -- Ideal; fanciful; chimerical; visionary; fancied;
unreal; illusive.</def>

<hw>Im*ag"i*na*ry</hw>, <pos>n.</pos> <fld>(Alg.)</fld> <def>An
imaginary expression or quantity.</def>

<hw>Im*ag"i*nate</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>a.</pos>
<def>Imaginative.</def> <mark>[Obs.]</mark>

<au>Holland.</au>

<hw>Im*ag`i*na"tion</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[OE.
<ets>imaginacionum</ets>, F. <ets>imagination</ets>, fr. L.
<ets>imaginatio</ets>. See <er>Imagine</er>.]</ety> <sn>1.</sn>
<def>The imagine-making power of the mind; the power to create or
reproduce ideally an object of sense previously perceived; the
power to call up mental imagines.</def>

<q>Our simple apprehension of corporeal objects, if present, is
sense; if absent, is <qex>imagination</qex>.</q>
<qau>Glanvill.</qau>

<q><qex>Imagination</qex> is of three kinds: joined with belief
of that which is to come; joined with memory of that which is
past; and of things present, or as if they were present.</q>
<qau>Bacon.</qau>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>The representative power; the power to
reconstruct or recombine the materials furnished by direct
apprehension; the complex faculty usually termed the
<xex>plastic</xex> or <xex>creative</xex> power; the fancy.</def>

<q>The <qex>imagination</qex> of common language -- the
productive <qex>imagination</qex> of philosophers -- is nothing
but the representative process plus the process to which I would
give the name of the \'bdcomparative.\'b8</q>
<qau>Sir W. Hamilton.</qau>

<q>The power of the mind to decompose its conceptions, and to
recombine the elements of them at its pleasure, is called its
faculty of <qex>imagination</qex>.</q>
<qau>I. Taylor.</qau>

<q>The business of conception is to present us with an exact
transcript of what we have felt or perceived. But we have
moreover a power of modifying our conceptions, by combining the
parts of different ones together, so as to form new wholes of our
creation. I shall employ the word <qex>imagination</qex> to
express this power.</q>
<qau>Stewart.</qau>

<sn>3.</sn> <def>The power to recombine the materials furnished
by experience or memory, for the accomplishment of an elevated
purpose; the power of conceiving and expressing the ideal.</def>

<q>The lunatic, the lover, and the poet
Are of <qex>imagination</qex> all compact . . . 
The poet's eye, in a fine frenzy rolling,
Doth glance from heaven to earth, from earth to heaven,
And as <qex>imagination</qex> bodies forth
The forms of things unknown, the poet's pen
Turns them to shapes, and gives to airy nothing
A local habitation and a name.</q>
<qau>Shak.</qau>

<sn>4.</sn> <def>A mental image formed by the action of the
imagination as a faculty; a conception; a notion.</def>

<au>Shak.</au>

<syn>Syn. -- Conception; idea; conceit; fancy; device;
origination; invention; scheme; design; purpose;
contrivance.</syn> -- <usage><er>Imagination</er>,
<er>Fancy</er>. These words have, to a great extent, been
interchanged by our best writers, and considered as strictly
synonymous. A distinction, however, is now made between them
which more fully exhibits their nature. Properly speaking, they
are different exercises of the same general power -- the plastic
or creative faculty. <xex>Imagination</xex> consists in taking
parts of our conceptions and combining them into new forms and
images more select, more striking, more delightful, more
terrible, etc., than those of ordinary nature. It is the higher
exercise of the two. It creates by laws more closely connected
with the reason; it has <xex>strong emotion</xex> as its
actuating and formative cause; it aims at results of a definite
and weighty character. Milton's fiery lake, the debates of his
Pandemonium, the exquisite scenes of his Paradise, are all
products of the imagination. <xex>Fancy</xex> moves on a lighter
wing; it is governed by laws of association which are more
remote, and sometimes arbitrary or capricious. Hence the term
<xex>fanciful</xex>, which exhibits fancy in its wilder flights.
It has for its actuating spirit feelings of a lively, gay, and
versatile character; it seeks to please by unexpected
combinations of thought, startling contrasts, flashes of
brilliant imagery, etc. Pope's Rape of the Lock is an exhibition
of fancy which has scarcely its equal in the literature of any
country. -- \'bdThis, for instance, Wordworth did in respect of
the words \'bfimagination' and \'bffancy.' Before he wrote, it
was, I suppose, obscurely felt by most that in \'bfimagination'
there was more of the earnest, in \'bffancy' of the play of the
spirit; that the first was a loftier faculty and gift than the
second; yet for all this words were continually, and not without
loss, confounded. He first, in the preface to his Lyrical
Ballads, rendered it henceforth impossible that any one, who had
read and mastered what he has written on the two words, should
remain unconscious any longer of the important difference between
them.\'b8 <au>Trench</au>.</usage>

<q>The same power, which we should call <qex>fancy</qex> if
employed on a production of a light nature, would be dignified
with the title of <qex>imagination</qex> if shown on a grander
scale.</q>
<qau>C. J. Smith.</qau>

<-- p. 730 -->

<hw>Im*ag`i*na"tion*al</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>a.</pos>
<def>Pertaining to, involving, or caused by, imagination.</def>

<hw>Im*ag`i*na"tion*al*ism</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos>
<def>Idealism.</def>

<au>J. Grote.</au>

<hw>Im*ag"i*na*tive</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>a.</pos> <ety>[F.
<ets>imaginatif</ets>.]</ety> <sn>1.</sn> <def>Proceeding from,
and characterized by, the imagination, generally in the highest
sense of the word.</def>

<q>In all the higher departments of <qex>imaginative</qex> art,
nature still constitues an important element.</q>
<qau>Mure.</qau>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>Given to imagining; full of images, fancies,
etc.; having a quick imagination; conceptive; creative.</def>

<q>Milton had a highly <qex>imaginative</qex>, Cowley a very
fanciful mind.</q>
<qau>Coleridge.</qau>

<sn>3.</sn> <def>Unreasonably suspicious; jealous.</def>
<mark>[Obs.]</mark>

<au>Chaucer.</au>

-- <wordforms><wf>Im*ag"i*na*tive*ly</wf>, <pos>adv.</pos> --
<wf>Im*ag"i*na*tive*ness</wf>, <pos>n.</pos></wordforms>

<hw>Im*ag"ine</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>v. t.</pos>
<wordforms>[<pos>imp. & p. p.</pos> <er>Imagined</er>
<pr>(?)</pr>; <pos>p. pr. & vb. n.</pos>
<er>Imagining</er>.]</wordforms> <ety>[F. <ets>imaginer</ets>, L.
<ets>imaginari</ets>, p.p. <ets>imaginatus</ets>, fr.
<ets>imago</ets> image. See <er>Image</er>.]</ety> <sn>1.</sn>
<def>To form in the mind a notion or idea of; to form a mental
image of; to conceive; to produce by the imagination.</def>

<q>In the night, <qex>imagining</qex> some fear,
How easy is a bush supposed a bear!</q>
<qau>Shak.</qau>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>To contrive in purpose; to scheme; to devise; to
compass; to purpose. See <er>Compass</er>, <pos>v. t.</pos>,
5.</def>

<q>How long will ye <qex>imagine</qex> mischief against a
man?</q>
<qau>Ps. lxii. 3.</qau>

<sn>3.</sn> <def>To represent to one's self; to think; to
believe.</def>

<au>Shak.</au>

<syn>Syn. -- To fancy; conceive; apprehend; think; believe;
suppose; opine; deem; plan; scheme; devise.</syn>

<hw>Im*ag"ine</hw>, <pos>v. i.</pos> <sn>1.</sn> <def>To form
images or conceptions; to conceive; to devise.</def>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>To think; to suppose.</def>

<q>My sister is not so defenseless left
As you <qex>imagine</qex>.</q>
<qau>Milton.</qau>

<hw>Im*ag"in*er</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <def>One who
forms ideas or conceptions; one who contrives.</def>

<au>Bacon.</au>

<hw>Im*ag"in*ous</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>a.</pos>
<def>Imaginative.</def> <mark>[R.]</mark>

<au>Chapman.</au>

<hw>\'d8I*ma"go</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos>; <plu>pl.
<plw>Imagoes</plw> <pr>(#)</pr></plu>. <ety>[L. See
<er>Image</er>.]</ety> <sn>1.</sn> <def>An image.</def>

<sn>2.</sn> <fld>(Zo\'94l.)</fld> <def>The final adult, and
usually winged, state of an insect. See <xex>Illust</xex>. of
<er>Ant-lion</er>, and <er>Army worm</er>.</def>

<mhw>{ <hw>\'d8I*mam"</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <hw>\'d8I*man"</hw>
<pr>(?)</pr>, <hw>\'d8I*maum"</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, }</mhw>
<pos>n.</pos> <ety>[Ar. <ets>im\'bem</ets>.]</ety> <sn>1.</sn>
<def>Among the Mohammedans, a minister or priest who performs the
regular service of the mosque.</def>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>A Mohammedan prince who, as a successor of
Mohammed, unites in his person supreme spiritual and temporal
power.</def>

<hw>Im"be*cile</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>a.</pos> <ety>[L.

origin: cf. F. <ets>imb\'82cile</ets>.]</ety> <def>Destitute of

mentally wea; feeble-minded; <as>as, hospitals for the
<ex>imbecile</ex> and insane</as>.</def>

<au>A. Wilson.</au>

<hw>Im`be*cil"i*ty</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos>; <plu>pl.
<plw>Imbecilities</plw> <pr>(#)</pr></plu>. <ety>[L.
<ets>imbecillitas</ets>: cf. F.
<ets>imb\'82cillit\'82</ets>.]</ety> <def>The quality of being
imbecile; weakness; feebleness, esp. of mind.</def>

<q>Cruelty . . . argues not only a depravedness of nature, but
also a meanness of courage and <qex>imbecility</qex> of mind.</q>
<qau>Sir W. Temple.</qau>

<note><hand/ This term is used specifically to denote natural
weakness of the mental faculties, affecting one's power to act
reasonably or intelligently.</note>

<syn>Syn. -- Debility; infirmity; weakness; feebleness;
impotence. See <er>Debility</er>.</syn>

<hw>Im*bibe"</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>v. t.</pos>

<er>Imbibing</er>.]</wordforms> <ety>[L. <ets>imbibere</ets>;

<as>as, to <ex>imbibe</ex> principles; to <ex>imbibe</ex>
errors.</as></def>

\'bdEarth, <xex>imbibed</xex> with . . . acid.\'b8

<mhw>{ <hw>Im"bri*cate</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <hw>Im"bri*ca`ted</hw>
<pr>(?)</pr>, }</mhw> <pos>a.</pos> <ety>[L.
<ets>imbricatus</ets>, p.p. of <ets>imbricare</ets> to cover with
tiles, to form like a gutter tile, fr. <ets>imbrex</ets>,
<ets>-icis</ets>, a hollow tile, gutter tile, fr.
<ets>imber</ets> rain.]</ety> <sn>1.</sn> <def>Bent and hollowed
like a roof or gutter tile.</def>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>Lying over each other in regular order, so as to
\'bdbreak joints,\'b8 like tiles or shingles on a roof, the
scales on the leaf buds of plants and the cups of some acorns, or
the scales of fishes; overlapping each other at the margins, as
leaves in \'91stivation.</def>

<sn>3.</sn> <def>In decorative art: Having scales lapping one
over the other, or a representation of such scales; <as>as, an
<ex>imbricated</ex> surface; an <ex>imbricated</ex>
pattern.</as></def>

<hw>Im"bri*cate</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>v. t.</pos> <def>To lay
in order, one lapping over another, so as to form an imbricated
surface.</def>

<hw>Im`bri*ca"tion</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[Cf. F.
<ets>imbrication</ets>.]</ety> <def>An overlapping of the edges,
like that of tiles or shingles; hence, intricacy of structure;
also, a pattern or decoration representing such a
structure.</def>

<hw>Im"bri*ca*tive</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>a.</pos>
<fld>(Bot.)</fld> <def>Imbricate.</def>

<hw>Im*brue"</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>v. t.</pos>
<wordforms>[<pos>imp. & p. p.</pos> <er>Imbureed</er>

<er>Imbureing</er>.]</wordforms> <ety>[Cf. OF.
<ets>embruer</ets>, also <ets>embruver</ets>,
<ets>embreuver</ets>, <ets>embrever</ets>, to give to drink, soak
(see pref. <er>En-</er>, 1, 1st <er>In-</er>, and

<ets>enbrowen</ets>, to stain, soil (cf. <er>Brewis</er>).]</ety>

<qex>imbrued</qex>.</q>
<qau>Milton.</qau>

<hw>Im*brute"</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>v. t.</pos>
<wordforms>[<pos>imp. & p. p.</pos> <er>Imbruted</er>; <pos>p.
pr. & vb. n.</pos> <er>Imbruting</er>.]</wordforms> <ety>[Pref.
<ets>im-</ets> in + <ets>brute</ets>: cf. F. <ets>abrutir</ets>.
Cf. <er>Embrute</er>.]</ety> <def>To degrade to the state of a

<qau>Milton.</qau>

<hw>Im*brute"</hw>, <pos>v. i.</pos> <def>To sink to the state of
a brute.</def>

<q>The soul grows clotted by contagion,
Imbodies, and <qex>imbrutes</qex>, till she quite lose
The divine property of her first being.</q>
<qau>Milton.</qau>

<hw>Im*brute"ment</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <def>The act
of imbruting, or the state of being imbruted.</def>

<hw>Im*bue"</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>v. t.</pos>
<wordforms>[<pos>imp. & p. p.</pos> <er>Imbued</er> <pr>(?)</pr>;
<pos>p. pr. & vb. n.</pos> <er>Imbuing</er>.]</wordforms>
<ety>[L. <ets>imbuere</ets>; pref. <ets>im-</ets> in + perh. a
disused simple word akin to L. <ets>bibere</ets> to drink. Cf.
<er>Imbibe</er>.]</ety> <sn>1.</sn> <def>To tinge deeply; to dye;
to cause to absorb; <as>as, clothes thoroughly <ex>imbued</ex>
with black</as>.</def>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>To tincture deply; to cause to become impressed
or penetrated; <as>as, to <ex>imbue</ex> the minds of youth with
good principles</as>.</def>

<q>Thy words with grace divine
<qex>Imbued</qex>, bring to their sweetness no satiety.</q>
<qau>Milton.</qau>

<hw>Im*bue"ment</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <def>The act of
imbuing; the state of being imbued; hence, a deep tincture.</def>

<hw>Im*burse"</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>v. t.</pos> <ety>[Pref.
<ets>im-</ets> in + <ets>burse</ets>: cf. F. <ets>embourser</ets>
to put into one's purse. See <er>Burse</er>, and
<er>Purse</er>.]</ety> <def>To supply or stock with money.</def>
<mark>[Obs.]</mark>

<hw>Im*burse"ment</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <sn>1.</sn>
<def>The act of imbursing, or the state of being imbursed.</def>
<mark>[Obs.]</mark>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>Money laid up in stock.</def>
<mark>[Obs.]</mark>

<hw>Im*bu"tion</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <def>An
imbuing.</def> <mark>[Obs.]</mark>

<hw>I*mes"a*tin</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos>
<ety>[<ets>Im</ets>id<ets>e</ets> + i<ets>satin</ets>.]</ety>
<fld>(Chem.)</fld> <def>A dark yellow, crystalline substance,
obtained by the action of ammonia on isatin.</def>

<hw>Im"ide</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <fld>(Chem.)</fld>
<def>A compound with, or derivative of, the imido group; specif.,
a compound of one or more acid radicals with the imido group, or
with a monamine; hence, also, a derivative of ammonia, in which
two atoms of hydrogen have been replaced by divalent basic or
acid radicals; -- frequently used as a combining form; <as>as,
succin<ex>imide</ex></as>.</def>

<hw>Im"i*do</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>a.</pos> <fld>(Chem.)</fld>
<def>Pertaining to, containing, or combined with, the radical NH,
which is called the <xex>imido group</xex>.</def>

<cs><col>Imido acid</col>, <cd>an organic acid, consisting of one
or more acid radicals so united with the imido group that it
contains replaceable acid hydrogen, and plays the part of an
acid; as, uric acid, succinimide, etc., are <xex>imido
acids<xex>.</cd></cs>

<hw>Im`it*a*bil"i*ty</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[See
<er>Imitable</er>.]</ety> <def>The quality of being
imitable.</def>

<au>Norris.</au>

<-- p. 731 -->

<hw>Im"i*ta*ble</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>a.</pos> <ety>[L.
<ets>imitabilis</ets>: cf. F. <ets>imitable</ets>. See
<er>Imitate</er>.]</ety> <sn>1.</sn> <def>Capble of being
imitated or copied.</def>

<q>The characters of man placed in lower stations of life are
more usefull, as being <qex>imitable</qex> by great numbers.</q>
<qau>Atterbury.</qau>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>Worthy of imitation; <as>as, <ex>imitable</ex>
character or qualities</as>.</def>

<au>Sir W. Raleigh.</au>

<hw>Im"i*ta*ble*ness</hw>, <pos>n.</pos> <def>The state or
quality of being imitable; worthness of imitation.</def>

<hw>Im"i*tan*cy</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[From L.
<ets>imitans</ets>, p. pr. of <ets>imitare</ets>.]</ety>
<def>Tendency to imitation.</def> <mark>[R.]</mark>

<au>Carlyle.</au>

<hw>Im"i*tate</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>v. t.</pos>
<wordforms>[<pos>imp. & p. p.</pos> <er>Imitated</er>
<pr>(?)</pr>; <pos>p. pr. & vb. n.</pos> <er>Imitating</er>
<pr>(?)</pr>.]</wordforms> <ety>[L. <ets>imitatus</ets>, p. p. of
<ets>imitari</ets> to imitate; of unknown origin. Cf.
<er>Image</er>.]</ety> <sn>1.</sn> <def>To follow as a pattern,
model, or example; to copy or strive to copy, in acts, manners
etc.</def>

<q>Despise wealth and <qex>imitate</qex> a dog.</q>
<qau>Cowlay.</qau>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>To produce a semblance or likeness of, in form,
character, color, qualities, conduct, manners, and the like; to
counterfeit; to copy.</def>

<q>A place picked out by choice of best alive
The Nature's work by art can <qex>imitate</qex>.</q>
<qau>Spenser.</qau>

<q>This hand appeared a shining sword to weild,
And that sustained an <qex>imitated</qex> shield.</q>
<qau>Dryden.</qau>

<sn>3.</sn> <fld>(Biol.)</fld> <def>To resemble (another species
of animal, or a plant, or inanimate object) in form, color,
ornamentation, or instinctive habits, so as to derive an
advantage thereby; sa, when a harmless snake <xex>imitates</xex>
a venomous one in color and manner, or when an odorless insect
<xex>imitates</xex>, in color, one having secretion offensive to
birds.</def>

<hw>Im"i*ta"tion</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[L.
<ets>imitatio</ets>: cf. F. <ets>imitation</ets>.]</ety>
<sn>1.</sn> <def>The act of imitating.</def>

<q>Poesy is an art of <qex>imitation</qex>, . . . that is to say,
a representing, counterfeiting, or figuring forth.</q>
<qau>Sir P. Sidney.</qau>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>That which is made or produced as a copy; that
which is made to resemble something else, whether for laudable or
for fraudulent purposes; likeness; resemblance.</def>

<q>Both these arts are not only true <qex>imitations</qex> of
nature, but of the best nature.</q>
<qau>Dryden.</qau>

<sn>3.</sn> <fld>(Mus.)</fld> <def>One of the principal means of
securing unity and consistency in polyphonic composition; the
repetition of essentially the same melodic theme, phrase, or
motive, on different degrees of pitch, by one or more of the
other parts of voises. Cf. <er>Canon</er>.</def>

<sn>4.</sn> <fld>(Biol.)</fld> <def>The act of condition of
imitating another species of animal, or a plant, or unanimate
object. See <er>Imitate</er>, <pos>v. t.</pos>, 3.</def>

<note><hand/ <xex>Imitation</xex> is often used adjectively to
characterize things which have a deceptive appearance, simulating
the qualities of a superior article; -- opposed to
<xex>real</xex> or <xex>genuine</xex>; as, <xex>imitation</xex>
lace; <xex>imitation</xex> bronze; <xex>imitation</xex> modesty,
etc.</note>

<hw>Im`i*ta"tion*al</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>a.</pos>
<def>Pertaining to, or employed in, imitation; <as>as,
<ex>imitational</ex> propensities</as>.</def>

<hw>Im"i*ta*tive</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>a.</pos> <ety>[L.
<ets>imitavitus</ets>: cf. F. <ets>imitatif</ets>.]</ety>
<sn>1.</sn> <def>Inclined to imitate, copy, or follow; imitating;
exhibiting some of the qualities or characteristics of a pattern
or model; dependent on example; not original; <as>as, man is an
<ex>imitative</ex> being; painting is an <ex>imitative</ex>
art.</as></def>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>Formed after a model, pattern, or
original.</def>

<q>This temple, less in form, with equal grace,
Was <qex>imitative</qex> of the first in Thrace.</q>
<qau>Dryden.</qau>

<sn>3.</sn> <fld>(Nat. Hist.)</fld> <def>Designed to imitate
another species of animal, or a plant, or inanimate object, for
some useful purpose, such as protection from enemies; having
resamblance to something else; <as>as, <ex>imitative</ex> colors;
<ex>imitative</ex> habits; dendritic and mammillary forms of
minerals are <ex>imitative</ex>.</as></def>

<mhw>{ <hw>Im"ma*nence</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <hw>Im"ma*nen*cy</hw>

<hw>Im"ma*nent</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>a.</pos> <ety>[L.
<ets>immanens</ets>, p. pr. of <ets>immanere</ets> to remain in

hence, limited in activity, agency, or effect, to the subject or
associated acts; -- opposed to <xex>emanant</xex>,
<xex>transitory</xex>, <xex>transitive</xex>, or
<xex>objective</xex>.</def>

<qau>Sir W. Hamilton.</qau>

<qau>Hare.</qau>

<hw>Im"ma*ter"ri*al</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>a.</pos> <ety>[Pref.
<ets>im-</ets> not + <ets>material</ets>: cf. F.
<ets>immat\'82riel</ets>.]</ety> <sn>1.</sn> <def>Not consisting
of matter; incorporeal; spiritual; disembodied.</def>

<q>Angels are spirits <qex>immaterial</qex> and intellectual.</q>
<qau>Hooker.</qau>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>Of no substantial consequence; without weight or
significance; unimportant; <as>as, it is wholly
<ex>immaterial</ex> whether he does so or not</as>.</def>

<syn>Syn. -- Unimportant; inconsequential; insignificant;
inconsiderable; trifling.</syn>

<hw>Im`ma*te"ri*al*ism</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[Cf.
F. <ets>immat\'82rialisme</ets>.]</ety> <sn>1.</sn> <def>The
doctrine that immaterial substances or spiritual being exist, or
are possible.</def>

<sn>2.</sn> <fld>(Philos.)</fld> <def>The doctrine that external
bodies may be reduced to mind and ideas in a mind; any doctrine
opposed to materialism or phenomenalism, esp. a system that
maintains the immateriality of the soul; idealism; esp., Bishop
Berkeley's theory of idealism.</def>

<hw>Im`ma*te"ri*al*ist</hw>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[Cf. F.
<ets>immat\'82rialiste</ets>.]</ety> <fld>(Philos.)</fld>
<def>One who believes in or professes, immaterialism.</def>

<hw>Im`ma*te`ri*al"i*ty</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos>;
<plu>pl. <plw>Immaterialities</plw> <pr>(#)</pr></plu>. <ety>[Cf.
F. <ets>immat\'82rialit</ets>\'82.]</ety> <def>The state or
quality of being immaterial or incorporeal; <as>as, the
<ex>immateriality</ex> of the soul</as>.</def>

<hw>Im*me"di*a*cy</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <def>The
relation of freedom from the interventionof a medium;
immediateness.</def>

<au>Shak.</au>

<hw>Im*me"di*ate</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>a.</pos> <ety>[F.
<ets>imm\'82diat</ets>. See <er>In-</er> not, and
<er>Mediate</er>.]</ety> <sn>1.</sn> <def>Not separated in
respect to place by anything intervening; proximate; close;
<as>as, <ex>immediate</ex> contact</as>.</def>

<q>You are the most <qex>immediate</qex> to our throne.</q>
<qau>Shak.</qau>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>Not deferred by an interval of time; present;
instant.</def> \'bdAssemble we <xex>immediate</xex> council.\'b8

<au>Shak.</au>

<q>Death . . . not yet inflicted, as he feared,
By some <qex>immediate</qex> stroke.</q>
<qau>Milton.</qau>

<sn>3.</sn> <def>Acting with nothing interposed or between, or
without the intervention of another object as a cause, means, or
agency; acting, perceived, or produced, directly; <as>as, an
<ex>immediate</ex> cause</as>.</def>

<q>The <qex>immediate</qex> knowledge of the past is therefore
impossible.</q>
<qau>Sir. W. Hamilton.</qau>

<cs><col>Immediate amputation</col> <fld>(Surg.)</fld>, <cd>an
amputation performed within the first few hours after an injury,
and before the the effects of the shock have passed
away.</cd></cs>

<syn>Syn. -- Proximate; close; direct; next.</syn>

<hw>Im*me"di*ate*ly</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>adv.</pos>
<sn>1.</sn> <def>In an immediate manner; without intervention of
any other person or thing; proximately; directly; -- opposed to
<xex>mediately</xex>; <as>as, <ex>immediately</ex>
contiguous</as>.</def>

<q>God's acceptance of it either <qex>immediately</qex> by
himself, or mediately by the hands of the bishop.</q>
<qau>South.</qau>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>Without interval of time; without delay;
promptly; instantly; at once.</def>

<q>And Jesus . . . touched him, saying, I will; be thou clean.
And <qex>immediately</qex> his leprosy was cleansed.</q>
<qau>Matt. viii. 3.</qau>

<sn>3.</sn> <def>As soon as. Cf. <er>Directly</er>, <sn>8</sn>,
Note.</def>

<syn>Syn. -- Directly; instantly; quickly; forthwith;
straightway; presently. See <er>Directly</er>.</syn>

relations of being immediate in manner, place, or time; exemption
from second or interventing causes.</def>

<au>Bp. Hall.</au>

<def>Immediateness.</def>

<hw>Im*mem"o*ra*ble</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>a.</pos> <ety>[L.
<ets>immemorabilis</ets>; pref. <ets>im-</ets> not +

<ets>imm\'82morable</ets>. See <er>Memorable</er>.]</ety>

<hw>Im`me*mo"ri*al</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>a.</pos> <ety>[Pref.
<ets>im-</ets> not + <ets>memorial</ets>: cf. F.
<ets>imm\'82morial</ets>.]</ety> <def>Extending beyond the reach
of memory, record, or tradition; indefinitely ancient; <as>as,
existing from time <ex>immemorial</ex></as>.</def>
\'bd<xex>Immemorial</xex> elms.\'b8 <au>Tennyson</au>.
\'bd<xex>Immemorial</xex> usage or custom.\'b8 <au>Sir M.
Hale</au>.

<cs><col>Time immemorial</col> <fld>(Eng. Law.)</fld>, <cd>a time
antedating (legal) history, and beyond \'bdlegal memory\'b8 so
called; formerly an indefinite time, but in 1276 this time was
fixed by statute as the begining of the reign of Richard I.
(1189). Proof of unbroken possession or use of any right since
that date made it unnecessary to establish the original grant. In
1832 the plan of dating legal memory from a fixed time was
abandoned and the principle substituted that rights which had
been enjoyed for full twenty years (or as against the crown
thirty years) should not be liable to impeachment merely by
proving that they had not been enjoyed before.</cd></cs>

<hw>Im`me*mo"ri*al*ly</hw>, <pos>adv.</pos> <def>Beyond
memory.</def>

<au>Bentley.</au>

<hw>Im*mense"</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>a.</pos> <ety>[L.
<ets>immensus</ets>; pref. <ets>im-</ets> not +
<ets>mensus</ets>, p. p. of <ets>metiri</ets> to measure: cf. F.
<ets>immense</ets>. See <er>Measure</er>.]</ety>
<def>Immeasurable; unlimited. In commonest use: Very great; vast;
huge.</def> \'bd<xex>Immense</xex> the power\'b8 <au>Pope</au>.
\'bd<xex>Immense</xex> and boundless ocean.\'b8 <au>Daniel</au>.

<qau>Milton.</qau>

<syn>Syn. -- Infinite; immeasurable; illimitable; unbounded;
unlimited; interminable; vast; prodigious; enormous; monstrous.
See <er>Enormous</er>.</syn>

<hw>Im*merge"</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>v. t.</pos>

<hw>Im*merse"</hw>, <pos>v. t.</pos> <wordforms>[<pos>imp. & p.
p.</pos> <er>Immersed</er> <pr>(?)</pr>; <pos>p. pr. & vb.
n.</pos> <er>Immersing</er>.]</wordforms> <sn>1.</sn> <def>To
plunge into anything that surrounds or covers, especially into a
fluid; to dip; to sink; to bury; to immerge.</def>

<q>Deep <qex>immersed</qex> beneath its whirling wave.</q>
<qau>J Warton.</qau>

<q>More than a mile <qex>immersed</qex> within the wood.</q>
<qau>Dryden.</qau>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>To baptize by immersion.</def>

<sn>3.</sn> <def>To engage deeply; to engross the attention of;
to involve; to overhelm.</def>

<q>The queen <qex>immersed</qex> in such a trance.</q>
<qau>Tennyson.</qau>

<q>It is impossible to have a lively hope in another life, and
yet be deeply <qex>immersed</qex> inn the enjoyments of this.</q>
<qau>Atterbury.</qau>

<-- p. 732 -->

<hw>Im*mersed"</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>p. p. & a.</pos>
<sn>1.</sn> <def>Deeply plunged into anything, especially a
fluid.</def>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>Deeply occupied; engrossed; entangled.</def>

<sn>3.</sn> <fld>(Bot.)</fld> <def>Growing wholly under
water.</def>

<au>Gray.</au>

<hw>Im*mers"i*ble</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>a.</pos> <ety>[From
<er>Immerse</er>.]</ety> <def>Capable of being immersed.</def>

<hw>Im*mer"sion</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[L.
<ets>immersio</ets>; cf. F. <ets>immersion</ets>.]</ety>
<sn>1.</sn> <def>The act of immersing, or the state of being
immersed; a sinking within a fluid; a dipping; <as>as, the
<ex>immersion</ex> of Achilles in the Styx</as>.</def>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>Submersion in water for the purpose of Christian
baptism, <as>as, practiced by the Baptists</as>.</def>

<sn>3.</sn> <def>The state of being overhelmed or deeply
absorbed; deep engagedness.</def>

<q>Too deep an <qex>immersion</qex> in the affairs of life.</q>
<qau>Atterbury.</qau>

<sn>4.</sn> <fld>(Astron.)</fld> <def>The dissapearance of a
celestail body, by passing either behind another, as in the
occultation of a star, or into its shadow, as in the eclipse of a
satellite; -- opposed to <xex>emersion</xex>.</def>

<cs><col>Immersion lens</col>, <cd>a microscopic objective of
short focal distance designed to work with a drop of liquid, as
oil, between the front lens and the slide, so that this lens is
practically <xex>immersed<xex>.</cd></cs>

<hw>Im*mer"sion*ist</hw>, <pos>n.</pos> <fld>(Eccl.)</fld>
<def>One who holds the doctrine that immersion is essential to
Christian baptism.</def>

<hw>Im"mi*nence</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[Cf. F.
<ets>imminence</ets>, L. <ets>imminentia</ets>, See
<er>Imminent</er>.]</ety> <sn>1.</sn> <def>The condition or
quality of being imminent; a threatening, as of something about
to happen. The imminence of any danger or distress.</def>

<au>Fuller.</au>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>That which is imminent; impending evil or
danger.</def> \'bdBut dare all <xex>imminence</xex>.\'b8

<au>Shak.</au>

<hw>Im"mi*nent</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>a.</pos> <ety>[L.
<ets>imminens</ets>, p. pr. of <ets>imminere</ets> to project;
pref. <ets>im-</ets> in + <ets>minere</ets> (in comp.) to jut,
project. See <er>Eminent</er>.]</ety> <sn>1.</sn>
<def>Threatening to occur immediately; near at hand; impending;
-- said especially of misfortune or peril.</def> \'bdIn danger
<xex>imminent</xex>.\'b8

<au>Spenser.</au>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>Full of danger; threatening; menacing;
perilous.</def>

<q>Hairbreadth scapes i' the <qex>imminent</qex> deadly
breach.</q>
<qau>Shak.</qau>

<sn>3.</sn> <def>(With <xex>upon</xex>) Bent upon; attentive
to.</def> <mark>[R.]</mark>

<q>Their eyes ever <qex>imminent</qex> upon worldly matters.</q>
<qau>Milton.</qau>

<syn>Syn. -- Impending; threatening; near; at hand.</syn> -- 
<usage><er>Imminent</er>, <er>Impending</er>,
<er>Threatening</er>. <xex>Imminent</xex> is the strongest: it
denotes that something is ready to fall or happen on the instant;
as, in <xex>imminent</xex> danger of one's life.
<xex>Impending</xex> denotes that something hangs suspended over
us, and may so remain indefinitely; as, the <xex>impending</xex>
evils of war. <xex>Threatening</xex> supposes some danger in
prospect, but more remote; as, <xex>threatening</xex> indications
for the future.</usage>

<q>Three times to-day
You have defended me from <qex>imminent</qex> death.</q>
<qau>Shak.</qau>

<q>No story I unfold of public woes,
Nor bear advices of <qex>impending</qex> foes.</q>
<qau>Pope.</qau>

<q>Fierce faces <qex>threatening</qex> war.</q>
<qau>Milton.</qau>

<hw>Im*mod"er*ate</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>a.</pos> <ety>[L.
<ets>immoderatus</ets>; pref. <ets>im-</ets> not +
<ets>moderatus</ets> moderate. See <er>Moderate</er>.]</ety>
<def>Not moderate; exceeding just or usual and suitable bounds;
excessive; extravagant; unreasonable; <as>as, <ex>immoderate</ex>
demands; <ex>immoderate</ex> grief; <ex>immoderate</ex>
laughter.</as></def>

<q>So every scope by the <qex>immoderate</qex> use
Turns to restraint.</q>
<qau>Shak.</qau>

<syn>Syn. -- Excessive; exorbitant; unreasonable; extravagant;
intemperate; inordinate.</syn>

<hw>Im*mod"er*ate*ly</hw>, <pos>adv.</pos> <def>In an immoderate
manner; excessively.</def>

<hw>Im*mod`er*a"tion</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[L.
<ets>immoderatio</ets>: cf. F. <ets>imod\'82ration</ets>.]</ety>
<def>Want of moderation.</def>

<au>Hallywell.</au>

<hw>Im*mod"est</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>a.</pos> <ety>[F.
<ets>immodeste</ets>, L. <ets>immodestus</ets> immoderate; pref.
<ets>im-</ets> not + <ets>modestus</ets> modest. See
<er>Modest</er>.]</ety> <sn>1.</sn> <def>Not limited to due
bounds; immoderate.</def>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>Not modest; wanting in the reserve or restraint
which decorum and decency require; indecent; indelicate; obscene;
lewd; <as>as, <ex>immodest</ex> persons, behavior, words,
pictures, etc.</as></def>

<q><qex>Immodest</qex> deeds you hinder to be wrought,
But we proscribe the least <qex>immodest</qex> thought.</q>
<qau>Dryden.</qau>

<syn>Syn. -- Indecorous; indelicate; shameless; shameful;
impudent; indecent; impure; unchaste; lewd; obscene.</syn>

manner.</def>

<hw>Im*mod"es*ty</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[L.

<hw>Im"mo*late</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>v. t.</pos>

<hw>Im*mor"tal</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>a.</pos> <ety>[L.
<ets>immortalis</ets>; pref. <ets>im-</ets> not +

<def>Not mortal; exempt from liability to die; undying;

existance.</def>

<q>Unto the King eternal, <qex>immortal</qex>, invisible.</q>
<qau>1 Tim. i. 17.</qau>

<q>For my soul, what can it do to that,
Being a thing <qex>immortal</qex> as itself?</q>
<qau>Shak.</qau>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>Connected with, or pertaining to
immortability.</def>

<q>I have <qex>immortal</qex> longings in me.</q>
<qau>Shak.</qau>

<sn>3.</sn> <def>Destined to live in all ages of this world;
abiding; exempt from oblivion; imperishable; <as>as,
<ex>immortal</ex> fame</as>.</def>

<q>One of the few, <qex>immortal</qex> names,
That were not born yo die.</q>
<qau>Halleck.</qau>

<sn>4.</sn> <def>Great; excessive; grievous.</def>
<mark>[Obs.]</mark>

<au>Hayward.</au>

everlastings.</cd></cs>

<syn>Syn. -- Eternal; everlasting; never-ending; ceaseless;
perpetual; continual; enduring; endless; imperishable;
incorruptible; deathless; undying.</syn>

<hw>Im*mov"a*bil"i*ty</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <def>The
quality or state of being immovable; fixedness; steadfastness;
<as>as, <ex>immovability</ex> of a heavy body;
<ex>immovability</ex> of purpose.</as></def>

<hw>Im*mov"a*ble</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>a.</pos> <sn>1.</sn>
<def>Incapable of being moved; firmly fixed; fast; -- used of
material things; <as>as, an <ex>immovable</ex>
foundatin</as>.</def>

<q><qex>Immovable</qex>, infixed, and frozen round.</q>
<qau>Milton.</qau>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>Steadfast; fixed; unalterable; unchangeable; --
used of the mind or will; <as>as, an <ex>immovable</ex> purpose,
or a man who remain <ex>immovable</ex></as>.</def>

<sn>3.</sn> <def>Not capable of being affected or moved in
feeling or by sympathy; unimpressible; impassive.</def>

<au>Dryden.</au>

<sn>4.</sn> <fld>(Law.)</fld> <def>Not liable to be removed;
permanent in place or tenure; fixed; <as>as, an
<ex>immovable</ex> estate</as>. See <er>Immovable</er>,
<pos>n.</pos></def>

<au>Blackstone.</au>

<cs><col>Immovable apparatus</col> <fld>(Med.)</fld>, <cd>an
appliance, like the plaster of paris bandage, which keeps
fractured parts firmly in place.</cd> -- <col>Immovable
feasts</col> <fld>(Eccl.)</fld>, <cd>feasts which occur on a
certain day of the year and do not depend on the date of Easter;
as, Christmas, the Epiphany, etc.</cd></cs>

<hw>Im*mov"a*ble</hw>, <pos>n.</pos> <sn>1.</sn> <def>That which
can not be moved.</def>

<sn>2.</sn> <pluf>pl.</pluf> <fld>(Civil Law)</fld> <def>Lands
and things adherent thereto by nature, as trees; by the hand of
man, as buildings and their accessories; by their destination, as
seeds, plants, manure, etc.; or by the objects to which they are
applied, as servitudes.</def>

<au>Ayliffe.</au> <au>Bouvier.</au>

<hw>Imp</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[OE. <ets>imp</ets>
a graft, AS. <ets>impa</ets>; akin to Dan. <ets>ympe</ets>, Sw.
<ets>ymp</ets>, prob. fr. LL. <ets>impotus</ets>, Gr. <?/
engrafted, innate, fr. <?/ to implant; <?/ in + <?/ to produce;
akin to E. <ets>be</ets>. See 1st <er>In-</er>,
<er>Be</er>.]</ety> <sn>1.</sn> <def>A shoot; a scion; a bud; a
slip; a graft.</def> <mark>[Obs.]</mark>

<au>Chaucer.</au>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>An offspring; progeny; child; scion.</def>
<mark>[Obs.]</mark>

<q>The tender <qex>imp</qex> was weaned.</q>
<qau>Fairfax.</qau>

<sn>3.</sn> <def>A young or inferior devil; a little, malignant
spirit; a puny demon; a contemptible evil worker.</def>

<q>To mingle in the clamorous fray
Of squabbling <qex>imps</qex>.</q>
<qau>Beattie.</qau>

<sn>4.</sn> <def>Something added to, or united with, another, to
lengthen it out or repair it, -- as, an addition to a beehive; a
feather inserted in a broken wing of a bird; a length of twisted
hair in a fishing line.</def> <mark>[Obs. or Prov. Eng.]</mark>

<hw>Imp</hw>, <pos>v. t.</pos> <wordforms>[<pos>imp. & p.
p.</pos> <er>Imped</er> <pr>(?)</pr>; <pos>p. pr. & vb. n.</pos>
<er>Imping</er>.]</wordforms> <ety>[AS. <ets>impian</ets> to imp,
ingraft, plant; akin to Dan. <ets>ympe</ets>, Sw.
<ets>ympa</ets>, OHG. <ets>impf\'d3n</ets>,
<ets>impit\'d3n</ets>, G. <ets>impfen</ets>. See <er>Imp</er>,

scion.</def> <mark>[Obs.]</mark>

<au>Rom. of R.</au>

<sn>2.</sn> <fld>(Falconry)</fld> <def>To graft with new
feathers, as a wing; to splice a broken feather. Hence, Fig.: To
repair; to extend; to increase; to strengthen to equip.</def>
<mark>[Archaic]</mark>

<q><qex>Imp</qex> out our drooping country's broken wing.</q>
<qau>Shak.</qau>

<q>Who lazily imp their wings with other men's plumes. Fuller.
Here no frail Muse shall <qex>imp</qex> her crippled wing.</q>
<qau>Holmes.</qau>

<q>Help, ye tart satirists, to <qex>imp</qex> my rage
With all the scorpions that should whip this age.</q>
<qau>Cleveland.</qau>

<cs><col>Impacted fracture</col> <fld>(Surg.)</fld>, <cd>a

<hw>Im*pac"tion</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[L.
<ets>impactio</ets> a striking : cf. F.
<ets>impaction</ets>.]</ety> <sn>1.</sn> <fld>(Surg.)</fld>
<def>The driving of one fragment of bone into another so that the
fragments are not movable upon each other; <as>as, impaction of
the skull or of the hip</as>.</def>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>An immovable packing; <fld>(Med.)</fld>, a
lodgment of something in a strait or passage of the body; <as>as,
<ex>impaction</ex> of the fetal head in the strait of the pelvis;
<ex>impaction</ex> of food or feces in the intestines of man or
beast.</as></def>

to adorn with colors.</def> <mark>[R.]</mark> \'bdTo
<xex>impaint</xex> his cause.\'b8

<hw>Im*pair"</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>v. t.</pos>
<wordforms>[<pos>imp & p. p.</pos> <er>Impaired</er>
<pr>(?)</pr>; <pos>p. pr. & vb. n.</pos>
<er>Impairing</er>.]</wordforms> <altsp>[Written also
<asp>empair</asp>.]</altsp> <ety>[OE. <ets>empeiren</ets>,
<ets>enpeiren</ets>, OF. <ets>empeirier</ets>,
<ets>empirier</ets>, F. <ets>empirer</ets>, LL.
<ets>impejorare</ets>; L. pref. <ets>im-</ets> in +
<ets>pejorare</ets> to make worse, fr. <ets>pejor</ets> worse.
Cf. <er>Appair</er>.]</ety> <def>To make worse; to diminish in
quantity, value, excellence, or strength; to deteriorate; <as>as,
to <ex>impair</ex> health, character, the mind, value</as>.</def>

<q>Time sensibly all things <qex>impairs</qex>.</q>
<qau>Roscommon.</qau>

<q>In years he seemed, but not <qex>impaired</qex> by years.</q>
<qau>Pope.</qau>

<syn>Syn. -- To diminish; decrease; injure; weaken; enfeeble;
debilitate; reduce; debase; deteriorate.</syn>

<hw>Im*pair"</hw>, <pos>v. t.</pos> <def>To grow worse; to
deteriorate.</def>

<au>Milton.</au>

<hw>Im*pair"ment</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[OE.
<ets>enpeirement</ets>, OF. <ets>empirement</ets>.]</ety>
<def>The state of being impaired; injury.</def> \'bdThe
<xex>impairment</xex> of my health.\'b8

<au>Dryden.</au>

<hw>Im*pal"a*ta*ble</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>a.</pos>
<def>Unpalatable.</def> <mark>[R.]</mark>

<hw>Im*pale"</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>v. t.</pos>
<wordforms>[<pos>imp. & p. p.</pos> <er>Impaled</er>
<pr>(?)</pr>; <pos>p. pr. & vb. n.</pos>
<er>Impaling</er>.]</wordforms> <ety>[See 2d
<er>Empale</er>.]</ety> <sn>1.</sn> <def>To pierce with a pale;
to put to death by fixing on a sharp stake. See
<er>Empale</er>.</def>

<q>Then with what life remains, <qex>impaled</qex>, and left
To writhe at leisure round the bloody stake.</q>
<qau>Addison.</qau>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>To inclose, as with pales or stakes; to
surround.</def>

<q><qex>Impale</qex> him with your weapons round about.</q>
<qau>Shak.</qau>

<q>Impenetrable, <qex>impaled</qex> with circling fire.</q>
<qau>Milton.</qau>

<sn>3.</sn> <fld>(Her.)</fld> <def>To join, as two coats of arms
on one shield, palewise; hence, to join in honorable
mention.</def>

<q>Ordered the admission of St. Patrick to the same to be matched
and <qex>impaled</qex> with the blessed Virgin in the honor
thereof.</q>
<qau>Fuller.</qau>

<hw>Im*pale"ment</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <sn>1.</sn>
<def>The act of impaling, or the state of being impaled.</def>

<au>Byron.</au>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>An inclosing by stakes or pales, or the space so
inclosed.</def>

<au>H. Brooke.</au>

<sn>3.</sn> <def>That which hedges in; inclosure.</def>
<mark>[R.]</mark>

<au>Milton.</au>

<sn>4.</sn> <fld>(Her.)</fld> <def>The division of a shield
palewise, or by a vertical line, esp. for the purpose of putting
side by side the arms of husband and wife. See <er>Impale</er>,
3.</def>

<hw>Im*pal`pa*bil"i*ty</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[Cf.

<au>Jortin.</au>

<hw>Im*pal"pa*ble</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>a.</pos> <ety>[Pref.
<ets>im-</ets> not + <ets>palpable</ets>: cf. F.
<ets>impalpable</ets>.]</ety> <sn>1.</sn> <def>Not palpable; that
cannot be felt; extremely fine, so that no grit can be perceived
by touch.</def> \'bd<xex>Impalpable</xex> powder.\'b8

<au>Boyle.</au>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>Not material; intangible; incorporeal.</def>
\'bd<xex>Impalpable</xex>, void, and bodiless.\'b8

<au>Holland.</au>

<sn>3.</sn> <def>Not apprehensible, or readily apprehensible, by
the mind; unreal; <as>as, <ex>impalpable</ex>
distinctions</as>.</def>

<hw>Im*pa"nate</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>a.</pos> <ety>[LL.

<au>Cranmer.</au>

<hw>Im*pa"nate</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>v. t.</pos>
<wordforms>[<pos>imp. & p. p.</pos> <er>Impanated</er>
<pr>(?)</pr>; <pos>p. pr. & vb. n.</pos>
<er>Impanating</er>.]</wordforms> <def>To embody in bread, esp.
in the bread of the eucharist.</def> <mark>[Obs.]</mark>

<hw>Im"pa*na"tion</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[Cf. F.
<ets>impanation</ets>. See <er>Impanate</er>,
<pos>a.</pos>]</ety> <fld>(Eccl.)</fld> <def>Embodiment in bread;
the supposed real presence and union of Christ's material body
and blood with the substance of the elements of the eucharist
without a change in their nature; -- distinguished from
<xex>transubstantiation</xex>, which supposes a miraculous change
of the substance of the elements. It is akin to
<xex>consubstantiation</xex>.</def>

<hw>Im*pa"na*tor</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos>
<ety>[LL.]</ety> <fld>(Eccl.)</fld> <def>One who holds the
doctrine of impanation.</def>

<hw>Im*par"i*syl*lab"ic</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>a.</pos> <ety>[L.

<hw>Im*par"i*ty</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[Pref.
<ets>im-</ets> + <ets>parity</ets>: cf. F.
<ets>imparit\'82</ets>.]</ety> <sn>1.</sn> <def>Inequality;
disparity; disproportion; difference of degree, rank, excellence,
number, etc.</def>

<au>Milton.</au>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>Lack of comparison, correspondence, or
suitableness; incongruity.</def>

<q>In this region of merely intellectual notion we are at once
encountered by the <qex>imparity</qex> of the object and the
faculty employed upon it.</q>
<qau>I. Taylor.</qau>

<sn>3.</sn> <def>Indivisibility into equal parts; oddness.</def>
<mark>[R.]</mark>

<hw>Im*parl"</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>v. i.</pos> <ety>[OF.

<au>Sir. T. North.</au>

<sn>2.</sn> <fld>(Law)</fld> <def>To have time before pleading;
to have delay for mutual adjustment.</def>

<au>Blackstone.</au>

<hw>Im*par"lance</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[Cf.
<er>Emparlance</er>, <er>Parlance</er>.]</ety> <altsp>[Written
also <asp>inparliance</asp>.]</altsp> <sn>1.</sn> <def>Mutual
discourse; conference.</def> <mark>[Obs.]</mark>

<sn>2.</sn> <fld>(Law)</fld> <sd>(a)</sd> <def>Time given to a
party to talk or converse with his opponent, originally with the
object of effecting, if possible, an amicable adjustment of the
suit. The actual object, however, has long been merely to obtain
further time to plead, answer to the allegations of the opposite
party. </def> <sd>(b)</sd> <def>Hence, the delay or continuance
of a suit.</def>

<note><hand/ <xex>Imparlance</xex> and <xex>continuance by
imparlance</xex> have been abolished in England.</note>

<au>Wharton (Law Dict. ).</au>

<def>Presented, instituted, and inducted into a rectory, and in
full possession.</def> -- <def2><pos>n.</pos> <def>A clergyman so
inducted.</def></def2>

<hw>Im*part"</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>v. t.</pos>
<wordforms>[<pos>imp. & p. p.</pos> <er>Imparted</er>; <pos>p.
pr. & vb. n.</pos> <er>Imparting</er>.]</wordforms> <ety>[OF.
<ets>impartir</ets>, <ets>empartir</ets>, L.
<ets>impartire</ets>, <ets>impertire</ets>; pref. <ets>im-</ets>
in + <ets>partire</ets> to part, divide, fr. <ets>pars</ets>,
<ets>partis</ets>, part, share. See <er>Part</er>, <pos>n.</pos>
]</ety> <sn>1.</sn> <def>To bestow a share or portion of; to
give, grant, or communicate; to allow another to partake in;
<as>as, to <ex>impart</ex> food to the poor; the sun
<ex>imparts</ex> warmth.</as></def>

<q>Well may he then to you his cares <qex>impart</qex>.</q>
<qau>Dryden.</qau>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>To obtain a share of; to partake of.</def>
<mark>[R.]</mark>

<au>Munday.</au>

<sn>3.</sn> <def>To communicate the knowledge of; to make known;
to show by words or tokens; to tell; to disclose.</def>

<q>Gentle lady,
When I did first <qex>impart</qex> my love to you.</q>
<qau>Shak.</qau>

<syn>Syn. -- To share; yield; confer; convey; grant; give;
reveal; disclose; discover; divulge. See
<er>Communicate</er>.</syn>

<hw>Im*part"</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>v. i.</pos> <sn>1.</sn>
<def>To give a part or share.</def>

<q>He that hath two coats, let him <qex>impart</qex> to him that
hath none.</q>
<qau>Luke iii. 11.</qau>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>To hold a conference or consultation.</def>

<au>Blackstone.</au>

<hw>Im*pas"si*ble</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>a.</pos> <ety>[L.
<ets>impassibilis</ets>; pref. <ets>im-</ets> not +
<ets>passibilis</ets> passable: cf. F. <ets>impassible</ets>. See
<er>Passible</er>.]</ety> <def>Incapable of suffering;
inaccessible to harm or pain; not to be touched or moved to
passion or sympathy; unfeeling, or not showing feeling; without
sensation.</def> \'bd<xex>Impassible</xex> to the critic.\'b8

<au>Sir W. Scott.</au>

<q>Secure of death, I should contemn thy dart
Though naked, and <qex>impassible</qex> depart.</q>
<qau>Dryden.</qau>

<hw>Im*paste"</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>v. t.</pos>
<wordforms>[<pos>imp. & p. p.</pos> <er>Impasted</er>; <pos>p.
pr. & vb. n.</pos> <er>Impasting</er>.]</wordforms> <ety>[Pref.
<ets>im-</ets> in + <ets>paste</ets>: cf. It.
<ets>impastare</ets>, OF. <ets>empaster</ets>, F.
<ets>emp\'83ter</ets>. See 1st <er>In-</er> and

<sn>2.</sn> <fld>(Paint.)</fld> <def>To lay color on canvas by

<er>Impasto</er>.</def>

<hw>Im*past"ing</hw>, <fld>(Paint.)</fld> <def>The laying on of
colors to produce impasto.</def>

<hw>Im*pas"to</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[It. See
<er>Impaste</er>.]</ety> <fld>(Paint.)</fld> <def>The thickness
of the layer or body of pigment applied by the painter to his
canvas with especial reference to the juxtaposition of different
colors and tints in forming a harmonious whole.</def>

<au>Fairholt.</au>
