<au>T. Adams.</au>

<hw>Im*pat"i*ble</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>a.</pos> <ety>[L.
<ets>impatibilis</ets>; pref. <ets>im-</ets> not +
<ets>patibilis</ets> supportable. See <er>Patible</er>.]</ety>
<sn>1.</sn> <def>Not capable of being borne; impassible.</def>

<q>A spirit, and so <qex>impatible</qex> of material fire.</q>
<qau>Fuller.</qau>

<hw>Im*pa"tience</hw> <pr>(?)</pr> <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[OE.
<ets>impacience</ets>, F. <ets>impatience</ets>, fr. L.
<ets>impatientia</ets>.]</ety> <def>The quality of being
impatient; want of endurance of pain, suffering, opposition, or
delay; eagerness for change, or for something expected;
restlessness; chafing of spirit; fretfulness; passion; <as>as,
the <ex>impatience</ex> of a child or an invalid</as>.</def>

<q>I then, . . . 
Out of my grief and my <qex>impatience</qex>,
Answered neglectingly.</q>
<qau>Shak.</qau>

<q>With huge <qex>impatience</qex> he inly swelt
More for great sorrow that he could not pass,
Than for the burning torment which he felt.</q>
<qau>Spenser.</qau>

<-- p. 734 -->

<hw>Im*pa"tien*cy</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos>
<def>Impatience.</def> <mark>[Obs.]</mark>

<hw>\'d8Im*pa"ti*ens</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[L.,
impatient.]</ety> <fld>(Bot.)</fld> <def>A genus of plants,
several species of which have very beautiful flowers; -- so
called because the elastic capsules burst when touched, and
scatter the seeds with considerable force. Called also
<altname>touch-me-not</altname>, <altname>jewelweed</altname>,
and <altname>snapweed</altname>.  <spn>I. Balsamina</spn>
(sometimes called <stype>lady's slipper</stype>) is the common
garden balsam.</def>

<hw>Im*pa"tient</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>a.</pos> <ety>[OE.
<ets>impacient</ets>, F. <ets>impatient</ets>, fr. L.
<ets>impatiens</ets>; pref. <ets>im-</ets> not +
<ets>patiens</ets> patient. See <er>Patient</er>.]</ety>
<sn>1.</sn> <def>Not patient; not bearing with composure;
intolerant; uneasy; fretful; restless, because of pain, delay, or
opposition; eager for change, or for something expected; hasty;
passionate; -- often followed by <xex>at</xex>, <xex>for</xex>,
<xex>of</xex>, and <xex>under</xex>.</def>

<q>A violent, sudden, and <qex>impatient</qex> necessity.</q>
<qau>Jer. Taylor.</qau>

<q>Fame, <qex>impatient</qex> of extremes, decays
Not more by envy than excess of praise.</q>
<qau>Pope.</qau>

<q>The <qex>impatient</qex> man will not give himself time to be
informed of the matter that lies before him.</q>
<qau>Addison.</qau>

<q>Dryden was poor and <qex>impatient</qex> of poverty.</q>
<qau>Macaulay.</qau>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>Not to be borne; unendurable.</def>
<mark>[Obs.]</mark>

<au>Spenser.</au>

<sn>3.</sn> <def>Prompted by, or exhibiting, impatience; <as>as,
<ex>impatient</ex> speeches or replies</as>.</def>

<au>Shak.</au>

<syn>Syn. -- Restless; uneasy; changeable; hot; eager; fretful;
intolerant; passionate.</syn>

<hw>Im*pa"tient</hw>, <pos>n.</pos> <def>One who is
impatient.</def> <mark>[R.]</mark>

<hw>Im*pa"tient*ly</hw>, <pos>adv.</pos> <def>In an impatient
manner.</def>

<hw>Im*pat`ron*i*za"tion</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos>
<def>Absolute seignory or possession; the act of investing with
such possession.</def> <mark>[R.]</mark>

<au>Cotgrave.</au>

<hw>Im*pat"ron*ize</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>v. t.</pos>
<wordforms>[<pos>imp. & p. p.</pos> <er>Impatronized</er>
<pr>(?)</pr>; <pos>p. pr. & vb. n.</pos> <er>Impatronizing</er>
<pr>(?)</pr>.]</wordforms> <def>To make lord or master; <as>as,
to impatronize one's self of a seigniory</as>.</def>
<mark>[R.]</mark>

<au>Bacon.</au>

<q><qex>Impaved</qex> with rude fidelity
Of art mosaic.</q>

<hw>Im*peach"</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>v. t.</pos>
<wordforms>[<pos>imp. & p. p.</pos> <er>Impeached</er>
<pr>(?)</pr>; <pos>p. pr. & vb. n.</pos>
<er>Impeaching</er>.]</wordforms> <ety>[OE. <ets>empeechier</ets>
to prevent, hinder, bar, F. <ets>emp\'88cher</ets>, L.
<ets>impedicare</ets> to entangle; pref. <ets>im-</ets> in +
<ets>pedica</ets> fetter, fr. <ets>pes</ets>, <ets>pedis</ets>,
foot. See <er>Foot</er>, and <er>Appeach</er>, <er>Dispatch</er>,
<er>Impede</er>.]</ety> <sn>1.</sn> <def>To hinder; to impede; to
prevent.</def> <mark>[Obs.]</mark>

<q>These ungracious practices of his sons did <qex>impeach</qex>
his journey to the Holy Land.</q>
<qau>Sir J. Davies.</qau>

<q>A defluxion on my throat <qex>impeached</qex> my
utterance.</q>
<qau>Howell.</qau>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>To charge with a crime or misdemeanor; to
accuse; especially to charge (a public officer), before a
competent tribunal, with misbehavior in office; to cite before a
tribunal for judgement of official misconduct; to arraign;
<as>as, to <ex>impeach</ex> a judge</as>. See
<er>Impeachment</er>.</def>

<sn>3.</sn> <def>Hence, to charge with impropriety; to dishonor;
to bring discredit on; to call in question; <as>as, to
<ex>impeach</ex> one's motives or conduct</as>.</def>

<q>And doth <qex>impeach</qex> the freedom of the state.</q>
<qau>Shak.</qau>

<sn>4.</sn> <fld>(Law)</fld> <def>To challenge or discredit the
credibility of, as of a witness, or the validity of, as of
commercial paper.</def>

<note><hand/ When used in law with reference to a witness, the
term signifies, to discredit, to show or prove unreliable or
unworthy of belief; when used in reference to the
<xex>credit</xex> of witness, the term denotes, to impair, to
lessen, to disparage, to destroy. The credit of a witness may be
<xex>impeached</xex> by showing that he has made statements out
of court contradictory to what he swears at the trial, or by
showing that his reputation for veracity is bad, etc.</note>

<syn>Syn. -- To accuse; arraign; censure; criminate; indict;
impair; disparage; discredit. See <er>Accuse</er>.</syn>

<hw>Im*peach"</hw>, <pos>n.</pos> <def>Hindrance;
impeachment.</def> <mark>[Obs.]</mark>

<hw>Im*peach"a*ble</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>a.</pos> <def>That may
be impeached; liable to impeachment; chargeable with a
crime.</def>

<q>Owners of lands in fee simple are not <qex>impeachable</qex>
for waste.</q>
<qau>Z. Swift.</qau>

<hw>Im*peach"er</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <def>One who
impeaches.</def>

<hw>Im*peach"ment</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[Cf. F.
<ets>emp\'88chement</ets>.]</ety> <def>The act of impeaching, or
the state of being impeached</def>; as: <sd>(a)</sd>
<def>Hindrance; impediment; obstruction.</def>
<mark>[Obs.]</mark>

<q>Willing to march on to Calais,
Without <qex>impeachment</qex>.</q>
<qau>Shak.</qau>

<sd>(b)</sd> <def>A calling to account; arraignment; especially,
of a public officer for maladministration</def>.

<q>The consequence of Coriolanus' <qex>impeachment</qex> had like
to have been fatal to their state.</q>
<qau>Swift.</qau>

<sd>(c)</sd> <def>A calling in question as to purity of motives,
rectitude of conduct, credibility, etc.; accusation; reproach;
<as>as, an <ex>impeachment</ex> of motives</as></def>.

<au>Shak.</au>

<note><hand/ In England, it is the privilege or right of the
House of Commons to impeach, and the right of the House of Lords
to try and determine impeachments. In the United States, it is
the right of the House of Representatives to impeach, and of the
Senate to try and determine impeachments.</note>

<cs><col>Articles of impeachment</col>. <cd>See under
<er>Article</er>.</cd> -- <col>Impeachment of waste</col>
<fld>(Law)</fld>, <cd>restraint from, or accountability for,
injury; also, a suit for damages for injury.</cd></cs>

<au>Abbott.</au>

<hw>Im*pearl"</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>v. t.</pos>

<q>The dews of the morning <qex>impearl</qex> every thorn.</q>
<qau>R. Digby.</qau>

<hw>Im*pede"</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>v. t.</pos>

<ets>impedire</ets>, lit., to entangle the feet; pref.
<ets>im-</ets> in + <ets>pes</ets>, <ets>pedis</ets>, foot. See
<er>Foot</er>, and cf. <er>Impeach</er>.]</ety> <def>To hinder;

<hw>Im*ped"i*ble</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>a.</pos> <def>Capable of
being impeded or hindered.</def> <mark>[R.]</mark>

<au>Jer. Taylor.</au>

<hw>Im*ped"i*ment</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[L.
<ets>impedimentum</ets>: cf. F. <ets>impediment</ets>.]</ety>
<def>That which impedes or hinders progress, motion, activity, or
effect.</def>

<q>Thus far into the bowels of the land
Have we marched on without <qex>impediment</qex>.</q>
<qau>Shak.</qau>

<cs><col>Impediment in speech</col>, <cd>a defect which prevents
distinct utterance.</cd></cs>

<syn>Syn. -- Hindrance; obstruction; obstacle; difficulty;
incumbrance.</syn> <usage> -- <er>Impediment</er>,
<er>Obstacle</er>, <er>Difficulty</er>, <er>Hindrance</er>. An
<xex>impediment</xex> literally strikes against our feet,
checking our progress, and we remove it. An <xex>obstacle</xex>
rises before us in our path, and we surmount or remove it. A
<xex>difficulty</xex> sets before us something hard to be done,
and we encounter it and overcome it. A <xex>hindrance</xex> holds
us back for a time, but we break away from it.</usage>

<q>The eloquence of Demosthenes was to Philip of Macedon, a
<qex>difficulty</qex> to be met with his best recources, ant
<qex>obstacle</qex> to his own ambition, and an
<qex>impedimen</qex> in his political career.</q>
<qau>C. J. Smith.</qau>

<hw>Im*ped"i*ment</hw>, <pos>v. t.</pos> <def>To impede.</def>
<mark>[R.]</mark>

<au>Bp. Reynolds.</au>

nature of an impediment; hindering; obstructing;
impeditive.</def>

<q>Things so <qex>impediental</qex> to success.</q>

<hw>Im*pen`e*tra*bil"i*ty</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos>
<ety>[Cf. F. <ets>imp\'82n\'82trabilit\'82</ets>.]</ety>
<sn>1.</sn> <def>Quality of being impenetrable.</def>

<sn>2.</sn> <fld>(Physics)</fld> <def>That property in virtue of
which two portions of matter can not at the same time occupy the
same portion of space.</def>

<sn>3.</sn> <def>Insusceptibility of intellectual or emotional
impression; obtuseness; stupidity; coldness.</def>

<hw>Im*pen"e*tra*ble</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>a.</pos> <ety>[L.
<ets>impenetrabilis</ets>; pref. <ets>im-</ets> not +
<ets>penetrabilis</ets> penetrable: cf. F.
<ets>imp\'82n\'82trable</ets>.]</ety> <sn>1.</sn> <def>Incapable
of being penetrated or pierced; not admitting the passage of
other bodies; not to be entered; impervious; <as>as, an
impenetrable shield</as>.</def>

<q>Highest woods <qex>impenetrable</qex>
To star or sunlight.</q>
<qau>Milton.</qau>

<sn>2.</sn> <fld>(Physics)</fld> <def>Having the property of
preventing any other substance from occupying the same space at
the same time.</def>

<sn>3.</sn> <def>Inaccessible, as to knowledge, reason, sympathy,
etc.; unimpressible; not to be moved by arguments or motives;
<as>as, an <ex>impenetrable</ex> mind, or heart</as>.</def>

<q>They will be credulous in all affairs of life, but
<qex>impenetrable</qex> by a sermon of the gospel.</q>
<qau>Jer. Taylor.</qau>

<hw>Im*pen"e*tra*ble*ness</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos>
<def>The quality of being impenetrable; impenetrability.</def>

<hw>Im*pen"e*tra*bly</hw>, <pos>adv.</pos> <def>In an
impenetrable manner or state; imperviously.</def>
\'bd<xex>Impenetrably</xex> armed.\'b8 <au>Milton</au>.
\'bd<xex>Impenetrably</xex> dull.\'b8 <au>Pope</au>.

<hw>Im*pen"i*tence</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[L.
<ets>impenitentia</ets>: cf. F. <ets>imp\'82nitence</ets>.]</ety>
<def>The condition of being impenitent; failure or refusal to
repent; hardness of heart.</def>

<q>He will advance from one degree of wickedness and
<qex>impenitence</qex> to another.</q>
<qau>Rogers.</qau>

<hw>Im*pen"i*ten*cy</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos>
<def>Impenitence.</def>

<au>Milton.</au>

<hw>Im*pen"i*tent</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>a.</pos> <ety>[L.
<ets>impaenitens</ets>; pref. <ets>im-</ets> not +
<ets>paenitens</ets> penitens: cf. F. <ets>imp\'82nitent</ets>.
See <er>Penitent</er>.]</ety> <def>Not penitent; not repenting of
sin; not contrite; of a hard heart.</def> \'bdThey . . . died
<xex>impenitent</xex>.\'b8 <au>Milton</au>. \'bdA careless and
<xex>impenitent</xex> heart.\'b8 <au>Bp. Hall</au>.

penitent.</def> <mark>[R.]</mark>

<hw>Im*pen"nate</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>a.</pos>
<fld>(Zo\'94l.)</fld> <def>Characterized by short wings covered
with feathers resembling scales, as the penguins.</def> --
<def2><pos>n.</pos> <def>One of the Impennes.</def></def2>

<hw>\'d8Im*pen"nes</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n. pl.</pos>
<ety>[NL., fr. L. pref. <ets>im-</ets> not + <ets>penna</ets>
feather.]</ety> <fld>(Zo\'94l.)</fld> <def>An order of birds,
including only the penguins, in which the wings are without
quills, and not suited for flight.</def>

<ets>im-</ets> not + <ets>penna</ets> wing.]</ety>
<fld>(Zo\'94l.)</fld> <def>Having no wings, as some
insects.</def>

<hw>Im*peo"ple</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>v. t.</pos>

<hw>Im"pe*rate</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>a.</pos> <ety>[L.
<ets>imperatus</ets>, p. p. of <ets>imperare</ets> to
command.]</ety> <def>Done by express direction; not involuntary;
communded.</def> <mark>[Obs.]</mark>

<q>Those <qex>imperate</qex> acts, wherein we see the empire of
the soul.</q>
<qau>Sir M. Hale.</qau>

<hw>Im*per`a*ti"val</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>a.</pos>
<fld>(Gram.)</fld> <def>Of or pertaining to the imperative
mood.</def>

<hw>Im*per"a*tive</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>a.</pos> <ety>[L.
<ets>imperativus</ets>, fr. <ets>imperare</ets> to command; pref.
<ets>im-</ets> in + <ets>parare</ets> to make ready, prepare: cf.
F. <ets>imp\'82ratif</ets>. See <er>Perade</er>, and cf.
<er>Empire</er>.]</ety> <sn>1.</sn> <def>Expressive of command;
containing positive command; authoritatively or absolutely
directive; commanding; authoritative; <as>as, <ex>imperative</ex>
orders</as>.</def>

<q>The suit of kings are <qex>imperative</qex>.</q>
<qau>Bp. Hall.</qau>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>Not to be avoided or evaded; obligatory;
binding; compulsory; <as>as, an <ex>imperative</ex> duty or
order</as>.</def>

<sn>3.</sn> <fld>(Gram.)</fld> <def>Expressive of commund,
entreaty, advice, or exhortation; <as>as, the imperative
mood</as>.</def>

<hw>Im*per"a*tive</hw>, <pos>n.</pos> <fld>(Gram.)</fld> <def>The
imperative mood; also, a verb in the imperative mood.</def>

<hw>Im*per"a*tive*ly</hw>, <pos>adv.</pos> <def>In an imperative
manner.</def>

<hw>\'d8Im`pe*ra"tor</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[L.
See <er>Emperor</er>.]</ety> <fld>(Rom. Antiq.)</fld> <def>A
commander; a leader; an emperor; -- originally an appellation of
honor by which Roman soldiers saluted their general after an
important victory. Subsequently the title was conferred as a
recognition of great military achievements by the senate, whence
it carried wiht it some special privileges. After the downfall of
the Republic it was assumed by Augustus and his successors, and
came to have the meaning now attached to the word
<xex>emperor</xex>.</def>

<hw>Im*per`a*to"ri*al</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>a.</pos> <ety>[L.
<ets>imperatorius</ets>.]</ety> <sn>1.</sn> <def>Commanding;
imperative; authoritative.</def>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>Of or pertaining to the title or office of
imperator.</def> \'bd<xex>Imperatorial</xex> laurels.\'b8

<au>C. Merivale.</au>

<hw>Im*per"fect</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>a.</pos> <ety>[L.
<ets>imperfectus</ets>: pref. <ets>im-</ets> not +
<ets>perfectus</ets> perfect: cf. F <ets>imparfait</ets>, whence
OE. <ets>imparfit</ets>. See <er>Perfect</er>.]</ety> <sn>1.</sn>
<def>Not perfect; not complete in all its parts; wanting a part;
deective; deficient.</def>

<q>Something he left <qex>imperfect</qex> in the state.</q>
<qau>Shak.</qau>

<q>Why, then, your other senses grow <qex>imperfect</qex>.</q>
<qau>Shak.</qau>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>Wanting in some elementary organ that is
essential to successful or normal activity.</def>

<q>He . . . stammered like a child, or an amazed,
<qex>imperfect</qex> person.</q>
<qau>Jer. Taylor.</qau>

<sn>3.</sn> <def>Not fulfilling its design; not realizing an
ideal; not conformed to a standard or rule; not satisfying the
taste or conscience; esthetically or morally defective.</def>

<q>Nothing <qex>imperfect</qex> or deficient left
Of all that he created.</q>
<qau>Milton.</qau>

<q>Then say not man's <qex>imperfect</qex>, Heaven in fault;
Say rather, man's as perfect as he ought.</q>
<qau>Pope.</qau>

<cs><col>Imperfect arch</col>, <cd>an arch of less than a
semicircle; a skew arch.</cd> -- <col>Imperfect cadence</col>
<fld>(Mus.)</fld>, <cd>one not ending with the tonic, but with
the dominant or some other chord; one not giving complete rest; a
half close.</cd> -- <col>Imperfect consonances</col>
<fld>(Mus.)</fld>, <cd>chords like the third and sixth, whose
ratios are less simple than those of the fifth and forth.</cd> --
<col>Imperfect flower</col> <fld>(Bot.)</fld>, <cd>a flower
wanting either stamens or pistils. <au>Gray</au>.</cd> --
<col>Imperfect interval</col> <fld>(Mus.)</fld>, <cd>one a
semitone less than perfect; as, an <xex>imperfect<xex>
fifth.</cd> -- <col>Imperfect number</col> <fld>(Math.)</fld>,
<cd>a number either greater or less than the sum of its several
divisors; in the former case, it is called also a
<stype>defective number</stype>; in the latter, an
<stype>abundant number</stype>.</cd> -- <col>Imperfect
obligations</col> <fld>(Law)</fld>, <cd>obligations as of charity
or gratitude, which cannot be enforced by law.</cd> --
<col>Imperfect power</col> <fld>(Math.)</fld>, <cd>a number which
can not be produced by taking any whole number or vulgar
fraction, as a factor, the number of times indicated by the
power; thus, 9 is a perfect square, but an <xex>imperfect<xex>
cube.</cd> -- <col>Imperfect tense</col> <sd>(Gram)</sd>, <cd>a
tense expressing past time and incomplete action.</cd></cs>

<-- p. 735 -->

<hw>Im*pe"ri*al</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>a.</pos> <ety>[OE.

That wore the <qex>imperial</qex> diadem of Rome.</q>
<qau>Shak.</qau>

or one who wields it; royal; sovereign; supreme.</def> \'bdThe
<xex>imperial</xex> democracy of Athens.\'b8

<au>Mitford.</au>

With an <qex>imperial</qex> voice.</q>
<qau>Shak.</qau>

<q>To tame the proud, the fetter'd slave to free,
These are <qex>imperial</qex> arts, and worthy thee.</q>
<qau>Dryden.</qau>

<q>He sounds his <qex>imperial</qex> clarion along the whole line
of battle.</q>
<qau>E. Everett.</qau>

<sn>3.</sn> <def>Of superior or unusual size or excellence;
<as>as, <ex>imperial</ex> paper; <ex>imperial</ex> tea,
etc.</as></def>

<cs><mcol><col>Imperial bushel</col>, <col>gallon</col></mcol>,
<cd>etc. See <er>Bushel</er>, <er>Gallon</er>, etc.</cd> --
<col>Imperial chamber</col>, <cd>the, the sovereign court of the
old German empire.</cd> -- <col>Imperial city</col>, <cd>under
the first German empire, a city having no head but the
emperor.</cd> -- <col>Imperial diet</col>, <cd>an assembly of all
the states of the German empire.</cd> -- <col>Imperial
drill</col>. <fld>(Manuf.)</fld> <cd>See under 8th
<er>Drill</er>.</cd> -- <col>Imperial eagle</col>.
<fld>(Zo\'94l.)</fld> <cd>See <er>Eagle</er>.</cd> --
<col>Imperial green</col>. <cd>See <cref>Paris green</cref>,
under <er>Green</er>.</cd> -- <col>Imperial guard</col>, <cd>the
royal guard instituted by Napoleon I.</cd> -- <col>Imperial
weights and measures</col>, <cd>the standards legalized by the
British Parliament.</cd></cs>

<au>T. Hughes.</au>

<au>Simmonds.</au>

<sn>5.</sn> <def>A gold coin of Russia worth ten rubles, or about
eight dollars.</def>

<au>McElrath.</au>

<sn>6.</sn> <def>A kind of fine cloth brought into England from
Greece. or other Eastern countries, in the Middle Ages.</def>

<hw>Im*pe"ri*ous</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>a.</pos> <ety>[L.
<ets>imperiosus</ets>: cf. F. <ets>imp\'82rieux</ets>. See
<er>Imperial</er>.]</ety> <sn>1.</sn> <def>Commanding; ascendant;
imperial; lordly; majestic.</def> <mark>[Obs.]</mark> \'bdA vast
and <xex>imperious</xex> mind.\'b8

<au>Tilloison.</au>

<q>Therefore, great lords, be, as your titles witness,
<qex>Imperious</qex>.</q>
<qau>Shak.</qau>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>Haughly; arrogant; overbearing; <as>as, an
<ex>imperious</ex> tyrant; an <ex>imperious</ex>
manner.</as></def>

<q>This <qex>imperious</qex> man will work us all
From princes into pages.</q>
<qau>Shak.</qau>

<q>His bold, contemptuous, and <qex>imperious</qex> spirit soon
made him conspicuous.</q>
<qau>Macaulay.</qau>

<sn>3.</sn> <def>Imperative; urgent; compelling.</def>

<q><qex>Imperious</qex> need, which can not be withstood.</q>
<qau>Dryden.</qau>

<syn>Syn. -- Dictatorial; haughty; domineering; overbearing;
lordly; tyrannical; despotic; arrogant; imperative;
authoritative; commanding; pressing.</syn> <usage> --
<er>Imperious</er>, <er>Lordly</er>, <er>Domineering</er>. One
who is <xex>imperious</xex> exercises his authority in a manner
highly offensive for its spirit and tone; one who is
<xex>lordly</xex> assumes a lofty air in order to display his
importance; one who is <xex>domineering</xex> gives orders in a
way to make other feel their inferiority.</usage>

<hw>Im*pe"ri*ous*ly</hw>, <pos>adv.</pos> <def>In an imperious
manner.</def>

state of being imperious; arrogance; haughtiness.</def>

<q><qex>Imperiousness</qex> and severity is but an ill way of
treating men who have reason of their own to guide them.</q>
<qau>Locke.</qau>

<hw>Im*per"son*al</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>a.</pos> <ety>[L.
<ets>impersonalis</ets>; pref. <ets>im-</ets> not + 
<ets>personalis</ets> personal: cf. F. <ets>impersonnel</ets>.
See <er>Personal</er>.]</ety> <def>Not personal; not representing
a person; not having personality.</def>

<q>An almighty but <qex>impersonal</qex> power, called Fate.</q>
<qau>Sir J. Stephen.</qau>

<cs><col>Impersonal verb</col> <fld>(Gram.)</fld>, <cd>a verb
used with an indeterminate subject, commonly, in English, with
the impersonal pronoun <xex>it<xex>; as, <xex>it rains<xex>;
<xex>it snows<xex>; <xex>methinks<xex> (it seems to me). Many
verbs which are not strictly impersonal are often used
impersonally; as, <xex>it goes<xex> well with him.</cd></cs>

<hw>Im*per"son*al</hw>, <pos>n.</pos> <def>That which wants
personality; specifically <fld>(Gram.)</fld>, an impersonal
verb.</def>

<hw>Im*per`son*al"i*ty</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <def>The
quality of being impersonal; want or absence of
personality.</def>

<hw>Im*per"son*al*ly</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>adv.</pos> <def>In
an impersonal manner.</def>

<hw>Im*per"son*ate</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>v. t.</pos>
<wordforms>[<pos>imp. & p. p.</pos> <er>Impersonated</er>
<pr>(?)</pr>; <pos>p. pr. & vb. n.</pos>
<er>Impersonating</er>.]</wordforms> <sn>1.</sn> <def>To invest
with personality; to endow with the form of a living being.</def>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>To ascribe the qualities of a person to; to
personify.</def>

<sn>3.</sn> <def>To assume, or to represent, the person or
character of; to personate; <as>as, he <ex>impersonated</ex>
Macbeth</as>.</def>

<q>Benedict <qex>impersonated</qex> his age.</q>
<qau>Milman.</qau>

<hw>Im`per*son`i*fi*ca"tion</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, }</mhw>
<pos>n.</pos> <def>The act of impersonating; personification;
investment with personality; representation in a personal
form.</def>

<hw>Im*per"son*a`tor</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <def>One
who impersonates; an actor; a mimic.</def>

<hw>Im*per`spi*cu"i*ty</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <def>Want
of perspicuity or clearness; vaguness; ambiguity.</def>

<hw>Im`per*spic"u*ous</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>a.</pos> <def>Not
perspicuous; not clear; obscure; vague; ambeguous.</def>

<hw>Im`per*suad"a*ble</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>a.</pos> <ety>[Cf.
<er>Impersuasible</er>.]</ety> <def>Not to be persuaded;
obstinate; unyielding; impersuasible.</def> --
<wordforms><wf>Im`per*suad"a*ble*ness</wf>,
<pos>n.</pos></wordforms>

<hw>Im`per*sua"si*ble</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>a.</pos>
<ety>[Pref. <ets>im-</ets> not + <ets>persuasible</ets>: cf. OF.
<ets>impersuasible</ets>.]</ety> <def>Not persuasible; not to be
moved by persuasion; inflexible; impersuadable.</def> <au>Dr. H.
More</au>. -- <wordforms><wf>Im`per*sua`si*bil"i*ty</wf>
<pr>(#)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos></wordforms>

<hw>Im*per"ti*nence</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[Cf. F.
<ets>impertinence</ets>. See <er>Impertinent</er>.]</ety>
<sn>1.</sn> <def>The condition or quality of being impertnent;
absence of pertinence, or of adaptedness; irrelevance;
unfitness.</def>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>Conduct or language unbecoming the person, the
society, or the circumstances; rudeness; incivility.</def>

<q>We should avoid the vexation and <qex>impertinence</qex> of
pedants who affect to talk in a language not to be
understood.</q>
<qau>Swift.</qau>

<sn>3.</sn> <def>That which is impertinent; a thing out of place,
or of no value.</def>

<q>There are many subtile <qex>impertinences</qex> learned in
schools.</q>
<qau>Watts.</qau>

<hw>Im*per"ti*nen*cy</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos>
<def>Impertinence.</def> <mark>[R.]</mark>

<q>O, matter and <qex>impertinency</qex> mixed!
Reason in madness!</q>
<qau>Shak.</qau>

<hw>Im*per"ti*nent</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>a.</pos> <ety>[F., fr.
L. <ets>impertinens</ets>, <ets>-entis</ets>; pref.
<ets>im-</ets> not + <ets>pertinens</ets>. See
<er>Pertinent</er>.]</ety> <sn>1.</sn> <def>Not pertinent; not
pertaining to the matter in hand; having no bearing on the
subject; not to the point; irrelevant; inapplicable.</def>

<q>Things that are <qex>impertinent</qex> to us.</q>
<qau>Tillotson.</qau>

<q>How <qex>impertinent</qex> that grief was which served no
end!</q>
<qau>Jer. Taylor.</qau>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>Contrary to, or offending against, the rules of
propriety or good breeding; guilty of, or prone to, rude,
unbecoming, or uncivil words or actions; <as>as, an
<ex>impertient</ex> coxcomb; an <ex>impertient</ex>
remark.</as></def>

<sn>3.</sn> <def>Trifing; inattentive; frivolous.</def>

<syn>Syn. -- Rude; officious; intrusive; saucy; unmannerly;
meddlesome; disrespectful; impudent; insolent.</syn> <usage> --
<er>Impertinent</er>, <er>Officious</er>, <er>Rude</er>. A person
is <xex>officious</xex> who obtrudes his <xex>offices</xex> or
assistance where they are not needed; he is
<xex>impertinent</xex> when he intermeddles in things with which
he has no concern. The former shows a want of tact, the latter a
want of breeding, or, more commonly, a spirit of sheer impudence.
A person is <xex>rude</xex> when he violates the proprieties of
social life either from ignorance or wantonness. \'bdAn
<xex>impertinent</xex> man will ask questions for the mere
grafication of curiosity; a <xex>rude</xex> man will burst into
the room of another, or push against his person, inviolant of all
decorum; one who is <xex>officious</xex> is quite as unfortunate
as he is troublesome; when he strives to serve, he has the
misfortune to annoy.\'b8 <au>Crabb</au>. See <er>Impudence</er>,
and <er>Insolent</er>.</usage>

<hw>Im*per"ti*nent</hw>, <pos>n.</pos> <def>An impertinent
person.</def> <mark>[R.]</mark>

<hw>Im*per"ti*nent*ly</hw>, <pos>adv.</pos> <def>In an
impertinent manner.</def> \'bdNot to betray myself
<xex>impertinently</xex>.\'b8

<au>B. Jonson.</au>

<hw>Im`per*tran`si*bil"i*ty</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos>
<def>The quality or state of being impertransible.</def>
<mark>[R.]</mark>

<hw>Im`per*tran"si*ble</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>a.</pos> <ety>[L.
pref. <ets>im-</ets> not + pertransire to go through. See
<er>Per-</er> and <er>Transient</er>.]</ety> <def>Incapable of
being passed through.</def> <mark>[R.]</mark>

<hw>Im`per*trub"a*ble</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>a.</pos> <ety>[L.
<ets>imperturbabilis</ets>; pref. <ets>im-</ets> not +
<ets>perturbare</ets> to disturb: cf. F.
<ets>imperturbable</ets>. See <er>Perture</er>.]</ety>
<def>Incapable of being disturbed or disconcerted; <as>as,

<hw>Im*per"vi*ous</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>a.</pos> <ety>[L.
<ets>impervius</ets>; pref. <ets>im-</ets> not + <ets>per</ets>
through + <ets>via</ets> way. See <er>Voyage</er>.]</ety>
<def>Not pervious; not admitting of entrance or passage through;
<as>as, a substance <ex>impervious</ex> to water or
air</as>.</def>

<q>This gulf impassable, <qex>impervious</qex>.</q>
<qau>Milton.</qau>

<q>The minds of these zealots were absolutely
<qex>impervious</qex>.</q>
<qau>Macaulay.</qau>

<syn>Syn. -- Impassable; pathless; impenetrable; imperviable;
impermeable.</syn>

<hw>Im*pet`u*os"i*ty</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[Cf.
F. <ets>imp\'82tuosit\'82</ets>.]</ety> <sn>1.</sn> <def>The
condition or quality of being impetuous; fury; violence.</def>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>Vehemence, or furiousnes of temper.</def>

<au>Shak.</au>

<hw>Im*pet"u*ous</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>a.</pos> <ety>[F.
<ets>impetueux</ets>, L. <ets>impetuosus</ets>. See
<er>Impetus</er>.]</ety> <sn>1.</sn> <def>Rushing with force and
violence; moving with impetus; furious; forcible; violent;
<as>as, an <ex>impetuous</ex> wind; an <ex>impetuous</ex>
torrent.</as></def>

<q>Went pouring forward with <qex>impetuous</qex> speed.</q>
<qau>Byron.</qau>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>Vehement in feeling; hasty; passionate; violent;
<as>as, a man of <ex>impetuous</ex> temper</as>.</def>

<q>The people, on their holidays,
<qex>Impetuous</qex>, insolent, unquenchable.</q>
<qau>Milton.</qau>

<syn>Syn. -- Forcible; rapid; hasty; precipitate; furious;
boisterous; violent; raging; fierce; passionate.</syn>

<hw>Im"pe*tus</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[L., fr.
<ets>impetere</ets> to rush upon, attack; pref. <ets>im-</ets> in
+ <ets>petere</ets> to fall upon, seek. See
<er>Petition</er>.]</ety> <sn>1.</sn> <def>A property possessed
by a moving body in virtue of its weight and its motion; the
force with which any body is driven or impelled; momentum.</def>

<note><hand/ <xex>Momentum</xex> is the technical term,
<xex>impetus</xex> its popular equivalent, yet differing from it
as applied commonly to bodies moving or moved suddenly or
violently, and indicating the origin and intensity of the motion,
rather than its quantity or effectiveness.</note>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>Fig.: Impulse; incentive; vigor; force.</def>

<au>Buckle.</au>

<sn>3.</sn> <fld>(Gun.)</fld> <def>The aititude through which a
heavy body must fall to acquire a velocity equal to that with
which a ball is discharged from a piece.</def>

<-- p. 736 -->

<hw>Im"pey*an pheas"ant</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>. <ety>[From Lady
<ets>Impey</ets>, who attempted to naturalize the bird in
England.]</ety> <fld>(Zo\'94l.)</fld> <def>An Indian crested
pheasant of the genus <spn>Lophophorus</spn>. Several species are
known. Called also <altname>monaul</altname>,
<altname>monal</altname>.</def>

<note><hand/ They are remarkable for the bright color and
brilliant matallic hues of their plumage. The best known species
(<spn>L. Impeyanus</spn>) has the neck of a brilliant metallic
red, changing to golden yellow in certain lights.</note>

<hw>Im"phee</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <fld>(Bot.)</fld>
<def>The African sugar cane (<spn>Holcus saccharatus</spn>), --
resembling the sorghum, or Chinese sugar cane.</def>

<hw>Im*pi"e*ty</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos>; <plu>pl.
<plw>Impieties</plw> <pr>(<?/)</pr></plu>. <ety>[L.
<ets>impietas</ets>, fr. <ets>impius</ets> impious; cf. F.
<ets>impi\'82t\'82</ets>. See <er>Impious</er>,
<er>Piety</er>.]</ety> <sn>1.</sn> <def>The quality of being
impious; want of piety; irreverence toward the Supreme Being;
ungodliness; wickedness.</def>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>An impious act; an act of wickednes.</def>

<q>Those <qex>impieties</qex> for the which they are now
visited.</q>
<qau>Shak.</qau>

<syn>Syn. -- Ungodliness; irreligion; unrighteousness;
sinfulness; profaneness; wickedness; godlessness.</syn>

<hw>Im*pinge"</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>v. t.</pos>
<wordforms>[<pos>imp. & p. p.</pos> <er>Impinged</er>
<pr>(?)</pr>; <pos>p. pr. & vb. n.</pos> <er>Impinging</er>
<pr>(?)</pr>.]</wordforms> <ety>[L. <ets>impingere</ets>; pref.
<ets>im-</ets> in + <ets>pangere</ets> to fix, strike; prob. akin
to <ets>pacisci</ets> to agree, contract. See <er>Pact</er>, and
cf. <er>Impact</er>.]</ety> <def>To fall or dash against; to
touch upon; to strike; to hit; to ciash with; -- with on or
<xex>upon</xex>.</def>

<q>The cause of reflection is not the <qex>impinging</qex> of
light on the solid or impervious parts of bodies.</q>
<qau>Sir I. Newton.</qau>

<q>But, in the present order of things, not to be employed
without <qex>impinging</qex> on God's justice.</q>
<qau>Bp. Warburton.</qau>

<hw>Im"pi*ous</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>a.</pos> <ety>[L.
<ets>impius</ets>; pref. <ets>im-</ets> not + <ets>pius</ets>
piou. See <er>Pious</er>.]</ety> <def>Not pious; wanting piety;
irreligious; irreverent; ungodly; profane; wanting in reverence
for the Supreme Being; <as>as, an <ex>impious</ex> deed;
<ex>impious</ex> language.</as></def>

<q>When vice prevails, and <qex>impious</qex> men bear away,
The post of honor is a private station.</q>
<qau>Addison.</qau>

<syn>Syn. -- <er>Impious</er>, <er>Irreligious</er>,
<er>Profane</er>.</syn> <usage> <xex>Irreligious</xex> is
negative, <xex>impious</xex> and <xex>profane</xex> are positive.
An indifferent man may be <xex>irreligious</xex>; a
<xex>profane</xex> man is irreverent in speech and conduct; an
<xex>impious</xex> man is wickedly and boldly defiant in the
strongest sense. <xex>Profane</xex> also has the milder sense of
<xex>secular</xex>.</usage>

<au>C. J. Smith.</au>

<hw>Im*pla`ca*bil"i*ty</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[L.

<ets>implacabilit\'82</ets>.]</ety> <def>The quality or state of

<hw>Im*pla"ca*ble</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>a.</pos> <ety>[L.
<ets>implacabilis</ets>; pref. <ets>im-</ets> not +
<ets>placabilis</ets>: cf. F. <ets>implacable</ets>. See
<er>Placable</er>.]</ety> <sn>1.</sn> <def>Not placable; not to
be appeased; incapable of being pacified; inexorable; <as>as, an
implacable prince</as>.</def>

<q>I see thou art <qex>implacable</qex>.</q>
<qau>Milton.</qau>

<q>An object of <qex>implacable</qex> enmity.</q>
<qau>Macaulay.</qau>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>Incapable of ebign relieved or assuaged;
inextinguishable.</def> <mark>[R.]</mark>

<q>O! how I burn with <qex>implacable</qex> fire.</q>
<qau>Spenser.</qau>

<q>Which wrought them pain
<qex>Implacable</qex>, and many a dolorous groan.</q>
<qau>Milton.</qau>

<syn>Syn. -- Unappeasable; inexorable; irreconcilable;
unrelenting; relentless; unyielding.</syn>

<hw>\'d8Im`pla*cen*ta"li*a</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n. pl.</pos>
<ety>[NL. See <er>In-</er> not, and <er>Placental</er>.]</ety>
<fld>(Zo\'94l.)</fld> <def>A primary division of the Mammalia,
including the monotremes and marsupials, in which no placenta is
formed.</def>

<hw>Im*plant"</hw> <pr>(?)</pr> <pos>v. t.</pos>
<wordforms>[<pos>imp. & p. p.</pos> <er>Implanted</er>; <pos>p.
pr. & vb. n.</pos> <er>Implanting</er>.]</wordforms> <ety>[Pref.
<ets>im-</ets> in + <ets>plant</ets>: cf. F.
<ets>implanter</ets>.]</ety> <def>To plant, or infix, for the
purpose of growth; to fix deeply; to instill; to inculate; to
introduce; <as>as, to <ex>implant</ex> the seeds of virtue, or
the principles of knowledge, in the minds of youth</as>.</def>

<q>Minds well <qex>implanted</qex> with solid . . . breeding.</q>
<qau>Milton.</qau>

<hw>Im*plau`si*bil"i*ty</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos>
<def>Want of plausibility; the quality of being
implausible.</def>

<hw>Im*plau"si*ble</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>a.</pos> <ety>[Pref.

<hw>Im"ple*ment</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[LL.
<ets>implementum</ets> accomplishment, fr. L. <ets>implere</ets>,
<ets>impletum</ets>, to fill up, finish, complete; pref.
<ets>im-</ets> in + <ets>plere</ets> to fill. The word was perh.
confuse with OF. <ets>empleier</ets>, <ets>emploier</ets>, to
employ, F. <ets>employer</ets>, whence E. <ets>employ</ets>. See
<er>Plenty</er>.]</ety> <def>That which fulfills or supplies a
want or use; esp., an instrument, toll, or utensil, as supplying
a requisite to an end; <as>as, the <ex>implements</ex> of trade,
of husbandry, or of war</as>.</def>

<q>Genius must have talent as its complement and
<qex>implement</qex>.</q>
<qau>Coleridge.</qau>

<hw>Im"ple*ment</hw>, <pos>v. t.</pos> <sn>1.</sn> <def>To
accomplish; to fulfill.</def> <mark>[R.]</mark>

<q>Revenge . . . executed and <qex>implemented</qex> by the hand
of Vanbeest Brown.</q>
<qau>Sir W. Scott.</qau>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>To provide with an implement or implements; to
cause to be fulfilled, satisfied, or carried out, by means of an
implement or implements.</def>

<q>The chief mechanical requisites of the barometer are
<qex>implemented</qex> in such an instrument as the
following.</q>
<qau>Nichol.</qau>

<sn>3.</sn> <fld>(Scots Law)</fld> <def>To fulfill or perform, as
a contract or an engagement.</def>

<def>Pertaining to, or characterized by, implements or their use;
mechanical.</def>

<hw>Im"plex</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>a.</pos> <ety>[L.
<ets>implexus</ets>, p. p. of <ets>implectere</ets> to infold;
pref. <ets>im-</ets> in + <ets>plectere</ets> to plait: cf. F
<ets>implexe</ets>.]</ety> <def>Intricate; entangled;
complicated; complex.</def>

<q>The fable of every poem is . . . simple or <qex>implex</qex>.
it is called simple when there is no change of fortune in it;
<qex>implex</qex>, when the fortune of the chief actor changes
from bad to good, or from good to bad.</q>
<qau>Addison.</qau>

<hw>Im"pli*cate</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>v. t.</pos>
<wordforms>[<pos>imp. & p. p.</pos> <er>Implicated</er>
<pr>(?)</pr>; <pos>p. pr. & vb. n.</pos>
<er>Implicating</er>.]</wordforms> <ety>[L.
<ets>implicatus</ets>, p. p. of <ets>implicare</ets> to involve;
pref. <ets>im-</ets> in + <ets>plicare</ets> to fold. See
<er>Employ</er>, <er>Ply</er>, and cf. <er>Imply</er>,
<er>Implicit</er>.]</ety> <sn>1.</sn> <def>To infold; to fold
together; to interweave.</def>

<q>The meeting boughs and <qex>implicated</qex> leaves.</q>
<qau>Shelley.</qau>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>To bring into connection with; to involve; to
connect; -- applied to persons, in an unfavorable sense; <as>as,
the evidence <ex>implicates</ex> many in this conspiracy; to be
<ex>implicated</ex> in a crime, a discreditable transaction, a
fault, etc.</as></def>

<hw>Im`pli*ca"tion</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[L.
<ets>implicatio</ets>: cf. F. <ets>implication</ets>.]</ety>
<sn>1.</sn> <def>The act of implicating, or the state of being
implicated.</def>

<q>Three principal causes of firmness are. the grossness, the
quiet contact, and the <qex>implication</qex> of component
parts.</q>
<qau>Boyle.</qau>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>An implying, or that which is implied, but not
expressed; an inference, or something which may fairly be
understood, though not expressed in words.</def>

<q>Whatever things, therefore, it was asserted that the king
might do, it was a necessary <qex>implication</qex> that there
were other things which he could not do.</q>
<qau>Hallam.</qau>

<hw>Im"pli*ca*tive</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>a.</pos> <def>Tending
to implicate.</def>

<hw>Im"pli*ca*tive*ly</hw>, <pos>adv.</pos> <def>By
implication.</def>

<au>Sir G. Buck.</au>

<hw>Im*plic"it</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>a.</pos> <ety>[L.
<ets>implicitus</ets>, p. p. of <ets>implicare</ets> to entwine,
entangle, attach closely: cf. F. <ets>implicite</ets>. See
<er>Implicate</er>.]</ety> <sn>1.</sn> <def>Infolded; entangled;
complicated; involved.</def> <mark>[Obs.]</mark>

<au>Milton.</au>

<q>In his woolly fleece
I cling <qex>implicit</qex>.</q>
<qau>Pope.</qau>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>Tacitly comprised; fairly to be understood,
though not expressed in words; implied; <as>as, an implicit
contract or agreement</as>.</def>

<au>South.</au>

<sn>3.</sn> <def>Resting on another; trusting in the word or
authority of another, without doubt or reserve; unquestioning;
complete; <as>as, <ex>implicit</ex> confidence; <ex>implicit</ex>
obedience.</as></def>

<q>Back again to <qex>implicit</qex> faith I fall.</q>
<qau>Donne.</qau>

under <er>Function</er>.</cd></cs>

<hw>Im*plore"</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>v. t.</pos>
<wordforms>[<pos>imp. & p. p.</pos> <er>Implored</er>
<pr>(?)</pr>; <pos>p. pr. & vb. n.</pos>
<er>Imploring</er>.]</wordforms> <ety>[L. <ets>implorare</ets>;
pref. <ets>im-</ets> in + <ets>plorare</ets> to cry aloud. See
<er>Deplore</er>.]</ety> <def>To call upon, or for, in
supplication; to beseech; to prey to, or for, earnestly; to
petition with urency; to entreat; to beg; -- followed directly by
the word expressing the thing sought, or the person from whom it
is sought.</def>

<q><qex>Imploring</qex> all the gods that reign above.</q>
<qau>Pope.</qau>

<q>I kneel, and then <qex>implore</qex> her blessing.</q>
<qau>Shak.</qau>

<syn>Syn. -- To beseech; supplicate; crave; entreat; beg;
solicit; petition; prey; request; adjure. See
<er>Beseech</er>.</syn>

prey.</def>

<hw>Im*plo"sion</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[Formed by
substitution of pref. <ets>im-</ets> in for pref. <ets>ex-</ets>
in <ets>explosion</ets>.]</ety> <sn>1.</sn> <def>A burstion
inwards, as of a vessel from which the air has been exhausted; --
contrasted with <xex>explosion</xex>.</def>

<sn>2.</sn> <fld>(Phon.)</fld> <def>A sudden compression of the
air in the mouth, simultaneously with and affecting the sound
made by the closure of the organs in uttering <xex>p</xex>,
<xex>t</xex>, or <xex>k</xex>, at the end of a syllable (see
<xex>Guide to Pronunciation</xex>, <sect/<sect/159, 189); also, a
similar compression made by an upward thrust of the larynx
without any accompanying explosive action, as in the peculiar
sound of <xex>b</xex>, <xex>d</xex>, and <xex>g</xex>, heard in
Southern Germany.</def>

<au>H. Sweet.</au>

<hw>Im*plo"sive</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>a.</pos>
<fld>(Phon.)</fld> <def>Formed by implosion.</def> --
<def2><pos>n.</pos> <def>An implosive sound, an

<pos>adv.</pos></wordforms>

<au>H. Sweet.</au>

<hw>\'d8Im*plu"vi*um</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[L.,

<hw>Im*ply"</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>v. t.</pos>
<wordforms>[<pos>imp. & p. p.</pos> <er>Implied</er>
<pr>(?)</pr>; <pos>p. pr. & vb. n.</pos>
<er>Implying</er>.]</wordforms> <ety>[From the same source as
employ. See <er>Employ</er>, <er>Ply</er>, and cf.
<er>Implicate</er>, <er>Apply</er>.]</ety> <sn>1.</sn> <def>To
infold or involve; to wrap up.</def> <mark>[Obs.]</mark> \'bdHis
head in curls <xex>implied</xex>.\'b8

<au>Chapman.</au>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>To involve in substance or essence, or by fair
inference, or by construction of law, when not include virtually;
<as>as, war <ex>implies</ex> fighting</as>.</def>

<q>Where a mulicious act is proved, a mulicious intention is
<qex>implied</qex>.</q>
<qau>Bp. Sherlock.</qau>

<q>When a man employs a laborer to work for him, . . . the act of
hiring <qex>implies</qex> an obligation and a promise that he
shall pay him a reasonable reward for his services.</q>
<qau>Blackstone.</qau>

<sn>3.</sn> <def>To refer, ascribe, or attribute.</def>
<mark>[Obs.]</mark>

<q>Whence might this distaste arise?</q>

<q>If [from] neither your perverse and peevish will.
To which I most <qex>imply</qex> it.</q>
<qau>J. Webster.</qau>

<syn>Syn. -- To involve; include; comprise; import; mean; denote;
signify; betoken. See <er>Involve</er>.</syn>

<hw>Im*pon`der*a*bil"i*ty</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos>
<ety>[Cf. F. <ets>impond\'82rabilit\'82</ets>.]</ety> <def>The

<hw>Im*pon"der*a*ble</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>a.</pos> <ety>[Pref.

<hw>Im*pon"der*a*ble</hw>, <pos>n.</pos> <fld>(Physics)</fld>
<def>An imponderable substance or body; specifically, in the
plural, a name formely applied to heat, light, electricity, and
magnetism, regarded as subtile flyids destitute of weight but in
modern science little used.</def>

<hw>Im*port"</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>v. t.</pos>
<wordforms>[<pos>imp. & p. p.</pos> <er>Imported</er>; <pos>p.
pr. & vb. n.</pos> <er>Importing</er>.]</wordforms> <ety>[L.
<ets>importare</ets> to bring in, to occasion, to cause; pref.
<ets>im-</ets> in + <ets>portare</ets> to bear. Sense 3 comes
through F. <ets>importer</ets>, from the Latin. See <er>Port</er>
demeanor.]</ety> <sn>1.</sn> <def>To bring in from abroad; to
introduce from without; especially, to bring (wares or
merchandise) into a place or country from a foreign country, in
the transactions of commerce; -- opposed to <xex>export</xex>. We
<xex>import</xex> teas from China, coffee from Brasil, etc.</def>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>To carry or include, as meaning or intention; to
imply; to signify.</def>

<q>Every petition . . . doth . . . always <qex>import</qex> a
multitude of speakers together.</q>
<qau>Hooker.</qau>

<sn>3.</sn> <def>To be of importance or consequence to; to have a
bearing on; to concern.</def>

<q>I have a motion much <qex>imports</qex> your good.</q>
<qau>Shak.</qau>

<q>If I endure it, what <qex>imports</qex> it you?</q>
<qau>Dryden.</qau>

<syn>Syn. -- To denote; mean; sighify; imply; indicate; betoken;
interest; concern.</syn>

<hw>Im*port"</hw>, <pos>v. i.</pos> <def>To signify; to purport;
to be of moment.</def> \'bdFor that . . . <xex>importeth</xex> to
the work.\'b8

<au>Bacon.</au>

<hw>Im"port</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <sn>1.</sn>
<def>Merchandise imported, or brought into a country from without
its boundaries; -- generally in the plural, opposed to
<xex>exports</xex>.</def>

<q>I take the <qex>imports</qex> from, and not the exports to,
these conquests, as the measure of these advantages which we
derived from them.</q>
<qau>Burke.</qau>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>That which a word, phrase, or document contains
as its signification or intention or interpretation of a word,
action, event, and the like.</def>

<sn>3.</sn> <def>Importance; weight; consequence.</def>

<q>Most serious design, and the great <qex>import</qex>.</q>
<qau>Shak.</qau>

<hw>Im*port"a*ble</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>a.</pos> <ety>[Cf. F.
<ets>importable</ets>. See <er>Import</er>.]</ety> <def>Capable
of being imported.</def>

<hw>Im*port"a*ble</hw>, <pos>a.</pos> <ety>[L.
<ets>importabilis</ets>; pref. <ets>im-</ets> not +
<ets>portabilis</ets> bearable: cf. OF. <ets>importable</ets>.
See <er>Portable</er>.]</ety> <def>Not to be endured;
insupportable; intolerable.</def> <mark>[Obs.]</mark>
<au>Chaucer</au>. -- <wordforms><wf>Im*port"a*ble*ness</wf>,
<pos>n.</pos> <mark>[Obs.]</mark></wordforms>

<hw>Im*por"tance</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[F.
<ets>importance</ets>. See <er>Important</er>.]</ety> <sn>1.</sn>
<def>The quality or state of being important; consequence;
weight; moment; significance.</def>

<q>Thy own <qex>importance</qex> know,
Nor bound thy narrow views to things below.</q>
<qau>Pope.</qau>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>Subject; matter.</def> <mark>[Obs.]</mark>

<q>Upon <qex>importance</qex> of so slight and trivial a
nature.</q>
<qau>Shak.</qau>

<sn>3.</sn> <def>Import; meaning; significance.</def>
<mark>[Obs.]</mark>

<q>The wisest beholder could not say if the <qex>importance</qex>
were joy or sorrow.</q>
<qau>Shak.</qau>

<sn>4.</sn> <def>Importunity; solicitation.</def>
<mark>[Obs.]</mark>

<q>At our <qex>importance</qex> hither is he come.</q>
<qau>Shak.</qau>

<hw>Im*por"tan*cy</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos>
<def>Importance; significance; consequence; that which is
important.</def> <mark>[Obs.]</mark> <au>Shak</au>. \'bdCareful
to conceal <xex>importancies</xex>.\'b8 <au>Fuller</au>.

<hw>Im*por"tant</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>a.</pos> <ety>[F.
<ets>important</ets>. See <er>Import</er>, <pos>v.
t.</pos>]</ety> <sn>1.</sn> <def>Full of, or burdened by, import;
charged with great interests; restless; anxious.</def>
<mark>[Obs.]</mark>

<q>Thou hast strength as much
As serves to execute a mind very <qex>important</qex>.</q>
<qau>Chapman.</qau>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>Carrying or possessing weight or consequence; of
valuable content or bearing; significant; weighty.</def>

<q>Things small as nothing . . . 
He makes <qex>important</qex>.</q>
<qau>Shak.</qau>

<sn>3.</sn> <def>Bearing on; forcible; driving.</def>
<mark>[Obs.]</mark>

<q>He fiercely at him flew,
And with <qex>important</qex> outrage him assailed.</q>
<qau>Spenser.</qau>

<sn>4.</sn> <def>Importunate; pressing; urgent.</def>
<mark>[Obs.]</mark>

<au>Shak.</au>

<syn>Syn. -- Weighty; momentous; significant; essential;
necessary; considerable; influential; serious.</syn>

<hw>Im*por"tant*ly</hw>, <pos>adv.</pos> <def>In an important
manner.</def>

<hw>Im`por*ta"tion</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[Cf. F.
<ets>importation</ets>. See <er>Import</er>, <pos>v.

or delivering.</def> <mark>[R.]</mark>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>The act or practice of importing, or bringing
into a country or state; -- opposed to
<xex>exportation</xex>.</def>

<sn>3.</sn> <def>That which is imported; commodities or wares
introduced into a country from abroad.</def>

<hw>Im*port"er</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <def>One who
imports; the merchant who brings goods into a country or state;
-- opposed to <xex>exporter</xex>.</def>

<hw>Im*por"tu*na*cy</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[From

<hw>Im*por"tu*nate</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>a.</pos> <ety>[See
<er>Importune</er>.]</ety> <sn>1.</sn> <def>Troublesomely urgent;

who importunes; an importuner.</def> <mark>[Obs.]</mark>

<au>Sir E. Sandys.</au>

<hw>Im`por*tunee"</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>a.</pos> <ety>[F.
<ets>importun</ets>, L. <ets>importunus</ets>; pref.
<ets>im-</ets> not + a derivative from the root of
<ets>portus</ets> harbor, <ets>importunus</ets> therefore orig.
meaning, hard of access. See <er>Port</er> harbor, and cf.
<er>Importunate</er>.]</ety> <sn>1.</sn> <def>Inopportune;
unseasonable.</def> <mark>[Obs.]</mark>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>Troublesome; vexatious; persistent; urgent;
hence, vexatious on account of untimely urgency or perinacious
solicitation.</def> <mark>[Obs.]</mark>

<q>And their <qex>importune</qex> fates all satisfied.</q>
<qau>Spenser.</qau>

<q>Of all other affections it [envy] is the most
<qex>importune</qex> and continual.</q>
<qau>Bacon.</qau>

<hw>Im`por*tune"</hw>, <pos>v. t.</pos> <wordforms>[<pos>imp. &
p. p.</pos> <er>Importuned</er> <pr>(?)</pr>; <pos>p. pr. & vb.
n.</pos> <er>Importuning</er>.]</wordforms> <ety>[From
<er>Importune</er>, <pos>a.</pos>: cf. F.
<ets>importuner</ets>.]</ety> <sn>1.</sn> <def>To request or
solicit, with urgency; to press with frequent, unreasonable, or
troublesome application or pertinacity; hence, to tease; to
irritate; to worry.</def>

<q>Their ministers and residents here have perpetually
<qex>importuned</qex> the court with unreasonable demands.</q>
<qau>Swift.</qau>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>To import; to signify.</def> <mark>[Obs.]</mark>
\'bdIt <xex>importunes</xex> death.\'b8

<au>Spenser.</au>

<hw>Im`por*tune"</hw>, <pos>v. i.</pos> <def>To require; to
demand.</def> <mark>[Obs.]</mark>

<q>We shall write to you,
As time and our concernings shall <qex>importune</qex>.</q>
<qau>Shak.</qau>

<hw>Im`por*tune"ly</hw>, <pos>adv.</pos> <def>In an importune
manner.</def> <mark>[Obs.]</mark>

<hw>Im`por*tun"er</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <def>One who
importunes.</def>

<hw>Im`por*tu"ni*ty</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos>; <plu>pl.
<plw>Importunities</plw> <pr>(#)</pr></plu>. <ety>[L.
<ets>importunitas</ets> unsuitableness, rudeness: cf. F.
<ets>importunit\'82</ets>.]</ety> <def>The quality of being
importunate; pressing or pertinacious solicitation; urgent
request; incessant or frequent application; troublesome
pertinacity.</def>

<q>O'ercome with importunity and tears.</q>
<qau>Milton.</qau>

<hw>Im*por"tu*ous</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>a.</pos> <ety>[L.

<ets>portuosus</ets> abounding in harbors, fr. <ets>portus</ets>

<mark>[R.]</mark>

<hw>Im*pos"a*ble</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>a.</pos> <ety>[Cf. F.
<ets>imposable</ets>.]</ety> <def>Capable of being imposed or
laid on.</def>

<au>Hammond.</au>

<hw>Im*pos"a*ble*ness</hw>, <pos>n.</pos> <def>Quality of being
imposable.</def>

<hw>Im*pose"</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>v. t.</pos>
<wordforms>[<pos>imp. & p. p.</pos> <er>Imposed</er>
<pr>(?)</pr>; <pos>p. pr. & vb. n.</pos>
<er>Imposing</er>.]</wordforms> <ety>[F. <ets>imposer</ets>;
pref. <ets>im-</ets> in + <ets>poser</ets> to place. See
<er>Pose</er>, <pos>v. t.</pos>]</ety> <sn>1.</sn> <def>To lay
on; to set or place; to put; to deposit.</def>

<q>Cakes of salt and barley [she] did <qex>impose</qex>
Within a wicker basket.</q>
<qau>Chapman.</qau>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>To lay as a charge, burden, tax, duty,
obligation, command, penalty, etc.; to enjoin; to levy; to
inflict; <as>as, to <ex>impose</ex> a toll or tribute</as>.</def>

<q>What fates <qex>impose</qex>, that men must needs abide.</q>
<qau>Shak.</qau>

<q>Death is the penalty <qex>imposed</qex>.</q>
<qau>Milton.</qau>

<q>Thou on the deep <qex>imposest</qex> nobler laws.</q>
<qau>Waller.</qau>

<sn>3.</sn> <fld>(Eccl.)</fld> <def>To lay on, as the hands, in
the religious rites of confirmation and ordination.</def>

<sn>4.</sn> <fld>(Print.)</fld> <def>To arrange in proper order
on a table of stone or metal and lock up in a chase for printing;
-- said of columns or pages of type, forms, etc.</def>

<hw>Im*pose"</hw>, <pos>v. i.</pos> <def>To practice trick or
deception.</def>

<cs><mcol><col>To impose on</col> <or/ <col>upon</col></mcol>,
<cd>to pass or put a trick on; to delude.</cd> \'bdHe
<xex>imposes on<xex> himself, and mistakes words for
things.\'b8</cs>

<au>Locke.</au>

<hw>Im*pose"</hw>, <pos>n.</pos> <def>A command;
injunction.</def> <mark>[Obs.]</mark>

<au>Shak.</au>

<hw>Im*pose"ment</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos>
<def>Imposition.</def> <mark>[Obs.]</mark>

<hw>Im*pos"er</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <def>One who
imposes.</def>

<q>The <qex>imposers</qex> of these oaths might repent.</q>
<qau>Walton.</qau>

<hw>Im*pos"ing</hw>, <pos>a.</pos> <sn>1.</sn> <def>Laying as a
duty; enjoining.</def>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>Adapted to impress forcibly; impressive;
commanding; <as>as, an <ex>imposing</ex> air; an
<ex>imposing</ex> spectacle.</as></def> \'bdLarge and
<xex>imposing</xex> edifices.\'b8

<au>Bp. Hobart.</au>

<sn>3.</sn> <def>Deceiving; deluding; misleading.</def>

<hw>Im*pos"ing</hw>, <pos>n.</pos> <fld>(Print.)</fld> <def>The
act of imposing the columns of a page, or the pages of a sheet.
See <er>Impose</er>, <pos>v. t.</pos>, 4.</def>

<cs><col>Imposing stone</col> <fld>(Print.)</fld>, <cd>the stone
on which the pages or columns of types are imposed or made into
forms; -- called also <altname>imposing
table</altname>.</cd></cs>

<hw>Im*pos"ing*ly</hw>, <pos>adv.</pos> <def>In an imposing
manner.</def>

<hw>Im*pos"ing*ness</hw>, <pos>n.</pos> <def>The quality of being
imposing.</def>

<hw>Im`po*si"tion</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[F., fr.
L. <ets>impositio</ets> the application of a name to a thing. See
<er>Impone</er>.]</ety> <sn>1.</sn> <def>The act of imposing,
laying on, affixing, enjoining, inflicting, obtruding, and the
like.</def> \'bdFrom <xex>imposition</xex> of strict laws.\'b8
<au>Milton</au>.

<q>Made more solemn by the <qex>imposition</qex> of hands.</q>
<qau>Hammond.</qau>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>That which is imposed, levied, or enjoined;
charge; burden; injunction; tax.</def>

<sn>3.</sn> <fld>(Eng. Univ.)</fld> <def>An extra exercise
enjoined on students as a punishment.</def>

<au>T. Warton.</au>

<sn>4.</sn> <def>An excessive, arbitrary, or unlawful exaction;
hence, a trick or deception put on laid on others; cheating;
fraud; delusion; imposture.</def>

<q>Reputation is an idle and most false
<qex>imposition</qex>.</q>
<qau>Shak.</qau>

<sn>5.</sn> <fld>(Eccl.)</fld> <def>The act of laying on the
hands as a religious ceremoy, in ordination, confirmation,
etc.</def>

<sn>6.</sn> <fld>(Print.)</fld> <def>The act or process of
imosing pages or columns of type. See <er>Impose</er>, <pos>v.
t.</pos>, 4.</def>

<syn>Syn. -- Deceit; fraud; imposture. See
<er>Deception</er>.</syn>

<hw>Im*pos`si*bil"i*ty</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos>; <plu>pl.
<plw>Impossibilities</plw> <pr>(#)</pr></plu>. <ety>[L.
<ets>impossibilitas</ets>: cf. F.
<ets>impossibilit\'82</ets>.]</ety> <sn>1.</sn> <def>The quality
of being impossible; impracticability.</def>

<q>They confound difficulty with <qex>impossibility</qex>.</q>
<qau>South.</qau>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>An impossible thing; that which can not be
thought, done, or endured.</def>

<q><qex>Impossibilities</qex>! O, no, there's none.</q>
<qau>Cowley.</qau>

<sn>3.</sn> <def>Inability; helplessness.</def> <mark>[R.]</mark>

<au>Latimer.</au>

<cs><col>Logical impossibility</col>, <cd>a condition or
statement involving contradiction or absurdity; as, that a thing
can be and not be at the same time. See <cref>Principle of
Contradiction</cref>, under <er>Contradiction</er>.</cd></cs>

<hw>Im*pos"si*ble</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>a.</pos> <ety>[F., fr.
L. <ets>impossibilis</ets>; pref. <ets>im-</ets> not +
<ets>possibilis</ets> possible. See <er>Possible</er>.]</ety>
<def>Not possible; incapable of being done, of existing, etc.;
unattainable in the nature of things, or by means at command;
insuperably difficult under the circumstances; absurd or
impracticable; not feasible.</def>

<q>With men this is <qex>impossible</qex>; but with God all
things are possible.</q>
<qau>Matt. xix. 26.</qau>

<q>Without faith it is <qex>impossible</qex> to please him.</q>
<qau>Heb. xi. 6.</qau>

<cs><col>Impossible quantity</col> <fld>(Math.)</fld>, <cd>an
imagnary quantity. See <er>Imaginary</er>.</cd></cs>

<syn>Syn. -- See <er>Impracticable</er>.</syn>

<hw>Im*pos"si*ble</hw>, <pos>n.</pos> <def>An
impossibility.</def> <mark>[Obs.]</mark>

<q>\'bdMadam,\'b8 quoth he, \'bdthis were an
<qex>impossible</qex>!\'b8</q>
<qau>Chaucer.</qau>

<hw>Im*pos"si*bly</hw>, <pos>adv.</pos> <def>Not possibly.</def>

<au>Sir. T. North.</au>

<hw>Im"post</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[OF.
<ets>impost</ets>, F. <ets>impot</ets>, LL. <ets>impostus</ets>,
fr. L. <ets>impostus</ets>, p. p. of <ets>imponere</ets> to
impose. See <er>Impone</er>.]</ety> <sn>1.</sn> <def>That which
is imposed or levied; a tax, tribute, or duty; especially, a duty
or tax laid by goverment on goods imported into a country.</def>

<q>Even the ship money . . . Johnson could not pronounce to have
been an unconstitutional <qex>impost</qex>.</q>
<qau>Macaulay.</qau>

<sn>2.</sn> <fld>(Arch.)</fld> <def>The top member of a pillar,
pier, wall, etc., upon which the weight of an arch rests.</def>

<note><hand/ The impost is called <xex>continuous</xex>, if the
moldings of the arch or architrave run down the jamb or pier
without a break.</note>

<syn>Syn. -- Tribute; excise; custom; duty; tax.</syn>

<hw>Im*post"hu*mate</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>v. t.</pos> <ety>[See

<hw>Im*pos"tor</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[L.

<mhw>{ <hw>Im"po*tence</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <hw>Im"po*ten*cy</hw>
<pr>(?)</pr>, }</mhw> <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[L. <ets>impotenia</ets>
inability, poverty, want of moderation. See
<er>Impotent</er>.]</ety> <sn>1.</sn> <def>The quality or
condition of being impotent; want of strength or power, animal,
intellectual, or moral; weakness; feebleness; inability;
imbecility.</def>

<q>Some were poor by <qex>impotency</qex> of nature; as young
fatherless children, old decrepit persons, idiots, and
cripples.</q>
<qau>Hayward.</qau>

<q>O, <qex>impotence</qex> of mind in body strong!</q>
<qau>Milton.</qau>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>Want of self-restraint or self-control.</def>
<mark>[R.]</mark>

<au>Milton.</au>

<sn>3.</sn> <fld>(Law & Med.)</fld> <def>Want of procreative
power; inability to copulate, or beget children; also, sometimes,
sterility; barrenness.</def>

<hw>Im"po*tent</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>a.</pos> <ety>[F.
<ets>impotent</ets>, L. <ets>impotens</ets>, <ets>-entis</ets>;
pref. <ets>im-</ets> not + <ets>potens</ets> potent, powerful.
See <er>Potent</er>.]</ety> <sn>1.</sn> <def>Not potent; wanting
power, strength. or vigor. whether physical, intellectual, or
moral; deficient in capacity; destitute of force; weak; feeble;
infirm.</def>

<q>There sat a certain man at Lystra, <qex>impotent</qex> inhis
feet.</q>
<qau>Acts xiv. 8.</qau>

<q>O most lame and <qex>impotent</qex> conclusion!</q>
<qau>Shak.</qau>

<q>Not slow to hear,
Nor <qex>impotent</qex> to save.</q>
<qau>Addison.</qau>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>Wanting the power of self-restraint;
incontrolled; ungovernable; violent.</def>

<q><qex>Impotent</qex> of tongue, her silence broke.</q>
<qau>Dryden.</qau>

<sn>3.</sn> <fld>(Med.)</fld> <def>Wanting the power of
procreation; unable to copulate; also, sometimes, sterile;
barren.</def>

imoitent.</def> <mark>[R.]</mark>

<au>Shak.</au>

<hw>Im"po*tent*ly</hw>, <pos>adv.</pos> <def>In an impotent
manner.</def>

<hw>Im*pound"</hw> <pr>(<?/)</pr>, <pos>v. t.</pos>
<wordforms>[<pos>imp. & p. p.</pos> <er>Impounded</er>; <pos>p.
pr. & vb. n.</pos> <er>Impounding</er>.]</wordforms> <def>To shut
up or place in an inclosure called a <xex>pound</xex>; hence, to
hold in the custody of a court; <as>as, to <ex>impound</ex> stray
cattle; to <ex>impound</ex> a document for safe
keeping.</as></def>

<q>But taken and <qex>impounded</qex> as a stray,
The king of Scots.</q>
<qau>Shak.</qau>

<-- p. 738 -->

<hw>Im*pov"er*ish</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>v. t.</pos>

<er>Impoverishing</er>.]</wordforms> <ety>[OF.
<ets>empovrir</ets>; pref. <ets>em-</ets> (L. <ets>in</ets>) +
<ets>povre</ets> poor, F. <ets>pauvre</ets>; cf. OF.
<ets>apovrir</ets>, F. <ets>appauvrir</ets>, where the prefix is
<ets>a-</ets>, L. <ets>ad</ets>. Cf. <er>Empoverish</er>, and see
<er>Poor</er>, and <er>-ish</er>.]</ety> <sn>1.</sn> <def>To make
poor; to reduce to poverty or indigence; <as>as, misfortune and
disease <ex>impoverish</ex> families</as>.</def>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>To exhaust the strength, richness, or fertility
of; to make sterile; <as>as, to <ex>impoverish</ex>

<hw>Im*prac`ti*ca*bil"i*ty</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos>;
<plu>pl. <plw>Impracticabilities</plw> <pr>(<?/)</pr>.</plu>
<sn>1.</sn> <def>The state or quality of being impracticable;
infeasibility.</def>

<au>Goldsmith.</au>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>An impracticable thing.</def>

<sn>3.</sn> <def>Intractableness; stubbornness.</def>

<hw>Im*prac"ti*ca*ble</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>a.</pos>
<sn>1.</sn> <def>Not practicable; incapable of being performed,
or accomplished by the means employed, or at command; impossible;
<as>as, an <ex>impracticable</ex> undertaking</as>.</def>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>Not to be overcome, presuaded, or controlled by
any reasonable method; unmanageable; intractable; not capable of
being easily dealt with; -- used in a general sense, as applied
to a person or thing that is difficult to control or get along
with.</def>

<q>This though, <qex>impracticable</qex> heart
Is governed by a dainty-fingered girl.</q>
<qau>Rowe.</qau>

<q>Patriotic butloyal men went away disguested afresh with the
<qex>impracticable</qex> arrogance of a sovereign.</q>
<qau>Palfrey.</qau>

<sn>3.</sn> <def>Incapable of being used or availed of; <as>as,
an <ex>impracticable</ex> road; an <ex>impracticable</ex>
method.</as></def>

<syn>Syn. -- Impossible; infeasible. -- <er>Impracticable</er>,
<er>Impossible</er>. A thing is <xex>impracticable</xex> when it
can not be accomplished by any human means at present possessed;
a thing is <xex>impossible</xex> when the laws of nature forbid
it. The navigation of a river may now be
<xex>impracticable</xex>, but not <xex>impossible</xex>, because
the existing obstructions may yet be removed. \'bdThe barons
exercised the most despotic authority over their vassals, and
every scheme of public utility was rendered
<xex>impracticable</xex> by their continued petty wars with each
other.\'b8 <au>Mickle</au>. \'bdWith men this is
<xex>impossible</xex>, but with God all things are possible.\'b8
<au>Matt. xix. 26</au>.</syn>

<hw>Im*prac"ti*ca*ble*ness</hw>, <pos>n.</pos> <def>The state or
quality of being impracticable; impracticability.</def>

<hw>Im*prac"ti*ca*bly</hw>, <pos>adv.</pos> <def>In an
impracticable manner.</def>

<q>Morality not <qex>impracticably</qex> rigid.</q>
<qau>Johnson.</qau>

<hw>Im*prac"ti*cal</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>a.</pos> <def>Not
practical.</def>

<hw>Im"pre*cate</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>v. t.</pos>
<wordforms>[<pos>imp. & p. p.</pos> <er>Imprecated</er>
<pr>(?)</pr>; <pos>p. pr. & vb. n.</pos> <er>Imprecating</er>
<pr>(?)</pr>.]</wordforms> <ety>[L. <ets>imprecatus</ets>, p. p.
of <ets>imprecari</ets> to imprecate; pref. <ets>im-</ets> in, on
+ <ets>precari</ets> to pray. See <er>Pray</er>.]</ety>
<sn>1.</sn> <def>To call down by prayer, as something hurtful or
calamitous.</def>

<q><qex>Imprecate</qex> the vengeance of Heaven on the guilty
empire.</q>
<qau>Mickle.</qau>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>To invoke evil upon; to curse; to swear
at.</def>

<q>In vain we blast the ministers of Fate,
And the forlorn physicians <qex>imprecate</qex>.</q>
<qau>Rochester.</qau>

<hw>Im`pre*ca"tion</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[L.
<ets>imprecatio</ets>: cf. F. <ets>impr\'82cation</ets>.]</ety>
<def>The act of imprecating, or unvoking evil upon any one; a
player that a curse or calamnity may fall on any one; a
curse.</def>

<q>Men cowered like slaves before such horrid
<qex>imprecations</qex>.</q>
<qau>Motley.</qau>

<syn>Syn. -- Malediction; curse; execration; anathema. See
<er>Malediction</er>.</syn>

<hw>Im"pre*ca*to*ry</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>a.</pos> <def>Of the
nature of, or containing, imprecation; invokingevil; <as>as, the
<ex>imprecatory</ex> psalms</as>.</def>

<hw>Im`pre*ci"sion</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <def>Want of
precision.</def> <mark>[R.]</mark>

<hw>Im*pregn"</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>v. t.</pos> <ety>[Cf. F.
<ets>impregner</ets>. See <er>Impregnate</er>.]</ety> <def>To

<q>His perniciousss words, <qex>impregned</qex>
With reason.</q>
<qau>Milton.</qau>

<q>Semele doth Bacchus bear
<qex>Impregned</qex> of Jove.</q>
<qau>Dr. H. More.</qau>

<hw>Im*preg`na*bil"i*ty</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <def>The
quality or state of being impregnable; invincibility.</def>

<hw>Im*preg"na*ble</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>a.</pos> <ety>[F.
<ets>imprenable</ets>; pref. <ets>im-</ets> not +
<ets>prenable</ets> pregnable, fr. <ets>prendre</ets> to take, L.
<ets>prehendere</ets>. See <er>Comprehend</er>, <er>Get</er> to
obtain.]</ety> <def>Not to be stormed, or taken by assault;
incapable of being subdued; able to resist attack; unconquerable;
<as>as, an <ex>impregnable</ex> fortress; <ex>impregnable</ex>
virtue.</as></def>

<q>The man's affection remains wholly unconcerned and
<qex>impregnable</qex>.</q>
<qau>South.</qau>

<hw>Im*preg"nate</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>v. t.</pos>
<wordforms>[<pos>imp. & p. p.</pos> <er>Impregnated</er>
<pr>(?)</pr>; <pos>p. pr. & vb. n.</pos> <er>Impregnating</er>
<pr>(?)</pr>.]</wordforms> <ety>[LL. <ets>impraegnatus</ets>, p.
p. of <ets>impraegnare</ets> to impregnate, fr. L. pref.
<ets>im-</ets> in + <ets>praegnans</ets> pregnant. See
<er>Pregnant</er>.]</ety> <sn>1.</sn> <def>To make pregnant; to
cause to conceive; to render prolific; to get with child or
young.</def>

<sn>2.</sn> <fld>(Biol.)</fld> <def>To come into contact with (an
ovum or egg) so as to cause impregnation; to fertilize; to
fecundate.</def>

<sn>3.</sn> <def>To infuse an active principle into; to render
frutful or fertile in any way; to fertilize; to imbue.</def>

<sn>4.</sn> <def>To infuse particles of another substance into;
to communicate the quality of another to; to cause to be filled,
imbued, mixed, or furnished (with something); <as>as, to
<ex>impregnate</ex> India rubber with sulphur; clothing
<ex>impregnated</ex> with contagion; rock <ex>impregnated</ex>
with ore.</as></def>

<hw>Im*preg"nate</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>v. i.</pos> <def>To
become pregnant.</def>

<au>Addison.</au>

<hw>Im*preg"nate</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>a.</pos> <ety>[LL.
<ets>impraegnatus</ets>, p. p.]</ety> <def>Impregnated; made
prolific.</def>

<q>The scorching ray
Here pierceth not, <qex>impregnate</qex> with disease.</q>
<qau>Byron.</qau>

<hw>Im`preg*na"tion</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[Cf. F.
<ets>impr\'82gnation</ets>, LL. <ets>impraegnatio</ets>.]</ety>
<sn>1.</sn> <def>The act of impregnating or the state of being
impregnated; fecundation.</def>

<sn>2.</sn> <fld>(Biol.)</fld> <def>The fusion of a female germ
cell (ovum) with a male germ cell (in animals, a spermatozo\'94n)
to form a single new cell endowed with the power of developing
into a new individual; fertilization; fecundation.</def>

<note><hand/ In the broadest biological sense, impregnation, or
sexual generation, consists simply in the coalescence of two
similar masses of protoplasmic matter, either derived from
different parts of the same organism or from two distinct
organisms. From the single mass, which results from the fusion,
or coalescence, of these two masses, a new organism
develops.</note>

<sn>3.</sn> <def>That with which anything is impregnated.</def>

<au>Derham.</au>

<sn>4.</sn> <def>Intimate mixture; influsion; saturation.</def>

<sn>5.</sn> <fld>(Mining)</fld> <def>An ore deposit, with
indefinite boundaries, consisting of rock impregnated with
ore.</def>

<au>Raymond.</au>

<hw>Im`pre*scrip`ti*bil"i*ty</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos>
<ety>[Cf. F. <ets>imprescriptibilit\'82</ets>.]</ety> <def>The
quality of being imprescriptible.</def>

<hw>Im`pre*scrip"ti*ble</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>a.</pos>
<ety>[Pref. <ets>im-</ets> not + <ets>prescriptible</ets>: cf. F.
<ets>imprescriptible</ets>.]</ety> <sn>1.</sn> <def>Not capable
of being lost or impaired by neglect, by disuse, or by the claims
of another founded on prescription.</def>

<q>The right of navigation, fishing, and others that may be
exercised on the sea, belonging to the right of mere ability, are
<qex>imprescriptible</qex>.</q>
<qau>Vattel (Trans. )</qau>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>Not derived from, or dependent on, external
authority; self-evidencing; obvious.</def>

<q>The <qex>imprescriptible</qex> laws of the pure reason.</q>
<qau>Colerridge.</qau>

<hw>Im`pre*scrip"ti*bly</hw>, <pos>adv.</pos> <def>In an
imprescriptible manner; obviously.</def>

<hw>Im*prese"</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <def>A device. See
<er>Impresa</er>.</def>

<q>An <qex>imprese</qex>, as the Italians call it, is a device in
picture with his motto or word, borne by noble or learned
personages.</q>
<qau>Camden.</qau>

<hw>Im*press"</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>v. t.</pos>
<wordforms>[<pos>imp. & p. p.</pos> <er>Impressed</er>
<pr>(?)</pr>; <pos>p. pr. & vb. n.</pos>
<er>Impressing</er>.]</wordforms> <ety>[L. <ets>impressus</ets>,
p. p. of <ets>imprimere</ets> to impress; pref. <ets>im-</ets>
in, on + <ets>premere</ets> to press. See <er>Press</er> to
squeeze, and cf. <er>Imprint</er>.]</ety> <sn>1.</sn> <def>To
press, stamp, or print something in or upon; to mark by pressure,
or as by pressure; to imprint (that which bears the
impression).</def>

<q>His heart, like an agate, with your print
<qex>impressed</qex>.</q>
<qau>Shak.</qau>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>To produce by pressure, as a mark, stamp, image,
etc.; to imprint (a mark or figure upon something).</def>

<sn>3.</sn> <def>Fig.: To fix deeply in the mind; to present
forcibly to the attention, etc.; to imprint; to inculcate.</def>

<q><qex>Impress</qex> the motives of persuasion upon our own
hearts till we feel the force of them.</q>
<qau>I. Watts.</qau>

<sn>4.</sn> <ety>[See <er>Imprest</er>, <er>Impress</er>,
<pos>n.</pos>, 5.]</ety> <def>To take by force for public
service; <as>as, to <ex>impress</ex> sailors or money</as>.</def>

<q>The second five thousand pounds <qex>impressed</qex> for the
service of the sick and wounded prisoners.</q>
<qau>Evelyn.</qau>

<hw>Im*press"</hw>, <pos>v. i.</pos> <def>To be impressed; to
rest.</def> <mark>[Obs.]</mark>

<q>Such fiendly thoughts in his heart <qex>impress</qex>.</q>
<qau>Chaucer.</qau>

<hw>Im"press</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos>; <plu>pl.
<plw>Impresses</plw> <pr>(<?/)</pr>.</plu> <sn>1.</sn> <def>The
act of impressing or making.</def>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>A mark made by pressure; an indentation;
imprint; the image or figure of anything, formed by pressure or
as if by pressure; result produced by pressure or
influence.</def>

<q>The <qex>impresses</qex> of the insides of these shells.</q>
<qau>Woodward.</qau>

<q>This weak <qex>impress</qex> of love is as a figure
Trenched in ice.</q>
<qau>Shak.</qau>

<sn>3.</sn> <def>Characteristic; mark of distinction;
stamp.</def>

<au>South.</au>

<sn>4.</sn> <def>A device. See <er>Impresa</er>.</def>

<au>Cussans.</au>

<q>To describe . . . emblazoned shields,
<qex>Impresses</qex> quaint.</q>
<qau>Milton.</qau>

<sn>5.</sn> <ety>[See <er>Imprest</er>, <er>Press</er> to force
into service.]</ety> <def>The act of impressing, or taking by
force for the public service; compulsion to serve; also, that
which is impressed.</def>

<q>Why such <qex>impress</qex> of shipwrights?</q>
<qau>Shak.</qau>

<cs><col>Impress gang</col>, <cd>a party of men, with an officer,
employed to impress seamen for ships of war; a press gang.</cd>
-- <col>Impress money</col>, <cd>a sum of money paid, immediately
upon their entering service, to men who have been
impressed.</cd></cs>

<hw>Im*press`i*bil"i*ty</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <def>The
quality of being impressible; susceptibility.</def>

<hw>Im*press"i*ble</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>a.</pos> <ety>[Cf. F.
<ets>impressible</ets>.]</ety> <def>Capable of being impressed;
