<hw>Im*pres"sion</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[F.
<ets>impression</ets>, L. <ets>impressio</ets>.]</ety>
<sn>1.</sn> <def>The act of impressing, or the state of being
impressed; the communication of a stamp, mold, style, or
character, by external force or by influence.</def>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>That which is impressed; stamp; mark;
indentation; sensible result of an influence exerted from
without.</def>

<q>The stamp and clear <qex>impression</qex> of good sense.</q>
<qau>Cowper.</qau>

<q>To shelter us from <qex>impressions</qex> of weather, we must
spin, we must weave, we must build.</q>
<qau>Barrow.</qau>

<sn>3.</sn> <def>That which impresses, or exercises an effect,
action, or agency; appearance; phenomenon.</def>
<mark>[Obs.]</mark>

<q>Portentous blaze of comets and <qex>impressions</qex> in the
air.</q>
<qau>Milton.</qau>

<q>A fiery <qex>impression</qex> falling from out of Heaven.</q>
<qau>Holland.</qau>

<sn>4.</sn> <def>Influence or effect on the senses or the
intellect hence, interest, concern.</def>

<au>Reid.</au>

<q>His words <qex>impression</qex> left.</q>
<qau>Milton.</qau>

<q>Such terrible <qex>impression</qex> made the dream.</q>
<qau>Shak.</qau>

<q>I have a father's dear <qex>impression</qex>,
And wish, before I fall into my grave,
That I might see her married.</q>
<qau>Ford.</qau>

<sn>5.</sn> <def>An indistinct notion, remembrance, or
belief.</def>

<sn>6.</sn> <def>Impressiveness; emphasis of delivery.</def>

<q>Which must be read with an <qex>impression</qex>.</q>
<qau>Milton.</qau>

<sn>7.</sn> <fld>(Print.)</fld> <def>The pressure of the type on
the paper, or the result of such pressure, as regards its
appearance; <as>as, a heavy <ex>impression</ex>; a clear, or a
poor, <ex>impression</ex></as>; also, a single copy as the result
of printing, or the whole edition printed at a given time.</def>

<q>Ten <qex>impressions</qex> which his books have had.</q>
<qau>Dryden.</qau>

<sn>8.</sn> <def>In painting, the first coat of color, as the
priming in house painting and the like.</def> <mark>[R.]</mark>

<sn>9.</sn> <fld>(Engraving)</fld> <def>A print on paper from a
wood block, metal plate, or the like.</def>

<cs><col>Proof impression</col>, <cd>one of the early impressions
taken from an engraving, before the plate or block is
worn.</cd></cs>

<hw>Im*pres`sion*a*bil"i*ty</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos>
<def>The quality of being impressionable.</def>

<hw>Im*pres"ion*a*ble</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>a.</pos> <ety>[Cf.
F. <ets>impressionnable</ets>.]</ety> <def>Liable or subject to
impression; capable of being molded; susceptible;
impressible.</def>

<q>He was too <qex>impressionable</qex>; he had too much of the
temperament of genius.</q>
<qau>Motley.</qau>

<q>A pretty face and an <qex>impressionable</qex>
disposition.</q>
<qau>T. Hook.</qau>

<hw>Im*pres"sion*a*ble*ness</hw>, <pos>n.</pos> <def>The quality
of being impressionable.</def>

<hw>Im*pres"sion*ism</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[F.
<ets>impressionnisme</ets>.]</ety> <fld>(Fine Arts)</fld>
<def>The theory or method of suggesting an effect or impression
without elaboration of the details; -- a disignation of a recent
fashion in painting and etching.</def>

<hw>Im*pres"sion*ist</hw>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[F.
<ets>impressionniste</ets>.]</ety> <fld>(Fine Arts)</fld>
<def>One who adheres to the theory or method of impressionism, so
called.</def>

<hw>Im*pres`sion*is"tic</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>a.</pos>
<def>Pertaining to, or characterized by, impressionism.</def>

<hw>Im*pres"sion*less</hw>, <pos>a.</pos> <def>Having the quality
of not being impressed or affected; not susceptible.</def>

<hw>Im*press"ive</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>a.</pos> <ety>[Cf. F.
impressif.]</ety> <sn>1.</sn> <def>Making, or tending to make, an
impression; having power to impress; adapted to excite attention
and feeling, to touch the sensibilities, or affect the
conscience; <as>as, an <ex>impressive</ex> discourse; an
<ex>impressive</ex> scene.</as></def>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>Capable of being impressed.</def>
<mark>[Obs.]</mark>

<au>Drayton.</au>

- <wordforms><wf>Im*press"ive*ly</wf>, <pos>adv.</pos> --
<wf>Im*press"ive*ness</wf>, <pos>n.</pos></wordforms>

<hw>Im*press"ment</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <def>The act
of seizing for public use, or of impressing into public service;
compulsion to serve; <as>as, the <ex>impressment</ex> of
provisions or of sailors</as>.</def>

<q>The great scandal of our naval service --
<qex>impressment</qex> -- died a protracted death.</q>
<qau>J. H. Burton.</qau>

<hw>Im*press"or</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[LL., a
printer.]</ety> <def>One who, or that which, impresses.</def>

<au>Boyle.</au>

<hw>Im*pres"sure</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[Cf. OF.
<ets>impressure</ets>, LL. <ets>impressura</ets>.]</ety>
<def>Dent; impression.</def> <mark>[Obs.]</mark>

<au>Shak.</au>

<hw>Im*prest"</hw> <pr>(<?/)</pr>, <pos>v. t.</pos> <wordforms>[
<pos>imp. & p. p.</pos> <er>Imprested</er>; <pos>p. pr. & vb.
n.</pos> <er>Impresting</er>.]</wordforms> <ety>[Pref.
<ets>im-</ets> + <ets>prest</ets>: cf. It. <ets>imprestare</ets>.
See <er>Prest</er>, <pos>n.</pos>]</ety> <def>To advance on
loan.</def>

<au>Burke.</au>

<hw>Im"prest</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[Cf. It.
<ets>impresto</ets>, <ets>imprestito</ets>, LL.
<ets>impraestitum</ets>. See <er>Imprest</er>, <pos>v. t.</pos>,
and <er>Impress</er> compulsion to serve.]</ety> <def>A kind of
earnest money; loan; -- specifically, money advanced for some
public service, as in enlistment.</def>

<au>Burke.</au>

<q>The clearing of their <qex>imprests</qex> for what little of
their debts they have received.</q>
<qau>Pepys.</qau>

<hw>\'d8Im`pri*ma"tur</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[L.,
let it be printed.]</ety> <fld>(Law)</fld> <def>A license to
print or publish a book, paper, etc.; also, in countries
subjected to the censorship of the press, approval of that which
is published.</def>

<hw>Im*prim"er*y</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[F.
<ets>imprimerie</ets>, fr. <ets>imprimer</ets> to imprint.]</ety>
<mark>[Obs.]</mark> <sd>(a)</sd> <def>A print; impression.</def>
<sd>(b)</sd> <def>A printing establishment</def>. <sd>(c)</sd>
<def>The art of printing.</def>

<hw>Im*prim"ing</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <def>A
begining.</def> <mark>[Obs.]</mark> \'bdTheir springings and
<xex>imprimings</xex>.\'b8

<au>Sir H. Wotton.</au>

<hw>\'d8Im*pri"mis</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>adv.</pos> <ety>[L.,
for <ets>in primis</ets> among the first, chiefly; <ets>in</ets>
in + <ets>primus</ets> first.]</ety> <def>In the first place;
first in order.</def>

<hw>Im*print"</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>v. t.</pos>
<wordforms>[<pos>imp. & p. p.</pos> <er>Imptrinted</er>; <pos>p.
pr. & vb. n.</pos> <er>Imprinting</er>.]</wordforms> <ety>[OE.
<ets>emprenten</ets>, F. <ets>empreint</ets>, p. p. of
<ets>empreindre</ets> to imprint, fr. L. <ets>imprimere</ets> to
impres, imprint. See 1st <er>In-</er>, <er>Print</er>, and cf.
<er>Impress</er>.]</ety> <sn>1.</sn> <def>To impress; to mark by
pressure; to indent; to stamp.</def>

<q>And sees his num'rous herds <qex>imprint</qex> her sands.</q>
<qau>Prior.</qau>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>To stamp or mark, as letters on paper, by means
of type, plates, stamps, or the like; to print the mark (figures,
letters, etc., upon something).</def>

<q>Nature <qex>imprints</qex> upon whate'er we see,
That has a heart and life in it, \'bdBe free.\'b8</q>
<qau>Cowper.</qau>

<sn>3.</sn> <def>To fix indelibly or permanently, as in the mind
or memory; to impress.</def>

<q>Ideas of those two different things distinctly
<qex>imprinted</qex> on his mind.</q>
<qau>Locke.</qau>

<-- p. 739 -->

<hw>Im"print</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[Cf. F.
<ets>empreinte</ets> impress, stamp. See <er>Imprint</er>,
<pos>v. t.</pos>]</ety> <def>Whatever is impressed or imprinted;
the impress or mark left by something; specifically, the name of
the printer or publisher (usually) with the time and place of
issue, in the title-page of a book, or on any printed
sheet.</def> \'bdThat <xex>imprint</xex> of their hands.\'b8

<au>Buckle.</au>

<hw>Im*pris"on</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>v. t.</pos>
<wordforms>[<pos>imp. & p. p.</pos> <er>Imprisoned</er>
<pr>(?)</pr>; <pos>p. pr. & vb. n.</pos>
<er>Imprisoning</er>.]</wordforms> <ety>[OE.
<ets>enprisonen</ets>, OF. <ets>enprisoner</ets>, F.
<ets>emprisonner</ets>; pref. <ets>en-</ets> (L. <ets>in</ets>) +
F. & OF. <ets>prison</ets>. See <er>Prison</er>.]</ety>
<sn>1.</sn> <def>To put in prison or jail; To arrest and detain
in custody; to confine.</def>

<q>He <qex>imprisoned</qex> was in chains remediles.</q>
<qau>Spenser.</qau>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>To limit, restrain, or confine in any way.</def>

<q>Try to <qex>imprison</qex> the resistless wind.</q>
<qau>Dryden.</qau>

<syn>Syn. -- To incarcerate; confine; immure.</syn>

<hw>Im*pris"on*er</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <def>One who
imprisons.</def>

<hw>Im*pris"on ment</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[OE.
<ets>enprisonment</ets>; F. <ets>emprisonnement</ets>.]</ety>
<def>The act of imprisoning, or the state of being imprisoned;
confinement; restraint.</def>

<q>His sinews waxen weak and raw
Through long <qex>imprisonment</qex> and hard constraint.</q>
<qau>Spenser.</qau>

<q>Every confinement of the person is an <qex>imprisonment</qex>,
whether it be in a common prison, or in a private house, or even
by foreibly detaining one in the public streets.</q>
<qau>Blackstone.</qau>

<cs><col>False imprisonment</col>. <fld>(Law)</fld> <cd>See under
<er>False</er>.</cd></cs>

<syn>Syn. -- Incarceration; custody; confinement; durance;
restraint.</syn>

<hw>Im*prob`a*bil"i*ty</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos>; <plu>pl.
<plw>Improbabilities</plw> <pr>(#)</pr></plu>. <ety>[Cf. F.
<ets>improbabilit\'82</ets>.]</ety> <def>The quality or state of
being improbable; unlikelihood; also, that which is improbable;
an improbable event or result.</def>

<hw>Im*prob"a*ble</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>a.</pos> <ety>[L.
<ets>improbabilis</ets>; pref. <ets>im-</ets> not +
<ets>probabilis</ets> probable: cf. F. <ets>improbable</ets>. See
<er>Probable</er>.]</ety> <def>Not probable; unlikely to be true;
not to be expected under the circumstances or in the usual course
of events; <as>as, an <ex>improbable</ex> story or
event</as>.</def>

<q>He . . . sent to Elutherius, then bishop of Rome, an
<qex>improbable</qex> letter, as some of the contents
discover.</q>
<qau>Milton.</qau>

<hw>Im*promp"tu</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>adv. <or/ a.</pos>
<ety>[F. <ets>impromptu</ets>, fr. L. <ets>in promptu</ets> in
readiness, at hand; <ets>in</ets> in + <ets>promptus</ets>
visibility, readiness, from <ets>promptus</ets> visible, ready.
See <er>Prompt</er>.]</ety> <def>Offhand; without previous study;
extemporaneous; extempore; <as>as, an <ex>impromptu</ex>
verse</as>.</def>

<hw>Im*promp"tu</hw>, <pos>n.</pos> <sn>1.</sn> <def>Something
made or done offhand, at the moment, or without previous study;
an extemporaneous composition, address, or remark.</def>

<sn>2.</sn> <fld>(Mus.)</fld> <def>A piece composed or played at
first thought; a composition in the style of an extempore
piece.</def>

<hw>Im*prop"er</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>a.</pos> <ety>[F.
<ets>impropre</ets>, L. <ets>improprius</ets>; pref.
<ets>im-</ets> not + <ets>proprius</ets> proper. See
<er>Proper</er>.]</ety> <sn>1.</sn> <def>Not proper; not
suitable; not fitted to the circumstances, design, or end; unfit;
not becoming; incongruous; inappropriate; indecent; <as>as, an
<ex>improper</ex> medicine; <ex>improper</ex> thought, behavior,
language, dress.</as></def>

<q>Follow'd his enemy king, and did him service,
<qex>Improper</qex> for a slave.</q>
<qau>Shak.</qau>

<q>And to their proper operation still,
Ascribe all Good; to their <qex>improper</qex>, Ill.</q>
<qau>Pope.</qau>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>Not peculiar or appropriate to individuals;
general; common.</def> <mark>[Obs.]</mark>

<q>Not to be adorned with any art but such <qex>improper</qex>
ones as nature is said to bestow, as singing and poetry.</q>
<qau>J. Fletcher.</qau>

<sn>3.</sn> <def>Not according to facts; inaccurate;
erroneous.</def>

<cs><col>Improper diphthong</col>. <cd>See under
<er>Diphthong</er>.</cd> -- <col>Improper feud</col>, <cd>an
originalfeud, not earned by military service. <xex>Mozley<xex> &
<xex>W<xex>.</cd> -- <col>Improper fraction</col>. <cd>See under
<er>Fraction</er>.</cd></cs>

<q>He would in like manner <qex>improper</qex> and inclose the
sunbeams to comfort the rich and not the poor.</q>
<qau>Jewel.</qau>

<hw>Im*pro"pri*ate</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>v. t.</pos>
<wordforms>[<pos>imp. & p. p.</pos> <er>Impropriated</er>
<pr>(?)</pr>; <pos>p. pr. & vb. n.</pos> <er>Impropriating</er>
<pr>(?)</pr>.]</wordforms> <ety>[Pref. <ets>im-</ets> in + L.
<ets>propriatus</ets>, p. p. of <ets>propriare</ets> to
appropriate. See <er>Appropriate</er>.]</ety> <sn>1.</sn> <def>To
appropriate to one's self; to assume.</def> <mark>[Obs.]</mark>

<q>To <qex>impropriate</qex> the thanks to himself.</q>
<qau>Bacon.</qau>

<sn>2.</sn> <fld>(Eng. Eccl. Law)</fld> <def>To place the profits
of (ecclesiastical property) in the hands of a layman for care
and disbursement.</def>

impropriator.</def> <mark>[R.]</mark>

impropriated.</def>

<hw>Im*pro`pri*a"tion</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos>
<sn>1.</sn> <def>The act of impropriating; <as>as, the
<ex>impropriation</ex> of property or tithes</as>; also, that
which is impropriated.</def>

<sn>2.</sn> <fld>(Eng. Eccl. Law)</fld> <sd>(a)</sd> <def>The act
of putting an ecclesiastical benefice in the hands of a layman,
or lay corporation.</def> <sd>(b)</sd> <def>A benefice in the
hands of a layman, or of a lay corporation.</def>

<hw>Im*pro"pri*a`tor</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <def>One
who impropriates; specifically, a layman in possession of church
property.</def>

<hw>Im*pro`pri*a"trix</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos>; <plu>pl.
E. <plw>-trixes</plw>, L. <plw>-trices</plw> <pr>(<?/)</pr>.
<def>A female impropriator.</def>

<hw>Im`pro*pri"e*ty</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos>; <plu>pl.
<plw>Improprieties</plw> <pr>(#)</pr></plu>. <ety>[L.
<ets>improprietas</ets>; cf. F. <ets>impropri\'82t\'82</ets>. See
<er>Improper</er>.]</ety> <sn>1.</sn> <def>The quality of being
improper; unfitness or unsuitableness to character, time place,
or circumstances; <as>as, <ex>improperiety</ex> of behavior or
manners</as>.</def>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>That which is improper; an unsuitable or
improper act, or an inaccurate use of language.</def>

<q>But every language has likewise its <qex>improprieties</qex>
and absurdities.</q>
<qau>Johnson.</qau>

<q>Many gross <qex>improprieties</qex>, however authorized by
practice, ought to be discarded.</q>
<qau>Swift.</qau>

<hw>Im*prov`a*bil"i*ty</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <def>The

<hw>Im*prov"a*ble</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>a.</pos> <ety>[From
<er>Improve</er>.]</ety> <sn>1.</sn> <def>Capable of being
improved; susceptible of improvement; admitting of being made
better; capable of cultivation, or of being advanced in good
qualities.</def>

<q>Man is accommodated with moral principles,
<qex>improvable</qex> by the exercise of his faculties.</q>
<qau>Sir M. Hale.</qau>

<q>I have a fine spread of <qex>improvable</qex> lands.</q>
<qau>Addison.</qau>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>Capable of being used to advantage; profitable;
serviceable; advantageous.</def>

<q>The essays of weaker heads afford <qex>improvable</qex> hints
to better.</q>
<qau>Sir T. Browne.</qau>

-- <wordforms><wf>Im*pro"a*ble*ness</wf>, <pos>n.</pos> --
<wf>Im*prov"a*bly</wf>, <pos>adv.</pos></wordforms>

<hw>Im*prove"</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>v. t.</pos> <ety>[Pref.
<ets>im-</ets> not + <ets>prove</ets>: cf. L.
<ets>improbare</ets>, F. <ets>improuver</ets>.]</ety> <sn>1.</sn>
<def>To disprove or make void; to refute.</def>
<mark>[Obs.]</mark>

<q>Neither can any of them make so strong a reason which another
can not <qex>improve</qex>.</q>
<qau>Tyndale.</qau>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>To disapprove; to find fault with; to reprove;
to censure; <as>as, to <ex>improve</ex> negligence</as>.</def>
<mark>[Obs.]</mark>

<au>Chapman.</au>

<q>When he rehearsed his preachings and his doing unto the high
apostles, they could <qex>improve</qex> nothing.</q>
<qau>Tyndale.</qau>

<hw>Im*prove"</hw>, <pos>v. t.</pos> <wordforms>[<pos>imp. & p.
p.</pos> <er>Improved</er> <pr>(?)</pr>; <pos>p. pr. & vb.
n.</pos> <er>Improving</er>.]</wordforms> <ety>[Pref.
<ets>in-</ets> in + <ets>prove</ets>, in <ets>approve.</ets>  See
<er>Approve</er>, <er>Prove.</er>]</ety> <sn>1.</sn> <def>To make
better; to increase the value or good qualities of; to ameliorate
by care or cultivation; <as>as, to <ex>improve</ex>
land</as>.</def>

<au>Donne.</au>

<q>I love not to <qex>improve</qex> the honor of the living by
impairing that of the dead.</q>
<qau>Denham.</qau>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>To use or employ to good purpose; to make
productive; to turn to profitable account; to utilize; <as>as, to
<ex>improve</ex> one's time; to <ex>improve</ex> his
means.</as></def>

<au>Shak.</au>

<q>We shall especially honor God by <qex>improving</qex>
diligently the talents which God hath committed to us.</q>
<qau>Barrow.</qau>

<q>A hint that I do not remember to have seen opened and
<qex>improved</qex>.</q>
<qau>Addison.</qau>

<q>The court seldom fails to <qex>improve</qex> the
oppotunity.</q>
<qau>Blackstone.</qau>

<q>How doth the little busy bee
<qex>Improve</qex> each shining hour.</q>
<qau>I. Watts.</qau>

<q>Those moments were diligently improved.</q>
<qau>Gibbon.</qau>

<q>True policy, as well as good faith, in my opinion, binds us to
<qex>improve</qex> the occasion.</q>
<qau>Washington.</qau>

<sn>3.</sn> <def>To advance or increase by use; to augment or add
to; -- said with reference to what is bad.</def>
<mark>[R.]</mark>

<q>We all have, I fear, . . . not a little <qex>improved</qex>
the wretched inheritance of our ancestors.</q>
<qau>Bp. Porteus.</qau>

<syn>Syn. -- To better; meliorate; ameliorate; advance; heighten;
mend; correct; recify; amend; reform.</syn>

<hw>Im*prove"</hw>, <pos>v. i.</pos> <sn>1.</sn> <def>To grow
better; to advance or make progress in what is desirable; to make
or show improvement; <as>as, to <ex>improve</ex> in
health</as>.</def>

<q>We take care to <qex>improve</qex> in our frugality and
diligence.</q>
<qau>Atterbury.</qau>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>To advance or progress in bad qualities; to grow
worse.</def> \'bdDomitain <xex>improved</xex> in cruelty.\'b8

<au>Milner.</au>

<sn>3.</sn> <def>To increase; to be enhanced; to rise in value;
<as>as, the price of cotton <ex>improves</ex></as>.</def>

<cs><mcol><col>To improve on</col> <or/ <col>upon</col></mcol>,
<cd>to make useful additions or amendments to, or changes in; to
bring nearer to perfection; <as>as, <ex>to improve on<ex> the
mode of tillage</as>.</cd></cs>

<hw>Im*prove"ment</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <sn>1.</sn>
<def>The act of improving; advancement or growth; promotion in
desirable qualities; progress toward what is better; melioration;
<as>as, the <ex>improvement</ex> of the mind, of land, roads,
etc.</as></def>

<q>I look upon your city as the best place of
<qex>improvement</qex>.</q>
<qau>South.</qau>

<q>Exercise is the chief source of <qex>improvement</qex> in all
our faculties.</q>
<qau>Blair.</qau>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>The act of making profitable use or applicaton
of anything, or the state of being profitably employed; a turning
to good account; practical application, as of a doctrine,
principle, or theory, stated in a discourse.</def> \'bdA good
<xex>improvement</xex> of his reason.\'b8

<au>S. Clarke.</au>

<q>I shall make some <qex>improvement</qex> of this doctrine.</q>
<qau>Tillotson.</qau>

<sn>3.</sn> <def>The state of being improved; betterment;
advance; also, that which is improved; <as>as, the new edition is
an <ex>improvement</ex> on the old</as>.</def>

<q>The parts of Sinon, Camilla, and some few others, are
<qex>improvements</qex> on the Greek poet.</q>
<qau>Addison.</qau>

<sn>4.</sn> <def>Increase; growth; progress; advance.</def>

<q>There is a design of publishing the history of architecture,
with its several <qex>improvements</qex> and decays.</q>
<qau>Addison.</qau>

<q>Those vices which more particularly receive
<qex>improvement</qex> by prosperity.</q>
<qau>South.</qau>

<sn>5.</sn> <pluf>pl.</pluf> <def>Valuable additions or
betterments, as buildings, clearings, drains, fences, etc., on
premises.</def>

<sn>6.</sn> <fld>(Patent Laws)</fld> <def>A useful addition to,
or modification of, a machine, manufacture, or composition.</def>

<au>Kent.</au>

<hw>Im*prov"er</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <def>One who, or
that which, improves.</def>

<hw>Im`pro*vid"ed</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>a.</pos>
<def>Unforeseen; unexpected; not provided against;
unprepared.</def> <mark>[Obs.]</mark>

<q>All <qex>improvided</qex> for dread of death.</q>
<qau>E. Hall.</qau>

<hw>Im*prov"i*dence</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[L.
<ets>improvidentia</ets>; OF. <ets>improvidence</ets>. Cf.
<er>Imprudence</er>.]</ety> <def>The quality of being
improvident; want of foresight or thrift.</def>

<q>The <qex>improvidence</qex> of my neighbor must not make me
inhuman.</q>
<qau>L'Estrange.</qau>

<hw>Im*prov"i*dent</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>a.</pos> <ety>[Pref.
<ets>im-</ets> not + <ets>provident</ets>: cf. L.
<ets>improvidus</ets>. See <er>Provident</er>, and cf.
<er>Imprudent</er>.]</ety> <def>Not provident; wanting foresight
or forethought; not foreseeing or providing for the future;
negligent; thoughtless; <as>as, an <ex>improvident</ex>
man</as>.</def>

<q><qex>Improvident</qex> soldires! had your watch been good,
This sudden mischief never could have fallen.</q>
<qau>Shak.</qau>

<syn>Syn. -- Inconsiderable; negligent; careless; shiftless;
prodigal; wasteful.</syn>

<hw>Im*prov`i*den"tial*ly</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>adv.</pos>
<def>Improvidently.</def> <mark>[R.]</mark>

<hw>Im*prov"i*dent*ly</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>adv.</pos> <def>In
a improvident manner.</def> \'bd<xex>Improvidently</xex>
rash.\'b8

<au>Drayton.</au>

<hw>Im*prov"ing</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>a.</pos> <def>Tending to
improve, beneficial; growing better.</def> --
<wordforms><wf>Im*prov"ing*ly</wf>, <pos>adv.</pos></wordforms>

<cs><col>Improving lease</col> <fld>(Scots Law)</fld>, <cd>an
extend lease to induce the tenant to make improvements on the
premises.</cd></cs>

<er>Improvise</er>.]</ety> <def>Unpremeditated; impromptu;
extempore.</def> <mark>[R.]</mark>

<hw>Im*prov"i*sate</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>v. t. & i.</pos>
<wordforms>[<pos>imp. & p. p.</pos> <er>Improvisated</er>
<pr>(?)</pr>; <pos>p. pr. & vb. n.</pos> <er>Improvisating</er>

<hw>Im*prov`i*sa"tion</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[Cf.

art of composing and rendering music, poetry, and the like,
extemporaneously; <as>as, <ex>improvisation</ex> on the
organ</as>.</def>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>That which is improvised; an impromptu.</def>

<def>Same as <er>Improvisate</er>.</def>

<hw>Im`pro*vise"</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>v. t.</pos>
<wordforms>[<pos>imp. & p. p.</pos> <er>Improvised</er>
<pr>(?)</pr>; <pos>p. pr. & vb. n.</pos>
<er>Improvising</er>.]</wordforms> <ety>[F.
<ets>improviser</ets>, it. <ets>improvvisare</ets>, fr.
<ets>improvviso</ets> unprovided, sudden, extempore, L.
<ets>improvisus</ets>; pref. <ets>im-</ets> not +
<ets>provisus</ets> foreseen, provided. See
<er>Proviso</er>.]</ety> <sn>1.</sn> <def>To compose, recite, or
sing extemporaneously, especially in verse; to extemporize; also,
to play upon an instrument, or to act, extemporaneously.</def>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>To bring about, arrange, or make, on a sudden,
or without previous preparation.</def>

<q>Charles attempted to <qex>improvise</qex> a peace.</q>
<qau>Motley.</qau>

<sn>3.</sn> <def>To invent, or provide, offhand, or on the spur
of the moment; <as>as, he <ex>improvised</ex> a hammer out of a
stone</as>.</def>

<hw>Im`pro*vise"</hw>, <pos>v. i.</pos> <def>To produce or render
extemporaneous compositions, especially in verse or in music,
without previous preparation; hence, to do anything
offhand.</def>

<hw>Im`pro*vis"er</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <def>One who
improvises.</def>

<hw>Im`pro*vi"sion</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[Pref.
<ets>im-</ets> not + <ets>provision</ets>.]</ety>
<def>Improvidence.</def> <mark>[Obs.]</mark>

<au>Sir T. Browne.</au>

<hw>Im`pro*vi"so</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>a.</pos> <ety>[L.
<ets>improvisus</ets> unforeseen; cf. It.
<ets>improvviso</ets>.]</ety> <def>Not prepared or mediated
beforehand; extemporaneous.</def> <mark>[Obs.]</mark>

<au>Jonhson.</au>

<hw>Im*pru"dence</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[L.
<ets>imprudentia</ets>: cf. F. <ets>imprudence</ets>. Cf.
<er>Improvidence</er>.]</ety> <def>The quality or state of being
imprudent; want to caution, circumspection, or a due regard to
consequences; indiscretion; inconsideration; reshness; also, an
imprudent act; <as>as, he was guilty of an
<ex>imprudence</ex></as>.</def>

<q>His serenity was interrupted, perhaps, by his own
<qex>imprudence</qex>.</q>
<qau>Mickle.</qau>

<hw>Im*pru"dent</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>a.</pos> <ety>[L.
<ets>imprudens</ets>; pref. <ets>im-</ets> not +
<ets>prudens</ets> prudent: cf. F. <ets>imprudent</ets>. See
<er>Prudent</er>, and cf. <er>Improvident</er>.]</ety> <def>Not
prudent; wanting in prudence or discretion; indiscreet;
injudicious; not attentive to consequence; improper.</def> --
<wordforms><wf>Im*pru"dent*ly</wf>, <pos>adv.</pos></wordforms>

<q>Her majesty took a great dislike at the <qex>imprudent</qex>
behavior of many of the ministers and readers.</q>
<qau>Strype.</qau>

<-- p. 740 -->

<syn>Syn. -- Indiscreet; injudicious; incautious; ill-advised;
unwise; heedless; careless; rash; negligent.</syn>

<hw>Im*pu"ber*al</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>a.</pos> <def>Not having
arrived at puberty; immature.</def>

<q>In <qex>impuberal</qex> animals the cerebellum is, in
proportion to the brain proper, greatly less than in adults.</q>
<qau>Sir W. Hamilton.</qau>

<hw>Im*pu"ber*ty</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <def>The
condition of not having reached puberty, or the age of ability to
reproduce one's species; want of age at which the marriage
contract can be legally entered into.</def>

<hw>Im"pu*dence</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[L.
<ets>impudentia</ets>: cf. F. <ets>impudence</ets>. See
<er>Impudent</er>.]</ety> <def>The quality of being impudent;
assurance, accompanied with a disregard of the presence or
opinions of others; shamelessness; forwardness; want of
modesty.</def>

<q>Clear truths that their own evidence forces us to admit, or
common experience makes it <qex>impudence</qex> to deny.</q>
<qau>Locke.</qau>

<q>Where pride and <qex>impudence</qex> (in fashion knit)
Usurp the chair of wit.</q>
<qau>B. Jonson.</qau>

<syn>Syn. -- Shamelessness; audacity; insolence; effrontery;
sauciness; impertinence; pertness; rudeness.</syn> <usage> --
<er>Impudence</er>, <er>Effrontery</er>, <er>Sauciness</er>.
<xex>Impudence</xex> refers more especially to the feelings as
manifested in action. <xex>Effrontery</xex> applies to some gross
and public exhibition of shamelessness. <xex>Sauciness</xex>
refers to a sudden pert outbreak of impudence, especially from an
inferior. <xex>Impudence</xex> is an unblushing kind of
impertinence, and may be manifested in words, tones, gestures,
looks, etc. <xex>Effrontery</xex> rises still higher, and shows a
total or shameless disregard of duty or decorum under the
circumstances of the case. <xex>Sauciness</xex> discovers itself
toward particular individuals, in certain relations; as in the
case of servants who are saucy to their masters, or children who
are saucy to their teachers. See <er>Impertinent</er>, and
<er>Insolent</er>.</usage>

<hw>Im"pu*den*cy</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos>
<def>Impudence.</def> <mark>[Obs.]</mark>

<au>Burton.</au>

<q>Audacious without <qex>impudency</qex>.</q>
<qau>Shak.</qau>

<hw>Im"pu*dent</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>a.</pos> <ety>[L.
<ets>impudens</ets>, <ets>-entis</ets>; pref. <ets>im-</ets> not
+ <ets>pudens</ets> ashamed, modest, p. pr. of <ets>pudere</ets>
to feel shame: cf. F. <ets>impudent</ets>.]</ety> <def>Bold, with
contempt or disregard; unblushingly forward; impertinent; wanting
modesty; shameless; saucy.</def>

<q>More than <qex>impudent</qex> sauciness.</q>
<qau>Shak.</qau>

<q>When we behold an angel, not to fear
Is to be <qex>impudent</qex>.</q>
<qau>Dryden.</qau>

<syn>Syn. -- Shameless; audacious; brazen; bold-faced; pert;
immodest; rude; saucy; impertinent; insolent.</syn>

<hw>Im"pu*dent*ly</hw>, <pos>adv.</pos> <def>In an impudent
manner; with unbecoming assurance; shamelessly.</def>

<q>At once assail
With open mouths, and <qex>impudently</qex> rail.</q>
<qau>Sandys.</qau>

<hw>Im`pu*dic"i*ty</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[L.
<ets>impudicus</ets> immodest; <ets>im-</ets> not +
<ets>pudicus</ets> shamefaced, modest: cf. F.
<ets>impudicit\'82</ets>, L. <ets>impudicitia</ets>.]</ety>
<def>Immodesty.</def>

<au>Sheldon.</au>

<hw>Im*pugn"</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>v. t.</pos>
<wordforms>[<pos>imp. & p. p.</pos> <er>Impugned</er>
<pr>(?)</pr>; <pos>p. pr. & vb. n.</pos>
<er>Impugning</er>.]</wordforms> <ety>[OE. <ets>impugnen</ets>,
F. <ets>impugner</ets>, fr. L. <ets>impugnare</ets>;
<ets>in</ets> on, against + <ets>pugnare</ets> to flight. See
<er>Pugnacious</er>.]</ety> <def>To attack by words or arguments;
to contradict; to assail; to call in question; to make
insinuations against; to gainsay; to oppose.</def>

<q>The truth hereof I will net rashly <qex>pugn</qex>, or
overboldly affirm.</q>
<qau>Peacham.</qau>

<hw>Im*pugn"a*ble</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>a.</pos> <def>Capable
of being impugned; that may be gainsaid.</def>

<hw>Im`pug*na"tion</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[L.
<ets>impugnatio</ets>: cf. OF. <ets>impugnation</ets>.]</ety>
<def>Act of impugning; opposition; attack.</def>
<mark>[Obs.]</mark>

<q>A perpetual <qex>impugnation</qex> and self-conflict.</q>
<qau>Bp. Hall.</qau>

<hw>Im*pugn"er</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <def>One who
impugns.</def>

<hw>Im*pugn"ment</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <def>The act of
impugning, or the state of being impugned.</def>

<au>Ed. Rev.</au>

<hw>Im*pu"is*sance</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[Cf. F.
<ets>impuissance</ets>.]</ety> <def>Lack of power;

<au>Bacon.</au>

<q>Their own <qex>impuissance</qex> and weakness.</q>

<hw>Im*pu"is*sant</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>a.</pos> <ety>[F., fr.
pref. <ets>im-</ets> not +  <ets>puissant</ets>. See
<er>Puissant</er>.]</ety> <def>Weak; impotent; feeble.</def>

<hw>Im"pulse</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[L.
<ets>impulsus</ets>, fr. <ets>impellere</ets>. See
<er>Impel</er>.]</ety>

<sn>1.</sn> <def>The act of impelling, or driving onward with
sudden force; impulsion; especially, force so communicated as to
produced motion suddenly, or immediately.</def>

<q>All spontaneous animal motion is performed by mechanical
<qex>impulse</qex>.</q>
<qau>S. Clarke.</qau>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>The effect of an impelling force; motion
produced by a sudden or momentary force.</def>

<sn>3.</sn> <fld>(Mech.)</fld> <def>The action of a force during
a very small interval of time; the effect of such action; <as>as,
the <ex>impulse</ex> of a sudden blow upon a hard elastic
body</as>.</def>

<sn>4.</sn> <def>A mental force which simply and directly urges
to action; hasty inclination; sudden motive; momentary or
transient influence of appetite or passion; propension;
incitement; <as>as, a man of good <ex>impulses</ex>; passion
often gives a violent <ex>impulse</ex> to the will.</as></def>

<q>These were my natural <qex>impulses</qex> for the
undertaking.</q>
<qau>Dryden.</qau>

<syn>Syn. -- Force; incentive; influence; motive; feeling;
incitement; instigation.</syn>

<hw>Im*pulse"</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>v. t.</pos> <ety>[See
<er>Impel</er>.]</ety> <def>To impel; to incite.</def>
<mark>[Obs.]</mark>

<au>Pope.</au>

<hw>Im*pul"sion</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[L.
<ets>impulsio</ets>: cf. F. <ets>impulsion</ets>. See
<er>Impel</er>.]</ety>

<sn>1.</sn> <def>The act of impelling or driving onward, or the
state of being impelled; the sudden or momentary agency of a body
in motion on another body; also, the impelling force, or
impulse.</def> \'bdThe <xex>impulsion</xex> of the air.\'b8

<au>Bacon.</au>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>Influence acting unexpectedly or temporarily on
the mind; sudden motive or influence; impulse.</def> \'bdThe
<xex>impulsion</xex> of conscience.\'b8 <au>Clarendon</au>.
\'bdDivine <xex>impulsion</xex> prompting.\'b8

<au>Milton.</au>

<hw>Im*pul"sive</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>a.</pos> <ety>[Cf. F.
<ets>impulsif</ets>.]</ety>

<sn>1.</sn> <def>Having the power of driving or impelling; giving
an impulse; moving; impellent.</def>

<q>Poor men! poor papers! We and they
Do some <qex>impulsive</qex> force obey.</q>
<qau>Prior.</qau>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>Actuated by impulse or by transient
feelings.</def>

<q>My heart, <qex>impulsive</qex> and wayward.</q>
<qau>Longfellow.</qau>

<sn>3.</sn> <fld>(Mech.)</fld> <def>Acting momentarily, or by
impulse; not continuous; -- said of forces.</def>

<hw>Im*pul"sive</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <def>That which
impels or gives an impulse; an impelling agent.</def>

<au>Sir W. Wotton.</au>

<hw>Im*pul"sive*ly</hw>, <pos>adv.</pos> <def>In an impulsive
manner.</def>

<hw>Im*pul"sive*ness</hw>, <pos>n.</pos> <def>The quality of
being impulsive.</def>

<def>One who, or that which, impels; an inciter.</def>
<mark>[R.]</mark>

<au>Sir T. Browne.</au>

<hw>Im*pune"</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>a.</pos> <ety>[L.
<ets>impunis</ets>.]</ety> <def>Unpunished.</def>
<mark>[R.]</mark>

<hw>Im*pu"ni*bly</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>adv.</pos> <def>Without

<hw>Im*pu"ni*ty</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[L.
<ets>impunitas</ets>, fr. <ets>impunis</ets> without punishment;
pref. <ets>im-</ets> not + <ets>poena</ets> punishment: cf. F.
<ets>impunit\'82</ets>. See <er>Pain</er>.]</ety> <def>Exemption
or freedom from punishment, harm, or loss.</def>

<q>Heaven, though slow to wrath,
Is ne<?/<?/<?/ with <qex>impunity</qex> defied.</q>
<qau>Cowper.</qau>

<q>The <qex>impunity</qex> and also the recompense.</q>
<qau>Holland.</qau>

<hw>Im`pu*ra"tion</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos>
<def>Defilement; obscuration.</def> <mark>[Obs.]</mark>

<au>Bp. Hall.</au>

<hw>Im*pure"</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>a.</pos> <ety>[L.
<ets>impurus</ets>; pref. <ets>im-</ets> not + <ets>purus</ets>
pure: cf. F. <ets>impur</ets>. See <er>Pure</er>.]</ety>

<sn>1.</sn> <def>Not pure; not clean; dirty; foul; filthy;
containing something which is unclean or unwholesome; mixed or
impregnated extraneous substances; adulterated; <as>as,
<ex>impure</ex> water or air; <ex>impure</ex> drugs, food,
etc.</as></def>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>Defiled by sin or guilt; unholy; unhallowed; --
said of persons or things.</def>

<sn>3.</sn> <def>Unchaste; lewd; unclean; obscene; <as>as,
<ex>impure</ex> language or ideas</as>.</def>
\'bd<xex>Impure</xex> desires.\'b8

<au>Cowper.</au>

<sn>4.</sn> <fld>(Script.)</fld> <def>Not purified according to
the ceremonial law of Moses; unclean.</def>

<sn>5.</sn> <fld>(Language)</fld> <def>Not accurate; not
idiomatic; <as>as, <ex>impure</ex> Latin; an <ex>impure</ex>
style.</as></def>

<hw>Im*pure"</hw>, <pos>v. t.</pos> <def>To defile; to
pollute.</def> <mark>[Obs.]</mark>

<au>Bp. Hall.</au>

<hw>Im*pure"ly</hw>, <pos>adv.</pos> <def>In an impure
manner.</def>

<hw>Im*pure"ness</hw>, <pos>n.</pos> <def>The quality or
condition of being impure; impurity.</def>

<au>Milton.</au>

<hw>Im*pu"ri*ty</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos>; <plu>pl.
Impurities <pr>(#)</pr></plu>. <ety>[L. <ets>impuritas</ets>: cf.
F. <ets>impuret\'82</ets>.]</ety>

<sn>1.</sn> <def>The condition or quality of being impure in any
sense; defilement; foulness; adulteration.</def>

<q>Profaneness, <qex>impurity</qex>, or scandal, is not wit.</q>
<qau>Buckminster.</qau>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>That which is, or which renders anything,
impure; foul matter, action, language, etc.; a foreign
ingredient.</def>

<q>Foul <qex>impurities</qex> reigned among the monkish
clergy.</q>
<qau>Atterbury.</qau>

<sn>3.</sn> <fld>(Script.)</fld> <def>Want of ceremonial purity;
defilement.</def>

<hw>Im*pur"ple</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>v. t.</pos>
<wordforms>[<pos>imp. & p. p.</pos> <er>Impurpled</er>
<pr>(?)</pr>; <pos>p. pr. & vb. n.</pos> <er>Impurpling</er>
<pr>(?)</pr>.]</wordforms> <ety>[Pref. <ets>im-</ets> in +
<ets>purple</ets>. Cf. <er>Empurple</er>.]</ety> <def>To color or
tinge with purple; to make red or reddish; to purple; <as>as, a
field <ex>impurpled</ex> with blood</as>.</def>

<q><qex>Impurpled</qex> with celestial roses, smiled.</q>
<qau>Milton.</qau>

<q>The silken fleece <qex>impurpled</qex> for the loom.</q>
<qau>Pope.</qau>

<hw>In*put`a*bil"i*ty</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <def>The
quality of being imputable; imputableness.</def>

<hw>Im*put"a*ble</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>a.</pos> <ety>[Cf. F.
<ets>imputable</ets>.]</ety>

<sn>1.</sn> <def>That may be imputed; capable of being imputed;
chargeable; ascribable; attributable; referable.</def>

<q>A prince whose political vices, at least, were
<qex>imputable</qex> to mental incapacity.</q>
<qau>Prescott.</qau>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>Accusable; culpable.</def> <mark>[R.]</mark>

<q>The fault lies at his door, and she is no wise
<qex>imputable</qex>.</q>
<qau>Ayliffe.</qau>

<hw>Im*put"a*ble*ness</hw>, <pos>n.</pos> <def>Quality of being
imputable.</def>

<hw>Im*put"a*bly</hw>, <pos>adv.</pos> <def>By imputation.</def>

<hw>Im`pu*ta"tion</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <ety>[L.
<ets>imputatio</ets> an account, a charge: cf. F.
<ets>imputation</ets>.]</ety>

<sn>1.</sn> <def>The act of imputing or charging; attribution;
ascription; also, anything imputed or charged.</def>

<q><qex>Shylock</qex>. Antonio is a good man.
<qex>Bassanio</qex>. Have you heard any <qex>imputation</qex> to
the contrary?</q>
<qau>Shak.</qau>

<q>If I had a suit to Master Shallow, I would humor his men with
the <qex>imputation</qex> of being near their master.</q>
<qau>Shak.</qau>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>Charge or attribution of evil; censure;
reproach; insinuation.</def>

<q>Let us be careful to guard ourselves against these groundless
<qex>imputation</qex> of our enemies.</q>
<qau>Addison.</qau>

<sn>3.</sn> <fld>(Theol.)</fld> <def>A setting of something to
the account of; the attribution of personal guilt or personal
righteousness of another; <as>as, the <ex>imputation</ex> of the
sin of Adam, or the righteousness of Christ</as>.</def>

<sn>4.</sn> <def>Opinion; intimation; hint.</def>

<hw>Im*put"a*tive</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>a.</pos> <ety>[L.
<ets>imputativus</ets>: cf. F. <ets>imputatif</ets>.]</ety>
<def>Transferred by imputation; that may be imputed.</def> --
<wordforms><wf>Im*put"a*tive*ly</wf>, <pos>adv.</pos></wordforms>

<q>Actual righteousness as well as <qex>imputative</qex>.</q>
<qau>Bp. Warburton.</qau>

<hw>Im*pute"</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>v. t.</pos>
<wordforms>[<pos>imp. & p. p.</pos> <er>Imputed</er>; <pos>p. pr.
& vb. n.</pos> <er>Imputing</er>.]</wordforms> <ety>[F.
<ets>imputer</ets>, L. <ets>imputare</ets> to bring into the
reckoning, charge, impute; pref. <ets>im-</ets> in +
<ets>putare</ets> to reckon, think. See <er>Putative</er>.]</ety>

<sn>1.</sn> <def>To charge; to ascribe; to attribute; to set to
the account of; to charge to one as the author, responsible
originator, or possessor; -- generally in a bad sense.</def>

<q>Nor you, ye proud, <qex>impute</qex> to these the fault,
If memory o'er their tomb no trophies raise.</q>
<qau>Gray.</qau>

<q>One vice of a darker shade was <qex>imputed</qex> to him --
envy.</q>
<qau>Macaulay.</qau>

<sn>2.</sn> <fld>(Theol.)</fld> <def>To adjudge as one's own (the
sin or righteousness) of another; <as>as, the righteousness of
Christ is <ex>imputed</ex> to us</as>.</def>

<q>It was <qex>imputed</qex> to him for
<qex>righteousness</qex>.</q>
<qau>Rom. iv. 22.</qau>

<q>They merit
<qex>Imputed</qex> shall absolve them who renounce
Their own, both righteous and unrighteous deeds.</q>
<qau>Milton.</qau>

<sn>3.</sn> <def>To take account of; to consider; to
regard.</def> <mark>[R.]</mark>

<q>If we <qex>impute</qex> this last humiliation as the cause of
his death.</q>
<qau>Gibbon.</qau>

<syn>Syn. -- To ascribe; attribute; charge; reckon; consider;
imply; insinuate; refer. See <er>Ascribe</er>.</syn>

<hw>Im*put"er</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <def>One who
imputes.</def>

<hw>Im`pu*tres"ci*ble</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>a.</pos>
<ety>[Pref. <ets>im-</ets> + <ets>putrescible</ets>: cf. F.
<ets>imputrescible</ets>.]</ety> <def>Not putrescible.</def>

<hw>Im"righ</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[Scot.; Gael.
<ets><?/un-bhrigh</ets> chicken soup.]</ety> <def>A peculiar
strong soup or broth, made in Scotland.</def> <altsp>[Written
also <asp>imrich</asp>.]</altsp>

<hw>In-</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>. <ety>[See <er>In</er>,
<pos>prep.</pos>  Cf. <er>Em-</er>, <er>En-</er>.]</ety> <def>A
prefix from Eng. prep. <xex>in</xex>, also from Lat. prep.
<xex>in</xex>, meaning <xex>in</xex>, <xex>into</xex>,
<xex>on</xex>, <xex>among</xex>; <as>as, <ex>in</ex>bred,
<ex>in</ex>born, <ex>in</ex>road; <xex>in</xex>cline,
<xex>in</xex>ject, <xex>in</xex>trude. In words from the Latin,
<xex>in-</xex> regularly becomes <xex>il-</xex> before
<xex>l</xex>, <xex>ir-</xex> before <xex>r</xex>, and
<xex>im-</xex> before a labial; <as>as, <ex>il</ex>lusion,
<ex>ir</ex>ruption, <ex>im</ex>blue, <ex>im</ex>migrate,
<ex>im</ex>part</as>. <xex>In-</xex> is sometimes used with an
simple intensive force.</def>

<hw>In-</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>. <ety>[L. <ets>in</ets>-; akin to E.
<ets>un</ets>-. See <er>Un-</er>.]</ety> <def>An inseparable
prefix, or particle, meaning <xex>not</xex>, <xex>non</xex>-,
<xex>un-</xex> as, <xex>in</xex>active, <xex>in</xex>capable,
<xex>in</xex>apt. <xex>In-</xex> regularly becomes <xex>il-</xex>
before <xex>l</xex>, <xex>ir-</xex> before <xex>r</xex>, and
<xex>im-</xex> before a labial.</def>

<hw>-in</hw>. <def>A suffix. See the Note under
<er>-ine</er>.</def>

<hw>In</hw>, <pos>prep.</pos> <ety>[AS. <ets>in</ets>; akin to D.
& G. <ets>in</ets>, Icel. <ets>\'c6</ets>, Sw. & Dan.
<ets>i</ets>, OIr. & L. <ets>in</ets>, Gr. <?/. <?/<?/<?/<?/. Cf.
1st <er>In-</er>, <er>Inn</er>.]</ety> <def>The specific
signification of <xex>in</xex> is situation or place with respect
to surrounding, environment, encompassment, etc. It is used with
verbs signifying being, resting, or moving within limits, or
within circumstances or conditions of any kind conceived of as
limiting, confining, or investing, either wholly or in part. In
its different applications, it approaches some of the meanings
of, and sometimes is interchangeable with, <xex>within</xex>,
<xex>into</xex>, <xex>on</xex>, <xex>at</xex>, <xex>of</xex>, and
<xex>among</xex>.</def> It is used: --

<sn>1.</sn> <def>With reference to space or place; <as>as, he
lives <ex>in</ex> Boston; he traveled <ex>in</ex> Italy; castles
<ex>in</ex> the air.</as></def>

<q>The babe lying <qex>in</qex> a manger.</q>
<qau>Luke ii. 16.</qau>

<q>Thy sun sets weeping <qex>in</qex> the lowly west.</q>
<qau>Shak.</qau>

<q>Situated <qex>in</qex> the forty-first degree of latitude.</q>
<qau>Gibbon.</qau>

<q>Matter for censure <qex>in</qex> every page.</q>
<qau>Macaulay.</qau>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>With reference to circumstances or conditions;
<as>as, he is <ex>in</ex> difficulties; she stood <ex>in</ex> a
blaze of light.</as></def> \'bdFettered <xex>in</xex> amorous
chains.\'b8

<au>Shak.</au>

<q>Wrapt <qex>in</qex> sweet sounds, as <qex>in</qex> bright
veils.</q>
<qau>Shelley.</qau>

<sn>3.</sn> <def>With reference to a whole which includes or
comprises the part spoken of; <as>as, the first <ex>in</ex> his
family; the first regiment <ex>in</ex> the army.</as></def>

<q>Nine <qex>in</qex> ten of those who enter the ministry.</q>
<qau>Swift.</qau>

<sn>4.</sn> <def>With reference to physical surrounding, personal
states, etc., abstractly denoted; <as>as, I am <ex>in</ex> doubt;
the room is <ex>in</ex> darkness; to live <ex>in</ex>
fear.</as></def>

<q>When shall we three meet again,
<qex>In</qex> thunder, lightning, or <qex>in</qex> rain?</q>
<qau>Shak.</qau>

<sn>5.</sn> <def>With reference to character, reach, scope, or
influence considered as establishing a limitation; <as>as, to be
<ex>in</ex> one's favor</as>.</def> \'bd<xex>In</xex> sight of
God's high throne.\'b8

<au>Milton.</au>

<q>Sounds inharmonious <qex>in</qex> themselves, and harsh.</q>
<qau>Cowper.</qau>

<sn>6.</sn> <def>With reference to movement or tendency toward a
certain limit or environment; -- sometimes equivalent to
<xex>into</xex>; <as>as, to put seed <ex>in</ex> the ground; to
fall <ex>in</ex> love; to end <ex>in</ex> death; to put our trust
<ex>in</ex> God.</as></def>

<q>He would not plunge his brother <qex>in</qex> despair.</q>
<qau>Addison.</qau>

<q>She had no jewels to deposit <qex>in</qex> their caskets.</q>
<qau>Fielding.</qau>

<sn>7.</sn> <def>With reference to a limit of time; <as>as,
<ex>in</ex> an hour; it happened <ex>in</ex> the last century;
<ex>in</ex> all my life.</as></def>

<cs><mcol><col>In as much as</col>, <or/ <col>Inasmuch
as</col></mcol>, <cd>in the degree that; in like manner as; in
consideration that; because that; since. See <er>Synonym</er> of
<er>Because</er>, and cf. <cref>For as much as</cref>, under
<er>For</er>, <pos>prep.</pos></cd> -- <col>In that</col>,
<cd>because; for the reason that.</cd> \'bdSome things they do
<xex>in that<xex> they are men . . . ; some things <xex>in
that<xex> they are men misled and blinded with error.\'b8
<au>Hooker</au>. -- <col>In the name of</col>, <cd>in behalf of;
on the part of; by authority; as, it was done <xex>in the name
of<xex> the people; -- often used in invocation, swearing,
praying, and the like.</cd> -- <col>To be in for it</col>.
<sd>(a)</sd> <cd>To be in favor of a thing; to be committed to a
course.</cd> <sd>(b)</sd> <cd>To be unable to escape from a
danger, penalty, etc.</cd> <mark>[Colloq.]</mark> -- <col>To
be</col> (<or/ <col>keep</col>) <col>in with</col></mcol>.
<sd>(a)</sd> <cd>To be close or near; <as>as, to <ex>keep<ex> a
ship <ex>in with<ex> the land</as>.</cd> <sd>(b)</sd> <cd>To be
on terms of friendship, familiarity, or intimacy with; to secure
and retain the favor of.</cd> <mark>[Colloq.]</mark></cs>

<syn>Syn. -- Into; within; on; at. See <er>At</er>.</syn>

<hw>In</hw>, <pos>adv.</pos> <sn>1.</sn> <def>Not out; within;
inside. <xex>In</xex>, the preposition, becomes an adverb by
omission of its object, leaving it as the representative of an
adverbial phrase, the context indicating what the omitted object
is; <as>as, he takes <ex>in</ex> the situation (<it>i.
e</it></xex>., he comprehends it <xex>in</xex> his mind); the
Republicans were <xex>in</xex> (<it>i. e.</it>, <xex>in</xex>
office); <xex>in</xex> at one ear and out at the other (<it>i.
e.</it>, <xex>in</xex> or <xex>into</xex> the head); his side was
<xex>in</xex> (<it>i. e.</it>, <xex>in</xex> the turn at the
bat); he came <xex>in</xex> (<it>i. e.</it>, into the
house).</def>

<q>Their vacation . . . falls <qex>in</qex> so pat with ours.</q>
<qau>Lamb.</qau>

<note><hand/ The sails of a vessel are said, in nautical
language, to be <xex>in</xex> when they are furled, or when
stowed.

   In certain cases <xex>in</xex> has an adjectival sense; as,
the <xex>in</xex> train (<it>i. e.</it>, the incoming train);
compare <xex>up</xex> grade, <xex>down</xex> grade,
<xex>under</xex>tow, <xex>after</xex>thought, etc.</note>

<sn>2.</sn> <fld>(Law)</fld> <def>With privilege or possession;
-- used to denote a holding, possession, or seisin; <as>as,
<ex>in</ex> by descent; <ex>in</ex> by purchase; <ex>in</ex> of
the seisin of her husband.</as></def>

<au>Burrill.</au>

<cs><col>In and in breeding</col>. <cd>See under
<er>Breeding</er>.</cd> -- <col>In and out</col>
<fld>(Naut.)</fld>, <cd>through and through; -- said of a through
bolt in a ship's side.</cd> <au>Knight</au>. -- <col>To be
in</col>, <cd>to be at home; <as>as, Mrs. A. <ex>is
in<ex></as>.</cd> -- <col>To come in</col>. <cd>See under
<er>Come</er>.</cd></cs>

<hw>In</hw>, <pos>n.</pos> <note>[Usually in the plural.]</note>

<sn>1.</sn> <def>One who is in office; -- the opposite of
<ant>out</ant>.</def>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>A re\'89ntrant angle; a nook or corner.</def>

<cs><col>Ins and outs</col>, <cd>nooks and corners; twists and
turns.</cd></cs><-- (b) (with "of") the peculiarities or
technicalities (of a subject) -->

<q>All the <qex>ins and outs</qex> of this neighborhood.</q>
<qau>D. Jerrold.</qau>

<-- p. 741 -->

<q>He that ears my land spares my team and gives me leave to
<qex>in</qex> the crop.</q>
<qau>Shak.</qau>

<hw>In`a*bil"i*ty</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[Pref.
<ets>in-</ets> not + <ets>ability</ets>: cf. F.
<ets>inhabilet\'82</ets>. See <er>Able</er>, and cf.
<er>Unable</er>.]</ety> <def>The quality or state of being
unable; lack of ability; want of sufficient power, strength,
resources, or capacity.</def>

<q>It is not from an <qex>inability</qex> to discover what they
ought to do, that men err in practice.</q>
<qau>Blair.</qau>

<syn>Syn. -- Impotence; incapacity; incompetence; weakness;
powerlessness; incapability. See <er>Disability</er>.</syn>

<hw>In*ac"cu*ra*cy</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos>; <plu>pl.
<plw>Inaccuracies</plw> <pr>(<?/)</pr>.</plu>

<sn>1.</sn> <def>The quality of being inaccurate; want of
accuracy or exactness.</def>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>That which is inaccurate or incorrect; mistake;
fault; defect; error; <as>as, in <ex>inaccuracy</ex> in speech,
copying, calculation, etc.</as></def>

<hw>In*ac"cu*rate</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>a.</pos> <def>Not
accurate; not according to truth; inexact; incorrect; erroneous;
<as>as, in <ex>inaccurate</ex> man, narration, copy, judgment,
calculation, etc.</as></def>

<q>The expression is plainly <qex>inaccurate</qex>.</q>
<qau>Bp. Hurd.</qau>

<syn>Syn. -- Inexact; incorrect; erroneous; faulty; imperfect;
incomplete; defective.</syn>

<hw>In*ac"cu*rate*ly</hw>, <pos>adv.</pos> <def>In an inaccurate

<hw>In*ac"tion</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[Pref.
<ets>in</ets>. not + <ets>action</ets>: cf.
<ets>inaction</ets>.]</ety> <def>Want of action or activity;
forbearance from labor; idleness; rest; inertness.</def>

<au>Berkeley.</au>

<hw>In*ac"tive</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>a.</pos> <ety>[Pref.
<ets>in-</ets> not + <ets>active</ets>: cf. F.
<ets>inactif</ets>.]</ety>

<sn>1.</sn> <def>Not active; having no power to move; that does
not or can not produce results; inert; <as>as, matter is, of
itself, <ex>inactive</ex></as>.</def>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>Not disposed to action or effort; not diligent
or industrious; not busy; idle; <as>as, an <ex>inactive</ex>
officer</as>.</def>

<sn>3.</sn> <fld>(Chem. & Opt.)</fld> <def>Not active; inert;
esp., not exhibiting any action or activity on polarized light;
optically neutral; -- said of isomeric forms of certain
substances, in distinction from other forms which are optically
active; <as>as, racemic acid is an <ex>inactive</ex> tartaric
acid</as>.</def>

<syn>Syn. -- Inert; dull; sluggish; idle; indolent; slothful;
lazy. See <er>Inert</er>.</syn>

<hw>In*ac"tive*ly</hw>, <pos>adv.</pos> <def>In an inactive
manner.</def>

<au>Locke.</au>

<hw>In`ac*tiv"i*ty</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[Cf. F.
<ets>inactivit\'82</ets>.]</ety>

<sn>1.</sn> <def>The state or quality of being inactive;
inertness; <as>as, the <ex>inactivity</ex> of matter</as>.</def>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>Idleness; habitual indisposition to action or
exertion; want of energy; sluggishness.</def>

<q>The gloomy <qex>inactivity</qex> of despair.</q>
<qau>Cook.</qau>

<hw>In*ac"tose</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos>
<fld>(Chem.)</fld> <def>A variety of sugar, found in certain
plants. It is optically <xex>inactive</xex>.</def>

<hw>In*ac"tu*ate</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>v. t.</pos> <def>To put
in action.</def> <mark>[Obs.]</mark>

<hw>In*ac`tu*a"tion</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos>
<def>Operation.</def> <mark>[Obs.]</mark>

<hw>In*ad`ap*ta"tion</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <def>Want
of adaptation; unsuitableness.</def>

<hw>In*ad"e*qua*cy</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[From
<er>Inadequate</er>.]</ety> <def>The quality or state of being
inadequate or insufficient; defectiveness; insufficiency;
inadequateness.</def>

<q>The <qex>inadequacy</qex> and consequent inefficacy of the
alleged causes.</q>
<qau>Dr. T. Dwight.</qau>

<hw>In`ad*mis"si*ble</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>a.</pos> <ety>[Pref.

<mhw>{ <hw>In`ad*vert"ence</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>; <plu>pl.
<plw>-ces</plw> <pr>(<?/)</pr></plu>, <hw>In`ad*vert"en*cy</hw>
<pr>(?)</pr>; <plu>pl. <plw>-cies</plw> <pr>(<?/)</pr></plu>,
}</mhw> <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[Cf. F.
<ets>inadvertance</ets>.]</ety>

<sn>1.</sn> <def>The quality of being inadvertent; lack of
heedfulness or attentiveness; inattention; negligence; <as>as,
many mistakes proceed from <ex>inadvertence</ex></as>.</def>

<q><qex>Inadvertency</qex>, or want of attendance to the sense
and intention of our prayers.</q>
<qau>Jer. Taylor.</qau>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>An effect of inattention; a result of
carelessness; an oversight, mistake, or fault from
negligence.</def>

<q>The productions of a great genius, with many lapses an
<qex>inadvertencies</qex>, are infinitely preferable to works of
an inferior kind of author which are scrupulously exact.</q>
<qau>Addison.</qau>

<syn>Syn. -- Inattention; heedlessness; carelessness; negligence;
thoughtlessness. See <er>Inattention</er>.</syn>

<er>Advert</er>.]</ety> <def>Not turning the mind to a matter;
heedless; careless; negligent; inattentive.</def>

<q>An <qex>inadvertent</qex> step may crush the snail
That crawls at evening in the public path.</q>
<qau>Cowper.</qau>

<hw>In`a*ni`ti*a"tion</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos>

<hw>In`a*ni"tion</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[F.
<ets>inanition</ets>, L. <ets>inanitio</ets> emptiness, fr.
<ets>inanire</ets> to empty, fr. <ets>inanis</ets> empty. Cf.
<er>Inane</er>.]</ety> <def>The condition of being inane;
emptiness; want of fullness, as in the vessels of the body;
hence, specifically, exhaustion from want of food, either from
partial or complete starvation, or from a disorder of the
digestive apparatus, producing the same result.</def>

<q>Feeble from <qex>inanition</qex>, inert from weariness.</q>
<qau>Landor.</qau>

<q>Repletion and <qex>inanition</qex> may both do harm in two
contrary extremes.</q>
<qau>Burton.</qau>

<ex>inanities</ex> of the world</as>.</def>

<hw>In`ar*tic"u*late</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>a.</pos> <ety>[L.
<ets>inarticulatus</ets>; pref. <ets>in-</ets> not +
<ets>articulatus</ets> articulate.]</ety>

<sn>1.</sn> <def>Not uttered with articulation or intelligible
distinctness, as speech or words.</def>

<q>Music which is <qex>inarticulate</qex> poesy.</q>
<qau>Dryden.</qau>

<sn>2.</sn> <fld>(Zo\'94l.)</fld> <sd>(a)</sd> <def>Not jointed
or articulated; having no distinct body segments; <as>as, an
<ex>inarticulate</ex> worm</as>.</def> <sd>(b)</sd> <def>Without
a hinge; -- said of an order (<spn>Inarticulata</spn> or
<spn>Ecardines</spn>) of brachiopods.</def>

<sn>3.</sn> <def>Incapable of articulating.</def>
<mark>[R.]</mark>

<q>The poor earl, who is <qex>inarticulate</qex> with palsy.</q>
<qau>Walpole.</qau>

<-- 4. incapable of expressing one's ideas or feelings clearly.
-->

<hw>In`as*much"</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>adv.</pos>
<ety>[<ets>In</ets> + <ets>as</ets> + <ets>much</ets>.]</ety>

<ets>in-</ets> not + <ets>attention</ets>: cf. F.
<ets>inattention</ets>.]</ety> <def>Want of attention, or failure
to pay attention; disregard; heedlessness; neglect.</def>

<q>Novel lays attract our ravished ears;
But old, the mind <qex>inattention</qex> hears.</q>
<qau>Pope.</qau>

<syn>Syn. -- Inadvertence; heedlessness; negligence;
carelessness; disregard; remissness; thoughtlessness; neglect. --
<er>Inattention</er>, <er>Inadvertence</er>. We miss seeing a
thing through <xex>inadvertence</xex> when <xex>do not happen to
look at</xex> it; through <xex>inattention</xex> when we
<xex>give no heed to</xex> it, though directly before us. The
latter is therefore the worse. <xex>Inadvertence</xex> may be an
involuntary accident; <xex>inattention</xex> is culpable neglect.
A versatile mind is often <xex>inadvertent</xex>; a careless or
stupid one is <xex>inattentive</xex>.</syn>

<-- p. 742 -->

<hw>In`at*ten"tive</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>a.</pos> <ety>[Cf. F.
<ets>inattentif</ets>.]</ety> <def>Not attentive; not fixing the
mind on an object; heedless; careless; negligent; regardless;
<as>as, an <ex>inattentive</ex> spectator or hearer; an
<ex>inattentive</ex> habit.</as></def>

<au>I. Watts.</au>

<syn>Syn. -- Careless; heedless; regardless; thoughtless;
negligent; remiss; inadvertent.</syn>

<wf>In`at*ten"tive*ness</wf>, <pos>n.</pos></wordforms>

<hw>In*au"gu*rate</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>a.</pos> <ety>[L.
<ets>inauguratus</ets>, p. p. of <ets>inaugurare</ets> to take
omens from the flight of birds (before entering upon any
important undertaking); hence, to consecrate, inaugurate, or
install, with such divination; pref. <ets>in-</ets> in +
<ets>augurare</ets>, <ets>augurari</ets>, to augur. See
<er>Augur</er>.]</ety> <def>Invested with office;

<au>Drayton.</au>

<hw>In*au"gu*rate</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>v. t.</pos>
<wordforms>[<pos>imp. & p. p.</pos> <er>Inaugurated</er>
<pr>(?)</pr>; <pos>p. pr. & vb. n.</pos> <er>Inaugurating</er>
<pr>(?)</pr>.]</wordforms>

<sn>1.</sn> <def>To introduce or induct into an office with
suitable ceremonies or solemnities; to invest with power or
authority in a formal manner; to install; <as>as, to
<ex>inaugurate</ex> a president; to <ex>inaugurate</ex> a
king.</as></def>

<au>Milton.</au>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>To cause to begin, esp. with formality or solemn
ceremony; hence, to set in motion, action, or progress; to
initiate; -- used especially of something of dignity or worth or
public concern; <as>as, to <ex>inaugurate</ex> a new era of
things, new methods, etc.</as></def>

<q>As if kings did closes remarkable days to
<qex>inaugurate</qex> their favors.</q>
<qau>Sir H. Wotton.</qau>

<sn>3.</sn> <def>To celebrate the completion of, or the first
public use of; to dedicate, as a statue.</def>
<mark>[Colloq.]</mark>

<sn>4.</sn> <def>To begin with good omens.</def>
<mark>[Obs.]</mark>

<au>Sir H. Wotton.</au>

<hw>In*au`gu*ra"tion</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[L.
<ets>inauguratio</ets> a beginning: cf. F.
<ets>inauguration</ets>.]</ety>

<sn>1.</sn> <def>The act of inuagurating, or inducting into
office with solemnity; investiture by appropriate
ceremonies.</def>

<q>At his regal <qex>inauguration</qex>, his old father resigned
the kingdom to him.</q>
<qau>Sir T. Browne.</qau>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>The formal beginning or initiation of any
movement, course of action, etc.; <as>as, the
<ex>inauguration</ex> of a new system, a new condition,
etc.</as></def>

<cs><mcol><col>Incandescent lamp</col> <or/

which the light is produced by a thin filament of conducting
material, usually carbon<-- usually tungsten! -->, contained in a
vacuum, and heated to incandescence by an electric current, as in
the Edison lamp; -- called also <altname>incandescence
lamp</altname>, and <altname>glowlamp</altname>.</cd></cs><--
incandescent bulb -- the light bulb used in an incandescent lamp;
contrasted with fluorescent lamp and fluorescent bulb -->

<hw>In*ca`pa*bil"i*ty</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos>
<sn>1.</sn> <def>The quality of being incapable;
incapacity.</def>

<au>Suckling.</au>

<sn>2.</sn> <fld>(Law)</fld> <def>Want of legal qualifications,
or of legal power; <as>as, <ex>incapability</ex> of holding an
office</as>.</def>

<hw>In*ca"pa*ble</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>a.</pos> <ety>[Pref.
<ets>in-</ets> not + <ets>capable</ets>: cf. F.
<ets>incapable</ets>, L. <ets>incapabilis</ets>
incomprehensible.]</ety>

<sn>1.</sn> <def>Wanting in ability or qualification for the
purpose or end in view; not large enough to contain or hold;
deficient in physical strength, mental or moral power, etc.; not
capable; <as>as, <ex>incapable</ex> of holding a certain quantity
of liquid; <ex>incapable</ex> of endurance, of comprehension, of
perseverance, of reform, etc.</as></def>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>Not capable of being brought to do or perform,
because morally strong or well disposed; -- used with reference
to some evil; <as>as, <ex>incapable</ex> of wrong, dishonesty, or
falsehood</as>.</def>

<sn>3.</sn> <def>Not in a state to receive; not receptive; not
susceptible; not able to admit; <as>as, <ex>incapable</ex> of
pain, or pleasure; <ex>incapable</ex> of stain or
injury.</as></def>

<sn>4.</sn> <fld>(Law)</fld> <def>Unqualified or disqualified, in
a legal sense; <as>as, a man under thirty-five years of age is
<ex>incapable</ex> of holding the office of president of the
United States; a person convicted on impeachment is thereby made
<ex>incapable</ex> of holding an office of profit or honor under
the government.</as></def>

<sn>5.</sn> <fld>(Mil.)</fld> <def>As a term of disgrace,
sometimes annexed to a sentence when an officer has been
cashiered and rendered <xex>incapable</xex> of serving his
country.</def>

<note><hand/ <xex>Incapable</xex> is often used
elliptically.</note>

<q>Is not your father grown <qex>incapable</qex> of reasonable
affairs?</q>
<qau>Shak.</qau>

<syn>Syn. -- Incompetent; unfit; unable; insufficient;
inadequate; deficient; disqualified. See
<er>Incompetent</er>.</syn>

mentally weak or inefficient; an imbecile; a simpleton.</def>

<hw>In*ca"pa*ble*ness</hw>, <pos>n.</pos> <def>The quality or
state of being incapable; incapability.</def>

<hw>In*ca"pa*bly</hw>, <pos>adv.</pos> <def>In an incapable
manner.</def>

<hw>In`ca*pa"cious</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>a.</pos> <ety>[Pref.

<ets>incapax</ets> incapable.]</ety> <def>Not capacious; narrow;

<hw>In`ca*pac"i*tate</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>v. t.</pos>
<wordforms>[<pos>imp. & p. p.</pos> <er>Incapacitated</er>
<pr>(?)</pr>; <pos>p. pr. & vb. n.</pos> <er>Incapacitating</er>
<pr>(?)</pr>.]</wordforms> <ety>[Pref. <ets>in-</ets> not +
<ets>capacitate</ets>.]</ety>

<sn>1.</sn> <def>To deprive of capacity or natural power; to
disable; to render incapable or unfit; to disqualify; <as>as, his
age <ex>incapacitated</ex> him for war</as>.</def>

<sn>2.</sn> <fld>(Law)</fld> <def>To deprive of legal or
constitutional requisites, or of ability or competency for the
performance of certain civil acts; to disqualify.</def>

<q>It absolutely <qex>incapacitated</qex> them from holding rank,
office, function, or property.</q>
<qau>Milman.</qau>

<hw>In`ca*pac`i*ta"tion</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <def>The
act of incapacitating or state of being incapacitated;
incapacity; disqualification.</def>

<au>Burke.</au>

<hw>In`ca*pac"i*ty</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos>; <plu>pl.
<plw>Incapacities</plw> <pr>(<?/)</pr></plu>. <ety>[Cf. F.
<ets>incapacit\'82</ets>.]</ety>

<sn>1.</sn> <def>Want of capacity; lack of physical or
intellectual power; inability.</def>

<sn>2.</sn> <fld>(Law)</fld> <def>Want of legal ability or
competency to do, give, transmit, or receive something;
inability; disqualification; <as>as, the <ex>inacapacity</ex> of
minors to make binding contracts, etc.</as></def>

<syn>Syn. -- Inability; incapability; incompetency; unfitness;
disqualification; disability.</syn>

<hw>In*cap"su*late</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>v. t.</pos>
<fld>(Physiol.)</fld> <def>To inclose completely, as in a
membrane.</def>

<hw>In*cap`su*la"tion</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos>
<fld>(Physiol.)</fld> <def>The process of becoming, or the state
or condition of being, incapsulated; <as>as,
<ex>incapsulation</ex> of the ovum in the uterus</as>.</def>

<hw>In*car"cer*ate</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>v. t.</pos>
<wordforms>[<pos>imp. & p. p.</pos> <er>Incarcerated</er>

fr. <ets>carcer</ets> prison.]</ety>

<sn>1.</sn> <def>To imprison; to confine in a jail or
priso<?/.</def>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>To confine; to shut up or inclose; to hem
in.</def>

<cs><col>Incarcerated hernia</col> <fld>(Med.)</fld>, <cd>hernia
in which the constriction can not be easily reduced.</cd></cs>

<hw>In*car"cer*ate</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>a.</pos>
<def>Imprisoned.</def>

<au>Dr. H. More.</au>

<hw>In*car`cer*a"tion</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[Cf.
F. <ets>incarc\'82ration</ets>.]</ety>

<sn>1.</sn> <def>The act of confining, or the state of being
confined; imprisonment.</def>

<au>Glanvill.</au>

<sn>2.</sn> <fld>(Med.)</fld> <sd>(a)</sd> <def>Formerly,
strangulation, as in hernia.</def> <sd>(b)</sd> <def>A
constriction of the hernial sac, rendering it irreducible, but
not great enough to cause strangulation.</def>

<hw>In*car"cer*a`tor</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <def>One
who incarcerates.</def>

or invest with flesh.</def> <mark>[R.]</mark>

<au>Wiseman.</au>

<hw>In*car"na*dine</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>a.</pos> <ety>[F.
<ets>incarnadin</ets>, It. <ets>incarnatino</ets>; L. pref.
<ets>in-</ets> in + <ets>caro</ets>, <ets>carnis</ets>, flesh.
Cf. <er>Carnation</er>, <er>Incarnate</er>.]</ety>
<def>Flesh-colored; of a carnation or pale red color.</def>
<mark>[Obs.]</mark>

<au>Lovelace.</au>

<hw>In*car"na*dine</hw>, <pos>v. t.</pos> <def>To dye red or
crimson.</def>

<q>Will all great Neptune's ocean wash this blood
Clean from my hand? No; this my hand will rather
The multitudinous seas <qex>incarnadine</qex>,
Making the green one red.</q>
<qau>Shak.</qau>

<hw>In*car"nate</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>a.</pos> <ety>[Pref.
<ets>in-</ets> not + <ets>carnate</ets>.]</ety> <def>Not in the
flesh; spiritual.</def> <mark>[Obs.]</mark>

<q>I fear nothing . . . that devil carnate or
<qex>incarnate</qex> can fairly do.</q>
<qau>Richardson.</qau>

<hw>In*car"nate</hw>, <pos>a.</pos> <ety>[L.
<ets>incarnatus</ets>, p. p. of <ets>incarnare</ets> to
incarnate, pref. <ets>in-</ets> in + <ets>caro</ets>,
<ets>carnis</ets>, flesh. See <er>Carnal</er>.]</ety>

<sn>1.</sn> <def>Invested with flesh; embodied in a human nature
and form; united with, or having, a human body.</def>

<q>Here shalt thou sit <qex>incarnate</qex>.</q>
<qau>Milton.</qau>

<q>He represents the emperor and his wife as two devils
<qex>incarnate</qex>, sent into the world for the destruction of
mankind.</q>
<qau>Jortin.</qau>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>Flesh-colored; rosy; red.</def>
<mark>[Obs.]</mark>

<au>Holland.</au>

<hw>In*car"nate</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>v. t.</pos>
<wordforms>[<pos>imp. & p. p.</pos> <er>Incarnated</er>
<pr>(?)</pr>; <pos>p. pr. & vb. n.</pos> <er>Incarnating</er>
<pr>(?)</pr>.]</wordforms> <def>To clothe with flesh; to embody
in flesh; to invest, as spirits, ideals, etc., with a human from
or nature.</def>

<q>This essence to <qex>incarnate</qex> and imbrute,
That to the height of deity aspired.</q>
<qau>Milton.</qau>

<hw>In*car"nate</hw>, <pos>v. i.</pos> <def>To form flesh; to
granulate, as a wound.</def> <mark>[R.]</mark>

<q>My uncle Toby's wound was nearly well -- 't was just beginning
to <qex>incarnate</qex>.</q>
<qau>Sterne.</qau>

<hw>In`car*na"tion</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[F.
<ets>incarnation</ets>, LL. <ets>incarnatio</ets>.]</ety>

<sn>1.</sn> <def>The act of clothing with flesh, or the state of
being so clothed; the act of taking, or being manifested in, a
human body and nature.</def>

<sn>2.</sn> <fld>(Theol.)</fld> <def>The union of the second
person of the Godhead with manhood in Christ.</def>

<sn>3.</sn> <def>An incarnate form; a personification; a
manifestation; a reduction to apparent from; a striking
exemplification in person or act.</def>

<q>She is a new <qex>incarnation</qex> of some of the illustrious
dead.</q>
<qau>Jeffrey.</qau>

<q>The very <qex>incarnation</qex> of selfishness.</q>
<qau>F. W. Robertson.</qau>

<sn>4.</sn> <def>A rosy or red color; flesh color;
carnation.</def> <mark>[Obs.]</mark>

<sn>5.</sn> <fld>(Med.)</fld> <def>The process of healing wounds
and filling the part with new flesh; granulation.</def>

<hw>In*car"na*tive</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>a.</pos> <ety>[Cf. F.
<ets>incarnatif</ets>.]</ety> <def>Causing new flesh to grow;
healing; regenerative.</def> -- <def2><pos>n.</pos> <def>An
incarnative medicine.</def></def2>

<hw>In*car`ni*fi*ca"tion</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos>
<ety>[See <er>Incarnation</er>, and <er>-fy</er>.]</ety> <def>The
act of assuming, or state of being clothed with, flesh;
incarnation.</def>

<ets>incautus</ets>.]</ety> <def>Not cautious; not circumspect;

<-- p. 743 -->

On fire with faithless embers overspread.</q>

<qex>incautious</qex> reader.</q>
<qau>Keill.</qau>

impolitic; careless; heedless; thoughtless.</syn>

<hw>In*cen"di*a*ry</hw> <pr>(?; 277)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos>;
<plu>pl. <plw>Incendiaries</plw> <pr>(#)</pr></plu>. <ety>[L.
<ets>incendiarius</ets>: cf. F. <ets>incendiaire</ets>. See
<er>Incense</er> to inflame.]</ety>

<sn>1.</sn> <def>Any person who maliciously sets fire to a
building or other valuable or other valuable property.</def>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>A person who excites or inflames factions, and
promotes quarrels or sedition; an agitator; an exciter.</def>

<q>Several cities . . . drove them out as
<qex>incendiaries</qex>.</q>
<qau>Bentley.</qau>

<hw>In*cen"di*a*ry</hw>, <pos>a.</pos> <ety>[L.
<ets>incendiarius</ets>, fr. <ets>incendium</ets> a fire,
conflagration: cf. F. <ets>incendiaire</ets>. See
<er>Incense</er> to inflame.]</ety>

<sn>1.</sn> <def>Of or pertaining to incendiarism, or the
malicious burning of valuable property; <as>as,
<ex>incendiary</ex> material; as <ex>incendiary</ex>
crime.</as></def>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>Tending to excite or inflame factions, sedition,
or quarrel; inflammatory; seditious.</def>

<au>Paley.</au>

<er>Carcass</er>, 4.</cd></cs>

<hw>In*cense"</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>v. t.</pos>
<wordforms>[<pos>imp. & p. p.</pos> <er>Incensed</er>
<pr>(?)</pr>; <pos>p. pr. & vb. n.</pos>
<er>Incensing</er>.]</wordforms> <ety>[L. <ets>incensus</ets>, p.
p. of <ets>incendere</ets>; pref. <ets>in-</ets> in + root of
<ets>candere</ets> to glow. See <er>Candle</er>.]</ety>

<sn>1.</sn> <def>To set on fire; to inflame; to kindle; to
burn.</def> <mark>[Obs.]</mark>

<q>Twelve Trojan princes wait on thee, and labor to
<qex>incense</qex>
Thy glorious heap of funeral.</q>
<qau>Chapman.</qau>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>To inflame with anger; to endkindle; to fire; to
incite; to provoke; to heat; to madden.</def>

<q>The people are <qex>incensed</qex> him.</q>
<qau>Shak.</qau>

<syn>Syn. -- To enrage; exasperate; provoke; anger; irritate;
heat; fire; instigate.</syn>

<hw>In"cense</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>v. t.</pos>
<wordforms>[<pos>imp. & p. p.</pos> <er>Incensed</er>
<pr>(?)</pr>; <pos>p. pr. & vb. n.</pos>
<er>Incensing</er>.]</wordforms> <ety>[LL. <ets>incensare</ets>:
cf. F. <ets>encenser</ets>. See <er>Incense</er>,
<pos>n.</pos>]</ety>

<sn>1.</sn> <def>To offer incense to. See <er>Incense</er>.</def>
<mark>[Obs.]</mark>

<au>Chaucer.</au>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>To perfume with, or as with, incense.</def>
\'bd<xex>Incensed</xex> with wanton sweets.\'b8

<au>Marston.</au>

<hw>In"cense</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[OE.
<ets>encens</ets>, F. <ets>encens</ets>, L. <ets>incensum</ets>,
fr. <ets>incensus</ets>, p. p. of <ets>incendere</ets> to burn.
See <er>Incense</er> to inflame.]</ety>

<sn>1.</sn> <def>The perfume or odors exhaled from spices and
gums when burned in celebrating religious rites or as an offering
to some deity.</def>

<q>A thick of <qex>incense</qex> went up.</q>
<qau>Ezek. viii. 11.</qau>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>The materials used for the purpose of producing
a perfume when burned, as fragrant gums, spices, frankincense,
etc.</def>

<q>Nadab and Abihu, the sons of Aaron, took either of them his
censer, and put fire therein, and put <qex>incense</qex>
thereon.</q>
<qau>Lev. x. 1.</qau>

<sn>3.</sn> <def>Also used figuratively.</def>

<q>Or heap the shrine of luxury and pride,</q>

<q>With <qex>incense</qex> kindled at the Muse's flame.</q>

<au>Gray.</au>

<cs><col>Incense tree</col>, <cd>the name of several balsamic
trees of the genus <spn>Bursera</spn> (or <spn>Icica</spn>)
mostly tropical American. The gum resin is used for incense. In
Jamaica the <spn>Chrysobalanus Icaco</spn>, a tree related to the
plums, is called <xex>incense tree<xex>.</cd> -- <col>Incense
wood</col>, <cd>the fragrant wood of the tropical American tree
<spn>Bursera heptaphylla</spn>.</cd></cs>

\'bd<xex>Incense-breathing</xex> morn.\'b8

<hw>In*cen"tive</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>a.</pos> <ety>[L.
<ets>incentivus</ets>, from <ets>incinere</ets> to strike up or
set the tune; pref. <ets>in-</ets> + <ets>canere</ets> to sing.
See <er>Enchant</er>, <er>Chant</er>.]</ety>

<sn>1.</sn> <def>Inciting; encouraging or moving; rousing to
action; stimulative.</def>

<q>Competency is the most <qex>incentive</qex> to industry.</q>
<qau>Dr. H. More.</qau>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>Serving to kindle or set on fire.</def>
<mark>[R.]</mark>

<q>Part <qex>incentive</qex> reed</q>

<q>Provide, pernicious with one touch of fire.</q>

<au>Milton.</au>

<hw>In*cen"tive</hw>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[L.
<ets>incentivum</ets>.]</ety> <def>That which moves or influences
the mind, or operates on the passions; that which incites, or has
a tendency to incite, to determination or action; that which
prompts to good or ill; motive; spur; <as>as, the love of money,
and the desire of promotion, are two powerful <ex>incentives</ex>
to action</as>.</def>

<q>The greatest obstacles, the greatest terrors that come in
their way, are so far from making them quit the work they had
begun, that they rather prove <qex>incentives</qex> to them to go
on in it.</q>
<qau>South.</qau>

<syn>Syn. -- Motive; spur; stimulus; incitement; encouragement;
inducement; influence.</syn>

<hw>In*cen"tive*ly</hw>, <pos>adv.</pos> <def>Incitingly;
encouragingly.</def>

<hw>\'d8In*cer"tum</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>a.</pos>
<def>Doubtful; not of definite form.</def>

<cs><col>Opus incertum</col> <fld>(Anc. Arch.)</fld>, <cd>a kind
of masonry employed in building walls, in which the stones were
not squared nor laid in courses; rubblework.</cd></cs>

<hw>In*ces"sa*ble</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>a.</pos> <ety>[L.
<ets>incessabilis</ets>; pref. <ets>in-</ets> not +
<ets>cessare</ets> to cease.]</ety> <def>Unceasing;
continual.</def> <mark>[Obs.]</mark> <au>Shelton</au>. --
<wordforms><wf>In*ces"sa*bly</wf>, <pos>adv.</pos>
<mark>[Obs.]</mark></wordforms>

<hw>In*ces"san*cy</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[From
<er>Incessant</er>.]</ety> <def>The quality of being incessant;
unintermitted continuance; unceasingness.</def>

<au>Dr. T. Dwight.</au>

<hw>In*ces"sant</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>a.</pos> <ety>[L.
<ets>incessans</ets>, <ets>-antis</ets>; pref. <ets>in-</ets> not
+ <ets>cessare</ets> to cease: cf. F. <ets>incessant</ets>. See
<er>Cease</er>.]</ety> <def>Continuing or following without
interruption; unceasing; unitermitted; uninterrupted; continual;
<as>as, <ex>incessant</ex> clamors; <ex>incessant</ex> pain,
etc.</as></def>

<q>Against the castle gate,
 . . . Which with <qex>incessant</qex> force and endless hate,
They batter'd day and night and entrance did await.</q>
<qau>Spenser.</qau>

<syn>Syn. -- Unceasing; uninterrupted; unintermitted;
unremitting; ceaseless; continual; constant; perpetual.</syn>

<hw>In*ces"sant*ly</hw>, <pos>adv.</pos> <def>Unceasingly;
continually.</def>

<au>Shak.</au>

<hw>In*ces"sion</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[L.
<ets>incedere</ets>, <ets>incessum</ets>, to walk.]</ety>
<def>Motion on foot; progress in walking.</def>
<mark>[Obs.]</mark>

<q>The <qex>incession</qex> or local motion of animals.</q>
<qau>Sir T. Browne.</qau>

<hw>In"cest</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[F.
<ets>inceste</ets>, L. <ets>incestum</ets> unchastity, incest,
fr. <ets>incestus</ets> unchaste; pref. <ets>in-</ets> not +
<ets>castus</ets> chaste. See <er>Chaste</er>.]</ety> <def>The
crime of cohabitation or sexual commerce between persons related
within the degrees wherein marriage is prohibited by law.</def>

<au>Shak.</au>

<cs><col>Spiritual incest</col>. <fld>(Eccl. Law)</fld>
<sd>(a)</sd> <cd>The crime of cohabitation committed between
persons who have a spiritual alliance by means of baptism or
confirmation.</cd> <sd>(b)</sd> <cd>The act of a vicar, or other
beneficiary, who holds two benefices, the one depending on the
collation of the other.</cd></cs>

<hw>In*cest"tu*ous</hw> <pr>(?; 135)</pr>, <pos>a.</pos> <ety>[L.
<ets>incestuosus</ets>: cf. F. <ets>incestueux</ets>.]</ety>
<def>Guilty of incest; involving, or pertaining to, the crime of
incest; <as>as, an <ex>incestuous</ex> person or
connection</as>.</def>

<au>Shak.</au>

<q>Ere you reach to this <qex>incestuous</qex> love,
You must divine and human rights remove.</q>
<qau>Dryden.</qau>
