<hw>Inch</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[Gael.
<ets>inis</ets>.]</ety> <def>An island; -- often used in the
names of small islands off the coast of Scotland, as in
<xex>Inch</xex>colm, <xex>Inch</xex>keith, etc.</def>
<mark>[Scot.]</mark>

<hw>Inch</hw>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[OE. <ets>inche</ets>,
<ets>unche</ets>, AS. <ets>ynce</ets>, L. <ets>uncia</ets> the
twelfth part, inch, ounce. See <er>Ounce</er> a weight.]</ety>

<sn>1.</sn> <def>A measure of length, the twelfth part of a foot,
commonly subdivided into halves, quarters, eights, sixteenths,
etc., as among mechanics. It was also formerly divided into
twelve parts, called <xex>lines</xex>, and originally into three
parts, called <xex>barleycorns</xex>, its length supposed to have
been determined from three grains of barley placed end to end
lengthwise. It is also sometimes called a <xex>prime</xex>
(\'b7), composed of twelve seconds (\'b7\'b7), as in the
duodecimal system of arithmetic.</def>
<-- \'b7 is the same symbol as the light accent, or the "minutes"
of an arc.  The "seconds" synbol should actually have the two
strokes closer than in repeated "minutes".  Here, \'b7\'b7 will
be interpreted as "seconds" -->

<q>12 seconds (\'b7\'b7) make 1 <qex>inch</qex> or prime. 12
<qex>inches</qex> or primes (\'b7)  make 1 foot.</q>
<qau>B. Greenleaf.</qau>

<note><hand/ The meter, the accepted scientific standard of
length, equals 39.37 inches; the inch is equal to 2.54
centimeters. See <er>Metric system</er>, and
<er>Meter</er>.</note>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>A small distance or degree, whether or time
<?/<?/ space; hence, a critical moment.</def>

<q>Beldame, I think we watched you at an <qex>inch</qex>.</q>
<qau>Shak.</qau>

<cs><col>By inches</col>, <cd>by slow degrees, gradually.</cd> --
<col>Inch of candle</col>. <cd>See under <er>Candle</er>.</cd> --
<col>Inches of pressure</col>, <cd>usually, the pressure
indicated by so many inches of a mercury column, as on a steam
gauge.</cd> -- <col>Inch of water</col>. <cd>See under
<er>Water</er>.</cd> -- <col>Miner's inch</col>, <fld>(Hydraulic
Mining)</fld>, <cd>a unit for the measurement of water. See
<cref>Inch of water</cref>, under <er>Water</er>.</cd></cs>

<hw>Inch</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>v. t.</pos>
<wordforms>[<pos>imp. & p. p.</pos> <er>Inched</er> <pr>(?)</pr>;
<pos>p. pr. & vb. n.</pos> <er>Inching</er>.]</wordforms>

<sn>1.</sn> <def>To drive by inches, or small degrees.</def>
<mark>[R.]</mark>

<q>He gets too far into the soldier's grace
And <qex>inches</qex> out my master.</q>
<qau>Dryden.</qau>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>To deal out by inches; to give sparingly.</def>
<mark>[R.]</mark>

<hw>Inch</hw>, <pos>v. i.</pos> <def>To advance or retire by
inches or small degrees; to move slowly.</def>

<q>With slow paces measures back the field,
And <qex>inches</qex> to the walls.</q>
<qau>Dryden.</qau>

<hw>Inch</hw>, <pos>a.</pos> <def>Measurement an inch in any
dimension, whether length, breadth, or thickness; -- used in
composition; <as>as, a two-<ex>inch</ex> cable; a
four-<ex>inch</ex> plank.</as></def>

<cs><col>Inch stuff</col>, <cd>boards, etc., sawed one inch
thick.</cd></cs>

<hw>In"ci*dence</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[Cf. F.
<ets>incidence</ets>.]</ety>

<sn>1.</sn> <def>A falling on or upon; an incident; an
event.</def> <mark>[Obs.]</mark>

<au>Bp. Hall.</au>

<sn>2.</sn> <fld>(Physics)</fld> <def>The direction in which a
body, or a ray of light or heat, falls on any surface.</def>

<q>In equal <qex>incidences</qex> there is a considerable
inequality of refractions.</q>
<qau>Sir I. Newton.</qau>

<cs><col>Angle of incidence</col>, <cd>the angle which a ray of
light, or the line of incidence of a body, falling on any
surface, makes with a perpendicular to that surface; also
formerly, the complement of this angle.</cd> -- <col>Line of
incidence</col>, <cd>the line in the direction of which a surface
is struck by a body, ray of light, and the like.</cd></cs>

<hw>In"ci*den*cy</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos>
<def>Incidence.</def> <mark>[Obs.]</mark>

<au>Shak.</au>

<hw>In"ci*dent</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>a.</pos> <ety>[L.
<ets>incidens</ets>, <ets>-entis</ets>, p. pr. & of
<ets>incidere</ets> to fall into or upon; pref. <ets>in-</ets>
in, on + <ets>cadere</ets> to fall: cf. F. <ets>incident</ets>.
See <er>Cadence</er>.]</ety>

<sn>1.</sn> <def>Falling or striking upon, as a ray of light upon
a reflecting surface.</def>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>Coming or happening accidentally; not in the
usual course of things; not in connection with the main design;
not according to expectation; casual; fortuitous.</def>

<q>As the ordinary course of common affairs is disposed of by
general laws, so likewise men's rarer <qex>incident</qex>
necessities and utilities should be with special equity
considered.</q>
<qau>Hooker.</qau>

<sn>3.</sn> <def>Liable to happen; apt to occur; befalling;
hence, naturally happening or appertaining.</def>

<q>All chances <qex>incident</qex> to man's frail life.</q>
<qau>Milton.</qau>

<q>The studies <qex>incident</qex> to his profession.</q>
<qau>Milward.</qau>

<sn>4.</sn> <fld>(Law)</fld> <def>Dependent upon, or appertaining
to, another thing, called the <xex>principal</xex>.</def>

<cs><col>Incident proposition</col> <fld>(Logic)</fld>, <cd>a
proposition subordinate to another, and introduced by
<xex>who<xex>, <xex>which<xex>, <xex>whose<xex>, <xex>whom<xex>,
etc.; as, Julius, <xex>whose surname was C\'91sar<xex>, overcame
Pompey.</cd></cs>

<au>I. Watts.</au>

<hw>In"ci*dent</hw>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[Cf. F.
<ets>incident</ets>.]</ety>

<sn>1.</sn> <def>That which falls out or takes place; an event;
casualty; occurrence.</def>

<-- p. 744 -->

<sn>2.</sn> <def>That which happens aside from the main design;
an accidental or subordinate action or event.</def>

<q>No person, no <qex>incident</qex>, in a play but must be of
use to carry on the main design.</q>
<qau>Dryden.</qau>

<sn>3.</sn> <fld>(Law)</fld> <def>Something appertaining to,
passing with, or depending on, another, called the
<xex>principal</xex>.</def>

<au>Tomlins.</au>

<syn>Syn. -- Circumstance; event; fact; adventure; contingency;
chance; accident; casualty. See <er>Event</er>.</syn>

<hw>In`cin*den"tal</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>a.</pos>
<def>Happening, as an occasional event, without regularity;
coming without design; casual; accidental; hence, not of prime
concern; subordinate; collateral; <as>as, an <ex>incidental</ex>
conversation; an <ex>incidental</ex> occurrence;
<ex>incidental</ex> expenses.</as></def>

<q>By some, religious duties . . . appear to be regarded . . . as
an <qex>incidental</qex> business.</q>
<qau>Rogers.</qau>

<syn>Syn. -- Accidental; casual; fortuitous; contingent; chance;
collateral. See <er>Accidental</er>.</syn>

-- <wordforms><wf>In`cen*den"tal*ly</wf>, <pos>adv.</pos> --
<wf>In`cen*den"tal*ness</wf>, <pos>n.</pos></wordforms>

<q>I treat either or <qex>incidentally</qex> of colors.</q>
<qau>Boyle.</qau>

<hw>In`cen*den"tal</hw>, <pos>n.</pos> <def>An incident; that
which is incidental; esp., in the plural, an aggregate of
subordinate or incidental items not particularized; <as>as, the
expense of tuition and <ex>incidentals</ex></as>.</def>

<au>Pope.</au>

<hw>In*cise"</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>v. t.</pos>
<wordforms>[<pos>imp. & p. p.</pos> <er>Incised</er>
<pr>(?)</pr>; <pos>p. pr. & vb. n.</pos>
<er>Incising</er>.]</wordforms> <ety>[L. <ets>incisus</ets>, p.
p. of <ets>incidere</ets> to incise: cf. F. <ets>inciser</ets>.
See <er>Incide</er>.]</ety>

<sn>1.</sn> <def>To cut in or into with a sharp instrument; to
carve; to engrave.</def>

<q>I on thy grave this epitaph <qex>incise</qex>.</q>
<qau>T. Carew.</qau>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>To cut, gash, or wound with a sharp instrument;
to cut off.</def>

<hw>In*cised"</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>a.</pos> <sn>1.</sn>
<def>Cut in; carved; engraved.</def>

<sn>2.</sn> <fld>(Bot.)</fld> <def>Having deep and sharp notches,
as a leaf or a petal.</def>

<hw>In*cise"ly</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>adv.</pos> <def>In an
incised manner.</def>

<hw>In*ci"sion</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[L.
<ets>incisio</ets>: cf. F. <ets>incision</ets>. See
<er>Incise</er>.]</ety>

<sn>1.</sn> <def>The act of incising, or cutting into a
substance.</def>

<au>Milton.</au>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>That which is produced by incising; the
separation of the parts of any substance made by a cutting or
pointed instrument; a cut; a gash.</def>

<sn>3.</sn> <def>Separation or solution of viscid matter by
medicines.</def> <mark>[Obs.]</mark>

<hw>In*ci"sive</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>a.</pos> <ety>[Cf. F.
<ets>incisif</ets>.]</ety>

<sn>1.</sn> <def>Having the quality of incising, cutting, or
penetrating, as with a sharp instrument; cutting; hence, sharp;
acute; sarcastic; biting.</def> \'bdAn <xex>incisive</xex>, high
voice.\'b8

<au>G. Eliot.</au>

<q>And her <qex>incisive</qex> smile accrediting
That treason of false witness in my blush.</q>
<qau>Mrs. Browning.</qau>

<sn>2.</sn> <fld>(Anat.)</fld> <def>Of or pertaining to the
incisors; incisor; <as>as, the <ex>incisive</ex> bones, the
premaxillaries</as>.</def>

<hw>In*ci"sor</hw> <pr>(?; 277)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos>
<ety>[NL.]</ety> <fld>(Anat.)</fld> <def>One of the teeth in
front of the canines in either jaw; an incisive tooth. See
<er>Tooth</er>.</def>

<hw>In*ci"sor</hw>, <pos>a.</pos> <def>Adapted for cutting; of or
pertaining to the incisors; incisive; <as>as, the
<ex>incisor</ex> nerve; an <ex>incisor</ex> foramen; an
<ex>incisor</ex> tooth.</as></def>

<hw>In*ci"so*ry</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>a.</pos> <def>Having the

<ets>incisura</ets>: cf. F. <ets>incisure</ets>.]</ety> <def>A

<au>Derham.</au>

<hw>In*cit"ant</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>a.</pos> <ety>[L.

<ets>incitare</ets>. See <er>Incite</er>.]</ety> <def>Inciting;

<hw>In*cit"ant</hw>, <pos>n.</pos> <def>That which incites; an

<au>E. Darwin.</au>

<hw>In`ci*ta"tion</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[L.
<ets>incitatio</ets>: cf. F. <ets>incitation</ets>.]</ety>

<sn>1.</sn> <def>The act of inciting or moving to action.</def>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>That which incites to action; that which rouses
or prompts; incitement; motive; incentive.</def>

<q>The noblest <qex>incitation</qex> to honest attempts.</q>
<qau>Tatler.</qau>

<hw>In*cit"a*tive</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <def>A
provocative; an incitant; a stimulant.</def> <mark>[R.]</mark>

<au>Jervas.</au>

<hw>In*cite"</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>v. t.</pos>
<wordforms>[<pos>imp. & p. p.</pos> <er>Incited</er>
<pr>(?)</pr>; <pos>p. pr. & vb. n.</pos>
<er>Inciting</er>.]</wordforms> <ety>[L. <ets>incitare</ets>;
pref. <ets>in-</ets> in + <ets>citare</ets> to rouse, stir up:
cf. F. <ets>inciter</ets>. See <er>Cite</er>.]</ety> <def>To move
to action; to stir up; to rouse; to spur or urge on.</def>

<q>Anthiochus, when he <qex>incited</qex> Prusias to join in war,
set before him the greatness of the Romans.</q>
<qau>Bacon.</qau>

<q>No blown ambition doth our arms <qex>incite</qex>.</q>
<qau>Shak.</qau>

<syn>Syn. -- Excite; stimulate; instigate; spur; goad; arouse;
move; urge; rouse; provoke; encourage; prompt; animate. See
<er>Excite</er>.</syn>

<hw>In*cite"ment</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[Cf. F.
<ets>incitement</ets>.]</ety>

<sn>1.</sn> <def>The act of inciting.</def>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>That which incites the mind, or moves to action;
motive; incentive; impulse.</def>

<au>Burke.</au>

<q>From the long records of a distant age,
Derive <qex>incitements</qex> to renew thy rage.</q>
<qau>Pope.</qau>

<syn>Syn. -- Motive; incentive; spur; stimulus; impulse;
encouragement.</syn>

that which, incites.</def>

<hw>In*cit"ing*ly</hw>, <pos>adv.</pos> <def>So as to incite or
stimulate.</def>

<hw>In*ci`to-mo"tor</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>a.</pos> <ety>[L.
<ets>incitus</ets> incited + E. <ets>motor</ets>.]</ety>
<fld>(Physiol.)</fld> <def>Inciting to motion; -- applied to that
action which, in the case of muscular motion, commences in the
nerve centers, and excites the muscles to contraction. Opposed to

<hw>In*civ"il</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>a.</pos> <ety>[L.

<def>Uncivil; rude.</def> <mark>[Obs.]</mark>

<hw>In`ci*vil"i*ty</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos>; <plu>pl.
<plw>Incivilities</plw> <pr>(#)</pr></plu>. <ety>[L.
<ets>incivilitas</ets>: cf. F. <ets>incivilit\'82</ets>.]</ety>

<sn>1.</sn> <def>The quality or state of being uncivil; want of
courtesy; rudeness of manner; impoliteness.</def>

<au>Shak. Tillotson.</au>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>Any act of rudeness or ill breeding.</def>

<q>Uncomely jests, loud talking and jeering, which, in civil
account, are called indecencies and <qex>incivilities</qex>.</q>
<qau>Jer. Taylor.</qau>

<sn>3.</sn> <def>Want of civilization; a state of rudeness or
barbarism.</def> <mark>[R.]</mark>

<au>Sir W. Raleigh.</au>

<syn>Syn. -- Impoliteness; uncourteousness; unmannerliness;
disrespect; rudeness; discourtesy.</syn>

barbarism.</def>

<hw>In*clem"en*cy</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos>; <plu>pl.
<plw>Inclemencies</plw> <pr>(#)</pr></plu>. <ety>[L.
<ets>inclementia</ets>: cf. F. <ets>incl\'82mence</ets>.]</ety>

<sn>1.</sn> <def>The state or quality of being inclement; want of
clemency; want of mildness of temper; unmercifulness;
severity.</def>

<q>The <qex>inclemency</qex> of the late pope.</q>
<qau>Bp. Hall.</qau>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>Physical severity or harshness (commonly in
respect to the elements or weather); roughness; storminess;
rigor; severe cold, wind, rain, or snow.</def>

<q>The <qex>inclemencies</qex> of morning air.</q>
<qau>Pope.</qau>

<q>The rude <qex>inclemency</qex> of wintry skies.</q>
<qau>Cowper.</qau>

<syn>Syn. -- Harshness; severity; cruelty; rigor; roughness;
storminess; boisterousness.</syn>

<hw>In*clem"ent</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>a.</pos> <ety>[L.
<ets>inclemens</ets>; pref. <ets>in-</ets> not +
<ets>clemens</ets> mild: cf. F. <ets>incl\'82ment</ets>. See
<er>Clement</er>.]</ety>

<sn>1.</sn> <def>Not clement; destitute of a mild and kind
temper; void of tenderness; unmerciful; severe; harsh.</def>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>Physically severe or harsh (generally restricted
to the elements or weather); rough; boisterous; stormy;
rigorously cold, etc.; <as>as, <ex>inclement</ex>
weather</as>.</def>

<au>Cowper.</au>

<q>The guard the wretched from the <qex>inclement</qex> sky.</q>
<qau>Pope.</qau>

<q>Teach us further by what means to shun
The <qex>inclement</qex> seasons, rain, ice, hail, and snow!</q>
<qau>Milton.</qau>

<hw>In*clem"ent*ly</hw>, <pos>adv.</pos> <def>In an inclement
manner.</def>

<hw>In*clin"a*ble</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>a.</pos> <ety>[L.
<ets>inclinabilis</ets>. See <er>Incline</er>.]</ety>

<sn>1.</sn> <def>Leaning; tending.</def>

<q>Likely and <qex>inclinable</qex> to fall.</q>
<qau>Bentley.</qau>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>Having a propensity of will or feeling; leaning
in disposition; disposed; propense; <as>as, a mind
<ex>inclinable</ex> to truth</as>.</def>

<q>Whatsoever other sins he may be <qex>inclinable</qex> to.</q>
<qau>South.</qau>

<q>The very constitution of a multitude is not so
<qex>inclinable</qex> to save as to destroy.</q>
<qau>Fuller.</qau>

<hw>In*clin"a*ble*ness</hw>, <pos>n.</pos> <def>The state or
quality of being inclinable; inclination.</def>

<hw>In`clin*na"tion</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[L.
<ets>inclinatio</ets>: cf. F. <ets>inclination</ets>.]</ety>

<sn>1.</sn> <def>The act of inclining, or state of being
inclined; a leaning; <as>as, an <ex>inclination</ex> of the
head</as>.</def>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>A direction or tendency from the true vertical
or horizontal direction; <as>as, the <ex>inclination</ex> of a
column, or of a road bed</as>.</def>

<sn>3.</sn> <def>A tendency towards another body or point</def>

<sn>4.</sn> <fld>(Geom.)</fld> <def>The angle made by two lines
or planes; <as>as, the <ex>inclination</ex> of the plane of the
earth's equator to the plane of the ecliptic is about 23<deg/
28\'b7; the <ex>inclination</ex> of two rays of light.</as></def>

<sn>5.</sn> <def>A leaning or tendency of the mind, feelings,
preferences, or will; propensity; a disposition more favorable to
one thing than to another; favor; desire; love.</def>

<q>A mere <qex>inclination</qex> to a thing is not properly a
willing of that thing.</q>
<qau>South.</qau>

<q>How dost thou find the <qex>inclination</qex> of the
people?</q>
<qau>Shak.</qau>

<sn>6.</sn> <def>A person or thing loved or admired.</def>

<au>Sir W. Temple.</au>

<sn>7.</sn> <fld>(Pharm.)</fld> <def>Decantation, or tipping for
pouring.</def>

<cs><col>Inclination compass</col>, <cd>an inclinometer.</cd> --
<col>Inclination of an orbit</col> <fld>(Astron.)</fld>, <cd>the
angle which the orbit makes the ecliptic.</cd> --
<col>Inclination of the needle</col>. <cd>See <cref>Dip of the
needle</cref>, under <er>Dip</er>.</cd></cs>

<syn>Syn. -- Bent; tendency; proneness; bias; proclivity;
propensity; prepossession; predilection; attachment; desire;
affection; love. See <er>Bent</er>, and cf.
<er>Disposition</er>.</syn>

<hw>In*clin"a*to*ry</hw> <pr>(?; 277)</pr>, <pos>a.</pos>
<def>Having the quality of leaning or inclining; <as>as, the
<ex>inclinatory</ex> needle</as>.</def> --
<wordforms><wf>In*clin"a*to*ri*ly</wf> <pr>(#)</pr>,
<pos>adv.</pos> <au>Sir T. Browne</au>.</wordforms>

<hw>In*cline"</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>v. i.</pos>
<wordforms>[<pos>imp. & p. p.</pos> <er>Inclined</er>
<pr>(?)</pr>; <pos>p. pr. & vb. n.</pos>
<er>Inclining</er>.]</wordforms> <ety>[OE. <ets>inclinen</ets>,
<ets>enclinen</ets>, OF. <ets>encliner</ets>,
<ets>incliner</ets>, F. <ets>incliner</ets>, L.
<ets>inclinare</ets>; pref. <ets>in-</ets> in +
<ets>clinare</ets> to bend, incline; akin to E. <ets>lean</ets>.
See <er>Lean</er> to incline.]</ety>

<sn>1.</sn> <def>To deviate from a line, direction, or course,
toward an object; to lean; to tend; <as>as, converging lines
<ex>incline</ex> toward each other; a road <ex>inclines</ex> to
the north or south.</as></def>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>Fig.: To lean or tend, in an intellectual or
moral sense; to favor an opinion, a course of conduct, or a
person; to have a propensity or inclination; to be
disposed.</def>

<q>Their hearts <qex>inclined</qex> to follow Abimelech.</q>
<qau>Judges ix. 3.</qau>

<q>Power finds its balance, giddy motions cease
In both the scales, and each <qex>inclines</qex> to peace.</q>
<qau>Parnell.</qau>

<sn>3.</sn> <def>To bow; to incline the head.</def>

<au>Chaucer.</au>

<syn>Syn. -- To lean; slope; slant; tend; bend.</syn>

<hw>In*cline"</hw>, <pos>v. t.</pos> <sn>1.</sn> <def>To cause to
deviate from a line, position, or direction; to give a leaning,
bend, or slope to; <as>as, <ex>incline</ex> the column or post to
the east; <ex>incline</ex> your head to the right.</as></def>

<q><qex>Incline</qex> thine ear, O Lord, and hear.</q>
<qau>Is. xxxvii. 17.</qau>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>To impart a tendency or propensity to, as to the
will or affections; to turn; to dispose; to influence.</def>

<q><qex>Incline</qex> my heart unto thy testimonies.</q>
<qau>Ps. cxix. 36.</qau>

<q><qex>Incline</qex> our hearts to keep this law.</q>
<qau>Book of Com. Prayer.</qau>

<sn>3.</sn> <def>To bend; to cause to stoop or bow; <as>as, to
<ex>incline</ex> the head or the body in acts of reverence or
civility</as>.</def>

<q>With due respect my body I <qex>inclined</qex>.</q>
<qau>Dryden.</qau>

<hw>In*cline"</hw>, <pos>n.</pos> <def>An inclined plane; an
ascent o<?/ descent; a grade or gradient; a slope.</def>

<hw>In*clined"</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>p. p. & a.</pos>
<sn>1.</sn> <def>Having a leaning or tendency towards, or away
from, a thing; disposed or moved by wish, desire, or judgment;
<as>as, a man <ex>inclined</ex> to virtue</as>.</def> \'bdEach
pensively <xex>inclined</xex>.\'b8

<au>Cowper.</au>

<sn>2.</sn> <fld>(Math.)</fld> <def>Making an angle with some
line or plane; -- said of a line or plane.</def>

<sn>3.</sn> <fld>(Bot.)</fld> <def>Bent out of a perpendicular
position, or into a curve with the convex side uppermost.</def>

<cs><col>Inclined plane</col>. <fld>(Mech.)</fld> <sd>(a)</sd>
<cd>A plane that makes an oblique angle with the plane of the
horizon; a sloping plane. When used to produce pressure, or as a
means of moving bodies, it is one of the mechanical powers, so
called.</cd> <sd>(b)</sd> <fld>(Railroad & Canal)</fld> <cd>An
inclined portion of track, on which trains or boats are raised or
lowered from one level to another.</cd></cs>

<hw>In*clin"er</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <def>One who, or
that which, inclines; specifically, an inclined dial.</def>

<hw>In*clin"ing</hw>, <pos>a.</pos> <fld>(Bot.)</fld> <def>Same
as <er>Inclined</er>, 3.</def>

<hw>In*clin"ing</hw>, <pos>n.</pos> <sn>1.</sn> <def>Inclination;
disposition.</def>

<q>On the first <qex>inclining</qex> towards sleep.</q>
<qau>Burke.</qau>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>Party or side chosen; a following.</def>

<q>Both you of my <qex>inclining</qex>, and the rest.</q>
<qau>Shak.</qau>

<hw>In`clin*nom"e*ter</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos>
<ety>[<ets>Incline</ets> + -<ets>meter</ets>.]</ety>
<fld>(Magnetism)</fld> <def>An apparatus to determine the
inclination of the earth's magnetic force to the plane of the
horizon; -- called also <altname>inclination compass</altname>,
and <altname>dip circle</altname>.</def>

<hw>In*clip"</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>v. t.</pos> <def>To clasp;
to inclose.</def>

<q>Whate'er the ocean pales, or sky <qex>inclips</qex>.</q>
<qau>Shak.</qau>

<hw>In*clois"ter</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>v. t.</pos> <ety>[Pref.
<ets>in-</ets> in + <ets>cloister</ets>: cf. F.
<ets>enclo\'8ctrer</ets>. Cf. <er>Encloister</er>.]</ety> <def>To
confine as in a cloister; to cloister.</def>

<au>Lovelace.</au>

<hw>In*close"</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>v. t.</pos>
<wordforms>[<pos>imp. & p. p.</pos> <er>Inclosed</er>
<pr>(?)</pr>; <pos>p. pr. & vb. n.</pos>
<er>Inclosing</er>.]</wordforms> <ety>[See <er>Enclose</er>, and
cf. <er>Include</er>.]</ety> <altsp>[Written also
<asp>enclose</asp>.]</altsp>

<sn>1.</sn> <def>To surround; to shut in; to confine on all
sides; to include; to shut up; to encompass; <as>as, to
<ex>inclose</ex> a fort or an army with troops; to
<ex>inclose</ex> a town with walls.</as></def>

<q>How many evils have <qex>inclosed</qex> me round!</q>
<qau>Milton.</qau>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>To put within a case, envelope, or the like; to
fold (a thing) within another or into the same parcel; <as>as, to
<ex>inclose</ex> a letter or a bank note</as>.</def>

<q>The <qex>inclosed</qex> copies of the treaty.</q>
<qau>Sir W. Temple.</qau>

<sn>3.</sn> <def>To separate from common grounds by a fence;
<as>as, to <ex>inclose</ex> lands</as>.</def>

<au>Blackstone.</au>

<sn>4.</sn> <def>To put into harness; to harness.</def>
<mark>[Obs.]</mark>

<q>They went to coach and their horse <qex>inclose</qex>.</q>
<qau>Chapman.</qau>

<hw>In*clos"er</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <def>One who, or
that which, incloses; one who fences off land from common
grounds.</def>

<hw>In*clo"sure</hw> <pr>(?; 135)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[See
<er>Inclose</er>, <er>Enclosure</er>.]</ety> <altsp>[Written also
<asp>enclosure</asp>.]</altsp>

<sn>1.</sn> <def>The act of inclosing; the state of being
inclosed, shut up, or encompassed; the separation of land from
common ground by a fence.</def>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>That which is inclosed or placed within
something; a thing contained; a space inclosed or fenced
up.</def>

<q>Within the <qex>inclosure</qex> there was a great store of
houses.</q>
<qau>Hakluyt.</qau>

<sn>3.</sn> <def>That which incloses; a barrier or fence.</def>

<q>Breaking our <qex>inclosures</qex> every morn.</q>
<qau>W. Browne.</qau>

<hw>In*cloud"</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>v. t.</pos> <def>To envelop
as in clouds; to darken; to obscure.</def>

<au>Milton.</au>

<-- p. 745 -->

<hw>In*clude"</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>v. t.</pos>
<wordforms>[<pos>imp. & p. p.</pos> <er>Included</er>; <pos>p.
pr. & vb. n.</pos> <er>Including</er>.]</wordforms> <ety>[L.
<ets>includere</ets>, <ets>inclusum</ets>; pref. <ets>in-</ets>
in + <ets>claudere</ets> to shut. See <er>Close</er>, and cf.
<er>Enclose</er>.]</ety>

<sn>1.</sn> <def>To confine within; to hold; to contain; to shut
up; to inclose; <as>as, the shell of a nut <ex>includes</ex> the
kernel; a pearl is <ex>included</ex> in a shell.</as></def>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>To comprehend or comprise, as a genus the
species, the whole a part, an argument or reason the inference;
to contain; to embrace; <as>as, this volume of Shakespeare
<ex>includes</ex> his sonnets; he was <ex>included</ex> in the
invitation to the family; to and <ex>including</ex> page
twenty-five.</as></def>
<-- usu. up to and including . . . -->

<q>The whole <qex>included</qex> race, his purposed prey.</q>
<qau>Milton.</qau>

<q>The loss of such a lord <qex>includes</qex> all harm.</q>
<qau>Shak.</qau>

<sn>3.</sn> <def>To conclude; to end; to terminate.</def>
<mark>[Obs.]</mark>

<q>Come, let us go; we will <qex>include</qex> all jars
With triumphs, mirth, and rare solemnity.</q>
<qau>Shak.</qau>

<syn>Syn. -- To contain; inclose; comprise; comprehend; embrace;
involve.</syn>

<hw>In*clud"ed</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>a.</pos> <def>Inclosed;
confined.</def>

<cs><col>Included stamens</col> <fld>(Bot.)</fld>, <cd>such as
are shorter than the floral envelopes, or are concealed within
them.</cd></cs>

<hw>In*clud"i*ble</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>a.</pos> <def>Capable
of being included.</def>

<hw>\'d8In*clu"sa</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n. pl.</pos> <ety>[NL.,
fr. L. <ets>inclusus</ets>, p. p. of <ets>includere</ets> to shut
in.]</ety> <fld>(Zo\'94l.)</fld> <def>A tribe of bivalve
mollusks, characterized by the closed state of the mantle which
envelops the body. The ship borer (<spn>Teredo navalis</spn>) is
an example.</def>

<hw>In*clu"sion</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[L.
<ets>inclusio</ets>: cf. F. <ets>inclusion</ets>. See
<er>Include</er>.]</ety>

<sn>1.</sn> <def>The act of including, or the state of being
included; limitation; restriction; <as>as, the lines of
<ex>inclusion</ex> of his policy</as>.</def>

<au>Sir W. Temple.</au>

<sn>2.</sn> <fld>(Min.)</fld> <def>A foreign substance, either
liquid or solid, usually of minute size, inclosed in the mass of
a mineral.</def>

<hw>In*clu"sive</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>a.</pos> <ety>[Cf. F.
<ets>inclusif</ets>.]</ety>

<sn>1.</sn> <def>Inclosing; encircling; surrounding.</def>

<q>The <qex>inclusive</qex> verge
Of golden metal that must round my brow.</q>
<qau>Shak.</qau>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>Comprehending the stated limit or extremes;
<as>as, from Monday to Saturday <ex>inclusive</ex>, that is,
taking in both Monday and Saturday</as>; -- opposed to
<contr>exclusive</contr>.</def>
<-- see include, v.t. 2 -->

<hw>In*clu"sive*ly</hw>, <pos>adv.</pos> <def>In an inclusive
manner.</def>

<hw>In`co*er"ci*ble</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>a.</pos> <ety>[Pref.
<ets>in-</ets> not + <ets>coercible</ets>: cf. F.
<ets>incoercible</ets>.]</ety>

<sn>1.</sn> <def>Not to be coerced; incapable of being compelled
or forced.</def>

<sn>2.</sn> <fld>(Physics)</fld> <def>Not capable of being
reduced to the form of a liquid by pressure; -- said of any gas
above its <xex>critical</xex> point; -- also particularly of
oxygen, hydrogen, nitrogen, and carbon monoxide, formerly
regarded as incapable of liquefaction at any temperature or
pressure.</def>

<sn>3.</sn> <fld>(Physics)</fld> <def>That can note be confined
in, or excluded from, vessels, like ordinary fluids, gases, etc.;
-- said of the imponderable fluids, heat, light, electricity,
etc.</def>

state of not coexisting.</def> <mark>[Obs.]</mark>

<au>Locke.</au>

<mhw>{ <hw>In`co*her"ence</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>,
<hw>In`co*her"en*cy</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, }</mhw> <pos>n.</pos>
<ety>[Cf. F. <ets>incoh\'82rence</ets>.]</ety>

<sn>1.</sn> <def>The quality or state of being incoherent; want
of coherence; want of cohesion or adherence.</def>

<au>Boyle.</au>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>Want of connection; incongruity; inconsistency;
want of agreement or dependence of one part on another; <as>as,
the <ex>incoherence</ex> of arguments, facts, etc.</as></def>

<q><qex>Incoherences</qex> in matter, and suppositions without
proofs, put handsomely together, are apt to pass for strong
reason.</q>
<qau>Locke.</qau>

<sn>3.</sn> <def>That which is incoherent.</def>

<q>Crude <qex>incoherencies</qex> . . . and nauseous
tautologies.</q>
<qau>South.</qau>

<hw>In`co*her"ent</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>a.</pos> <ety>[Pref.
<ets>in-</ets> not + <ets>coherent</ets>: cf. F.
<ets>incoh\'82rent</ets>.]</ety>

<sn>1.</sn> <def>Not coherent; wanting cohesion; loose;
unconnected; physically disconnected; not fixed to each; -- said
of material substances.</def>

<au>Woodward.</au>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>Wanting coherence or agreement; incongruous;
inconsistent; having no dependence of one part on another;
logically disconnected.</def> \'bdThe same rambling,
<xex>incoherent</xex> manner.\'b8

<au>Bp. Warburton.</au>

<cs><col>Incombustible cloth</col>, <cd>a tissue of amianthus or

<hw>In"come</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <sn>1.</sn> <def>A
coming in; entrance; admittance; ingress; infusion.</def>
<mark>[Obs.]</mark>

<au>Shak.</au>

<q>More abundant <qex>incomes</qex> of light and strength from
God.</q>
<qau>Bp. Rust.</qau>

<q>At mine <qex>income</qex> I louted low.</q>
<qau>Drant.</qau>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>That which is caused to enter; inspiration;
influence; hence, courage or zeal imparted.</def>
<mark>[R.]</mark>

<q>I would then make in and steep
My <qex>income</qex> in their blood.</q>
<qau>Chapman.</qau>

<sn>3.</sn> <def>That gain which proceeds from labor, business,
property, or capital of any kind, as the produce of a farm, the
rent of houses, the proceeds of professional business, the
profits of commerce or of occupation, or the interest of money or
stock in funds, etc.; revenue; receipts; salary; especially, the
annual receipts of a private person, or a corporation, from
property; <as>as, a large <ex>income</ex></as>.</def>

<q>No fields afford
So large an <qex>income</qex> to the village lord.</q>
<qau>Dryden.</qau>

<sn>4.</sn> <fld>(Physiol.)</fld> <def>That which is taken into
the body as food; the ingesta; -- sometimes restricted to the
nutritive, or digestible, portion of the food. See <er>Food</er>.
Opposed to <xex>output</xex>.</def>

<cs><col>Income bond</col>, <cd>a bond issued on the income of
the corporation or company issuing it, and the interest of which
is to be paid from the earnings of the company before any
dividends are made to stockholders; -- issued chiefly or
exclusively by railroad companies.</cd> -- <col>Income tax</col>,
<cd>a tax upon a person's incomes, emoluments, profits, etc., or
upon the excess beyond a certain amount.</cd></cs>

<syn>Syn. -- Gain; profit; proceeds; salary; revenue; receipts;
interest; emolument; produce.</syn>

<hw>In`com*men`su*ra*bil"i*ty</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos>
<ety>[Cf. F. <ets>incommensurabilit\'82</ets>.]</ety> <def>The
quality or state of being incommensurable.</def>

<au>Reid.</au>

<hw>In`com*men"su*ra*ble</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>a.</pos>
<ety>[Pref. <ets>in-</ets> not + <ets>commensurable</ets>: cf. F.
<ets>incommensurable</ets>.]</ety> <def>Not commensurable; having
no common measure or standard of comparison; <as>as, quantities
are <ex>incommensurable</ex> when no third quantity can be found
that is an aliquot part of both; the side and diagonal of a
square are <ex>incommensurable</ex> with each other; the diameter
and circumference of a circle are
<ex>incommensurable</ex>.</as></def>

<q>They are quantities <qex>incommensurable</qex>.</q>
<qau>Burke.</qau>

-- <wordforms><wf>In`com*men"su*ra*ble*ness</wf>, <pos>n.</pos>
-- <wf>In`com*men"su*ra*bly</wf>, <pos>adv.</pos></wordforms>

<hw>In`com*men"su*ra*ble</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos>
<def>One of two or more quantities which have no common
measure.</def>

<hw>In`com*men"su*rate</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>a.</pos>
<sn>1.</sn> <def>Not commensurate; not admitting of a common
measure; incommensurable.</def>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>Not of equal of sufficient measure or extent;
not adequate; <as>as, our means are <ex>incommensurate</ex> to
our wants</as>.</def>

<syn>Syn. -- Inadequate; insufficient; disproportionate.</syn>

-- <wordforms><wf>In`com*men"su*rate*ly</wf>, <pos>adv.</pos> --
<wf>In`com*men"su*rate*ness</wf>, <pos>n.</pos></wordforms>

<hw>In`com*mu`ni*ca*bil"i*ty</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos>
<ety>[Cf. F. <ets>incommunicabilit\'82</ets>.]</ety> <def>The
quality or state of being incommunicable, or incapable of being
imparted.</def>

<hw>In`com*mu"ni*ca*ble</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>a.</pos> <ety>[L.
<ets>incommunicabilis</ets>: cf. F. <ets>incommunicable</ets>.
See <er>In-</er> not, and <er>Communicable</er>.]</ety> <def>Not
communicable; incapable of being communicated, shared, told, or
imparted, to others.</def>

<q>Health and understanding are <qex>incommunicable</qex>.</q>
<qau>Southey.</qau>

<q>Those <qex>incommunicable</qex> relations of the divine
love.</q>
<qau>South.</qau>

<wf>In`com*mu"ni*ca*bly</wf>, <pos>adv.</pos></wordforms>

communicated or imparted.</def> <mark>[Obs.]</mark>

<au>Dr. H. More.</au>

<hw>In`com*mu"ni*ca`ting</hw>, <pos>a.</pos> <def>Having no
communion or intercourse with each other.</def>
<mark>[Obs.]</mark>

<au>Sir M. Hale.</au>

<hw>In`com*mu"ni*ca*tive</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>a.</pos>
<def>Not communicative; not free or apt to impart to others in
conversation; reserved; silent; <as>as, the messenger was
<ex>incommunicative</ex></as>; hence, not disposed to hold
fellowship or intercourse with others; exclusive.</def>

<q>The Chinese . . . an <qex>incommunicative</qex> nation.</q>
<qau>C. Buchanan.</qau>

-- <wordforms><wf>In`com*mu"ni*ca*tive*ly</wf>, <pos>adv.</pos>
-- <wf>In`com*mu"ni*ca*tive*ness</wf>, <pos>n.</pos></wordforms>

<au>Lamb.</au>

<q>His usual <qex>incommunicativeness</qex>.</q>
<qau>G. Eliot.</qau>

<hw>In`com*mu`ta*bil"i*ty</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos>
<ety>[L. <ets>incommutabilitas</ets>: cf. F.
<ets>incommutabilit\'82</ets>.]</ety> <def>The quality or state
of being incommutable.</def>

<hw>In`com*mut"a*ble</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>a.</pos> <ety>[L.
<ets>incommutabilis</ets>: cf. F. <ets>incommutable</ets>. See

<hw>In`com*pat`i*bil"i*ty</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos>;
<plu>pl. <plw>-ties</plw> <pr>(<?/)</pr></plu>. <ety>[Cf. F.
<ets>incompatibilit\'82</ets>.]</ety> <def>The quality or state
of being incompatible; inconsistency; irreconcilableness.</def>

<hw>In`com*pat"i*ble</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>a.</pos> <ety>[Pref.
<ets>in-</ets> not + <ets>compatible</ets>: cf. F.
<ets>incompatible</ets>.]</ety> <altsp>[It was formerly sometimes
written <asp>incompetible</asp>.]</altsp>

<sn>1.</sn> <def>Not compatible; so differing as to be incapable
of harmonious combination or coexistence; inconsistent in thought
or being; irreconcilably disagreeing; <as>as, persons of
<ex>incompatible</ex> tempers; <ex>incompatible</ex> colors,
desires, ambition.</as></def>

<q>A strength and obduracy of character <qex>incompatible</qex>
with his meek and innocent nature.</q>
<qau>Southey.</qau>

<-- p. 746 -->

<sn>2.</sn> <fld>(Chem.)</fld> <def>Incapable of being together
without mutual reaction or decomposition, as certain
medicines.</def>

<cs><col>Incompatible terms</col> <fld>(Logic)</fld>, <cd>terms
which can not be combined in thought.</cd></cs>

<syn>Syn. -- Inconsistent; incongruous; dissimilar;
irreconcilable; unsuitable; disagreeing; inharmonious;
discordant; repugnant; contradictory. See
<er>Inconsistent</er>.</syn>

<hw>In`com*pat"i*ble</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <fld>(Med.
& Chem.)</fld> <def>An incompatible substance; esp., in
<pluf>pl.</pluf>, things which can not be placed or used together
because of a change of chemical composition or of opposing
medicinal qualities; <as>as, the <ex>incompatibles</ex> of
iron</as>.</def>

<hw>In`com*pat"i*ble*ness</hw>, <pos>n.</pos> <def>The quality or
state of being incompatible; incompatibility.</def>

<hw>In`com*pat"i*bly</hw>, <pos>adv.</pos> <def>In an
incompatible manner; inconsistently; incongruously.</def>

<mhw>{ <hw>In*com"pe*tence</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>,
<hw>In*com"pe*tency</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, }</mhw> <pos>n.</pos>
<ety>[Cf. F. <ets>incomp\'82tence</ets>.]</ety>

<sn>1.</sn> <def>The quality or state of being incompetent; want
of physical, intellectual, or moral ability; insufficiency;
inadequacy; <as>as, the <ex>incompetency</ex> of a child hard
labor, or of an idiot for intellectual efforts</as>.</def>
\'bdSome inherent <xex>incompetency</xex>.\'b8

<au>Gladstone.</au>

<sn>2.</sn> <fld>(Law)</fld> <def>Want of competency or legal
fitness; incapacity; disqualification, as of a person to be heard
as a witness, or to act as a juror, or of a judge to try a
cause.</def>

<syn>Syn. -- Inability; insufficiency; inadequacy;
disqualification; incapability; unfitness.</syn>

<hw>In*com"pe*tent</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>a.</pos> <ety>[L.
<ets>incompetens</ets>: cf. F. <ets>incomp\'82tent</ets>. See
<er>In-</er> not, and <er>Competent</er>.]</ety>

<sn>1.</sn> <def>Not competent; wanting in adequate strength,
power, capacity, means, qualifications, or the like; incapable;
unable; inadequate; unfit.</def>

<q><qex>Incompetent</qex> to perform the duties of the place.</q>
<qau>Macaulay.</qau>

<sn>2.</sn> <fld>(Law)</fld> <def>Wanting the legal or
constitutional qualifications; inadmissible; <as>as, a person
professedly wanting in religious belief is an
<ex>incompetent</ex> witness in a court of law or equity;
<ex>incompetent</ex> evidence.</as></def>

<q>Richard III. had a resolution, out of hatred to his brethren,
to disable their issues, upon false and <qex>incompetent</qex>
pretexts, the one of attainder, the other of illegitimation.</q>
<qau>Bacon.</qau>

<sn>3.</sn> <def>Not lying within one's competency, capacity, or
authorized power; not permissible.</def>

<syn>Syn. -- Incapable; unable; inadequate; insufficient;
inefficient; disqualified; unfit; improper.</syn> <usage> --
<er>Incompetent</er>, <er>Incapable</er>. <xex>Incompetent</xex>
is a relative term, denoting a want of the requisite
qualifications for performing a given act, service, etc.;
<xex>incapable</xex> is absolute in its meaning, denoting want of
power, either natural or moral. We speak of a man as
<xex>incompetent</xex> to a certain task, of an
<xex>incompetent</xex> judge, etc. We say of an idiot that he is
<xex>incapable</xex> of learning to read; and of a man
distinguished for his honor, that he is <xex>incapable</xex> of a
mean action.</usage>

<hw>In*com"pe*tent*ly</hw>, <pos>adv.</pos> <def>In an competent
manner; inadequately; unsuitably.</def>

<hw>In`com*pet`i*bil"i*ty</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos>
<def>See <er>Incompatibility</er>.</def>

<hw>In`com*pet"i*ble</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>a.</pos> <def>See
<er>Incompatible</er>.</def>

<hw>In`com*plete"</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>a.</pos> <ety>[L.
<ets>incompletus</ets>: cf. F. <ets>incomplet</ets>. See
<er>In-</er> not, and <er>Complete</er>.]</ety>

<sn>1.</sn> <def>Not complete; not filled up; not finished; not
having all its parts, or not having them all adjusted; imperfect;
defective.</def>

<q>A most imperfect and <qex>incomplete</qex> divine.</q>
<qau>Milton.</qau>

<sn>2.</sn> <fld>(Bot.)</fld> <def>Wanting any of the usual
floral organs; -- said of a flower.</def>

<cs><col>Incomplete equation</col> <fld>(Alg.)</fld>, <cd>an
equation some of whose terms are wanting; or one in which the
coefficient of some one or more of the powers of the unknown
quantity is equal to 0.</cd></cs>

<hw>In`com*plete"ly</hw>, <pos>adv.</pos> <def>In an incomplete
manner.</def>

<hw>In`com*plete"ness</hw>, <pos>n.</pos> <def>The state of being
incomplete; imperfectness; defectiveness.</def>

<au>Boyle.</au>

completion; incompleteness.</def>

<au>Smart.</au>

<hw>In*com`pre*hen`si*bil"i*ty</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos>
<ety>[Cf. F. <ets>incompr\'82hensibilit\'82</ets>.]</ety>

<qau>South.</qau>

<hw>In*com`pre*hen"si*ble</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>a.</pos>

<ets>incompr\'82hensible</ets>. See <er>In-</er> not, and

<qau>Hooker.</qau>

<q>And all her numbered stars that seem to roll

<qau>Milton.</qau>

<hw>In`com*press`i*bil"i*ty</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos>

<hw>In`com*press"i*ble</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>a.</pos>

<ets>inconcevable</ets>.]</ety> <def>Not conceivable; incapable

the will acts in producing muscular motion</as>.</def>

substance should represent an extended figure.</q>

<-- no POS in original for -ity -->

<hw>In*con"gru*ence</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[L.
<ets>incongruentia</ets>.]</ety> <def>Want of congruence;
incongruity.</def>

<au>Boyle.</au>

<hw>In*con"gru*ent</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>a.</pos> <ety>[L.
<ets>incongruens</ets>. See <er>In-</er> not, and
<er>Congruent</er>.]</ety> <def>Incongruous.</def>

<au>Sir T. Elyot.</au>

<hw>In`con*gru"i*ty</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos>; <plu>pl.
<plw>Incongruities</plw> <pr>(#)</pr></plu>. <ety>[Pref.
<ets>in-</ets> not + <ets>congruity</ets>: cf. F.
<ets>incongruit\'82</ets>.]</ety>

<sn>1.</sn> <def>The quality or state of being incongruous; want
of congruity; unsuitableness; inconsistency; impropriety.</def>

<q>The fathers make use of this acknowledgment of the
<qex>incongruity</qex> of images to the Deity, from thence to
prove the <qex>incongruity</qex> of the worship of them.</q>
<qau>Bp. Stillingfleet.</qau>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>Disagreement of parts; want of symmetry or of
harmony.</def> <mark>[Obs.]</mark>

<sn>3.</sn> <def>That which is incongruous; want of
congruity.</def>

<hw>In*con"gru*ous</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>a.</pos> <ety>[L.
<ets>incongruus</ets>. See <er>In-</er> not, and
<er>Congruous</er>.]</ety> <def>Not congruous; reciprocally
disagreeing; not capable of harmonizing or readily assimilating;
inharmonious; inappropriate; unsuitable; not fitting;
inconsistent; improper; <as>as, an <ex>incongruous</ex> remark;
<ex>incongruous</ex> behavior, action, dress, etc.</as></def>
\'bd<xex>Incongruous</xex> mixtures of opinions.\'b8 <au>I.
Taylor</au>. \'bdMade up of <xex>incongruous</xex> parts.\'b8

<au>Macaulay.</au>

<q>Incongruous denotes that kind of absence of harmony or
suitableness of which the taste and experience of men takes
cognizance.</q>
<qau>C. J. Smith.</qau>

<cs><col>Incongruous numbers</col> <fld>(Arith.)</fld>, <cd>two
numbers, which, with respect to a third, are such that their
difference can not be divided by it without a remainder, the two
numbers being said to be <xex>incongruous<xex> with respect to
the third; as, twenty-five are <xex>incongruous<xex> with respect
to four.</cd></cs>

<syn>Syn. -- Inconsistent; unsuitable; inharmonious; disagreeing;
absurd; inappropriate; unfit; improper. See
<er>Inconsistent</er>.</syn>

-- <wordforms><wf>In*con"gru*ous*ly</wf>, <pos>adv.</pos> --
<wf>In*con"gru*ous*ness</wf>, <pos>n.</pos></wordforms>

<au>Bp. Warburton.</au>

without connection.</def> <mark>[Obs.]</mark>

<au>Sir T. Browne.</au>

<def>Unconscionable.</def> <mark>[Obs.]</mark>

<au>Spenser.</au>

<hw>In*con"scious</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>a.</pos>
<def>Unconscious.</def> <mark>[Obs.]</mark>

<hw>In`con*sec"u*tive*ness</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos>
<def>The state or quality of not being consecutive.</def>

<au>J. H. Newman.</au>

<hw>In*con"se*quence</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[L.
<ets>inconsequentia</ets>: cf. F.
<ets>incons\'82quence</ets>.]</ety> <def>The quality or state of
being inconsequent; want of just or logical inference or
argument; inconclusiveness.</def>

<au>Bp. Stillingfleet.</au>

<q>Strange, that you should not see the <qex>inconsequence</qex>
of your own reasoning!</q>
<qau>Bp. Hurd.</qau>

<hw>In*con"se*quent</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>a.</pos> <ety>[L.
<ets>inconsequens</ets>: cf. F. <ets>incons\'82quent</ets>. See
<er>In-</er> not, and <er>Consequent</er>.]</ety> <def>Not
following from the premises; not regularly inferred; invalid; not
characterized by logical method; illogical; arbitrary;
inconsistent; of no consequence.</def>

<q>Loose and <qex>inconsequent</qex> conjectures.</q>
<qau>Sir T. Browne.</qau>

<hw>In*con`se*quen"tial</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>a.</pos> <def>Not
regularly following from the premises; hence, irrelevant;
unimportant; of no consequence.</def> <au>Chesterfield</au>. --
<wordforms><wf>In*con`se*quen"tial*ly</wf> <pr>(#)</pr>,
<pos>adv.</pos></wordforms>

<hw>In*con`se*quen`ti*al"i*ty</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos>
<def>The state of being inconsequential.</def>

<hw>In*con"se*quent*ness</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos>
<def>Inconsequence.</def>

<hw>In`con*sid"er*a*ble</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>a.</pos> <def>Not
considerable; unworthy of consideration or notice; unimportant;
small; trivial; <as>as, an <ex>inconsiderable</ex> distance; an
<ex>inconsiderable</ex> quantity, degree, value, or
sum.</as></def>  \'bdThe baser scum and <xex>inconsiderable</xex>
dregs of Rome.\'b8 <au>Stepney</au>. --
<wordforms><wf>In`con*sid"er*a*ble*ness</wf>, <pos>n.</pos> --
<wf>In`con*sid"er*a*bly</wf>, <pos>adv.</pos></wordforms>

<hw>In`con*sid"er*a*cy</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos>
<def>Inconsiderateness; thoughtlessness.</def>
<mark>[Obs.]</mark>

<au>Chesterfield.</au>

<hw>In`con*sid"er*ate</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>a.</pos> <ety>[L.
<ets>inconsideratus</ets>. See <er>In-</er> not, and
<er>Considerate</er>.]</ety>

<sn>1.</sn> <def>Not considerate; not attentive to safety or to
propriety; not regarding the rights or feelings of others; hasty;
careless; thoughtless; heedless; <as>as, the young are generally
<ex>inconsiderate</ex>; <ex>inconsiderate</ex>
conduct.</as></def>

<q>It is a very unhappy token of our corruption, that ther<?/
should be any so <qex>inconsiderate</qex> among us as to
sacrifice morality to politics.</q>
<qau>Addison.</qau>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>Inconsiderable.</def> <mark>[Obs.]</mark>

<au>E. Terry.</au>

<syn>Syn. -- Thoughtless; inattentive; inadvertent; heedless;
negligent; improvident; careless; imprudent; indiscreet;
incautious; injudicious; rash; hasty.</syn>

<hw>In`con*sid"er*ate*ly</hw>, <pos>adv.</pos> <def>In an
inconsiderate manner.</def>

<hw>In`con*sid"er*ate*ness</hw>, <pos>n.</pos> <def>The quality
or state of being inconsiderate.</def>

<au>Tillotson.</au>

<hw>In`con*sid`er*a"tion</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos>
<ety>[L. <ets>inconsideratio</ets>: cf. F.
<ets>inconsid\'82ration</ets>.]</ety> <def>Want of due
consideration; inattention to consequences;
inconsiderateness.</def>

<q>Blindness of mind, <qex>inconsideration</qex>,
precipitation.</q>
<qau>Jer. Taylor.</qau>

<q>Not gross, willful, deliberate, crimes; but rather the effects
of <qex>inconsideration</qex>.</q>
<qau>Sharp.</qau>

<hw>In`con*sist"ence</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos>
<def>Inconsistency.</def>

<hw>In`con*sist"en*cy</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos>; <plu>pl.
<plw>Inconsistencies</plw> <pr>(#)</pr></plu>. <ety>[Cf. F.
<ets>inconsistance</ets>.]</ety>

<sn>1.</sn> <def>The quality or state of being inconsistent;
discordance in respect to sentiment or action; such contrariety
between two things that both can not exist or be true together;
disagreement; incompatibility.</def>

<q>There is a perfect <qex>inconsistency</qex> between that which
is of debt and that which is of free gift.</q>
<qau>South.</qau>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>Absurdity in argument ore narration; incoherence
or irreconcilability in the parts of a statement, argument, or
narration; that which is inconsistent.</def>

<q>If a man would register all his opinions upon love, politics,
religion, and learning, what a bundle of
<qex>inconsistencies</qex> and contradictions would appear at
last!</q>
<qau>Swift.</qau>

<sn>3.</sn> <def>Want of stability or uniformity; unsteadiness;
changeableness; variableness.</def>

<q>Mutability of temper, and <qex>inconsistency</qex> with
ourselves, is the greatest weakness of human nature.</q>
<qau>Addison.</qau>

<hw>In`con*sist"ent</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>a.</pos> <ety>[Pref.
<ets>in-</ets> not + <ets>consistent</ets>: cf. F.
<ets>inconsistant</ets>.]</ety>

<sn>1.</sn> <def>Not consistent; showing inconsistency;
irreconcilable; discordant; at variance, esp. as regards
character, sentiment, or action; incompatible; incongruous;
contradictory.</def>

<-- p. 747 -->

<q>Compositions of this nature . . . show that wisdom and virtue
are far from being <qex>inconsistent</qex> with politeness and
good humor.</q>
<qau>Addison.</qau>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>Not exhibiting uniformity of sentiment,
steadiness to principle, etc.; unequal; fickle; changeable.</def>

<q>Ah, how unjust to nature, and himself,
Is thoughtless, thankless, <qex>inconsistent</qex> man.</q>
<qau>Young.</qau>

<syn>Syn. -- Incompatible; incongruous; irreconcilable;
discordant; repugnant; contradictory.</syn> <usage> --
<er>Inconsistent</er>, <er>Incongruous</er>,
<er>Incompatible</er>. Things are <xex>incongruous</xex> when
they are not suited to each other, so that their union is
unbecoming; <xex>inconsistent</xex> when they are opposed to each
other, so as render it improper or wrong; <xex>incompatible</xex>
when they <xex>can not</xex> coexist, and it is therefore
impossible to unite them. Habitual levity of mind is
<xex>incongruous</xex> with the profession of a clergyman; it is
<xex>inconsistent</xex> with his ordination vows; it is
<xex>incompatible</xex> with his permanent usefulness.
<xex>Incongruity</xex> attaches to the modes and qualities of
things; <xex>incompatibility</xex> attaches to their essential
attributes; <xex>inconsistency</xex> attaches to the actions,
sentiments, etc., of men.</usage>

<hw>In`con*sist"ent*ly</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>adv.</pos> <def>In
an inconsistent manner.</def>

<hw>In`con*sist"ent*ness</hw>, <pos>n.</pos>
<def>Inconsistency.</def> <mark>[R.]</mark>

<hw>In`con*sist"ing</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>a.</pos>
<def>Inconsistent.</def> <mark>[Obs.]</mark>

<hw>In`con*sol"a*ble</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>a.</pos> <ety>[L.
<ets>inconsolabilis</ets>: cf. F. <ets>inconsolable</ets>. See
<er>In-</er> not, and <er>Console</er>.]</ety> <def>Not
consolable; incapable of being consoled; grieved beyond
susceptibility of comfort; disconsolate.</def>

<au>Dryden.</au>

<q>With <qex>inconsolable</qex> distress she griev'd,
And from her cheek the rose of beauty fied.</q>
<qau>Falconer.</qau>

<wf>In`con*sol"a*bly</wf>, <pos>adv.</pos></wordforms>

<hw>In*con"stance</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[F. See
<er>Inconstancy</er>.]</ety> <def>Inconstancy.</def>

<au>Chaucer.</au>

<hw>In*con"stan*cy</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[L.
<ets>inconstantia</ets>.]</ety> <def>The quality or state of
being inconstant; want of constancy; mutability; fickleness;
variableness.</def>

<q>For unto knight there was no greater shame,
Than lightness and <qex>inconstancie</qex> in love.</q>
<qau>Spenser.</qau>

<hw>In*con"stant</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>a.</pos> <ety>[L.
<ets>inconstans</ets>: cf. F. <ets>inconstant</ets>. See
<er>In-</er> not, and <er>Constant</er>.]</ety> <def>Not
constant; not stable or uniform; subject to change of character,
appearance, opinion, inclination, or purpose, etc.; not firm;
unsteady; fickle; changeable; variable; -- said of persons or
things; <as>as, <ex>inconstant</ex> in love or
friendship</as>.</def> \'bdThe <xex>inconstant</xex> moon.\'b8

<au>Shak.</au>

<q>While we, inquiring phantoms of a day,
<qex>Inconstant</qex> as the shadows we survey!</q>
<qau>Boyse.</qau>

<syn>Syn. -- Mutable; fickle; volatile; unsteady; unstable;
changeable; variable; wavering; fluctuating.</syn>

<hw>In*con"stant*ly</hw>, <pos>adv.</pos> <def>In an inconstant
manner.</def>

consumable; incapable of being consumed, wasted, or spent.</def>
<au>Paley</au>. -- <wordforms><wf>In`con*sum"a*bly</wf>,
<pos>adv.</pos></wordforms>

<hw>In`con*test`a*bil"i*ty</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos>
<def>The quality or state of being incontestable.</def>

<hw>In`con*test"a*ble</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>a.</pos>
<ety>[Pref. <ets>in-</ets> not + <ets>contestable</ets>: cf. F.
<ets>incontestable</ets>.]</ety> <def>Not contestable; not to be
disputed; that cannot be called in question or controverted;
incontrovertible; indisputable; <as>as, <ex>incontestable</ex>
evidence, truth, or facts</as>.</def>

<au>Locke.</au>

<syn>Syn. -- Incontrovertible; indisputable; irrefragable;
undeniable; unquestionable; intuitable; certain.</syn>

-- <wordforms><wf>In`con*test"a*ble*ness</wf>, <pos>n.</pos> --
<wf>In`con*test"a*bly</wf>, <pos>adv.</pos></wordforms>

<hw>In`con*test"ed</hw>, <pos>a.</pos> <def>Not contested.</def>

<au>Addison.</au>

<hw>In`con*tig"u*ous</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>a.</pos> <ety>[L.
<ets>incontiguus</ets> that can not be touched. See <er>In-</er>
not, and <er>Contiguous</er>.]</ety> <def>Not contiguous; not
adjoining or in contact; separate.</def> <au>Boyle</au>. --

<mhw>{ <hw>In*con"ti*nence</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>,
<hw>In*con"ti*nen*cy</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, }</mhw> <pos>n.</pos>
<ety>[L. <ets>incontinentia</ets>: cf. F.
<ets>incontinence</ets>.]</ety>

<sn>1.</sn> <def>Incapacity to hold; hence, incapacity to hold
back or restrain; the quality or state of being incontinent; want
of continence; failure to restrain the passions or appetites;
indulgence of lust; lewdness.</def>

<q>That Satan tempt you not for your <qex>incontinency</qex>.</q>
<qau>1 Cor. vii. 5.</qau>

<q>From the rash hand of bold <qex>incontinence</qex>.</q>
<qau>Milton.</qau>

<sn>2.</sn> <fld>(Med.)</fld> <def>The inability of any of the
animal organs to restrain the natural evacuations, so that the
discharges are involuntary; <as>as, <ex>incontinence</ex> of
urine</as>.</def>

<hw>In*con"ti*nent</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>a.</pos> <ety>[L.
<ets>incontinens</ets>: cf. F. <ets>incontinent</ets>. See
<er>In-</er> not, and <er>Continent</er>.]</ety>

<sn>1.</sn> <def>Not continent; uncontrolled; not restraining the
passions or appetites, particularly the sexual appetite;
indulging unlawful lust; unchaste; lewd.</def>

<sn>2.</sn> <fld>(Med.)</fld> <def>Unable to restrain natural
evacuations.</def>

<hw>In*con"ti*nent</hw>, <pos>n.</pos> <def>One who is
unchaste.</def>

<au>B. Jonson.</au>

<hw>In*con"ti*nent</hw>, <pos>adv.</pos> <ety>[Cf. F.
<ets>incontinent</ets>.]</ety> <def>Incontinently; instantly
immediately.</def> <mark>[Obs.]</mark>

<q>He says he will return <qex>incontinent</qex>.</q>
<qau>Shak.</qau>

<hw>In*con"ti*nent*ly</hw>, <pos>adv.</pos> <sn>1.</sn> <def>In
an incontinent manner; without restraint, or without due
restraint; -- used esp. of the passions or appetites.</def>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>Immediately; at once; forthwith.</def>
<mark>[Archaic]</mark>

<q>Immediately he sent word to Athens that he would
<qex>incontinently</qex> come hither with a host of men.</q>
<qau>Golding.</qau>

<hw>In`con*tract"ed</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>a.</pos>
<def>Uncontracted.</def> <mark>[Obs.]</mark>

<au>Blackwall.</au>

<hw>In`con*trol"la*ble</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>a.</pos>
<ety>[Pref. <ets>in-</ets> not + <ets>controllable</ets>: cf. F.
<ets>incontr\'93lable</ets>.]</ety> <def>Not controllable;
uncontrollable.</def> -- <wordforms><wf>In`con*trol"la*bly</wf>,
<pos>adv.</pos></wordforms>

<au>South.</au>

<hw>In*con`tro*ver`ti*bil"i*ty</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos>
<def>The state or condition of being incontrovertible.</def>

<hw>In*con`tro*ver"ti*ble</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>a.</pos>
<def>Not controvertible; too clear or certain to admit of
dispute; indisputable.</def> <au>Sir T. Browne</au>. --
<wordforms><wf>In*con`tro*ver"ti*ble*ness</wf>, <pos>n.</pos> --
<wf>In*con`tro*ver"ti*bly</wf>, <pos>adv.</pos></wordforms>

<hw>In`con*ven"ience</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[L.
<ets>inconvenientia</ets> inconsistency: cf. OF.
<ets>inconvenience</ets>.]</ety>

<sn>1.</sn> <def>The quality or condition of being inconvenient;
want of convenience; unfitness; unsuitableness; inexpediency;
awkwardness; <as>as, the <ex>inconvenience</ex> of the
arrangement</as>.</def>

<q>They plead against the <qex>inconvenience</qex>, not the
unlawfulness, . . . of ceremonies in burial.</q>
<qau>Hooker.</qau>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>That which gives trouble, embarrassment, or
uneasiness; disadvantage; anything that disturbs quiet, impedes
prosperity, or increases the difficulty of action or success;
<as>as, one <ex>inconvenience</ex> of life is poverty</as>.</def>

<q>A place upon the top of Mount Athos above all clouds of rain,
or other <qex>inconvenience</qex>.</q>
<qau>Sir W. Raleigh.</qau>

<q>Man is liable to a great many <qex>inconveniences</qex>.</q>
<qau>Tillotson.</qau>

<syn>Syn. -- Incommodiousness; awkwardness; disadvantage;
disquiet; uneasiness; disturbance; annoyance.</syn>

<hw>In`con*ven"ience</hw>, <pos>v. t.</pos> <def>To put to
inconvenience; to incommode; <as>as, to <ex>inconvenience</ex> a
neighbor</as>.</def>

<hw>In`con*ven"ien*cy</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos>
<def>Inconvenience.</def>

<hw>In`con*ven"ient</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>a.</pos> <ety>[L.
<ets>inconveniens</ets> unbefitting: cf. F.
<ets>inconv\'82nient</ets>. See <er>In-</er> not, and
<er>Convenient</er>.]</ety>

<sn>1.</sn> <def>Not becoming or suitable; unfit;
inexpedient.</def>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>Not convenient; giving trouble, uneasiness, or
annoyance; hindering progress or success; uncomfortable;
disadvantageous; incommodious; inopportune; <as>as, an
<ex>inconvenient</ex> house, garment, arrangement, or
time</as>.</def>

<syn>Syn. -- Unsuitable; uncomfortable; disaccommodating;
awkward; unseasonable; inopportune; incommodious;
disadvantageous; troublesome; cumbersome; embarrassing;
objectionable.</syn>

<hw>In`con*ven"ient*ly</hw>, <pos>adv.</pos> <def>In an
inconvenient manner; incommodiously; unsuitably;

<hw>In*cor"po*rate</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>a.</pos> <ety>[L.
<ets>incorporatus</ets>. See <er>In-</er> not, and
<er>Corporate</er>.]</ety>

<sn>1.</sn> <def>Not consisting of matter; not having a material
body; incorporeal; spiritual.</def>

<q>Moses forbore to speak of angles, and things invisible, and
<qex>incorporate</qex>.</q>
<qau>Sir W. Raleigh.</qau>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>Not incorporated; not existing as a corporation;
<as>as, an <ex>incorporate</ex> banking association</as>.</def>

<hw>In*cor"po*rate</hw>, <pos>a.</pos> <ety>[L.
<ets>incorporatus</ets>, p. p. of <ets>incorporare</ets> to
incorporate; pref. <ets>in-</ets> in + <ets>corporare</ets> to
make into a body. See <er>Corporate</er>.]</ety> <def>Corporate;
incorporated; made one body, or united in one body; associated;
mixed together; combined; embodied.</def>

<q>As if our hands, our sides, voices, and minds
Had been <qex>incorporate</qex>.</q>
<qau>Shak.</qau>

<q>A fifteenth part of silver <qex>incorporate</qex> with
gold.</q>
<qau>Bacon.</qau>

<hw>In*cor"po*rate</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>v. t.</pos>
<wordforms>[<pos>imp. & p. p.</pos> <er>Incorporated</er>
<pr>(?)</pr>; <pos>p. pr. & vb. n.</pos> <er>Incorporating</er>
<pr>(?)</pr>.]</wordforms>

<sn>1.</sn> <def>To form into a body; to combine, as different
ingredients. into one consistent mass.</def>

<q>By your leaves, you shall not stay alone,
Till holy church <qex>incorporate</qex> two in one.</q>
<qau>Shak.</qau>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>To unite with a material body; to give a
material form to; to embody.</def>

<q>The idolaters, who worshiped their images as golds, supposed
some spirit to be <qex>incorporated</qex> therein.</q>
<qau>Bp. Stillingfleet.</qau>

<sn>3.</sn> <def>To unite with, or introduce into, a mass already
formed; <as>as, to <ex>incorporate</ex> copper with silver</as>;
-- used with <xex>with</xex> and <xex>into</xex>.</def>

<sn>4.</sn> <def>To unite intimately; to blend; to assimilate; to
combine into a structure or organization, whether material or
mental; <as>as, to <ex>incorporate</ex> provinces into the realm;
to <ex>incorporate</ex> another's ideas into one's
work.</as></def>

<q>The Romans did not subdue a country to put the inhabitants to
fire and sword, but to <qex>incorporate</qex> them into their own
community.</q>
<qau>Addison.</qau>

<sn>5.</sn> <def>To form into a legal body, or body politic; to
constitute into a corporation recognized by law, with special
functions, rights, duties and liabilities; <as>as, to
<ex>incorporate</ex> a bank, a railroad company, a city or town,
etc.</as></def>

<hw>In*cor"po*rate</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>v. i.</pos> <def>To
unite in one body so as to make a part of it; to be mixed or
blended; -- usually followed by <xex>with</xex>.</def>

<q>Painters' colors and ashes do better <qex>incorporate</qex>
will oil.</q>
<qau>Bacon.</qau>

<q>He never suffers wrong so long to grow,
And to <qex>incorporate</qex> with right so far
As it might come to seem the same in show.</q>
<qau>Daniel.</qau>

<hw>In*cor"po*ra`ted</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>a.</pos> <def>United
in one body; formed into a corporation; made a legal
entity.</def>

<hw>In*cor`po*ra"tion</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[L.
<ets>incorporatio</ets>: cf. F. <ets>incorporation</ets>.]</ety>

<sn>1.</sn> <def>The act of incorporating, or the state of being
incorporated.</def>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>The union of different ingredients in one mass;
mixture; combination; synthesis.</def>

<sn>3.</sn> <def>The union of something with a body already
existing; association; intimate union; assimilation; <as>as, the
<ex>incorporation</ex> of conquered countries into the Roman
republic</as>.</def>

<sn>4.</sn> <fld>(Law)</fld> <sd>(a)</sd> <def>The act of
creating a corporation.</def> <sd>(b)</sd> <def>A body
incorporated; a corporation.</def>

<hw>In*cor"po*ra*tive</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>a.</pos>
<def>Incorporating or tending to incorporate; <as>as, the
<ex>incorporative</ex> languages (as of the Basques, North
American Indians, etc.</as> ) which run a whole phrase into one
word.</def>

<q>History demonstrates that <qex>incorporative</qex> unions are
solid and permanent; but that a federal union is weak.</q>
<qau>W. Belsham.</qau>

<hw>In*cor"po*ra`tor</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <def>One of
a number of persons who gets a company incorporated; one of the
original members of a corporation.</def>

<hw>In`cor*po"re*al</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>a.</pos> <ety>[Pref.
<ets>in-</ets> not + <ets>corporeal</ets>: cf. L.
<ets>incorporeus</ets>. Cf. <er>Incorporal</er>.]</ety>

<sn>1.</sn> <def>Not corporeal; not having a material body or
form; not consisting of matter; immaterial.</def>

<q>Thus <qex>incorporeal</qex> spirits to smaller forms
Reduced their shapes immense.</q>
<qau>Milton.</qau>

<q>Sense and perception must necessarily proceed from some
<qex>incorporeal</qex> substance within us.</q>
<qau>Bentley.</qau>

<sn>2.</sn> <fld>(Law)</fld> <def>Existing only in contemplation
of law; not capable of actual visible seizin or possession; not
being an object of sense; intangible; -- opposed to
<xex>corporeal</xex>.</def>

<cs><col>Incorporeal hereditament</col>. <cd>See under
<er>Hereditament</er>.</cd></cs>

<syn>Syn. -- Immaterial; unsubstantial; bodiless;
spiritual.</syn>

<au>Cudworth.</au>

<au>Cudworth.</au>

<hw>In`cor*rect"</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>a.</pos> <ety>[L.

<er>In-</er> not, and <er>Correct</er>.]</ety>

<sn>1.</sn> <def>Not correct; not according to a copy or model,
or to established rules; inaccurate; faulty.</def>

<q>The piece, you think, is <qex>incorrect</qex>.</q>
<qau>Pope.</qau>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>Not in accordance with the truth; inaccurate;
not exact; <as>as, an <ex>incorrect</ex> statement or
calculation</as>.</def>

<sn>3.</sn> <def>Not accordant with duty or morality; not duly
regulated or subordinated; unbecoming; improper; <as>as,
<ex>incorrect</ex> conduct</as>.</def>

<q>It shows a will most <qex>incorrect</qex> to heaven.</q>
<qau>Shak.</qau>

<q>The wit of the last age was yet more <qex>incorrect</qex> than
their language.</q>
<qau>Dryden.</qau>

<syn>Syn. -- Inaccurate; erroneous; wrong; faulty.</syn>

inflexibly just and upright.</def>

believed that the body of Christ was incorruptible, and that he
suffered hunger, thirst, pain, only in appearance.</def>

<hw>In*cras"sate</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>v. t.</pos>
<wordforms>[<pos>imp. & p. p.</pos> <er>Incrassated</er>
<pr>(?)</pr>; <pos>p. pr. & vb. n.</pos>
<er>Incrassating</er>.]</wordforms> <ety>[L.
<ets>incrassatus</ets>, p. p. of <ets>incrassare</ets>; pref.
<ets>in-</ets> in + <ets>crassus</ets> thick.]</ety> <def>To make
thick or thicker; to thicken; especially, in pharmacy, to thicken
(a liquid) by the mixture of another substance, or by evaporating
the thinner parts.</def>

<q>Acids dissolve or attenuate; alkalies precipitate or
<qex>incrassate</qex>.</q>
<qau>Sir I. Newton.</qau>

<q>Liquors which time hath <qex>incrassated</qex> into
jellies.</q>
<qau>Sir T. Browne.</qau>

<hw>In*cras"sate</hw>, <pos>v. i.</pos> <def>To become thick or
thicker.</def>

<mhw>{ <hw>In*cras"sate</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>,
<hw>In*cras"sa*ted</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, }</mhw> <pos>a.</pos>
<ety>[L. <ets>incrassatus</ets>, p. p.]</ety>

<sn>1.</sn> <def>Made thick or thicker; thickened;
inspissated.</def>

<sn>2.</sn> <fld>(Bot.)</fld> <def>Thickened; becoming
thicker.</def>

<au>Martyn.</au>

<sn>3.</sn> <fld>(Zo\'94l.)</fld> <def>Swelled out on some
particular part, as the antenn\'91 of certain insects.</def>

<hw>In`cras*sa"tion</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[Cf. F.
<ets>incrassation</ets>.]</ety>

<sn>1.</sn> <def>The act or process of thickening or making
thick; the process of becoming thick or thicker.</def>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>The state of being incrassated or made thick;
inspissation.</def>

<au>Sir T. Browne.</au>

<hw>In*cras"sa*tive</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>a.</pos> <def>Having
the quality of thickening; tending to thicken.</def>

<au>Harvey.</au>

<hw>In*cras"sa*tive</hw>, <pos>n.</pos> <def>A substance which
has the power to thicken; formerly, a medicine supposed to
thicken the humors.</def>

<au>Harvey.</au>

<hw>In*creas"a*ble</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>a.</pos> <def>Capable
of being increased.</def> <au>Sherwood</au>. --
<wordforms><wf>In*creas"a*ble*ness</wf>,
<pos>n.</pos></wordforms>

<q>An indefinite <qex>increasableness</qex> of some of our
ideas.</q>
<qau>Bp. Law.</qau>

<hw>In*crease"</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>v. i.</pos>
<wordforms>[<pos>imp. & p. p.</pos> <er>Increased</er>
<pr>(?)</pr>; <pos>p. pr. & vb. n.</pos>
<er>Increasing</er>.]</wordforms> <ety>[OE. <ets>incresen</ets>,
<ets>encresen</ets>, <ets>enrescen</ets>, OF.
<ets>encreistre</ets>, fr. L. <ets>increscere</ets>; pref.
<ets>in-</ets> in + <ets>crescere</ets> to grow. See
<er>Crescent</er>, and cf. <er>Decrease</er>.]</ety>

<sn>1.</sn> <def>To become greater or more in size, quantity,
number, degree, value, intensity, power, authority, reputation,
wealth; to grow; to augment; to advance; -- opposed to
<xex>decrease</xex>.</def>

<q>The waters <qex>increased</qex> and bare up the ark.</q>
<qau>Gen. vii. 17.</qau>

<q>He must <qex>increase</qex>, but I must decrease.</q>
<qau>John iii. 30.</qau>

<q>The heavens forbid
But that our loves and comforts should <qex>increase</qex>,
Even as our days do grow!</q>
<qau>Shak.</qau>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>To multiply by the production of young; to be
fertile, fruitful, or prolific.</def>

<q>Fishes are more numerous of <qex>increasing</qex> than beasts
or birds, as appears by their numerous spawn.</q>
<qau>Sir M. Hale.</qau>

<sn>3.</sn> <fld>(Astron.)</fld> <def>To become more nearly full;
to show more of the surface; to wax; <as>as, the moon
<ex>increases</ex></as>.</def>

<cs><col>Increasing function</col> <fld>(Math.)</fld>, <cd>a
function whose value increases when that of the variable
increases, and decreases when the latter is diminished.</cd></cs>

<syn>Syn. -- To enlarge; extend; multiply; expand; develop;
heighten; amplify; raise; enhance; spread; aggravate; magnify;
augment; advance.</syn> <usage> -- To <er>Increase</er>,
<er>Enlarge</er>, <er>Extend</er>. <xex>Enlarge</xex> implies to
make larger or broader in size. <xex>Extend</xex> marks the
progress of enlargement so as to have wider boundaries.
<xex>Increase</xex> denotes enlargement by growth and internal
vitality, as in the case of plants. A kingdom is
<xex>enlarged</xex> by the addition of new territories; the mind
is <xex>enlarged</xex> by knowledge. A kingdom is
<xex>extended</xex> when its boundaries are carried to a greater
distance from the center. A man's riches, honors, knowledge,
etc., are <xex>increased</xex> by accessions which are made from
time to time.</usage>

<hw>In*crease"</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>v. t.</pos> <def>To
augment or make greater in bulk, quantity, extent, value, or
amount, etc.; to add to; to extend; to lengthen; to enhance; to
aggravate; <as>as, to <ex>increase</ex> one's possessions,
influence</as>.</def>

<q>I will <qex>increase</qex> the famine.</q>
<qau>Ezek. v. 16.</qau>

<q>Make denials
<qex>Increase</qex> your services.</q>
<qau>Shak.</qau>

<hw>In"crease</hw> <pr>(?; 277)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[OE.
<ets>encres</ets>, <ets>encresse</ets>. See <er>Increase</er>,
<pos>v. i.</pos>]</ety>

<sn>1.</sn> <def>Addition or enlargement in size, extent,
quantity, number, intensity, value, substance, etc.;
augmentation; growth.</def>

<q>As if <qex>increase</qex> of appetite had grown
By what if fed on.</q>
<qau>Shak.</qau>

<q>For things of tender kind for pleasure made
Shoot up with swift <qex>increase</qex>, and sudden are
decay'd.</q>
<qau>Dryden.</qau>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>That which is added to the original stock by
augmentation or growth; produce; profit; interest.</def>

<q>Take thou no usury of him, or <qex>increase</qex>.</q>
<qau>Lev. xxv. 36.</qau>

<q>Let them not live to taste this land's
<qex>increase</qex>.</q>
<qau>Shak.</qau>

<sn>3.</sn> <def>Progeny; issue; offspring.</def>

<q>All the <qex>increase</qex> of thy house shall die in the
flower of their age.</q>
<qau>1 Sam. ii. 33.</qau>

<sn>4.</sn> <def>Generation.</def> <mark>[Obs.]</mark> \'bdOrgans
of <xex>increase</xex>.\'b8

<au>Shak.</au>

<sn>5.</sn> <fld>(Astron.)</fld> <def>The period of increasing
light, or luminous phase; the waxing; -- said of the moon.</def>

<q>Seeds, hair, nails, hedges, and herbs will grow soonest if set
or cut in the <qex>increase</qex> of the moon.</q>
<qau>Bacon.</qau>

<cs><col>Increase twist</col>, <cd>the twixt of a rifle groove in
which the angle of twist increases from the breech to the
muzzle.</cd></cs>

<syn>Syn. -- Enlargement; extension; growth; development;
increment; addition; accession; production.</syn>

<hw>In*crease"ful</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>a.</pos> <def>Full of
increase; abundant in produce.</def> \'bd<xex>Increaseful</xex>
crops.\'b8 <mark>[R.]</mark>

<au>Shak.</au>

<def>Increase.</def> <mark>[R.]</mark>

<au>Bacon.</au>

that, increases.</def>

<hw>In*creas"ing*ly</hw>, <pos>adv.</pos> <def>More and
more.</def>

<hw>In*cred`i*bil"i*ty</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[L.

<hw>In*cred"i*ble</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>a.</pos> <ety>[L.

you, that God should raise the dead?</q>
<qau>Acts xxvi. 8.</qau>

<ets>incr\'82dulit\'82</ets>.]</ety> <def>The state or quality of

<q>Of every species of <qex>incredulity</qex>, religious unbelief

<qau>Buckminster.</qau>

<hw>In*cred"u*lous</hw> <pr>(?; 135)</pr>, <pos>a.</pos> <ety>[L.

<qau>Bp. Wilkins.</qau>

<au>Shak.</au>

<hw>In*crem"a*ble</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>a.</pos> <ety>[Pref.

<hw>In"cre*ment</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[L.
<ets>incrementum</ets>: cf. F. <ets>incr\'82ment</ets>. See
<er>Increase</er>.]</ety>

<sn>1.</sn> <def>The act or process of increasing; growth in
bulk, guantity, number, value, or amount; augmentation;
enlargement.</def>

<q>The seminary that furnisheth matter for the formation and
<qex>increment</qex> of animal and vegetable bodies.</q>
<qau>Woodward.</qau>

<q>A nation, to be great, ought to be compressed in its
<qex>increment</qex> by nations more civilized than itself.</q>
<qau>Coleridge.</qau>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>Matter added; increase; produce; production; --
opposed to <xex>decrement</xex>.</def> \'bdLarge
<xex>increment</xex>.\'b8

<au>J. Philips.</au>

<sn>3.</sn> <fld>(Math.)</fld> <def>The increase of a variable
quantity or fraction from its present value to its next ascending
value; the finite quantity, generally variable, by which a
variable quantity is increased.</def>

<sn>4.</sn> <fld>(Rhet.)</fld> <def>An amplification without
strict climax, as in the following passage:</def>

<q>Finally, brethren, whatsoever things are true, whatsoever
things are honest, whatsoever things are just, whatsoever things
are pure, whatsoever things are lovely, whatsoever things are of
good report, . . . think on these things.</q>
<qau>Phil. iv. 8.</qau>

<cs><col>Infinitesimal increment</col> <fld>(Math.)</fld>, <cd>an
infinitesimally small variation considered in Differential
Calculus. See <er>Calculus</er>.</cd> -- <col>Method of
increments</col> <fld>(Math.)</fld>, <cd>a calculus founded on
the properties of the successive values of variable quantities
and their differences or increments. It differs from the
<xex>method of fluxions<xex> in treating these differences as
finite, instead of infinitely small, and is equivalent to the
calculus of <xex>finite differences<xex>.</cd></cs>

<fld>(Biol.)</fld> <def>Pertaining to, or resulting from, the
process of growth; <as>as, the <ex>incremental</ex> lines in the
dentine of teeth</as>.</def>

<hw>In*crust"</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>v. t.</pos>
<wordforms>[<pos>imp. & p. p.</pos> <er>Incrusted</er>; <pos>p.

<ets>incrustare</ets>; pref. <ets>in-</ets> in +

<ets>incruster</ets>. See <er>Crust</er>.]</ety> <altsp>[Written
also <asp>encrust</asp>.]</altsp>

<sn>1.</sn> <def>To cover or line with a crust, or hard coat; to
form a crust on the surface of; <as>as, iron <ex>incrusted</ex>
with rust; a vessel <ex>incrusted</ex> with salt; a sweetmeat
<ex>incrusted</ex> with sugar.</as></def>

<q>And by the frost refin'd the whiter snow,
<qex>Incrusted</qex> hard.</q>
<qau>Thomson.</qau>

<sn>2.</sn> <fld>(Fine Arts)</fld> <def>To inlay into, as a piece
of carving or other ornamental object.</def>

<sn>1.</sn> <def>The act of incrusting, or the state of being

<sn>2.</sn> <def>A crust or hard coating of anything upon or

<hw>In"cu*bate</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>v. i. & t.</pos>

<hw>In`cu*ba"tion</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[L.
<ets>incubatio</ets>: cf. F. <ets>incubation</ets>.]</ety>

<sn>1.</sn> <def>A sitting on eggs for the purpose of hatching
young; a brooding on, or keeping warm, (eggs) to develop the life
within, by any process.</def>

<au>Ray.</au>

<sn>2.</sn> <fld>(Med.)</fld> <def>The development of a disease
from its causes, or its period of incubation. (See below.)</def>

<sn>3.</sn> <def>A sleeping in a consecrated place for the
purpose of dreaming oracular dreams.</def>

<au>Tylor.</au>

<cs><mcol><col>Period of incubation</col>, <or/ <col>Stage of
incubation</col></mcol> <fld>(Med.)</fld>, <cd>the period which
elapses between exposure to the causes of a disease and the
attack resulting from it; the time of development of the supposed
germs or spores.</cd></cs><-- for infectious diseases -->

pertaining to incubation, or to the period of incubation.</def>

incubates, especially, an apparatus by means of which eggs are
hatched by artificial heat.</def>

<hw>In*cu"ba*to*ry</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>a.</pos> <def>Serving
for incubation.</def>

<hw>In"cu*bous</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>a.</pos> <ety>[From L.
<ets>incubare</ets> to lie on.]</ety> <fld>(Bot.)</fld>
<def>Having the leaves so placed that the upper part of each one

<hw>In"cu*bus</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos>; <plu>pl. E.
<plw>Incubuses</plw> <pr>(#)</pr>, L. <plw>Incubi</plw>
<pr>(#)</pr></plu>. <ety>[L., the nightmare. Cf.
<er>Incubate</er>.]</ety>

<sn>1.</sn> <def>A demon; a fiend; a lascivious spirit, supposed
to have sexual intercourse with women by night.</def>

<au>Tylor.</au>

<q>The devils who appeared in the female form were generally
called succubi; those who appeared like men <qex>incubi</qex>,
though this distinction was not always preserved.</q>
<qau>Lecky.</qau>

<sn>2.</sn> <fld>(Med.)</fld> <def>The nightmare. See
<er>Nightmare</er>.</def>

<q>Such as are troubled with <qex>incubus</qex>, or witch-ridden,
as we call it.</q>
<qau>Burton.</qau>

<sn>3.</sn> <def>Any oppressive encumbrance or burden; anything
that prevents the free use of the faculties.</def>

<q>Debt and usury is the <qex>incubus</qex> which weighs most
heavily on the agricultural resources of Turkey.</q>
<qau>J. L. Farley.</qau>

<hw>In*cul"cate</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>v. t.</pos>
<wordforms>[<pos>imp. & p. p.</pos> <er>Inculcated</er>; <pos>p.
pr. & vb. n.</pos> <er>Inculcating</er>
<pr>(?)</pr>.]</wordforms> <ety>[L. <ets>inculcatus</ets>, p. p.
of <ets>inculcare</ets> to tread on; pref. <ets>in-</ets> in, on
+ <ets>calcare</ets> to tread, fr. <ets>calx</ets> the heel;
perh. akin to E. <ets>heel</ets>. Cf. 2d <er>Calk</er>,
<er>Heel</er>.]</ety> <def>To teach and impress by frequent
repetitions or admonitions; to urge on the mind; <as>as, Christ
<ex>inculcates</ex> on his followers humility</as>.</def>

<q>The most obvious and necessary duties of life they have not
yet had authority enough to enforce and <qex>inculcate</qex> upon
men's minds.</q>
<qau>S. Clarke.</qau>

<syn>Syn. -- To instill; infuse; implant; engraft; impress.</syn>

<hw>In*cul"pate</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>v. t.</pos>
<wordforms>[<pos>imp. & p. p.</pos> <er>Inculpated</er>
<pr>(?)</pr>; <pos>p. pr. & vb. n.</pos> <er>Inculpating</er>
<pr>(?)</pr>.]</wordforms> <ety>[LL. <ets>inculpatus</ets>, p. p.
of <ets>inculpare</ets> to blame; pref. <ets>in-</ets> in +
<ets>culpa</ets> fault. See <er>Culpable</er>.]</ety> <note>[A
word of recent introduction.]</note> <def>To blame; to impute
guilt to; to accuse; to involve or implicate in guilt.</def>

<q>That risk could only exculpate her and not
<qex>inculpate</qex> them -- the probabilities protected them so
perfectly.</q>
<qau>H. James.</qau>
