<hw>In*cult"</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>a.</pos> <ety>[L.
<ets>incultus</ets>; pref. <ets>in-</ets> not +

F. <ets>inculte</ets>.]</ety> <def>Untilled; uncultivated; crude;

now full of magnificent cities.</q>
<qau>Burton.</qau>

<q>His style is diffuse and <qex>incult</qex>.</q>
<qau>M. W. Shelley.</qau>

<hw>In*cul`ti*va"tion</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <def>Want
of cultivation.</def> <mark>[Obs.]</mark>

<au>Berington.</au>

<hw>In*cul"ture</hw> <pr>(?; 135)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[Pref.
<ets>in-</ets> not + <ets>culture</ets>: cf. F.
<ets>inculture</ets>.]</ety> <def>Want or neglect of cultivation
or culture.</def> <mark>[Obs.]</mark>

<au>Feltham.</au>

<hw>In*cum"ben*cy</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos>; <plu>pl.
<plw>Incumbencies</plw> <pr>(#)</pr></plu>. <ety>[From
<er>Incumbent</er>.]</ety>

<sn>1.</sn> <def>The state of being incumbent; a lying or resting
on something.</def>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>That which is physically incumbent; that which
lies as a burden; a weight.</def>

<au>Evelyn.</au>

<sn>3.</sn> <def>That which is morally incumbent, or is imposed,
as a rule, a duty, obligation, or responsibility.</def> \'bdThe
<xex>incumbencies</xex> of a family.\'b8

<au>Donne.</au>

<sn>4.</sn> <def>The state of holding a benefice; the full
possession and exercise of any office.</def>

<q>These fines are only to be paid to the bishop during his
<qex>incumbency</qex>.</q>
<qau>Swift.</qau>

<hw>In*cum"bent</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>a.</pos> <ety>[L.
<ets>incumbens</ets>, <ets>-entis</ets>, p. pr. of
<ets>incumbere</ets> to lie down upon, press upon; pref.
<ets>in-</ets> in, on + <ets>cumbere</ets> (in comp.); akin to
<ets>cubare</ets> to lie down. See <er>Incubate</er>.]</ety>

<sn>1.</sn> <def>Lying; resting; reclining; recumbent;
superimposed; superincumbent.</def>

<q>Two <qex>incumbent</qex> figures, gracefully leaning upon
it.</q>
<qau>Sir H. Wotton.</qau>

<q>To move the <qex>incumbent</qex> load they try.</q>
<qau>Addison.</qau>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>Lying, resting, or imposed, as a duty or
obligation; obligatory; always with <xex>on</xex> or
<xex>upon</xex>.</def>

<q>All men, truly zealous, will perform those good works that are
<qex>incumbent</qex> on all Christians.</q>
<qau>Sprat.</qau>

<sn>3.</sn> <fld>(Bot.)</fld> <def>Leaning or resting; -- said of
anthers when lying on the inner side of the filament, or of
cotyledons when the radicle lies against the back of one of
them.</def>

<au>Gray.</au>

<sn>4.</sn> <fld>(Zo\'94l.)</fld> <def>Bent downwards so that the
ends touch, or rest on, something else; <as>as, the
<ex>incumbent</ex> toe of a bird</as>.</def>

<hw>In*cum"bent</hw>, <pos>n.</pos> <def>A person who is in
present possession of a benefice or of any office.</def>

<q>The <qex>incumbent</qex> lieth at the mercy of his patron.</q>
<qau>Swift.</qau>

<hw>In*cum"bent*ly</hw>, <pos>adv.</pos> <def>In an incumbent
manner; so as to be incumbent.</def>

<hw>\'d8In`cu*nab"u*lum</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos>;

<hw>In*cur"</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>v. t.</pos>
<wordforms>[<pos>imp. & p. p.</pos> <er>Incurred</er>
<pr>(?)</pr>; <pos>p. pr. & vb. n.</pos> <er>Incurring</er>
<pr>(?)</pr>.]</wordforms> <ety>[L. <ets>incurrere</ets> to run
into or toward; pref. <ets>in-</ets> in + <ets>currere</ets> to
run. See <er>Current</er>.]</ety>

<sn>1.</sn> <def>To meet or fall in with, as something
inconvenient, harmful, or onerous; to put one's self in the way
of; to expose one's self to; to become liable or subject to; to
bring down upon one's self; to encounter; to contract; <as>as, to
<ex>incur</ex> debt, danger, displeasure<?/ penalty,
responsibility, etc.</as></def>

<q>I know not what I shall <qex>incur</qex> to pass<?/<?/,
Having no warrant.</q>
<qau>Shak.</qau>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>To render liable or subject to; to
occasion.</def> <mark>[Obs.]</mark>

<q>Lest you <qex>incur</qex> me much more damage in my fame than
you have done me pleasure in preserving my life.</q>
<qau>Chapman.</qau>

<hw>In*cur"</hw>, <pos>v. i.</pos> <def>To pass; to enter.</def>
<mark>[Obs.]</mark>

<q>Light is discerned by itself because by itself it
<qex>incurs</qex> into the eye.</q>
<qau>South.</qau>

<hw>In*cur`a*bil"i*ty</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[Cf.
F. <ets>incurabilit\'82</ets> incurability, LL.
<ets>incurabilitas</ets> negligence.]</ety> <def>The state of
being uncurable; irremediableness.</def>

<au>Harvey.</au>

<hw>In*cur"a*ble</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>a.</pos> <ety>[F.
<ets>incurable</ets>, L. <ets>incurabilis</ets>. See <er>In-</er>
not, and <er>Curable</er>.]</ety>

<sn>1.</sn> <def>Not capable of being cured; beyond the power of
skill or medicine to remedy; <as>as, an <ex>incurable</ex>
disease</as>.</def>

<q>A scirrh is not absolutely <qex>incurable</qex>.</q>
<qau>Arbuthnot.</qau>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>Not admitting or capable of remedy or
correction; irremediable; remediless; <as>as, <ex>incurable</ex>
evils</as>.</def>

<q>Rancorous and <qex>incurable</qex> hostility.</q>
<qau>Burke.</qau>

<q>They were laboring under a profound, and, as it might have
seemed, an almost <qex>incurable</qex> ignorance.</q>
<qau>Sir J. Stephen.</qau>

<syn>Syn. -- Irremediable; remediless; irrecoverable;
irretrievable; irreparable; hopeless.</syn>

<hw>In*cur"a*ble</hw>, <pos>n.</pos> <def>A person diseased
beyond cure.</def>

<hw>In*cur"a*ble*ness</hw>, <pos>n.</pos> <def>The state of being
incurable; incurability.</def>

<au>Boyle.</au>

<hw>In*cur"a*bly</hw>, <pos>adv.</pos> <def>In a manner that
renders cure impracticable or impossible; irremediably.</def>
\'bd<xex>Incurably</xex> diseased.\'b8 <au>Bp. Hall</au>.
\'bd<xex>Incurably</xex> wicked.\'b8

<au>Blair.</au>

<hw>In*cur"rent</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>a.</pos> <ety>[L.

<hw>In*cur"sion</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[L.
<ets>incursio</ets>: cf. F. <ets>incursion</ets>. See
<er>Incur</er>.]</ety>

<sn>1.</sn> <def>A running into; hence, an entering into a
territory with hostile intention; a temporary invasion; a
predatory or harassing inroad; a raid.</def>

<q>The Scythian, whose <qex>incursions</qex> wild
Have wasted Sogdiana.</q>
<qau>Milton.</qau>

<q>The <qex>incursions</qex> of the Goths disordered the affairs
of the Roman Empire.</q>
<qau>Arbuthnot.</qau>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>Attack; occurrence.</def> <mark>[Obs.]</mark>

<q>Sins of daily <qex>incursion</qex>.</q>
<qau>South.</qau>

<syn>Syn. -- Invasion; inroad; raid; foray; sally; attack; onset;
irruption. See <er>Invasion</er>.</syn>

<hw>In*de"cen*cy</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos>; <plu>pl.
<plw>Indecencies</plw> <pr>(#)</pr></plu>. <ety>[L.
<ets>indecentia</ets> unseemliness: cf. F.
<ets>ind\'82cence</ets>.]</ety>

<sn>1.</sn> <def>The quality or state of being indecent; want of
decency, modesty, or good manners; obscenity.</def>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>That which is indecent; an indecent word or act;
an offense against delicacy.</def>

<q>They who, by speech or writing, present to the ear or the eye
of modesty any of the <qex>indecencies</qex> I allude to, are
pests of society.</q>
<qau>Beattie.</qau>

<syn>Syn. -- Indelicacy; indecorum; immodesty; impurity;
obscenity. See <er>Indecorum</er>.</syn>

<hw>In*de"cent</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>a.</pos> <ety>[L.
<ets>indecens</ets> unseemly, unbecoming: cf. F.
<ets>ind\'82cent</ets>. See <er>In-</er> not, and
<er>Decent</er>.]</ety> <def>Not decent; unfit to be seen or
heard; offensive to modesty and delicacy; <as>as,
<ex>indecent</ex> language</as>.</def>

<au>Cowper.</au>

<syn>Syn. -- Unbecoming; indecorous; indelicate; unseemly;
immodest; gross; shameful; impure; improper; obscene;
filthy.</syn>

<hw>In`de*ci"sion</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[Pref.
<ets>in-</ets> not + <ets>decision</ets>: cf. F.
<ets>ind\'82cision</ets>.]</ety> <def>Want of decision; want of
settled purpose, or of firmness; indetermination; wavering of
mind; irresolution; vacillation; hesitation.</def>

<q>The term <qex>indecision</qex> . . . implies an idea very
nicely different from irresolution; yet it has a tendency to
produce it.</q>
<qau>Shenstone.</qau>

<q><qex>Indecision</qex> . . . is the natural accomplice of
violence.</q>
<qau>Burke.</qau>

<hw>In`de*ci"sive</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>a.</pos> <ety>[Cf. F.
<ets>ind\'82cisif</ets>.]</ety>

<sn>1.</sn> <def>Not decisive; not bringing to a final or
ultimate issue; <as>as, an <ex>indecisive</ex> battle, argument,
answer</as>.</def>

<q>The campaign had everywhere been <qex>indecisive</qex>.</q>
<qau>Macaulay.</qau>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>Undetermined; prone to indecision; irresolute;
unsettled; wavering; vacillating; hesitating; <as>as, an
<ex>indecisive</ex> state of mind; an <ex>indecisive</ex>
character.</as></def>

<hw>In`de*ci"sive*ly</hw>, <pos>adv.</pos> <def>Without
decision.</def>

<hw>In`de*ci"sive*ness</hw>, <pos>n.</pos> <def>The state of
being indecisive; unsettled state.</def>

<hw>In`de*cin"a*ble</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>a.</pos> <ety>[L.
<ets>indeclinabilis</ets>: cf. F. <ets>ind\'82clinable</ets>. See
<er>In-</er> not, and <er>Decline</er>.]</ety> <fld>(Gram.)</fld>
<def>Not declinable; not varied by inflective terminations;
<as>as, <ex>nihil</ex> (nothing), in Latin, is an
<ex>indeclinable</ex> noun</as>.</def> -- <def2><pos>n.</pos>
<def>An indeclinable word.</def></def2>

<hw>In`de*cin"a*bly</hw>, <pos>adv.</pos> <sn>1.</sn>
<def>Without variation.</def>

<sn>2.</sn> <fld>(Gram.)</fld> <def>Without variation of
termination.</def>

<hw>In*de`com*pos"a*ble</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>a.</pos>
<ety>[Pref. <ets>in-</ets> not + <ets>decomposable</ets>: cf. F.
<ets>ind\'82composable</ets>.]</ety> <def>Not decomposable;
incapable or difficult of decomposition; not resolvable into its
constituents or elements.</def>

<hw>In*de`com*pos"a*ble*ness</hw>, <pos>n.</pos>
<def>Incapableness of decomposition; stability; permanence;
durability.</def>

<hw>In`de*co"rous</hw> <pr>(?; 277)</pr>, <pos>a.</pos> <ety>[L.
<ets>indecorous</ets>. See <er>In-</er> not, and
<er>Decorous</er>.]</ety> <def>Not decorous; violating good
manners; contrary to good breeding or etiquette; unbecoming;
improper; out of place; <as>as, <ex>indecorous</ex>
conduct</as>.</def>

<q>It was useless and <qex>indecorous</qex> to attempt anything
more by mere struggle.</q>
<qau>Burke.</qau>

<syn>Syn. -- Unbecoming; unseemly; unbefitting; rude; coarse;
impolite; uncivil; ill-bred.</syn>

<hw>In`de*co"rous*ly</hw>, <pos>adv.</pos> <def>In an indecorous
manner.</def>

<hw>In`de*co"rous*ness</hw>, <pos>n.</pos> <def>The quality of
being indecorous; want of decorum.</def>

<hw>In`de*co"rum</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[Pref.
<ets>in-</ets> not + <ets>decorum</ets>: cf. L.
<ets>indecorous</ets> unbecoming.]</ety>

<sn>1.</sn> <def>Want of decorum; impropriety of behavior; that
in behavior or manners which violates the established rules of
civility, custom, or etiquette; indecorousness.</def>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>An indecorous or becoming action.</def>

<au>Young.</au>

<syn>Syn. -- <xex>Indecorum</xex> is sometimes synonymous with
<xex>indecency</xex>; but <xex>indecency</xex>, more frequently
than <xex>indecorum</xex>, is applied to words or actions which
refer to what nature and propriety require to be concealed or
suppressed. <xex>Indecency</xex> is the stronger word;
<xex>indecorum</xex> refers to any transgression of etiquette or
civility, especially in public.</syn>

<hw>In*deed"</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>adv.</pos> <ety>[Prep.
<ets>in + deed</ets>.]</ety> <def>In reality; in truth; in fact;
verily; truly; -- used in a variety of sense. Esp.: <sd>(a)</sd>
Denoting emphasis; <as>as, <ex>indeed</ex> it is so</as>.
<sd>(b)</sd> Denoting concession or admission; <as>as,
<ex>indeed</ex>, you are right</as>. <sd>(c)</sd> Denoting
surprise; <as>as, <ex>indeed</ex>, is it you? Its meaning is not
intrinsic or fixed, but depends largely on the form of expression
which it accompanies</as>.</def>

<-- p. 750 -->

<q>The carnal mind is enmity against God; for it is not subject
to the law of God, neither <qex>indeed</qex> can be.</q>
<qau>Rom. viii. 7.</qau>

<q>I were a beast <qex>indeed</qex> to do you wrong.</q>
<qau>Dryden.</qau>

<q>There is, <qex>indeed</qex>, no great pleasure in visiting
these magazines of war.</q>
<qau>Addison.</qau>

<hw>In`de*fat`i*ga*bil"i*ty</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos>

<hw>In`de*fat"i*ga*ble</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>a.</pos> <ety>[L.
<ets>indefatigabilis</ets>: cf. OF. <ets>indefatigable</ets>. See
<er>In-</er> not, and <er>Defatigable</er>, and cf.
<er>Infatigable</er>.]</ety> <def>Incapable of being fatigued;
not readily exhausted; unremitting in labor or effort; untiring;

<ex>indefatigable</ex> exertions, perseverance,

attendance.\'b8

<au>South.</au>

<q>Upborne with <qex>indefatigable</qex> wings.</q>
<qau>Milton.</qau>

<syn>Syn. -- Unwearied; untiring; persevering; persistent.</syn>

<hw>In*def"i*nite</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>a.</pos> <ety>[L.
<ets>indefinitus</ets>. See <er>In-</er> not, and
<er>Definite</er>.]</ety>

<sn>1.</sn> <def>Not definite; not limited, defined, or
specified; not explicit; not determined or fixed upon; not
precise; uncertain; vague; confused; obscure; <as>as, an
<ex>indefinite</ex> time, plan, etc.</as></def>

<q>It were to be wished that . . . men would leave off that
<qex>indefinite</qex> way of vouching, \'bdthe chymists say
this,\'b8 or \'bdthe chymists affirm that.\'b8</q>
<qau>Boyle.</qau>

<q>The time of this last is left <qex>indefinite</qex>.</q>
<qau>Dryden.</qau>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>Having no determined or certain limits; large
and unmeasured, though not infinite; unlimited; as
<xex>indefinite</xex> space; the <xex>indefinite</xex> extension
of a straight line.</def>

<q>Though it is not infinite, it may be <qex>indefinite</qex>;
though it is not boundless in itself, it may be so to human
comprehension.</q>
<qau>Spectator.</qau>

<sn>3.</sn> <def>Boundless; infinite.</def> <mark>[R.]</mark>

<q><qex>Indefinite</qex> and omnipresent God,
Inhabiting eternity.</q>
<qau>W. Thompson (1745).</qau>

<sn>4.</sn> <fld>(Bot.)</fld> <def>Too numerous or variable to
make a particular enumeration important; -- said of the parts of
a flower, and the like. Also, indeterminate.</def>

<cs><col>Indefinite article</col> <fld>(Gram.)</fld>, <cd>the
word <xex>a<xex> or <xex>an<xex>, used with nouns to denote any
one of a common or general class.</cd> -- <col>Indefinite
inflorescence</col>. <fld>(Bot.)</fld> <cd>See
<cref>Indeterminate inflorescence</cref>, under
<er>Indeterminate</er>.</cd> -- <col>Indefinite proposition</col>
<fld>(Logic)</fld>, <cd>a statement whose subject is a common
term, with nothing to indicate distribution or nondistribution;
as, <xex>Man is mortal<xex>.</cd> -- <col>Indefinite term</col>
<fld>(Logic)</fld>, <cd>a negative term; as, <xex>the
not-good<xex>.</cd></cs>

<syn>Syn. -- Inexplicit; vague; uncertain; unsettled;
indeterminate; loose; equivocal; inexact; approximate.</syn>

<hw>In*def"i*nite*ly</hw>, <pos>adv.</pos> <def>In an indefinite
manner or degree; without any settled limitation; vaguely; not
with certainty or exactness; <as>as, to use a word
<ex>indefinitely</ex></as>.</def>

<q>If the world be <qex>indefinitely</qex> extended, that is, so
far as no human intellect can fancy any bound of it.</q>
<qau>Ray.</qau>

<hw>In*def"i*nite*ness</hw>, <pos>n.</pos> <def>The quality of
being indefinite.</def>

<au>Sir M . Hale.</au>

<hw>In*del`i*bil"i*ty</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[Cf.
F. <ets>ind\'82l\'82bilit\'82</ets>.]</ety> <def>The quality of
being indelible.</def>

<au>Bp. Horsley.</au>

<hw>In*del"i*ble</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>a.</pos> <ety>[L.
<ets>indelebilis</ets>; pref.<ets>in-</ets> not +
<ets>delebilis</ets> capable of being destroyed: cf. F.
<ets>ind\'82l\'82bile</ets>. See <er>In-</er> not, and
<er>Deleble</er>.]</ety> <altsp>[Formerly written also
<asp>indeleble</asp>, which accords with the etymology of the
word.]</altsp>

<sn>1.</sn> <def>That can not be removed, washed away, blotted
out, or effaced; incapable of being canceled, lost, or forgotten;
<as>as, <ex>indelible</ex> characters; an <ex>indelible</ex>
stain; an <ex>indelible</ex> impression on the memory.</as></def>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>That can not be annulled; indestructible.</def>
<mark>[R.]</mark>

<q>They are endued with <qex>indelible</qex> power from
above.</q>
<qau>Sprat.</qau>

<cs><col>Indelible colors</col>, <cd>fast colors which do not
fade or tarnish by exposure.</cd> -- <col>Indelible ink</col>,
<cd>an ink obliterated by washing; esp., a solution of silver
nitrate.</cd></cs>

<syn>Syn. -- Fixed; fast; permanent; ineffaceable.</syn>

-- <wordforms><wf>In*del"i*ble*ness</wf>, <pos>n.</pos> --
<wf>In*del"i*bly</wf>, <pos>adv.</pos></wordforms>

<q><qex>Indelibly</qex> stamped and impressed.</q>
<qau>J. Ellis.</qau>

<hw>In*del"i*ca*cy</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos>; <plu>pl.
<plw>Indelicacies</plw> <pr>(#)</pr></plu>. <ety>[From
<er>Indelicate</er>.]</ety> <def>The quality of being indelicate;
want of delicacy, or of a nice sense of, or regard for, purity,
propriety, or refinement in manners, language, etc.; rudeness;
coarseness; also, that which is offensive to refined taste or
purity of mind.</def>

<q>The <qex>indelicacy</qex> of English comedy.</q>
<qau>Blair.</qau>

<q>Your papers would be chargeable with worse than
<qex>indelicacy</qex>; they would be immoral.</q>
<qau>Addison.</qau>

<hw>In*del"i*cate</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>a.</pos> <ety>[Pref.
<ets>in-</ets> not + <ets>delicate</ets>: cf. F.
<ets>ind\'82licat</ets>.]</ety> <def>Not delicate; wanting
delicacy; offensive to good manners, or to purity of mind;
coarse; rude; <as>as, an <ex>indelicate</ex> word or suggestion;
<ex>indelicate</ex> behavior</as>.</def> <au>Macaulay</au>. --
<wordforms><wf>In*del"i*cate*ly</wf>, <pos>adv.</pos></wordforms>

<syn>Syn. -- Indecorous; unbecoming; unseemly; rude; coarse;
broad; impolite; gross; indecent; offensive; improper; unchaste;
impure; unrefined.</syn>

<hw>In*dem`ni*fi*ca"tion</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos>
<sn>1.</sn> <def>The act or process of indemnifying, preserving,
or securing against loss, damage, or penalty; reimbursement of
loss, damage, or penalty; the state of being indemnified.</def>

<q><qex>Indemnification</qex> is capable of some estimate;
dignity has no standard.</q>
<qau>Burke.</qau>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>That which indemnifies.</def>

<q>No reward with the name of an <qex>indemnification</qex>.</q>
<qau>De Quincey.</qau>

<hw>In*dem"ni*fy</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>v. t.</pos>
<wordforms>[<pos>imp. & p. p.</pos> <er>Indemnified</er>
<pr>(?)</pr>; <pos>p. pr. & vb. n.</pos> <er>Indemnifying</er>
<pr>(?)</pr>.]</wordforms> <ety>[L. <ets>indemnis</ets> unhurt
(in- not + <ets>damnum</ets> hurt, damage) + <ets>-fy</ets>. Cf.
<er>Damn</er>, <er>Damnify</er>.]</ety>

<sn>1.</sn> <def>To save harmless; to secure against loss or
damage; to insure.</def>

<q>The states must at last engage to the merchants here that they
will <qex>indemnify</qex> them from all that shall fall out.</q>
<qau>Sir W. Temple.</qau>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>To make restitution or compensation for, as for
that which is lost; to make whole; to reimburse; to
compensate.</def>

<au>Beattie.</au>

<hw>In*dem"ni*ty</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos>; <plu>pl.
<plw>Indemnities</plw> <pr>(#)</pr></plu>. <ety>[L.
<ets>indemnitas</ets>, fr. <ets>indemnis</ets> uninjured: cf. F.
<ets>indemnit\'82</ets>. See <er>Indemnify</er>.]</ety>

<sn>1.</sn> <def>Security; insurance; exemption from loss or
damage, past or to come; immunity from penalty, or the punishment
of past offenses; amnesty.</def>

<q>Having first obtained a promise of <qex>indemnity</qex> for
the riot they had committed.</q>
<qau>Sir W. Scott.</qau>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>Indemnification, compensation, or remuneration
for loss, damage, or injury sustained.</def>

<q>They were told to expect, upon the fall of Walpole, a large
and lucrative <qex>indemnity</qex> for their pretended
wrongs.</q>
<qau>Ld. Mahon.</qau>

<note><hand/ Insurance is a contract of <xex>indemnity</xex>.
<au>Arnould</au>. The owner of private property taken for public
use is entitled to compensation or <xex>indemnity</xex>.</note>

<au>Kent.</au>

<cs><col>Act of indemnity</col> <fld>(Law)</fld>, <cd>an act or
law passed in order to relieve persons, especially in an official
station, from some penalty to which they are liable in
consequence of acting illegally, or, in case of ministers, in
consequence of exceeding the limits of their strict
constitutional powers. These acts also sometimes provide
compensation for losses or damage, either incurred in the service
of the government, or resulting from some public
measure.</cd></cs>

<def>The quality of being indemonstrable.</def>

<hw>In`de*mon"stra*ble</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>a.</pos> <ety>[L.
<ets>indemonstrabilis</ets>. See <er>In-</er> not, and
<er>Demonstrable</er>.]</ety> <def>Incapable of being

<hw>In*den"i*zen</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>v. t.</pos>

<hw>In*dent"</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>v. t.</pos>
<wordforms>[<pos>imp. & p. p.</pos> <er>Indented</er>; <pos>p.
pr. & vb. n.</pos> <er>Indenting</er>.]</wordforms> <ety>[OE.
<ets>endenten</ets> to notch, fit in, OF. <ets>endenter</ets>,
LL. <ets>indentare</ets>, fr. L. <ets>in + dens</ets>,
<ets>dentis</ets>, tooth. See <er>Tooth</er>, and cf.
<er>Indenture</er>.]</ety>

<sn>1.</sn> <def>To notch; to jag; to cut into points like a row
of teeth; <as>as, to <ex>indent</ex> the edge of
paper</as>.</def>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>To dent; to stamp or to press in; to impress;
<as>as, <ex>indent</ex> a smooth surface with a hammer; to
<ex>indent</ex> wax with a stamp.</as></def>

<sn>3.</sn> <ety>[Cf. <er>Indenture</er>.]</ety> <def>To bind out
by indenture or contract; to indenture; to apprentice; <as>as, to
<ex>indent</ex> a young man to a shoemaker; to <ex>indent</ex> a
servant.</as></def>

<sn>4.</sn> <fld>(Print.)</fld> <def>To begin (a line or lines)
at a greater or less distance from the margin; <as>as, to
<ex>indent</ex> the first line of a paragraph one em; to
<ex>indent</ex> the second paragraph two ems more than the first.
See <er>Indentation</er>, and <er>Indention</er>.</as></def>

<sn>5.</sn> <fld>(Mil.)</fld> <def>To make an order upon; to draw
upon, as for military stores.</def> <mark>[India]</mark>

<au>Wilhelm.</au>

<hw>In*dent"</hw>, <pos>v. i.</pos> <sn>1.</sn> <def>To be cut,
notched, or dented.</def>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>To crook or turn; to wind in and out; to
zigzag.</def>

<sn>3.</sn> <def>To contract; to bargain or covenant.</def>

<au>Shak.</au>

<q>To <qex>indent</qex> and drive bargains with the Almighty.</q>
<qau>South.</qau>

<hw>In*dent"</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <sn>1.</sn> <def>A
cut or notch in the man gin of anything, or a recess like a
notch.</def>

<au>Shak.</au>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>A stamp; an impression.</def>
<mark>[Obs.]</mark>

<sn>3.</sn> <def>A certificate, or intended certificate, issued
by the government of the United States at the close of the
Revolution, for the principal or interest of the public
debt.</def>

<au>D. Ramsay. A. Hamilton.</au>

<sn>4.</sn> <fld>(Mil.)</fld> <def>A requisition or order for
supplies, sent to the commissariat of an army.</def>
<mark>[India]</mark>

<au>Wilhelm.</au>

<hw>In`den*ta"tion</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <sn>1.</sn>
<def>The act of indenting or state of being indented.</def>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>A notch or recess, in the margin or border of
anything; <as>as, the <ex>indentations</ex> of a leaf, of the
coast, etc.</as></def>

<sn>3.</sn> <def>A recess or sharp depression in any
surface.</def>

<sn>4.</sn> <fld>(Print.)</fld> <sd>(a)</sd> <def>The act of
beginning a line or series of lines at a little distance within
the flush line of the column or page, as in the common way of
beginning the first line of a paragraph.</def> <sd>(b)</sd>
<def>The measure of the distance; <as>as, an <ex>indentation</ex>
of one em, or of two ems</as>.</def>

<cs><mcol><col>Hanging</col>, <or/ <col>Reverse</col>,
<col>indentation</col></mcol>, <cd>indentation of all the lines
of a paragraph except the first, which is a full line.</cd></cs>

<hw>In*dent"ed</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>a.</pos> <sn>1.</sn>
<def>Cut in the edge into points or inequalities, like teeth;
jagged; notched; stamped in; dented on the surface.</def>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>Having an uneven, irregular border; sinuous;
undulating.</def>

<au>Milton. Shak.</au>

<sn>3.</sn> <fld>(Her.)</fld> <def>Notched like the part of a saw
consisting of the teeth; serrated; <as>as, an <ex>indented</ex>
border or ordinary</as>.</def>

<sn>4.</sn> <def>Bound out by an indenture; apprenticed;
indentured; <as>as, an <ex>indented</ex> servant</as>.</def>

<sn>5.</sn> <fld>(Zo\'94l.)</fld> <def>Notched along the margin
with a different color, as the feathers of some birds.</def>

<cs><col>Indented line</col> <fld>(Fort.)</fld>, <cd>a line with
alternate long and short faces, with salient and receding angles,
each face giving a flanking fire along the front of the
next.</cd></cs>

<hw>In*dent"ed*ly</hw>, <pos>adv.</pos> <def>With
indentations.</def>

<hw>In*dent"ing</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos>
<def>Indentation; an impression like that made by a tooth.</def>

<hw>In*den"tion</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos>
<fld>(Print.)</fld> <def>Same as <er>Indentation</er>, 4.</def>

<hw>In*dent"ment</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos>
<def>Indenture.</def> <mark>[Obs.]</mark>

<hw>In*den"ture</hw> <pr>(?; 135)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[OE.
<ets>endenture</ets>, OF. <ets>endenture</ets>, LL.
<ets>indentura</ets> a deed in duplicate, with indented edges.
See the Note below. See <er>Indent</er>.]</ety>

<sn>1.</sn> <def>The act of indenting, or state of being
indented.</def>

<sn>2.</sn> <fld>(Law)</fld> <def>A mutual agreement in writing
between two or more parties, whereof each party has usually a
counterpart or duplicate; sometimes in the <pluf>pl.</pluf>, a
short form for <altname>indentures of apprenticeship</altname>,
the contract by which a youth is bound apprentice to a
master.</def><-- obs? -->

<q>The law is the best expositor of the gospel; they are like a
pair of <qex>indentures</qex>: they answer in every part.</q>
<qau>C. Leslie.</qau>

<note><hand/ Indentures were originally duplicates, laid together
and intended by a notched cut or line, or else written on the
same piece of parchment and separated by a notched line so that
the two papers or parchments corresponded to each other. But
indenting has gradually become a mere form, and is often
neglected, while the writings or counterparts retain the name of
<xex>indentures</xex>.</note>

<hw>In*den"ture</hw>, <pos>v. t.</pos> <wordforms>[<pos>imp. & p.
p.</pos> <er>Indentured</er> <pr>(?)</pr>; <pos>p. pr. & vb.
n.</pos> <er>Indenturing</er>.]</wordforms>

<sn>1.</sn> <def>To indent; to make hollows, notches, or wrinkles
in; to furrow.</def>

<q>Though age may creep on, and <qex>indenture</qex> the
brow.</q>
<qau>Woty.</qau>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>To bind by indentures or written contract;
<as>as, to <ex>indenture</ex> an apprentice</as>.</def>

<hw>In*den"ture</hw>, <pos>v. i.</pos> <def>To run or wind in and
out; to be cut or notched; to indent.</def>

<au>Heywood.</au>

<hw>In`de*pend"ence</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[Cf. F.
<ets>ind\'82pendance</ets>.]</ety>

<sn>1.</sn> <def>The state or quality of being independent;
freedom from dependence; exemption from reliance on, or control
by, others; self-subsistence or maintenance; direction of one's
own affairs without interference.</def>

<q>Let fortune do her worst, . . . as long as she never makes us
lose our honesty and our <qex>independence</qex>.</q>
<qau>Pope.</qau>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>Sufficient means for a comfortable
livelihood.</def>

<cs><col>Declaration of Independence</col> <fld>(Amer.
Hist.)</fld>, <cd>the declaration of the Congress of the Thirteen
United States of America, on the 4th of July, 1776, by which they
formally declared that these colonies were free and independent
States, not subject to the government of Great Britain.</cd></cs>

<hw>In`de*pend"en*cy</hw>, <pos>n.</pos> <sn>1.</sn>
<def>Independence.</def>

<q>\'bdGive me,\'b8 I cried (enough for me),
\'bdMy bread, and <qex>independency</qex>!\'b8</q>
<qau>Pope.</qau>

<sn>2.</sn> <fld>(Eccl.)</fld> <def>Doctrine and polity of the
Independents.</def>

<hw>In`de*pend"ent</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>a.</pos> <ety>[Pref.
<ets>in-</ets> not + <ets>dependent</ets>: cf. F.
<ets>ind\'82pendant</ets>.]</ety>

<sn>1.</sn> <def>Not dependent; free; not subject to control by
others; not relying on others; not subordinate; <as>as, few men
are wholly <ex>independent</ex></as>.</def>

<q>A dry, but <qex>independent</qex> crust.</q>
<qau>Cowper.</qau>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>Affording a comfortable livelihood; <as>as, an
<ex>independent</ex> property</as>.</def>

<sn>3.</sn> <def>Not subject to bias or influence; not
obsequious; self-directing; <as>as, a man of an
<ex>independent</ex> mind</as>.</def>

<sn>4.</sn> <def>Expressing or indicating the feeling of
independence; free; easy; bold; unconstrained; <as>as, an
<ex>independent</ex> air or manner</as>.</def>

<sn>5.</sn> <def>Separate from; exclusive; irrespective.</def>

<q>That obligation in general, under which we conceive ourselves
bound to obey a law, <qex>independent</qex> of those resources
which the law provides for its own enforcement.</q>
<qau>R. P. Ward.</qau>

<sn>6.</sn> <fld>(Eccl.)</fld> <def>Belonging or pertaining to,
or holding to the doctrines or methods of, the
Independents.</def>

<sn>7.</sn> <fld>(Math.)</fld> <def>Not dependent upon another
quantity in respect to value or rate of variation; -- said of
quantities or functions.</def>

<sn>8.</sn> <fld>(U. S. Politics)</fld> <def>Not bound by party;
exercising a free choice in voting with either or any
party.</def>

<cs><col>Independent company</col> <fld>(Mil.)</fld>, <cd>one not
incorporated in any regiment.</cd> -- <col>Independent seconds
watch</col>, <cd>a stop watch having a second hand driven by a
separate set of wheels, springs, etc., for timing to a fraction
of a second.</cd> -- <col>Independent variable</col>.
<fld>(Math.)</fld> <cd>See <cref>Dependent variable</cref>, under
<er>Dependent</er>.</cd></cs>

<syn>Syn. -- Free; uncontrolled; separate; uncoerced;
self-reliant; bold; unconstrained; unrestricted.</syn>

<-- p. 751 -->

<hw>In`de*pend"ent</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <sn>1.</sn>
<fld>(Eccl.)</fld> <def>One who believes that an organized
Christian church is complete in itself, competent to
self-government, and independent of all ecclesiastical
authority.</def>

<note><hand/ In England the name is often applied (commonly in
the <pluf>pl.</pluf>) to the Congregationalists.</note>

<sn>2.</sn> <fld>(Politics)</fld> <def>One who does not
acknowledge an obligation to support a party's candidate under
all circumstances; one who exercises liberty in voting.</def>

<hw>In`de*pend"ent*ism</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos>
<def>Independency; the church system of Independents.</def>

<au>Bp. Gauden.</au>

<hw>In`de*pend"ent*ly</hw>, <pos>adv.</pos> <def>In an
independent manner; without control.</def>

<q>Princes <qex>indeposable</qex> by the pope.</q>
<qau>Bp. Stillingfleet.</qau>

<hw>In`de*ter"mi*na*ble</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>a.</pos> <ety>[L.
<ets>indeterminabilis</ets>: cf. F. <ets>ind\'82terminable</ets>.
See <er>In-</er> not, and Determine.]</ety> <def>Not
determinable; impossible to be determined; not to be definitely
known, ascertained, defined, or limited.</def> --
<wordforms><wf>In`de*ter"mi*na*bly</wf>,
<pos>adv.</pos></wordforms>

<hw>In`de*ter"mi*na*ble</hw>, <pos>n.</pos> <def>An
indeterminable thing or quantity.</def>

<au>Sir T. Browne.</au>

<hw>In`de*ter"mi*nate</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>a.</pos> <ety>[L.
<ets>indeterminatus</ets>.]</ety> <def>Not determinate; not
certain or fixed; indefinite; not precise; <as>as, an
<ex>indeterminate</ex> number of years</as>.</def>

<au>Paley.</au>

<cs><col>Indeterminate analysis</col> <fld>(Math.)</fld>,
<cd>that branch of analysis which has for its object the solution
of indeterminate problems.</cd> -- <col>Indeterminate
coefficients</col> <fld>(Math.)</fld>, <cd>coefficients
arbitrarily assumed for convenience of calculation, or to
facilitate some artifice of analysis. Their values are
subsequently determined.</cd> -- <col>Indeterminate
equation</col> <fld>(Math.)</fld>, <cd>an equation in which the
unknown quantities admit of an infinite number of values, or sets
of values. A group of equations is <xex>indeterminate<xex> when
it contains more unknown quantities than there are
equations.</cd> -- <col>Indeterminate inflorescence</col>
<fld>(Bot.)</fld>, <cd>a mode of inflorescence in which the
flowers all arise from axillary buds, the terminal bud going on
to grow and sometimes continuing the stem indefinitely; -- called
also <altname>acropetal, botryose, centripetal, <and/ indefinite
inflorescence</altname>. <au>Gray</au>.</cd> --
<col>Indeterminate problem</col> <fld>(Math.)</fld>, <cd>a
problem which admits of an infinite number of solutions, or one
in which there are fewer imposed conditions than there are
unknown or required results.</cd> -- <col>Indeterminate
quantity</col> <fld>(Math.)</fld>, <cd>a quantity which has no
fixed value, but which may be varied in accordance with any
proposed condition.</cd> -- <col>Indeterminate series</col>
<fld>(Math.)</fld>, <cd>a series whose terms proceed by the
powers of an indeterminate quantity, sometimes also with
indeterminate exponents, or indeterminate coefficients.</cd></cs>

-- <wordforms><wf>In`de*ter"mi*nate*ly</wf> <pos>adv.</pos> --
<wf>In`de*ter"mi*nate*ness</wf>, <pos>n.</pos></wordforms>

<hw>In`de*ter`mi*na"tion</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos>

<ets>ind\'82termination</ets>.]</ety>

<au>Jer. Taylor.</au>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>Want of fixed or stated direction.</def>

<au>Abp. Bramhall.</au>

<def>Undetermined.</def>

<hw>In"dex</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos>; <plu>pl. E.
<plw>Indexes</plw> <pr>(#)</pr>, L. <plw>Indices</plw>
<pr>(#)</pr>(<?/)</plu>. <ety>[L.: cf. F. <ets>index</ets>. See
<er>Indicate</er>, <er>Diction</er>.]</ety>

<sn>1.</sn> <def>That which points out; that which shows,
indicates, manifests, or discloses.</def>

<q>Tastes are the <qex>indexes</qex> of the different qualities
of plants.</q>
<qau>Arbuthnot.</qau>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>That which guides, points out, informs, or
directs; a pointer or a hand that directs to anything, as the
hand of a watch, a movable finger on a gauge, scale, or other
graduated instrument. In printing, a sign [\'b5] used to direct
particular attention to a note or paragraph; -- called also
<altname>fist</altname>.</def><-- here represented by "<hand/"
-->

<sn>3.</sn> <def>A table for facilitating reference to topics,
names, and the like, in a book; -- usually alphabetical in
arrangement, and printed at the end of the volume.</def>

<sn>4.</sn> <def>A prologue indicating what follows.</def>
<mark>[Obs.]</mark>

<au>Shak.</au>

<sn>5.</sn> <fld>(Anat.)</fld> <def>The second digit, that next
pollex, in the manus, or hand; the forefinger; index
finger.</def>

<sn>6.</sn> <fld>(Math.)</fld> <def>The figure or letter which
shows the power or root of a quantity; the exponent. <plu>[In
this sense the plural is always <plw>indices</plw>.]</plu></def>

<cs><col>Index error</col>, <cd>the error in the reading of a
mathematical instrument arising from the zero of the index not
being in complete adjustment with that of the limb, or with its
theoretically perfect position in the instrument; a correction to
be applied to the instrument readings equal to the error of the
zero adjustment.</cd> -- <col>Index expurgatorius</col>.
<ety>[L.]</ety> <cd>See <cref>Index prohibitorius</cref>
(below).</cd> -- <col>Index finger</col>. <cd>See <er>Index</er>,
5.</cd> -- <col>Index glass</col>, <cd>the mirror on the index of
a quadrant, sextant, etc.</cd> -- <col>Index hand</col>, <cd>the
pointer or hand of a clock, watch, or other registering machine;
a hand that points to something.</cd> -- <col>Index of a
logarithm</col> <fld>(Math.)</fld>,  <cd>the integral part of the
logarithm, and always one less than the number of integral
figures in the given number. It is also called the
<altname>characteristic</altname>.</cd> -- <mcol><col>Index of
refraction</col>, <or/ <col>Refractive index</col></mcol>
<fld>(Opt.)</fld>, <cd>the number which expresses the ratio of
the sine of the angle of incidence to the sine of the angle of
refraction. Thus the <xex>index of refraction<xex> for sulphur is
2, because, when light passes out of air into sulphur, the sine
of the angle of incidence is double the sine of the angle of
refraction.</cd> -- <col>Index plate</col>, <cd>a graduated
circular plate, or one with circular rows of holes differently
spaced; used in machines for graduating circles, cutting gear
teeth, etc.</cd> -- <mcol><col>Index prohibitorius</col>
<ety>[L.]</ety>, or <col>Prohibitory index</col></mcol> <fld>(R.
C. Ch.)</fld>, <cd>a catalogue of books which are forbidden by
the church to be read; the <xex>index expurgatorius</xex>
<ety>[L.]</ety>, or <xex>expurgatory index<xex>, is a catalogue
of books from which passages marked as against faith or morals
must be removed before Catholics can read them. These catalogues
are published with additions, from time to time, by the
Congregation of the Index, composed of cardinals, theologians,
etc., under the sanction of the pope.</cd> <au>Hook</au>. --
<col>Index rerum</col> <ety>[L.]</ety>, <cd>a tabulated and
alphabetized notebook, for systematic preservation of items,
quotations, etc.</cd></cs>

<hw>In"dex</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>v. t.</pos>
<wordforms>[<pos>imp. & p. p.</pos> <er>Indexed</er>
<pr>(?)</pr>; <pos>p. pr. & vb. n.</pos>
<er>Indexing</er>.]</wordforms> <def>To provide with an index or
table of references; to put into an index; <as>as, to
<ex>index</ex> a book, or its contents</as>.</def>

<hw>In"dex*er</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <def>One who makes
an index.</def>

<hw>In*dex"ic*al</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>a.</pos> <def>Of,
pertaining to, or like, an index; having the form of an
index.</def>

<hw>In*dex"ic*al*ly</hw>, <pos>adv.</pos> <def>In the manner of
an index.</def>

<hw>In`dex*ter"i*ty</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[Pref.
<ets>in-</ets> not + <ets>dexterity</ets>: cf. F.
<ets>indext\'82rit\'82</ets>.]</ety> <def>Want of dexterity or
readiness, especially in the use of the hands; clumsiness;
awkwardness.</def>

<au>Harvey.</au>

<hw>In"di*a</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[See
<er>Indian</er>.]</ety> <def>A country in Southern Asia; the two
peninsulas of Hither and Farther India; in a restricted sense,
Hither India, or Hindostan.</def>

<cs><col>India ink</col>, <cd>a nearly black pigment brought
chiefly from China, used for water colors. It is in rolls, or in
square, and consists of lampblack or ivory black and animal glue.
Called also <altname>China ink</altname>. The true India ink is
sepia. See <er>Sepia</er>.</cd> -- <col>India matting</col>,
<cd>floor matting made in China, India, etc., from grass and
reeds; -- also called <altname>Canton, <or/ China,
matting</altname>.</cd> -- <col>India paper</col>, <cd>a variety
of Chinese paper, of smooth but not glossy surface, used for
printing from engravings, woodcuts, etc.</cd> -- <col>India
proof</col> <fld>(Engraving)</fld>, <cd>a proof impression from
an engraved plate, taken on India paper.</cd> -- <col>India
rubber</col>. <cd>See <er>Caoutchouc</er>.</cd> --
<col>India-rubber tree</col> <fld>(Bot.)</fld>, <cd>any tree
yielding caoutchouc, but especially the East Indian <spn>Ficus
elastica</spn>, often cultivated for its large, shining,
elliptical leaves.</cd></cs>

<hw>In*di"a*dem</hw>, <pos>v. t.</pos> <def>To place or set in a
diadem, as a gem or gems.</def>

<hw>In"di*a*man</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos>; <plu>pl.
<plw>Indiamen</plw> <pr>(<?/)</pr>.</plu> <def>A large vessel in
the India trade.</def>

<au>Macaulay.</au>

<hw>In"di*an</hw> <pr>(?; 277)</pr>, <pos>a</pos> <ety>[From
<ets>India</ets>, and this fr. <ets>Indus</ets>, the name of a
river in Asia, L. <ets>Indus</ets>, Gr. <?/, OPers.
<ets>Hindu</ets>, name of the land on the Indus, Skr.
<ets>sindhu</ets> river, the Indus. Cf. <er>Hindoo</er>.]</ety>

<sn>1.</sn> <def>Of or pertaining to India proper; also to the
East Indies, or, sometimes, to the West Indies.</def>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>Of or pertaining to the aborigines, or Indians,
of America; <as>as, <ex>Indian</ex> wars; the <ex>Indian</ex>
tomahawk.</as></def>

<sn>3.</sn> <def>Made of maize or Indian corn; <as>as,
<ex>Indian</ex> corn, <ex>Indian</ex> meal, <ex>Indian</ex>
bread, and the like</as>.</def> <mark>[U.S.]</mark>

<cs><col>Indian</col> bay <fld>(Bot.)</fld>, <cd>a lauraceous
tree (<spn>Persea Indica</spn>).</cd> -- <col>Indian bean</col>
<fld>(Bot.)</fld>, <cd>a name of the catalpa.</cd> -- <col>Indian
berry</col>. <fld>(Bot.)</fld> <cd>Same as <er>Cocculus
indicus</er>.</cd> -- <col>Indian bread</col>. <fld>(Bot.)</fld>
<cd>Same as <er>Cassava</er>.</cd> -- <col>Indian club</col>,
<cd>a wooden club, which is swung by the hand for gymnastic
exercise.</cd> -- <col>Indian cordage</col>, <cd>cordage made of
the fibers of cocoanut husk.</cd> -- <col>Indian corn</col>
<fld>(Bot.)</fld>, <cd>a plant of the genus <spn>Zea</spn>
(<spn>Z. Mays</spn>); the maize, a native of America. See
<er>Corn</er>, and <er>Maize</er>.</cd> -- <col>Indian
cress</col> <fld>(Bot.)</fld>, <cd>nasturtium. See
<er>Nasturtium</er>, 2.</cd> -- <col>Indian cucumber</col>
<fld>(Bot.)</fld>, <cd>a plant of the genus <spn>Medeola</spn>
(<spn>M. Virginica</spn>), a common in woods in the United
States. The white rootstock has a taste like cucumbers.</cd> --
<col>Indian currant</col> <fld>(Bot.)</fld>, <cd>a plant of the
genus <spn>Symphoricarpus</spn> (<spn>S. vulgaris</spn>), bearing
small red berries.</cd> -- <col>Indian dye</col>, <cd>the
puccoon.</cd> -- <col>Indian fig</col>. <fld>(Bot.)</fld>
<sd>(a)</sd> <cd>The banyan. See <er>Banyan</er>.</cd>
<sd>(b)</sd> <cd>The prickly pear.</cd> -- <col>Indian
file</col>, <cd>single file; arrangement of persons in a row
following one after another, the usual way among Indians of
traversing woods, especially when on the war path.</cd> --
<col>Indian fire</col>, <cd>a pyrotechnic composition of sulphur,
niter, and realgar, burning with a brilliant white light.</cd> --
<col>Indian grass</col> <fld>(Bot.)</fld>, <cd>a coarse, high
grass (<spn>Chrysopogon nutans</spn>), common in the southern
portions of the United States; wood grass. <au>Gray</au>.</cd> --
<col>Indian hemp</col>. <fld>(Bot.)</fld> <sd>(a)</sd> <cd>A
plant of the genus <spn>Apocynum</spn> (<spn>A.
cannabinum</spn>), having a milky juice, and a tough, fibrous
bark, whence the name. The root it used in medicine and is both
emetic and cathartic in properties.</cd> <sd>(b)</sd> <cd>The
variety of common hemp (<spn>Cannabis Indica</spn>), from which
hasheesh is obtained.</cd> -- <col>Indian mallow</col>
<fld>(Bot.)</fld>, <cd>the velvet leaf (<spn>Abutilon
Avicenn\'91</spn>). See <er>Abutilon</er>.</cd> -- <col>Indian
meal</col>, <cd>ground corn or maize.</cd> <mark>[U.S.]</mark> --
<col>Indian millet</col> <fld>(Bot.)</fld>, <cd>a tall annual
grass (<spn>Sorghum vulgare</spn>), having many varieties, among
which are broom corn, Guinea corn, durra, and the Chinese sugar
cane. It is called also <altname>Guinea corn</altname>. See
<er>Durra</er>.</cd> -- <col>Indian ox</col>
<fld>(Zo\'94l.)</fld>, <cd>the zebu.</cd> -- <col>Indian
paint</col>. <cd>See <er>Bloodroot</er>.</cd> -- <col>Indian
paper</col>. <cd>See <cref>India paper</cref>, under
<er>India</er>.</cd> -- <col>Indian physic</col>
<fld>(Bot.)</fld>, <cd>a plant of two species of the genus
<spn>Gillenia</spn> (<spn>G. trifoliata</spn>, and <spn>G.
stipulacea</spn>), common in the United States, the roots of
which are used in medicine as a mild emetic; -- called also
<altname>American ipecac</altname>, and <altname>bowman's
root</altname>. <au>Gray</au>.</cd> -- <col>Indian pink</col>.
<fld>(Bot.)</fld> <sd>(a)</sd> <cd>The Cypress vine
(<spn>Ipom\'d2a Quamoclit</spn>); -- so called in the West
Indies.</cd> <sd>(b)</sd> <cd>See <cref>China pink</cref>, under
<er>China</er>.</cd> -- <col>Indian pipe</col> <fld>(Bot.)</fld>,
<cd>a low, fleshy herb (<spn>Monotropa uniflora</spn>), growing
in clusters in dark woods, and having scalelike leaves, and a
solitary nodding flower. The whole plant is waxy white, but turns
black in drying.</cd> -- <col>Indian plantain</col>
<fld>(Bot.)</fld>, <cd>a name given to several species of the
genus <spn>Cacalia</spn>, tall herbs with composite white
flowers, common through the United States in rich woods.
<au>Gray</au>.</cd> -- <col>Indian poke</col> <fld>(Bot.)</fld>,
<cd>a plant usually known as the <altname>white
hellebore</altname> (<spn>Veratrum viride</spn>).</cd> --
<col>Indian pudding</col>, <cd>a pudding of which the chief
ingredients are Indian meal, milk, and molasses.</cd> --
<col>Indian purple</col>. <sd>(a)</sd> <cd>A dull purple
color.</cd> <sd>(b)</sd> <cd>The pigment of the same name,
intensely blue and black.</cd> -- <col>Indian red</col>.
<sd>(a)</sd> <cd>A purplish red earth or pigment composed of a
silicate of iron and alumina, with magnesia. It comes from the
Persian Gulf. Called also <altname>Persian red</altname>.</cd>
<sd>(b)</sd> <cd>See <er>Almagra</er>.</cd> -- <col>Indian
rice</col> <fld>(Bot.)</fld>, <cd>a reedlike water grass. See
<er>Rice</er>.</cd> -- <col>Indian shot</col> <fld>(Bot.)</fld>,
<cd>a plant of the genus <spn>Canna</spn> (<spn>C. Indica</spn>).
The hard black seeds are as large as swan shot. See
<er>Canna</er>.</cd> -- <col>Indian summer</col>, <cd>in the
United States, a period of warm and pleasant weather occurring
late in autumn. See under <er>Summer</er>.</cd> -- <col>Indian
tobacco</col> <fld>(Bot.)</fld>, <cd>a species of
<spn>Lobelia</spn>. See <er>Lobelia</er>.</cd> -- <col>Indian
turnip</col> <fld>(Bot.)</fld>, <cd>an American plant of the
genus <spn>Aris\'91ma</spn>. <spn>A. triphyllum</spn> has a
wrinkled farinaceous root resembling a small turnip, but with a
very acrid juice. See <er>Jack in the Pulpit</er>, and
<er>Wake-robin</er>.</cd> -- <col>Indian wheat</col>, <cd>maize
or Indian corn.</cd> -- <col>Indian yellow</col>. <sd>(a)</sd>
<cd>An intense rich yellow color, deeper than gamboge but less
pure than cadmium.</cd> <sd>(b)</sd> <cd>See
<er>Euxanthin</er>.</cd></cs>

<hw>In"di*an</hw> <pr>(?; 277)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <sn>1.</sn>
<def>A native or inhabitant of India.</def>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>One of the aboriginal inhabitants of America; --
so called originally from the supposed identity of America with
India.</def>

<hw>In`di*an*eer"</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos>
<fld>(Naut.)</fld> <def>An Indiaman.</def>

<hw>In"di*a rub"ber</hw> <pr>(?)</pr><def>. See
<er>Caoutchouc</er>.</def>

<hw>In"dic*al</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>a.</pos> <ety>[From L.
<ets>index</ets>, <ets>indicis</ets>, an index.]</ety>
<def>Indexical.</def> <mark>[R.]</mark>

<au>Fuller.</au>

<hw>In"di*can</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[See
<er>Indigo</er>.]</ety>

<sn>1.</sn> <fld>(Chem.)</fld> <def>A glucoside obtained from
woad (indigo plant) and other plants, as a yellow or light brown
sirup. It has a nauseous bitter taste, a decomposes or drying. By
the action of acids, ferments, etc., it breaks down into sugar
and indigo. It is the source of natural indigo.</def>

<sn>2.</sn> <fld>(Physiol. Chem.)</fld> <def>An indigo-forming
substance, found in urine, and other animal fluids, and
convertible into red and blue indigo (<xex>urrhodin</xex> and
<xex>uroglaucin</xex>). Chemically, it is indoxyl sulphate of
potash, <chform>C8H6NSO4K</chform>, and is derived from the indol
formed in the alimentary canal. Called also
<altname>uroxanthin</altname>.</def>

<hw>In"di*cant</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>a.</pos> <ety>[L.
<ets>indicans</ets>, p. pr. <ets>indicare</ets>. See
<er>Indicate</er>.]</ety> <def>Serving to point out, as a remedy;
indicating.</def>

<hw>In"di*cant</hw>, <pos>n.</pos> <def>That which indicates or
points out; <as>as, an <ex>indicant</ex> of the remedy for a
disease</as>.</def>

<hw>In"di*cate</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>v. t.</pos>
<wordforms>[<pos>imp. & p. p.</pos> <er>Indicated</er>
<pr>(?)</pr>; <pos>p. pr. & vb. n.</pos> <er>Indicating</er>
<pr>(?)</pr>.]</wordforms> <ety>[L. <ets>indicatus</ets>, p. p.
of <ets>indicare</ets> to indicate; pref. <ets>in-</ets> in +
<ets>dicare</ets> to proclaim; akin to <ets>dicere</ets> to say.
See <er>Diction</er>, and cf. <er>Indict</er>,
<er>Indite</er>.]</ety>

<sn>1.</sn> <def>To point out; to discover; to direct to a
knowledge of; to show; to make known.</def>

<q>That turns and turns to <qex>indicate</qex>
From what point blows the weather.</q>
<qau>Cowper.</qau>

<sn>2.</sn> <fld>(Med.)</fld> <def>To show or manifest by
symptoms; to point to as the proper remedies; <as>as, great
prostration of strength <ex>indicates</ex> the use of
stimulants</as>.</def>

<sn>3.</sn> <fld>(Mach.)</fld> <def>To investigate the condition
or power of, as of steam engine, by means of an indicator.</def>

<syn>Syn. -- To show; mark; signify; denote; discover; evidence;
evince; manifest; declare; specify; explain; exhibit; present;
reveal; disclose; display.</syn>

<hw>In"di*ca`ted</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>a.</pos> <def>Shown;
denoted; registered; measured.</def>

<cs><col>Indicated power</col>. <cd>See <cref>Indicated horse
power</cref>, under <er>Horse power</er>.</cd></cs>

<hw>In`di*ca"tion</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[L.
<ets>indicatio</ets>: cf. F. <ets>indication</ets>.]</ety>

<sn>1.</sn> <def>Act of pointing out or indicating.</def>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>That which serves to indicate or point out;
mark; token; sign; symptom; evidence.</def>

<q>The frequent stops they make in the most convenient places are
plain <qex>indications</qex> of their weariness.</q>
<qau>Addison.</qau>

<sn>3.</sn> <def>Discovery made; information.</def>

<au>Bentley.</au>

<sn>4.</sn> <def>Explanation; display.</def> <mark>[Obs.]</mark>

<au>Bacon.</au>

<sn>5.</sn> <fld>(Med.)</fld> <def>Any symptom or occurrence in a
disease, which serves to direct to suitable remedies.</def>

<syn>Syn. -- Proof; demonstration; sign; token; mark; evidence;
signal.</syn>

<hw>In*dic"a*tive</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>a.</pos> <ety>[L.
<ets>indicativus</ets>: cf. F. <ets>indicatif</ets>.]</ety>

<sn>1.</sn> <def>Pointing out; bringing to notice; giving
intimation or knowledge of something not visible or
obvious.</def>

<q>That truth id productive of utility, and utility
<qex>indicative</qex> of truth, may be thus proved.</q>
<qau>Bp. Warburton.</qau>

<sn>2.</sn> <fld>(Fine Arts)</fld> <def>Suggestive; representing
the whole by a part, as a fleet by a ship, a forest by a tree,
etc.</def>

<cs><col>Indicative mood</col> <fld>(Gram.)</fld>, <cd>that mood
or form of the verb which indicates, that is, which simply
affirms or denies or inquires; as, he <xex>writes<xex>; he
<xex>is not writing<xex>; <xex>has<xex> the mail
<xex>arrived<xex>?</cd></cs>

<hw>In*dic"a*tive</hw>, <pos>n.</pos> <fld>(Gram.)</fld> <def>The
indicative mood.</def>

<hw>In*dic"a*tive*ly</hw>, <pos>adv.</pos> <def>In an indicative
manner; in a way to show or signify.</def>

<hw>In"di*ca`tor</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[L.: cf.
F. <ets>indicateur</ets>.]</ety>

<sn>1.</sn> <def>One who, or that which, shows or points out;
<as>as, a fare <ex>indicator</ex> in a street car</as>.</def>

<sn>2.</sn> <fld>(Mach.)</fld> <def>A pressure gauge; a water
gauge, as for a steam boiler; an apparatus or instrument for
showing the working of a machine or moving part</def>; as:
<sd>(a)</sd> <fld>(Steam Engine)</fld> <def>An instrument which
draws a diagram showing the varying pressure in the cylinder of
an engine or pump at every point of the stroke. It consists of a
small cylinder communicating with the engine cylinder and fitted
with a piston which the varying pressure drives upward more or
less against the resistance of a spring. A lever imparts motion
to a pencil which traces the diagram on a card wrapped around a
vertical drum which is turned back and forth by a string
connected with the piston rod of the engine. See <cref>Indicator
card</cref> (below).</def> <sd>(b)</sd> <def>A telltale connected
with a hoisting machine, to show, at the surface, the position of
the cage in the shaft of a mine, etc.</def>

<-- p. 752 -->

<sn>3.</sn> <fld>(Mech.)</fld> <def>The part of an instrument by
which an effect is indicated, as an index or pointer.</def>

<sn>4.</sn> <fld>(Zo\'94l.)</fld> <def>Any bird of the genus
<spn>Indicator</spn> and allied genera. See <cref>Honey
guide</cref>, under <er>Honey</er>.</def>

<sn>5.</sn> <fld>(Chem.)</fld> <def>That which indicates the
condition of acidity, alkalinity, or the deficiency, excess, or
sufficiency of a standard reagent, by causing an appearance,
disappearance, or change of color, as in titration or volumetric
analysis.</def>

<note><hand/ The common indicators are limits, trop\'91olin,
phenol phthalein, potassic permanganate, etc.</note>

<cs><col>Indicator card</col>, <cd>the figure drawn by an engine
indicator, by means of which the working of the engine can be
investigated and its power calculated. The Illustration shows one
form of indicator card, from a steam engine, together with scales
by which the pressure of the steam above or below that of the
atmosphere, corresponding to any position of the engine piston in
its stroke, can be measured. Called also <altname>indicator
diagram</altname>.</cd> -- <col>Indicator telegraph</col>, <cd>a
telegraph in which the signals are the deflections of a magnetic
needle, as in the trans-Atlantic system.</cd></cs>

<hw>In"di*ca*to*ry</hw> <pr>(?; 277)</pr>, <pos>a.</pos>
<def>Serving to show or make known; showing; indicative;
signifying; implying.</def>

<hw>In`di*ca"trix</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos>
<ety>[NL.]</ety> <fld>(Geom. of Three Dimensions)</fld> <def>A
certain conic section supposed to be drawn in the tangent plane
to any surface, and used to determine the accidents of curvature
of the surface at the point of contact. The curve is similar to
the intersection of the surface with a parallel to the tangent
plane and indefinitely near it. It is an ellipse when the
curvature is synclastic, and an hyperbola when the curvature is
anticlastic.</def>

<hw>\'d8In`di*ca"vit</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[L.,
he has indicated.]</ety> <fld>(Eng. Law)</fld> <def>A writ of
prohibition against proceeding in the spiritual court in certain
cases, when the suit belongs to the common-law courts.</def>

<au>Wharton (Law Dict. ).</au>

<au>B. Jonson.</au>

<hw>In"di*ces</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n. pl.</pos> <def>See

<hw>\'d8In*di"ci*a</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n. pl.</pos> <ety>[L.,

<hw>In*dic"i*ble</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>a.</pos> <ety>[F.]</ety>

<hw>In*dic"o*lite</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[L.
<ets>indicum</ets> indigo + <ets>-lite</ets>: cf. F.

<hw>In*dict"</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>v. t.</pos>
<wordforms>[<pos>imp. & p. p.</pos> <er>Indicted</er>
<pr>(?)</pr>; <pos>p. pr. & vb. n.</pos>
<er>Indicting</er>.]</wordforms> <ety>[OE. <ets>enditen</ets>.
See <er>Indite</er>.]</ety>

<sn>1.</sn> <def>To write; to compose; to dictate; to
indite.</def> <mark>[Obs.]</mark>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>To appoint publicly or by authority; to proclaim
or announce.</def> <mark>[Obs.]</mark>

<q>I am told shall have no Lent <qex>indicted</qex> this
year.</q>
<qau>Evelyn.</qau>

<sn>3.</sn> <fld>(Law)</fld> <def>To charge with a crime, in due
form of law, by the finding or presentment of a grand jury; to
find an indictment against; <as>as, to <ex>indict</ex> a man for
arson</as>. It is the peculiar province of a grand jury to
<xex>indict</xex>, as it is of a house of representatives to
<xex>impeach</xex>.</def>

<hw>In*dict"a*ble</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>a.</pos> <def>Capable
of being, or liable to be, indicted; subject to indictment;
<as>as, an <ex>indictable</ex> offender or offense</as>.</def>

<hw>In`dict*ee"</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <fld>(Law)</fld>
<def>A person indicted.</def>

<hw>In*dict"er</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <def>One who
indicts.</def>

<hw>In*dic"tion</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[L.
<ets>indictio</ets>: cf. F. <ets>indiction</ets>. See
<er>Indict</er>, <er>Indite</er>.]</ety>

<sn>1.</sn> <def>Declaration; proclamation; public notice or
appointment.</def> <mark>[Obs.]</mark> \'bd<xex>Indiction</xex>
of a war.\'b8

<au>Bacon.</au>

<q>Secular princes did use to indict, or permit the
<qex>indiction</qex> of, synods of bishops.</q>
<qau>Jer. Taylor.</qau>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>A cycle of fifteen years.</def>

<note><hand/ This mode of reckoning time is said to have been
introduced by Constantine the Great, in connection with the
payment of tribute. It was adopted at various times by the Greek
emperors of Constantinople, the popes, and the parliaments of
France. Through the influence of the popes, it was extensively
used in the ecclesiastical chronology of the Middle Ages. The
number of indictions was reckoned at first from 312 <sc>a. 
d.</sc>, but since the twelfth century it has been reckoned from
the birth of Christ. The papal indiction is the only one ever
used at the present day. To find the indiction and year of the
indiction by the first method, subtract 312 from the given year
<sc>a. d.</sc>, and divide by 15; by the second method, add 3 to
the given year <sc>a. d.</sc>, and the divide by 15. In either
case, the quotient is the number of the current indiction, and
the remainder the year of the indiction. See <cref>Cycle of
indiction</cref>, under <er>Cycle</er>.</note>

<hw>In*dic"tive</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>a.</pos> <ety>[L.
<ets>indictivus</ets>. See <er>Indict</er>.]</ety>
<def>Proclaimed; declared; public.</def>

<au>Kennet.</au>

<hw>In*dict"ment</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[Cf.
<er>Inditement</er>.]</ety>

<sn>1.</sn> <def>The act of indicting, or the state of being
indicted.</def>

<sn>2.</sn> <fld>(Law)</fld> <def>The formal statement of an
offense, as framed by the prosecuting authority of the State, and
found by the grand jury.</def>

<note><hand/ To the validity of an indictment a finding by the
grand jury is essential, while an information rests only on
presentation by the prosecuting authority.</note>

<sn>3.</sn> <def>An accusation in general; a formal
accusation.</def>

<cs><col>Bill of indictment</col>. <cd>See under
<er>Bill</er>.</cd></cs>

<hw>In*dict"or</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <fld>(Law)</fld>
<def>One who indicts.</def>

<au>Bacon.</au>

<hw>In"dies</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n. pl.</pos> <def>A name
designating the East Indies, also the West Indies.</def>

<q>Our king has all the <qex>Indies</qex> in his arms.</q>
<qau>Shak.</qau>

<hw>In*dif"fer*ence</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[L.
<ets>indifferentia</ets> similarity, want of difference: cf. F.
<ets>indiff\'82rence</ets>.]</ety>

<sn>1.</sn> <def>The quality or state of being indifferent, or
not making a difference; want of sufficient importance to
constitute a difference; absence of weight; insignificance.</def>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>Passableness; mediocrity.</def>

<sn>3.</sn> <def>Impartiality; freedom from prejudice,
prepossession, or bias.</def>

<q>He . . . is far from such <qex>indifference</qex> and equity
as ought and must be in judges which he saith I assign.</q>
<qau>Sir T. More.</qau>

<sn>4.</sn> <def>Absence of anxiety or interest in respect to
what is presented to the mind; unconcernedness; <as>as, entire
<ex>indifference</ex> to all that occurs</as>.</def>

<q><qex>Indifference</qex> can not but be criminal, when it is
conversant about objects which are so far from being of an
indifferent nature, that they are highest importance.</q>
<qau>Addison.</qau>

<syn>Syn. -- Carelessness; negligence; unconcern; apathy;
insensibility; coldness; lukewarmness.</syn>

<hw>In*dif"fer*en*cy</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos>
<def>Absence of interest in, or influence from, anything;
unconcernedness; equilibrium; indifferentism; indifference.</def>

<au>Gladstone.</au>

<q>To give ourselves to a detestable <qex>indifferency</qex> or
neutrality in this cause.</q>
<qau>Fuller.</qau>

<q>Moral liberty . . . does not, after all, consist in a power of
<qex>indifferency</qex>, or in a power of choosing without regard
to motives.</q>
<qau>Hazlitt.</qau>

<hw>In*dif"fer*ent</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>a.</pos> <ety>[F.
<ets>indiff\'82rent</ets>, L. <ets>indifferens</ets>. See
<er>In-</er> not, and <er>Different</er>.]</ety>

<sn>1.</sn> <def>Not mal<?/ing a difference; having no influence
or preponderating weight; involving no preference, concern, or
attention; of no account; without significance or
importance.</def>

<q>Dangers are to me <qex>indifferent</qex>.</q>
<qau>Shak.</qau>

<q>Everything in the world is <qex>indifferent</qex> but sin.</q>
<qau>Jer. Taylor.</qau>

<q>His slightest and most <qex>indifferent</qex> acts . . . were
odious in the clergyman's sight.</q>
<qau>Hawthorne.</qau>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>Neither particularly good, not very bad; of a
middle state or quality; passable; mediocre.</def>

<q>The staterooms are in <qex>indifferent</qex> order.</q>
<qau>Sir W. Scott.</qau>

<sn>3.</sn> <def>Not inclined to one side, party, or choice more
than to another; neutral; impartial.</def>

<q><qex>Indifferent</qex> in his choice to sleep or die.</q>
<qau>Addison.</qau>

<sn>4.</sn> <def>Feeling no interest, anxiety, or care,
respecting anything; unconcerned; inattentive; apathetic;
heedless; <as>as, to be <ex>indifferent</ex> to the welfare of
one's family</as>.</def>

<q>It was a law of Solon, that any person who, in the civil
commotions of the republic, remained neuter, or an
<qex>indifferent</qex> spectator of the contending parties,
should be condemned to perpetual banishment.</q>
<qau>Addison.</qau>

<sn>5.</sn> <fld>(Law)</fld> <def>Free from bias or prejudice;
impartial; unbiased; disinterested.</def>

<q>In choice of committees for ripening business for the counsel,
it is better <qex>indifferent</qex> persons than to make an
indifferency by putting in those that are strong on both
sides.</q>
<qau>Bacon.</qau>

<cs><col>Indifferent tissue</col> <fld>(Anat.)</fld>, <cd>the
primitive, embryonic, undifferentiated tissue, before conversion
into connective, muscular, nervous, or other definite
tissue.</cd></cs>

<hw>In*dif"fer*ent</hw>, <pos>adv.</pos> <def>To a moderate
degree; passably; tolerably.</def> <mark>[Obs.]</mark> \'bdNews
<xex>indifferent</xex> good.\'b8

<au>Shak.</au>

<hw>In*dif"fer*ent*ism</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[Cf.
F. <ets>indiff\'82rentisme</ets>.]</ety>

<sn>1.</sn> <def>State of indifference; want of interest or
earnestness; especially, a systematic apathy regarding what is
true or false in religion or philosophy; agnosticism.</def>

<q>The <qex>indifferentism</qex> which equalizes all religions
and gives equal rights to truth and error.</q>
<qau>Cardinal Manning.</qau>

<sn>2.</sn> <fld>(Metaph.)</fld> <def>Same as
<er>Identism</er>.</def>

<sn>3.</sn> <fld>(R. C. Ch.)</fld> <def>A heresy consisting in an
unconcern for any particular creed, provided the morals be right
and good.</def>

<au>Gregory XVI.</au>

<hw>In*dif"fer*ent*ist</hw>, <pos>n.</pos> <def>One governed by
indifferentism.</def>

<hw>In*dif"fer*ent*ly</hw>, <pos>adv.</pos> <def>In an
indifferent manner; without distinction or preference;
impartially; without concern, wish, affection, or aversion;
tolerably; passably.</def>

<q>That they may truly and <qex>indifferently</qex> minister
justice, to the punishment of wickedness and vice, and to the
maintenance of thy true religion, and virtue.</q>
<qau>Book of Com. Prayer [Eng. Ed. ]</qau>

<q>Set honor in one eye and death i' the other,
And I will look on both <qex>indifferently</qex>.</q>
<qau>Shak.</qau>

<q>I hope it may <qex>indifferently</qex> entertain your lordship
at an unbending hour.</q>
<qau>Rowe.</qau>

<hw>In`di*ful"vin</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos>
<ety>[<ets>Indi</ets>can + L. <ets>fulvus</ets> reddish
yellow.]</ety> <fld>(Chem.)</fld> <def>A reddish resinous
substance, obtained from indican.</def>

<hw>In`di*fus"cin</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos>

<hw>In"di*geen</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <def>Same as

<au>Darwin.</au>

<hw>In"di*gence</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[L.

<er>Indigent</er>.]</ety> <def>The condition of being indigent;

<hw>In"di*gene</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[L.
<ets>indigena</ets>: cf. F. <ets>indig\'8ane</ets>. See

aboriginal animal or plant; an autochthon.</def>

<au>Evelyn. Tylor.</au>

<hw>In*dig"e*nous</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>a.</pos> <ety>[L.
<ets>indigenus</ets>, <ets>indigena</ets>, fr. OL.
<ets>indu</ets> (fr. <ets>in</ets> in) + the root of L.
<ets>gignere</ets> to beget, bear. See <er>In</er>, and
<er>Gender</er>.]</ety>

<sn>1.</sn> <def>Native; produced, growing, or living, naturally
in a country or climate; not exotic; not imported.</def>

<q>Negroes were all transported from Africa and are not
<qex>indigenous</qex> or proper natives of America.</q>
<qau>Sir T. Browne.</qau>

<q>In America, cotton, being <qex>indigenous</qex>, is cheap.</q>
<qau>Lion Playas.</qau>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>Native; inherent; innate.</def>

<q>Joy and hope are emotions <qex>indigenous</qex> to the human
mind.</q>
<qau>I. Taylor.</qau>

<hw>In"di*gent</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>a.</pos> <ety>[L.
<ets>indigent</ets>, L. <ets>indigens</ets>, p. p. of
<ets>indigere</ets> to stand in need of, fr. OL. <ets>indu</ets>
(fr. <ets>in-</ets> in) + L. <ets>egere</ets> to be needy, to
need.]</ety>

<sn>1.</sn> <def>Wanting; void; free; destitute; -- used with
<xex>of</xex>.</def> <mark>[Obs.]</mark>

<au>Bacon.</au>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>Destitute of property or means of comfortable
subsistence; needy; poor; in want; necessitous.</def>

<q><qex>Indigent</qex> faint souls past corporal toil.</q>
<qau>Shak.</qau>

<q>Charity consists in relieving the <qex>indigent</qex>.</q>
<qau>Addison.</qau>

<hw>In"di*gent*ly</hw>, <pos>adv.</pos> <def>In an indigent
manner.</def>

<hw>In`di*gest"</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>a.</pos> <ety>[L.
<ets>indigestus</ets> unarranged. See <er>Indigested</er>.]</ety>
<def>Crude; unformed; unorganized; undigested.</def>
<mark>[Obs.]</mark> \'bdA chaos rude and <xex>indigest</xex>.\'b8
<au>W. Browne</au>. \'bdMonsters and things
<xex>indigest</xex>.\'b8 <au>Shak</au>.

<hw>In`di*gest"</hw>, <pos>n.</pos> <def>Something
indigested.</def> <mark>[Obs.]</mark>

<au>Shak.</au>

<hw>In`di*gest"ed</hw>, <pos>a.</pos> <ety>[Pref. <ets>in-</ets>
not + <ets>digested</ets>.]</ety>

<sn>1.</sn> <def>Not digested; undigested.</def>
\'bd<xex>Indigested</xex> food.\'b8

<au>Dryden.</au>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>Not resolved; not regularly disposed and
arranged; not methodical; crude; <as>as, an <ex>indigested</ex>
array of facts</as>.</def>

<q>In hot reformations . . . the whole is generally crude, harsh,
and <qex>indigested</qex>.</q>
<qau>Burke.</qau>

<q>This, like an <qex>indigested</qex> meteor, appeared and
disappeared almost at the same time.</q>
<qau>South.</qau>

<sn>3.</sn> <fld>(Med.)</fld> <sd>(a)</sd> <def>Not in a state
suitable for healing; -- said of wounds.</def> <sd>(b)</sd>
<def>Not ripened or suppurated; -- said of an abscess or its
contents.</def>

<sn>4.</sn> <def>Not softened by heat, hot water, or steam.</def>

<hw>In`di*gest"ed*ness</hw>, <pos>n.</pos> <def>The state or
quality of being undigested; crudeness.</def>

<au>Bp. Burnet.</au>

<hw>In*di*gest`i*bil"i*ty</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos>
<def>The state or quality of being indigestible;
indigestibleness.</def>

<hw>In`di*gest"i*ble</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>a.</pos> <ety>[L.
<ets>indigestibilis</ets>: cf. F. <ets>indigestible</ets>. See
<er>In-</er> not, and <er>Digest</er>.]</ety>

<sn>1.</sn> <def>Not digestible; not readily soluble in the
digestive juices; not easily convertible into products fitted for
absorption.</def>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>Not digestible in the mind; distressful;
intolerable; <as>as, an <ex>indigestible</ex> simile</as>.</def>

<au>T. Warton.</au>

<wf>In`di*gest"i*bly</wf>, <pos>adv.</pos></wordforms>

<hw>In`di*ges"tion</hw> <pr>(?; 106)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[L.
<ets>indigestio</ets>: cf. F. <ets>indigestion</ets>. See

should undergo in the alimentary canal; dyspepsia; incomplete or
difficult digestion.</def>

<hw>In`di*glu"cin</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos>

<fld>(Chem.)</fld> <def>The variety of sugar (glucose) obtained
from the glucoside indican. It is unfermentable, but reduces

<hw>In*dign"</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>a.</pos> <ety>[L.
<ets>indignus</ets>; pref. <ets>in-</ets> not + <ets>dignus</ets>

<def>Unworthy; undeserving; disgraceful; degrading.</def>

<q>Counts it scorn to draw
Comfort <qex>indign</qex> from any meaner thing.</q>
<qau>Trench.</qau>

<mhw>{ <hw>In*dig"nance</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <hw>In*dig"nan*cy</hw>
<pr>(?)</pr>, }</mhw> <pos>n.</pos> <def>Indignation.</def>
<mark>[Obs.]</mark>

<au>Spenser.</au>

<hw>In*dig"nant</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>a.</pos> <ety>[L.
<ets>indignans</ets>, <ets>-antis</ets>, p. pr. of
<ets>indignari</ets> to be indignant, disdain. See
<er>Indign</er>.]</ety> <def>Affected with indignation; wrathful;
passionate; irate; feeling wrath, as when a person is exasperated
by unworthy or unjust treatment, by a mean action, or by a
degrading accusation.</def>

<q>He strides <qex>indignant</qex>, and with haughty cries
To single fight the fairy prince defies.</q>
<qau>Tickell.</qau>

<hw>In*dig"nant*ly</hw>, <pos>adv.</pos> <def>In an indignant
manner.</def>

<hw>In`dig*na"tion</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[F.
<ets>indignation</ets>, L. <ets>indignatio</ets>. See
<er>Indign</er>.]</ety>

<sn>1.</sn> <def>The feeling excited by that which is unworthy,
base, or disgraceful; anger mingled with contempt, disgust, or
abhorrence.</def>

<au>Shak.</au>

<q><qex>Indignation</qex> expresses a strong and elevated
disapprobation of mind, which is also inspired by something
flagitious in the conduct of another.</q>
<qau>Cogan.</qau>

<q>When Haman saw Mordecai in the king's gate, that he stood not
up, nor moved for him, he was full of <qex>indignation</qex>
against Mordecai.</q>
<qau>Esther v. 9.</qau>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>The effect of anger; punishment.</def>

<au>Shak.</au>

<q>Hide thyself . . . until the <qex>indignation</qex> be
overpast.</q>
<qau>Is. xxvi. 20.</qau>

<syn>Syn. -- Anger; ire wrath; fury; rage. See
<er>Anger</er>.</syn>

<hw>In*dig"ni*fy</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>v. t.</pos> <ety>[L.
<ets>indignus</ets> unworthy + <ets>-fy</ets>.]</ety> <def>To
treat disdainfully or with indignity; to contemn.</def>
<mark>[Obs.]</mark>

<au>Spenser.</au>

<hw>In*dig"ni*ty</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos>; <plu>pl.
<plw>Indignities</plw> <pr>(#)</pr></plu>. <ety>[L.
<ets>indignitas</ets>: cf. F. <ets>indignit\'82</ets>. See
<er>Indign</er>.]</ety> <def>Any action toward another which
manifests contempt for him; an offense against personal dignity;
unmerited contemptuous treatment; contumely; incivility or
injury, accompanied with insult.</def>

<q>How might a prince of my great hopes forget
So great <qex>indignities</qex> you laid upon me?</q>
<qau>Shak.</qau>

<q>A person of so great place and worth constrained to endure so
foul <qex>indignities</qex>.</q>
<qau>Hooker.</qau>

<hw>In*dign"ly</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>adv.</pos>
<def>Unworthily.</def> <mark>[Obs.]</mark>

<hw>In"di*go</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos>; <plu>pl.
<plw>Indigoes</plw> <pr>(#)</pr></plu>. <ety>[F.
<ets>indigo</ets>, Sp. <ets>indigo</ets>, <ets>indico</ets>, L.
<ets>indicum</ets> indigo, fr. <ets>Indicus</ets> Indian. See
<er>Indian</er>.]</ety>

<sn>1.</sn> <def>A kind of deep blue, one of the seven prismatic
colors.</def>

<-- p. 753 -->

<sn>2.</sn> <fld>(Chem.)</fld> <def>A blue dyestuff obtained from
several plants belonging to very different genera and orders;
<as>as, the woad, <spn>Isatis tinctoria</spn>, <spn>Indigofera
tinctoria</spn>, <spn>I. Anil</spn>, <spn>Nereum
tinctorium</spn>, etc.</as> It is a dark blue earthy substance,
tasteless and odorless, with a copper-violet luster when rubbed.
Indigo does not exist in the plants as such, but is obtained by
decomposition of the glycoside indican.</def>

<note><hand/ Commercial indigo contains the essential coloring
principle <xex>indigo blue</xex> or <xex>indigotine</xex>, with
several other dyes; as, <xex>indigo red</xex>, <xex>indigo
brown</xex>, etc., and various impurities. Indigo is insoluble in
ordinary reagents, with the exception of strong sulphuric
acid.</note>

<cs><col>Chinese indigo</col> <fld>(Bot.)</fld>, <cd><spn>Isatis
indigotica</spn>, a kind of woad.</cd> -- <col>Wild indigo</col>
<fld>(Bot.)</fld>, <cd>the American herb <spn>Baptisia
tinctoria</spn> which yields a poor quality of indigo, as do
several other species of the same genus.</cd></cs>

<hw>In"di*go</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>a.</pos> <def>Having the
color of, pertaining to, or derived from, indigo.</def>

<cs><col>Indigo berry</col> <fld>(Bot.)</fld>, <cd>the fruit of
the West Indian shrub <spn>Randia aculeata</spn>, used as a blue
dye.</cd> -- <col>Indigo bird</col> <fld>(Zo\'94l.)</fld>, <cd>a
small North American finch (<spn>Cyanospiza cyanea</spn>). The
male is indigo blue in color. Called also <altname>indigo
bunting</altname>.</cd> -- <col>Indigo blue</col>. <sd>(a)</sd>
<cd>The essential coloring material of commercial indigo, from
which it is obtained as a dark blue earthy powder, with a reddish
luster, <chform>C16H10N2O2</chform>, which may be crystallized by
sublimation. Indigo blue is also made from artificial amido
cinnamic acid, and from artificial isatine; and these methods are
of great commercial importance. Called also
<altname>indigotin</altname>.</cd> <sd>(b)</sd> <cd>A dark, dull
blue color like the indigo of commerce.</cd> -- <col>Indigo
brown</col> <fld>(Chem.)</fld>, <cd>a brown resinous substance
found in crude indigo.</cd> -- <col>Indigo copper</col>
<fld>(Min.)</fld>, <cd>covellite.</cd> -- <col>Indigo
green</col>, <cd>a green obtained from indigo.</cd> --
<col>Indigo plant</col> <fld>(Bot.)</fld>, <cd>a leguminous plant
of several species (genus <spn>Indigofera</spn>), from which
indigo is prepared. The different varieties are natives of Asia,
Africa, and America. Several species are cultivated, of which the
most important are the <spn>I. tinctoria</spn>, or common indigo
plant, the <spn>I. Anil</spn>, a larger species, and the <spn>I.
disperma</spn>.</cd> -- <col>Indigo purple</col>, <cd>a purple
obtained from indigo.</cd> -- <col>Indigo red</col>, <cd>a
dyestuff, isomeric with indigo blue, obtained from crude indigo
as a dark brown amorphous powder.</cd> -- <col>Indigo snake</col>
<fld>(Zo\'94l.)</fld>, <cd>the gopher snake.</cd> -- <col>Indigo
white</col>, <cd>a white crystalline powder obtained by reduction
from indigo blue, and by oxidation easily changed back to it; --
called also <altname>indigogen</altname>.</cd> -- <col>Indigo
yellow</col>, <cd>a substance obtained from indigo.</cd></cs>

<hw>\'d8In`di*gof"e*ra</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos>
<ety>[NL., from E. <ets>indigo</ets> + L. <ets>ferre</ets> to
bear.]</ety> <fld>(Bot.)</fld> <def>A genus of leguminous plants
having many species, mostly in tropical countries, several of
them yielding indigo, esp. <spn>Indigofera tinctoria</spn>, and
<spn>I. Anil</spn>.</def>

<hw>In"di*go*gen</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos>

<sn>1.</sn> <fld>(Chem.)</fld> <def>See <cref>Indigo

<sn>2.</sn> <fld>(Physiol. Chem.)</fld> <def>Same as
<er>Indican</er>, 2.</def>
