<hw>In"din</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[From
<er>Indigo</er>.]</ety> <fld>(Chem.)</fld> <def>A dark red
crystalline substance, isomeric with and resembling indigo blue,
and obtained from isatide and dioxindol.</def>

<hw>In`di*rect"</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>a.</pos> <ety>[Pref.
<ets>in-</ets> not + <ets>direct</ets>: cf. F.
<ets>indirect</ets>.]</ety>

<sn>1.</sn> <def>Not direct; not straight or rectilinear;
deviating from a direct line or course; circuitous; <as>as, an
<ex>indirect</ex> road</as>.</def>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>Not tending to an aim, purpose, or result by the
plainest course, or by obvious means, but obliquely or
consequentially; by remote means; <as>as, an <ex>indirect</ex>
accusation, attack, answer, or proposal</as>.</def>

<q>By what bypaths and <qex>indirect</qex>, crooked ways
I met this crown.</q>
<qau>Shak.</qau>

<sn>3.</sn> <def>Not straightforward or upright; unfair;
dishonest; tending to mislead or deceive.</def>

<q><qex>Indirect</qex> dealing will be discovered one time or
other.</q>
<qau>Tillotson.</qau>

<sn>4.</sn> <def>Not resulting directly from an act or cause, but
more or less remotely connected with or growing out of it;
<as>as, <ex>indirect</ex> results, damages, or claims</as>.</def>

<sn>5.</sn> <fld>(Logic & Math.)</fld> <def>Not reaching the end
aimed at by the most plain and direct method; <as>as, an
<ex>indirect</ex> proof, demonstration, etc.</as></def>

<cs><col>Indirect claims</col>, <cd>claims for remote or
consequential damage. Such claims were presented to and thrown
out by the commissioners who arbitrated the damage inflicted on
the United States by the Confederate States cruisers built and
supplied by Great Britain.</cd> -- <col>Indirect
demonstration</col>, <cd>a mode of demonstration in which proof
is given by showing that any other supposition involves an
absurdity (<xex>reductio ad absurdum<xex>), or an impossibility;
thus, one quantity may be proved equal to another by showing that
it can be neither greater nor less.</cd> -- <col>Indirect
discourse</col>. <fld>(Gram.)</fld> <cd>See <cref>Direct
discourse</cref>, under <er>Direct</er>.</cd> -- <col>Indirect
evidence</col>, <cd>evidence or testimony which is circumstantial
or inferential, but without witness; -- opposed to <xex>direct
evidence<xex>.</cd> -- <col>Indirect tax</col>, <cd>a tax, such
as customs, excises, <-- VAT,-->etc., exacted directly from the
merchant, but paid indirectly by the consumer in the higher price
demanded for the articles of merchandise.</cd></cs>

<hw>In`di*rect"ed</hw>, <pos>a.</pos> <def>Not directed;
aimless.</def> <mark>[Obs.]</mark>

<hw>In`di*rec"tion</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[Cf. F.
<ets>indirection</ets>.]</ety> <def>Oblique course or means;
dishonest practices; indirectness.</def> \'bdBy
<xex>indirections</xex> find directions out.\'b8

<au>Shak.</au>

<hw>In`di*rect"ly</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>adv.</pos> <def>In an
direct manner; not in a straight line or course; not in express
terms; obliquely; not by direct means; hence, unfairly;
wrongly.</def>

<q>To tax it <qex>indirectly</qex> by taxing their expense.</q>
<qau>A. Smith.</qau>

<q>Your crown and kingdom <qex>indirectly</qex> held.</q>
<qau>Shak.</qau>

<hw>In`di*rect"ness</hw>, <pos>n.</pos> <sn>1.</sn> <def>The
quality or state of being indirect; obliquity; deviousness;
crookedness.</def>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>Deviation from an upright or straightforward
course; unfairness; dishonesty.</def>

<au>W. Montagu.</au>

<hw>In`dis*pose"</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>v. t.</pos>

<pr>(?)</pr>; <pos>p. pr. & vb. n.</pos>
<er>Indisposing</er>.]</wordforms> <ety>[OE. <ets>indispos</ets>
indisposed, feeble, or F. <ets>indispos\'82</ets> indisposed. See
<er>In-</er> not, and <er>Dispose</er>.]</ety>

<sn>1.</sn> <def>To render unfit or unsuited; to
disqualify.</def>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>To disorder slightly as regards health; to make

<au>Shak.</au>

<q>It made him rather <qex>indisposed</qex> than sick.</q>
<qau>Walton.</qau>

<sn>3.</sn> <def>To disincline; to render averse or unfavorable;
<as>as, a love of pleasure <ex>indisposes</ex> the mind to severe
study; the pride and selfishness of men <ex>indispose</ex> them
to religious duties.</as></def>

<q>The king was sufficiently <qex>indisposed</qex> towards the
persons, or the principles, of Calvin's disciples.</q>
<qau>Clarendon.</qau>

<hw>In*dis"so*lu*ble</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>a.</pos> <ety>[L.

<sn>1.</sn> <def>Not dissoluble; not capable of being dissolved,
melted, or liquefied; insoluble; as few substances are
<xex>indissoluble</xex> by heat, but many are
<xex>indissoluble</xex> in water.</def>

<au>Boyle.</au>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>Incapable of being rightfully broken or
dissolved; perpetually binding or obligatory; firm; stable,
<as>as, an <ex>indissoluble</ex> league or covenant</as>.</def>

<q>To the which my duties
Are with a most <qex>indissoluble</qex> tie
Forever knit.</q>
<qau>Shak.</qau>

<hw>In`dis*tinct"</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>a.</pos> <ety>[L.
<ets>indistinctus</ets>: cf. F. <ets>indistinct</ets>. See
<er>In-</er> not, and <er>Distinct</er>.]</ety>

<sn>1.</sn> <def>Not distinct or distinguishable; not separate in
such a manner as to be perceptible by itself; <as>as, the
<ex>indistinct</ex> parts of a substance</as>.</def>
\'bd<xex>Indistinct</xex> as water is in water.\'b8

<au>Shak.</au>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>Obscure to the mind or senses; not clear; not
definite; confused; imperfect; faint; <as>as, <ex>indistinct</ex>
vision; an <ex>indistinct</ex> sound; an <ex>indistinct</ex> idea
or recollection.</as></def>

<q>When we come to parts too small four our senses, our ideas of
these little bodies become obscure and <qex>indistinct</qex>.</q>
<qau>I. Watts.</qau>

<q>Their views, indeed, are <qex>indistinct</qex> and dim.</q>
<qau>Cowper.</qau>

<syn>Syn. -- Undefined; indistinguishable; obscure; indefinite;
vague; ambiguous; uncertain; confused.</syn>

<hw>In*dite"</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>v. t.</pos>
<wordforms>[<pos>imp. & p. p.</pos> <er>Indited</er>; <pos>p. pr.
& vb. n.</pos> <er>Inditing</er>.]</wordforms> <ety>[OE.
<ets>enditen</ets> to indite, indict, OF. <ets>enditer</ets> to
indicate, show, dictate, write, inform, and <ets>endicter</ets>
to accuse; both fr. LL. <ets>indictare</ets> to show, to accuse,
fr. L. <ets>indicere</ets> to proclaim, announce; pref.
<ets>in-</ets> in + <ets>dicere</ets> to say. The word was
influenced also by L. <ets>indicare</ets> to indicate, and by
<ets>dictare</ets> to dictate. See <er>Diction</er>, and cf.
<er>Indict</er>, <er>Indicate</er>, <er>Dictate</er>.]</ety>

<sn>1.</sn> <def>To compose; to write; to be author of; to
dictate; to prompt.</def>

<q>My heart is <qex>inditing</qex> a good matter.</q>
<qau>Ps. xlv. 1.</qau>

<q>Could a common grief have <qex>indited</qex> such
expressions?</q>
<qau>South.</qau>

<q>Hear how learned Greece her useful rules
<qex>indites</qex>.</q>
<qau>Pope.</qau>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>To invite or ask.</def> <mark>[Obs.]</mark>

<q>She will <qex>indite</qex> him so supper.</q>
<qau>Shak.</qau>

<sn>3.</sn> <def>To indict; to accuse; to censure.</def>
<mark>[Obs.]</mark>

<au>Spenser.</au>

<hw>In*dite"</hw>, <pos>v. i.</pos> <def>To compose; to write, as
a poem.</def>

<q>Wounded I sing, tormented I <qex>indite</qex>.</q>
<qau>Herbert.</qau>

<hw>In*dite"ment</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[Cf.
<er>Indictment</er>.]</ety> <def>The act of inditing.</def>

<au>Craig.</au>

<hw>In*dit"er</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <def>One who
indites.</def>

<au>Smart.</au>

<hw>In"di*um</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[NL. See
<er>Indigo</er>.]</ety> <fld>(Chem.)</fld> <def>A rare metallic
element, discovered in certain ores of zinc, by means of its
characteristic spectrum of two indigo blue lines; hence, its
name. In appearance it resembles zinc, being white or lead gray,
soft, malleable and easily fusible, but in its chemical relation
it resembles aluminium or gallium. Symbol In. Atomic weight,
113.4.</def>

<-- p. 754 -->

<hw>In`di*vid"u*al</hw> <pr>(?; 135)</pr>, <pos>a.</pos> <ety>[L.
<ets>individuus</ets> indivisible; pref. <ets>in-</ets> not +
<ets>dividuus</ets> divisible, fr. <ets>dividere</ets> to divide:
cf. F. <ets>individuel</ets>. See <er>Divide</er>.]</ety>

<sn>1.</sn> <def>Not divided, or not to be divided; existing as
one entity, or distinct being or object; single; one; <as>as, an
<ex>individual</ex> man, animal, or city</as>.</def>

<q>Mind has a being of its own, distinct from that of all other
things, and is pure, unmingled, <qex>individual</qex>
substance.</q>
<qau>A. Tucker.</qau>

<q>United as one <qex>individual</qex> soul.</q>
<qau>Milton.</qau>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>Of or pertaining to one only; peculiar to, or
characteristic of, a single person or thing; distinctive; <as>as,
<ex>individual</ex> traits of character; <ex>individual</ex>
exertions; <ex>individual</ex> peculiarities.</as></def>

<hw>In`di*vid"u*al</hw>, <pos>n.</pos> <sn>1.</sn> <def>A single
person, animal, or thing of any kind; a thing or being incapable
of separation or division, without losing its identity;
especially, a human being; a person.</def>

<au>Cowper.</au>

<q>An object which is in the strict and primary sense one, and
can not be logically divided, is called an
<qex>individual</qex>.</q>
<qau>Whately.</qau>

<q>That <qex>individuals</qex> die, his will ordains.</q>
<qau>Dryden.</qau>

<sn>2.</sn> <fld>(Zo\'94l.)</fld> <sd>(a)</sd> <def>An
independent, or partially independent, zooid of a compound
animal.</def> <sd>(b)</sd> <def>The product of a single egg,
whether it remains a single animal or becomes compound by budding
or fission.</def>

<hw>In`di*vid"u*al*ism</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[Cf.
F. <ets>individualisme</ets>.]</ety>

<sn>1.</sn> <def>The quality of being individual; individuality;
personality.</def>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>An excessive or exclusive regard to one's
personal interest; self-interest; selfishness.</def>

<q>The selfishness of the small proprietor has been described by
the best writers as <qex>individualism</qex>.</q>
<qau>Ed. Rev.</qau>

<hw>In`di*vid`u*al*is"tic</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>a.</pos>
<def>Of or pertaining to the individual or individualism.</def>

<au>London Athen\'91um.</au>

<hw>In`di*vid`u*al"i*ty</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos>;
<plu>pl. <plw>Individualities</plw> <pr>(#)</pr></plu>. <ety>[Cf.
F. <ets>individualit\'82</ets>.]</ety>

<sn>1.</sn> <def>The quality or state of being individual or
constituting an individual; separate or distinct existence;
oneness; unity.</def>

<au>Arbuthnot.</au>

<q>They possess separate <qex>individualities</qex>.</q>
<qau>H. Spencer.</qau>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>The character or property appropriate or
peculiar to an individual; that quality which distinguishes one
person or thing from another; the sum of characteristic traits;
distinctive character; <as>as, he is a person of marked
<ex>individuality</ex></as>.</def>

<hw>In`di*vid`u*al*i*za"tion</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos>
<ety>[Cf. F. <ets>individualization</ets>.]</ety> <def>The act of
individualizing; the state of being individualized;
individuation.</def>

<hw>In`di*vid"u*al*ize</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>v. t.</pos>
<wordforms>[<pos>imp. & p. p.</pos> <er>Individualized</er>
<pr>(?)</pr>; <pos>p. pr. & vb. n.</pos> <er>Individualizing</er>
<pr>(?)</pr>.]</wordforms> <ety>[Cf. F.
<ets>individualiser</ets>.]</ety> <def>The mark as an individual,
or to distinguish from others by peculiar properties; to invest
with individuality.</def>

<q>The peculiarities which <qex>individualize</qex> and
distinguish the humor of Addison.</q>
<qau>N. Drake.</qau>

<hw>In`di*vid"u*al*i`zer</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos>
<def>One who individualizes.</def>

<hw>In`di*vid"u*al*ly</hw>, <pos>adv.</pos> <sn>1.</sn> <def>In
an individual manner or relation; as individuals; separately;
each by itself.</def> \'bd<xex>Individually</xex> or
collectively.\'b8

<au>Burke.</au>

<q>How should that subsist solitarily by itself which hath no
substance, but <qex>individually</qex> the very same whereby
others subsist with it?</q>
<qau>Hooker.</qau>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>In an inseparable manner; inseparably;
incommunicably; indivisibly; <as>as, <ex>individually</ex>he
same</as>.</def>

<q>[Omniscience], an attribute <qex>individually</qex> proper to
the Godhead.</q>
<qau>Hakewill.</qau>

<hw>In`di*vid"u*ate</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>a.</pos> <ety>[See
<er>Individual</er>.]</ety> <def>Undivided.</def>
<mark>[Obs.]</mark>

<hw>In`di*vid"u*ate</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>v. t.</pos>
<wordforms>[<pos>imp. & p. p.</pos> <er>Individua</er>ted (<?/);
<pos>p. pr. & vb. n.</pos> <er>Individuating</er>.]</wordforms>
<def>To distinguish from others from others of the species; to
endow with individuality; to divide into individuals; to
discriminate.</def>

<q>The soul, as the prime <qex>individuating</qex> principle, and
the said reserved portion of matter as an essential and radical
part of the individuation, shall . . . make up and restore the
same individual person.</q>
<qau>South.</qau>

<q>Life is <qex>individuated</qex> into infinite numbers, that
have their distinct sense and pleasure.</q>
<qau>Dr. H. More.</qau>

<hw>In`di*vid`u*a"tion</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[Cf.

<au>H. Spencer.</au>

<au>Fuller.</au>

<hw>In`di*vin"i*ty</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[Pref.

<hw>In`di*vis`i*bil"i*ty</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos>

<au>Locke.</au>

<hw>In`di*vis"i*ble</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>a.</pos> <ety>[L.
<ets>indivisibilis</ets>: cf. F. <ets>indivisible</ets>. See
<er>In-</er> not, and <er>Divisible</er>.]</ety>

<sn>1.</sn> <def>Not divisible; incapable of being divided,
separated, or broken; not separable into parts.</def> \'bdOne
<xex>indivisible</xex> point of time.\'b8

<au>Dryden.</au>

<sn>2.</sn> <fld>(Math.)</fld> <def>Not capable of exact
division, as one quantity by another; incommensurable.</def>

<hw>In`di*vis"i*ble</hw>, <pos>n.</pos> <sn>1.</sn> <def>That
which is indivisible.</def>

<q>By atom, nobody will imagine we intend to express a perfect
<qex>indivisible</qex>, but only the least sort of natural
bodies.</q>
<qau>Digby.</qau>

<sn>2.</sn> <fld>(Geom.)</fld> <def>An infinitely small quantity
which is assumed to admit of no further division.</def>

<cs><col>Method of indivisibles</col>, <cd>a kind of calculus,
formerly in use, in which lines were considered as made up of an
infinite number of points; surfaces, as made up of an infinite
number of lines; and volumes, as made up of an infinite number of
surfaces.</cd></cs>

<au>W. Montagu.</au>

manner.</def>

<hw>In*doc"tri*nate</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>v. t.</pos>

<er>Indoctrinating</er>.]</wordforms> <ety>[Pref. <ets>in-</ets>

<hw>In"do*in</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <fld>(Chem.)</fld>

<hw>In"dol</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos>
<ety>[<ets>Ind</ets>igo + -<ets>ol</ets> of
<ets>phenol</ets>.]</ety> <fld>(Physiol. Chem.)</fld> <def>A
white, crystalline substance, <chform>C8H7N</chform>, obtained
from blue indigo, and almost all indigo derivatives, by a process
of reduction. It is also formed from albuminous matter, together
with skatol, by putrefaction, and by fusion with caustic potash,
and is present in human excrement, as well as in the intestinal
canal of some herbivora.</def>

<hw>In"do*lence</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[L.
<ets>indolentia</ets> freedom from pain: cf. F.
<ets>indolence</ets>.]</ety>

<sn>1.</sn> <def>Freedom from that which pains, or harasses, as
toil, care, grief, etc.</def> <mark>[Obs.]</mark>

<q>I have ease, if it may not rather be called
<qex>indolence</qex>.</q>
<qau>Bp. Hough.</qau>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>The quality or condition of being indolent;
inaction, or want of exertion of body or mind, proceeding from
love of ease or aversion to toil; habitual idleness;
indisposition to labor; laziness; sloth; inactivity.</def>

<q>Life spent in <qex>indolence</qex>, and therefore sad.</q>
<qau>Cowper.</qau>

<q>As there is a great truth wrapped up in \'bddiligence,\'b8
what a lie, on the other hand, lurks at the root of our present
use of the word \'bd<qex>indolence</qex>\'b8! This is from
\'bdin\'b8 and \'bddoleo,\'b8 not to grieve; and
<qex>indolence</qex> is thus a state in which we have no grief or
pain; so that the word, as we now employ it, seems to affirm that
indulgence in sloth and ease is that which would constitute for
us the absence of all pain.</q>
<qau>Trench.</qau>

<hw>In"do*len*cy</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos>
<def>Indolence.</def> <mark>[Obs.]</mark>

<au>Holland.</au>

<hw>In"do*lent</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>a.</pos> <ety>[Pref.
<ets>in-</ets> not + L. <ets>dolens</ets>, <ets>-entis</ets>, p.
pr. of <ets>dolere</ets> to feel pain: cf. F.
<ets>indolent</ets>. See <er>Dolorous</er>.]</ety>

<sn>1.</sn> <def>Free from toil, pain, or trouble.</def>
<mark>[Obs.]</mark>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>Indulging in ease; avoiding labor and exertion;
habitually idle; lazy; inactive; <as>as, an <ex>indolent</ex>
man</as>.</def>

<q>To waste long nights in <qex>indolent</qex> repose.</q>
<qau>Pope.</qau>

<sn>3.</sn> <fld>(Med.)</fld> <def>Causing little or no pain or
annoyance; <as>as, an <ex>indolent</ex> tumor</as>.</def>

<syn>Syn. -- Idle; lazy; slothful; sluggish; listless; inactive;
inert. See <er>Idle</er>.</syn>

<hw>In"do*lent*ly</hw>, <pos>adv.</pos> <def>In an indolent
manner.</def>

<q>Calm and serene you <qex>indolently</qex> sit.</q>
<qau>Addison.</qau>

<hw>In`do*phe"nol</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos>
<ety>[<ets>Ind</ets>igo + <ets>phenol</ets>.]</ety>
<fld>(Chem.)</fld> <def>Any one of a series of artificial blue
dyestuffs, resembling indigo in appearance, and obtained by the
action of phenol on certain nitrogenous derivatives of quinone.
Simple indophenol proper has not yet been isolated.</def>

<hw>In*dors"a*ble</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>a.</pos> <def>Capable
of being indorsed; transferable; convertible.</def>

<hw>In`dor*sa"tion</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos>
<def>Indorsement.</def> <mark>[Obs.]</mark>

<hw>In*dorse"</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>v. t.</pos>
<wordforms>[<pos>imp. & p. p.</pos> <er>Indorsed</er>
<pr>(?)</pr>; <pos>p. pr. & vb. n.</pos>
<er>Indorsing</er>.]</wordforms> <ety>[LL. <ets>indorsare</ets>.
See <er>Endorse</er>.]</ety> <altsp>[Written also
<asp>endorse</asp>.]</altsp>

<sn>1.</sn> <def>To cover the back of; to load or burden.</def>
<mark>[Obs.]</mark>

<q>Elephants <qex>indorsed</qex> with towers.</q>
<qau>Milton.</qau>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>To write upon the back or outside of a paper or
letter, as a direction, heading, memorandum, or address.</def>

<sn>3.</sn> <fld>(Law & Com.)</fld> <def>To write one's name,
alone or with other words, upon the back of (a paper), for the
purpose of transferring it, or to secure the payment of a <?/ote,
draft, or the like; to guarantee the payment, fulfillment,
performance, or validity of, or to certify something upon the
back of (a check, draft, writ, warrant of arrest, etc.).</def>

<sn>4.</sn> <def>To give one's name or support to; to sanction;
to aid by approval; to approve; <as>as, to <ex>indorse</ex> an
opinion</as>.</def>

<cs><col>To indorse in blank</col>, <cd>to write one's name on
the back of a note or bill, leaving a blank to be filled by the
holder.</cd></cs>

<hw>In*dorsed"</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>a.</pos> <fld>(Her.)</fld>
<def>See <er>Addorsed</er>.</def>

<hw>In`dor*see"</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <def>The person
to whom a note or bill is indorsed, or assigned by
indorsement.</def>

<hw>In*dorse"ment</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[From
<er>Indorse</er>; cf. <er>Endorsement</er>.]</ety>
<altsp>[Written also <asp>endorsement</asp>.]</altsp>

<sn>1.</sn> <def>The act of writing on the back of a note, bill,
or other written instrument.</def>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>That which is written on the back of a note,
bill, or other paper, as a name, an order for, or a receipt of,
payment, or the return of an officer, etc.; a writing, usually
upon the back, but sometimes on the face, of a negotiable
instrument, by which the property therein is assigned and
transferred.</def>

<au>Story. Byles. Burrill.</au>

<sn>3.</sn> <def>Sanction, support, or approval; <as>as, the
<ex>indorsement</ex> of a rumor, an opinion, a course,
conduct</as>.</def>

<cs><col>Blank indorsement</col>. <cd>See under
<er>Blank</er>.</cd></cs>

<pr>(?)</pr>, }</mhw> <pos>n.</pos> <def>The person who
indorses.</def> <altsp>[Written also
<asp>endorser</asp>.]</altsp>

<mark>[Obs.]</mark>

<au>Shak.</au>

<mhw>{ <hw>In"dris</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <hw>In"dri</hw>
<pr>(?)</pr>, }</mhw> <pos>n.</pos> <fld>(Zo\'94l.)</fld>
<def>Any lemurine animal of the genus <spn>Indris</spn>.</def>

<note><hand/ Several species are known, all of them natives of
Madagascar, as the diadem indris (<spn>I. diadema</spn>), which
has a white ruff around the forehead; the woolly indris (<spn>I.
laniger</spn>); and the short-tailed or black indris (<spn>I.
brevicaudatus</spn>), which is black, varied with gray.</note>

<hw>In*du"bi*ous</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>a.</pos> <ety>[L.
<ets>indubius</ets>. See <er>In-</er> not, and
<er>Dubious</er>.]</ety>

<sn>1.</sn> <def>Not dubious or doubtful; certain.</def>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>Not doubting; unsuspecting.</def>
\'bd<xex>Indubious</xex> confidence.\'b8

<au>Harvey.</au>

<hw>In*du"bi*ta*ble</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>a.</pos> <ety>[L.
<ets>indubitabilis</ets>: cf. F. <ets>indubitable</ets>. See
<er>In-</er> not, and <er>Dubitable</er>.]</ety> <def>Not
dubitable or doubtful; too evident to admit of doubt;
unquestionable; evident; apparently certain; <as>as, an
<ex>indubitable</ex> conclusion</as>.</def> --
<def2><pos>n.</pos> <def>That which is indubitable.</def></def2>

<syn>Syn. -- Unquestionable; evident; incontrovertible;
incontestable; undeniable; irrefragable.</syn>

<hw>In*du"bi*ta*ble*ness</hw>, <pos>n.</pos> <def>The state or
quality of being indubitable.</def>

<hw>In*du"bi*ta*bly</hw>, <pos>adv.</pos> <def>Undoubtedly;
unquestionably; in a manner to remove all doubt.</def>

<q>Oracles <qex>indubitably</qex> clear and infallibly
certain.</q>
<qau>Barrow.</qau>

<hw>In*du"bi*tate</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>a.</pos> <ety>[L.
<ets>indubitatus</ets>; pref. <ets>in-</ets> not +
<ets>dubitatus</ets>, p. p. of <ets>dubitare</ets> to
doubt.]</ety> <def>Not questioned or doubtful; evident;
certain.</def> <mark>[Obs.]</mark>

<au>Bacon.</au>

<hw>In*du"bi*tate</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>v. t.</pos> <ety>[L.
<ets>indubitatus</ets>, p. p. of <ets>indubitare</ets>; pref.
<ets>in-</ets> in + <ets>dubitare</ets> to doubt.]</ety> <def>To
bring into doubt; to cause to be doubted.</def>
<mark>[Obs.]</mark>

<q>To conceal, or <qex>indubitate</qex>, his exigency.</q>
<qau>Sir T. Browne.</qau>

<hw>In*duce"</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>v. t.</pos>
<wordforms>[<pos>imp. & p. p.</pos> <er>Induced</er>
<pr>(?)</pr>; <pos>p. pr. & vb. n.</pos> <er>Inducing</er>
<pr>(?)</pr>.]</wordforms> <ety>[L. <ets>inducere</ets>,
<ets>inductum</ets>; pref. <ets>in-</ets> in + <ets>ducere</ets>
to lead. See <er>Duke</er>, and cf. <er>Induct</er>.]</ety>

<sn>1.</sn> <def>To lead in; to introduce.</def>
<mark>[Obs.]</mark>

<q>The poet may be seen <qex>inducing</qex> his personages in the
first Iliad.</q>
<qau>Pope.</qau>

<-- p. 755 -->

<sn>2.</sn> <def>To draw on; to overspread. [<mark>A
Latinism</mark>]</def>

<au>Cowper.</au>

<sn>3.</sn> <def>To lead on; to influence; to prevail on; to
incite; to move by persuasion or influence.</def>

<au>Shak.</au>

<q>He is not obliged by your offer to do it, . . . though he may
be <qex>induced</qex>, persuaded, prevailed upon, tempted.</q>
<qau>Paley.</qau>

<q>Let not the covetous desire of growing rich <qex>induce</qex>
you to ruin your reputation.</q>
<qau>Dryden.</qau>

<sn>4.</sn> <def>To bring on; to effect; to cause; <as>as, a
fever <ex>induced</ex> by fatigue or exposure</as>.</def>

<q>Sour things <qex>induces</qex> a contraction in the
nerves.</q>
<qau>Bacon.</qau>

<sn>5.</sn> <fld>(Physics)</fld> <def>To produce, or cause, by
proximity without contact or transmission, as a particular
electric or magnetic condition in a body, by the approach of
another body in an opposite electric or magnetic state.</def>

<sn>6.</sn> <fld>(Logic)</fld> <def>To generalize or conclude as
an inference from all the particulars; -- the opposite of
<xex>deduce</xex>.</def>

<syn>Syn. -- To move; instigate; urge; impel; incite; press;
influence; actuate.</syn>

<hw>In*duce"ment</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[From
<er>Induce</er>.]</ety>

<sn>1.</sn> <def>The act of inducing, or the state of being
induced.</def>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>That which induces; a motive or consideration
that leads one to action or induces one to act; <as>as, reward is
an <ex>inducement</ex> to toil</as>.</def> \'bdMark the
<xex>inducement</xex>.\'b8

<au>Shak.</au>

<sn>3.</sn> <fld>(Law)</fld> <def>Matter stated by way of
explanatory preamble or introduction to the main allegations of a
pleading; a leading to.</def>

<syn>Syn. -- Motive; reason; influence. See
<er>Motive</er>.</syn>

<hw>In*du"cer</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <def>One who, or
that which, induces or incites.</def>

<hw>In*du"ci*ble</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>a.</pos> <sn>1.</sn>
<def>Capable of being induced, caused, or made to take
place.</def>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>Obtainable by induction; derivable;
inferable.</def>

<hw>In*duct"</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>v. t.</pos>
<wordforms>[<pos>imp. & p. p.</pos> <er>Inducted</er>; <pos>p.
pr. & vb. n.</pos> <er>Inducting</er>.]</wordforms> <ety>[L.
<ets>inductus</ets>, p. p. of <ets>inducere</ets>. See
<er>Induce</er>.]</ety>

<sn>1.</sn> <def>To bring in; to introduce; to usher in.</def>

<q>The independent orator <qex>inducting</qex> himself without
further ceremony into the pulpit.</q>
<qau>Sir W. Scott.</qau>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>To introduce, as to a benefice or office; to put
in actual possession of the temporal rights of an ecclesiastical
living, or of any other office, with the customary forms and
ceremonies.</def>

<q>The prior, when <qex>inducted</qex> into that dignity, took an
oath not to alienate any of their lands.</q>
<qau>Bp. Burnet.</qau>

<hw>In*duc"te*ous</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>a.</pos>
<fld>(Elec.)</fld> <def>Rendered electro-polar by induction, or
brought into the opposite electrical state by the influence of
inductive bodies.</def>

<hw>In*duc"tile</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>a.</pos> <ety>[Pref.
<ets>in-</ets> not + <ets>ductile</ets>: cf. F.
<ets>inductile</ets>.]</ety> <def>Not ductile; incapable of being
drawn into threads, as a metal; inelastic; tough.</def>

<hw>In`duc*til"i*ty</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <def>The
quality or state of being inductile.</def>

<hw>In*duc"tion</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[L.
<ets>inductio</ets>: cf. F. <ets>induction</ets>. See
<er>Induct</er>.]</ety>

<sn>1.</sn> <def>The act or process of inducting or bringing in;
introduction; entrance; beginning; commencement.</def>

<q>I know not you; nor am I well pleased to make this time, as
the affair now stands, the <qex>induction</qex> of your
acquaintance.</q>
<qau>Beau. & Fl.</qau>

<q>These promises are fair, the parties sure,
And our <qex>induction</qex> dull of prosperous hope.</q>
<qau>Shak.</qau>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>An introduction or introductory scene, as to a
play; a preface; a prologue.</def> <mark>[Obs.]</mark>

<q>This is but an <qex>induction</qex>: I will d<?/aw
The curtains of the tragedy hereafter.</q>
<qau>Massinger.</qau>

<sn>3.</sn> <fld>(Philos.)</fld> <def>The act or process of
reasoning from a part to a whole, from particulars to generals,
or from the individual to the universal; also, the result or
inference so reached.</def>

<q><qex>Induction</qex> is an inference drawn from all the
particulars.</q>
<qau>Sir W. Hamilton.</qau>

<q><qex>Induction</qex> is the process by which we conclude that
what is true of certain individuals of a class, is true of the
whole class, or that what is true at certain times will be true
in similar circumstances at all times.</q>
<qau>J. S. Mill.</qau>

<sn>4.</sn> <def>The introduction of a clergyman into a benefice,
or of an official into a office, with appropriate acts or
ceremonies; the giving actual possession of an ecclesiastical
living or its temporalities.</def>

<sn>5.</sn> <fld>(Math.)</fld> <def>A process of demonstration in
which a general truth is gathered from an examination of
particular cases, one of which is known to be true, the
examination being so conducted that each case is made to depend
on the preceding one; -- called also <altname>successive
induction</altname>.</def>

<sn>6.</sn> <fld>(Physics)</fld> <def>The property by which one
body, having electrical or magnetic polarity, causes or induces
it in another body without direct contact; an impress of
electrical or magnetic force or condition from one body on
another without actual contact.</def>

<cs><col>Electro-dynamic induction</col>, <cd>the action by which
a variable or interrupted current of electricity excites another
current in a neighboring conductor forming a closed circuit.</cd>
-- <col>Electro-magnetic induction</col>, <cd>the influence by
which an electric current produces magnetic polarity in certain
bodies near or around which it passes.</cd> --
<col>Electro-static induction</col>, <cd>the action by which a
body possessing a charge of statical electricity develops a
charge of statical electricity of the opposite character in a
neighboring body.</cd> -- <col>Induction coil</col>, <cd>an
apparatus producing induced currents of great intensity. It
consists of a coil or helix of stout insulated copper wire,
surrounded by another coil of very fine insulated wire, in which
a momentary current is induced, when a current (as from a voltaic
battery), passing through the inner coil, is made, broken, or
varied. The inner coil has within it a core of soft iron, and is
connected at its terminals with a condenser; -- called also
<altname>inductorium</altname>, and <altname>Ruhmkorff's
coil</altname>.</cd> -- <mcol><col>Induction pipe</col>,
<col>port</col>, <or/ <col>valve</col></mcol>, <cd>a pipe,
passageway, or valve, for leading or admitting a fluid to a
receiver, as steam to an engine cylinder, or water to a
pump.</cd> -- <col>Magnetic induction</col>, <cd>the action by
which magnetic polarity is developed in a body susceptible to
magnetic effects when brought under the influence of a
magnet.</cd> -- <col>Magneto-electric induction</col>, <cd>the
influence by which a magnet excites electric currents in closed
circuits.</cd></cs>

<cs><col>Logical induction</col>, <fld>(Philos.)</fld>, <cd>an
act or method of reasoning from all the parts separately to the
whole which they constitute, or into which they may be united
collectively; the operation of discovering and proving general
propositions; the scientific method.</cd> -- <col>Philosophical
induction</col>, <cd>the inference, or the act of inferring, that
what has been observed or established in respect to a part,
individual, or species, may, on the ground of analogy, be
affirmed or received of the whole to which it belongs. This last
is the <xex>inductive method<xex> of Bacon. It ascends from the
parts to the whole, and forms, from the general analogy of
nature, or special presumptions in the case, conclusions which
have greater or less degrees of force, and which may be
strengthened or weakened by subsequent experience and experiment.
It relates to actual existences, as in physical science or the
concerns of life. <xex>Logical induction<xex> is founded on the
necessary laws of thought; <xex>philosophical induction<xex>, on
the interpretation of the indications or analogy of
nature.</cd></cs><-- "scientific method" is now considered as the
latter, rather than the former! -->

<syn>Syn. -- Deduction.</syn> <usage> -- <er>Induction</er>,
<er>Deduction</er>. In <xex>induction</xex> we observe a
sufficient number of individual facts, and, on the ground of
analogy, extend what is true of them to others of the same class,
thus arriving at <xex>general</xex> principles or laws. This is
the kind of reasoning in physical science. In
<xex>deduction</xex> we begin with a <xex>general</xex> truth,
which is already proven or provisionally assumed, and seek to
connect it with some particular case by means of a middle term,
or class of objects, known to be equally connected with both.
Thus, we bring down the general into the particular, affirming of
the latter the distinctive qualities of the former. This is the
syllogistic method. By <xex>induction</xex> Franklin established
the identity of lightning and electricity; by
<xex>deduction</xex> he inferred that dwellings might be
protected by lightning rods.</usage>

<hw>In*duc"tion*al</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>a.</pos>
<def>Pertaining to, or proceeding by, induction; inductive.</def>

<hw>In*duct"ive</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>a.</pos> <ety>[LL.
<ets>inductivus</ets>: cf. F. <ets>inductif</ets>. See
<er>Induce</er>.]</ety>

<sn>1.</sn> <def>Leading or drawing; persuasive; tempting; --
usually followed by <xex>to</xex>.</def>

<q>A brutish vice,
<qex>Inductive</qex> mainly to the sin of Eve.</q>
<qau>Milton.</qau>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>Tending to induce or cause.</def>
<mark>[R.]</mark>

<q>They may be . . . <qex>inductive</qex> of credibility.</q>
<qau>Sir M. Hale.</qau>

<sn>3.</sn> <def>Leading to inferences; proceeding by, derived
from, or using, induction; <as>as, <ex>inductive</ex>
reasoning</as>.</def>

<sn>4.</sn> <fld>(Physics)</fld> <sd>(a)</sd> <def>Operating by
induction; <as>as, an <ex>inductive</ex> electrical
machine</as>.</def> <sd>(b)</sd> <def>Facilitating induction;
susceptible of being acted upon by induction; as certain
substances have a great <xex>inductive</xex> capacity.</def>

<cs><col>Inductive embarrassment</col> <fld>(Physics)</fld>,
<cd>the retardation in signaling on an electric wire, produced by
lateral induction.</cd> -- <mcol><col>Inductive</col>
<col>philosophy <or/ method</col></mcol>. <cd>See
<cref>Philosophical induction</cref>, under
<er>Induction</er>.</cd> -- <col>Inductive sciences</col>,
<cd>those sciences which admit of, and employ, the inductive
method, as astronomy, botany, chemistry, etc.</cd></cs>

<hw>In*duct"ive*ly</hw>, <pos>adv.</pos> <def>By induction or
inference.</def>

<hw>In`duc*tom"e*ter</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos>
<ety>[<ets>Induct</ets>ion + -<ets>meter</ets>.]</ety>
<fld>(Elec.)</fld> <def>An instrument for measuring or
ascertaining the degree or rate of electrical induction.</def>

<hw>In*duct"or</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[L., one who
stirs up or rouses. See <er>Induce</er>.]</ety>

<sn>1.</sn> <def>The person who inducts another into an office or
benefice.</def>

<sn>2.</sn> <fld>(Elec.)</fld> <def>That portion of an electrical
apparatus, in which is the inducing charge or current.</def>

<hw>In`duc*to"ri*um</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos>; <plu>pl. E.
<plw>Inductoriums</plw> <pr>(#)</pr>, L. <plw>Inductoria</plw>
<pr>(#)</pr></plu>. <ety>[NL., fr. E.
<ets>induct</ets>ion.]</ety> <fld>(Elec.)</fld> <def>An induction
coil.</def>

<mhw>{ <hw>In*duc"tric</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <hw>In*duc"tric*al</hw>
<pr>(?)</pr>, }</mhw> <pos>a.</pos> <fld>(Elec.)</fld>
<def>Acting by, or in a state of, induction; relating to

<hw>In*due"</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>v. t.</pos>
<wordforms>[<pos>imp. & p. p.</pos> <er>Indued</er> <pr>(?)</pr>;
<pos>p. pr. & vb. n.</pos> <er>Induing</er>.]</wordforms>
<altsp>[Written also <asp>endue</asp>.]</altsp> <ety>[L.
<ets>induere</ets> to put on, clothe, fr. OL. <ets>indu</ets>
(fr. <ets>in-</ets> in) + a root seen also in L.
<ets>exuere</ets> to put off, divest, <ets>exuviae</ets> the skin
of an animal, slough, <ets>induviae</ets> clothes. Cf.
<er>Endue</er> to invest.]</ety>

<sn>1.</sn> <def>To put on, as clothes; to draw on.</def>

<q>The baron had <qex>indued</qex> a pair of jack boots.</q>
<qau>Sir W. Scott.</qau>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>To clothe; to invest; hence, to endow; to
furnish; to supply with moral or mental qualities.</def>

<q><qex>Indu'd</qex> with robes of various hue she flies.</q>
<qau>Dryden.</qau>

<q><qex>Indued</qex> with intellectual sense and souls.</q>
<qau>Shak.</qau>

<hw>In*due"ment</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[From
<er>Indue</er>; cf. <er>Indument</er>, <er>Enduement</er>.]</ety>
<def>The act of induing, or state of being indued; investment;
endowment.</def>

<au>W. Montagu.</au>

<hw>In*dulge"</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>v. t.</pos>
<wordforms>[<pos>imp. & p. p.</pos> <er>Indulged</er>
<pr>(?)</pr>; <pos>p. pr. & vb. n.</pos> <er>Indulging</er>
<pr>(?)</pr>.]</wordforms> <ety>[L. <ets>indulgere</ets> to be
kind or tender to one; cf. OIr. <ets>dilgud</ets>, equiv. to L.
<ets>remissio</ets>, OIr. <ets>dligeth</ets>, equiv. to L.
<ets>lex</ets>, Goth. <ets>dulgs</ets> debt.]</ety>

<sn>1.</sn> <def>To be complacent toward; to give way to; not to
oppose or restrain; <sd>(a)</sd> when said of a habit, desire,
etc.: to give free course to; to give one's self up to; <as>as,
to <ex>indulge</ex> sloth, pride, selfishness, or inclinations;
<sd>(b)</sd> when said of a person: to yield to the desire of; to
gratify by compliance; to humor; to withhold restraint from;
<as>as, to <ex>indulge</ex> children in their caprices or
willfulness</as>; to <ex>indulge</ex> one's self with a rest or
in pleasure.</as></def>

<q>Hope in another life implies that we <qex>indulge</qex>
ourselves in the gratifications of this very sparingly.</q>
<qau>Atterbury.</qau>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>To grant as by favor; to bestow in concession,
or in compliance with a wish or request.</def>

<q>Persuading us that something must be <qex>indulged</qex> to
public manners.</q>
<qau>Jer. Taylor.</qau>

<q>Yet, yet a moment, one dim ray of light
<qex>Indulge</qex>, dread Chaos, and eternal Night!</q>
<qau>Pope.</qau>

<note><hand/ It is remarked by Johnson, that if the matter of
indulgence is a single thing, it has <xex>with</xex> before it;
if it is a habit, it has <xex>in</xex>; as, he indulged himself
<xex>with</xex> a glass of wine or a new book; he indulges
himself <xex>in</xex> idleness or intemperance. See
<er>Gratify</er>.</note>

<hw>In*dulge"</hw>, <pos>v. i.</pos> <def>To indulge one's self;
to gratify one's tastes or desires; esp., to give one's self up
(to); to practice a forbidden or questionable act without
restraint; -- followed by <xex>in</xex>, but formerly, also, by
<xex>to</xex>.</def> \'bdWilling to <xex>indulge</xex> in easy
vices.\'b8

<au>Johnson.</au>

<hw>In*dulge"ment</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos>
<def>Indulgence.</def> <mark>[R.]</mark>

<au>Wood.</au>

<hw>In*dul"gence</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[L.
<ets>indulgentia</ets>: cf. F. <ets>indulgence</ets>.]</ety>

<sn>1.</sn> <def>The act of indulging or humoring; the quality of
being indulgent; forbearance of restrain or control.</def>

<q>If I were a judge, that word <qex>indulgence</qex> should
never issue from my lips.</q>
<qau>Tooke.</qau>

<q>They err, that through <qex>indulgence</qex> to others, or
fondness to any sin in themselves, substitute for repentance
anything less.</q>
<qau>Hammond.</qau>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>An indulgent act; favor granted;
gratification.</def>

<q>If all these gracious <qex>indulgences</qex> are without any
effect on us, we must perish in our own folly.</q>
<qau>Rogers.</qau>

<sn>3.</sn> <fld>(R. C. Ch.)</fld> <def>Remission of the temporal
punishment due to sins, after the guilt of sin has been remitted
by sincere repentance; absolution from the censures and public
penances of the church. It is a payment of the debt of justice to
God by the application of the merits of Christ and his saints to
the contrite soul through the church. It is therefore believed to
diminish or destroy for sins the punishment of purgatory.</def>

<hw>In*dul"gence</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>v. t.</pos> <def>To
grant an indulgence to.</def>

<hw>In*dul"gen*cy</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos>
<def>Indulgence.</def>

<au>Dryden.</au>

<hw>In*dul"gent</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>a.</pos> <ety>[L.
<ets>indulgens</ets>, <ets>-entis</ets>, p. pr. of
<ets>indulgere</ets>: cf. F. <ets>indulgent</ets>. See
<er>Indulge</er>.]</ety> <def>Prone to indulge; yielding to the
wishes, humor, or appetites of those under one's care; compliant;
not opposing or restraining; tolerant; mild; favorable; not
severe; <as>as, an <ex>indulgent</ex> parent</as>.</def>

<au>Shak.</au>

<q>The <qex>indulgent</qex> censure of posterity.</q>
<qau>Waller.</qau>

<q>The feeble old, <qex>indulgent</qex> of their ease.</q>
<qau>Dryden.</qau>

<hw>In`dul*gen"tial</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>a.</pos>
<def>Relating to the indulgences of the Roman Catholic
Church.</def>

<au>Brevint.</au>

<hw>In*dul"gent*ly</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>adv.</pos> <def>In an
indulgent manner; mildly; favorably.</def>

<au>Dryden.</au>

<hw>In*dul"ger</hw>, <pos>n.</pos> <def>One who indulges.</def>

<au>W. Montagu.</au>

<hw>In*dul"gi*ate</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>v. t.</pos> <def>To
indulge.</def> <mark>[R.]</mark>

<au>Sandys.</au>

<hw>In"du*line</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[Perh. fr.
<ets>ind</ets>igo.]</ety> <fld>(Chem.)</fld> <sd>(a)</sd>
<def>Any one of a large series of aniline dyes, colored blue or
violet, and represented by aniline violet.</def> <sd>(b)</sd>
<def>A dark green amorphous dyestuff, produced by the oxidation
of aniline in the presence of copper or vanadium salts; -- called
also <altname>aniline black</altname>.</def>

<mhw>{ <hw>In*dult"</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <hw>In*dul"to</hw>
<pr>(?)</pr>, }</mhw> <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[L. <ets>indultum</ets>
indulgence, favor, fr. <ets>indultus</ets>, p. p. of
<ets>indulgere</ets>: cf. It. <ets>indulto</ets>, F.
<ets>indult</ets>. See <er>Indulge</er>.]</ety>

<sn>1.</sn> <def>A privilege or exemption; an indulgence; a
dispensation granted by the pope.</def>

<sn>2.</sn> <fld>(Spain)</fld> <def>A duty levied on all
importations.</def>

<hw>In"du*ment</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[L.
<ets>indumentum</ets> a covering. See <er>Indue</er>, and cf.
<er>Induement</er>.]</ety> <fld>(Zo\'94l.)</fld> <def>Plumage;
feathers.</def>

<hw>In*du"pli*cate</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>a.</pos>
<fld>(Bot.)</fld> <sd>(a)</sd> <def>Having the edges bent
abruptly toward the axis; -- said of the parts of the calyx or
corolla in \'91stivation.</def> <sd>(b)</sd> <def>Having the
edges rolled inward and then arranged about the axis without
overlapping; -- said of leaves in vernation.</def>

<hw>In*du"pli*ca*tive</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>a.</pos>
<fld>(Bot.)</fld> <sd>(a)</sd> <def>Having induplicate sepals or
petals in \'91stivation.</def> <sd>(b)</sd> <def>Having
induplicate leaves in vernation.</def>

<hw>In*dur"ance</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos>
<mark>[Obs.]</mark> <def>See <er>Endurance</er>.</def>

<hw>In"du*rate</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>a.</pos> <ety>[L.
<ets>induratus</ets>, p. p. of <ets>indurare</ets> to harden. See
<er>Endure</er>.]</ety>

<sn>1.</sn> <def>Hardened; not soft; indurated.</def>

<au>Tyndale.</au>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>Without sensibility; unfeeling; obdurate.</def>

<hw>In"du*rate</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>v. t.</pos>
<wordforms>[<pos>imp. & p. p.</pos> <er>Indurated</er>
<pr>(?)</pr>; <pos>p. pr. & vb. n.</pos> <er>Indurating</er>
<pr>(?)</pr>.]</wordforms>

<sn>1.</sn> <def>To make hard; <as>as, extreme heat
<ex>indurates</ex> clay; some fossils are <ex>indurated</ex> by
exposure to the air.</as></def>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>To make unfeeling; to deprive of sensibility; to
render obdurate.</def>

<hw>In"du*rate</hw>, <pos>v. i.</pos> <def>To grow hard; to
harden, or become hard; <as>as, clay <ex>indurates</ex> by
drying, and by heat</as>.</def>

<hw>In"du*ra`ted</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>a.</pos> <def>Hardened;
<as>as, <ex>indurated</ex> clay; an <ex>indurated</ex>
heart.</as></def>

<au>Goldsmith.</au>

<hw>In`du*ra"tion</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[Cf. F.
<ets>induration</ets>, L. <ets>induratio</ets> hardness of
heart.]</ety>

<sn>1.</sn> <def>The act of hardening, or the process of growing
hard.</def>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>State of being indurated, or of having become
hard.</def>

<sn>3.</sn> <def>Hardness of character, manner, sensibility,
etc.; obduracy; stiffness; want of pliancy or feeling.</def>

<q>A certain <qex>induration</qex> of character had arisen from
long habits of business.</q>
<qau>Coleridge.</qau>

<hw>In*du"sial</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>a.</pos> <ety>[See
<er>Indusium</er>.]</ety> <def>Of, pertaining to, or containing,
the petrified cases of the larv\'91 of certain insects.</def>

<cs><col>Indusial limestone</col> <fld>(Geol.)</fld>, <cd>a
fresh-water limestone, largely composed of the agglomerated cases
of caddice worms, or larv\'91 of caddice flies
(<spn>Phryganea</spn>). It is found in Miocene strata of
Auvergne, France, and some other localities.</cd></cs>

<mhw>{ <hw>In*du"si*ate</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>,
<hw>In*du"si*a`ted</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, }</mhw> <pos>a.</pos>
<fld>(Bot.)</fld> <def>Furnished with an indusium.</def>

<hw>\'d8In*du"si*um</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos>; <plu>pl.
<plw>Indu<?/<?/<?/</plw> <pr>(#)</pr></plu>. <ety>[L., an under
garment, fr. <ets>induere</ets> to put on: cf. F.
<ets>indusie</ets> the covering of the seed spots of
ferns.]</ety> <fld>(Bot.)</fld> <sd>(a)</sd> <def>A collection of
hairs united so as to form a sort of cup, and inclosing the
stigma of a flower.</def> <sd>(b)</sd> <def>The immediate
covering of the fruit dots or sori in many ferns, usually a very
thin scale attached by the middle or side to a veinlet.</def>
<sd>(c)</sd> <def>A peculiar covering found in certain
fungi.</def>

<hw>In*dus"tri*al</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>a.</pos> <ety>[Cf. F.
<ets>industriel</ets>, LL. <ets>industrialis</ets>. See
<er>Industry</er>.]</ety> <def>Consisting in industry; pertaining
to industry, or the arts and products of industry; concerning
those employed in labor, especially in manual labor, and their
wages, duties, and rights.</def>

<q>The great ideas of <qex>industrial</qex> development and
economic social amelioration.</q>
<qau>M. Arnold.</qau>

<-- p. 756 -->

<cs><col>Industrial exhibition</col>, <cd>a public exhibition of
the various industrial products of a country, or of various
countries.</cd> -- <col>Industrial school</col>, <cd>a school for
teaching one or more branches of industry; also, a school for
educating neglected children, and training them to habits of
industry.</cd></cs>

<hw>In*dus"tri*al*ism</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos>
<sn>1.</sn> <def>Devotion to industrial pursuits; labor;
industry.</def>

<au>J. S. Mill.</au>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>The principles or policy applicable to
industrial pursuits or organized labor.</def>

<q><qex>Industrialism</qex> must not confounded with
industriousness.</q>
<qau>H. Spencer.</qau>

<hw>In*dus"tri*al*ly</hw>, <pos>adv.</pos> <def>With reference to
industry.</def>

<hw>In*dus"tri*ous</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>a.</pos> <ety>[L.
<ets>industrius</ets>, <ets>industriosus</ets>: cf. F.
<ets>industrieux</ets>. See <er>Industry</er>.]</ety>

<sn>1.</sn> <def>Given to industry; characterized by diligence;
constantly, regularly, or habitually occupied; busy; assiduous;
not slothful or idle; -- commonly implying devotion to lawful and
useful labor.</def>

<q>Frugal and <qex>industrious</qex> men are commonly friendly to
the established government.</q>
<qau>Sir W. Temple.</qau>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>Steadily and perseveringly active in a
particular pursuit or aim; <as>as, he was negligent in business,
but <ex>industrious</ex> in pleasure; an <ex>industrious</ex>
mischief maker.</as></def>

<q><qex>Industrious</qex> to seek out the truth of all
things.</q>
<qau>Spenser.</qau>

-- <wordforms><wf>In*dus"tri*ous*ly</wf>, <pos>adv.</pos> --
<wf>In*dus"tri*ous*ness</wf>, <pos>n.</pos></wordforms>

<hw>In"dus*try</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos>; <plu>pl.
<plw>Industries</plw> <pr>(#)</pr></plu>. <ety>[L.
<ets>industria</ets>, cf. <ets>industrius</ets> diligent; of
uncertain origin: cf. F. <ets>industrie</ets>.]</ety>

<sn>1.</sn> <def>Habitual diligence in any employment or pursuit,
either bodily or mental; steady attention to business; assiduity;
-- opposed to <xex>sloth</xex> and <xex>idleness</xex>; <as>as,
<ex>industry</ex> pays debts, while idleness or despair will
increase them</as>.</def>

<q>We are more industrious than our forefathers, because in the
present times the funds destined for the maintenance of
<qex>industry</qex> are much greater in proportion to those which
are likely to be employed in the maintenance of idleness, than
they were two or three centuries ago.</q>
<qau>A. Smith.</qau>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>Any department or branch of art, occupation, or
business; especially, one which employs much labor and capital
and is a distinct branch of trade; <as>as, the sugar
<ex>industry</ex>; the iron <ex>industry</ex>; the cotton
<ex>industry</ex>.</as></def>

<sn>3.</sn> <fld>(Polit. Econ.)</fld> <def>Human exertion of any
kind employed for the creation of value, and regarded by some as
a species of capital or wealth; labor.</def>

<syn>Syn. -- Diligence; assiduity; perseverance; activity;
laboriousness; attention. See <er>Diligence</er>.</syn>

to seeds which have the usual integumentary covering.</def>

<hw>In"dwell`</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>v. t. & i.</pos>

<hw>-ine</hw> <pr>(?; 104)</pr>. <sn>1.</sn> <fld>(Chem.)</fld>
<def>A suffix, indicating that those substances of whose names it
is a part are <xex>basic</xex>, and <xex>alkaloidal</xex> in
their nature.</def>

<note><hand/ All organic bases, and basic substances (especially
nitrogenous substances), are systematically written with the
termination <xex>-ine</xex>; as, quin<xex>ine</xex>,
morph<xex>ine</xex>, guanid<xex>ine</xex>, etc. All indifferent
and neutral substances, as proteids, glycerides, glucosides,
etc., should commonly be spelled with <xex>-in</xex>; as,
gelat<xex>in</xex>, amygdal<xex>in</xex>, etc. This rue has no
application to those numerous commercial or popular names with
the termination <xex>-ine</xex>; as, gasol<xex>ine</xex>,
vasel<xex>ine</xex>, etc.</note>

<sn>2.</sn> <fld>(Organ. Chem.)</fld> <def>A suffix, used to
indicate <xex>hydrocarbons of the second degree of
unsaturation</xex>; i. e., members of the acetyline series;
<as>as, <ex>hexine</ex>, <ex>heptine</ex>, etc.</as></def>
<-- now "-yne" -->

<hw>In*e"bri*ate</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>v. t.</pos>
<wordforms>[<pos>imp. & p. p.</pos> <er>Inebriated</er>
<pr>(?)</pr>; <pos>p. pr. & vb. n.</pos> <er>Inebriating</er>
<pr>(?)</pr>.]</wordforms> <ety>[L. <ets>inebriatus</ets>, p. p.
of <ets>inebriare</ets>; pref. <ets>in-</ets> in +
<ets>ebriare</ets> to make drunk, fr. <ets>ebrius</ets> drunk. 
See <er>Ebriety</er>.]</ety>

<sn>1.</sn> <def>To make drunk; to intoxicate.</def>

<q>The cups
That cheer but not <qex>inebriate</qex>.</q>
<qau>Cowper.</qau>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>Fig.: To disorder the senses of; to exhilarate
or elate as if by spirituous drink; to deprive of sense and
judgment; also, to stupefy.</def>

<q>The <qex>inebriating</qex> effect of popular applause.</q>
<qau>Macaulay.</qau>

<hw>In*e"bri*ate</hw>, <pos>v. i.</pos> <def>To become
drunk.</def> <mark>[Obs.]</mark>

<au>Bacon.</au>

<hw>In*e"bri*ate</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>a.</pos> <ety>[L.
<ets>inebriatus</ets>, p. p.]</ety> <def>Intoxicated; drunk;
habitually given to drink; stupefied.</def>

<q>Thus spake Peter, as a man <qex>inebriate</qex> and made
drunken with the sweetness of this vision, not knowing what he
said.</q>
<qau>Udall.</qau>

<hw>In*e"bri*ate</hw>, <pos>n.</pos> <def>One who is drunk or
intoxicated; esp., an habitual drunkard; <as>as, an asylum fro
<ex>inebriates</ex></as>.</def>

<q>Some <qex>inebriates</qex> have their paroxysms of
inebriety.</q>
<qau>E. Darwin.</qau>

<hw>In*e`bri*a"tion</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[L.
<ets>inebriatio</ets>.]</ety> <def>The condition of being
inebriated; intoxication; figuratively, deprivation of sense and
judgment by anything that exhilarates, as success.</def>

<au>Sir T. Browne.</au>

<q>Preserve him from the <qex>inebriation</qex> of
prosperity.</q>
<qau>Macaulay.</qau>

<syn>Syn. -- See <er>Drunkenness</er>.</syn>

<def>Incapable of being expresses in words; unspeakable;
unutterable; indescribable; <as>as, the <ex>ineffable</ex> joys
of heaven</as>.</def>

<q>Contentment with our lot . . . will diffuse
<qex>ineffable</qex> conten<?/ment over the soul.</q>
<qau>Beattie.</qau>

<hw>In`ef*fec"tu*al</hw> <pr>(?; 135)</pr>, <pos>a.</pos>
<def>Not producing the proper effect; without effect;
inefficient; weak; useless; futile; unavailing; <as>as, an
<ex>ineffectual</ex> attempt; an <ex>ineffectual</ex>
expedient.</as></def>

<au>Pope.</au>

<q>The peony root has been much commended, . . . and yet has been
by many found <qex>ineffectual</qex>.</q>
<qau>Boyle.</qau>

<syn>Syn. -- Inefficient; useless; inefficacious; vain;
fruitless; unavailing; futile. See <er>Uselesss</er>,
<er>Inefficacious</er>.</syn>

<hw>In*ef`fi*ca"cious</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>a.</pos>
<ety>[Pref. <ets>in-</ets> not +  <ets>efficacious</ets>: cf. F.
<ets>inefficace</ets>, L. <ets>inefficax</ets>.]</ety> <def>Not
efficacious; not having power to produce the effect desired;
inadequate; incompetent; inefficient; impotent.</def>

<au>Boyle.</au>

<q>The authority of Parliament must become
<qex>inefficacious</qex> . . . to restrain the growth of
disorders.</q>
<qau>Burke.</qau>

<note><hand/ <xex>Ineffectual</xex>, says Johnson, rather denotes
an actual failure, and <xex>inefficacious</xex> and habitual
impotence to any effect. But the distinction is not always
observed, nor can it be; for we can not always know whether means
are <xex>inefficacious</xex> till experiment has proved them
<xex>ineffectual</xex>. <xex>Inefficacious</xex> is therefore
sometimes synonymous with <xex>ineffectual</xex>.</note>

<hw>In*ef`fi*ca"cious*ly</hw>, <pos>adv.</pos> <def>without
efficacy or effect.</def>

<hw>In*ef`fi*ca"cious*ness</hw>, <pos>n.</pos> <def>Want of
effect, or of power to produce the effect; inefficacy.</def>

<hw>In*ef"fi*ca*cy</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[L.
<ets>inefficacia</ets>. See <er>In-</er> not, and
<er>Efficacy</er>.]</ety> <def>Want of power to produce the
desired or proper effect; inefficiency; ineffectualness;
futility; uselessness; fruitlessness; <as>as, the
<ex>inefficacy</ex> of medicines or means</as>.</def>

<q>The seeming <qex>inefficacy</qex> of censures.</q>
<qau>Bp. Hall.</qau>

<q>The <qex>inefficacy</qex> was soon proved, like that of many
similar medicines.</q>
<qau>James Gregory.</qau>

<hw>In`en*fi"cien*cy</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <def>The
quality of being inefficient; want of power or energy sufficient;
want of power or energy sufficient for the desired effect;
inefficacy; incapacity; <as>as, he was discharged from his
position for <ex>inefficiency</ex></as>.</def>

<hw>In`en*fi"cient</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>a.</pos> <sn>1.</sn>
<def>Not efficient; not producing the effect intended or desired;
inefficacious; <as>as, <ex>inefficient</ex> means or
measures</as>.</def>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>Incapable of, or indisposed to, effective
action; habitually slack or remiss; effecting little or nothing;
<as>as, <ex>inefficient</ex> workmen; an <ex>inefficient</ex>
administrator.</as></def>

<hw>In`en*fi"cient*ly</hw>, <pos>adv.</pos> <def>In an
inefficient manner.</def>

<ets>inelaboratus</ets>. See <er>In-</er> not, and
<er>Elaborate</er>.]</ety> <def>Not elaborate; not wrought with

<mhw>{ <hw>In*el"e*gance</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>,
<hw>In*el"e*gan*cy</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, }</mhw> <pos>n.</pos>;
<plu>pl. <plw>Inelegances</plw> <pr>(#)</pr>,
<plw>Inelegancies</plw> <pr>(#)</pr></plu>. <ety>[L.
<ets>inelegantia</ets>: cf. F.
<ets>in\'82l\'82gance</ets>.]</ety>

<sn>1.</sn> <def>The quality of being inelegant; want of elegance
or grace; want of refinement, beauty, or polish in language,
composition, or manners.</def>

<q>The notorious <qex>inelegance</qex> of her figure.</q>
<qau>T. Hook.</qau>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>Anything inelegant; <as>as, <ex>inelegance</ex>
of style in literary composition</as>.</def>

<hw>In*el"e*gant</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>a.</pos> <ety>[L.
<ets>inelegans</ets>: cf. F. <ets>in\'82l\'82gant</ets>. See
<er>In-</er> not, and <er>Elegant</er>.]</ety> <def>Not elegant;
deficient in beauty, polish, refinement, grave, or ornament;
wanting in anything which correct taste requires.</def>

<q>What order so contrived as not to mix
Tastes, not well joined, <qex>inelegant</qex>.</q>
<qau>Milton.</qau>

<q>It renders style often obscure, always embarrassed and
<qex>inelegant</qex>.</q>
<qau>Blair.</qau>

<hw>In*el"e*gant*ly</hw>, <pos>adv.</pos> <def>In an inelegant
manner.</def>

<hw>In*el`i*gi*bil"i*ty</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos>
<ety>[Cf. F. <ets>in\'82ligibilit\'82</ets>.]</ety> <def>The
state or quality of being ineligible.</def>

<hw>In*el"i*gi*ble</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>a.</pos> <ety>[Pref.
<ets>in-</ets> not + <ets>eligible</ets>: cf. F.
<ets>in\'82ligible</ets>.]</ety> <def>Not eligible; not qualified
to be chos<?/<?/ for an office; not worthy to be chosen or
preffered; not expedient or desirable.</def>

<au>Burke.</au>

<hw>In*el"li*gi*bly</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>adv.</pos> <def>In an
ineligible manner.</def>

<hw>In*e"lo*quent</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>a.</pos> <ety>[L.
<ets>ineloquens</ets>: cf. F. <ets>in\'82loquent</ets>. See
<er>In-</er> not, and <er>Eloquent</er>.]</ety> <def>Not
eloquent; not fluent, graceful, or pathetic; not persuasive;
<as>as, <ex>ineloquent</ex> language</as>.</def>

<q>Nor are thy lips ungraceful, sire of men,
Nor tongue <qex>ineloquent</qex>.</q>
<qau>Milton.</qau>

<hw>In*e"lo*quent*ly</hw>, <pos>adv.</pos> <def>Without
eloquence.</def>

<hw>In`e*luc"ta*ble</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>a.</pos> <ety>[L.
<ets>ineluctabilis</ets>; pref. <ets>in-</ets> not +
<ets>eluctabilis</ets> to be surmounted, fr. <ets>eluctari</ets>
to struggle out of, to surmount: cf. F.
<ets>in\'82luctable</ets>. See <er>Eluctate</er>.]</ety> <def>Not
to be overcome by struggling; irresistible; inevitable.</def>

<au>Bp. Pearson.</au>

<q>The <qex>ineluctable</qex> conditions of matter.</q>
<qau>Hamerton.</qau>

<hw>In`e*lud"i*ble</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>a.</pos>
<def>Incapable of being eluded or evaded; unvoidable.</def>

<q>Most pressing reasons and <qex>ineludible</qex>
demonstrations.</q>
<qau>Glanvill.</qau>

<hw>In*em"bry*o*nate</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>a.</pos>
<fld>(Biol.)</fld> <def>Not embryonate.</def>

<hw>In`er*nar"ra*ble</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>a.</pos> <ety>[L.
<ets>inenarrabilis</ets>; pref. <ets>in-</ets> not +
<ets>enarrabilis</ets> that may be related; fr.
<ets>enarrare</ets> to relate: cf. F. <ets>in\'82narrable</ets>.
See <er>Enarration</er>.]</ety> <def>Incapable of being narrated;
indescribable; ineffable.</def> <mark>[Obs.]</mark>
\'bd<xex>Inenarrable</xex> goodness.\'b8

<au>Bp. Fisher.</au>

<hw>In*ept"</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>a.</pos> <ety>[L.
<ets>ineptus</ets>; prefix. <ets>in-</ets> not + <ets>aptus</ets>
apt, fit: cf. F. <ets>inepte</ets>. Cf. <er>Inapt</er>.]</ety>

<sn>1.</sn> <def>Not apt or fit; unfit; unsuitable; improper;
unbecoming.</def>

<q>The Aristotelian philosophy is <qex>inept</qex> for new
discoveries.</q>
<qau>Glanvill.</qau>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>Silly; useless; nonsensical; absurd;
foolish.</def>

<q>To view attention as a special act of intelligence, and to
distinguish it from consciousness, is utterly
<qex>inept</qex>.</q>
<qau>Sir W. Hamilton.</qau>

<hw>In*ept"i*tude</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[L.
<ets>ineptitudo</ets>.]</ety>

<sn>1.</sn> <def>The quality of being inept; unfitness;
inaptitude; unsuitableness.</def>

<q>That <qex>ineptitude</qex> for society, which is frequently
the fault of us scholars.</q>
<qau>Tatler.</qau>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>Absurdity; nonsense; foolishness.</def>

<hw>In*ept"ly</hw>, <pos>adv.</pos> <def>Unfitly; unsuitably;
awkwardly.</def>

<q>None of them are made foolishly or <qex>ineptly</qex>.</q>
<qau>Dr. H. More.</qau>

<hw>In*ept"ness</hw>, <pos>n.</pos> <def>Unfitness;
ineptitude.</def>

<q>The feebleness and miserable <qex>ineptness</qex> of
infancy.</q>
<qau>Dr. H. More.</qau>

<hw>In*e"qua*ble</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>a.</pos>
<def>Unequable.</def> <mark>[R.]</mark>

<au>Bailey.</au>

<hw>In*e"qual</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>a.</pos> <ety>[L.
<ets>inaequalis</ets>. See <er>In-</er> not, and
<er>Equal</er>.]</ety> <def>Unequal; uneven; various.</def>
<mark>[Obs.]</mark>

<au>Chaucer.</au>

<hw>In`e*qual"i*ty</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos>; <plu>pl.
<plw>Inequalities</plw> <pr>(#)</pr></plu>. <ety>[L.
<ets>inaequalitas</ets>.]</ety>

<sn>1.</sn> <def>The quality of being unequal; difference, or
want of equality, in any respect; lack of uniformity;
disproportion; unevenness; disparity; diversity; <as>as, an
<ex>inequality</ex> in size, stature, numbers, power, distances,
motions, rank, property, etc.</as></def>

<q>There is so great an <qex>inequality</qex> in the length of
our legs and arms as makes it impossible for us to walk on all
four.</q>
<qau>Ray.</qau>

<q>Notwithstanding which <qex>inequality</qex> of number, it was
resolved in a council of war to fight the Dutch fleet.</q>
<qau>Ludlow.</qau>

<q>Sympathy is rarely strong where there is a great
<qex>inequality</qex> of condition.</q>
<qau>Macaulay.</qau>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>Unevenness; want of levelness; the alternate
rising and falling of a surface; <as>as, the
<ex>inequalities</ex> of the surface of the earth, or of a marble
slab, etc.</as></def>

<q>The country is cut into so many hills and
<qex>inequalities</qex> as renders it defensible.</q>
<qau>Addison.</qau>

<sn>3.</sn> <def>Variableness; changeableness; inconstancy; lack
of smoothness or equability; deviation; unsteadiness, as of the
weather, feelings, etc.</def>

<q><qex>Inequality</qex> of air is ever an enemy to health.</q>
<qau>Bacon.</qau>

<sn>4.</sn> <def>Disproportion to any office or purpose;
inadequacy; competency; <as>as, the <ex>inequality</ex> of
terrestrial things to the wants of a rational soul</as>.</def>

<au>South.</au>

<sn>5.</sn> <fld>(Alg.)</fld> <def>An expression consisting of
two unequal quantities, with the sign of inequality (<gt/ or
<lt/) between them; <as>as, the <ex>inequality</ex> 2 <lt/ 3, or
4 <gt/ 1</as>.</def>

<sn>6.</sn> <fld>(Astron.)</fld> <def>An irregularity, or a
deviation, in the motion of a planet or satellite from its
uniform mean motion; the amount of such deviation.</def>

<fld>(Math.)</fld> <def>An inequality.</def>

<hw>In*e`qui*dis"tant</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>a.</pos> <def>Not

<hw>In*e`qui*lat"er*al</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>a.</pos>

<sn>2.</sn> <fld>(Zo\'94l.)</fld> <def>Having the two ends

shells.</def>

from error.</def>

<q>The absolute <qex>inerrancy</qex> odf the Bible.</q>
<qau>The Century.</qau>

erratic or wandering; fixed; settled; established.</def>

<hw>In*ert"</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>a.</pos> <ety>[L.
<ets>iners</ets>, <ets>inertis</ets>, unskilled, idle; pref.
<ets>in-</ets> + <ets>ars</ets> art: cf. F. <ets>inerte</ets>.
See <er>Art</er>.]</ety>

<sn>1.</sn> <def>Destitute of the power of moving itself, or of
active resistance to motion; <as>as, matter is
<ex>inert</ex></as>.</def>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>Indisposed to move or act; very slow to act;
sluggish; dull; inactive; indolent; lifeless.</def>

<q>The <qex>inert</qex> and desponding party of the court.</q>
<qau>Macaulay.</qau>

<q>It present becomes extravagant, then imbecile, and at length
utterly <qex>inert</qex>.</q>
<qau>I. Taylor.</qau>

<sn>3.</sn> <def>Not having or manifesting active properties; not
affecting other substances when brought in contact with them;
powerless for an expected or desired effect.</dsyn

<syn>Syn. -- Inactive; dull; passive; indolent; sluggish;
slothful; lazy; lifeless; irresolute; stupid; senseless;
insensible. -- <er>Inert</er>, <er>Inactive</er>,
<er>Sluggish</er>. A man may be <xex>inactive</xex> from mere
want of stimulus to effort; but one who is <xex>inert</xex> has
something in his constitution or his habits which operates like a
weight holding him back from exertion. <xex>Sluggish</xex> is
still stronger, implying some defect of temperament which
directly impedes action. <xex>Inert</xex> and <xex>inactive</xex>
are negative, <xex>sluggish</xex> is positive.</def>

<q>Even the favored isles . . . 
Can boast but little virtue; and, <qex>inert</qex>
Through plenty, lose in morals what they gain
In manners -- victims of luxurious ease.</q>
<qau>Cowper.</qau>

<q>Doomed to lose four months in <qex>inactive</qex>
obscurity.</q>
<qau>Johnson.</qau>

<q><qex>Sluggish</qex> Idleness, the nurse of sin,
Upon a slothful ass he chose to ride.</q>
<qau>Spenser.</qau>

<hw>In*er"ti*a</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[L.,
idleness, fr. <ets>iners</ets> idle. See <er>Inert</er>.]</ety>

<sn>1.</sn> <fld>(Physics)</fld> <def>That property of matter by
which it tends when at rest to remain so, and when in motion to
continue in motion, and in the same straight line or direction,
unless acted on by some external force; -- sometimes called
<altname>vis inerti\'91</altname>.</def>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>Inertness; indisposition to motion, exertion, or
action; want of energy; sluggishness.</def>

<q>Men . . . have immense irresolution and
<qex>inertia</qex>.</q>
<qau>Carlyle.</qau>

<sn>3.</sn> <fld>(Med.)</fld> <def>Want of activity;
sluggishness; -- said especially of the uterus, when, in labor,
its contractions have nearly or wholly ceased.</def>

<cs><col>Center of inertia</col>. <fld>(Mech.)</fld> <cd>See
under <er>Center</er>.</cd></cs>

<hw>In*er"tion</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <def>Want of
activity or exertion; inertness; quietude.</def>
<mark>[R.]</mark>

<q>These vicissitudes of exertion and <qex>inertion</qex> of the
arterial system constitute the paroxysms of remittent fever.</q>
<qau>E. Darwin.</qau>

<hw>In*ert"i*tude</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[See
<er>Inert</er>.]</ety> <def>Inertness; inertia.</def>
<mark>[R.]</mark>

<au>Good.</au>

<hw>In*ert"ly</hw>, <pos>adv.</pos> <def>Without activity;
sluggishly.</def>

<au>Pope.</au>

<hw>In*ert"ness</hw>, <pos>n.</pos> <sn>1.</sn> <def>Want of
activity or exertion; habitual indisposition to action or motion;
sluggishness; apathy; insensibility.</def>

<au>Glanvill.</au>

<q>Laziness and <qex>inertness</qex> of mind.</q>

<au>Burke.</au>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>Absence of the power of self-motion;
inertia.</def>

<hw>\'d8In` es"se</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>. <ety>[L.]</ety> <def>In
being; actually existing; -- distinguished from <xex>in

is not, but may be.</def>

<hw>In`es*sen"tial</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>a.</pos> <ety>[Pref.
<ets>in-</ets> not + <ets>essential</ets>: cf. F.
<ets>inessentiel</ets>.]</ety>

<sn>1.</sn> <def>Having no essence or being.</def>

<au>H. Brooke.</au>

<q>The womb of <qex>inessential</qex> Naught.</q>
<qau>Shelley.</qau>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>Not essential; unessential.</def>

<hw>In*es"ti*ma*ble</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>a.</pos> <ety>[L.
<ets>inaestimabilis</ets>: cf. F. <ets>inestimable</ets>. See
<er>In-</er> not, and <er>Estimate</er>.]</ety> <def>Incapable of
being estimated or computed; especially, too valuable or
excellent to be measured or fully appreciated; above all price;
<as>as, <ex>inestimable</ex> rights or privileges</as>.</def>

<q>But above all, for thine <qex>inestimable</qex> love.</q>
<qau>Bk. of Com. Prayer.</qau>

<q>Science is too <qex>inestimable</qex> for expression by a
money standard.</q>
<qau>Lyon Playfair.</qau>

<syn>Syn. -- Incalculable; invaluable; priceless.</syn>

<hw>In*es"ti*ma*bly</hw>, <pos>adv.</pos> <def>In a manner, or to
a degree, above estimation; <as>as, things <ex>inestimably</ex>
excellent</as>.</def>

<hw>In`e*va"si*ble</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>a.</pos>
<def>Incapable of being <?/vaded; inevitable; unavoidable.</def>

<hw>In*ev`i*ta*bil"i*ty</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos>

<hw>In*ev"i*ta*ble</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>a.</pos> <ety>[L.
<ets>inevitabilis</ets>: cf. F. <ets>in\'82vitable</ets>. See
<er>In-</er> not, and <er>Evitable</er>.]</ety>

<sn>1.</sn> <def>Not evitable; incapable of being shunned;
unavoidable; certain.</def> \'bdThe <xex>inevitable</xex>
hour.\'b8

<au>Gray.</au>

<q>It was <qex>inevitable</qex>; it was necessary; it was planted
in the nature of things.</q>
<qau>Burke.</qau>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>Irresistible.</def> \'bd<xex>Inevitable</xex>
charms.\'b8

<au>Dryden.</au>

<hw>In*ev"i*ta*ble*ness</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <def>The
state of being unavoidable; certainty to happen.</def>

<au>Prideaux.</au>

<hw>In*ev"i*ta*bly</hw>, <pos>adv.</pos> <def>Without possibility
of escape or evasion; unavoidably; certainly.</def>

<q><qex>Inevitably</qex> thou shalt die.</q>
<qau>Milton.</qau>

<q>How <qex>inevitably</qex> does immoderate laughter end in a
sigh!</q>
<qau>South.</qau>

<mhw>{ <hw>In`ex*pe"di*ence</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>,
<hw>In`ex*pe"di*en*cy</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, }</mhw> <pos>n.</pos>
<def>The quality or state of being inexpedient; want of fitness;
unsuitableness to the end or object; impropriety; <as>as, the
<ex>inexpedience</ex> of some measures</as>.</def>

<q>It is not the rigor but the <qex>inexpediency</qex> of laws
and acts of authority which makes them tyrannical.</q>
<qau>Paley.</qau>

<hw>In`ex*pe"di*ent</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>a.</pos> <def>Not
expedient; not tending to promote a purpose; not tending to the
end desired; inadvisable; unfit; improper; unsuitable to time and
place; <as>as, what is expedient at one time may be
<ex>inexpedient</ex> at another</as>.</def>

<q>If it was not unlawful, yet it was highly
<qex>inexpedient</qex> to use those ceremonies.</q>
<qau>Bp. Burnet.</qau>

<syn>Syn. -- Unwise; impolitic; imprudent; indiscreet;
unprofitable; inadvisable; disadvantageous.</syn>

<hw>In*eye"</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>v. t.</pos>

<hw>In*fal"li*bil*ist</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <def>One
who accepts or maintains the dogma of papal infallibility.</def>

<hw>In*fal`li*bil"i*ty</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[Cf.
F. <ets>infaillibilit\'82</ets>.]</ety> <def>The quality or state
of being infallible, or exempt from error; inerrability.</def>

<q><qex>Infallibility</qex> is the highest perfection of the
knowing faculty.</q>
<qau>Tillotson.</qau>

<cs><col>Papal infallibility</col> <fld>(R. C. Ch.)</fld>,
<cd>the dogma that the pope can not, when acting in his official
character of supreme pontiff, err in defining a doctrine of
Christian faith or rule of morals, to be held by the church. This
was decreed by the Ecumenical Council at the Vatican, July 18,
1870.</cd></cs>

<hw>In*fal"li*ble</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>a.</pos> <ety>[Pref.
<ets>in-</ets> not + <ets>fallible</ets>: cf. F.
<ets>infallible</ets>.]</ety>

<sn>1.</sn> <def>Not fallible; not capable of erring; entirely
exempt from liability to mistake; unerring; inerrable.</def>

<au>Dryden.</au>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>Not liable to fail, deceive, or disappoint;
indubitable; sure; certain; <as>as, <ex>infallible</ex> evidence;
<ex>infallible</ex> success; an <ex>infallible</ex>
remedy.</as></def>

<q>To whom also he showed himself alive, after his passion, by
many <qex>infallible</qex> proofs.</q>
<qau>Acts i. 3.</qau>

<sn>3.</sn> <fld>(R. C. Ch.)</fld> <def>Incapable of error in
defining doctrines touching faith or morals. See <cref>Papal
infallibility</cref>, under <er>Infallibility</er>.</def>

<hw>In*fal"li*ble*ness</hw>, <pos>n.</pos> <def>The state or
quality of being infallible; infallibility.</def>

<hw>In*fame"</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>v. t.</pos> <ety>[L.
<ets>infamare</ets>, fr. <ets>infamis</ets> infamous: cf. F.
<ets>infamer</ets>, It. <ets>infamare</ets>. See
<er>Infamous</er>.]</ety> <def>To defame; to make infamous.</def>
<mark>[Obs.]</mark>

<au>Milton.</au>

<q>Livia is <qex>infamed</qex> for the poisoning of her
husband.</q>
<qau>Bacon.</qau>

<hw>In"fa*mize</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>v. t.</pos>
<wordforms>[<pos>imp. & p. p.</pos> <er>Infamized</er>
<pr>(?)</pr>; <pos>p. pr. & vb. n.</pos> <er>Infamizing</er>
<pr>(?)</pr>.]</wordforms> <def>To make infamous; to
defame.</def> <mark>[R.]</mark>

<au>Coleridge.</au>

<hw>In"fa*mous</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>a.</pos> <ety>[Pref.
<ets>in-</ets> not + <ets>famous</ets>: cf. L.
<ets>infamis</ets>. See <er>Infamy</er>.]</ety>

<sn>1.</sn> <def>Of very bad report; having a reputation of the
worst kind; held in abhorrence; guilty of something that exposes
to infamy; base; notoriously vile; detestable; <as>as, an
<ex>infamous</ex> traitor; an <ex>infamous</ex>
perjurer.</as></def>

<q>False errant knight, <qex>infamous</qex>, and forsworn.</q>
<qau>Spenser.</qau>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>Causing or producing infamy; deserving
detestation; scandalous to the last degree; <as>as, an
<ex>infamous</ex> act; <ex>infamous</ex> vices; <ex>infamous</ex>
corruption.</as></def>

<au>Macaulay.</au>

<sn>3.</sn> <fld>(Law)</fld> <def>Branded with infamy by
conviction of a crime; <as>as, at common law, an
<ex>infamous</ex> person can not be a witness</as>.</def>

<sn>4.</sn> <def>Having a bad name as being the place where an
odious crime was committed, or as being associated with something
detestable; hence, unlucky; perilous; dangerous.</def>
\'bd<xex>Infamous</xex> woods.\'b8

<au>P. Fletcher.</au>

<q><qex>Infamous</qex> hills, and sandy perilous wilds.</q>
<qau>Milton.</qau>

<q>The piny shade
More <qex>infamous</qex> by cursed Lycaon made.</q>
<qau>Dryden.</qau>

<syn>Syn. -- Detestable; odious; scandalous; disgraceful; base;
vile; shameful; ignominious.</syn>

<hw>In"fa*mous*ly</hw>, <pos>adv.</pos> <def>In an infamous
manner or degree; scandalously; disgracefully; shamefully.</def>

<q>The sealed fountain of royal bounty which had been
<qex>infamously</qex> monopolized and huckstered.</q>
<qau>Burke.</qau>

<hw>In"fa*mous*ness</hw>, <pos>n.</pos> <def>The state or quality
of being infamous; infamy.</def>

<hw>In"fa*my</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos>; <plu>pl.
<plw>Infamies</plw> <pr>(#)</pr></plu>. <ety>[L.
<ets>infamia</ets>, fr. <ets>infamis</ets> infamous; pref.
<ets>in-</ets> not + <ets>fama</ets> fame: cf. F.
<ets>infamie</ets>. See <er>Fame</er>.]</ety>

<sn>1.</sn> <def>Total loss of reputation; public disgrace;
dishonor; ignominy; indignity.</def>

<q>The afflicted queen would not yield, and said she would not .
. . submit to such <qex>infamy</qex>.</q>
<qau>Bp. Burnet.</qau>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>A quality which exposes to disgrace; extreme
baseness or vileness; <as>as, the <ex>infamy</ex> of an
action</as>.</def>

<sn>3.</sn> <fld>(Law)</fld> <def>That loss of character, or
public disgrace, which a convict incurs, and by which he is at
common law rendered incompetent as a witness.</def>

<-- Yesterday, Dec. 7, 1941 -- a day which will live in infamy, .
. . 
 [Roosevelt] -->

<hw>In"fan*cy</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[L.
<ets>infantia</ets>: cf. F. <ets>enfance</ets>. See
<er>Infant</er>.]</ety>

<sn>1.</sn> <def>The state or period of being an infant; the
first part of life; early childhood.</def>

<q>The babe yet lies in smiling <qex>infancy</qex>.</q>
<qau>Milton.</qau>

<q>Their love in early <qex>infancy</qex> began.</q>
<qau>Dryden.</qau>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>The first age of anything; the beginning or
early period of existence; <as>as, the <ex>infancy</ex> of an
art</as>.</def>

<q>The <qex>infancy</qex> and the grandeur of Rome.</q>
<qau>Arbuthnot.</qau>

<sn>3.</sn> <fld>(Law)</fld> <def>The state or condition of one
under age, or under the age of twenty-one years; nonage;
minority.</def>

<hw>In*fan"dous</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>a.</pos> <ety>[L.
<ets>infandus</ets>; pref. <ets>in-</ets> not + <ets>fari</ets>
to speak.]</ety> <def>Too odious to be expressed or
mentioned.</def> <mark>[Obs.]</mark>

<au>Howell.</au>

<hw>In*fang"thef</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[AS.
<ets>in-fangen-pe\'a2f</ets>; <ets>in</ets> in, into +
<ets>fangen</ets> taken (p. p. of <ets>f<?/n</ets> to take) +
<ets>pe\'a2f</ets> thief.]</ety> <fld>(O. Eng. Law)</fld>
<def>The privilege granted to lords of certain manors to judge

<hw>In"fant</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[L.
<ets>infans</ets>; pref. <ets>in-</ets> not +<ets>fari</ets> to
speak: cf. F. <ets>enfant</ets>, whence OE. <ets>enfaunt</ets>.
See <er>Fame</er>, and cf. <er>Infante</er>,
<er>Infanta</er>.]</ety>

<sn>1.</sn> <def>A child in the first period of life, beginning
at his birth; a young babe; sometimes, a child several years of
age.</def>

<q>And tender cries of <qex>infants</qex> pierce the ear.</q>
<qau>C. Pitt.</qau>

<sn>2.</sn> <fld>(Law)</fld> <def>A person who is not of full
age, or who has not attained the age of legal capacity; a person
under the age of twenty-one years; a minor.</def>

<note><hand/ An infant under seven years of age is not penally
responsible; between seven and fourteen years of age, he may be
convicted of a malicious offense if malice be proved. He becomes
of age on the day preceding his twenty-first birthday, previous
to which time an infant has no capacity to contract.</note>

<sn>3.</sn> <def>Same as <er>Infante</er>.</def>
<mark>[Obs.]</mark>

<au>Spenser.</au>

<hw>In"fant</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>a.</pos> <sn>1.</sn> <def>Of
or pertaining to infancy, or the first period of life; tender;
not mature; <as>as, <ex>infant</ex> strength</as>.</def>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>Intended for young children; <as>as, an
<ex>infant</ex> school</as>.</def>

<hw>In"fant</hw>, <pos>v. t.</pos> <ety>[Cf. F.
<ets>enfanter</ets>.]</ety> <def>To bear or bring forth, as a

<q>This worthy motto, \'bdNo bishop, no king,\'b8 is . . .
<qex>infanted</qex> out of the same fears.</q>
<qau>Milton.</qau>

<hw>In*fat"u*ate</hw> <pr>(?; 135)</pr>, <pos>a.</pos> <ety>[L.
