<hw>In*fat"u*ate</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>v. t.</pos>
<wordforms>[<pos>imp. & p. p.</pos> <er>Infatuated</er>
<pr>(?)</pr>; <pos>p. pr. & vb. n.</pos>
<er>Infatuating</er>.]</wordforms>

<sn>1.</sn> <def>To make foolish; to affect with folly; to weaken
the intellectual powers of, or to deprive of sound
judgment.</def>

<q>The judgment of God will be very visible in
<qex>infatuating</qex> a people . . . ripe and prepared for
destruction.</q>
<qau>Clarendon.</qau>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>To inspire with a foolish and extravagant
passion; <as>as, to be <ex>infatuated</ex> with
gaming</as>.</def>

<q>The people are . . . <qex>infatuated</qex> with the
notion.</q>
<qau>Addison.</qau>

<hw>In*fat"u*a`ted</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>a.</pos> <def>Overcome
by some foolish passion or desire; affected by infatuation.</def>

<hw>In*fat`u*a"tion</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[LL.
<ets>infatuatio</ets>: cf. F. <ets>infatuation</ets>.]</ety>
<def>The act of infatuating; the state of being infatuated;
folly; that which infatuates.</def>

<q>The <qex>infatuations</qex> of the sensual and frivolous part
of mankind are amazing; but the <qex>infatuations</qex> of the
learned and sophistical are incomparably more so.</q>
<qau>I. Taylor.</qau>

<q>Such is the <qex>infatuation</qex> of self-love.</q>
<qau>Blair.</qau>

<hw>In*fect"</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>a.</pos> <ety>[L.
<ets>infectus</ets>: cf. F. <ets>infect</ets>. See
<er>Infect</er>, <pos>v. t.</pos>]</ety> <def>Infected. Cf.
<er>Enfect</er>.</def> <mark>[Obs.]</mark>

<au>Shak.</au>

<hw>In*fect"</hw>, <pos>v. t.</pos> <wordforms>[<pos>imp. & p.
p.</pos> <er>Infected</er>; <pos>p. pr. & vb. n.</pos>
<er>Infecting</er>.]</wordforms> <ety>[L. <ets>infectus</ets>, p.
p. of <ets>inficere</ets> to put or dip into, to stain, infect;
pref. <ets>in-</ets> in + <ets>facere</ets> to make; cf. F.
<ets>infecter</ets>. See <er>Fact</er>.]</ety>

<sn>1.</sn> <def>To taint with morbid matter or any pestilential
or noxious substance or effluvium by which disease is produced;
<as>as, to <ex>infect</ex> a lancet; to <ex>infect</ex> an
apartment.</as></def>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>To affect with infectious disease; to
communicate infection to; <as>as, <ex>infected</ex> with the
plague</as>.</def>

<q>Them that were left alive being <qex>infected</qex> with this
disease.</q>
<qau>Sir T. North.</qau>

<sn>3.</sn> <def>To communicate to or affect with, as qualities
or emotions, esp. bad qualities; to corrupt; to contaminate; to
taint by the communication of anything noxious or
pernicious.</def>

<au>Cowper.</au>

<q><qex>Infected</qex> Ston's daughters with like heat.</q>
<qau>Milton.</qau>

<sn>4.</sn> <fld>(Law)</fld> <def>To contaminate with illegality
or to expo<?/<?/ to penalty.</def>

<syn>Syn. -- To poison; vitiate; pollute; defile.</syn>

<hw>In*fect"er</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <def>One who, or
that which, infects.</def>

<hw>In*fect"i*ble</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>a.</pos> <def>Capable
of being infected.</def>

<hw>In*fec"tion</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[Cf. F.
<ets>infection</ets>, L. <ets>infectio</ets> a dyeing.]</ety>

<sn>1.</sn> <def>The act or process of infecting.</def>

<q>There was a strict order against coming to those pits, and
that was only to prevent <qex>infection</qex>.</q>
<qau>De Foe.</qau>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>That which infects, or causes the communicated
disease; any effluvium, miasm, or pestilential matter by which an
infectious disease is caused.</def>

<q>And that which was still worse, they that did thus break out
spread the <qex>infection</qex> further by their wandering about
with the distemper upon them.</q>
<qau>De Foe.</qau>

<sn>3.</sn> <def>The state of being infected; contamination by
morbific particles; the result of infecting influence; a
prevailing disease; epidemic.</def>

<q>The danger was really very great, the <qex>infection</qex>
being so very violent in London.</q>
<qau>De Foe.</qau>

<sn>4.</sn> <def>That which taints or corrupts morally; <as>as,
the <ex>infection</ex> of vicious principles</as>.</def>

<q>It was her chance to light
Amidst the gross <qex>infections</qex> of those times.</q>
<qau>Daniel.</qau>

<sn>5.</sn> <fld>(Law)</fld> <def>Contamination by illegality, as
in cases of contraband goods; implication.</def>

<sn>6.</sn> <def>Sympathetic communication of like qualities or
emotions; influence.</def>

<q>Through all her train the soft <qex>infection</qex> ran.</q>
<qau>Pope.</qau>

<q>Mankind are gay or serious by <qex>infection</qex>.</q>
<qau>Rambler.</qau>

<syn>Syn. -- <er>Infection</er>, <er>Contagion</er>.</syn>
<usage> -- <xex>Infection</xex> is often used in a definite and
limited sense of the transmission of affections without direct
contact of individuals or immediate application or introduction
of the morbific agent, in contradistinction to
<xex>contagion</xex>, which then implies transmission by direct
contact. <xex>Quain</xex>. See <er>Contagious</er>.</usage>

<hw>In*fec"tious</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>a.</pos> <ety>[Cf. F.
<ets>infectieux</ets>.]</ety>

<sn>1.</sn> <def>Having qualities that may infect; communicable
or caused by infection; pestilential; epidemic; <as>as, an
<ex>infectious</ex> fever; <ex>infectious</ex> clothing;
<ex>infectious</ex> air; <ex>infectious</ex> vices.</as></def>

<q>Where the <qex>infectious</qex> pestilence.</q>
<qau>Shak.</qau>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>Corrupting, or tending to corrupt or
contaminate; vitiating; demoralizing.</def>

<q>It [the court] is necessary for the polishing of manners . . .
but it is <qex>infectious</qex> even to the best morals to live
always in it.</q>
<qau>Dryden.</qau>

<sn>3.</sn> <fld>(Law)</fld> <def>Contaminating with illegality;
exposing to seizure and forfeiture.</def>

<q>Contraband articles are said to be of an <qex>infectious</qex>
nature.</q>
<qau>Kent.</qau>

<sn>4.</sn> <def>Capable of being easily diffused or spread;
sympathetic; readily communicated; <as>as, <ex>infectious</ex>
mirth</as>.</def>

<q>The laughter was so genuine as to be
<qex>infectious</qex>.</q>
<qau>W. Black.</qau>

<syn>Syn. -- See <er>Contagious</er>.</syn>

<hw>In*fec"tious*ly</hw>, <pos>adv.</pos> <def>In an infectious
manner.</def>

<au>Shak.</au>

<hw>In*fec"tious*ness</hw>, <pos>n.</pos> <def>The quality of
being infectious.</def>

<hw>In*fect"ive</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>a.</pos> <ety>[L.
<ets>infectivus</ets> pertaining to dyeing.]</ety>
<def>Infectious.</def>

<au>Beau. & Fl.</au>

<q>True love . . . hath an <qex>infective</qex> power.</q>
<qau>Sir P. Sidney.</qau>

<hw>In*fec"und</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>a.</pos> <ety>[L.
<ets>infecundus</ets>: cf. F. <ets>inf\'82cond</ets>. See
<er>In-</er> not, and <er>Fecund</er>.]</ety> <def>Unfruitful;
not producing young; barren; infertile.</def> <mark>[Obs.]</mark>

<au>Evelyn.</au>

<hw>In`fe*cun"di*ty</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[L.
<ets>infecunditas</ets>: cf. F.
<ets>inf\'82condit\'82</ets>.]</ety> <def>Want of fecundity or

<hw>In`fe*cun"dous</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>a.</pos> <ety>[See

<hw>In*fee"ble</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>v. t.</pos> <def>See
<er>Enfeeble</er>.</def>

<hw>In`fe*lic"i*tous</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>a.</pos> <def>Not
felicitous; unhappy; unfortunate; not fortunate or appropriate in
application; not well said, expressed, or done; <as>as, an
<ex>infelicitous</ex> condition; an <ex>infelicitous</ex> remark;
an <ex>infelicitous</ex> description; <ex>infelicitous</ex>
words.</as></def>

<hw>In`fe*lic"i*ty</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos>; <plu>pl.
<plw>Infelicities</plw> <pr>(#)</pr></plu>. <ety>[L.
<ets>infelicitas</ets>: cf. F. <ets>inf\'82licit\'82</ets>. See
<er>In-</er> not, and <er>Felicity</er>.]</ety>

<sn>1.</sn> <def>The state or quality of being infelicitous;
unhappiness; misery; wretchedness; misfortune; want of
suitableness or appropriateness.</def>

<au>I. Watts.</au>

<q>Whatever is the ignorance and <qex>infelicity</qex> of the
present state, we were made wise and happy.</q>
<qau>Glanvill.</qau>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>That (as an act, word, expression, etc.) which
is infelicitous; <as>as, <ex>infelicities</ex> of
speech</as>.</def>

<hw>In`fe*lo"ni*ous</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>a.</pos> <def>Not
felonious, malignant, or criminal.</def>

<au>G. Eliot.</au>

<hw>In"felt`</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>a.</pos> <ety>[Pref.
<ets>in-</ets> in + <ets>felt</ets>.]</ety> <def>Felt inwardly;
heartfelt.</def> <mark>[R.]</mark>

<q>The baron stood afar off, or knelt in submissive,
acknowledged, <qex>infelt</qex> inferiority.</q>
<qau>Milman.</qau>

<hw>In`feo*da"tion</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos>
<fld>(Law)</fld> <def>See <er>Infeudation</er>.</def>

<hw>In*feoff"</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>v. t.</pos>
<fld>(Law)</fld> <def>See <er>Enfeoff</er>.</def>

<hw>In*feoff"ment</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos>
<fld>(Law)</fld> <def>See <er>Enfeoffment</er>.</def>

<hw>In*fer"</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>v. t.</pos>
<wordforms>[<pos>imp. & p. p.</pos> <er>Inferred</er>
<pr>(?)</pr>; <pos>p. pr. & vb. n.</pos>
<er>Inferring</er>.]</wordforms> <ety>[L. <ets>inferre</ets> to
bring into, bring forward, occasion, infer; pref. <ets>in-</ets>
in + <ets>ferre</ets> to carry, bring: cf. F.
<ets>inf\'82rer</ets>. See 1 st <er>Bear</er>.]</ety>

<sn>1.</sn> <def>To bring on; to induce; to occasion.</def>
<mark>[Obs.]</mark>

<au>Harvey.</au>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>To offer, as violence.</def> <mark>[Obs.]</mark>

<au>Spenser.</au>

<sn>3.</sn> <def>To bring forward, or employ as an argument; to
adduce; to allege; to offer.</def> <mark>[Obs.]</mark>

<q>Full well hath Clifford played the orator,
<qex>Inferring</qex> arguments of mighty force.</q>
<qau>Shak.</qau>

<sn>4.</sn> <def>To derive by deduction or by induction; to
conclude or surmise from facts or premises; to accept or derive,
as a consequence, conclusion, or probability; to imply; <as>as, I
<ex>inferred</ex> his determination from his silence</as>.</def>

<q>To <qex>infer</qex> is nothing but by virtue of one
proposition laid down as true, to draw in another as true.</q>
<qau>Locke.</qau>

<q>Such opportunities always <qex>infer</qex> obligations.</q>
<qau>Atterbury.</qau>

<sn>5.</sn> <def>To show; to manifest; to prove.</def>
<mark>[Obs.]</mark>

<q>The first part is not the proof of the second, but rather
contrariwise, the second <qex>inferreth</qex> well the first.</q>
<qau>Sir T. More.</qau>

<q>This doth <qex>infer</qex> the zeal I had to see him.</q>
<qau>Shak.</qau>

<-- p. 759 -->

<hw>In*fer"a*ble</hw> <pr>(?; 277)</pr>, <pos>a.</pos>
<def>Capable of being inferred or deduced from premises.</def>
<altsp>[Written also <asp>inferrible</asp>.]</altsp>

<au>H. Spencer.</au>

<q>A sufficient argument . . . is <qex>inferable</qex> from these
premises.</q>
<qau>Burke.</qau>

<hw>In"fer*ence</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[From
<er>Infer</er>.]</ety>

<sn>1.</sn> <def>The act or process of inferring by deduction or
induction.</def>

<q>Though it may chance to be right in the conclusions, it is yet
unjust and mistaken in the method of <qex>inference</qex>.</q>
<qau>Glanvill.</qau>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>That which inferred; a truth or proposition
drawn from another which is admitted or supposed to be true; a
conclusion; a deduction.</def>

<au>Milton.</au>

<q>These <qex>inferences</qex>, or conclusions, are the effects
of reasoning, and the three propositions, taken all together, are
called syllogism, or argument.</q>
<qau>I. Watts.</qau>

<syn>Syn. -- Conclusion; deduction; consequence.</syn> <usage> --
<er>Inference</er>, <er>Conclusion</er>. An <xex>inference</xex>
is literally that which is <xex>brought in</xex>; and hence, a
deduction or induction from premises, -- something which follows
as certainly or probably true. A <xex>conclusion</xex> is
stronger than an <xex>inference</xex>; it <xex>shuts us up</xex>
to the result, and terminates inquiry. We <xex>infer</xex> what
is particular or probable; we <xex>conclude</xex> what is
certain. In a chain of reasoning we have many
<xex>inferences</xex>, which lead to the ultimate
<xex>conclusion</xex>. \'bdAn <xex>inference</xex> is a
proposition which is perceived to be true, because of its
connection with some known fact.\'b8 \'bdWhen something is simply
affirmed to be true, it is called a <xex>proposition</xex>; after
it has been found to be true by several reasons or arguments, it
is called a <xex>conclusion</xex>.\'b8 <au>I.
Taylor.</au></usage>

<hw>In`fer*en"tial</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>a.</pos> <def>Deduced
or deducible by inference.</def> \'bd<xex>Inferential</xex>
proofs.\'b8

<au>J. S. Mill.</au>

<hw>In`fer*en"tial*ly</hw>, <pos>adv.</pos> <def>By way of
inference.</def>

<hw>\'d8In*fe"ri*\'91</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n. pl.</pos>
<ety>[L., fr. <ets>inferus</ets> underneath.]</ety> <fld>(Rom.
Antiq.)</fld> <def>Sacrifices offered to the souls of deceased
heroes or friends.</def>

<hw>In*fe"ri*or</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>a.</pos> <ety>[L.,
compar. of <ets>inferus</ets> that is below, underneath, the
lower; akin to E. <ets>under</ets>: cf. F.
<ets>inf\'82rieur</ets>. See <er>Under</er>.]</ety>

<sn>1.</sn> <def>Lower in place, rank, excellence, etc.; less
important or valuable; subordinate; underneath; beneath.</def>

<q>A thousand <qex>inferior</qex> and particular
propositions.</q>
<qau>I. Watts.</qau>

<q>The body, or, as some love to call it, our <qex>inferior</qex>
nature.</q>
<qau>Burke.</qau>

<q>Whether they are equal or <qex>inferior</qex> to my other
poems, an author is the most improper judge.</q>
<qau>Dryden.</qau>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>Poor or mediocre; <as>as, an <ex>inferior</ex>
quality of goods</as>.</def>

<sn>3.</sn> <fld>(Astron.)</fld> <sd>(a)</sd> <def>Nearer the sun
than the earth is; <as>as, the <ex>inferior</ex> or interior
planets; an <ex>inferior</ex> conjunction of Mercury or
Venus.</as></def> <sd>(b)</sd> <def>Below the horizon; as, the
<xex>inferior</xex> part of a meridian,</def>

<sn>4.</sn> <fld>(Bot.)</fld> <sd>(a)</sd> <def>Situated below
some other organ; -- said of a calyx when free from the ovary,
and therefore below it, or of an ovary with an adherent and
therefore inferior calyx.</def> <sd>(b)</sd> <def>On the side of
a flower which is next the bract; anterior.</def>

<sn>5.</sn> <fld>(Min.)</fld> <def>Junior or subordinate in rank;
<as>as, an <ex>inferior</ex> officer</as>.</def>

<cs><col>Inferior court</col> <fld>(Law)</fld>, <cd>a court
subject to the jurisdiction of another court known as the
<xex>superior<xex>, or <xex>higher<xex>, <xex>court<xex>.</cd> --
<mcol><col>Inferior letter</col>, <col>Inferior
figure</col></mcol> <fld>(Print.)</fld>, <cd>a small letter or
figure standing at the bottom of the line (opposed to
<contr>superior letter</contr> or <xex>figure<xex>), <as>as in
A<subs>2</subs>, B<subs>n</subs>, 2 and <it>n<it> are
<ex>inferior<ex> characters</as>.</cd> -- <col>Inferior
tide</col>, <cd>the tide corresponding to the moon's transit of
the meridian, when below the horizon.</cd></cs>

<hw>In*fe"ri*or</hw>, <pos>n.</pos> <def>A person lower in
station, rank, intellect, etc., than another.</def>

<q>A great person gets more by obliging his <qex>inferior</qex>
than by disdaining him.</q>
<qau>South.</qau>

<hw>In*fe`ri*or"i*ty</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <ety>[Cf. F.
<ets>inf\'82riorit\'82</ets>.]</ety> <def>The state of being
inferior; a lower state or condition; <as>as,

<q>A deep sense of our own great <qex>inferiority</qex>.</q>

<hw>In*fe"ri*or*ly</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>adv.</pos> <def>In an

<hw>In*fer"nal</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>a.</pos> <ety>[F.
<ets>infernal</ets>, L. <ets>infernalis</ets>, fr.
<ets>infernus</ets> that which lies beneath, the lower. See
<er>Inferior</er>.]</ety>

<sn>1.</sn> <def>Of or pertaining to or suitable for the lower
regions, inhabited, according to the ancients, by the dead;
pertaining to Pluto's realm of the dead, the Tartarus of the
ancients.</def>

<q>The Elysian fields, the <qex>infernal</qex> monarchy.</q>
<qau>Garth.</qau>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>Of or pertaining to, resembling, or inhabiting,
hell; suitable for hell, or to the character of the inhabitants
of hell; hellish; diabolical; <as>as, <ex>infernal</ex> spirits,
or conduct</as>.</def>

<q>The instruments or abettors in such <qex>infernal</qex>
dealings.</q>
<qau>Addison.</qau>

<cs><col>Infernal machine</col>, <cd>a machine or apparatus
maliciously designed to explode, and destroy life or
property.</cd> -- <col>Infernal stone</col> <cd>(<xex>lapis
infernalis<xex>), lunar caustic; formerly so called. The name was
also applied to caustic potash.</cd></cs>

<syn>Syn. -- Tartarean; Stygian; hellish; devilish; diabolical;
satanic; fiendish; malicious.</syn>

<hw>In*fest"</hw>, <pos>v. t.</pos> <wordforms>[<pos>imp. & p.

<er>Infesting</er>.]</wordforms> <ety>[L. <ets>infestare</ets>,

F. <ets>infester</ets>. See <er>Defend</er>.]</ety> <def>To
trouble greatly by numbers or by frequency of presence; to
disturb; to annoy; to frequent and molest or harass; <as>as,
fleas <ex>infest</ex> dogs and cats; a sea <ex>infested</ex> with
pirates.</as></def>

<q>To poison vermin that <qex>infest</qex> his plants.</q>
<qau>Cowper.</qau>

<q>These, said the genius, are envy, avarice, superstition, love,
with the like cares and passions that <qex>infest</qex> human
life.</q>
<qau>Addison.</qau>

<q>And the cares, that <qex>infest</qex> the day,
Shall fold their tents, like the Arabs,
And as silently steal away.</q>
<qau>Longfellow.</qau>

<hw>In`feu*da"tion</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[LL.

<sn>1.</sn> <fld>(Law)</fld> <def>The act of putting one in

<hw>In*fib`u*la"tion</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[L.

<sn>1.</sn> <def>The act of clasping, or fastening, as with a

<sn>2.</sn> <def>The act of attaching a ring, clasp, or frame, to

<hw>In"fi*del</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>a.</pos> <ety>[L.
<ets>infidelis</ets>; pref. <ets>in-</ets> not +
<ets>fidelis</ets> faithful, fr. <ets>fides</ets> faith: cf. F.
<ets>infid\'8ale</ets>. See <er>Fidelity</er>.]</ety> <def>Not
holding the faith; -- applied esp. to one who does not believe in
the inspiration of the Scriptures, and the supernatural origin of
Christianity.</def>

<q>The <qex>infidel</qex> writer is a great enemy to society.</q>
<qau>V. Knox.</qau>

<hw>In"fi*del</hw>, <pos>n.</pos> <def>One who does not believe
in the prevailing religious faith; especially, one who does not
believe in the divine origin and authority of Christianity; a
Mohammedan; a heathen; a freethinker.</def>

<note><hand/ <xex>Infidel</xex> is used by English writers to
translate the equivalent word used Mohammedans in speaking of
Christians and other disbelievers in Mohammedanism.</note>

<syn>Syn. -- <er>Infidel</er>, <er>Unbeliever</er>,
<er>Freethinker</er>, <er>Deist</er>, <er>Atheist</er>,
<er>Sceptic</er>, <er>Agnostic</er>.</syn> <usage> An
<xex>infidel</xex>, in common usage, is one who denies
Christianity and the truth of the Scriptures. Some have
endeavored to widen the sense of <xex>infidel</xex> so as to
embrace atheism and every form of unbelief; but this use does not
generally prevail. A <xex>freethinker</xex> is now only another
name for an <xex>infidel</xex>. An <xex>unbeliever</xex> is not
necessarily a <xex>dis</xex>believer or infidel, because he may
still be inquiring after evidence to satisfy his mind; the word,
however, is more commonly used in the extreme sense. A
<xex>deist</xex> believes in one God and a divine providence, but
rejects revelation. An <xex>atheist</xex> denies the being of
God. A <xex>sceptic</xex> is one whose faith in the
<xex>credibility of evidence</xex> is weakened or destroyed, so
that religion, to the same extent, has no practical hold on his
mind. An <xex>agnostic</xex> remains in a state of suspended
judgment, neither affirming nor denying the existence of a
personal Deity.</usage>

<hw>In`fi*del"i*ty</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos>; <plu>pl.
<plw>Infidelities</plw> <pr>(<?/)</pr></plu>. <ety>[L.
<ets>infidelitas</ets>: cf. F.
<ets>infid\'82lit\'82</ets>.]</ety>

<sn>1.</sn> <def>Want of faith or belief in some religious
system; especially, a want of faith in, or disbelief of, the
inspiration of the Scriptures, of the divine origin of
Christianity.</def>

<q>There is, indeed, no doubt but that vanity is one of the
principal causes of <qex>infidelity</qex>.</q>
<qau>V. Knox.</qau>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>Unfaithfulness to the marriage vow or contract;
violation of the marriage covenant by adultery.</def>

<sn>3.</sn> <def>Breach of trust; unfaithfulness to a charge, or
to moral obligation; treachery; deceit; <as>as, the
<ex>infidelity</ex> of a servant</as>.</def> \'bdThe
<xex>infidelity</xex> of friends.\'b8

<au>Sir W. Temple.</au>

inclose, as a field.</def> <mark>[R.]</mark>

<au>Holland.</au>

with a film; to coat thinly; <as>as, to <ex>infilm</ex> one metal

<hw>In*fil"ter</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>v. t. & i.</pos>
<wordforms>[<pos>imp. & p. p.</pos> <er>Infiltered</er>; <pos>p.
pr. & vb. n.</pos> <er>Infiltering</er>.]</wordforms> <ety>[Cf.
<er>Infiltrate</er>.]</ety> <def>To filter or sift in.</def>

<hw>In*fil"trate</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>v. i.</pos>
<wordforms>[<pos>imp. & p. p.</pos> <er>Infiltrated</er>
<pr>(?)</pr>; <pos>p. pr. & vb. n.</pos> <er>Infiltrating</er>
<pr>(?)</pr>.]</wordforms> <ety>[Pref. <ets>in-</ets> +
<ets>filtrate</ets>: cf. F, <ets>s'infiltrer</ets>. Cf.
<er>Infilter</er>.]</ety> <def>To enter by penetrating the pores
or interstices of a substance; to filter into or through
something.</def>

<q>The water <qex>infiltrates</qex> through the porous rock.</q>
<qau>Addison.</qau>

<hw>In*fil"trate</hw>, <pos>v. t.</pos> <def>To penetrate
gradually; -- sometimes used reflexively.</def>

<au>J. S. Mill.</au>

<hw>In`fil*tra"tion</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[Cf. F.
<ets>infiltration</ets>.]</ety>

<sn>1.</sn> <def>The act or process of infiltrating, as if water
into a porous substance, or of a fluid into the cells of an organ
or part of the body.</def>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>The substance which has entered the pores or
cavities of a body.</def>

<au>Addison.</au>

<q>Calcareous <qex>infiltrations</qex> filling the cavities.</q>
<qau>Kirwan.</qau>

<cs><col>Fatty infiltration</col>. <fld>(Med.)</fld> <cd>See
under <er>Fatty</er>.</cd> -- <col>Infiltration gallery</col>,
<cd>a filter gallery.</cd></cs>

<hw>In*fil"tra*tive</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>a.</pos> <def>Of or
pertaining to infiltration.</def>

<au>Kane.</au>

<hw>In"fi*nite</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>a.</pos> <ety>[L.
<ets>infinitus</ets>: cf. F. <ets>infini</ets>. See <er>In-</er>
not, and <er>Finite</er>.]</ety>

<sn>1.</sn> <def>Unlimited or boundless, in time or space;
<as>as, <ex>infinite</ex> duration or distance</as>.</def>

<q>Whatever is finite, as finite, will admit of no comparative
relation with infinity; for whatever is less than
<qex>infinite</qex> is still infinitely distant from infinity;
and lower than <qex>infinite</qex> distance the lowest or least
can not sink.</q>
<qau>H. Brooke.</qau>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>Without limit in power, capacity, knowledge, or
excellence; boundless; immeasurably or inconceivably great;
perfect; <as>as, the <ex>infinite</ex> wisdom and goodness of
God</as>; -- opposed to <xex>finite</xex>.</def>

<q>Great is our Lord, and of great power; his understanding is
<qex>infinite</qex>.</q>
<qau>Ps. cxlvii. 5.</qau>

<q>O God, how <qex>infinite</qex> thou art!</q>
<qau>I. Watts.</qau>

<sn>3.</sn> <def>Indefinitely large or extensive; great; vast;
immense; gigantic; prodigious.</def>

<q><qex>Infinite</qex> riches in a little room.</q>
<qau>Marlowe.</qau>

<q>Which <qex>infinite</qex> calamity shall cause
To human life.</q>
<qau>Milton.</qau>

<sn>4.</sn> <fld>(Math.)</fld> <def>Greater than any assignable
quantity of the same kind; -- said of certain quantities.</def>

<sn>5.</sn> <fld>(Mus.)</fld> <def>Capable of endless repetition;
-- said of certain forms of the canon, called also
<altname>perpetual fugues</altname>, so constructed that their
ends lead to their beginnings, and the performance may be
incessantly repeated.</def>

<au>Moore (Encyc. of Music).</au>

<syn>Syn. -- Boundless; immeasurable; illimitable; interminable;
limitless; unlimited; endless; eternal.</syn>

<hw>In"fi*nite</hw>, <pos>n.</pos> <sn>1.</sn> <def>That which is
infinite; boundless space or duration; infinity;
boundlessness.</def>

<q>Not till the weight is heaved from off the air, and the
thunders roll down the horizon, will the serene light of God flow
upon us, and the blue <qex>infinite</qex> embrace us again.</q>
<qau>J. Martineau.</qau>

<sn>2.</sn> <fld>(Math.)</fld> <def>An infinite quantity or
magnitude.</def>

<sn>3.</sn> <def>An infinity; an incalculable or very great
number.</def>

<q>Glittering chains, embroidered richly o'er
With <qex>infinite</qex> of pearls and finest gold.</q>
<qau>Fanshawe.</qau>

<sn>4.</sn> <def>The Infinite Being; God; the Almighty.</def>

<hw>In"fi*nite*ly</hw>, <pos>adv.</pos> <sn>1.</sn> <def>Without
bounds or limits; beyond or below assignable limits; <as>as, an
<ex>infinitely</ex> large or <ex>infinitely</ex> small
quantity</as>.</def>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>Very; exceedingly; vastly; highly;
extremely.</def> \'bd<xex>Infinitely</xex> pleased.\'b8

<au>Dryden.</au>

<hw>In"fi*nite*ness</hw>, <pos>n.</pos> <def>The state or quality
of being infinite; infinity; greatness; immensity.</def>

<au>Jer. Taylor.</au>

<hw>In`fin*i*tes"i*mal</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>a.</pos> <ety>[Cf.
F. <ets>infinit\'82simal</ets>, fr. <ets>infinit\'82sime</ets>
infinitely small, fr. L. <ets>infinitus</ets>. See
<er>Infinite</er>, <pos>a.</pos>]</ety> <def>Infinitely or
indefinitely small; less than any assignable quantity or value;
very small.</def>

<cs><col>Infinitesimal calculus</col>, <cd>the different and the
integral calculus, when developed according to the method used by
Leibnitz, who regarded the increments given to variables as
infinitesimal.</cd></cs>

<hw>In`fin*i*tes"i*mal</hw>, <pos>n.</pos> <fld>(Math.)</fld>
<def>An infinitely small quantity; that which is less than any
assignable quantity.</def>

<hw>In`fin*i*tes"i*mal*ly</hw>, <pos>adv.</pos> <def>By
infinitesimals; in infinitely small quantities; in an
infinitesimal degree.</def>

<hw>In*fin`i*ti"val</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>a.</pos>
<def>Pertaining to the infinite mood.</def>
\'bd<xex>Infinitival</xex> stems.\'b8

<au>Fitzed. Hall.</au>

<hw>In*fin"i*tive</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[L.
<ets>infinitivus</ets>: cf. F. <ets>infinitif</ets>. See
<er>Infinite</er>.]</ety> <def>Unlimited; not bounded or
restricted; undefined.</def>

<cs><col>Infinitive mood</col> <fld>(Gram.)</fld>, <cd>that form
of the verb which merely names the action, and performs the
office of a verbal noun. Some grammarians make two forms in
English: (<stype>a<stype>) The simple form, as, <xex>speak<xex>,
<xex>go<xex>, <xex>hear<xex>, before which <xex>to<xex> is
commonly placed, as, <xex>to speak<xex>; <xex>to go<xex>; <xex>to
hear<xex>. (<stype>b</stype>) The form of the imperfect
participle, called the infinitive in <xex>-ing<xex>; as,
<xex>going<xex> is as easy as <xex>standing<xex>.</cd></cs>

<note>With the auxiliary verbs <xex>may</xex>, <xex>can</xex>,
<xex>must</xex>, <xex>might</xex>, <xex>could</xex>,
<xex>would</xex>, and <xex>should</xex>, the simple infinitive is
expressed without <xex>to</xex>; as, you <xex>may speak</xex>;
they <xex>must hear</xex>, etc. The infinitive usually omits
<xex>to</xex> with the verbs <xex>let</xex>, <xex>dare</xex>,
<xex>do</xex>, <xex>bid</xex>, <xex>make</xex>, <xex>see</xex>,
<xex>hear</xex>, <xex>need</xex>, etc.; as, let me <xex>go</xex>;
you dare not <xex>tell</xex>; make him <xex>work</xex>; hear him
<xex>talk</xex>, etc.</note>

<note><hand/ In Anglo-Saxon, the simple infinitive was not
preceded by <xex>to</xex> (the sign of modern simple infinitive),
but it had a dative form (sometimes called the gerundial
infinitive) which was preceded by <xex>to</xex>, and was chiefly
employed in expressing purpose. See <er>Gerund</er>, 2.</note>

<note>The gerundial ending (-<xex>anne</xex>) not only took the
same form as the simple infinitive (-<xex>an</xex>), but it was
confounded with the present participle in -<xex>ende</xex>, or
-<xex>inde</xex> (later -<xex>inge</xex>).</note>

<hw>In*fin"i*tive</hw>, <pos>n.</pos> <fld>(Gram.)</fld> <def>An
infinitive form of the verb; a verb in the infinitive mood; the
infinitive mood.</def>

<hw>In*fin"i*tive</hw>, <pos>adv.</pos> <fld>(Gram.)</fld>
<def>In the manner of an infinitive mood.</def>

<hw>\'d8In`fi*ni"to</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>a.</pos>
<ety>[It.]</ety> <fld>(Mus.)</fld> <def>Infinite; perpetual, as a
canon whose end leads back to the beginning. See
<er>Infinite</er>, <pos>a.</pos>, 5.</def>

<hw>In*fin"i*tude</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <sn>1.</sn>
<def>The quality or state of being infinite, or without limits;
infiniteness.</def>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>Infinite extent; unlimited space; immensity;
infinity.</def> \'bdI am who fill <xex>infinitude</xex>.\'b8

<au>Milton.</au>

<q>As pleasing to the fancy, as speculations of eternity or
<qex>infinitude</qex> are to the understanding.</q>
<qau>Addison.</qau>

<sn>3.</sn> <def>Boundless number; countless multitude.</def>
\'bdAn <xex>infinitude</xex> of distinctions.\'b8

<au>Addison.</au>

<hw>In*fin"i*tu`ple</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>a.</pos> <ety>[Cf.
<er>Quadruple</er>.]</ety> <def>Multipied an infinite number of
times.</def> <mark>[R.]</mark>

<au>Wollaston.</au>

<hw>In*fin"i*ty</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos>; <plu>pl.
<plw>Infinities</plw> <pr>(#)</pr></plu>. <ety>[L.
<ets>infinitas</ets>; pref. <ets>in-</ets> not + <ets>finis</ets>
boundary, limit, end: cf. F. <ets>infinit\'82</ets>. See
<er>Finite</er>.]</ety>

<sn>1.</sn> <def>Unlimited extent of time, space, or quantity;
eternity; boundlessness; immensity.</def>

<au>Sir T. More.</au>

<q>There can not be more <qex>infinities</qex> than one; for one
of them would limit the other.</q>
<qau>Sir W. Raleigh.</qau>
<-- now known to be false! -- See aleph null, etc.-->

<sn>2.</sn> <def>Unlimited capacity, energy, excellence, or
knowledge; <as>as, the <ex>infinity</ex> of God and his
perfections</as>.</def>

<au>Hooker.</au>

<sn>3.</sn> <def>Endless or indefinite number; great multitude;
as an <xex>infinity</xex> of beauties.</def>

<au>Broome.</au>

<-- p. 760 -->

<-- p. 760 -->

<sn>4.</sn> <fld>(Math.)</fld> <def>A quantity greater than any
assignable quantity of the same kind.</def>

<note><hand/ Mathematically considered, infinity is always a
limit of a variable quantity, resulting from a particular
supposition made upon the varying element which enters it.</note>

<au>Davies & Peck (Math. Dict. ).</au>

<sn>5.</sn> <fld>(Geom.)</fld> <def>That part of a line, or of a
plane, or of space, which is infinitely distant. In modern
geometry, parallel lines or planes are sometimes treated as lines
or planes meeting at infinity.</def>

<cs><col>Circle at infinity</col>, <cd>an imaginary circle at
infinity, through which, in geometry of three dimensions, every
sphere is imagined to pass.</cd> -- <col>Circular points at
infinity</col>. <cd>See under <er>Circular</er>.</cd></cs>

<hw>In*firm"</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>a.</pos>
<ety>[L.<ets>infirmus</ets>: cf.F.<ets>infirme</ets>. See
<er>In-</er> not, and <er>Firm</er>, <pos>a.</pos>]</ety>
<sn>1.</sn> <def>Not firm or sound; weak; feeble; <as>as, an
<ex>infirm</ex> body; an <ex>infirm</ex> constitution.</as></def>

<q>A poor, <qex>infirm</qex>, weak, and despised old man.</q>
<qau>Shak.</qau>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>Weak of mind or will; irresolute;
vacillating.</def> \'bdAn <xex>infirm</xex> judgment.\'b8

<au>Burke.</au>

<q><qex>Infirm</qex> of purpose!</q>
<qau>Shak.</qau>

<sn>3.</sn> <def>Not solid or stable; insecure; precarious.</def>

<q>He who fixes on false principles treads or <qex>infirm</qex>
ground.</q>
<qau>South.</qau>

<syn>Syn. -- Debilitated; sickly; feeble; decrepit; weak;
enfeebled; irresolute; vacillating; imbecile.</syn>

<hw>In*firm"</hw>, <pos>v. t.</pos> <ety>[L. <ets>infirmare</ets>
:  cf. F.<ets>infirmer</ets>.]</ety> <def>To weaken; to
enfeeble.</def> <mark>[Obs.]</mark>

<au>Sir W. Raleigh.</au>

<hw>In`fir*ma"ri*an</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <def>A
person dwelling in, or having charge of, an infirmary, esp. in a
monastic institution.</def>

<hw>In*firm"a*ry</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos>; <plu>pl.
<plw>Infirmaries</plw> <pr>(#)</pr></plu>. <ety>[Cf. OE.
<ets>fermerie</ets>, OF. <ets>enfermerie</ets>, F.
<ets>infirmerie</ets>, LL. <ets>infirmaria</ets>. See
<er>Infirm</er>.]</ety> <def>A hospital, or place where the
infirm or sick are lodged and nursed gratuitously, or where
out-patients are treated.</def>

<hw>In*firm"a*tive</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>a.</pos> <ety>[Cf. F.
<ets>infirmatif</ets>.]</ety> <def>Weakening; annulling, or
tending to make void.</def> <mark>[Obs.]</mark>

<hw>In*firm"a*to*ry</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <def>An
infirmary.</def> <mark>[Obs.]</mark>

<hw>In*firm"i*ty</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos>; <plu>pl.
<plw>Infirmities</plw> <pr>(#)</pr></plu>. <ety>[L.
<ets>infirmitas</ets> : cf. F. <ets>infirmite</ets>. See
<er>Infirm</er>, <pos>a.</pos>]</ety> <sn>1.</sn> <def>The state
of being infirm; feebleness; an imperfection or weakness; esp.,
an unsound, unhealthy, or debilitated state; a disease; a malady;
<as>as, <ex>infirmity</ex> of body or mind</as>.</def>

<q>'T is the <qex>infirmity</qex> of his age.</q>
<qau>Shak.</qau>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>A personal frailty or failing; foible;
eccentricity; a weakness or defect.</def>

<q>Will you be cured of your <qex>infirmity</qex> ?</q>
<qau>Shak.</qau>

<q>A friend should bear his friend's <qex>infirmities</qex>.</q>
<qau>Shak.</qau>

<q>The house has also its <qex>infirmities</qex>.</q>
<qau>Evelyn.</qau>

<syn>Syn. -- Debility; imbecility; weakness; feebleness; failing;
foible; defect; disease; malady. See <er>Debility</er>.</syn>

<hw>In*firm"ly</hw>, <pos>adv.</pos> <def>In an infirm
manner.</def>

<hw>In*firm"ness</hw>, <pos>n.</pos> <def>Infirmity;
feebleness.</def>

<au>Boyle.</au>

<hw>In*fix"</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>v. t.</pos>
<wordforms>[<pos>imp. & p. p.</pos> <er>Infixed</er>
<pr>(?)</pr>; <pos>p. pr. & vb. n.</pos>
<er>Infixing</er>.]</wordforms> <ety>[L. <ets>infixus</ets>, p.p
of <ets>infigere</ets> to infix; pref. <ets>in-</ets> in +
<ets>figere</ets> to fix: cf. F. <ets>infixer</ets>. See
<er>Fix</er>.]</ety> <sn>1.</sn> <def>To set; to fasten or fix by
piercing or thrusting in; <as>as, to <ex>infix</ex> a sting,
spear, or dart</as>.</def>

<au>Shak.</au>

<q>The fatal dart a ready passage found,
And deep within her heart <qex>infixed</qex> the wound.</q>
<qau>Dryden.</qau>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>To implant or fix; to instill; to inculcate, as
principles, thoughts, or instructions; <as>as, to <ex>infix</ex>
good principles in the mind, or ideas in the memory</as>.</def>

<hw>In"fix</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <def>Something
infixed.</def> <mark>[R.]</mark>

<au>Welsford.</au>

<hw>In*flame"</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>v. t.</pos>
<wordforms>[<pos>imp. & p. p.</pos> <er>Inflamed</er>
<pr>(?)</pr>; <pos>p. pr. & vb. n.</pos>
<er>Inflaming</er>.]</wordforms> <ety>[OE. <ets>enflamen</ets>,
OF. <ets>enflamer</ets>, F. <ets>enflammer</ets>, L.
<ets>inflammare</ets>,<ets>inflammatum</ets>; pref.<ets>in-</ets>
in + <ets>flammare</ets> to flame, fr.<ets>flamma</ets> flame.
See <er>Flame</er>.]</ety> <sn>1.</sn> <def>To set on fire; to
kindle; to cause to burn, flame, or glow.</def>

<q>We should have made retreat
By light of the <qex>inflamed</qex> fleet.</q>
<qau>Chapman.</qau>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>Fig.: To kindle or intensify, as passion or
appetite; to excite to an excessive or unnatural action or heat;
<as>as, to <ex>inflame</ex> desire</as>.</def>

<q>Though more,it seems,
<qex>Inflamed</qex> with lust than rage.</q>
<qau>Milton.</qau>

<q>But, O <qex>inflame</qex> and fire our hearts.</q>
<qau>Dryden.</qau>

<sn>3.</sn> <def>To provoke to anger or rage; to exasperate; to
irritate; to incense; to enrage.</def>

<q>It will <qex>inflame</qex> you; it will make you mad.</q>
<qau>Shak.</qau>

<sn>4.</sn> <fld>(Med.)</fld> <def>To put in a state of
inflammation; to produce morbid heat, congestion, or swelling,
of; <as>as, to <ex>inflame</ex> the eyes by overwork</as>.</def>

<sn>5.</sn> <def>To exaggerate; to enlarge upon.</def>
<mark>[Obs.]</mark>

<q> A friend exaggerates a man's virtues, an enemy
<qex>inflames</qex> his crimes.</q>
<qau>Addison.</qau>

<syn>Syn. -- To provoke; fire; kindle; irritate; exasperate;
incense; enrage; anger; excite; arouse.</syn>

<hw>In*flame"</hw>, <pos>v. i.</pos> <def>To grow morbidly hot,
congested, or painful; to become angry or incensed.</def>

<au>Wiseman.</au>

<hw>In*flamed"</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>p. a.</pos> <sn>1.</sn>
<def>Set on fire; enkindled; heated; congested; provoked;
exasperated.</def>

<sn>2.</sn> <fld>(Her.)</fld> <def>Represented as burning, or as
adorned with tongues of flame.</def>

<hw>In*flam"er</hw> <pr>(?n-fl\'bem\'b6?r)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos>
<def>The person or thing that inflames.</def>

<au>Addison.</au>

<hw>In*flam"ma*bil"l*ty</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos>
<ety>[Cf.F. <ets>inflammabilite</ets>.]</ety> <def>Susceptibility
of taking fire readily; the state or quality of being
inflammable.</def>

<hw>In*flam"ma*ble</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>a.</pos> <ety>[CF. F.
<ets>inflammable</ets>.]</ety> <sn>1.</sn> <def>Capable of being
easily set fire; easily enkindled; combustible; <as>as,
<ex>inflammable</ex> oils or spirits</as>.</def>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>Excitable; irritable; irascible; easily
provoked; <as>as, an <ex>inflammable</ex> temper</as>.</def>

<cs><col>Inflammable air</col>, <cd>the old chemical name for
hydrogen.</cd></cs>

<hw>In*flam"ma*ble*ness</hw>, <pos>n.</pos> <def>The quality or
state of being inflammable; inflammability.</def>

<au>Boyle.</au>

<hw>In*flam"mbly</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>adv.</pos> <def>In an
inflammable manner.</def>

<hw>In*flam*ma"tion</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[L.
<ets>inflammatio</ets>: cf. F. <ets>inflammation</ets>. See
<er>Inflame</er>.]</ety> <sn>1.</sn> <def>The act of inflaming,
kindling, or setting on fire; also, the state of being
inflamed.</def> \'bdThe <xex>inflammation</xex> of fat.\'b8

<au>Wilkins.</au>

<sn>2.</sn> <fld>(Med.)</fld> <def>A morbid condition of any part
of the body, consisting in congestion of the blood vessels, with
obstruction of the blood current, and growth of morbid tissue. It
is manifested outwardly by redness and swelling, attended with
heat and pain.</def>

<sn>3.</sn> <def>Violent excitement; heat; passion; animosity;
turbulence; <as>as, an <ex>inflammation</ex> of the mind, of the
body politic, or of parties</as>.</def>

<au>Hooker.</au>

<hw>In*flam"ma*tive</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>a.</pos>
<def>Inflammatory.</def>

<hw>In*flam"ma*to*ry</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>a.</pos> <ety>[Cf.
F. <ets>inflammatoire</ets>.]</ety> <sn>1.</sn> <def>Tending to
inflame, kindle, or irritate.</def>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>Tending to excite anger, animosity, tumult, or
sedition; seditious; <as>as, <ex>inflammatory</ex> libels,
writings, speeches, or publications</as>.</def>

<au>Burke.</au>

<sn>3.</sn> <fld>(Med.)</fld> <def>Accompanied with, or tending
to cause, preternatural heat and excitement of arterial action;
<as>as, an <ex>inflammatory</ex> disease</as>.</def>

<cs><col>Inflammatory crust</col>. <fld>(Med.)</fld> <cd>Same as
<cref>Buffy coat</cref>, under <er>Buffy</er>.</cd> --
<col>Inflammatory fever</col>, <cd>a variety of fever due to
inflammation.</cd></cs>

<hw>In*flat"a*ble</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>a.</pos> <def>That may
be inflated.</def>

<hw>In*flate"</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>p. a.</pos> <ety>[L.
<ets>inflatus</ets>, p.p. of <ets>inflare</ets> to inflate; pref.
<ets>in-</ets> in + <ets>flare</ets> to blow. See <er>Blow</er>
to puff wind.]</ety> <def>Blown in; inflated.</def>

<au>Chaucer.</au>

<hw>In*flate"</hw>, <pos>v. t.</pos> <wordforms>[<pos>imp. & p.
p.</pos> <er>Inflated</er>; <pos>p. pr. & vb. n.</pos>
<er>Inflating</er>.]</wordforms> <sn>1.</sn> <def>To swell or
distend with air or gas; to dilate; to expand; to enlarge;
<as>as, to <ex>inflate</ex> a bladder; to <ex>inflate</ex> the
lungs.</as></def>

<q>When passion's tumults in the bosom rise,
<qex>Inflate</qex> the features, and enrage the eyes.</q>
<qau>J. Scott of Amwell.</qau>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>Fig.: To swell; to puff up; to elate; <as>as, to
<ex>inflate</ex> one with pride or vanity</as>.</def>

<q><qex>Inflate</qex> themselves with some insane delight.</q>
<qau>Tennyson.</qau>

<sn>3.</sn> <def>To cause to become unduly expanded or increased;
<as>as, to <ex>inflate</ex> the currency</as>.</def>

<hw>In*flate"</hw>, <pos>v. i.</pos> <def>To expand; to fill; to
distend.</def>

<hw>In*flat"ed</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>a.</pos> <sn>1.</sn>
<def>Filled, as with air or gas; blown up; distended; <as>as, a
balloon <ex>inflated</ex> with gas</as>.</def>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>Turgid; swelling; puffed up; bombastic; pompous;
<as>as, an <ex>inflated</ex> style</as>.</def>

<q><qex>Inflated</qex> and astrut with self-conceit.</q>
<qau>Cowper.</qau>

<sn>3.</sn> <fld>(Bot.)</fld> <def>Hollow and distended, as a
perianth, corolla, nectary, or pericarp.</def>

<au>Martyn.</au>

<sn>4.</sn> <def>Distended or enlarged fictitiously; <as>as,
<ex>inflated</ex> prices, etc.</as></def>

<hw>In*flat"er</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <def>One who, or
that which, inflates; <as>as, the <ex>inflaters</ex> of the stock
exchange</as>.</def>

<hw>In*flat"ing*ly</hw>, <pos>adv.</pos> <def>In a manner tending
to inflate.</def>

<hw>In*fla"tion</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[L.
<ets>inflatio</ets>: cf. F. <ets>inflation</ets>.]</ety>
<sn>1.</sn> <def>The act or process of inflating, or the state of
being inflated, as with air or gas; distention; expansion;
enlargement.</def>

<au>Boyle.</au>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>The state of being puffed up, as with pride;
conceit; vanity.</def>

<au>B. Jonson.</au>

<sn>3.</sn> <def>Undue expansion or increase, from overissue; --
said of currency.</def> <mark>[U.S.]</mark>

<hw>In*fla"tion*ist</hw>, <pos>n.</pos> <def>One who favors an
increased or very large issue of paper money.</def>
<mark>[U.S.]</mark>

<hw>\'d8In*fla"tus</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[L. See
<er>Inflate</er>, <pos>v. t.</pos>]</ety> <def>A blowing or
breathing into; inflation; inspiration.</def>

<q>The divine breath that blows the nostrils out
To ineffable <qex>inflatus</qex>.</q>
<qau>Mrs. Browning.</qau>

<hw>In*flect"</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>v. t.</pos>
<wordforms>[<pos>imp. & p. p.</pos> <er>Inflected</er>; <pos>p.
pr. & vb. n.</pos> <er>Inflecting</er>.]</wordforms> <ety>[L.
<ets>inflectere</ets>, <ets>inflexum</ets>; pref. <ets>in</ets>.-
in + <ets>flectere</ets> to bend. See <er>Flexibl</er>, and cf.
<er>Inflex</er>.]</ety> <sn>1.</sn> <def>To turn from a direct
line or course; to bend; to incline, to deflect; to curve; to
bow.</def>

<q>Are they [the rays of the sun] not reflected, refracted, and
<qex>inflected</qex> by one and the same principle ?</q>
<qau>Sir I. Newton.</qau>

<sn>2.</sn> <fld>(Gram.)</fld> <def>To vary, as a noun or a verb
in its terminations; to decline, as a noun or adjective, or to
conjugate, as a verb.</def>

<sn>3.</sn> <def>To modulate, as the voice.</def>

<hw>In*flect"ed</hw>, <pos>a.</pos> <sn>1.</sn> <def>Bent;
turned; deflected.</def>

<sn>2.</sn> <fld>(Gram.)</fld> <def>Having inflections; capable
of, or subject to, inflection; inflective.</def>

<cs><col>Inflected cycloid</col> <fld>(Geom.)</fld>, <cd>a
prolate cycloid. See <er>Cycloid</er>.</cd></cs>

<hw>In*flec"tion</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[L.
<ets>inflexio</ets> : cf. F. <ets>inflexion</ets>. See
<er>Inflect</er>.]</ety> <altsp>[Written also
<asp>inflecxion</asp>.]</altsp> <sn>1.</sn> <def>The act of
inflecting, or the state of being inflected.</def>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>A bend; a fold; a curve; a turn; a twist.</def>

<sn>3.</sn> <def>A slide, modulation, or accent of the voice;
<as>as, the rising and the falling
<ex>inflection</ex></as>.</def>

<sn>4.</sn> <fld>(Gram.)</fld> <def>The variation or change which
words undergo to mark case, gender, number, comparison, tense,
person, mood, voice, etc.</def>

<sn>5.</sn> <fld>(Mus.)</fld> <sd>(a)</sd> <def>Any change or
modification in the pitch or tone of the voice.</def>
<sd>(b)</sd> <def>A departure from the monotone, or reciting
note, in chanting.</def>

<sn>6.</sn> <fld>(Opt.)</fld> <def>Same as
<er>Diffraction</er>.</def>

<cs><col>Point of inflection</col> <fld>(Geom.)</fld>, <cd>the
point on opposite sides of which a curve bends in contrary
ways.</cd></cs>

<hw>In*flec"tion*al</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>a.</pos> <def>Of or
pertaining to inflection; having, or characterized by,
inflection.</def>

<au>Max M\'81ller.</au>

<hw>In*flect"ive</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>a.</pos> <sn>1.</sn>
<def>Capable of, or pertaining to, inflection; deflecting;
<as>as, the <ex>inflective</ex> quality of the air</as>.</def>

<au>Derham.</au>

<sn>2.</sn> <fld>(Gram.)</fld> <def>Inflectional; characterized
by variation, or change in form, to mark case, tense, etc.;
subject to inflection.</def>

<cs><col>Inflective language</col> <fld>(Philol.)</fld>, <cd>a
language like the Greek or Latin, consisting largely of stems
with variable terminations or suffixes which were once
independent words. English is both agglutinative, as,
<xex>manlike<xex>, <xex>headache<xex>, and inflective, as,
<xex>he<xex>, <xex>his<xex>, <xex>him<xex>. Cf.
<er>Agglutinative</er>.</cd></cs>

incarnate.</def>

<hw>In*flexed"</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>a.</pos> <sn>1.</sn>

<sn>2.</sn> <fld>(Bot.)</fld> <def>Bent or turned abruptly

<hw>In*flex"i*bil"i*ty</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[Cf.
F. <ets>inflexibilit\'82</ets>.]</ety> <def>The quality or state
of being inflexible, or not capable of being bent or changed;
unyielding stiffness; inflexibleness; rigidity; firmness of will
or purpose; unbending pertinacity; steadfastness; resoluteness;
unchangeableness; obstinacy.</def>

<q>The <qex>inflexibility</qex> of mechanism.</q>
<qau>A. Baxter.</qau>

<q>That grave <qex>inflexibility</qex> of soul.</q>
<qau>Churchill.</qau>

<q>The purity and <qex>inflexibility</qex> of their faith.</q>
<qau>T. Warton.</qau>

<hw>In*flex"i*ble</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>a.</pos> <ety>[L.
<ets>inflexiblis</ets>: cf. F. <ets>inflexible</ets>. See
<er>In-</er> not, and <er>Flexible</er>.]</ety> <sn>1.</sn>
<def>Not capable of being bent; stiff; rigid; firm;
unyielding.</def>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>Firm in will or purpose; not to be turned,
changed, or altered; resolute; determined; unyieding; inexorable;
stubborn.</def>

<q>\'bd<qex>Inflexible</qex>as steel.\'b8</q>
<qau>Miltom.</qau>

<q>Amanof upright and <qex>inflexible</qex>temper . . . can
overcome all private fear.</q>
<qau>Addison.</qau>

<sn>3.</sn> <def>Incapable of change; unalterable;
immutable.</def>

<q>The nature of things is <qex>inflexible</qex>.</q>
<qau>I. Watts.</qau>

<syn>Syn. -- -- Unbending; unyielding; rigid; inexorable;
pertinacious; obstinate; stubborn; unrelenting.</syn>

<hw>In*flict"</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>v. t.</pos>
<wordforms>[<pos>imp. & p. p.</pos> <er>Inflicted</er>; <pos>p.
pr. & vb. n.</pos> <er>Inflicting</er>.]</wordforms> <ety>[L.
<ets>inflictus</ets>, p.p. of <ets>infligere</ets> to strike on,
to inflict; pref. <ets>in-</ets> in, on + <ets>fligere</ets> to
strike. Cf. <er>Flail</er>.]</ety> <def>To give, cause, or
produce by striking, or as if by striking; to apply forcibly; to
lay or impose; to send; to cause to bear, feel, or suffer;
<as>as, to <ex>inflict</ex> blows; to <ex>inflict</ex> a wound
with a dagger; to <ex>inflict</ex> severe pain by ingratitude; to
<ex>inflict</ex> punishment on an offender; to <ex>inflict</ex>
the penalty of death on a criminal.</as></def>

<q>What heart could wish, what hand <qex>inflict</qex>, this dire
disgrace?</q>
<qau>Drygen.</qau>

<q>The persecution and the pain
That man <qex>inflicts</qex> on infero-ior kinds.</q>
<qau>Cowper.</qau>

<hw>In*flic"tion</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[L.
<ets>inflictio</ets>: cf. F. <ets>infliction</ets>.]</ety>
<sn>1.</sn> <def>The act of inflicting or imposing; <as>as, the
<ex>infliction</ex> of torment, or of punishment</as>.</def>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>That which is inflicted or imposed, as
punishment, disgrace, calamity, etc.</def>

<q>His severest <qex>inflictions</qex> are in themselves acts of
justice and righteousness.</q>
<qau>Rogers.</qau>

<au>Whitehead.</au>

<hw>In`flo*res"cence</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[L.
<ets>inflorescens</ets>, p.pr. of <ets>inflorescere</ets> to
begin to blossom; pref. <ets>in-</ets> in + <ets>florescere</ets>
to begin to blossom: cf.F. <ets>inflorescence</ets>. See
<er>Florescent</er>.]</ety> <sn>1.</sn> <def>A flowering; the
putting forth and unfolding of blossoms.</def>

<sn>2.</sn> <fld>(Bot.)</fld> <sd>(a)</sd> <def>The mode of
flowering, or the general arrangement and disposition of the
flowers with reference to the axis, and to each other.</def>
<sd>(b)</sd> <def>An axis on which all the flower buds.</def>

<q><qex>Inflorescence</qex> affords an excellent characteristic
mark in distinguishing the species of plants.</q>
<qau>Milne.</qau>

<cs><col>Centrifugal inflorescence</col>, <cd>determinate
inflorescence.</cd> -- <col>Centripetal inflorescence</col>,
<cd>indeterminate inflorescence. See under <er>Determinate</er>,
and <er>Indeterminate</er>.</cd></cs>

<hw>In"flu*ence</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[F.
<ets>influence</ets>, fr. L. <ets>influens</ets>,
-<ets>entis</ets>, p.pr. See <er>Influent</er>, and cf.
<er>Influenza</er>.]</ety> <sn>1.</sn> <def>A flowing in or upon;
influx.</def> <mark>[Obs.]</mark>

<q>God hath his <qex>influence</qex> into the very essence of all
things.</q>
<qau>Hooker.</qau>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>Hence, in general, the bringing about of an
effect, phusical or moral, by a gradual process; controlling
power quietly exerted; agency, force, or tendency of any kind
which the sun exerts on animal and vegetable life; the
<xex>influence</xex> of education on the mind; the
<xex>influence</xex>, according to astrologers,of the stars over
affairs.</def>

<q>Astrologers call the evil <qex>influences</qex> of the
stars,evil aspects.</q>
<qau>Bacon.</qau>

<q>Cantsthou bind the sweet <qex>influences</qex> of Pleiades, or
loose the bands of Orion ?</q>
<qau>Job xxxviii. 31.</qau>

<q>She said : <?/Ah,dearest lord ! what evil star
On you hath frown'd,and poured, his <qex>influence</qex> bad
?\'b8</q>
<qau>Spenser.</qau>

<sn>3.</sn> <def>Power or authority arising from elevated
station, excelence of character or intellect, wealth, etc.;
reputation; acknowledged ascendency; <as>as, he is a man of
<ex>influence</ex> in the community</as>.</def>

<q>Such <qex>influence</qex> hath your excellency.</q>
<qau>Sir P. Sidney.</qau>

<sn>4.</sn> <fld>(Elec.)</fld> <def>Induction.</def>

<syn>Syn. -- Control; persuasion; ascendency; sway; power;
authority; supremacy; mastery; management; restraint; character;
reputation; prestige.</syn>

<hw>In"flu*ence</hw>, <pos>v. t.</pos> <wordforms>[<pos>imp. & p.
p.</pos> <er>Influenced</er> <pr>(?)</pr>; <pos>p. pr. & vb.
n.</pos> <er>Influencing</er> <pr>(?)</pr>.]</wordforms> <def>To
control or move by power, physical or moral; to affect by gentle
action; to exert an influence upon; to modify, bias, or sway; to
move; to persuade; to induce.</def>

<q>Theseexperiments succeed after the same manner in vacuo as in
the open air,and therefore are not <qex>influenced</qex> by the
weight or pressure of the atmosphere.</q>
<qau>Sir I. Newton.</qau>

<q>This standing revelation . . . is sufficient to
<qex>influence</qex> their faith and practice, if they
attend.</q>
<qau>Attebury.</qau>

<q>The principle which <qex>influenced</qex> their obedience has
lost its efficacy.</q>
<qau>Rogers.</qau>

<hw>In`flu*en"za</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[It.
<ets>influenza</ets> influence, an epidemic formerly attributed

influenza. See <er>Influence</er>.]</ety> <fld>(Med.)</fld>
<def>An epidemic affection characterized by acute nasal catarrh,
or by inflammation of the throat or the bronchi, and usually
accompanied by fever.</def>

<hw>In"flux`</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[L.

<er>Influent</er>.]</ety> <sn>1.</sn> <def>The act of flowing in;
<as>as, an <ex>influx</ex> of light</as>.</def>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>A coming in; infusion; intromission;
introduction; importation in abundance; also, that which flows or
comes in; <as>as, a great <ex>influx</ex> of goods into a
country, or an <ex>influx</ex> of gold and silver</as>.</def>

<q>The <qex>influx</qex> of food into the Celtic region, however,
was far from keeping pace with the <qex>influx</qex> of
consumers.</q>
<qau>Macaulau.</qau>

<q>The general <qex>influx</qex> of Greek into modern
languages.</q>
<qau>Earle.</qau>

<au>Sir M. Hale.</au>

<hw>In*fold"</hw> <pr>(?n-f?ld\'b6)</pr>, <pos>v. t.</pos>

<hw>In*form"</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>a.</pos> <ety>[L.
<ets>informis</ets>; pref. <ets>in-</ets> not + <ets>forma</ets>
form, shape: cf. F. <ets>informe</ets>]</ety> <def>Without

<au>Cotton.</au>

<hw>In*form"</hw>, <pos>v. t.</pos>   <wordforms>[<pos>imp. & p.
p.</pos> <er>Informed</er> <pr>(?)</pr>; <pos>p. pr. & vb.
n.</pos> <er>Informing</er>.]</wordforms> <ety>[OE.
<ets>enformen</ets>, OF. <ets>enformer</ets>, F.
<ets>informer</ets>. L. <ets>informare</ets>; pref.
<ets>in-</ets> in + <ets>formare</ets> to form, share, fr.
<ets>forma</ets> form. See <er>Form</er>.]</ety> <sn>1.</sn>
<def>To give form or share to; to give vital ororganizing power
to; to give life to; to imbue and actuate with vitality; to
animate; to mold; to figure; to fashion.</def>

<q>\'bdThe <qex>informing</qex> Word.\'b8</q>
<qau>Coleridge.</qau>

<q>Let others better mold the running mass
Of metals, and <qex>inform</qex> the breathing brass.</q>
<qau>Dryden.</qau>

<q>Breath <qex>informs</qex> this fleeting frame.</q>
<qau>Prior.</qau>

<q>Breathes in our soul,<qex>informs</qex> our mortal part.</q>
<qau>Pope.</qau>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>To communicate knowledge to; to make known to;
to acquaint; to advise; to instruct; to tell; to notify; to
enlighten; -- usually followed by <xex>of</xex>.</def>

<q>For he would learn their business secretly,
And then <qex>inform</qex> his master hastily.</q>
<qau>Spenser.</qau>

<q>I am <qex>informed</qex> thoroughky of the cause.</q>
<qau>Shak.</qau>

<sn>3.</sn> <def>To communicate a knowledge of facts to,by way of
accusation; to warn against anybody.</def>

<q>Tertullus . . . <qex>informed</qex> the governor against
Paul.</q>
<qau>Acts xxiv. 1.</qau>

<syn>Syn. -- To acquaint; apprise; tell; teach; instruct;
enlighten; animate; fashion.</syn>

<hw>In*form"</hw>, <pos>v. t.</pos> <sn>1.</sn> <def>To take
form; to become visible or manifest; to appear.</def>
<mark>[Obs.]</mark>

<q>It is the bloody business which <qex>informs</qex>
Thus to mine eyes.</q>
<qau>Shak.</qau>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>To give intelligence or information; to
tell.</def>

<au>Shak.</au>

<q>He might either teach in the same manner,or <qex>inform</qex>
how he had been taught.</q>
<qau>Monthly Rev.</qau>

<cs><col>To inform against</col>, <cd>to communicate facts by way
of accusation against; to denounce; as, two persons came to the
magistrate, and <xex>informed against<xex> A.</cd></cs>

<hw>In*form"al</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>a.</pos> <ety>[Pref.
<ets>in-</ets> not + <ets>formal</ets>.]</ety> <sn>1.</sn>
<def>Not in the regular, usual, or established form; not
according to official, conventional, prescribed, or customary
forms or rules; irregular; hence, without ceremony; <as>as, an
<ex>informal</ex> writting, proceeding, or visit</as>.</def>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>Deranged in mind; out of one's senses.</def>
<mark>[Obs.]</mark>

<q>These poor <qex>informal</qex> women.</q>
<qau>Shak.</qau>

<hw>In`for*mal"i*ty</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos>; <plu>pl.
<plw>Informalities</plw> <pr>(<?/)</pr>.</plu> <sn>1.</sn>
<def>The state of being informal; want of regular, prescribed, or
customary form; <as>as, the <ex>informality</ex> of legal
proceedings</as>.</def>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>An informal, unconventional, or unofficial act
or proceeding; something which is not in proper or prescribed
form or does not conform to the established rule.</def>

<hw>In*form"al*ly</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>adv.</pos> <def>In an
informal manner.</def>

<hw>In*form"ant</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[L.
<ets>informans</ets>, <ets>-antis</ets>, p.pr. of
<ets>informare</ets>. See <er>Inform</er>, <pos>v.
t.</pos>]</ety> <sn>1.</sn> <def>One who, or that which, informs,
animates, or vivifies.</def> <mark>[Obs.]</mark>

<au>Glanvill.</au>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>One who imparts information or
instruction.</def>

<sn>3.</sn> <def>One who offers an accusation; an informer. See
<er>Informer</er>.</def> <mark>[Obs. or R.]</mark>

<q>It was the last evidence of the kind; the <qex>informant</qex>
was hanged.</q>
<qau>Burke.</qau>

<hw>In`for*ma"tion</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[F., fr.
L. <ets>informatio</ets> representation, cinception. See
<er>Inform</er>, <pos>v. t.</pos>]</ety> <sn>1.</sn> <def>The act
of informing, or communicating knowledge or intelligence.</def>

<q>The active <qex>informations</qex> of the intellect.</q>
<qau>South.</qau>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>News, advice, or knowledge, communicated by
others or obtained by personal study and investigation;
intelligence; knowledge derived from reading, observation, or
instruction.</def>

<q>Larger opportunities of <qex>information</qex>.</q>
<qau>Rogers.</qau>

<q>He should get some <qex>information</qex> in the subject he
intends
to handle.</q>
<qau>Swift.</qau>

<sn>3.</sn> <fld>(Law)</fld> <def>A proceeding in the nature of a
prosecution for some offens against the government, instituted
and prosecuted, really or nominally, by some authorized public
officer on behalt of the government. It differs from an
indictment in criminal cases chiefly in not being based on the
finding of a grand juri. See <er>Indictment</er>.</def>

<hw>In*form"a*tive</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>a.</pos> <def>Having
power to inform, animate, or vivify.</def>

<au>Dr. H. More.</au>

<hw>In*form"a*to*ry</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>a.</pos> <def>Full
of, or conveying, information; instructive.</def>
<mark>[R.]</mark>

<au>London Spectator.</au>

<def>Unformed or ill-formed; deformed; shapeless.</def>

<au>Spenser.</au>

<cs><col>Informed stars</col>. <cd>See under
<er>Unformed</er>.</cd></cs>

<au>Thomson.</au>

<q>Nature, <qex>informer</qex> of the poet's art.</q>
<qau>Pope.</qau>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>One who informs, or imparts knowledge or
news.</def>

<sn>3.</sn> <fld>(Law)</fld> <def>One who informs a magistrate of
violations of law; one who informs against another for violation
of some law or penal statute.</def>

<cs><col>Common informer</col> <fld>(Law)</fld>, <cd>one who
habitually gives information of the violation of penal statutes,
with a view to a prosecution therefor.</cd>  <au>Bouvier.
Wharton.</au></cs>

<hw>In`fra*lap*sa"ri*an</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos>
<ety>[<ets>Infra</ets> + <ets>lapse</ets>: cf. F.
<ets>infralapsaire.</ets> See</pos> <er>Lapse</er>.]</ety>
<fld>(Eccl. Hist.)</fld> <def>One of that class of Calvinists who
consider the decree of election as contemplating the apostasy as
past and the elect as being at the time of election in a fallen
and guilty state; -- opposed to <xex>Supralapsarian</xex>.  The
former considered the election of grace as a remedy for an
existing evil; the latter regarded the fall as a part of God's
original purpose in regard to men.</def>

doctrine.</def>

<hw>In*fringe"</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>v. t.</pos>
<wordforms>[<pos>imp. & p. p.</pos> <er>Infringed</er>
<pr>(?)</pr>; <pos>p. pr. & vb. n.</pos> <er>Infringing</er>
<pr>(?)</pr>.]</wordforms> <ety>[L. <ets>infringere</ets>; pref.
<ets>in-</ets> in + <ets>frangere</ets> to break. See
<er>Fraction</er>, and cf. <er>Infract</er> .]</ety> <sn>1.</sn>
<def>To break; to violate; to transgress; to neglect to fulfill
or obey; <as>as, to <ex>infringe</ex> a law or
contract</as>.</def>

<q>If the first that did the edict <qex>infringe</qex>,
Had answered for his deed.</q>
<qau>Shak.</qau>

<q>The peace . . . was <qex>infringed</qex> by Appius
Claudius.</q>
<qau>Golding.</qau>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>To hinder; to destroy; <as>as, to
<ex>infringe</ex> efficacy; to <ex>infringe</ex> delight or
power.</as></def> <mark>[Obs.]</mark>

<au>Hooker.</au>

<hw>In*fringe"</hw>, <pos>v. i.</pos> <sn>1.</sn> <def>To break,
violate, or transgress some contract, rule, or law; to injure; to
offend.</def>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>To encroach; to trespass; -- followed by
<xex>on</xex> or <xex>upon</xex>; <as>as, to <ex>infringe</ex>
upon the rights of another</as>.</def>

<hw>In*fringe"ment</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <sn>1.</sn>
<def>The act of infringing; breach; violation; nonfulfillment;
<as>as, the <ex>infringement</ex> of a treaty, compact, law, or
constitution</as>.</def>

<q>The punishing of this <qex>infringement</qex> is proper to
that
jurisdiction against which the contempt is.</q>
<qau>Clarendon.</qau>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>An encroachment on a patent, copyright, or other
special privilege; a trespass.</def>

<hw>In*frin"ger</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <def>One who
infringes or violates; a violator.</def>

<au>Strype.</au>

<mhw>{ <hw>In`fun*dib"u*lar</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>,
<hw>In`fun*dib"u*late</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, }</mhw> <pos>a.</pos>
<ety>[See <er>Infundibulum</er>.]</ety> <def>Having the form of a
funnel; pertaining to an infundibulum.</def>

<cs><col>Infundibulate Bryozoa</col> <fld>(Zo\'94l.)</fld>,<cd>a
group of marine Bryozoa having a circular arrangement of the
tentacles upon the disk.</cd></cs>

<hw>In`fun*dib"u*li*form</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>a.</pos>
<ety>[L. <ets>infundibulum</ets> funnel + <ets>-form</ets>: cf.
F. <ets>infundibuliforme</ets>.]</ety> <sn>1.</sn> <def>Having
the form of a funnel or cone; funnel-shaped.</def>

<sn>2.</sn> <fld>(Bot.)</fld> <def>Same as
<er>Funnelform</er>.</def>

<hw>\'d8In`fun*dib"u*lum</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos>;
<plu>pl. L. <plw>Infundibula</plw> <pr>(#)</pr>, E.
<plw>Infundibulums</plw> <pr>(#)</pr></plu>. <ety>[L., a funnel,
from <ets>infundere</ets> to pour in or into. See
<er>Infuse</er>.]</ety> <sn>1.</sn> <fld>(Anat.)</fld> <def>A
funnel-shaped or dilated organ or part; <as>as, the
<ex>infundibulum</ex> of the brain, a hollow, conical process,
connecting the floor of the third ventricle with the pituitary
body; the <ex>infundibula</ex> of the lungs, the enlarged
terminations of the bronchial tubes.</as></def>

<sn>2.</sn> <fld>(Zo\'94l.)</fld> <sd>(a)</sd> <def>A central
cavity in the Ctenophora, into which the gastric sac leads.</def>
<sd>(b)</sd> <def>The siphon of Cephalopoda. See
<er>Cephalopoda</er>.</def>

<hw>In*fu"ner*al</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>v. t.</pos> <def>To
inter with funeral rites; to bury.</def> <mark>[Obs.]</mark>

<au>G. Fletcher.</au>

<hw>In`fur*ca"tion</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[Pref.
<ets>in-</ets> in + L. <ets>furca</ets> fork.]</ety> <def>A
forked exlpansion or divergence; a bifurcation; a
branching.</def>

<au>Craig.</au>

<hw>In*fuse"</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>v. t.</pos>
<wordforms>[<pos>imp. & p. p.</pos> <er>Infused</er>
<pr>(?)</pr>; <pos>p. pr. & vb. n.</pos>
<er>Infusing</er>.]</wordforms> <ety>[L. <ets>infusus</ets>, p.p.
of <ets>infundere</ets> to pour in or into; pref. <ets>in-</ets>
in + <ets>fundere</ets> to pour: cf. F. <ets>infuser</ets>. See
<er>Found</er> to cast.]</ety> <sn>1.</sn> <def>To pour in, as a
liquid; to pour (into or upon); to shed.</def>

<q>That strong Circean liquor cease to <qex>infuse</qex>.</q>
<qau>Denham.</qau>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>To instill, as principles or qualities; to
introduce.</def>

<q>That souls of animals <qex>infuse</qex> themselves Into the
trunks of men.</q>
<qau>Shak.</qau>

<q>Why should he desire to have qualities <qex>infused</qex> into
his son which himself never possessd?</q>
<qau>Swift.</qau>

<sn>3.</sn> <def>To inspire; to inspirit or animate; to fill; --
followed by <xex>with</xex>.</def>

<q><qex>Infuse</qex> his breast with magnanimity.</q>
<qau>Shak.</qau>

<q><qex>Infusing</qex> him with self and vain conceit.</q>
<qau>Shak.</qau>

<sn>4.</sn> <def>To steep in water or other fluid without
boiling, for the propose of extracting medicinal qualities; to
soak.</def>

<q>One scruple of dried leaves is <qex>infused</qex> in ten
ounces of warm water.</q>
<qau>Coxe.</qau>

<sn>5.</sn> <def>To make an infusion with, as an ingredient; to
tincture; to saturate.</def> <mark>[R.]</mark>

<au>Bacon.</au>

<hw>In*fu"sion</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[L.

immersion.</def> <mark>[Obs.]</mark> \'bdBaptism by
<xex>infusion</xex>.\'b8

<au>Jortin.</au>

<sn>4.</sn> <fld>(Pharmacy)</fld> <sd>(a)</sd> <def>The act or

<hw>In*fu"sion*ism</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <def>The

into it at conception or birth; -- opposed to
<xex>tradicianism</xex> and <xex>creationism</xex>.</def>

<hw>In*fu"sive</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>a.</pos> <def>Having the

<hw>\'d8In`fu*so"ri*a</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n. pl.</pos>
<ety>[NL.; -- so called because found in infusions which are left
exposed to the air for a time. See <er>Infuse</er>.]</ety>
<fld>(Zo\'94l.)</fld> <def>One of the classes of Protozoa,
including a large number of species, all of minute size.</def>

<note><hand/ They are found in all seas, lakes, ponds, and
streams, as well as in infusions of organic matter exposed to the
air. They are distinguished by having vibrating lashes or cilia,
with which they obtain their food and swim about.They are devided
into the orders Flagellata, Ciliata, and Tentaculifera. See these
words in the Vocabulary.

   Formely the term <xex>Infusoria</xex> was applied to all
microscopic organisms found in water, including many minute
plants, belonging to the diatoms, as well as minute animals
belonging to various classes, as the Rotifera, which are worms;
and the Rhizopoda, which constitute a distinct class of Protozoa.
Fossil Infusoria are mostly the siliceous shells of diatoms;
sometimes they are siliceous skeletons of Radiolaria, or the
calcareous shells of Foraminifera.</note>

<hw>In`fu*so"ri*al</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>a.</pos>
<fld>(Zo\'94l.)</fld> <def>Belonging to the Infusoria; composed
of, or containing, Infusoria; <as>as, <ex>infusorial</ex>
earth</as>.</def>

<cs><col>Infusorial earth</col> <fld>(Geol.)</fld>, <cd>a deposit
of fine, usually white, siliceous material, composed mainly of
the shells of the microscopic plants called <xex>diatoms<xex>. It
is used in polishing powder, and in the manufacture of
dynamite.</cd></cs><-- = kieselguhr -->

<hw>In`fu*so"ri*an</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos>
<fld>(Zo\'94l.)</fld> <def>One of the Infusoria.</def>

<hw>In*fu"so*ry</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>a.</pos>
<fld>(Zo\'94l.)</fld> <def>Infusorial.</def>

<hw>In*fu"so*ry</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos>; <plu>pl.
<plw>Infusories</plw> <pr>(<?/)</pr>.</plu> <fld>(Zo\'94l.)</fld>
<def>One of the Infusoria; -- usually in the
<pluf>pl.</pluf></def>

<hw>-ing</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>. <sn>1.</sn> <ety>[For OE.
-<ets>and</ets>, -<ets>end</ets>, -<ets>ind</ets>, AS.
-<ets>ende</ets>; akin to Goth. -<ets>and-</ets>, L.
-<ets>ant-</ets>, -<ets>ent-</ets>, Gr. <?/.]</ety> <def>A suffix
used to from present participles; <as>as, sing<ex>ing</ex>,
play<ex>ing</ex></as>.</def>

<sn>2.</sn> <ety>[OE. -<ets>ing</ets>, AS. -<ets>ing</ets>,
-<ets>ung</ets>.]</ety> <def>A suffix used to form nouns from
verbs, and signifying the act of; the result of the act; <as>as,
rid<ex>ing</ex>, dy<ex>ing</ex>, feel<ex>ing</ex></as>. It has
also a secondary collective force; <as>as, shipp<ex>ing</ex>,
cloth<ex>ing</ex></as>.</def>

<note><hand/ The Old English ending of the present participle and
verbal noun became confused, both becoming
<xex>-ing</xex>.</note>

<sn>3.</sn> <ety>[AS. <ets>-ing</ets>.]</ety> <def>A suffix
formerly used to form diminutives; <as>as, lord<ex>ing</ex>,
farth<ex>ing</ex></as>.</def>

<hw>In*ge`ni*os"i*ty</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[LL.

<hw>In*gen"ious</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>a.</pos> <ety>[L.
<ets>ingeniosus</ets>, fr. <ets>ingenium</ets> innate or natural
quality, natural capacity, genius: cf. F.
<ets>ing\'82nieux</ets>. See <er>Engine</er>.]</ety> <sn>1.</sn>
<def>Possessed of genius, or the faculty of invention; skillful
or promp to invent; having an aptitude to contrive, or to form
new combinations; <as>as, an <ex>ingenious</ex> author,
mechanic</as>.</def>

<q>A man . . . very wise and <qex>ingenious</qex> in feats of
war.</q>
<qau>Hakluyt.</qau>

<q>Thou, king, send out
For torturers <qex>ingenious</qex>.</q>
<qau>Shak.</qau>

<q>The more <qex>ingenious</qex> men are, the more apt are they
to trouble themselves.</q>
<qau>Sir W. Temple.</qau>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>Proseeding from, pertaining to, or characterized
by, genius or ingenuity; of curious design, structure, or
mechanism; <as>as, an <ex>ingenious</ex> model, or machine; an
<ex>ingenious</ex> scheme, contrivance, etc.</as></def>

<q>Thus men go wrong with an <qex>ingenious</qex> skill.</q>
<qau>Cowper.</qau>

<sn>3.</sn> <def>Witty; shrewd; adroit; keen; sagacious; <as>as,
an <ex>ingenious</ex> reply</as>.</def>

<sn>4.</sn> <def>Mental; intellectual.</def> <mark>[Obs.]</mark>

<q>A course of learning and <qex>ingenious</qex> studies.</q>
<qau>Shak.</qau>

<hw>In*gen"ious*ly</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>adv.</pos> <def>In an
ingenious manner; with ingenuity; skillfully; wittily;
cleverly.</def>

<q>\'bdToo <qex>ingeniously</qex> politic.\'b8</q>
<qau>Sir W. Temple.</qau>

<hw>In*gen"ious*ness</hw>, <pos>n.</pos> <def>The quality or
state of being ingenious; ingenuity.</def>

<mhw>{ <hw>In*gen"ite In*gen"it</hw> }</mhw> <pr>(?)</pr>,
<pos>a.</pos> <ety>[L. <ets>ingenitus</ets>, p. p. of
<ets>ingignere</ets> to instill by birthor nature; pref.
<ets>in-</ets> + <ets>gignere</ets> to beget.]</ety> <def>Innate;
inborn; inbred; inherent; native; ingenerate.</def>
<mark>[Obs.]</mark>

<q>It is naturalor <qex>ingenite</qex>, which comes by some
defect of the organs and overmuch brain.</q>
<qau>Burton.</qau>

<hw>In`ge*nu"i*ty</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[L.
<ets>ingenuitas</ets> ingenuousness: cf. F.
<ets>ing\'82nuit\'82</ets>. See <er>Ingenuous</er>.]</ety>
<sn>1.</sn> <def>The quality or power of ready invention;
quickness or acuteness in forming new combinations;
ingeniousness; skill in devising or combining.</def>

<q>All the means which human <qex>ingenuity</qex> has
contrived.</q>
<qau>Blair.</qau>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>Curiousness, or cleverness in design or
contrivance; <as>as, the ingenuity of a plan, or of
mechanism</as>.</def>

<q>He gives . . . 
To artist <qex>ingenuity</qex> and skill.</q>
<qau>Cowper.</qau>

<sn>3.</sn> <def>Openness of heat; ingeniuousness.</def>
<mark>[Obs.]</mark>

<q>The stings and remores of natural <qex>ingenuity</qex>, a
principle that men scarcely ever shake off, as long as they carry
anything of human nature about them.</q>
<qau>South.</qau>

<syn>Syn. -- Inventiveness; ingeniousness; skill; cunning;
cleverness; genius.</syn> <usage> -- <er>Ingenuity</er>,
<er>Cleverness</er>. <xex>Ingenuity</xex> is a form of genius,
and <xex>cleverness</xex> of talent. The former implies
invention, the letter a peculiar dexterity and readiness of
execution. Sir James Mackintosh remarks that the English overdo
in the use of the word <xex>clever</xex> and
<xex>cleverness</xex>, applying them loosely to almost every form
of intellectual ability.</usage>

<hw>In*gen"u*ous</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>a.</pos> <ety>[L.
<ets>ingenuus</ets> inborn, innate, freeborn, noble, frank; pref.
<ets>in-</ets> in + the root of <ets>gignere</ets> to beget. See
<er>Genius</er>, and cf. <er>Ingenious</er>.]</ety> <sn>1.</sn>
<def>Of honorable extraction; freeborn; noble; <as>as,
<ex>ingenuous</ex> blood of birth</as>.</def>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>Noble; generous; magnanimous; honorable;
uprigth; high-minded; <as>as, an <ex>ingenuous</ex> ardor or
zeal</as>.</def>

<q>If an <qex>ingenuous</qex> detestation of falsehood be but
carefully and early instilled, that is the true and genuin method
to obviate dishonesty.</q>
<qau>Locke.</qau>

<sn>3.</sn> <def>Free from reserve, disguise, equivocation, or
dissimulation; open; frank; sa, an <xex>ingenuous</xex> man; an
<xex>ingenuous</xex> declaration, confession, etc.</def>

<q>Sensible in myself . . . what a burden it is for me, who would
be <qex>ingenuous</qex>, to be loaded with courtesies which he
hath not the least hope to requite or deserve.</q>
<qau>Fuller.</qau>

<sn>4.</sn> <def>Ingenious.</def> <mark>[Obs.]</mark>

<au>Shak.</au>

<note><hand/ (Formerly) printers did not discriminate between . .
. <xex>ingenuous</xex> and <xex>ingenious</xex>, and these words
were used or rather printed interchangeably almost to the
begining of the eighteenth century.</note>

<au>G. P. Marsh.</au>

<syn>Syn. -- Open; frank; unreserved; artless; plain; sincere;
candid; fair; noble; generous.</syn> <usage> --
<er>Ingenuous</er>, <er>Open</er>, <er>Frank</er>. One who is
<xex>open</xex> speaks out at once what is uppermost in his mind;
one who is <xex>frank</xex> does it from a natural boldness, or
dislike of self-restraint; one who is <xex>ingenuous</xex> is
actuated by a native simplicity and artlessness, which make him
willing to confess faults, and make known his sentiments without
reserve. See <er>Candid</er>.</usage>

<hw>In*gen"u*ous*ly</hw>, <pos>adv.</pos> <def>In an ingenuous
manner; openly; fairly; candidly; artlessly.</def>

<q>Being required to explane himself, he <qex>ingeniously</qex>
confessed.</q>
<qau>Ludlow.</qau>

<hw>In*gen"u*ous*ness</hw>, <pos>n.</pos> <sn>1.</sn> <def>The
state or quality of being ingenuous; openness of heart;
frankness.</def>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>Ingenuity.</def> <mark>[Obs.]</mark>

<au>Fuller.</au>

<hw>In"ge*ny</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[L.
<ets>ingenium</ets>. See <er>Ingenious</er>.]</ety> <def>Natural
gift or talent; ability; wit; ingenuity.</def>
<mark>[Obs.]</mark> <altsp>[Written also
<asp>ingenie</asp>.]</altsp>

<au>Becon.</au>

<hw>In*ger"mi*nate</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>v. t.</pos> <def>To
cause to germinate.</def>

<hw>In*gest"</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>v. t.</pos> <ety>[L.
<ets>ingenium</ets>, p. p. of <ets>ingerere</ets> to put in;
pref. <ets>in-</ets> in + <ets>gerere</ets> to bear.]</ety>
<def>To take into, or as into, the stomach or alimentary
canal.</def>

<au>Sir T. Browne.</au>

is introduced into the body by the stomach or alimentary canal;

<hw>In*glo"ri*ous</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>a.</pos> <ety>[L.

<sn>1.</sn> <def>Not glorious; not bringing honor or glory; not

<as>as, an <ex>inglorious</ex> life of ease</as>.</def>

<au>Shak.</au>

<q>My next desire is, void of care and strife,
To lead a soft, secure, <qex>inglorious</qex> life.</q>
<qau>Dryden.</qau>

<q>Some mute <qex>inglorious</qex> Milton here may rest.</q>
<qau>Gray.</qau>

<ex>inglorious</ex> flight, defeat, etc.</as></def>

<q><qex>Inglorious</qex> shelter in an alien land.</q>
<qau>J. Philips.</qau>

being inglorious.</def>

<hw>In"got</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[Prob. from AS.
<ets>in</ets> in + <ets>ge\'a2tan</ets> to pour: cf. F.
<ets>linglot</ets>, LL. <ets>lingotus</ets> a mass of gold or
silver, extended in the manner of a tongue, and G.
<ets>einguss</ets>, LG. & OE. <ets>ingot</ets> ingot, a mold for
casting metals in. See <er>Found</er> to cast, and cf.
<er>Linget</er>, <er>Lingot</er>, <er>Nugget</er>.]</ety>

<sn>1.</sn> <def>That in which metal is cast; a mold.</def>
<mark>[Obs.]</mark>

<q>And from the fire he took up his matter
And in the <qex>ingot</qex> put it with merry cheer.</q>
<qau>Chaucer.</qau>

malleable metal, cast in a mold; a mass of unwrought cast
metal.</def>

<qau>Sir W. Jones.</qau>

cast.</cd> -- <col>Ingot iron</col>. <cd>See <cref>Decarbonized
steel</cref>, under <er>Decarbonize</er>.</cd></cs>

<hw>In*graft"</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>v. t.</pos>
<wordforms>[<pos>imp. & p. p.</pos> <er>Ingrafted</er>; <pos>p.
pr. & vb. n.</pos> <er>Ingrafting</er>.]</wordforms>
<ety>[Written also <ets>engraft</ets>.]</ety>

<sn>1.</sn> <def>To insert, as a scion of one tree, shrub, or
plant in another for propagation; <as>as, to <ex>ingraft</ex> a
peach scion on a plum tree</as>; figuratively, to insert or
introduce in such a way as to make a part of something.</def>

<q>This fellow would <qex>ingraft</qex> a foreign name
Upon our stock.</q>
<qau>Dryden.</qau>

<q>A custom . . . <qex>ingrafted</qex> into the monarchy of
Rome.</q>
<qau>Burke.</qau>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>To subject to the process of grafting; to
furnish with grafts or scions; to graft; <as>as, to
<ex>ingraft</ex> a tree</as>.</def>

<hw>In*graft"er</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <def>A person
who ingrafts.</def>
