<def>The act of ingrafting.</def>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>The thing ingrafted; a scion.</def>

<hw>In"grain`</hw> <pr>(?; 277)</pr>, <pos>a.</pos> <ety>[Pref.
<ets>in-</ets> in + <ets>grain</ets> kermes. See
<er>Engrain</er>, <er>Grain</er>.]</ety>

<sn>1.</sn> <def>Dyed with grain, or kermes.</def>
<mark>[Obs.]</mark>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>Dyed before manufacture, -- said of the material
of a textile fabric; hence, in general, thoroughly inwrought;
forming an essential part of the substance.</def>

<cs><col>Ingrain carpet</col>, <cd>a double or two-ply
carpet.</cd> -- <col>Triple ingrain carpet</col>, <cd>a three-ply
carpet.</cd></cs>

<hw>In"grain`</hw>, <pos>n.</pos> <def>An ingrain fabric, as a
carpet.</def>

<hw>In"grain`</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>v. t.</pos>
<wordforms>[<pos>imp. & p. p.</pos> <er>Ingrained</er>
<pr>(?)</pr>; <pos>p. pr. & vb. n.</pos>
<er>Ingraining</er>.]</wordforms> <ety>[Written also
<ets>engrain</ets>.]</ety>

<sn>1.</sn> <def>To dye with or in grain or kermes.</def>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>To dye in the grain, or before
manufacture.</def>

<sn>3.</sn> <def>To work into the natural texture or into the
mental or moral constitution of; to stain; to saturate; to imbue;
to infix deeply.</def>

<q>Our fields <qex>ingrained</qex> with blood.</q>
<qau>Daniel.</qau>

<q>Cruelty and jealousy seem to be <qex>ingrained</qex> in a man
who has these vices at all.</q>
<qau>Helps.</qau>

seize; to clutch; to grapple.</def> <mark>[Obs.]</mark>

<au>Drayton.</au>

<hw>In*gra"ti*ate</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>v. t.</pos>
<wordforms>[<pos>imp. & p. p.</pos> <er>Ingratiated</er>

<mhw>{ <hw>In*gre"di*ence</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>,

<au>Sir M. Hale.</au>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>The quality or state of being an ingredient or

<hw>In*gre"di*ent</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[F.
<ets>ingr\'82dient</ets>, L. <ets>ingrediens</ets>,
<ets>-entis</ets>, entering into, p. pr. of <ets>ingredi</ets>,

<ets>in-</ets> in + <ets>gradi</ets> to walk, go. See
<er>Grade</er>.]</ety> <def>That which enters into a compound, or
is a component part of any combination or mixture; an element; a
constituent.</def>

<qex>ingredients</qex>.</q>
<qau>Sir I. Newton.</qau>

<q>Water is the chief <qex>ingredient</qex> in all the animal
fluids and solids.</q>
<qau>Arbuthnot.</qau>

forming, an ingredient or component part.</def>

<q>Acts where no sin is <qex>ingredient</qex>.</q>
<qau>Jer. Taylor.</qau>

<def>The act of swallowing greedily or immoderately; that which

<au>E. Darwin.</au>

<q>He drowned his stomach and senses with a large draught and
<qex>ingurgitation</qex> of wine.</q>

<hw>In*hab"ile</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>a.</pos> <ety>[L.
<ets>inhabilis</ets>: cf. F. <ets>inhabile</ets>. See
<er>In-</er> not, and <er>Habile</er>, and cf.
<er>Unable</er>.]</ety>

<sn>1.</sn> <def>Not apt or fit; unfit; not convenient;
inappropriate; unsuitable; <as>as, <ex>inhabile</ex>
matter</as>.</def> <mark>[Obs.]</mark>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>Unskilled; unready; awkward; incompetent;
unqualified; -- said of person. <mark>[Obs.]</mark> See

<hw>In`ha*bil"i*ty</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[Cf. F.

<au>Barrow.</au>

<hw>In*hab"it</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>v. t.</pos>
<wordforms>[<pos>imp. & p. p.</pos> <er>Inhabited</er>; <pos>p.
pr. & vb. n.</pos> <er>Inhabiting</er>.]</wordforms> <ety>[OE.
<ets>enhabiten</ets>, OF. <ets>enhabiter</ets>, L.
<ets>inhabitare</ets>; pref. <ets>in-</ets> in +
<ets>habitare</ets> to dwell. See <er>Habit</er>.]</ety> <def>To
live or dwell in; to occupy, as a place of settled residence;
<as>as, wild beasts <ex>inhabit</ex> the forest; men
<ex>inhabit</ex> cities and houses.</as></def>

<q>The high and lofty One, that <qex>inhabiteth</qex>
eternity.</q>
<qau>Is. lvii. 15.</qau>

<q>O, who would <qex>inhabit</qex>
This bleak world alone?</q>
<qau>Moore.</qau>

<hw>In*hab"it</hw>, <pos>v. i.</pos> <def>To have residence in a
place; to dwell; to live; to abide.</def> <mark>[Archaic or
Poetic]</mark>

<au>Shak.</au>

<q>They say wild beasts <qex>inhabit</qex> here.</q>
<qau>Waller.</qau>

<hw>In*hab"it*a*ble</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>a.</pos> <ety>[L.
<ets>inhabitabilis</ets>. See <er>Inhabit</er>.]</ety>
<def>Capable of being inhabited; habitable.</def>

<q>Systems of <qex>inhabitable</qex> planets.</q>
<qau>Locke.</qau>

<hw>In*hab"it*a*ble</hw>, <pos>a.</pos> <ety>[L.
<ets>inhabitabilis</ets>: cf. F. <ets>inhabitable</ets>. See
<er>In-</er> not, and <er>Habitable</er>.]</ety> <def>Not
habitable; not suitable to be inhabited.</def>
<mark>[Obs.]</mark>

<q>The frozen ridges of the Alps
Or other ground <qex>inhabitable</qex>.</q>
<qau>Shak.</qau>

<mhw>{ <hw>In*hab"it*ance</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>,
<hw>In*hab"it*an*cy</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, }</mhw> <pos>n.</pos>
<sn>1.</sn> <def>The act of inhabiting, or the state of being
inhabited; the condition of an inhabitant; residence;
occupancy.</def>

<q>Ruins yet resting in the wild moors testify a former
<qex>inhabitance</qex>.</q>
<qau>Carew.</qau>

<sn>2.</sn> <fld>(Law)</fld> <def>The state of having legal right
to claim the privileges of a recognized inhabitant; especially,
the right to support in case of poverty, acquired by residence in
a town; habitancy.</def>

<hw>In*hab"it*ant</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[L.
<ets>inhabitans</ets>, <ets>-antis</ets>, p. pr. of
<ets>inhabitare</ets>.]</ety>

<sn>1.</sn> <def>One who dwells or resides permanently in a
place, as distinguished from a transient lodger or visitor;
<as>as, an <ex>inhabitant</ex> of a house, a town, a city,
county, or state</as>.</def> \'bdFrail <xex>inhabitants</xex> of
earth.\'b8

<au>Cowper.</au>

<q>In this place, they report that they saw
<qex>inhabitants</qex> which were very fair and fat people.</q>
<qau>Abp. Abbot.</qau>

<sn>2.</sn> <fld>(Law)</fld> <def>One who has a legal settlement
in a town, city, or parish; a permanent resident.</def>

<hw>In*hab"i*tate</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>v. t.</pos> <def>To
inhabit.</def> <mark>[Obs.]</mark>

<hw>In*hab`i*ta"tion</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[L.
<ets>inhabitatio</ets> a dwelling.]</ety>

<sn>1.</sn> <def>The act of inhabiting, or the state of being
inhabited; indwelling.</def>

<q>The <qex>inhabitation</qex> of the Holy Ghost.</q>
<qau>Bp. Pearson.</qau>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>Abode; place of dwelling; residence.</def>
<mark>[Obs.]</mark>

<au>Milton.</au>

<sn>3.</sn> <def>Population; inhabitants.</def>
<mark>[Obs.]</mark>

<au>Sir T. Browne.</au>

<q>The beginning of nations and of the world's
<qex>inhabitation</qex>.</q>
<qau>Sir W. Raleigh.</qau>

<hw>In*hale"</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>v. t.</pos>
<wordforms>[<pos>imp. & p. p.</pos> <er>Inhaled</er>
<pr>(?)</pr>; <pos>p. pr. & vb. n.</pos>
<er>Inhaling</er>.]</wordforms> <ety>[L. <ets>inhalare</ets> to

breathe: cf. F. <ets>inhaler</ets>. Cf. <er>Exhale</er>.]</ety>
<def>To breathe or draw into the lungs; to inspire; <as>as, to
<ex>inhale</ex> air</as>; -- opposed to
<contr>exhale</contr>.</def>

<q>Martin was walking forth to <qex>inhale</qex> the fresh breeze
of the evening.</q>
<qau>Arbuthnot.</qau>

inhaling; <as>as, the <ex>inhalent</ex> end of a duct</as>.</def>

<au>Dana.</au>

<hw>In*hal"er</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <sn>1.</sn>
<def>One who inhales.</def>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>An apparatus for inhaling any vapor or volatile
substance, as ether or chloroform, for medicinal purposes.</def>

<sn>3.</sn> <def>A contrivance to filter, as air, in order to
protect the lungs from inhaling damp or cold air, noxious gases,
dust, etc.; also, the respiratory apparatus for divers.</def>

<hw>In*here"</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>v. i.</pos>

<mhw>{ <hw>In*her"ence</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <hw>In*her"en*cy</hw>
<pr>(?)</pr>, }</mhw> <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[Cf. F.
<ets>inh\'82rence</ets>.]</ety> <def>The state of inhering;
permanent existence in something; innateness; inseparable and
essential connection.</def>

<au>Jer. Taylor.</au>

<hw>In*her"ent</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>a.</pos> <ety>[L.
<ets>inhaerens</ets>, <ets>-entis</ets>, p. pr. of
<ets>inhaerere</ets>: cf. F. <ets>inh\'82rent</ets>. See
<er>Inhere</er>.]</ety> <def>Permanently existing in something;
inseparably attached or connected; naturally pertaining to;
innate; inalienable; <as>as, polarity is an <ex>inherent</ex>
quality of the magnet; the <ex>inherent</ex> right of men to
life, liberty, and protection.</as></def> \'bdA most
<xex>inherent</xex> baseness.\'b8

<au>Shak.</au>

<q>The sore disease which seems <qex>inherent</qex> in
civilization.</q>
<qau>Southey.</qau>

<syn>Syn. -- Innate; inborn; native; natural; inbred; inwrought;
inseparable; essential; indispensable.</syn>

<hw>In*her"ent*ly</hw>, <pos>adv.</pos> <def>By inherence;
inseparably.</def>

<q>Matter hath <qex>inherently</qex> and essentially such an
internal energy.</q>
<qau>Bentley.</qau>

<hw>In*her"it</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>v. t.</pos>
<wordforms>[<pos>imp. & p. p.</pos> <er>Inherited</er>; <pos>p.
pr. & vb. n.</pos> <er>Inheriting</er>.]</wordforms> <ety>[OE.
<ets>enheriten</ets> to inherit, to give a heritage to, OF.
<ets>enheriter</ets> to appoint as an heir, L.
<ets>inhereditare</ets>; pref. <ets>in-</ets> in +
<ets>hereditare</ets> to inherit, fr. <ets>heres</ets> heir. See
<er>Heir</er>.]</ety>

<sn>1.</sn> <fld>(Law)</fld> <def>To take by descent from an
ancestor; to take by inheritance; to take as heir on the death of
an ancestor or other person to whose estate one succeeds; to
receive as a right or title descendible by law from an ancestor
at his decease; <as>as, the heir <ex>inherits</ex> the land or
real estate of his father; the eldest son of a nobleman
<ex>inherits</ex> his father's title; the eldest son of a king
<ex>inherits</ex> the crown.</as></def>

<-- p. 764 -->

<sn>2.</sn> <def>To receive or take by birth; to have by nature;
to derive or acquire from ancestors, as mental or physical
qualities; <as>as, he <ex>inherits</ex> a strong constitution, a
tendency to disease, etc.</as></def>

<q>Prince Harry is valiant; for the cold blood he did naturally
<qex>inherit</qex> of his father he hath . . . manured . . . with
good store of fertile sherris.</q>
<qau>Shak.</qau>

<sn>3.</sn> <def>To come into possession of; to possess; to own;
to enjoy as a possession.</def>

<q>But the meek shall <qex>inherit</qex> the earth.</q>
<qau>Ps. xxxvii. 11.</qau>

<q>To bury so much gold under a tree,
And never after to <qex>inherit</qex> it.</q>
<qau>Shak.</qau>

<sn>4.</sn> <def>To put in possession of.</def> <mark>[R.]</mark>

<au>Shak.</au>

<hw>In*her"it</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>v. i.</pos> <def>To take or
hold a possession, property, estate, or rights by
inheritance.</def>

<q>Thou shalt not <qex>inherit</qex> our father's house.</q>
<qau>Judg. xi. 2.</qau>

<hw>In*her`it*a*bil"i*ty</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos>
<def>The quality of being inheritable or descendible to
heirs.</def>

<au>Jefferson.</au>

<hw>In*her"it*a*ble</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>a.</pos> <sn>1.</sn>
<def>Capable of being inherited; transmissible or descendible;
<as>as, an <ex>inheritable</ex> estate or title</as>.</def>

<au>Blackstone.</au>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>Capable of being transmitted from parent to
child; <as>as, <ex>inheritable</ex> qualities or
infirmities</as>.</def>

<sn>3.</sn> <ety>[Cf. OF. <ets>enheritable</ets>,
<ets>inheritable</ets>.]</ety> <def>Capable of taking by
inheritance, or of receiving by descent; capable of succeeding
to, as an heir.</def>

<q>By attainder . . . the blood of the person attainted is so
corrupted as to be rendered no longer <qex>inheritable</qex>.</q>
<qau>Blackstone.</qau>

<q>The eldest daughter of the king is also alone
<qex>inheritable</qex> to the crown on failure of issue male.</q>
<qau>Blackstone.</qau>

<cs><col>Inheritable blood</col>, <cd>blood or relationship by
which a person becomes qualified to be an heir, or to transmit
possessions by inheritance.</cd></cs>

<hw>In*her"it*a*bly</hw>, <pos>adv.</pos> <def>By
inheritance.</def>

<au>Sherwood.</au>

<hw>In*her"it*ance</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[Cf. OF.
<ets>enheritance</ets>.]</ety>

<sn>1.</sn> <def>The act or state of inheriting; <as>as, the
<ex>inheritance</ex> of an estate; the <ex>inheritance</ex> of
mental or physical qualities.</as></def>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>That which is or may be inherited; that which is
derived by an heir from an ancestor or other person; a heritage;
a possession which passes by descent.</def>

<q>When the man dies, let the <qex>inheritance</qex>
Descend unto the daughter.</q>
<qau>Shak.</qau>

<sn>3.</sn> <def>A permanent or valuable possession or blessing,
esp. one received by gift or without purchase; a
benefaction.</def>

<q>To an <qex>inheritance</qex> incorruptible, and undefiled, and
that fadeth not away.</q>
<qau>1 Pet. i. 4.</qau>

<sn>4.</sn> <def>Possession; ownership; acquisition.</def>
\'bdThe <xex>inheritance</xex> of their loves.\'b8

<au>Shak.</au>

<q>To you th' <qex>inheritance</qex> belongs by right
Of brother's praise; to you eke <?/longs his love.</q>
<qau>Spenser.</qau>

<sn>5.</sn> <fld>(Biol.)</fld> <def>Transmission and reception by
animal or plant generation.</def>

<sn>6.</sn> <fld>(Law)</fld> <def>A perpetual or continuing right
which a man and his heirs have to an estate; an estate which a
man has by descent as heir to another, or which he may transmit
to another as his heir; an estate derived from an ancestor to an
heir in course of law.</def>

<au>Blackstone.</au>

<note><hand/ The word <xex>inheritance</xex> (used simply) is
mostly confined to the title to land and tenements by a
descent.</note>

<au>Mozley & W.</au>

<q>Men are not proprietors of what they have, merely for
themselves; their children have a title to part of it which comes
to be wholly theirs when death has put an end to their parents'
use of it; and this we call <qex>inheritance</qex>.</q>
<qau>Locke.</qau>

<q>Born <qex>inheritors</qex> of the dignity.</q>
<qau>Milton.</qau>

<hw>In*hib"it</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>v. t.</pos>
<wordforms>[<pos>imp. & p. p.</pos> <er>Inhibited</er>; <pos>p.
pr. & vb. n.</pos> <er>Inhibiting</er>.]</wordforms> <ety>[L.
<ets>inhibitus</ets>, p. p. of <ets>inhibere</ets>; pref.
<ets>in-</ets> in + <ets>habere</ets> to have, hold. See
<er>Habit</er>.]</ety>

<sn>1.</sn> <def>To check; to hold back; to restrain; to
hinder.</def>

<q>Their motions also are excited or <qex>inhibited</qex> . . .
by the objects without them.</q>
<qau>Bentley.</qau>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>To forbid; to prohibit; to interdict.</def>

<q>All men were <qex>inhibited</qex>, by proclamation, at the
dissolution, so much as to mention a Parliament.</q>
<qau>Clarendon.</qau>

<q>Burial may not be <qex>inhibited</qex> or denied to any
one.</q>
<qau>Ayliffe.</qau>

<hw>In`hi*bi"tion</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[L.
<ets>inhibitio</ets>: cf. F. <ets>inhibition</ets>.]</ety>

<sn>1.</sn> <def>The act of inhibiting, or the state of being
inhibited; restraint; prohibition; embargo.</def>

<sn>2.</sn> <fld>(Physiol.)</fld> <def>A stopping or checking of
an already present action; a restraining of the function of an
organ, or an agent, as a digestive fluid or ferment, etc.;
<as>as, the <ex>inhibition</ex> of the respiratory center by the
pneumogastric nerve; the <ex>inhibition</ex> of reflexes,
etc.</as></def>

<sn>3.</sn> <fld>(Law)</fld> <def>A writ from a higher court
forbidding an inferior judge from further proceedings in a cause
before; esp., a writ issuing from a higher ecclesiastical court
to an inferior one, on appeal.</def>

<au>Cowell.</au>

<hw>In*hib"i*tor</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos>
<ety>[NL.]</ety> <def>That which causes inhibitory action; esp.,
an inhibitory nerve.</def>

<hw>In*hib"i*to*ry</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>a.</pos> <ety>[LL.
<ets>inhibitorius</ets>: cf. F. <ets>inhibitoire</ets>.]</ety>
<def>Of or pertaining to, or producing, inhibition; consisting in
inhibition; tending or serving to inhibit; <as>as, the
<ex>inhibitory</ex> action of the pneumogastric on the
respiratory center</as>.</def>

<q>I would not have you consider these criticisms as
<qex>inhibitory</qex>.</q>
<qau>Lamb.</qau>

<cs><col>Inhibitory nerves</col> <fld>(Physiol.)</fld>, <cd>those
nerves which modify, inhibit, or suppress a motor or secretory
act already in progress.</cd></cs>

<hw>In*hib"i*to*ry-mo"tor</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>a.</pos>
<fld>(Physiol.)</fld> <def>A term applied to certain nerve
centers which govern or restrain subsidiary centers, from which
motor impressions issue.</def>

<au>McKendrick.</au>

<hw>In*hos"pi*ta*ble</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>a.</pos> <ety>[Pref.
<ets>in-</ets> not + <ets>hospitable</ets>: cf. L.
<ets>inhospitalis</ets>.]</ety>

<sn>1.</sn> <def>Not hospitable; not disposed to show hospitality
to strangers or guests; <as>as, an <ex>inhospitable</ex> person
or people</as>.</def>

<q>Have you no touch of pity, that the poor
Stand starved at your <qex>inhospitable</qex> door?</q>
<qau>Cowper.</qau>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>Affording no shelter or sustenance; barren;
desert; bleak; cheerless; wild.</def> \'bd<xex>Inhospitable</xex>
wastes.\'b8

<au>Blair.</au>

-- <wordforms><wf>In*hos"pi*ta*ble*mess</wf>, <pos>n.</pos> --
<wf>In*hos"pi*ta*bly</wf>, <pos>adv.</pos></wordforms>

<hw>In*hos`pi*tal"i*ty</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[L.

<hw>In*hu"man</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>a.</pos> <ety>[L.
<ets>inhumanus</ets>: cf. F. <ets>inhumain</ets>. See
<er>In-</er> not, and <er>Human</er>.]</ety>

<sn>1.</sn> <def>Destitute of the kindness and tenderness that
belong to a human being; cruel; barbarous; savage; unfeeling;
<as>as, an <ex>inhuman</ex> person or people</as>.</def>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>Characterized by, or attended with, cruelty;
<as>as, an <ex>inhuman</ex> act or punishment</as>.</def>

<syn>Syn. -- Cruel; unfeeling; pitiless; merciless; savage;
barbarous; brutal; ferocious; ruthless; fiendish.</syn>

<hw>In`hu*man"i*ty</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos>; <plu>pl.
<plw>Inhumanities</plw> <pr>(#)</pr></plu>. <ety>[L.
<ets>inhumanitas</ets>: cf. F. <ets>inhumanit\'82</ets>.]</ety>
<def>The quality or state of being inhuman; cruelty;
barbarity.</def>

<q>Man's <qex>inhumanity</qex> to man
Makes countless thousands mourn.</q>
<qau>Burns.</qau>

<hw>In*hu"man*ly</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>adv.</pos> <def>In an
inhuman manner; cruelly; barbarously.</def>

<hw>In`hu*ma"tion</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[Cf. F.
<ets>inhumation</ets>.]</ety>

<sn>1.</sn> <def>The act of inhuming or burying; interment.</def>

<sn>2.</sn> <fld>(Old Chem.)</fld> <def>The act of burying
vessels in warm earth in order to expose their contents to a
steady moderate heat; the state of being thus exposed.</def>

<sn>3.</sn> <fld>(Med.)</fld> <def>Arenation.</def>

<hw>In*hume"</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>v. t.</pos>
<wordforms>[<pos>imp. & p. p.</pos> <er>Inhumed</er>
<pr>(?)</pr>; <pos>p. pr. & vb. n.</pos>

See <er>Inhumate</er>.]</ety>

<qex>Inhume</qex> the natives in their native plain.</q>
<qau>Pope.</qau>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>To bury or place in warm earth for chemical or
medicinal purposes.</def>

<hw>In*iq"ui*tous</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>a.</pos> <ety>[From
<er>Iniquity</er>.]</ety> <def>Characterized by iniquity; unjust;
wicked; <as>as, an <ex>iniquitous</ex> bargain; an
<ex>iniquitous</ex> proceeding.</as></def>

<q>Demagogues . . . bribed to this <qex>iniquitous</qex>
service.</q>
<qau>Burke.</qau>

<syn>Syn. -- Wicked; wrong; unjust; unrighteous; nefarious;
criminal.</syn> <usage> -- <er>Iniquitous</er>, <er>Wicked</er>,
<er>Nefarious</er>. <xex>Wicked</xex> is the generic term.
<xex>Iniquitous</xex> is stronger, denoting a violation of the
rights of others, usually by fraud or circumvention.
<xex>Nefarious</xex> is still stronger, implying a breach of the
most sacred obligations, and points more directly to the
intrinsic badness of the deed.</usage>

<hw>In*iq"ui*tous*ly</hw>, <pos>adv.</pos> <def>In an iniquitous
manner; unjustly; wickedly.</def>

<hw>In*iq"ui*ty</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos>; <plu>pl.
<plw>Iniquities</plw> <pr>(#)</pr></plu>. <ety>[OE.
<ets>iniquitee</ets>, F. <ets>iniquit\'82</ets>, L.
<ets>iniquitas</ets>, inequality, unfairness, injustice. See
<er>Iniquous</er>.]</ety>

<sn>1.</sn> <def>Absence of, or deviation from, just dealing;
want of rectitude or uprightness; gross injustice;
unrighteousness; wickedness; <as>as, the <ex>iniquity</ex> of
bribery; the <ex>iniquity</ex> of an unjust judge.</as></def>

<q>Till the world from his perfection fell
Into all filth and foul <qex>iniquity</qex>.</q>
<qau>Spenser.</qau>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>An iniquitous act or thing; a deed of injustice
o<?/ unrighteousness; a sin; a crime.</def>

<au>Milton.</au>

<q>Your <qex>iniquities</qex> have separated between you and your
God.</q>
<qau>Is. lix. 2.</qau>

<sn>3.</sn> <def>A character or personification in the old
English moralities, or moral dramas, having the name sometimes of
one vice and sometimes of another. See <er>Vice</er>.</def>

<q>Acts old <qex>Iniquity</qex>, and in the fit
Of miming gets the opinion of a wit.</q>
<qau>B. Jonson.</qau>

<hw>In*i"tial</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>a.</pos> <ety>[L.
<ets>initialis</ets>, from <ets>initium</ets> a going in,

<sn>1.</sn> <def>Of or pertaining to the beginning; marking the

<sn>2.</sn> <def>Placed at the beginning; standing at the head,
as of a list or series; <as>as, the <ex>initial</ex> letters of a
name</as>.</def>

or a name.</def>

<hw>In*i"ti*ate</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>v. t.</pos>
<wordforms>[<pos>imp. & p. p.</pos> <er>Initiated</er>
<pr>(?)</pr>; <pos>p. pr. & vb. n.</pos> <er>Initiating</er>
<pr>(?)</pr>.]</wordforms> <ety>[L. <ets>initiatus</ets>, p. p.
of <ets>initiare</ets> to begin, fr. <ets>initium</ets>
beginning. See <er>Initial</er>.]</ety>

<sn>1.</sn> <def>To introduce by a first act; to make a beginning
with; to set afoot; to originate; to commence; to begin or enter
upon.</def>

<q>How are changes of this sort to be <qex>initiated</qex>?</q>
<qau>I. Taylor.</qau>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>To acquaint with the beginnings; to instruct in
the rudiments or principles; to introduce.</def>

<q>Providence would only <qex>initiate</qex> mankind into the
useful knowledge of her treasures, leaving the rest to employ our
industry.</q>
<qau>Dr. H. More.</qau>

<q>To <qex>initiate</qex> his pupil into any part of learning, an
ordinary skill in the governor is enough.</q>
<qau>Locke.</qau>

<sn>3.</sn> <def>To introduce into a society or organization; to
confer membership on; especially, to admit to a secret order with
mysterious rites or ceremonies.</def>

<q>The Athenians believed that he who was <qex>initiated</qex>
and instructed in the mysteries would obtain celestial honor
after death.</q>
<qau>Bp. Warburton.</qau>

<q>He was <qex>initiated</qex> into half a dozen clubs before he
was one and twenty.</q>
<qau>Spectator.</qau>

<hw>In*i"ti*ate</hw>, <pos>v. i.</pos> <def>To do the first act;
to perform the first rite; to take the initiative.</def>
<mark>[R.]</mark>

<au>Pope.</au>

<qau>Young.</qau>

<hw>In*ject"</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>v. t.</pos>
<wordforms>[<pos>imp. & p. p.</pos> <er>Injected</er>; <pos>p.
pr. & vb. n.</pos> <er>Injecting</er>.]</wordforms> <ety>[L.
<ets>injectus</ets>, p. p. of <ets>inicere</ets>,
<ets>injicere</ets>, to throw in; pref. <ets>in-</ets> in +
<ets>jacere</ets> to throw: cf. F. <ets>injecter</ets>. See
<er>Jet</er> a shooting forth.]</ety>

<sn>1.</sn> <def>To throw in; to dart in; to force in; <as>as, to
<ex>inject</ex> cold water into a condenser; to <ex>inject</ex> a
medicinal liquid into a cavity of the body; to <ex>inject</ex>
morphine with a hypodermic syringe.</as></def>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>Fig.: To throw; to offer; to propose; to
instill.</def>

<q>C\'91sar also, then hatching tyranny, <qex>injected</qex> the
same scrupulous demurs.</q>
<qau>Milton.</qau>

<sn>3.</sn> <def>To cast or throw; -- with <xex>on</xex>.</def>
<mark>[R.]</mark>

<q>And mound <qex>inject</qex> on mound.</q>
<qau>Pope.</qau>

<-- p. 765 -->

<sn>4.</sn> <fld>(Anat.)</fld> <def>To fill (a vessel, cavity, or
tissue) with a fluid or other substance; <as>as, to
<ex>inject</ex> the blood vessels</as>.</def>

<hw>In*jec"tion</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[L.
<ets>injectio</ets> : cf.F. <ets>injection</ets>.]</ety>
<sn>1.</sn> <def>The act of injecting or throwing in; -- applied
particularly to the forcible throwing in of a liquid, or
a\'89riform body, by means of a syringe, pump, etc.</def>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>That which is injected; especially, a liquid
medicine thrown into a cavity of the body by a syringe or pipe; a
clyster; an enema.</def>

<au>Mayne.</au>

<sn>3.</sn> <fld>(Anat.)</fld> <sd>(a)</sd> <def>The act or
process of filling vessels, cavities, or tissues with a fluid or
other substance.</def> <sd>(b)</sd> <def>A specimen prepared by
injection.</def>

<sn>4.</sn> <fld>(Steam Eng.)</fld> <sd>(a)</sd> <def>The act of
throwing cold water into a condenser to produce a vacuum.</def>
<sd>(b)</sd> <def>The cold water thrown into a condenser.</def>

<cs><mcol><col>Injection cock</col>, <or/ <col>Injection
valve</col></mcol> <fld>(Steam Eng.)</fld>, <cd>the cock or valve
through which cold water is admitted into a condenser.</cd> --
<col>Injection condenser</col>. <cd>See under
<er>Condenser</er>.</cd> -- <col>Injection pipe</col>, <cd>the
pipe through which cold water is through into the condenser of a
steam engine.</cd></cs>

<hw>In*ject"or</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <sn>1.</sn>
<def>One who, or that which, injects.</def>

<sn>2.</sn> <fld>(Mach.)</fld> <def>A contrivance for forcing
feed water into a steam boiler by the direct action of the steam
upon the water. The water is driven into the boiler by the
impulse of a jet of the steam which becomes condensed as soon as
it strikes the stream of cold water it impels; -- also called
<altname>Giffard's injector</altname>, from the inventor.</def>

<-- fuel injector -- a device for actively injecting fuel into an
internal combustion engine -->

<hw>In`ju*di"cious</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>a.</pos> <ety>[Pref.

<ets>injudicieux</ets>.]</ety> <sn>1.</sn> <def>Not judicious;

<as>as, an <ex>injudicious</ex> adviser</as>.</def>

<q>An <qex>injudicious</qex> biographer who undertook to be his
editor and the protector of his memory.</q>
<qau>A. Murphy.</qau>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>Not according to sound judgment or discretion;
unwise; <as>as, an <ex>injudicious</ex> measure</as>.</def>

unwise; rash; hasty; imprudent.</syn>

<hw>In*junc"tion</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[L.
<ets>injunctio</ets>, fr. <ets>injungere</ets>,
<ets>injunctum</ets>, to join into, to enjoin. See
<er>Enjoin</er>.]</ety> <sn>1.</sn> <def>The act of enjoining;
the act of directing, commanding, or prohibiting.</def>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>That which is enjoined; an order; a mandate; a
decree; a command; a precept; a direction.</def>

<q>For still they knew,and ought to have still remembered,
The high <qex>injunction</qex>,not to taste that fruit.</q>
<qau>Milton.</qau>

<q>Necessary as the <qex>injunctions</qex> of lawful
authority.</q>
<qau>South.</qau>

<sn>3.</sn> <fld>(Law)</fld> <def>A writ or process, granted by a
court of equity, and, insome cases, under statutes, by a court of
law,whereby a party is required to do or to refrain from doing
certain acts, according to the exigency of the writ.</def>

<note><hand/ It is more generally used as a preventive than as a
restorative process, although by no means confined to the
former.</note>

<au>Wharton. Daniell. Story.</au>

<hw>In"jure</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>v. t.</pos>
<wordforms>[<pos>imp. & p. p.</pos> <er>Injured</er>
<pr>(?)</pr>; <pos>p. pr. & vb. n.</pos>
<er>Injuring</er>.]</wordforms> <ety>[L. <ets>injuriari</ets>,
fr. <ets>injuria</ets> injury, perh. through F.
<ets>injurier</ets> to insult, in OF. also, to injure; or perhaps
fr. E. <ets>injury</ets>, or F. <ets>injure</ets> injury. See
<er>Injury</er>.]</ety> <def>To do harm to; to impair the
excellence and value of; to hurt; to damage; -- used in a variety
of senses; as: <sd>(a)</sd> To hurt or wound, as the person; to
impair soundness, as of health. <sd>(b)</sd> To damage or lessen
the value of, as goods or estate. <sd>(c)</sd> To slander,
tarnish, or impair, as reputation or character. <sd>(d)</sd> To
impair or diminish, as happiness or virtue. <sd>(e)</sd> To give
pain to, as the sensibilities or the feelings; to grieve; to
annoy. <sd>(f)</sd> To impair, as the intellect or mind.</def>

<q>When have I <qex>injured</qex> thee? when done thee wrong?</q>
<qau>Shak.</qau>

<syn>Syn. -- To damage; mar; spoil; harm; sully; wrong; maltreat;
abuse; insult; affront; dishonor.</syn>

<hw>In"jur*er</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <def>One who
injures or wrongs.</def>

<hw>\'d8In*ju"ri*a</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos>; <plu>pl.
<plw>Injurie</plw> <pr>(#)</pr></plu>. <ety>[L.]</ety>
<fld>(Law)</fld> <def>Injury; invasion of another's rights.</def>

<hw>In*ju"ri*ous</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>a.</pos> <ety>[L.
<ets>injuriousus</ets>, injurius; cf. F. <ets>injurieux</ets>.
See <er>Injury</er>.]</ety> <sn>1.</sn> <def>Not just; wrongful;
iniquitous; culpable.</def> <mark>[Obs.]</mark>

<au>Milton.</au>

<q>Till the <qex>injurious</qex> Roman did extort
This tribute from us, we were free.</q>
<qau>Shak.</qau>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>Causing injury or harm; hurtful; harmful;
detrimental; mischievous; <as>as, acts <ex>injurious</ex> to
health, credit, reputation, property, etc.</as></def>

<q>Without being <qex>injurious</qex> to the memory of our
English Pindar.</q>
<qau>Dryden.</qau>

<syn>Syn. -- Harmful; hurtful; pernicious; mischievous; baneful;
deleterious; noxious; ruinous; detrimental.</syn>

<hw>In*ju"ri*ous*ly</hw>, <pos>adv.</pos> <def>In an injurious or
hurtful manner; wrongfully; hurtfully; mischievously.</def>

<hw>In*ju"ri*ous*ness</hw>, <pos>n.</pos> <def>The quality of
being injurious or hurtful; harmfulness; injury.</def>

<hw>In"ju*ry</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos>; <plu>pl.
<plw>Injuries</plw> <pr>(#)</pr></plu>. <ety>[OE.
<ets>injurie</ets>, L. <ets>injuria</ets>, fr.
<ets>injurius</ets> injurious, wrongful, unjust; pref.
<ets>in-</ets> not + <ets>jus</ets>,<ets>juris</ets>,
right,law,justice: cf. F. <ets>injure</ets>. See <er>Just</er>,
<pos>a.</pos>]</ety> <def>Any damage or violation of, the person,
character, feelings, rights, property, or interests of an
individual; that which injures, or occasions wrong, loss, damage,
or detriment; harm; hurt; loss; mischief; wrong; evil; <as>as,
his health was impaired by a severe <ex>injury</ex>; slander is
an <ex>injury</ex> to the character.</as></def>

<q>For he that doeth <qex>injury</qex> shall receve that he did
evil.</q>
<qau>Wyclif(Col. iii. 25).</qau>

<q>Many times we do <qex>injury</qex> to a cause by dwelling on
trifling arguments.</q>
<qau>I. Watts.</qau>

<q>Riot ascends above their loftiest towers,
And <qex>injury</qex> and outrage.</q>
<qau>Milton.</qau>

<note><hand/ <xex>Injury</xex> in morals and jurisprudence is the
intentional doing of wrong.</note>

<au>Fleming.</au>

<syn>Syn. -- Harm; hurt; damage; loss; impairment; detriment;
wrong; evil; injustice.</syn>

<hw>In*jus"tice</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[F.
<ets>injustice</ets>, L. <ets>injustitia</ets>. See <er>In-</er>
not, and <er>Justice</er>, and cf. <er>Unjust</er>.]</ety>
<sn>1.</sn> <def>Want of justice and equity; violation of the
rights of another or others; iniquity; wrong; unfairness;
imposition.</def>

<q>If this people [the Athenians] resembled Nero in their
extravagance, much more did they resemble and even exceed him in
cruelty and <qex>injustice</qex>.</q>
<qau>Burke.</qau>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>An unjust act or deed; a sin; a crime; a
wrong.</def>

<q>Cunning men can be guilty of a thousand <qex>injustices</qex>
without being discovered, or at least without being punished.</q>
<qau>Swift.</qau>

<hw>Ink</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <fld>(Mach.)</fld>
<def>The step, or socket, in which the lower end of a millstone
spindle runs.</def>

<hw>Ink</hw>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[OE. <ets>enke</ets>,
<ets>inke</ets>, OF. <ets>enque</ets>, F. <ets>encre</ets>, L.
<ets>encaustum</ets> the purple red ink with which the Roman
emperors signed their edicts, Gr. <?/, fr. <?/ burnt in,
encaustic, fr. <?/ to burn in. See <er>Encaustic</er>,
<er>Caustic</er>.]</ety> <sn>1.</sn> <def>A fluid, or a viscous
material or preparation of various kinds (commonly black or
colored), used in writing or printing.</def>

<q>Make there a prick with <qex>ink</qex>.</q>
<qau>Chaucer.</qau>

<q>Deformed monsters, foul and black as <qex>ink</qex>.</q>
<qau>Spenser.</qau>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>A pigment. See <cref>India ink</cref>, under
<er>India</er>.</def>

<note><hand/ Ordinarily, <xex>black</xex> ink is made from
nutgalls and a solution of some salt of iron, and consists
essentially of a tannate or gallate of iron; sometimes indigo
sulphate, or other coloring matter,is added. Other black inks
contain potassium chromate, and extract of logwood, salts of
vanadium, etc. <xex>Blue</xex> ink is usually a solution of
Prussian blue. <xex>Red</xex> ink was formerly made from carmine
(cochineal), Brazil wood, etc., but potassium eosin is now used.
Also red, blue, violet, and yellow inks are largely made from
aniline dyes. <xex>Indelible</xex> ink is usually a weak solution
of silver nitrate, but carbon in the form of lampblack or India
ink, salts of molybdenum, vanadium, etc., are also used.
<xex>Sympathetic</xex> inks may be made of milk, salts of cobalt,
etc. See <cref>Sympathetic ink</cref> (below).</note>

<cs><col>Copying ink</col>, <cd>a peculiar ink used for writings
of which copies by impression are to be taken.</cd> -- <col>Ink
bag</col> <fld>(Zo\'94l.)</fld>, <cd>an ink sac.</cd> -- <col>Ink
berry</col>. <fld>(Bot.)</fld> <sd>(a)</sd> <cd>A shrub of the
Holly family (<spn>Ilex glabra</spn>), found in sandy grounds
along the coast from New England to Florida, and producing a
small black berry.  <sd>(b)</sd> <cd>The West Indian indigo
berry. See <er>Indigo</er>.</cd> -- <col>Ink plant</col>
<fld>(Bot.)</fld>, <cd>a New Zealand shrub (<spn>Coriaria
thumifolia</spn>), the berries of which uield a juice which forms
an ink.</cd> -- <col>Ink powder</col>, <cd>a powder from which
ink is made by solution.</cd> -- <col>Ink sac</col>
<fld>(Zo\'94l.)</fld>, <cd>an organ, found in most cephalopods,
containing an inky fluid which can be ejected from a duct opening
at the base of the siphon. The fluid serves to cloud the water,
and enable these animals to escape from their enemies. See
<xex>Illust<xex>. of <er>Dibranchiata</er>.</cd> --
<mcol><col>Printer's ink</col>, <or/ <col>Printing
ink</col></mcol>. <cd>See under <er>Printing</er>.</cd> --
<col>Sympathetic ink</col>, <cd>a writing fluid of such a nature
that what is written remains invisible till the action of a
reagent on the characters makes it visible.</cd></cs>

n.</pos> <er>Inking</er>.]</wordforms> <def>To put ink upon; to
supply with ink; to blacken, color, or daub with ink.</def>

<hw>In"land</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>a.</pos> <sn>1.</sn>
<def>Within the land; more or less remote from the ocean or from
open water; interior; <as>as, an <ex>inland</ex> town</as>.</def>
\'bdThis wide <xex>inland</xex> sea.\'b8

<au>Spenser.</au>

<q>From <qex>inland</qex> regions to the distant main.</q>
<qau>Cowper.</qau>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>Limited to the land, or to inland routes; within
the seashore boundary; not passing on, or over, the sea; <as>as,
<ex>inland</ex> transportation, commerce, navigation,
etc.</as></def>

<sn>3.</sn> <def>Confined to a country or state; domestic; not
foreing; <as>as, an <ex>inland</ex> bill of exchange</as>. See
<er>Exchange</er>.</def>

country.</def>

interior, away from the coast.</def>

from the east.</q>
<qau>S. Turner.</qau>

<hw>In*lay"</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>v. t.</pos>

a groundwork of some other material; to form an ornamental
surface; to diversify or adorn with insertions.</def>

<q>Look,how the floor of heaven
Is thick <qex>inlaid</qex> with patines of bright gold.</q>
<qau>Shak.</qau>

<q>But these things are . . . borrowed by the monks to
<qex>inlay</qex> their story.</q>
<qau>Milton.</qau>

Broidered the ground.</q>
<qau>Milton.</qau>

Was damask work, and deep <qex>inlay</qex>
Of braided blooms.</q>

or large river; a narrow strip of water running into the land or

material.</def>

<hw>In"most`</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>a.</pos> <ety>[OE.
<ets>innemest</ets>, AS. <ets>innemest</ets>, a double
superlative form fr. <ets>inne</ets> within, fr. <ets>in</ets>
in. The modern form is due to confusion with <ets>most</ets>. See
<er>In</er>, and cf. <er>Aftermost</er>, <er>Foremost</er>,
<er>Innermost</er>.]</ety> <def>Deepest within; farthest from the
surface or external part; innermost.</def>

<q>And pierce the <qex>inmost</qex> center of the earth.</q>
<qau>Shak.</qau>

<q>The silent, slow, consuming fires,
Which on my <qex>inmost</qex> vitals prey.</q>
<qau>Addison.</qau>

<hw>Inn</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[AS.
<ets>in</ets>,<ets>inn</ets>, house, chamber, inn, from AS.
<ets>in</ets> in; akin to Icel. <ets>inni</ets> house. See
<er>In</er>.]</ety> <sn>1.</sn> <def>A place of shelter; hence,
dwelling; habitation; residence; abode.</def> <mark>[Obs.]</mark>

<au>Chaucer.</au>

<q>Therefore with me ye may take up your <qex>inn</qex>
For this same night.</q>
<qau>Spenser.</qau>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>A house for the lodging and entertainment of
travelers or wayfarers; a tavern; a public house; a hotel.</def>

<note><hand/ As distinguished from a private boarding house, an
inn is a house for the entertainment of all travelers of good
conduct and means of payment,as guests for a brief period,not as
lodgers or boarders by contract.</note>

<q>The miserable fare and miserable lodgment of a provincial
<qex>inn</qex>.</q>
<qau>W. Irving.</qau>

<sn>3.</sn> <def>The town residence of a nobleman or
distinguished person; <as>as, Leicester <ex>Inn</ex></as>.</def>
<mark>[Eng.]</mark>

<sn>4.</sn> <def>One of the colleges (societies or buildings) in
London, for students of the law barristers; <as>as, the
<ex>Inns</ex> of Court; the <ex>Inns</ex> of Chancery; Serjeants'
<ex>Inns</ex>.</as></def>

<cs><col>Inns of chancery</col> <fld>(Eng.)</fld>, <cd>colleges
in which young students formerly began their law studies, now
occupied chiefly by attorneys, solicitors, etc.</cd> -- <col>Inns
of court</col> <fld>(Eng.)</fld>, <cd>the four societies of
\'bdstudents and practicers of the law of England\'b8 which in
London exercise the exclusive right of admitting persons to
practice at the bar; also, the buildings in which the law
students and barristers have their chambers. They are the Inner
Temple, the Middle Temple, Lincoln's Inn, and Gray's
Inn.</cd></cs>

<-- p. 766 -->

<hw>Inn</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>v. i.</pos>  
<wordforms>[<pos>imp. & p. p.</pos> <er>Inned</er> <pr>(?)</pr>;
<pos>p. pr. & vb. n.</pos> <er>Inning</er>.]</wordforms> <def>To
take lodging; to lodge.</def> <mark>[R.]</mark>

<au>Addison.</au>

<hw>Inn</hw>, <pos>v. t.</pos> <sn>1.</sn> <def>To house; to
lodge.</def> <mark>[Obs.]</mark>

<q>When he had brought them into his city
And <qex>inned</qex> them, everich at his degree.</q>
<qau>Chaucer.</qau>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>To get in; to in. See <er>In</er>, <pos>v.
t.</pos></def>

<hw>In"nate</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>a.</pos> <ety>[L.
<ets>innatus</ets>; pref. <ets>in-</ets> in + <ets>natus</ets>
born, p.p. of <ets>nasci</ets> to be born. See
<er>Native</er>.]</ety> <sn>1.</sn> <def>Inborn; native; natural;
<as>as, <ex>innate</ex> vigor; <ex>innate</ex>
eloquence.</as></def>

<sn>2.</sn> <fld>(Metaph.)</fld> <def>Originating in, or derived
from, the constitution of the intellect, as opposed to acquired
from experience; <as>as, <ex>innate</ex> ideas</as>. See <er>A
priori</er>, <er>Intuitive</er>.</def>

<q>There is an <qex>innate</qex> light in every man, discovering
to him the first lines of duty in the common notions of good and
evil.</q>
<qau>South.</qau>

<q>Men would not be guilty if they did not carry in their mind
common notions of morality,<qex>innate</qex> and written in
divine letters.</q>
<qau>Fleming (Origen).</qau>

<q>If I could only show,as I hope I shall . . . how men, barely
by the use of their natural faculties, may attain to all the
knowledge they have, without the help of any <qex>innate</qex>
impressions; and may arrive at certainty without any such
original notions or principles.</q>
<qau>Locke.</qau>

<sn>3.</sn> <fld>(Bot.)</fld> <def>Joined by the base to the very
tip of a filament; <as>as, an <ex>innate</ex> anther</as>.</def>

<au>Gray.</au>

<cs><col>Innate ideas</col> <fld>(Metaph.)</fld>, <cd>ideas, as
of God, immortality, right and wrong, supposed by some to be
inherent in the mind, as a priori principles of
knowledge.</cd></cs>

exit; to call into being.</def> <mark>[Obs.]</mark> \'bdThe first
<xex>innating</xex> cause.\'b8

<hw>In"ner</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>a.</pos> <ety>[AS.

<cs><col>Inner house</col> <fld>(Scot.)</fld>, <cd>the first and
second divisions of the court of Session at Edinburgh; also,the
place of their sittings.</cd> -- <col>Inner jib</col>
<fld>(Naut.)</fld>, <cd>a fore-and-aft sail set on a stay running
from the fore-topmast head to the jib boom.</cd> -- <col>Inner
plate</col> <fld>(Arch.)</fld>, <cd>the wall plate which lies
nearest to the center of the roof,in a double-plated roof.</cd>
-- <col>Inner post</col> <fld>(Naut.)</fld>, <cd>a piece brought
on at the fore side of the main post, to support the
transoms.</cd> -- <col>Inner square</col> <fld>(Carp.)</fld>,
<cd>the angle formed by the inner edges of a carpenter's
square.</cd></cs>

<hw>In"no*cence</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[F.
<ets>innocence</ets>, L. <ets>innocentia</ets>. See
<er>Innocent</er>.]</ety> <sn>1.</sn> <def>The state or quality
of being innocent; freedom from that which is harmful or
infurious; harmlessness.</def>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>The state or quality of being morally free from
guilt or sin; purity of heart; blamelessness.</def>

<q>The silence often of pure <qex>innocence</qex>
Persuades when speaking fails.</q>
<qau>Shak.</qau>

<q>Banished from man's life his happiest life,
Simplicity and spotless <qex>innocence</qex>!</q>
<qau>Milton.</qau>

<sn>3.</sn> <def>The state or quality of being not chargeable
for, or guilty of, a particular crime or offense; <as>as, the
<ex>innocence</ex> of the prisoner was clearly shown</as>.</def>

<sn>4.</sn> <def>Simplicity or plainness, bordering on weakness
or silliness; artlessness; ingenuousness.</def>

<au>Chaucer. Shak.</au>

<syn>Syn. -- Harmlessness; innocuousness; blamelessness; purity;
sinlessness; guiltlessness.</syn>

<hw>In"no*cen*cy</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos>
<def>Innocence.</def>

<hw>In"no*cent</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>a.</pos>
<ety>[F.<ets>innocent</ets>, L. <ets>innocens</ets>,
<ets>-entis</ets>; pref. <ets>in-</ets> not + <ets>nocens</ets>,
p.pr. of <ets>nocere</ets> to harm, hurt. See
<er>Noxious</er>.]</ety> <sn>1.</sn> <def>Not harmful; free from
that which can injure; innoxious; innocuous; harmless; <as>as, an
<ex>innocent</ex> medicine or remedy</as>.</def>

<q>The spear
Sung <qex>innocent</qex>,and spent its force in air.</q>
<qau>Pope.</qau>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>Morally free from guilt; guiltless; not tainted
with sin; pure; upright.</def>

<q>To offer up a weak, poor, <qex>innocent</qex> lamb.</q>
<qau>Shak.</qau>

<q>I have sinned in that I have betrayed the <qex>innocent</qex>
blood.</q>
<qau>Matt. xxvii. 4.</qau>

<q>The aidless,<qex>innocent</qex> lady, his wished prey.</q>
<qau>Milton.</qau>

<sn>3.</sn> <def>Free from the guilt of a particular crime or
offense; <as>as, a man is <ex>innocent</ex> of the crime
charged</as>.</def>

<q><qex>Innocent</qex> from the great transgression.</q>
<qau>Ps. xix. 13.</qau>

<sn>4.</sn> <def>Simple; artless; foolish.</def>

<au>Shak.</au>

<sn>5.</sn> <def>Lawful; permitted; <as>as, an <ex>innocent</ex>
trade</as>.</def>

<sn>6.</sn> <def>Not contraband; not subject to forfeiture;
<as>as, <ex>innocent</ex> goods carried to a belligerent
nation</as>.</def>

<cs><col>Innocent party</col> <fld>(Law)</fld>,<cd>a party who
has not notice of a fact tainting a litigated transaction with
illegality.</cd></cs>

<syn>Syn. -- Harmless; innoxious; innoffensive; guiltless;
spotless; immaculate; pure; unblamable; blameless; faultless;
guileless; upright.</syn>

<hw>In"no*cent</hw>, <pos>n.</pos> <sn>1.</sn> <def>An innocent
person; one free from, or unacquainted with, guilt or sin.</def>

<au>Shak.</au>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>An unsophisticated person; hence, a child; a
simpleton; an idiot.</def>

<au>B. Jonson.</au>

<q>In Scotland a natural fool was called an
<qex>innocent</qex>.</q>
<qau>Sir W. Scott.</qau>

<cs><col>Innocents' day</col> <fld>(Eccl.)</fld>, <cd>Childermas
day.</cd></cs>

<hw>In"no*cent*ly</hw>, <pos>adv.</pos> <def>In an innocent
manner.</def>

<hw>In*noc"u*ous</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>a.</pos> <ety>[L.
<ets>innocuus</ets>; <ets>in-</ets> not + <ets>nocuus</ets>

<hw>In*nom"i*nate</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>a.</pos> <ety>[L.

<ets>nominare</ets> to name.]</ety> <sn>1.</sn> <def>Having no

<au>Ray.</au>

<sn>2.</sn> <fld>(Anat.)</fld> <def>A term used in designating
many parts otherwise unnamed; <as>as, the <ex>innominate</ex>
artery, a great branch of the arch of the aorta; the
<ex>innominate</ex> vein, a great branch of the superior vena
cava.</as></def>

<cs><col>Innominate bone</col> <fld>(Anat.)</fld>, <cd>the great
bone which makes a lateral half of the pelvis in mammals; hip
bone; haunch bone; huckle bone. It is composed of three bones,
ilium, ischium, and pubis, consolidated into one in the adult,
though separate in the fetus, as also in many adult reptiles and
amphibians.</cd> -- <col>Innominate contracts</col>
<fld>(Law)</fld>, <cd>in the Roman law, contracts without a
specific name.</cd></cs>

<hw>In"no*vate</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>v. t.</pos>  
<wordforms>[<pos>imp. & p. p.</pos> <er>Innovated</er>
<pr>(?)</pr>; <pos>p. pr. & vb. n.</pos> <er>Innovating</er>
<pr>(?)</pr>.]</wordforms> <ety>[L. <ets>innovatus</ets>,p.p. of
<ets>innovare</ets> to revew; pref. <ets>in-</ets> in +
<ets>novare</ets> to make new,fr. <ets>novus</ets> new.  See
<er>New</er>.]</ety> <sn>1.</sn> <def>To bring in as new; to
introduce as a novelty; <as>as, to <ex>innovate</ex> a word or an
act</as>.</def> <mark>[Archaic]</mark>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>To change or alter by introducing something new;
to remodel; to revolutionize.</def> <mark>[Archaic]</mark>

<au>Burton.</au>

<q>From his attempts upon the civil power, he proceeds
to <qex>innovate</qex> God's worship.</q>
<qau>South.</qau>

<hw>In"no*vate</hw>, <pos>v. i.</pos> <def>To introduce novelties
or changes; -- sometimes with <xex>in</xex> or
<xex>on</xex>.</def>

<au>Bacon.</au>

<q>Every man,therefore,is not fit to <qex>innovate</qex>.</q>
<qau>Dryden.</qau>

<hw>In`no*va"tion</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[L.
<ets>innovatio</ets>; cf. F. <ets>innovation</ets>.]</ety>
<sn>1.</sn> <def>The act of innovating; introduction of something
new, in customs, rites, etc.</def>

<au>Dryden.</au>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>A change effected by innovating; a change in
customs; something new, and contrary to established customs,
manners, or rites.</def>

<au>Bacon.</au>

<q>The love of things ancient doth argue stayedness, but levity
and want of experience maketh apt unto
<qex>innovations</qex>.</q>
<qau>Hooker.</qau>

<sn>3.</sn> <fld>(Bot.)</fld> <def>A newly formed shoot, or the
annually produced addition to the stems of many mosses.</def>

<hw>In`no*va"tion*ist</hw>, <pos>n.</pos> <def>One who favors
innovation.</def>

<def>Cloudless.</def> <mark>[Obs.]</mark>

<au>Blount.</au>

<hw>In`nu*en"do</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos>; <plu>pl.
<plw>Innuedoes</plw>(<?/)</plu>. <ety>[L., by intimation, by
hinting, gerund of <ets>innuere</ets>, <ets>innutum</ets>, to
give a nod, to intimate; pref. <ets>in-</ets> in, to +
-<ets>nuere</ets> (in comp.) to nod. See
<er>Nutation</er>.]</ety> <sn>1.</sn> <def>An oblique hint; a
remote allusion or reference, usually derogatory to a person or
thing not named; an insinuation.</def>

<q>Mercury . . . owns it a marriage by an
<qex>innuendo</qex>.</q>
<qau>Dryden.</qau>

<q>Pursue your trade of scandal picking;
Your <qex>innuendoes</qex>, when you tell us,
That Stella loves to talk with fellows.</q>
<qau>Swift.</qau>

<sn>2.</sn> <fld>(Law)</fld> <def>An averment employed in
pleading, to point the application of matter otherwise
unintelligible; an interpretative parenthesis thrown into quoted
matter to explain an obscure word or words; -- as, the plaintiff
avers that the defendant said that he (<xex>innuendo</xex> the
plaintiff) was a thief.</def>

<au>Wharton.</au>

<note><hand/ The term is so applied from having been the
introductory word of this averment or parenthetic explanation
when pleadings were in Latin. The word \'bdmeaning\'b8 is used as
its equivalent in modern forms.</note>

<syn>Syn. -- Insinuation; suggestion; hint; intimation;
reference; allusion; implication; representation; --
<er>Innuendo</er>, <er>Insinuation</er>.</syn> <usage> An
<xex>innuendo</xex> is an equivocal allusion so framed as to
point distinctly at something which is injurious to the character
or reputation of the person referred to. An
<xex>insinuation</xex> turns on no such double use of language,
but consists in artfully <xex>winding</xex> into the mind
imputations of an injurious nature without making any direct
charge.</usage>

<hw>In"nu*ent</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>a.</pos>
<ety>[L.<ets>innuens</ets>, p.pr.]</ety> <def>Conveying a hint;
significant.</def> <mark>[Obs.]</mark>

<au>Burton.</au>

<hw>In"nu*it</hw>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[Native name.]</ety>
<fld>(Ethnol.)</fld> <def>An Eskimo.</def>

<hw>In*nu`mer*a*bil"i*ty</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos>
<ety>[L. <ets>innumerabilitas</ets>.]</ety> <def>State of being
innumerable.</def>

<au>Fotherby.</au>

<hw>In*nu`mer*a*ble</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>a.</pos> <ety>[L.
<ets>innumerabilis</ets> : cf.F. <ets>innumefable</ets>. See
<er>In-</er> not, and <er>Numerable</er>.]</ety> <def>Not capable
of being counted, enumerated, or numbered, for multitude;
countless; numberless; unnumbered, hence, indefinitely numerous;
of great number.</def>

<q><qex>Innumerable</qex> as the stars of night.</q>
<qau>Milton.</qau>

-- <wordforms><wf>In*nu"mer*a*ble*ness</wf>, <pos>n.</pos> --
<wf>In*nu"mer*a*bly</wf>, <pos>adv.</pos></wordforms>

<er>Numerous</er>.]</ety> <def>Innumerable.</def>

<hw>In`o*be"di*ence</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[L.
<ets>inoboedientia</ets> : cf.F. <ets>inobedience</ets>.]</ety>
<def>Disobedience.</def> <mark>[Obs.]</mark>

<au>Wyclif. Chaucer.</au>

<hw>In`o*be"di*ent</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>a.</pos> <ety>[L.

<hw>In*oc"u*late</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>v. t.</pos>
<wordforms>[<pos>imp. & p. p.</pos> <er>Inoculated</er>
<pr>(?)</pr>; <pos>p. pr. & vb. n.</pos> <er>Inoculating</er>
<pr>(?)</pr>,.]</wordforms> <ety>[L. <ets>inoculatus</ets>, p.p.
of <ets>inoculare</ets> to ingraft; pref. <ets>in-</ets> in,on +
<ets>oculare</ets> to furnish with eyes, fr. <ets>oculus</ets> an
eye, also, a bud. See <er>Ocular</er>.]</ety> <sn>1.</sn> <def>To
bud; to insert, or graft, as the bud of a tree or plant in
another tree or plant.</def>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>To insert a foreign bud into; <as>as, to
<ex>inoculate</ex> a tree</as>.</def>

<sn>3.</sn> <fld>(Med.)</fld> <def>To communicate a disease to (
a person ) by inserting infectious matter in the skin or flesh;
<as>as, to <ex>inoculate</ex> a person with the virus of
smallpox,rabies, etc.</as>  See <er>Vaccinate</er>.</def>

<sn>4.</sn> <def>Fig.: To introduce into the mind; -- used
especially of harmful ideas or principles; to imbue; <as>as, to
<ex>inoculate</ex> one with treason or infidelity</as>.</def>

<hw>In*oc"u*late</hw>, <pos>v. i.</pos> <sn>1.</sn> <def>To graft
by inserting buds.</def>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>To communicate disease by inoculation.</def>

<hw>In*oc"u*la"tion</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[L.
<ets>inoculatio</ets>: cf. F. <ets>inoculation</ets>.]</ety>
<sn>1.</sn> <def>The act or art of inoculating trees or
plants.</def>

<sn>2.</sn> <fld>(Med.)</fld> <def>The act or practice of
communicating a disease to a person in health, by inserting
contagious matter in his skin or flesh.</def>

<note><hand/ The use was formerly limited to the intentional
communication of the smallpox, but is now extended to include any
similar introduction of modified virus; as, the
<xex>inoculation</xex> of rabies by Pasteur.</note>

<sn>3.</sn> <def>Fig.: The communication of principles,
especially false principles, to the mind.</def>

<hw>In*oc"u*la`tor</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[L.: cf.
F. <ets>inoculateur</ets>.]</ety> <def>One who inoculates; one
who propagates plants or diseases by inoculation.</def>

<hw>In`or*gan"ic</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>a.</pos> <ety>[Pref.
<ets>in-</ets> not + <ets>organic</ets>: cf. F.
<ets>inorganique</ets>.]</ety> <def>Not organic; without the
organs necessary for life; devoid of an organized structure;
unorganized; lifeness; inanimate; <as>as, all chemical compounds
are <ex>inorganic</ex> substances</as>.</def>

<note><hand/ The term <xex>inorganic</xex> is used to denote any
one the large series of substances (as minerals, metals, etc.),
which are not directly connected with vital processes, either in
origin or nature, and which are broadly and relatively contrasted
with <xex>organic</xex> subscances. See <er>Organic</er>.</note>

<cs><col>Inorganic Chemistry</col>. <cd>See under
<er>Chemistry</er>.</cd></cs>

<hw>In*os"cu*late</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>v. i.</pos>
<wordforms>[<pos>imp. & p. p.</pos> <er>Inosculated</er>
<pr>(?)</pr>; <pos>p. pr. & vb. n.</pos> <er>Inosculating</er>
<pr>(?)</pr>.]</wordforms> <ety>[Pref. <ets>in-</ets> in +
<ets>osculate</ets>.]</ety> <sn>1.</sn> <def>To unite by
apposition or contact, as two tubular vessels at their
extremities; to anastomose.</def>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>To intercommunicate; to interjoin.</def>

<q>The several monthly divisions of the journal may inosculate,
but not the several volumes.</q>
<qau>De Quincey.</qau>

<hw>In*os"cu*late</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>v. t.</pos> <sn>1.</sn>
<def>To unite by apposition or contact, as two vessels in an
animal body.</def>

<au>Berkeley.</au>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>To unite intimately; to cause to become as
one.</def>

<q>They were still together, grew
(For so they said themselves) <qex>inosculated</qex>.</q>
<qau>Tennyson.</qau>

<hw>In*os`cu*la"tion</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[Cf.
F. <ets>inosculation</ets>.]</ety> <def>The junction or
connection of vessels, channels, or passages, so that their
contents pass from one to the other; union by mouths or ducts;
anastomosis; intercommunication; <as>as, <ex>inosculation</ex> of
veins, etc.</as></def>

<au>Ray.</au>

<hw>In`o*sin"ic</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>a.</pos> <ety>[From
<er>Inosite</er>.]</ety> <fld>(Chem.)</fld> <def>Pertaining to,
or derived from, inosite; <as>as, <ex>inosinic</ex>

<hw>In"o*site</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[Gr. <?/,
<?/, strength, muscle.]</ety> <fld>(Physiol. Chem.)</fld> <def>A
white crystalline substance with a sweet taste, found in certain
animal tissues and fluids, particularly in the muscles of the
heart and lungs, also in some plants, as in unripe pease, beans,
potato sprouts, etc.  Called also
<altname>phaseomannite</altname>.</def>

<note><hand/ Chemically,it has the composition represented by the
formula, <chform>C6H12O6+H2O</chform>, and was formerly regarded
as a carbohydrate, isomeric with dextrose, but is now known to be
an aromatic compound (a hexacid phenol derivative of
benzene).</note>

and platinum are <ex>inoxidizable</ex> in the air</as>.</def>

<hw>In"quest</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[OE.
<ets>enqueste</ets>, OF. <ets>enqueste</ets>, F.
<ets>enqu\'88te</ets>, LL. <ets>inquesta</ets>, for
<ets>inquisita</ets>, fr. L. <ets>inquisitus</ets>, p.p. of
<ets>inquirere</ets>. See <er>Inquire</er>.]</ety> <sn>1.</sn>
<def>Inquiry; quest; search.</def> <mark>[R.]</mark>

<au>Spenser.</au>

<q>The laborious and vexatious <qex>inquest</qex> that the soul
must make after science.</q>
<qau>South.</qau>

<sn>2.</sn> <fld>(Law)</fld> <sd>(a)</sd> <def>Judicial inquiry;
official examination, esp. before a jury; <as>as, a coroner's
<ex>inquest</ex> in case of a sudden death</as>.</def>
<sd>(b)</sd> <def>A body of men assembled under authority of law
to inquire into any matterm civil or criminal, particularly any
case of violent or sudden death; a jury, particularly a coroner's
jury. The <xex>grand jury</xex> is sometimes called the
<xex>grand inquest</xex>. See under <er>Grand</er>.</def>
<sd>(c)</sd> <def>The finding of the jury upon such
inquiry.</def>

<cs><col>Coroner's inquest</col>, <cd>an inquest held by a
coroner to determine the cause of any violent, sudden, or
mysterious death. See <er>Coroner</er>.</cd> -- <col>Inquest of
office</col>, <cd>an inquiry made, by authority or direction of
proper officer, into matters affecting the rights and interests
of the crown or of the state.</cd></cs>

<au>Craig. Bouvier.</au>

<hw>In*quire"</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>v. i.</pos>
<wordforms>[<pos>imp. & p. p.</pos> <er>Inquired</er>
<pr>(?)</pr>; <pos>p. pr. & vb. n.</pos>
<er>Inquiring</er>.]</wordforms> <ety>[OE. <ets>enqueren</ets>,
<ets>inqueren</ets>, OF. <ets>enquerre</ets>, F.
<ets>enqu\'82rir</ets>, L. <ets>inquirere</ets>,
<ets>inquisitum</ets>; pref. <ets>in-</ets> in +
<ets>quarere</ets> to seek. See <er>Quest</er> a seeking, and cf.
<er>Inquiry</er>.]</ety> <altsp>[Written also
<asp>enquire</asp>.]</altsp> <sn>1.</sn> <def>To ask a question;
to seek for truth or information by putting queries.</def>

<q>We will call the damsel, and <qex>inquire</qex>.</q>
<qau>Gen. xxiv. 57.</qau>

<q>Then David <qex>inquired</qex> of the Lord yet again. And the
Lord answered him.</q>
<qau>1 Sam. xxiii. 4.</qau>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>To seek to learn anything by recourse to the
proper means of knoledge; to make examination.</def>

<q>And <qex>inquire</qex>
Gladly into the ways of God with man.</q>
<qau>Miltom.</qau>

<note><hand/ This word is followed by <xex>of</xex> before the
person asked; as, to <xex>inquire</xex> of a neighbor. It is
followed by <xex>concerning</xex>, <xex>after</xex>, or
<xex>about</xex>, before the subject of inquiry; as, his friends
<xex>inquired about or concerning</xex> his welfare. \'bdThou
dost not <xex>inquire</xex> wisely <xex>concerning</xex>
this.\'b8 <au>Eccl. vii. 10</au>. It is followed by
<xex>into</xex> when search is made for particular knowledge or
information; as, to <xex>inquire into</xex> the cause of a sudden
death. It is followed by <xex>for</xex> or <xex>after</xex> when
a place or person is sought, or something is missing.
\'bd<xex>Inquire</xex> in the house of Judas <xex>for</xex> one
called Saul of Tarsus.\'b8 <au>Acts ix. 11</au>.</note>

<hw>In*quire"</hw>, <pos>v. t.</pos> <sn>1.</sn> <def>To ask
about; to seek to know by asking; to make examination or inquiry
respecting.</def>

<q>Having thus at length <qex>inquired</qex> the truth concerning
law and dispense.</q>
<qau>Milton.</qau>

<q>And all obey and few <qex>inquire</qex> his will.</q>
<qau>Byron.</qau>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>To call or name.</def> <mark>[Obs.]</mark>

<au>Spenser.</au>

<syn>Syn. -- To ask; question. See <er>Question</er>.</syn>

<hw>In*quir"ent</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>a.</pos> <ety>[L.
<ets>inquirens</ets>, <ets>p. pr.</ets>]</ety> <def>Making
inquiry; inquiring; questioning.</def> <mark>[Obs.]</mark>

<au>Shenstone.</au>

<hw>In*quir"er</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[Written
also <ets>enquirer</ets>.]</ety> <def>One who inquires or
examines; questioner; investigator.</def>

<au>Locke.</au>

<q>Expert <qex>inquirers</qex> after truth.</q>
<qau>Cowper.</qau>

<hw>In*quir"ing</hw>, <pos>a.</pos> <def>Given to inquiry;
disposed to investigate causes; curious; <as>as, an
<ex>inquiring</ex> mind</as>.</def>

<hw>In*quir"ing*ly</hw>, <pos>adv.</pos> <def>In an inquiring
manner.</def>

<hw>In*quir"y</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos>; <plu>pl.
<plw>Inquiries</plw> <pr>(#)</pr></plu>. <ety>[See
<er>Inquire</er>.]</ety> <altsp>[Written also
<asp>enquiry</asp>.]</altsp> <sn>1.</sn> <def>The act of
inquiring; a seeking for information by asking questions;
interrogation; a question or questioning.</def>

<q>He could no path nor track of foot descry,
Nor by <qex>inquiry</qex> learn, nor guess by aim.</q>
<qau>Spenser.</qau>

<q>The men which were sent from Cornelius had made
<qex>inquiry</qex> for Simon's house, and stood before the
gate.</q>
<qau>Acts x. 17.</qau>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>Search for truth, information, or knoledge;
examination into facts or principles; research; invextigation;
<as>as, physical <ex>inquiries</ex></as>.</def>

<q>All that is wanting to the perfection of this art will
undoubtedly be found, if able men . . . will make
<qex>inquiry</qex> into it.</q>
<qau>Dryden.</qau>

<cs><col>Court of inquiry</col>. <cd>See under
<er>Court</er>.</cd> -- <col>Writ of inquiry</col>, <cd>a writ
issued in certain actions at law, where the defendant has
suffered judgment to pass against him by default, in order to
ascertain and assess the plaintiff's damages, where they can not
readily be ascertained by mere calculation.
<xex>Burrill<xex>.</cd></cs>

<syn>Syn. -- Interrogation; interrogatory; question; query;
scrutiny; investigation; research; examination.</syn>

<hw>In*quis"i*ble</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>a.</pos> <def>Admitting
judicial inquiry.</def> <mark>[Obs.]</mark>

<au>Sir M. Hale.</au>

<hw>In`qui*si"tion</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[L.
<ets>inquisitio</ets> : cf. F. <ets>inquisition</ets>.  See
<er>Inquire</er>, and cf. <er>Inquest</er>.]</ety> <sn>1.</sn>
<def>The act of inquiring; inquiry; search; examination;
inspection; investigation.</def>

<q>As I could learn through earnest <qex>inquisition</qex>.</q>
<qau>Latimer.</qau>

<q>Let not search and <qex>inquisition</qex> quail
To bring again these foolish runaways.</q>
<qau>Shak.</qau>

<sn>2.</sn> <fld>(Law)</fld> <sd>(a)</sd> <def>Judicial inquiry;
official examination; inquest.</def> <sd>(b)</sd> <def>The
finding of a jury, especially such a finding under a writ of
inquiry.</def>

<au>Bouvier.</au>

<q>The justices in eyre had it formerly in charge to make
<qex>inquisition</qex> concerning them by a jury of the
county.</q>
<qau>Blackstone.</qau>

<sn>3.</sn> <fld>(R. C. Ch.)</fld> <def>A court or tribunal for
the examination and punishment of heretics, fully established by
Pope Gregory IX. in 1235. Its operations were chiefly confined to
Spain, Portugal, and their dependencies, and a part of
Italy.</def>

<hw>In`qui*si"tion</hw>, <pos>v. t.</pos> <def>To make
inquisistion concerning; to inquire into.</def>
<mark>[Obs.]</mark>

<au>Milton.</au>

<hw>In`qui*si"tion*al</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>a.</pos> <ety>[LL.
<ets>inquisitionalis</ets>.]</ety> <def>Relating to inquiry or
inquisition; inquisitorial; also, of or pertaining to, or
characteristic of, the Inquisition.</def>

<q>All the <qex>inquisitional</qex> rigor . . . executed upon
books.</q>
<qau>Milton.</qau>

<hw>In`qui*si"tion*a*ry</hw>, <pr>(<?/)</pr>, <pos>a.</pos>
<ety>[Cf. F. <ets>inquisitionnaire</ets>.]</ety>
<mark>[R.]</mark> <def>Inquisitional.</def>

<hw>In*quis"i*tive</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>a.</pos> <ety>[OE.
<ets>inquisitif</ets>, F. <ets>inquisitif</ets>.]</ety>
<sn>1.</sn> <def>Disposed to ask questions, especially in matters
which do not concern the inquirer.</def>

<q>A wise man is not <qex>inquisitive</qex> about things
impertinent.</q>
<qau>Broome.</qau>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>Given to examination, investigation, or
research; searching; curious.</def>

<q>A young, <qex>inquisitive</qex>, and sprightly genius.</q>
<qau>I. Watts.</qau>

<syn>Syn. -- Inquiring; prying; curious; meddling;
intrusive.</syn> <usage> -- <er>Inquisitive</er>,
<er>Curious</er>, <er>Prying</er>. <xex>Curious</xex> denotes a
feeling, and <xex>inquisitive</xex> a habit. We are
<xex>curious</xex> when we desire to learn something new; we are
<xex>inquisitive</xex> when we set ourselves to gain it by
inquiry or research. <xex>Prying</xex> implies
<xex>inquisitiveness</xex>, and is more commonly used in a bad
sense, as indicating a desire to penetrate into the secrets of
others.</usage>

<q>[We] <qex>curious</qex> are to hear,
What happens new.</q>
<qau>Milton.</qau>

<q>This folio of four pages [a newspaper], happy work!
Which not even critics criticise; that holds
<qex>Inquisitive</qex> attention, while I read.</q>
<qau>Cowper.</qau>

<q>Nor need we with a <qex>prying</qex> eye survey
The distant skies, to find the Milky Way.</q>
<qau>Creech.</qau>

<hw>In*quis"i*tive</hw>, <pos>n.</pos> <def>A person who is
inquisitive; one curious in research.</def>

<au>Sir W. Temple.</au>

<hw>In*quis"i*tive*ly</hw>, <pos>adv.</pos> <def>In an
inquisitive manner.</def>

<q>The occasion that made him afterwards so
<qex>inquisitively</qex> apply himself to the study of
physic.</q>
<qau>Boyle.</qau>

<hw>In*quis"i*tive*ness</hw>, <pos>n.</pos> <def>The quality or
state of being inquisitive; the disposition to seek explanation
and information; curiosity to learn what is unknown; esp.,
uncontrolled and impertinent curiosity.</def>

<q>Mr. Boswell, whose <qex>inquisitiveness</qex> is seconded by
great activity, scrambled in at a high window.</q>
<qau>Johnson.</qau>

<q>Curiosity in children nature has provided, to remove that
ignorance they were born with; which, without this busy
<qex>inquisitiveness</qex>, will make them dull.</q>
<qau>Locke.</qau>

<hw>In*quis"i*tor</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[L.: cf.
F. <ets>inquisiteur</ets>. See <er>Inquire</er>.]</ety>
<sn>1.</sn> <def>An inquisitive person; one fond of asking
questions.</def> <mark>[R.]</mark> \'bd<xex>Inquisitors</xex> are
tatlers.\'b8

<au>Feltham.</au>

<sn>2.</sn> <fld>(Law)</fld> <def>One whose official duty it is
to examine and inquire, as coroners, sheriffs, etc.</def>

<au>Mozley & W.</au>

<sn>3.</sn> <fld>(R.C.Ch.)</fld> <def>A member of the Court of
Inquisition.</def>

<hw>In*quis`i*to"ri*al</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>a.</pos> <ety>[Cf.
F. <ets>inquisitorial</ets>.]</ety> <sn>1.</sn> <def>Pertaining

\'bdIlliberal and <xex>inquisitorial</xex> abuse.\'b8

<au>F. Blackburne.</au>

<q>He conferred on it a kind of <qex>inquisitorial</qex> and
censorious power even over the laity, and directed it to inquire
into all matters of conscience.</q>
<qau>Hume.</qau>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>Pertaining to the Court of Inquisition or
resembling its practices.</def> \'bd<xex>Inquisitorial</xex>
robes.\'b8

<au>C. Buchanan.</au>

<hw>In*quis`i*to"ri*al*ly</hw>, <pos>adv.</pos> <def>In an
inquisitorial manner.</def>

<hw>In"road`</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <def>The entrance

or desultory incursion or invasion; raid; encroachment.</def>

<q>The loss of Shrewsbury exposed all North Wales to the daily
<qex>inroads</qex> of the enemy.</q>
<qau>Clarendon.</qau>

<q>With perpetual <qex>inroads</qex> to alarm,
Though inaccessible, his fatal throne.</q>
<qau>Milton.</qau>

<syn>Syn. -- Invasion; incursion; irruption. See
<er>Invasion</er>.</syn>

<hw>In*sane"</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>a.</pos> <ety>[L.
<ets>insanus</ets>. See <er>In-</er> not, and
<er>Sane</er>.]</ety> <sn>1.</sn> <def>Exhibiting unsoundness or
disorded of mind; not sane; mad; deranged in mind; delirious;
distracted. See <er>Insanity</er>, 2.</def>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>Used by, or appropriated to, insane persons;
<as>as, an <ex>insane</ex> hospital</as>.</def>

<sn>3.</sn> <def>Causing insanity or madness.</def>
<mark>[R.]</mark>

<q>Or have we eaten on the <qex>insane</qex>root
That takes the reason prisoner ?</q>
<qau>Shak.</qau>

<sn>4.</sn> <def>Characterized by insanity or the utmost folly;
chimerical; unpractical; <as>as, an <ex>insane</ex> plan,
attempt, etc.</as></def>

<q>I know not which was the <qex>insane</qex> measure.</q>
<qau>Southey.</qau>

<hw>In*sane"ly</hw>, <pos>adv.</pos> <def>Without reason; madly;
foolishly.</def>

<hw>In*sane"ness</hw>, <pos>n.</pos> <def>Insanity;
madness.</def>

<def>Insanity.</def> <mark>[Obs.]</mark>

<au>Shak.</au>

<hw>In*san"i*ta*ry</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>a.</pos> <def>Not
sanitary; unhealthy; <as>as, <ex>insanitary</ex> conditions of
drainage</as>.</def>

<hw>In*san`i*ta"tion</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <def>Lack
of sanitation; careless or dangerous hygienic conditions.</def>

<hw>In*san"i*ty</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[L.
<ets>insanitas</ets> unsoundness; cf. <ets>insania</ets>
insanity, F. <ets>insanite</ets>.]</ety> <sn>1.</sn> <def>The
state of being insane; unsoundness or derangement of mind;
madness; lunacy.</def>

<q>All power of fancy overreason is a degree of
<qex>insanity</qex>.</q>
<qau>Johnson.</qau>

<q>Without grace
The heart's <qex>insanity</qex> admits no cure.</q>
<qau>Cowper.</qau>

<sn>2.</sn> <fld>(Law)</fld> <def>Such a mental condition,
<as>as, either from the existence of delusions, or from
incapacity to distinguish between right and wrong, with regard to
any matter under action, does away with individual
responsibility</as>.</def>

<syn>Syn>- <er>Insanity</er>, <er>Lunacy</er>, <er>Madness</er>,
<er>Derangement</er>, <er>Aliention</er>, <er>Aberration</er>,
<er>Mania</er>, <er>Delirium</er>, <er>Frenzy</er>,
<er>Monomania</er>, <er>Dementia</er>.</syn> <usage>
<xex>Insanity</xex> is the generic term for all such diseases;
<xex>lunacy</xex> has now an equal extent of meaning, though once
used to denote periodical insanity; <xex>madness</xex> has the
same extent, though originally referring to the rage created by
the disease; <xex>derangement</xex>, <xex>alienation</xex>, are
popular terms for insanity; <xex>delirium</xex>,
<xex>mania</xex>, and <xex>frenzy</xex> denote excited states of
the disease; <xex>dementia</xex> denotes the loss of mental power
by this means; <xex>monomania</xex> is insanity upon a single
subject.</usage>

<hw>In*sa"po*ry</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>a.</pos> <ety>[Pref.
<ets>in-</ets> not + <ets>sapor</ets>.]</ety> <def>Tasteless;
unsavory.</def> <mark>[R.]</mark>

<au>Sir T. Herbert.</au>

<hw>In*sa`tia*bil"i*ty</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos>, <ety>[L.
<ets>insatiabilitas</ets>; cf. F.
<ets>insatiabilite</ets>.]</ety> <def> The state or quality of
being insatiable; insatiableness.</def>

<q>Eagerness for increase of possession deluges the soul, and we
sink into the gulfs of <qex>insatiability</qex>.</q>
<qau>Rambler.</qau>

<hw>In*sa"tia*ble</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>a.</pos> <ety>[F.
<ets>insatiable</ets>, L. <ets>ionsatiabilis</ets>. See
<er>In-</er> not, and <er>Satiable</er>.]</ety> <def>Not
satiable; incapable of being satisfied or appeased; very greedy;
<as>as, an <ex>insatiable</ex> appetite, thirst, or
desire</as>.</def>

<q>\'bd<qex>Insatiable</qex> of glory.\'b8</q>
<qau>Milton.</qau>

<hw>In*sa"tia*ble*ness</hw>, <pos>n.</pos> <def>Greediness of
appetite that can not be satisfied or appeased;
insatiability.</def>

<q>The eye of the covetous hath a more particular
<qex>insatiableness</qex>.</q>
<qau>Bp. Hall.</qau>

<hw>In*sa"tia*bly</hw>, <pos>adv.</pos> <def>In an insatiable
manner or degree; unappeasably.</def> \'bd<xex>Insatiably</xex>
covetous.\'b8

<au>South.</au>

<hw>In*sa"ti*ate</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>a.</pos> <ety>[L.
<ets>insatiatus</ets>.]</ety> <def>Insatiable; <as>as,
<ex>insatiate</ex> thirst</as>.</def>

<au>Sir T. Herbert.</au>

<hw>In*sa"ti*ate*ness</hw>, <pos>n.</pos> <def>The state of being
insatiate.</def>

<hw>In"scient</hw>, <pos>a.</pos> <ety>[Pref. <ets>in-</ets> in +
L. <ets>sciens</ets> knowing.]</ety> <def>Having knowledge or
insight; intelligent.</def> <mark>[R.]</mark>

<q>Gaze on, with <qex>inscient</qex> vision, toward the sun.</q>
<qau>Mrs. Browning.</qau>

<hw>In*sconce"</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>v. t.</pos> <def>See
<er>Ensconce</er>.</def>

<hw>In*scrib"a*ble</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>a.</pos> <def>Capable
of being inscribed, -- used specif. <fld>(Math.)</fld> of solids
or plane figures capable of being inscribed in other solids or
figures.</def>

<hw>In*scrib"a*ble*ness</hw>, <pos>n.</pos> <def>Quality of being
inscribable.</def>

<hw>In*scribe"</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>v. t.</pos>
<wordforms>[<pos>imp. & p. p.</pos> <er>Inscribed</er>
<pr>(?)</pr>; <pos>p. pr. & vb. n.</pos>
<er>Inscribing</er>.]</wordforms> <ety>[L. <ets>inscribere</ets>.
See 1st <er>In-</er>, and <er>Scribe</er>.]</ety> <sn>1.</sn>
<def>To write or engrave; to mark down as something to be read;
to imprint.</def>

<q><qex>Inscribe</qex> a verse on this relenting stone.</q>
<qau>Pope.</qau>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>To mark with letters, charakters, or
words.</def>

<q>O let thy once lov'd friend <qex>inscribe</qex> thy stone.</q>
<qau>Pope.</qau>

<sn>3.</sn> <def>To assign or address to; to commend to by a shot
address; to dedicate informally; <as>as, to <ex>inscribe</ex> an
ode to a friend</as>.</def>

<au>Dryden.</au>

<sn>4.</sn> <def>To imprint deeply; to impress; to stamp; <as>as,
to <ex>inscribe</ex> a sentence on the memory</as>.</def>

<sn>5.</sn> <fld>(Geom.)</fld> <def>To draw within so as to meet
yet not cut the boundaries.</def>

<note><hand/ A <xex>line</xex> is inscribed in a circle, or in a
sphere, when its two ends are in the circumference of the circle,
or in the surface of the sphere. A <xex>triangle</xex> is
inscribed in another triangle, when the three angles of the
former are severally on the three sides of the latter. A
<xex>circle</xex> is inscribed in a polygon, when it touches each
side of the polygon. A <xex>sphere</xex> is inscribed in a
polyhedron, when the sphere touches each boundary plane of the
polyhedron. The latter figure in each case is
<xex>circumscribed</xex> about the former.</note>

<hw>In*scrib"er</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <def>One who
inscribes.</def>

<au>Pownall.</au>

<hw>In*scrip"ti*ble</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>a.</pos> <def>Capable
of being inscribed; inscribable.</def>

<hw>In*scrip"tion</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[L.
<ets>inscriptio</ets>, fr.<ets>inscribere</ets>,
<ets>inscriptum</ets>, to inscribe: cf. F.
<ets>inscription</ets>. See <er>Inscribe</er>.]</ety> <sn>1.</sn>
<def>The act or process of inscribing.</def>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>That which is inscribed; something written or
engraved; especially, a word or words written or engraved on a
solid substance for preservation or public inspection; <as>as,
<ex>inscriptions</ex> on monuments, pillars, coins, medals,
etc.</as></def>

<sn>3.</sn> <fld>(Anat.)</fld> <def>A line of division or
intersection; <as>as, the tendinous <ex>inscriptions</ex>, or
intersections, of a muscle</as>.</def>

<sn>4.</sn> <def>An address, consignment, or informal dedication,
as of a book to a person, as a mark of respect or an invitation
of patronage.</def>

<hw>In*scrip"tive</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>a.</pos> <def>Bearing
inscription; of the character or nature of an inscription.</def>

<hw>In*scroll"</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>v. t.</pos>
<wordforms>[<pos>imp. & p. p.</pos> <er>Inscrolled</er>
<pr>(?)</pr>; <pos>p. pr. & vb. n.</pos>
<er>Inscrolling</er>.]</wordforms> <def>To write on a scroll; to
record.</def> <altsp>[Written also <asp>inscrol</asp>.]</altsp>

<au>Shak.</au>

<hw>In*scru`ta*bil"i*ty</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <def>The
quality or state of being inscrutable; inscrutableness.</def>

<hw>In*scru"ta*ble</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>a.</pos> <ety>[L.
<ets>inscrutabilis</ets> : cf. F. <ets>inscrutable</ets>. See
<er>In-</er> not, and <er>Scrutiny</er>.]</ety>
<def>Unsearchable; incapable of being searched into and
understood by inquiry or study; impossible or difficult to be
explained or accounted for satisfactorily; obscure;
incomprehensible; <as>as, an <ex>inscrutable</ex> design or
event</as>.</def>

<q>'T is not in man
To yield a reason for the will of Heaven
Which is <qex>inscrutable</qex>.</q>
<qau>Beau. & Fl.</qau>

<q>Waiving a question so <qex>inscrutable</qex> as this.</q>
<qau>De Quincey.</qau>

<hw>In*scru"ta*ble*ness</hw>, <pos>n.</pos> <def>The quality or
state of being inscrutable; inscrutability.</def>

<hw>In*scru"ta*bly</hw>, <pos>adv.</pos> <def>In an inscrutable
manner.</def>

<hw>In*sculp"</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>v. t.</pos> <ety>[L.

<q>Which he <qex>insculped</qex> in two likely stones.</q>
<qau>Drayton.</qau>

<def>Engraved.</def>

<hw>In*sec"a*ble</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>a.</pos> <ety>[L.
<ets>insecabilis</ets>; pref. <ets>in-</ets> not +
<ets>secabilis</ets> that may be cut: cf. F.
<ets>insecable</ets>.]</ety> <def>Incapable of being divided by
