<hw>In"sect</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos>
<ety>[F.<ets>insecte</ets>, <ets>L</ets>. <ets>insectum</ets>,
fr. <ets>insectus</ets>, p.p. of <ets>insecare</ets> to cut in.
See <er>Section</er>. The name was originally given to certain
small animals, whose bodies appear <ets>cut in</ets>, or almost
divided. Cf. <er>Entomology</er>.]</ety> <sn>1.</sn>
<fld>(Zo\'94l.)</fld> <def>One of the Insecta; esp., one of the
Hexapoda. See <er>Insecta</er>.</def>

<note><hand/ The hexapod insects pass through three stages during
their growth, viz., the larva, pupa, and imago or adult, but in
some of the orders the larva differs little from the imago,
except in lacking wings, and the active pupa is very much like
the larva, except in having rudiments of wings. In the higher
orders, the larva is usually a grub, maggot, or caterpillar,
totally unlike the adult, while the pupa is very different from
both larva and imago and is inactive, taking no food.</note>

<sn>2.</sn> <fld>(Zo\'94l.)</fld> <def>Any air-breathing
arthropod, as a spider or scorpion.</def>

<sn>3.</sn> <fld>(Zo\'94l.)</fld> <def>Any small crustacean. In a
wider sense, the word is often loosely applied to various small
invertebrates.</def>

<sn>4.</sn> <def>Fig.: Any small, trivial, or contemptible person
or thing.</def>

<au>Thomson.</au>
<-- Russian: bukashka -->

<cs><col>Insect powder</col>,<cd>a powder used for the
extermination of insects; esp., the powdered flowers of certain
species of <spn>Pyrethrum</spn>, a genus now merged in
<spn>Chrysanthemum</spn>. Called also <altname>Persian
powder</altname>.</cd></cs><-- containing pyrethrin -->

<hw>In"sect</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>a.</pos> <sn>1.</sn> <def>Of
or pertaining to an insect or insects.</def>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>Like an insect; small; mean; ephemeral.</def>

<hw>\'d8In*sec"ta</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n. pl.</pos> <ety>[NL.
See <er>Insect</er>.]</ety> <sn>1.</sn> <fld>(Zo\'94l.)</fld>
<def>One of the classes of Arthropoda, including those that have
one pair of antenn\'91, three pairs of mouth organs, and breathe
air by means of trache\'91, opening by spiracles along the sides
of the body. In this sense it includes the Hexapoda, or
six-legged insects and the Myriapoda, with numerous legs. See
<er>Insect</er>, <pos>n.</pos></def>

<sn>2.</sn> <fld>(Zo\'94l.)</fld> <def>In a more restricted
sense, the Hexapoda alone. See <er>Hexapoda</er>.</def>

<sn>3.</sn> <fld>(Zo\'94l.)</fld> <def>In the most general sense,
the Hexapoda, Myriapoda, and Arachnoidea, combined.</def>

<note><hand/ The typical Insecta, or hexapod insects, are divided
into several orders, viz.: <stype>Hymenoptera</stype>, as the
bees and ants; <stype>Diptera</stype>, as the common flies and
gnats; <stype>Aphaniptera</stype>, or fleas;
<stype>Lepidoptera</stype>, or moths and butterflies;
<stype>Neuroptera</stype>, as the ant-lions and hellgamite;
<stype>Coleoptera</stype>, or beetles; <stype>Hemiptera</stype>,
as bugs, lice, aphids; <stype>Orthoptera</stype>, as grasshoppers
and cockroaches; <stype>Pseudoneuroptera</stype>, as the dragon
flies and termites; <stype>Euplexoptera</stype>, or earwings;
<stype>Thysanura</stype>, as the springtails, podura, and
lepisma. See these words in the Vocabulary.</note>

<hw>In"sec*ta*ry</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <def>A place
for keeping living insects.</def> --
<wordforms><wf>In`sec*ta"ri*um</wf> <pr>(#)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos>
<ety>[L.]</ety></wordforms>

<hw>\'d8In`sec*tiv"o*ra</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n. pl.</pos>
<ety>[NL., from L. <ets>insectum</ets> an insect +
<ets>vorare</ets> to devour.]</ety> <fld>(Zo\'94l.)</fld>
<sn>1.</sn> <def>An order of mammals which feed principally upon
insects.</def>

<note><hand/ They are mostly of small size, and their molar teeth
have sharp cusps. Most of the species burrow in the earth, and
many of those of cold climates hibernate in winter. The order
includes the moles, shrews, hedgehogs, tanrecs, and allied
animals, also the colugo.</note>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>A division of the Cheiroptera, including the
common or insect-eating bats.</def>

<hw>In*sec"ti*vore</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos>; <plu>pl.
<plw>Insectivores</plw> <pr>(-v<omac/rz)</pr></plu>.
<ety>[F.]</ety> <fld>(Zo\'94l.)</fld> <def>One of the
Insectivora.</def>

<hw>In`sec*tiv"o*rous</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>a.</pos> <ety>[See
<er>Insectivora</er>.]</ety> <def>Feeding or subsisting on
insects; carnivorous</def>. The term is applied: <sd>(a)</sd> to
<def>plants which have some special adaptation for catching and
digesting insects, as the sundew, Venus's flytrap, Sarracenia,
etc.</def> <sd>(b)</sd> to <def>the Insectivora, and to many
bats, birds, and reptiles.</def>

<hw>In`sec*tol"o*ger</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <def>An
entomologist.</def> <mark>[Obs.]</mark>

<ety>[<ets>Insect</ets> + -<ets>logy</ets>: cf. F.
<ets>insectologie</ets>.]</ety> <def>Entomology.</def>

<hw>In`se*cure"</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>a.</pos> <sn>1.</sn>
<def>Not secure; not confident of safety or permanence;

<q>With sorrow and <qex>insecure</qex> apprehensions.</q>
<qau>Jer. Taylor.</qau>

<au>Bp. Hurg.</au>

<q>The trade with Egypt was exceedingly <qex>insecure</qex> and
precarious.</q>
<qau>Mickle.</qau>

<hw>In`se*cu"ri*ty</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos>; <plu>pl.
<plw>Insecurities</plw> <pr>(#)</pr></plu>.
<ety>[Pref.<ets>in-</ets> not + <ets>security</ets> : cf. LL.
<ets>insecuritas</ets>, F. <ets>insecurite</ets>.]</ety>
<sn>1.</sn> <def>The condition or quality of being insecure; want
of safety; danger; hazard; <as>as, the <ex>insecurity</ex> of a
building liable to fire; <ex>insecurity</ex> of a
debt.</as></def>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>The state of feeling insecure; uncertainty; want
of confidence.</def>

<q>With what <qex>insecurity</qex> of truth we ascribe effects .
. . unto arbitrary calculations.</q>
<qau>Sir T. Browne.</qau>

<q>A time of <qex>insecurity</qex>, when interests of all sorts
become objects of speculation.</q>
<qau>Burke.</qau>

<hw>In*sen`si*bil"i*ty</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[Cf.
F. <ets>insensibilit\'82</ets>.]</ety>

<sn>1.</sn> <def>The state or quality of being insensible; want
of sensibility; torpor; unconsciousness; <as>as, the
<ex>insensibility</ex> produced by a fall, or by
opiates</as>.</def>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>Want of tenderness or susceptibility of emotion
or passion; dullness; stupidity.</def>

<syn>Syn. -- Dullness; numbness; unfeelingness; stupidity;
torpor; apathy; impassiveness; indifference.</syn>

<hw>In*sen"si*ble</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>a.</pos> <ety>[L.
<ets>insensibilis</ets>: cf. F. <ets>insensible</ets>. See
<er>In-</er> not, and <er>Sensible</er>.]</ety>

<sn>1.</sn> <def>Destitute of the power of feeling or perceiving;
wanting bodily sensibility.</def>

<au>Milton.</au>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>Not susceptible of emotion or passion; void of
feeling; apathetic; unconcerned; indifferent; <as>as,
<ex>insensible</ex> to danger, fear, love, etc.</as>; -- often
used with <xex>of</xex> or <xex>to</xex>.</def>

<q>Accept an obligation without being a slave to the giver, or
<qex>insensible</qex> to his kindness.</q>
<qau>Sir H. Wotton.</qau>

<q>Lost in their loves, <qex>insensible</qex> of shame.</q>
<qau>Dryden.</qau>

<sn>3.</sn> <def>Incapable of being perceived by the senses;
imperceptible. Hence: Progressing by imperceptible degrees; slow;
gradual; <as>as, <ex>insensible</ex> motion</as>.</def>

<q>Two small and almost <qex>insensible</qex> pricks were found
upon Cleopatra's arm.</q>
<qau>Sir T. Browne.</qau>

<q>They fall away,
And languish with <qex>insensible</qex> decay.</q>
<qau>Dryden.</qau>

<sn>4.</sn> <def>Not sensible or reasonable; meaningless.</def>
<mark>[Obs.]</mark>

<q>If it make the indictment be <qex>insensible</qex> or
uncertain, it shall be quashed.</q>
<qau>Sir M. Hale.</qau>

<syn>Syn. -- Imperceptible; imperceivable; dull; stupid; torpid;
numb; unfeeling; apathetic; stoical; impassive; indifferent;
unsusceptible; hard; callous.</syn>

<hw>In*sen"si*ble*ness</hw>, <pos>n.</pos>
<def>Insensibility.</def>

<au>Bp. Hall.</au>

<hw>In*sen"si*bly</hw>, <pos>adv.</pos> <def>In a manner not to
be felt or perceived; imperceptibly; gradually.</def>

<q>The hills rise <qex>insensibly</qex>.</q>
<qau>Addison.</qau>

<hw>In*sen"si*tive</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>a.</pos> <def>Not
sensitive; wanting sensation, or wanting acute sensibility.</def>

<au>Tillotson. Ruskin.</au>

<hw>In*sen"su*ous</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>a.</pos> <ety>[Pref.
<ets>in-</ets> not + <ets>sensuous</ets>.]</ety> <def>Not
sensuous; not pertaining to, affecting, or addressing, the
senses.</def>

<q>That intermediate door
Betwixt the different planes of sensuous form
And form <qex>insensuous</qex>.</q>
<qau>Mrs. Browning.</qau>

<hw>In*sen"ti*ment</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>a.</pos> <def>Not
sentient; not having perception, or the power of
perception.</def>

<q>The . . . attributes of an <qex>insentient</qex>, inert
substance.</q>
<qau>Reid.</qau>

<q>But there can be nothing like to this sensation in the rose,
because it is <qex>insentient</qex>.</q>
<qau>Sir W. Hamilton.</qau>

<hw>In*sep`a*ra*bil"i*ty</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos>
<ety>[L. <ets>inseparabilitas</ets>: cf. F.
<ets>ins\'82parabilit\'82</ets>.]</ety> <def>The quality or state
of being inseparable; inseparableness.</def>

<au>Locke.</au>

<hw>In*sep"a*ra*ble</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>a.</pos> <ety>[L.
<ets>inseparabilis</ets>: cf. F. <ets>ins\'82parable</ets>. See
<er>In-</er>, and <er>Separable</er>.]</ety>

<sn>1.</sn> <def>Not separable; incapable of being separated or
disjoined.</def>

<q>The history of every language is <qex>inseparable</qex> from
that of the people by whom it is spoken.</q>
<qau>Mure.</qau>

<q>Liberty and union, now and forever, one and
<qex>inseparable</qex>.</q>
<qau>D. Webster.</qau>

<sn>2.</sn> <fld>(Gram.)</fld> <def>Invariably attached to some
word, stem, or root; <as>as, the <ex>inseparable</ex> particle
<ex>un</ex>-</as>.</def>

<hw>In*sep"a*ra*ble*ness</hw>, <pos>n.</pos> <def>The quality or
state of being inseparable; inseparability.</def>

<au>Bp. Burnet.</au>

<hw>In*sep"a*ra*bly</hw>, <pos>adv.</pos> <def>In an inseparable
manner or condition; so as not to be separable.</def>

<au>Bacon.</au>

<q>And cleaves through life <qex>inseparably</qex> close.</q>
<qau>Cowper.</qau>

<hw>In*sep"a*rate</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>a.</pos> <ety>[L.
<ets>inseparatus</ets>. See <er>In-</er> not, and

<au>Cranmer.</au>

<hw>In*sert"</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>v. t.</pos>
<wordforms>[<pos>imp. & p. p.</pos> <er>Inserted</er>; <pos>p.
pr. & vb. n.</pos> <er>Inserting</er>.]</wordforms> <ety>[L.
<ets>insertus</ets>, p. p. of <ets>inserere</ets> to insert;
pref. <ets>in-</ets> in + <ets>serere</ets> to join, connect. See
<er>Series</er>.]</ety> <def>To set within something; to put or
thrust in; to introduce; to cause to enter, or be included, or
contained; <as>as, to <ex>insert</ex> a scion in a stock; to
<ex>insert</ex> a letter, word, or passage in a composition; to
<ex>insert</ex> an advertisement in a newspaper.</as></def>

<q>These words were very weakly <qex>inserted</qex> where they
will be so liable to misconstruction.</q>
<qau>Bp. Stillingfleet.</qau>

<hw>In*sert"ed</hw>, <pos>a.</pos> <fld>(Bot.)</fld>
<def>Situated upon, attached to, or growing out of, some part; --
said especially of the parts of the flower; <as>as, the calyx,
corolla, and stamens of many flowers are <ex>inserted</ex> upon
the receptacle</as>.</def>

<au>Gray.</au>

<hw>In*sert"ing</hw>, <pos>n.</pos> <sn>1.</sn> <def>A setting
in.</def>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>Something inserted or set in, as lace, etc., in
garments.</def> <mark>[R.]</mark>

<hw>In*ser"tion</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[L.
<ets>insertio</ets>: cf. F. <ets>insertion</ets>. See
<er>Insert</er>.]</ety>

<sn>1.</sn> <def>The act of inserting; <as>as, the
<ex>insertion</ex> of scions in stocks; the <ex>insertion</ex> of
words or passages in writings.</as></def>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>The condition or mode of being inserted or
attached; <as>as, the <ex>insertion</ex> of stamens in a
calyx</as>.</def>

<sn>3.</sn> <def>That which is set in or inserted, especially a
narrow strip of embroidered lace, muslin, or cambric.</def>

<sn>4.</sn> <fld>(Anat.)</fld> <def>The point or part by which a
muscle or tendon is attached to the part to be moved; -- in
contradistinction to its <xex>origin</xex>.</def>

<cs><col>Epigynous insertion</col> <fld>(Bot.)</fld>, <cd>the
insertion of stamens upon the ovary.</cd> -- <col>Hypogynous
insertion</col> <fld>(Bot.)</fld>, <cd>insertion beneath the
ovary.</cd></cs>

<hw>In"side`</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>prep.</pos> or

<hw>In"side`</hw>, <pos>a</pos> <sn>1.</sn> <def>Being within;
included or inclosed in anything; contained; interior; internal;
<as>as, the <ex>inside</ex> passengers of a stagecoach;
<ex>inside</ex> decoration.</as></def>

<q>Kissing with <qex>inside</qex> lip.</q>
<qau>Shak.</qau>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>Adapted to the interior.</def>

<cs><col>Inside callipers</col> <fld>(Mech.)</fld>, <cd>callipers
for measuring the diameters of holes, etc.</cd> -- <col>Inside
finish</col> <fld>(Arch.)</fld>, <cd>a general term for the final
work in any building necessary for its completion, but other than
unusual decoration; thus, in joiner work, the doors and windows,
inside shutters, door and window trimmings, paneled jams,
baseboards, and sometimes flooring and stairs; in plaster work,
the finishing coat, the cornices, centerpieces, etc.,; in
painting, all simple painting of woodwork and plastering.</cd> --
<col>Inside track</col>, <cd>the inner part of a race course;
hence, colloquially, advantage of place, facilities, etc., in
competition.</cd></cs>

<hw>In"side`</hw>, <pos>n.</pos> <sn>1.</sn> <def>The part
within; interior or internal portion; content.</def>

<q>Looked he o' the <qex>inside</qex> of the paper?</q>
<qau>Shak.</qau>

<sn>2.</sn> <pluf>pl.</pluf> <def>The inward parts; entrails;
bowels; hence, that which is within; private thoughts and
feelings.</def>

<q>Here's none but friends; we may speak
Our <qex>insides</qex> freely.</q>
<qau>Massinger.</qau>

<sn>3.</sn> <def>An inside passenger of a coach or carriage, as
distinguished from one upon the outside.</def> <mark>[Colloq.
Eng.]</mark>

<q>So down thy hill, romantic Ashbourne, glides
The Derby dilly, carrying three <qex>insides</qex>.</q>
<qau>Anti-Jacobin.</qau>

<cs><mcol><col>Patent insides</col> <or/
<col>outside</col></mcol>, <cd>a name give to newspaper sheets
printed on one side with general and miscellaneous matter, and
furnished wholesale to offices of small newspapers, where the
blank pages are filled up with recent and local news.</cd></cs>

<hw>In*sid"i*ate</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>v. t.</pos> <ety>[L.

<hw>In*sid"i*ous</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>a.</pos> <ety>[L.
<ets>insidiosus</ets>, fr. <ets>insidiae</ets> an ambush, fr.
<ets>insidere</ets> to sit in; pref. <ets>in-</ets> +
<ets>sedere</ets> to sit: cf. F. <ets>insidieux</ets>. See
<er>Sit</er>.]</ety>

<sn>1.</sn> <def>Lying in wait; watching an opportunity to
insnare or entrap; deceitful; sly; treacherous; -- said of
persons; <as>as, the <ex>insidious</ex> foe</as>.</def> \'bdThe
<xex>insidious</xex> witch.\'b8

<au>Cowper.</au>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>Intended to entrap; characterized by treachery
and deceit; <as>as, <ex>insidious</ex> arts</as>.</def>

<q>The <qex>insidious</qex> whisper of the bad angel.</q>
<qau>Hawthorne.</qau>

<cs><col>Insidious disease</col> <fld>(Med.)</fld>, <cd>a disease
existing, without marked symptoms, but ready to become active
upon some slight occasion; a disease not appearing to be as bad
as it really is.</cd></cs>

<syn>Syn. -- Crafty; wily; artful; sly; designing; guileful;
circumventive; treacherous; deceitful; deceptive.</syn>

<hw>In"sight`</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <sn>1.</sn> <def>A

<q>He had an <qex>insight</qex> into almost all the secrets of
state.</q>
<qau>Jortin.</qau>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>Power of acute observation and deduction;
penetration; discernment; perception.</def>

<q>Quickest <qex>insight</qex>
In all things that to greatest actions lead.</q>
<qau>Milton.</qau>

<hw>In*sig"ni*a</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n. pl.</pos> <ety>[L.
<ets>insigne</ets>, pl. <ets>insignia</ets>, fr.
<ets>insignis</ets> distinguished by a mark; pref. <ets>in-</ets>

<er>Sign</er>.]</ety>

<sn>1.</sn> <def>Distinguishing marks of authority, office, or
honor; badges; tokens; decorations; <as>as, the <ex>insignia</ex>
of royalty or of an order</as>.</def>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>Typical and characteristic marks or signs, by
which anything is known or distinguished; <as>as, the
<ex>insignia</ex> of a trade</as>.</def>

<hw>In`sig*nif"i*cance</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos>
<sn>1.</sn> <def>The condition or quality of being insignificant;
want of significance, sense, or meaning; <as>as, the
<ex>insignificance</ex> of words or phrases</as>.</def>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>Want of force or effect; unimportance;
pettiness; inefficacy; <as>as, the <ex>insignificance</ex> of
human art</as>.</def>

<sn>3.</sn> <def>Want of claim to consideration or notice; want
of influence or standing; meanness.</def>

<q>Reduce him, from being the first person in the nation, to a
state of <qex>insignificance</qex>.</q>
<qau>Beattie.</qau>

<hw>In`sig*nif"i*can*cy</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos>
<def>Insignificance.</def>

<hw>In`sig*nif"i*cant</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>a.</pos>
<sn>1.</sn> <def>Not significant; void of signification, sense,
or import; meaningless; <as>as, <ex>insignificant</ex>
words</as>.</def>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>Having no weight or effect; answering no
purpose; unimportant; valueless; futile.</def>

<q>Laws must be <qex>insignificant</qex> without the sanction of
rewards and punishments.</q>
<qau>Bp. Wilkins.</qau>

<sn>3.</sn> <def>Without weight of character or social standing;
mean; contemptible; <as>as, an <ex>insignificant</ex>
person</as>.</def>

<syn>Syn. -- Unimportant; immaterial; inconsiderable; small;
inferior; trivial; mean; contemptible.</syn>

<hw>In`sig*nif"i*cant*ly</hw>, <pos>adv.</pos> <def>without
significance, importance, or effect; to no purpose.</def>
\'bdAnger <xex>insignificantly</xex> fierce.\'b8

<au>Cowper.</au>

<er>Significative</er>.]</ety> <def>Not expressing meaning; not

<hw>In`sin*cere"</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>a.</pos> <ety>[L.
<ets>insincerus</ets>. See <er>In-</er> not, and
<er>Sincere</er>.]</ety>

<sn>1.</sn> <def>Not being in truth what one appears to be; not
sincere; dissembling; hypocritical; disingenuous; deceitful;
false; -- said of persons; also of speech, thought; etc.; <as>as,
<ex>insincere</ex> declarations</as>.</def>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>Disappointing; imperfect; unsound.</def>
<mark>[Obs.]</mark>

<q>To render sleep's soft blessings <qex>insincere</qex>.</q>
<qau>Pope.</qau>

<syn>Syn. -- Dissembling; hollow; hypocritical; deceptive
deceitful; false; disingenuous; untrustworthy.</syn>

<hw>In`sin*cere"ly</hw>, <pos>adv.</pos> <def>Without
sincerity.</def>

<hw>In`sin*cer"i*ty</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[Cf. F.
<ets>insinc\'82rit\'82</ets>.]</ety> <def>The quality of being
insincere; want of sincerity, or of being in reality what one
appears to be; dissimulation; hypocritical; deceitfulness;
hollowness; untrustworthiness; <as>as, the <ex>insincerity</ex>
of a professed friend; the <ex>insincerity</ex> of professions of
regard.</as></def>

<q>What men call policy and knowledge of the world, is commonly
no other thing than dissimulation and <qex>insincerity</qex>.</q>
<qau>Blair.</qau>

<hw>In*sin"ew</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>v. t.</pos>
<wordforms>[<pos>imp. & p. p.</pos> <er>Insinewed</er>
<pr>(?)</pr>; <pos>p. pr. & vb. n.</pos>
<er>Insinewing</er>.]</wordforms> <def>To strengthen, as with
sinews; to invigorate.</def> <mark>[Obs.]</mark>

<q>All members of our cause, . . . 
That are <qex>insinewed</qex> to this action.</q>
<qau>Shak.</qau>

<hw>In*sin"u*ant</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>a.</pos> <ety>[L.
<ets>insinuans</ets>, p. pr.: cf. F. <ets>insinuant</ets>.]</ety>
<def>Insinuating; insinuative.</def> <mark>[Obs.]</mark>

<hw>In*sin"u*ate</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>v. t.</pos>
<wordforms>[<pos>imp. & p. p.</pos> <er>Insinuated</er>
<pr>(?)</pr>; <pos>p. pr. & vb. n.</pos>
<er>Insinuating</er>.]</wordforms> <ety>[L.
<ets>insinuatus</ets>, p. p. of <ets>insinuare</ets>to insinuate;
pref. <ets>in-</ets> in + <ets>sinus</ets> the bosom. See
<er>Sinuous</er>.]</ety>

<sn>1.</sn> <def>To introduce gently or slowly, as by a winding
or narrow passage, or a gentle, persistent movement.</def>

<q>The water easily <qex>insinuates</qex> itself into, and
placidly distends, the vessels of vegetables.</q>
<qau>Woodward.</qau>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>To introduce artfully; to infuse gently; to
instill.</def>

<q>All the art of rhetoric, besides order and clearness, are for
nothing else but to <qex>insinuate</qex> wrong ideas, move the
passions, and thereby mislead the judgment.</q>
<qau>Locke.</qau>

<q>Horace laughs to shame all follies and <qex>insinuates</qex>
virtue, rather by familiar examples than by the severity of
precepts.</q>
<qau>Dryden.</qau>

<sn>3.</sn> <def>To hint; to suggest by remote allusion; -- often
used derogatorily; as, did you mean to <xex>insinuate</xex>
anything?</def>

<sn>4.</sn> <def>To push or work (one's self), as into favor; to
introduce by slow, gentle, or artful means; to ingratiate; --
used reflexively.</def>

<q>He <qex>insinuated</qex> himself into the very good grace of
the Duke of Buckingham.</q>
<qau>Clarendon.</qau>

<syn>Syn. -- To instill; hint; suggest; intimate.</syn>

<hw>In*sin"u*ate</hw>, <pos>v. i.</pos> <sn>1.</sn> <def>To
creep, wind, or flow in; to enter gently, slowly, or
imperceptibly, as into crevices.</def>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>To ingratiate one's self; to obtain access or
favor by flattery or cunning.</def>

<q>He would <qex>insinuate</qex> with thee but to make thee
sigh.</q>
<qau>Shak.</qau>

<q>To <qex>insinuate</qex>, flatter, bow, and bend my limbs.</q>
<qau>Shak.</qau>

<hw>In*sin"u*a`ting</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>a.</pos>
<def>Winding, creeping, or flowing in, quietly or stealthily;
suggesting; winning favor and confidence insensibly.</def>

<au>Milton.</au>

<q>His address was courteous, and even
<qex>insinuating</qex>.</q>
<qau>Prescott.</qau>

<hw>In*sin"u*a`ting*ly</hw>, <pos>adv.</pos> <def>By
insinuation.</def>

<hw>In*sin"u*a`tion</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[L.
<ets>insinuatio</ets>: cf. F. <ets>insinuation</ets>.]</ety>

<sn>1.</sn> <def>The act or process of insinuating; a creeping,
winding, or flowing in.</def>

<q>By a soft <qex>insinuation</qex> mix'd
With earth's large mass.</q>
<qau>Crashaw.</qau>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>The act of gaining favor, affection, or
influence, by gentle or artful means; -- formerly used in a good
sense, as of friendly influence or interposition.</def>

<au>Sir H. Wotton.</au>

<q>I hope through the <qex>insinuation</qex> of Lord Scarborough
to keep them here till further orders.</q>
<qau>Lady Cowper.</qau>

<sn>3.</sn> <def>The art or power of gaining good will by a
prepossessing manner.</def>

<q>He bad a natural <qex>insinuation</qex> and address which made
him acceptable in the best company.</q>
<qau>Clarendon.</qau>

<sn>4.</sn> <def>That which is insinuated; a hint; a suggestion
or intimation by distant allusion; <as>as, slander may be
conveyed by <ex>insinuations</ex></as>.</def>

<q>I scorn your coarse <qex>insinuation</qex>.</q>
<qau>Cowper.</qau>

<syn>Syn. -- Hint; intimation; suggestion. See
<er>Innuendo</er>.</syn>

<-- p. 770 -->

<hw>In*sin"u*a*tive</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>a.</pos> <ety>[Cf. F.
<ets>insinuatif</ets>.]</ety>

<sn>1.</sn> <def>Stealing on or into the confidence or
affections; having power to gain favor.</def> \'bdCrafty,
<xex>insinuative</xex>, plausible men.\'b8

<au>Bp. Reynolds.</au>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>Using insinuations; giving hints; insinuating;
<as>as, <ex>insinuative</ex> remark</as>.</def>

<hw>In*sin"u*a`tor</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[L., an
introducer.]</ety> <def>One who, or that which, insinuates.</def>

<au>De Foe.</au>

<hw>In*sin"u*a*to*ry</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>a.</pos>
<def>Insinuative.</def>

<hw>In*sip"id</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>a.</pos> <ety>[L.
<ets>insipidus</ets>; pref. <ets>in-</ets> not +
<ets>sapidus</ets> savory, fr. <ets>sapere</ets> to taste: cf. F.
<ets>insipide</ets>. See <er>Savor</er>.]</ety>

<sn>1.</sn> <def>Wanting in the qualities which affect the organs
of taste; without taste or savor; vapid; tasteless; <as>as,
<ex>insipid</ex> drink or food</as>.</def>

<au>Boyle.</au>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>Wanting in spirit, life, or animation;
uninteresting; weak; vapid; flat; dull; heavy; <as>as, an
<ex>insipid</ex> woman; an <ex>insipid</ex>
composition.</as></def>

<q>Flat, <qex>insipid</qex>, and ridiculous stuff to him.</q>
<qau>South.</qau>

<q>But his wit is faint, and his salt, if I may dare to say so,
almost <qex>insipid</qex>.</q>
<qau>Dryden.</qau>

<syn>Syn. -- Tasteless; vapid; dull; spiritless; unanimated;
lifeless; flat; stale; pointless; uninteresting.</syn>

<mhw>{ <hw>In`si*pid"i*ty</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>,

<hw>In*sist"</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>v. i.</pos>
<wordforms>[<pos>imp. & p. p.</pos> <er>Insisted</er>; <pos>p.
pr. & vb. n.</pos> <er>Insisting</er>.]</wordforms> <ety>[F.
<ets>insister</ets>, L. <ets>insistere</ets> to set foot upon,
follow, persist; pref. <ets>in-</ets> in + <ets>sistere</ets> to
stand, cause to stand. See <er>Stand</er>.]</ety>

<sn>1.</sn> <def>To stand or rest; to find support; -- with
<xex>in</xex>, <xex>on</xex>, or <xex>upon</xex>.</def>
<mark>[R.]</mark>

<au>Ray.</au>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>To take a stand and refuse to give way; to hold
to something firmly or determinedly; to be persistent, urgent, or
pressing; to persist in demanding; -- followed by <xex>on</xex>,
<xex>upon</xex>, or <xex>that</xex>; <as>as, he <ex>insisted</ex>
on these conditions; he <ex>insisted</ex> on going at once; he
<ex>insists</ex> that he must have money.</as></def>

<q><qex>Insisting</qex> on the old prerogative.</q>
<qau>Shak.</qau>

<q>Without further <qex>insisting</qex> on the different tempers
of Juvenal and Horace.</q>
<qau>Dryden.</qau>

<syn>Syn. -- <er>Insist</er>, <er>Persist</er>.</syn>  --
<usage><xex>Insist</xex> implies some alleged right, as authority
or claim. <xex>Persist</xex> may be from obstinacy alone, and
either with or against rights. We <xex>insist</xex> as against
others; we <xex>persist</xex> in what exclusively relates to
ourselves; <as>as, he <ex>persisted</ex> in that course</as>; he
<xex>insisted</xex> on his friend's adopting it.</usage>

<au>C. J. Smith.</au>

<hw>In*sist"ence</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <def>The
quality of insisting, or being urgent or pressing; the act of
dwelling upon as of special importance; persistence;
urgency.</def>

<hw>In*sist"ent</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>a.</pos> <ety>[L.
<ets>insistens</ets>, <ets>-entis</ets>, p. pr. of
<ets>insistere</ets>.]</ety>

<ex>insistent</ex> wall</as>.</def>

<au>Sir H. Wotton.</au>

<sn>3.</sn> <fld>(Zo\'94l.)</fld> <def>See
<er>Incumbent</er>.</def>

<au>Shak.</au>

<hw>In"so*lence</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[F.
<ets>insolence</ets>, L. <ets>insolentia</ets>. See
<er>Insolent</er>.]</ety>

<sn>1.</sn> <def>The quality of being unusual or novel.</def>
<mark>[Obs.]</mark>

<au>Spenser.</au>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>The quality of being insolent; pride or
haughtiness manifested in contemptuous and overbearing treatment
of others; arrogant contempt; brutal imprudence.</def>

<q>Flown with <qex>insolence</qex> and wine.</q>
<qau>Milton.</qau>

<sn>3.</sn> <def>Insolent conduct or treatment; insult.</def>

<q>Loaded with fetters and <qex>insolences</qex> from the
soldiers.</q>
<qau>Fuller.</qau>

<hw>In"so*lence</hw>, <pos>v. t.</pos> <def>To insult.</def>
<mark>[Obs.]</mark>

<au>Eikon Basilike.</au>

<hw>In"so*len*cy</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos>
<def>Insolence.</def> <mark>[R.]</mark>

<au>Evelyn.</au>

<hw>In"so*lent</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>a.</pos> <ety>[F.
<ets>insolent</ets>, L. <ets>insolens</ets>, <ets>-entis</ets>,
pref. <ets>in-</ets> not + <ets>solens</ets> accustomed, p. pr.
of <ets>solere</ets> to be accustomed.]</ety>

<sn>1.</sn> <def>Deviating from that which is customary; novel;
strange; unusual.</def> <mark>[Obs.]</mark>

<q>If one chance to derive any word from the Latin which is
<qex>insolent</qex> to their ears . . . they forth with make a
jest at it.</q>
<qau>Petti<?/<?/</qau>

<q>If any should accuse me of being new or
<qex>insolent</qex>.</q>
<qau>Milton.</qau>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>Haughty and contemptuous or brutal in behavior
or language; overbearing; domineering; grossly rude or
disrespectful; saucy; <as>as, an <ex>insolent</ex> master; an
<ex>insolent</ex> servant.</as></def> \'bdA paltry,
<xex>insolent</xex> fellow.\'b8

<au>Shak.</au>

<q><qex>Insolent</qex> is he that despiseth in his judgment all
other folks as in regard of his value, of his cunning, of his
speaking, and of his bearing.</q>
<qau>Chaucer.</qau>

<q>Can you not see? or will ye not observe . . . 
How <qex>insolent</qex> of late he is become,
How proud, how peremptory?</q>
<qau>Shak.</qau>

<sn>3.</sn> <def>Proceeding from or characterized by insolence;
insulting; <as>as, <ex>insolent</ex> words or
behavior</as>.</def>

<q>Their <qex>insolent</qex> triumph excited . . .
indignation.</q>
<qau>Macaulay.</qau>

<syn>Syn. -- Overbearing; insulting; abusive; offensive; saucy;
impudent; audacious; pert; impertinent; rude; reproachful;
opprobrious.</syn> <usage> -- <er>Insolent</er>,
<er>Insulting</er>. <xex>Insolent</xex>, in its primitive sense,
simply denoted <xex>unusual</xex>; and to act
<xex>insolently</xex> was to act in violation of the established
rules of social intercourse. He who did this was
<xex>insolent</xex>; and thus the word became one of the most
offensive in our language, indicating gross disregard for the
feelings of others. <xex>Insulting</xex> denotes a personal
attack, either in words or actions, indicative either of scorn or
triumph. Compare <er>Impertinent</er>, <er>Affront</er>,
<er>Impudence</er>.</usage>

<hw>In"so*lent*ly</hw>, <pos>adv.</pos> <def>In an insolent
manner.</def>

<ets>in-</ets> not + <ets>solidity</ets>: cf. F.
<ets>insolidit\'82</ets>.]</ety> <def>Want of solidity; weakness;
<as>as, the <ex>insolidity</ex> of an argument</as>.</def>

<au>Dr. H. More.</au>

<hw>In*sol`u*bil"i*ty</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[L.
<ets>insolubilitas</ets>: cf. F.
<ets>insolubilit\'82</ets>.]</ety>

<sn>1.</sn> <def>The quality or state of being insoluble or not
dissolvable, as in a fluid.</def>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>The quality of being inexplicable or
insolvable.</def>

<hw>In*sol"u*ble</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>a.</pos> <ety>[L.
<ets>insolubilis</ets> indissoluble, that can not be loosed: cf.
F. <ets>insoluble</ets>. See <er>In-</er> not, and
<er>Soluble</er>, and cf. <er>Insolvable</er>.]</ety>

<sn>1.</sn> <def>Not soluble; in capable or difficult of being
dissolved, as by a liquid; <as>as, chalk is <ex>insoluble</ex> in
water</as>.</def>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>Not to be solved or explained; insolvable;
<as>as, an <ex>insoluble</ex> doubt, question, or
difficulty</as>.</def>

<sn>3.</sn> <def>Strong.</def> \'bdAn <xex>insoluble</xex>
wall.\'b8 <mark>[Obs.]</mark>

<au>Holland</au>

<hw>In*sol"u*ble*ness</hw>, <pos>n.</pos> <def>The quality or
state of being insoluble; insolubility</def>.

<au>Boyle.</au>

<hw>In*solv"a*ble</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>a.</pos> <sn>1.</sn>
<def>Not solvable; insoluble; admitting no solution or
explanation; <as>as, an <ex>insolvable</ex> problem or
difficulty</as>.</def>

<au>I. Watts.</au>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>Incapable of being paid or discharged, as
debts.</def>

<sn>3.</sn> <def>Not capable of being loosed or disentangled;
inextricable.</def> \'bdBands <xex>insolvable</xex>.\'b8

<au>Pope.</au>

<hw>In*sol"ven*cy</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos>; <plu>pl.
<plw>Insolvencies</plw> <pr>(<?/)</pr>.</plu> <fld>(Law)</fld>
<sd>(a)</sd> <def>The condition of being insolvent; the state or
condition of a person who is insolvent; the condition of one who
is unable to pay his debts as they fall due, or in the usual
course of trade and business; <as>as, a merchant's
<ex>insolvency</ex></as>.</def> <sd>(b)</sd> <def>Insufficiency
to discharge all debts of the owner; <as>as, the
<ex>insolvency</ex> of an estate</as>.</def>

<cs><col>Act of insolvency</col>. <cd>See <cref>Insolvent
law</cref> under <er>Insolvent</er>, <pos>a.</pos></cd></cs>

<hw>In*sol"vent</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>a.</pos> <ety>[Pref.
<ets>in-</ets> not + <ets>solvent</ets>: cf. OF.
<ets>insolvent</ets>.]</ety> <fld>(Law)</fld> <sd>(a)</sd>
<def>Not solvent; not having sufficient estate to pay one's
debts; unable to pay one's debts as they fall due, in the
ordinary course of trade and business; <as>as, in
<ex>insolvent</ex> debtor</as>.</def> <sd>(b)</sd> <def>Not
sufficient to pay all the debts of the owner; <as>as, an
<ex>insolvent</ex> estate</as>.</def> <sd>(c)</sd> <def>Relating
to persons unable to pay their debts.</def>

<cs><mcol><col>Insolvent law</col>, <or/ <col>Act of
insolvency</col></mcol>, <cd>a law affording relief, -- subject
to various modifications in different States, -- to insolvent
debtors, upon their delivering up their property for the benefit
of their creditors. See <cref>Bankrupt law</cref>, under
<er>Bankrupt</er>, <pos>a.</pos></cd></cs>

<hw>In*sol"vent</hw>, <pos>n.</pos> <fld>(Law)</fld> <def>One who
is insolvent; as insolvent debtor; -- in England, before 1861,
especially applied to persons not traders.</def>

<au>Bouvier.</au>

<hw>In*spect"</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>v. t.</pos>
<wordforms>[<pos>imp. & p. p.</pos> <er>Inspected</er>; <pos>p.
pr. & vb. n.</pos> <er>Inspecting</er>.]</wordforms> <ety>[L.
<ets>inspectus</ets>, p. p. of <ets>inspicere</ets> to inspect;
pref. <ets>in-</ets> in  + <ets>specere</ets> to look at, to
view: cf. F. <ets>inspecter</ets>, fr. L. <ets>inspectare</ets>,
freq. fr. <ets>inspicere</ets>. See <er>Spy</er>.]</ety>

<sn>1.</sn> <def>To look upon; to view closely and critically,
esp. in order to ascertain quality or condition, to detect
errors, etc., to examine; to scrutinize; to investigate; <as>as,
to <ex>inspect</ex> conduct</as>.</def>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>To view and examine officially, as troops, arms,
goods offered, work done for the public, etc.; to oversee; to
superintend.</def>

<au>Sir W. Temple.</au>

<hw>In*spect"</hw>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[L. <ets>inspectus</ets>.
See <er>Inspect</er>, <pos>v. t.</pos>]</ety>

<au>Thomson.</au>

<hw>In*spect"tion</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[L.
<ets>inspectio</ets>: cf. F. <ets>inspection</ets>.]</ety>

<sn>1.</sn> <def>The act or process of inspecting or looking at
carefully; a strict or prying examination; close or careful
scrutiny; investigation.</def>

<au>Spenser.</au>

<q>With narrow search, and with <qex>inspection</qex> deep,
Considered every creature.</q>
<qau>Milton.</qau>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>The act of overseeing; official examination or
superintendence.</def>

<cs><col>Trial by inspection</col> <fld>(O. Eng. Law)</fld>,
<cd>a mode of trial in which the case was settled by the
individual observation and decision of the judge upon the
testimony of his own senses, without the intervention of a
jury.</cd></cs>

<au>Abbott.</au>

<hw>In*spect"ive</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>a.</pos> <ety>[L.
<ets>inspectivus</ets>.]</ety> <def>Engaged in inspection;
inspecting; involving inspection.</def>

<hw>In*spect"or</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[L.: cf. F.
<ets>inspecteur</ets>.]</ety> <def>One who inspects, views, or
oversees; one to whom the supervision of any work is committed;
one who makes an official view or examination, as a military or
civil officer; a superintendent; a supervisor; an overseer.</def>

<cs><col>Inspector general</col> <fld>(Mil.)</fld>, <cd>a staff
officer of an army, whose duties are those of inspection, and
embrace everything relative to organization, recruiting,
discharge, administration, accountability for money and property,
instruction, police, and discipline.</cd></cs>

<hw>In*spect"or*ate</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos>
<def>Inspectorship.</def> <mark>[R.]</mark>

pertaining to an inspector or to inspection.</def>

<def>The office of an inspector.</def>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>The district embraced by an inspector's
jurisdiction.</def>

<hw>In*sperse"</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>v. t.</pos> <ety>[L.
<ets>inspersus</ets>, p. p. of <ets>inspergere</ets> to sprinkle
upon; pref. <ets>in-</ets> in, on + <ets>spargere</ets> to
sprinkle.]</ety> <def>To sprinkle; to scatter.</def>
<mark>[Obs.]</mark>

<au>Bailey.</au>

<hw>In*sper"sion</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[L.
<ets>inspersio</ets>.]</ety> <def>The act of sprinkling.</def>
<mark>[Obs.]</mark>

<au>Chapman.</au>

<hw>\'d8In*spex"i*mus</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[L.,
we have inspected.]</ety> <def>The first word of ancient charters
in England, confirming a grant made by a former king; hence, a
royal grant.</def>

<hw>In*sphere"</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>v. t.</pos>
<wordforms>[<pos>imp. & p. p.</pos> <er>Insphered</er>
<pr>(?)</pr>; <pos>p. pr. & vb. n.</pos>
<er>Insphering</er>.]</wordforms> <ety>[Cf.
<er>Ensphere</er>.]</ety> <def>To place in, or as in, an orb a
sphere. Cf. <er>Ensphere</er>.</def>

<q>Bright a\'89rial spirits live <qex>insphered</qex>
In regions mild of calm and serene air.</q>
<qau>Milton.</qau>

<hw>In*spir"a*ble</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>a.</pos> <def>Capable
of being inspired or drawn into the lungs; inhalable; respirable;
admitting inspiration.</def>

<au>Harvey.</au>

<hw>In`spi*ra"tion</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[F.
<ets>inspiration</ets>, L. <ets>inspiratio</ets>. See
<er>Inspire</er>.]</ety>

<sn>1.</sn> <def>The act of inspiring or breathing in; breath;
specif. <fld>(Physiol.)</fld>, the drawing of air into the lungs,
accomplished in mammals by elevation of the chest walls and
flattening of the diaphragm; -- the opposite of
<xex>expiration</xex>.</def>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>The act or power of exercising an elevating or
stimulating influence upon the intellect or emotions; the result
of such influence which quickens or stimulates; <as>as, the
<ex>inspiration</ex> of occasion, of art, etc.</as></def>

<q>Your father was ever virtuous, and holy men at their death
have good <qex>inspirations</qex>.</q>
<qau>Shak.</qau>

<sn>3.</sn> <fld>(Theol.)</fld> <def>A supernatural divine
influence on the prophets, apostles, or sacred writers, by which
they were qualified to communicate moral or religious truth with
authority; a supernatural influence which qualifies men to
receive and communicate divine truth; also, the truth
communicated.</def>

<q>All Scripture is given by <qex>inspiration</qex> of God.</q>
<qau>2 Tim. iii. 16.</qau>

<q>The age which we now live in is not an age of
<qex>inspiration</qex> and impulses.</q>
<qau>Sharp.</qau>

<cs><col>Plenary inspiration</col> <fld>(Theol.)</fld>, <cd>that
kind of inspiration which excludes all defect in the utterance of
the inspired message.</cd> -- <col>Verbal inspiration</col>
<fld>(Theol.)</fld>, <cd>that kind of inspiration which extends
to the very words and forms of expression of the divine
message.</cd></cs>

<hw>In`spi*ra"tion*al</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>a.</pos>
<def>Pertaining to inspiration.</def>

<hw>In`spi*ra"tion*ist</hw>, <pos>n.</pos> <def>One who holds to
inspiration.</def>

<hw>In"spi*ra`tor</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos>
<fld>(Mach.)</fld> <def>A kind of injector for forcing water by
steam. See <er>Injector</er>, <pos>n.</pos>, 2.</def>

<hw>In*spir"to*ry</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>a.</pos>
<def>Pertaining to, or aiding, inspiration; <as>as, the
<ex>inspiratory</ex> muscles</as>.</def>

<hw>In*spire"</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>v. t.</pos> <ety>[OE.
<ets>enspiren</ets>, OF. <ets>enspirer</ets>,
<ets>inspirer</ets>, F. <ets>inspirer</ets>, fr. L.
<ets>inspirare</ets>; pref. <ets>in-</ets> in +
<ets>spirare</ets> to breathe. See <er>Spirit</er>.]</ety>

<sn>1.</sn> <def>To breathe into; to fill with the breath; to
animate.</def>

<q>When Zephirus eek, with his sweete breath,
<qex>Inspir\'8ad</qex> hath in every holt and health
The tender crops.</q>
<qau>Chaucer.</qau>

<q>Descend, ye Nine, descend and sing,
The breathing instruments <qex>inspire</qex>.</q>
<qau>Pope.</qau>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>To infuse by breathing, or as if by
breathing.</def>

<q>He knew not his Maker, and him that <qex>inspired</qex> into
him an active soul.</q>
<qau>Wisdom xv. 11.</qau>

<sn>3.</sn> <def>To draw in by the operation of breathing; to
inhale; -- opposed to <xex>expire</xex>.</def>

<q>Forced to <qex>inspire</qex> and expire the air with
difficulty.</q>
<qau>Harvey.</qau>

<-- p. 771 -->

<sn>4.</sn> <def>To infuse into the mind; to communicate to the
spirit; to convey, as by a divine or supernatural influence; to
disclose preternaturally; to produce in, as by inspiration.</def>

<q>And generous stout courage did <qex>inspire</qex>.</q>
<qau>Spenser.</qau>

<q>But dawning day new comfort hath <qex>inspired</qex>.</q>
<qau>Shak.</qau>

<sn>5.</sn> <def>To infuse into; to affect, as with a superior or
supernatural influence; to fill with what animates, enlivens, or
exalts; to communicate inspiration to; <as>as, to
<ex>inspire</ex> a child with sentiments of virtue</as>.</def>

<q>Erato, thy poet's mind <qex>inspire</qex>,
And fill his soul with thy celestial fire.</q>
<qau>Dryden.</qau>

<hw>In*spire"</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>v. i.</pos>
<wordforms>[<pos>imp. & p. p.</pos> <er>Inspired</er>; <pos>p.
pr. & vb. n.</pos> <er>Inspiring</er>.]</wordforms>

<sn>1.</sn> <def>To draw in breath; to inhale air into the lungs;
-- opposed to <xex>expire</xex>.</def>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>To breathe; to blow gently.</def>
<mark>[Obs.]</mark>

<q>And when the wind amongst them did <qex>inspire</qex>,
They wav\'8ad like a penon wide dispread.</q>
<qau>Spenser.</qau>

<hw>In*spired"</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>a.</pos> <sn>1.</sn>
<def>Breathed in; inhaled.</def>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>Moved or animated by, or as by, a supernatural
influence; affected by divine inspiration; <as>as, the
<ex>inspired</ex> prophets; the <ex>inspired</ex>
writers.</as></def>

<sn>3.</sn> <def>Communicated or given as by supernatural or
divine inspiration; having divine authority; hence, sacred, holy;
-- opposed to <xex>uninspired</xex>, <xex>profane</xex>, or
<xex>secular</xex>; <as>as, the <ex>inspired</ex> writings, that
is, the Scriptures</as>.</def>

<hw>In*spir"er</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <def>One who, or
that which, inspirer.</def> \'bd<xex>Inspirer</xex> of that holy
flame.\'b8

<au>Cowper.</au>

<hw>In*spir"ing</hw>, <pos>a.</pos> <def>Animating; cheering;
moving; exhilarating; <as>as, an <ex>inspiring</ex> or
scene</as>.</def>

<hw>In*spir"it</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>v. t.</pos>
<wordforms>[<pos>imp. & p. p.</pos> <er>Inspirited</er>; <pos>p.
pr. & vb. n.</pos> <er>Inspiriting</er>.]</wordforms> <def>To
infuse new life or spirit into; to animate; to encourage; to
invigorate.</def>

<q>The courage of Agamemnon is <qex>inspirited</qex> by the love
of empire and ambition.</q>
<qau>Pope.</qau>

<syn>Syn. -- To enliven; invigorate; exhilarate; animate; cheer;
encourage; inspire.</syn>

<hw>In*spis"sate</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>v. t.</pos>
<wordforms>[<pos>imp. & p. p.</pos> <er>Inspissated</er>
<pr>(?)</pr>; <pos>p. pr. & vb. n.</pos> <er>Inspissating</er>
<pr>(?)</pr>.]</wordforms> <ety>[L. <ets>inspissatus</ets>, p. p.
of <ets>inspissare</ets> to thicken; pref. <ets>in-</ets> +
<ets>spissare</ets> to thicken, fr. <ets>spissus</ets>
thick.]</ety> <def>To thicken or bring to greater consistence, as
fluids by evaporation.</def>

<hw>In*spis"sate</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>a.</pos> <ety>[L.
<ets>inspissatus</ets>, p. p.]</ety> <def>Thick or thickened;
inspissated.</def>

<au>Greenhill.</au>

<hw>In`spis*sa"tion</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <def>The act
or the process of inspissating, or thickening a fluid substance,
as by evaporation; also, the state of being so thickened.</def>

<hw>In`sta*bil"i*ty</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos>; <plu>pl.
<plw>Instabilities</plw> <pr>(#)</pr></plu>. <ety>[L.
<ets>instabilitas</ets>: cf. F. <ets>instabilit\'82</ets>.]</ety>

<sn>1.</sn> <def>The quality or condition of being unstable; want
of stability, firmness, or steadiness; liability to give way or
to fail; insecurity; precariousness; <as>as, the
<ex>instability</ex> of a building</as>.</def>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>Lack of determination of fixedness; inconstancy;
fickleness; mutability; changeableness; <as>as,
<ex>instability</ex> of character, temper, custom,
etc.</as></def>

<au>Addison.</au>

<syn>Syn. -- Inconstancy; fickleness; changeableness; wavering;
unsteadiness; unstableness.</syn>

<hw>In*sta"ble</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>a.</pos> <ety>[L.
<ets>instabilis</ets>: cf. F. <ets>instable</ets>. See
<er>In-</er> not, and <er>Stable</er>, <pos>a.</pos>, and cf.
<er>Unstable</er>.]</ety> <def>Not stable; not standing fast or
firm; unstable; prone to change or recede from a purpose;
mutable; inconstant.</def>

<hw>In*sta"ble*ness</hw>, <pos>n.</pos> <def>Instability;
unstableness.</def>

<hw>In*stall"</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>v. t.</pos>
<wordforms>[<pos>imp. & p. p.</pos> <er>Installed</er>
<pr>(?)</pr>; <pos>p. pr. & vb. n.</pos>
<er>Installing</er>.]</wordforms> <ety>[F. <ets>installer</ets>,
LL. <ets>installare</ets>, fr. pref. <ets>in-</ets> in + OHG.
<ets>stal</ets> a place, stall, G. <ets>stall</ets>, akin to E.
<ets>stall</ets>: cf. It. <ets>installare</ets>. See
<er>Stall</er>.]</ety> <altsp>[Written also
<asp>instal</asp>.]</altsp>

<sn>1.</sn> <def>To set in a seat; to give a place to; establish
(one) in a place.</def>

<q>She <qex>installed</qex> her guest hospitably by the
fireside.</q>
<qau>Sir W. Scott.</qau>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>To place in an office, rank, or order; to invest
with any charge by the usual ceremonies; to instate; to induct;
<as>as, to <ex>install</ex> an ordained minister as pastor of a
church; to <ex>install</ex> a college president.</as></def>

<q>Unworthily
Thou wast <qex>installed</qex> in that high degree.</q>
<qau>Shak.</qau>

<hw>In`stal*la"tion</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[F.
<ets>installation</ets>, LL. <ets>installatio</ets>: cf. It.
<ets>installazione</ets>. See <er>Install</er>.]</ety>

<sn>1.</sn> <def>The act of installing or giving possession of an
office, rank, or order, with the usual rites or ceremonies;
<as>as, the <ex>installation</ex> of an ordained minister in a
parish</as>.</def>

<q>On the election, the bishop gives a mandate for his
<qex>installation</qex>.</q>
<qau>Ayliffe.</qau>

<sn>2.</sn> <fld>(Mech.)</fld> <def>The whole of a system of
machines, apparatus, and accessories, when set up and arranged
for practical working, as in electric lighting, transmission of
power, etc.</def>

<hw>In*stall"ment</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[Written
also <ets>instalment</ets>.]</ety>

<sn>1.</sn> <def>The act of installing; installation.</def>

<q>Take oaths from all kings and magistrates at their
<qex>installment</qex>, to do impartial justice by law.</q>
<qau>Milton.</qau>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>The seat in which one is placed.</def>
<mark>[Obs.]</mark>

<q>The several chairs of order, look, you scour; . . . 
Each fair <qex>installment</qex>, coat, and several crest
With loyal blazon, evermore be blest.</q>
<qau>Shak.</qau>

<sn>3.</sn> <def>A portion of a debt, or sum of money, which is
divided into portions that are made payable at different times.
Payment by <xex>installment</xex> is payment by parts at
different times, the amounts and times being often definitely
stipulated.</def>

<au>Bouvier.</au>

<hw>In*stamp"</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>v. t.</pos> <def>See
<er>Enstamp</er>.</def>

<hw>In"stance</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[F.
<ets>instance</ets>, L. <ets>instantia</ets>, fr.
<ets>instans</ets>. See <er>Instant</er>.]</ety>

<sn>1.</sn> <def>The act or quality of being instant or pressing;
urgency; solicitation; application; suggestion; motion.</def>

<q>Undertook at her <qex>instance</qex> to restore them.</q>
<qau>Sir W. Scott.</qau>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>That which is instant or urgent; motive.</def>
<mark>[Obs.]</mark>

<q>The <qex>instances</qex> that second marriage move
Are base respects of thrift, but none of love.</q>
<qau>Shak.</qau>

<sn>3.</sn> <def>Occasion; order of occurrence.</def>

<q>These seem as if, in the time of Edward I., they were drawn up
into the form of a law, in the first <qex>instance</qex>.</q>
<qau>Sir M. Hale.</qau>

<sn>4.</sn> <def>That which offers itself or is offered as an
illustrative case; something cited in proof or exemplification; a
case occurring; an example.</def>

<q>Most remarkable <qex>instances</qex> of suffering.</q>
<qau>Atterbury.</qau>

<sn>5.</sn> <def>A token; a sign; a symptom or indication.</def>

<au>Shak.</au>

<cs><col>Causes of instance</col>, <cd>those which proceed at the
solicitation of some party. <au>Hallifax</au>.</cd> -- <col>Court
of first instance</col>, <cd>the court by which a case is first
tried.</cd> -- <col>For instance</col>, <cd>by way of example or
illustration.</cd> -- <col>Instance Court</col> <fld>(Law)</fld>,
<cd>the Court of Admiralty acting within its ordinary
jurisdiction, as distinguished from its action as a <xex>prize
court<xex>.</cd></cs>

<syn>Syn. -- Example; case. See <er>Example</er>.</syn>

<hw>In"stance</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>v. t.</pos>
<wordforms>[<pos>imp. & p. p.</pos> <er>Instanced</er>
<pr>(?)</pr>; <pos>p. pr. & vb. n.</pos> <er>Instancing</er>
<pr>(?)</pr>.]</wordforms> <def>To mention as a case or example;
to refer to; to cite; <as>as, to <ex>instance</ex> a
fact</as>.</def>

<au>H. Spenser.</au>

<q>I shall not <qex>instance</qex> an abstruse author.</q>
<qau>Milton.</qau>

<hw>In"stance</hw>, <pos>v. i.</pos> <def>To give an
example.</def> <mark>[Obs.]</mark>

<q>This story doth not only <qex>instance</qex> in kingdoms, but
in families too.</q>
<qau>Jer. Taylor.</qau>

<hw>In"stan*cy</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <def>Instance;
urgency.</def> <mark>[Obs.]</mark>

<q>Those heavenly precepts which our Lord and Savior with so
great <qex>instancy</qex> gave.</q>
<qau>Hooker.</qau>

<hw>In"stant</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>a.</pos> <ety>[L.
<ets>instans</ets>, <ets>-antis</ets>, p. pr. of
<ets>instare</ets> to stand upon, to press upon; pref.
<ets>in-</ets> in, on + <ets>stare</ets> to stand: cf. F.
<ets>in<?/tant</ets>. See <er>Stand</er>.]</ety>

<sn>1.</sn> <def>Pressing; urgent; importunate; earnest.</def>

<q>Rejoicing in hope; patient in tribulation; continuing
<qex>instant</qex> in prayer.</q>
<qau>Rom. xii. 12.            </qau>

<q>I am beginning to be very <qex>instant</qex> for some sort of
occupation.</q>
<qau>Carlyle.</qau>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>Closely pressing or impending in respect to
time; not deferred; immediate; without delay.</def>

<q>Impending death is thine, and <qex>instant</qex> doom.</q>
<qau>Prior.</qau>

<sn>3.</sn> <def>Present; current.</def>

<q>The <qex>instant</qex> time is always the fittest time.</q>
<qau>Fuller.</qau>

<note><hand/ The word in this sense is now used only in dates, to
indicate the current month; as, the tenth of July
<xex>instant</xex>.</note>

<hw>In"stant</hw>, <pos>adv.</pos> <def>Instantly.</def>
<mark>[Poetic]</mark>

<q><qex>Instant</qex> he flew with hospitable haste.</q>
<qau>Pope.</qau>

<hw>In"stant</hw>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[F. <ets>instant</ets>, fr.
L. <ets>instans</ets> standing by, being near, present. See
<er>Instant</er>, <pos>a.</pos>]</ety>

<sn>1.</sn> <def>A point in duration; a moment; a portion of time
too short to be estimated; also, any particular moment.</def>

<q>There is scarce an <qex>instant</qex> between their
flourishing and their not being.</q>
<qau>Hooker.</qau>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>A day of the present or current month; <as>as,
the sixth <ex>instant</ex>; -- an elliptical expression
equivalent to the sixth of the month <ex>instant</ex>, i. e., the
current month</as>. See <er>Instant</er>, <pos>a.</pos>, 3.</def>

<syn>Syn. -- Moment; flash; second.</syn>

<hw>In*stan`ta*ne"i*ty</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[Cf.
F. <ets>instantan\'82it\'82</ets>.]</ety> <def>Quality of being
instantaneous.</def>

<au>Shenstone.</au>

<hw>In`stan*ta"ne*ous</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>a.</pos> <ety>[Cf.
F. <ets>instantan\'82</ets>.]</ety>

<sn>1.</sn> <def>Done or occurring in an instant, or without any
perceptible duration of time; <as>as, the passage of electricity
appears to be <ex>instantaneous</ex></as>.</def>

<q>His reason saw
With <qex>instantaneous</qex> view, the truth of things.</q>
<qau>Thomson.</qau>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>At or during a given instant; <as>as,
<ex>instantaneous</ex> acceleration, velocity, etc.</as></def>

<cs><col>Instantaneous center of rotation</col>
<fld>(Kinematics)</fld>, <cd>in a plane or in a plane figure
which has motions both of translation and of rotation in the
plane, is the point which for the instant is at rest.</cd> --
<col>Instantaneous axis of rotation</col>
<fld>(Kinematics)</fld>, <cd>in a body which has motions both of
translation and rotation, is a line, which is supposed to be
rigidly united with the body, and which for the instant is at
rest. The motion of the body is for the instant simply that of
rotation about the instantaneous axis.</cd></cs>

-- <wordforms><wf>In`stan*ta"ne*ous*ly</wf>, <pos>adv.</pos> --
<wf>In`stan*ta"ne*ous*ness</wf>, <pos>n.</pos></wordforms>

<pos>a.</pos>]</ety> <def>Immediately; instantly; at once;
<as>as, he left <ex>instanter</ex></as>.</def>

<au>Macaulay.</au>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>With urgency or importunity; earnestly;

<au>Luke vii. 4.</au>

<hw>In*stau"rate</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>v. t.</pos>

<hw>In`stau*ra"tion</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[L.
<ets>instauratio</ets>: cf. F. <ets>instauration</ets>.]</ety>
<def>Restoration after decay, lapse, or dilapidation; renewal;
repair; renovation; renaissance.</def>

<q>Some great catastrophe or . . . <qex>instauration</qex>.</q>
<qau>T. Burnet.</qau>

<hw>In"stau*ra`tor</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[L.: cf.
F. <ets>instaurateur</ets>.]</ety> <def>One who renews or
restores to a former condition.</def> <mark>[R.]</mark>

<au>Dr. H. More.</au>

<hw>In*staure"</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>v. t.</pos> <ety>[See
<er>Instaurate</er>.]</ety> <def>To renew or renovate; to
instaurate.</def> <mark>[Obs.]</mark>

<au>Marston.</au>

<hw>In*stead"</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>adv.</pos> <ety>[Pref.
<ets>in-</ets> + <ets>stead</ets> place.]</ety>

<sn>1.</sn> <def>In the place or room; -- usually followed by
<xex>of</xex>.</def>

<q>Let thistles grow of wheat.</q>
<qau>Job xxxi. 40.</qau>

<q>Absalom made Amasa captain of the host <qex>instead</qex> of
Joab.</q>
<qau>2 Sam. xvii. 25.</qau>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>Equivalent; equal to; -- usually with
<xex>of</xex>.</def> <mark>[R.]</mark>

<q>This very consideration to a wise man is <qex>instead</qex> of
a thousand arguments, to satisfy him, that in those times no such
thing was believed.</q>
<qau>Tillotson.</qau>

<hw>In*steep"</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>v. t.</pos>
<wordforms>[<pos>imp. & p. p.</pos> <er>Insteeped</er>
<pr>(?)</pr>; <pos>p. pr. & vb. n.</pos>
<er>Insteeping</er>.]</wordforms> <def>To steep or soak; to
drench.</def> <mark>[R.]</mark> \'bdIn gore he lay
<xex>insteeped</xex>.\'b8

<au>Shak.</au>

<hw>In"step</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <altsp>[Formerly
also <asp>instop</asp>, <asp>instup</asp>.]</altsp>

<sn>1.</sn> <def>The arched middle portion of the human foot next
in front of the ankle joint.</def>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>That part of the hind leg of the horse and
allied animals, between the hock, or ham, and the pastern
joint.</def>

<hw>In"sti*gate</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>v. t.</pos>
<wordforms>[<pos>imp. & p. p.</pos> <er>Instigated</er>
<pr>(?)</pr>; <pos>p. pr. & vb. n.</pos> <er>Instigating</er>
<pr>(?)</pr>.]</wordforms> <ety>[L. <ets>instigatus</ets>, p. p.
of <ets>instigare</ets> to instigate; pref. <ets>in-</ets> in + a
root akin to G. <ets>stechen</ets> to prick, E. <ets>stick</ets>.
See <er>Stick</er>.]</ety> <def>To goad or urge forward; to set
on; to provoke; to incite; -- used chiefly with reference to evil
actions; as to <xex>instigate</xex> one to a crime.</def>

<q>He hath only <qex>instigated</qex> his blackest agents to the
very extent of their malignity.</q>
<qau>Bp. Warburton.</qau>

<syn>Syn. -- To stimulate; urge; spur; provoke; tempt; incite;
impel; encourage; animate.</syn>

<hw>In"sti*ga`ting*ly</hw>, <pos>adv.</pos> <def>Incitingly;
temptingly.</def>

<hw>In`sti*ga"tion</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[L.
<ets>instigatio</ets>: cf. F. <ets>instigation</ets>.]</ety>
<def>The act of instigating, or the state of being instigated;
incitement; esp. to evil or wickedness.</def>

<q>The baseness and villainy that . . . the
<qex>instigation</qex> of the devil could bring the sons of men
to.</q>
<qau>South.</qau>

<hw>In"sti*ga`tor</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[L.: cf.
F. <ets>instigateur</ets>.]</ety> <def>One who instigates or
incites.</def>

<au>Burke.</au>

<hw>In*still"</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>v. t.</pos>
<wordforms>[<pos>imp. & p. p.</pos> <er>Instilled</er>
<pr>(?)</pr>; <pos>p. pr. & vb. n.</pos>
<er>Instilling</er>.]</wordforms> <ety>[L. <ets>instillare</ets>,
<ets>instillatum</ets>; pref. <ets>in-</ets> in +
<ets>stillare</ets> to drop, fr. <ets>stilla</ets> a drop: cf. F.
<ets>instiller</ets>. See <er>Distill</er>.]</ety>
<altsp>[Written also <asp>instil</asp>.]</altsp> <def>To drop in;
to pour in drop by drop; hence, to impart gradually; to infuse
slowly; to cause to be imbibed.</def>

<q>That starlight dews
All silently their tears of love <qex>instill</qex>.</q>
<qau>Byron.</qau>

<q>How hast thou <qex>instilled</qex>
Thy malice into thousands.</q>
<qau>Milton.</qau>

<syn>Syn. -- To infuse; impart; inspire; implant; inculcate;
insinuate.</syn>

<ets>instillatio</ets>: cf. F. <ets>instillation</ets>.]</ety>

<au>Johnson.</au>

<hw>In*stinct"</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>a.</pos> <ety>[L.
<ets>instinctus</ets>, p. p. of <ets>instinguere</ets> to
instigate, incite; cf. <ets>instigare</ets> to instigate. Cf.
<er>Instigate</er>, <er>Distinguish</er>.]</ety> <def>Urged or
s<?/<?/mulated from within; naturally moved or impelled; imbued;
animated; alive; quick; <as>as, birds <ex>instinct</ex> with
life</as>.</def>

<q>The chariot of paternal deity . . . 
Itself <qex>instinct</qex> with spirit, but convoyed
By four cherubic shapes.</q>
<qau>Milton.</qau>

<q>A noble performance, <qex>instinct</qex> with sound
principle.</q>
<qau>Brougham.</qau>

<hw>In"stinct</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[L.
<ets>instinctus</ets> instigation, impulse, fr.
<ets>instinguere</ets> to instigate: cf. F. <ets>instinct</ets>.
See <er>Instinct</er>, <pos>a.</pos>]</ety>

<sn>1.</sn> <def>Natural inward impulse; unconscious,
involuntary, or unreasoning prompting to any mode of action,
whether bodily, or mental, without a distinct apprehension of the
end or object to be accomplished.</def>

<q>An <qex>instinct</qex> is a propensity prior to experience,
and independent of instructions.</q>
<qau>Paley.</qau>

<q>An <qex>instinct</qex> is a blind tendency to some mode of
action, independent of any consideration, on the part of the
agent, of the end to which the action leads.</q>
<qau>Whately.</qau>

<q>An <qex>instinct</qex> is an agent which performs blindly and
ignorantly a work of intelligence and knowledge.</q>
<qau>Sir W. Hamilton.</qau>

<q>By a divine <qex>instinct</qex>, men's minds mistrust
Ensuing dangers.</q>
<qau>Shak.</qau>

<sn>2.</sn> <fld>(Zo\'94l.)</fld> <def>Specif., the natural,
unreasoning, impulse by which an animal is guided to the
performance of any action, without of improvement in the
method.</def>

<q>The resemblance between what originally was a habit, and an
<qex>instinct</qex> becomes so close as not to be
distinguished.</q>
<qau>Darwin.</qau>

<sn>3.</sn> <def>A natural aptitude or knack; a predilection;
<as>as, an <ex>instinct</ex> for order; to be modest by
<ex>instinct</ex>.</as></def>

<hw>In*stinct"</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>v. t.</pos> <def>To
impress, as an animating power, or instinct.</def>
<mark>[Obs.]</mark>

<au>Bentley.</au>

<hw>In*stinc"tion</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <def>Instinct;
incitement; inspiration.</def> <mark>[Obs.]</mark>

<au>Sir T. Elyot.</au>

<hw>In*stinc"tive</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>a.</pos> <ety>[Cf. F.
<ets>instinctif</ets>.]</ety> <def>Of or pertaining to instinct;
derived from, or prompted by, instinct; of the nature of
instinct; determined by natural impulse or propensity; acting or
produced without reasoning, deliberation, instruction, or
experience; spontaneous.</def> \'bd<xex>Instinctive</xex>
motion.\'b8 <au>Milton</au>. \'bd<xex>Instinctive</xex>
dread.\'b8

<au>Cowper.</au>

<q>With taste <qex>instinctive</qex> give
Each grace appropriate.</q>
<qau>Mason.</qau>

<q>Have we had <qex>instinctive</qex> intimations of the death of
some absent friends?</q>
<qau>Bp. Hall.</qau>

<note><hand/ The terms <xex>instinctive belief</xex>,
<xex>instinctive judgment</xex>, <xex>instinctive
cognition</xex>, are expressions not ill adapted to characterize
a belief, judgment, or cognition, which, as the result of no
anterior consciousness, is, like the products of animal instinct,
the intelligent effect of (as far as we are concerned) an unknown
cause.</note>

<au>Sir H. Hamilton.</au>

<syn>Syn. -- Natural; voluntary; spontaneous; original; innate;
inherent; automatic.</syn>

<hw>In*stinc"tive*ly</hw>, <pos>adv.</pos> <def>In an instinctive
manner; by force of instinct; by natural impulse.</def>

<hw>In`stinc*tiv"i*ty</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <def>The
quality of being instinctive, or prompted by instinct.</def>
<mark>[R.]</mark>

<au>Coleridge.</au>

<hw>In*stip"u*late</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>a.</pos> <def>See
<er>Exstipulate</er>.</def>

<hw>In"sti*tute</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>p. a.</pos> <ety>[L.
<ets>institutus</ets>, p. p. of <ets>instituere</ets> to place
in, to institute, to instruct; pref. <ets>in-</ets> in +
<ets>statuere</ets> to cause to stand, to set. See
<er>Statute</er>.]</ety> <def>Established; organized;
founded.</def> <mark>[Obs.]</mark>

<q>They have but few laws. For to a people so instruct and
<qex>institute</qex>, very few to suffice.</q>
<qau>Robynson (More's Utopia).</qau>

<-- p. 772 -->

<hw>In"sti*tute</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>v. t.</pos>
<wordforms>[<pos>imp. & p. p.</pos> <er>Instituted</er>
<pr>(?)</pr>; <pos>p. pr. & vb. n.</pos>
<er>Instituting</er>.]</wordforms>

<sn>1.</sn> <def>To set up; to establish; to ordain; <as>as, to
<ex>institute</ex> laws, rules, etc.</as></def>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>To originate and establish; to found; to
organize; <as>as, to <ex>institute</ex> a court, or a
society</as>.</def>

<q>Whenever any from of government becomes destructive of these
ends it is the right of the people to alter or to abolish it, and
to <qex>institute</qex> a new government.</q>
<qau>Jefferson (Decl. of Indep. ).</qau>

<sn>3.</sn> <def>To nominate; to appoint.</def>
<mark>[Obs.]</mark>

<q>We <qex>institute</qex> your Grace
To be our regent in these parts of France.</q>
<qau>Shak.</qau>

<sn>4.</sn> <def>To begin; to commence; to set on foot; <as>as,
to <ex>institute</ex> an inquiry; to <ex>institute</ex> a
suit.</as></def>

<q>And haply <qex>institute</qex>
A course of learning and ingenious studies.</q>
<qau>Shak.</qau>

<sn>5.</sn> <def>To ground or establish in principles and
rudiments; to educate; to instruct.</def> <mark>[Obs.]</mark>

<q>If children were early <qex>instituted</qex>, knowledge would
insensibly insinuate itself.</q>
<qau>Dr. H. More.</qau>

<sn>6.</sn> <fld>(Eccl. Law)</fld> <def>To invest with the
spiritual charge of a benefice, or the care of souls.</def>

<au>Blackstone.</au>

<syn>Syn. -- To originate; begin; commence; establish; found;
erect; organize; appoint; ordain.</syn>

<hw>In"sti*tute</hw>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[L.
<ets>institutum</ets>: cf. F. <ets>institut</ets>. See
<er>Institute</er>, <pos>v. t.</pos> & <pos>a.</pos>]</ety>

<sn>1.</sn> <def>The act of instituting; institution.</def>
<mark>[Obs.]</mark> \'bdWater sanctified by Christ's
<xex>institute</xex>.\'b8

<au>Milton.</au>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>That which is instituted, established, or fixed,
as a law, habit, or custom.</def>

<au>Glover.</au>

<sn>3.</sn> <def>Hence: An elementary and necessary principle; a
precept, maxim, or rule, recognized as established and
authoritative; usually in the plural, a collection of such
principles and precepts; esp., a comprehensive summary of legal
principles and decisions; <as>as, the <ex>Institutes</ex> of
Justinian; Coke's <ex>Institutes</ex> of the Laws of
England</as>.  Cf. <er>Digest</er>, <pos>n.</pos></def>

<q>They made a sort of <qex>institute</qex> and digest of
anarchy.</q>
<qau>Burke.</qau>

<q>To make the Stoics' <qex>institutes</qex> thy own.</q>
<qau>Dryden.</qau>

<sn>4.</sn> <def>An institution; a society established for the
promotion of learning, art, science, etc.; a college; <as>as, the
<ex>Institute</ex> of Technology</as>; also, a building owned or
occupied by such an institute; <as>as, the Cooper
<ex>Institute</ex></as>.</def>

<sn>5.</sn> <fld>(Scots Law)</fld> <def>The person to whom an
estate is first given by destination or limitation.</def>

<au>Tomlins.</au>

<cs><col>Institutes of medicine</col>, <cd>theoretical medicine;
that department of medical science which attempts to account
philosophically for the various phenomena of health as well as of
disease; physiology applied to the practice of medicine.</cd>

<au>Dunglison.</au>
</cs>

<hw>In"sti*tu`ter</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <def>An
institutor.</def> <mark>[R.]</mark>

<hw>In`sti*tu"tion</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[L.
<ets>institutio</ets>: cf. F. <ets>institution</ets>.]</ety>

<sn>1.</sn> <def>The act or process of instituting; as:
<sd>(a)</sd> Establishment; foundation; enactment; <as>as, the
<ex>institution</ex> of a school</as>.</def>

<q>The <qex>institution</qex> of God's law is described as being
established by solemn injunction.</q>
<qau>Hooker.</qau>

<sd>(b)</sd> <def>Instruction; education</def>.
<mark>[Obs.]</mark> <au>Bentley</au>. <sd>(c)</sd> <fld>(Eccl.
Law)</fld> <def>The act or ceremony of investing a clergyman with
the spiritual part of a benefice, by which the care of souls is
committed to his charge</def>.

<au>Blackstone.</au>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>That which instituted or established</def>; as:
<sd>(a)</sd> <def>Established order, method, or custom;
enactment; ordinance; permanent form of law or polity.</def>

<q>The nature of our people,
Our city's <qex>institutions</qex>.</q>
<qau>Shak.</qau>

<sd>(b)</sd> <def>An established or organized society or
corporation; an establishment, especially of a public character,
or affecting a community; a foundation; as, a literary
<xex>institution</xex>; a charitable <xex>institution</xex>;
also, a building or the buildings occupied or used by such
organization; as, the Smithsonian <xex>Institution</xex></def>.
<sd>(c)</sd> <def>Anything forming a characteristic and
persistent feature in social or national life or habits</def>.

<q>We ordered a lunch (the most delightful of English
<qex>institutions</qex>, next to dinner) to be ready against our
return.</q>
<qau>Hawthorne.</qau>

<sn>3.</sn> <def>That which institutes or instructs; a textbook;
a system of elements or rules; an institute.</def>
<mark>[Obs.]</mark>

<q>There is another manuscript, of above three hundred years old,
. . . being an <qex>institution</qex> of physic.</q>
<qau>Evelyn.</qau>

<hw>In`sti*tu"tion*al</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>a.</pos>
<sn>1.</sn> <def>Pertaining to, or treating of, institutions;
<as>as, <ex>institutional</ex> legends</as>.</def>

<q><qex>Institutional</qex> writers as Rousseau.</q>
<qau>J. S. Mill.</qau>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>Instituted by authority.</def>

<sn>3.</sn> <def>Elementary; rudimental.</def>

<hw>In*struct"</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>a.</pos> <ety>[L.
<ets>instructus</ets>, p. p. of <ets>instruere</ets> to furnish,

<hw>In*struct"</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>v. t.</pos>
<wordforms>[<pos>imp. & p. p.</pos> <er>Instructed</er>; <pos>p.
pr. & vb. n.</pos> <er>Instructing</er>.]</wordforms>

<sn>1.</sn> <def>To put in order; to form; to prepare.</def>
<mark>[Obs.]</mark>

<q>They speak to the merits of a cause, after the proctor has
prepared and <qex>instructed</qex> the same for a hearing.</q>
<qau>Ayliffe.</qau>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>To form by communication of knowledge; to inform
the mind of; to impart knowledge or information to; to enlighten;
to teach; to discipline.</def>

<q>Schoolmasters will I keep within my house,
Fit to <qex>instruct</qex> her youth.</q>
<qau>Shak.</qau>

<sn>3.</sn> <def>To furnish with directions; to advise; to
direct; to command; <as>as, the judge <ex>instructs</ex> the
jury</as>.</def>

<q>She, being before <qex>instructed</qex> of her mother, said,
Give me here John Baptist's head in a charger.</q>
<qau>Matt. xiv. 8.</qau>

<q>Take her in; <qex>instruct</qex> her what she has to do.</q>
<qau>Shak.</qau>

<syn>Syn. -- To teach; educate; inform; train; discipline;
indoctrinate; direct; enjoin.</syn>

<hw>In*struc"tion</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[L.
<ets>instructio</ets>: cf. F. <ets>instruction</ets>.]</ety>

<sn>1.</sn> <def>The act of instructing, teaching, or furnishing
with knowledge; information.</def>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>That which instructs, or with which one is
instructed; the intelligence or information imparted; as:
<sd>(a)</sd> Precept; information; teachings. <sd>(b)</sd>
Direction; order; command.</def> \'bdIf my
<xex>instructions</xex> may be your guide.\'b8

<au>Shak.</au>

<syn>Syn. -- Education; teaching; indoctrination; information;
advice; counsel. See <er>Education</er>.</syn>

<hw>In*struc"tion*al</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>a.</pos>
<def>Pertaining to, or promoting, instruction; educational.</def>

<hw>In*struct"ive</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>a.</pos> <ety>[Cf. F.
<ets>instructif</ets>.]</ety> <def>Conveying knowledge; serving
to instruct or inform; <as>as, experience furnishes very
<ex>instructive</ex> lessons</as>.</def>

<au>Addison.</au>

<q>In various talk the <qex>instructive</qex> hours they
past.</q>
<qau>Pope.</qau>

<hw>In*struct"or</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[L., a

also <asp>instructer</asp>.]</altsp> <def>One who instructs; one

<hw>In*struct"ress</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <def>A woman

<au>Johnson.</au>

<hw>In"stru*ment</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[F.
<ets>instrument</ets>, L. <ets>instrumentum</ets>. See
<er>Instruct</er>.]</ety>

<sn>1.</sn> <def>That by means of which any work is performed, or
result is effected; a tool; a utensil; an implement; <as>as, the
<ex>instruments</ex> of a mechanic; astronomical
<ex>instruments</ex>.</as></def>

<q>All the lofty <qex>instruments</qex> of war.</q>
<qau>Shak.</qau>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>A contrivance or implement, by which musical
sounds are produced; <as>as, a musical
<ex>instrument</ex></as>.</def>

<q>Praise him with stringed <qex>instruments</qex> and
organs.</q>
<qau>Ps. cl. 4.</qau>

<q>But signs when songs and <qex>instruments</qex> he hears.</q>
<qau>Dryden.</qau>

<sn>3.</sn> <fld>(Law)</fld> <def>A writing, as the means of
giving formal expression to some act; a writing expressive of
some act, contract, process, as a deed, contract, writ,
etc.</def>

<au>Burrill.</au>

<sn>4.</sn> <def>One who, or that which, is made a means, or is
caused to serve a purpose; a medium, means, or agent.</def>

<q>Or useful serving man and <qex>instrument</qex>,
To any sovereign state.</q>
<qau>Shak.</qau>

<q>The bold are but the <qex>instruments</qex> of the wise.</q>
<qau>Dryden.</qau>

<syn>Syn. -- Tool; implement; utensil; machine; apparatus;
channel; agent.</syn>

<hw>In"stru*ment</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>v. t.</pos> <def>To
perform upon an instrument; to prepare for an instrument; <as>as,
a sonata <ex>instrumented</ex> for orchestra</as>.</def>

<hw>In`stru*men"tal</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>a.</pos> <ety>[Cf. F.
<ets>instrumental</ets>.]</ety>

<sn>1.</sn> <def>Acting as an instrument; serving as a means;
contributing to promote; conductive; helpful; serviceable;
<as>as, he was <ex>instrumental</ex> in conducting the
business</as>.</def>

<q>The head is not more native to the heart,
The hand more <qex>instrumental</qex> to the mouth.</q>
<qau>Shak.</qau>

<sn>2.</sn> <fld>(Mus.)</fld> <def>Pertaining to, made by, or
prepared for, an instrument, esp. a musical instrument; <as>as,
<ex>instrumental</ex> music, distinguished from <ex>vocal</ex>
music</as>.</def> \'bdHe defended the use of
<xex>instrumental</xex> music in public worship.\'b8

<au>Macaulay.</au>

<q>Sweet voices mix'd with <qex>instrumental</qex> sounds.</q>
<qau>Dryden.</qau>

<sn>3.</sn> <fld>(Gram.)</fld> <def>Applied to a case expressing
means or agency; <as>as, the <ex>instrumental</ex> case</as>.
This is found in Sanskrit as a separate case, but in Greek it was
merged into the dative, and in Latin into the ablative. In Old
English it was a separate case, but has disappeared, leaving only
a few anomalous forms.</def>

<cs><col>Instrumental errors</col>, <cd>those errors in
instrumental measurements, etc., which arise, exclusively from
want of mathematical accuracy in an instrument.</cd></cs>

<hw>In`stru*men"tal*ist</hw>, <pos>n.</pos> <def>One who plays
upon an instrument of music, as distinguished from a
<xex>vocalist</xex>.</def>

<hw>In`stru*men*tal"i*ty</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos>;
<plu>pl. <plw>Instrumentalities</plw> <pr>(<?/)</pr>.</plu>
<def>The quality or condition of being instrumental; that which
is instrumental; anything used as a means; medium; agency.</def>

<q>The <qex>instrumentality</qex> of faith in justification.</q>
<qau>Bp. Burnet.</qau>

<q>The discovery of gunpowder developed the science of attack and
defense in a new <qex>instrumentality</qex>.</q>
<qau>J. H. Newman.</qau>

<hw>In`stru*men"tal*ly</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>adv.</pos>
<sn>1.</sn> <def>By means of an instrument or agency; as means to
an end.</def>

<au>South.</au>

<q>They will argue that the end being essentially beneficial, the
means become <qex>instrumentally</qex> so.</q>
<qau>Burke.</qau>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>With instruments of music; <as>as, a song
<ex>instrumentally</ex> accompanied</as>.</def>

<au>Mason.</au>

agency, as means to an end; instrumentality.</def>

<au>Hammond.</au>

<hw>In`stru*men"ta*ry</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>a.</pos>
<def>Instrumental.</def> <mark>[R.]</mark>

<hw>In`stru*men*ta"tion</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos>
<sn>1.</sn> <def>The act of using or adapting as an instrument; a
series or combination of instruments; means; agency.</def>

<q>Otherwise we have no sufficient <qex>instrumentation</qex> for
our human use or handling of so great a fact.</q>
<qau>H. Bushnell.</qau>

<-- (b). The act of using instruments to measure or control the
behavior of an object, as a patient in a hospital or a machine
being tested while under development. -->

<sn>2.</sn> <fld>(Mus.)</fld> <sd>(a)</sd> <def>The arrangement
of a musical composition for performance by a number of different
instruments; orchestration; instrumental composition; composition
for an orchestra or military band.</def> <sd>(b)</sd> <def>The
act or manner of playing upon musical instruments; performance;
<as>as, his <ex>instrumentation</ex> is perfect</as>.</def>

<-- Instrumented, a. having instruments attached for the purpose
of measuring conditions while under observation; said of a person
under medical observation or a machine whose performance is being
tested. -->

<hw>In`suf*fi"cience</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos>

<hw>In`suf*fi"cien*cy</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[L.
<ets>insufficientia</ets>: cf. F. <ets>insuffisance</ets>, whence
OE. <ets>insuffisance</ets>. See <er>Insufficient</er>.]</ety>

<sn>1.</sn> <def>The quality or state of being insufficient; want
of sufficiency; deficiency; inadequateness; <as>as, the
<ex>insufficiency</ex> of provisions, of an excuse,
etc.</as></def>

<q>The <qex>insufficiency</qex> of the light of nature is, by the
light of Scripture, . . . fully supplied.</q>
<qau>Hooker.</qau>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>Want of power or skill; inability; incapacity;
incompetency; <as>as, the <ex>insufficiency</ex> of a man for an
office</as>.</def>

<hw>In`suf*fi"cient</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>a.</pos> <ety>[L.
<ets>insufficiens</ets>, <ets>-entis</ets>. See <er>In-</er> not,
and <er>Sufficient</er>.]</ety>

<sn>1.</sn> <def>Not sufficient; not enough; inadequate to any
need, use, or purpose; <as>as, the provisions are
<ex>insufficient</ex> in quantity, and defective in
quality</as>.</def> \'bd<xex>Insufficient</xex> for His
praise.\'b8

<au>Cowper.</au>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>Wanting in strength, power, ability, capacity,
or skill; incompetent; incapable; unfit; <as>as, a person
<ex>insufficient</ex> to discharge the duties of an
office</as>.</def>

<syn>Syn. -- Inadequate; scanty; incommensurate; unequal; unfit;
incompetent; incapable; inefficient.</syn>

insufficient manner or degree; unadequately.</def>

sacrament of baptism to symbolize the inspiration of a new
spiritual life</def>. <sd>(b)</sd> <fld>(Med.)</fld> <def>The act
of blowing (a gas, powder, or vapor) into any cavity of the
body.</def>
