<hw>In"su*lar</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>a.</pos> <ety>[L.
<ets>insularis</ets>, fr. <ets>insula</ets> island: cf. F.
<ets>insulaire</ets>. See <er>Isle</er>.]</ety>

<sn>1.</sn> <def>Of or pertaining to an island; of the nature, or
possessing the characteristics, of an island; <as>as, an
<ex>insular</ex> climate, fauna, etc.</as></def>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>Of or pertaining to the people of an island;
narrow; circumscribed; illiberal; contracted; <as>as,
<ex>insular</ex> habits, opinions, or prejudices</as>.</def>

<q>The penury of <qex>insular</qex> conversation.</q>
<qau>Johnson.</qau>

<ets>insularit\'82</ets>.]</ety>

<sn>1.</sn> <def>The state or quality of being an island or

<q>The <qex>insularity</qex> of Britain was first shown by

<qau>Pinkerton.</qau>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>Narrowness or illiberality of opinion;

<hw>In"su*late</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>v. t.</pos>
<wordforms>[<pos>imp. & p. p.</pos> <er>Insulated</er>
<pr>(?)</pr>; <pos>p. pr. & vb. n.</pos> <er>Insulating</er>
<pr>(?)</pr>.]</wordforms> <ety>[L. <ets>insulatus</ets>
insulated, fr. <ets>insula</ets> island. See <er>Isle</er>, and
cf. <er>Isolate</er>.]</ety>

<sn>1.</sn> <def>To make an island of.</def> <mark>[Obs.]</mark>

<au>Pennant.</au>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>To place in a detached situation, or in a state
having no communication with surrounding objects; to isolate; to
separate.</def>

<sn>3.</sn> <fld>(Elec. & Thermotics)</fld> <def>To prevent the
transfer o<?/ electricity or heat to or from (bodies) by the
interposition of nonconductors.</def>

<cs><col>Insulating stool</col> <fld>(Elec.)</fld>, <cd>a stool
with legs of glass or some other nonconductor of electricity,
used for insulating a person or any object placed upon
it.</cd></cs>

<-- p. 773 -->

<hw>In"su*la`ted</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>p. a.</pos> <sn>1.</sn>
<def>Standing by itself; not being contiguous to other bodies;
separated; unconnected; isolated; <as>as, an <ex>insulated</ex>
house or column</as>.</def>

<q>The special and <qex>insulated</qex> situation of the
Jews.</q>
<qau>De Quincey.</qau>

<sn>2.</sn> <fld>(Elect. & Thermotics)</fld> <def>Separated from
other bodies by means of nonconductors of heat or
electricity.</def>

<sn>3.</sn> <fld>(Astron.)</fld> <def>Situated at so great a
distance as to be beyond the effect of gravitation; -- said of
stars supposed to be so far apart that the affect of their mutual
attraction is insensible.</def>

<au>C. A. Young.</au>

<cs><col>Insulated wire</col>, <cd>wire wound with silk, or
covered with other nonconducting material, for electrical
use.</cd></cs>

<hw>In`su*la"tion</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <sn>1.</sn>
<def>The act of insulating, or the state of being insulated;
detachment from other objects; isolation.</def>

<sn>2.</sn> <fld>(Elec. & Thermotics)</fld> <def>The act of
separating a body from others by nonconductors, so as to prevent
the transfer of electricity or of heat; also, the state of a body
so separated.</def>

<hw>In"su*la`tor</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <sn>1.</sn>
<def>One who, or that which, insulates.</def>

<sn>2.</sn> <fld>(Elec. & Thermotics)</fld> <def>The substance or
body that insulates; a nonconductor.</def>

<hw>In"su*lite</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos>
<fld>(Elec.)</fld> <def>An insulating material, usually some
variety of compressed cellulose, made of sawdust, paper pulp,
cotton waste, etc.</def>

<hw>In"sult</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[L.
<ets>insultus</ets>, fr. <ets>insilire</ets> to leap upon: cf. F.
<ets>insulte</ets>. See <er>Insult</er>, <pos>v. t.</pos>]</ety>

<sn>1.</sn> <def>The act of leaping on; onset; attack.</def>
<mark>[Obs.]</mark>

<au>Dryden.</au>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>Gross abuse offered to another, either by word
or act; an act or speech of insolence or contempt; an affront; an
indignity.</def>

<q>The ruthless sneer that <qex>insult</qex> adds to grief.</q>
<qau>Savage.</qau>

<syn>Syn. -- Affront; indignity; abuse; outrage; contumely. See
<er>Affront</er>.</syn>

<hw>In*sult"</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>v. t.</pos>
<wordforms>[<pos>imp. & p. p.</pos> <er>Insulted</er>; <pos>p.
pr. & vb. n.</pos> <er>Insulting</er>.]</wordforms> <ety>[F.
<ets>insulter</ets>, L. <ets>insultare</ets>, freq. fr.
<ets>insilire</ets> to leap into or upon; pref. <ets>in-</ets>
in, on + <ets>salire</ets> to leap. See <er>Salient</er>.]</ety>

<sn>1.</sn> <def>To leap or trample upon; to make a sudden onset
upon.</def> <mark>[Obs.]</mark>

<au>Shak.</au>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>To treat with abuse, insolence, indignity, or
contempt, by word or action; to abuse; <as>as, to call a man a
coward or a liar, or to sneer at him, is to <ex>insult</ex>
him</as>.</def>

<hw>In*sult"</hw>, <pos>v. i.</pos> <sn>1.</sn> <def>To leap or
jump.</def>

<q>Give me thy knife, I will <qex>insult</qex> on him.</q>
<qau>Shak.</qau>

<q>Like the frogs in the apologue, <qex>insulting</qex> upon
their wooden king.</q>
<qau>Jer. Taylor.</qau>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>To behave with insolence; to exult.</def>
<mark>[Archaic]</mark>

<q>The lion being dead, even hares <qex>insult</qex>.</q>
<qau>Daniel.</qau>

<q>An unwillingness to <qex>insult</qex> over their helpless
fatuity.</q>
<qau>Landor.</qau>

<hw>In*su"per*a*ble</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>a.</pos> <ety>[L.

<hw>In*sur"a*ble</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>a.</pos> <ety>[From
<er>Insure</er>.]</ety> <def>Capable of being insured against
loss, damage, death, etc.; proper to be insured.</def>

<q>The French law annuls the latter policies so far as they
exceed the <qex>insurable</qex> interest which remained in the
insured at the time of the subscription thereof.</q>
<qau>Walsh.</qau>

<hw>In*sur"ance</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[From
<er>Insure</er>.]</ety>

<sn>1.</sn> <def>The act of insuring, or assuring, against loss
or damage by a contingent event; a contract whereby, for a
stipulated consideration, called <xex>premium</xex>, one party
undertakes to indemnify or guarantee another against loss by
certain specified risks. Cf. <er>Assurance</er>, <pos>n.</pos>,
6.</def>

<note><hand/ The person who undertakes to pay in case of loss is
termed the <xex>insurer</xex>; the danger against which he
undertakes, the <xex>risk</xex>; the person protected, the
<xex>insured</xex>; the sum which he pays for the protection, the
<xex>premium</xex>; and the contract itself, when reduced to
form, the <xex>policy</xex>.</note>

<au>Johnson's Cyc.</au>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>The premium paid for insuring property or
life.</def>

<sn>3.</sn> <def>The sum for which life or property is
insured.</def>

<sn>4.</sn> <def>A guaranty, security, or pledge;
assurance.</def> <mark>[Obs.]</mark>

<q>The most acceptable <qex>insurance</qex> of the divine
protection.</q>
<qau>Mickle.</qau>

<cs><col>Accident insurance</col>, <cd>insurance against
pecuniary loss by reason of accident to the person.</cd> --
<mcol><col>Endowment insurance</col> <or/
<col>assurance</col></mcol>, <cd>a combination of life insurance
and investment such that if the person upon whose life a risk is
taken dies before a certain specified time the insurance becomes
due at once, and if he survives, it becomes due at the time
specified.</cd> -- <col>Fire insurance</col>. <cd>See under
<er>Fire</er>.</cd> -- <col>Insurance broker</col>, <cd>a broker
or agent who effects insurance.</cd> -- <col>Insurance
company</col>, <cd>a company or corporation whose business it is
to insure against loss, damage, or death.</cd> -- <col>Insurance
policy</col>, <cd>a certificate of insurance; the document
containing the contract made by an insurance company with a
person whose property or life is insured.</cd> -- <col>Life
insurance</col>. <cd>See under <er>Life</er>.</cd></cs>

<au>Dryden.</au>

<q>hose bold <qex>insurancers</qex> of deathless fame.</q>
<qau>Blair.</qau>

<hw>In*sur"ant</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <def>The person

<hw>In"sure</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>v. t.</pos>
<wordforms>[<pos>imp. & p. p.</pos> <er>Insured</er>
<pr>(?)</pr>; <pos>p. pr. & vb. n.</pos>
<er>Insuring</er>.]</wordforms> <ety>[OE. <ets>ensuren</ets>,
prob. for <ets>assuren</ets>, by a change of prefix. See 1st
<er>In-</er>, and <er>Sure</er>, and cf. <er>Assure</er>,
<er>Ensure</er>.]</ety> <altsp>[Written also
<asp>ensure</asp>.]</altsp>

<sn>1.</sn> <def>To make sure or secure; <as>as, to
<ex>insure</ex> safety to any one</as>.</def>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>Specifically, to secure against a loss by a
contingent event, on certain stipulated conditions, or at a given
rate or premium; to give or to take an insurance on or for;
<as>as, a merchant <ex>insures</ex> his ship or its cargo, or
both, against the dangers of the sea; goods and buildings are
<ex>insured</ex> against fire or water; persons are
<ex>insured</ex> against sickness, accident, or death; and
sometimes hazardous debts are <ex>insured</ex>.</as></def>

<hw>In*sure"</hw>, <pos>v. i.</pos> <def>To underwrite; to make
insurance; <as>as, a company <ex>insures</ex> at three per
cent</as>.</def>

<hw>In*sur"er</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <def>One who, or
that which, insures; the person or company that contracts to
indemnify losses for a premium; an underwriter.</def>

<hw>In*sur"gent</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>a.</pos> <ety>[L.

<hw>In`sur*mount`a*bil"i*ty</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos>
<def>The state or quality of being insurmountable.</def>

<hw>In`sur*mount"a*ble</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>a.</pos>
<ety>[Pref. <ets>in-</ets> not + <ets>surmountable</ets>: cf. F.
<ets>insurmountable</ets>.]</ety> <def>Incapable of being passed
over, surmounted, or overcome; insuperable; <as>as,
<ex>insurmountable</ex> difficulty or obstacle</as>.</def>

<au>Locke.</au>

<q>Hope thinks nothing difficult; despair tells us that
difficulty is <qex>insurmountable</qex>.</q>
<qau>I. Watts.</qau>

<syn>Syn. -- Insuperable; impassable; invincible.</syn>

<hw>In`sur*mount"a*ble*ness</hw>, <pos>n.</pos> <def>The state or
quality of being insurmountable; insurmountability.</def>

<hw>In`sur*mount"a*bly</hw>, <pos>adv.</pos> <def>In a manner or
to a degree not to be overcome.</def>

<hw>In`sur*rec"tion</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[L.
<ets>insurrectio</ets>, fr. <ets>insurgere</ets>,
<ets>insurrectum</ets>: cf. F. <ets>insurrection</ets>. See
<er>Insurgent</er>.]</ety>

<sn>1.</sn> <def>A rising against civil or political authority,
or the established government; open and active opposition to the
execution of law in a city or state.</def>

<q>It is found that this city of old time hath made
<qex>insurrection</qex> against kings, and that rebellion and
sedition have been made therein.</q>
<qau>Ezra iv. 19.</qau>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>A rising in mass to oppose an enemy.</def>
<mark>[Obs.]</mark>

<syn>Syn. -- <er>Insurrection</er>, <er>Sedition</er>,
<er>Revolt</er>, <er>Rebellion</er>, <er>Mutiny</er>.</syn>
<usage> <xex>Sedition</xex> is the raising of commotion in a
state, as by conspiracy, without aiming at open violence against
the laws. <xex>Insurrection</xex> is a rising of individuals to
prevent the execution of law by force of arms. <xex>Revolt</xex>
is a casting off the authority of a government, with a view to
put it down by force, or to substitute one ruler for another.
<xex>Rebellion</xex> is an extended insurrection and revolt.
<xex>Mutiny</xex> is an insurrection on a small scale, as a
<xex>mutiny</xex> of a regiment, or of a ship's crew.</usage>

<q>I say again,
In soothing them, we nourish 'gainst our senate
The cockle of rebellion, insolence, <qex>sedition</qex>.</q>
<qau>Shak.</qau>

<q><qex>Insurrections</qex> of base people are commonly more
furious in their beginnings.</q>
<qau>Bacon.</qau>

<q>He was greatly strengthened, and the enemy as much enfeebled,
by daily <qex>revolts</qex>.</q>
<qau>Sir W. Raleigh.</qau>

<q>Though of their names in heavenly records now
Be no memorial, blotted out and razed
By their <qex>rebellion</qex> from the books of life.</q>
<qau>Milton.</qau>

F. <ets>insurrectionnel</ets>.]</ety> <def>Pertaining to
insurrection; consisting in insurrection.</def>

<cs><col>Complex integer</col> <fld>(Theory of Numbers)</fld>,
<cd>an expression of the form <mathex>a + b<root/-1<mathex>,

<hw>In`te*gra*bil"i*ty</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos>
<fld>(Math.)</fld> <def>The quality of being integrable.</def>

<hw>In"te*gra*ble</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>a.</pos>
<fld>(Math.)</fld> <def>Capable of being integrated.</def>

<hw>In"te*gral</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>a.</pos> <ety>[Cf. F.
<ets>int\'82gral</ets>. See <er>Integer</er>.]</ety>

<sn>1.</sn> <def>Lacking nothing of completeness; complete;
perfect; uninjured; whole; entire.</def>

<q>A local motion keepeth bodies <qex>integral</qex>.</q>
<qau>Bacon.</qau>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>Essential to completeness; constituent, as a
part; pertaining to, or serving to form, an integer;
integrant.</as></def>

<q>Ceasing to do evil, and doing good, are the two great
<qex>integral</qex> parts that complete this duty.</q>
<qau>South.</qau>

<sn>3.</sn> <fld>(Math.)</fld> <sd>(a)</sd> <def>Of, pertaining
to, or being, a whole number or undivided quantity; not
fractional.</def> <sd>(b)</sd> <def>Pertaining to, or proceeding
by, integration; <as>as, the <ex>integral</ex>
calculus</as>.</def>

<cs><col>Integral calculus</col>. <cd>See under
<er>Calculus</er>.</cd></cs>

<hw>In"te*gral</hw>, <pos>n.</pos> <sn>1.</sn> <def>A whole; an
entire thing; a whole number; an individual.</def>

<sn>2.</sn> <fld>(Math.)</fld> <def>An expression which, being
differentiated, will produce a given differential. See
differential <er>Differential</er>, and <er>Integration</er>. Cf.
<er>Fluent</er>.</def>

<cs><col>Elliptic integral</col>, <cd>one of an important class
of integrals, occurring in the higher mathematics; -- so called
because one of the integrals expresses the length of an arc of an
<xex>ellipse<xex>.</cd></cs>

<hw>In`te*gral"i*ty</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[Cf. F.
<ets>int\'82gralit\'82</ets>.]</ety> <def>Entireness.</def>
<mark>[Obs.]</mark>

<au>Whitaker.</au>

<hw>In"te*gral*ly</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>adv.</pos> <def>In an
integral manner; wholly; completely; also, by integration.</def>

<hw>In"te*grant</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>a.</pos> <ety>[L.
<ets>integrans</ets>, <ets>-antis</ets>, p. pr. of
<ets>integrare</ets> to make whole, renew: cf. F.
<ets>int\'82grant</ets>. See <er>Integrate</er>.]</ety>
<def>Making part of a whole; necessary to constitute an entire
thing; integral.</def>

<au>Boyle.</au>

<q>All these are <qex>integrant</qex> parts of the republic.</q>
<qau>Burke.</qau>

<cs><mcol><col>Integrant parts</col>, <or/
<col>particles</col></mcol>, <cd>of bodies, those smaller
particles into which a body may be reduced without loss of its
original constitution, as by mechanical division.</cd></cs>

<hw>In"te*grate</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>v. t.</pos>
<wordforms>[<pos>imp. & p. p.</pos> <er>Integrated</er>
<pr>(?)</pr>; <pos>p. pr. & vb. n.</pos> <er>Integrating</er>
<pr>(?)</pr>.]</wordforms> <ety>[L. <ets>integratus</ets>, p. p.
of <ets>integrare</ets> to make whole, renew: cf. F.
<ets>int\'82grer</ets>. See <er>Integer</er>,
<er>Entire</er>.]</ety>

<sn>1.</sn> <def>To form into one whole; to make entire; to
complete; to renew; to restore; to perfect.</def> \'bdThat
conquest rounded and <xex>integrated</xex> the glorious
empire.\'b8

<au>De Quincey.</au>

<q>Two distinct substances, the soul and body, go to compound and
<qex>integrate</qex> the man.</q>
<qau>South.</qau>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>To indicate the whole of; to give the sum or
total of; <as>as, an <ex>integrating</ex> anemometer, one that
indicates or registers the entire action of the wind in a given
time</as>.</def>

<sn>3.</sn> <fld>(Math.)</fld> <def>To subject to the operation
of integration; to find the integral of.</def>

<-- p. 774 -->

<hw>In`te*gra"tion</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[L.
<ets>integratio</ets> a renewing, restoring: cf. F.
<ets>int\'82gration</ets>.]</ety>

<sn>1.</sn> <def>The act or process of making whole or
entire.</def>

<sn>2.</sn> <fld>(Math.)</fld> <def>The operation of finding the
primitive function which has a given function for its
differential coefficient. See <er>Integral</er>.</def>

<note><hand/ The symbol of integration is <integral2l/ (standing
for the Latin <xex>summa</xex> sum), and the integral is also
regarded as the limiting value of the sum of great numbers of
differentials, when the magnitude of the differentials decreases,
and their number increases indefinitely. See <er>Limit</er>,
<pos>n.</pos>  When the summation is made between specified
values of the variable, the result is a <xex>definite
integral</xex>, and those values of the variable are the limits
of the integral. When the summation is made successively for two
or more variables, the result is a <xex>multiple
integral</xex>.</note>

<sn>3.</sn> <def>In the theory of evolution: The process by which
the manifold is compacted into the relatively simple and
permanent. It is supposed to alternate with differentiation as an
agent in development.</def>

<hw>In"te*gra`tor</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <fld>(Math. &
Mech.)</fld> <def>That which integrates; esp., an instrument by
means of which the area of a figure can be measured directly, or
its moment of inertia, or statical moment, etc., be
determined.</def>

<hw>In*teg"ri*ty</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[L.
<ets>integritas</ets>: cf. F. <ets>int\'82grit\'82</ets>. See
<er>Integer</er>, and cf. <er>Entirety</er>.]</ety>

<sn>1.</sn> <def>The state or quality of being entire or
complete; wholeness; entireness; unbroken state; <as>as, the
<ex>integrity</ex> of an empire or territory</as>.</def>

<au>Sir T. More.</au>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>Moral soundness; honesty; freedom from
corrupting influence or motive; -- used especially with reference
to the fulfillment of contracts, the discharge of agencies,
trusts, and the like; uprightness; rectitude.</def>

<q>The moral grandeur of independent <qex>integrity</qex> is the
sublimest thing in nature.</q>
<qau>Buckminster.</qau>

<q>Their sober zeal, <qex>integrity</qex>. and worth.</q>
<qau>Cowper.</qau>

<sn>3.</sn> <def>Unimpaired, unadulterated, or genuine state;
entire correspondence with an original condition; purity.</def>

<q>Language continued long in its purity and
<qex>integrity</qex>.</q>
<qau>Sir M. Hale.</qau>

<syn>Syn. -- Honesty; uprightness; rectitude. See
<er>Probity</er>.</syn>

<hw>In`te*gro*pal"li*al</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>a.</pos> <ety>[L.
<ets>integer</ets> whole + E. <ets>pallial</ets>.]</ety>
<fld>(Zo\'94l.)</fld> <def>Having the pallial line entire, or
without a sinus, as certain bivalve shells.</def>

<hw>In*teg`u*ma"tion</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[See
<er>Integument</er>.]</ety> <def>That part of physiology which
treats of the integuments of animals and plants.</def>

<hw>In*teg"u*ment</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[L.
<ets>integumentum</ets>, fr. <ets>integere</ets> to cover; pref.
<ets>in-</ets> in, on + <ets>tegere</ets> to cover: cf. F.
<ets>int\'82gument</ets>. See 1st <er>n-</er>, and
<er>Tegument</er>.]</ety> <def>That which naturally invests or
covers another thing, as the testa or the tegmen of a seed;
specifically <fld>(Anat.)</fld>, a covering which invests the
body, as the skin, or a membrane that invests a particular.</def>

<hw>In*teg`u*men"ta*ry</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos>
<def>Belonging to, or composed of, integuments.</def>

<hw>In*teg`u*men*ta"tion</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos>
<def>The act or process of covering with integuments; the state
or manner of being thus covered.</def>

<hw>In"tel*lect</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[L.
<ets>intellectus</ets>, fr. <ets>intelligere</ets>,
<ets>intellectum</ets>, to understand: cf. <ets>intellect</ets>.
See <er>Intelligent</er>.]</ety> <fld>(Metaph.)</fld> <def>The
part or faculty of the human soul by which it knows, as
distinguished from the power to feel and to will; sometimes, the
capacity for higher forms of knowledge, as distinguished from the
power to perceive objects in their relations; the power to judge
and comprehend; the thinking faculty; the understanding.</def>

<hw>In"tel*lect`ed</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>a.</pos> <def>Endowed
with intellect; having intellectual powers or capacities.</def>
<mark>[R.]</mark>

<q>In body, and in bristles, they became
As swine, yet <qex>intellected</qex> as before.</q>
<qau>Cowper.</qau>

<hw>In`tel*lec"tion</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[L.
<ets>intellectio</ets> synecdoche: cf. F.
<ets>intellection</ets>.]</ety> <def>A mental act or process;
especially: <sd>(a)</sd> The act of understanding; simple
apprehension of ideas; intuition. <xex>Bentley</xex>.
<sd>(b)</sd> A creation of the mind itself.</def>

<au>Hickok.</au>

<hw>In`tel*lec"tive</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>a.</pos> <ety>[Cf. F.
<ets>intellectif</ets>.]</ety>

<sn>1.</sn> <def>Pertaining to, or produced by, the intellect or
understanding; intellectual.</def>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>Having power to understand, know, or comprehend;
intelligent; rational.</def>

<au>Glanvill.</au>

<sn>3.</sn> <def>Capable of being perceived by the understanding
only, not by the senses.</def>

<q><qex>Intellective</qex> abstractions of logic and
metaphysics.</q>
<qau>Milton.</qau>

<hw>In`tel*lec"tive*ly</hw>, <pos>adv.</pos> <def>In an
intellective manner.</def> <mark>[R.]</mark> \'bdNot
<xex>intellectivelly</xex> to write.\'b8

<au>Warner.</au>

<hw>In`tel*lec"tu*al</hw> <pr>(?; 135)</pr>, <pos>a.</pos>
<ety>[L. <ets>intellectualis</ets>: cf. F.
<ets>intellectuel</ets>.]</ety>

<sn>1.</sn> <def>Belonging to, or performed by, the intellect;
mental; <as>as, <ex>intellectual</ex> powers, activities,
etc.</as></def>

<q>Logic is to teach us the right use of our reason or
<qex>intellectual</qex> powers.</q>
<qau>I. Watts.</qau>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>Endowed with intellect; having the power of
understanding; having capacity for the higher forms of knowledge
or thought; characterized by intelligence or mental capacity;
<as>as, an <ex>intellectual</ex> person</as>.</def>

<q>Who would lose,
Though full of pain, this <qex>intellectual</qex> being,
Those thoughts that wander through eternity?</q>
<qau>Milton.</qau>

<sn>3.</sn> <def>Suitable for exercising the intellect; formed
by, and existing for, the intellect alone; perceived by the
intellect; <as>as, <ex>intellectual</ex> employments</as>.</def>

<sn>4.</sn> <def>Relating to the understanding; treating of the
mind; <as>as, <ex>intellectual</ex> philosophy, sometimes called
\'bdmental\'b8 philosophy</as>.</def>

<hw>In`tel*lec"tu*al</hw>, <pos>n.</pos> <def>The intellect or
understanding; mental powers or faculties.</def>

<q>Her husband, for I view far round, not nigh,
Whose higher <qex>intellectual</qex> more I shun.</q>
<qau>Milton.</qau>

<q>I kept her <qex>intellectuals</qex> in a state of
exercise.</q>
<qau>De Quincey.</qau>

<hw>In`tel*lec"tu*al*ism</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos>
<sn>1.</sn> <def>Intellectual power; intellectuality.</def>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>The doctrine that knowledge is derived from pure
reason.</def>

<hw>In`tel*lec"tu*al*ist</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos>
<sn>1.</sn> <def>One who overrates the importance of the
understanding.</def> <mark>[R.]</mark>

<au>Bacon.</au>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>One who accepts the doctrine of

<hw>In`tel*lec`tu*al"i*ty</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos>

<ets>intellectualit\'82</ets>.]</ety> <def>Intellectual powers;

<hw>In`tel*lec"tu*al*ize</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>v. t.</pos>
<sn>1.</sn> <def>To treat in an intellectual manner; to discuss

<q>Sentiment is <qex>intellectualized</qex> emotion.</q>
<qau>Lowell.</qau>

<hw>In`tel*lec"tu*al*ly</hw>, <pos>adv.</pos> <def>In an

<hw>In*tel"li*gence</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[F.
<ets>intelligence</ets>, L. <ets>intelligentia</ets>,
<ets>intellegentia</ets>. See <er>Intelligent</er>.]</ety>

<sn>1.</sn> <def>The act or state of knowing; the exercise of the
understanding.</def>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>The capacity to know or understand; readiness of
comprehension; the intellect, as a gift or an endowment.</def>

<q>And dimmed with darkness their <qex>intelligence</qex>.</q>
<qau>Spenser.</qau>

<sn>3.</sn> <def>Information communicated; news; notice;
advice.</def>

<q><qex>Intelligence</qex> is given where you are hid.</q>
<qau>Shak.</qau>

<sn>4.</sn> <def>Acquaintance; intercourse; familiarity.</def>
<mark>[Obs.]</mark>

<q>He lived rather in a fair <qex>intelligence</qex> than any
friendship with the favorites.</q>
<qau>Clarendon.</qau>

<sn>5.</sn> <def>Knowledge imparted or acquired, whether by
study, research, or experience; general information.</def>

<q>I write as he that none <qex>intelligence</qex>
Of meters hath, n<?/ flowers of sentence.</q>
<qau>Court of Love.</qau>

<sn>6.</sn> <def>An intelligent being or spirit; -- generally
applied to pure spirits; <as>as, a created
<ex>intelligence</ex></as>.</def>

<au>Milton.</au>

<q>The great <qex>Intelligences</qex> fair
That range above our mortal state,
In circle round the blessed gate,
Received and gave him welcome there.</q>
<qau>Tennyson.</qau>

<cs><col>Intelligence office</col>, <cd>an office where
information may be obtained, particularly respecting servants to
be hired.</cd></cs>

<syn>Syn. -- Understanding; intellect; instruction; advice;
notice; notification; news; information; report.</syn>

<hw>In*tel"li*gen*cer</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <def>One
who, or that which, sends or conveys intelligence or news; a

<q>All the intriguers in foreign politics, all the spies, and all
the <qex>intelligencers</qex> . . . acted solely upon that
principle.</q>
<qau>Burke.</qau>

<mark>[Obs.]</mark>

<au>Shak.</au>

<q>That sad <qex>intelligencing</qex> tyrant.</q>
<qau>Milton.</qau>

<hw>In*tel"li*gent</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>a.</pos> <ety>[L.
<ets>intelligens</ets>, <ets>intellegens</ets>,
<ets>-entis</ets>, p. pr. of <ets>intelligere</ets>,

<sn>1.</sn> <def>Endowed with the faculty of understanding or

<as>as, an <ex>intelligent</ex> young man; an
<ex>intelligent</ex> architect; an <ex>intelligent</ex>

<sn>3.</sn> <def>Gognizant; aware; communicate.</def>

<qau>Milton.</qau>

<qex>Intelligent</qex> of our state.</q>

<hw>In*tem"per*ance</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[F.
<ets>intemp\'82rance</ets>, L. <ets>intemperantia</ets>. See
<er>In-</er> not, and <er>Temperance</er>.]</ety>

<sn>1.</sn> <def>The act of becoming, or state of being,
intemperate; excess in any kind of action or indulgence; any
immoderate indulgence of the appetites or passions.</def>

<q>God is in every creature; be cruel toward none, neither abuse
any by <qex>intemperance</qex>.</q>
<qau>Jer. Taylor.</qau>

<q>Some, as thou sawest, by violent stroke shall die,
By fire, flood, famine, by <qex>intemperance</qex> more
In meats and drinks.</q>
<qau>Milton.</qau>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>Specifically: Habitual or excessive indulgence
in alcoholic liquors.</def>

<hw>In*tem"per*an*cy</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos>
<def>Intemperance.</def> <mark>[Obs.]</mark>

<mark>[Obs.]</mark>

<q>Such as be <qex>intemperant</qex>, that is, followers of their
naughty appetites and lusts.</q>
<qau>Udall.</qau>

<hw>In*tem`per*ate</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>a.</pos> <ety>[L.
<ets>intemperatus</ets>. See <er>In-</er> not, and
<er>Temperate</er>.]</ety>

<sn>1.</sn> <def>Indulging any appetite or passion to excess;
immoderate to enjoyments or exertion.</def>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>Specifically, addicted to an excessive or
habitual use of alcoholic liquors.</def>

<sn>3.</sn> <def>Excessive; ungovernable; inordinate; violent;
immoderate; <as>as, <ex>intemperate</ex> language, zeal,
etc.</as>; <xex>intemperate</xex> weather.</def>

<q>Most do taste through fond <qex>intemperate</qex> thirst.</q>
<qau>Milton.</qau>

<q>Use not thy mouth to <qex>intemperate</qex> swearing.</q>
<qau>Ecclus. xxiii. 13.</qau>

<hw>In*tem`per*ate</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>v. t.</pos> <def>To
disorder.</def> <mark>[Obs.]</mark>

<hw>In*tem`per*ate*ly</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>adv.</pos> <def>In
an intemperate manner; immoderately; excessively; without
restraint.</def>

<q>The people . . . who behaved very unwisely and
<qex>intemperately</qex> on that occasion.</q>
<qau>Burke.</qau>

<hw>In*tem`per*ate*ness</hw>, <pos>n.</pos> <sn>1.</sn> <def>The
state of being intemperate; excessive indulgence of any appetite
or passion; <as>as, <ex>intemperateness</ex> in eating or
drinking</as>.</def>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>Severity of weather; inclemency.</def>

<au>Boyle.</au>

<q>By unseasonable weather, by <qex>intemperateness</qex> of the
air or meteors.</q>
<qau>Sir M. Hale.</qau>

<hw>In*tend"</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>v. t.</pos>
<wordforms>[<pos>imp. & p. p.</pos> <er>Intended</er>; <pos>p.
pr. & vb. n.</pos> <er>Intending</er>.]</wordforms> <ety>[OE.
<ets>entenden</ets> to be attentive, F. <ets>entendre</ets>, fr.
L. <ets>intendre</ets>, <ets>intentum</ets>, and
<ets>intensum</ets>, to intend, attend, stretch out, extend;
pref. <ets>in-</ets> in + <ets>tendere</ets> to stretch, stretch
out. See <er>Tend</er>.]</ety>

<sn>1.</sn> <def>To stretch' to extend; to distend.</def>
<mark>[Obs.]</mark>

<q>By this the lungs are <qex>intended</qex> or remitted.</q>
<qau>Sir M. Hale.</qau>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>To strain; to make tense.</def>
<mark>[Obs.]</mark>

<q>When a bow is successively <qex>intended</qex> and
remedied.</q>
<qau>Cudworth.</qau>

<sn>3.</sn> <def>To intensify; to strengthen.</def>
<mark>[Obs.]</mark>

<au>Sir T. Browne.</au>

<q>Magnetism may be <qex>intended</qex> and remitted.</q>
<qau>Sir I. Newton.</qau>

<sn>4.</sn> <def>To apply with energy.</def>

<q>Let him <qex>intend</qex> his mind, without respite, without
rest, in one direction.</q>
<qau>Emerson.</qau>

<sn>5.</sn> <def>To bend or turn; to direct, as one's course or
journey.</def> <mark>[Archaic]</mark>

<au>Shak.</au>

<sn>6.</sn> <def>To fix the mind on; to attend to; to take care
of; to superintend; to regard.</def> <mark>[Obs.]</mark>

<q>Having no children, she did, with singular care and
tenderness, <qex>intend</qex> the education of Philip.</q>
<qau>Bacon.</qau>

<q>My soul, not being able to <qex>intend</qex> two things at
once, abated of its fervency in praying.</q>
<qau>Fuller.</qau>

<sn>7.</sn> <def>To fix the mind upon (something to be
accomplished); to be intent upon; to mean; to design; to plan; to
purpose; -- often followed by an infinitely with <xex>to</xex>,
or a dependent clause with <xex>that</xex>; <as>as, he
<ex>intends</ex> to go; he <ex>intends</ex> that she shall
remain.</as></def>

<q>They <qex>intended</qex> evil against thee.</q>
<qau>Ps. xxi. 11.</qau>

<q>To-morrow he <qex>intends</qex>
To hunt the boar with certain of his friends.</q>
<qau>Shak.</qau>

<sn>8.</sn> <def>To design mechanically or artistically; to
fashion; to mold.</def> <mark>[Obs.]</mark>

<q>Modesty was made
When she was first <qex>intended</qex>.</q>
<qau>Beau. & Fl.</qau>

<sn>9.</sn> <def>To pretend; to counterfeit; to simulate.</def>
<mark>[Obs.]</mark>

<q><qex>Intend</qex> a kind of zeal both to the prince and
Claudio.</q>
<qau>Shak.</qau>

<syn>Syn. -- To purpose; mean; design; plan; conceive;
contemplate.</syn>

<hw>In*ten"er*ate</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>v. t.</pos>
<wordforms>[<pos>imp. & p. p.</pos> <er>Intenerated</er>

<qau>Bp. Hall.</qau>

<q>So have I seen the little purls of a stream . . .
<qex>intenerate</qex> the stubborn pavement.</q>

<hw>In*ten"er*ate</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>a.</pos> <def>Made

intenerated; softening.</def> <mark>[R.]</mark>

<au>Bacon.</au>

<hw>In*ten"i*ble</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>a.</pos> <ety>[Pref.
<ets>in-</ets> not + L. <ets>tenere</ets> to hold: cf. L.

<q>This captious and <qex>intenible</qex> sieve.</q>

<hw>In*tense"</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>a.</pos> <ety>[L.
<ets>intensus</ets> stretched, tight, p. p. of
<ets>intendere</ets> to stretch: cf. F. <ets>intense</ets>. See
<er>Intend</er>, and cf. <er>Intent</er>, and cf.
<er>Intent</er>, <pos>a.</pos>]</ety>

<sn>1.</sn> <def>Strained; tightly drawn; kept on the stretch;
strict; very close or earnest; <as>as, <ex>intense</ex> study or
application; <ex>intense</ex> thought.</as></def>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>Extreme in degree; excessive; immoderate; as:
<sd>(a)</sd> Ardent; fervent; <as>as, <ex>intense</ex> heat</as>.
<sd>(b)</sd> Keen; biting; <as>as, <ex>intense</ex> cold</as>.
<sd>(c)</sd> Vehement; earnest; exceedingly strong; <as>as,
<ex>intense</ex> passion or hate</as>. <sd>(d)</sd> Very severe;
violent; <as>as, <ex>intense</ex> pain or anguish</as>.
<sd>(e)</sd> Deep; strong; brilliant; <as>as, <ex>intense</ex>
color or light</as>.</def>

<q>In this <qex>intense</qex> seclusion of the forest.</q>
<qau>Hawthorne.</qau>

<hw>In*tense"ly</hw>, <pos>adv.</pos> <sn>1.</sn>
<def>Intently.</def> <mark>[Obs.]</mark>

<au>J. Spencer.</au>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>To an extreme degree; <as>as, weather
<ex>intensely</ex> cold</as>.</def>

<hw>In*tense"ness</hw>, <pos>n.</pos> <def>The state or quality
of being intense; intensity; <as>as, the <ex>intenseness</ex> of
heat or cold; the <ex>intenseness</ex> of study or
thought.</as></def>

<hw>In*ten`si*fi*ca"tion</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos>
<def>The act or process of intensifying, or of making more
intense.</def>

<hw>In*ten"si*fi`er</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <def>One who
or that which intensifies or strengthens; in photography, an
agent used to intensify the lights or shadows of a picture.</def>

<hw>In*ten"si*fy</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>v. t.</pos>
<wordforms>[<pos>imp. & p. p.</pos> <er>Intensified</er>
<pr>(?)</pr>; <pos>p. pr. & vb. n.</pos> <er>Intensifying</er>
<pr>(?)</pr>.]</wordforms> <ety>[<ets>Intense</ets> +
-<ets>fly</ets>.]</ety> <def>To render more intense; <as>as, to
<ex>intensify</ex> heat or cold; to <ex>intensify</ex> colors; to
<ex>intensify</ex> a photographic negative; to <ex>intensify</ex>
animosity.</as></def>

<au>Bacon.</au>

<q>How piercing is the sting of pride
By want embittered and <qex>intensified</qex>.</q>
<qau>Longfellow.</qau>

<hw>In*ten"si*fy</hw>, <pos>v. i.</pos> <def>To become intense,
or more intense; to act with increasing power or energy.</def>

<hw>In*ten"sion</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[L.
<ets>intensio</ets>: cf. F. <ets>intension</ets>. See
<er>Intend</er>, and cf. <er>Intention</er>.]</ety>

<sn>1.</sn> <def>A straining, stretching, or bending; the state
of being strained; <as>as, the <ex>intension</ex> of a musical
string</as>.</def>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>Increase of power or energy of any quality or
thing; intenseness; fervency.</def>

<au>Jer. Taylor.</au>

<q>Sounds . . . likewise do rise and fall with the
<qex>intension</qex> or remission of the wind.</q>
<qau>Bacon.</qau>

<sn>3.</sn> <fld>(Logic & Metaph.)</fld> <def>The collective
attributes, qualities, or marks that make up a complex general
notion; the comprehension, content, or connotation; -- opposed to
<xex>extension</xex>, <xex>extent</xex>, or
<xex>sphere</xex>.</def>

<q>This law is, that the <qex>intension</qex> of our knowledge is
in the inverse ratio of its extension.</q>
<qau>Sir W. Hamilton.</qau>

<hw>In*ten"si*tive</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>a.</pos>
<def>Increasing the force or intensity of; intensive; <as>as, the
<ex>intensitive</ex> words of a sentence</as>.</def>

<au>H. Sweet.</au>

<hw>In*ten"si*ty</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[LL.
<ets>intensitas</ets>: cf. F. <ets>intensit\'82</ets>. See
<er>Intense</er>.]</ety>

<sn>1.</sn> <def>The state or quality of being intense;
intenseness; extreme degree; <as>as, <ex>intensity</ex> of heat,
cold, mental application, passion, etc.</as></def>

<q>If you would deepen the <qex>intensity</qex> of light, you
must be content to bring into deeper blackness and more distinct
and definite outline the shade that accompanies it.</q>

<au>F. W. Robertson.</au>

<sn>2.</sn> <fld>(Physics)</fld> <def>The amount or degree of
energy with which a force operates or a cause acts;
effectiveness, as estimated by results produced.</def>

<sn>3.</sn> <fld>(Mech.)</fld> <def>The magnitude of a
distributed force, as pressure, stress, weight, etc., per unit of
surface, or of volume, as the case may be; <as>as, the measure of
the <ex>intensity</ex> of a total stress of forty pounds which is
distributed uniformly over a surface of four square inches area
is ten pounds per square inch</as>.</def>

<sn>4.</sn> <fld>(Photog.)</fld> <def>The degree or depth of
shade in a picture.</def>

<hw>In*ten"sive</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>a.</pos> <ety>[Cf. F.
<ets>intensif</ets>. See <er>Intense</er>.]</ety>

<sn>1.</sn> <def>Stretched; admitting of intension, or increase
of degree; that can be intensified.</def>

<au>Sir M. Hale.</au>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>Characterized by persistence; intent;
unremitted; assiduous; intense.</def> <mark>[Obs.]</mark>

<au>Sir H. Wotton.</au>

<sn>3.</sn> <fld>(Gram.)</fld> <def>Serving to give force or
emphasis; <as>as, an <ex>intensive</ex> verb or
preposition</as>.</def>

<hw>In*ten"sive</hw>, <pos>n.</pos> <def>That which intensifies
or emphasizes; an intensive verb or word.</def>

<hw>In*ten"sive*ly</hw>, <pos>adv.</pos> <def>In an intensive
manner; by increase of degree.</def>

<au>Abp. Bramhall.</au>

<hw>In*ten"sive*ness</hw>, <pos>n.</pos> <def>The quality or
state of being intensive; intensity.</def>

<au>Sir M. Hale.</au>

<hw>In*tent"</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>a.</pos> <ety>[L.
<ets>intentus</ets>, p. p. of <ets>intendere</ets>. See
<er>Intend</er>, and cf. <er>Intense</er>.]</ety>

<sn>1.</sn> <def>Closely directed; strictly attentive; bent; --
said of the mind, thoughts, etc.; <as>as, a mind <ex>intent</ex>
on self-improvement</as>.</def>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>Having the mind closely directed to or bent on
an object; sedulous; eager in pursuit of an object; -- formerly
with <xex>to</xex>, but now with <xex>on</xex>; <as>as,
<ex>intent</ex> on business or pleasure</as>.</def>
\'bd<xex>Intent</xex> on mischief.\'b8

<au>Milton.</au>

<q>Be <qex>intent</qex> and solicitous to take up the meaning of
the speaker.</q>
<qau>I. Watts.</qau>

<hw>In*tent"</hw>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[OE. <ets>entent</ets>,
<ets>entente</ets>, attention, purpose, OF. <ets>entente</ets>,
F. <ets>entente</ets> understanding, meaning; a participial noun,
fr. F. & OF. <ets>entendre</ets>. See <er>Intend</er>.]</ety>
<def>The act of turning the mind toward an object; hence, a
design; a purpose; intention; meaning; drift; aim.</def>

<q>Be thy <qex>intents</qex> wicked or charitable.</q>
<qau>Shak.</qau>

<q>The principal <qex>intent</qex> of Scripture is to deliver the
<?/aws of duties supernatural.</q>
<qau>Hooker.</qau>

<cs><mcol><col>To all intents</col>, <col>and
purposes</col></mcol>, <cd>in all applications or senses;
practically; really; virtually; essentially. \'bdHe was miserable
<xex>to all intents and purpose<xex>.\'b8</cd></cs>

<au>L'Estrange.</au>

<syn>Syn. -- Design; purpose; intention; meaning; purport; view;
drift; object; end; aim; plan.</syn>

<hw>In`ten*ta"tion</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos>
<def>Intention.</def> <mark>[Obs.]</mark>

<hw>In*ten"tion</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[F.
<ets>intention</ets>, L. <ets>intentio</ets>. See
<er>Intend</er>, and cf. <er>Intension</er>.]</ety>

<sn>1.</sn> <def>A stretching or bending of the mind toward of
the mind toward an object; closeness of application; fixedness of
attention; earnestness.</def>

<q><qex>Intention</qex> is when the mind, with great earnestness,
and of choice, fixes its view on any idea.</q>
<qau>Locke.</qau>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>A determination to act in a certain way or to do
a certain thing; purpose; design; <as>as, an <ex>intention</ex>
to go to New York</as>.</def>

<q>Hell is paved with good <qex>intentions</qex>.</q>
<qau>Johnson.</qau>

<sn>3.</sn> <def>The object toward which the thoughts are
directed; end; aim.</def>

<q>In [chronical distempers], the principal <qex>intention</qex>
is to restore the tone of the solid parts.</q>
<qau>Arbuthnot.</qau>

<sn>4.</sn> <def>The state of being strained. See
<er>Intension</er>.</def> <mark>[Obs.]</mark>

<sn>5.</sn> <fld>(Logic)</fld> <def>Any mental apprehension of an
object.</def>

<cs><col>First intention</col> <fld>(Logic)</fld>, <cd>a
conception of a thing formed by the first or direct application
of the mind to the individual object; an idea or image; as,
<xex>man<xex>, <xex>stone<xex>.</cd> -- <col>Second
intention</col> <fld>(Logic)</fld>, <cd>a conception generalized
from first intuition or apprehension already formed by the mind;
an abstract notion; especially, a classified notion, as
<xex>species<xex>, <xex>genus<xex>, <xex>whiteness<xex>.</cd> --
<col>To heal by the first intention</col> <fld>(Surg.)</fld>,
<cd>to cicatrize, as a wound, without suppuration.</cd> --
<col>To heal by the second intention</col> <fld>(Surg.)</fld>,
<cd>to unite after suppuration.</cd></cs>

<syn>Syn. -- Design; purpose; object; aim; intent; drift;
purport; meaning. See <er>Design</er>.</syn>

<hw>In*ter"ca*lar</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>a.</pos>
<def>Intercalary.</def>

<hw>In*ter"ca*la*ry</hw> <pr>(?; 277)</pr>, <pos>a.</pos>
<ety>[L. <ets>intercalaris</ets>, <ets>intercalarius</ets>: cf.
F. <ets>intercalaire</ets>. See <er>Intercalate</er>.]</ety>

<sn>1.</sn> <fld>(Chron.)</fld> <def>Inserted or introduced among
others in the calendar; <as>as, an <ex>intercalary</ex> month,
day, etc.</as>; -- now applied particularly to the odd day (Feb.
29) inserted in the calendar of leap year. See
<er>Bissextile</er>, <pos>n.</pos></def>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>Introduced or inserted among others; additional;
supernumerary.</def> \'bd<xex>Intercalary</xex> spines.\'b8

<au>Owen.</au>

<q>This <qex>intercalary</qex> line . . . is made the last of a
triplet.</q>
<qau>Beattie.</qau>

<cs><col>Intercalary day</col> <fld>(Med.)</fld>, <cd>one on
which no paroxysm of an intermittent disease occurs.</cd></cs>

<au>Mayne.</au>

<hw>In*ter"ca*late</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>v. t.</pos>
<wordforms>[<pos>imp. & p. p.</pos> <er>Intercalated</er>
<pr>(?)</pr>; <pos>p. pr. & vb. n.</pos> <er>Intercalating</er>
<pr>(?)</pr>.]</wordforms> <ety>[L. <ets>intercalatus</ets>, p.
p. of <ets>intercalare</ets> to intercalate to intercalate;
<ets>inter</ets> between + <ets>calare</ets> to call, proclaim.
See <er>Calendar</er>.]</ety>

<sn>1.</sn> <fld>(Chron.)</fld> <def>To insert, as a day or other
portion of time, in a calendar.</def>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>To insert among others, as a verse in a stanza;
specif. <fld>(Geol.)</fld>, to introduce as a bed or stratum,
between the layers of a regular series of rocks.</def>

<q>Beds of fresh-water shells . . . are <qex>intercalated</qex>
and interstratified with the shale.</q>
<qau>Mantell.</qau>

<hw>In*ter`ca*la"tion</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[L.
<ets>intercalatio</ets>: cf. F. <ets>intercalation</ets>.]</ety>

<sn>1.</sn> <fld>(Chron.)</fld> <def>The insertion of a day, or
other portion of time, in a calendar.</def>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>The insertion or introduction of anything among
others, as the insertion of a phrase, line, or verse in a
metrical composition; specif. <fld>(Geol.)</fld>, the intrusion
of a bed or layer between other layers.</def>

<q><qex>Intercalations</qex> of fresh-water species in some
localities.</q>
<qau>Mantell.</qau>

<hw>In`ter*ca*rot"id</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>a.</pos>
<fld>(Anat.)</fld> <def>Situated between the external and
internal carotid arteries; <as>as, an <ex>intercarotid</ex>
ganglion</as>.</def>

<hw>In`ter*car"pal</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>a.</pos>
<fld>(Anat.)</fld> <def>Between the carpal bone; <as>as,
<ex>intercarpal</ex> articulations, ligaments</as>.</def>

<hw>In`ter*car`ti*lag"i*nous</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>a.</pos>
<fld>(Anat.)</fld> <def>Within cartilage; endochondral; <as>as,
<ex>intercartilaginous</ex> ossification</as>.</def>

<hw>In`ter*cav"ern*ous</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>a.</pos>
<fld>(Anat.)</fld> <def>Between the cavernous sinuses; <as>as,
the <ex>intercavernous</ex> sinuses connecting the cavernous
sinuses at the base of the brain</as>.</def>

<hw>In`ter*cede"</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>v. i.</pos>
<wordforms>[<pos>imp. & p. p.</pos> <er>Interceded</er>; <pos>p.
pr. & vb. n.</pos> <er>Interceding</er>.]</wordforms> <ety>[L.
<ets>intercedere</ets>, <ets>intercessum</ets>; <ets>inter</ets>
between + <ets>cedere</ets> to pass: cf. F.
<ets>interc\'82der</ets>. See <er>Cede</er>.]</ety>

<sn>1.</sn> <def>To pass between; to intervene.</def>
<mark>[Obs.]</mark>

<q>He supposed that a vast period <qex>interceded</qex> between
that origination and the age wherein he lived.</q>
<qau>Sir M. Hale.</qau>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>To act between parties with a view to reconcile
differences; to make intercession; to beg or plead in behalf of
another; to mediate; -- usually followed by <xex>with</xex> and
<xex>for</xex>; <as>as, I will <ex>intercede with</ex> him
<ex>for</ex> you</as>.</def>

<q>I to the lords will <qex>intercede</qex>, not doubting
Their favorable ear.</q>
<qau>Milton.</qau>

<syn>Syn. -- To mediate; arbitrate. See <er>Interpose</er>.</syn>

<hw>In`ter*cede"</hw>, <pos>v. t.</pos> <def>To be, to come, or
to pass, between; to separate.</def> <mark>[Obs.]</mark>

<au>Sir I. Newton.</au>

<hw>In`ter*ced"ence</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <def>The act
of interceding; intercession; intervention.</def>
<mark>[R.]</mark>

<au>Bp. Reynolds.</au>

<hw>In`ter*ced"ent</hw>, <pos>a.</pos> <ety>[L.
<ets>intercedens</ets>, p. pr. of <ets>intercedere</ets>.]</ety>
<def>Passing between; mediating; pleading.</def>
<mark>[R.]</mark> -- <wordforms><wf>In`ter*ced"ent*ly</wf>,
<pos>adv.</pos></wordforms>

<hw>In`ter*ced"er</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <def>One who
intercedes; an intercessor; a mediator.</def>

<au>Johnson.</au>

<hw>In`ter*cel"lu*lar</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>a.</pos> <def>Lying
between cells or cellules; <as>as, <ex>intercellular</ex>
substance, space, or fluids; <ex>intercellular</ex> blood
channels.</as></def>

<hw>In`ter*cen"tral</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>a.</pos> <def>Between
centers.</def>

<cs><col>Intercentral nerves</col> <fld>(Physiol.)</fld>,
<cd>those nerves which transmit impulses between nerve centers,
as opposed to peripheral fibers, which convey impulses between
peripheral parts and nerve centers.</cd></cs>

<hw>\'d8In`ter*cen"trum</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos>;
<plu>pl. <plw>Intercentra</plw> <pr>(<?/)</pr>.</plu>
<fld>(Anat.)</fld> <def>The median of the three elements
composing the centra of the vertebr\'91 in some fossil
batrachians.</def>

<hw>In`ter*cept"</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>v. t.</pos>
<wordforms>[<pos>imp. & p. p.</pos> <er>Intercepted</er>; <pos>p.
pr. & vb. n.</pos> <er>Intercepting</er>.]</wordforms> <ety>[L.
<ets>interceptus</ets>, p. p. of <ets>intercipere</ets> to
intercept; <ets>inter</ets> between + <ets>capere</ets> to take,
seize: cf. F. <ets>intercepter</ets>. See
<er>Capable</er>.]</ety>

<sn>1.</sn> <def>To take or seize by the way, or before arrival
at the destined place; to cause to stop on the passage; <as>as,
to <ex>intercept</ex> a letter; a telegram will
<ex>intercept</ex> him at Paris.</as></def>

<q>God will shortly <qex>intercept</qex> your breath.</q>
<qau>Joye.</qau>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>To obstruct or interrupt the progress of; to
stop; to hinder or oppose; <as>as, to <ex>intercept</ex> the
current of a river</as>.</def>

<q>Who <qex>intercepts</qex> me in my expedition?</q>
<qau>Shak.</qau>

<q>We must meet first, and <qex>intercept</qex> his course.</q>
<qau>Dryden.</qau>

<sn>3.</sn> <def>To interrupt communication with, or progress
toward; to cut off, as the destination; to blockade.</def>

<q>While storms vindictive <qex>intercept</qex> the shore.</q>
<qau>Pope.</qau>

<-- p. 776 -->

<sn>4.</sn> <fld>(Math.)</fld> <def>To include between; <as>as,
that part of the <?/ine which is <ex>intercepted</ex> between the
points <er>A</er> and <er>B</er></as>.</def>

<syn>Syn. -- To cut off; stop; catch; seize; obstruct.</syn>

<hw>In"ter*cept`</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos>
<fld>(Math.)</fld> <def>A part cut off or intercepted, as a
portion of a line included between two points, or cut off two
straight lines or curves.</def>

<hw>In`ter*cept"er</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <def>One who,
or that which, intercepts.</def>

<au>Shak.</au>

<hw>In`ter*cep"tion</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[L.
<ets>interceptio</ets> a taking away: cf. F.
<ets>interception</ets>.]</ety> <def>The act of intercepting;
<as>as, <ex>interception</ex> of a letter; <ex>interception</ex>
of the enemy.</as></def>

<hw>In`ter*cept"ive</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>a.</pos>
<def>Intercepting or tending to intercept.</def>

<-- interceptor n.  one that intercepts, esp. a fast-climbing
high-speed combat airplane for defense against attacking
airplanes; also, a missile which intercepts and destroys incoming
missiles or airplanes.  Also spelt intercepter. [MW10]-->

<hw>In`ter*ces"sion</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[L.
<ets>intercessio</ets> an intervention, a becoming surety: cf. F.
<ets>intercession</ets>. See <er>Intercede</er>.]</ety> <def>The
act of interceding; mediation; interposition between parties at
variance, with a view to reconcilation; prayer, petition, or
entreaty in favor of, or (less often) against, another or
others.</def>

<q>But the Spirit itself maketh <qex>intercession</qex> for us
with groanings which can not be uttered.</q>
<qau>Rom. viii. 26.</qau>

<hw>In`ter*ces"sion*al</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>a.</pos>
<def>Pertaining to, of the nature of, or characterized by,
intercession or entreaty.</def>

<hw>In`ter*ces"sion*ate</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>v. t.</pos>
<def>To entreat.</def> <mark>[Obs.]</mark>

<hw>In`ter*ces"sor</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[L., a
surety: cf. F. <ets>intercesseur</ets>.]</ety>

<sn>1.</sn> <def>One who goes between, or intercedes; a mediator.
<sd>(a)</sd> One who interposes between parties at variance, with
a view to reconcile them. <sd>(b)</sd> One who pleads in behalf
of another.</def>

<au>Milton.</au>

<sn>2.</sn> <fld>(Eccl.)</fld> <def>A bishop, who, during a
vacancy of the see, administers the bishopric till a successor is
installed.</def>

<hw>In`ter*ces*so"ri*al</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>a.</pos>
<def>Intercessory.</def>

<ets>intercessorius</ets>.]</ety> <def>Pertaining to, of the
nature of, or characterized by, intercession; interceding;
<as>as, <ex>intercessory</ex> prayer</as>.</def>

<hw>In`ter*chain"</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>v. t.</pos>
<wordforms>[<pos>imp. & p. p.</pos> <er>Interchained</er>
<pr>(?)</pr>; <pos>p. pr. & vb. n.</pos>
<er>Interchaining</er>.]</wordforms> <def>To link together; to
unite closely or firmly, as by a chain.</def>

<q>Two bosoms <qex>interchained</qex> with an oath.</q>
<qau>Shak.</qau>

<hw>In`ter*change"</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>v. t.</pos>
<wordforms>[<pos>imp. & p. p.</pos> <er>Interchanged</er>
<pr>(?)</pr>; <pos>p. pr. & vb. n.</pos> <er>Interchanging</er>
<pr>(?)</pr>.]</wordforms> <ety>[OE. <ets>entrechangen</ets>, OF.
<ets>entrechangier</ets>. See <er>Inter-</er>, and
<er>Change</er>.]</ety>

<sn>1.</sn> <def>To put each in the place of the other; to give
and take mutually; to exchange; to reciprocate; <as>as, to
<ex>interchange</ex> places; they <ex>interchanged</ex> friendly
offices and services.</as></def>

<q>I shall <qex>interchange</qex>
My waned state for Henry's regal crown.</q>
<qau>Shak.</qau>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>To cause to follow alternately; to intermingle;
to vary; <as>as, to <ex>interchange</ex> cares with
pleasures</as>.</def>

<hw>In`ter*change"</hw>, <pos>v. i.</pos> <def>To make an
interchange; to alternate.</def>

<au>Sir P. Sidney.</au>

<hw>In`ter*change"</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[Cf. OF.
<ets>entrechange</ets>.]</ety>

<sn>1.</sn> <def>The act of mutually changing; the act of
mutually giving and receiving; exchange; <as>as, the
<ex>interchange</ex> of civilities between two
persons</as>.</def> \'bd<xex>Interchange</xex> of kindnesses.\'b8

<au>South.</au>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>The mutual exchange of commodities between two
persons or countries; barter; commerce.</def>

<au>Howell.</au>

<sn>3.</sn> <def>Alternate succession; alternation; a
mingling.</def>

<q>The <qex>interchanges</qex> of light and darkness.</q>
<qau>Holder.</qau>

<q>Sweet <qex>interchange</qex>
Of hill and valley, rivers, woods, and plains.</q>
<qau>Milton.</qau>

<hw>In`ter*co*lum"nar</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>a.</pos>
<def>Between columns or pillars; <as>as, the

<hw>In`ter*co*lum`ni*a"tion</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos>
<fld>(Arch.)</fld> <def>The clear space between two columns,
measured at the bottom of their shafts.</def>

<au>Gwilt.</au>

<note><hand/ It is customary to measure the intercolumniation in
terms of the diameter of the shaft, taken also at the bottom.
Different words, derived from the Greek, are in use to denote
certain common proportions. They are: <stype>Pycnostyle</stype>,
when the intercolumniation is of one and a half diameters;
<stype>Systyle</stype>, of two diameters; <stype>Eustyle</stype>,
of two and a quarter diameters; <stype>Diastyle</stype>, of three
diameters; <stype>Ar\'91ostyle</stype>, of four or more, and so
great that a wooden architrave has to be used instead of stone;
<stype>Ar\'91osystyle</stype>, when the intercolumniations are
alternately systyle and ar\'91ostyle.</note>

<hw>In"ter*course</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[Formerly
<ets>entercourse</ets>, OF. <ets>entrecours</ets> commerce,
exchange, F. <ets>entrecours</ets> a reciprocal right on
neighboring lands, L. <ets>intercursus</ets> a running between,
fr. <ets>intercurrere</ets> to run between. See <er>Inter-</er>,
and <er>Course</er>.]</ety> <def>A <?/<?/mmingling; intimate
connection or dealings between persons or nations, as in common
affairs and civilities, in correspondence or trade;
communication; commerce; especially, interchange of thought and
feeling; association; communion.</def>

<q>This sweet <qex>intercourse</qex>
Of looks and smiles.</q>
<qau>Milton.</qau>

<cs><col>Sexual intercourse</col>, <cd>sexual or carnal
connection; coition.</cd></cs>

<syn>Syn. -- Communication; connection; commerce; communion;
fellowship; familiarity; acquaintance.</syn>

<hw>In`ter*cross"</hw> <pr>(?; 115)</pr>, <pos>v. t. & i.</pos>
<wordforms>[<pos>imp. & p. p.</pos> <er>Intercrossed</er>
<pr>(?)</pr>; <pos>p. pr. & vb. n.</pos>
<er>Intercrossing</er>.]</wordforms>

<sn>1.</sn> <def>To cross each other, as lines.</def>

<sn>2.</sn> <fld>(Biol.)</fld> <def>To fertilize by the
impregnation of one species or variety by another; to impregnate
by a different species or variety.</def>

<hw>In"ter*cross`</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <def>The
process or result of cross fertilization between different kinds
of animals, or different varieties of plants.</def>

<q>We have reason to believe that occasional
<qex>intercrosses</qex> take place with all animals and
plants.</q>
<qau>Darwin.</qau>

<hw>In`ter*cru"ral</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>a.</pos>
<fld>(Anat.)</fld> <def>Between crura; -- applied especially to
the interneural plates in the vertebral column of many
cartilaginous fishes.</def>

<hw>In`ter*cur"</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>v. i.</pos> <ety>[L.
<ets>intercurrere</ets>. See <er>Intercourse</er>.]</ety> <def>To
intervene; to come or occur in the meantime.</def>
<mark>[Obs.]</mark>

<au>Shelton.</au>

<hw>In`ter*cur"rence</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[See
<er>Intercurrent</er>.]</ety> <def>A passing or running between;
occurrence.</def>

<au>Boyle.</au>

<hw>In`ter*cur"rent</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>a.</pos> <ety>[L.
<ets>intercurrens</ets>, p. pr. of <ets>intercurrere</ets>: cf.
F. <ets>intercurrent</ets>. See <er>Intercur</er>.]</ety>

<sn>1.</sn> <def>Running between or among; intervening.</def>

<au>Boyle. Bp. Fell.</au>

<sn>2.</sn> <fld>(Med.)</fld> <sd>(a)</sd> <def>Not belonging to
any particular season.</def> <sd>(b)</sd> <def>Said of diseases
occurring in the course of another disease.</def>

<au>Dunglison.</au>

<hw>In`ter*cur"rent</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos>
<def>Something intervening.</def>

<au>Holland.</au>

<hw>In`ter*cu*ta"ne*ous</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>a.</pos>
<def>Subcutaneous.</def>

<hw>In`ter*dash"</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>v. t.</pos>
<wordforms>[<pos>imp. & p. p.</pos> <er>Interdashed</er>
<pr>(?)</pr>; <pos>p. pr. & vb. n.</pos>
<er>Interdashing</er>.]</wordforms> <def>To dash between or

<au>Cowper.</au>

<hw>In`ter*deal"</hw>, <pos>v. i.</pos> <def>To intrigue.</def>
<mark>[Obs.]</mark>

<au>Daniel.</au>

<hw>In`ter*den"tal</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>a.</pos> <sn>1.</sn>
<def>Situated between teeth; <as>as, an <ex>interdental</ex>
space, the space between two teeth in a gear wheel</as>.</def>

<sn>2.</sn> <fld>(Phon.)</fld> <def>Formed between the upper and

<hw>In`ter*den"til</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos>

<def>Mutual dependence.</def> \'bdThe <xex>interdependence</xex>

<au>M. Arnold.</au>

<au>De Quincey.</au>

<hw>In`ter*de*pend"ent</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>a.</pos>
<def>Mutually dependent.</def>

<hw>In`ter*dict"</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>v. t.</pos>
<wordforms>[<pos>imp. & p. p.</pos> <er>Interdicted</er>; <pos>p.
pr. & vb. n.</pos> <er>Interdicting</er>.]</wordforms> <ety>[OE.
<ets>entrediten</ets> to forbid communion, L.
<ets>interdicere</ets>, <ets>interdictum</ets>. See
<er>Interdict</er>, <pos>n.</pos>]</ety>

<sn>1.</sn> <def>To forbid; to prohibit or debar; <as>as, to
<ex>interdict</ex> intercourse with foreign nations</as>.</def>

<q>Charged not to touch the <qex>interdicted</qex> tree.</q>
<qau>Milton.</qau>

<sn>2.</sn> <fld>(Eccl.)</fld> <def>To lay under an interdict; to
cut off from the enjoyment of religious privileges, as a city, a
church, an individual.</def>

<q>An archbishop may not only excommunicate and
<qex>interdict</qex> his suffragans, but his vicar general may do
the same.</q>
<qau>Ayliffe.</qau>

<hw>In"ter*dict`</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[OE.
<ets>entredit</ets>, <ets>enterdit</ets>, OF.
<ets>entredit</ets>, F. <ets>interdit</ets>, fr. L.
<ets>interdictum</ets>, fr. <ets>interdicere</ets> to interpose,
prohibit; <ets>inter</ets> between + <ets>dicere</ets> to say.
See <er>Diction</er>.]</ety>

<sn>1.</sn> <def>A prohibitory order or decree; a
prohibition.</def>

<q>These are not fruits forbidden; no <qex>interdict</qex>
Defends the touching of these viands pure.</q>
<qau>Milton.</qau>

<sn>2.</sn> <fld>(R. C. Ch.)</fld> <def>A prohibition of the
pope, by which the clergy or laymen are restrained from
performing, or from attending, divine service, or from
administering the offices or enjoying the privileges of the
church.</def>

<sn>3.</sn> <fld>(Scots Law)</fld> <def>An order of the court of
session, having the like purpose and effect with a writ of
injunction out of chancery in England and America.</def>

<hw>In`ter*dic"tion</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[L.
<ets>interdictio</ets>: cf. F. <ets>interdiction</ets>.]</ety>
<def>The act of interdicting; prohibition; prohibiting decree;
curse; interdict.</def>

<q>The truest issue of thy throne
By his own <qex>interdiction</qex> stands accurst.</q>
<qau>Shak.</qau>

<hw>In`ter*dict"ive</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>a.</pos> <def>Having
the power to prohibit; <as>as, an <ex>interdictive</ex>
sentence</as>.</def>

<au>Milton.</au>

<hw>In`ter*dict"o*ry</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>a.</pos> <ety>[L.
<ets>interdictorius</ets>.]</ety> <def>Belonging to an
interdiction; prohibitory.</def>

<hw>In`ter*dig"i*tal</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>a.</pos>
<fld>(Anat.)</fld> <def>Between the fingers or toes; <as>as,
<ex>interdigital</ex> space</as>.</def>

<hw>In`ter*dig"i*tate</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>v. t.</pos> <def>To
interweave.</def> <mark>[R.]</mark>

<hw>In`ter*dig"i*tate</hw>, <pos>v. i.</pos> <ety>[Pref.
<ets>inter-</ets> + L. <ets>digitus</ets> finger.]</ety> <def>To
interlock, as the fingers of two hands that are joined; to be
interwoven; to commingle.</def>

<au>Owen.</au>

<hw>In`ter*dig`i*ta"tion</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos>
<fld>(Anat.)</fld> <def>The state of interdigitating;
interdigital space.</def>

<au>Owen.</au>

<hw>In"ter*dome`</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos>
<fld>(Arch.)</fld> <def>The open space between the inner and
outer shells of a dome or cupola of masonry.</def>

<hw>In"ter*duce</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[Cf. F.
<ets>entre-deux</ets>, literally, between two.]</ety>
<fld>(Carp.)</fld> <def>An intertie.</def>

<hw>In"ter*e*pim"er*al</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>a.</pos>
<fld>(Zo\'94l.)</fld> <def>Between the epimeral plates of insects
and crustaceans.</def>

<hw>In`ter*e`qui*noc"tial</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>a.</pos>
<def>Coming between the equinoxes.</def>

<q>Summer and winter I have called <qex>interequinoctial</qex>
intervals.</q>
<qau>F. Balfour.</qau>

<hw>In"ter*ess</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>v. t.</pos> <ety>[See
<er>Interest</er>, <pos>v. t.</pos>]</ety> <def>To interest or
affect.</def> <mark>[Obs.]</mark>

<au>Hooker.</au>

<hw>In"ter*esse</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos>
<def>Interest.</def> <mark>[Obs.]</mark>

<au>Spenser.</au>

<hw>In"ter*est</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>v. t.</pos>
<wordforms>[<pos>imp. & p. p.</pos> <er>Interested</er>
<pr>(?)</pr>; <pos>p. pr. & vb. n.</pos>
<er>Interesting</er>.]</wordforms> <ety>[From
<ets>interess'd</ets>, p. p. of the older form
<ets>interess</ets>, fr. F. <ets>int\'82resser</ets>, L.
<ets>interesse</ets>. See <er>Interest</er>, <pos>n.</pos>]</ety>

<sn>1.</sn> <def>To engage the attention of; to awaken interest
in; to excite emotion or passion in, in behalf of a person or
thing; <as>as, the subject did not <ex>interest</ex> him; to
<ex>interest</ex> one in charitable work.</as></def>

<q>To love our native country . . . to be <qex>interested</qex>
in its concerns is natural to all men.</q>
<qau>Dryden.</qau>

<q>A goddess who used to <qex>interest</qex> herself in
marriages.</q>
<qau>Addison.</qau>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>To be concerned with or engaged in; to affect;
to concern; to excite; -- often used impersonally.</def>
<mark>[Obs.]</mark>

<q>Or rather, gracious sir,
Create me to this glory, since my cause
Doth <qex>interest</qex> this fair quarrel.</q>
<qau>Ford.</qau>

<sn>3.</sn> <def>To cause or permit to share.</def>
<mark>[Obs.]</mark>

<q>The mystical communion of all faithful men is such as maketh
every one to be <qex>interested</qex> in those precious blessings
which any one of them receiveth at God's hands.</q>
<qau>Hooker.</qau>

<syn>Syn. -- To concern; excite; attract; entertain; engage;
occupy; hold.</syn>

<hw>In"ter*est</hw>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[OF. <ets>interest</ets>,
F. <ets>int\'82r\'88t</ets>, fr. L. <ets>interest</ets> it
interests, is of interest, fr. <ets>interesse</ets> to be
between, to be difference, to be importance; <ets>inter</ets>
between + <ets>esse</ets> to be; cf. LL. <ets>interesse</ets>
usury. See <er>Essence</er>.]</ety>

<sn>1.</sn> <def>Excitement of feeling, whether pleasant or
painful, accompanying special attention to some object;
concern.</def>

<note><hand/ <xex>Interest</xex> expresses mental excitement of
various kinds and degrees. It may be intellectual, or sympathetic
and emotional, or merely personal; as, an <xex>interest</xex> in
philosophical research; an <xex>interest</xex> in human
suffering; the <xex>interest</xex> which an avaricious man takes
in money getting.</note>

<q>So much <qex>interest</qex> have I in thy sorrow.</q>
<qau>Shak.</qau>

<-- p. 777 -->

<sn>2.</sn> <def>Participation in advantage, profit, and
responsibility; share; portion; part; <as>as, an
<ex>interest</ex> in a brewery; he has parted with his
<ex>interest</ex> in the stocks.</as></def>

<sn>3.</sn> <def>Advantage, personal or general; good, regarded
as a selfish benefit; profit; benefit.</def>

<q>Divisions hinder the common <qex>interest</qex> and public
good.</q>
<qau>Sir W. Temple.</qau>

<q>When <qex>interest</qex> calls of all her sneaking train.</q>
<qau>Pope.</qau>

<sn>4.</sn> <def>Premium paid for the use of money, -- usually
reckoned as a percentage; <as>as, <ex>interest</ex> at five per
cent per annum on ten thousand dollars</as>.</def>

<q>They have told their money, and let out
Their coin upon large <qex>interest</qex>.</q>
<qau>Shak.</qau>

<sn>5.</sn> <def>Any excess of advantage over and above an exact
equivalent for what is given or rendered.</def>

<q>You shall have your desires with <qex>interest</qex>.</q>
<qau>Shak.</qau>

<sn>6.</sn> <def>The persons interested in any particular
business or measure, taken collectively; <as>as, the iron
<ex>interest</ex>; the cotton <ex>interest</ex>.</as></def>

<cs><col>Compound interest</col>, <cd>interest, not only on the
original principal, but also on unpaid interest from the time it
fell due.</cd> -- <col>Simple interest</col>, <cd>interest on the
principal sum without interest on overdue interest.</cd></cs>

<hw>In"ter*est*ed</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>a.</pos> <ety>[See
<er>Interest</er>, <pos>v. t.</pos>]</ety>

<sn>1.</sn> <def>Having the attention engaged; having emotion or
passion excited; <as>as, an <ex>interested</ex>
listener</as>.</def>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>Having an interest; concerned in a cause or in
consequences; liable to be affected or prejudiced; <as>as, an
<ex>interested</ex> witness</as>.</def>

<hw>In"ter*est*ed*ness</hw>, <pos>n.</pos> <def>The state or
quality of being interested; selfishness.</def>

<au>Richardson.</au>

<hw>In"ter*est*ing</hw>, <pos>a.</pos> <def>Engaging the
attention; exciting, or adapted to excite, interest, curiosity,
or emotion; <as>as, an <ex>interesting</ex> story;
<ex>interesting</ex> news.</as></def>

<au>Cowper.</au>

<hw>In"ter*est*ing*ly</hw>, <pos>adv.</pos> <def>In an
interesting manner.</def>

<hw>In"ter*est*ing*ness</hw>, <pos>n.</pos> <def>The condition or
quality of being interesting.</def>

<au>A. Smith.</au>

<hw>In`ter*fa"cial</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>a.</pos>
<fld>(Geom.)</fld> <def>Included between two plane surfaces or
faces; <as>as, an <ex>interfacial</ex> angle</as>.</def>

<hw>In`ter*fas*cic"u*lar</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>a.</pos>
<fld>(Anat.)</fld> <def>Between fascicles or bundles; <as>as, the
<ex>interfascicular</ex> spaces of connective tissue</as>.</def>

<hw>In`ter*fer"ant</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos>
<fld>(Law)</fld> <def>One of the contestants in interference
before the Patent Office.</def> <mark>[U.S.]</mark>

<hw>In`ter*fere"</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>v. i.</pos>
<wordforms>[<pos>imp. & p. p.</pos> <er>Interfered</er>
<pr>(?)</pr>; <pos>p. pr. & vb. n.</pos>
<er>Interfering</er>.]</wordforms> <ety>[OF.
<ets>entreferir</ets> to strike each other; <ets>entre</ets>
between (L. <ets>inter</ets>) + OF. <ets>ferir</ets> to strike,
F. <ets>f\'82rir</ets>, fr. L. <ets>ferire</ets>. See
<er>Ferula</er>.]</ety>

<sn>1.</sn> <def>To come in collision; to be in opposition; to
clash; <as>as, <ex>interfering</ex> claims, or
commands</as>.</def>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>To enter into, or take a part in, the concerns
of others; to intermeddle; to interpose.</def>

<q>To <qex>interfere</qex> with party disputes.</q>
<qau>Swift.</qau>

<q>There was no room for anyone to <qex>interfere</qex> with his
own opinions.</q>
<qau>Bp. Warburton.</qau>

<sn>3.</sn> <def>To strike one foot against the opposite foot or
ankle in using the legs; -- sometimes said of a human being, but
usually of a horse; <as>as, the horse
<ex>interferes</ex></as>.</def>

<sn>4.</sn> <fld>(Physics)</fld> <def>To act reciprocally, so as
to augment, diminish, or otherwise affect one another; -- said of
waves, rays of light, heat, etc. See <er>Interference</er>,
2.</def>

<sn>5.</sn> <fld>(Patent Law)</fld> <def>To cover the same
ground; to claim the same invention.</def>

<syn>Syn. -- To interpose; intermeddle. See
<er>Interpose</er>.</syn>

<hw>In`ter*fer"ence</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[See
<er>Interfere</er>.]</ety>

<sn>1.</sn> <def>The act or state of interfering; <as>as, the
stoppage of a machine by the <ex>interference</ex> of some of its
parts; a meddlesome <ex>interference</ex> in the business of
others.</as></def>

<sn>2.</sn> <fld>(Physics)</fld> <def>The mutual influence, under
certain conditions, of two streams of light, or series of
pulsations of sound, or, generally, two waves or vibrations of
any kind, producing certain characteristic phenomena, as colored
fringes, dark bands, or darkness, in the case of light, silence
or increased intensity in sounds; neutralization or superposition
of waves generally.</def>

<note><hand/ The term is most commonly applied to light, and the
<xex>undulatory</xex> theory of light affords the proper
explanation of the phenomena which are considered to be produced
by the superposition of waves, and are thus substantially
identical in their origin with the phenomena of heat, sound,
waves of water, and the like.</note>

<sn>3.</sn> <fld>(Patent Law)</fld> <def>The act or state of
interfering, or of claiming a right to the same invention.</def>

<cs><col>Interference figures</col> <fld>(Optics)</fld>, <cd>the
figures observed when certain sections of crystallized bodies are
viewed in converging polarized light; thus, a section of a
uniaxial crystal, cut normal to the vertical axis, shows a series
of concentric colored rings with a single black cross; -- so
called because produced by the <xex>interference<xex> of luminous
waves.</cd> -- <col>Interference fringe</col>.
<fld>(Optics)</fld> <cd>See <er>Fringe</er>.</cd></cs>

<hw>In`ter*fer"er</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <def>One who
interferes.</def>

<hw>In`ter*fer"ing*ly</hw>, <pos>adv.</pos> <def>By or with
interference.</def>

<hw>In`ter*flow"</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>v. i.</pos> <def>To flow
in.</def> <mark>[R.]</mark>

<au>Holland.</au>

<hw>In*ter"flu*ous</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, }</mhw> <pos>a.</pos>

<hw>In`ter*fo`li*a"ceous</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>a.</pos>

<hw>In`ter*fret"ted</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>a.</pos>
<fld>(Her.)</fld> <def>Interlaced; linked together; -- said of
charges or bearings. See <er>Fretted</er>.</def>

<hw>In`ter*ful"gent</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>a.</pos> <ety>[L.
<ets>interfulgens</ets>, p. pr. See <er>Inter-</er>, and
<er>Fulgent</er>.]</ety> <def>Shining between.</def>

<hw>In`ter*fuse"</hw> <pr>(<?/)</pr>, <pos>v. t.</pos> <ety>[L.
<ets>interfusus</ets>, p. p. of <ets>interfundere</ets> to pour
between; <ets>inter</ets> between + <ets>fundere</ets> to pour.
See <er>Fuse</er> to melt.]</ety>

<sn>1.</sn> <def>To pour or spread between or among; to diffuse;
to scatter.</def>

<q>The ambient air, wide <qex>interfused</qex>,
Embracing round this florid earth.</q>
<qau>Milton.</qau>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>To spread through; to permeate; to
pervade.</def> <mark>[R.]</mark>

<q>Keats, in whom the moral seems to have so perfectly
<qex>interfused</qex> the physical man, that you might almost say
he could feel sorrow with his hands.</q>
<qau>Lowell.</qau>

<sn>3.</sn> <def>To mix up together; to associate.</def>

<au>H. Spencer.</au>

<hw>In`ter*fu"sion</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[L.
<ets>interfusio</ets>.]</ety> <def>The act of interfusing, or the
state of being interfused.</def>

<au>Coleridge.</au>

<hw>In`ter*gan`gli*on"ic</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>a.</pos>
<fld>(Anat.)</fld> <def>Between and uniting the nervous
ganglions; <as>as, <ex>interganglionic</ex> cords</as>.</def>

<hw>In`ter*glob"u*lar</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>a.</pos>
<fld>(Anat.)</fld> <def>Between globules; -- applied esp. to
certain small spaces, surrounded by minute globules, in
dentine.</def>

<hw>In`ter*grave"</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>v. t.</pos>
<wordforms>[<pos>imp.</pos> <er>Intergraved</er> <pr>(?)</pr>;
<pos>p. p.</pos> <er>Intergraved</er> or <er>Intergraven</er>
(<?/); <pos>p. pr. & vb. n.</pos>
<er>Intergraving</er>.]</wordforms> <def>To grave or carve
between; to engrave in the alternate sections.</def>

<q>The work itself of the bases, was <qex>intergraven</qex>.</q>
<qau>3 Kings vii. 28 (Douay version. )</qau>

<mhw>{ <hw>In`ter*he"mal</hw>, <hw>In`ter*h\'91"mal</hw>  }</mhw>
<pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>a.</pos> <fld>(Anat.)</fld> <def>Between the
hemal arches or hemal spines.</def> -- <def2><pos>n.</pos>
<def>An interhemal spine or cartilage.</def></def2>

<hw>In`ter*hy"al</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>a.</pos>
<ety>[<ets>Inter-</ets> + the Greek letter <?/.]</ety>
<fld>(Anat.)</fld> <def>Of or pertaining to a segment sometimes
present at the proximal end of the hyoidean arch.</def> --
<def2><pos>n.</pos> <def>An interhyal ligament or
cartilage.</def></def2>

<hw>In"ter*im</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[L., fr.
<ets>inter</ets> between + <ets>im</ets>, an old accusative of
<ets>is</ets> he, this, that.]</ety>

<sn>1.</sn> <def>The meantime; time intervening; interval between
events, etc.</def>

<q>All the <qex>interim</qex> is
Like a phantasms, or a hideous dream.</q>
<qau>Shak.</qau>

<sn>2.</sn> <fld>(Hist.)</fld> <def>A name given to each of three
compromises made by the emperor Charles V. of Germany for the
sake of harmonizing the connecting opinions of Protestants and
Catholics.</def>

<hw>In*te"ri*or</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>a.</pos> <ety>[L.,
compar. fr. <ets>inter</ets> between: cf. F.
<ets>int\'82rieur</ets>. See <er>Inter-</er>, and cf.
<er>Intimate</er>.]</ety>

<sn>1.</sn> <def>Being within any limits, inclosure, or
substance; inside; internal; inner; -- opposed to
<xex>exterior</xex>, or <xex>superficial</xex>; <as>as, the
<ex>interior</ex> apartments of a house; the <ex>interior</ex>
surface of a hollow ball.</as></def>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>Remote from the limits, frontier, or shore;
inland; <as>as, the <ex>interior</ex> parts of a region or
country</as>.</def>

<cs><col>Interior angle</col> <fld>(Geom.)</fld>, <cd>an angle
formed between two sides, within any rectilinear figure, as a
polygon, or between two parallel lines by these lines and another
intersecting them; -- called also <altname>internal
angle</altname>.</cd> -- <col>Interior planets</col>
<fld>(Astron.)</fld>, <cd>those planets within the orbit of the
earth.</cd> -- <col>Interior screw</col>, <cd>a screw cut on an
interior surface, as in a nut; a female screw.</cd></cs>

<syn>Syn. -- Internal; inside; inner; inland; inward.</syn>

<hw>In*te"ri*or</hw>, <pos>n.</pos> <sn>1.</sn> <def>That which
is within; the internal or inner part of a thing; the
inside.</def>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>The inland part of a country, state, or
kingdom.</def>

<cs><col>Department of the Interior</col>, <cd>that department of
the government of the United States which has charge of pensions,
patents, public lands and surveys, the Indians, education, etc.;
that department of the government of a country which is specially
charged with the internal affairs of that country; the home
department.</cd> -- <col>Secretary of the Interior</col>, <cd>the
cabinet officer who, in the United States, is at the head of the
Department of the Interior.</cd></cs>

<hw>In*te`ri*or"i*ty</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <def>State
of being interior.</def>

<hw>In*te"ri*or*ly</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>adv.</pos>
<def>Internally; inwardly.</def>

<mhw>{ <hw>In`ter*ja"cence</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>,
<hw>In`ter*ja"cen*cy</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, }</mhw> <pos>n.</pos>
<ety>[See <er>Interjacent</er>.]</ety> <def>The state of being
between; a coming or lying between or among; intervention; also,
that which lies between.</def>

<q>England and Scotland is divided only by the
<qex>interjacency</qex> of the Tweed.</q>
<qau>Sir M. Hale.</qau>

<hw>In`ter*ja"cent</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>a.</pos> <ety>[L.
<ets>interjacens</ets>, <ets>-entis</ets>, p. pr. of
<ets>interjacere</ets> to lie between; <ets>inter</ets> between +
<ets>jac<?/re</ets> to lie.]</ety> <def>Lying or being between or
among; intervening; <as>as, <ex>interjacent</ex>
isles</as>.</def>

<au>Sir W. Raleigh.</au>

<au>Thackeray.</au>
