<hw>In`ter*ject"</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>v. t.</pos>
<wordforms>[<pos>imp. & p. p.</pos> <er>Interjected</er>; <pos>p.
pr. & vb. n.</pos> <er>Interjecting</er>.]</wordforms> <ety>[L.
<ets>interjectus</ets>, p. p. of <ets>interjicere</ets> to
interject; <ets>inter</ets> between + <ets>jac<?/re</ets> to
throw. See <er>Jet</er> a shooting forth.]</ety> <def>To throw in
between; to insert; to interpose.</def>

<au>Sir H. Wotton.</au>

<hw>In`ter*ject"</hw>, <pos>v. i.</pos> <def>To throw one's self
between or among; to come between; to interpose.</def>

<au>Sir G. Buck.</au>

<hw>In`ter*jec"tion</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[L.
<ets>interjectio</ets>: cf. F. <ets>interjection</ets>. See
<er>Interject</er>.]</ety>

<sn>1.</sn> <def>The act of interjecting or throwing between;
also, that which is interjected.</def>

<q>The <qex>interjection</qex> of laughing.</q>
<qau>Bacon.</qau>

<sn>2.</sn> <fld>(Gram.)</fld> <def>A word or form of speech
thrown in to express emotion or feeling, as <xex>O</xex>!
<xex>Alas</xex>! <xex>Ha ha</xex>! <xex>Begone</xex>! etc.
Compare <er>Exclamation</er>.</def>

<q>An <qex>interjection</qex> implies a meaning which it would
require a whole grammatical sentence to expound, and it may be
regarded as the rudiment of such a sentence. But it is a
confusion of thought to rank it among the parts of speech.</q>
<qau>Earle.</qau>

<q>How now! <qex>interjections</qex>? Why, then, some be of
laughing, as, ah, ha, he!</q>
<qau>Shak.</qau>

<hw>In`ter*jec"tion*al</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>a.</pos>
<sn>1.</sn> <def>Thrown in between other words or phrases;
parenthetical; ejaculatory; <as>as, an <ex>interjectional</ex>
remark</as>.</def>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>Pertaining to, or having the nature of, an
interjection; consisting of natural and spontaneous
exclamations.</def>

<q>Certain of the natural accompaniments of
<qex>interjectional</qex> speech, such as gestures, grimaces, and
gesticulations, are restrained by civilization.</q>
<qau>Earle.</qau>

<hw>In`ter*jec"tion*al*ize</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>v. t.</pos>
<def>To convert into, or to use as, an interjection.</def>

<au>Earle.</au>

<hw>In`ter*jec"tion*al*ly</hw>, <pos>adv.</pos> <def>In an
interjectional manner.</def>

<au>G. Eliot.</au>

<hw>In`ter*jec"tion*a*ry</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>a.</pos>
<def>Interjectional.</def>

<hw>In`ter*lace"</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>v. t. & i.</pos>
<wordforms>[<pos>imp. & p. p.</pos> <er>Interlaced</er>
<pr>(?)</pr>; <pos>p. pr. & vb. n.</pos> <er>Interlacing</er>

<q>Severed into stripes
That <qex>interlaced</qex> each other.</q>
<qau>Cowper.</qau>

dialogue.</q>
<qau>Dryden.</qau>

<cs><col>Interlacing arches</col> <fld>(Arch.)</fld>, <cd>arches,
usually circular, so constructed that their archivolts intersect
and seem to be interlaced.</cd></cs>

<hw>In`ter*lard"</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>v. t.</pos>
<wordforms>[<pos>imp. & p. p.</pos> <er>Interlarded</er>; <pos>p.
pr. & vb. n.</pos> <er>Interlarding</er>.]</wordforms> <ety>[F.
<ets>entrelarder</ets>. See <er>Inter-</er>, and
<er>Lard</er>.]</ety>

<sn>1.</sn> <def>To place lard or bacon amongst; to mix, as fat
meat with lean.</def> <mark>[Obs.]</mark>

<q>Whose grain doth rise in flakes, with fatness
<qex>interlarded</qex>.</q>
<qau>Drayton.</qau>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>Hence: To insert between; to mix or mingle;
especially, to introduce that which is foreign or irrelevant;
<as>as, to <ex>interlard</ex> a conservation with oaths or
allusions</as>.</def>

<q>The English laws . . . [were] mingled and
<qex>interlarded</qex> with many particular laws of their
own.</q>
<qau>Sir M. Hale.</qau>

<q>They <qex>interlard</qex> their native drinks with choice
Of strongest brandy.</q>
<qau>J. Philips.</qau>

<hw>In`ter*line"</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>v. t.</pos>

<sn>1.</sn> <def>To write or insert between lines already written
or printed, as for correction or addition; to write or print
something between the lines of; <as>as, to <ex>interline</ex> a
page or a book</as>.</def>

<au>Swift.</au>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>To arrange in alternate lines; <as>as, to
<ex>interline</ex> Latin and English</as>.</def>

<au>Locke.</au>

<sn>3.</sn> <def>To mark or imprint with lines.</def>

<q>A crooked wrinkle <qex>interlines</qex> my brow.</q>
<qau>Marlowe.</qau>

<hw>In`ter*lo*cu"tion</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[L.
<ets>interlocutio</ets>, from <ets>interloqui</ets>,
<ets>interlocutus</ets>, to speak between; <ets>inter</ets>
between + <ets>loqui</ets> to speak: cf. F.
<ets>interlocution</ets>. See <er>Loquacious</er>.]</ety>

<sn>1.</sn> <def>Interchange of speech; dialogue; conversation;
conference.</def>

<sn>2.</sn> <fld>(Law)</fld> <def>An intermediate act or decree
before final decision.</def>

<au>Ayliffe.</au>

<sn>3.</sn> <def>Hence, intermediate argument or
discussion.</def>

<hw>In`ter*loc"u*tor</hw> <pr>(?; 277)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos>
<ety>[Cf. F. <ets>interlocuteur</ets>.]</ety>

<sn>1.</sn> <def>One who takes part in dialogue or conversation;
a talker, interpreter, or questioner.</def>

<au>Jer. Taylor.</au>

<sn>2.</sn> <fld>(Law)</fld> <def>An interlocutory judgment or
sentence.</def>

<hw>In`ter*loc"u*to*ry</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>a.</pos> <ety>[Cf.
LL. <ets>interlocutorius</ets>, F.
<ets>interlocutoire</ets>.]</ety>

<sn>1.</sn> <def>Consisting of, or having the nature of,
dialogue; conversational.</def>

<q><qex>Interlocutory</qex> discourses in the Holy
Scriptures.</q>
<qau>Fiddes.</qau>

<sn>2.</sn> <fld>(Law)</fld> <def>Intermediate; not final or
definitive; made or done during the progress of an action.</def>

<note><hand/ An order, sentence, decree, or judgment, given in an
intermediate stage between the commencement and termination of a
cause, is called <xex>interlocutory</xex>.</note>

<hw>In`ter*loc"u*to*ry</hw>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[Cf. F.
<ets>interlocutoire</ets>.]</ety> <def>Interpolated discussion or
dialogue.</def>

<ety>[F.]</ety> <def>A female interlocutor.</def>

<hw>In`ter*lope"</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>v. i.</pos>
<wordforms>[<pos>imp. & p. p.</pos> <er>Interloped</er>
<pr>(?)</pr>; <pos>p. pr. & vb. n.</pos>
<er>Interloping</er>.]</wordforms> <ety>[See
<er>Interloper</er>.]</ety> <def>To run between parties and
intercept without right the advantage that one should gain from
the other; to traffic without a proper license; to intrude; to
forestall others; to intermeddle.</def>

<hw>In"ter*lo`per</hw> <pr>(?; 277)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos>
<ety>[Pref. <ets>inter-</ets> + D. <ets>looper</ets> a runner,
fr. <ets>loopen</ets> to run; akin to E. <ets>leap</ets>. See
<er>Leap</er>, and cf. <er>Elope</er>.]</ety> <def>One who
interlopes; one who interlopes; one who unlawfully intrudes upon
a property, a station, or an office; one who interferes
wrongfully or officiously.</def>

<q>The untrained man, . . . the <qex>interloper</qex> as to the
professions.</q>
<qau>I. Taylor.</qau>

<hw>In`ter*lu"cate</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>v. t.</pos> <ety>[L.
<ets>interlucatus</ets>, p. p. of <ets>interlucare</ets>;
<ets>inter</ets> between + <ets>lux</ets>, <ets>lucis</ets>,
light.]</ety> <def>To let in light upon, as by cutting away
branches.</def> <mark>[Obs.]</mark>

<hw>In`ter*lu*ca"tion</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[L.
<ets>interlucatio</ets>.]</ety> <def>Act of thinning a wood to

<au>Evelyn.</au>

<hw>In`ter*lu"cent</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>a.</pos> <ety>[L.
<ets>interlucens</ets>, p. pr. See <er>Inter-</er>, and
<er>Lucent</er>.]</ety> <def>Shining between.</def>

<hw>In`ter*lude</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[OE.
<ets>enterlude</ets>, LL. <ets>interludium</ets>; LL.
<ets>inter</ets> between + <ets>ludus</ets> play, fr.
<ets>ludere</ets> to play: cf. F. <ets>interlude</ets>. See
<er>Ludicrous</er>.]</ety>

<sn>1.</sn> <def>A short entertainment exhibited on the stage
between the acts of a play, or between the play and the
afterpiece, to relieve the tedium of waiting.</def>

<q>Dreams are but <qex>interludes</qex>, which fancy makes
When monarch reason sleeps.</q>
<qau>Dryden.</qau>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>A form of English drama or play, usually short,
merry, and farcical, which succeeded the Moralities or Moral
Plays in the transition to the romantic or Elizabethan
drama.</def>

<sn>3.</sn> <fld>(Mus.)</fld> <def>A short piece of instrumental
music played between the parts of a song or cantata, or the acts
of a drama; especially, in church music, a short passage played
by the organist between the stanzas of a hymn, or in German
chorals after each line.</def>

<hw>In"ter*lu`ded</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>a.</pos> <def>Inserted
in the manner of an interlude; having or containing
interludes.</def>

<hw>In"ter*lu`der</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <def>An actor
who performs in an interlude.</def>

<au>B. Jonson.</au>

<hw>In"ter*lu`en*cy</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[L.
<ets>interluens</ets>, p. pr. of <ets>interluere</ets> to flow
between; <ets>inter + luere</ets>.]</ety> <def>A flowing between;
intervening water.</def> <mark>[Obs.]</mark>

<au>Sir M. Hale.</au>

<mhw>{ <hw>In`ter*lu"nar</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>,
<hw>In`ter*lu"na*ry</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, }</mhw> <pos>a.</pos>
<ety>[Pref. <ets>inter-</ets> + <ets>lunar</ets>: cf. L.
<ets>interlunis</ets>.]</ety> <def>Belonging or pertaining to the
time when the moon, at or near its conjunction with the sun, is
invisible.</def>

<au>Milton.</au>

<hw>In`ter*man*dib"u*lar</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>a.</pos>
<fld>(Anat.)</fld> <def>Between the mandibles; interramal;
<as>as, the <ex>intermandibular</ex> space</as>.</def>

<hw>In`ter*mar"riage</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos>
<def>Connection by marriage; reciprocal marriage; giving and
taking in marriage, as between two families, tribes, castes, or
nations.</def>

<hw>In`ter*mar"ry</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>v. i.</pos> <def>To
become connected by marriage between their members; to give and
take mutually in marriage; -- said of families, ranks, castes,
etc.</def>

<q>About the middle of the fourth century from the building of
Rome, it was declared lawful for nobles and plebeians to
<qex>intermarry</qex>.</q>
<qau>Swift.</qau>

<hw>\'d8In`ter*max*il"la</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos>;
<plu>pl. <plw>Intermaxill\'91</plw> <pr>(<?/)</pr>.</plu>
<fld>(Anat.)</fld> <def>See <er>Premaxilla</er>.</def>

<hw>In`ter*med"dle</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>v. i.</pos> <ety>[OE.
<ets>entremedlen</ets>, <ets>entermellen</ets>, to mix together,
OF. <ets>entremedler</ets>, <ets>entremeller</ets>,
<ets>entremesler</ets>, F. <ets>entrem\'88ler</ets>. See
<er>Inter-</er>, and <er>Meddle</er>.]</ety> <def>To meddle with
the affairs of others; to meddle officiously; to interpose or
interfere improperly; to mix or meddle with.</def>

<q>The practice of Spain hath been, by war and by conditions of
treaty, to <qex>intermeddle</qex> with foreign states.</q>
<qau>Bacon.</qau>

<syn>Syn. -- To interpose; interfere. See
<er>Interpose</er>.</syn>

<hw>In`ter*mis"sion</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[L.
<ets>intermissio</ets>: cf. F. <ets>intermission</ets>. See
<er>Intermit</er>.]</ety>

<sn>1.</sn> <def>The act or the state of intermitting; the state
of being neglected or disused; disuse; discontinuance.</def>

<au>B. Jonson.</au>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>Cessation for a time; an intervening period of
time; an interval; a temporary pause; <as>as, to labor without
<ex>intermission</ex>; an <ex>intermission</ex> of ten
minutes.</as></def>

<q>Rest or <qex>intermission</qex> none I find.</q>
<qau>Milton.</qau>

<sn>3.</sn> <fld>(Med.)</fld> <def>The temporary cessation or
subsidence of a fever; the space of time between the paroxysms of
a disease. <xex>Intermission</xex> is an entire cessation, as
distinguished from <xex>remission</xex>, or abatement of
fever.</def>

<sn>4.</sn> <def>Intervention; interposition.</def>
<mark>[Obs.]</mark>

<au>Heylin.</au>

<syn>Syn. -- Cessation; interruption; interval; pause; stop;
rest; suspension. See <er>Cessation</er>.</syn>

<hw>In`ter*mis"sive</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>a.</pos> <def>Having

\'bd<xex>Intermissive</xex> miseries.\'b8 <au>Shak</au>.

<au>Howell.</au>

<hw>In`ter*mit"</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>v. t.</pos>
<wordforms>[<pos>imp. & p. p.</pos> <er>Intermitted</er>

<er>Intermitting</er>.]</wordforms> <ety>[L.

<hw>In`ter*mit"tence</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[Cf.

<au>Tyndall.</au>

<hw>In`ter*mit"tent</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>a.</pos> <ety>[L.
<ets>intermittens</ets>, <ets>-entis</ets>, p. pr. of
<ets>intermittere</ets>: cf. F. <ets>intermittent</ets>.]</ety>
<def>Coming and going at intervals; alternating; recurrent;
periodic; <as>as, an <ex>intermittent</ex> fever</as>.</def>

<au>Boyle.</au>

<cs><col>Intermittent fever</col> <fld>(Med.)</fld>, <cd>a
disease with fever which recurs at certain intervals; -- applied
particularly to fever and ague. See <er>Fever</er>.</cd> --
<col>Intermittent gearing</col> <fld>(Mach.)</fld>, <cd>gearing
which receives, or produces, intermittent motion.</cd> --
<col>Intermittent springs</col>, <cd>springs which flow at
intervals, not apparently dependent upon rain or drought. They
probably owe their intermittent action to their being connected
with natural reservoirs in hills or mountains by passages having
the form of a siphon, the water beginning to flow when it has
accumulated so as to fill the upper part of the siphon, and
ceasing when, by running through it, it has fallen below the
orifice of the upper part of the siphon in the
reservoir.</cd></cs>

<hw>In`ter*mit"tent</hw>, <pos>n.</pos> <fld>(Med.)</fld> <def>An
intermittent fever or disease.</def>

<au>Dunglison.</au>

<hw>In`ter*mit"tent*ly</hw>, <pos>adv.</pos> <def>With
intermissions; in an intermittent manner; intermittingly.</def>

<hw>In`ter*mit"ting*ly</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>adv.</pos>
<def>With intermissions; at intervals.</def>

<au>W. Montagu.</au>

<hw>In*tern"</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>a.</pos> <ety>[L.
<ets>internus</ets>: cf. F. <ets>interne</ets>. See

<mark>[Obs.]</mark>

<au>Howell.</au>

<hw>In*tern"</hw>, <pos>v. t.</pos> <ety>[F. <ets>interne</ets>.
See <er>Intern</er>, <pos>a.</pos>]</ety> <def>To put for safe
keeping in the interior of a place or country; to confine to one
locality; <as>as, to <ex>intern</ex> troops which have fled for
refuge to a neutral country</as>.</def>

<hw>In*tern"al</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>a.</pos> <ety>[L.
<ets>internus</ets>; akin to <ets>interior</ets>. See
<er>Interior</er>.]</ety>

<sn>1.</sn> <def>Inward; interior; being within any limit or
surface; inclosed; -- opposed to <xex>external</xex>; <as>as, the
<ex>internal</ex> parts of a body, or of the earth</as>.</def>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>Derived from, or dependent on, the thing itself;
inherent; <as>as, the <ex>internal</ex> evidence of the divine
origin of the Scriptures</as>.</def>

<sn>3.</sn> <def>Pertaining to its own affairs or interests;
especially, (said of a country) domestic, as opposed to
<xex>foreign</xex>; <as>as, <ex>internal</ex> trade;
<ex>internal</ex> troubles or war.</as></def>

<sn>4.</sn> <def>Pertaining to the inner being or the heart;
spiritual.</def>

<q>With our Savior, <qex>internal</qex> purity is everything.</q>
<qau>Paley.</qau>

<sn>5.</sn> <def>Intrinsic; inherent; real.</def>
<mark>[R.]</mark>

<q>The <qex>internal</qex> rectitude of our actions in the sight
of God.</q>
<qau>Rogers.</qau>

<-- p. 779 -->

<sn>6.</sn> <fld>(Anat.)</fld> <def>Lying toward the mesial
plane; mesial.</def>

<cs><col>Internal angle</col> <fld>(Geom.)</fld>, <cd>an interior
angle. See under <er>Interior</er>.</cd> -- <col>Internal
gear</col> <fld>(Mach.)</fld>, <cd>a gear in which the teeth
project inward from the rim instead of outward.</cd></cs>

<syn>Syn. -- Inner; interior; inward; inland; inside.</syn>

<hw>In`ter*nal"i*ty</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <def>The
state of being internal or within; interiority.</def>

<hw>In*ter"nal*ly</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>adv.</pos> <sn>1.</sn>
<def>Inwardly; within the enveloping surface, or the boundary of
a thing; within the body; beneath the surface.</def>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>Hence: Mentally; spiritually.</def>

<au>Jer. Taylor.</au>

<hw>In`ter*na"sal</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>a.</pos>
<fld>(Anat.)</fld> <def>Between the nasal cavities; <as>as, the
<ex>internasal</ex> cartilage</as>.</def>

<hw>In`ter*na"tion*al</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>a.</pos>
<ety>[Pref. <ets>inter-</ets> + <ets>national</ets>: cf. F.
<ets>international</ets>.]</ety>

<sn>1.</sn> <def>Between or among nations; pertaining to the
intercourse of nations; participated in by two or more nations;
common to, or affecting, two or more nations.</def>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>Of or concerning the association called the
International.</def>

<cs><col>International code</col> <fld>(Naut.)</fld>, <cd>a
common system of signaling adopted by nearly all maritime
nations, whereby communication may be had between vessels at
sea.</cd> -- <col>International copyright</col>. <cd>See under
<er>Copyright</er>.</cd> -- <col>International law</col>, <cd>the
rules regulating the mutual intercourse of nations. International
law is mainly the product of the conditions from time to time of
international intercourse, being drawn from diplomatic
discussion, textbooks, proof of usage, and from recitals in
treaties. It is called <xex>public<xex> when treating of the
relations of sovereign powers, and <xex>private<xex> when of the
relations of persons of different nationalities. International
law is now, by the better opinion, part of the common law of the
land. Cf. <xex>Conflict of laws<xex>, under
<er>Conflict</er>.</cd></cs>

<au>Wharton.</au>

<hw>In`ter*na"tion*al</hw>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[Cf. F.
<ets>internationale</ets>.]</ety>

<sn>1.</sn> <def>The International; an abbreviated from of the
title of the International Workingmen's Association, the name of
an association, formed in London in 1864, which has for object
the promotion of the interests of the industrial classes of all
nations.</def>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>A member of the International Association.</def>

<hw>In`ter*na"tion*al*ism</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos>
<sn>1.</sn> <def>The state or principles of international
interests and intercourse.</def>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>The doctrines or organization of the
International.</def>

<hw>In`ter*na"tion*al*ist</hw>, <pos>n.</pos> <sn>1.</sn>
<def>One who is versed in the principles of international
law.</def>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>A member of the International; one who believes
in, or advocates the doctrines of, the International.</def>

<hw>In`ter*na"tion*al*ize</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>v. t.</pos>
<def>To make international; to cause to affect the mutual
relations of two or more nations; <as>as, to
<ex>internationalize</ex> a principle of law, or a philanthropic
enterprise</as>.</def>

<hw>In`ter*na"tion*al*ly</hw>, <pos>adv.</pos> <def>In an

<cs><col>Interpenetrating molding</col> <fld>(Arch.)</fld>,
<cd>in late Gothic architecture, a decoration by means of
moldings which seem to pass through solid uprights, transoms, or
other members; often, two sets of architectural members
penetrating one another, in appearance, as if both had been
plastic when they were put together.</cd></cs>

<hw>In`ter*plead"er</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <sn>1.</sn>
<def>One who interpleads.</def>

<sn>2.</sn> <fld>(Law)</fld> <def>A proceeding devised to enable

adversely by two or more parties, to compel them to litigate the
right or title between themselves, and thereby to relieve himself
from the suits which they might otherwise bring against
him.</def>

<hw>In*ter"po*la*ble</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>a.</pos> <def>That
may be interpolated; suitable to be interpolated.</def>

<q>A most <qex>interpolable</qex> clause of one sentence.</q>
<qau>De Morgan.</qau>

<hw>In*ter"po*late</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>v. t.</pos>
<wordforms>[<pos>imp. & p. p.</pos> <er>Interpolated</er>
<pr>(?)</pr>; <pos>p. pr. & vb. n.</pos>
<er>Interpolating</er>.]</wordforms> <ety>[L.
<ets>interpolatus</ets>, p. p. of <ets>interpolare</ets> to form
anew, to interpolate, fr. <ets>interpolus</ets>,
<ets>interpolis</ets>, falsified, vamped up, polished up;
<ets>inter</ets> between + <ets>polire</ets> to polish. See
<er>Polish</er>, <pos>v. t.</pos>]</ety>

<sn>1.</sn> <def>To renew; to carry on with intermission.</def>
<mark>[Obs.]</mark>

<q>Motion . . . partly continued and unintermitted, . . . partly
<qex>interpolated</qex> and interrupted.</q>
<qau>Sir M. Hale.</qau>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>To alter or corrupt by the insertion of new or
foreign matter; especially, to change, as a book or text, by the
insertion of matter that is new, or foreign to the purpose of the
author.</def>

<q>How strangely Ignatius is mangled and <qex>interpolated</qex>,
you may see by the vast difference of all copies and
editions.</q>
<qau>Bp. Barlow.</qau>

<q>The Athenians were put in possession of Salamis by another
law, which was cited by Solon, or, as some think,
<qex>interpolated</qex> by him for that purpose.</q>
<qau>Pope.</qau>

<sn>3.</sn> <fld>(Math.)</fld> <def>To fill up intermediate terms
of, as of a series, according to the law of the series; to
introduce, as a number or quantity, in a partial series,
according to the law of that part of the series.</def>

<hw>In*ter"po*la`ted</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>a.</pos> <sn>1.</sn>
<def>Inserted in, or added to, the original; introduced; foisted
in; changed by the insertion of new or spurious matter.</def>

<sn>2.</sn> <fld>(Math.)</fld> <sd>(a)</sd> <def>Provided with
necessary interpolations; <as>as, an <ex>interpolated</ex>
table</as>.</def> <sd>(b)</sd> <def>Introduced or determined by
interpolation; <as>as, <ex>interpolated</ex> quantities or
numbers</as>.</def>

<hw>In*ter`po*la"tion</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[L.
<ets>interpolatio</ets> an alteration made here and there: cf. F.
<ets>interpolation</ets>.]</ety> <sn>1.</sn> <def>The act of
introducing or inserting anything, especially that which is
spurious or foreign.</def>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>That which is introduced or inserted, especially
something foreign or spurious.</def>

<q>Bentley wrote a letter . . . . upon the scriptural glosses in
our present copies of Hesychius, which he considered
<qex>interpolations</qex> from a later hand.</q>
<qau>De Quincey.</qau>

<sn>3.</sn> <fld>(Math.)</fld> <def>The method or operation of
finding from a few given terms of a series, as of numbers or
observations, other intermediate terms in conformity with the law
of the series.</def>

<hw>In*ter"po*la`tor</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[L., a
corrupter: of. F. <ets>interpolateur</ets>.]</ety> <def>One who
interpolates; esp., one who inserts foreign or spurious matter in
genuine writings.</def>

<hw>In`ter*po"nent</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <def>One who,

<au>Heywood.</au>

<hw>In`ter*pos"al</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[From
<er>Interpose</er>.]</ety> <def>The act of interposing;
interposition; intervention.</def>

<hw>In`ter*pose"</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>v. t.</pos>
<wordforms>[<pos>imp. & p. p.</pos> <er>Interposed</er>
<pr>(?)</pr>; <pos>p. pr. & vb. n.</pos>
<er>Interposing</er>.]</wordforms> <ety>[F.
<ets>interposer</ets>. See <er>Inter-</er>, and <er>Pose</er>,
<pos>v. t.</pos>]</ety>

<sn>1.</sn> <def>To place between; <as>as, to <ex>interpose</ex>
a screen between the eye and the light</as>.</def>

<q>Mountains <qex>interposed</qex>
Make enemies of nations.</q>
<qau>Cowper.</qau>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>To thrust; to intrude; to between, either for
aid or for troubling.</def>

<q>What watchful cares do <qex>interpose</qex> themselves
Betwixt your eyes and night?</q>
<qau>Shak.</qau>

<q>The common Father of mankind seasonably <qex>interposed</qex>
his hand, and rescues miserable man.</q>
<qau>Woodward.</qau>

<sn>3.</sn> <def>To introduce or inject between the parts of a
conversation or argument.</def>

<au>Milton.</au>

<hw>In`ter*pose"</hw>, <pos>v. i.</pos> <sn>1.</sn> <def>To be or
come between.</def>

<q>Long hid by <qex>interposing</qex> hill or wood.</q>
<qau>Cowper.</qau>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>To step in between parties at variance; to
mediate; <as>as, the prince <ex>interposed</ex> and made
peace</as>.</def>

<au>Pope.</au>

<sn>3.</sn> <def>To utter a sentiment by way of
interruption.</def>

<au>Boyle.</au>

<syn>Syn. -- To intervene; intercede; mediate; interfere;
intermeddle.</syn> <usage> -- To <er>Interpose</er>,
<er>Intermeddle</er>, <er>Interfere</er>. A man may often
<xex>interpose</xex> with propriety in the concerns of others; he
can never <xex>intermeddle</xex> without being impertinent or
officious; nor can be <xex>interfere</xex> without being liable
to the same charge, unless he has rights which are interfered
with. \'bdIn our practical use, <xex>interference</xex> is
something offensive. It is the pushing in of himself between two
parties on the part of a third who was not asked, and is not
thanked for his pains, and who, as the feeling of the word
implies, had no business there; while <xex>interposition</xex> is
employed to express the friendly, peacemaking mediation of one
whom the act well became, and who, even if he was not specially
invited thereunto, is still thanked for what he has done.\'b8
<au>Trench.</au></usage>

<hw>In"ter*pose</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos>
<def>Interposition.</def> <mark>[Obs.]</mark>

<hw>In`ter*pos"er</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <def>One who,
or that which, interposes or intervenes; an obstacle or
interruption; a mediator or agent between parties.</def>

<au>Shak.</au>

<hw>In`ter*pos"it</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[From L.
<ets>interpositus</ets>, p. p. of <ets>interponere</ets>. See
<er>Interposition</er>.]</ety> <def>An intermediate depot or
station between one commercial city or country and another.</def>

<au>Mitford.</au>

<hw>In`ter*po*si"tion</hw> <pr>(?; 277)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos>
<ety>[L. <ets>interpositio</ets> a putting between, insertion,
fr. <ets>interponere</ets>, <ets>interpositum</ets>: cf. F.
<ets>interposition</ets>. See <er>Interpone</er>,
<er>Position</er>.]</ety>

<sn>1.</sn> <def>The act of interposing, or the state of being
interposed; a being, placing, or coming between; mediation.</def>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>The thing interposed.</def>

<hw>In`ter*po"sure</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos>
<def>Interposition.</def> <mark>[Obs.]</mark>

<hw>In*ter"pret</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>v. t.</pos>
<wordforms>[<pos>imp. & p. p.</pos> <er>Interpreted</er>; <pos>p.
pr. & vb. n.</pos> <er>Interpreting</er>.]</wordforms> <ety>[F.
<ets>interpr\'88ter</ets>, L. <ets>interpretari</ets>, p. p.
<ets>interpretatus</ets>, fr. <ets>interpre<?/</ets> interpeter,
agent, negotiator; <ets>inter</ets> between + (prob.) the root of
<ets>pretium</ets> price. See <er>Price</er>.]</ety>

<sn>1.</sn> <def>To explain or tell the meaning of; to expound;
to translate orally into intelligible or familiar language or
terms; to decipher; to define; -- applied esp. to language, but
also to dreams, signs, conduct, mysteries, etc.; <as>as, to
<ex>interpret</ex> the Hebrew language to an Englishman; to
<ex>interpret</ex> an Indian speech.</as></def>

<q>Emmanuel, which being <qex>interpreted</qex> is, God with
us.</q>
<qau>Matt. i. 23.</qau>

<q>And Pharaoh told them his dreams; but there was none that
could <qex>interpret</qex> them unto Pharaoh.</q>
<qau>Gen. xli. 8.</qau>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>To apprehend and represent by means of art; to
show by illustrative representation; <as>as, an actor
<ex>interprets</ex> the character of Hamlet; a musician
<ex>interprets</ex> a sonata; an artist <ex>interprets</ex> a
landscape.</as></def>

<syn>Syn. -- To translate; explain; solve; render; expound;
elucidate; decipher; unfold; unravel.</syn>

<hw>In*ter"pret</hw>, <pos>v. i.</pos> <def>To act as an
interpreter.</def>

<au>Shak.</au>

<hw>In*ter"pret*a*ble</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>a.</pos> <ety>[L.
<ets>interpretabilis</ets>: cf. F.
<ets>interpr\'88table</ets>.]</ety> <def>Admitting of
interpretation; capable of being interpreted or explained.</def>

<hw>In*ter"pre*ta*ment</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[L.
<ets>interpretamentum</ets>.]</ety> <def>Interpretation.</def>
<mark>[Obs.]</mark>

<au>Milton.</au>

<-- p. 780 -->

<-- p. 780 -->

<hw>In*ter`pre*ta"tion</hw>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[L.
<ets>interpretatio</ets>: cf. F.
<ets>interpr\'82tation</ets>.]</ety>

<sn>1.</sn> <def>The act of interpreting; explanation of what is
obscure; translation; version; construction; <as>as, the
<ex>interpretation</ex> of a foreign language, of a dream, or of
an enigma</as>.</def>

<q>Look how we can, or sad or merrily,
<qex>Interpretation</qex> will misquote our looks.</q>
<qau>Shak.</qau>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>The sense given by an interpreter; exposition or
explanation given; meaning; <as>as, commentators give various
<ex>interpretations</ex> of the same passage of
Scripture</as>.</def>

<sn>3.</sn> <def>The power or explaining.</def> <mark>[R.]</mark>

<au>Bacon.</au>

<sn>4.</sn> <fld>(Fine Arts)</fld> <def>An artist's way of
expressing his thought or embodying his conception of
nature.</def>

<sn>5.</sn> <fld>(Math.)</fld> <def>The act or process of
applying general principles or formul\'91 to the explanation of
the results obtained in special cases.</def>

<syn>Syn. -- Explanation; solution; translation; version; sense;
exposition; rendering; definition.</syn>

<hw>In*ter"pre*ta*tive</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>a.</pos> <ety>[Cf.
F. <ets>interpr\'82tatif</ets>.]</ety>

explanatory.</def> \'bd<xex>Interpretative</xex>
lexicography.\'b8

<q>An <qex>interpretative</qex> siding with heresies.</q>
<qau>Hammond.</qau>

<hw>In*ter"ro*gate</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>v. t.</pos>
<wordforms>[<pos>imp. & p. p.</pos> <er>Interrogating</er>
<pr>(?)</pr>.]</wordforms> <ety>[L. <ets>interrogatus</ets>, p.
p. of <ets>interrogare</ets> to ask; <ets>inter</ets> between +
<ets>rogare</ets> to ask. See Rogation.]</ety> <def>To question
formally; to question; to examine by asking questions; <as>as, to
<ex>interrogate</ex> a witness</as>.</def>

<q>Wilt thou, uncalled, <qex>interrogate</qex>,
Talker! the unreplying Fate?</q>
<qau>Emerson.</qau>

<hw>In*ter`ro*ga*tee"</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <def>One
who is interrogated.</def>

<hw>In*ter`ro*ga"tion</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[L.
<ets>interrogatio</ets>: cf. F. <ets>interrogation</ets>.]</ety>

<sn>1.</sn> <def>The act of interrogating or questioning;
examination by questions; inquiry.</def>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>A question put; an inquiry.</def>

<sn>3.</sn> <def>A point, mark, or sign, thus [?], indicating
that the sentence with which it is connected is a question. It is
used to express doubt, or to mark a query. Called also
<altname>interrogation point</altname>.</def><-- usu. question
mark. -->

<note><hand/ In works printed in the Spanish language this mark
is not only placed at the end of an interrogative sentence, but
is also placed, inverted [as thus (<iques/)], at the
beginning.</note>

<hw>In`ter*rog"a*tive</hw> <pr>(<?/)</pr>, <pos>a.</pos> <ety>[L.
<ets>interrogativus</ets>: cf. F. <ets>interrogatif</ets>.]</ety>
<def>Denoting a question; expressed in the form of a question;
<as>as, an <ex>interrogative</ex> sentence; an
<ex>interrogative</ex> pronoun.</as></def>

<hw>In`ter*rupt"</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>v. t.</pos>
<wordforms>[<pos>imp. & p. p.</pos> <er>Interrupted</er>; <pos>p.
pr. & vb. n.</pos> <er>Interrupting</er>.]</wordforms> <ety>[L.
<ets>interruptus</ets>, p. p. of <ets>interrumpere</ets> to
interrupt; <ets>inter</ets> between + <ets>rumpere</ets> to
break. See <er>Rupture</er>.]</ety>

<sn>1.</sn> <def>To break into, or between; to stop, or hinder by
breaking in upon the course or progress of; to interfere with the
current or motion of; to cause a temporary cessation of; <as>as,
to <ex>interrupt</ex> the remarks speaking</as>.</def>

<q>Do not <qex>interrupt</qex> me in my course.</q>
<qau>Shak.</qau>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>To divide; to separate; to break the monotony
of; <as>as, the evenness of the road was not <ex>interrupted</ex>
by a single hill</as>.</def>

<hw>In`ter*rupt"</hw>, <pos>p. a.</pos> <ety>[L.

interrupted.</def> <mark>[Obs.]</mark>

<au>Milton.</au>

<sn>2.</sn> <fld>(Bot.)</fld> <def>Irregular; -- said of any

arranged to make and break a circuit at rapidly recurring
intervals, by the action of the current itself.</def>

<hw>In`ter*rup"tion</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[L.
<ets>interruptio</ets>: cf. F. <ets>interruption</ets>.]</ety>

<sn>1.</sn> <def>The act of interrupting, or breaking in
upon.</def>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>The state of being interrupted; a breach or
break, caused by the abrupt intervention of something foreign;
intervention; interposition.</def>

<au>Sir M. Hale.</au>

<q>Lest the <qex>interruption</qex> of time cause you to lose the
idea of one part.</q>
<qau>Dryden.</qau>

<sn>3.</sn> <def>Obstruction caused by breaking in upon course,
current, progress, or motion; stop; hindrance; <as>as, the author
has met with many <ex>interruptions</ex> in the execution of his
work; the speaker or the argument proceeds without
<ex>interruption</ex>.</as></def>

<sn>4.</sn> <def>Temporary cessation; intermission;
suspension.</def>

<hw>In`ter*sperse"</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>v. t.</pos>
<wordforms>[<pos>imp. & p. p.</pos> <er>Interspersed</er>
<pr>(?)</pr>; <pos>p. pr. & vb. n.</pos>
<er>Interspersing</er>.]</wordforms> <ety>[L.
<ets>interspersus</ets> interspersed; <ets>inter</ets> between,
among + <ets>spargere</ets> to scatter. See
<er>Sparse</er>.]</ety>

<sn>1.</sn> <def>To scatter or set here and there among other
things; to insert at intervals; <as>as, to <ex>intersperse</ex>
pictures in a book</as>.</def>

<q>There, <qex>interspersed</qex> in lawns and op'ning glades,
Thin trees arise that shun each other's shades.</q>
<qau>Pope.</qau>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>To diversify or adorn with things set or
scattered at intervals; to place something at intervals in or
among; <as>as, to <ex>intersperse</ex> a book with
pictures</as>.</def>

<q>Which space is <qex>interspersed</qex> with small islands and
rock.</q>
<qau>Cook.</qau>

<hw>In`ter*sper"sion</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <def>The
act of interspersing, or the state of being interspersed.</def>

<mhw>{ <hw>In`ter*spi"nal</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>,
<hw>In`ter*spi"nous</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, }</mhw> <pos>a.</pos>
<fld>(Anat.)</fld> <def>Between spines; esp., between the spinous
processes of the vertebral column.</def>

<hw>In*ter"stice</hw> <pr>(?; 277)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos>; <plu>pl.
<plw>Interstices</plw> <pr>(#)</pr></plu>. <ety>[L.
<ets>interstitium</ets> a pause, interval; <ets>inter</ets>
between + <ets>sistere</ets> to set, fr. <ets>stare</ets> to
stand: cf. F. <ets>interstice</ets>. See <er>Stand</er>.]</ety>

<sn>1.</sn> <def>That which intervenes between one thing and
another; especially, a space between things closely set, or
between the parts which compose a body; a narrow chink; a crack;
a crevice; a hole; an interval; <as>as, the <ex>interstices</ex>
of a wall</as>.</def>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>An interval of time; specifically <fld>(R. C.
Ch.)</fld>, in the plural, the intervals which the canon law
requires between the reception of the various degrees of
orders.</def>

<q>Nonobservance of the <qex>interstices</qex> . . . is a
sin.</q>
<qau>Addis & Arnold.</qau>

<hw>In*ter"sticed</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>a.</pos> <def>Provided
with interstices; having interstices between; situated at
intervals.</def>

<au>Wallis.</au>

<hw>In"ter*val</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[L.
<ets>intervallum</ets>; <ets>inter</ets> between +
<ets>vallum</ets> a wall: cf. F. <ets>intervalle</ets>. See
<er>Wall</er>.]</ety>

<sn>1.</sn> <def>A space between things; a void space intervening
between any two objects; <as>as, an <ex>interval</ex> between two
houses or hills</as>.</def>

<q>'Twixt host and host but narrow space was left,
A dreadful <qex>interval</qex>.</q>
<qau>Milton.</qau>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>Space of time between any two points or events;
<as>as, the <ex>interval</ex> between the death of Charles
I</as>. of England, and the accession of Charles II.</def>

<sn>3.</sn> <def>A brief space of time between the recurrence of
similar conditions or states; <as>as, the <ex>interval</ex>
between paroxysms of pain; <ex>intervals</ex> of sanity or
delirium.</as></def>

<sn>4.</sn> <fld>(Mus.)</fld> <def>Difference in pitch between
any two tones.</def>

<cs><col>At intervals</col>, <cd>coming or happening with
intervals between; now and then. \'bdAnd Miriam watch'd and dozed
<xex>at intervals<xex>.\'b8 <au>Tennyson</au>.</cd> --
<col>Augmented interval</col> <fld>(Mus.)</fld>, <cd>an interval
increased by half a step or half a tone.</cd></cs>

<mhw>{ <hw>In"ter*val</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <hw>In"ter*vale</hw>
<pr>(?)</pr>, }</mhw> <pos>n.</pos> <def>A tract of low ground
between hills, or along the banks of a stream, usually alluvial
land, enriched by the overflowings of the river, or by
fertilizing deposits of earth from the adjacent hills. Cf.
<er>Bottom</er>, <pos>n.</pos>, 7.</def> <mark>[Local, U.
S.]</mark>

<q>The woody <qex>intervale</qex> just beyond the marshy
land.</q>
<qau>The Century.</qau>

<hw>\'d8In`ter*val"lum</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos>; <plu>pl.
<plw>Intervallums</plw> <pr>(#)</pr>, L. <plw>Intervalla</plw>
<pr>(#)</pr></plu>. <ety>[L.]</ety> <def>An interval.</def>
<mark>[R.]</mark>

<q>And a' shall laugh without <qex>intervallums</qex>.</q>

<hw>In`ter*vene"</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>v. i.</pos>
<wordforms>[<pos>imp. & p. p.</pos> <er>Intervened</er>
<pr>(?)</pr>; <pos>p. pr. & vb. n.</pos>
<er>Intervening</er>.]</wordforms> <ety>[L.
<ets>intervenire</ets>, <ets>interventum</ets>, to intervene, to
hinder; <ets>inter</ets> between + <ets>venire</ets> to come;
akin to E. <ets>come</ets>: cf. F. <ets>intervenir</ets>. See
<er>Come</er>.]</ety>

<sn>1.</sn> <def>To come between, or to be between, persons or
things; -- followed by <xex>between</xex>; <as>as, the
Mediterranean <ex>intervenes</ex> between Europe and
Africa</as>.</def>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>To occur, fall, or come between, points of time,
or events; <as>as, an instant <ex>intervened</ex> between the
flash and the report; nothing <ex>intervened</ex> ( <it>i.
e.</it>, between the intention and the execution) to prevent the
undertaking.</as></def>

<sn>3.</sn> <def>To interpose; <as>as, to <ex>intervene</ex> to
settle a quarrel</as>.</def>

<sn>4.</sn> <def>In a suit to which one has not been made a
party, to put forward a defense of one's interest in the  
subject matter.</def>

<au>Abbott.</au>

<hw>In`ter*vene"</hw>, <pos>v. t.</pos> <def>To come
between.</def> <mark>[R.]</mark>

<q>Self-sown woodlands of birch, alder, etc.,
<qex>intervening</qex> the different estates.</q>
<qau>De Quincey.</qau>

<hw>In`ter*ven"tion</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[L.
<ets>interventio</ets> an interposition: cf. F.
<ets>intervention</ets>.]</ety>

<sn>1.</sn> <def>The act of intervening; interposition.</def>

<q>Sound is shut out by the <qex>intervention</qex> of that lax
membrane.</q>
<qau>Holder.</qau>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>Any interference that may affect the interests
of others; especially, of one or more states with the affairs of
another; mediation.</def>

<q>Let us decide our quarrels at home, without the
<qex>intervention</qex>, of any foreign power.</q>
<qau>Sir W. Temple.</qau>

<sn>3.</sn> <fld>(Civil Law)</fld> <def>The act by which a third
person, to protect his own interest, interposes and becomes a
party to a suit pending between other parties.</def>

<hw>In"ter*view</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[F.
<ets>entrevue</ets>, fr. <ets>entrevoir</ets> to see imperfectly,
to have a glimpse of, <ets>s'entrevoir</ets> to visit each other.
See <er>Inter-</er>, and <er>View</er>.]</ety>

<sn>1.</sn> <def>A mutual sight or view; a meeting face to face;
usually, a formal or official meeting for consultation; a
conference; <as>as, the secretary had an <ex>interview</ex> with
the President</as>.</def>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>A conservation, or questioning, for the purpose
of eliciting information for publication; the published statement
so elicited.</def>

<note><hand/ A recent use, originating in American newspapers,
but apparently becoming general.</note>

<hw>In"ter*view</hw>, <pos>v. t.</pos> <def>To have an interview
with; to question or converse with, especially for the purpose of
obtaining information for publication.</def>

<hw>In*tes"ti*nal</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>a.</pos> <ety>[Cf. F.

<ex>intestinal</ex> digestion; <ex>intestinal</ex>
ferments.</as></def>

<cs><col>Intestinal canal</col>. <cd>Same as <er>Intestine</er>,
<pos>n.</pos></cd> -- <col>Intestinal worm</col>
<fld>(Zo\'94l.)</fld>, <cd>any species of helminth living in the
intestinal canal of any animal.  The species are
numerous.</cd></cs>

<hw>In*tes"tine</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>a.</pos> <ety>[L.
<ets>intestinus</ets>, fr. <ets>intus</ets> on the inside,
within, fr. <ets>in</ets> in: cf. F. <ets>intestine</ets>. See
<er>In</er>.]</ety>

<sn>1.</sn> <def>Internal; inward; -- opposed to
<xex>external</xex>.</def>

<q>Epilepsies, fierce catarrhs,
<qex>Intestine</qex> stone and ulcers.</q>
<qau>Milton.</qau>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>Internal with regard to a state or country;
domestic; not foreign; -- applied usually to that which is evil;
<as>as, <ex>intestine</ex> disorders, calamities, etc.</as></def>

<q>Hoping here to end
<qex>Intestine</qex> war in heaven, the arch foe subdued.</q>
<qau>Milton.</qau>

<q>An <qex>intestine</qex> struggle . . . between authority and
liberty.</q>
<qau>Hume.</qau>

<sn>3.</sn> <def>Depending upon the internal constitution of a
body or entity; subjective.</def>

<q>Everything labors under and <qex>intestine</qex>
necessity.</q>
<qau>Cudworth.</qau>

<sn>4.</sn> <def>Shut up; inclosed.</def> <mark>[R.]</mark>

<au>Cowper.</au>

<hw>In*tes"tine</hw>, <pos>n.</pos>; <plu>pl.
<plw>Intestines</plw> <pr>(#)</pr></plu>. <ety>[L.
<ets>intestinum</ets>: cf.  F. <ets>intestin</ets>. See
<er>Intestine</er>, <pos>a.</pos>]</ety>

<sn>1.</sn> <fld>(Anat.)</fld> <def>That part of the alimentary
canal between the stomach and the anus. See <xex>Illust</xex>. of
<xex>Digestive apparatus</xex>.</def>

<sn>2.</sn> <pluf>pl.</pluf> <def>The bowels; entrails;
viscera.</def>

<cs><col>Large intestine</col> <fld>(Human Anat. & Med.)</fld>,
<cd>the lower portion of the bowel, terminating at the anus. It
is adapted for the retention of fecal matter, being shorter,
broader, and less convoluted than the <xex>small intestine<xex>;
it consists of three parts, the c\'91cum, colon, and rectum.</cd>
-- <col>Small intestine</col> <fld>(Human Anat. & Med.)</fld>,
<cd>the upper portion of the bowel, in which the process of
digestion is practically completed. It is narrow and contorted,
and consists of three parts, the duodenum, jejunum, and
ileum.</cd></cs>

book.</def> <mark>[R.]</mark>

<au>Herrick.</au>

<ety>[<ets>In</ets>fine + <ets>extine</ets>.]</ety>
<fld>(Bot.)</fld> <def>A thin membrane existing in the pollen
grains of some plants, and situated between the extine and the
intine, as in <xex><OE/nothera</xex>.</def>

<hw>In*tex"tured</hw> <pr>(?; 135)</pr>, <pos>a.</pos>
<def>Inwrought; woven in.</def>

<q>She soothes, but never can <qex>inthrall</qex> my mind.</q>

<hw>In"ti*mate</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>a.</pos> <ety>[Formerly
<ets>intime</ets>, L. <ets>intimus</ets>, a superl. corresponding
to the compar. <ets>interior<?/<?/</ets> cf. F.
<ets>intime</ets>. The form <ets>intimate</ets> is due to
confusion with <ets>intimate</ets>, v. t. See
<er>Interior</er>.]</ety>

<sn>1.</sn> <def>Innermost; inward; internal; deep-seated;
hearty.</def> \'bdI knew from <xex>intimate</xex> impulse.\'b8

<au>Milton.</au>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>Near; close; direct; thorough; complete.</def>

<q>He was honored with an <qex>intimate</qex> and immediate
admission.</q>
<qau>South.</qau>

confidential; <as>as, an <ex>intimate</ex> friend</as>.</def>

<hw>In"ti*mate</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>v. t.</pos>
<wordforms>[<pos>imp. & p. p.</pos> <er>Intimated</er>
<pr>(?)</pr>; <pos>p. pr. & vb. n.</pos>
<er>Intimating</er>.]</wordforms> <ety>[L. <ets>intimatus</ets>,
p. p. of <ets>intimare</ets> to put, bring, drive, or press into,
to announce, make known, from <ets>intimus</ets> the inmost. See
<er>Intimate</er>, <pos>a.</pos>]</ety>

<sn>1.</sn> <def>To announce; to declare; to publish; to
communicate; to make known.</def> <mark>[Obs.]</mark>

<q>He, incontinent, did proclaim and <qex>intimate</qex> open
war.</q>
<qau>E. Hall.</qau>

<q>So both conspiring 'gan to <qex>intimate</qex>
Each other's grief.</q>
<qau>Spenser.</qau>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>To suggest obscurely or indirectly; to refer to
remotely; to give slight notice of; to hint; <as>as, he
<ex>intimated</ex> his intention of resigning his
office</as>.</def>

<q>The names of simple ideas and substances, with the abstract
ideas in the mind, <qex>intimate</qex> some real existence, from
which was derived their original pattern.</q>
<qau>Locke.</qau>

<hw>In"ti*mate*ly</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>adv.</pos> <def>In an
intimate manner.</def>

<hw>In`ti*ma"tion</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[L.
<ets>intimatio</ets>: cf. F. <ets>intimation</ets>.]</ety>

<sn>1.</sn> <def>The act of intimating; also, the thing
intimated.</def>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>Announcement; declaration.</def>

<au>Macaulay.</au>

<q>They made an edict with an <qex>intimation</qex> that
whosoever killed a stork, should be banished.</q>
<qau>Holland.</qau>

<sn>3.</sn> <def>A hint; an obscure or indirect suggestion or
notice; a remote or ambiguous reference; <as>as, he had given
only <ex>intimations</ex> of his design</as>.</def>

<q>Without mentioning the king of England, or giving the least
<qex>intimation</qex> that he was sent by him.</q>
<qau>Bp. Burnet.</qau>

<au>Sir K. Digby.</au>

<hw>In*tim"i*date</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>v. t.</pos>
<wordforms>[<pos>imp. & p. p.</pos> <er>Intimidated</er>
<pr>(?)</pr>; <pos>p. pr. & vb. n.</pos> <er>Intimidating</er>
<pr>(?)</pr>.]</wordforms> <ety>[LL. <ets>intimidatus</ets>, p.
p. of <ets>intimidare</ets> to frighten; pref. <ets>in-</ets> in
+ <ets>timidus</ets> fearful, timid: cf. F. <ets>intimider</ets>.
See <er>Timid</er>.]</ety> <def>To make timid or fearful; to
inspire of affect with fear; to deter, as by threats; to
dishearten; to abash.</def>

<q>Now guilt, once harbored in the conscious breast,
<qex>Intimidates</qex> the brave, degrades the great.</q>
<qau>Johnson.</qau>

<syn>Syn. -- To dishearten; dispirit; abash; deter; frighten;
terrify; daunt; cow.</syn>

<ex>intimidation</ex></as>.</def>

<q>The king carried his measures in Parliament by

<hw>In"to</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>prep.</pos> <ety>[<ets>In</ets>
+ <ets>to</ets>.]</ety> <def>To the inside of; within. It is used
in a variety of applications.</def>

<sn>1.</sn> <def>Expressing entrance, or a passing from the
outside of a thing to its interior parts; -- following verbs
expressing motion; <as>as, come <ex>into</ex> the house; go
<ex>into</ex> the church; one stream falls or runs <ex>into</ex>
another; water enters <ex>into</ex> the fine vessels of
plants.</as></def>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>Expressing penetration beyond the outside or
surface, or access to the inside, or contents; <as>as, to look
<ex>into</ex> a letter or book; to look <ex>into</ex> an
apartment.</as></def>

<sn>3.</sn> <def>Indicating insertion; <as>as, to infuse more
spirit or animation <ex>into</ex> a composition</as>.</def>

<sn>4.</sn> <def>Denoting inclusion; <as>as, put these ideas
<ex>into</ex> other words</as>.</def>

<sn>5.</sn> <def>Indicating the passing of a thing from one form,
condition, or state to another; <as>as, compound substances may
be resolved <ex>into</ex> others which are more simple; ice is
convertible <ex>into</ex> water, and water <ex>into</ex> vapor;
men are more easily drawn than forced <ex>into</ex> compliance;
we may reduce many distinct substances <ex>into</ex> one mass;
men are led by evidence <ex>into</ex> belief of truth, and are
often enticed <ex>into</ex> the commission of
crimes'<ex>into</ex>; she burst <ex>into</ex> tears; children are
sometimes frightened <ex>into</ex> fits; all persons are liable
to be seduced <ex>into</ex> error and folly.</as></def>

<note>Compare <er>In</er>.</note>

<hw>In*tol`er*a*bil"i*ty</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos>
<def>The quality of being intolerable; intolerableness.</def>
<mark>[R.]</mark>

<hw>In*tol"er*a*ble</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>a.</pos> <ety>[F.
<ets>intol\'82rable</ets>, L. <ets>intolerabilis</ets>. See
<er>In-</er> not, and <er>Tolerable</er>.]</ety>

<sn>1.</sn> <def>Not tolerable; not capable of being borne or
endured; not proper or right to be allowed; insufferable;
insupportable; unbearable; <as>as, <ex>intolerable</ex> pain;
<ex>intolerable</ex> heat or cold; an <ex>intolerable</ex>
burden.</as></def>

<-- p. 782 -->

<q>His insolence is more <qex>intolerable</qex>
Than all the princes in the land beside.</q>
<qau>Shak.</qau>

<sn>4.</sn> <def>Enormous.</def>

<q>This <qex>intolerable</qex> deal of sack.</q>
<qau>Shak.</qau>

-- <wordforms><wf>In*tol"er*a*ble*ness</wf>, <pos>n.</pos> --
<wf>In*tol"er*a*bly</wf>, <pos>adv.</pos></wordforms>

<hw>In*tol"er*ance</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[L.
<ets>intolerantia</ets> impatience, unendurableness: cf. F.
<ets>intol\'82rance</ets>.]</ety>

<sn>1.</sn> <def>Want of capacity to endure; <as>as,
<ex>intolerance</ex> of light</as>.</def>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>The quality of being intolerant; refusal to
allow to others the enjoyment of their opinions, chosen modes of
worship, and the like; want of patience and forbearance;
illiberality; bigotry; <as>as, <ex>intolerance</ex> shown toward
a religious sect</as>.</def>

<q>These few restrictions, I hope, are no great stretches of
<qex>intolerance</qex>, no very violent exertions of
despotism.</q>
<qau>Burke.</qau>

<hw>In*tol"er*an*cy</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos>

<au>Bailey.</au>

<hw>In*tol"er*ant</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>a.</pos> <ety>[L.
<ets>intolerans</ets>, <ets>-antis</ets>: cf. F.
<ets>intol\'82rant</ets>. See <er>In-</er> not, and
<er>Tolerant</er>.]</ety>

<sn>1.</sn> <def>Not enduring; not able to endure.</def>

<q>The powers of human bodies being limited and
<qex>intolerant</qex> of excesses.</q>
<qau>Arbuthnot.</qau>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>Not tolerating difference of opinion or
sentiment, especially in religious matters; refusing to allow
others the enjoyment of their opinions, rights, or worship;
unjustly impatient of the opinion of those disagree with us; not
tolerant; unforbearing; bigoted.</def>

<q>Religion, harsh, <qex>intolerant</qex>, austere,
Parent of manners like herself severe.</q>
<qau>Cowper.</qau>

<hw>In"to*nate</hw>, <pos>v. i.</pos> <wordforms>[<pos>imp. & p.

<sn>1.</sn> <fld>(Mus.)</fld> <def>To sound the tones of the

or sonorous manner; to chant; <as>as, to <ex>intonate</ex> the

<er>Intonate</er>.]</ety> <def>A thundering; thunder.</def>
<mark>[Obs.]</mark>

<au>Bailey.</au>

<hw>In`to*na"tion</hw>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[Cf. F.
<ets>intonation</ets>. See <er>Intone</er>.]</ety>
<fld>(Mus.)</fld> <sd>(a)</sd> <def>The act of sounding the tones
of the musical scale.</def> <sd>(b)</sd> <def>Singing or playing
in good tune or otherwise; <as>as, her <ex>intonation</ex> was
false</as>.</def> <sd>(c)</sd> <def>Reciting in a musical
prolonged tone; intonating, or singing of the opening phrase of a
plain-chant, psalm, or canticle by a single voice, as of a
priest. See <er>Intone</er>, <pos>v. t.</pos></def>
<-- 2. the manner of speaking, esp. the rise and fall of the
pitch of the voice while speaking. -->

<hw>In*tone"</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>v. t.</pos>
<wordforms>[<pos>imp. & p. p.</pos> <er>Intoned</er>
<pr>(?)</pr>; <pos>p. pr. & vb. n.</pos>
<er>Intoning</er>.]</wordforms> <ety>[LL. <ets>intonare</ets>,
<ets>intonatum</ets>; pref. <ets>in-</ets> in + L.
<ets>tonus</ets> tone. See <er>Tone</er> and cf. <er>Entune</er>,
<er>Intonate</er>.]</ety> <def>To utter with a musical or
prolonged note or tone; to chant; <as>as, to <ex>intone</ex> the
church service</as>.</def>

<hw>In*tone"</hw>, <pos>v. i.</pos> <def>To utter a prolonged
tone or a deep, protracted sound; to speak or recite in a
measured, sonorous manner; to intonate.</def>

<au>Pope.</au>

<hw>In*tor"sion</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[L.
<ets>intortio</ets> a curling, crisping: cf. F.
<ets>intorsion</ets>. See <er>Intort</er>, and cf.
<er>Intortion</er>.]</ety>

<sn>1.</sn> <def>A winding, bending, or twisting.</def>

<sn>2.</sn> <fld>(Bot.)</fld> <def>The bending or twining of any
part of a plant toward one side or the other, or in any direction
from the vertical.</def>

<hw>In*tort"</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>v. t.</pos>
<wordforms>[<pos>imp. & p. p.</pos> <er>Intorted</er>; <pos>p.

<hw>In*tox"i*cant</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <def>That
which intoxicates; an intoxicating agent; <as>as, alcohol, opium,
and laughing gas are <ex>intoxicants</ex></as>.</def>

<hw>In*tox"i*cate</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>a.</pos> <ety>[LL.
<ets>intoxicatus</ets>, p. p. of <ets>intoxicare</ets> to drug or
poison; pref. <ets>in-</ets> in + L. <ets>toxicum</ets> a poison
in which arrows were dipped, Gr. <?/, fr. <?/ pertaining to a
bow. See <er>Toxic</er>.]</ety>

<sn>1.</sn> <def>Intoxicated.</def>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>Overexcited, as with joy or grief.</def>

<q>Alas, good mother, be not <qex>intoxicate</qex> for me;
I am well enough.</q>
<qau>Chapman.</qau>

<hw>In*tox"i*cate</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>v. t.</pos>
<wordforms>[<pos>imp. & p. p.</pos> <er>Intoxicated</er>
<pr>(?)</pr>; <pos>p. pr. & vb. n.</pos>
<er>Intoxicating</er>.]</wordforms>

<sn>1.</sn> <def>To poison; to drug.</def>

<au>South.</au>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>To make drunk; to inebriate; to excite or to
stupefy by strong drink or by a narcotic substance.</def>

<q>With new wine <qex>inoxicated</qex> both.</q>
<qau>Milton.</qau>

<sn>3.</sn> <def>To excite to a transport of enthusiasm, frenzy,
or madness; to elate unduly or excessively.</def>

<q><qex>Intoxicated</qex> with the sound of those very bells.</q>
<qau>G. Eliot.</qau>

<q>They are not <qex>intoxicated</qex> by military success.</q>
<qau>Jowett (Thuc. ).</qau>

<hw>In*tox"i*ca`ted*ness</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos>
<def>The state of being intoxicated; intoxication;
drunkenness.</def> <mark>[R.]</mark>

<hw>In*tox"i*ca`ting</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>a.</pos>
<def>Producing intoxication; <?/<?/tted to intoxicate; <as>as,
<ex>intoxicating</ex> liquors</as>.</def>

<hw>In*tox`i*ca"tion</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <sn>1.</sn>
<fld>(Med.)</fld> <def>A poisoning, as by a spirituous or a
narcotic substance.</def>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>The state of being intoxicated or drunk;
inebriation; ebriety; drunkenness; the act of intoxicating or
making drunk.</def>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>A high excitement of mind; an elation which
rises to enthusiasm, frenzy, or madness.</def>

<q>That secret <qex>intoxication</qex> of pleasure.</q>
<qau>Spectator.</qsyn

<syn>Syn. -- Drunkenness; inebriation; inebriety; ebriety;
infatuation; delirium. See <er>Drunkenness</er>.</def>

<hw>\'d8In`trans"i*gen*tes</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n. pl.</pos>

<hw>In*tran"si*tive</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>a.</pos> <ety>[L.
<ets>intransitivus</ets>: cf. F. <ets>intransitif</ets>. See
<er>In-</er> not, and <er>Transitive</er>.]</ety>

<sn>1.</sn> <def>Not passing farther; kept; detained.</def>
<mark>[R.]</mark>

<q>And then it is for the image's sake and so far is
<qex>intransitive</qex>; but whatever is paid more to the image
is transitive and passes further.</q>
<qau>Jer. Taylor.</qau>

<sn>2.</sn> <fld>(Gram.)</fld> <def>Not transitive; not passing
over t<?/ an object; expressing an action or state that is
limited to the agent or subject, or, in other words, an action
which does not require an object to complete the sense; <as>as,
an <ex>intransitive</ex> verb, <ex>e</ex></as>. <xex>g</xex>.,
the bird <xex>flies</xex>; the dog <xex>runs</xex>.</def>

<note><hand/ <xex>Intransitive</xex> verbs have no passive form.
Some verbs which appear at first sight to be
<xex>intransitive</xex> are in reality, or were originally,
<xex>transitive</xex> verbs with a reflexive or other object
omitted; as, he <xex>keeps</xex> (<it>i. e.</it>, himself) aloof
from danger. <xex>Intransitive</xex> verbs may take a noun of
kindred signification for a cognate object; as, he
<xex>died</xex> the <xex>death</xex> of a hero; he
<xex>dreamed</xex> a <xex>dream</xex>. Some
<xex>intransitive</xex> verbs, by the addition of a preposition,
become <xex>transitive</xex>, and so admit of a passive voice;
as, the man <xex>laughed at</xex>; he <xex>was laughed at</xex>
by the man.</note>

<hw>In*tran"si*tive*ly</hw>, <pos>adv.</pos> <fld>(Gram.)</fld>
<def>Without an object following; in the manner of an
intransitive verb.</def>

<hw>\'d8In` tran"si*tu</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>. <ety>[L.]</ety>
<fld>(Law)</fld> <def>In transit; during passage; <as>as, goods
<ex>in transitu</ex></as>.</def>

<hw>In*trench"</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>v. t.</pos>
<wordforms>[<pos>imp. & p. p.</pos> <er>Intrenched</er>
<pr>(?)</pr>; <pos>p. pr. & vb. n.</pos>
<er>Intrenching</er>.]</wordforms>

<sn>1.</sn> <def>To cut in; to furrow; to make trenches in or
upon.</def>

<q>It was this very sword <qex>intrenched</qex> it.</q>
<qau>Shak.</qau>

<q>His face
Deep scars of thunder had <qex>intrenched</qex>.</q>
<qau>Milton.</qau>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>To surround with a trench or with intrenchments,
as in fortification; to fortify with a ditch and parapet; <as>as,
the army <ex>intrenched</ex> their camp, or <ex>intrenched</ex>
itself</as>.</def> \'bdIn the suburbs close
<xex>intrenched</xex>.\'b8

<au>Shak.</au>

<hw>In*trench"</hw>, <pos>v. i.</pos> <def>To invade; to
encroach; to infringe or trespass; to enter on, and take
possession of, that which belongs to another; -- usually followed
by <xex>on</xex> or <xex>upon</xex>; <as>as, the king was charged
with <ex>intrenching</ex> on the rights of the nobles, and the
nobles were accused of <ex>intrenching</ex> on the prerogative of
the crown</as>.</def>

<q>We are not to <qex>intrench</qex> upon truth in any
conversation, but least of all with children.</q>
<qau>Locke.</qau>

<hw>In*trench"ant</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>a.</pos> <ety>[Pref.
<ets>in-</ets> not + <ets>trenchant</ets>.]</ety> <def>Not to be
gashed or marked with furrows.</def> <mark>[Obs.]</mark>

<q>As easy mayest thou the <qex>intrenchant</qex> air
With thy keen sword impress, as make me bleed.</q>
<qau>Shak.</qau>

<hw>In*trench"ment</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[From
<er>Intrench</er>.]</ety>

<sn>1.</sn> <def>The act of intrenching or the state of being
intrenched.</def>

<sn>2.</sn> <fld>(Mil.)</fld> <def>Any defensive work consisting
of at least a trench or ditch and a parapet made from the earth
thrown up in making such a ditch.</def>

<q>On our side, we have thrown up <qex>intrenchments</qex> on
Winter and Prospect Hills.</q>
<qau>Washington.</qau>

<sn>3.</sn> <def>Any defense or protection.</def>

<sn>4.</sn> <def>An encroachment or infringement.</def>

<q>The slight <qex>intrenchment</qex> upon individual
freedom.</q>
<qau>Southey.</qau>

<hw>In*trep"id</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>a.</pos> <ety>[L.
<ets>intrepidus</ets>: cf. F. <ets>intr\'82pide</ets>. See
<er>In-</er> not, and <er>Trepidation</er>.]</ety> <def>Not
trembling or shaking with fear; fearless; bold; brave; undaunted;
courageous; <as>as, an <ex>intrepid</ex> soldier;
<ex>intrepid</ex> spirit.</as></def>

<syn>Syn. -- Fearless; dauntless; resolute; brave; courageous;
daring; valiant; heroic; doughty.</syn>

<hw>In`tre*pid"i*ty</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[Cf. F.
<ets>intr\'82pidit\'82</ets>.]</ety> <def>The quality or state of
being intrepid; fearless bravery; courage; resoluteness;
valor.</def>

<q>Sir Roger had acquitted himself of two or three sentences with
a look of much business and great <qex>intrepidity</qex>.</q>
<qau>Addison.</qau>

<syn>Syn. -- Courage; heroism; bravery; fortitude; gallantry;
valor. See <er>Courage</er>, <er>Heroism</er>.</syn>

<hw>In"tri*ca*ble</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>a.</pos> <ety>[See
<er>Intricate</er>.]</ety> <def>Entangling.</def>
<mark>[Obs.]</mark>

<au>Shelton.</au>

<hw>In"tri*ca*cy</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos>; <plu>pl.
<plw>Intricacies</plw> <pr>(#)</pr></plu>. <ety>[From
<er>Intricate</er>.]</ety> <def>The state or quality of being
intricate or entangled; perplexity; involution; complication;
complexity; that which is intricate or involved; <as>as, the
<ex>intricacy</ex> of a knot; the <ex>intricacy</ex> of accounts;
the <ex>intricacy</ex> of a cause in controversy; the
<ex>intricacy</ex> of a plot.</as></def>

<q>Freed from <qex>intricacies</qex>, taught to live
The easiest way.</q>
<qau>Milton.</qau>

<hw>In"tri*cate</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>a.</pos> <ety>[L.
<ets>intricatus</ets>, p. p. of <ets>intricare</ets> to entangle,
perplex. Cf. <er>Intrigue</er>, <er>Extricate</er>.]</ety>
<def>Entangled; involved; perplexed; complicated; difficult to
understand, follow, arrange, or adjust; <as>as,
<ex>intricate</ex> machinery, labyrinths, accounts, plots,
etc.</as></def>

<q>His style was fit to convey the most <qex>intricate</qex>
business to the understanding with the utmost clearness.</q>
<qau>Addison.</qau>

<q>The nature of man is <qex>intricate</qex>.</q>
<qau>Burke.</qau>

<syn>Syn. -- <er>Intricate</er>, <er>Complex</er>,
<er>Complicated</er>.</syn> <usage> A thing is <xex>complex</xex>
when it is made up of parts; it is <xex>complicated</xex> when
those parts are so many, or so arranged, as to make it difficult
to grasp them; it is <xex>intricate</xex> when it has numerous
windings and confused involutions which it is hard to follow out.
What is <xex>complex</xex> must be resolved into its parts; what
is <xex>complicated</xex> must be drawn out and developed; what
is <xex>intricate</xex> must be unraveled.</usage>

<hw>In"tri*cate</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>v. t.</pos> <def>To
entangle; to involve; to make perplexing.</def>
<mark>[Obs.]</mark>

<q>It makes men troublesome, and <qex>intricates</qex> all wise
discourses.</q>
<qau>Jer. Taylor.</qau>

<hw>In"tri*cate*ly</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>adv.</pos> <def>In an
intricate manner.</def>

<hw>In"tri*cate*ness</hw>, <pos>n.</pos> <def>The state or
quality of being intricate; intricacy.</def>

<hw>In`tri*ca"tion</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos>
<def>Entanglement.</def> <mark>[Obs.]</mark>

<hw>\'d8In`tri`gante"</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos>
<ety>[F.]</ety> <def>A female intriguer.</def>

<hw>In*trigue"</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>v. i.</pos>
<wordforms>[<pos>imp. & p. p.</pos> <er>Intrigued</er>
<pr>(?)</pr>; <pos>p. pr. & vb. n.</pos>
<er>Intriguing</er>.]</wordforms> <ety>[F. <ets>intriguer</ets>,
OF. <ets>intriquer</ets>, <ets>entriquer</ets>; cf. It.
<ets>intrigare</ets>. See <er>Intricate</er>,
<er>Extricate</er>.]</ety>

<sn>1.</sn> <def>To form a plot or scheme; to contrive to
accomplish a purpose by secret artifice.</def>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>To carry on a secret and illicit love or
amour.</def>

<hw>In*trigue"</hw>, <pos>v. t.</pos> <def>To fill with artifice
and duplicity; to complicate; to embarrass.</def>
<mark>[Obs.]</mark>

<q>How doth it [sin] perplex and <qex>intrique</qex> the whole
course of your lives!</q>
<qau>Dr. J. Scott.</qau>

<hw>In*trigue"</hw>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[Cf. F.
<ets>intrique</ets>. See <er>Intrigue</er>, <pos>v.
i.</pos>]</ety>

<sn>1.</sn> <def>Intricacy; complication.</def>
<mark>[Obs.]</mark>

<au>Sir M. Hale.</au>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>A complicated plot or scheme intended to effect
some purpose by secret artifice; conspiracy; stratagem.</def>

<q>Busy meddlers with <qex>intrigues</qex> of state.</q>
<qau>Pomfret.</qau>

<sn>3.</sn> <def>The plot or romance; a complicated scheme of
designs, actions, and events.</def>

<au>Pope.</au>

<sn>4.</sn> <def>A secret and illicit love affair between two
persons of different sexes; an amour; a liaison.</def>

<q>The hero of a comedy is represented victorious in all his
<qex>intrigues</qex>.</q>
<qau>Swift.</qau>

<syn>Syn. -- Plot; scheme; conspiracy; machination.</syn>

<hw>In*trigu"er</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <def>One who
intrigues.</def>

<hw>In*trigu"er*y</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <def>Arts or
practice of intrigue.</def>

<hw>In*trigu"ing*ly</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>adv.</pos> <def>By
means of, or in the manner of, intrigue.</def>

<hw>In*trinse"</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>a.</pos> <ety>[See
<er>Intrinsic</er>, and <er>Intense</er>.]</ety> <def>Tightly
drawn; or (perhaps) intricate.</def> <mark>[Very rare]</mark>

<q>Like rats, oft bite the holy cords atwain,
Which are too <qex>intrinse</qex> to unloose.</q>
<qau>Shak.</qau>

<hw>In*trin"sic</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>a.</pos> <ety>[L.
<ets>intrinsecus</ets> inward, on the inside; <ets>intra</ets>
within + <ets>secus</ets> otherwise, beside; akin to E.
<ets>second</ets>: cf. F. <ets>intrins\'8aque</ets>. See
<er>Inter-</er>, <er>Second</er>, and cf.
<er>Extrinsic</er>.]</ety>

<sn>1.</sn> <def>Inward; internal; hence, true; genuine; real;
essential; inherent; not merely apparent or accidental; --
opposed to <xex>extrinsic</xex>; <as>as, the <ex>intrinsic</ex>
value of gold or silver; the <ex>intrinsic</ex> merit of an
action; the <ex>intrinsic</ex> worth or goodness of a
person.</as></def>

<q>He was better qualified than they to estimate justly the
<qex>intrinsic</qex> value of Grecian philosophy and
refinement.</q>
<qau>I. Taylor.</qau>

<sn>2.</sn> <fld>(Anat.)</fld> <def>Included wholly within an
organ or limb, as certain groups of muscles; -- opposed to
<xex>extrinsic</xex>.</def>

<cs><col>Intrinsic energy of a body</col> <fld>(Physics)</fld>,
<cd>the work it can do in virtue of its actual condition, without
any supply of energy from without.</cd> -- <col>Intrinsic
equation of a curve</col> <fld>(Geom.)</fld>, <cd>the equation
which expresses the relation which the length of a curve,
measured from a given point of it, to a movable point, has to the
angle which the tangent to the curve at the movable point makes
with a fixed line.</cd> -- <col>Intrinsic value</col>. <cd>See
the Note under <er>Value</er>, <pos>n.</pos></cd></syn

<syn>Syn. -- Inherent; innate; natural; real; genuine.</def>

<hw>In*trin"sic</hw>, <pos>n.</pos> <def>A genuine quality.</def>
<mark>[Obs.]</mark>

<au>Warburton.</au>

<hw>In*trin"sic*al</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>a.</pos>
<altsp>[Formerly written <asp>intrinsecal</asp>.]</altsp>

<sn>1.</sn> <def>Intrinsic.</def>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>Intimate; closely familiar.</def>
<mark>[Obs.]</mark>

<au>Sir H. Wotton.</au>

<hw>In*trin`si*cal"i*ty</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <def>The
quality of <?/eing intrinsic; essentialness; genuineness;
reality.</def>

<hw>In*trin"sic*al*ly</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>adv.</pos>
<def>Internally; <?/n its nature; essentially; really;
truly.</def>

<q>A lie is a thing absolutely and <qex>intrinsically</qex>
evil.</q>
<qau>South.</qau>

<hw>In*trin"sic*al*ness</hw>, <pos>n.</pos> <def>The quality of
being intrinsical; intrinsicality.</def>

<def>Intricate.</def> <mark>[Obs.]</mark>

<au>Shak.</au>

<hw>In"tro-</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>. <ety>[L. <ets>intro</ets>, adv.,
inwardly, within. See <er>Inter-</er>.]</ety> <def>A prefix
signifying <xex>within</xex>, <xex>into</xex>, <xex>in</xex>,
<xex>inward</xex>; <as>as, <ex>intro</ex>duce,
<ex>intro</ex>reception, <ex>intro</ex>thoracic</as>.</def>

<hw>In`tro*ces"sion</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[L.
<ets>introcedere</ets>, <ets>introcessum</ets>, to go in;
<ets>intro</ets> within + <ets>cedere</ets> to go.]</ety>
<fld>(Med.)</fld> <def>A depression, or inward sinking of
parts.</def>

<hw>In`tro*duce"</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>v. t.</pos>
<wordforms>[<pos>imp. & p. p.</pos> <er>Introduced</er>
<pr>(?)</pr>; <pos>p. pr. & vb. n.</pos> <er>Introducing</er>
<pr>(?)</pr>.]</wordforms> <ety>[L. <ets>introducere</ets>,
<ets>introductum</ets>; <ets>intro</ets> within +
<ets>ducere</ets> to lead. See <er>Intro-</er>, and
<er>Duke</er>.]</ety>

<sn>1.</sn> <def>To lead or bring in; to conduct or usher in;
<as>as, to <ex>introduce</ex> a person into a
drawing-room</as>.</def>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>To put (something into a place); to insert;
<as>as, to <ex>introduce</ex> the finger, or a probe</as>.</def>

<sn>3.</sn> <def>To lead to and make known by formal announcement
or recommendation; hence, to cause to be acquainted; <as>as, to
<ex>introduce</ex> strangers; to <ex>introduce</ex> one person to
another.</as></def>

<sn>4.</sn> <def>To bring into notice, practice, cultivation, or
use; <as>as, to <ex>introduce</ex> a new fashion, method, or
plant</as>.</def>

<sn>5.</sn> <def>To produce; to cause to exist; to induce.</def>
<mark>[Obs.]</mark>

<q>Whosoever <qex>introduces</qex> habits in children, deserves
the care and attention of their governors.</q>
<qau>Locke.</qau>

<sn>6.</sn> <def>To open to notice; to begin; to present; <as>as,
he <ex>introduced</ex> the subject with a long
preface</as>.</def>

<syn>Syn. -- To bring in; usher in; insert; begin; preface.</syn>

<hw>In`tro*duce"ment</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos>
<def>Introduction.</def> <mark>[Obs.]</mark>

<hw>In`tro*du"cer</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <def>One who,
or that which, introduces.</def>

<hw>In`tro*duct"</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>v. t.</pos> <def>To
introduce.</def> <mark>[Obs.]</mark>

<hw>In`tro*duc"tion</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[L.
<ets>introductio</ets>: cf. F. <ets>introduction</ets>. See
<er>Introduce</er>.]</ety>

<sn>1.</sn> <def>The act of introducing, or bringing to
notice.</def>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>The act of formally making persons known to each
other; a presentation or making known of one person to another by
name; <as>as, the <ex>introduction</ex> of one stranger to
another</as>.</def>

<sn>3.</sn> <def>That part of a book or discourse which
introduces or leads the way to the main subject, or part;
preliminary; matter; preface; proem; exordium.</def>

<sn>4.</sn> <def>A formal and elaborate preliminary treatise;
specifically, a treatise introductory to other treatises, or to a
course of study; a guide; <as>as, an <ex>introduction</ex> to
English literature</as>.</def>

<hw>In`tro*duc"tive</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>a.</pos> <ety>[Cf. F.

<hw>In`tro*mit"</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>v. t.</pos>

<hw>In*trude"</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>v. i.</pos> <ety>[L.
<ets>intrudere</ets>, <ets>intrusum</ets>; pref. <ets>in-</ets>
in + <ets>trudere</ets> to thrust, akin to E. <ets>threat</ets>.
See <er>Threat</er>.]</ety> <def>To thrust one's self in; to come
or go in without invitation, permission, or welcome; to encroach;
to trespass; <as>as, to <ex>intrude</ex> on families at
unseasonable hours; to <ex>intrude</ex> on the lands of
another.</as></def>

<q>Thy wit wants edge
And manners, to <qex>intrude</qex> where I am graced.</q>
<qau>Shak.</qau>

<q>Some thoughts rise and <qex>intrude</qex> upon us, while we
shun them; others fly from us, when we would hold them.</q>
<qau>I. Watts.</qau>

<hw>In*trude"</hw>, <pos>v. t.</pos> <wordforms>[<pos>imp. & p.
p.</pos> <er>Intruded</er>; <pos>p. pr. & vb. n.</pos>
<er>Intruding</er>.]</wordforms>

<sn>1.</sn> <def>To thrust or force (something) in or upon;
especially, to force (one's self) in without leave or welcome;
<as>as, to <ex>intrude</ex> one's presence into a conference; to
<ex>intrude</ex> one's opinions upon another.</as></def>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>To enter by force; to invade.</def>
<mark>[Obs.]</mark>

<q>Why should the worm <qex>intrude</qex> the maiden bud?</q>
<qau>Shak.</qau>

<sn>3.</sn> <fld>(Geol.)</fld> <def>The cause to enter or force a
way, as into the crevices of rocks.</def>

<syn>Syn. -- To obtrude; encroach; infringe; intrench; trespass.
See <er>Obtrude</er>.</syn>

<hw>In*trud"ed</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>p. a.</pos>
<fld>(Geol.)</fld> <def>Same as <er>Intrusive</er>.</def>

<hw>In*trud"er</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <def>One who

without leave or welcome; a trespasser.</def>

<q>They were all strangers and <qex>intruders</qex>.</q>
<qau>Locke.</qau>
