<hw>In*tru"sion</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[Cf. F.
<ets>intrusion</ets>. See <er>Intrude</er>.]</ety>

<sn>1.</sn> <def>The act of intruding, or of forcing in;
especially, the forcing (one's self) into a place without right
or welcome; encroachment.</def>

<q>Why this <qex>intrusion</qex>?
Were not my orders that I should be private?</q>
<qau>Addison.</qau>

<sn>2.</sn> <fld>(Geol.)</fld> <def>The penetrating of one rock,
while in a plastic or metal state, into the cavities of
another.</def>

<sn>3.</sn> <fld>(Law)</fld> <def>The entry of a stranger, after
a particular estate or freehold is determined, before the person
who holds in remainder or reversion has taken possession.</def>

<sn>4.</sn> <fld>(Scotch Ch.)</fld> <def>The settlement of a
minister over 3 congregation without their consent.</def>

<hw>In*tru"sion*al</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>a.</pos> <def>Of or
pertaining to intrusion.</def>

<hw>In*tru"sion*ist</hw>, <pos>n.</pos> <def>One who intrudes;
especially, one who favors the appointment of a clergyman to a
parish, by a patron, against the wishes of the
parishioners.</def>

<hw>In*tru"sive</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>a.</pos> <def>Apt to
intrude; characterized by intrusion; entering without right or
welcome.</def>

<cs><col>Intrusive rocks</col> <fld>(Geol.)</fld>, <cd>rocks
which have been forced, while in a plastic or melted state, into
the cavities or between the cracks or layers of other rocks. The
term is sometimes used as equivalent to <xex>plutonic rocks<xex>.
It is then contrasted with <xex>effusive<xex> or <xex>volcanic
rocks<xex>.</cd></cs><-- e.g. dikes, igneous rock injected into a
fissure -->

-- <wordforms><wf>In*tru"sive*ly</wf>, <pos>adv.</pos> --
<wf>In*tru"sive*ness</wf>, <pos>n.</pos></wordforms>

<hw>In*trust"</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>v. t.</pos>
<wordforms>[<pos>imp. & p. p.</pos> <er>Intrusted</er>, <pos>p.
pr. & vb. n.</pos> <er>Intrusting</er>.]</wordforms> <def>To
deliver (something) to another in trust; to deliver to (another)
something in trust; to commit or surrender (something) to another
with a certain confidence regarding his care, use, or disposal of
it; <as>as, to <ex>intrust</ex> a servant with one's money or
<ex>intrust</ex> money or goods to a servant</as>.</def>

<syn>Syn. -- To commit; consign; confide. See
<er>Commit</er>.</syn>

<hw>In`tu*ba"tion</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[Pref.
<ets>in-</ets> in + <ets>tube</ets>.]</ety> <fld>(Med.)</fld>
<def>The introduction of a tube into an organ to keep it open, as
into the larynx in croup.</def>

<hw>In`tu*i"tion</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[L.
<ets>intuitus</ets>, p. p. of <ets>intueri</ets> to look on;
<ets>in-</ets> in, on + <ets>tueri</ets>: cf. F.
<ets>intuition</ets>. See <er>Tuition</er>.]</ety>

<sn>1.</sn> <def>A looking after; a regard to.</def>
<mark>[Obs.]</mark>

<q>What, no reflection on a reward! He might have an
<qex>intuition</qex> at it, as the encouragement, though not the
cause, of his pains.</q>
<qau>Fuller.</qau>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>Direct apprehension or cognition; immediate
knowledge, as in perception or consciousness; -- distinguished
from \'bdmediate\'b8 knowledge, as in reasoning; <as>as, the mind
knows by <ex>intuition</ex> that black is not white, that a
circle is not a square, that three are more than two, etc.</as>;
quick or ready insight or apprehension.</def>

<q>Sagacity and a nameless something more, -- let us call it
<qex>intuition</qex>.</q>
<qau>Hawthorne.</qau>

<sn>3.</sn> <def>Any object or truth discerned by direct
cognition; especially, a first or primary truth.</def>

<hw>In`tu*i"tion*al</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>a.</pos>
<def>Pertaining to, or derived from, intuition; characterized by
intuition; perceived by intuition; intuitive.</def>

<hw>In`tu*i"tion*al*ism</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos>
<fld>(Metaph.)</fld> <def>The doctrine that the perception or
recognition of primary truth is intuitive, or direct and
immediate; -- opposed to <xex>sensationalism</xex>, and
<xex>experientialism</xex>.</def>

<hw>In`tu*i"tion*al*ist</hw>, <pos>n.</pos> <def>One who holds
the doctrine of intuitionalism.</def>

<hw>In`tu*i"tion*ism</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <def>Same
as <er>Intuitionalism</er>.</def>

<hw>In`tu*i"tion*ist</hw>, <pos>n.</pos> <def>Same as
<er>Intuitionalist</er>.</def>

<au>Bain.</au>

<hw>In*tu"i*tive</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>a.</pos> <ety>[Cf. F.
<ets>intuitif</ets>.]</ety>

<sn>1.</sn> <def>Seeing clearly; <as>as, an <ex>intuitive</ex>
view; <ex>intuitive</ex> vision.</as></def>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>Knowing, or perceiving, by intuition; capable of
knowing without deduction or reasoning.</def>

<q>Whence the soul
Reason receives, and reason is her being,
Discursive, or <qex>intuitive</qex>.</q>
<qau>Milton.</qau>

<sn>3.</sn> <def>Received. reached, obtained, or perceived, by
intuition; <as>as, <ex>intuitive</ex> judgment or knowledge</as>;
-- opposed to <contr>deductive</contr>.</def>

<au>Locke.</au>

<hw>In*tu"i*tive*ly</hw>, <pos>adv.</pos> <def>In an intuitive
manner.</def>

<hw>In*tu"i*tiv*ism</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <def>The
doctrine that the ideas of right and wrong are intuitive.</def>

<au>J. Grote.</au>

<hw>In`tu*mesce"</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>v. i.</pos>
<wordforms>[<pos>imp. & p. p.</pos> <er>Intumesced</er>
<pr>(?)</pr>; <pos>p. pr. & vb. n.</pos> <er>Intumescing</er>
<pr>(?)</pr>.]</wordforms> <ety>[L. <ets>intumescere</ets>; pref.
<ets>in-</ets> in + <ets>tumescere</ets> to swell up, incho. fr.
<ets>tumere</ets> to swell. See <er>Tumid</er>.]</ety> <def>To
enlarge or expand with heat; to swell; specifically, to swell up
or bubble up under the action of heat, as before the
blowpipe.</def>

<q>In a higher heat, it <qex>intumesces</qex>, and melts into a
yellowish black mass.</q>
<qau>Kirwan.</qau>

<hw>In`tu*mes"cence</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[Cf. F.
<ets>intumescence</ets>.]</ety>

<sn>1.</sn> <def>The act or process of swelling or enlarging;
also, the state of being swollen; expansion; tumidity;
especially, the swelling up of bodies under the action of
heat.</def>

<q>The <qex>intumescence</qex> of nations.</q>
<qau>Johnson.</qau>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>Anything swollen or enlarged, as a tumor.</def>

<hw>In`tu*mes"cent</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>a.</pos> <ety>[L.
<ets>intumescens</ets>, p. pr.]</ety> <def>Swelling up;
expanding.</def>

<hw>In`tus*sus*cep"ted</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>a.</pos> <ety>[See
<er>Intussusception</er>.]</ety> <def>Received into some other
thing or part, as a sword into a sheath; invaginated.</def>

<hw>In`tus*sus*cep"tion</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[L.
<ets>intus</ets> within + <ets>susception</ets>. Cf.
<er>Introsusception</er>.]</ety>

<sn>1.</sn> <def>The reception of one part within another.</def>

<sn>2.</sn> <fld>(Med.)</fld> <def>The abnormal reception or
slipping of a part of a tube, by inversion and descent, within a
contiguous part of it; specifically, the reception or slipping of
the upper part of the small intestine into the lower;
introsusception; invagination.</def>

<au>Dunglison.</au>

<sn>3.</sn> <fld>(Bot.)</fld> <def>The interposition of new
particles of formative material among those already existing, as
in a cell wall, or in a starch grain.</def>

<sn>4.</sn> <fld>(Physiol.)</fld> <def>The act of taking foreign
matter, as food, into a living body; the process of nutrition, by
which dead matter is absorbed by the living organism, and
ultimately converted into the organized substance of its various
tissues and organs.</def>

<q>Dead bodies increase by apposition; living bodies by
<qex>intrussusception</qex>.</q>
<qau>McKendrick.</qau>

together; to wreathe; <as>as, a wreath of flowers
<ex>intwined</ex></as>.</def> <altsp>[Written also
<asp>entwine</asp>.]</altsp>

<hw>In*twine"</hw>, <pos>v. i.</pos> <def>To be or to become

<hw>In"u*lin</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[From NL.
<ets>Inula</ets> Helenium, the elecampane: cf. F.
<ets>inuline</ets>.]</ety> <fld>(Chem.)</fld> <def>A substance of
very wide occurrence. It is found dissolved in the sap of the
roots and rhizomes of many composite and other plants, as
<spn>Inula</spn>, <spn>Helianthus</spn>, <spn>Campanula</spn>,
etc., and is extracted by solution as a tasteless, white,
semicrystalline substance, resembling starch, with which it is
isomeric. It is intermediate in nature between starch and sugar.
Called also <altname>dahlin</altname>,
<altname>helenin</altname>, <altname>alantin</altname>,
etc.</def><-- also = alant starch.  a polysaccharide found in
Compositae [MI11]-->

<ety>[<ets>Inul</ets>in + -<ets>oid</ets>.]</ety>
<fld>(Chem.)</fld> <def>A substance resembling inulin, found in
the unripe bulbs of the dahila.</def>

<hw>In*un"date</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>v. t.</pos>
<wordforms>[<pos>imp. & p. p.</pos> <er>Inundated</er>
<pr>(?)</pr>; <pos>p. pr. & vb. n.</pos>
<er>Inundating</er>.]</wordforms> <ety>[L. <ets>inundatus</ets>,
p. p. of <ets>inundare</ets> to inundate; pref. <ets>in-</ets> in
+ <ets>undare</ets> to rise in waves, to overflow, fr.
<ets>unda</ets> a wave. See <er>Undulate</er>.]</ety>

<sn>1.</sn> <def>To cover with a flood; to overflow; to deluge;
to flood; <as>as, the river <ex>inundated</ex> the
town</as>.</def>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>To fill with an overflowing abundance or
superfluity; <as>as, the country was <ex>inundated</ex> with
bills of credit</as>.</def>

<syn>Syn. -- To overflow; deluge; flood; overwhelm; submerge;
drown.</syn>

<hw>In`un*da"tion</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[L.

<sn>1.</sn> <def>The act of inundating, or the state of being
inundated; an overflow; a flood; a rising and spreading of water
over grounds.</def>

<q>With <qex>inundation</qex> wide the deluge reigns,
Drowns the deep valleys, and o'erspreads the plains.</q>
<qau>Wilkie.</qau>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>An overspreading of any kind; overflowing or
superfluous abundance; a flood; a great influx; <as>as, an
<ex>inundation</ex> of tourists</as>.</def>

<q>To stop the <qex>inundation</qex> of her tears.</q>
<qau>Shak.</qau>

<hw>In*vade"</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>v. t.</pos>
<wordforms>[<pos>imp. & p. p.</pos> <er>Invaded</er>; <pos>p. pr.
& vb. n.</pos> <er>Invading</er>.]</wordforms> <ety>[L.
<ets>invadere</ets>, <ets>invasum</ets>; pref. <ets>in-</ets> in
+ <ets>vadere</ets> to go, akin to E. <ets>wade</ets>:  cf. OF.
<ets>invader</ets>, F. <ets>envahir</ets>. See
<er>Wade</er>.]</ety>

<sn>1.</sn> <def>To go into or upon; to pass within the confines
of; to enter; -- used of forcible or rude ingress.</def>
<mark>[Obs.]</mark>

<q>Which becomes a body, and doth then <qex>invade</qex>
The state of life, out of the grisly shade.</q>
<qau>Spenser.</qau>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>To enter with hostile intentions; to enter with
a view to conquest or plunder; to make an irruption into; to
attack; <as>as, the Romans <ex>invaded</ex> Great
Britain</as>.</def>

<q>Such an enemy
Is risen to <qex>invade</qex> us.</q>
<qau>Milton.</qau>

<sn>3.</sn> <def>To attack; to infringe; to encroach on; to
violate; <as>as, the king <ex>invaded</ex> the rights of the
people</as>.</def>

<sn>4.</sn> <def>To grow or spread over; to affect injuriously
and progressively; <as>as, gangrene <ex>invades</ex> healthy
tissue</as>.</def>

<syn>Syn. -- To attack; assail; encroach upon. See
<er>Attack</er>.</syn>

<hw>In*vade"</hw>, <pos>v. i.</pos> <def>To make an
invasion.</def>

<au>Brougham.</au>

<hw>In*vad"er</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <def>One who
invades; an assailant; an encroacher; an intruder.</def>

<hw>In*vag"i*nate</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>v. t.</pos> <def>To
insert as in a sheath; to pr<?/<?/<?/ce intussusception in.</def>

<mhw>{ <hw>In*vag"i*nate</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>,
<hw>In*vag"i*na`ted</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, }</mhw> <pos>a.</pos>
<fld>(Biol.)</fld> <sd>(a)</sd> <def>Sheathed.</def> <sd>(b)</sd>
<def>Having one portion of a hollow organ drawn back within
another portion.</def>

<hw>In*vag`i*na"tion</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[L.
pref. <ets>in-</ets> + <ets>vagina</ets> sheath.]</ety>

<sn>1.</sn> <fld>(Biol.)</fld> <def>The condition of an
invaginated organ or part.</def>

<sn>2.</sn> <fld>(Biol.)</fld> <def>One of the methods by which
the various germinal layers of the ovum are differentiated.</def>

<note><hand/ In <xex>embolic invagination</xex>, one half of the
blastosphere is pushed in towards the other half, producing an
embryonic form known as a <xex>gastrula</xex>. -- In
<xex>epibolic invagination</xex>, a phenomenon in the development
of some invertebrate ova, the epiblast appears to grow over or
around the hypoblast.</note>

<hw>In*val"id</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>a.</pos> <ety>[Pref.

<ets>invalide</ets>, L. <ets>invalidus</ets> infirm, weak. Cf.

<hw>In*val"i*date</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>v. t.</pos>

<hw>In*va`ri*a*bil"i*ty</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos>
<ety>[Cf. F. <ets>invariabilit\'82</ets>.]</ety> <def>The quality

<hw>In*va"ri*a*ble</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>a.</pos> <ety>[Pref.

<q>Physical laws which are <qex>invariable</qex>.</q>
<qau>I. Taylor.</qau>

<hw>In*va"ri*a*ble</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos>
<fld>(Math.)</fld> <def>An invariable quantity; a constant.</def>

<hw>In*va"ri*ance</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos>
<fld>(Math.)</fld> <def>The property of remaining invariable
under prescribed or implied conditions.</def>

<au>J. J. Sylvester.</au>

<hw>In*va"ri*ant</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos>
<fld>(Math.)</fld> <def>An invariable quantity; specifically, a
function of the coefficients of one or more forms, which remains
unaltered, when these undergo suitable linear
transformations.</def>

<au>J. J. Sylvester.</au>

<hw>In*va"sion</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[L.
<ets>invasio</ets>: cf. F. <ets>invasion</ets>. See
<er>Invade</er>.]</ety>

<sn>1.</sn> <def>The act of invading; the act of encroaching upon
the rights or possessions of another; encroachment;
trespass.</def>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>A warlike or hostile entrance into the
possessions or domains of another; the incursion of an army for
conquest or plunder.</def>

<sn>3.</sn> <def>The incoming or first attack of anything hurtful
or pernicious; <as>as, the <ex>invasion</ex> of a
disease</as>.</def>

<syn>Syn. -- <er>Invasion</er>, <er>Irruption</er>,
<er>Inroad</er>.</syn> <usage> <xex>Invasion</xex> is the generic
term, denoting a forcible entrance into a foreign country.
<xex>Incursion</xex> signifies a hasty and sudden invasion.
<xex>Irruption</xex> denotes particularly violent invasion.
<xex>Inroad</xex> is entry by some unusual way involving trespass
and injury.</usage>

<hw>In*va"sive</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>a.</pos> <ety>[LL.
<ets>invasivus</ets>: cf. F. <ets>invasif</ets>. See
<er>Invade</er>.]</ety> <def>Tending to invade; characterized by
invasion; aggressive.</def> \'bd<xex>Invasive</xex> war.\'b8

<au>Hoole.</au>

<hw>In*vect"</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>v. i.</pos> <def>To
inveigh.</def> <mark>[Obs.]</mark>

<au>Beau. & Fl.</au>

<hw>In*vec"ted</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>a.</pos> <ety>[L.
<ets>invectus</ets> carried in. See <er>Inveigh</er>.]</ety>
<fld>(Her.)</fld> <def>Having a border or outline composed of
semicircles with the convexity outward; -- the opposite of
<xex>engrailed</xex>.</def>

<hw>In*vec"tion</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[L.
<ets>invectio</ets>. See <er>Inveigh</er>.]</ety> <def>An
inveighing against; invective.</def> <mark>[Obs.]</mark>

<au>Fulke.</au>

<hw>In*vec"tive</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>a.</pos> <ety>[L.
<ets>invectivus</ets>: cf. F. <ets>invectif</ets>. See
<er>Inveigh</er>.]</ety> <def>Characterized by invection;
critical; denunciatory; satirical; abusive; railing.</def>

<hw>In*vec"tive</hw>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[F.
<ets>invective</ets>.]</ety> <def>An expression which inveighs or
rails against a person; a severe or violent censure or reproach;
something uttered or written, intended to cast opprobrium,
censure, or reproach on another; a harsh or reproachful
accusation; -- followed by <xex>against</xex>, having reference
to the person or thing affected; as an <xex>invective</xex>
against tyranny.</def>

<q>The world will be able to judge of his [Junius'] motives for
writing such famous <qex>invectives</qex>.</q>
<qau>Sir W. Draper.</qau>

<syn>Syn. -- Abuse; censure; reproach; satire; sarcasm; railing;
diatribe. See <er>Abuse</er>.</syn>

<hw>In*vec"tive*ly</hw>, <pos>adv.</pos> <def>In an invective
manner.</def>

<au>Shak.</au>

<hw>In*veigh"</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>v. i.</pos>
<wordforms>[<pos>imp. & p. p.</pos> <er>Inveighed</er>
<pr>(?)</pr>; <pos>p. pr. & vb. n.</pos>
<er>Inveighing</er>.]</wordforms> <ety>[L. <ets>invehere</ets>,
<ets>invectum</ets>, to carry or bring into or against, to attack
with words, to inveigh; pref. <ets>in-</ets> in +
<ets>vehere</ets> to carry. See <er>Vehicle</er>, and cf.
<er>Invective</er>.]</ety> <def>To declaim or rail (against some
person or thing); to utter censorious and bitter language; to
attack with harsh criticism or reproach, either spoken or
written; to use invectives; -- with <xex>against</xex>; <as>as,
to <ex>inveigh</ex> against character, conduct, manners, customs,
morals, a law, an abuse</as>.</def>

<q>All men <qex>inveighed</qex> against him; all men, except
court vassals, opposed him.</q>
<qau>Milton.</qau>

<q>The artificial life against which we <qex>inveighed</qex>.</q>
<qau>Hawthorne.</qau>

<hw>In*veigh"er</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <def>One who
inveighs.</def>

<hw>In*vei"gle</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>v. t.</pos>
<wordforms>[<pos>imp. & p. p.</pos> <er>Inveigled</er>
<pr>(?)</pr>; <pos>p. pr. & vb. n.</pos> <er>Inveigling</er>
<pr>(?)</pr>.]</wordforms> <ety>[Prob. fr. F. <ets>aveugler</ets>
to blind, to delude, OF. <ets>aveugler</ets>, <ets>avugler</ets>,
<ets>avegler</ets>, fr. F. <ets>aveugle</ets> blind, OF.
<ets>aveugle</ets>, <ets>avugle</ets>, properly, without eyes,
fr. L. <ets>ab + oculus</ets> eye. The pref. <ets>in-</ets> seems
to have been substituted for <ets>a-</ets> taken as the pref. F.
<ets>\'85</ets>, L. <ets>ad</ets>. See <er>Ocular</er>.]</ety>
<def>To lead astray as if blind; to persuade to something evil by
deceptive arts or flattery; to entice; to insnare; to seduce; to
wheedle.</def>

<q>Yet have they many baits and guileful spells
To <qex>inveigle</qex> and invite the un unwary sense.</q>
<qau>Milton.</qau>

<hw>In*vei"gle*ment</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <def>The act
of inveigling, or the state of being inveigled; that which

<au>W. Browne.</au>

<hw>In*vend`i*bil"i*ty</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <def>The

<hw>In*vent"</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>v. t.</pos>
<wordforms>[<pos>imp. & p. p.</pos> <er>Invented</er>; <pos>p.
pr. & vb. n.</pos> <er>Inventing</er>.]</wordforms> <ety>[L.
<ets>inventus</ets>, p. p. of <ets>invenire</ets> to come upon,
to find, invent; pref. <ets>in-</ets> in + <ets>venire</ets> to
come, akin to E. <ets>come</ets>: cf. F. <ets>inventer</ets>. See
<er>Come</er>.]</ety>

<sn>1.</sn> <def>To come or light upon; to meet; to find.</def>
<mark>[Obs.]</mark>

<q>And vowed never to return again,
Till him alive or dead she did <qex>invent</qex>.</q>
<qau>Spenser.</qau>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>To discover, as by study or inquiry; to find
out; to devise; to contrive or produce for the first time; --
applied commonly to the discovery of some serviceable mode,
instrument, or machine.</def>

<q>Thus first Necessity <qex>invented</qex> stools.</q>
<qau>Cowper.</qau>

<sn>3.</sn> <def>To frame by the imagination; to fabricate
mentally; to forge; -- in a good or a bad sense; <as>as, to
<ex>invent</ex> the machinery of a poem; to <ex>invent</ex> a
falsehood.</as></def>

<q>Whate'er his cruel malice could <qex>invent</qex>.</q>
<qau>Milton.</qau>

<q>He had <qex>invented</qex> some circumstances, and put the
worst possible construction on others.</q>
<qau>Sir W. Scott.</qau>

<syn>Syn. -- To discover; contrive; devise; frame; design;
fabricate; concoct; elaborate. See <er>Discover</er>.</syn>

<hw>In*vent"er</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <def>One who
invents.</def>

<hw>In*vent"ful</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>a.</pos> <def>Full of
invention.</def>

<au>J. Gifford.</au>

<hw>In*vent"i*ble</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>a.</pos> <def>Capable
of being invented.</def>

<hw>In*vent"i*ble*ness</hw>, <pos>n.</pos> <def>Quality of being
inventible.</def>

<hw>In*ven"tion</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[L.
<ets>inventio</ets>: cf. F. <ets>invention</ets>. See
<er>Invent</er>.]</ety>

<sn>1.</sn> <def>The act of finding out or inventing; contrivance
or construction of that which has not before existed; <as>as, the
<ex>invention</ex> of logarithms; the <ex>invention</ex> of the
art of printing.</as></def>

<-- p. 785 -->

<q>As the search of it [truth] is the duty, so the
<qex>invention</qex> will be the happiness of man.</q>
<qau>Tatham.</qau>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>That which is invented; an original contrivance
or construction; a device; <as>as, this fable was the
<ex>invention</ex> of Esop; that falsehood was her own
<ex>invention</ex>.</as></def>

<q>We entered by the drawbridge, which has an
<qex>invention</qex> to let one fall if not premonished.</q>
<qau>Evelyn.</qau>

<sn>3.</sn> <def>Thought; idea.</def>

<au>Shak.</au>

<sn>4.</sn> <def>A fabrication to deceive; a fiction; a forgery;
a falsehood.</def>

<q>Filling their hearers
With strange <qex>invention</qex>.</q>
<qau>Shak.</qau>

<sn>5.</sn> <def>The faculty of inventing; imaginative faculty;
skill or ingenuity in contriving anything new; <as>as, a man of
<ex>invention</ex></as>.</def>

<q>They lay no less than a want of <qex>invention</qex> to his
charge; a capital crime, . . . for a poet is a maker.</q>
<qau>Dryden.</qau>

<sn>6.</sn> <fld>(Fine Arts, Rhet., etc.)</fld> <def>The exercise
of the imagination in selecting and treating a theme, or more
commonly in contriving the arrangement of a piece, or the method
of presenting its parts.</def>

<cs><col>Invention of the cross</col> <fld>(Eccl.)</fld>, <cd>a
festival celebrated May 3d, in honor of the finding of our
Savior's cross by St. Helena.</cd></cs>

<hw>In*ven"tious</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>a.</pos>
<def>Inventive.</def> <mark>[Obs.]</mark>

<hw>In*vent"ive</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>a.</pos> <ety>[Cf. F.
<ets>inventif</ets>.]</ety> <def>Able and apt to invent; quick at
contrivance; ready at expedients; <as>as, an <ex>inventive</ex>
head or genius</as>.</def> <au>Dryden</au>. --
<wordforms><wf>In*vent"ive*ly</wf>, <pos>adv.</pos> --
<wf>In*vent"ive*ness</wf>, <pos>n.</pos></wordforms>

<hw>In*vent"or</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[L.: cf. F.
<ets>inventeur</ets>.]</ety> <def>One who invents or finds out
something new; a contriver; especially, one who invents
mechanical devices.</def>

<hw>In`ven*to"ri*al</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>a.</pos> <def>Of or
pertaining to an inventory.</def> --
<wordforms><wf>In`ven*to"ri*al*ly</wf>,
<pos>adv.</pos></wordforms>

<au>Shak.</au>

<hw>In"ven*to*ry</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos>; <plu>pl.
<plw>Inventories</plw> <pr>(#)</pr></plu>. <ety>[L.
<ets>inventarium</ets>: cf. LL. <ets>inventorium</ets>, F.
<ets>inventaire</ets>, OF. also <ets>inventoire</ets>. See
<er>Invent</er>.]</ety> <def>An account, catalogue, or schedule,
made by an executor or administrator, of all the goods and
chattels, and sometimes of the real estate, of a deceased person;
a list of the property of which a person or estate is found to be
possessed; hence, an itemized list of goods or valuables, with
their estimated worth; specifically, the annual account of stock
taken in any business.</def>

<q>There take an <qex>inventory</qex> of all I have.</q>
<qau>Shak.</qau>

<syn>Syn. -- List; register; schedule; catalogue. See
<er>List</er>.</syn>

<hw>In"ven*to*ry</hw>, <pos>v. t.</pos> <wordforms>[<pos>imp. &
p. p.</pos> <er>Inventoried</er> <pr>(?)</pr>; <pos>p. pr. & vb.
n.</pos> <er>Inventorying</er>.]</wordforms> <ety>[Cf. F.
<ets>inventorier</ets>.]</ety> <def>To make an inventory of; to
make a list, catalogue, or schedule of; to insert or register in
an account of goods; <as>as, a merchant <ex>inventories</ex> his
stock</as>.</def>

<q>I will give out divers schedules of my beauty; it shall be
<qex>inventoried</qex>, and every particle and utensil
labeled.</q>
<qau>Shak.</qau>

<hw>In*vent"ress</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[Cf. L.
<ets>inventrix</ets>, F. <ets>inventrice</ets>.]</ety> <def>A
woman who invents.</def>

<au>Dryden.</au>

<hw>In`ve*rac"i*ty</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <def>Want of
veracity.</def>

<hw>In*ver`i*si*mil"i*tude</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos>
<def>Want of verisimilitude or likelihood; improbability.</def>

<hw>In*verse"</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>a.</pos> <ety>[L.
<ets>inversus</ets>, p. p. of <ets>invertere</ets>: cf. F.
<ets>inverse</ets>. See <er>Invert</er>.]</ety>

<sn>1.</sn> <def>Opposite in order, relation, or effect;
reversed; inverted; reciprocal; -- opposed to
<xex>direct</xex>.</def>

<sn>2.</sn> <fld>(Bot.)</fld> <def>Inverted; having a position or
mode of attachment the reverse of that which is usual.</def>

<sn>3.</sn> <fld>(Math.)</fld> <def>Opposite in nature and
effect; -- said with reference to any two operations, which, when
both are performed in succession upon any quantity, reproduce
that quantity; <as>as, multiplication is the <ex>inverse</ex>
operation to division</as>. The symbol of an inverse operation is
the symbol of the direct operation with <sps>-1</sps> as an
index. Thus <funct><it>sin</it><sps>-1</sps> <it>x</it></funct>
means the arc whose sine is <it>x</it>.</def>

<cs><col>Inverse figures</col> <fld>(Geom.)</fld>, <cd>two
figures, such that each point of either figure is inverse to a
corresponding point in the order figure.</cd> -- <col>Inverse
points</col> <fld>(Geom.)</fld>, <cd>two points lying on a line
drawn from the center of a fixed circle or sphere, and so related
that the product of their distances from the center of the circle
or sphere is equal to the square of the radius.</cd> --
<mcol><col>Inverse</col>, <or/  <col>Reciprocal</col>,
<col>ratio</col></mcol> <fld>(Math.)</fld>, <cd>the ratio of the
reciprocals of two quantities.</cd> -- <mcol><col>Inverse</col>,
<or/  <col>Reciprocal,</col> <col>proportion</col></mcol>, <cd>an
equality between a direct ratio and a reciprocal ratio; thus,
<mathex>4 : 2 : : <frac13/ : <frac16/</mathex>, or 4 : 2 : : 3 :
6, <xex>inversely<xex>.</cd></cs>

<hw>In"verse</hw>, <pos>n.</pos> <def>That which is
inverse.</def>

<q>Thus the course of human study is the <qex>inverse</qex> of
the course of things in nature.</q>
<qau>Tatham.</qau>

<hw>In*verse"ly</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>adv.</pos> <def>In an
inverse order or manner; by inversion; -- opposed to
<xex>directly</xex>.</def>

<cs><col>Inversely proportional</col>. <cd>See <cref>Directly
proportional</cref>, under <er>Directly</er>, and
<er>Inversion</er>, 4.</cd></cs>

<hw>In*ver"sion</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[L.
<ets>inversio</ets>: cf. F. <ets>inversion</ets>. See
<er>Invert</er>.]</ety>

<sn>1.</sn> <def>The act of inverting, or turning over or
backward, or the state of being inverted.</def>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>A change by inverted order; a reversed position
or arrangement of things; transposition.</def>

<q>It is just the <qex>inversion</qex> of an act of Parliament;
your lordship first signed it, and then it was passed among the
Lords and Commons.</q>
<qau>Dryden.</qau>

<sn>3.</sn> <fld>(Mil.)</fld> <def>A movement in tactics by which
the order of companies in line is inverted, the right being on
the left, the left on the right, and so on.</def>

<sn>4.</sn> <fld>(Math.)</fld> <def>A change in the order of the
terms of a proportion, so that the second takes the place of the
first, and the fourth of the third.</def>

<sn>5.</sn> <fld>(Geom.)</fld> <def>A peculiar method of
transformation, in which a figure is replaced by its inverse
figure. Propositions that are true for the original figure thus
furnish new propositions that are true in the inverse figure. See
<cref>Inverse figures</cref>, under <er>Inverse</er>.</def>

<sn>6.</sn> <fld>(Gram.)</fld> <def>A change of the usual order
of words or phrases; <as>as, \'bdof all vices, impurity is one of
the most detestable,\'b8 instead of, \'bdimpurity is one of the
most detestable of all vices</as>.\'b8</def>

<sn>7.</sn> <fld>(Rhet.)</fld> <def>A method of reasoning in
which the orator shows that arguments advanced by his adversary
in opposition to him are really favorable to his cause.</def>

<sn>8.</sn> <fld>(Mus.)</fld> <sd>(a)</sd> <def>Said of
<xex>intervals</xex>, when the lower tone is placed an octave
higher, so that fifths become fourths, thirds sixths, etc.</def>
<sd>(b)</sd> <def>Said of a <xex>chord</xex>, when one of its
notes, other than its root, is made the bass.</def> <sd>(c)</sd>
<def>Said of a <xex>subject</xex>, or phrase, when the intervals
of which it consists are repeated in the contrary direction,
rising instead of falling, or vice versa.</def> <sd>(d)</sd>
<def>Said of <xex>double counterpoint</xex>, when an upper and a
lower part change places.</def>

<sn>9.</sn> <fld>(Geol.)</fld> <def>The folding back of strata
upon themselves, as by upheaval, in such a manner that the order
of succession appears to be reversed.</def>

<sn>10.</sn> <fld>(Chem.)</fld> <def>The act or process by which
cane sugar (<xex>sucrose</xex>), under the action of heat and
acids or ferments (as <xex>diastase</xex>), is broken or split up
into grape sugar (<xex>dextrose</xex>), and fruit sugar
(<xex>levulose</xex>); also, less properly, the process by which
starch is converted into grape sugar (<xex>dextrose</xex>).</def>

<note><hand/ The terms <xex>invert</xex> and
<xex>inversion</xex>, in this sense, owe their meaning to the
fact that the plane of polarization of light, which is rotated to
the right by cane sugar, is turned toward the left by
levulose.</note>

<hw>In*vert"</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>v. t.</pos>
<wordforms>[<pos>imp. & p. p.</pos> <er>Inverted</er>; <pos>p.
pr. & vb. n.</pos> <er>Inverting</er>.]</wordforms> <ety>[L.
<ets>invertere</ets>, <ets>inversum</ets>; pref. <ets>in-</ets>
in + <ets>vertere</ets> to turn. See <er>Verse</er>.]</ety>

<sn>1.</sn> <def>To turn over; to put upside down; to upset; to
place in a contrary order or direction; to reverse; <as>as, to
<ex>invert</ex> a cup, the order of words, rules of justice,
etc.</as></def>

<q>That doth <qex>invert</qex> the attest of eyes and ears,
As if these organs had deceptious functions.</q>
<qau>Shak.</qau>

<q>Such reasoning falls like an <qex>inverted</qex> cone,
Wanting its proper base to stand upon.</q>
<qau>Cowper.</qau>

<sn>2.</sn> <fld>(Mus.)</fld> <def>To change the position of; --
said of tones which form a chord, or parts which compose
harmony.</def>

<sn>3.</sn> <def>To divert; to convert to a wrong use.</def>
<mark>[Obs.]</mark>

<au>Knolles.</au>

<sn>4.</sn> <fld>(Chem.)</fld> <def>To convert; to reverse; to
decompose by, or subject to, inversion. See <er>Inversion</er>,
<pos>n.</pos>, 10.</def>

<hw>In*vert"</hw>, <pos>v. i.</pos> <fld>(Chem.)</fld> <def>To
undergo inversion, as sugar.</def>

<hw>In"vert</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>a.</pos> <fld>(Chem.)</fld>
<def>Subjected to the process of inversion; inverted; converted;
<as>as, <ex>invert</ex> sugar</as>.</def>

<cs><col>Invert sugar</col> <fld>(Chem.)</fld>, <cd>a variety of
sugar, consisting of a mixture of dextrose and levulose, found
naturally in fruits, and produced artificially by the inversion
of cane sugar (sucrose); also, less properly, the grape sugar or
dextrose obtained from starch. See <er>Inversion</er>,
<er>Dextrose</er>, <er>Levulose</er>, and
<er>Sugar</er>.</cd></cs>

<hw>In"vert</hw>, <pos>n.</pos> <fld>(Masonry)</fld> <def>An
inverted arch.</def>

<hw>In*ver"te*bral</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>a.</pos>
<fld>(Zo\'94l.)</fld> <def>Same as <er>Invertebrate</er>.</def>

<hw>\'d8In*ver`te*bra"ta</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n. pl.</pos>
<ety>[NL., fr. L. <ets>in-</ets> not + <ets>vertebratus</ets>
vertebrate.]</ety> <fld>(Zo\'94l.)</fld> <def>A comprehensive
division of the animal kingdom, including all except the
Vertebrata.</def>

<hw>In*ver"te*brate</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>a.</pos>
<fld>(Zo\'94l.)</fld> <def>Destitute of a backbone; having no
vertebr\'91; of or pertaining to the Invertebrata.</def> --
<def2><pos>n.</pos> <def>One of the Invertebrata.</def></def2>

<cs><col>Age of invertebrates</col>. <cd>See <er>Age</er>, and
<er>Silurian</er>.</cd></cs>

<hw>In*ver"te*bra`ted</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>a.</pos>
<def>Having no backbone; invertebrate.</def>

<hw>In*vert"ed</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>a.</pos>

<sn>1.</sn> <def>Changed to a contrary or counterchanged order;
reversed; characterized by inversion.</def>

<sn>2.</sn> <fld>(Geol.)</fld> <def>Situated apparently in
reverse order, as strata when folded back upon themselves by
upheaval.</def>

<cs><col>Inverted arch</col> <fld>(Arch.)</fld>, <cd>an arch
placed with crown downward; -- much used in
foundations.</cd></cs>

<hw>In*vert"ed*ly</hw>, <pos>adv.</pos> <def>In an inverted
order.</def>

<au>Derham.</au>

<hw>In*vert"i*ble</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>a.</pos> <ety>[From
<er>Invert</er>.]</ety>

<sn>1.</sn> <def>Capable of being inverted or turned.</def>

<sn>2.</sn> <fld>(Chem.)</fld> <def>Capable of being changed or
converted; <as>as, <ex>invertible</ex> sugar</as>.</def>

<hw>In*vert"i*ble</hw>, <pos>a.</pos> <ety>[Pref. <ets>in-</ets>
not + L. <ets>vertere</ets> to turn + <ets>-ible</ets>.]</ety>
<def>Incapable of being turned or changed.</def>

<q>An indurate and <qex>invertible</qex> conscience.</q>
<qau>Cranmer.</qau>

<hw>In*vert"in</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <fld>(Physiol.
Chem.)</fld> <def>An unorganized ferment which causes cane sugar
to take up a molecule of water and be converted into invert
sugar.</def>

<hw>In*vest"</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>v. t.</pos>
<wordforms>[<pos>imp. & p. p.</pos> <er>Invested</er>; <pos>p.
pr. & vb. n.</pos> <er>Investing</er>.]</wordforms> <ety>[L.
<ets>investire</ets>, <ets>investitum</ets>; pref. <ets>in-</ets>
in + <ets>vestire</ets> to clothe, fr. <ets>vestis</ets>
clothing: cf. F. <ets>investir</ets>. See <er>Vest</er>.]</ety>

<sn>1.</sn> <def>To put garments on; to clothe; to dress; to
array; -- opposed to <xex>divest</xex>. Usually followed by
<xex>with</xex>, sometimes by <xex>in</xex>; <as>as, to
<ex>invest</ex> one with a robe</as>.</def>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>To put on.</def> <mark>[Obs.]</mark>

<q>Can not find one this girdle to <qex>invest</qex>.</q>
<qau>Spenser.</qau>

<sn>3.</sn> <def>To clothe, as with office or authority; to place
in possession of rank, dignity, or estate; to endow; to adorn; to
grace; to bedeck; <as>as, to <ex>invest</ex> with honor or glory;
to <ex>invest</ex> with an estate.</as></def>

<q>I do <qex>invest</qex> you jointly with my power.</q>
<qau>Shak.</qau>

<sn>4.</sn> <def>To surround, accompany, or attend.</def>

<q>Awe such as must always <qex>invest</qex> the spectacle of the
guilt.</q>
<qau>Hawthorne.</qau>

<sn>5.</sn> <def>To confer; to give.</def> <mark>[R.]</mark>

<q>It <qex>investeth</qex> a right of government.</q>
<qau>Bacon.</qau>

<sn>6.</sn> <fld>(Mil.)</fld> <def>To inclose; to surround of hem
in with troops, so as to intercept succors of men and provisions
and prevent escape; to lay siege to; <as>as, to <ex>invest</ex> a
town</as>.</def>

<sn>7.</sn> <def>To lay out (money or capital) in business with
the <?/iew of obtaining an income or profit; <as>as, to
<ex>invest</ex> money in bank stock</as>.</def>

<hw>In*vest"</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>v. i.</pos> <def>To make an
investment; <as>as, to <ex>invest</ex> in stocks</as>; -- usually
followed by <xex>in</xex>.</def>

<ets>investiens</ets>, p. pr. of <ets>investire</ets>.]</ety>
<def>Covering; clothing.</def> <mark>[R.]</mark>

<au>Woodward.</au>

<hw>In*ves"ti*ga*ble</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>a.</pos> <ety>[L.

<hw>In*ves"ti*gate</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>v. t.</pos>
<wordforms>[<pos>imp. & p. p.</pos> <er>Investigated</er>
<pr>(?)</pr>; <pos>p. pr. & vb. n.</pos>
<er>Investigating</er>.]</wordforms> <ety>[L.
<ets>investigatus</ets>, p. p. of <ets>investigare</ets> to

track, trace. See <er>Vestige</er>.]</ety> <def>To follow up step
by step by patient inquiry or observation; to trace or track
mentally; to search into; to inquire and examine into with care
and accuracy; to find out by careful inquisition; <as>as, to
<ex>investigate</ex> the causes of natural phenomena</as>.</def>

<hw>In*ves"ti*gate</hw>, <pos>v. i.</pos> <def>To pursue a course
of investigation and study; to make investigation.</def>

<hw>In*ves`ti*ga"tion</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[L.
<ets>investigatio</ets>: cf. F. <ets>investigation</ets>.]</ety>
<def>The act of investigating; the process of inquiring into or
following up; research; study; inquiry, esp. patient or thorough
inquiry or examination; <as>as, the <ex>investigations</ex> of
the philosopher and the mathematician; the
<ex>investigations</ex> of the judge, the moralist.</as></def>

<hw>In*ves"ti*ture</hw> <pr>(?; 135)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos>

<sn>1.</sn> <def>The act or ceremony of investing, or the of

<hw>In*vet"er*a*cy</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[From

<sn>1.</sn> <def>Firm establishment by long continuance; firmness

disease</as>; -- usually in a bad sense; <as>as, the
<ex>inveteracy</ex> of prejudice or of error</as>.</def>

<q>An <qex>inveteracy</qex> of evil habits that will prompt him
to contract more.</q>
<qau>A. Tucker.</qau>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>Malignity; spitefulness; virulency.</def>

<q>The rancor of pamphlets, the <qex>inveteracy</qex> of
epigrams, an the mortification of lampoons.</q>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>Firmly established by long continuance;

abuse.</as></def>

<q>Heal the <qex>inveterate</qex> canker of one wound.</q>

<sn>3.</sn> <def>Having habits fixed by long continuance;
confirmed; habitual; <as>as, an <ex>inveterate</ex> idler or
smoker</as>.</def>

<sn>4.</sn> <def>Malignant; virulent; spiteful.</def>

And bound them with <qex>inviolable</qex> bands.</q>

<cs><col>Invisible bird</col> <fld>(Zo\'94l.)</fld>, <cd>a small,
shy singing bird (<spn>Myadestes sibilons</spn>), of St. Vincent
Islands.</cd> -- <col>Invisible green</col>, <cd>a very dark
shade of green, approaching to black, and liable to be mistaken
for it.</cd></cs>

<hw>In*vi"ta*to*ry</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos>; <plu>pl.
<plw>Invitatories</plw> <pr>(#)</pr></plu>. <ety>[LL.
<ets>invitatorium</ets>: cf. F. <ets>invitatoire</ets>.]</ety>
<def>That which invites; specifically, the invitatory psalm, or a
part of it used in worship.</def>

<hw>In*vite"</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>v. t.</pos>
<wordforms>[<pos>imp. & p. p.</pos> <er>Invited</er>; <pos>p. pr.
& vb. n.</pos> <er>Inviting</er>.]</wordforms> <ety>[L.
<ets>invitare</ets>: cf. F. <ets>inviter</ets>. See
<er>Vie</er>.]</ety>

<sn>1.</sn> <def>To ask; to request; to bid; to summon; to ask to
do some act, or go to some place; esp., to ask to an
entertainment or visit; to request the company of; <as>as, to
<ex>invite</ex> to dinner, or a wedding, or an
excursion</as>.</def>

<q>So many guests <qex>invite</qex> as here are writ.</q>
<qau>Shak.</qau>

<q>I <qex>invite</qex> his Grace of Castle Rackrent to reflect on
this.</q>
<qau>Carlyle.</qau>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>To allure; to draw to; to tempt to come; to
induce by pleasure or hope; to attract.</def>

<q>To inveigle and <qex>invite</qex> the unwary sense.</q>
<qau>Milton.</qau>

<q>Shady groves, that easy sleep <qex>invite</qex>.</q>
<qau>Dryden.</qau>

<q>There no delusive hope <qex>invites</qex> despair.</q>
<qau>Cowper.</qau>

<sn>3.</sn> <def>To give occasion for; <as>as, to <ex>invite</ex>
criticism</as>.</def>

<syn>Syn. -- To solicit; bid; call; ask; summon; allure; attract;
entice; persuade.</syn>

<hw>In*vite"</hw>, <pos>v. i.</pos> <def>To give
invitation.</def>

<au>Milton.</au>

<hw>In*vite"ment</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos>
<def>Invitation.</def> <mark>[Obs.]</mark>

<au>Chapman.</au>

<hw>In*vit"er</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <def>One who, or
that which, invites.</def>

<hw>In*vi"ti*ate</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>a.</pos> <def>Not
vitiated.</def>

<au>Lowell.</au>

<hw>In*vit"ing</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>a.</pos> <def>Alluring;
tempting; <as>as, an <ex>inviting</ex> amusement or
prospect</as>.</def>

<q>Nothing is so easy and <qex>inviting</qex> as the retort of
abuse and sarcasm.</q>
<qau>W. Irving.</qau>

-- <wordforms><wf>In*vit"ing*ly</wf>, <pos>adv.</pos> --
<wf>In*vit"ing*ness</wf>, <pos>n.</pos></wordforms>

<au>Jer. Taylor.</au>

<hw>In*vit"ri*fi`a*ble</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>a.</pos> <def>Not
admitting of being vitrified, or converted into glass.</def>

<au>Kirwan.</au>

<hw>In"vo*cate</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>v. t.</pos>
<wordforms>[<pos>imp. & p. p.</pos> <er>Invocated</er>
<pr>(?)</pr>; <pos>p. pr. & vb. n.</pos> <er>Invocating</er>
<pr>(?)</pr>.]</wordforms> <ety>[L. <ets>invocatus</ets>, p. p.
of <ets>invocare</ets>. See <er>Invoke</er>.]</ety> <def>To
invoke; to call on, or for, in supplication; to implore.</def>

<q>If Dagon be thy god,
Go to his temple, <qex>invocate</qex> his aid.</q>
<qau>Milton.</qau>

<hw>In`vo*ca"tion</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[F.
<ets>invocation</ets>, L. <ets>invocatio</ets>.]</ety>

<sn>1.</sn> <def>The act or form of calling for the assistance or
presence of some superior being; earnest and solemn entreaty;
esp., prayer offered to a divine being.</def>

<q>Sweet <qex>invocation</qex> of a child; most pretty and
pathetical!</q>
<qau>Shak.</qau>

<q>The whole poem is a prayer to Fortune, and the
<qex>invocation</qex> is divided between the two deities.</q>
<qau>Addison.</qau>

<sn>2.</sn> <fld>(Law)</fld> <def>A call or summons; especially,
a judicial call, demand, or order; <as>as, the
<ex>invocation</ex> of papers or evidence into court</as>.</def>

<hw>In"vo*ca*to*ry</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>a.</pos> <def>Making
or containing invocation; invoking.</def>

<hw>In"voice`</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[F.
<ets>envois</ets> things sent, goods forwarded, pl. of
<ets>envoi</ets> a sending or things sent, fr. <ets>envoyer</ets>
to send; cf. F. lettre <ets>d'envoi</ets> letter of advice of
goods forwarded. See <er>Envoy</er>.]</ety>

<sn>1.</sn> <fld>(Com.)</fld> <def>A written account of the
particulars of merchandise shipped or sent to a purchaser,
consignee, factor, etc., with the value or prices and charges
annexed.</def>

<au>Wharton.</au>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>The lot or set of goods as shipped or received;
<as>as, the merchant receives a large <ex>invoice</ex> of
goods</as>.</def>

<hw>In"voice`</hw>, <pos>v. t.</pos> <wordforms>[<pos>imp. & p.

invoice.</def>

<q>Goods, wares, and merchandise imported from Norway, and
<qex>invoiced</qex> in the current dollar of Norway.</q>
<qau>Madison.</qau>

<hw>In*voke"</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>v. t.</pos>
<wordforms>[<pos>imp. & p. p.</pos> <er>Invoked</er>
<pr>(?)</pr>; <pos>p. pr. & vb. n.</pos>
<er>Invoking</er>.]</wordforms> <ety>[F. <ets>invoquer</ets>, L.

<qau>Shak.</qau>

<hw>In"vo*lu`cre</hw> <pr>(?; 277)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[L.
<ets>involucrum</ets> a covering, wrapper, fr.

<fld>(Bot.)</fld> <sd>(a)</sd> <def>A whorl or set of bracts

in the common brake, or the cup-shaped processes of the filmy
ferns.</def> <sd>(c)</sd> <def>The peridium or volva of certain
fungi. Called also <altname>involucrum</altname>.</def>

<hw>In*vol"un*ta*ri*ly</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>adv.</pos>

<def>The quality or state of being involuntary; unwillingness;

<hw>In*vol"un*ta*ry</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>a.</pos> <ety>[L.
<ets>involuntarius</ets>. See <er>In-</er> not, and
<er>Voluntary</er>.]</ety>

<sn>1.</sn> <def>Not having will of the power of choice.</def>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>Not under the influence or control of the will;
not voluntary; <as>as, the <ex>involuntary</ex> movements of the
body; <ex>involuntary</ex> muscle fibers.</as></def>

<sn>3.</sn> <def>Not proceeding from choice; done unwillingly;
reluctant; compulsory; <as>as, <ex>involuntary</ex>
submission</as>.</def>

<mhw>{ <hw>In"vo*lute</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <hw>In"vo*lu`ted</hw>
<pr>(?)</pr>, }</mhw> <pos>a.</pos> <ety>[L.
<ets>involutus</ets>, p. p. of <ets>involvere</ets>. See
<er>Involve</er>.]</ety>

<sn>1.</sn> <fld>(Bot.)</fld> <def>Rolled inward from the edges;
-- said of leaves in vernation, or of the petals of flowers in
\'91stivation.</def>

<au>Gray.</au>

<sn>2.</sn> <fld>(Zo\'94l.)</fld> <sd>(a)</sd> <def>Turned inward
at the margin, as the exterior lip of the Cyprea.</def>
<sd>(b)</sd> <def>Rolled inward spirally.</def>

<hw>In"vo*lute</hw>, <pos>n.</pos> <fld>(Geom.)</fld> <def>A
curve traced by the end of a string wound upon another curve, or
unwound from it; -- called also <altname>evolvent</altname>. See
<er>Evolute</er>.</def>

<hw>In`vo*lu"tion</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[L.
<ets>involutio</ets>: cf. F. <ets>involution</ets>. See
<er>Involve</er>.]</ety>

<sn>1.</sn> <def>The act of involving or infolding.</def>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>The state of being entangled or involved;
complication; entanglement.</def>

<q>All things are mixed, and causes blended, by mutual
<qex>involutions</qex>.</q>
<qau>Glanvill.</qau>

<sn>3.</sn> <def>That in which anything is involved, folded, or
wrapped; envelope.</def>

<au>Sir T. Browne.</au>

<sn>4.</sn> <fld>(Gram.)</fld> <def>The insertion of one or more
clauses between the subject and the verb, in a way that involves
or complicates the construction.</def>

<sn>5.</sn> <fld>(Math.)</fld> <def>The act or process of raising
a quantity to any power assigned; the multiplication of a
quantity into itself a given number of times; -- the reverse of
<xex>evolution</xex>.</def>

<sn>6.</sn> <fld>(Geom.)</fld> <def>The relation which exists
between three or more sets of points, <mathex>a.a\'b7</mathex>,
<xex>b.b\'b7</xex>, <mathex>c.c\'b7</mathex>, so related to a
point O on the line, that the product <mathex>Oa.Oa\'b7</mathex>
= <mathex>Ob.Ob\'b7</mathex> = <mathex>Oc.Oc\'b7</mathex> is
constant. Sets of lines or surfaces possessing corresponding
properties may be in <xex>involution</xex>.</def>

<sn>7.</sn> <fld>(Med.)</fld> <def>The return of an enlarged part
or organ to its normal size, as of the <xex>uterus</xex> after
pregnancy.</def>

<hw>In*volve"</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>v. t.</pos>
<wordforms>[<pos>imp. & p. p.</pos> <er>Involved</er>
<pr>(?)</pr>; <pos>p. pr. & vb. n.</pos>
<er>Involving</er>.]</wordforms> <ety>[L. <ets>involvere</ets>,
<ets>involutum</ets>, to roll about, wrap up; pref.
<ets>in-</ets> in + <ets>volvere</ets> to roll: cf. OF.
<ets>involver</ets>. See <er>Voluble</er>, and cf.
<er>Involute</er>.]</ety>

<sn>1.</sn> <def>To roll or fold up; to wind round; to
entwine.</def>

<q>Some of serpent kind . . . <qex>involved</qex>
Their snaky folds.</q>
<qau>Milton.</qau>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>To envelop completely; to surround; to cover; to
hide; to <xex>involve</xex> in darkness or obscurity.</def>

<q>And leave a sing\'8ad bottom all <qex>involved</qex>
With stench and smoke.</q>
<qau>Milton.</qau>

<sn>3.</sn> <def>To complicate or make intricate, as in
grammatical structure.</def> \'bd<xex>Involved</xex>
discourses.\'b8

<au>Locke.</au>

<sn>4.</sn> <def>To connect with something as a natural or
logical consequence or effect; to include necessarily; to
imply.</def>

<q>He knows
His end with mine <qex>involved</qex>.</q>
<qau>Milton.</qau>

<q>The contrary necessarily <qex>involves</qex> a
contradiction.</q>
<qau>Tillotson.</qau>

<sn>5.</sn> <def>To take in; to gather in; to mingle confusedly;
to blend or merge.</def> <mark>[R.]</mark>

<q>The gathering number, as it moves along,
<qex>Involves</qex> a vast involuntary throng.</q>
<qau>Pope.</qau>

<q>Earth with hell
To mingle and <qex>involve</qex>.</q>
<qau>Milton.</qau>

<sn>6.</sn> <def>To envelop, infold, entangle, or embarrass;
<as>as, to <ex>involve</ex> a person in debt or
misery</as>.</def>

<sn>7.</sn> <def>To engage thoroughly; to occupy, employ, or
absorb.</def> \'bd<xex>Involved</xex> in a deep study.\'b8

<au>Sir W. Scott.</au>

<sn>8.</sn> <fld>(Math.)</fld> <def>To raise to any assigned
power; to multiply, as a quantity, into itself a given number of
times; <as>as, a quantity <ex>involved</ex> to the third or
fourth power</as>.</def>

<syn>Syn. -- To imply; include; implicate; complicate; entangle;
embarrass; overwhelm.</syn> <usage> -- To <er>Involve</er>,
<er>Imply</er>. <xex>Imply</xex> is opposed to
<xex>express</xex>, or <xex>set forth</xex>; thus, an
<xex>implied</xex> engagement is one fairly to be understood from
the words used or the circumstances of the case, though not set
forth in form. <xex>Involve</xex> goes beyond the mere
interpretation of things into their necessary relations; and
hence, if one thing <xex>involves</xex> another, it so contains
it that the two must go together by an indissoluble connection.
War, for example, <xex>involves</xex> wide spread misery and
death; the premises of a syllogism <xex>involve</xex> the
conclusion.</usage>

<hw>In*volved"</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>a.</pos>
<fld>(Zo\'94l.)</fld> <def>Same as <er>Involute</er>.</def>

<hw>In*volv"ed*ness</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <def>The
state of being involved.</def>

<hw>In*volve"ment</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <def>The act
of involving, or the state of being involved.</def>

<au>Lew Wallace.</au>

<hw>In*vul"gar</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>v. t.</pos> <ety>[Pref.
<ets>in-</ets> in + <ets>vulgar</ets>.]</ety> <def>To cause to
become or appear vulgar.</def> <mark>[Obs.]</mark>

<au>Daniel.</au>

+ <ets>vulgar</ets>.]</ety> <def>Not vulgar; refined;
elegant.</def> <mark>[Obs.]</mark>

<au>Drayton.</au>

<hw>In*vul"ner*a*bil`i*ty</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos>
<ety>[Cf. F. <ets>invuln\'82rabilit\'82</ets>.]</ety>
<def>Quality or state of being invulnerable.</def>

<hw>In*vul"ner*a*ble</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>a.</pos> <ety>[L.
<ets>invulnerabilis</ets>: cf. F. <ets>invuln\'82rable</ets>. See
<er>In-</er> not, and <er>Vulnerable</er>.]</ety>

<sn>1.</sn> <def>Incapable of being wounded, or of receiving
injury.</def>

<q>Neither vainly hope
To be <qex>invulnerable</qex> in those bright arms.</q>
<qau>Milton.</qau>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>Unanswerable; irrefutable; that can not be
refuted or convinced; <as>as, an <ex>invulnerable</ex>
argument</as>.</def>

<def>Invulnerability.</def>

<ets>invulneratus</ets> unwounded.]</ety>

<hw>In"ward</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>a.</pos> <ety>[AS.
<ets>inweard</ets>, <ets>inneweard</ets>, <ets>innanweard</ets>,
fr. <ets>innan</ets>, <ets>inne</ets>, within (fr. <ets>in</ets>
in; see <er>In</er>) + the suffix <ets>-weard</ets>, E.
<ets>-ward</ets>.]</ety>

<sn>1.</sn> <def>Being or placed within; inner; interior; --
opposed to <xex>outward</xex>.</def>

<au>Milton.</au>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>Seated in the mind, heart, spirit, or
soul.</def> \'bd<xex>Inward</xex> beauty.\'b8

<au>Shak.</au>

<sn>3.</sn> <def>Intimate; domestic; private.</def>
<mark>[Obs.]</mark>

<q>All my <qex>inward</qex> friends abhorred me.</q>
<qau>Job xix. 19.</qau>

<q>He had had occasion, by one very <qex>inward</qex> with him,
to know in part the discourse of his life.</q>
<qau>Sir P. Sidney.</qau>

<hw>In"ward</hw>, <pos>n.</pos> <sn>1.</sn> <def>That which is
inward or within; especially, in the plural, the inner parts or
organs of the body; the viscera.</def>

<au>Jer. Taylor.</au>

<q>Then sacrificing, laid the <qex>inwards</qex> and their
fat.</q>
<qau>Milton.</qau>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>The mental faculties; -- usually
<pluf>pl.</pluf></def> <mark>[Obs.]</mark>

<sn>3.</sn> <def>An intimate or familiar friend or
acquaintance.</def> <mark>[Obs.]</mark> \'bdI was an
<xex>inward</xex> of his.\'b8

<au>Shak.</au>

<mhw>{ <hw>In"ward</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <hw>In"wards</hw>
<pr>(?)</pr>, }</mhw> <pos>adv.</pos> <ety>[AS.
<ets>inweard</ets>.  The ending <it>-s</it> is prop. a genitive
ending. See <er>Inward</er>, <pos>a.</pos>,
<er>-wards</er>.]</ety>

<sn>1.</sn> <def>Toward the inside; toward the center or
interior; <as>as, to bend a thing <ex>inward</ex></as>.</def>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>Into, or toward, the mind or thoughts; inwardly;
<as>as, to turn the attention <ex>inward</ex></as>.</def>

<q>So much the rather, thou Celestial Light,
Shine <qex>inward</qex>.</q>
<qau>Milton.</qau>

<hw>In"ward*ly</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>adv.</pos> <ety>[AS.
<ets>inweardlice</ets>.]</ety>

<sn>1.</sn> <def>In the inner parts; internally.</def>

<q>Let Benedick, like covered fire,
Consume away in sighs, waste <qex>inwardly</qex>.</q>
<qau>Shak.</qau>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>Toward the center; inward; <as>as, to curve
<ex>inwardly</ex></as>.</def>

<sn>3.</sn> <def>In the heart or mind; mentally; privately;
secret<?/y; <as>as, he <ex>inwardly</ex> repines</as>.</def>

<sn>4.</sn> <def>Intimately; thoroughly.</def>
<mark>[Obs.]</mark>

<q>I shall desire to know him more <qex>inwardly</qex>.</q>
<qau>Beau. & Fl.</qau>

<hw>In"ward*ness</hw>, <pos>n.</pos> <sn>1.</sn> <def>Internal or
true state; essential nature; <as>as, the <ex>inwardness</ex> of
conduct</as>.</def>

<q>Sense can not arrive to the <qex>inwardness</qex>
Of things.</q>
<qau>Dr. H. More.</qau>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>Intimacy; familiarity.</def> <mark>[Obs.]</mark>

<au>Shak.</au>

<sn>3.</sn> <def>Heartiness; earnestness.</def>

<q>What was wanted was more <qex>inwardness</qex>, more
feeling.</q>
<qau>M. Arnold.</qau>

<hw>In"wards</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>adv.</pos> <def>See
<er>Inward</er>.</def>

<hw>In*weave"</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>v. t.</pos> <def>To weave
in or together; to intermix or intertwine by weaving; to
interlace.</def>

<q>Down they cast
Their crowns, <qex>inwove</qex> with amaranth and gold.</q>
<qau>Milton.</qau>

<hw>In*wrought"</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>p. p. <or/ a.</pos>

<hw>I"o</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos>; <plu>pl. <plw>Ios</plw>
<pr>(#)</pr></plu>. <ety>[L.; cf. Gr. <grk>"iw`</grk>.]</ety>

interjectional.</def>

<hw>I"od-</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>. <fld>(Chem.)</fld> <def>See
<er>Iodo-</er>.</def>

<hw>I"o*dal</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos>
<ety>[<ets>Iod-</ets> + <ets>al</ets>cohol.]</ety>
<fld>(Chem.)</fld> <def>An oily liquid, <chform>Cl3.CHO</chform>,
analogous to chloral and bromal.</def>

<hw>I"o*date</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <fld>(Chem.)</fld>
<def>A salt of iodic acid.</def>

<hw>I`od*hy"drin</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos>
<ety>[<ets>Iod-</ets> + chlor<ets>hydrin</ets>.]</ety>
<fld>(Chem.)</fld> <def>One of a series of compounds containing
iodine, and analogous to the chlorhydrins.</def>

<hw>I*od"ic</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>a.</pos> <ety>[Cf. F.
<ets>iodique</ets>. See <er>Iodine</er>.]</ety>
<fld>(Chem.)</fld> <def>to, or containing, iodine; specif.,
denoting those compounds in which it has a relatively high
valence; <as>as, <ex>iodic</ex> acid</as>.</def>

<cs><col>Iodic acid</col>, <cd>a monobasic acid, consisting of
iodine with three parts of oxygen and one of hydrogen.</cd></cs>

<hw>I"o*dide</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <fld>(Chem.)</fld>
<def>A binary compound of iodine, or one which may be regarded as
binary; <as>as, potassium <ex>iodide</ex></as>.</def>

<hw>I"o*dine</hw> <pr>(?; 104)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[Gr. <?/
violetlike; <?/ a violet + <?/ form: cf. F. <ets>iode</ets>,
<ets>iodine</ets>. The name was given from the violet color of
its vapor. See <er>Violet</er>, <er>Idyl</er>.]</ety>
<fld>(Chem.)</fld> <def>A nonmetallic element, of the halogen
group, occurring always in combination, as in the iodides. When
isolated it is in the form of dark gray metallic scales,
resembling plumbago, soft but brittle, and emitting a
chlorinelike odor. Symbol I. Atomic weight 126.5. If heated,
iodine volatilizes in beautiful violet vapors.</def>

<note><hand/ Iodine was formerly obtained from the ashes of
seaweed (<xex>kelp</xex> or <xex>varec</xex>), but is now also
extracted from certain natural brines. In the free state, iodine,
even in very minute quantities, colors starch blue. Iodine and
its compounds are largely used in medicine (as in liniments,
antisyphilitics, etc.), in photography, in the preparation of
aniline dyes, and as an indicator in titration.</note>

<cs><col>Iodine green</col>, <cd>an artificial green dyestuff,
consisting of an iodine derivative of rosaniline; -- called also
<altname>night green</altname>.</cd> -- <col>Iodine
scarlet</col>, <cd>a pigment of an intense scarlet color,
consisting of mercuric iodide.</cd> -- <col>Iodine yellow</col>,
<cd>a brilliant yellow pigment, consisting of plumbic
iodide.</cd></cs>

<hw>I"o*dism</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <fld>(Med.)</fld>
<def>A morbid state produced by the use of iodine and its
compounds, and characterized by palpitation, depression, and
general emaciation, with a pustular eruption upon the skin.</def>

<hw>I"o*dize</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>v. t.</pos>
<wordforms>[<pos>imp. & p. p.</pos> <er>Iodized</er>
<pr>(?)</pr>; <pos>p. pr. & vb. n.</pos> <er>Iodizing</er>
<pr>(?)</pr>.]</wordforms> <def>To treat or impregnate with
iodine or its compounds; <as>as, to <ex>iodize</ex> a plate for
photography</as>.</def>

<au>R. Hunt.</au>

<-- iodized salt = table salt to which an iodide compound has
been added as a nutritional supplement to prevent goiter -->

<hw>I"o*di`zer</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <def>One who, or
that which, iodizes.</def>

<mhw>{ <hw>I"o*do-</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <hw>I"od-</hw>
<pr>(?)</pr>. }</mhw> <fld>(Chem.)</fld> <def>A prefix, or
combining from, indicating <xex>iodine</xex> as an ingredient;
<as>as, <ex>iodo</ex>form</as>.</def>

<hw>I*od"o*form</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos>
<ety>[<ets>Iodo-</ets> + <ets>formyl.</ets> See <er>Formyl</er>,
and cf. <er>Chloroform</er>.]</ety> <fld>(Chem.)</fld> <def>A
yellow, crystalline, volatile substance, <chform>CI3H</chform>,
having an offensive odor and sweetish taste, and analogous to
chloroform. It is used in medicine as a healing and antiseptic
dressing for wounds and sores.</def>

<hw>I`o*do*qui"nine</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos>
<ety>[<ets>Iodo-</ets> + <ets>quinine</ets>.]</ety>
<fld>(Chem.)</fld> <def>A iodide of quinine obtained as a brown
substance,. It is the base of herapathite. See
<er>Herapathite</er>.</def>

<hw>I"o*dous</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>a.</pos> <fld>(Chem.)</fld>
<def>Pertaining to, or containing, iodine. See <er>-ous</er>
(chemical suffix).</def>

<cs><col>Iodous acid</col>, <cd>a hypothetical acid, analogous to
chlorous acid.</cd></cs>

<hw>I*od"u*ret</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos>
<fld>(Chem.)</fld> <def>Iodide.</def> <mark>[Obs.]</mark>

<hw>I*od"y*rite</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[From
<er>Iodine</er>.]</ety> <fld>(Min.)</fld> <def>Silver iodide, a
mineral of a yellowish color.</def>

<hw>I"o*lite</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[Gr. <?/ a
violet  + <ets>-lite</ets>.]</ety> <fld>(Min.)</fld> <def>A
silicate of alumina, iron, and magnesia, having a bright blue
color and vitreous luster; cordierite. It is remarkable for its
dichroism, and is also called <xex>dichroite</xex>.</def>

<hw>I"o moth`</hw> <pr>(?; 115)</pr>. <fld>(Zo\'94l.)</fld>
<def>A large and handsome American moth (<spn>Hyperchiria
Io</spn>), having a large, bright-colored spot on each hind wing,
resembling the spots on the tail of a peacock. The larva is
covered with prickly hairs, which sting like nettles.</def>

<hw>-ion</hw> <pr>(?; 106)</pr>. <ety>[L. -<ets>io</ets>, acc.
-<ets>ionem</ets>: cf. F. -<ets>ion</ets>.]</ety> <def>A noun
suffix denoting <xex>act</xex>, <xex>process</xex>, <xex>result
of an act or a process</xex>, <xex>thing acted upon</xex>,
<xex>state</xex>, or <xex>condition</xex>; <as>as,
revolut<ex>ion</ex>, the act or process of revolving;
construct<ex>ion</ex>, the act or process of constructing; a
thing constructed; domin<ex>ion</ex>, territory ruled over;
subject<ex>ion</ex>, state of being subject; deject<ex>ion</ex>;
abstract<ex>ion</ex>.</as></def>

<hw>I"on</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[Gr. <?/, neut, of
<?/, p. pr. of <?/ to go.]</ety> <fld>(Elec. Chem.)</fld>
<def>One of the elements which appear at the respective poles
when a body is subjected to electro-chemical decomposition. Cf.
<er>Anion</er>, <er>Cation</er>.</def>
<-- an atom or goup of atoms (radical) carrying an electrical
charge.  Contrasted with neutral atoms or molecules, and free
radicals.  Certain compounds, such as sodium chloride, are
composed of complementary ions in the solid (crystalline) as well
as in solution.  Others, notable acids such as hydrogen chloride,
may occur as neutral molecules in the pure liquid or gas forms,
and ionize almost completely in dilute aqueous solutions.  In
solutions (as in water) ions are frequently bound non-covalently
with the molecules of solvent, and in that case are said to be
solvated. -->

<hw>I*o"ni*an</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>a.</pos> <ety>[L.
<ets>Ionius</ets>. See <er>Ionic</er>.]</ety> <def>Of or
pertaining to Ionia or the Ionians; Ionic.</def> --
<def2><pos>n.</pos> <def>A native or citizen of
Ionia.</def></def2>

<hw>I*on"ic</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>a.</pos> <ety>[L.
<ets>Ionicus</ets>, Gr. <?/, fr. <?/ Ionia.]</ety>

<sn>1.</sn> <def>Of or pertaining to Ionia or the Ionians.</def>

<sn>2.</sn> <fld>(Arch.)</fld> <def>Pertaining to the Ionic order
of architecture, one of the three orders invented by the Greeks,
and one of the five recognized by the Italian writers of the
sixteenth century. Its distinguishing feature is a capital with
spiral volutes. See <xex>Illust</xex>. of <er>Capital</er>.</def>

<cs><col>Ionic dialect</col> <fld>(Gr. Gram.)</fld>, <cd>a
dialect of the Greek language, used in Ionia. The Homeric poems
are written in what is designated <xex>old Ionic<xex>, as
distinguished from <xex>new Ionic<xex>, or <xex>Attic<xex>, the
dialect of all cultivated Greeks in the period of Athenian
prosperity and glory.</cd> -- <col>Ionic foot</col>.
<fld>(Pros.)</fld> <cd>See <er>Ionic</er>, <pos>n.</pos>, 1.</cd>
-- <mcol><col>Ionic</col>, <or/ <col>Ionian</col>,
<col>mode</col></mcol> <fld>(Mus.)</fld>, <cd>an ancient mode,
supposed to correspond with the modern major scale of C.</cd> --
<col>Ionic sect</col>, <cd>a sect of philosophers founded by
Thales of Miletus, in Ionia. Their distinguishing tenet was, that
water is the original principle of all things.</cd> -- <col>Ionic
type</col>, <cd>a kind of heavy-faced type (as that of the
following line).</cd></cs>

<note><hand/<nonpareiltype>This is Nonpareil
Ionic.</nonpareiltype></note>

<-- <hw>Ionic</hw> <pos>a.</pos> <def>Of or pertaining to an ion;
composed of ions.</def> -->

<hw>I*on"ic</hw>, <pos>n.</pos> <sn>1.</sn> <fld>(Pros.)</fld>
<sd>(a)</sd> <def>A foot consisting of four syllables: either two
long and two short, -- that is, a spondee and a pyrrhic, in which
case it is called the <xex>greater Ionic</xex>; or two short and
two long, -- that is, a pyrrhic and a spondee, in which case it
is called the <xex>smaller Ionic</xex>.</def> <sd>(b)</sd> <def>A
verse or meter composed or consisting of Ionic feet.</def>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>The Ionic dialect; <as>as, the Homeric
<ex>Ionic</ex></as>.</def>

<sn>3.</sn> <fld>(Print.)</fld> <def>Ionic type.</def>

<hw>I"o*qua shell`</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>. <ety>[From the native

<hw>I*o"ta</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[L., fr. Gr.
<?/. See <er>Jot</er>.]</ety>

<sn>1.</sn> <def>The ninth letter of the Greek alphabet (<iota/)
corresponding with the English <it>i.</it></def>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>A very small quantity or degree; a jot; a
particle.</def><-- from iota being the smallest letter -->

<q>They never depart an <qex>iota</qex> from the authentic
formulas of tyranny and usurpation.</q>
<qau>Burke.</qau>

<cs><col>Iota subscript</col> <fld>(Gr. Gram.)</fld>, <cd>iota
written beneath a preceding vowel, as <grk>a,</grk>,
<grk>h,</grk>, <grk>w,</grk>, -- done when iota is
silent.</cd></cs><-- we use a following comma to represent the
iota subscript within Greek transcriptions.  See the "readme.fnt"
file for complete description of Greek transliterations. -->

<hw>I*o"ta*cism</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[Gr. <?/ a
laying too much stress upon the iota (<?/): cf. F.
<ets>iotacisme</ets>. See <er>Iota</er>.]</ety> <def>The frequent
use of the sound of iota (that of English <xex>e</xex> in
<xex>be</xex>), as among the modern Greeks; also, confusion from
sounding <?/, <?/, <?/, <?/, <?/, etc., like <?/.</def>

<au>Littr\'82.</au>

<hw>I O U</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>. <ety>[i. e., I owe you.]</ety>
<def>A paper having on it these letters, with a sum named, and
duly signed; -- in use in England as an acknowledgment of a debt,
and taken as evidence thereof, but not amounting to a promissory
note; a due bill.</def>

<au>Wharton. Story.</au>

<hw>Ip`e*cac`u*an"ha</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[Pg.
<ets>ipecacuanha</ets> (cf. Sp. <ets>ipecacuana</ets>); fr. Braz.
<ets>ipe-kaa-guena</ets>, prop., a creeping plant that causes
vomiting.]</ety> <fld>(Med. & Bot.)</fld> <def>The root of a
Brazilian rubiaceous herb (<spn>Cepha\'89lis Ipecacuanha</spn>),
largely employed as an emetic; also, the plant itself; also, a
medicinal extract of the root. Many other plants are used as a
substitutes; among them are the black or Peruvian ipecac
(<spn>Psychotria emetica</spn>), the white ipecac (<spn>Ionidium
Ipecacuanha</spn>), the bastard or wild ipecac (<spn>Asclepias
Curassavica</spn>), and the undulated ipecac (<spn>Richardsonia
scabra</spn>).</def>

colors</as>.</def>

<au>Whewell.</au>

<hw>Ir`i*dec"to*my</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[Gr.
<?/, <?/, iris + <?/ cutting out; <?/ out + <?/ to cut.]</ety>
<fld>(Surg.)</fld> <def>The act or process of cutting out a
portion of the iris in order to form an artificial pupil.</def>

<hw>Ir`i*des"cence</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[See
<er>Iridescent</er>.]</ety> <def>Exhibition of colors like those
of the rainbow; the quality or state of being iridescent; a
prismatic play of color; <as>as, the <ex>iridescence</ex> of
mother-of-pearl</as>.</def>

<hw>Ir`i*des"cent</hw> <pr>(?; 277)</pr>, <pos>a.</pos> <ety>[L.
<ets>iris</ets>, <ets>iridis</ets>, the rainbow: cf. F.
<ets>iridescent</ets>.]</ety> <def>Having colors like the
rainbow; exhibiting a play of changeable colors; nacreous;
prismatic; <as>as, <ex>iridescent</ex> glass</as>.</def>

<hw>I*rid"i*an</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>a.</pos> <def>Of or
pertaining to the iris or rainbow.</def>

<hw>I*rid"i*a`ted</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>a.</pos>
<def>Iridescent.</def>

<hw>I*rid"ic</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>a.</pos> <def>Of or
pertaining to the iris of the eye.</def>

<hw>I*rid"ic</hw>, <pos>a.</pos> <fld>(Chem.)</fld> <def>Of or
pertaining to iridium; -- said specifically of those compounds in
which iridium has a relatively high valence.</def>

<hw>I*rid"i*o*scope</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[See
<er>Iris</er>, and <er>-scope</er>.]</ety> <def>A kind of
ophthalmoscope.</def>

<hw>I*rid"i*ous</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>a.</pos>
<fld>(Chem.)</fld> <def>Of or pertaining to iridium; -- applied
specifically to compounds in which iridium has a low
valence.</def>

<-- p. 788 -->

<hw>I*rid"i*um</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[NL., fr. L.
<ets>iris</ets>, <ets>iridis</ets>, the rainbow. So called from
the iridescence of some of its solutions. See
<er>Iris</er>.]</ety> <fld>(Chem.)</fld> <def>A rare metallic
element, of the same group as platinum, which it much resembles,
being silver-white, but harder, and brittle, and indifferent to
most corrosive agents. With the exception of osmium, it is the
heaviest substance known, its specific gravity being 22.4. Symbol
Ir. Atomic weight 192.5.</def>

<note><hand/ Iridium usually occurs as a native alloy with osmium
(<xex>iridosmine</xex> or <xex>osmiridium</xex>), which may occur
alone or with platinum. Iridium, as an alloy with platinum, is
used in bushing the vents of heavy ordnance. It is also used for
the points of gold pens, and in a finely powdered condition
(<xex>iridium black</xex>), for painting porcelain black.</note>

<hw>Ir"i*dize</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>v. t.</pos>
<wordforms>[<pos>imp. & p. p.</pos> <er>Iridized</er>
<pr>(?)</pr>; <pos>p. pr. & vb. n.</pos> <er>Iridizing</er>
<pr>(?)</pr>.]</wordforms>

<sn>1.</sn> <def>To point or tip with iridium, as a gold
pen.</def>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>To make iridescent; <as>as, to <ex>iridize</ex>
glass</as>.</def>

<hw>I*rid"o*line</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos>
<ety>[<ets>Irid</ets>escent + L. <ets>ol</ets>eum oil.]</ety>
<fld>(Chem.)</fld> <def>A nitrogenous base
<chform>C10H9N</chform>, extracted from coal-tar naphtha, as an
oily liquid. It is a member of the quinoline series, and is
probably identical with <altname>lepidine</altname>.</def>

<mhw>{ <hw>Ir`i*dos"mine</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>,
<hw>Ir`i*dos"mi*um</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, }</mhw> <pos>n.</pos>
<ety>[<ets>Irid</ets>ium + <ets>osmium</ets>.]</ety>
<fld>(Min.)</fld> <def>The native compound of iridium and osmium.
It is found in flattened metallic grains of extreme hardness, and
is often used for pointing gold pens.</def>

<hw>I"ris</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos>; <plu>pl. E.
<plw>Irises</plw> <pr>(#)</pr>, L. <plw>Irides</plw>
<pr>(#)</pr></plu>. <ety>[L. <ets>iris</ets>, <ets>iridis</ets>,
the goddess, Gr. <?/, <?/, the rainbow, iris of the eye, the
plant Iris. Cf. <er>Orris</er>.]</ety>

<sn>1.</sn> <fld>(Class. Myth.)</fld> <def>The goddess of the
rainbow, and swift-footed messenger of the gods.</def>

<au>Shak.</au>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>The rainbow.</def>

<au>Sir T. Browne.</au>

<sn>3.</sn> <def>An appearance resembling the rainbow; a
prismatic play of colors.</def>

<au>Tennyson.</au>

<sn>4.</sn> <fld>(Anat.)</fld> <def>The contractile membrane
perforated by the pupil, and forming the colored portion of the
eye. See <er>Eye</er>.</def>

<sn>5.</sn> <fld>(Bot.)</fld> <def>A genus of plants having showy
flowers and bulbous or tuberous roots, of which the
flower-de-luce (<xex>fleur-de-lis</xex>), orris, and other
species of flag are examples. See <xex>Illust</xex>. of
<er>Flower-de-luce</er>.</def>

<sn>6.</sn> <fld>(Her.)</fld> <def>See <er>Fleur-de-lis</er>,
2.</def>

<er>Iris</er>.]</ety> <def>Exhibiting the prismatic colors;

<au>W. Phillips.</au>

<hw>I"ri*scope</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos>

<hw>I*rish"</hw>, <pos>n. sing. & pl.</pos> <sn>1.</sn>
<pluf>pl.</pluf> <def>The natives or inhabitants of Ireland, esp.
the Celtic natives or their descendants.</def>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>The language of the Irish; the
Hiberno-Celtic.</def>

<sn>3.</sn> <def>An old game resembling backgammon.</def>

speaking peculiar to the Irish; an Hibernicism.</def>

<plw>Irishmen</plw> <pr>(<?/)</pr>.</plu> <def>A man born in

<cs><col>Irishman's hurricane</col> <fld>(Naut.)</fld>, <cd>a

<cd>See <cref>Irish reef</cref>, under <er>Irish</er>,
<pos>a.</pos></cd></cs>

<hw>I"rish*ry</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <def>The Celtic
people of Ireland.</def> \'bdThe whole <xex>Irishry</xex> of

<au>Milton.</au>

<hw>\'d8I*ri"tis</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[NL. See
<er>Iris</er>, and <er>-itis</er>.]</ety> <fld>(Med.)</fld>
