<hw>Irk</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>v. t.</pos> <ety>[OE.
<ets>irken</ets> to tire, become tired; cf. Sw. <ets>yrka</ets>
to urge, enforce, press, or G. <ets>ekel</ets> disgust, MHG.
<ets>erklich</ets> disgusting; perh. akin to L. <ets>urgere</ets>
to urge, E. <ets>urge</ets>.]</ety> <def>To weary; to give pain;
to annoy; -- used only impersonally at present.</def>

<q>To see this sight, it <qex>irks</qex> my very soul.</q>
<qau>Shak.</qau>

<q>It <qex>irketh</qex> him to be here.</q>
<qau>M. Arnold.</qau>

<hw>Irk"some</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>a.</pos> <sn>1.</sn>
<def>Wearisome; tedious; disagreeable or troublesome by reason of
long continuance or repetition; <as>as, <ex>irksome</ex> hours;
<ex>irksome</ex> tasks.</as></def>

<q>For not to <qex>irksome</qex> toil, but to delight,
He made us.</q>
<qau>Milton.</qau>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>Weary; vexed; uneasy.</def> <mark>[Obs.]</mark>

<q>Let us therefore learn not to be <qex>irksome</qex> when God
layeth his cross upon us.</q>
<qau>Latimer.</qau>

<syn>Syn. -- Wearisome; tedious; tiresome; vexatious;
burdensome.</syn> <usage> -- <er>Irksome</er>,
<er>Wearisome</er>, <er>Tedious</er>. These epithets describe
things which give pain or disgust. <xex>Irksome</xex> is applied
to something which disgusts by its nature or quality; <as>as, an
<ex>irksome</ex> task</as>. <xex>Wearisome</xex> denotes that
which wearies or <xex>wears</xex> us out by severe labor; <as>as,
<ex>wearisome</ex> employment</as>. <xex>Tedious</xex> is applied
to something which tires us out by the length of time occupied in
its performance; <as>as, a <ex>tedious</ex> speech</as>.</usage>

<q><qex>Wearisome</qex> nights are appointed to me.</q>
<qau>Job vii. 3.</qau>

<q>Pity only on fresh objects stays,
But with the <qex>tedious</qex> sight of woes decays.</q>
<qau>Dryden.</qau>

-- <wordforms><wf>Irk"some*ly</wf>, <pos>adv.</pos> --
<wf>Irk"some*ness</wf>, <pos>n.</pos></wordforms>

<hw>I"ron</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[OE.
<ets>iren</ets>, AS. <ets>\'c6ren</ets>, <ets>\'c6sen</ets>,
<ets>\'c6sern</ets>; akin to D. <ets>ijzer</ets>, OS.
<ets>\'c6sarn</ets>, OHG. <ets>\'c6sarn</ets>,
<ets>\'c6san</ets>, G. <ets>eisen</ets>, Icel.
<ets>\'c6sarn</ets>, <ets>j\'bern</ets>, Sw. & Dan.
<ets>jern</ets>, and perh. to E. <ets>ice</ets>; cf. Ir.
<ets>iarann</ets>, W. <ets>haiarn</ets>, Armor.
<ets>houarn</ets>.]</ety>

<sn>1.</sn> <fld>(Chem.)</fld> <def>The most common and most
useful metallic element, being of almost universal occurrence,
usually in the form of an oxide (as <xex>hematite</xex>,
<xex>magnetite</xex>, etc.), or a hydrous oxide (as
<xex>limonite</xex>, <xex>turgite</xex>, etc.). It is reduced on
an enormous scale in three principal forms; viz., <xex>cast
iron</xex>, <xex>steel</xex>, and <xex>wrought iron</xex>. Iron
usually appears dark brown, from oxidation or impurity, but when
pure, or an fresh surface, is a gray or white metal. It is easily
oxidized (rusted) by moisture, and is attacked by many corrosive
agents. Symbol Fe (Latin <xex>Ferrum</xex>). Atomic weight 55.9.
Specific gravity, pure iron, 7.86; cast iron, 7.1. In magnetic
properties, it is superior to all other substances.</def>

<note><hand/ The value of iron is largely due to the facility
with which it can be worked. Thus, when heated it is malleable
and ductile, and can be easily welded and forged at a high
temperature. As <xex>cast iron</xex>, it is easily fusible; as
<xex>steel</xex>, is very tough, and (when tempered) very hard
and elastic. Chemically, iron is grouped with cobalt and nickel.
<xex>Steel</xex> is a variety of iron containing more carbon than
wrought iron, but less that cast iron. It is made either from
wrought iron, by roasting in a packing of carbon
(<xex>cementation</xex>) or from cast iron, by burning off the
impurities in a Bessemer converter (then called <xex>Bessemer
steel</xex>), or directly from the iron ore (as in the Siemens
rotatory and generating furnace).</note>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>An instrument or utensil made of iron; --
chiefly in composition; <as>as, a flat<ex>iron</ex>, a smoothing
<ex>iron</ex>, etc.</as></def>

<q>My young soldier, put up your <qex>iron</qex>.</q>
<qau>Shak.</qau>

<sn>3.</sn> <pluf>pl.</pluf> <def>Fetters; chains; handcuffs;
manacles.</def>

<q>Four of the sufferers were left to rot in
<qex>irons</qex>.</q>
<qau>Macaulay.</qau>

<sn>4.</sn> <def>Strength; power; firmness; inflexibility;
<as>as, to rule with a rod of <ex>iron</ex></as>.</def>

<cs><col>Bar iron</col>. <cd>See <cref>Wrought iron</cref>
(below).</cd> -- <col>Bog iron</col>, <cd>bog ore; limonite. See
<cref>Bog ore</cref>, under <er>Bog</er>.</cd> -- <col>Cast
iron</col> <fld>(Metal.)</fld>, <cd>an impure variety of iron,
containing from three to six percent of carbon, part of which is
united with a part of the iron, as a carbide, and the rest is
uncombined, as graphite. It there is little free carbon, the
product is <xex>white iron<xex>; if much of the carbon has
separated as graphite, it is called <xex>gray iron<xex>. See also
<er>Cast iron</er>, in the Vocabulary.</cd> -- <col>Fire
irons</col>. <cd>See under <er>Fire</er>, <pos>n.</pos></cd> --
<col>Gray irons</col>. <cd>See under <er>Fire</er>,
<pos>n.</pos></cd> -- <col>Gray iron</col>. <cd>See <cref>Cast
iron</cref> (above).</cd> -- <col>It irons</col>
<fld>(Naut.)</fld>, <cd>said of a sailing vessel, when, in
tacking, she comes up head to the wind and will not fill away on
either tack.</cd> -- <col>Magnetic iron</col>. <cd>See
<er>Magnetite</er>.</cd> -- <col>Malleable iron</col>
<fld>(Metal.)</fld>, <cd>iron sufficiently pure or soft to be
capable of extension under the hammer; also, specif., a kind of
iron produced by removing a portion of the carbon or other
impurities from cast iron, rendering it less brittle, and to some
extent malleable.</cd> -- <col>Meteoric iron</col>
<fld>(Chem.)</fld>, <cd>iron forming a large, and often the
chief, ingredient of meteorites. It invariably contains a small
amount of nickel and cobalt. Cf. <er>Meteorite</er>.</cd> --
<col>Pig iron</col>, <cd>the form in which cast iron is made at
the blast furnace, being run into molds, called
<xex>pigs<xex>.</cd> -- <col>Reduced iron</col>. <cd>See under
<er>Reduced</er>.</cd> -- <col>Specular iron</col>. <cd>See
<er>Hematite</er>.</cd> -- <col>Too many irons in the fire</col>,
<cd>too many objects requiring the attention at once.</cd> --
<col>White iron</col>. <cd>See <cref>Cast iron</cref>
(above).</cd> -- <col>Wrought iron</col> <fld>(Metal.)</fld>,
<cd>the purest form of iron commonly known in the arts,
containing only about half of one per cent of carbon. It is made
either directly from the ore, as in the Catalan forge or
bloomery, or by purifying (<xex>puddling<xex>) cast iron in a
reverberatory furnace or refinery. It is tough, malleable, and
ductile. When formed into bars, it is called <xex>bar
iron<xex>.</cd></cs>

<hw>I"ron</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>a.</pos> <ety>[AS.
<ets>\'c6ren</ets>, <ets>\'c6sen</ets>. See <er>Iron</er>,
<pos>n.</pos>]</ety>

<sn>1.</sn> <def>Of, or made of iron; consisting of iron; <as>as,
an <ex>iron</ex> bar, dust</as>.</def>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>Resembling iron in color; <as>as, <ex>iron</ex>
blackness</as>.</def>

<sn>3.</sn> <def>Like iron in hardness, strength,
impenetrability, power of endurance, insensibility, etc.;
as:</def>

<sd>(a)</sd> <def>Rude; hard; harsh; severe</def>.

<q><qex>Iron</qex> years of wars and dangers.</q>
<qau>Rowe.</qau>

<q>Jove crushed the nations with an <qex>iron</qex> rod.</q>
<qau>Pope.</qau>

<sd>(b)</sd> <def>Firm; robust; enduring; as, an <xex>iron</xex>
constitution</def>.

<sd>(c)</sd> <def>Inflexible; unrelenting; as, an <xex>iron</xex>
will</def>.

<sd>(d)</sd> <def>Not to be broken; holding or binding fast;
tenacious</def>. \'bdHim death's <xex>iron</xex> sleep
oppressed.\'b8

<au>Philips.</au>

<note><hand/ <xex>Iron</xex> is often used in composition,
denoting <xex>made of iron</xex>, <xex>relating to iron</xex>,
<xex>of or with iron</xex>; <xex>producing iron</xex>, etc.;
<xex>resembling</xex> iron, literally or figuratively, in some of
its properties or characteristics; as, <xex>iron</xex>-shod,
<xex>iron</xex>-sheathed, <xex>iron</xex>-fisted,
<xex>iron</xex>-framed, <xex>iron</xex>-handed,
<xex>iron</xex>-hearted, <xex>iron</xex> foundry or
<xex>iron</xex>-foundry.</note>

<cs><col>Iron age</col>. <sd>(a)</sd> <fld>(Myth.)</fld> <cd>The
age following the golden, silver, and bronze ages, and
characterized by a general degeneration of talent and virtue, and
of literary excellence. In Roman literature the <xex>Iron
Age<xex> is commonly regarded as beginning after the taking of
Rome by the Goths, <sc>A. D.</sc> 410.</cd> <sd>(b)</sd>
<fld>(Arch\'91ol.)</fld> <cd>That stage in the development of any
people characterized by the use of iron implements in the place
of the more cumbrous stone and bronze.</cd> -- <col>Iron
cement</col>, <cd>a cement for joints, composed of cast-iron
borings or filings, sal ammoniac, etc.</cd> -- <col>Iron
clay</col> <fld>(Min.)</fld>, <cd>a yellowish clay containing a
large proportion of an ore of iron.</cd> -- <col>Iron
cross</col>, <cd>a Prussian order of military merit; also, the
decoration of the order.</cd> -- <col>Iron crown</col>, <cd>a
golden crown set with jewels, belonging originally to the Lombard
kings, and indicating the dominion of Italy. It was so called
from containing a circle said to have been forged from one of the
nails in the cross of Christ.</cd> -- <col>Iron flint</col>
<fld>(Min.)</fld>, <cd>an opaque, flintlike, ferruginous variety
of quartz.</cd> -- <col>Iron founder</col>, <cd>a maker of iron
castings.</cd> -- <col>Iron foundry</col>, <cd>the place where
iron castings are made.</cd> -- <col>Iron furnace</col>, <cd>a
furnace for reducing iron from the ore, or for melting iron for
castings, etc.; a forge; a reverberatory; a bloomery.</cd> --
<col>Iron glance</col> <fld>(Min.)</fld>, <cd>hematite.</cd> --
<col>Iron hat</col>, <cd>a headpiece of iron or steel, shaped
like a hat with a broad brim, and used as armor during the Middle
Ages.</cd> -- <col>Iron horse</col>, <cd>a locomotive
engine.</cd> <mark>[Colloq.]</mark> -- <col>Iron
liquor</col></mcol>, <cd>a solution of an iron salt, used as a
mordant by dyers.</cd> -- <col>Iron man</col> <fld>(Cotton
Manuf.)</fld>, <cd>a name for the self-acting spinning mule.</cd>
-- <mcol><col>Iron mold</col> <or/ <col>mould</col></mcol>, <cd>a
yellow spot on cloth stained by rusty iron.</cd> -- <col>Iron
ore</col> <fld>(Min.)</fld>, <cd>any native compound of iron from
which the metal may be profitably extracted. The principal ores
are magnetite, hematite, siderite, limonite, G\'94thite, turgite,
and the bog and clay iron ores.</cd> -- <col>Iron pyrites</col>
<fld>(Min.)</fld>, <cd>common pyrites, or pyrite. See
<er>Pyrites</er>.</cd> -- <col>Iron sand</col>, <cd>an iron ore
in grains, usually the magnetic iron ore, formerly used to sand
paper after writing.</cd> -- <col>Iron scale</col>, <cd>the thin
film which on the surface of wrought iron in the process of
forging. It consists essentially of the magnetic oxide of iron,
<chform>Fe3O4></chform>.</cd> -- <col>Iron works</col>, <cd>a
furnace where iron is smelted, or a forge, rolling mill, or
foundry, where it is made into heavy work, such as shafting,
rails, cannon, merchant bar, etc.</cd></cs>

<hw>I"ron</hw>, <pos>v. t.</pos> <wordforms>[<pos>imp. & p.
p.</pos> <er>Ironed</er> <pr>(?)</pr>; <pos>p. pr. & vb. n.</pos>
<er>Ironing</er>.]</wordforms>

<sn>1.</sn> <def>To smooth with an instrument of iron;
especially, to smooth, as cloth, with a heated flatiron; --
sometimes used with <xex>out.</def>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>To shackle with irons; to fetter or
handcuff.</def> \'bd<xex>Ironed</xex> like a malefactor.\'b8

<au>Sir W. Scott.</au>

<sn>3.</sn> <def>To furnish or arm with iron; <as>as, to
<ex>iron</ex> a wagon</as>.</def>

<-- iron out differences = resolve differences; settle a dispute.
-->

<hw>I"ron*bark` tree`</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>. <fld>(Bot.)</fld>
<def>The Australian <spn>Eucalyptus Sideroxylon</spn>, used
largely by carpenters and shipbuilders; -- called also
<altname>ironwood</altname>.</def>

<hw>I"ron*bound`</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>a.</pos> <sn>1.</sn>
<def>Bound as with iron; rugged; <as>as, an <ex>ironbound</ex>
coast</as>.</def>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>Rigid; unyielding; <as>as, <ex>ironbound</ex>
traditions</as>.</def>

<hw>I"ron-cased`</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>a.</pos> <def>Cased or
covered with iron, as a vessel; ironclad.</def>

<hw>I"ron*clad`</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>a.</pos> <sn>1.</sn>
<def>Clad in iron; protected or covered with iron, as a vessel
for naval warfare.</def>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>Rigorous; severe; exacting; <as>as, an
<ex>ironclad</ex> oath or pledge</as>.</def>
<mark>[Colloq.]</mark>

<hw>I"ron*clad`</hw>, <pos>n.</pos> <def>A naval vessel having
the parts above water covered and protected by iron or steel
usually in large plates closely joined and made sufficiently
thick and strong to resist heavy shot.</def>

<hw>I"ron*er</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <def>One who, or
that which, irons.</def>

<hw>I"ron-fist`ed</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>a.</pos>
<def>Closefisted; stingy; mean.</def>

<hw>I"ron-gray`</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>a.</pos> <def>Of a gray
color, somewhat resembling that of iron freshly broken.</def> --
<def2><pos>n.</pos> <def>An iron-gray color; also, a horse of
this color.</def></def2>

<hw>I"ron*heads`</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos>
<fld>(Bot.)</fld> <def>A European composite herb (<spn>Centaurea
nigra</spn>); -- so called from the resemblance of its knobbed
head to an iron ball fixed on a long handle.</def>

<au>Dr. Prior.</au>

<hw>I"ron-heart`ed</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>a.</pos>
<def>Hard-hearted; unfeeling; cruel; <as>as, an
<ex>iron-hearted</ex> master</as>.</def>

<au>Cowper.</au>

<hw>I*ron"ic</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>a.</pos>
<def>Ironical.</def>

<au>Sir T. Herbert.</au>

<hw>I*ron"ic*al</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>a.</pos> <ety>[LL.
<ets>ironicus</ets>, Gr. <?/ dissembling: cf. F.
<ets>ironique</ets>. See <er>Irony</er>.]</ety>

<sn>1.</sn> <def>Pertaining to irony; containing, expressing, or
characterized by, irony; <as>as, an <ex>ironical</ex>
remark</as>.</def>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>Addicted to the use of irony; given to
irony.</def>

-- <wordforms><wf>I*ron"ic*al*ly</wf>, <pos>adv.</pos> --
<wf>I*ron"ic*al*ness</wf>, <pos>n.</pos></wordforms>

<hw>I"ron*ing</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <sn>1.</sn>
<def>The act or process of smoothing, as clothes, with hot
flatirons.</def>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>The clothes ironed.</def>

<cs><col>Ironing board</col>, <cd>a flat board, upon which
clothes are laid being ironed.</cd></cs>

<hw>I"ron-sick`</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>a.</pos>
<fld>(Naut.)</fld> <def>Having the ironwork loose or corroded; --
said of a ship when her bolts and nails are so eaten with rust
that she has become leaky.</def>

<hw>I"ron-sid`ed</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>a.</pos> <def>Having
iron sides, or very firm sides.</def>

<hw>I"ron*sides"</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n. <?/</pos> <def>A
cuirassier or cuirassiers; also, hardy veteran soldiers; --
applied specifically to Cromwell's cavalry.</def>

<-- Old Ironsides.  The U.S.S. Constitution, a ship which fought
in the American Revolutionary war, and now functions as a museum
in Boston harbor. -->

<hw>I"ron*smith`</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <sn>1.</sn>
<def>A worker in iron; one who makes and repairs utensils of
iron; a blacksmith.</def>

<sn>2.</sn> <fld>(Zo\'94l.)</fld> <def>An East Indian barbet
(<spn>Megalaima faber</spn>), inhabiting the Island of Hainan.
The name alludes to its note, which resembles the sounds made by
a smith.</def>

<hw>I"ron*stone`</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <def>A hard,
earthy ore of iron.</def>

<cs><col>Clay ironstone</col>. <cd>See under <er>Clay</er>.</cd>
-- <col>Ironstone china</col>, <cd>a hard white pottery, first
made in England during the 18th century.</cd></cs>

<hw>I"ron*ware`</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <def>Articles
made of iron, as household utensils, tools, and the like.</def>

<hw>I"ron*weed`</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos>
<fld>(Bot.)</fld> <def>A tall weed with purplish flowers
(<spn>Vernonia Noveboracensis</spn>). The name is also applied to
other plants of the same genus.</def>

<hw>I"ron*wood`</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos>
<fld>(Bot.)</fld> <def>A tree unusually hard, strong, or heavy
wood.</def>

<note><hand/ In the United States, the hornbeam and the hop
hornbeam are so called; also the <spn>Olneya Tesota</spn>, a
small tree of Arizona; in the West Indies, the <spn>Erythroxylon
areolatum</spn>, and several other unrelated trees; in China, the
<spn>Metrosideros vera</spn>; in India, the <spn>Mesua
ferrea</spn>, and two species of <spn>Inga</spn>; in Australia,
the <spn>Eucalyptus Sideroxylon</spn>, and in many countries,
species of <spn>Sideroxylon</spn> and <spn>Diospyros</spn>, and
many other trees.</note>

<hw>I"ron*work`</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <def>Anything
made of iron; -- a general name of such parts or pieces of a
building, vessel, carriage, etc., as consist of iron.</def>

<hw>I"ron works`</hw><def>. See under <er>Iron</er>,
<pos>a.</pos></def>

<hw>I"ron*wort`</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos>
<fld>(Bot.)</fld> <def>An herb of the Mint family
(<spn>Sideritis</spn>), supposed to heal sword cuts; also, a
species of <spn>Galeopsis</spn>.</def>

<hw>I"ron*y</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>a.</pos> <ety>[From

particles.</as></def> <mark>[R.]</mark>
<-- in this sense iron is more common. -->

<au>Woodward.</au>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>Resembling iron taste, hardness, or other
physical property.</def>

<hw>I"ron*y</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos><ety>[L.
<ets>ironia</ets>, Gr. <?/ dissimulation, fr. <?/ a dissembler in
speech, fr. <?/ to speak; perh. akin to E. <ets>word</ets>: cf.
F. <ets>ironie</ets>.]</ety>

<sn>1.</sn> <def>Dissimulation; ignorance feigned for the purpose
of confounding or provoking an antagonist.</def>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>A sort of humor, ridicule, or light sarcasm,
which adopts a mode of speech the meaning of which is contrary to
the literal sense of the words.</def>

<hw>Ir`o*quois"</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n. sing. & pl.</pos>
<ety>[F.]</ety> <fld>(Ethnol.)</fld> <def>A powerful and warlike
confederacy of Indian tribes, formerly inhabiting Central New
York and constituting most of the Five Nations. Also, any Indian
of the Iroquois tribes.</def>

<mhw>{ <hw>Ir*ra"di*ance</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>,
<hw>Ir*ra"di*an*cy</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, }</mhw> <pos>n.</pos>
<ety>[From <er>Irradiant</er>.]</ety>

<sn>1.</sn> <def>The act of irradiating; emission of rays of
light.</def>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>That which irradiates or is irradiated; luster;
splendor; irradiation; brilliancy.</def>

<au>Milton.</au>

<hw>Ir*ra"di*ant</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>a.</pos> <ety>[L.
<ets>irradians</ets>, <ets>-antis</ets>, p. pr. See
<er>Irradiate</er>.]</ety> <def>Irradiating or illuminating;
<as>as, the <ex>irradiant</ex> moon</as>.</def>

<au>Boyse.</au>

<hw>Ir*ra"di*ate</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>v. t.</pos>
<wordforms>[<pos>imp. & p. p.</pos> <er>Irradiated</er>
<pr>(?)</pr>; <pos>p. pr. & vb. n.</pos> <er>Irradiating</er>
<pr>(?)</pr>.]</wordforms> <ety>[L. <ets>irradiatus</ets>, p. p.
of irradiate. See <er>In-</er> <ets>in</ets>, and
<er>Radiate</er>.]</ety>

<sn>1.</sn> <def>To throw rays of light upon; to illuminate; to
brighten; to adorn with luster.</def>

<q>Thy smile <qex>irradiates</qex> yon blue fields.</q>
<qau>Sir W. Jones.</qau>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>To enlighten intellectually; to illuminate;
<as>as, to <ex>irradiate</ex> the mind</as>.</def>

<au>Bp. Bull.</au>

<sn>3.</sn> <def>To animate by heat or light.</def>

<au>Sir M. Hale.</au>

<sn>4.</sn> <def>To radiate, shed, or diffuse.</def>

<q>A splendid fa<?/ade, . . . <qex>irradiating</qex>
hospitality.</q>
<qau>H. James.</qau>

<hw>Ir*ra"di*ate</hw>, <pos>v. i.</pos> <def>To emit rays; to
shine.</def>

<hw>Ir*ra"di*ate</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>a.</pos> <ety>[L.
<ets>irradiatus</ets>, p. p.]</ety> <def>Illuminated;
irradiated.</def>

<au>Mason.</au>

<hw>Ir*ra`di*a"tion</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[Cf. F.
<ets>irradiation</ets>.]</ety>

<sn>1.</sn> <def>Act of irradiating, or state of being
irradiated.</def>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>Illumination; irradiance; brilliancy.</def>

<au>Sir W. Scott.</au>

<sn>3.</sn> <def>Fig.: Mental light or illumination.</def>

<au>Sir M. Hale.</au>

<sn>4.</sn> <fld>(Opt.)</fld> <def>The apparent enlargement of a
bright object seen upon a dark ground, due to the fact that the
portions of the retina around the image are stimulated by the
intense light; as when a dark spot on a white ground appears
smaller, or a white spot on a dark ground larger, than it really
is, esp. when a little out of focus.</def>

<hw>Ir*rad"i*cate</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>v. t.</pos> <def>To
root deeply.</def> <mark>[R.]</mark>

<hw>Ir*ra"tion*al</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>a.</pos> <ety>[L.
<ets>irrationalis</ets>: cf. F. <ets>irrationnel</ets>. See
<er>In-</er> not, and <er>Rational</er>.]</ety>

<sn>1.</sn> <def>Not rational; void of reason or understanding;
<as>as, brutes are <ex>irrational</ex> animals</as>.</def>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>Not according to reason; absurd; foolish.</def>

<q>It seemed utterly <qex>irrational</qex> any longer to maintain
it.</q>
<qau>I. Taylor.</qau>

<sn>3.</sn> <fld>(Math.)</fld> <def>Not capable of being exactly
expressed by an integral number, or by a vulgar fraction; surd;
-- said especially of roots. See <er>Surd</er>.</def>

<syn>Syn. -- Absurd; foolish; preposterous; unreasonable;
senseless. See <er>Absurd</er>.</syn>

<hw>Ir`re*du`ci*bil"i*ty</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos>
<def>The state or quality of being irreducible.</def>

<hw>Ir`re*du"ci*ble</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>a.</pos> <sn>1.</sn>
<def>Incapable of being reduced, or brought into a different
state; incapable of restoration to its proper or normal
condition; <as>as, an <ex>irreducible</ex> hernia</as>.</def>

<sn>2.</sn> <fld>(Math.)</fld> <def>Incapable of being reduced to
a simpler form of expression; <as>as, an <ex>irreducible</ex>
formula</as>.</def>

<cs><col>Irreducible case</col> <fld>(Alg.)</fld>, <cd>a
particular case in the solution of a cubic equation, in which the
formula commonly employed contains an imaginary quantity, and
therefore fails in its application.</cd></cs>

<wf>Ir`re*du"ci*bly</wf>, <pos>adv.</pos></wordforms>

<ex>irrefragable</ex> argument; <ex>irrefragable</ex>

<wf>Ir*ref"ra*ga*bly</wf>, <pos>adv.</pos></wordforms>

<hw>Ir*reg"u*lar</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>a.</pos> <ety>[Pref.
<ets>ir-</ets> not + <ets>regular</ets>: cf. F.
<ets>irr\'82gulier</ets>.]</ety> <def>Not regular; not conforming
to a law, method, or usage recognized as the general rule; not
according to common form; not conformable to nature, to the rules
of moral rectitude, or to established principles; not normal;
unnatural; immethodical; unsymmetrical; erratic; no straight; not
uniform; <as>as, an <ex>irregular</ex> line; an
<ex>irregular</ex> figure; an <ex>irregular</ex> verse; an
<ex>irregular</ex> physician; an <ex>irregular</ex> proceeding;
<ex>irregular</ex> motion; <ex>irregular</ex> conduct, etc. Cf.
<er>Regular</er>.</as></def>

<q>Mazes intricate,
Eccentric, intervolved, yet regular
Then most when most <qex>irregular</qex> they seem.</q>
<qau>Milton.</qau>

<q>Leading the men of Herefordshire to fight
Against the <qex>irregular</qex> and wild Glendower.</q>
<qau>Shak.</qau>

<q>A flowery meadow through which a clear stream murmured in many
<qex>irregular</qex> meanders.</q>
<qau>Jones.</qau>

<syn>Syn. -- Immethodical; unsystematic; abnormal; unnatural;
anomalous; erratic; devious; crooked; eccentric; unsettled;
uneven; variable; changeable; mutable; desultory; disorderly;
wild; immoderate; intemperate; inordinate; vicious.</syn>

<hw>Ir*reg"u*lar</hw>, <pos>n.</pos> <def>One who is not regular;
especially, a soldier not in regular service.</def>

<hw>Ir*reg"u*lar*ist</hw>, <pos>n.</pos> <def>One who is
irregular.</def>

<au>Baxter.</au>

<hw>Ir*reg`u*lar"i*ty</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos>; <plu>pl.
<plw>Irregularities</plw> <pr>(#)</pr></plu>. <ety>[Cf. F.
<ets>irr\'82gularit\'82</ets>.]</ety> <def>The state or quality
of being irregular; that which is irregular.</def>

<hw>Ir*reg"u*lar*ly</hw>, <pos>adv.</pos> <def>In an irregular
manner.</def>

<hw>Ir*reg"u*late</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>v. t.</pos> <def>To
make irregular; to disorder.</def> <mark>[Obs.]</mark>

<au>Sir T. Browne.</au>

<hw>Ir*reg"u*lous</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>a.</pos>
<def>Lawless.</def> <mark>[Obs.]</mark>

<au>Shak.</au>

<hw>Ir`re*ject"a*ble</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>a.</pos> <def>That
can not be rejected; irresistible.</def>

<au>Boyle.</au>

<hw>Ir`re*laps"a*ble</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>a.</pos> <def>Not
liable to relapse; secure.</def>

<pr>(?)</pr>.]</wordforms> <ety>[L. <ets>irrigatus</ets>, p. p.
of <ets>irrigare</ets> to irrigate: <ets>ir-</ets> in +
<ets>rigare</ets> to water; prob. akin to E. <ets>rain</ets>. See
<er>Rain</er>.]</ety>

<sn>1.</sn> <def>To water; to wet; to moisten with running or
dropping water; to bedew.</def>

<sn>2.</sn> <fld>(Agric.)</fld> <def>To water, as land, by
causing a stream to flow upon, over, or through it, as in
artificial channels.</def>

<hw>Ir`ri*ga"tion</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[L.
<ets>irrigatio</ets>: cf. F. <ets>irrigation</ets>.]</ety>
<def>The act or process of irrigating, or the state of being
irrigated; especially, the operation of causing water to flow
over lands, for nourishing plants.</def>

<hw>Ir*rig"u*ous</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>a.</pos> <ety>[L.
<ets>irriguus</ets>. See <er>Irrigate</er>.]</ety>

<sn>1.</sn> <def>Watered; watery; moist; dewy.</def>
<mark>[Obs.]</mark>

<q>The flowery lap
Of some <qex>irriguous</qex> valley spreads her store.</q>
<qau>Milton.</qau>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>Gently penetrating or pervading.</def>
<mark>[Obs.]</mark>

<au>J. Philips.</au>

<hw>Ir*ris"i*ble</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>a.</pos> <ety>[Pref.
<ets>ir-</ets> not + <ets>risible</ets>. See
<er>Irrision</er>.]</ety> <def>Not risible.</def>
<mark>[R.]</mark>

<hw>Ir*ri"sion</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[L.
<ets>irrisio</ets>, fr. <ets>irridere</ets>, <ets>irrisum</ets>.
to laugh at; pref. <ets>ir-</ets> in + <ets>ridere</ets> to
laugh: cf. F. <ets>irrision</ets>.]</ety> <def>The act of
laughing at another; derision.</def>

<q>This being spoken <qex>sceptic\'8a</qex>, or by way of
<qex>irrision</qex>.</q>
<qau>Chapman.</qau>

<hw>Ir`ri*ta*bil"i*ty</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[L.
<ets>irritabilitas</ets>: cf. F.
<ets>irritabilit\'82</ets>.]</ety>

<sn>1.</sn> <def>The state or quality of being irritable; quick
excitability; petulance; fretfulness; <as>as,
<ex>irritability</ex> of temper</as>.</def>

<sn>2.</sn> <fld>(Physiol.)</fld> <def>A natural susceptibility,
characteristic of all living organisms, tissues, and cells, to
the influence of certain stimuli, response being manifested in a
variety of ways, -- as that quality in plants by which they
exhibit motion under suitable stimulation; esp., the property
which living muscle processes, of responding either to a direct
stimulus of its substance, or to the stimulating influence of its
nerve fibers, the response being indicated by a change of form,
or contraction; contractility.</def>

<sn>3.</sn> <fld>(Med.)</fld> <def>A condition of morbid
excitability of an organ or part of the body; undue
susceptibility to the influence of stimuli. See
<er>Irritation</er>, <pos>n.</pos>, 3.</def>

<hw>Ir"ri*ta*ble</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>a.</pos> <ety>[L.
<ets>irritabilis</ets>: cf. F. <ets>irritable</ets>. See
<er>Irritate</er>.]</ety>

<sn>1.</sn> <def>Capable of being irriated.</def>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>Very susceptible of anger or passion; easily
inflamed or exasperated; <as>as, an <ex>irritable</ex>
temper</as>.</def>

<q>Vicious, old, and <qex>irritable</qex>.</q>
<qau>Tennyson.</qau>

<sn>3.</sn> <fld>(Physiol.)</fld> <def>Endowed with irritability;
susceptible of irritation; capable of being excited to action by
the application of certain stimuli.</def>

<sn>4.</sn> <fld>(Med.)</fld> <def>Susceptible of irritation;
unduly sensitive to irritants or stimuli. See
<er>Irritation</er>, <pos>n.</pos>, 3.</def>

<syn>Syn. -- Excitable; irascible; touchy; fretful;
peevish.</syn>

<hw>Ir"ri*ta*ble*ness</hw>, <pos>n.</pos>
<def>Irritability.</def>

<hw>Ir"ri*ta*bly</hw>, <pos>adv.</pos> <def>In an irritable
manner.</def>

<hw>Ir"ri*tan*cy</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[From 1st
<er>Irritant</er>.]</ety> <fld>(Scots Law)</fld> <def>The state
or quality of being null and void; invalidity; forfeiture.</def>

<au>Burrill.</au>

<hw>Ir"ri*tan*cy</hw>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[From 2d
<er>Irritant</er>.]</ety> <def>The state o quality of being
irritant or irritating.</def>

<hw>Ir"ri*tant</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>a.</pos> <ety>[LL.
<ets>irritants</ets>, <ets>-antis</ets>, p. pr. of
<ets>irritare</ets> to make null, fr. L. <ets>irritus</ets> void;
pref. <ets>ir-</ets> not + <ets>ratus</ets> established.]</ety>
<fld>(Scots Law)</fld> <def>Rendering null and void;
conditionally invalidating.</def>

<q>The states elected Harry, Duke of Anjou, for their king, with
this clause <qex>irritant</qex>; that, if he did violate any part
of his oath, the people should owe him no allegiance.</q>
<qau>Hayward.</qau>

<hw>Ir"ri*tant</hw>, <pos>a.</pos> <ety>[L. <ets>irritans</ets>,
<ets>-antis</ets>, p. pr. of <ets>irritare</ets>: cf. F.
<ets>irritant</ets>. See <er>Irritate</er> to excite.]</ety>
<def>Irritating; producing irritation or inflammation.</def>

<hw>Ir"ri*tant</hw>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[Cf. F.
<ets>irritant</ets>.]</ety>

<sn>1.</sn> <def>That which irritates or excites.</def>

<sn>2.</sn> <fld>(Physiol. & Med.)</fld> <def>Any agent by which
irritation is produced; <as>as, a chemical <ex>irritant</ex>; a
mechanical or electrical <ex>irritant</ex>.</as></def>

<sn>3.</sn> <fld>(Toxicology)</fld> <def>A poison that produces
inflammation.</def>

<cs><col>Counter irritant</col>. <cd>See under
<er>Counter</er>.</cd> -- <col>Pure irritant</col>
<fld>(Toxicology)</fld>, <cd>a poison that produces inflammation
without any corrosive action upon the tissues.</cd></cs>

<hw>Ir"ri*tate</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>v. t.</pos> <ety>[See 1 st
<er>Irritant</er>.]</ety> <def>To render null and void.</def>
<mark>[R.]</mark>

<au>Abp. Bramhall.</au>

<hw>Ir"ri*tate</hw>, <pos>v. t.</pos> <wordforms>[<pos>imp. & p.
p.</pos> <er>Irritated</er> <pr>(?)</pr>; <pos>p. pr. & vb.
n.</pos> <er>Irritating</er> <pr>(?)</pr>.]</wordforms> <ety>[L.
<ets>irritatus</ets>, p. p. of <ets>irritare</ets>. Of doubtful
origin.]</ety>

<sn>1.</sn> <def>To increase the action or violence of; to
heighten excitement in; to intensify; to stimulate.</def>

<q>Cold maketh the spirits vigorous and <qex>irritateth</qex>
them.</q>
<qau>Bacon.</qau>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>To excite anger or displeasure in; to provoke;
to tease; to exasperate; to annoy; to vex; <as>as, the insolence
of a tyrant <ex>irritates</ex> his subjects</as>.</def>

<q>Dismiss the man, nor <qex>irritate</qex> the god:
Prevent the rage of him who reigns above.</q>
<qau>Pope.</qau>

<sn>3.</sn> <fld>(Physiol.)</fld> <def>To produce irritation in;
to stimulate; to cause to contract. See <er>Irritation</er>,
<pos>n.</pos>, 2.</def>

<sn>4.</sn> <fld>(Med.)</fld> <def>To make morbidly excitable, or
oversensitive; to fret; <as>as, the skin is <ex>irritated</ex> by
friction; to <ex>irritate</ex> a wound by a coarse
bandage.</as></def>

<syn>Syn. -- To fret; inflame; excite; provoke; tease; vex;
exasperate; anger; incense; enrage.</syn> <usage> -- To
<er>Irritate</er>, <er>Provoke</er>, <er>Exasperate</er>. These
words express different stages of excited or angry feeling.
<xex>Irritate</xex> denotes an excitement of quick and slightly
angry feeling which is only momentary; <as>as, <ex>irritated</ex>
by a hasty remark</as>. To <xex>provoke</xex> implies the
awakening of some open expression of decided anger; <as>as, a
<ex>provoking</ex> insult</as>. <xex>Exasperate</xex> denotes a
provoking of anger at something unendurable. Whatever comes
across our feelings <xex>irritates</xex>; whatever excites anger
<xex>provokes</xex>; whatever raises anger to a high point
<xex>exasperates</xex>. \'bdSusceptible and nervous people are
most easily <xex>irritated</xex>; proud people are quickly
<xex>provoked</xex>; hot and fiery people are soonest
<xex>exasperated</xex>.\'b8
<au>Crabb.</au></usage>

<hw>Ir"ri*tate</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>a.</pos> <def>Excited;
heightened.</def> <mark>[Obs.]</mark>

<hw>Ir`ri*ta"tion</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[L.
<ets>irritatio</ets>: cf. F. <ets>irritation</ets>.]</ety>

<sn>1.</sn> <def>The act of irritating, or exciting, or the state
of being irritated; excitement; stimulation, usually of an undue
and uncomfortable kind; especially, excitement of anger or
passion; provocation; annoyance; anger.</def>

<q>The whole body of the arts and sciences composes one vast
machinery for the <qex>irritation</qex> and development of the
human intellect.</q>
<qau>De Quincey.</qau>

<sn>2.</sn> <fld>(Physiol.)</fld> <def>The act of exciting, or
the condition of being excited to action, by stimulation; -- as,
the condition of an organ of sense, when its nerve is affected by
some external body; esp., the act of exciting muscle fibers to
contraction, by artificial stimulation; <as>as, the
<ex>irritation</ex> of a motor nerve by electricity</as>; also,
the condition of a muscle and nerve, under such
stimulation.</def>

<sn>3.</sn> <fld>(Med.)</fld> <def>A condition of morbid
excitability or oversensitiveness of an organ or part of the
body; a state in which the application of ordinary stimuli
produces pain or excessive or vitiated action.</def>

<hw>Ir"ri*ta*tive</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>a.</pos> <sn>1.</sn>
<def>Serving to excite or irritate; irritating; <as>as, an
<ex>irritative</ex> agent</as>.</def>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>Accompanied with, or produced by, increased
action or irritation; <as>as, an <ex>irritative</ex>
fever</as>.</def>

<au>E. Darwin.</au>

<hw>Ir"ri*ta*to*ry</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>a.</pos>
<def>Exciting; producing irritation; irritating.</def>
<mark>[R.]</mark>

<au>Hales.</au>

<hw>Ir*rupt"ed</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>a.</pos> <ety>[L.

<sn>1.</sn> <def>A bursting in; a sudden, violent rushing into a

<q>Lest evil tidings, with too rude <qex>irruption</qex>
Hitting thy aged ear, should pierce too deep.</q>
<qau>Milton.</qau>

<hw>Ir"ving*ite</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos>
<fld>(Eccl.)</fld> <def>The common designation of one a sect
founded by the Rev. Edward Irving (about 1830), who call
themselves the Catholic Apostolic Church. They are highly
ritualistic in worship, have an elaborate hierarchy of apostles,
prophets, etc., and look for the speedy coming of Christ.</def>

<hw>Is-</hw> <pr>(?)</pr><def>. See <er>Iso-</er>.</def>

<hw>Is</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>v. i.</pos> <ety>[AS.
<ets>is</ets>; akin to G. & Goth. <ets>ist</ets>, L.
<ets>est</ets>, Gr. <?/, Skr. <ets>asti</ets>. <ets><?/<?/</ets>.
Cf. <er>Am</er>, <er>Entity</er>, <er>Essence</er>,
<er>Absent</er>.]</ety> <def>The third person singular of the
substantive verb <xex>be</xex>, in the indicative mood, present
tense; <as>as, he <ex>is</ex>; he <ex>is</ex> a man</as>.  See
<er>Be</er>.</def>

<note><hand/ In some varieties of the Northern dialect of Old
English, <xex>is</xex> was used for all persons of the
singular.</note>

<q>For thy <qex>is</qex> I come, and eke Alain.</q>
<qau>Chaucer.</qau>

<q>Aye <qex>is</qex> thou merry.</q>
<qau>Chaucer.</qau>

<note><hand/ The idiom of using the present for future events
sure to happen is a relic of Old English in which the present and
future had the same form; as, this year Christmas <xex>is</xex>
on Friday.</note>

<q>To-morrow <qex>is</qex> the new moon.</q>
<qau>1 Sam. xx. 5.</qau>

Crustacea.</def>

<hw>I*seth`i*on"ic</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>a.</pos>

<hw>-ish</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>. <ety>[AS. -<ets>isc</ets>; akin to G.
-<ets>isch</ets>, OHG. -<ets>isc</ets>, Goth. & Dan.
-<ets>isk</ets>, Gr. <?/. Cf. <er>-esque</er>.]</ety> <def>A
suffix used to from adjectives from nouns and from adjectives. It
denotes <xex>relation</xex>, <xex>resemblance</xex>,
<xex>similarity</xex>, and sometimes has a <xex>diminutive</xex>
force; <as>as, self<ex>ish</ex>, boy<ex>ish</ex>,
brut<ex>ish</ex>; whit<ex>ish</ex>, somewhat white.</as></def>

<hw>-ish</hw>. <ety>[OE. -<ets>issen</ets>, fr. F.
-<ets>is</ets>, -<ets>iss-</ets> (found in the present particle,
etc., of certain verbs, as <ets>finir</ets> to finish,
<ets>fleurir</ets> to flourish), corresponding to L.
-<ets>escere</ets>, an inchoative ending.]</ety> <def>A verb

impover<ex>ish</ex></as>.</def>

<hw>Ish"ma*el*ite</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <sn>1.</sn>

<hw>I"sin*glass</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[Prob.
corrupted fr. D. <ets>huizenblas</ets> (akin to G.
<ets>hausenblase</ets>), lit., bladder of the huso, or large
sturgeon; <ets>huizen</ets> sturgeon  + <ets>blas</ets> bladder.
Cf. <er>Bladder</er>, <er>Blast</er> a gust of wind.]</ety>

<sn>1.</sn> <def>A semitransparent, whitish, and very pure from
of gelatin, chiefly prepared from the sounds or air bladders of
various species of sturgeons (as the <spn>Acipenser huso</spn>)
found in the of Western Russia. It used for making jellies, as a
clarifier, etc. Cheaper forms of gelatin are not unfrequently so
called. Called also <altname>fish glue</altname>.</def>

<sn>2.</sn> <fld>(Min.)</fld> <def>A popular name for mica,
especially when in thin sheets.</def>

<hw>I"sis</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[L., the goddess
Isis, fr. Gr. <?/.]</ety>

<sn>1.</sn> <fld>(Myth.)</fld> <def>The principal goddess
worshiped by the Egyptians. She was regarded as the mother of
Horus, and the sister and wife of Osiris. The Egyptians adored
her as the goddess of fecundity, and as the great benefactress of
their country, who instructed their ancestors in the art of
agriculture.</def>

<sn>2.</sn> <fld>(Zo\'94l.)</fld> <def>Any coral of the genus
Isis, or family <xex>Isid\'91</xex>, composed of joints of white,
stony coral, alternating with flexible, horny joints. See
<er>Gorgoniacea</er>.</def>

<sn>3.</sn> <fld>(Astron.)</fld> <def>One of the asteroids.</def>

<hw>Is"lam</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[Ar.
<ets>isl\'bem</ets> obedience to the will of God, submission,
humbling one's self, resigning one's self to the divine disposal.
Cf. <er>Moslem</er>.]</ety>

<sn>1.</sn> <def>The religion of the Mohammedans; Mohammedanism;
Islamism. Their formula of faith is: There is no God but Allah,
and Mohammed is his prophet.</def>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>The whole body of Mohammedans, or the countries
which they occupy.</def>

<hw>Is"land</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[OE.
<ets>iland</ets>, <ets>yland</ets>, AS. <ets>\'c6gland</ets>,
<ets><?/gland</ets>, <ets><?/glond</ets>; <ets>\'c6g</ets>,
<ets><?/g</ets>, island + <ets>land</ets>, <ets>lond</ets>, land.
AS. <ets>\'c6g</ets>, <ets><?/g</ets>, is akin to AS.
<ets>e\'a0</ets> water, river, OHG. <ets><?/uwa</ets>, G.
<ets>au</ets> meadow, Icel. <ets>ey</ets> island, Dan. & Sw.
<ets>\'94</ets>, Goth. <ets>ahwa</ets> a stream, water, L.
<ets>aqua</ets> water. The <ets>s</ets> is due to confusion with
<ets>isle</ets>. Cf. <er>Ait</er>, <er>Eyot</er>, <er>Ewer</er>,
<er>Aquatic</er>.]</ety>

<sn>1.</sn> <def>A tract of land surrounded by water, and smaller
than a continent. Cf. <er>Continent</er>.</def>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>Anything regarded as resembling an island;
<as>as, an <ex>island</ex> of ice</as>.</def>

<sn>3.</sn> <fld>(Zo\'94l.)</fld> <def>See <er>Isle</er>,
<pos>n.</pos>, 2.</def>

<cs><col>Islands of the blessed</col> <fld>(Myth.)</fld>,
<cd>islands supposed to lie in the Western Ocean, where the
favorites of the gods are conveyed at death, and dwell in
everlasting joy.</cd></cs>

<hw>Is"land</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>v. t.</pos> <sn>1.</sn>

<hw>-ism</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>. <ety>[F. -<ets>isme</ets>, or L.

<mhw>{ <hw>I"so-</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <hw>Is-</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>.
}</mhw><ety>[Gr. <grk>'i`sos</grk> equal.]</ety> <def>A prefix or
combining form, indicating <xex>identity</xex>, or
<xex>equality</xex>; <xex>the same numerical value</xex>; as in
<xex>iso</xex>pod, <xex>iso</xex>morphous,
<xex>iso</xex>chromatic</def>. Specif.: <sd>(a)</sd>
<fld>(Chem.)</fld> <def>Applied to certain compounds having the
same composition but different properties; as in
<xex>iso</xex>cyanic</def>. <sd>(b)</sd> <fld>(Organic
Chem.)</fld> <def>Applied to compounds of certain isomeric series
in whose structure one carbon atom, at least, is connected with
three other carbon atoms; -- contrasted with <xex>neo-</xex> and
<xex>normal</xex>; as in <xex>iso</xex>paraffine;
<xex>iso</xex>pentane.</def>

level is the same either at a given time, or for a certain period

<hw>I`so*cy*an"ic</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>a.</pos>
<ety>[<ets>Iso-</ets> + <ets>cyanic</ets>.]</ety>
<fld>(Chem.)</fld> <def>Designating an acid isomeric with cyanic

<cs><col>Isocyanic acid</col>, <cd>an acid metameric with cyanic
acid, and resembling it in its salts. It is obtained as a
colorless, mobile, unstable liquid by the heating cyanuric acid.
Called technically <altname>carbimide</altname>.</cd></cs>

<hw>I`so*cy`a*nu"ric</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>a.</pos>

<hw>I`so*di`a*bat"ic</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>a.</pos>
<ety>[<ets>Iso-</ets> + Gr. <?/ to pass through.]</ety>
<fld>(Physics)</fld> <def>Pertaining to the reception or the
giving out of equal quantities of heat by a substance.</def>

<au>Rankine.</au>

<cs><mcol><col>Isodiabatic lines</col> <or/
<col>curves</col></mcol>, <cd>a pair of lines or curves
exhibiting, on a diagram of energy, the law of variation of the
pressure and density of a fluid, the one during the lowering, and
the other during the raising, of its temperature, when the
quantity of heat given out by the fluid during any given stage of
the one process is equal to the quantity received during the
corresponding stage of the other. Such lines are said to be
<xex>isodiabatic<xex> with respect to each other. Compare
<er>Adiabatic</er>.</cd></cs>

<hw>I`so*di`a*met"ric</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>a.</pos>
<ety>[<ets>Iso-</ets> + <ets>diametric</ets>.]</ety>

<sn>1.</sn> <fld>(Crystallog.)</fld> <def>Developed alike in the
directions of the several lateral axes; -- said of crystals of
both the tetragonal and hexagonal systems.</def>

<sn>2.</sn> <fld>(Bot.)</fld> <def>Having the several diameters
nearly equal; -- said of the cells of ordinary parenchyma.</def>

<hw>I`so*di*mor"phic</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>a.</pos>
<ety>[<ets>Iso-</ets> + <ets>dimorphic</ets>.]</ety>
<def>Isodimorphous.</def>

<hw>I`so*di*mor"phism</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos>
<def>Isomorphism between the two forms severally of two
dimorphous substances.</def>

<hw>I`so*di*mor"phous</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>a.</pos>
<ety>[<ets>Iso-</ets> + <ets>dimorphous</ets>.]</ety> <def>Having
the quality of isodimorphism.</def>

<hw>I`so*dul"cite</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos>
<ety>[<ets>Iso-</ets> + <ets>dulcite</ets>.]</ety>
<fld>(Chem.)</fld> <def>A white, crystalline, sugarlike
substance, obtained by the decomposition of certain glucosides,
and intermediate in nature between the hexacid alcohols
(<xex>ductile</xex>, <xex>mannite</xex>, etc.) and the
glucoses.</def>

<hw>I`so*dy*nam"ic</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>a.</pos>
<ety>[<ets>Iso-</ets> + <ets>dynamic</ets>.]</ety> <def>Of,
pertaining to, having, or denoting, equality of force.</def>

<cs><col>Isodynamic foods</col> <fld>(Physiol.)</fld>, <cd>those
foods that produce a similar amount of heat.</cd> --
<col>Isodynamic lines</col> <fld>(Magnetism)</fld>, <cd>lines on
the earth's surface connecting places at which the magnetic
intensity is the same.</cd></cs>

<hw>I`so*dy"na*mous</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>a.</pos> <ety>[Gr.
<?/. See <er>Isodynamic</er>.]</ety> <def>Of equal force or
size.</def>

<hw>I`so*ge"o*therm</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos>
<ety>[<ets>Iso-</ets> + Gr. <grk>gh^</grk> the earth +
<grk>qe`rmh</grk> heat.]</ety> <fld>(Phys. Geog.)</fld> <def>A
line or curved surface passing beneath the earth's surface
through points having the same mean temperature.</def>

<mhw>{ <hw>I`so*ge`o*ther"mal</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>,
<hw>I`so*ge`o*ther"mic</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, }</mhw> <pos>a.</pos>
<def>Pertaining to, having the nature of, or marking,

as <ex>isogeothermal</ex> chart.</as></def> --

<hw>I`so*gon"ic</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>a.</pos>
<ety>[<ets>Iso-</ets> + Gr. <?/ angle.]</ety> <def>Pertaining to,
or noting, equal angles.</def>

<cs><col>Isogonic lines</col> <fld>(Magnetism)</fld>, <cd>lines
traced on the surface of the globe, or upon a chart, connecting
places at which the deviation of the magnetic needle from the
meridian or true north is the same.</cd></cs>

<hw>I"so*la*ble</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>a.</pos> <ety>[See
<er>Isolate</er>.]</ety> <fld>(Chem.)</fld> <def>Capable of being

<hw>I"so*late</hw> <pr>(?; 277)</pr>, <pos>v. t.</pos>
<wordforms>[<pos>imp. & p. p.</pos> <er>Isolated</er>
<pr>(?)</pr>; <pos>p. pr. & vb. n.</pos> <er>Isolating</er>
<pr>(?)</pr>.]</wordforms> <ety>[It. <ets>isolato</ets>, p. p. of
<ets>isolare</ets> to isolate, fr. <ets>isola</ets> island, L.
<ets>insula</ets>. See 2d <er>Isle</er>, and cf.
<er>Insulate</er>.]</ety>

<sn>1.</sn> <def>To place in a detached situation; to place by
itself or alone; to insulate; to separate from others.</def>

<q>Short <qex>isolated</qex> sentences were the mode in which
ancient wisdom delighted to convey its precepts.</q>
<qau>Bp. Warburton.</qau>

<sn>2.</sn> <fld>(Elec.)</fld> <def>To insulate. See
<er>Insulate</er>.</def>

<sn>3.</sn> <fld>(Chem.)</fld> <def>To separate from all foreign
substances; to make pure; to obtain in a free state.</def>

<hw>I"so*la`ted</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>a.</pos> <def>Placed or
standing alone; detached; separated from others.</def>

<cs><col>Isolated point of a curve</col>. <fld>(Geom.)</fld>
<cd>See <er>Acnode</er>.</cd></cs>

<hw>I"so*la`ted*ly</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>adv.</pos> <def>In an
isolated manner.</def>

<hw>I`so*la"tion</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[Cf. F.
<ets>isolation</ets>.]</ety> <def>The act of isolating, or the
state of being isolated; insulation; separation;
loneliness.</def>

<au>Milman.</au>

<hw>I*sol"o*gous</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>a.</pos>
<ety>[<ets>Iso-</ets> + Gr. <?/ proportion.]</ety>
<fld>(Chem.)</fld> <def>Having similar proportions, similar
relations, or similar differences of composition; -- said
specifically of groups or series which differ by a constant
difference; <as>as, ethane, ethylene, an acetylene, or their
analogous compounds, form an <ex>isologous</ex>
series</as>.</def>

<hw>I"so*mer</hw>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[See
<er>Isomeric</er>.]</ety> <fld>(Chem.)</fld> <def>A body or
compound which is isomeric with another body or compound; a
member of an isomeric series.</def>

<hw>I`so*mer"ic</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>a.</pos>
<ety>[<ets>Iso-</ets> + Gr. <?/ part: cf. F.
<ets>isom\'82rique</ets>.]</ety> <fld>(Chem.)</fld> <def>Having
the same percentage composition; -- said of two or more different
substances which contain the same ingredients in the same
proportions by weight, often used with <xex>with</xex>. Specif.:
<sd>(a)</sd> Polymeric; <it>i. e.</it>, having the same elements
united in the same proportion by weight, but with different
molecular weights; <as>as, acetylene and benzine are
<ex>isomeric</ex> (<ex>polymeric</ex>) with each other in this
sense</as>. See <er>Polymeric</er>. <sd>(b)</sd> Metameric;
<it>i. e.</it>, having the same elements united in the same
proportions by weight, and with the same molecular weight, but
which a different structure or arrangement of the ultimate parts;
<as>as, ethyl alcohol and methyl ether are <ex>isomeric</ex>
(<ex>metameric</ex>) with each other in this sense</as>. See
<er>Metameric</er>.</def>

<hw>I*som"er*ide</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos>
<fld>(Chem.)</fld> <def>An isomer.</def> <mark>[R.]</mark>

<hw>I*som"er*ism</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos>
<fld>(Chem.)</fld> <def>The state, quality, or relation, of two
or more isomeric substances.</def>

<cs><col>Physical isomerism</col> <fld>(Chem.)</fld>, <cd>the
condition or relation of certain (<it>metameric<it>) substances,
which, while chemically identical (in that they have the same
composition, the same molecular weights, and the same ultimate
constitution), are yet physically different, as in their action
on polarized light, as dextro- and l\'91vo-tartaric acids. In
such compounds there is usually at least one unsymmetrical carbon
atom. See <er>Unsymmetrical</er>.</cd></cs><-- "metamerism" is no
longer used, and "isomerism" is generally applied to this conept.
including optical isomerism, the property of optical isomers -->

<hw>I`so*mer`o*mor"phism</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos>
<ety>[<ets>Isomer</ets> + Gr. <?/ form + -<ets>ism</ets>.]</ety>
<fld>(Crystallog.)</fld> <def>Isomorphism between substances that
are isomeric.</def>

<mhw>{ <hw>I`so*met"ric</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>,
<hw>I`so*met"ric*al</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, }</mhw> <pos>a.</pos>
<ety>[<ets>Iso-</ets> + Gr. <?/ measure.]</ety>

<sn>1.</sn> <def>Pertaining to, or characterized by, equality of
measure.</def>

<sn>2.</sn> <fld>(Crystallog.)</fld> <def>Noting, or conforming
to, that system of crystallization in which the three axes are of
equal length and at right angles to each other; monometric;
regular; cubic. Cf. <er>Crystallization</er>.</def>

<cs><col>Isometric lines</col> <fld>(Thermodynamics)</fld>,
<cd>lines representing in a diagram the relations of pressure and
temperature in a gas, when the volume remains constant.</cd> --
<col>Isometrical perspective</col>. <cd>See under
<er>Perspective</er>.</cd> -- <col>Isometrical projection</col>,
<cd>a species of orthographic projection, in which but a single
plane of projection is used. It is so named from the fact that
the projections of three equal lines, parallel respectively to
three rectangular axes, are equal to one another. This kind of
projection is principally used in delineating buildings or
machinery, in which the principal lines are parallel to three
rectangular axes, and the principal planes are parallel to three
rectangular planes passing through the three axes.</cd></cs>

<hw>I"so*morph</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[See
<er>Isomorphous</er>.]</ety> <def>A substance which is similar to
another in crystalline form and composition.</def>

<hw>I`so*mor"phic</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>a.</pos>
<def>Isomorphous.</def>

<hw>I`so*mor"phism</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[Cf. F.
<ets>isomorphisme</ets>.]</ety> <fld>(Crystallog.)</fld> <def>A
similarity of crystalline form between substances of similar
composition, as between the sulphates of barium
(<chform>BaSO4</chform>) and strontium (<chform>SrSO4</chform>).
It is sometimes extended to include similarity of form between
substances of unlike composition, which is more properly called
<xex>hom\'d2omorphism</xex>.</def>

<-- (math): see isomorphic -->

<hw>I*sop"a*thy</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos>
<ety>[<ets>Iso-</ets> + Gr. <?/ suffering.]</ety>
<fld>(Med.)</fld> <sd>(a)</sd> <def>The system which undertakes

<au>Mayne</au>. <sd>(c)</sd> <def>The doctrine that the power of
therapeutics is equal to that of the causes of disease.</def>

<hw>\'d8I`so*pleu"ra</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n. pl.</pos>
<ety>[NL. See <er>Iso-</er>, and <er>Pleura</er>.]</ety>
<fld>(Zo\'94l.)</fld> <def>A subclass of Gastropoda, in which the
body is symmetrical, the right and left sides being equal.</def>

<note><hand/ The intestine terminates at the posterior end of the
body, and the gills and circulatory and reproductive organs are
paired. It includes the chitons (<spn>Polyplacophora</spn>),
together with <spn>Neomenia</spn> and <spn>Ch\'91toderma</spn>,
which are wormlike forms without a shell.</note>

<hw>I"so*pod</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>a.</pos>
<fld>(Zo\'94l.)</fld> <def>Having the legs similar in structure;
belonging to the Isopoda.</def> -- <def2><pos>n.</pos> <def>One
of the Isopoda.</def></def2>

<hw>\'d8I*sop"o*da</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n. pl.</pos> <ety>[NL.
See <er>Iso-</er>, and <er>-poda</er>.]</ety>
<fld>(Zo\'94l.)</fld> <def>An order of sessile-eyed Crustacea,
usually having seven pairs of legs, which are all similar in
structure.</def>

<note><hand/ The body is usually depressed, with the abdominal
segments short, and often consolidated in part. The branchi\'91
are on the abdominal appendages. The group includes the
terrestrial pill bugs and sow bugs, with numerous marine forms.
See <er>Arthrostrata</er>, <er>Gribble</er>.</note>

<hw>I"so*there</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos>
<ety>[<ets>Iso-</ets> + Gr. <?/ summer, <?/ to heat.]</ety>
<fld>(Phys. Geog.)</fld> <def>A line connecting points on the

<hw>I"so*therm</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos>
<ety>[<ets>Iso-</ets> + Gr. <?/ heat, fr. <?/ hot.]</ety>
<fld>(Phys. Geog.)</fld> <def>A line connecting or marking points
on the earth's surface having the same temperature. This may be
the temperature for a given time of observation, or the mean
temperature for a year or other period. Also, a similar line
based on the distribution of temperature in the ocean.</def>

<hw>I`so*ther"mal</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>a.</pos> <ety>[Cf. F.
<ets>isotherme</ets>.]</ety> <sd>(a)</sd> <def>Relating to
equality of temperature.</def> <sd>(b)</sd> <fld>(Phys.
Geog.)</fld> <def>Having reference to the geographical
distribution of temperature, as exhibited by means of isotherms;
<as>as, an <ex>isothermal</ex> line; an <ex>isothermal</ex>
chart.</as></def>

<cs><col>Isothermal line</col>. <sd>(a)</sd> <cd>An
isotherm</cd>. <sd>(b)</sd> <cd>A line drawn on a diagram of
energy such that its ordinates represent the pressures of a
substance corresponding to various volumes, while the absolute
temperature is maintained at a constant value.</cd> --
<col>Isothermal zones</col>, <cd>spaces on opposite sides of the
equator having the same mean temperature, and bounded by
corresponding isothermal lines.</cd></cs>

<hw>I`so*ther"mo*bath</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos>
<ety>[<ets>Iso-</ets> + Gr. <?/ hot + <?/ depth.]</ety>
<fld>(Phys. Geog)</fld> <def>A line drawn through points of equal
temperature in a vertical section of the ocean.</def>

<hw>I`so*ther`mo*bath"ic</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>a.</pos> <def>Of
or pertaining to an isothermobath; possessing or indicating equal
temperatures in a vertical section, as of the ocean.</def>

<hw>I*soth`er*om"brose</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos>
<ety>[<ets>Iso-</ets> + Gr. <grk>qe`ros</grk> summer +
<grk>'o`mbros</grk> rain.]</ety> <fld>(Phys. Geog)</fld> <def>A
line connecting or marking points on the earth's surface, which
have the same mean summer rainfall.</def>

<hw>I`so*ton"ic</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>a.</pos>
<ety>[<ets>Iso-</ets> + <ets>tonic</ets>.]</ety> <def>Having or
indicating, equal tones, or tension.</def>

<cs><col>Isotonic system</col> <fld>(Mus.)</fld>, <cd>a system
consisting of intervals, in which each concord is alike tempered,
and in which there are twelve equal semitones.</cd></cs>

<hw>I`so*u"ric</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>a.</pos>
<ety>[<ets>Iso-</ets> + <ets>uric</ets>.]</ety>
<fld>(Chem.)</fld> <def>Pertaining to, or designating, a complex
nitrogenous acid, isomeric with uric acid.</def>

<hw>Is"ra*el*ite</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[L.
<ets>Isra\'89lites</ets>, Gr. <?/, fr. <?/, <?/, Israel, Heb.
<ets>Yisr\'be<?/l</ets>, i. e., champion of God;
<ets>s\'ber\'beh</ets> to fight + <ets><?/l</ets> God.]</ety>
<def>A descendant of Israel, or Jacob; a Hebrew; a Jew.</def>

<mhw>{ <hw>Is`ra*el*it"ic</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>,
<hw>Is"ra*el*i`tish</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, }</mhw> <pos>a.</pos>

Hebrew.</def>

<hw>Is"su*a*ble</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>a.</pos> <ety>[From
<er>Issue</er>.]</ety>

<sn>1.</sn> <def>Leading to, producing, or relating to, an issue;
capable of being made an issue at law.</def>

<au>Burrill.</au>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>Lawful or suitable to be issued; <as>as, a writ
<ex>issuable</ex> on these grounds</as>.</def>

<cs><col>Issuable plea</col> <fld>(Law)</fld>, <cd>a plea to the
merits, on which the adverse party may take issue and proceed to
trial.</cd></cs>

<hw>Is"su*a*bly</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>adv.</pos> <def>In an
issuable manner; by way of issue; <as>as, to plead
<ex>issuably</ex></as>.</def>

<hw>Is"su*ance</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <def>The act of
issuing, or giving out; <as>as, the <ex>issuance</ex> of an
order; the <ex>issuance</ex> of rations, and the like.</as></def>

<hw>Is"su*ant</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>a.</pos> <fld>(Her.)</fld>
<def>Issuing or coming up; -- a term used to express a charge or
bearing rising or coming out of another.</def>

<hw>Is"sue</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[OF.
<ets>issue</ets>, <ets>eissue</ets>, F. <ets>issue</ets>, fr. OF.
<ets>issir</ets>, <ets>eissir</ets>, to go out, L.
<ets>exire</ets>; <ets>ex</ets> out of, from + <ets>ire</ets> to
go, akin to Gr. <?/, Skr. <ets>i</ets>., Goth. <ets>iddja</ets>
went, used as prefect of <ets>gaggan</ets> to go. Cf.
<er>Ambition</er>, <er>Count</er> a nobleman, <er>Commence</er>,
<er>Errant</er>, <er>Exit</er>, <er>Eyre</er>, <er>Initial</er>,
<er>Yede</er> went.]</ety>

<sn>1.</sn> <def>The act of passing or flowing out; a moving out
from any inclosed place; egress; <as>as, the <ex>issue</ex> of
water from a pipe, of blood from a wound, of air from a bellows,
of people from a house</as>.</def>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>The act of sending out, or causing to go forth;
delivery; issuance; <as>as, the <ex>issue</ex> of an order from a
commanding officer; the <ex>issue</ex> of money from a
treasury.</as></def>

<sn>3.</sn> <def>That which passes, flows, or is sent out; the
whole quantity sent forth or emitted at one time; <as>as, an
<ex>issue</ex> of bank notes; the daily <ex>issue</ex> of a
newspaper.</as></def>

<sn>4.</sn> <def>Progeny; a child or children; offspring. In law,
sometimes, in a general sense, all persons descended from a
common ancestor; all lineal descendants.</def>

<q>If the king
Should without <qex>issue</qex> die.</q>
<qau>Shak.</qau>

<sn>5.</sn> <def>Produce of the earth, or profits of land,
tenements, or other property; <as>as, <er>A</er> conveyed to
<er>B</er> all his right for a term of years, with all the
<ex>issues</ex>, rents, and profits</as>.</def>

<sn>6.</sn> <def>A discharge of flux, as of blood.</def>

<au>Matt. ix. 20.</au>

<sn>7.</sn> <fld>(Med.)</fld> <def>An artificial ulcer, usually
made in the fleshy part of the arm or leg, to produce the
secretion and discharge of pus for the relief of some affected
part.</def>

<sn>8.</sn> <def>The final outcome or result; upshot; conclusion;
event; hence, contest; test; trial.</def>

<q>Come forth to view
The <qex>issue</qex> of the exploit.</q>
<qau>Shak.</qau>

<q>While it is hot, I 'll put it to the <qex>issue</qex>.</q>
<qau>Shak.</qau>

<sn>9.</sn> <def>A point in debate or controversy on which the
parties take affirmative and negative positions; a presentation
of alternatives between which to choose or decide.</def>

<sn>10.</sn> <fld>(Law)</fld> <def>In pleading, a single material
point of law or fact depending in the suit, which, being affirmed
on the one side and denied on the other, is presented for
determination. See <cref>General issue</cref>, under
<er>General</er>, and <cref>Feigned issue</cref>, under
<er>Feigned</er>.</def>

<au>Blount. Cowell.</au>

<cs><col>At issue</col>, <cd>in controversy; disputed; opposing
or contesting; hence, at variance; disagreeing;
inconsistent.</cd>

<q>As much <qex>at issue</qex> with the summer day
As if you brought a candle out of doors.</q>
<qau>Mrs. Browning.</qau>

-- <mcol><col>Bank of issue</col>, <col>Collateral
issue</col></mcol>, etc. <cd>See under <er>Bank</er>,
<er>Collateral</er>, etc.</cd> -- <col>Issue pea</col>, <cd>a
pea, or a similar round body, used to maintain irritation in a
wound, and promote the secretion and discharge of pus.</cd> --
<mcol><col>To join</col>, <or/ <col>take</col>,
<col>issue</col></mcol>, <cd>to take opposing sides in a matter
in controversy.</cd></cs>

<hw>Is"sue</hw>, <pos>v. i.</pos> <wordforms>[<pos>imp. & p.
p.</pos> <er>Issued</er> <pr>(?)</pr>; <pos>p. pr. & vb. n.</pos>
<er>Issuing</er>.]</wordforms>

<-- p. 793 -->

<sn>1.</sn> <def>To pass or flow out; to run out, as from any
inclosed place.</def>

<q>From it <qex>issued</qex> forced drops of blood.</q>
<qau>Shak.</qau>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>To go out; to rush out; to sally forth; <as>as,
troops <ex>issued</ex> from the town, and attacked the
besiegers</as>.</def>

<sn>3.</sn> <def>To proceed, as from a source; <as>as, water
<ex>issues</ex> from springs; light <ex>issues</ex> from the
sun.</as></def>

<sn>4.</sn> <def>To proceed, as progeny; to be derived; to be
descended; to spring.</def>

<q>Of thy sons that shall <qex>issue</qex> from thee.</q>
<qau>2  Kings xx. 18.</qau>

<sn>5.</sn> <def>To extend; to pass or open; <as>as, the path
<ex>issues</ex> into the highway</as>.</def>

<sn>6.</sn> <def>To be produced as an effect or result; to grow
or accrue; to arise; to proceed; <as>as, rents and profits
<ex>issuing</ex> from land, tenements, or a capital
stock</as>.</def>

<sn>7.</sn> <def>To close; to end; to terminate; to turn out;
<as>as, we know not how the cause will <ex>issue</ex></as>.</def>

<sn>8.</sn> <fld>(Law)</fld> <def>In pleading, to come to a point
in fact or law, on which the parties join issue.</def>

<hw>Is"sue</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>v. t.</pos> <sn>1.</sn>
<def>To send out; to put into circulation; <as>as, to
<ex>issue</ex> notes from a bank</as>.</def>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>To deliver for use; <as>as, to <ex>issue</ex>
provisions</as>.</def>

<sn>3.</sn> <def>To send out officially; to deliver by authority;
<as>as, to <ex>issue</ex> an order; to <ex>issue</ex> a
writ.</as></def>

<hw>Is"sue*less</hw>, <pos>a.</pos> <def>Having no issue or
progeny; childless.</def> \'bdThe heavens . . . have left me
<xex>issueless</xex>.\'b8

<au>Shak.</au>

<hw>Is"su*er</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <def>One who
issues, emits, or publishes.</def>

<hw>-ist</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>. <ety>[Gr. <?/: cf. F.
-<ets>iste</ets>.]</ety> <def>A noun suffix denoting an
<xex>agent</xex>, or <xex>doer</xex>, <xex>one who
practices</xex>, a <xex>believer in</xex>; <as>as,
theor<ex>ist</ex>, one who theorizes; social<ex>ist</ex>, one who
holds to socialism; sensual<ex>ist</ex>, one given to
sensuality.</as></def>

<hw>Is't</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>. <def>A contraction of <xex>is
it</xex>.</def>

<hw>Isth"mi*an</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>a.</pos> <ety>[L.
<ets>Isthmius</ets>, Gr. <?/. See <er>Isthmus</er>.]</ety>
<def>Of or pertaining to an isthmus, especially to the Isthmus of
Corinth, in Greece.</def>

<cs><col>Isthmian games</col> <fld>(Gr. Antiq.)</fld>, <cd>one of
the four great national festivals of Greece, celebrated on the
Isthmus of Corinth in the spring of every alternate year. They
consisted of all kinds of athletic sports, wrestling, boxing,
racing on foot and in chariots, and also contests in music and
poetry. The prize was a garland of pine leaves.</cd></cs>

<hw>Isth"mus</hw> <pr>(?; 277)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos>; <plu>pl.
<plw>Isthmuses</plw> <pr>(#)</pr></plu>. <ety>[L.
<ets>isthmus</ets>, Gr. <grk>'isqmo`s</grk> a neck, a neck of
land between two seas, an isthmus, especially the Isthmus of
Corinth; prob. from the root of <grk>'ie`nai</grk> to go; cf.
Icel. <ets>ei<edh/</ets> isthmus. See <er>Issue</er>.]</ety>
<fld>(Geog.)</fld> <def>A neck or narrow slip of land by which
two continents are connected, or by which a peninsula is united
to the mainland; <as>as, the <ex>Isthmus</ex> of Panama; the
<ex>Isthmus</ex> of Suez, etc.</as></def>

<cs><col>Isthmus of the fauces</col>. <fld>(Anat.)</fld> <cd>See
<er>Fauces</er>.</cd></cs>

<hw>Is"tle</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <def>Same as
<er>Ixtle</er>.</def>

<hw>I*su"ret</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos>
<ety>[<ets>Iso-</ets> + <ets>ur</ets>ea.]</ety>
<fld>(Chem.)</fld> <def>An artificial nitrogenous base, isomeric
with urea, and forming a white crystalline substance; -- called
also <altname>isuretine</altname>.</def>

<hw>It</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>pron.</pos> <ety>[OE.
<ets>it</ets>, <ets>hit</ets>, AS. <ets>hit</ets>; cf. D.
<ets>het</ets>. <root/181. See <er>He</er>.]</ety> <def>The
neuter pronoun of the third person, corresponding to the
masculine pronoun <xex>he</xex> and the feminine <xex>she</xex>,
and having the same plural (<xex>they</xex>, <xex>their</xex> of
<xex>theirs</xex>, <xex>them</xex>).</def>

<note><hand/ The possessive form <xex>its</xex> is modern, being
rarely found in the writings of Shakespeare and Milton, and not
at all in the original King James's version of the Bible. During
the transition from the regular <xex>his</xex> to the anomalous
<xex>its</xex>, <xex>it</xex> was to some extent employed in the
possessive without the case ending. See <er>His</er>, and
<er>He</er>. In Dryden's time <xex>its</xex> had become quite
established as the regular form.</note>

<q>The day present hath ever inough to do with <qex>it</qex> owne
grief.</q>
<qau>Genevan Test.</qau>

<q>Do, child, go to <qex>it</qex> grandam, child.</q>
<qau>Shak.</qau>

<q><qex>It</qex> knighthood shall do worse. It shall fright all
<qex>it</qex> friends with borrowing letters.</q>
<qau>B. Jonson.</qau>

<note><hand/ In the course of time, the nature of the neuter sign
<it>i</it> in <xex>it</xex>, the form being found in but a few
words, became misunderstood. Instead of being looked upon as an
affix, it passed for part of the original word. Hence was formed
from <xex>it</xex> the anomalous genitive <xex>it</xex>,
superseding the Saxon <xex>his</xex>.</note>

<au>Latham.</au>

<q>The fruit tree yielding fruit after <qex>his</qex> (its)
kind.</q>
<qau>Gen. i. 11.</qau>

<usage><xex>It</xex> is used, --

<sn>1.</sn> <def>As a substance for any noun of the neuter
gender; <as>as, here is the book, take <ex>it</ex>
home</as>.</def>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>As a demonstrative, especially at the beginning
of a sentence, pointing to that which is about to be stated,
named, or mentioned, or referring to that which apparent or well
known; <as>as, I saw <ex>it</ex> was John</as>.</def>

<q><qex>It</qex> is I; be not afraid.</q>
<qau>Matt. xiv. 27.</qau>

<q>Peter heard that <qex>it</qex> was the Lord.</q>
<qau>John xxi. 7.</qau>

Often, in such cases, as a substitute for a sentence or clause;
as, <xex>it</xex> is thought <xex>he will come</xex>;
<xex>it</xex> is wrong <xex>to do this</xex>.

<sn>3.</sn> <def>As an indefinite nominative for a impersonal
verb; <as>as, <ex>it</ex> snows; <ex>it</ex> rains.</as></def>

<sn>4.</sn> <def>As a substitute for such general terms as, the
state of affairs, the condition of things, and the like; <as>as,
how is <ex>it</ex> with the sick man?</as></def>

<q>Think on me when <qex>it</qex> shall be well with thee.</q>
<qau>Gen. xl. 14.</qau>

<sn>5.</sn> <def>As an indefinite object after some intransitive
verbs, or after a substantive used humorously as a verb; <as>as,
to foot <ex>it</ex> (<it>i. e.</it>, to walk)</as>.</def>

<q>The Lacedemonians, at the Straits of Thermopyl\'91, when their
arms failed them, fought <qex>it</qex> out with nails and
teeth.</q>
<qau>Dryden.</qau>

<q>Whether the charmer sinner <qex>it</qex>, or saint
<qex>it</qex>,
If folly grows romantic, I must paint it.</q>
<qau>Pope.</qau>

<hw>I"ta*cism</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[Cf. F.
<ets>itacisme</ets>. See <er>Etacism</er>, and cf.
<er>Iotacism</er>.]</ety> <fld>(Greek Gram.)</fld>
<def>Pronunciation of <?/ (eta) as the modern Greeks pronounce
it, that is, like <xex>e</xex> in the English word <xex>be</xex>.
This was the pronunciation advocated by Reu<?/hlin and his
followers, in opposition to the etacism of Erasmus. See
<er>Etacism</er>.</def>

<q>In all such questions between <?/ and <qex>a<?/</qex> the
confusing element of <qex>itacism</qex> comes in.</q>
<qau>Alford.</qau>

<ets>itaciste</ets>.]</ety> <def>One who is in favor of

<hw>I*tal"ic</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>a.</pos> <ety>[L.
<ets>Italicus</ets>: cf. F. <ets>italique</ets>. Cf.
<er>Italian</er>.]</ety>

<sn>1.</sn> <def>Relating to Italy or to its people.</def>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>Applied especially to a kind of type in which
the letters do not stand upright, but slope toward the right; --
so called because dedicated to the States of Italy by the
inventor, Aldus Manutius, about the year 1500.</def>

<cs><col>Italic languages</col>, <cd>the group or family of
languages of ancient Italy.</cd> -- <col>Italic order</col>
<fld>(Arch.)</fld>, <cd>the composite order. See
<er>Composite</er>.</cd> -- <col>Italic school</col>, <cd>a term
given to the Pythagorean and Eleatic philosophers, from the
country where their doctrines were first promulgated.</cd> --
<col>Italic version</col>. <cd>See <er>Itala</er>.</cd></cs>

<hw>I*tal"ic</hw>, <pos>n.</pos>; <plu>pl. <plw>Italics</plw>
<pr>(<?/)</pr>.</plu> <fld>(Print.)</fld> <def>An Italic letter,
character, or type (see <er>Italic</er>, <pos>a.</pos>, 2.); --
often in the plural; <as>as, the <ex>Italics</ex> are the
author's</as>. Italic letters are used to distinguish words for
emphasis, importance, antithesis, etc. Also, collectively, Italic
letters.</def>

<hw>I"ta palm`</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>. <fld>(Bot.)</fld> <def>A
magnificent species of palm (<spn>Mauritia flexuosa</spn>),
growing near the Orinoco. The natives eat its fruit and buds,
drink its sap, and make thread and cord from its fiber.</def>

<hw>Itch</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>v. i.</pos>
<wordforms>[<pos>imp. & p. p.</pos> <er>Itched</er> <pr>(?)</pr>;
<pos>p. pr. & vb. n.</pos> <er>Itching</er>.]</wordforms>
<ety>[OE. <ets>icchen</ets>, <ets><?/icchen</ets>, AS.
<ets>giccan</ets>; akin to D. <ets>jeuken</ets>,
<ets>joken</ets>, G. <ets>jucken</ets>, OHG.
<ets>jucchen</ets>.]</ety>

<sn>1.</sn> <def>To have an uneasy sensation in the skin, which
inclines the person to scratch the part affected.</def>

<q>My mouth hath <qex>itched</qex> all this long day.</q>
<qau>Chaucer.</qau>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>To have a constant desire or teasing uneasiness;
to long for; <as>as, <ex>itching</ex> ears</as>.</def> \'bdAn
<xex>itching</xex> palm.\'b8

<au>Shak.</au>

<hw>Itch</hw>, <pos>n.</pos> <sn>1.</sn> <fld>(Med.)</fld>
<def>An eruption of small, isolated, acuminated vesicles,
produced by the entrance of a parasitic mite (the <spn>Sarcoptes
scabei</spn>), and attended with itching. It is transmissible by
contact.</def>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>Any itching eruption.</def>

<sn>3.</sn> <def>A sensation in the skin occasioned (or
resembling that occasioned) by the itch eruption; -- called also
<altname>scabies</altname>, <altname>psora</altname>, etc.</def>

<sn>4.</sn> <def>A constant irritating desire.</def>

<q>An <qex>itch</qex> of being thought a divine king.</q>
<qau>Dryden.</qau>

<cs><col>Baker's itch</col>. <cd>See under <er>Baker</er>.</cd>
-- <col>Barber's itch</col>, <cd>sycosis.</cd> --
<col>Bricklayer's itch</col>, <cd>an eczema of the hands attended
with much itching, occurring among bricklayers.</cd> --
<col>Grocer's itch</col>, <cd>an itching eruption, being a
variety of eczema, produced by the sugar mite (<spn>Tyrogluphus
sacchari</spn>).</cd> -- <col>Itch insect</col>
<fld>(Zo\'94l.)</fld>, <cd>a small parasitic mite (<spn>Sarcoptes
scabei</spn>) which burrows and breeds beneath the human skin,
thus causing the disease known as the itch. See <xex>Illust<xex>.
in Append.</cd> -- <col>Itch mite</col>. <fld>(Zo\'94l.)</fld>
<cd>Same as <cref>Itch insect</cref>, above. Also, other similar
mites affecting the lower animals, as the horse and ox.</cd> --
<col>Sugar baker's itch</col>, <cd>a variety of eczema, due to
the action of sugar upon the skin.</cd> -- <col>Washerwoman's
itch</col>, <cd>eczema of the hands and arms, occurring among
washerwomen.</cd></cs>

<hw>Itch"i*ness</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <def>The state
of being itchy.</def>

<hw>Itch"less</hw>, <pos>a.</pos> <def>Free from itching.</def>

<hw>Itch"y</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>a.</pos> <def>Infected with
the itch, or with an itching sensation.</def>

<au>Cowper.</au>

<hw>-ite</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>. <ety>[From Gr. <?/, <?/.]</ety>

<sn>1.</sn> <def>A suffix denoting <xex>one of a party</xex>, a
<xex>sympathizer with</xex> or <xex>adherent of</xex>, and the
like, and frequently used in ridicule; <as>as, a
Miller<ex>ite</ex>; a Bentham<ex>ite</ex>.</as></def>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>A suffix used in naming minerals; <as>as,
chlor<ex>ite</ex>, from its characteristic green color;
bar<ex>ite</ex>, from its heaviness; graph<ex>ite</ex>, from its
use in writing.</as></def>

<sn>3.</sn> <fld>(Chem.)</fld> <def>A suffix used to denote the
salts formed from those acids whose names end in <xex>-ous</xex>;
<as>as, sulph<ex>ite</ex>, from sulphur<ex>ous</ex>;
nitr<ex>ite</ex>, from nitr<ex>ous</ex> acid, etc.</as></def>

<hw>I"tem</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>adv.</pos> <ety>[L.
<ets>See</ets> <er>Iterate</er>.]</ety> <def>Also; as an
additional article.</def>

<er>Item</er>, <ets>adv</ets>.]</ety>

<sn>1.</sn> <def>An article; a separate particular in an account;
<as>as, the <ex>items</ex> in a bill</as>.</def>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>A hint; an innuendo.</def> <mark>[Obs.]</mark>

. to absent themselves.</q>
<qau>Fuller.</qau>

<sn>3.</sn> <def>A short article in a newspaper; a paragraph;
<as>as, an <ex>item</ex> concerning the weather</as>.</def>

<hw>I*tin"er*ant</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>a.</pos> <ety>[LL.

kept in the king's palace, and removing with his household in

<qau>Blackstone.</qau>

<hw>\'d8I*u"lus</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[L., down,

genus of chilognathous myriapods. The body is long and round,

bears two pairs of short legs. It includes the galleyworms. See
