<hw>Jer"sey</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos>; <plu>pl.
<plw>Jerseys</plw> <pr>(#)</pr></plu>. <ety>[From
<ets>Jersey</ets>, the largest of the Channel Islands.]</ety>

<sn>1.</sn>  <def>The finest of wool separated from the rest;
combed wool; also, fine yarn of wool.</def>

<sn>2.</sn>  <def>A kind of knitted jacket; hence, in general, a
closefitting jacket or upper garment made of an elastic fabric
(as stockinet).</def>

<sn>3.</sn>  <def>One of a breed of cattle in the Island of
Jersey. Jerseys are noted for the richness of their milk.</def>

<hw>Je*ru"sa*lem</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[Gr. <?/,
fr. Heb. <ets>Y<?/r<?/sh\'belaim</ets>.]</ety> <def>The chief
city of Palestine, intimately associated with the glory of the
Jewish nation, and the life and death of Jesus Christ.</def>

<cs><col>Jerusalem artichoke</col> <ety>[Perh. a corrupt. of It.
<ets>girasole</ets> <it>i.e.</it>, sunflower, or turnsole. See
<er>Gyre</er>, <er>Solar</er>.]</ety> <fld>(Bot.)</fld>
<sd>(a)</sd> <cd>An American plant, a perennial species of
sunflower (<spn>Helianthus tuberosus</spn>), whose tubers are
sometimes used as food</cd>. <sd>(b)</sd> <cd>One of the tubers
themselves.</cd> -- <col>Jerusalem cherry</col>
<fld>(Bot.)</fld>, <cd>the popular name of either of either of
two species of <spn>Solanum</spn> (<spn>S. Pseudo-capsicum</spn>
and <spn>S. capsicastrum</spn>), cultivated as ornamental house
plants. They bear bright red berries of about the size of
cherries.</cd> -- <col>Jerusalem oak</col> <fld>(Bot.)</fld>,
<cd>an aromatic goosefoot (<spn>Chenopodium Botrys</spn>), common
about houses and along roadsides.</cd> -- <col>Jerusalem
sage</col> <fld>(Bot.)</fld>, <cd>a perennial herb of the Mint
family (<spn>Phlomis tuberosa</spn>).</cd> -- <col>Jerusalem
thorn</col> <fld>(Bot.)</fld>, <cd>a spiny, leguminous tree
(<spn>Parkinsonia aculeata</spn>), widely dispersed in warm
countries, and used for hedges.</cd> -- <col>The New
Jerusalem</col>, <cd>Heaven; the Celestial City.</cd></cs>

<hw>Jer"vine</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[Prob. fr. Sp.
<ets>yerba</ets> herb, OSp., the poison of the veratrum.]</ety>
<fld>(Chem.)</fld> <def>A poisonous alkaloid resembling
veratrine, and found with it in white hellebore (<spn>Veratrum
album</spn>); -- called also <altname>jervina</altname>.</def>

<hw>Jess</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos>; <plu>pl.
<plw>Jesses</plw> <pr>(#)</pr></plu>. <ety>[OF. <ets>gies</ets>,
<ets>giez</ets>, prop. pl. of  <ets>giet</ets>, <ets>get</ets>,
<ets>jet</ets>, F. <ets>jet</ets>, a throwing, jess. See
<er>Jet</er> a shooting forth.]</ety> (<xex>falconry</xex>)
<def>A short strap of leather or silk secured round the leg of a
hawk, to which the leash or line, wrapped round the falconer's
hand, was attached when used. See <xex>Illust</xex>. of
<er>Falcon</er>.</def>

<q>Like a hawk, which feeling freed
From bells and <qex>jesses</qex> which did let her flight.</q>
<qau>Spenser.</qau>

<hw>Jes"sa*mine</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos>
<fld>(Bot.)</fld> <def>Same as <er>Jasmine</er>.</def>

<hw>Jes"sant</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>a.</pos> <fld>(Her.)</fld>
<def>Springing up or emerging; -- said of a plant or
animal.</def>

<hw>Jes"se</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos>
<ety>[LL.<ets>Jesse</ets>, the father of David, fr. Gr. <?/, fr.
Herb. <ets>Yishai</ets>.]</ety> <def>Any representation or
suggestion of the genealogy of Christ, in decorative art</def>;
as: <sd>(a)</sd> <def>A genealogical tree represented in stained
glass</def>. <sd>(b)</sd> <def>A candlestick with many branches,
each of which bears the name of some one of the descendants of
Jesse; -- called also  <altname>tree of Jesse</altname>.</def>

<cs><col>Jesse window</col> <fld>(Arch.)</fld>, <cd>a window of
which the glazing and tracery represent the tree of
Jesse.</cd></cs>

<hw>Jessed</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>a.</pos> <fld>(Her.)</fld>
<def>Having jesses on, as a hawk.</def>

<hw>Jest</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[OE.
<ets>jeste</ets>, <ets>geste</ets>, deed, action, story, tale,
OF.  <ets>geste</ets>, LL. <ets>gesta</ets>, orig., exploits,
neut. pl. from L. <ets>gestus</ets>, p. p. of <ets>gerere</ets>
to bear, carry, accomplish, perform; perh. orig., to make to
come, bring, and perh. akin to E. <ets>come</ets>. Cf.
<er>Gest</er> a deed, <er>Register</er>, <pos>n.</pos>]</ety>

<sn>1.</sn>  <def>A deed; an action; a gest.</def>
<mark>[Obs.]</mark>

<q>The <qex>jests</qex> or actions of princes.</q>
<qau>Sir T. Elyot.</qau>

<sn>2.</sn>  <def>A mask; a pageant; an interlude.</def>
<mark>[Obs.]</mark>

<au>Nares.</au>

<q>He promised us, in honor of our guest,
To grace our banquet with some  pompous <qex>jest</qex>.</q>
<qau>Kyd.</qau>

<sn>3.</sn>  <def>Something done or said in order to amuse; a
joke; a witticism; a jocose or sportive remark or phrase. See
Synonyms under <er>Jest</er>, <pos>v. i.</pos></def>

<q>I must be sad . . . smile at no man's <qex>jests</qex>.</q>
<qau>Shak.</qau>

<q>The Right Honorable gentleman is indebted to his memory for
his <qex>jests</qex>, and to his imagination for his facts.</q>
<qau>Sheridan.</qau>

<sn>4.</sn>  <def>The object of laughter or sport; a
laughingstock.</def>

<q>Then let me be your <qex>jest</qex>; I deserve it.</q>
<qau>Shak.</qau>

<cs><col>In jest</col>, <cd>for mere sport or diversion; not in
truth and reality; not in earnest.</cd>

<q>And given in earnest what I begged <qex>in jest</qex>.</q>
<qau>Shak.</qau>

-- <col>Jest book</col>, <cd>a book containing a collection of
jests, jokes, and amusing anecdotes; a Joe Miller.</cd></cs>

<hw>Jest</hw>, <pos>v. i.</pos>  <wordforms>[<pos>imp. & p.
p.</pos> <er>Jested</er>; <pos>p. pr. & vb. n.</pos>
<er>Jesting</er>.]</wordforms>

<sn>1.</sn>  <def>To take part in a merrymaking; -- especially,
to act in a mask or interlude.</def> <mark>[Obs.]</mark>

<au>Shak.</au>

<sn>2.</sn>  <def>To make merriment by words or actions; to joke;
to make light of anything.</def>

<q>He <qex>jests</qex> at scars that never felt a wound.</q>
<qau>Shak.</qau>

<syn>Syn. -- To joke; sport; rally.</syn> <usage> -- To
<er>Jest</er>, <er>Joke</er>.  One  <xex>jests</xex> in order to
make others laugh; one <xex>jokes</xex> to please himself. A
<xex>jest</xex> is usually at the expense of another, and is
often ill-natured; a <xex>joke</xex> is a sportive sally designed
to promote good humor without wounding the feelings of its
object. \'bd<xex>Jests</xex> are, therefore, seldom harmless;
<xex>jokes</xex> frequently allowable. The most serious subject
may be degraded by being turned into a
<xex>jest</xex>.\'b8</usage>

<au>Crabb.</au>

<hw>Jest"er</hw>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[Cf.
<er>Gestour</er>.]</ety>

<sn>1.</sn>  <def>A buffoon; a merry-andrew; a court fool.</def>

<q>This . . . was Yorick's skull, the king's
<qex>jester</qex>.</q>
<qau>Shak.</qau>

<q>Dressed in the motley garb that <qex>jesters</qex> wear.</q>
<qau>Longfellow.</qau>

<sn>2.</sn>  <def>A person addicted to jesting, or to indulgence
in light and amusing talk.</def>

<q>He ambled up and down
With shallow <qex>jesters</qex>.</q>
<qau>Shak.</qau>

<hw>Jest"ful</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>a.</pos> <def>Given to
jesting; full of jokes.</def>

<hw>Jest"ing</hw>, <pos>a.</pos> <def>Sportive; not serious; fit
for jests.</def>

<q>He will find that these are no <qex>jesting</qex> matters.</q>
<qau>Macaulay</qau>.

<hw>Jest"ing</hw>, <pos>n.</pos> <def>The act or practice of
making jests; joking; pleasantry.</def>

<au>Eph. v. 4.</au>

<hw>Jest"ing*ly</hw>, <pos>adv.</pos> <def>In a jesting
manner.</def>

<hw>Jes"u*it</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[F.
<ets>J\'82suite</ets>, Sp. <ets>Jesuita</ets>: cf. It.
<ets>Gesuita</ets>.]</ety>

<sn>1.</sn>  <fld>(R. C. Ch.)</fld> <def>One of a religious order
founded by Ignatius Loyola, and approved in 1540, under the title
of The Society of Jesus.</def>

<note><hand/ The order consists of Scholastics, the Professed,
the Spiritual Coadjutors, and the Temporal Coadjutors or Lay
Brothers. The Jesuit novice after two years becomes a Scholastic,
and takes his first vows of poverty, chastity, and obedience
simply. Some years after, at the close of a second novitiate, he
takes his second vows and is ranked among the Coadjutors or
Professed. The Professed are bound by a fourth vow, from which
only the pope can dispense, requiring them to go wherever the
pope may send them for missionary duty. The Coadjutors teach in
the schools, and are employed in general missionary labors. The
Society is governed by a General who holds office for life. He
has associated with him \'bdAssistants\'b8 (five at the present
time), representing different provinces. The Society was first
established in the United States in 1807. The Jesuits have
displayed in their enterprises a high degree of zeal, learning,
and skill, but, by their enemies, have been generally reputed to
use art and intrigue in promoting or accomplishing their
purposes, whence the words <xex>Jesuit</xex>,
<xex>Jesuitical</xex>, and the like, have acquired an opprobrious
sense.</note>

<sn>2.</sn>  <def>Fig.: A crafty person; an intriguer.</def>

<cs><col>Jesuits' bark</col>, <cd>Peruvian bark, or the bark of
certain species of <spn>Cinchona</spn>; -- so called because its
medicinal properties were first made known in Europe by Jesuit
missionaries to South America.</cd> -- <col>Jesuits' drops</col>.
<cd>See <cref>Friar's balsam</cref>, under <er>Friar</er>.</cd>
-- <col>Jesuits' nut</col>, <cd>the European water chestnut.</cd>
-- <col>Jesuits' powder</col>, <cd>powdered cinchona bark.</cd>
-- <col>Jesuits' tea</col>, <cd>a Chilian leguminous shrub, used
as a tea  and medicinally.</cd></cs>

<hw>Jes"u*it*ed</hw>, <pos>a.</pos> <def>Conforming to the
principles of the Jesuits.</def>

<au>Milton.</au>

<hw>Jes"u*it*ess</hw>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[Cf. F.
<ets>J\'82suitesse</ets>.]</ety> <fld>(R. C. Hist.)</fld>
<def>One of an order of nuns established on the principles of the
Jesuits, but suppressed by Pope Urban in 1633.</def>

<mhw>{ <hw>Jes`u*it"ic</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <hw>Jes`u*it"ic*al</hw>
<pr>(?)</pr>, }</mhw> <pos>a.</pos> <ety>[Cf. F.
<ets>j\'82suitique</ets>.]</ety>

<sn>1.</sn>  <def>Of or pertaining to the Jesuits, or to their
principles and methods.</def>

<sn>2.</sn>  <def>Designing; cunning; deceitful; crafty; -- an
opprobrious use of the word.</def>

<au>Dryden.</au>

<hw>Jes`u*it"ic*al*ly</hw>, <pos>adv.</pos> <def>In a jesuitical
manner.</def>

<hw>Jes"u*it*ism</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[Cf. F.
<ets>j\'82suitisme</ets>.]</ety>

<sn>1.</sn>  <def>The principles and practices of the
Jesuits.</def>

<sn>2.</sn>  <def>Cunning; deceit; deceptive practices to effect
a purpose; subtle argument; -- an opprobrious use of the 
word.</def>

<hw>Jes`u*it*oc"ra*cy</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> 
<ety>[<ets>Jesuit</ets> + -<ets>cracy</ets>,  as in 
<ets>aristocracy</ets>.]</ety> <def>Government by Jesuits; also,
the whole body of Jesuits in a country.</def> <mark>[R.]</mark>

<au>C. Kingsley.</au>

<hw>Jes"u*it*ry</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <def>Jesuitism;
subtle argument.</def> <mark>[R.]</mark>

<au>Carlyle.</au>

<hw>Je"sus</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[L.
<ets>Jesus</ets>, Gr. <?/, from Heb. <ets>Y\'82sh<?/a'</ets>;
<ets>Y\'beh</ets> Jehovah + <ets>h<?/sh<?/a'</ets> to
help.]</ety> <def>The <er>Savior</er>;  the name of the Son of
God as announced by the angel to his parents; the personal name
of Our Lord, in distinction from Christ, his official
appellation.</def>

<au>Luke i. 31.</au>

<q>Thou shalt call his name <qex>Jesus</qex>; for he shall save
his people from their sins.</q>
<qau>Matt. i. 21.</qau>

<note><hand/The form <xex>Jesu</xex> is often used, esp. in the
vocative.</note>

<q><qex>Jesu</qex>, do thou my soul receive.</q>
<qau>Keble.</qau>

<cs><col>The Society of Jesus</col>. <cd>See
<er>Jesuit</er>.</cd></cs>

<hw>Jet</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <def>Same as 2d
<er>Get</er>.</def> <mark>[Obs.]</mark>

<au>Chaucer.</au>

<hw>Jet</hw>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[OF. <ets>jet</ets>,
<ets>jayet</ets>, F. <ets>ja\'8bet</ets>, <ets>jais</ets>, L.
<ets>gagates</ets>, fr. Gr. <?/; -- so called from <?/ or <?/, a
town and river in Lycia.]</ety> <altsp>[written also
<asp>jeat</asp>, <asp>jayet</asp>.]</altsp> <fld>(Min.)</fld>
<def>A variety of lignite, of a very compact texture and velvet
black color, susceptible of a good polish, and often wrought into
mourning jewelry, toys, buttons, etc. Formerly called also
<altname>black amber</altname>.</def>

<cs><col>Jet ant</col> <fld>(Zo\'94l.)</fld>, <cd>a blackish
European ant (<spn>Formica fuliginosa</spn>), which builds its
nest of a paperlike material in the trunks of trees.</cd></cs>

<hw>Jet</hw>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[F. <ets>jet</ets>, OF.
<ets>get</ets>, <ets>giet</ets>, L. <ets>jactus</ets> a throwing,
a throw, fr. <ets>jacere</ets> to throw. Cf. <er>Abject</er>,
<er>Ejaculate</er>, <er>Gist</er>, <er>Jess</er>,
<er>Jut</er>.]</ety>

<sn>1.</sn>  <def>A shooting forth; a spouting; a spurt; a sudden
rush or gush, as of water from a pipe, or of flame from an
orifice; also, that which issues in a jet.</def>

<sn>2.</sn>  <def>Drift; scope; range, as of an argument.</def>
<mark>[Obs.]</mark>

<sn>3.</sn>  <def>The sprue of a type, which is broken from it
when the type is cold.</def>

<au>Knight.</au>

<cs><col>Jet propeller</col> <fld>(Naut.)</fld>, <cd>a device for
propelling vessels by means of a forcible jet of water ejected
from the vessel, as by a centrifugal pump.</cd> -- <col>Jet
pump</col>, <cd>a device in which a small jet of steam, air,
water, or other fluid, in rapid motion, lifts or otherwise moves,
by its impulse, a larger quantity of the fluid with which it
mingles.</cd></cs>

<hw>Jet</hw>, <pos>v. i.</pos>  <wordforms>[<pos>imp. & p.
p.</pos> <er>Jetted</er> <pr>(?)</pr>; <pos>p. pr. & vb. n.</pos>
<er>Jetting</er>.]</wordforms> <ety>[F. <ets>jeter</ets>, L.
<ets>jactare</ets>, freq. fr. <ets>jacere</ets> to throw. See 3d
<er>Jet</er>, and cf. <er>Jut</er>.]</ety>

<sn>1.</sn>  <def>To strut; to walk with a lofty or haughty gait;
to be insolent; to obtrude.</def> <mark>[Obs.]</mark>

<q> he <qex>jets</qex> under his advanced plumes!</q>
<qau>Shak.</qau>

<q>To <qex>jet</qex> upon a prince's right.</q>
<qau>Shak.</qau>

<sn>2.</sn>  <def>To jerk; to jolt; to be shaken.</def>
<mark>[Obs.]</mark>

<au>Wiseman.</au>

<sn>3.</sn>  <def>To shoot forward or out; to project; to jut
out.</def>

<hw>Jet</hw>, <pos>v. t.</pos> <def>To spout; to emit in a stream
or jet.</def>

<q>A dozen angry models <qex>jetted</qex> steam.</q>
<qau>Tennyson.</qau>

<hw>Jet"-black`</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>a.</pos> <def>Black as

<mhw>{ <hw>\'d8Jet"sam</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <hw>\'d8Jet"son</hw>

<sn>1.</sn>  <fld>(Mar. Law)</fld> <def>Goods which sink when
cast into the sea, and remain under water; -- distinguished from
<xex>flotsam</xex>, goods which float, and <xex>ligan</xex>,
goods which are sunk attached to a buoy.</def>

<sn>2.</sn>  <def>Jettison. See <er>Jettison</er>, 1.</def>

was transferred to the file W700-799 -->

<-- jet set.  an international group of wealthy individuals who
travel frequently to international resorts. -- the group is not
organized, but membership defined solely by frequent travel for
pleasure -- [from jet plane, the conveyance used in their
travels.]
  jet-setter a member of the jet set.
  jet-setting. frequent international travel for pleasure, as
contrasted with business.
 -->

<hw>Jew</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[OF.

Israelite.</def>

<cs><col>Jew's frankincense</col>, <cd>gum styrax, or

<cd>an annual herb (<spn>Corchorus olitorius</spn>) cultivated in

-- <col>Jew's pitch</col>, <cd>asphaltum; bitumen.</cd> --
<col>The Wandering Jew</col>, <cd>an imaginary personage, who,

wander on the earth till Christ's second coming.</cd></cs>

<hw>Jew"bush`</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <fld>(Bot.)</fld>
<def>A euphorbiaceous shrub of the genus <spn>Pedilanthus</spn>

<hw>Jew"el</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[OE.
<ets>juel</ets>, <ets>jowel</ets>, OF. <ets>jouel</ets>,

<sn>1.</sn> <def>An ornament of dress usually made of a precious

<hw>Jew"fish`</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos>
<fld>(Zo\'94l.)</fld>

<sn>1.</sn> <def>A very large serranoid fish (<spn>Promicrops
itaiara</spn>) of Florida and the Gulf of Mexico. It often
reaches the weight of five hundred pounds. Its color is
olivaceous or yellowish, with numerous brown spots. Called also
<altname>guasa</altname>, and <altname>warsaw</altname>.</def>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>A similar gigantic fish (<spn>Stereolepis
gigas</spn>) of Southern California, valued as a food fish.</def>

<sn>3.</sn> <def>The black grouper of Florida and Texas.</def>

<sn>4.</sn> <def>A large herringlike fish; the tarpum.</def>

<hw>Jew*ise"</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <def>Same as
<er>Juise</er>.</def> <mark>[Obs.]</mark>

<au>Chaucer.</au>

<hw>Jew"ish</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>a.</pos> <def>Of or
pertaining to the Jews or Hebrews; characteristic of or
resembling the Jews or their customs; Israelitish.</def> --
<wordforms><wf>Jew"ish*ly</wf>, <pos>adv.</pos> --
<wf>Jew"ish*ness</wf>, <pos>n.</pos></wordforms>

<hw>Jew"ry</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[OE.
<ets>Jewerie</ets>, OF. <ets>Juierie</ets>, F.
<ets>Juiverie</ets>.]</ety> <def>Judea; also, a district
inhabited by Jews; a Jews' quarter.</def>

<au>Chaucer.</au>

<q>Teaching throughout all <qex>Jewry</qex>.</q>
<qau> Luke xxiii. 5.</qau>

<hw>Jew's"-ear`</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos>
<fld>(Bot.)</fld> <def>A species of fungus (<spn>Hirneola
Auricula-Jud\'91, <or/ Auricula</spn>), bearing some resemblance
to the human ear.</def>

<hw>Jew's-harp`</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos>
<ety>[<ets>Jew</ets> + <ets>harp</ets>; or possibly a corrupt. of
<ets>jaw's harp</ets>; cf. G. <ets>maultrommel</ets>, lit.,
mouthdrum.]</ety

<sn>1.</sn> <def>An instrument of music, which, when placed
between the teeth, gives, by means of a bent metal tongue struck
by the finger, a sound which is modulated by the breath; --
called also <altname>Jew's-trump</altname>.</def>

<sn>2.</sn> <fld>(Naut.)</fld> <def>The shackle for joining a
chain cable to an anchor.</def>

<mhw>{ <hw>Jew's-stone`</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <hw>Jew"stone`</hw>
<pr>(?)</pr> }</mhw>, <pos>n.</pos> <fld>(Paleon.)</fld> <def>A
large clavate spine of a fossil sea urchin.</def>

<hw>Jez"e*bel</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[From
<ets>Jezebel</ets>, Heb. <ets>Izebel</ets>, the wife of Ahab king
of Israel.]</ety> <def>A bold, vicious woman; a termagant.</def>

<au>Spectator.</au>

<hw>Jha"ral</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[Native
name.]</ety> <fld>(Zo\'94l.)</fld> <def>A wild goat (<spn>Capra
Jemlaica</spn>) which inhabits the loftiest mountains of India.
It has long, coarse hair, forming a thick mane on its head and
neck.</def>

<hw>Jib</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[Named from its
shifting from side to side. See <er>Jib</er>, <pos>v. i.</pos>.,
<er>Jibe</er>.]</ety>

<sn>1.</sn> <fld>(Naut.)</fld> <def>A triangular sail set upon a
stay or halyard extending from the foremast or fore-topmast to
the bowsprit or the jib boom. Large vessels often carry several
jibe; <as>as, inner <ex>jib</ex>; outer <ex>jib</ex>; flying
<ex>jib</ex>; etc.</as></def>

<sn>2.</sn> <fld>(Mach.)</fld> <def>The projecting arm of a
crane, from which the load is suspended.</def>

<cs><col>Jib boom</col> <fld>(Naut.)</fld>, <cd>a spar or boom
which serves as an extension of the bowsprit. It is sometimes
extended by another spar called the <xex>flying jib
boom</xex></cd>. <altsp>[Written also <asp>gib
boom</asp>.]</altsp> -- <col>Jib crane</col> <fld>(Mach.)</fld>,
<cd>a crane having a horizontal jib on which a trolley moves,
bearing the load.</cd> -- <col>Jib door</col> <fld>(Arch.)</fld>,
<cd>a door made flush with the wall, without dressings or
moldings; a disguised door.</cd> -- <col>Jib header</col>
<fld>(Naut.)</fld>, <cd>a gaff-topsail, shaped like a jib; a
jib-headed topsail.</cd> -- <col>Jib topsail</col>
<fld>(Naut.)</fld>, <cd>a small jib set above and outside of all
the other jibs.</cd> -- <col>The cut of one's jib</col>,
<cd>one's outward appearance. <mark>[Colloq.]</mark></cd></cs>

<au>Sir W. Scott. </au>

<hw>Jib</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>v. i.</pos> <ety>[Connected with
<ets>jibe</ets>; cf. OF. <ets>giber</ets> to shake.]</ety>
<def>To move restively backward or sidewise, -- said of a horse;
to balk.</def> <altsp>[Written also <asp>jibb</asp>.]</altsp>
<mark>[Eng.]</mark>

<hw>Jib"ber</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <def>A horse that
jibs.</def> <mark>[Eng.]</mark>

<hw>Jibe</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>v. t.</pos>
<wordforms>[<pos>imp. & p. p.</pos> <er>Jibed</er> <pr>(?)</pr>;
<pos>p. pr. & vb. n.</pos> <er>Jibing</er>
<pr>(?)</pr>.]</wordforms> <ety>[Cf. Dan. <ets>gibbe</ets>, D.
<ets>gijpen</ets>, <pos>v. i.</pos>, and dial. Sw.
<ets>gippa</ets> to jerk. Cf. <er>Jib</er>, <pos>n.</pos> &
<pos>v. i.</pos>]</ety> <fld>(Naut.)</fld> <def>To shift, as the
boom of a fore-and-aft sail, from one side of a vessel to the
other when the wind is aft or on the quarter. See
<er>Gybe</er>.</def>

<hw>Jibe</hw>, <pos>v. i.</pos> <sn>1.</sn> <fld>(Naut.)</fld>
<def>To change a ship's course so as to cause a shifting of the
boom. See <er>Jibe</er>, <pos>v. t.</pos>, and
<er>Gybe</er>.</def>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>To agree; to harmonize.</def>
<mark>[Colloq.]</mark>

<au>Bartlett.</au>

<hw>Jif"fy</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[Perh. corrupt.
fr. <ets>gliff</ets>.]</ety> <altsp>[Written also
<asp>giffy</asp>.]</altsp> <def>A moment; an instant; <as>as, I
will be ready in a <ex>jiffy</ex></as>.</def>
<mark>[Colloq.]</mark>

<au>J. & H. Smith.</au>

<hw>Jig</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[OF.
<ets>gigue</ets> a stringed instrument, a kind of dance, F.
<ets>gigue</ets> dance, tune, gig; of German origin; cf. MHG.
<ets>g\'c6ge</ets> fiddle, G. <ets>geige</ets>. Cf. <er>Gig</er>
a fiddle, <er>Gig</er> a whirligig.]</ety>

<sn>1.</sn> <fld>(Mus.)</fld> <def>A light, brisk musical
movement.</def>

<q>Hot and hasty, like a Scotch <qex>jib</qex>.</q>
<qau> Shak.</qau>

<sn>3.</sn> <def>A light, humorous piece of writing, esp. in
rhyme; a farce in verse; a ballad.</def> <mark>[Obs.]</mark>

<q>A <qex>jig</qex> shall be clapped at, and every rhyme
Praised and applauded.</q>
<qau>Beau. & Fl.</qau>

<sn>4.</sn> <def>A piece of sport; a trick; a prank.</def>
<mark>[Obs.]</mark>

<q>Is't not a fine <qex>jig</qex>,
A precious cunning, in the late Protector?</q>
<qau> Beau & Fl.</qau>

<sn>5.</sn> <def>A trolling bait, consisting of a bright spoon
and a hook attached.</def>

<sn>6.</sn> <fld>(Mach.)</fld> <sd>(a)</sd> <def>A small machine
or handy tool</def>; esp.: <fld>(Metal Working)</fld> <def>A
contrivance fastened to or inclosing a piece of work, and having
hard steel surfaces to guide a tool, as a drill, or to form a
shield or templet to work to, as in filing</def>. <sd>(b)</sd>
<fld>(Mining)</fld> <def>An apparatus or a machine for jigging
ore.</def>

<cs><col>Drill jig</col>, <cd>a jig for guiding a drill. See
<er>Jig</er>, <sn>6</sn> <sd>(a)</sd>.</cd> -- <mcol><col>Jig
drilling</col>, <col>Jig filing</col></mcol> <fld>(Metal
Working)</fld>, <cd>a process of drilling or filing in which the
action of the tool is directed or limited by a jig.</cd> --
<col>Jig saw</col>, <cd>a sawing machine with a narrow,
vertically reciprocating saw, used to cut curved and irregular
lines, or ornamental patterns in openwork, a scroll saw; --
called also <altname>gig saw</altname>.</cd></cs>

<hw>Jig</hw>, <pos>v. t.</pos> <wordforms>[<pos>imp. & p.
p.</pos> <er>Jigged</er> <pr>(?)</pr>; <pos>p. pr. & vb. n.</pos>
<er>Jigging</er> <pr>(?)</pr>.]</wordforms>

<sn>1.</sn> <def>To sing to the tune of a jig.</def>

<q><qex>Jig</qex> off a tune at the tongue's end.</q>
<qau> Shak.</qau>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>To trick or cheat; to cajole; to delude.</def>

<au>Ford.</au>

<sn>3.</sn> <fld>(Mining)</fld> <def>To sort or separate, as ore
in a jigger or sieve. See <er>Jigging</er>, <pos>n.</pos></def>

<sn>4.</sn> <fld>(Metal Working)</fld> <def>To cut or form, as a
piece of metal, in a jigging machine.</def>

<hw>Jig</hw>, <pos>v. i.</pos> <def>To dance a jig; to skip
about.</def>

<q>You <qex>jig</qex>, you amble, and you lisp.</q>
<qau> Shak.</qau>

<hw>Jig"ger</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[A corrupt. of
<ets>chigre</ets>.]</ety> <fld>(Zo\'94l.)</fld> <def>A species of
flea (<spn>Sarcopsylla, <or/ Pulex, penetrans</spn>), which
burrows beneath the skin. See <er>Chigoe</er>.</def>

<hw>Jig"ger</hw>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[See <er>Jig</er>, <ets>n. &
v.</ets>]</ety>

<sn>1.</sn> <def>One who, or that which, jigs; specifically, a
miner who sorts or cleans ore by the process of jigging; also,
the sieve used in jigging.</def>

<sn>2.</sn> <fld>(Pottery)</fld> <sd>(a)</sd> <def>A horizontal
table carrying a revolving mold, on which earthen vessels are
shaped by rapid motion; a potter's wheel.</def> <sd>(b)</sd>
<def>A templet or tool by which vessels are shaped on a potter's
wheel.</def>

<sn>3.</sn> <fld>(Naut.)</fld> <sd>(a)</sd> <def>A light tackle,
consisting of a double and single block and the fall, used for
various purposes, as to increase the purchase on a topsail sheet
in hauling it home; the watch tackle.</def> <au>Totten</au>.
<sd>(b)</sd> <def>A small fishing vessel, rigged like a
yawl.</def> <mark>[New Eng.]</mark> <sd>(c)</sd> <def>A
supplementary sail. See <er>Dandy</er>, <pos>n.</pos>, 2</def>
<sd>(b)</sd>.</def>

<sn>4.</sn> <def>A pendulum rolling machine for slicking or
graining leather; same as <er>Jack</er>, 4 <sd>(i)</sd>.</def>

<cs><col>Jigger mast</col>. <fld>(Naut.)</fld> <sd>(a)</sd>
<cd>The after mast of a four-masted vessel</cd>. <sd>(b)</sd>
<cd>The small mast set at the stern of a yawlrigged
boat.</cd></cs>

<hw>Jig"ging</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <fld>(Mining)</fld>
<def>The act or using a jig; the act of separating ore with a
jigger, or wire-bottomed sieve, which is moved up and down in
water.</def>

<cs><col>Jigging machine</col>. <sd>(a)</sd> <fld>(Mining)</fld>
<cd>A machine for separating ore by the process of jigging</cd>.
<sd>(b)</sd> <fld>(Metal Working)</fld> <cd>A machine with a
rotary milling cutter and a templet by which the action of the
cutter is guided or limited; -- used for forming the profile of
an irregularly shaped piece; a profiling machine.</cd></cs>

<hw>Jig"gish</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>a.</pos> <sn>1.</sn>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>Playful; frisky.</def> <mark>[R.]</mark>

<q>She is never sad, and yet not <qex>jiggish</qex>.</q>
<qau> Habington.</qau>

<mhw>{ <hw>Jin</hw>, <hw>Jinn</hw> <pr>(?)</pr> }</mhw>,
<pos>n.</pos> <def>See <er>Jinnee</er>.</def> \'bdSolomon is said
to have had power over the <xex>jin</xex>.\'b8

<hw>Jin*gal"</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[Hind.
<ets>jang\'bel</ets> a swivel, a large musket.]</ety> <def>A
small portable piece of ordnance, mounted on a swivel.</def>
<altsp>[Written also <asp>gingal</asp> and
<asp>jingall</asp>.]</altsp> <mark>[India]</mark>

<hw>Jin"gle</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>v. i.</pos> <ety>[OE.
<ets>gingelen</ets>, <ets>ginglen</ets>; prob. akin to E.
<ets>chink</ets>; cf. also E. <ets>jangle</ets>.]</ety>

<sn>1.</sn> <def>To sound with a fine, sharp, rattling, clinking,
or tinkling sound; <as>as, sleigh bells
<ex>jingle</ex></as>.</def> <altsp>[Written also
<asp>gingle</asp>.]</altsp>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>To rhyme or sound with a jingling effect.</def>
\'bd<xex>Jingling</xex> street ballads.\'b8

<au>Macaulay.</au>

<hw>Jin"gle</hw>, <pos>v. t.</pos> <wordforms>[<pos>imp. & p.
p.</pos> <er>Jingled</er> <pr>(?)</pr>; <pos>p. pr. & vb.
n.</pos> <er>Jingling</er> <pr>(?)</pr>.]</wordforms> <def>To
cause to give a sharp metallic sound as a little bell, or as
coins shaken together; to tinkle.</def>

<q>The bells she <qex>jingled</qex>, and the whistle blew.</q>
<qau> Pope.</qau>

<hw>Jin"gle</hw>, <pos>n.</pos> <sn>1.</sn> <def>A rattling,
clinking, or tinkling sound, as of little bells or pieces of
metal.</def>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>That which makes a jingling sound, as a
rattle.</def>

<q>If you plant where savages are, do not only entertain them
with trifles and <qex>jingles</qex>,but use them justly.</q>
<qau> Bacon.</qau>

<sn>3.</sn> <def>A correspondence of sound in rhymes, especially
when the verse has little merit; hence, the verse
itself.</def>\'bd The least <xex>jingle</xex> of verse.\'b8

<au>Guardian.</au>

<cs><col>Jingle shell</col>. <cd>See <cref>Gold shell</cref>
<sd>(b)</sd>, under <er>Gold</er>.</cd></cs>

<hw>Jin"gler</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <def>One who, or
that which, jingles.</def>

<hw>Jin"gling</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <def>The act or
process of producing a jingle; also, the sound itself; a
chink.</def> \'bdThe <xex>jingling</xex> of the guinea.\'b8

<au>Tennyson.</au>

<hw>Jin"gling*ly</hw>, <pos>adv.</pos> <def>So as to
jingle.</def>

<au>Lowell.</au>

<hw>Jin"go</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos>; <plu>pl.
<plw>Jingoes</plw> <pr>(#)</pr></plu>. <ety>[Said to be a
corruption of St. <ets>Gingoulph</ets>.]</ety>

<sn>1.</sn> <def>A word used as a jocular oath.</def> \'bdBy the
living <xex>jingo</xex>.\'b8

<au>Goldsmith.</au>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>A statesman who pursues, or who favors,
aggressive, domineering policy in foreign affairs.</def>
<mark>[Cant, Eng.]</mark>

<note><hand/ This sense arose from a doggerel song which was
popular during the Turco-Russian war of 1877 and 1878. The first
two lines were as follows: --

<q>We don't want to fight, but by <qex>Jingo</qex> if we do,
We 've got the ships, we 've got the men, we 've got the money
too.</q>
</note>

<hw>Jin"go*ism</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <def>The policy
of the Jingoes, so called. See <er>Jingo</er>, 2.</def>
<mark>[Cant, Eng.]</mark>

<hw>Jin"nee</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos>; <plu>pl.
<plw>Jinn</plw> <pr>(#)</pr></plu>. <ety>[Ar.]</ety>
<fld>(Arabian & Mohammedan Myth.)</fld> <def>A genius or demon;
one of the fabled genii, good and evil spirits, supposed to be
the children of fire, and to have the power of assuming various
forms.</def> <altsp>[Written also <asp>jin</asp>,
<asp>djinnee</asp>, etc.]</altsp>

<note><hand/ <xex>Jinn</xex> is also used as <pos>sing.</pos>,
with <pos>pl.</pos> <xex>jinns</xex> <pr>(<?/)</pr>.</note>

<hw>Jin"ny road`</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>. <ety>[Cf. <er>Gin</er> an
engine, <er>Ginnycarriage</er>.]</ety> <fld>(Mining)</fld>
<def>An inclined road in a coal mine, on which loaded cars
descend by gravity, drawing up empty ones.</def>

<au>Knight.</au>

<hw>Jin*rik"i*sha</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[Jap.
<ets>jin</ets> man + <ets>riki</ets> power + <ets>sha</ets>
carriage.]</ety> <def>A small, two-wheeled, hooded vehicle drawn
by one more men.</def> <mark>[Japan]</mark>

<hw>Jip"po</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[Abbrev. fr.
<ets>juppon</ets>.]</ety> <def>A waistcoat or kind of stays for
women.</def>

<hw>Jo</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos>; <plu>pl. <plw>Joes</plw>
<pr>(#)</pr></plu>. <ety>[Etymol. uncertain.]</ety> <def>A
sweetheart; a darling.</def> <mark>[Scot.]</mark>

<au>Burns.</au>

<hw>Job</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[Prov. E.
<ets>job</ets>, <ets>gob</ets>, <pos>n.</pos>, a small piece of
wood, v., to stab, strike; cf. E. <ets>gob</ets>,
<ets>gobbet</ets>; perh. influenced by E. <ets>chop</ets> to cut
off, to mince. See <er>Gob</er>.]</ety>

<sn>1.</sn> <def>A sudden thrust or stab; a jab.</def>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>A piece of chance or occasional work; any
definite work undertaken in gross for a fixed price; <as>as, he
did the <ex>job</ex> for a thousand dollars</as>.</def>

<sn>3.</sn> <def>A public transaction done for private profit;
something performed ostensibly as a part of official duty, but
really for private gain; a corrupt official business.</def>

<sn>4.</sn> <def>Any affair or event which affects one, whether
fortunately or unfortunately.</def> <mark>[Colloq.]</mark>

<-- p. 801 -->

<sn>5.</sn> <def>A situation or opportunity of work; <as>as, he
lost his <ex>job</ex></as>.</def> <mark>[Colloq.]</mark>

<note><hand/ <xex>Job</xex> is used adjectively to signify
<xex>doing jobs</xex>, <xex>used for jobs</xex>, or <xex>let on
hire to do jobs</xex>; as, <xex>job</xex> printer; <xex>job</xex>
master; <xex>job</xex> horse; <xex>job</xex> wagon, etc.</note>

<cs><col>By the job</col>, <cd>at a stipulated sum for the work,
or for each piece of work done; -- distinguished from <xex>time
work<xex>; <as>as, the house was built <ex>by the
job<ex></as>.</cd> -- <col>Job lot</col>, <cd>a quantity of
goods, usually miscellaneous, sold out of the regular course of
trade, at a certain price for the whole; <as>as, these articles
were included in a <ex>job lot<ex></as>.</cd> -- <col>Job
master</col>, <cd>one who lest out horses and carriages for hire,
as for family use.</cd> <mark>[Eng.]</mark> -- <col>Job
printer</col>, <cd>one who does miscellaneous printing, esp.
circulars, cards, billheads, etc.</cd> -- <col>Odd job</col>,
<cd>miscellaneous work of a petty kind; occasional work, of
various kinds, or for various people.</cd></cs>

<hw>Job</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>v. t.</pos> <wordforms>[<pos>imp.
& p. p.</pos> <er>Jobbed</er> <pr>(?)</pr>; <pos>p. pr. & vb.
n.</pos> <er>Jobbing</er>.]</wordforms>

<sn>1.</sn> <def>To strike or stab with a pointed
instrument.</def>

<au>L'Estrange.</au>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>To thrust in, as a pointed instrument.</def>

<au>Moxon.</au>

<sn>3.</sn> <def>To do or cause to be done by separate portions
or lots; to sublet (work); <as>as, to <ex>job</ex> a
contract</as>.</def>

<sn>4.</sn> <fld>(Com.)</fld> <def>To buy and sell, as a broker;
to purchase of importers or manufacturers for the purpose of
selling to retailers; <as>as, to <ex>job</ex> goods</as>.</def>

<sn>5.</sn> <def>To hire or let by the job or for a period of
service; <as>as, to <ex>job</ex> a carriage</as>.</def>

<au>Thackeray.</au>

<hw>Job</hw>, <pos>v. i.</pos> <sn>1.</sn> <def>To do chance work
for hire; to work by the piece; to do petty work.</def>

<q>Authors of all work, to <qex>job</qex> for the season.</q>
<qau>Moore.</qau>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>To seek private gain under pretense of public
service; to turn public matters to private advantage.</def>

<q>And judges <qex>job</qex>, and bishops bite the town.</q>
<qau>Pope.</qau>

<sn>3.</sn> <def>To carry on the business of a jobber in
merchandise or stocks.</def>

<hw>Job</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <def>The hero of the
book of that name in the Old Testament; the typical patient
man.</def>

<cs><col>Job's comforter</col>. <sd>(a)</sd> <cd>A false friend;
a tactless or malicious person who, under pretense of sympathy,
insinuates rebukes.</cd> <sd>(b)</sd> <cd>A boil</cd>.
<mark>[Colloq.]</mark> -- <col>Job's news</col>, <cd>bad news.
<au>Carlyle</au>.</cd> -- <col>Job's tears</col>
<fld>(Bot.)</fld>, <cd>a kind of grass (<spn>Coix Lacryma</spn>),
with hard, shining, pearly grains.</cd></cs>

<ets>job</ets> to scold, to reprove, perh. fr. <ets>Job</ets>,
the proper name.]</ety> <def>A scolding; a hand, tedious
reproof.</def> <mark>[Law]</mark>

<au>Grose.</au>

<hw>Job"ber</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <sn>1.</sn> <def>One
who works by the job.</def>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>A dealer in the public stocks or funds; a
stockjobber.</def> <mark>[Eng.]</mark>

<sn>3.</sn> <def>One who buys goods from importers, wholesalers,
or manufacturers, and sells to retailers.</def>

<sn>4.</sn> <def>One who turns official or public business to
private advantage; hence, one who performs low or mercenary work
in office, politics, or intrigue.</def>

excluded.</q>

sportive; funny; comical.</syn>

and serious life.</q>

<hw>Jog</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>v. t.</pos> <wordforms>[<pos>imp.
& p. p.</pos> <er>Jogged</er> <pr>(?)</pr>; <pos>p. pr. & vb.
n.</pos> <er>Jogging</er> <pr>(?)</pr>.]</wordforms> <ety>[OE.
<ets>joggen</ets>; cf. W. <ets>gogi</ets> to shake, and also E.
<ets>shog</ets>, <ets>shock</ets>, v.]</ety>

<sn>1.</sn> <def>To push or shake with the elbow or hand; to
jostle; esp., to push or touch, in order to give notice, to
excite one's attention, or to warn.</def>

<q>Now leaps he upright, <qex>jogs</qex> me, and cries: Do you
see
Yonder well-favored youth?</q>
<qau>Donne.</qau>

<q>Sudden I <qex>jogged</qex> Ulysses, who was laid
Fast by my side.</q>
<qau>Pope.</qau>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>To suggest to; to notify; to remind; to call the
attention of; <as>as, to <ex>jog</ex> the memory</as>.</def>

<sn>3.</sn> <def>To cause to jog; to drive at a jog, as a horse.
See <er>Jog</er>, <pos>v. i.</pos></def>

<hw>Jog</hw>, <pos>v. i.</pos> <def>To move by jogs or small
shocks, like those of a slow trot; to move slowly, leisurely, or
monotonously; -- usually with <xex>on</xex>, sometimes with
<xex>over</xex>.</def>

<q><qex>Jog</qex> on, <qex>jog</qex> on, the footpath way.</q>
<qau>Shak.</qau>

<q>So hung his destiny, never to rot,</q>

<q>While he might still <qex>jog</qex> on and keep his trot.</q>
<qau>Milton</qau>.

<q>The good old ways our sires <qex>jogged</qex> safely over.</q>
<qau>R. Browning.</qau>

<hw>Jog</hw>, <pos>n.</pos> <sn>1.</sn> <def>A slight shake; a
shake or push intended to give notice or awaken attention; a
push; a jolt.</def>

<q>To give them by turns an invisible <qex>jog</qex>.</q>
<qau>Swift.</qau>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>A rub; a slight stop; an obstruction; hence, an
irregularity in motion of from; a hitch; a break in the direction
of a line or the surface of a plane.</def>

<au>Glanvill.</au>

<cs><col>Jog trot</col>, <cd>a slow, regular, jolting gait;
hence, a routine habit or method, persistently adhered
to.</cd></cs>

<au>T. Hook.</au>

<hw>Jog"ger</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <def>One who
jogs.</def>

<au>Dryden.</au>

<hw>Jog"ging</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <def>The act of
giving a jog or jogs; traveling at a jog.</def>

<hw>Jog"gle</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>v. t.</pos>
<wordforms>[<pos>imp. & p. p.</pos> <er>Joggled</er>
<pr>(?)</pr>; <pos>p. pr. & vb. n.</pos> <er>Joggling</er>
<pr>(?)</pr>.]</wordforms> <ety>[Freq. of <ets>jog</ets>.]</ety>

<sn>1.</sn> <def>To shake slightly; to push suddenly but
slightly, so as to cause to shake or totter; to jostle; to
jog.</def>

<sn>2.</sn> <fld>(Arch.)</fld> <def>To join by means of joggles,
so as to prevent sliding apart; sometimes, loosely, to
dowel.</def>

<q>The struts of a roof are <qex>joggled</qex> into the truss
posts.</q>
<qau>Gwilt.</qau>

<hw>Jog"gle</hw>, <pos>v. i.</pos> <def>To shake or totter; to
slip out of place.</def>

<hw>Jog"gle</hw>, <pos>n.</pos> <mark>[Arch.]</mark> <def>A notch
or tooth in the joining surface of any piece of building material
to prevent slipping; sometimes, but incorrectly, applied to a
separate piece fitted into two adjacent stones, or the
like.</def>

<cs><col>Joggle joint</col> <fld>(Arch.)</fld>, <cd>a joint in
any kind of building material, where the joining surfaces are
made with joggles.</cd></cs>

Doree</col>, <col>John Dory</col></mcol>. <ety>[<ets>John<ets>

<hw>John"son grass`</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>. <ety>[Named after W.
<ets>Johnson</ets> of Alabama, who planted it about
1840-1845.]</ety> <fld>(Bot.)</fld> <def>A tall perennial grass
(<spn>Sorghum Halepense</spn>), valuable in the Southern and
Western States for pasture and hay. The rootstocks are large and
juicy and are eagerly sought by swine. Called also <altname>Cuba
grass</altname>, <altname>Means grass</altname>,
<altname>Evergreen millet</altname>, and <altname>Arabian
millet</altname>.</def>

<hw>Join</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>v. t.</pos>
<wordforms>[<pos>imp. & p. p.</pos> <er>Joined</er> <pr>(?)</pr>;
<pos>p. pr. & vb. n.</pos> <er>Joining</er>.]</wordforms>
<ety>[OE. <ets>joinen</ets>, <ets>joignen</ets>, F.
<ets>joindre</ets>, fr. L. <ets>jungere</ets> to yoke, bind
together, join; akin to <ets>jugum</ets> yoke. See <er>Yoke</er>,
and cf. <er>Conjugal</er>, <er>Junction</er>,
<er>Junta</er>.]</ety>

<sn>1.</sn> <def>To bring together, literally or figuratively; to
place in contact; to connect; to couple; to unite; to combine; to
associate; to add; to append.</def>

<q>Woe unto them that <qex>join</qex> house to house.</q>
<qau>Is. v. 8.</qau>

<q>Held up his left hand, which did flame and burn
Like twenty torches <qex>joined</qex>.</q>
<qau>Shak.</qau>

<q>Thy tuneful voice with numbers <qex>join</qex>.</q>
<qau>Dryden.</qau>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>To associate one's self to; to be or become
connected with; to league one's self with; to unite with; <as>as,
to <ex>join</ex> a party; to <ex>join</ex> the church.</as></def>

<q>We jointly now to <qex>join</qex> no other head.</q>
<qau>Dryden.</qau>

<sn>3.</sn> <def>To unite in marriage.</def>

<q>He that <qex>joineth</qex> his virgin in matrimony.</q>
<qau>Wyclif.</qau>

<q>What, therefore, God hath <qex>joined</qex> together, let not
man put asunder.</q>
<qau>Matt. xix. 6.</qau>

<sn>4.</sn> <def>To enjoin upon; to command.</def> <mark>[Obs. &
R.]</mark>

<q>They <qex>join</qex> them penance, as they call it.</q>
<qau>Tyndale.</qau>

<sn>5.</sn> <def>To accept, or engage in, as a contest; <as>as,
to <ex>join</ex> encounter, battle, issue</as>.</def>

<au>Milton.</au>

<cs><mcol><col>To join battle</col>, <col>To join
issue</col></mcol>. <cd>See under <er>Battle</er>,
<er>Issue</er>.</cd></cs>

<syn>Syn. -- To add; annex; unite; connect; combine; consociate;
couple; link; append. See <er>Add</er>.</syn>

<hw>Join</hw>, <pos>v. i.</pos> <def>To be contiguous, close, or
in contact; to come together; to unite; to mingle; to form a
union; <as>as, the hones of the skull <ex>join</ex>; two rivers
<ex>join</ex>.</as></def>

<q>Whose house <qex>joined</qex> hard to the synagogue.</q>
<qau>Acts xviii. 7.</qau>

<q>Should we again break thy commandments, and <qex>join</qex> in
affinity with the people of these abominations?</q>
<qau>Ezra ix. 14.</qau>

<q>Nature and fortune <qex>joined</qex> to make thee great.</q>
<qau>Shak.</qau>

<hw>Join</hw>, <pos>n.</pos> <fld>(Geom.)</fld> <def>The line
joining two points; the point common to two intersecting
lines.</def>

<au>Henrici.</au>

<hw>Join"ant</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>a.</pos> <ety>[OF. & F.
<ets>joignant</ets>, p. pr. of <ets>joindre</ets> to join.]</ety>
<def>Adjoining.</def> <mark>[Obs.]</mark>

<au>Chaucer.</au>

<hw>Join"der</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[F.
<ets>joindre</ets>. See <er>Join</er>, <pos>v. t.</pos>]</ety>

<sn>1.</sn> <def>The act of joining; a putting together;
conjunction.</def>

<q>Confirmed by mutual <qex>joinder</qex> of your hands.</q>
<qau>Shak.</qau>

<sn>2.</sn> <fld>(Law)</fld> <sd>(a)</sd> <def>A joining of
parties as plaintiffs or defendants in a suit.</def> <sd>(b)</sd>
<def>Acceptance of an issue tendered in law or fact.</def>
<sd>(c)</sd> <def>A joining of causes of action or defense in
civil suits or criminal prosecutions.</def>

<hw>Join"er</hw>, <pos>n.</pos> <sn>1.</sn> <def>One who, or that
which, joins.</def>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>One whose occupation is to construct articles by
joining pieces of wood; a mechanic who does the woodwork (as
doors, stairs, etc.) necessary for the finishing of
buildings.</def> \'bdOne Snug, the <xex>joiner</xex>.\'b8

<au>Shak.</au>

<sn>3.</sn> <def>A wood-working machine, for sawing, plaining,
mortising, tenoning, grooving, etc.</def>

<syn>Syn. -- See <er>Carpenter</er>.</syn>

<hw>Join"er*y</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <def>The art, or
trade, of a joiner; the work of a joiner.</def>

<q>A piece of <qex>joinery</qex> . . . whimsically
dovetailed.</q>
<qau>Burke.</qau>

<hw>Join"hand`</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <def>Writing in
which letters are joined in words; -- distinguished from writing
in single letters.</def>

<au>Addison.</au>

<hw>Joint</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[F.
<ets>joint</ets>, fr. <ets>joindre</ets>, <ets>p. p. joint</ets>.
See <er>Join</er>.]</ety>

<sn>1.</sn> <def>The place or part where two things or parts are
joined or united; the union of two or more smooth or even
surfaces admitting of a close-fitting or junction; junction as, a
<xex>joint</xex> between two pieces of timber; a <xex>joint</xex>
in a pipe.</def>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>A joining of two things or parts so as to admit
of motion; an articulation, whether movable or not; a hinge;
<as>as, the knee <ex>joint</ex>; a node or <ex>joint</ex> of a
stem; a ball and socket <ex>joint</ex></as>.  See
<er>Articulation</er>.</def>

<q>A scaly gauntlet now, with <qex>joints</qex> of steel,
Must glove this hand.</q>
<qau>Shak.</qau>

<q>To tear thee <qex>joint</qex> by <qex>joint</qex>.</q>
<qau>Milton.</qau>

<sn>3.</sn> <def>The part or space included between two joints,
knots, nodes, or articulations; <as>as, a <ex>joint</ex> of cane
or of a grass stem; a <ex>joint</ex> of the leg.</as></def>

<sn>4.</sn> <def>Any one of the large pieces of meat, as cut into
portions by the butcher for roasting.</def>

<sn>5.</sn> <fld>(Geol.)</fld> <def>A plane of fracture, or
divisional plane, of a rock transverse to the
stratification.</def>

<sn>6.</sn> <fld>(Arch.)</fld> <def>The space between the
adjacent surfaces of two bodies joined and held together, as by
means of cement, mortar, etc.; <as>as, a thin
<ex>joint</ex></as>.</def>

<sn>7.</sn> <def>The means whereby the meeting surfaces of pieces
in a structure are secured together.</def>

<cs><col>Coursing joint</col> <fld>(Masonry)</fld>, <cd>the
mortar joint between two courses of bricks or stones.</cd> --
<mcol><col>Fish joint</col>, <col>Miter joint</col>,
<col>Universal joint</col></mcol>, etc. <cd>See under
<er>Fish</er>, <er>Miter</er>, etc.</cd> -- <col>Joint
bolt</col>, <cd>a bolt for fastening two pieces, as of wood, one
endwise to the other, having a nut embedded in one of the
pieces.</cd> -- <col>Joint chair</col> <fld>(Railroad)</fld>,
<cd>the chair that supports the ends of abutting rails.</cd> --
<col>Joint coupling</col>, <cd>a universal joint for coupling
shafting. See under <er>Universal</er>.</cd> -- <col>Joint
hinge</col>, <cd>a hinge having long leaves; a strap hinge.</cd>
-- <col>Joint splice</col>, <cd>a re\'89nforce at a joint, to
sustain the parts in their true relation.</cd> -- <col>Joint
stool</col>. <sd>(a)</sd> <cd>A stool consisting of jointed
parts; a folding stool. <au>Shak</au>.</cd> <sd>(b)</sd> <cd>A
block for supporting the end of a piece at a joint; a joint
chair.</cd> -- <col>Out of joint</col>, <cd>out of place;
dislocated, as when the head of a bone slips from its socket;
hence, not working well together; disordered. \'bdThe time is
<xex>out of joint</xex>.\'b8 <au>Shak.</au></cd></cs>

<-- p. 802 -->

<hw>Joint</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>a.</pos> <ety>[F., <ets>p.
p.</ets> of <ets>joindre</ets>. See <er>Join</er>.]</ety>

<sn>1.</sn> <def>Joined; united; combined; concerted; as
<xex>joint</xex> action.</def>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>Involving the united activity of two or more;
done or produced by two or more working together.</def>

<q>I read this <qex>joint</qex> effusion twice over.</q>
<qau>T. Hook.</qau>

<sn>3.</sn> <def>United, joined, or sharing with another or with
others; not solitary in interest or action; holding in common
with an associate, or with associates; acting together; <as>as,
<ex>joint</ex> heir; <ex>joint</ex> creditor; <ex>joint</ex>
debtor, etc.</as></def> \'bd<xex>Joint</xex> tenants of the
world.\'b8

<au>Donne.</au>

<sn>4.</sn> <def>Shared by, or affecting two or more; held in
common; <as>as, <ex>joint</ex> property; a <ex>joint</ex>
bond.</as></def>

<q>A <qex>joint</qex> burden laid upon us all.</q>
<qau>Shak.</qau>

<cs><col>Joint committee</col> <fld>(Parliamentary
Practice)</fld>, <cd>a committee composed of members of the two
houses of a legislative body, for the appointment of which
concurrent resolutions of the two houses are necessary.
<au>Cushing</au>.</cd> -- <mcol><col>Joint meeting</col>, <or/
<col>Joint session</col></mcol>, <cd>the meeting or session of
two distinct bodies as one; <as>as, a <ex>joint meeting<ex> of
committees representing different corporations; a <ex>joint
session<ex> of both branches of a State legislature to chose a
United States senator.</as> \'bdSuch <ex>joint meeting<ex> shall
not be dissolved until the electoral votes are all counted and
the result declared.\'b8 <au>Joint Rules of Congress, U.
S</au>.</cd> -- <col>Joint resolution</col> <fld>(Parliamentary
Practice)</fld>, <cd>a resolution adopted concurrently by the two
branches of a legislative body. \'bdBy the constitution of the
United States and the rules of the two houses, no absolute
distinction is made between bills and <xex>joint
resolutions<xex>.\'b8 <au>Barclay (Digest)</au>.</cd> --
<col>Joint rule</col> <fld>(Parliamentary Practice)</fld>, <cd>a
rule of proceeding adopted by the concurrent action of both
branches of a legislative assembly. \'bdResolved, by the House of
Representatives (the Senate concurring), that the sixteenth and
seventeenth <xex>joint rules<xex> be suspended for the remainder
of the session.\'b8 <au>Journal H. of R., U. S</au>.</cd> --
<col>Joint and several</col> <fld>(Law)</fld>, <cd>a phrase
signifying that the debt, credit, obligation, etc., to which it
is applied is held in such a way that the parties in interest are
engaged both together and individually thus a <xex>joint and
several<xex> debt is one for which all the debtors may be sued
together or either of them individually.</cd> -- <col>Joint
stock</col>, <cd>stock held in company.</cd> -- <col>Joint-stock
company</col> <fld>(Law)</fld>, <cd>a species of partnership,
consisting generally of a large number of members, having a
capital divided, or agreed to be divided, into shares, the shares
owned by any member being usually transferable without the
consent of the rest.</cd> -- <col>Joint tenancy</col>
<fld>(Law)</fld>, <cd>a tenure by two or more persons of estate
by unity of interest, title, time, and possession, under which
the survivor takes the whole. <au>Blackstone</au>.</cd> --
<col>Joint tenant</col> <fld>(Law)</fld>, <cd>one who holds an
estate by joint tenancy.</cd></cs>

<hw>Joint</hw>, <pos>v. t.</pos> <wordforms>[<pos>imp. & p.
p.</pos> <er>Jointed</er>; <pos>p. pr. & vb. n.</pos>
<er>Jointing</er>.]</wordforms>

<sn>1.</sn> <def>To unite by a joint or joints; to fit together;
to prepare so as to fit together; <as>as, to <ex>joint</ex>
boards</as>.</def>

<q>Pierced through the yielding planks of <qex>jointed</qex>
wood.</q>
<qau>Pope.</qau>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>To join; to connect; to unite; to combine.</def>

<q><qex>Jointing</qex> their force 'gainst C\'91sar.</q>
<qau>Shak.</qau>

<sn>3.</sn> <def>To provide with a joint or joints; to
articulate.</def>

<q>The fingers are <qex>jointed</qex> together for motion.</q>
<qau>Ray.</qau>

<sn>4.</sn> <def>To separate the joints; of; to divide at the
joint or joints; to disjoint; to cut up into joints, as meat.
\'bdHe <xex>joints</xex> the neck.</def>

<au>Dryden.</au>

<q>Quartering, <qex>jointing</qex>, seething, and roasting.</q>
<qau>Holland.</qau>

<hw>Joint</hw>, <pos>v. i.</pos> <def>To fit as if by joints; to
coalesce as joints do; <as>as, the stones <ex>joint</ex>,
neatly</as>.</def>

<hw>Joint"ed</hw>, <pos>a.</pos> <def>Having joints; articulated;
full of nodes; knotty; <as>as, a <ex>jointed</ex> doll;
<ex>jointed</ex> structure.</as></def>  \'bdThe
<xex>jointed</xex> herbage.\'b8 <au>J. Philips</au>. --
<wordforms><wf>Joint"ed*ly</wf>, <pos>adv.</pos></wordforms>

<hw>Joint"er</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <sn>1.</sn>
<def>One who, or that which, joints.</def>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>A plane for smoothing the surfaces of pieces
which are to be accurately joined</def>; especially: <sd>(a)</sd>
<def>The longest plane used by a joiner</def>. <sd>(b)</sd>
<fld>(Coopering)</fld> <def>A long stationary plane, for plaining
the edges of barrel staves.</def>

<sn>3.</sn> <fld>(Masonry)</fld> <sd>(a)</sd> <def>A bent piece
of iron inserted to strengthen the joints of a wall.</def>
<sd>(b)</sd> <def>A tool for pointing the joints in
brickwork.</def>

<hw>Joint"-fir`</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos>
<fld>(Bot.)</fld> <def>A genus (<spn>Ephedra</spn>) of leafless
shrubs, with the stems conspicuously jointed; -- called also
<altname>shrubby horsetail</altname>. There are about thirty
species, of which two or three are found from Texas to
California.</def>

<hw>Joint"ing</hw>, <pos>n.</pos> <def>The act or process of
making a joint; also, the joints thus produced.</def>

<cs><col>Jointing machine</col>, <cd>a planing machine for wood
used in furniture and piano factories, etc.</cd> -- <col>Jointing
plane</col>. <cd>See <er>Jointer</er>, 2.</cd> -- <col>Jointing
rule</col> <fld>(Masonry)</fld>, <cd>a long straight rule, used
by bricklayers for securing straight joints and faces.</cd></cs>

<hw>Joint"less</hw>, <pos>a.</pos> <def>Without a joint; rigid;
stiff.</def>

<hw>Joint"ly</hw>, <pos>adv.</pos> <def>In a joint manner;
together; unitedly; in concert; not separately.</def>

<q>Then <qex>jointly</qex> to the ground their knees they
bow.</q>
<qau>Shak.</qau>

<hw>Joint"ress</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <fld>(Law)</fld>
<def>A woman who has a jointure.</def> <altsp>[Written also
<asp>jointuress</asp>.]</altsp>

<au>Blackstone.</au>

<hw>Join"ture</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[F.
<ets>jointure</ets> a joint, orig., a joining, L.
<ets>junctura</ets>, fr. <ets>jungere</ets> to join. See
<er>Join</er>, and cf. <er>Juncture</er>.]</ety>

<sn>1.</sn> <def>A joining; a joint.</def> <mark>[Obs.]</mark>

<sn>2.</sn> <fld>(Law)</fld> <def>An estate settled on a wife,
which she is to enjoy after husband's decease, for her own life
at least, in satisfaction of dower.</def>

<q>The <qex>jointure</qex> that your king must make,
Which with her dowry shall be counterpoised.</q>
<qau>Shak.</qau>

<au>Bouvier.</au>

<hw>Joint"weed`</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos>
<fld>(Bot.)</fld> <def>A slender, nearly leafless, American herb
(<spn>Polygonum articulatum</spn>), with jointed spikes of small
flowers.</def>

<hw>Joint"worm`</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos>
<fld>(Zo\'94l.)</fld> <def>The larva of a small, hymenopterous
fly (<spn>Eurytoma hordei</spn>), which is found in gall-like
swellings on the stalks of wheat, usually at or just above the
first joint. In some parts of America it does great damage to the
crop.</def>

<hw>Joist</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[OE.
<ets>giste</ets>, OF. <ets>giste</ets>, F. <ets>g\'8cte</ets>,
fr. <ets>gesir</ets> to lie, F. <ets>g\'82sir</ets>. See
<er>Gist</er>.]</ety> <fld>(Arch.)</fld> <def>A piece of timber
laid horizontally, or nearly so, to which the planks of the
floor, or the laths or furring strips of a ceiling, are nailed;
-- called, according to its position or use, <stype>binding
joist</stype>, <stype>bridging joist</stype>, <stype>ceiling
joist</stype>, <stype>trimming joist</stype>, etc. See
<xex>Illust</xex>. of <cref>Double-framed floor</cref>, under
<er>Double</er>, <pos>a.</pos></def>

<hw>Joist</hw>, <pos>v. t.</pos> <wordforms>[<pos>imp. & p.
p.</pos> <er>Joisted</er>; <pos>p. pr. & vb. n.</pos>
<er>Joisting</er>.]</wordforms> <def>To fit or furnish with

<au>Johnson.</au>

<hw>Joke</hw>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[L. <ets>jocus</ets>. Cf
<er>Jeopardy</er>, <er>Jocular</er>, <er>Juggler</er>.]</ety>

<sn>1.</sn> <def>Something said for the sake of exciting a laugh;
something witty or sportive (commonly indicating more of hilarity
or humor than <xex>jest</xex>); a jest; a witticism; <as>as, to
crack good-natured <ex>jokes</ex></as>.</def>

<q>And gentle dullness ever loves a <qex>joke</qex>.</q>
<qau>Pope.</qau>

<q>Or witty <qex>joke</qex> our airy senses moves
To pleasant laughter.</q>
<qau>Gay.</qau>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>Something not said seriously, or not actually
meant; something done in sport.</def>

<q>Inclose whole downs in walls, 't is all a <qex>joke</qex>.</q>
<qau>Pope.</qau>

<cs><col>In joke</col>, <cd>in jest; sportively; not meant
seriously.</cd> -- <col>Practical joke</col>. <cd>See under
<er>Practical</er>.</cd></cs>

<hw>Joke</hw>, <pos>v. t.</pos> <wordforms>[<pos>imp. & p.
p.</pos> <er>Joked</er> <pr>(?)</pr>; <pos>p. pr. & vb. n.</pos>
<er>Joking</er>.]</wordforms> <def>To make merry with; to make
jokes upon; to rally; to banter; <as>as, to joke a
comrade</as>.</def>

<hw>Joke</hw>, <pos>v. i.</pos> <ety>[L.
<ets>jocari</ets>.]</ety> <def>To do something for sport, or as a
joke; to be merry in words or actions; to jest.</def>

<q>He laughed, shouted, <qex>joked</qex>, and swore.</q>
<qau>Macaulay.</qau>

<syn>Syn. -- To jest; sport; rally; banter. See
<er>Jest</er>.</syn>

<au>Chaucer.</au>

<hw>Jol`li*fi*ca"tion</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos>

<er>-fy</er>.]</ety> <def>A merrymaking; noisy festivity.</def>

<q>We have had a <qex>jollification</qex> or so together.</q>

<au>Chaucer.</au>

<hw>Jol"li*ty</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[From
<er>Jolly</er>: cf. OF. <ets>joliet\'82</ets>,
<ets>jolivet\'82</ets>.]</ety> <def>Noisy mirth; gayety;
merriment; festivity; boisterous enjoyment.</def>

<au>Chaucer.</au>

<q>All now was turned to <qex>jollity</qex> and game.</q>
<qau>Milton.</qau>

<q>He with a proud <qex>jollity</qex> commanded him to leave that
quarrel only for him, who was only worthy to enter into it.</q>
<qau>Sir P. Sidney.</qau>

<syn>Syn. -- Merriment; mirth; gayety; festivity; hilarity.</syn>

<hw>Jol"ly</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>a.</pos>
<wordforms>[<pos>Compar.</pos> <er>Jollier</er> <pr>(?)</pr>;
<pos>superl.</pos> <er>Jolliest</er>.]</wordforms> <ety>[OF.
<ets>joli</ets>, <ets>jolif</ets>, joyful, merry, F.
<ets>joli</ets> pretty; of Scand. origin, akin to E.
<ets>yule</ets>; cf. Icel. <ets>j<?/l</ets> yule, Christmass
feast. See <er>Yule</er>.]</ety>

<sn>1.</sn> <def>Full of life and mirth; jovial; joyous; merry;
mirthful.</def>

<q>Like a <qex>jolly</qex> troop of huntsmen.</q>
<qau>Shak.</qau>

<q>\'bdA <qex>jolly</qex> place,\'b8 said he, \'bdin times of
old!
But something ails it now: the spot is cursed.\'b8</q>
<qau>Wordsworth.</qau>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>Expressing mirth, or inspiring it; exciting
mirth and gayety.</def>

<q>And with his <qex>jolly</qex> pipe delights the groves.</q>
<qau>Prior.</qau>

<q>Their <qex>jolly</qex> notes they chanted loud and clear.</q>
<qau>Fairfax.</qau>

<sn>3.</sn> <def>Of fine appearance; handsome; excellent; lively;
agreeable; pleasant.</def> \'bdA <xex>jolly</xex> cool wind.\'b8
<au>Sir T. North</au>. <mark>[Now mostly colloq.]</mark>

<q>Full <qex>jolly</qex> knight he seemed, and fair did sit.</q>
<qau>Spenser.</qau>

<q><qex>The</qex> coachman is swelled into <qex>jolly</qex>
dimensions.</q>
<qau>W. Irving.</qau>

<hw>Jol"ly-boat`</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[A

<fld>(Naut.)</fld> <def>A boat of medium size belonging to a

<hw>Jolt</hw>, <pos>v. i.</pos> <wordforms>[<pos>imp. & p.
p.</pos> <er>Jolted</er>; <pos>p. pr. & vb. n.</pos>
Jolting.]</wordforms> <ety>[Prob. fr. <ets>jole</ets>,
<ets>joll</ets>, <ets>jowl</ets>, and orig. meaning, to knock on
the head. See <er>Jowl</er>.]</ety> <def>To shake with short,
abrupt risings and fallings, as a carriage moving on rough
ground; <as>as, the coach <ex>jolts</ex></as>.</def>

<hw>Jolt</hw>, <pos>v. t.</pos> <def>To cause to shake with a
sudden up and down motion, as in a carriage going over rough
ground, or on a high-trotting horse; <as>as, the horse
<ex>jolts</ex> the rider; fast driving <ex>jolts</ex> the
carriage and the passengers.</as></def>

<hw>Jolt</hw>, <pos>n.</pos> <def>A sudden shock or jerk; a
jolting motion, as in a carriage moving over rough ground.</def>

<q>The first <qex>jolt</qex> had like to have shaken me out.</q>
<qau>Swift.</qau>

<hw>Jolt"er</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <def>One who, or
that which, jolts.</def>

<hw>Jo"nah</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <def>The Hebrew
prophet, who was cast overboard as one who endangered the ship;
hence, any person whose presence is unpropitious.</def>

<cs><col>Jonah crab</col> <fld>(Zo\'94l.)</fld>, <cd>a large crab
(<spn>Cancer borealis</spn>) of the eastern coast of the United
States, sometimes found between tides, but usually in deep
water.</cd></cs>

<hw>Jo*ne"sian</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>a.</pos> <def>Of or
pertaining to Jones.</def>

<cs><col>The Jonesian system</col>, <cd>a system of
transliterating Oriental words by English letters, invented by
Sir William Jones.</cd></cs>

<mhw>{ <hw>Jon"gleur</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <hw>Jon"gler</hw>
<pr>(?)</pr>, }</mhw> <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[F. <ets>jongleur</ets>.
See <er>Juggler</er>.]</ety>

<sn>1.</sn> <def>In the Middle Ages, a court attendant or other
person who, for hire, recited or sang verses, usually of his own
composition. See <er>Troubadour</er>.</def>

<q>Vivacity and picturesquenees of the <qex>jongleur's
verse</qex>.</q>
<qau>J R. Green.</qau>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>A juggler; a conjuror. See
<er>Juggler</er>.</def>

<au>Milton.</au>

<mhw>{ <hw>Jon"quil</hw>, <hw>Jon"quille</hw>  }</mhw>,
<pos>n.</pos> <ety>[F. <ets>jonquille</ets>, fr. L.
<ets>juncus</ets> a rush, because it has rushlike leaves.]</ety>
<fld>(Bot.)</fld> <def>A bulbous plant of the genus Narcissus
(<spn>N. Jonquilla</spn>), allied to the daffodil. It has long,
rushlike leaves, and yellow or white fragrant flowers. The root
has emetic properties. It is sometimes called the
<altname>rush-leaved daffodil</altname>. See <xex>Illust</xex>.
of <er>Corona</er>.</def>

<hw>Joule</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[From the
distinguished English physicist, James P.
<ets>Joule</ets>.]</ety> <fld>(Physics.)</fld> <def>A unit of
work which is equal to 10<exp>7</exp> units of work in the C. G.
S. system of units (ergs), and is practically equivalent to the
energy expended in one second by an electric current of one
ampere in a resistance of one ohm. One <xex>joule</xex> is
approximately equal to 0.738 foot pounds.</def>

<cs><col>Joule's equivalent</col>. <cd>See under
<er>Equivalent</er>, <pos>n.</pos></cd></cs>

<hw>Jounce</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>v. t. & i.</pos>

<pr>(?)</pr>.]</wordforms> <ety>[Cf. <er>Jaunce</er>.]</ety>
<def>To jolt; to shake, especially by rough riding or by driving
over obstructions.</def>

<hw>Jour"nal</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>a.</pos> <ety>[F., fr. L.
<ets>diurnalis</ets> diurnal, fr. <ets>diurnus</ets> belonging to
the day, fr. <ets>dies</ets> day. See <er>Diurnal</er>.]</ety>
<def>Daily; diurnal.</def> <mark>[Obs.]</mark>

<q>Whiles from their <qex>journal</qex> labors they did rest.</q>
<qau>Spenser.</qau>

<hw>Jour"nal</hw>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[F. <ets>journal</ets>. See
<er>Journal</er>, <pos>a.</pos>]</ety>

<sn>1.</sn> <def>A diary; an account of daily transactions and
events</def>. Specifically: <sd>(a)</sd> <fld>(Bookkeeping)</fld>
<def>A book of accounts, in which is entered a condensed and
grouped statement of the daily transactions.</def> <sd>(b)</sd>
<fld>(Naut.)</fld> <def>A daily register of the ship's course and
distance, the winds, weather, incidents of the voyage, etc.</def> 
<sd>(c)</sd> <fld>(Legislature)</fld> <def>The record of daily
proceedings, kept by the clerk</def>. <sd>(d)</sd> <def>A
newspaper published daily; by extension, a weekly newspaper or
any periodical publication, giving an account of passing events,
the proceedings and memoirs of societies, etc.</def> ; a
periodical; a magazine.

<-- p. 803 -->

<sn>2.</sn> <def>That which has occurred in a day; a day's work
or travel; a day's journey.</def> <mark>[Obs. &
<er>R</er>.]</mark>

<au>B. Jonson.</au>

<sn>3.</sn> <fld>(Mach.)</fld> <def>That portion of a rotating
piece, as a shaft, axle, spindle, etc., which turns in a bearing
or box. See <xex>Illust</xex>. of <er>Axle box</er>.</def>

<cs><mcol><col>Journal box</col>, <or/ <col>Journal
bearing</col></mcol> <fld>(Mach.)</fld> <cd>the carrier of a
journal; the box in which the journal of a shaft, axle, or pin
turns.</cd></cs>

<hw>Jour"nal*ism</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[Cf. F.
<ets>journalisme</ets>.]</ety>

<sn>1.</sn> <def>The keeping of a journal or diary.</def>
<mark>[Obs.]</mark>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>The periodical collection and publication of
current news; the business of managing, editing, or writing for,
journals or newspapers; <as>as, political
<ex>journalism</ex></as>.</def>

<q><qex>Journalism</qex> is now truly an estate of the realm.</q>
<qau>Ed. Rev.</qau>

<hw>Jour"nal*ist</hw>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[Cf. F.
<ets>journaliste</ets>.]</ety>

<sn>1.</sn> <def>One who keeps a journal or diary.</def>
<mark>[Obs.]</mark>

<au>Mickle.</au>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>The conductor of a public journal, or one whose
business it to write for a public journal; an editorial or other
professional writer for a periodical.</def>

<au>Addison.</au>

<hw>Jour"nal*is"tic</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>a.</pos>
<def>Pertaining to journals or to journalists; contained in, or
characteristic of, the public journals; as
<xex>journalistic</xex> literature or enterprise.</def>

<hw>Jour"nal*ize</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>v. t.</pos>
<wordforms>[<pos>imp. & p. p.</pos> <er>Journalized</er>
<pr>(?)</pr>; <pos>p. pr. & vb. n.</pos> <er>Journalizing</er>
<pr>(?)</pr>.]</wordforms> <def>To enter or record in a journal
or diary.</def>

<au>Johnson.</au>

<hw>Jour"nal*ize</hw>, <pos>v. i.</pos> <def>to conduct or
contribute to a public journal; to follow the profession of a
journalist.</def>

<hw>Jour"ney</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos>; <plu>pl.
<plw>Journeys</plw> <pr>(#)</pr></plu>. <ety>[OE.
<ets>jornee</ets>, <ets>journee</ets>, prop., a day's journey,
OF. <ets>jorn\'82e</ets>, <ets>jurn\'82e</ets>, a day, a day's
work of journey, F. <ets>journ\'82e</ets>, fr. OF.
<ets>jorn</ets>, <ets>jurn</ets>, <ets>jor</ets> a day, F.
<ets>jour</ets>, fr. L. <ets>diurnus</ets>. See
<er>Journal</er>.]</ety>

<sn>1.</sn> <def>The travel or work of a day.</def>
<mark>[Obs.]</mark>

<au>Chaucer.</au>

<q>We have yet large day, for scarce the sun
Hath finished half his <qex>journey</qex>.</q>
<qau>Milton.</qau>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>Travel or passage from one place to another;
hence, figuratively, a passage through life.</def>

<q>The good man . . . is gone a long <qex>journey</qex>.</q>
<qau>Prov. vii. 19.</qau>

<q><qex>We</qex> must all have the same <qex>journey's
end</qex>.</q>
<qau>Bp. Stillingfleet.</qau>

<syn>Syn. -- Tour; excursion; trip; expedition; pilgrimage.</syn>
<usage> -- <er>Journey</er>, <er>Tour</er>, <er>Excursion</er>,
<er>Pilgrimage</er>. The word <xex>journey</xex> suggests the
idea of a somewhat prolonged traveling for a specific object,
leading a person to pass directly from one point to another. In a
<xex>tour</xex>, we take a roundabout course from place to place,
more commonly for pleasure, though sometimes on business. An
<xex>excursion</xex> is usually a brief tour or trip for
pleasure, health, etc. In a <xex>pilgrimage</xex> we travel to a
place hallowed by our religions affections, or by some train of
sacred or tender associations. A <xex>journey</xex> on important
business; the <xex>tour</xex> of Europe; an <xex>excursion</xex>
to the lakes; a <xex>pilgrimage</xex> to the Holy Land.</usage>

<hw>Jour"ney</hw>, <pos>v. i.</pos> <wordforms>[<pos>imp. & p.
p.</pos> <er>Journeyed</er> <pr>(?)</pr>; <pos>p. pr. & vb.
n.</pos> <er>Journeying</er>.]</wordforms> <def>To travel from
place to place; to go from home to a distance.</def>

<q>Abram <qex>journeyed</qex>, going on still toward the
south.</q>
<qau>Gen. xii. 9. </qau>

<hw>Jour"ney</hw>, <pos>v. t.</pos> <def>To traverse; to travel
over or through.</def> <mark>[R.]</mark> \'bdI
<xex>journeyed</xex> many a land.\'b8

<au>Sir W. Scott.</au>

<hw>Jour"ney-bat`ed</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>a.</pos> <def>Worn
out with journeying.</def> <mark>[Obs.]</mark>

<au>Shak.</au>

<hw>Jour"ney*er</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <def>One who
journeys.</def>

<hw>Jour"ney*man</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos>; <plu>pl.
<plw>Journeymen</plw> <pr>(<?/)</pr>.</plu> <def>Formerly, a man
hired to work by the day; now, commonly, one who has mastered a
handicraft or trade; -- distinguished from <xex>apprentice</xex>
and from <xex>master workman</xex>.</def>

<q>I have thought some of nature's <qex>journeymen</qex> had made
men, and not made them well.</q>
<qau>Shak.</qau>

<hw>Jour"ney*work`</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos>
<def>Originally, work done by the day; work done by a journeyman
at his trade.</def>

<hw>Joust</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>v. i.</pos> <ety>[OE.
<ets>justen</ets>, <ets>jousten</ets>, OF. <ets>jouster</ets>,
<ets>jouster</ets>, <ets>joster</ets>, F. <ets>jouter</ets>, fr.
L. <ets>juxta</ets> near to, nigh, from the root of
<ets>jungere</ets> to join. See <er>Join</er>, and cf.
<er>Jostle</er>.]</ety> <def>To engage in mock combat on
horseback, as two knights in the lists; to tilt.</def>
<altsp>[Written also <asp>just</asp>.]</altsp>

<q>For the whole army to <qex>joust</qex> and tourney.</q>
<qau>Holland.</qau>

<hw>Joust</hw>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[OE. <ets>juste</ets>,
<ets>jouste</ets>, OF. <ets>juste</ets>, <ets>jouste</ets>,
<ets>joste</ets>, F. <ets>joute</ets>. See <er>Joust</er>,
<pos>v. i.</pos>]</ety> <def>A tilting match; a mock combat on
horseback between two knights in the lists or inclosed
field.</def> <altsp>[Written also <asp>just</asp>.]</altsp>

<q>Gorgeous knights at <qex>joust</qex> and tournament.</q>
<qau>Milton.</qau>

<hw>Joust"er</hw>, <pos>n.</pos> <def>One who jousts or
tilts.</def>

<hw>Jove</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[L.
<ets>Jupiter</ets>, gen. <ets>Jovis</ets>, OL. <ets>Jovis</ets>,
nom. & gen. for <ets>Djovis</ets>; akin to E. <ets>Tuesday</ets>.
See <er>Tuesday</er>, and cf. <er>Jupiter</er>.]</ety>

<sn>1.</sn> <def>The chief divinity of the ancient Romans;
Jupiter.</def>

<sn>2.</sn> <fld>(Astron.)</fld> <def>The planet Jupiter.</def>
<mark>[R.]</mark>

<au>Pope.</au>

<sn>3.</sn> <fld>(Alchemy)</fld> <def>The metal tin.</def>

<cs><col>Bird of Jove</col>, <cd>the eagle.</cd></cs>

<hw>Jo"vi*al</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>a.</pos> <ety>[F., fr. L.
<ets>Jovialis</ets> pertaining to Jove. The planet Jupiter was
thought to make those born under it joyful or jovial. See
<er>Jove</er>.]</ety>

<sn>1.</sn> <def>Of or pertaining to the god, or the planet,
Jupiter.</def> <mark>[Obs.]</mark>

<q>Our <qex>jovial</qex> star reigned at his birth.</q>
<qau>Shak.</qau>

<q>The fixed stars astrologically differenced by the planets, and
esteemed Martial or <qex>Jovial</qex> according to the colors
whereby they answer these planets.</q>
<qau>Sir T. Browne.</qau>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>Sunny; serene.</def> <mark>[Obs.]</mark> \'bdThe
heavens always <xex>joviall</xex>.\'b8

<au>Spenser.</au>

<sn>3.</sn> <def>Gay; merry; joyous; jolly; mirth-inspiring;
hilarious; characterized by mirth or jollity; <as>as, a
<ex>jovial</ex> youth; a <ex>jovial</ex> company; a
<ex>jovial</ex> poem.</as></def>

<q>Be bright and <qex>jovial</qex> among your guests.</q>
<qau>Shak.</qau>

<q>His odes are some of them panegyrical, others moral; the rest
are <qex>jovial</qex> or bacchanalian.</q>
<qau>Dryden.</qau>

<note><hand/ This word is a relic of the belief in planetary
influence. Other examples are <xex>saturnine</xex>,
<xex>mercurial</xex>, <xex>martial</xex>, <xex>lunatic</xex>,
etc.</note>

<syn>Syn. -- Merry; joyous; gay; festive; mirthful; gleeful;
jolly; hilarious.</syn>

<hw>Jo"vi*al*ist</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <def>One who
lives a jovial life.</def>

<au>Bp. Hall.</au>

<hw>Jo`vi*al"i*ty</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[Cf. F.
<ets>jovialit\'82</ets>.]</ety> <def>The quality or state of
being jovial.</def>

<au>Sir T. Herbert.</au>

<hw>Jo"vi*al*ly</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>adv.</pos> <def>In a
jovial manner; merrily; gayly.</def>

<au>B. Jonson.</au>

<hw>Jo"vi*al*ness</hw>, <pos>n.</pos> <def>Noisy mirth;
joviality.</def>

<au>Hewyt.</au>

<hw>Jo"vi*al*ty</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos>
<def>Joviality.</def> <mark>[R.]</mark>

<au>Barrow.</au>

<hw>Jo"vi*an</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>a.</pos> <def>Of or
pertaining to Jove, or Jupiter (either the deity or the

<hw>Jo`vi*cen"tric</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>a.</pos> <ety>[See
<er>Jove</er>, and <er>Center</er>.]</ety> <fld>(Astron.)</fld>
<def>Revolving around the planet Jupiter; appearing as viewed
from Jupiter.</def> <mark>[R.]</mark>

<au>J. R. Hind.</au>

<hw>Jo*vin"ian*ist</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <fld>(Script.
Hist.)</fld> <def>An adherent to the doctrines of Jovinian, a
monk of the fourth century, who denied the virginity of Mary, and
opposed the asceticism of his time.</def>

<hw>Jowl</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[For older
<ets>chole</ets>, <ets>chaul</ets>, AS. <ets>ceaft</ets> jaw. Cf.
<er>Chaps</er>.]</ety> <def>The cheek; the jaw.</def>
<altsp>[Written also <asp>jole</asp>, <asp>choule</asp>,
<asp>chowle</asp>, and <asp>geoule</asp>.]</altsp>

<cs><col>Cheek by jowl</col>, <cd>with the cheeks close together;
side by side; in close proximity.</cd> \'bdI will go with three
<xex>cheek by jole<xex>.\'b8 <au>Shak</au>.  \'bd Sits <xex>cheek
by jowl<xex>.\'b8</cs>

<au>Dryden.</au>

<hw>Jowl</hw>, <pos>v. t.</pos> <def>To throw, dash, or
knock.</def> <mark>[Obs.]</mark>

<q>How the knave <qex>jowls</qex> it to the ground.</q>
<qau>Shak.</qau>

<hw>Jowl"er</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos>
<fld>(Zo\'94l.)</fld> <def>A dog with large jowls, as the
beagle.</def>

<hw>Jow"ter</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <def>A mounted
peddler of fish; -- called also <altname>jouster</altname>.</def>
<mark>[Obs.]</mark>

<au>Carew.</au>

<hw>Joy</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[OE.
<ets>joye</ets>, OF. <ets>joye</ets>, <ets>joie</ets>,
<ets>goie</ets>, F. <ets>joie</ets>, L. <ets>gaudia</ets>, pl. of
<ets>gaudium</ets> joy, fr. <ets>gaudere</ets> to rejoice, to be
glad; cf. Gr. <?/ to rejoice, <?/ proud. Cf. <er>Gaud</er>,
<er>Jewel</er>.]</ety>

<sn>1.</sn> <def>The passion or emotion excited by the
acquisition or expectation of good; pleasurable feelings or
emotions caused by success, good fortune, and the like, or by a
rational prospect of possessing what we love or desire; gladness;
exhilaration of spirits; delight.</def>

<q>Her heavenly form beheld, all wished her <qex>joy</qex>.</q>
<qau>Dryden.</qau>

<q>Glides the smooth current of domestic <qex>joy</qex>.</q>
<qau>Johnson.</qau>

<q>Who, for the <qex>joy</qex> that was set before him, endured
the cross, despising the shame.</q>
<qau>Heb. xii. 2. </qau>

<q>Tears of true <qex>joy</qex> for his return.</q>
<qau>Shak.</qau>

<q><qex>Joy</qex> is a delight of the mind, from the
consideration of the present or assured approaching possession of
a good.</q>
<qau>Locke.</qau>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>That which causes joy or happiness.</def>

<q>For ye are our glory and <qex>joy</qex>.</q>
<qau>1 Thess. ii. 20.</qau>

<q> A thing of beauty is a <qex>joy</qex> forever.</q>
<qau>Keats.</qau>

<sn>3.</sn> <def>The sign or exhibition of joy; gayety; mirth;
merriment; festivity.</def>

<q>Such <qex>joy</qex> made Una, when her knight she found.</q>
<qau>Spenser.</qau>

<q>The roofs with <qex>joy</qex> resound.</q>
<qau>Dryden.</qau>

<note><hand/ <xex>Joy</xex> is used in composition, esp. with
participles, to from many self-explaining compounds; as,
<xex>joy</xex>-hells, <xex>joy</xex>-ringing,
<xex>joy</xex>-inspiring, <xex>joy</xex>-resounding, etc.</note>

<syn>Syn. -- Gladness; pleasure; delight; happiness; exultation;
transport; felicity; ecstasy; rapture; bliss; gayety; mirth;
merriment; festivity; hilarity.</syn>

<hw>Joy</hw>, <pos>v. i.</pos> <wordforms>[<pos>imp. & p.
p.</pos> <er>Joyed</er> <pr>(?)</pr>; <pos>p. pr. & vb. n.</pos>
<er>Joying</er>.]</wordforms> <ety>[OF. <ets>joir</ets>, F.
<ets>jouir</ets>. See <er>Joy</er>, <pos>n.</pos>]</ety> <def>To
rejoice; to be glad; to delight; to exult.</def>

<q>I will <qex>joy</qex> in the God of my salvation.</q>
<qau>Hab. iii. 18.</qau>

<q>In whose sight all things <qex>joy</qex>.</q>
<qau>Milton.</qau>

<hw>Joy</hw>, <pos>v. t.</pos> <sn>1.</sn> <def>To give joy to;
to congratulate.</def> <mark>[Obs.]</mark> \'bd<xex>Joy</xex> us
of our conquest.\'b8

<au>Dryden.</au>

<q>To <qex>joy</qex> the friend, or grapple with the foe.</q>
<qau>Prior.</qau>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>To gladden; to make joyful; to exhilarate.</def>
<mark>[Obs.]</mark>

<q>Neither pleasure's art can <qex>joy</qex> my spirits.</q>
<qau>Shak.</qau>

<sn>3.</sn> <def>To enjoy. <mark>[Obs.]</mark> See
<er>Enjoy</er>.</def>

<q>Who might have lived and <qex>joyed</qex> immortal bliss.</q>
<qau>Milton.</qau>

Is <qex>joyless</qex> of the grove, and spurns the growing

<hw>Joy"ous</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>a.</pos> <ety>[OE.

<qau>Spenser.</qau>

<q>And <qex>joyous</qex> of our conquest early won.</q>
<qau>Dryden.</qau>

sportive; festive; joyful; happy; blissful; charming;
delightful.</syn>

<hw>Ju"bi*lant</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>a.</pos> <ety>[L.

<hw>Ju"bi*lar</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>a.</pos> <ety>[Cf. F.

<hw>Ju`bi*la"te</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[L.,
imperat. of <ets>jubilare</ets> to shout for joy.]</ety>

<sn>1.</sn> <def>The third Sunday after Easter; -- so called
because the introit is the 66th Psalm, which, in the Latin
version, begins with the words, \'bdJubilate Deo.\'b8</def>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>A name of the 100th Psalm; -- so called from its
opening word in the Latin version.</def>

<hw>Ju"bi*late</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>v. i.</pos> <ety>[L.
<ets>jubilatus</ets>, <ets>p. p.</ets> of
<ets>jubilare</ets>.]</ety> <def>To exult; to rejoice.</def>
