<au>De Quincey.</au>

<hw>Ju`bi*la"tion</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[L.
<ets>jubilatio</ets>: cf. F. <ets>jubilation</ets>.]</ety> <def>A
triumphant shouting; rejoicing; exultation.</def>
\'bd<xex>Jubilations</xex> and hallelujahs.\'b8

<au>South.</au>

<hw>Ju"bi*lee</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[F.
<ets>jubil\'82</ets>, L. <ets>jubilaeus</ets>, Gr. <?/, fr. Heb.
<ets>y<?/bel</ets> the blast of a trumpet, also the grand
sabbatical year, which was announced by sound of trumpet.]</ety>

<sn>1.</sn> <fld>(Jewish Hist.)</fld> <def>Every fiftieth year,
being the year following the completion of each seventh sabbath
of years, at which time all the slaves of Hebrew blood were
liberated, and all lands which had been alienated during the
whole period reverted to their former owners.</def> <altsp>[In
this sense spelled also, in some English Bibles,
<asp>jubile</asp>.]</altsp>

<au>Lev. xxv. 8-17.</au>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>The joyful commemoration held on the fiftieth
anniversary of any event; <as>as, the <ex>jubilee</ex> of Queen
Victoria's reign; the <ex>jubilee</ex> of the American Board of
Missions.</as></def>

<sn>3.</sn> <fld>(R. C. Ch.)</fld> <def>A church solemnity or
ceremony celebrated at Rome, at stated intervals, originally of
one hundred years, but latterly of twenty-five; a plenary and
extraordinary indulgence grated by the sovereign pontiff to the
universal church. One invariable condition of granting this
indulgence is the confession of sins and receiving of the
eucharist.</def>

<sn>4.</sn> <def>A season of general joy.</def>

<q>The town was all a <qex>jubilee</qex> of feasts.</q>
<qau>Dryden.</qau>

<sn>5.</sn> <def>A state of joy or exultation.</def>
<mark>[R.]</mark> \'bdIn the <xex>jubilee</xex> of his
spirits.\'b8

<au>Sir W. Scott.</au>

<hw>Ju*cun"di*ty</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[L.
<ets>jucunditas</ets>, from <ets>jucundus</ets>.]</ety>
<def>Pleasantness; agreeableness. See <er>Jocundity</er>.</def>
<mark>[R.]</mark>

<au>Sir T. Browne.</au>

<hw>Ju"dah*ite</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <def>One of the
tribe of Judah; a member of the kingdom of Judah; a Jew.</def>

<au>Kitto.</au>

<mhw>{ <hw>Ju*da"ic</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <hw>Ju*da"ic*al</hw>

<sn>1.</sn> <def>The religious doctrines and rites of the Jews as

<au>J. S. Mill.</au>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>Conformity to the Jewish rites and
ceremonies.</def>

<hw>Ju"da*ist</hw>, <pos>n.</pos> <def>One who believes and
practices Judaism.</def>

<hw>Ju`da*is"tic</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>a.</pos> <def>Of or
pertaining to Judaism.</def>

<hw>Ju`da*i*za"tion</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <def>The act
of Judaizing; a conforming to the Jewish religion or
ritual.</def> <mark>[R.]</mark>

<hw>Ju"da*ize</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>v. i.</pos>
<wordforms>[<pos>imp. & p. p.</pos> <er>Judaized</er>
<pr>(?)</pr>; <pos>p. pr. & vb. n.</pos> <er>Judaizing</er>
<pr>(?)</pr>.]</wordforms> <ety>[Cf. F.
<ets>juda\'8bser</ets>.]</ety> <def>To conform to the doctrines,
observances, or methods of the Jews; to inculcate or impose
Judaism.</def>

<q>They . . . prevailed on the Galatians to <qex>Judaize</qex> so
far as to observe the rites of Moses in various instances.
They were <qex>Judaizing</qex> doctors, who taught the
observation of the Mosaic law.</q>
<qau>Bp. Bull.</qau>

<hw>Ju"da*ize</hw>, <pos>v. t.</pos> <def>To impose Jewish
observances or rites upon; to convert to Judaism.</def>

<q>The heretical Theodotion, the <qex>Judaized</qex>
Symmachus.</q>
<qau>Milton.</qau>

<hw>Ju"da*i`zer</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <def>One who
conforms to or inculcates Judaism; specifically, <pluf>pl.</pluf>
<fld>(Ch. Hist.)</fld>, those Jews who accepted Christianity but
still adhered to the law of Moses and worshiped in the temple at
Jerusalem.</def>

<hw>Ju"das</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <def>The disciple who
betrayed Christ. Hence: A treacherous person; one who betrays
under the semblance of friendship.</def> -- <def2><pos>a.</pos>
<def>Treacherous; betraying.</def></def2>

<cs><col>Judas hole</col>, <cd>a peephole or secret opening for
spying.</cd> -- <col>Judas kiss</col>, <cd>a deceitful and
treacherous kiss.</cd> -- <col>Judas tree</col>
<fld>(Bot.)</fld>, <cd>a leguminous tree of the genus
<spn>Cercis</spn>, with pretty, rose-colored flowers in clusters
along the branches. Judas is said to have hanged himself on a
tree of this genus (<spn>C. Siliquastrum</spn>). <spn>C.
Canadensis</spn> and <spn>C. occidentalis</spn> are the American
species, and are called also <altname>redbud</altname>.</cd></cs>

<hw>Ju"das-col`ored</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>a.</pos> <def>Red; --
from a tradition that Judas Iscariot had red hair and
beard.</def>

<q>There's treachery in that <qex>Judas-colored</qex> beard.</q>
<qau>Dryden.</qau>

<hw>Jud"dock</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[For
<ets>judcock</ets>; <ets>jud</ets> (equiv. to Prov. E.
<ets>gid</ets> a jacksnipe, W. <ets>giach</ets> snipe) +
<ets>cock</ets>.]</ety> <fld>(Zo\'94l.)</fld> <def>See
<er>Jacksnipe</er>.</def>

<-- p. 804 -->

<hw>Ju*de"an</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>a.</pos> <ety>[L.
<ets>Judaeus</ets>. See <er>Jew</er>.]</ety> <def>Of or
pertaining to Judea.</def> -- <def2><pos>n.</pos> <def>A native
of Judea; a Jew.</def></def2>

<hw>Judge</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[OE.
<ets>juge</ets>, OF. & F. <ets>juge</ets>, fr. OF.
<ets>jugier</ets>, F. <ets>juger</ets>, to judge. See
<er>Judge</er>, <pos>v. i.</pos>]</ety>

<sn>1.</sn> <fld>(Law)</fld> <def>A public officer who is
invested with authority to hear and determine litigated causes,
and to administer justice between parties in courts held for that
purpose.</def>

<q>The parts of a <qex>judge</qex> in hearing are four: to direct
the evidence; to moderate length, repetition, or impertinency of
speech; to recapitulate, select, and collate the material points
of that which hath been said; and to give the rule or
sentence.</q>
<qau>Bacon.</qau>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>One who has skill, knowledge, or experience,
sufficient to decide on the merits of a question, or on the
quality or value of anything; one who discerns properties or
relations with skill and readiness; a connoisseur; an expert; a
critic.</def>

<q>A man who is no <qex>judge</qex> of law may be a good
<qex>judge</qex> of poetry, or eloquence, or of the merits of a
painting.</q>
<qau>Dryden.</qau>

<sn>3.</sn> <def>A person appointed to decide in a<?/trial of
skill, speed, etc., between two or more parties; an umpire;
<as>as, a <ex>judge</ex> in a horse race</as>.</def>

<sn>4.</sn> <fld>(Jewish Hist.)</fld> <def>One of supreme
magistrates, with both civil and military powers, who governed
Israel for more than four hundred years.</def>

<sn>5.</sn> <pluf>pl.</pluf> <def>The title of the seventh book
of the Old Testament; the Book of Judges.</def>

<cs><col>Judge Advocate</col> <fld>(Mil. & Nav.)</fld>, <cd>a
person appointed to act as prosecutor at a court-martial; he acts
as the representative of the government, as the responsible
adviser of the court, and also, to a certain extent, as counsel
for the accused, when he has no other counsel.</cd> --
<col>Judge-Advocate General</col>, <cd>in the United States, the
title of two officers, one attached to the War Department and
having the rank of brigadier general, the other attached to the
Navy Department and having the rank of colonel of marines or
captain in the navy. The first is chief of the Bureau of Military
Justice of the army, the other performs a similar duty for the
navy. In England, the designation of a member of the ministry who
is the legal adviser of the secretary of state for war, and
supreme judge of the proceedings of courts-martial.</cd></cs>

<syn>Syn. -- <er>Judge</er>, <er>Umpire</er>,
<er>Arbitrator</er>, <er>Referee</er>.</syn> <usage> A
<xex>judge</xex>, in the legal sense, is a magistrate appointed
to determine questions of law. An <xex>umpire</xex> is a person
selected to decide between two or more who contend for a prize.
An <xex>arbitrator</xex> is one chosen to allot to two
contestants their portion of a claim, usually on grounds of
equity and common sense. A <xex>referee</xex> is one to whom a
case is referred for final adjustment. <xex>Arbitrations</xex>
and <xex>references</xex> are sometimes voluntary, sometimes
appointed by a court.</usage>

<hw>Judge</hw>, <pos>v. i.</pos> <wordforms>[<pos>imp. & p.
p.</pos> <er>Judged</er> <pr>(?)</pr>; <pos>p. pr. & vb. n.</pos>
<er>Judging</er>.]</wordforms> <ety>[OE. <ets>jugen</ets>, OF.
<ets>jugier</ets>, F. <ets>juger</ets>, L. <ets>judicare</ets>,
fr. <ets>judex</ets> judge; <ets>jus</ets> law or right +
<ets>dicare</ets> to proclaim, pronounce, akin to
<ets>dicere</ets> to say. See <er>Just</er>, <pos>a.</pos>, and
<er>Diction</er>, and cf. <er>Judicial</er>.]</ety>

<sn>1.</sn> <def>To hear and determine, as in causes on trial; to
decide as a judge; to give judgment; to pass sentence.</def>

<q>The Lord <qex>judge</qex> between thee and me.</q>
<qau>Gen. xvi. 5.</qau>

<q>Father, who art judge
Of all things made, and <qex>judgest</qex> only right!</q>
<qau>Milton.</qau>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>To assume the right to pass judgment on another;
to sit in judgment or commendation; to criticise or pass adverse
judgment upon others. See <er>Judge</er>, <pos>v. t.</pos>,
3.</def>

<q>Forbear to <qex>judge</qex>, for we are sinners all.</q>
<qau>Shak.</qau>

<sn>3.</sn> <def>To compare facts or ideas, and perceive their
relations and attributes, and thus distinguish truth from
falsehood; to determine; to discern; to distinguish; to form an
opinion about.</def>

<q><qex>Judge</qex> not according to the appearance.</q>
<qau>John vii. 24.</qau>

<q>She is wise if I can <qex>judge</qex> of her.</q>
<qau>Shak.</qau>

<hw>Judge</hw>, <pos>v. t.</pos> <sn>1.</sn> <def>To hear and
determine by authority, as a case before a court, or a
controversy between two parties.</def> \'bdChaos [shall]
<xex>judge</xex> the strife.\'b8

<au>Milton.</au>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>To examine and pass sentence on; to try; to
doom.</def>

<q>God shall <qex>judge</qex> the righteous and the wicked.</q>
<qau>Eccl. iii. 7.</qau>

<q>To bring my whole cause 'fore his holiness,
And to be <qex>judged</qex> by him.</q>
<qau>Shak.</qau>

<sn>3.</sn> <def>To arrogate judicial authority over; to sit in
judgment upon; to be censorious toward.</def>

<q><qex>Judge</qex> not, that ye be not <qex>judged</qex>.</q>
<qau>Matt. vii. 1.</qau>

<sn>4.</sn> <def>To determine upon or deliberation; to esteem; to
think; to reckon.</def>

<q>If ye have <qex>judged</qex> me to be faithful to the
Lord.</q>
<qau>Acts xvi. 15.</qau>

<sn>5.</sn> <def>To exercise the functions of a magistrate over;
to govern.</def> <mark>[Obs.]</mark>

<q>Make us a king to <qex>judge</qex> us.</q>
<qau>1 Sam. viii. 5.</qau>

<hw>Judg"er</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <def>One who
judges.</def>

<au>Sir K. Digby.</au>

<hw>Judge"ship</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <def>The office
of a judge.</def>

<hw>Judg"ment</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[OE.
<ets>jugement</ets>, F. <ets>jugement</ets>, LL.
<ets>judicamentum</ets>, fr. L. <ets>judicare</ets>. See
<er>Judge</er>, <pos>v. i.</pos>]</ety>

<sn>1.</sn> <def>The act of judging; the operation of the mind,
involving comparison and discrimination, by which a knowledge of
the values and relations of thins, whether of moral qualities,
intellectual concepts, logical propositions, or material facts,
is obtained; <as>as, by careful <ex>judgment</ex> he avoided the
peril; by a series of wrong <ex>judgments</ex> he forfeited
confidence.</as></def>

<q>I oughte deme, of skilful <qex>jugement</qex>,
That in the salte sea my wife is deed.</q>
<qau>Chaucer.</qau>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>The power or faculty of performing such
operations (see 1); esp., when unqualified, the faculty of
judging or deciding rightly, justly, or wisely; good sense;
<as>as, a man of <ex>judgment</ex>; a politician without
<ex>judgment</ex>.</as></def>

<q>He shall judge thy people with righteousness and thy poor with
<qex>judgment</qex>.</q>
<qau>Ps. lxxii. 2.</qau>

<q><qex>Hernia</qex>. I would my father look'd but with my eyes.
<qex>Theseus</qex>. Rather your eyes must with his
<qex>judgment</qex> look.</q>
<qau>Shak.</qau>

<sn>3.</sn> <def>The conclusion or result of judging; an opinion;
a decision.</def>

<q>She in my <qex>judgment</qex> was as fair as you.</q>
<qau>Shak.</qau>

<q>Who first his <qex>judgment</qex> asked, and then a place.</q>
<qau>Pope.</qau>

<sn>4.</sn> <def>The act of determining, as in courts of law,
what is conformable to law and justice; also, the determination,
decision, or sentence of a court, or of a judge; the mandate or
sentence of God as the judge of all.</def>

<q>In <qex>judgments</qex> between rich and poor, consider not
what the poor man needs, but what is his own.</q>
<qau>Jer. Taylor.</qau>

<q>Most heartily I do beseech the court
To give the <qex>judgment</qex>.</q>
<qau>Shak.</qau>

<sn>5.</sn> <fld>(Philos.)</fld> <sd>(a)</sd> <def>That act of
the mind by which two notions or ideas which are apprehended as
distinct are compared for the purpose of ascertaining their
agreement or disagreement. See 1. The comparison may be
threefold: (1) Of individual objects forming a concept. (2) Of
concepts giving what is technically called a judgment. (3) Of two
judgments giving an inference. Judgments have been further
classed as analytic, synthetic, and identical.</def> <sd>(b)</sd>
<def>That power or faculty by which knowledge dependent upon
comparison and discrimination is acquired. See 2.</def>

<q>A <qex>judgment</qex> is the mental act by which one thing is
affirmed or denied of another.</q>
<qau>Sir W. Hamilton.</qau>

<q>The power by which we are enabled to perceive what is true or
false, probable or improbable, is called by logicians the faculty
of <qex>judgment</qex>.</q>
<qau>Stewart.</qau>

<sn>6.</sn> <def>A calamity regarded as sent by God, by way of
recompense for wrong committed; a providential punishment.</def>
\'bd<xex>Judgments</xex> are prepared for scorners.\'b8 <au>Prov.
xix. 29</au>. \'bdThis <xex>judgment</xex> of the heavens that
makes us tremble.\'b8

<au>Shak.</au>

<sn>7.</sn> <fld>(Theol.)</fld> <def>The final award; the last
sentence.</def>

<note><hand/ <xex>Judgment</xex>, <xex>abridgment</xex>,
<xex>acknowledgment</xex>, and <xex>lodgment</xex> are in England
sometimes written, <xex>judgement</xex>, <xex>abridgement</xex>,
<xex>acknowledgement</xex>, and <xex>lodgement</xex>.</note>

<note><hand/ <xex>Judgment</xex> is used adjectively in many
self-explaining combinations; as, <xex>judgment</xex> hour;
<xex>judgment</xex> throne.</note>

<cs><col>Judgment day</col> <fld>(Theol.)</fld>, <cd>the last
day, or period when final judgment will be pronounced on the
subjects of God's moral government.</cd> -- <col>Judgment
debt</col> <fld>(Law)</fld>, <cd>a debt secured to the creditor
by a judge's order.</cd> -- <col>Judgment hall</col>, <cd>a hall
where courts are held.</cd> -- <col>Judgment seat</col>, <cd>the
seat or bench on which judges sit in court; hence, a court; a
tribunal. \'bdWe shall all stand before the <xex>judgment
seat<xex> of Christ.\'b8 <au>Rom. xiv. 10.</au></cd> --
<col>Judgment summons</col> <fld>(Law)</fld>, <cd>a proceeding by
a judgment creditor against a judgment debtor upon an unsatisfied
judgment.</cd></cs>

<cs>   <col>Arrest of judgment</col>. <fld>(Law)</fld> <cd>See
under <er>Arrest</er>, <pos>n.</pos></cd> -- <col>Judgment of
God</col>, <cd>a term formerly applied to extraordinary trials of
secret crimes, as by arms and single combat, by ordeal, etc.; it
being imagined that God would work miracles to vindicate
innocence. See under <er>Ordeal</er>.</cd></cs>

<syn>Syn. -- Discernment; decision; determination; award;
estimate; criticism; taste; discrimination; penetration;
sagacity; intelligence; understanding. See <er>Taste</er>.</syn>

<ets>judicabilis</ets>. See <er>Judge</er>, <pos>v.
i.</pos>]</ety> <def>Capable of being judged; capable of being

<hw>Ju"di*ca*ture</hw> <pr>(?; 135)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[F.,
fr. LL. <ets>judicatura</ets>.]</ety>

<sn>1.</sn> <def>The state or profession of those employed in the

of justice.</def>

<q>The honor of the judges in their <qex>judicature</qex> is the

<qau>Milton.</qau>

<hw>Ju*di"cial</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>a.</pos> <ety>[L.

<qau>Milton.</qau>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>Fitted or apt for judging or deciding; <as>as, a
<ex>judicial</ex> mind</as>.</def>

<sn>3.</sn> <def>Belonging to the judiciary, as distinguished
from <xex>legislative</xex>, <xex>administrative</xex>, or
<xex>executive</xex>. See <er>Executive</er>.</def>

<sn>4.</sn> <def>Judicious.</def> <mark>[Obs.]</mark>

<hw>Jug"ger*naut`</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[Skr.
<ets>jagann\'betha</ets> lord of the world.]</ety> <def>One of
the names under which Vishnu, in his incarnation as Krishna, is
worshiped by the Hindoos.</def> <altsp>[Written also
<asp>Juggernnath</asp>, <asp>Jaganath</asp>,
<asp>Jaganatha</asp>, etc.]</altsp>

<note><hand/ The principal seat of the worship of Juggernaut is
at P\'96ri in Orissa. At certain times the idol is drawn from the
temple by the multitude, on a high car with sixteen wheels.
Formerly, fanatics sometimes threw themselves under the wheels to
be crushed as a sacrifice to the god.</note>

<hw>Jug"gle</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>v. i.</pos>
<wordforms>[<pos>imp. & p. p.</pos> <er>Juggled</er>
<pr>(?)</pr>; <pos>p. pr. & vb. n.</pos> <er>Juggling</er>
<pr>(?)</pr>.]</wordforms> <ety>[OE. <ets>juglen</ets>; cf. OF.

<hw>Jug"gler</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[OE.

<hw>Ju"jube</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[F., fr. L.
<ets>zizyphum</ets>, Gr. <?/, Per. <ets>z\'c6zf<?/n</ets>,
<ets>zizaf<?/n</ets>, <ets>zayzaf<?/n</ets>.]</ety> <def>The
sweet and edible drupes (fruits) of several Mediterranean and
African species small trees, of the genus <spn>Zizyphus</spn>,
especially the <spn>Z. jujuba</spn>, <spn>Z. vulgaris</spn>,
<spn>Z. mucronata</spn>, and <spn>Z. Lotus</spn>. The last named
is thought to have furnished the lotus of the ancient Libyan
<xex>Lotophagi</xex>, or lotus eaters.</def>

<cs><col>Jujube paste</col>, <cd>the dried or inspissated jelly
of the jujube; also, a confection made of gum arabic
sweetened.</cd></cs>

<hw>Juke</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>v. i.</pos> <ety>[from Scottish
<ets>jouk</ets> to bow.]</ety> <def>To bend the neck; to bow or
duck the head.</def> <altsp>[Written also <asp>jook</asp> and
<asp>jouk</asp>.]</altsp>

<q>The money merchant was so proud of his trust that he went
<qex>juking</qex> and tossing of his head.</q>
<qau> L' Estrange.</qau>

<hw>Juke</hw>, <pos>n.</pos> <def>The neck of a bird.</def>
<mark>[Prov. Eng.]</mark>

<hw>Ju*la"ceous</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>a.</pos> <ety>[See

<hw>Ju"lep</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[F., fr. Sp.
<ets>julepe</ets>, fr. Ar. & Per. <ets>jul\'beb</ets>,
<ets>jull\'beb</ets>, fr. Per. <ets>gul\'beb</ets> rose water and
julep; <ets>gul</ets> rose + <ets>\'beb</ets> water.]</ety>

<sn>1.</sn> <def>A refreshing drink flavored with aromatic
herbs</def>; esp. <fld>(Med.)</fld>, <def>a sweet, demulcent,
acidulous, or mucilaginous mixture, used as a vehicle.</def>

<au>Milton.</au>

<q>Honey in woods, <qex>juleps</qex> in brooks.</q>
<qau> H. Vaughan.</qau>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>A beverage composed of brandy, whisky, or some
other spirituous liquor, with sugar, pounded ice, and sprigs of
mint; -- called also <altname>mint julep</altname>.</def>
<mark>[U.S.]</mark>

<hw>Jul"ian</hw> <pr>(?; 277)</pr> <pos>a.</pos> <ety>[L.
<ets>Julianus</ets>, fr. <ets>Julius</ets>. Cf. <er>July</er>,
<er>Gillian</er>.]</ety> <def>Relating to, or derived from,
Julius C\'91sar.</def>

<cs><col>Julian calendar</col>, <cd>the calendar as adjusted by
Julius C\'91sar, in which the year was made to consist of 365
days, each fourth year having 366 days.</cd> -- <col>Julian
epoch</col>, <cd>the epoch of the commencement of the Julian
calendar, or 46 b. c.</cd> -- <col>Julian period</col>, <cd>a
chronological period of 7,980 years, combining the solar, lunar,
and indiction cycles (28 x 19 x 15 = 7,980), being reckoned from
the year 4713 <sc>B. C.</sc>, when the first years of these
several cycles would coincide, so that if any year of the period
be divided by 28, 19, or 15, the remainder will be the year of
the corresponding cycle. The Julian period was proposed by
Scaliger, to remove or avoid ambiguities in chronological dates,
and was so named because composed of Julian years.</cd> --
<col>Julian year</col>, <cd>the year of 365 days, 6 hours,
adopted in the Julian calendar, and in use until superseded by
the Gregorian year, as established in the reformed or Gregorian
calendar.</cd></cs>

<hw>\'d8Ju`li*enne"</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos>
<ety>[F.]</ety> <def>A kind of soup containing thin slices or
shreds of carrots, onions, etc.</def>

<hw>Ju"li*form</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>a.</pos>
<ety>[<ets>Julus</ets> + <ets>-form</ets>.]</ety>
<fld>(Bot.)</fld> <def>Having the shape or appearance of a julus
or catkin.</def>

-- named from Caius <ets>Julius</ets> C\'91sar, who was born in
this month: cf. F. <ets>Juillet</ets>.]</ety> <def>The seventh
month of the year, containing thirty-one days.</def>

fifth month, according to the old Roman calendar, in which March
was the first month of the year.</note>

<hw>Jum"ble</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>v. t.</pos>

<pr>(?)</pr>.]</wordforms> <ety>[Prob. fr. <ets>jump</ets>, i.

mass; to put or throw together without order; -- often followed

<q>Why dost thou blend and <qex>jumble</qex> such inconsistencies
together?</q>
<qau> Burton.</qau>

<q>Every clime and age
<qex>Jumbled</qex> together.</q>
<qau> Tennyson.</qau>

confused way; to mix confusedly.</def>

<au>Swift.</au>

<hw>Jump</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[Cf. F.
<ets>jupe</ets> a long petticoat, a skirt. Cf.
<er>Juppon</er>.]</ety> <sd>(a)</sd> <def>A kind of loose jacket
for men.</def> <sd>(b)</sd> <pluf>pl.</pluf> <def>A bodice worn
instead of stays by women in the 18th century.</def>

<hw>Jump</hw>, <pos>v. i.</pos> <wordforms>[<pos>imp. & p.
p.</pos> <er>Jumped</er> <pr>(?)</pr>; <pos>p. pr. & vb. n.</pos>
<er>Jumping</er>.]</wordforms> <ety>[Akin to OD.
<ets>gumpen</ets>, dial. G. <ets>gumpen</ets>,
<ets>jumpen</ets>.]</ety>

<sn>1.</sn> <def>To spring free from the ground by the muscular
action of the feet and legs; to project one's self through the
air; to spring; to bound; to leap.</def>

<q>Not the worst of the three but <qex>jumps</qex> twelve foot
and a half by the square.</q>
<qau> Shak.</qau>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>To move as if by jumping; to bounce; to
jolt.</def> \'bdThe <xex>jumping</xex> chariots.\'b8

<au>Nahum iii. 2.</au>

<q>A flock of geese <qex>jump</qex> down together.</q>
<qau> Dryden.</qau>

<sn>3.</sn> <def>To coincide; to agree; to accord; to tally; --
followed by <xex>with</xex>.</def> \'bdIt <xex>jumps</xex> with
my humor.\'b8

<au>Shak.</au>

<cs><col>To jump at</col>, <cd>to spring to; hence, fig., to
accept suddenly or eagerly; as, a fish <xex>jumps at<xex> a bait;
to <xex>jump at<xex> a chance.</cd></cs>

<hw>Jump</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>v. t.</pos> <sn>1.</sn> <def>To
pass by a spring or leap; to overleap; <as>as, to <ex>jump</ex> a
stream</as>.</def>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>To cause to jump; <as>as, he <ex>jumped</ex> his
horse across the ditch</as>.</def>

<sn>3.</sn> <def>To expose to danger; to risk; to hazard.</def>
<mark>[Obs.]</mark>

<q>To <qex>jump</qex> a body with a dangerous physic.</q>
<qau> Shak.</qau>

<sn>4.</sn> <fld>(Smithwork)</fld> <sd>(a)</sd> <def>To join by a
butt weld.</def> <sd>(b)</sd> <def>To thicken or enlarge by
endwise blows; to upset.</def>

<sn>5.</sn> <fld>(Quarrying)</fld> <def>To bore with a
jumper.</def>

<cs><col>To jump a claim</col>, <cd>to enter upon and take
possession of land to which another has acquired a claim by prior
entry and occupation. <mark>[Western U. S. & Australia]</mark>
See <er>Claim</er>, <pos>n.</pos>, 3.</cd> -- <col>To jump one's
bail</col>, <cd>to abscond while at liberty under bail bonds.
<mark>[Slang, U. S.]</mark></cd></cs>

<hw>Jump</hw>, <pos>n.</pos> <sn>1.</sn> <def>The act of jumping;
a leap; a spring; a bound.</def> \'bdTo advance by
<xex>jumps</xex>.\'b8

<au>Locke.</au>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>An effort; an attempt; a venture.</def>
<mark>[Obs.]</mark>

<q>Our fortune lies
Upon this<qex>jump</qex>.</q>
<qau> Shak.</qau>

<sn>3.</sn> <def>The space traversed by a leap.</def>

<sn>4.</sn> <fld>(Mining)</fld> <def>A dislocation in a stratum;
a fault.</def>

<sn>5.</sn> <fld>(Arch.)</fld> <def>An abrupt interruption of
level in a piece of brickwork or masonry.</def>

<cs><col>From the jump</col>, <cd>from the start or
beginning.</cd> <mark>[Colloq.]</mark> -- <col>Jump joint</col>.
<sd>(a)</sd> <cd>A butt joint</cd>. <sd>(b)</sd> <cd>A flush
joint, as of plank in carvel-built vessels.</cd> -- <col>Jump
seat</col>. <sd>(a)</sd> <cd>A movable carriage seat</cd>.
<sd>(b)</sd> <cd>A carriage constructed with a seat which may be
shifted so as to make room for second or extra seat</cd>. Also
used adjectively; <as>as, a <ex>jump-seat<ex>
wagon</as>.</cd></cs>

<hw>Jump</hw>, <pos>a.</pos> <def>Nice; exact; matched; fitting;
precise.</def> <mark>[Obs.]</mark> \'bd<xex>Jump</xex> names.\'b8

<au>B. Jonson.</au>

<hw>Jump</hw>, <pos>adv.</pos> <def>Exactly;
pat.</def><mark>[Obs.]</mark>

<au>Shak.</au>

<cs><col>Jumping bean</col>, <cd>a seed of a Mexican
<spn>Euphorbia</spn>, containing the larva of a moth
(<spn>Carpocapsa saltitans</spn>). The larva by its sudden
movements causes the seed to roll to roll and jump about.</cd> --
<col>Jumping deer</col> <fld>(Zo\'94l.)</fld>, <cd>a South
African rodent (<spn>Pedetes Caffer</spn>), allied to the
jerboa.</cd> -- <col>Jumping jack</col>, <cd>a toy figure of a
man, jointed and made to jump or dance by means of strings.</cd>
-- <col>Jumping louse</col> <fld>(Zo\'94l.)</fld>, <cd>any of the
numerous species of plant lice belonging to the family
<spn>Psyllid\'91</spn>, several of which are injurious to fruit
trees.</cd> -- <col>Jumping mouse</col> <fld>(Zo\'94l.)</fld>,
<cd>North American mouse (<spn>Zapus Hudsonius</spn>), having a
long tail and large hind legs. It is noted for its jumping
powers. Called also <altname>kangaroo mouse</altname>.</cd> --
<col>Jumping mullet</col> <fld>(Zo\'94l.)</fld>, <cd>gray
mullet.</cd> -- <col>Jumping shrew</col> <fld>(Zo\'94l.)</fld>,
<cd>any African insectivore of the genus
<spn>Macroscelides</spn>. They are allied to the shrews, but have
large hind legs adapted for jumping.</cd> -- <col>Jumping
spider</col> <fld>(Zo\'94l.)</fld>, <cd>spider of the genus
<spn>Salticus</spn> and other related genera; one of the
Saltigrad\'91; -- so called because it leaps upon its
prey.</cd></cs>

<hw>Junc"tion</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[L.
<ets>junctio</ets>, fr. <ets>jungere</ets>, <ets>junctum</ets>,
to join: cf. F. <ets>jonction</ets>. See <er>Join</er>.]</ety>

<sn>1.</sn> <def>The act of joining, or the state of being
joined; union; combination; coalition; <as>as, the
<ex>junction</ex> of two armies or detachments; the
<ex>junction</ex> of paths.</as></def>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>The place or point of union, meeting, or
junction; specifically, the place where two or more lines of
railway meet or cross.</def>

<cs><col>Junction plate</col> <fld>(Boilers)</fld>, <cd>a
covering or break-join plate riveted to and uniting the edges of
sheets which make a butt joint.</cd> -- <col>Junction rails</col>
<fld>(Railroads)</fld>, <cd>the switch, or movable, rails,
connecting one line of track with another.</cd></cs>

<hw>Junc"ture</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos>
<ety>[L.<ets>junctura</ets>, fr. <ets>jungere</ets> to join. See
<er>Jointure</er>.]</ety> <sn>1.</sn> <def>A joining; a union; an
alliance.</def> <mark>[Obs.]</mark> \'bdDevotional compliance and
<xex>juncture</xex> of hearts.\'b8

<au>Eikon Basilike.</au>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>The line or point at which two bodies are
joined; a joint; an articulation; a seam; <as>as, the
<ex>junctures</ex> of a vessel or of the bones</as>.</def>

<au>Boyle.</au>

<sn>3.</sn> <def>A point of time; esp., one made critical or
important by a concurrence of circumstances; hence, a crisis; an
exigency.</def> \'bdExtraordinary <xex>junctures</xex>.\'b8

<au>Addison.</au>

<q>In such a <qex>juncture</qex>, what can the most plausible and
refined philosophy offer?</q>
<qau> Berkeley.</qau>

<hw>June</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[L.
<ets>Junius</ets>: cf. F. <ets>Juin</ets>. So called either from
<ets>Junius</ets>, the name of a Roman gens, or from
<ets>Juno</ets>, the goddess.]</ety> <def>The sixth month of the
year, containing thirty days.</def>

<q>And what is so rare as a day in <qex>June</qex>?
Then, if ever, come perfect days.</q>
<qau> Lowell.</qau>

<cs><mcol><col>June beetle</col>, <col>June bug</col></mcol>
<fld>(Zo\'94l.)</fld>, <cd>any one of several species of large
brown beetles of the genus <spn>Lachnosterna</spn> and related
genera; -- so called because they begin to fly, in the northern
United States, about the first of June. The larv\'91 of the June
beetles live under ground, and feed upon the roots of grasses and
other plants. Called also <altname>May bug</altname> or
<altname>May beetle</altname>.</cd> -- <col>June grass</col>
<fld>(Bot.)</fld>, <cd>a New England name for Kentucky blue
grass. See <er>Blue glass</er>, and <xex>Illustration<xex> in
Appendix.</cd></cs>

<hw>June"a*ting</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <def>A kind of
early apple.</def> <altsp>[Written also
<asp>jenneting</asp>.]</altsp>

<hw>June"ber`ry</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos>
<fld>(Bot.)</fld> <sd>(a)</sd> <def>The small applelike berry of
American trees of genus <spn>Amelanchier</spn>; -- also called
<altname>service berry</altname>.</def> <sd>(b)</sd> <def>The
shrub or tree which bears this fruit; -- also called
<altname>shad bush</altname>, and <altname>had
tree</altname>.</def>

<hw>\'d8Jun`ger*man"ni*a</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos>;
<plu>pl. <plw>Jungermanni\'91</plw> <pr>(#)</pr></plu>. <ety>[NL.
Named after Ludwig <ets>Jungermann</ets>, a German
botanist.]</ety> <fld>(Bot.)</fld> <def>A genus of hepatic
mosses, now much circumscribed, but formerly comprising most
plants of the order, which is sometimes therefore called
<altname>Jungermanniace\'91</altname>.</def>

<hw>Jun"gle</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[Hind.
<ets>jangal</ets> desert, forest, jungle; Skr.
<ets>ja<?/gala</ets> desert.]</ety> <def>A dense growth of
brushwood, grasses, reeds, vines, etc.; an almost impenetrable
thicket of trees, canes, and reedy vegetation, as in India,
Africa, Australia, and Brazil.</def>

<-- (Fig.) 2. a place of danger or ruthless competition for
survival.
    "It's a jungle out there" 
 3. anything which causes difficulty due to intricacy; as a
jungle of environmental regulations. (MW10)
 -->

<q>The <qex>jungles</qex> of India are of bamboos, canes, and
other palms, very difficult to penetrate.</q>
<qau> Balfour (Cyc. of India).</qau>

<cs><col>Jungle bear</col> <fld>(Zo\'94l.)</fld>, <cd>the aswail
or sloth bear.</cd> -- <col>Jungle cat</col>
<fld>(Zo\'94l.)</fld>, <cd>the chaus.</cd> -- <col>Jungle
cock</col> <fld>(Zo\'94l.)</fld>, <cd>the male of a jungle
fowl.</cd> -- <col>Jungle fowl</col>. <fld>(Zo\'94l.)</fld>
<sd>(a)</sd> <cd>Any wild species of the genus <spn>Gallus</spn>,
of which several species inhabit India and the adjacent islands;
as, the fork-tailed <xex>jungle fowl<xex> (<spn>G. varius</spn>)
of Java, <spn>G. Stanleyi</spn> of Ceylon, and <spn>G.
Bankiva</spn> of India.</cd> <note>The latter, which resembles
the domestic gamecock, is supposed to be one of the original
species from which the domestic fowl was derived.</note>
<sd>(b)</sd> <cd>An Australian grallatorial bird (<spn>Megapodius
tumulus</spn>) which is allied to the brush turkey, and, like the
latter, lays its eggs in mounds of vegetable matter, where they
are hatched by the heat produced by decomposition.</cd></cs>

<hw>Jun"gly</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>a.</pos> <def>Consisting of
jungles; abounding with jungles; of the nature of a jungle.</def>

<hw>Jun"ior</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>a.</pos> <ety>[L. contr. fr.
<ets>juvenior</ets>, compar. of <ets>juvenis</ets> young. See
<er>Juvenile</er>.]</ety>

<sn>1.</sn> <def>Less advanced in age than another;
younger.</def>

<note><hand/ <xex>Junior</xex> is applied to distinguish the
younger of two persons bearing the same name in the same family,
and is opposed to <xex>senior or elder</xex>. Commonly applied to
a son who has the same Christian name as his father.</note>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>Lower in standing or in rank; later in office;
<as>as, a <ex>junior</ex> partner; <ex>junior</ex> counsel;
<ex>junior</ex> captain.</as></def>

<sn>3.</sn> <def>Composed of juniors, whether younger or a lower
standing; <as>as, the <ex>junior</ex> class</as>; of or
pertaining to juniors or to a junior class. See <er>Junior</er>,
<pos>n.</pos>, 2.</def>

<sn>4.</sn> <def>Belonging to a younger person, or an earlier
time of life.</def>

<q>Our first studies and <qex>junior</qex> endeavors.</q>
<qau> Sir T. Browne.</qau>

<hw>Jun"ior</hw>, <pos>n.</pos> <sn>1.</sn> <def>A younger
person.</def>

<q>His <qex>junior</qex> she, by thirty years.</q>
<qau> Byron.</qau>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>Hence: One of a lower or later standing;
specifically, in American colleges, one in the third year of his
course, one in the fourth or final year being designated a
<xex>senior</xex>; in some seminaries, one in the first year, in
others, one in the second year, of a three years' course.</def>

<hw>Jun*ior"i*ty</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <def>The state
or quality of being junior.</def>

<hw>Ju"ni*per</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[L.
<ets>juniperus</ets>, prop., youth-producing, and so called from
its evergreen appearance, from the roots of E.
<ets>juvenile</ets>, and <ets>parent</ets>. <ets>Cf</ets>.
<er>Gin</er> the liquor.]</ety> <fld>(Bot.)</fld> <def>Any
evergreen shrub or tree, of the genus <spn>Juniperus</spn> and
order <spn>Conifer\'91</spn>.</def>

<note><hand/ The common juniper (<spn>J. communis</spn>) is a
shrub of a low, spreading form, having awl-shaped, rigid leaves
in whorls of threes, and bearing small purplish blue berries (or
galbuli), of a warm, pungent taste, used as diuretic and in
flavoring gin. A resin exudes from the bark, which has
erroneously been considered identical with sandarach, and is used
as pounce. The oil of juniper is acrid, and used for various
purposes, as in medicine, for making varnish, etc. The wood of
several species is of a reddish color, hard and durable, and is
used in cabinetwork under the names of <xex>red cedar</xex>,
<xex>Bermuda cedar</xex>, etc.</note>

<cs><col>Juniper worm</col> <fld>(Zo\'94l.)</fld>, <cd>the larva
of a geometrid moth (<spn>Drepanodes varus</spn>). It feeds upon
the leaves of the juniper, and mimics the small twigs both in
form and color, in a remarkable manner.</cd></cs>

<hw>Ju"ni*per*in</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos>
<fld>(Chem.)</fld> <def>A yellow amorphous substance extracted
from juniper berries.</def>

<hw>Ju"ni*per*ite</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos>
<fld>(Paleon.)</fld> <def>One of the fossil
<spn>Conifer\'91</spn>, evidently allied to the juniper.</def>

<-- p. 806 -->

<hw>Junk</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <def>A fragment of any
solid substance; a thick piece. See <er>Chunk</er>.</def>
<mark>[Colloq.]</mark>

<au>Lowell.</au>

<hw>Junk</hw>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[Pg. <ets>junco</ets> junk,
rush, L. <ets>juncus</ets> a bulrush, of which ropes were made in
early ages. Cf. <er>Junket</er>.]</ety>

<sn>1.</sn> <def>Pieces of old cable or old cordage, used for
making gaskets, mats, swabs, etc., and when picked to pieces,
forming oakum for filling the seams of ships.</def>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>Old iron, or other metal, glass, paper, etc.,
bought and sold by junk dealers.</def>

<sn>3.</sn> <fld>(Naut.)</fld> <def>Hard salted beef supplied to
ships.</def>

<cs><col>Junk bottle</col> , <cd>a stout bottle made of thick
dark-colored glass.</cd> -- <col>Junk dealer</col>, <cd>a dealer
in old cordage, old metal, glass, etc.</cd> -- <col>Junk
hook</col> <fld>(Whaling)</fld>, <cd>a hook for hauling heavy
pieces of blubber on deck.</cd> -- <col>Junk ring</col>.
<sd>(a)</sd> <cd>A packing of soft material round the piston of a
steam engine</cd>. <sd>(b)</sd> <cd>A metallic ring for retaining
a piston packing in place</cd>; <sd>(c)</sd> <cd>A follower.</cd>
-- <col>Junk shop</col>, <cd>a shop where old cordage, and ship's
tackle, old iron, old bottles, old paper, etc., are kept for
sale.</cd> -- <col>Junk vat</col> <fld>(Leather Manuf.)</fld>,
<cd>a large vat into which spent tan liquor or ooze is
pumped.</cd> -- <col>Junk wad</col> <fld>(Mil.)</fld>, <cd>a wad
used in proving cannon; also used in firing hot shot.</cd></cs>

<hw>Junk</hw>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[Pg. <ets>junco</ets>; cf. Jav.
& Malay <ets>jong</ets>, <ets>ajong</ets>, Chin.
<ets>chwan</ets>.]</ety> <fld>(Naut.)</fld> <def>A large vessel,
without keel or prominent stem, and with huge masts in one piece,
used by the Chinese, Japanese, Siamese, Malays, etc., in
navigating their waters.</def>

<hw>\'d8Jun"ker</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[G. Cf.
<er>Yonker</er>.]</ety> <def>A young German noble or squire;
esp., a member of the aristocratic party in Prussia.</def>

<hw>Jun"ker*ism</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <def>The
principles of the aristocratic party in Prussia.</def>

<hw>Jun"ket</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[Formerly also
<ets>juncate</ets>, fr. It.  <ets>giuncata</ets> cream cheese,
made in a wicker or rush basket, fr. L. <ets>juncus</ets> a rush.
See 2d <er>Junk</er>, and cf. <er>Juncate</er>.]</ety>

<sn>1.</sn> <def>A cheese cake; a sweetmeat; any delicate
food.</def>

<q>How Faery Mab the <qex>junkets</qex> eat.</q>
<qau> Milton.</qau>

<q>Victuals varied well in taste,
And other <qex>junkets</qex>.</q>
<qau> Chapman.</qau>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>A feast; an entertainment.</def>

<q>A new jaunt or <qex>junket</qex> every night.</q>
<qau> Thackeray.</qau>

<hw>Jun"ket</hw>, <pos>v. i.</pos> <def>To feast; to banquet; to
make an entertainment; -- sometimes applied opprobriously to
feasting by public officers at the public cost.</def>

<q>Job's children <qex>junketed</qex> and feasted together
often.</q>
<qau> South.</qau>

<hw>Jun"ket</hw>, <pos>v. t.</pos> <wordforms>[<pos>imp. & p.
p.</pos> <er>Junketed</er>; <pos>p. pr. & vb. n.</pos>
<er>Junketing</er>.]</wordforms> <def>To give entertainment to;
to feast.</def>

<q>The good woman took my lodgings over my head, and was in such
a hurry to <qex>junket</qex> her neighbors.</q>
<qau> Walpole.</qau>

<hw>Jun"ket*ing</hw>, <pos>n.</pos> <def>A feast or
entertainment; a revel.</def>

<q>All those snug <qex>junketings</qex> and public gormandizings
for which the ancient magistrates were equally famous with their
modern successors.</q>
<qau> W. Irving.</qau>

<q>The apostle would have no reveling or <qex>junketing</qex>
upon the altar.</q>
<qau> South.</qau>

<hw>Jun"ket*ries</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n. pl.</pos>
<def>Sweetmeats.</def> <mark>[Obs.]</mark>

<hw>Jun"to</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos>; <plu>pl.

<hw>Ju"pi*ter</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[L., fr.
<ets>Jovis pater</ets>. See <er>Jove</er>.]</ety>

<sn>1.</sn> <fld>(Rom. Myth.)</fld> <def>The supreme deity, king
of gods and men, and reputed to be the son of Saturn and Rhea;
Jove. He corresponds to the Greek Zeus.</def>

<sn>2.</sn> <fld>(Astron.)</fld> <def>One of the planets, being
the brightest except Venus, and the largest of them all, its mean
diameter being about 85,000 miles. It revolves about the sun in
4,332.6 days, at a mean distance of 5.2028 from the sun, the
earth's mean distance being taken as unity.</def>

<cs><col>Jupiter's beard</col>. <fld>(Bot.)</fld> <sd>(a)</sd>
<cd>A South European herb, with cymes of small red blossoms
(<spn>Centranthus ruber</spn>)</cd>. <sd>(b)</sd> <cd>The
houseleek (<spn>Sempervivum tectorum</spn>); -- so called from
its massive inflorescence, like the sculptured beard of
Jove</cd>. <au>Prior</au>. <sd>(c)</sd> <cd>the cloverlike
<spn>Anthyllis Barba-Jovis</spn>.</cd> -- <col>Jupiter's
staff</col> <fld>(Bot.)</fld>, <cd>the common mullein; -- so
called from its long, rigid spike of yellow blossoms.</cd></cs>

<mhw>{ <hw>Ju*pon"</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <hw>Jup*pon"</hw>

<hw>Ju"rel</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <fld>(Zo\'94l.)</fld>
<def>A yellow carangoid fish of the Atlantic and Gulf coasts
(<spn>Caranx chrysos</spn>), most abundant southward, where it is
valued as a food fish; -- called also
<altname>hardtail</altname>, <altname>horse
crevall\'82</altname>, <altname>jack</altname>, <altname>buffalo
jack</altname>, <altname>skipjack</altname>, <altname>yellow
mackerel</altname>, and sometimes, improperly, <altname>horse
mackerel</altname>. Other species of <spn>Caranx</spn> (as
<spn>C. fallax</spn>) are also sometimes called
<xex>jurel</xex>.</def>

<mhw>{ <hw>Ju*rid"ic</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <hw>Ju*rid"ic*al</hw>
<pr>(?)</pr>, }</mhw> <pos>a.</pos> <ety>[L. <ets>juridicus</ets>
relating to the administration of justice; <ets>jus</ets>,
<ets>juris</ets>, right, law + <ets>dicare</ets> to pronounce:
cf. F. <ets>juridique</ets>. See <er>Just</er>, <pos>a.</pos>,
and <er>Diction</er>.]</ety> <def>Pertaining to a judge or to
jurisprudence; acting in the distribution of justice; used in
courts of law; according to law; legal; <as>as,
<ex>juridical</ex> law</as>.</def> \'bdThis <xex>juridical</xex>
sword.\'b8

<au>Milton.</au>

<q>The body corporate of the kingdom, in <qex>juridical</qex>
construction, never dies.</q>
<qau> Burke.</qau>

<cs><col>Juridical days</col>, <cd>days on which courts are
open.</cd></cs>

<hw>Ju*rid*ic*al*ly</hw>, <pos>adv.</pos> <def>In a juridical
manner.</def>

<hw>Ju`ris*con"sult</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[L.
<ets>jurisconsultus</ets>; <ets>jus</ets>, <ets>juris</ets>,
right + <ets>consulere</ets>, <ets>consultum</ets>, to consult:
cf. F. <ets>jurisconsulte</ets>.]</ety> <fld>(Law)</fld> <def>A
man learned in the civil law; an expert in juridical science; a
professor of jurisprudence; a jurist.</def>

<hw>Ju`ris*dic"tion</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[L.
<ets>jurisdictio</ets>; <ets>jus</ets>, <ets>juris</ets>, right,
law + <ets>dictio</ets> a saying, speaking: cf. OF.
<ets>jurisdiction</ets>, F. <ets>juridiction</ets>. See
<er>Just</er>, <pos>a.</pos>, and <er>Diction</er>.]</ety>

<sn>1.</sn> <fld>(Law)</fld> <def>The legal power, right, or
authority of a particular court to hear and determine causes, to
try criminals, or to execute justice; judicial authority over a
cause or class of causes; <as>as, certain suits or actions, or
the cognizance of certain crimes, are within the
<ex>jurisdiction</ex> of a particular court, that is, within the
limits of its authority or commission</as>.</def>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>The authority of a sovereign power to govern or
legislate; the right of making or enforcing laws; the power or
right of exercising authority.</def>

<q>To live exempt
From Heaven's high <qex>jurisdiction</qex>.</q>
<qau> Milton.</qau>

<q>You wrought to be a legate; by which power
You maim'd the <qex>jurisdiction</qex> of all bishops.</q>
<qau> Shak.</qau>

<sn>3.</sn> <def>Sphere of authority; the limits within which any
particular power may be exercised, or within which a government
or a court has authority.</def>

<note><hand/ <xex>Jurisdiction</xex>, in its most general sense,
is the power to make, declare, or apply the law. When confined to
the <xex>judiciary department</xex>, it is what we denominate the
<xex>judicial power</xex>, the right of administering justice
through the laws, by the means which the laws have provided for
that purpose.  <xex>Jurisdiction</xex> is limited to place or
territory, to persons, or to particular subjects.</note>

<au>Duponceau.</au>

<hw>Ju`ris*dic"tion*al</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>a.</pos> <ety>[Cf.
LL. <ets>jurisdictionalis</ets>, F.
<ets>juridictionnel</ets>.]</ety> <def>Of or pertaining to
jurisdiction; as <xex>jurisdictional</xex> rights.</def>

<au>Barrow.</au>

<hw>Ju`ris*dic"tive</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>a.</pos> <def>Having
jurisdiction.</def>

<au> Milton.</au>

<hw>Ju`ris*pru"dence</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[L.
<ets>jurisprudentia</ets>; <ets>jus</ets>, <ets>juris</ets>,
right, law +  <ets>prudentia</ets> a foreseeing, knowledge of a
matter, prudence: cf. F. <ets>jurisprudence</ets>. See
<er>Just</er>, <pos>a.</pos>, and <er>Prudence</er>.]</ety>
<def>The science of juridical law; the knowledge of the laws,
customs, and rights of men in a state or community, necessary for
the due administration of justice.</def>

<q>The talents of Abelard were not confined to theology,
<qex>jurisprudence</qex>, philosophy.</q>
<qau> J. Warton.</qau>

<cs><col>Medical jurisprudence</col>, <cd>that branch of
juridical law which concerns questions of medicine.</cd></cs>

<hw>Ju`ris*pru"dent</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>a.</pos><ety>[See
<er>Jurisprudence</er>.]</ety> <def>Understanding law; skilled in
jurisprudence.</def>

<au>G. West.</au>

<hw>Ju`ris*pru"dent</hw>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[Cf. F.
<ets>jurisprudent</ets>.]</ety> <def>One skilled in law or
jurisprudence.</def> <mark>[R.]</mark>

<au>De Quincey.</au>

<hw>Ju`ris*pru*den"tial</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>a.</pos> <def>Of
or pertaining to jurisprudence.</def>

<au>Stewart.</au>

<hw>Ju`rist</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[F.
<ets>juriste</ets>, LL. <ets>jurista</ets>, fr. L.
<ets>jus</ets>, <ets>juris</ets>, right, law. See <er>Just</er>,
<pos>a.</pos>]</ety> <def>One who professes the science of law;

<q>It has ever been the method of public <qex>jurists</qex> to
<?/raw a great part of the analogies on which they form the law
of nations from the principles of law which prevail in civil
community.</q>
<qau> Burke.</qau>

<mhw>{ <hw>Ju*ris"tic</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <hw>Ju*ris"tic*al</hw>
<pr>(?)</pr>, }</mhw> <pos>a.</pos> <def>Of or pertaining to a
jurist, to the legal profession, or to jurisprudence.</def>
<mark>[R.]</mark> \'bd<xex>Juristic</xex> ancestry.\'b8

<au>Lowell.</au>

<hw>Ju"ror</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[F.
<ets>jureur</ets> one who takes oath, L. <ets>jurator</ets> a
swearer, fr.  <ets>jurare</ets>, <ets>jurari</ets>, to swear. See
<er>Jury</er>, <pos>n.</pos>]</ety>

<sn>1.</sn> <fld>(Law)</fld> <def>A member of a jury; a
juryman.</def>

<q>I shall both find your lordship judge and
<qex>juror</qex>.</q>
<qau> Shak.</qau>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>A member of any jury for awarding prizes,
etc.</def>

<hw>Ju"ry</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>a.</pos> <ety>[Etymol.
uncertain.]</ety> <fld>(Naut.)</fld> <def>For temporary use; --
applied to a temporary contrivance.</def>

<cs><col>Jury mast</col>, <cd>a temporary mast, in place of one
that has been carried away, or broken.</cd> -- <col>Jury
rudder</col>, <cd>a rudder constructed for temporary
use.</cd></cs>

<hw>Ju"ry</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos>; <plu>pl.
<plw>Juries</plw> <pr>(#)</pr></plu>. <ety>[OF.
<ets>jur\'82e</ets> an assize, fr.  <ets>jurer</ets> to swear, L.
<ets>jurare</ets>, <ets>jurari</ets>; akin to <ets>jus</ets>,
<ets>juris</ets>, right, law. See <er>Just</er>,<pos>a.</pos>,
and cf. <er>Jurat</er>, <er>Abjure</er>.]</ety>

<sn>1.</sn> <fld>(Law)</fld> <def>A body of men, usually twelve,
selected according to law, impaneled and sworn to inquire into
and try any matter of fact, and to render their true verdict
according to the evidence legally adduced. See <cref>Grand
jury</cref> under <er>Grand</er>, and <er>Inquest</er>.</def>

<q>The <qex>jury</qex>, passing on the prisoner's life.</q>
<qau> Shak.</qau>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>A committee for determining relative merit or
awarding prizes at an exhibition or competition; <as>as, the art
<ex>jury</ex> gave him the first prize</as>.</def>

<cs><col>Jury of inquest</col>, <cd>a coroner's jury. See
<er>Inquest</er>.</cd></cs>

<hw>Ju"ry*man</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos>; <plu>pl.
<plw>Jurymen</plw> <pr>(<?/)</pr>.</plu> <def>One who is
impaneled on a jury, or who serves as a juror.</def>

<hw>Ju"ry-rigged`</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>a.</pos>
<fld>(Naut.)</fld> <def>Rigged for temporary service. See
<er>Jury</er>, <pos>a.</pos></def>

<hw>Jus"si</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <def>A delicate
fiber, produced in the Philippine Islands from an unidentified
plant, of which dresses, etc., are made.</def>

<hw>Just</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>a.</pos> <ety>[F.
<ets>juste</ets>, L. <ets>justus</ets>, fr. <ets>jus</ets> right,
law, justice; orig., that which is fitting; akin to Skr.
<ets>yu</ets> to join. Cf. <er>Injury</er>, <er>Judge</er>,
<er>Jury</er>, <er>Giusto</er>.]</ety>

<sn>1.</sn> <def>Conforming or conformable to rectitude or
justice; not doing wrong to any; violating no right or
obligation; upright; righteous; honest; true; -- said both of
persons and things.</def> \'bdO <xex>just</xex> but severe
law!\'b8

<au>Shak.</au>

<q>There is not a <qex>just</qex> man upon earth, that doeth
good, and sinneth not.</q>
<qau> Eccl. vii. 20.</qau>

<q><qex>Just</qex> balances, <qex>just</qex> weights, . . . shall
ye have.</q>
<qau> Lev. xix. 36.</qau>

<q>How should man be <qex>just</qex> with God?</q>
<qau> Job ix. 2.</qau>

<q>We know your grace to be a man.
<qex>Just</qex> and upright.</q>
<qau> Shak.</qau>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>Not transgressing the requirement of truth and
propriety; conformed to the truth of things, to reason, or to a
proper standard; exact; normal; reasonable; regular; due; <as>as,
a <ex>just</ex> statement; a <ex>just</ex> inference.</as></def>

<q><qex>Just</qex> of thy word, in every thought sincere.</q>
<qau> Pope.</qau>

<q>The prince is here at hand: pleaseth your lordship
To meet his grace <qex>just</qex> distance 'tween our armies.</q>
<qau> Shak.</qau>

<q>He was a comely personage, a little above <qex>just
stature.</</qex>q> <qau>Bacon.</qau>

<q>Fire fitted with <qex>just</qex> materials casts a constant
heat.</q>
<qau> Jer. Taylor.</qau>

<q>When all
The war shall stand ranged in its <qex>just</qex> array.</q>
<qau> Addison.</qau>

<q>Their named alone would make a <qex>just</qex> volume.</q>
<qau> Burton.</qau>

<sn>3.</sn> <def>Rendering or disposed to render to each one his
due; equitable; fair; impartial; <as>as, <ex>just</ex>
judge</as>.</def>

<q>Men are commonly so <qex>just</qex> to virtue and goodness as
to praise it in others, even when they do not practice it
themselves.</q>
<qau>Tillotson.</qau>

<cs><col>Just intonation</col>. <fld>(Mus.)</fld> <sd>(a)</sd>
<cd>The correct sounding of notes or intervals; true pitch</cd>.
<sd>(b)</sd> <cd>The giving all chords and intervals in their
purity or their exact mathematical ratio, or without
<xex>temperament<xex>; a process in which the number of notes and
intervals required in the various keys is much greater than the
twelve to the octave used in systems of temperament.</cd></cs>

<au>H. W. Poole.</au>

<syn>Syn. -- Equitable; upright; honest; true; fair; impartial;
proper; exact; normal; orderly; regular.</syn>

<hw>Just</hw>, <pos>adv.</pos> <sn>1.</sn> <def>Precisely;
exactly; -- in place, time, or degree; neither more nor less than
is stated.</def>

<q>And having <qex>just</qex> enough, not covet more.</q>
<qau> Dryden.</qau>

<q>The god Pan guided my hand <qex>just</qex> to the heart of the
beast.</q>
<qau>Sir P. Sidney.</qau>

<q>To-night, at Herne's oak, <qex>just</qex> 'twixt twelve and
one.</q>
<qau> Shak.</qau>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>Closely; nearly; almost.</def>

<q><qex>Just</qex> at the point of death.</q>
<qau> Sir W. Temple.</qau>

<sn>3.</sn> <def>Barely; merely; scarcely; only; by a very small
space or time; <as>as, he <ex>just</ex> missed the train;
<ex>just</ex> too late.</as></def>

<q>A soft Etesian gale
But <qex>just</qex> inspired and gently swelled the sail.</q>
<qau> Dryden.</qau>

<cs><col>Just now</col>, <cd>the least possible time since; a
moment ago.</cd></cs>

<hw>Just</hw>, <pos>v. i.</pos> <ety>[See <er>Joust</er>.]</ety>
<def>To joust.</def>

<au>Fairfax.</au>

<hw>Just</hw>, <pos>n.</pos> <def>A joust.</def>

<au>Dryden.</au>

<hw>Jus"tice</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[F., fr. L.
<ets>justitia</ets>, fr.  <ets>justus</ets> just. See
<er>Just</er>, <pos>a.</pos>]</ety>

<sn>1.</sn> <def>The quality of being just; conformity to the
principles of righteousness and rectitude in all things; strict
performance of moral obligations; practical conformity to human
or divine law; integrity in the dealings of men with each other;
rectitude; equity; uprightness.</def>

<q><qex>Justice</qex> and judgment are the haditation of thy
throne.</q>
<qau> Ps. ixxxix. 11.</qau>

<q>The king-becoming graces,
As justice, verity, temperance, stableness, . . . 
I have no relish of them.</q>
<qau> Shak.</qau>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>Conformity to truth and reality in expressing
opinions and in conduct; fair representation of facts respecting
merit or demerit; honesty; fidelity; impartiality; <as>as, the
<ex>justice</ex> of a description or of a judgment; historical
<ex>justice</ex>.</as></def>

<sn>3.</sn> <def>The rendering to every one his due or right;
just treatment; requital of desert; merited reward or punishment;
that which is due to one's conduct or motives.</def>

<q>This even-handed <qex>justice</qex>
Commends the ingredients of our poisoned chalice
To our own lips.</q>
<qau> Shak.</qau>

<sn>4.</sn> <def>Agreeableness to right; equity; justness;
<as>as, the <ex>justice</ex> of a claim</as>.</def>

<-- p. 807 -->

<sn>5.</sn> <def>A person duly commissioned to hold courts, or to
try and decide controversies and administer justice.</def>

<note><hand/ This title is given to the judges of the common law
courts in England and in the United States, and extends to
judicial officers and magistrates of every grade.</note>

<cs><col>Bed of justice</col>. <cd>See under <er>Bed</er>.</cd>
-- <col>Chief justice</col>. <cd>See in the Vocabulary.</cd> --
<col>Justice of the peace</col> <fld>(Law)</fld>, <cd>a judicial
officer or subordinate magistrate appointed for the conservation
of the peace in a specified district, with other incidental
powers specified in his commission. In the United States a
justice of the peace has jurisdiction to adjudicate certain minor
cases, commit offenders, etc.</cd></cs>

<syn>Syn. -- Equity; law; right; rectitude; honesty; integrity;
uprightness; fairness; impartiality.</syn> <usage> --
<er>Justice</er>, <er>Equity</er>, <er>Law</er>.
<xex>Justice</xex> and <xex>equity</xex> are the same; but human
laws, though designed to secure justice, are of necessity
imperfect, and hence what is strictly <xex>legal</xex> is at
times far from being <xex>equitable</xex> or <xex>just</xex>.
Here a court of <xex>equity</xex> comes in to redress the
grievances. It does so, as distinguished from courts of
<xex>law</xex>; and as the latter are often styled courts of
<xex>justice</xex>, some have fancied that there is in this case
a conflict between <xex>justice</xex> and <xex>equity</xex>. The
real conflict is against the <xex>working</xex> of the
<xex>law</xex>; this a court of <xex>equity</xex> brings into
accordance with the claims of <xex>justice</xex>. It would be an
unfortunate use of language which should lead any one to imagine
he might have <xex>justice</xex> on his side while practicing
iniquity (<xex>inequity</xex>).

   <er>Justice</er>, <er>Rectitude</er>. <xex>Rectitude</xex>, in
its widest sense, is one of the most comprehensive words in our
language, denoting absolute conformity to the rule of right in
principle and practice. <xex>Justice</xex> refers more especially
to the carrying out of law, and has been considered by moralists
as of three kinds: (1) <xex>Commutative</xex> justice, which
gives every man his own property, including things pledged by
promise. (2) <xex>Distributive</xex> justice, which gives every
man his exact deserts. (3) <xex>General</xex> justice, which
carries out all the <xex>ends</xex> of law, though not in every
case through the precise channels of commutative or distributive
justice; as we see often done by a parent or a ruler in his
dealings with those who are subject to his control.</usage>

administer justice to.</def> <mark>[Obs.]</mark>

<au>Bacon.</au>

<hw>Jus*ti"ci*a*ble</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>a.</pos> <ety>[Cf.

<hw>Jus*ti"ci*ar</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <def>Same as
<er>Justiciary</er>.</def>

<hw>Jus*ti"ci*a*ry</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[Cf. LL.
<ets>justitiarius</ets>, F. <ets>justicier</ets>. See
<er>Justice</er>.]</ety> <fld>(Old Eng. Law)</fld> <def>An old
name for the judges of the higher English courts.</def>

<note><hand/ The <xex>chief justiciary</xex>, or
<xex>justiciar</xex>, in early English history, was not only the
chief justice of the kingdom, but also <xex>ex officio</xex>
regent in the king's absence.</note>

<cs><col>Court of justiciary</col> <fld>(Scots Law)</fld>,
<cd>the supreme criminal court, having jurisdiction over the
whole of Scotland.</cd></cs>

<ets>justaucorps</ets>, lit., close to the body.]</ety>
<def>Formerly, a close coat or waistcoat with sleeves.</def>

<hw>Jus"ti*fi`a*ble</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>a.</pos> <ety>[Cf. F.
<ets>justifiable</ets>. See <er>Justify</er>.]</ety> <def>Capable
of being justified, or shown to be just.</def>

<q>Just are the ways of God,
An <qex>justifiable</qex> to men.</q>
<qau>Milton.</qau>

<syn>Syn. -- Defensible; vindicable; warrantable; excusable;
exculpable; authorizable.</syn>

<hw>Jus`ti*fi*ca"tion</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[L.
<ets>justificatio</ets>: cf. F. <ets>justification</ets>. See
<er>Justify</er>.]</ety>

<sn>1.</sn> <def>The act of justifying or the state of being
justified; a showing or proving to be just or conformable to law,
justice, right, or duty; defense; vindication; support; <as>as,
arguments in <ex>justification</ex> of the prisoner's conduct;
his disobedience admits <ex>justification</ex>.</as></def>

<q>I hope, for my brother's <qex>justification</qex>, he wrote
this but as an essay or taste of my virtue.</q>
<qau>Shak.</qau>

<sn>2.</sn> <fld>(Law)</fld> <def>The showing in court of a
sufficient lawful reason why a party charged or accused did that
for which he is called to answer.</def>

<sn>3.</sn> <fld>(Theol.)</fld> <def>The act of justifying, or
the state of being justified, in respect to God's
requirements.</def>

<q>Who was delivered for our offenses, and was raised again for
our <qex>justification</qex>.</q>
<qau>Rom. iv. 25.</qau>

<q>In such righteousness
To them by faith imputed, they may find
<qex>Justification</qex> toward God, and peace
Of conscience.</q>
<qau>Milton.</qau>

<sn>4.</sn> <fld>(Print.)</fld> <def>Adjustment of type by
spacing it so as to make it exactly fill a line, or of a cut so
as to hold it in the right place; also, the leads, quads, etc.,
used for making such adjustment.</def>

<hw>Jus*tif"i*ca*tive</hw> <pr>(?; 277)</pr>, <pos>a.</pos>
<ety>[Cf. F. <ets>justificatif</ets>.]</ety> <def>Having power to
justify; justificatory.</def>

<hw>Jus"ti*fi*ca`tor</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[LL.

<au>Johnson.</au>

<hw>Jus*tif"i*ca*to*ry</hw> <pr>(?; 277)</pr>, <pos>a.</pos>
<def>Vindicatory; defensory; justificative.</def>

<hw>Jus"ti*fi`er</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <def>One who

absolves.</def>

<q><qex>Justifiers</qex> of themselves and hypocrites.</q>
<qau>Strype.</qau>

<q>That he might be just, and the <qex>justifier</qex> of him

<hw>Jus"ti*fy</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>v. t.</pos>
<wordforms>[<pos>imp. & p. p.</pos> <er>Justified</er>
<pr>(?)</pr>; <pos>p. pr. & vb. n.</pos> <er>Justifying</er>
<pr>(?)</pr>.]</wordforms> <ety>[F. <ets>justifier</ets>, L.
<ets>justificare</ets>; <ets>justus</ets> just +
<ets>-ficare</ets> (in comp.) to make. See <er>Just</er>,
<pos>a.</pos>, and <er>-fy</er>.]</ety>

<sn>1.</sn> <def>To prove or show to be just; to vindicate; to
maintain or defend as conformable to law, right, justice,
propriety, or duty.</def>

<q>That to the height of this great argument
I may assert eternal providence,
And <qex>justify</qex> the ways of God to men.</q>
<qau>Milton.</qau>

<q>Unless the oppression is so extreme as to <qex>justify</qex>
revolution, it would not <qex>justify</qex> the evil of breaking
up a government.</q>
<qau>E. Everett.</qau>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>To pronounce free from guilt or blame; to
declare or prove to have done that which is just, right, proper,
etc.; to absolve; to exonerate; to clear.</def>

<q>I can not <qex>justify</qex> whom the law condemns.</q>
<qau>Shak.</qau>

<sn>3.</sn> <fld>(Theol.)</fld> <def>To treat as if righteous and
just; to pardon; to exculpate; to absolve.</def>

<q>By him all that believe are <qex>justified</qex> from all
things, from which ye could not be <qex>justified</qex> by the
law of Moses.</q>
<qau>Acts xiii. 39.</qau>

<sn>4.</sn> <def>To prove; to ratify; to confirm.</def>
<mark>[Obs.]</mark>

<au>Shak.</au>

<sn>5.</sn> <fld>(Print.)</fld> <def>To make even or true, as
lines of type, by proper spacing; to adjust, as type. See
<er>Justification</er>, 4.</def>

<syn>Syn. -- To defend; maintain; vindicate; excuse; exculpate;
absolve; exonerate.</syn>

<hw>Jus"ti*fy</hw>, <pos>v. i.</pos> <sn>1.</sn>
<fld>(Print.)</fld> <def>To form an even surface or true line
with something else; to fit exactly.</def>

<-- esp. in printing, to align (text) at the left (left justify)
or right (right justify) margins of a column or page, or at both
margins -->

<sn>2.</sn> <fld>(Law)</fld> <def>To take oath to the ownership
of property sufficient to qualify one's self as bail or
surety.</def>

<hw>Jus"tle</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>v. i.</pos> <ety>[Freq. of
<ets>joust</ets>, <ets>just</ets>, <pos>v. i.</pos> See

<q>The chariots shall rage in the streets; they shall

<hw>Jus"tle</hw>, <pos>v. t.</pos> <wordforms>[<pos>imp. & p.

<hw>Jus"tle</hw>, <pos>n.</pos> <def>An encounter or shock; a

<hw>Just"ly</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>adv.</pos> <ety>[From
<er>Just</er>, <pos>a.</pos>]</ety> <def>In a just manner; in
conformity to law, justice, or propriety; by right; honestly;
fairly; accurately.</def> \'bdIn equal balance <xex>justly</xex>
weighed.\'b8

<au>Shak.</au>

<q>Nothing can <qex>justly</qex> be despised that can not
<qex>justly</qex> be blamed: where there is no choice there can
be no blame.</q>
<qau>South.</qau>

<hw>Just"ness</hw>, <pos>n.</pos> <def>The quality of being just;
conformity to truth, propriety, accuracy, exactness, and the
like; justice; reasonableness; fairness; equity; <as>as,
<ex>justness</ex> of proportions; the <ex>justness</ex> of a
description or representation; the <ex>justness</ex> of a
cause.</as></def>

<q>In value the satisfaction I had in seeing it represented with
all the <qex>justness</qex> and gracefulness of action.</q>
<qau>Dryden.</qau>

<note><hand/ <xex>Justness</xex> is properly applied to things,
and <xex>justice</xex> to persons; but the distinction is not
always observed.</note>

<syn>Syn. -- Accuracy; exactness; correctness; propriety;
fitness; reasonableness; equity; uprightness; justice.</syn>

<hw>Jut</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>v. i.</pos> <wordforms>[<pos>imp.

<hw>Jux`ta*pose"</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>v. t.</pos> <ety>[Cf.
<er>Juxtaposit</er>, <er>Pose</er>.]</ety> <def>To place in

<au>Huxley.</au>

<hw>Jux`ta*pos"it</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>v. t.</pos>
<wordforms>[<pos>imp. & p. p.</pos> <er>Juxtaposited</er>;
<pos>p. pr. & vb. n.</pos> <er>Juxtapositing</er>.]</wordforms>
<ety>[L. <ets>juxta</ets> near + <ets>positus</ets>, p. p. of
<ets>ponere</ets> to put.]</ety> <def>To place in close
connection or contiguity; to juxtapose.</def>

<au>Derham.</au>

<hw>Jux`ta*po*si"tion</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[L.
<ets>juxta</ets> near + <ets>positio</ets> position: cf. F.
<ets>juxtaposition</ets>. See <er>Just</er>, <pos>v. i.</pos>,
and <er>Position</er>.]</ety> <def>A placing or being placed in
nearness or contiguity, or side by side; <as>as, a
<ex>juxtaposition</ex> of words</as>.</def>

<q>Parts that are united by a a mere
<qex>juxtaposition</qex>.</q>
<qau>Glanvill.</qau>

<q><qex>Juxtaposition</qex> is a very unsafe criterion of
continuity.</q>
<qau>Hare.</qau>

<hw>Jun"old</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>a.</pos> <mark>[Obs.]</mark>
<def>See <er>Gimmal</er>.</def>

<-- p. 808 -->

<centered><point26>K.</point26></centered>

<hw>K</hw><def>, (<?/), the eleventh letter of the English
alphabet, is nonvocal consonant. The form and sound of the letter
<hwf>K</hwf> are from the Latin, which used the letter but little
except in the early period of the language. It came into the
Latin from the Greek, which received it from a Ph\'d2nician
source, the ultimate origin probably being Egyptian,.
Etymologically <hwf>K</hwf> is most nearly related to
<xex>c</xex>, <xex>g</xex>, <xex>h</xex> (which see).</def>

   <note>In many words of one syllable <xex>k</xex> is used after
<xex>c</xex>, as in <xex>crack</xex>, <xex>check</xex>,
<xex>deck</xex>, being necessary to exhibit a correct
pronunciation in the derivatives, <xex>cracked</xex>,
<xex>checked</xex>, <xex>decked</xex>, <xex>cracking</xex>; since
without it, <xex>c</xex>, before the vowels <xex>e</xex> and
<xex>i</xex>, would be sounded like <xex>s</xex>. Formerly,
<xex>k</xex> was added to <xex>c</xex> in certain words of Latin
origin, as in <xex>musick</xex>, <xex>publick</xex>,
<xex>republick</xex>; but now it is omitted.</note>

<note>See <xex>Guide to Pronunciation</xex> , <sect/<sect/ 240,
178, 179, 185.</note>

<mhw>{ <hw>Kaf"fir</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <hw>Ka"fir</hw>
<pr>(?)</pr>, }</mhw> <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[Ar. <ets>k<?/fir</ets>
infidel, pagan, fr. <ets>kafara</ets> to be skeptical in
religious matters; -- a name given to certain infidel races by
the Mohammedans. Cf. <er>Giaour</er>.]</ety> <fld>(Ethnol.)</fld>
<sd>(a)</sd> <def>One of a race which, with the Hottentots and
Bushmen, inhabit South Africa. They inhabit the country north of
Cape Colony, the name being now specifically applied to the
tribes living between Cape Colony and Natal; but the Zulus of
Natal are true Kaffirs.</def> <sd>(b)</sd> <def>One of a race
inhabiting Kafiristan in Central Asia.</def> <altsp>[Spelt also
<asp>Caffre</asp>.]</altsp>

<cs><col>Kaffir corn</col> <fld>(Bot.)</fld>, <cd>a Cape Colony
name for Indian millet.</cd></cs>

<hw>\'d8Ka"gu</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos>
<fld>(Zo\'94l.)</fld> <def>A singular, crested, grallatorial bird
<fld>(Rhinochetos jubatus)</fld>, native of New Caledonia. It is
gray above, paler beneath, and the feathers of the wings and tail
are handsomely barred with brown, black, and gray. It is allied
to the sun bittern.</def>

<hw>Ka*hau"</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[Native name,
from its cry.]</ety> <fld>(Zo\'94l.)</fld> <def>A long-nosed
monkey (<spn>Semnopithecus nasalis</spn>), native of Borneo. The
general color of the body is bright chestnut, with the under
parts, shoulders, and sides of the head, golden yellow, and the
top of the head and upper part of the back brown. Called also
<altname>proboscis monkey</altname>.</def> <altsp>[Written also
<asp>kaha</asp>.]</altsp>

hence, any broth; also, a dinner.</def> <mark>[Scot.]</mark>

<hw>Kai"ser</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[Gr., fr. L.

empire in 1871.</def>

<hw>Ka"ka</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[Maori
<ets>kaka</ets> a parrot; -- so named from its note.]</ety>
<fld>(Zo\'94l.)</fld> <def>A New Zealand parrot of the genus
<spn>Nestor</spn>, especially the <xex>brown parrot</xex>
(<spn>Nestor meridionalis</spn>).</def>

<note><hand/ The <xex>mountain kaka</xex>, or <xex>kea</xex>
(<spn>N. notabilis</spn>), is remarkable for having recently
acquired carnivorous habits. It attacks and kills lambs and pigs,
sometimes doing great damage.</note>

<cs><col>Night kaka</col>. <fld>(Zo\'94l.)</fld> <cd>The
kakapo.</cd></cs>

<hw>Ka`ka*po"</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos>
<fld>(Zo\'94l.)</fld> <def>A singular nocturnal parrot
(<spn>Strigops habroptilus</spn>), native of New Zealand. It
lives in holes during the day, but is active at night. It
resembles an owl in its colors and general appearance. It has
large wings, but can fly only a short distance. Called also
<altname>owl parrot</altname>, <altname>night parrot</altname>,
and <altname>night kaka</altname>.</def>

<hw>Kak`a*ral"li</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <def>A kind of
wood common in Demerara, durable in salt water, because not
subject to the depredations of the sea worm and barnacle.</def>

<hw>Kale</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[Scot.

<mhw>{ <hw>Ka*lei"do*phon</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>,
<hw>Ka*lei"do*phone</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, }</mhw> <ety>[Gr. <?/
beautiful + <?/ appearance, form + <?/ sound.]</ety>
<fld>(Physics.)</fld> <def>An instrument invented by Professor
Wheatstone, consisting of a reflecting knob at the end of a
vibrating rod or thin plate, for making visible, in the motion of
a point of light reflected from the knob, the paths or curves
corresponding with the musical notes produced by the
vibrations.</def>

<hw>Ka*lei"do*scope</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[Gr.
<?/ beautiful + <?/ form + <ets>-scope</ets>.]</ety> <def>An
instrument invented by Sir David Brewster, which contains loose
fragments of colored glass, etc., and reflecting surfaces so
arranged that changes of position exhibit its contents in an
endless variety of beautiful colors and symmetrical forms. It has
been much employed in arts of design.</def>

<q>Shifting like the fragments of colored glass in the
<qex>kaleidoscope</qex>.</q>
<qau>G. W. Cable.</qau>

<def>Of, pertaining to, or formed by, a kaleidoscope;
variegated.</def>

<ets>k\'bema</ets> love, the god of love.]</ety> <def>The Hindoo

<hw>Ka*ma"la</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <fld>(Bot.)</fld>
<def>The red dusty hairs of the capsules of an East Indian tree
(<spn>Mallotus Philippinensis</spn>) used for dyeing silk. It is
violently emetic, and is used in the treatment of tapeworm.</def>
<altsp>[Written also <asp>kameela</asp>.]</altsp>

<hw>Kame</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <def>A low ridge.
<mark>[Scot.]</mark> See <er>Eschar</er>.</def>

<hw>\'d8Ka"mi</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n. pl.</pos>
<ety>[Japanese.]</ety> <def>A title given to the celestial gods
of the first mythical dynasty of Japan and extended to the
demigods of the second dynasty, and then to the long line of
spiritual princes still represented by the mikado.</def>

<hw>Ka"mi*chi</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos>
<fld>(Zo\'94l.)</fld> <def>A curious South American bird
(<spn>Anhima, <or/ Palamedea, cornuta</spn>), often domesticated
by the natives and kept with poultry, which it defends against
birds of prey. It has a long, slender, hornlike ornament on its
head, and two sharp spurs on each wing. Although its beak, feet,
and legs resemble those of gallinaceous birds, it is related in
anatomical characters to the ducks and geese
(<spn>Anseres</spn>). Called also <altname>horned
screamer</altname>. The name is sometimes applied also to the
chaja. See <er>Chaja</er>, and <er>Screamer</er>.</def>

<hw>Kamp*tu"li*con</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[Gr. <?/
to bend + <?/ material, fr. <?/ wood, matter.]</ety> <def>A kind
of elastic floor cloth, made of India rubber, gutta-percha,
linseed oil, and powdered cork.</def>

<hw>Kam"py*lite</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[Gr. <?/
bent, curved, fr. <?/ to bend.]</ety> <fld>(Min.)</fld> <def>A
variety of mimetite or arseniate of lead in hexagonal prisms of a
fine orange yellow.</def> <altsp>[Written also
<asp>campylite</asp>.]</altsp>

<mhw>{ <hw>Kam*sin"</hw>, <hw>Kham*sin"</hw>  }</mhw>
<pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[Ar. <ets>khams\'c6n</ets>, fr.
<ets>khams\'d4n</ets>, oblique case <ets>khams\'c6n</ets>, fifty;
-- so called because it blows for about fifty days, from April
till June.]</ety> <def>A hot southwesterly wind in Egypt, coming
from the Sahara.</def> <altsp>[Written also
<asp>Khamseen</asp>.]</altsp>

<mhw>{ <hw>Ka*nack"a</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <hw>Ka*na"ka</hw>

<hw>Kan"chil</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[Malay
<ets>canch\'c6l</ets>.]</ety> <fld>(Zo\'94l.)</fld> <def>A small
chevrotain of the genus <spn>Tragulus</spn>, esp. <spn>T.
pygm\'91us</spn>, or <spn>T. kanchil</spn>, inhabiting Java,
Sumatra, and adjacent islands; a deerlet. It is noted for its
agility and cunning.</def>

<hw>Kand</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <fld>(Mining)</fld>
<def>Fluor spar; -- so called by Cornish miners.</def>

<hw>Kan"ga*roo"</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[Said to be
the native name.]</ety> <fld>(Zo\'94l.)</fld> <def>Any one of
numerous species of jumping marsupials of the family
<spn>Macropodid\'91</spn>. They inhabit Australia, New Guinea,
and adjacent islands, They have long and strong hind legs and a
large tail, while the fore legs are comparatively short and
feeble. The giant kangaroo (<spn>Macropus major</spn>) is the
largest species, sometimes becoming twelve or fourteen feet in
total length. The tree kangaroos, belonging to the genus
<spn>Dendrolagus</spn>, live in trees; the rock kangaroos, of the
genus <spn>Petrogale</spn>, inhabit rocky situations; and the
brush kangaroos, of the genus <spn>Halmaturus</spn>, inhabit
wooded districts. See <er>Wallaby</er>.</def>

<-- p. 809 -->

<cs><col>Kangaroo apple</col> <fld>(Bot.)</fld>, <cd>the edible
fruit of the Tasmanian plant <spn>Solanum aviculare</spn>.</cd>
-- <col>Kangaroo grass</col> <fld>(Bot.)</fld>, <cd>a perennial
Australian forage grass (<spn>Anthistiria australis</spn>).</cd>
-- <col>Kangaroo hare</col> <fld>(Zo\'94l.)</fld>, <cd>the jerboa
kangaroo. See under <er>Jerboa</er>.</cd> -- <col>Kangaroo

rat</col> <fld>(Zo\'94l.)</fld>, <cd>the potoroo.</cd></cs>

<hw>Kan"sas</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n. pl.</pos>
<fld>(Ethnol.)</fld> <def>A tribe of Indians allied to the
Winnebagoes and Osages. They formerly inhabited the region which
is now the State of Kansas, but were removed to the Indian
Territory.</def>

<mhw>{ <hw>Ka"o*lin</hw>, <hw>Ka"o*line</hw>  }</mhw>
<pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[Chin.
<ets>kao-ling</ets>.]</ety> <fld>(Min.)</fld> <def>A very pure
white clay, ordinarily in the form of an impalpable powder, and
used to form the paste of porcelain; China clay; porcelain clay.
It is chiefly derived from the decomposition of common
feldspar.</def>

<note><hand/ The name is now applied to all porcelain clays which
endure the fire without discoloration.</note>

<hw>\'d8Kar"y*o*ki*ne`sis</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos>
<ety>[NL., fr. Gr. <?/ a nut, kernel + <?/ to move.]</ety>
<fld>(Biol.)</fld> <def>The indirect division of cells in which,
prior to division of the cell protoplasm, complicated changes
take place in the nucleus, attended with movement of the nuclear
fibrils; -- opposed to <xex>karyostenosis</xex>. The nucleus
becomes enlarged and convoluted, and finally the threads are
separated into two groups which ultimately become disconnected
and constitute the <xex>daughter nuclei</xex>. Called also
<altname>mitosis</altname>. See <cref>Cell development</cref>,
under <er>Cell</er>.</def>

<hw>Kar`y*o*ki*net"ic</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>a.</pos>
<fld>(Biol.)</fld> <def>Of or pertaining to karyokinesis; <as>as,
<ex>karyokinetic</ex> changes of cell division</as>.</def>

<hw>\'d8Kar`y*om"i*ton</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos>
<ety>[NL., Gr. (<?/) a nut + (<?/) a thread.]</ety>
<fld>(Biol.)</fld> <def>The reticular network of fine fibers, of
which the <xex>nucleus</xex> of a cell is in part composed; -- in
opposition to <xex>kytomiton</xex>, or the network in the
<xex>body</xex> of the cell.</def>

<au>W. Flemming.</au>

<hw>\'d8Kar`y*o*plas"ma</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos>
<ety>[NL., fr. Gr. <ets><?/</ets> a num + <?/ a thing
molded.]</ety> <fld>(Biol.)</fld> <def>The protoplasmic substance
of the nucleus of a cell: nucleoplasm; -- in opposition to
<xex>kytoplasma</xex>, the protoplasm of the cell.</def>

<hw>\'d8Kar`y*o*ste*no"sis</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos>
<ety>[NL., fr. Gr. <?/ a nut, kernel + <?/ a being
straitened.]</ety> <fld>(Biol.)</fld> <def>Direct cell division
(in which there is first a simple division of the nucleus,
without any changes in its structure, followed by division of the
protoplasm of the <xex>karyostenotic</xex> mode of nuclear
division.</def>

<hw>Ka"ty*did`</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos>
<fld>(Zo\'94l.)</fld> <def>A large, green, arboreal, orthopterous
insect (<spn>Cyrtophyllus concavus</spn>) of the family
<spn>Locustid\'91</spn>, common in the United States. The males
have stridulating organs at the bases of the front wings. During
the summer and autumn, in the evening, the males make a peculiar,
loud, shrill sound, resembling the combination
<xex>Katy-did</xex>, whence the name.</def>

<hw>Keel</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>v. t. & i.</pos> <ety>[AS.

<mark>[Obs.]</mark>
