<qau>Shak.</qau>

<hw>Keel</hw>, <pos>n.</pos> <def>A brewer's cooling vat; a
keelfat.</def>

<hw>Keel</hw>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[Cf. AS. <ets>ce\'a2l</ets>
ship; akin to D. & G. <ets>kiel</ets> keel, OHG. <ets>chiol</ets>
ship, Icel. <ets>kj<?/ll</ets>, and perh. to Gr. <?/ a
round-built Ph<?/nician merchant vessel, <?/ bucket; cf. Skr.
<ets>g</ets><?/<ets>la</ets> ball, round water vessel. But the
meaning of the English word seems to come from Icel.
<ets>kj\'94lr</ets> keel, akin to Sw. <ets>k\'94l</ets>, Dan.
<ets>kj\'94l</ets>.]</ety> <sn>1.</sn> <fld>(Shipbuilding)</fld>
<def>A longitudinal timber, or series of timbers scarfed
together, extending from stem to stern along the bottom of a
vessel. It is the principal timber of the vessel, and, by means
of the ribs attached on each side, supports the vessel's frame.
In an iron vessel, a combination of plates supplies the place of
the keel of a wooden ship. See <xex>Illust</xex>. of
<er>Keelson</er>.</def>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>Fig.: The whole ship.</def>

<sn>3.</sn> <def>A barge or lighter, used on the Type for
carrying coal from Newcastle; also, a barge load of coal,
twentyone tons, four cwt.</def> <mark>[Eng.]</mark>

<sn>4.</sn> <fld>(Bot.)</fld> <def>The two lowest petals of the
corolla of a papilionaceous flower, united and inclosing the
stamens and pistil; a carina. See <er>Carina</er>.</def>

<sn>5.</sn> <fld>(Nat. Hist.)</fld> <def>A projecting ridge along
the middle of a flat or curved surface.</def>

<cs><col>Bilge keel</col> <fld>(Naut.)</fld>, <cd>a keel peculiar
to ironclad vessels, extending only a portion of the length of
the vessel under the bilges. <au>Ham. Nav. Encyc</au>.</cd> --
<col>False keel</col>. <cd>See under <er>False</er>.</cd> --
<col>Keel boat</col>. <sd>(a)</sd> <cd>A covered freight boat,
with a keel, but no sails, used on Western rivers</cd>. <mark>[U.
S.]</mark> <sd>(b)</sd> <cd>A low, flat-bottomed freight boat.
See <er>Keel</er>, <pos>n.</pos>, 3.</cd> -- <col>Keel
piece</col>, <cd>one of the timbers or sections of which a keel
is composed. <col>On even keel</col>, in a level or horizontal
position, so that the draught of water at the stern and the bow
is the same. <au>Ham. Nav. Encyc.</au></cd></cs>

<hw>Keel</hw>, <pos>v. i.</pos> <wordforms>[<pos>imp. & p.
p.</pos> <er>Keeled</er> <pr>(?)</pr>; <pos>p. pr. & vb. n.</pos>
<er>Keeling</er>.]</wordforms> <sn>1.</sn> <def>To traverse with
a keel; to navigate.</def>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>To turn up the keel; to show the bottom.</def>

<cs><col>To keel over</col>, <cd>to upset; to capsize.
<mark>[Colloq.]</mark></cd></cs>

<hw>Keel"age</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[Cf. F.
<ets>guillage</ets>, fr. <ets>guille</ets> keel; of German or
Scand origin. See 3d <er>Keel</er>.]</ety> <def>The right of
demanding a duty or toll for a ship entering a port; also, the
duty or toll.</def>

<au>Bouvier. Wharton.</au>

<hw>Keeled</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>a.</pos> <sn>1.</sn>
<fld>(Bot.)</fld> <def>Keel-shaped; having a longitudinal
prominence on the back; <as>as, a <ex>keeled</ex>
leaf</as>.</def>

<sn>2.</sn> <fld>(Zo\'94l.)</fld> <def>Having a median ridge;
carinate; <as>as, a <ex>keeled</ex> scale</as>.</def>

<hw>Keel"er</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[See 3d
<er>Keel</er>.]</ety> <sn>1.</sn> <def>One employed in managing a
Newcastle keel; -- called also <altname>keelman</altname>.</def>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>A small or shallow tub; esp., one used for
holding materials for calking ships, or one used for washing
dishes, etc.</def>

<hw>Keel"fat`</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos>
<ety>[<ets>Keel</ets> to cool + <ets>fat</ets> a large tub, a
vat.]</ety> <fld>(Brewing)</fld> <def>A cooler; a vat for cooling
wort, etc.</def> <altsp>[Written also
<asp>keelvat</asp>.]</altsp>

<au>Johnson.</au>

<hw>Keel"haul`</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>v. i.</pos>
<wordforms>[<pos>imp. & p. p.</pos> <er>Keelhauled</er>
<pr>(?)</pr>; <pos>p. pr. & vb. n.</pos>
<er>Keelhauling</er>.]</wordforms> <ety>[<ets>3d keel</ets> +
<ets>haul</ets>: cf. LG. & D. <ets>kielhalen</ets>, G.
<ets>kielholen</ets>. ]</ety> <altsp>[Written also
<asp>keelhale</asp>.]</altsp> <fld>(Naut.)</fld> <def>To haul
under the keel of a ship, by ropes attached to the yardarms on
each side. It was formerly practiced as a punishment in the Dutch
and English navies.</def>

<au>Totten.</au>

<hw>Kee"ling</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[Cf. Icel.
<ets>keila</ets>, Sw. <ets>kolja</ets>, Dan.
<ets>kulle</ets>.]</ety> <fld>(Zo\'94l.)</fld> <def>A cod.</def>

<hw>Kee"li*vine</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[Cf. Gael.
<ets>cil</ets> ruddle.]</ety> <def>A pencil of black or red lead;
-- called also <altname>keelyvine pen</altname>.</def>
<mark>[Scot.]</mark>

<au>Sir W. Scott.</au>

<hw>Keel"man</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos>; <plu>pl.
-<plw>men</plw> <pr>(<?/)</pr>.</plu> <def>See <er>Keeler</er>,
<sn>1.</sn></def>

<hw>Keel"rake`</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>v. t.</pos>
<fld>(Naut.)</fld> <def>Same as <er>Keelhaul</er>.</def>

<hw>Keels</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n. pl.</pos> <def>Ninepins. See
<er>Kayles</er>.</def>

<hw>Keel"son</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[Akin to Sw.
<ets>k\'94lsvin</ets>, Dan. <ets>kj\'94lsviin</ets>, G.
<ets>kielschwein</ets>; apparently compounded of the words
<ets>keel</ets> and <ets>swine</ets>; but cf. Norweg.
<ets>kj\'94lsvill</ets>, where <ets>svill</ets> is akin to E.
<ets>sill</ets>, <pos>n.</pos> ]</ety> <fld>(Shipbuilding)</fld>
<def>A piece of timber in a ship laid on the middle of the floor
timbers over the keel, and binding the floor timbers to the keel;
in iron vessels, a structure of plates, situated like the keelson
of a timber ship.</def>

<cs><col>Cross keelson</col>, <cd>a similar structure lying
athwart the main keelson, to support the engines and
boilers.</cd></cs>

<-- p. 810 -->

<hw>Keel"vat`</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <def>See
<er>Keelfat</er>.</def>

<hw>Keen</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>a.</pos>
<wordforms>[<pos>Compar.</pos> <er>Keener</er> <pr>(?)</pr>;
<pos>superl.</pos> <er>Keenest</er>.]</wordforms> <ety>[OE.
<ets>kene</ets> sharp, bold, AS.<ets>c<?/ne</ets> bold; akin to
D. <ets>koen</ets>, OHG. <ets>kuoni</ets>, G. <ets>k\'81hn</ets>,
OSw. <ets>kyn</ets>, <ets>k\'94n</ets>, Icel. <ets>k\'91nn</ets>,
for <ets>koenn</ets> wise; perh. akin to E. <ets>ken</ets>,
<ets>can</ets> to be able. <?/45. ]</ety> <sn>1.</sn> <def>Sharp;
having a fine edge or point; <as>as, a <ex>keen</ex> razor, or a
razor with a <ex>keen</ex> edge</as>.</def>

<q>A bow he bare and arwes [arrows] bright and
<qex>kene</qex>.</q>
<qau>Chaucer.</qau>

<q>That my <qex>keen</qex> knife see not the wound it makes.</q>
<qau>Shak.</qau>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>Acute of mind; sharp; penetrating; having or
expressing mental acuteness; <as>as, a man of <ex>keen</ex>
understanding; a <ex>keen</ex> look; <ex>keen</ex>
features.</as></def>

<q>To make our wits more <qex>keen</qex>.</q>
<qau>Shak.</qau>

<q>Before the <qex>keen</qex> inquiry of her thought.</q>
<qau>Cowper.</qau>

<sn>3.</sn> <def>Bitter; piercing; acrimonious; cutting;
stinging; severe; <as>as, <ex>keen</ex> satire or
sarcasm</as>.</def>

<q>Good father cardinal, cry thou amen
To my <qex>keen</qex> curses.</q>
<qau>Shak.</qau>

<sn>4.</sn> <def>Piercing; penetrating; cutting; sharp; --
applied to cold, wind, etc, ; <as>as, a <ex>keen</ex> wind; the
cold is very <ex>keen</ex>.</as></def>

<q>Breasts the <qex>keen</qex> air, and carols as he goes.</q>
<qau>Goldsmith.</qau>

<sn>5.</sn> <def>Eager; vehement; fierce; <as>as, a <ex>keen</ex>
appetite</as>.</def> \'bdOf full <xex>kene</xex> will.\'b8

<au>Piers Plowman.</au>

<q>So <qex>keen</qex> and greedy to confound a man.</q>
<qau>Shak.</qau>

<note><hand/ <xex>Keen</xex> is often used in the composition of
words, most of which are of obvious signification; as,
<xex>keen</xex>-edged, <xex>keen</xex>-eyed,
<xex>keen</xex>-sighted, <xex>keen</xex>-witted, etc.</note>

<syn>Syn. -- Prompt; eager; ardent; sharp; acute; cutting;
penetrating; biting; severe; sarcastic; satirical; piercing;
shrewd.</syn>

<hw>Keen</hw>, <pos>v. t.</pos> <def>To sharpen; to make
cold.</def> <mark>[R.]</mark>

<q>Cold winter <qex>keens</qex> the brightening flood.</q>
<qau>Thomson.</qau>

<hw>Keen</hw>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[Ir. <ets>caoine</ets>.]</ety>
<def>A prolonged wail for a deceased person. Cf.
<er>Coranach</er>.</def> <mark>[Ireland]</mark>

<au>Froude.</au>

<hw>Keen</hw>, <pos>v. i.</pos> <def>To wail as a keener
does.</def> <mark>[Ireland]</mark>

<hw>Keen"er</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <def>A professional
mourner who wails at a funeral.</def> <mark>[Ireland]</mark>

<hw>Keen"ly</hw>, <pos>adv.</pos> <def>In a keen manner.</def>

<hw>Keen"ness</hw>, <pos>n.</pos> <def>The quality or state of
being keen.</def>

<hw>Keep</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>v. t.</pos>
<wordforms>[<pos>imp. & p. p.</pos> <er>Kept</er> <pr>(?)</pr>;
<pos>p. pr. & vb. n.</pos> <er>Keeping</er>.]</wordforms>
<ety>[OE. <ets>k<?/pen</ets>, AS.<ets>c<?/pan</ets> to keep,
regard, desire, await, take, betake; cf. AS. <ets>copenere</ets>
lover, OE. <ets>copnien</ets> to desire.]</ety> <sn>1.</sn>
<def>To care; to desire.</def> <mark>[Obs.]</mark>

<q>I <qex>kepe</qex> not of armes for to yelp [boast].</q>
<qau>Chaucer.</qau>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>To hold; to restrain from departure or removal;
not to let go of; to retain in one's power or possession; not to
lose; to retain; to detain.</def>

<q>If we lose the field,
We can not <qex>keep</qex> the town.</q>
<qau>Shak.</qau>

<q>That I may know what <qex>keeps</qex> me here with you.</q>
<qau>Dryden.</qau>

<q>If we would weigh and <qex>keep</qex> in our minds what we are
considering, that would instruct us.</q>
<qau>Locke.</qau>

<sn>3.</sn> <def>To cause to remain in a given situation or
condition; to maintain unchanged; to hold or preserve in any
state or tenor.</def>

<q>His loyalty he <qex>kept</qex>, his love, his zeal.</q>
<qau>Milton.</qau>

<q><qex>Keep</qex> a stiff rein, and move but gently on.</q>
<qau>Addison.</qau>

<note><hand/ In this sense it is often used with prepositions and
adverbs, as to <xex>keep away</xex>, to <xex>keep down</xex>, to
<xex>keep from</xex>, to <xex>keep in</xex>, <xex>out</xex>, or
<xex>off</xex>, etc. \'bdTo <xex>keep off</xex> impertinence and
solicitation from his superior.\'b8</note>

<au>Addison.</au>

<sn>4.</sn> <def>To have in custody; to have in some place for
preservation; to take charge of.</def>

<q>The crown of Stephanus, first king of Hungary, was always
<qex>kept</qex> in the castle of Vicegrade.</q>
<qau>Knolles.</qau>

<sn>5.</sn> <def>To preserve from danger, harm, or loss; to
guard.</def>

<q>Behold, I am with thee, and will <qex>keep</qex> thee.</q>
<qau>Gen. xxviii. 15.</qau>

<sn>6.</sn> <def>To preserve from discovery or publicity; not to
communicate, reveal, or betray, as a secret.</def>

<q>Great are thy virtues . . . though <qex>kept</qex> from
man.</q>
<qau>Milton.</qau>

<sn>7.</sn> <def>To attend upon; to have the care of; to
tend.</def>

<q>And the Lord God took the man, and put him into the garden of
Eden, to dress it and to <qex>keep</qex> it.</q>
<qau>Gen. ii. 15.</qau>

<q>In her girlish age, she <qex>kept</qex> sheep on the moor.</q>
<qau>Carew.</qau>

<sn>8.</sn> <def>To record transactions, accounts, or events in;
<as>as, to <ex>keep</ex> books, a journal, etc.</as>  ; also, to
enter (as accounts, records, etc. ) in a book.</def>

<sn>9.</sn> <def>To maintain, as an establishment, institution,
or the like; to conduct; to manage; <as>as, to <ex>keep</ex>
store</as>.</def>

<q>Like a pedant that <qex>keeps</qex> a school.</q>
<qau>Shak.</qau>

<q>Every one of them <qex>kept</qex> house by himself.</q>
<qau>Hayward.</qau>

<sn>10.</sn> <def>To supply with necessaries of life; to
entertain; <as>as, to <ex>keep</ex> boarders</as>.</def>

<sn>11.</sn> <def>To have in one's service; to have and maintain,
as an assistant, a servant, a mistress, a horse, etc.</def>

<q>I <qex>keep</qex> but three men and a boy.</q>
<qau>Shak.</qau>

<sn>12.</sn> <def>To have habitually in stock for sale.</def>

<sn>13.</sn> <def>To continue in, as a course or mode of action;
not to intermit or fall from; to hold to; to maintain; <as>as, to
<ex>keep</ex> silence; to <ex>keep</ex> one's word; to
<ex>keep</ex> possession.</as></def>

<q>Both day and night did we <qex>keep</qex> company.</q>
<qau>Shak.</qau>

<q>Within this portal as I <qex>kept</qex> my watch.</q>
<qau>Smollett.</qau>

<sn>14.</sn> <def>To observe; to adhere to; to fulfill; not to
swerve from or violate; to practice or perform, as duty; not to
neglect; to be faithful to.</def>

<q>I have <qex>kept</qex> the faith.</q>
<qau>2 Tim. iv. 7.</qau>

<q>Him whom to love is to obey, and <qex>keep</qex>
His great command.</q>
<qau>Milton.</qau>

<sn>15.</sn> <def>To confine one's self to; not to quit; to
remain in; <as>as, to <ex>keep</ex> one's house, room, bed,
etc.</as>  ; hence, to haunt; to frequent.</def>

<au>Shak.</au>

<q>'Tis hallowed ground;
Fairies, and fawns, and satyrs do it <qex>keep</qex>.</q>
<qau>J. Fletcher.</qau>

<sn>16.</sn> <def>To observe duty, as a festival, etc. ; to
celebrate; to solemnize; <as>as, to <ex>keep</ex> a
feast</as>.</def>

<q>I went with them to the house of God . . . with a multitude
that <qex>kept</qex> holyday.</q>
<qau>Ps. xlii. 4.</qau>

<cs><col>To keep at arm's length</col>. <cd>See under
<er>Arm</er>, <pos>n.</pos></cd> -- <col>To keep back</col>.
<sd>(a)</sd> <cd>To reserve; to withhold</cd>. \'bdI will
<xex>keep<xex> nothing <xex>back<xex> from you.\'b8 <au>Jer.
xlii. 4.</au> <sd>(b)</sd> <cd>To restrain; to hold back.</cd>
\'bd<xex>Keep back<xex> thy servant also from presumptuous
sins.\'b8  <au>Ps. xix. 13</au>. -- <col>To keep company
with</col>. <sd>(a)</sd> <cd>To frequent the society of; to
associate with; as, let youth <xex>keep company with</xex> the
wise and good.</cd> <sd>(b)</sd> <cd>To accompany; to go with;
as, to <xex>keep company with</xex> one on a voyage; also, to pay
court to, or accept attentions from, with a view to
marriage</cd>. <mark>[Colloq.]</mark> -- <col>To keep
counsel</col></mcol>. <cd>See under <er>Counsel</er>,
<pos>n.</pos></cd> -- <col>To keep down</col>. <sd>(a)</sd>
<cd>To hold in subjection; to restrain; to hinder</cd>.
<sd>(b)</sd> <fld>(Fine Arts)</fld> <cd>To subdue in tint or
tone, as a portion of a picture, so that the spectator's
attention may not be diverted from the more important parts of
the work.</cd> -- <mcol><col>To keep good</col>  (<or/
<col>bad</col>) <col>hours</col>, <cd>to be customarily early (or
late) in returning home or in retiring to rest.</cd> -- <col>To
keep house</col>. <sd>(a)</sd> <cd>To occupy a separate house or
establishment, as with one's family, as distinguished from
<xex>boarding<xex>; to manage domestic affairs</cd>. <sd>(b)</sd>
<fld>(Eng. Bankrupt Law)</fld> <cd>To seclude one's self in one's
house in order to evade the demands of creditors.</cd> -- <col>To
keep one's hand in</col>, <cd>to keep in practice.</cd> --
<col>To keep open house</col>, <cd>to be hospitable.</cd> --
<col>To keep the peace</col> <fld>(Law)</fld>, <cd>to avoid or to
prevent a breach of the peace.</cd> -- <col>To keep school</col>,
<cd>to govern, manage and instruct or teach a school, as a
preceptor.</cd> -- <col>To keep a stiff upper lip</col>, <cd>to
keep up one's courage.</cd> <mark>[Slang]</mark> -- <col>To keep
term</col></mcol>. <sd>(a)</sd> <fld>(Eng. Universities)</fld>
<cd>To reside during a term</cd>. <sd>(b)</sd> <fld>(Inns of
Court)</fld> <cd>To eat a sufficient number of dinners in hall to
make the term count for the purpose of being called to the
bar</cd>. <mark>[Eng.]</mark> <au>Mozley & W.</au></cd> --
<col>To keep touch</col>. <cd>See under <er>Touch</er>,
<pos>n.</pos></cd> -- <col>To keep under</col>, <cd>to hold in
subjection; hence, to oppress.</cd> -- <col>To keep up</col>.
<sd>(a)</sd> <cd>To maintain; to prevent from falling or
diminution; <as>as, to <ex>keep up<ex> the price of goods; to
<ex>keep up<ex> one's credit</as></cd>. <sd>(b)</sd> <cd>To
maintain; to continue; to prevent from ceasing</cd>. \'bdIn joy,
that which <xex>keeps up<xex> the action is the desire to
continue it.\'b8</cs>

<au>Locke.</au>

<syn>Syn. -- To retain; detain; reserve; preserve; hold;
restrain; maintain; sustain; support; withhold.</syn> -- To
<er>Keep</er>. <usage> <er>Retain</er>, <er>Preserve</er>.
<xex>Keep</xex> is the generic term, and is often used where
<xex>retain</xex> or <xex>preserve</xex> would too much restrict
the meaning; as, to <xex>keep</xex> silence, etc.
<xex>Retain</xex> denotes that we <xex>keep</xex> or
<xex>hold</xex> things, as against influences which might deprive
us of them, or reasons which might lead us to give them up; as,
to <xex>retain</xex> vivacity in old age; to <xex>retain</xex>
counsel in a lawsuit; to <xex>retain</xex> one's servant after a
reverse of fortune. <xex>Preserve</xex> denotes that we keep a
thing against agencies which might lead to its being destroyed or
broken in upon; as, to <xex>preserve</xex> one's health; to
<xex>preserve</xex> appearances.</usage>

<hw>Keep</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>v. i.</pos> <sn>1.</sn> <def>To
remain in any position or state; to continue; to abide; to stay;
<as>as, to <ex>keep</ex> at a distance; to <ex>keep</ex> aloft;
to <ex>keep</ex> near; to <ex>keep</ex> in the house; to
<ex>keep</ex> before or behind; to <ex>keep</ex> in favor; to
<ex>keep</ex> out of company, or out reach.</as></def>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>To last; to endure; to remain unimpaired.</def>

<q>If the malt be not thoroughly dried, the ale it makes will not
<qex>keep</qex>.</q>
<qau>Mortimer.</qau>

<sn>3.</sn> <def>To reside for a time; to lodge; to dwell.</def>
<mark>[Now disused except locally or colloquially.]</mark>

<q>Knock at his study, where, they say, he <qex>keeps</qex>.</q>
<qau>Shak.</qau>

<sn>4.</sn> <def>To take care; to be solicitous; to watch.</def>
<mark>[Obs.]</mark>

<q><qex>Keep</qex> that the lusts choke not the word of God that
is in us.</q>
<qau>Tyndale.</qau>

<sn>5.</sn> <def>To be in session; <as>as, school <ex>keeps</ex>
to-day</as>.</def> <mark>[Colloq.]</mark>

<cs><col>To keep from</col>, <cd>to abstain or refrain from.</cd>
-- <col>To keep in with</col>, <cd>to keep on good terms with;
<as>as, <ex>to keep in with<ex> an opponent</as>.</cd> -- <col>To
keep on</col>, <cd>to go forward; to proceed; to continue to
advance.</cd> -- <col>To keep to</col>, <cd>to adhere strictly
to; not to neglect or deviate from; <as>as, <ex>to keep to<ex>
old customs; <ex>to keep to<ex> a rule; <ex>to keep to<ex> one's
word or promise</as>.</cd> -- <col>To keep up</col>, <cd>to
remain unsubdued; also, not to be confined to one's
bed.</cd></cs>

<hw>Keep</hw>, <pos>n.</pos> <sn>1.</sn> <def>The act or office
of keeping; custody; guard; care; heed; charge.</def>

<au>Chaucer.</au>

<q>Pan, thou god of shepherds all,
Which of our tender lambkins takest <qex>keep</qex>.</q>
<qau>Spenser.</qau>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>The state of being kept; hence, the resulting
condition; case; <as>as, to be in good <ex>keep</ex></as>.</def>

<sn>3.</sn> <def>The means or provisions by which one is kept;
maintenance; support; <as>as, the <ex>keep</ex> of a
horse</as>.</def>

<q>Grass equal to the <qex>keep</qex> of seven cows.</q>
<qau>Carlyle.</qau>

<q>I performed some services to the college in return for my
<qex>keep</qex>.</q>
<qau>T. Hughes.</qau>

<sn>4.</sn> <def>That which keeps or protects; a stronghold; a
fortress; a castle; specifically, the strongest and securest part
of a castle, often used as a place of residence by the lord of
the castle, especially during a siege; the donjon. See
<xex>Illust</xex>. of <er>Castle</er>.</def>

<q>The prison strong,
Within whose <qex>keep</qex> the captive knights were laid.</q>
<qau>Dryden.</qau>

<q>The lower chambers of those gloomy <qex>keeps</qex>.</q>
<qau>Hallam.</qau>

<q>I think . . . the <qex>keep</qex>, or principal part of a
castle, was so called because the lord and his domestic circle
<qex>kept</qex>, abode, or lived there.</q>
<qau>M. A. Lower.</qau>

<sn>5.</sn> <def>That which is kept in charge; a charge.</def>
<mark>[Obs.]</mark>

<q>Often he used of his <qex>keep</qex>
A sacrifice to bring.</q>
<qau>Spenser.</qau>

<sn>6.</sn> <fld>(Mach.)</fld> <def>A cap for retaining anything,
as a journal box, in place.</def>

<cs><col>To take keep</col>, <cd>to take care; to heed.</cd>
<mark>[Obs.]</mark>
<au>Chaucer.</au></cs>

<hw>Keep"er</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <sn>1.</sn> <def>One
who, or that which, keeps; one who, or that which, holds or has
possession of anything.</def>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>One who retains in custody; one who has the care
of a prison and the charge of prisoners.</def>

<sn>3.</sn> <def>One who has the care, custody, or
superintendence of anything; <as>as, the <ex>keeper</ex> of a
park, a pound, of sheep, of a gate, etc.</as>  ; the
<xex>keeper</xex> of attached property; hence, one who saves from
harm; a defender; a preserver.</def>

<q>The Lord is thy <qex>keeper</qex>.</q>
<qau>Ps. cxxi. 6.</qau>

<sn>4.</sn> <def>One who remains or keeps in a place or
position.</def>

<q>Discreet; chaste; <qex>keepers</qex> at home.</q>
<qau>Titus ii. 5.</qau>

<sn>5.</sn> <def>A ring, strap, clamp, or any device for holding
an object in place; as: <sd>(a)</sd> The box on a door jamb into
which the bolt of a lock protrudes, when shot. <sd>(b)</sd> A
ring serving to keep another ring on the finger. <sd>(c)</sd> A
loop near the buckle of a strap to receive the end of the
strap.</def>

<sn>6.</sn> <def>A fruit that keeps well; <as>as, the Roxbury
Russet is a good <ex>keeper</ex></as>.</def>

<au> Downing.</au>

<cs><col>Keeper of the forest</col> <fld>(O. Eng. Law)</fld>,
<cd>an officer who had the principal government of all things
relating to the forest.</cd> -- <col>Keeper of the great
seal</col>, <cd>a high officer of state, who has custody of the
great seal. The office is now united with that of lord
chancellor.</cd> <mark>[Eng.]</mark> -- <col>Keeper of the King's
conscience</col>, <cd>the lord chancellor; -- a name given when
the chancellor was an ecclesiastic.</cd> <mark>[Eng.]</mark> --
<col>Keeper of the privy seal</col> (styled also <xex>lord privy
seal</xex>), <cd>a high officer of state, through whose hands
pass all charters, pardons, etc., before they come to the great
seal. He is a privy councillor, and was formerly called
<altname>clerk of the privy seal</altname>.</cd>
<mark>[Eng.]</mark> -- <col>Keeper of a magnet</col>, <cd>a piece
of iron which connects the two poles, for the purpose of keeping
the magnetic power undiminished; an armature.</cd></cs>

<hw>Keep"er*ship</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <def>The office
or position of a keeper.</def>

<au>Carew.</au>

<hw>Keep"ing</hw>, <pos>n.</pos> <sn>1.</sn> <def>A holding;
restraint; custody; guard; charge; care; preservation.</def>

<q>His happiness is in his own <qex>keeping</qex>.</q>
<qau>South.</qau>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>Maintenance; support; provision; feed; <as>as,
the cattle have good <ex>keeping</ex></as>.</def>

<q>The work of many hands, which earns my <qex>keeping</qex>.</q>
<qau>Milton.</qau>

<sn>3.</sn> <def>Conformity; congruity; harmony; consistency;
<as>as, these subjects are in <ex>keeping</ex> with each
other</as>.</def>

<sn>4.</sn> <fld>(Paint.)</fld> <def>Harmony or correspondence
between the different parts of a work of art; <as>as, the
foreground of this painting is not in
<ex>keeping</ex></as>.</def>

<cs><col>Keeping room</col>, <cd>a family sitting room.
<mark>[New Eng. & Prov. Eng.]</mark></cd></cs>

<syn>Syn. -- Care; guardianship; custody; possession.</syn>

friendship.</def>

<hw>Kelp</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[Formerly
<ets>kilpe</ets>; of unknown origin.]</ety> <sn>1.</sn> <def>The
calcined ashes of seaweed, -- formerly much used in the
manufacture of glass, now used in the manufacture of
iodine.</def>

<sn>2.</sn> <fld>(Bot.)</fld> <def>Any large blackish
seaweed.</def>

<note><hand/ <xex>Laminaria</xex> is the common kelp of Great
Britain; <xex>Macrocystis pyrifera</xex> and <xex>Nereocystis
Lutkeana</xex> are the great kelps of the Pacific Ocean.</note>

<cs><col>Kelp crab</col> <fld>(Zo\'94l.)</fld>, <cd>a California
spider crab (<spn>Epialtus productus</spn>), found among
seaweeds, which it resembles in color.</cd> -- <col>Kelp
salmon</col> <fld>(Zo\'94l.)</fld>, <cd>a serranoid food fish
(<spn>Serranus clathratus</spn>) of California. See
<er>Cabrilla</er>.</cd></cs>

<hw>Kelp"fish`</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos>
<fld>(Zo\'94l.)</fld> <def>A small California food fish
(<spn>Heterostichus rostratus</spn>), living among kelp. The name
is also applied to species of the genus
<spn>Platyglossus</spn>.</def>

<hw>Ken</hw>, <pos>n. t.</pos> <wordforms>[<pos>imp. & p.

<ets>kannjan</ets> to make known; orig., a causative

apprehension.</q>

<hw>Ker"a*tin</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[Gr. <?/,
<?/, horn.]</ety> <fld>(Physiol. Chem.)</fld> <def>A nitrogenous
substance, or mixture of substances, containing sulphur in a
loose state of combination, and forming the chemical basis of
epidermal tissues, such as horn, hair, feathers, and the like. It
is an insoluble substance, and, unlike elastin, is not dissolved
even by gastric or pancreatic juice. By decomposition with
sulphuric acid it yields leucin and tyrosin, as does albumin.
Called also <altname>epidermose</altname>.</def><-- a
sulfur-containing fibrous proein.  -->

bound round, with a kercher.</def> <mark>[Obs.]</mark>

<hw>Ker"chief</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos>; <plu>pl.
<plw>Kerchiefs</plw> <pr>(#)</pr></plu>. <ety>[OE.
<ets>coverchef</ets>, OF. <ets>cuevrechief</ets>,
<ets>couvrechef</ets>, F. <ets>couvrechef</ets>, a head covering,
fr. <ets>couvrir</ets> to cover + OF. <ets>chief</ets> head, F.
<ets>chef</ets>. See <er>Cover</er>, <er>Chief</er>, and cf.
<er>Curfew</er>.]</ety> <sn>1.</sn> <def>A square of fine linen
worn by women as a covering for the head; hence, anything similar
in form or material, worn for ornament on other parts of the
person; -- mostly used in compounds; <as>as,
nec<ex>kerchief</ex>; breast<ex>kerchief</ex>; and later,
hand<ex>kerchief</ex>.</as></def>

<q>He might put on a hat, a muffler, and a <qex>kerchief</qex>,
and so escape.</q>
<qau>Shak.</qau>

<q>Her black hair strained away
To a scarlet <qex>kerchief</qex> caught beneath her chin.</q>
<qau>Mrs. Browning.</qau>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>A lady who wears a kerchief.</def>

<au>Dryden.</au>

<mhw>{ <hw>Ker"chiefed</hw>, <hw>Ker"chieft</hw>  }</mhw>
<pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>a.</pos> <def>Dressed; hooded; covered;
wearing a kerchief.</def>

<au>Milton.</au>

<hw>Kerf</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[AS.
<ets>cyrf</ets> a cutting off, fr. <ets>ceorfan</ets> to cut,

<hw>Ke"rite</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[Gr. <?/ 
horn.]</ety> <def>A compound in which tar or asphaltum combined
with animal or vegetable oils is vulcanized by sulphur, the
product closely resembling rubber; -- used principally as an
insulating material in telegraphy.</def>

<au>Knight.</au>

<hw>Kerl</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <def>See
<er>Carl</er>.</def>

<hw>Ker"mes</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[Ar. & Per.
<ets>girmiz</ets>. See <er>Crimson</er>, and cf.
<er>Alkermes</er>.]</ety> <sn>1.</sn> <fld>(Zo\'94l.)</fld>
<def>The dried bodies of the females of a scale insect
(<spn>Coccus ilicis</spn>), allied to the cochineal insect, and
found on several species of oak near the Mediterranean. They are
round, about the size of a pea, contain coloring matter analogous
to carmine, and are used in dyeing. They were anciently thought
to be of a vegetable nature, and were used in medicine.</def>
<altsp>[Written also <asp>chermes</asp>.]</altsp>

<sn>2.</sn> <fld>(Bot.)</fld> <def>A small European evergreen oak
(<spn>Quercus coccifera</spn>) on which the kermes insect
(<spn>Coccus ilicis</spn>) feeds.</def>

<au>J. Smith (Dict. Econ. Plants).</au>

<cs><col>Kermes mineral</col>. <sd>(a)</sd> <fld>(Old
Chem.)</fld> <cd>An artificial amorphous trisulphide of antimony;
-- so called on account of its red color</cd>. <sd>(b)</sd>
<fld>(Med. Chem.)</fld> <cd>A compound of the trioxide and
trisulphide of antimony, used in medicine. This substance occurs
in nature as the mineral <xex>kermesite<xex>.</cd></cs>

<def>See <er>Kirmess</er>.</def>

<hw>Kern</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos>
<ety>[Ir.<ets>ceatharnach</ets>.Cf. <er>Cateran</er>. ]</ety>
<sn>1.</sn> <def>A light-armed foot soldier of the ancient
militia of Ireland and Scotland; -- distinguished from
<xex>gallowglass</xex>, and often used as a term of
contempt.</def>

<au>Macaulay.</au>

<q>Now for our Irish wars;
We must supplant those rough, rug-headed <qex>kerns</qex>.</q>
<qau>Shak.</qau>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>Any kind of boor or low-lived person.</def>
<mark>[Obs.]</mark>

<au>Blount.</au>

<sn>3.</sn> <fld>(O. Eng. Law)</fld> <def>An idler; a
vagabond.</def>

<au>Wharton.</au>

<hw>Kern</hw>, <pos>n.</pos> <fld>(Type Founding)</fld> <def>A
part of the face of a type which projects beyond the body, or
shank.</def>

<hw>Kern</hw>, <pos>v. t.</pos> <wordforms>[<pos>imp. & p.

See <er>Quern</er>.</def>

<au>Johnson.</au>

<hw>Kern</hw>, <pos>v. i.</pos> <ety>[Cf. G. <ets>kern</ets>
kernel, grain; akin to E. <ets>corn</ets>. See <er>Corn</er>,
<er>Kernel</er>. ]</ety> <sn>1.</sn> <def>To harden, as corn in
ripening.</def> <mark>[Obs.]</mark>

<au>Carew.</au>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>To take the form of kernels; to granulate.</def>
<mark>[Obs.]</mark>

<q>It is observed that rain makes the salt <qex>kern</qex>.</q>
<qau>Dampier.</qau>

<hw>Kerned</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>a.</pos> <fld>(Print.)</fld>
<def>Having part of the face projecting beyond the body or shank;
-- said of type.</def> \'bdIn Roman, <xex>f</xex> and
<xex>j</xex> are the only <xex>kerned</xex> letters.\'b8

<au>MacKellar.</au>

<hw>Ker"nel</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[OE.
<ets>kernel</ets>, <ets>kirnel</ets>, <ets>curnel</ets>,
AS.<ets>cyrnel</ets>, fr. <ets>corn</ets> grain. See
<er>Corn</er>, and cf. <er>Kern</er> to harden.]</ety>
<sn>1.</sn> <def>The essential part of a seed; all that is within
the seed walls; the edible substance contained in the shell of a
nut; hence, anything included in a shell, husk, or integument;
<as>as, the <ex>kernel</ex> of a nut</as>. See <xex>Illust</xex>.
of <er>Endocarp</er>.</def>

<q>' A were as good crack a fusty nut with no
<qex>kernel</qex></q>
<qau>Shak.</qau>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>A single seed or grain; <as>as, a
<ex>kernel</ex> of corn</as>.</def>

<sn>3.</sn> <def>A small mass around which other matter is
concreted; a nucleus; a concretion or hard lump in the
flesh.</def>

<sn>4.</sn> <def>The central, substantial or essential part of
anything; the gist; the core; <as>as, the <ex>kernel</ex> of an
argument</as>.</def>

<hw>Ker"nel</hw>, <pos>v. i.</pos> <wordforms>[<pos>imp. & p.
p.</pos> <er>Kerneled</er> <pr>(?)</pr> <or/ <er>Kernelled</er>;
<pos>p. pr. & vb. n.</pos> <er>Kerneling</er> <or/
<er>Kernelling</er>.]</wordforms> <def>To harden or ripen into
kernels; to produce kernels.</def>

<hw>Ker"o*sene`</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[Gr. <?/

obtained from the distillation of mineral wax, bituminous shale,
etc., and hence called also <altname>coal oil</altname>. It is
now produced in immense quantities, chiefly by the distillation
and purification of petroleum. It consists chiefly of several
hydrocarbons of the methane series.</def>

<hw>Kes"trel</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[See

the sparrow hawk. Its color is reddish fawn, streaked and spotted
with white and black. Also called <altname>windhover</altname>
and <altname>stannel</altname>. The name is also applied to other
allied species.</def>

<note><hand/ This word is often used in contempt, as of a mean
kind of hawk. \'bdKites and <xex>kestrels</xex> have a
resemblance with hawks.\'b8</note>

<hw>Ke"tine</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[See
<er>Ketone</er>.]</ety> <fld>(Chem.)</fld> <def>One of a series
of organic bases obtained by the reduction of certain isonitroso
compounds of the ketones. In general they are unstable oily
substances having a pungent aromatic odor.</def>

<hw>\'d8Ket`mie"</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos>
<fld>(Bot.)</fld> <def>The name of certain African species of
<spn>Hibiscus</spn>, cultivated for the acid of their
mucilage.</def> <altsp>[Written also <asp>ketmia</asp>.]</altsp>

<hw>Ke"tol</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos>
<ety>[<ets>Ket</ets>one + ind<ets>ol</ets>.]</ety>
<fld>(Chem.)</fld> <def>One of a series of series of complex
nitrogenous substances, represented by methyl ketol and related
to indol.</def>

<cs><col>Methyl ketol</col>, <cd>a weak organic base, obtained as
a white crystalline substance having the odor of
f\'91ces.</cd></cs>

<hw>Ke"tone</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[Cf.
<er>Acetone</er>.]</ety> <fld>(Chem.)</fld> <def>One of a large
class of organic substances resembling the aldehydes, obtained by
the distillation of certain salts of organic acids and consisting
of carbonyl (<chform>CO</chform>) united with two hydrocarbon
radicals. In general the ketones are colorless volatile liquids
having a pungent ethereal odor.</def>

<note><hand/ The ketones are named by adding the
suffix-<xex>one</xex> to the stems of the organic acids from
which they are respectively derived; thus, <xex>acetic</xex> acid
gives acetone; <xex>butyric</xex> acid, <xex>butyrone</xex>,
etc.</note>

<hw>Ke*ton"ic</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>a.</pos> <fld>(Chem.)</fld>
<def>Pertaining to, or derived from, a ketone; <as>as, a
<ex>ketonic</ex> acid</as>.</def>

<hw>Ket"tle</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[OE.
<ets>ketel</ets>; cf. AS. <ets>cetel</ets>, <ets>cetil</ets>,
<ets>cytel</ets>; akin to D. <ets>kjedel</ets>, G.
<ets>kessel</ets>, OHG. <ets>chezzil</ets>, Icel.
<ets>ketill</ets>, SW. <ets>kittel</ets>, Dan. <ets>kjedel</ets>,
Goth. <ets>katils</ets>; all perh. fr. L. <ets>catillus</ets>,
dim. of <ets>catinus</ets> a deep vessel, bowl; but cf. also OHG.
<ets>chezz\'c6</ets> kettle, Icel. <ets>kati</ets> small
ship.]</ety> <def>A metallic vessel, with a wide mouth, often
without a cover, used for heating and boiling water or other
liguids.</def>

<cs><col>Kettle pins</col>, <cd>ninepins; skittles.
<mark>[Obs.]</mark> <au>Shelton</au>.</cd> -- <col>Kettle
stitch</col> <fld>(Bookbinding)</fld>, <cd>the stitch made in
sewing at the head and tail of a book. <au>Knight</au>.</cd></cs>

<hw>Ket"tle*drum`</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <sn>1.</sn>
<fld>(Mus.)</fld> <def>A drum made of thin copper in the form of
a hemispherical kettle, with parchment stretched over the mouth
of it.</def>

<note><hand/ <xex>Kettledrums</xex>, in pairs, were formerly used
in martial music for cavalry, but are now chiefly confined to
orchestras, where they are called <xex>tympani</xex>.</note>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>An informal social party at which a light
collation is offered, held in the afternoon or early evening. Cf.
<er>Drum</er>, <pos>n.</pos>, 4 and 5.</def>

<hw>Ket"tle*drum`mer</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <def>One
who plays on a kettledrum.</def>

<hw>Kex</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[W.
<ets>cecys</ets>, pl., hollow stalks.]</ety>

<sn>1.</sn> <fld>(Bot.)</fld> <def>A weed; a kecksy.</def>

<au>Bp. Gauden.</au>

<q>Though the rough <qex>kex</qex> break
The starred mosaic.</q>
<qau>Tennyson.</qau>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>A dry husk or covering.</def>

<q>When the <qex>kex</qex>, or husk, is broken, he proveth a fair
flying butterfly.</q>
<qau>Holland.</qau>

<hw>Key</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[OE.
<ets>keye</ets>, <ets>key</ets>, <ets>kay</ets>, AS.
<ets>c</ets><?/g.]</ety> <sn>1.</sn> <def>An instrument by means
of which the bolt of a lock is shot or drawn; usually, a
removable metal instrument fitted to the mechanism of a
particular lock and operated by turning in its place.</def>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>An instrument which is turned like a key in
fastening or adjusting any mechanism; <as>as, a watch
<ex>key</ex>; a bed <ex>key</ex>, etc.</as></def>

<sn>3.</sn> <def>That part of an instrument or machine which
serves as the means of operating it; <as>as, a telegraph
<ex>key</ex>; the <ex>keys</ex> of a pianoforte, or of a
typewriter.</as></def>

<sn>4.</sn> <def>A position or condition which affords entrance,
control, pr possession, etc.; <as>as, the <ex>key</ex> of a line
of defense; the <xex>key</xex> of a country; the <xex>key</xex>
of a political situation. Hence, that which serves to unlock,
open, discover, or solve something unknown or difficult; <as>as,
the <ex>key</ex> to a riddle</as>; the <ex>key</ex> to a
problem.</as></def>

<q>Those who are accustomed to reason have got the true
<qex>key</qex> of books.</q>
<qau>Locke.</qau>

<q>Who keeps the <qex>keys</qex> of all the creeds.</q>
<qau>Tennyson.</qau>

<sn>5.</sn> <def>That part of a mechanism which serves to lock
up, make fast, or adjust to position.</def>

<sn>6.</sn> <fld>(Arch.)</fld> <sd>(a)</sd> <def>A piece of wood
used as a wedge.</def> <sd>(b)</sd> <def>The last board of a
floor when laid down.</def>

<sn>7.</sn> <fld>(Masonry)</fld> <sd>(a)</sd> <def>A
keystone.</def> <sd>(b)</sd> <def>That part of the plastering
which is forced through between the laths and holds the rest in
place.</def>

<sn>8.</sn> <fld>(Mach.)</fld> <sd>(a)</sd> <def>A wedge to unite
two or more pieces, or adjust their relative position; a cotter;
a forelock.</def> See <xex>Illusts</xex>. of <er>Cotter</er>, and
<er>Gib</er>. <sd>(b)</sd> <def>A bar, pin or wedge, to secure a
crank, pulley, coupling, etc., upon a shaft, and prevent relative
turning; sometimes holding by friction alone, but more frequently
by its resistance to shearing, being usually embedded partly in
the shaft and partly in the crank, pulley, etc.</def>

<sn>9.</sn> <fld>(Bot.)</fld> <def>An indehiscent, one-seeded
fruit furnished with a wing, as the fruit of the ash and maple; a
samara; -- called also <altname>key fruit</altname>.</def>

<sn>10.</sn> <fld>(Mus.)</fld> <sd>(a)</sd> <def>A family of
tones whose regular members are called diatonic tones, and named
key tone  (or tonic) or one (or eight), mediant or three,
dominant or five, subdominant or four, submediant or six,
supertonic or two, and subtonic or seven. Chromatic tones are
temporary members of a key, under such names as \'bd sharp
four,\'b8 \'bdflat seven,\'b8 etc. Scales and tunes of every
variety are made from the tones of a key.</def> <sd>(b)</sd>
<def>The fundamental tone of a movement to which its modulations
are referred, and with which it generally begins and ends;
keynote.</def>

<q>Both warbling of one song, both in one <qex>key</qex>.</q>
<qau>Shak.</qau>

<sn>11.</sn> <def>Fig: The general pitch or tone of a sentence or
utterance.</def>

<q>You fall at once into a lower <qex>key</qex>.</q>
<qau>Cowper.</qau>

<cs><col>Key bed</col>. <cd>Same as <cref>Key seat</cref>.</cd>
-- <col>Key bolt</col>, <cd>a bolt which has a mortise near the
end, and is secured by a cotter or wedge instead of a nut.</cd>
<col>Key bugle</col>. <cd>See <er>Kent bugle</er>.</cd> --
<mcol><col>Key of a position</col> <or/
<col>country.</col></mcol> <fld>(Mil.)</fld> <cd>See
<er>Key</er>, 4.</cd> -- <col>Key seat</col> <fld>(Mach.)</fld>,
<cd>a bed or groove to receive a key which prevents one part from
turning on the other.</cd> -- <col>Key way</col>, <cd>a channel
for a key, in the hole of a piece which is keyed to a shaft; an
internal key seat; -- called also <altname>key
seat</altname>.</cd> -- <col>Key wrench</col> <fld>(Mach.)</fld>,
<cd>an adjustable wrench in which the movable jaw is made fast by
a key.</cd> -- <col>Power of the keys</col> <fld>(Eccl.)</fld>,
<cd>the authority claimed by the ministry in some Christian
churches to administer the discipline of the church, and to grant
or withhold its privileges; -- so called from the declaration of
Christ, \'bdI will give unto thee the <xex>keys<xex> of the
kingdom of heaven.\'b8 <au>Matt. xvi. 19</au>.</cd></cs>

<hw>Key</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>v. t.</pos> <wordforms>[<pos>imp.
& p. p.</pos> <er>Keved</er> <pr>(?)</pr>; <pos>p. pr. & vb.
n.</pos> <er>Keying</er>.]</wordforms> <def>To fasten or secure
firmly; to fasten or tighten with keys or wedges.</def>

<au>Francis.</au>

<cs><col>To key up</col>. <sd>(a)</sd> <fld>(Arch.)</fld> <cd>To
raise (the whole ring of an arch) off its centering, by driving
in the keystone forcibly</cd>. <sd>(b)</sd> <fld>(Mus.)</fld>
<cd>To raise the pitch of</cd>. <sd>(c)</sd> <cd>Hence, fig., to
produce nervous tension in.</cd></cs>

etc.</def>

<hw>Key"hole`</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <sn>1.</sn> <def>A

<sn>2.</sn> <sd>(a)</sd> <fld>(Carp.)</fld> <def>A hole or
excavation in beams intended to be joined together, to receive
the key which fastens them.</def> <sd>(b)</sd> <fld>(Mach.)</fld>
<def>a mortise for a key or cotter.</def>

<cs><col>Keyhole limpet</col> <fld>(Zo\'94l.)</fld>, <cd>a marine
gastropod of the genus Fissurella and allied genera. See
<er>Fissurella</er>.</cd> -- <col>Keyhole saw</col>, <cd>a
narrow, slender saw, used in cutting keyholes, etc., as in doors;
a kind of compass saw or fret saw.</cd> -- <col>Keyhole
urchin</col> <fld>(Zo\'94l.)</fld>, <cd>any one of numerous
clypeastroid sea urchins, of the genera <spn>Melitta</spn>,
<spn>Rotula</spn>, and <spn>Encope</spn>; -- so called because
they have one or more perforations resembling keyholes.</cd></cs>

<hw>Key"note`</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <sn>1.</sn>
<fld>(Mus.)</fld> <def>The tonic or first tone of the scale in
which a piece or passage is written; the fundamental tone of the
chord, to which all the modulations of the piece are referred; --
called also <altname>key tone</altname>.</def>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>The fundamental fact or idea; that which gives
the key; <as>as, the <ex>keynote</ex> of a policy or a
sermon</as>.</def>

voussoirs, or projects, or is decorated with carving. See

so called from its having been the central State of the Union at

<hw>Kick</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>v. t.</pos>
<wordforms>[<pos>imp. & p. p.</pos> <er>Kicred</er> <pr>(#)</pr>;
<pos>p. pr. & vb. n.</pos> <er>Kicking</er>.]</wordforms>
<ety>[W. <ets>cicio</ets>, fr. <ets>cic</ets> foot.]</ety>
<def>To strike, thrust, or hit violently with the foot; <as>as, a
horse <ex>kicks</ex> a groom; a man <ex>kicks</ex> a
dog.</as></def>

<q>He [Frederick the Great] <qex>kicked</qex> the shins of his
judges.</q>
<qau>Macaulay.</qau>

<cs><col>To kick the beam</col>, <cd>to fit up and strike the
beam; -- said of the lighter arm of a loaded balance; hence, to
be found wanting in weight. <au>Milton</au>.</cd> -- <col>To kick
the bucket</col>, <cd>to lose one's life; to die. <mark>[Colloq.
& Low]</mark></cd></cs>

<hw>Kick</hw>, <pos>v. i.</pos> <sn>1.</sn> <def>To thrust out
the foot or feet with violence; to strike out with the foot or
feet, as in defense or in bad temper; esp., to strike backward,
as a horse does, or to have a habit of doing so. Hence,
figuratively: To show ugly resistance, opposition, or hostility;
to spurn.</def>

<q>I should <qex>kick</qex>, being kicked.</q>
<qau>Shak.</qau>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>To recoil; -- said of a musket, cannon,
etc.</def><-- also kicj back -->

<hw>Kick</hw>, <pos>n.</pos> <sn>1.</sn> <def>A blow with the
foot or feet; a striking or thrust with the foot.</def>

<q>A <qex>kick</qex>, that scarce would more a horse,
May kill a sound divine.</q>
<qau>Cowper.</qau>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>The projection on the tang of the blade of a
pocket knife, which prevents the edge of the blade from striking
the spring. See <xex>Illust</xex>. of <er>Pocketknife</er>.</def>

<sn>3.</sn> <fld>(Brickmaking)</fld> <def>A projection in a mold,
to form a depression in the surface of the brick.</def>

<sn>4.</sn> <def>The recoil of a musket or other firearm, when
discharged.</def>

<hw>Kick"a*ble</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>a.</pos> <def>Capable or
deserving of being kicked.</def> \'bdA <xex>kickable</xex>
boy.\'b8

<au>G. Eliot. </au>

<hw>Kick`a*poos"</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n. pl.</pos>;
<sing>sing. <singw>Kickapoo</singw> <pr>(<?/)</pr></sing>.
<fld>(Ethnol.)</fld> <def>A tribe of Indians which formerly
occupied the region of Northern Illinois, allied in language to
the Sacs and Foxes.</def>

<-- kickback. n. recoil, of a gun or machine, as in older
automobile engines when started by turning a crank.
  2. a secret, and usually illegal, payment, by a recipient of
money paid for goods or services, to a facilitator of the
transaction, of a portion of that money. -->

<hw>Kick"shaws`</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos>; <plu>pl</plu>.
<plw>Kickshawses</plw> <pr>(#)</pr> <ety>[Corrupt. fr. F.
<ets>guelgue chose</ets> something, fr. L. <ets>gualis</ets> of
what kind (akin to E. <ets>which</ets>) + <ets>suffix</ets>
<ets>-guam</ets> + <ets>causa</ets> cause, in LL., a thing. See

tiny <qex>kickshaws</qex>.</q>
<qau>Shak.</qau>

<hw>Kid</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[Of Scand. origin;

<hw>Kid"nap`</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>v. t.</pos>
<wordforms>[<pos>imp. & p. p.</pos> <er>Kidnaped</er>
<pr>(?)</pr> or <er>Kidnapped</er>; <pos>p. pr. & vb. n.</pos>
<er>Kidnaping</er> or <er>Kidnapping</er>.]</wordforms>
<ety>[<ets>Kid</ets> a child + Prov. E. <ets>nap</ets> to seize,
to grasp. Cf. <er>Knab</er>, <er>Knap</er>, <er>Nab</er>.]</ety>
<def>To take (any one) by force or fear, and against one's will,
with intent to carry to another place.</def>

<au>Abbott.</au>

<q>You may reason or expostulate with the parents, but never
attempt to <qex>kidnap</qex> their children, and to make
proselytes of them.</q>
<qau>Whately.</qau>

<note><hand/ Originally used only of stealing children, but now
extended in application to any human being, involuntarily
abducted.</note>

<mhw>{ <hw>Kid"nap`er</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <or/
<hw>Kid"nap`per</hw>  }</mhw>, <pos>n.</pos> <def>One who steals
or forcibly carries away a human being; a manstealer.</def>

<hw>Kid"ney</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos>; <plu>pl.
<plw>Kidneys</plw> <pr>(#)</pr></plu>.  <ety>[OE.
<ets>kidnei</ets>, <ets>kidnere</ets>, from Icel.
<ets>koi<?/r</ets> belly, womb (akin to Goth. <ets>gipus</ets>,
AS. <ets>cwip</ets> womb) + OE. <ets>nere</ets> kidney; akin to
D. <ets>nier</ets>, G. <ets>niere</ets>, OHG. <ets>nioro</ets>,
Icel. <ets>n<?/ra</ets>, Dan. <ets>nyre</ets>, Sw.
<ets>njure</ets>, and probably to Gr. (<?/) Cf. <er>Kite</er>
belly.]</ety>

<-- p. 813 -->

<sn>1.</sn> <fld>(Anat.)</fld> <def>A glandular organ which
excretes urea and other waste products from the animal body; a
urinary gland.</def>

<note><hand/ In man and in other mammals there are two kidneys,
one each side of vertebral column in the back part of the
abdomen, each kidney being connected with the bladder by a long
tube, the ureter, through which the urine is constantly excreted
into the bladder to be periodically discharged.</note>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>Habit; disposition; sort; kind.</def>

<au>Shak.</au>

<q>There are in later other decrees, made by popes of another
<qex>kidney</qex>.</q>
<qau>Barrow.</qau>

<q>Millions in the world of this man's <qex>kidney</qex>.</q>
<qau>L'Estrange.</qau>

<q>Your poets, spendthrifts, and other fools of that
<qex>kidney</qex>, pretend, forsooth, to crack their jokes on
prudence.</q>
<qau>Burns.</qau>

<note><hand/ This use of the word perhaps arose from the fact
that the <xex>kidneys</xex> and the fat about them are an easy
test of the condition of an animal as to fatness. \'bdThink of
that, -- a man of my <xex>kidney</xex>; -- . . . as subject to
heat as butter.\'b8</note>

<au>Shak.</au>

<sn>3.</sn> <def>A waiter</def>. <mark>[Old Cant]</mark>

<au>Tatler.</au>

<cs><col>Floating kidney</col>. <cd>See <cref>Wandering
kidney</cref>, under <er>Wandering</er>.</cd> -- <col>Kidney
bean</col> <fld>(Bot.)</fld>, <cd>a sort of bean; -- so named
from its shape. It is of the genus <spn>Phaseolus</spn> (<spn>P.
vulgaris</spn>). See under <er>Bean</er>.</cd> -- <col>Kidney
ore</col> <fld>(Min.)</fld>, <cd>a variety of hematite or iron
sesquioxide, occurring in compact kidney-shaped masses.</cd> --
<col>Kidney stone</col>. <fld>(Min.)</fld> <cd>See
<er>Nephrite</er>, and <er>Jade</er>.</cd> -- <col>Kidney
vetch</col> <fld>(Bot.)</fld>, <cd>a leguminous herb of Europe
and Asia (<spn>Anthyllis vulneraria</spn>), with cloverlike heads
of red or yellow flowers, once used as a remedy for renal
disorders, and also to stop the flow of blood from wounds;
lady's-fingers.</cd></cs>

<hw>Kid"ney-shaped`</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, }</mhw> <pos>a.</pos>
<def>Having the form or shape of a kidney; reniform; <as>as, a
<ex>kidney-shaped</ex> leaf</as>.</def>

<au>Gray.</au>

<au>Halliwell.</au>

<altname>keeve</altname>.</def>

<hw>\'d8Kie"sel*guhr`</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[G.,
fr. <ets>kiesel</ets> flint + <ets>guhr</ets> an earthy deposit
or sediment in water.]</ety> <def>Siliceous earth; specifically,
porous infusorial earth, used as an absorbent of nitroglycerin in
the manufacture of dynamite.</def>

Stassfurt, Prussian Saxony.</def>

<hw>Kil"der*kin</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[OD.
<ets>kindeken</ets>, <ets>kinneken</ets>, a small barrel, orig.,

<hw>Kill</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <def>A kiln.</def>
<mark>[Obs.]</mark>

<au>Fuller.</au>

<hw>Kill</hw>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[D. <ets>kil</ets>.]</ety>
<def>A channel or arm of the sea; a river; a stream; <as>as, the
channel between Staten Island and Bergen Neck is the
<ex>Kill</ex> van Kull, or the <ex>Kills</ex>; -- used also in
composition; <as>as, Schuyl<ex>kill</ex>, Cats<ex>kill</ex>,
etc.</as></as></def>

<hw>Kill</hw>, <pos>v. t.</pos> <wordforms>[<pos>imp. & p.
p.</pos> <er>Killed</er> <pr>(?)</pr>; <pos>p. pr. & vb. n.</pos>
<er>Killing</er>.]</wordforms> <ety>[OE. <ets>killen</ets>,
<ets>kellen</ets>, <ets>cullen</ets>, to kill, strike; perh. the
same word as <ets>cwellen</ets>, <ets>quellen</ets>, to kill (cf.
<er>Quell</er>), or perh. rather akin to Icel. <ets>kolla</ets>
to hit in the head, harm, <ets>kollr</ets> top, summit, head, Sw.
<ets>kulle</ets>, D. <ets>kollen</ets> to kill with the
ax.]</ety> <sn>1.</sn> <def>To deprive of life, animal or
vegetable, in any manner or by any means; to render inanimate; to
put to death; to slay.</def>

<q>Ah, <qex>kill</qex> me with thy weapon, not with words !</q>
<qau>Shak.</qau>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>To destroy; to ruin; <as>as, to <ex>kill</ex>
one's chances; to <ex>kill</ex> the sale of a book.</as></def>
\'bdTo <xex>kill</xex> thine honor.\'b8

<au>Shak.</au>

<q>Her lively color <qex>kill'd</qex> with deadly cares.</q>
<qau>Shak.</qau>

<sn>3.</sn> <def>To cause to cease; to quell; to calm; to still;
<as>as, in seamen's language, a shower of rain <ex>kills</ex> the
wind</as>.</def>

<q>Be comforted, good madam; the great rage,
You see, is <qex>killed</qex> in him.</q>
<qau>Shak.</qau>

<sn>4.</sn> <def>To destroy the effect of; to counteract; to
neutralize; <as>as, alkali <ex>kills</ex> acid</as>.</def>

<cs><col>To kill time</col>, <cd>to busy one's self with
something which occupies the attention, or makes the time pass
without tediousness.</cd></cs>

<syn>Syn. -- To murder; assassinate; slay; butcher; destroy. --
To <er>Kill</er>, <er>Murder</er>, <er>Assassinate</er>. To
<xex>kill</xex> does not necessarily mean any more than to
deprive of life. A man may <xex>kill</xex> another by accident or
in self-defense, without the imputation of guilt. To
<xex>murder</xex> is to kill with malicious forethought and
intention. To <xex>assassinate</xex> is to<xex>murder</xex>
suddenly and by stealth. The sheriff may <xex>kill</xex> without
<xex>murdering</xex>; the duelist <xex>murders</xex>, but does
not <xex>assassinate</xex> his antagonist; the assassin
<xex>kills</xex> and <xex>murders</xex>.</syn>

<mhw>{ <hw>Kill"dee`</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <hw>Kill"deer`</hw>
<pr>(?)</pr>, }</mhw> <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[So named from its
notes.]</ety> <fld>(Zo\'94l.)</fld> <def>A small American plover
(<spn>\'92gialitis vocifera</spn>).</def>

<note><hand/ It is dark grayish brown above; the rump and upper
tail coverts are yellowish rufous; the belly, throat, and a line
over the eyes, white; a ring round the neck and band across the
breast, black.</note>

<hw>Kill"er</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <sn>1.</sn> <def>One
who deprives of life; one who, or that which, kills.</def>

<sn>2.</sn> <fld>(Zo\'94l.)</fld> <def>A voracious, toothed whale
of the genus <spn>Orca</spn>, of which several species are
known.</def>

<note><hand/ The <xex>killers</xex> have a high dorsal fin, and
powerful jaws armed with large, sharp teeth. They capture, and
swallow entire, large numbers of seals, porpoises, and dolphins,
and are celebrated for their savage, combined attacks upon the
right whales, which they are said to mutilate and kill. The
common Atlantic species (<spn>Orca gladiator</spn>), is found
both on the European and the American coast. Two species
(<spn>Orca ater</spn> and <spn>O. rectipinna</spn>) <xex>occur on
the Pacific coast</xex>.</note>

<hw>Kil*lesse"</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[Cf.
<er>Coulisse</er>.]</ety> <fld>(Arch.)</fld> <sd>(a)</sd> <def>A
gutter, groove, or channel.</def> <sd>(b)</sd> <def>A hipped
roof.</def> <mark>[Prov. Eng.]</mark>

<au>Parker.</au>

<hw>Kil"li*fish`</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos>
<fld>(Zo\'94l.)</fld> <def>Any one of several small American
cyprinodont fishes of the genus <spn>Fundulus</spn> and allied
genera. They live equally well in fresh and brackish water, or
even in the sea. They are usually striped or barred with black.
Called also <altname>minnow</altname>, and <altname>brook
fish</altname>. See <er>Minnow</er>.</def>

<hw>Kil"li*grew</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos>

<er>Chough</er>.</def> <mark>[Prov. Eng. & Scot.]</mark>

<hw>Kiln</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos>
<ety>[OE.<ets>kilne</ets>, <ets>kulne</ets>, AS. <ets>cyln</ets>,
<ets>cylen</ets>; akin to Icel. <ets>kylna</ets>;
<ets>prob</ets>. from the same source as <ets>coal</ets>. See
<er>Coal</er>.]</ety> <sn>1.</sn> <def>A large stove or oven; a

<ex>kiln</ex> for baking or hardening earthen vessels; a
<ex>kiln</ex> for drying grain, meal, lumber, etc.; a
<ex>kiln</ex> for calcining limestone.</as></def>

<hw>Ki"lo</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos>; <plu>pl.

<mhw>{ <hw>Kil"o*gram</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <hw>Kil"o*gramme</hw> 
}</mhw>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[F. <ets>kilogramme</ets>; pref.
<ets>kilo-</ets> (fr. Gr. <grk>chi`lioi</grk> a thousand ) +
<ets>gramme.</ets> See 3d <er>Gram</er>.]</ety> <def>A measure of
weight, being a thousand grams, equal to 2.2046 pounds
avoirdupois (15,432.34 grains). It is equal to the weight of a
cubic decimeter of distilled water at the temperature of maximum
density, or 39<deg/ Fahrenheit.</def>

<mhw>{ <hw>Kil"o*gram*me`ter</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>,
<hw>Kil"o*gram*me`tre</hw>  }</mhw>, <pos>n.</pos>
<fld>(Mech.)</fld> <def>A measure of energy or work done, being
the amount expended in raising one kilogram through the height of
one meter, in the latitude of Paris.</def>

<mhw>{ <hw>Kil"o*li`ter</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <hw>Kil"o*li`tre</hw> 
}</mhw>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[F. <ets>kilolitre</ets>. See
<er>Kilogram</er>, and <er>Liter</er>.]</ety> <def>A measure of
capacity equal to a cubic meter, or a thousand liters. It is
equivalent to 35.315 cubic feet, and to 220.04 imperial gallons,
or 264.18 American gallons of 321 cubic inches.</def>

<mhw>{ <hw>Kil"o*me`ter</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <hw>Kil"o*me`tre</hw> 
}</mhw>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[F. <ets>kilometre</ets>. See
<er>Kilogram</er>, and <er>Meter</er>.]</ety> <def>A measure of
length, being a thousand meters. It is equal to 3,280.8 feet, or
62137 of a mile.</def>

<hw>Kil"o*stere`</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos>
<ety>[F.<ets>kilostere</ets>. See <er>Kilogram</er>, and
<er>Stere</er>.]</ety> <def>A cubic measure containing 1000 cubic
meters, and equivalent to 35,315 cubic feet.</def>

<hw>Kin</hw>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[OE. <ets>kin</ets>,
<ets>cun</ets>, AS. <ets>cynn</ets> kin, kind, race, people; akin
to <ets>cennan</ets> to beget, D. <ets>kunne</ets> sex, OS. &
OHG. <ets>kunni</ets> kin, race, Icel. <ets>kyn</ets>, Goth.
<ets>kuni</ets>, G. & D. <ets>kind</ets> a child, L.
<ets>genus</ets> kind, race, L. <ets>gignere</ets> to beget, Gr.
<?/ to be born, Skr. <ets>jan</ets> to beget. <?/. Cf.
<er>Kind</er>, <er>King</er>, <er>Gender</er> kind,
<er>Nation</er>.]</ety> <sn>1.</sn> <def>Relationship,
consanguinity, or affinity; connection by birth or marriage;
kindred; near connection or alliance, as of those having common
descent.</def>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>Relatives; persons of the same family or
race.</def>

<q>The father, mother, and the <qex>kin</qex>beside.</q>
<qau>Dryden.</qau>

<q>You are of <qex>kin</qex>, and so a friend to their
persons.</q>
<qau>Bacon.</qau>

kinder.</def> \'bd<xex>Kin</xex> to the king.\'b8
