<hw>Knock</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>v. i.</pos>
<wordforms>[<pos>imp. & p. p.</pos> <er>Knocked</er>
<pr>(?)</pr>; <pos>p. pr. & vb. n.</pos>
<er>Knocking</er>.]</wordforms> <ety>[OE. <ets>knoken</ets>, AS.
<ets>cnocian</ets>, <ets>cnucian</ets>; prob. of imitative
origin; cf. Sw. <ets>knacka</ets>.Cf. <er>Knack</er>.]</ety>
<sn>1.</sn> <def>To drive or be driven against something; to
strike against something; to clash; <as>as, one heavy body
<ex>knocks</ex> against another</as>.</def>

<au>Bacon.</au>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>To strike or beat with something hard or heavy;
to rap; <as>as, to <ex>knock</ex> with a club; to <ex>knock</ex>
on the door.</as></def>

<q>For harbor at a thousand doors they <qex>knocked</qex>.</q>
<qau>Dryden.</qau>

<q>Seek, and ye shall find; <qex>knock</qex>, and it shall be
opened unto you.</q>
<qau>Matt. vii. 7.</qau>

<cs><col>To knock about</col>, <cd>to go about, taking knocks or
rough usage; to wander about; to saunter. <mark>[Colloq.]</mark>
\'bd<xex>Knocking about town<xex>.\'b8 <au>W. Irving</au>.</cd>
-- <col>To knock up</col>, <cd>to fail of strength; to become
wearied or worn out, as with labor; to give out. \'bdThe horses
were beginning to <xex>knock up<xex> under the fatigue of such
severe service.\'b8 <au>De Quincey</au>.</cd><-- (b) to make
pregnant (vulgar) --> -- <col>To knock off</col>, <cd>to cease,
as from work; to desist.</cd> -- <col>To knock under</col>,
<cd>to yield; to submit; to acknowledge one's self conquered; --
an expression probably borrowed from the practice of
<xex>knocking under the table<xex> with the knuckles, when
conquered. \'bdColonel Esmond <xex>knocked under<xex> to his
fate.\'b8 <au>Thackeray</au>.</cd></cs>

<hw>Knock</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>v. t.</pos> <sn>1.</sn> <def>To
strike with something hard or heavy; to move by striking; to
drive (a thing) against something; <as>as, to <ex>knock</ex> a
ball with a bat; to <ex>knock</ex> the head against a post; to
<ex>knock</ex> a lamp off the table.</as></def>

<q>When heroes <qex>knock</qex> their knotty heads together.</q>
<qau>Rowe.</qau>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>To strike for admittance; to rap upon, as a
door.</def>

<q>Master, <qex>knock</qex> the door hard.</q>
<qau>Shak.</qau>

<cs><col>To knock down</col>. <sd>(a)</sd> <cd>To strike down; to
fell; to prostrate by a blow or by blows; as, <xex>to knock
down<xex> an assailant</cd>. <sd>(b)</sd> <cd>To assign to a
bidder at an auction, by a blow or knock; to knock off.</cd> --
<mcol><col>To knock in the head</col>, <or/ <col>on the
head</col>, <cd>to stun or kill by a blow upon the head; hence,
to put am end to; to defeat, as a scheme or project; to
frustrate; to quash.</cd> <mark>[Colloq.]</mark> -- <col>To knock
off</col>. <sd>(a)</sd> <cd>To force off by a blow or by
beating.</cd> <sd>(b)</sd> <cd>To assign to a bidder at an
auction, by a blow on the counter</cd>. <sd>(c)</sd> <cd>To leave
off (work, etc.)</cd>. <mark>[Colloq.]</mark> -- <col>To knock
out</col></mcol>, <cd>to force out by a blow or by blows; <as>as,
to <ex>knock out<ex> the brains</as>.</cd> -- <col>To knock
up</col>. <sd>(a)</sd> <cd>To arouse by knocking</cd>.
<sd>(b)</sd> <cd>To beat or tire out; to fatigue till unable to
do more; as, the men were entirely <xex>knocked up<xex>.
<mark>[Colloq.]</mark> \'bdThe day being exceedingly hot, the
want of food had <xex>knocked up<xex> my followers.\'b8
<au>Petherick</au>. <sd>(c)</sd> <fld>(Bookbinding)</fld> <cd>To
make even at the edges, or to shape into book form, as printed
sheets.</cd><-- (d) To make pregnant. [vulgar: Often used in
passive, "she got knocked up"] --></cs>

<-- [MW10]: Knock off (a) v. i. and t. to quit (working). (b)
accomplish, frequently used when the task is accomplished
rapidly. (c) (Coll.) to kill; to defeat (opponents). (d) to
discount, to deduct (a sum from a price).  (d) rob. (also "knock
over") (e) to make a knockoff of; copy, imitate.-->

<hw>Knock</hw>, <pos>n.</pos> <sn>1.</sn> <def>A blow; a stroke
with something hard or heavy; a jar.</def>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>A stroke, as on a door for admittance; a
rap.</def> \'bd A <xex>knock</xex> at the door.\'b8

<au>Longfellow.</au>

<q>A loud cry or some great <qex>knock</qex>.</q>
<qau>Holland.</qau>

<cs><col>Knock off</col>, <cd>a device in a knitting machine to
remove loops from the needles.</cd></cs>

<hw>Knock"down`</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <def>A felling
by a knock, as of a combatant, or of an animal.</def>

<hw>Knock"down`</hw>, <pos>a.</pos> <def>Of force sufficient to
fell or completely overthrow; <as>as, a <ex>knockdown</ex> blow;
a <ex>knockdown</ex> argument.</as></def> <mark>[Colloq.]</mark>

<hw>Knock"er</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <def>One who, or
that which, knocks; specifically, an instrument, or kind of
hammer, fastened to a door, to be used in seeking for
admittance.</def>

<q>Shut, shut the door, good John ! fatigued, <-I said;
Tie up the <qex>knocker</qex>; say I'm sick, I'm dead.</q>
<qau>Pope.</qau>

<hw>Knock"ing</hw>, <pos>n.</pos> <def>A beating; a rap; a series
of raps.</def>

<q>The . . . repeated <qex>knockings</qex> of the head upon the
ground by the Chinese worshiper.</q>
<qau>H. Spencer.</qau>

<hw>Knock"ings</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n. pl.</pos>
<fld>(Mining)</fld> <def>Large lumps picked out of the sieve, in
dressing ore.</def>

<hw>Knock"-knee`</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos>
<fld>(Med.)</fld> <def>A condition in which the knees are bent in
so as to touch each other in walking; inknee.</def>

<hw>Knock"-kneed`</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>a.</pos> <def>Having
the legs bent inward so that the knees touch in walking.</def>
<altsp>[Written also <asp>knack-kneed</asp>.]</altsp>


<-- knockoff. a cheap imitation of something popular, often
produced illegally and of inferior materials. -->

<hw>Knock"stone`</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos>
<fld>(Mining)</fld> <def>A block upon which ore is broken
up.</def>

<hw>Knoll</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[AS.
<ets>cnoll</ets>; akin to G. <ets>knolle</ets>,
<ets>knollen</ets>, clod, lump, knob, bunch, OD.
<ets>knolle</ets> ball, bunch, Sw. <ets>kn\'94l</ets>, Dan.
<ets>knold</ets>.]</ety> <def>A little round hill; a mound; a
small elevation of earth; the top or crown of a hill.</def>

<q>On <qex>knoll</qex> or hillock rears his crest,
Lonely and huge, the giant oak.</q>
<qau>Sir W. Scott.</qau>

<hw>Knoll</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>v. t.</pos>
<wordforms>[<pos>imp. & p. p.</pos> <er>Knolled</er>
<pr>(?)</pr>; <pos>p. pr. & vb. n.</pos>
<er>Knolling</er>.]</wordforms> <ety>[OE. <ets>knollen</ets>, AS.
<ets>cnyllan</ets>. See <er>Knell</er>.]</ety> <def>To ring, as a
bell; to strike a knell upon; to toll; to proclaim, or summon, by
ringing.</def> \'bd<xex>Knolled</xex> to church.\'b8

<au>Shak.</au>

<q>Heavy clocks <qex>knolling</qex> the drowsy hours.</q>
<qau>Tennyson.</qau>

<hw>Knoll</hw>, <pos>v. i.</pos> <def>To sound, as a bell; to
knell.</def>

<au>Shak.</au>

<q>For a departed being's soul
The death hymn peals, and the hollow bells <qex>knoll</qex>.</q>
<qau>Byron.</qau>

<hw>Knoll</hw>, <pos>n.</pos> <def>The tolling of a bell; a
knell.</def> <mark>[R.]</mark>

<au>Byron.</au>

<hw>Knoll"er</hw>, <pos>n.</pos> <def>One who tolls a bell.</def>
<mark>[Obs.]</mark>

<au>Sherwood.</au>

<hw>Knop</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[OE.
<ets>knop</ets>, <ets>knoppe</ets>; cf. D.<ets>knop</ets>,
<ets>knoop</ets>, G. <ets>knopf</ets>, Dan. <ets>knap</ets>,
<ets>knop</ets>, Sw. <ets>knapp</ets>, <ets>knopp</ets>, button,
bud, Icel. <ets>knappr</ets>, and E. <ets>knap</ets>,
<pos>n.</pos> Cf. <er>Knap</er>, <er>Knob</er>.]</ety>
<sn>1.</sn> <def>A knob; a bud; a bunch; a button.</def>

<q>Four bowls made like unto almonds, with their <qex>knops</qex>
and their flowers.</q>
<qau>Ex. xxv. 21.</qau>

<sn>2.</sn> <fld>(Arch.)</fld> <def>Any boldly projecting
sculptured ornament; esp., the ornamental termination of a
pinnacle, and then synonymous with <xex>finial</xex>; -- called
also <altname>knob</altname>, and <altname>knosp</altname>.</def>

<cs><col>Knop sedge</col> <fld>(Bot.)</fld>, <cd>the bur reed
(<spn>Sparganium</spn>); -- so called from its globular clusters
of seed vessels.</cd></cs>

<au>Prior.</au>

<hw>Knopped</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>a.</pos> <def>Having knops or
knobs; fastened as with buttons.</def> <mark>[Obs.]</mark>

<au>Rom. of R.</au>

<hw>Knop"pern</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[Cf. G.
<ets>knopper</ets>. See <er>Knop</er>.]</ety>
<fld>(Zo\'94l.)</fld> <def>A kind of gall produced by a gallfly
on the cup of an acorn, -- used in tanning and dyeing.</def>

<hw>Knop"weed`</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <def>Same as
<er>Knapweed</er>.</def>

<hw>Knor</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <def>See
<er>Knur</er>.</def> <mark>[Obs.]</mark>

<hw>Knosp</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[Cf. G.
<ets>knospe</ets> bud, E. <ets>knop</ets>,
<ets>knar</ets>.]</ety> <fld>(Arch.)</fld> <def>Same as
<er>Knop</er>,2.</def>

<au>Milman.</au>

<hw>Knot</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[OE.
<ets>knot</ets>, <ets>knotte</ets>, AS. <ets>cnotta</ets>; akin
to D. <ets>knot</ets>, OHG. <ets>chnodo</ets>, <ets>chnoto</ets>,
G. <ets>knoten</ets>, Icel. <ets>kn<?/tr</ets>, Sw.
<ets>knut</ets>, Dan. <ets>knude</ets>, and perh. to L.
<ets>nodus</ets>. Cf. <er>Knout</er>, <er>Knit</er>.]</ety>
<sn>1.</sn> <sd>(a)</sd> <def>A fastening together of the pars or
ends of one or more threads, cords, ropes, etc., by any one of
various ways of tying or entangling.</def> <sd>(b)</sd> <def>A
lump or loop formed in a thread, cord, rope. etc., as at the end,
by tying or interweaving it upon itself.</def> <sd>(c)</sd>
<def>An ornamental tie, as of a ribbon.</def>

<note><hand/ The names of knots vary according to the manner of
their making, or the use for which they are intended; as,
<xex>dow</xex>knot, <xex>reef</xex> knot, <xex>stopper</xex>
knot, <xex>diamond</xex> knot, etc.</note>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>A bond of union; a connection; a tie.</def>
\'bdWith nuptial <xex>knot</xex>.\'b8

<au>Shak.</au>

<q>Ere we knit the <qex>knot</qex> that can never be loosed.</q>
<qau>Bp. Hall.</qau>

<sn>3.</sn> <def>Something not easily solved; an intricacy; a
difficulty; a perplexity; a problem.</def>

<q><qex>Knots</qex> worthy of solution.</q>
<qau>Cowper.</qau>

<q>A man shall be perplexed with <qex>knots</qex>, and problems
of business, and contrary affairs.</q>
<qau>South.</qau>

<sn>4.</sn> <def>A figure the lines of which are interlaced or
intricately interwoven, as in embroidery, gardening, etc.</def>
\'bdGarden <xex>knots</xex>.\'b8

<au>Bacon.</au>

<q>Flowers worthy of paradise, which, not nice art
In beds and curious <qex>knots</qex>, but nature boon
Poured forth profuse on hill, and dale, and plain.</q>
<qau>Milton.</qau>

<sn>5.</sn> <def>A cluster of persons or things; a collection; a
group; a hand; a clique; <as>as, a <ex>knot</ex> of
politicians</as>.</def> \'bd<xex>Knots</xex> of talk.\'b8

<au>Tennyson.</au>

<q>His ancient <qex>knot</qex> of dangerous adversaries.</q>
<qau>Shak.</qau>

<q>Palms in cluster, <qex>knots</qex> of Paradise.</q>
<qau>Tennyson.</qau>

<q>As they sat together in small, separate <qex>knots</qex>, they
discussed doctrinal and metaphysical points of belief.</q>
<qau>Sir W. Scott. </qau>

<sn>6.</sn> <def>A portion of a branch of a tree that forms a
mass of woody fiber running at an angle with the grain of the
main stock and making a hard place in the timber. A loose knot is
generally the remains of a dead branch of a tree covered by later
woody growth.</def>

<sn>7.</sn> <def>A knob, lump, swelling, or protuberance.</def>

<q>With lips serenely placid, felt the <qex>knot</qex>
Climb in her throat.</q>
<qau>Tennyson.</qau>

<sn>8.</sn> <def>A protuberant joint in a plant.</def>

<sn>9.</sn> <def>The point on which the action of a story
depends; the gist of a matter.</def> <mark>[Obs.]</mark>

<q>I shoulde to the <qex>knotte</qex> condescend,
And maken of her walking soon an end.</q>
<qau>Chaucer.</qau>

<sn>10.</sn> <fld>(Mech.)</fld> <def>See <er>Node</er>.</def>

<sn>11.</sn> <fld>(Naut.)</fld> <sd>(a)</sd> <def>A division of
the log line, serving to measure the rate of the vessel's motion.
Each knot on the line bears the same proportion to a mile that
thirty seconds do to an hour. The number of knots which run off
from the reel in half a minute, therefore, shows the number of
miles the vessel sails in an hour.</def> Hence: <sd>(b)</sd>
<def>A nautical mile, or 6080.27 feet; <as>as, when a ship goes
eight miles an hour, her speed is said to be eight
<ex>knots</ex></as>.</def>

<sn>12.</sn> <def>A kind of epaulet. See <er>Shoulder
knot</er>.</def>

<sn>13.</sn> <fld>(Zo\'94l.)</fld> <def>A sandpiper (<spn>Tringa
canutus</spn>), found in the northern parts of all the
continents, in summer. It is grayish or ashy above, with the rump
and upper tail coverts white, barred with dusky. The lower parts
are pale brown, with the flanks and under tail coverts white.
When fat it is prized by epicures. Called also
<altname>dunne</altname>.</def>

<note><hand/ The name is said to be derived from King Canute,
this bird being a favorite article of food with him.</note>

<q>The <qex>knot</qex> that called was Canutus' bird of old,
Of that great king of Danes his name that still doth hold,
His appetite to please that far and near was sought.</q>
<qau>Drayton.</qau>

<hw>Knot</hw>, <pos>v. t.</pos> <wordforms>[<pos>imp. & p.
p.</pos> <er>Knotted</er>; <pos>p. pr. & vb. n.</pos>
<er>Knotting</er>.]</wordforms> <sn>1.</sn> <def>To tie in or
with, or form into, a knot or knots; to form a knot on, as a
rope; to entangle.</def> \'bd<xex>Knotted</xex> curls.\'b8

<au>Drayton.</au>

<q>As tight as I could <qex>knot</qex> the noose.</q>
<qau>Tennyson.</qau>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>To unite closely; to knit together.</def>

<au>Bacon.</au>

<sn>3.</sn> <def>To entangle or perplex; to puzzle.</def>
<mark>[Obs. or R.]</mark>

<hw>Knot</hw>, <pos>v. i.</pos> <sn>1.</sn> <def>To form knots or
joints, as in a cord, a plant, etc.; to become entangled.</def>

<q>Cut hay when it begins to <qex>knot</qex>.</q>
<qau>Mortimer.</qau>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>To knit knots for fringe or trimming.</def>

<sn>3.</sn> <def>To copulate; -- said of toads.</def>
<mark>[R.]</mark>

<au>Shak.</au>

<hw>Knot"ber`ry</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos>
<fld>(Bot.)</fld> <def>The cloudberry (<spn>Rudus
Cham\'91morus</spn>); -- so called from its knotted stems.</def>

<hw>Knot"grass`</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos>
<fld>(Bot.)</fld> <sd>(a)</sd> <def>a common weed with jointed
stems <spn>(Polygonum aviculare)</spn>; knotweed.</def>
<sd>(b)</sd> <def>The dog grass. See under <er>Dog</er>.</def>

<note><hand/ An infusion of <spn>Polygonum aviculare</spn> was
once supposed to have the effect of stopping the growth of an
animal, and hence it was called, as by Shakespeare, \'bdhindering
<xex>knotgrass</xex>.\'b8</note>

<q>We want a boy extremely for this function,
Kept under for a year with milk and <qex>knotgrass</qex>.</q>
<qau>Beau. &  Fl.</qau>

<hw>Knot"less</hw>, <pos>a.</pos> <def>Free from knots; without
knots.</def> \'bdSilver firs with <xex>knotless</xex> trunks.\'b8

<qau>Congreve.</qau>

<hw>Knot"ted</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>a.</pos> <sn>1.</sn>
<def>Full of knots; having knots knurled; <as>as, a
<ex>knotted</ex> cord; the <ex>knotted</ex> oak.</as></def>

<au>Dryden.</au>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>Interwoven; matted; entangled.</def>

<q>Make . . . thy <qex>knotted</qex> and combined locks to
part.</q>
<qau>Shak.</qau>

<sn>3.</sn> <def>Having intersecting lines or figures.</def>

<q>The west corner of thy curious <qex>knotted</qex> garden.</q>
<qau>Shak.</qau>

<sn>4.</sn> <fld>(Geol.)</fld> <def>Characterized by small,
detached points, chiefly composed of mica, less decomposable than
the mass of the rock, and forming knots in relief on the
weathered surface; <as>as, <ex>knotted</ex> rocks</as>.</def>

<au>Percival.</au>

<sn>5.</sn> <def>Entangled; puzzling; knotty.</def>
<mark>[R.]</mark>

<q>They're catched in <qex>knotted</qex> lawlike nets.</q>
<qau>Hudibras.</qau>

<hw>Knot"ti*ness</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[From
<er>Knotty</er>.]</ety> <sn>1.</sn> <def>The quality or state of
being knotty or full of knots.</def>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>Difficulty of solution; intricacy;
complication.</def> \'bd <xex>Knottiness</xex> of his style.\'b8

<au>Hare.</au>

<hw>Knot"ty</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>a.</pos>
<wordforms>[<pos>Compar.</pos> <er>Knottier</er> <pr>(?)</pr>;
<pos>superl.</pos> <er>Knottiest</er>.]</wordforms> <sn>1.</sn>
<def>Full of knots; knotted; having many knots; <as>as,
<ex>knotty</ex> timber; a <ex>knotty</ex> rope.</as></def>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>Hard; rugged; <as>as, a <ex>knotty</ex>
head</as>.</def><mark>[R.]</mark>

<au>Rewe.</au>

<sn>3.</sn> <def>Difficult; intricate; perplexed.</def>

<q>A <qex>knotty</qex> point to which we now proceed</q>

<hw>Knot"wort</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <fld>(Bot.)</fld>
<def>A small, herbaceous, trailing plant, of the genus
<spn>Illecebrum</spn> (<spn>I. verticillatum</spn>.)</def>

<hw>Knout</hw> <pr>(nout <or/ n??t)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos>
<ety>[Russ. <ets>knut'</ets>; prob. of Scand. origin; cf. Sw.
<ets>knut</ets> knot, knout, Icel. <ets>kn<?/tr</ets> knot: cf.
F. <ets>knout</ets>. See <er>Knot</er>.]</ety> <def>A kind of
whip for flogging criminals, formerly much used in Russia. The
last is a tapering bundle of leather thongs twisted with wire and
hardened, so that it mangles the flesh.</def>

<hw>Knout</hw>, <pos>v. t.</pos> <def>To punish with the
knout</def>

<au>Brougham.</au>

<hw>Know</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <def>Knee.</def>

<au>Chaucer.</au>

<hw>Know</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>v. t.</pos>
<wordforms>[<pos>imp.</pos> <er>Knew</er> <pr>(?)</pr>; <pos>p.
p.</pos> <er>Known</er> <pr>(?)</pr>; <pos>p. pr. & vb. n.</pos>
<er>Knowing</er>.]</wordforms> <ety>[OE. <ets>knowen</ets>,
<ets>knawen</ets>, AS. <ets>cn\'84wan</ets>; akin to OHG.
<ets>chn\'84an</ets> (in comp.), Icel. <ets>kn\'84</ets> to be
able, Russ, <ets>znate</ets> to know, L. <ets>gnoscere</ets>,
<ets>noscere</ets>, Gr. <?/, Skr. <ets>jn<?/</ets>; fr. the root
of E. <ets>can</ets>, <pos>v. i.</pos>, <ets>ken</ets>. (<?/).
See <er>Ken</er>, <er>Can</er> to be able, and cf.
<er>Acquaint</er>, <er>Cognition</er>, <er>Gnome</er>,
<er>Ignore</er>, <er>Noble</er>, <er>Note</er>.]</ety>
<sn>1.</sn> <def>To perceive or apprehend clearly and certainly;
to understand; to have full information of; <as>as, to
<ex>know</ex> one's duty</as>.</def>

<q>O, that a man might <qex>know</qex>
The end of this day's business ere it come!</q>
<qau>Shak.</qau>

<q>There is a certainty in the proposition, and we
<qex>know</qex> it.</q>
<qau>Dryden.</qau>

<q><qex>Know</qex> how sublime a thing it is
To suffer and be strong.</q>
<qau>Longfellow.</qau>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>To be convinced of the truth of; to be fully
assured of; <as>as, to <ex>know</ex> things from
information</as>.</def>

<sn>3.</sn> <def>To be acquainted with; to be no stranger to; to
be more or less familiar with the person, character, etc., of; to
possess experience of; <as>as, to <ex>know</ex> an author; to
<ex>know</ex> the rules of an organization.</as></def>

<q>He hath made him to be sin for us, who <qex>knew</qex> no
sin.</q>
<qau>2 Cor. v. 21.</qau>

<q>Not to <qex>know</qex> me argues yourselves unknown.</q>
<qau>Milton.</qau>

<sn>4.</sn> <def>To recognize; to distinguish; to discern the
character of; <as>as, to <ex>know</ex> a person's face or
figure</as>.</def>

<q>Ye shall <qex>know</qex> them by their fruits.</q>
<qau>Matt. vil. 16. </qau>

<q>And their eyes were opened, and they <qex>knew</qex> him.</q>
<qau>Luke xxiv. 31.</qau>

<q>To know
Faithful friend from flattering foe.</q>
<qau>Shak.</qau>

<q>At nearer view he thought he <qex>knew</qex> the dead.</q>
<qau>Flatman.</qau>

<sn>5.</sn> <def>To have sexual commerce with.</def>

<q>And Adam <qex>knew</qex> Eve his wife.</q>
<qau>Gen. iv. 1.</qau>

<note><hand/ <xex>Know</xex> is often followed by an objective
and an infinitive (with or without to) or a participle, a
dependent sentence, etc.</note>

<q>And I <qex>knew</qex> that thou hearest me always.</q>
<qau>John xi. 42.</qau>

<q>The monk he instantly <qex>knew</qex> to be the prior.</q>
<qau>Sir W. Scott.</qau>

<q>In other hands I have <qex>known</qex> money do good.</q>
<qau>Dickens.</qau>

<cs><col>To know how</col>, <cd>to understand the manner, way, or
means; to have requisite information, intelligence, or sagacity.
<xex>How<xex> is sometimes omitted. \'bd If we fear to die, or
<xex>know<xex> not to be patient.\'b8</cd></cs>

<au>Jer. Taylor.</au>

<hw>Know</hw>, <pos>v. i.</pos> <sn>1.</sn> <def>To have
knowledge; to have a clear and certain perception; to possess
wisdom, instruction, or information; -- often with of.</def>

<q>Israel doth not <qex>know</qex>, my people doth not
consider.</q>
<qau>Is. i. 3.</qau>

<q>If any man will do his will, he shall <qex>know</qex> of the
doctrine, whether it be of God, or whether I speak of myself.</q>
<qau>John vii. 17.</qau>

<q>The peasant folklore of Europe still <qex>knows</qex> of
willows that bleed and weep and speak when hewn.</q>
<qau>Tylor.</qau>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>To be assured; to feel confident.</def>

<cs><col>To know of</col>,<cd>to ask, to inquire.
<mark>[Obs.]</mark> \'bd <xex>Know<xex> of your youth, examine
well your blood.\'b8</cd></cs>

<au>Shak.</au>

<hw>Know"a*ble</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>a.</pos> <def>That may be
known; capable of being discovered, understood, or
ascertained.</def>

<q>Thus mind and matter, as known or <qex>knowable</qex>, are
only two different series of phenomena or qualities.</q>
<qau>Sir W. Hamilton. </qau>

<hw>Know"a* ble*ness</hw>, <pos>n.</pos> <def>The state or
quality of being knowable.</def>

<au>Locke.</au>

<hw>Know"-all`</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <def>One who
knows everything; hence, one who makes pretension to great
knowledge; a wiseacre; -- usually ironical.</def> <mark>[Colloq.
or R.]</mark><-- = know-it-all -->

<hw>Know"er</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <def>One who
knows.</def>

<au>Shak.</au>

<hw>Know"ing</hw>, <pos>a.</pos> <sn>1.</sn> <def>Skilful; well
informed; intelligent; <as>as, a <ex>knowing</ex> man; a
<ex>knowing</ex> dog.</as></def>

<q>The <qex>knowing</qex> and intelligent part of the world.</q>
<qau>South.</qau>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>Artful; cunning; <as>as, a <ex>knowing</ex>
rascal</as>.</def> <mark>[Colloq.]</mark>

<hw>Know"ing</hw>, <pos>n.</pos> <def>Knowledge; hence,
experience.</def> \'bd In my <xex>knowing</xex>.\'b8

<au>Shak.</au>

<q>This sore night
Hath trifled former <qex>knowings</qex>.</q>
<qau>Shak.</qau>

<hw>Know"ing*ly</hw>, <pos>adv.</pos> <sn>1.</sn> <def>With
knowledge; in a knowing manner; intelligently; consciously;
deliberately; <as>as, he would not <ex>knowingly</ex>
offend</as>.</def>

<au>Strype.</au>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>By experience.</def> <mark>[Obs.]</mark>

<au>Shak.</au>

<hw>Know"ing*ness</hw>, <pos>n.</pos> <def>The state or quality
of being knowing or intelligent; shrewdness; skillfulness.</def>

<hw>Knowl"eche</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n. & v.</pos>
<mark>[Obs.]</mark> <def>See <er>Knowl</er>, <er>edge</er>.</def>

<q>We consider and <qex>knowleche</qex> that we have
offended.</q>
<qau>Chaucer.</qau>

<-- p. 819 -->

<hw>Knowl"ech*ing</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos>
<def>Knowledge.</def> <mark>[Obs.]</mark>

<au>Chaucer.</au>

<hw>Knowl"edge</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[OE.
<ets>knowlage</ets>, <ets>knowlege</ets>, <ets>knowleche</ets>,
<ets>knawleche</ets>. The last part is the Icel. suffix
<ets>-leikr</ets>, forming abstract nouns, orig. the same as
Icel. <ets>leikr</ets> game, play, sport, akin to AS.
<ets>l\'bec</ets>, Goth. <ets>laiks</ets> dance. See
<er>Know</er>, and cf. <er>Lake</er>, <pos>v. i.</pos>,
<er>Lark</er> a frolic.]</ety>

<sn>1.</sn> <def>The act or state of knowing; clear perception of
fact, truth, or duty; certain apprehension; familiar cognizance;
cognition.</def>

<q><qex>Knowledge</qex>, which is the highest degree of the
speculative faculties, consists in the perception of the truth of
affirmative or negative propositions.</q>
<qau>Locke.</qau>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>That which is or may be known; the object of an
act of knowing; a cognition; -- chiefly used in the plural.</def>

<q>There is a great difference in the delivery of the
mathematics, which are the most abstracted of
<qex>knowledges</qex>.</q>
<qau>Bacon.</qau>

<q><qex>Knowledges</qex> is a term in frequent use by Bacon, and,
though now obsolete, should be revived, as without it we are
compelled to borrow \'bdcognitions\'b8 to express its import.</q>
<qau>Sir W. Hamilton.</qau>

<q>To use a word of Bacon's, now unfortunately obsolete, we must
determine the relative value of <qex>knowledges</qex>.</q>
<qau>H. Spencer.</qau>

<sn>3.</sn> <def>That which is gained and preserved by knowing;
instruction; acquaintance; enlightenment; learning; scholarship;
erudition.</def>

<q><qex>Knowledge</qex> puffeth up, but charity edifieth.</q>
<qau>1 Cor. viii. 1.</qau>

<q>Ignorance is the curse of God; -
<qex>Knowledge</qex>, the wing wherewith we fly to heaven.</q>
<qau>Shak.</qau>

<sn>4.</sn> <def>That familiarity which is gained by actual
experience; practical skill; <as>as, a <ex>knowledge</ex> of
life</as>.</def>

<q>Shipmen that had <qex>knowledge</qex> of the sea.</q>
<qau>1 Kings ix. 27.</qau>

<sn>5.</sn> <def>Scope of information; cognizance; notice;
<as>as, it has not come to my <ex>knowledge</ex></as>.</def>

<q>Why have I found grace in thine eyes, that thou shouldst take
<qex>knowledge</qex> of me?</q>
<qau>Ruth ii. 10.</qau>

<sn>6</sn>. <def>Sexual intercourse; -- usually preceded by
<xex>carnal</xex>; <as>as, <ex>carnal knowledge</ex></as></def>.

<syn>Syn. -- See <er>Wisdom</er>.</syn>

<hw>Knowl"edge</hw>, <pos>v. t.</pos> <def>To acknowledge.</def>
<mark>[Obs.]</mark> \'bdSinners which <xex>knowledge</xex> their
sins.\'b8

<au>Tyndale.</au>

<hw>Known</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>p. p.</pos> <def>of
<er>Know</er>.</def>

<hw>Know"-noth`ing</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <def>A member
of a secret political organization in the United States, the
chief objects of which were the proscription of foreigners by the
repeal of the naturalization laws, and the exclusive choice of
native Americans for office.</def>

<note><hand/ The party originated in 1853, and existed for about
three years. The members of it were called
<xex>Know-nothings</xex>, because they replied \'bdI don't
know,\'b8 to any questions asked them in reference to the
party.</note>

<hw>Know"-noth`ing*ism</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <def>The
doctrines, principles, or practices, of the Know-nothings.</def>

<hw>Knubs</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n. pl.</pos> <def>Waste silk
formed in winding off the threads from a cocoon.</def>

<hw>Knuc"kle</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[OE.
<ets>knokel</ets>, <ets>knokil</ets>, AS. <ets>cuncel</ets>; akin
to D. <ets>knokkel</ets>, OFries. <ets>knokele</ets>,
<ets>knokle</ets>, G. <ets>kn\'94chel</ets>, Sw.
<ets>knoge</ets>, Dan. <ets>knokkel</ets>, G. <ets>knochen</ets>
bone, and perh. to E. <ets>knock</ets>.]</ety> <sn>1.</sn>
<def>The joint of a finger, particularly when made prominent by
the closing of the fingers.</def>

<au>Davenant.</au>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>The kneejoint, or middle joint, of either leg of
a quadruped, especially of a calf; -- formerly used of the
kneejoint of a human being.</def>

<q>With weary <qex>knuckles</qex> on thy brim she kneeled sadly
down.</q>
<qau>Golding.</qau>

<sn>3.</sn> <def>The joint of a plant.</def> <mark>[Obs.]</mark>

<au>Bacon.</au>

<sn>4.</sn> <fld>(Mech.)</fld> <def>The joining pars of a hinge
through which the pin or rivet passes; a knuckle joint.</def>

<sn>5.</sn> <fld>(Shipbuilding)</fld> <def>A convex portion of a
vessel's figure where a sudden change of shape occurs, as in a
canal boat, where a nearly vertical side joins a nearly flat
bottom.</def>

<sn>6.</sn> <def>A contrivance, usually of brass or iron, and
furnished with points, worn to protect the hand, to add force to
a blow, and to disfigure the person struck; <as>as, brass
<ex>knuckles</ex></as>; -- called also <altname>knuckle
duster</altname>.</def> <mark>[Slang.]</mark>

<cs><col>Knuckle joint</col> <fld>(Mach.)</fld>, <cd>a hinge
joint, in which a projection with an eye, on one piece, enters a
jaw between two corresponding projections with eyes, on another
piece, and is retained by a pin which passes through the eyes and
forms the pivot.</cd> -- <col>Knuckle of veal</col>
<fld>(Cookery)</fld>, <cd>the lower part of a leg of veal, from
the line of the body to the knuckle.</cd></cs>

<hw>Knuc"kle</hw>, <pos>v. i.</pos> <wordforms>[<pos>imp. & p.
p.</pos> <er>Knuckled</er> <pr>(?)</pr>;; <pos>p. pr. & vb.
n.</pos> <er>Knuckling</er> <pr>(?)</pr>.]</wordforms> <def>To
yield; to submit; -- used with <xex>down</xex>, <xex>to</xex>, or
<xex>under</xex>.</def>

<cs><col>To knuckle to</col>. <sd>(a)</sd> <cd>To submit to in a
contest; to yield to</cd>. <mark>[Colloq.]</mark> See <cref>To
knock under</cref>, under <er>Knock</er>, <pos>v. i.</pos>
<sd>(b)</sd> <cd>To apply one's self vigorously or earnestly to;
<as>as, <ex>to knuckle to<ex> work.
<mark>[Colloq.]</mark></as></cd></cs>

<hw>Knuc"kle</hw>, <pos>v. t.</pos> <def>To beat with the
knuckles; to pommel.</def> <mark>[R.]</mark>

<au>Horace Smith.</au>

<hw>Knuc"kled</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>a.</pos>
<def>Jointed.</def> <mark>[Obs.]</mark>

<au>Bacon.</au>

<hw>Knuff</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[Cf.

<hw>Knurl"y</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <wordforms>[<pos>Compar.</pos>
<er>Knurlier</er> <pr>(<?/)</pr>; <pos>superl.</pos>
<er>Knurliest</er>.]</wordforms> <ety>[See <er>Knur</er>, and cf.

According to Hindoo legends, it was found in a Golconda mine, and
has been the property of various Hindoo and Persian rulers.</def>

ingredients, used by Egyptian and other Eastern women to darken
the edges of the eyelids.</def>

<hw>Kohl"-ra`bi</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos>; <plu>pl.

<hw>Kom"tok</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos>
<fld>(Zo\'94l.)</fld> <def>An African freshwater fish
(<spn>Protopterus annectens</spn>), belonging to the Dipnoi. It
can breathe air by means of its lungs, and when waters dry up, it
encases itself in a nest of hard mud, where it remains till the
rainy season. It is used as food.</def>

<def>A large African antelope (<spn>Alcelaphus
Lichtensteini</spn>), allied to the hartbeest, but having shorter
and flatter horns, and lacking a black patch on the face.</def>

<hw>Koo"doo</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos>
<fld>(Zo\'94l.)</fld> <def>A large South African antelope
(<spn>Strepsiceros kudu</spn>). The males have graceful spiral
horns, sometimes four feet long. The general color is reddish or
grayish brown, with eight or nine white bands on each side, and a
pale dorsal stripe. The old males become dark bluish gray, due to
the skin showing through the hair. The females are hornless.
Called also <altname>nellut</altname>.</def> <altsp>[Written also
<asp>kudu</asp>.]</altsp>

allied to the chimpanzee and gorilla, and, in some respects,
intermediate between them.</def>

<hw>Ko*tow"</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[Chinese, knock
head.]</ety> <def>The prostration made by mandarins and others to
their superiors, either as homage or worship, by knocking the
forehead on the ground. There are degrees in the rite, the
highest being expressed by three knockings.</def>

<au>S. W. Williams. </au>

<hw>Ko*tow"</hw>, <pos>v. i.</pos> <wordforms>[<pos>imp. & p.

<hw>\'d8Kou"lan</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[Native
name.]</ety> <fld>(Zo\'94l.)</fld> <def>A wild horse
(<spn>Equus</spn>, or <spn>Asinus, onager</spn>) inhabiting the
plants of Central Asia; -- called also <altname>gour</altname>,
<altname>khur</altname>, and <altname>onager</altname>.</def>
<altsp>[Written also <asp>kulan</asp>.]</altsp>

<note><hand/ It is sometimes confounded with the dziggetai, to
which it is closely related. It is gray in winter, but fulvous in
summer. It has a well defined, dark, dorsal stripe, and a short,
erect mane. In size, it is intermediate between the horse and
ass.</note>

<hw>Kou"miss</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[Russ.
<ets>kumys</ets>; of Mongolian origin.]</ety> <def>An
intoxicating fermented or distilled liquor originally made by the
Tartars from mare's or camel's milk. It can be obtained from any
kind of milk, and is now largely made in Europe.</def>
<altsp>[Written also <asp>koumyss</asp>, <asp>kumiss</asp>,
<asp>kumish</asp>, and <asp>kumys</asp>.]</altsp>

<q><qex>Koumiss</qex> has from time immemorial served the Tartar
instead of wine or spirits.</q>
<qau>J. H. Newman.</qau>

<hw>Kous"so</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <fld>(Bot.)</fld>
<def>An Abyssinian rosaceous tree (<spn>Brayera
anthelmintica</spn>), the flowers of which are used as a
vermifuge.</def> <altsp>[Written also <asp>cusso</asp> and
<asp>kosso</asp>.]</altsp>

same as <er>Kotow</er>.</def>

<hw>Kra</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <fld>(Zo\'94l.)</fld>
<def>A long-tailed ape (<spn>Macacus cynomolgus</spn>) of India
and Sumatra. It is reddish olive, spotted with black, and has a
black tail.</def>

<hw>Kraal</hw> <pr>(?; 277)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[D., a
village, inclosure, park, prob. fr. Pg. <ets>curral</ets> a
cattle pen; the same word as Sp. <ets>corral</ets>. See
<er>Corral</er>.]</ety> <sn>1.</sn> <def>A collection of huts
within a stockade; a village; sometimes, a single hut.</def>
<mark>[South Africa]</mark>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>An inclosure into which are driven wild
elephants which are to be tamed and educated.</def>
<mark>[Ceylon]</mark>

<hw>\'d8Krait</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[Native
name.]</ety> <fld>(Zo\'94l.)</fld> <def>A very venomous snake of
India (<spn>Bungarus c\'d2ruleus</spn>), allied to the cobra. Its
upper parts are bluish or brownish black, often with narrow white
streaks; the belly is whitish.</def>

<hw>Kra"ken</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[Prob. from
OSw. <ets>krake</ets>, or ODan. <ets>krage</ets> the trunk of a
tree, the branches of which are not entirely cut off, to which it
was likened by the Norwegian mariners.]</ety> <def>A fabulous
Scandinavian sea monster, often represented as resembling an
island, but sometimes as resembling an immense octopus.</def>

<q>To believe all that has been said of the sea serpent or
<qex>kraken</qex>, would be credulity; to reject the possibility
of their existence, would be presumption.</q>
<qau>Goldsmith.</qau>

<q>Like a <qex>kraken</qex> huge and black.</q>
<qau>Longfellow.</qau>

<fld>(Mus.)</fld> <def>A lively Polish dance. See
<er>Cracovienne</er>.</def>

<hw>\'d8Kra*me"ri*a</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[NL. So
called after the German botanists, J. G. H. & W. H.
<ets>Kramer</ets>.]</ety> <fld>(Bot.)</fld> <def>A genus of
spreading shrubs with many stems, from one species of which
(<spn>K. triandra</spn>), found in Peru, rhatany root, used as a
medicine, is obtained.</def>

<hw>Kra*mer"ic</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>a.</pos>
<fld>(Chem.)</fld> <def>Pertaining to, or derived from,
<xex>Krameria</xex> (rhatany); <as>as, <ex>krameric</ex> acid,
usually called <ex>ratanhia-tannic</ex> acid</as>.</def>

<ets>kreng</ets> a carcass.]</ety> <def>The carcass of a whale
after the blubber has been removed.</def> <altsp>[Written also
<asp>crang</asp> and <asp>kreng</asp>.]</altsp>

<hw>Kyr`i*o*log"ic*al</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>a.</pos> <ety>[See
<er>Curiologic</er>.]</ety> <def>Serving to denote objects by
conventional signs or alphabetical characters; <as>as, the
original Greek alphabet of sixteen letters was called
<ex>kyriologic</ex>, because it represented the pure elementary
sounds</as>. See <er>Curiologic</er>.</def> <altsp>[Written also
<asp>curiologic</asp> and <asp>kuriologic</asp>.]</altsp>

<note><hand/ The term is also applied, as by Warburton, to those
Egyptian hieroglyphics, in which a part is put conventionally for
the whole, as in depicting a battle by two hands, one holding a
shield and the other a bow.</note>

<-- p. 821 -->

<centered><point26>L.</point26></centered>


<hw>L</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>. <sn>1.</sn> <def>L is the twelfth letter
of the English alphabet, and a vocal consonant. It is usually
called a <xex>semivowel</xex> or <xex>liquid</xex>. Its form and
value are from the Greek, through the Latin, the form of the
Greek letter being from the Ph\'d2nician, and the ultimate origin
prob. Egyptian. Etymologically, it is most closely related to
<xex>r</xex> and <xex>u</xex>; as in pi<xex>l</xex>grim,
pe<xex>r</xex>egrine, co<xex>u</xex>ch (fr.
co<xex>ll</xex>ocare), a<xex>u</xex>bura (fr. LL.
a<xex>l</xex>burnus).</def>

<note>    At the end of monosyllables containing a single vowel,
it is often doubled, as in <xex>fall</xex>, <xex>full</xex>,
<xex>bell</xex>; but not after digraphs, as in <xex>foul</xex>,
<xex>fool</xex>, <xex>prowl</xex>, <xex>growl</xex>,
<xex>foal</xex>. In English words, the terminating syllable
<xex>le</xex> is unaccented, the <xex>e</xex> is silent, and
<xex>l</xex> is preceded by a voice glide, as in <xex>able</xex>,
<xex>eagle</xex>, pronounced <xex>\'be</xex>\'b6<xex>b'l</xex>,
<xex><?/</xex>\'b6<xex>g'l</xex>.
    See <it>Guide to Pronunciation</it>, <sect/ 241.</note>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>As a numeral, L stands for fifty in the English,
as in the Latin language.</def>

<q>For 50 the Romans used the Chalcidian <it>chi</it>, <?/, which
assumed the less difficult lapidary type, <?/, and was then
easily assimilated to L.</q>
<qau>I. Taylor (The Alphabet).</qau>

<hw>L</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <sn>1.</sn> <def>An
extension at right angles to the length of a main building,
giving to the ground plan a form resembling the letter
<boxtype>L</boxtype>; sometimes less properly applied to a
narrower, or lower, extension in the direction of the length of
the main building; a wing. <altsp>[Written also
<asp>ell</asp>.]</altsp>

<sn>2.</sn> <fld>(Mech.)</fld> <def>A short right-angled pipe
fitting, used in connecting two pipes at right angles</def>.
<altsp>[Written also <asp>ell</asp>.]</altsp>

<hw>La</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <fld>(Mus.)</fld>
<sd>(a)</sd> <def>A syllable applied to the sixth tone of the
scale in music in solmization.</def> <sd>(b)</sd> <def>The tone
A; -- so called among the French and Italians.</def>

<hw>La</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>interj.</pos> <ety>[Cf.
<er>Lo</er>.]</ety> <sn>1.</sn> <def>Look; see; behold; --
sometimes followed by <spn>you</spn>. <mark>[Obs.]</mark>

<au>Shak.</au>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>An exclamation of surprise; -- commonly followed
by <xex>me</xex>; <as>as, <ex>La</ex> me!</as></def>
<mark>[Low]</mark>

<hw>Lab"a*dist</hw>, <pos>n.</pos> <fld>(Eccl. Hist.)</fld>
<def>A follower of Jean de <xex>Labadie</xex>, a religious
teacher of the 17th century, who left the Roman Catholic Church
and taught a kind of mysticism, and the obligation of community
of property among Christians.</def>

<hw>La`bar`raque's" so*lu"tion</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>. <ety>[From
<ets>Labarraque</ets>, a Parisian apothecary.]</ety>
<fld>(Med.)</fld> <def>An aqueous solution of hypochlorite of
sodium, extensively used as a disinfectant.</def>

<hw>\'d8Lab"a*rum</hw> <pr>(<?/)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos>; <plu>pl.
<plw>Labara</plw> <pr>(#)</pr></plu>. <ety>[L.]</ety> <def>The
standard adopted by the Emperor Constantine after his conversion
to Christianity. It is described as a pike bearing a silk banner
hanging from a crosspiece, and surmounted by a golden crown. It
bore a monogram of the first two letters (<grk>CHR</grk>)<--
appearing as English XP --> of the name of Christ in its Greek
form. Later, the name was given to various modifications of this
standard.</def>
<-- Illustration of monogram, an X (Greek CHI) superimposed on a
lengthened P (Greek RHO) -->

<def>See <er>Ladanum</er>.</def>

<hw>Lab`e*fac"tion</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[See
<er>Labefy</er>.]</ety> <def>The act of labefying or making weak;
the state of being weakened; decay; ruin.</def>

<q>There is in it such a <qex>labefaction</qex> of all principles
as may be injurious to morality.</q>
<qau>Johnson.</qau>

<ets>labefacere</ets>; <ets>labare</ets> to totter +
<ets>facere</ets> to make.]</ety> <def>To weaken or impair.</def>
<mark>[R.]</mark>

<hw>La"bel</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[OF.
<ets>label</ets> sort of ribbon or fringe, label in heraldry, F.
<ets>lambeau</ets> shred, strip, rag; of uncertain origin; cf.
L.<ets>labellum</ets>, dim. of <ets>labrum</ets> lip, edge,
margin, G. <ets>lappen</ets> flap, patch, rag, tatter (cf.
<er>Lap</er> of a dress), W. <ets>llab</ets>, <ets>llabed</ets>,
label, flap, Gael. <ets>leab</ets>, <ets>leob</ets>, slice,
shred, hanging lip.]</ety> <sn>1.</sn> <def>A tassel.</def>
<mark>[Obs.]</mark>

<au>Huloet. Fuller.</au>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>A slip of silk, paper, parchment, etc., affixed
to anything, usually by an inscription, the contents, ownership,
destination, etc.; <as>as, the <ex>label</ex> of a bottle or a
package</as>.</def>

<sn>3.</sn> <def>A slip of ribbon, parchment, etc., attached to a
document to hold the appended seal; also, the seal.</def>

<sn>4.</sn> <def>A writing annexed by way of addition, as a
codicil added to a will.</def>

<sn>5.</sn> <fld>(Her.)</fld> <def>A barrulet, or, rarely, a
bendlet, with pendants, or points, usually three, especially used
as a mark of cadency to distinguish an eldest or only son while
his father is still living.</def>

<sn>6.</sn> <def>A brass rule with sights, formerly used, in
connection with a circumferentor, to take altitudes.</def>

<au>Knight.</au>

<sn>7.</sn> <fld>(Gothic Arch.)</fld> <def>The name now generally
given to the projecting molding by the sides, and over the tops,
of openings in medi\'91val architecture. It always has a <?/quare
form, as in the illustration.</def>

<au>Arch. Pub. Soc.</au>

<sn>8.</sn> <def>In medi\'91val art, the representation of a band
or scroll containing an inscription.</def>

<au>Fairholt.</au>

<hw>La"bel</hw>, <pos>v. t.</pos> <wordforms>[<pos>imp. & p.
p.</pos> <er>Labeled</er> <pr>(?)</pr> or <er>Labelled</er>;
<pos>p. pr. & vb. n.</pos> <er>Labeling</er> or
<er>Labelling</er>.]</wordforms> <sn>1.</sn> <def>To affix a
label to; to mark with a name, etc.; <as>as, to <ex>label</ex> a
bottle or a package</as>.</def>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>To affix in or on a label.</def>
<mark>[R.]</mark>

<hw>La"bel*er</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <def>One who
labels.</def> <altsp>[Written also <asp>labeller</asp>.]</altsp>

<hw>\'d8La*bel"lum</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos>; <plu>pl. L.
<plw>Labella</plw> <pr>(#)</pr>, E. <plw>Labellums</plw>
<pr>(#)</pr></plu>. <ety>[L., dim. of <ets>labrum</ets>
lip.]</ety> <sn>1.</sn> <fld>(Bot.)</fld> <def>The lower or
apparently anterior petal of an orchidaceous flower, often of a
very curious shape.</def>

<sn>2.</sn> <fld>(Zo\'94l.)</fld> <def>A small appendage beneath
the upper lip or labrum of certain insects.</def>

<hw>\'d8La"bi*a</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n. pl.</pos> <def>See
<er>Labium</er>.</def>

<hw>La"bi*al</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>a.</pos> <ety>[LL.
<ets>labialis</ets>, fr. L. <ets>labium</ets> lip: cf. F.
<ets>labial</ets>. See <er>Lip</er>.]</ety> <sn>1.</sn> <def>Of
or pertaining to the lips or labia; <as>as, <ex>labial</ex>
veins</as>.</def>

<sn>2.</sn> <fld>(Mus.)</fld> <def>Furnished with lips; <as>as, a
<ex>labial</ex> organ pipe</as>.</def>

<sn>3.</sn> <fld>(Phonetics)</fld> <sd>(a)</sd> <def>Articulated,
as a consonant, mainly by the lips, as b, p, m, w</def>.
<sd>(b)</sd> <def>Modified, as a vowel, by contraction of the lip
opening, as <oomac/ (f<oomac/d), <omac/ (<omac/ld), etc., and as
<it>eu</it> and <it>u</it> in French, and <it>\'94</it>,
<it>\'81</it> in German. See Guide to Pronunciation, <sect<sect/
11, 178.</def>

<sn>4.</sn> <fld>(Zo\'94l.)</fld> <def>Of or pertaining to the
labium; <as>as, the <ex>labial</ex> palpi of insects</as>. See
<er>Labium</er>.</def>

<hw>La"bi*al</hw>, <pos>n.</pos> <sn>1.</sn>
<fld>(Phonetics)</fld> <def>A letter or character representing an
articulation or sound formed or uttered chiefly with the lips, as
<stype>b</stype>, <stype>p</stype>, <stype>w</stype>.</def>

<sn>2.</sn> <fld>(Mus.)</fld> <def>An organ pipe that is
furnished with lips; a flue pipe.</def>

<sn>3.</sn> <fld>(Zo\'94l.)</fld> <def>One of the scales which
border the mouth of a fish or reptile.</def>

<hw>La"bi*al*ism</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos>
<fld>(Phonetics)</fld> <def>The quality of being labial; <as>as,
the <ex>labialism</ex> of an articulation</as>; conversion into a
labial, as of a sound which is different in another
language.</def>

<au>J. Peile.</au>

<hw>La`bi*al*i*za"tion</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos>
<fld>(Phonetics)</fld> <def>The modification of an articulation
by contraction of the lip opening.</def>

<hw>La"bi*al*ize</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>v. t.</pos>
<fld>(Phonetics)</fld> <def>To modify by contraction of the lip
opening.</def>

<hw>La"bi*al*ly</hw>, <pos>adv.</pos> <def>In a labial manner;
with, or by means of, the lips.</def>

<hw>La"bi*ate</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>v. t.</pos> <def>To
labialize.</def>

<au>Brewer.</au>

<hw>La"bi*ate</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>a.</pos> <ety>[NL.
<ets>labiatus</ets>, fr. L. <ets>labium</ets> lip.]</ety>
<fld>(Bot.)</fld> <sd>(a)</sd> <def>Having the limb of a tubular
corolla or calyx divided into two unequal parts, one projecting
over the other like the lips of a mouth, as in the snapdragon,
sage, and catnip.</def> <sd>(b)</sd> <def>Belonging to a natural
order of plants (<spn>Labiat\'91</spn>), of which the mint, sage,
and catnip are examples. They are mostly aromatic herbs.</def>

<hw>La"bi*ate</hw>, <pos>n.</pos> <fld>(Bot.)</fld> <def>A plant
of the order <spn>Labiat\'91</spn>.</def>

<hw>La"bi*a`ted</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>a.</pos>
<fld>(Bot.)</fld> <def>Same as <er>Labiate</er>, <pos>a.</pos>
<sd>(a)</sd>.</def>

<hw>\'d8La`bi*pal"pus</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos>; <plu>pl.
<plw>Labipalpi</plw> <pr>(<?/)</pr>.</plu> <ety>[NL. See

<hw>\'d8La"bi*um</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> ; <plu>pl. L.
<plw>Labia</plw> <pr>(#)</pr>, E. <plw>Labiums</plw>
<pr>(#)</pr></plu>. <ety>[L.]</ety> <sn>1.</sn> <def>A lip, or
liplike organ.</def>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>The lip of an organ pipe.</def>

<sn>3.</sn> <pluf>pl.</pluf> <fld>(Anat.)</fld> <def>The folds of
integument at the opening of the vulva.</def>

<sn>4.</sn> <fld>(Zo\'94l.)</fld> <sd>(a)</sd> <def>The organ of
insects which covers the mouth beneath, and serves as an under
lip. It consists of the second pair of maxill\'91, usually
closely united in the middle line, but bearing a pair of palpi in
most insects. It often consists of a thin anterior part
(<xex>ligula or palpiger</xex>) and a firmer posterior plate
(<xex>mentum</xex>).</def> <sd>(b)</sd> <def>Inner margin of the
aperture of a shell.</def>

<hw>Lab"lab</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <fld>(Bot.)</fld>
<def>an East Indian name for several twining leguminous plants
related to the bean, but commonly applied to the hyacinth bean
(<spn>Delichos Lablab</spn>).</def>

<hw>La"bor</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[OE.
<ets>labour</ets>, OF. <ets>labour</ets>, <ets>laber</ets>,
<ets>labur</ets>, F. <ets>labeur</ets>, L. <ets>labor</ets>; cf.
Gr. <?/ to take, Skr. <ets>labh</ets> to get, seize.]</ety>
<altsp>[Written also <asp>labour</asp>.]</altsp> <sn>1.</sn>
<def>Physical toil or bodily exertion, especially when fatiguing,
irksome, or unavoidable, in distinction from sportive exercise;
hard, muscular effort directed to some useful end, as
agriculture, manufactures, and like; servile toil; exertion;
work.</def>

<q>God hath set
<qex>Labor</qex> and rest, as day and night, to men
Successive.</q>
<qau>Milton.</qau>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>Intellectual exertion; mental effort; <as>as,
the <ex>labor</ex> of compiling a history</as>.</def>

<sn>3.</sn> <def>That which requires hard work for its
accomplishment; that which demands effort.</def>

<q>Being a <qex>labor</qex> of so great a difficulty, the exact
performance thereof we may rather wish than look for.</q>
<qau>Hooker.</qau>

<sn>4.</sn> <def>Travail; the pangs and efforts of
childbirth.</def>

<q>The queen's in <qex>labor</qex>,
They say, in great extremity; and feared
She'll with the <qex>labor</qex> end.</q>
<qau>Shak.</qau>

<sn>5.</sn> <def>Any pang or distress.</def>

<au>Shak.</au>

<sn>6.</sn> <fld>(Naut.)</fld> <def>The pitching or tossing of a
vessel which results in the straining of timbers and
rigging.</def>

<sn>7.</sn> <ety>[Sp.]</ety> <def>A measure of land in Mexico and
Texas, equivalent to an area of 177<frac17/ acres.</def>

<au>Bartlett.</au>

<syn>Syn. -- Work; toil; drudgery; task; exertion; effort;
industry; painstaking. See <er>Toll</er>.</syn>

<hw>La"bor</hw>, <pos>v. i.</pos> <wordforms>[<pos>imp. & p.
p.</pos> <er>Labored</er> <pr>(?)</pr>; <pos>p. pr. & vb.
n.</pos> <er>Laboring</er>.]</wordforms> <ety>[OE.
<ets>labouren</ets>, F. <ets>labourer</ets>, L.
<ets>laborare</ets>. See <er>Labor</er>, <pos>n.</pos>]</ety>
<altsp>[Written also <asp>labour</asp>.]</altsp> <sn>1.</sn>
<def>To exert muscular strength; to exert one's strength with
painful effort, particularly in servile occupations; to work; to
toil.</def>

<q>Adam, well may we <qex>labor</qex> still to dress
This garden.</q>
<qau>Milton.</qau>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>To exert one's powers of mind in the prosecution
of any design; to strive; to take pains.</def>

<sn>3.</sn> <def>To be oppressed with difficulties or disease; to
do one's work under conditions which make it especially hard,
wearisome; to move slowly, as against opposition, or under a
burden; to be burdened; -- often with <xex>under</xex>, and
formerly with <xex>of</xex>.</def>

<q>The stone that <qex>labors</qex> up the hill.</q>
<qau>Granville.</qau>

<q>The line too <qex>labors</qex>,and the words move slow.</q>
<qau>Pope.</qau>

<q>To cure the disorder under which he <qex>labored</qex>.</q>
<qau>Sir W. Scott.</qau>

<q>Come unto me, all ye that <qex>labor</qex> and are heavy
laden, and I will give you rest.</q>
<qau>Matt. xi. 28</qau>

<sn>4.</sn> <def>To be in travail; to suffer the pangs of
childbirth.</def>

<sn>5.</sn> <fld>(Naut.)</fld> <def>To pitch or roll heavily, as
a ship in a turbulent sea.</def>

<au> Totten.</au>

<hw>La"bor</hw>, <pos>v. t.</pos> <ety>[F. <ets>labourer</ets>,
L. <ets>laborare</ets>.]</ety> <sn>1.</sn> <def>To work at; to
work; to till; to cultivate by toil.</def>

<q>The most excellent lands are lying fallow, or only
<qex>labored</qex> by children.</q>
<qau>W. Tooke.</qau>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>To form or fabricate with toil, exertion, or
care.</def> \'bdTo <xex>labor</xex> arms for Troy.\'b8

<au>Dryden.</au>

<sn>3.</sn> <def>To prosecute, or perfect, with effort; to urge
stre<?/uously; <as>as, to <ex>labor</ex> a point or
argument</as>.</def>

<sn>4.</sn> <def>To belabor; to beat.</def> <mark>[Obs.]</mark>

<au>Dryden.</au>

<hw>Lab"o*rant</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos>
<ety>[L.<ets>laborans</ets>, <ets>p</ets>. <ets>pr</ets>. <ets>of
laborare</ets> to labor.]</ety> <def>A chemist.</def>
<mark>[Obs.]</mark>

<au>Boyle.</au>

<hw>Lab"o*ra*to*ry</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos>; <plu>pl.
<plw>Laboratories</plw> <pr>(#)</pr></plu>. <ety>[Shortened fr.
<ets>elaboratory</ets>; cf. OF. <ets>elaboratoire</ets>, F.
<ets>laboratoire</ets>. See <er>Elaborate</er>,
<er>Labor.</er>]</ety> <altsp>[Formerly written also
<asp>elaboratory.</asp>]</altsp> <def>The workroom of a chemist;
also, a place devoted to experiments in any branch of natural
science; <as>as, a chemical, physical, or biological
<ex>laboratory</ex></as>. Hence, by extension, a place where
something is prepared, or some operation is performed; <as>as,
the liver is the <ex>laboratory</ex> of the bile</as>.</def>

<hw>La"bored</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>a.</pos> <def>Bearing marks
of labor and effort; elaborately wrought; not easy or natural;
<as>as, <ex>labored</ex> poetry; a <ex>labored</ex>
style.</as></def>

<hw>La"bored*ly</hw>, <pos>adv.</pos> <def>In a labored manner;
with labor.</def>

<hw>La"bor*er</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[Written also
<ets>labourer</ets>.]</ety> <def>One who labors in a toilsome
occupation; a person who does work that requires strength rather
than skill, as distinguished from that of an
<xex>artisan</xex>.</def>

<hw>La"bor*ing</hw>, <pos>a.</pos> <sn>1.</sn> <def>That labors;
performing labor; esp., performing coarse, heavy work, not
requiring skill also, set apart for labor; <as>as,
<ex>laboring</ex> days</as>.</def>

<q>The sleep of a <qex>laboring</qex> man is sweet.</q>
<qau>eccl. v. 12.</qau>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>Suffering pain or grief.</def>

<au>Pope.</au>

<cs><col>Laboring oar</col>, <cd>the oar which requires most
strength and exertion; often used figuratively; as, to have, or
pull, the <xex>laboring oar<xex> in some difficult
undertaking.</cd></cs>

<hw>La*bo"ri*ous</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>a.</pos> <ety>[L.
<ets>laboriosus</ets>,fr. <ets>labor</ets> labor: cf. F.
<ets>laborieux</ets>.]</ety> <sn>1.</sn> <def>Requiring labor,
perseverance, or sacrifices; toilsome; tiresome.</def>

<q>Dost thou love watchings, abstinence, or toil,
<qex>Laborious</qex> virtues all ? Learn these from Cato.</q>
<qau>Addison.</qau>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>Devoted to labor; diligent; industrious; <as>as,
a <ex>laborious</ex> mechanic</as>.</def>

-- <wordforms><wf>La*bo"ri*ous*ly</wf>, <pos>adv.</pos> --
<wf>La*bo"ri*ous*ness</wf>, <pos>n.</pos></wordforms>

<def>Laborious.</def> <mark>[Obs.]</mark> <au>Wyatt</au>. --

<hw>La"bor-sav`ing</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>a.</pos> <def>Saving

<hw>La"bor*some</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>a.</pos> <sn>1.</sn>
<def>Made with, or requiring, great labor, pains, or

<au>Shak.</au>

<sn>2.</sn> <fld>(Naut.)</fld> <def>Likely or inclined to roll or

<hw>Lab`ra*dor"</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <def>A region of
British America on the Atlantic coast, north of
Newfoundland.</def>

<cs><col>Labrador duck</col> <fld>(Zo\'94l.)</fld>, <cd>a sea
duck (<spn>Camtolaimus Labradorius</spn>) allied to the eider
ducks. It was formerly common on the coast of New England, but is
now supposed to be extinct, no specimens having been reported
since 1878.</cd> -- <col>Labrador feldspar</col>. <cd>See
<er>Labradorite</er>.</cd> -- <col>Labrador tea</col>
<fld>(Bot.)</fld>, <cd>a name of two low, evergreen shrubs of the
genus <spn>Ledum</spn> (<spn>L. palustre</spn> and <spn>L.
latifolium</spn>), found in Northern Europe and America. They are
used as tea in British America, and in Scandinavia as a
substitute for hops.</cd></cs>

<hw>Lab"ra*dor`ite</hw> <pr>(<?/)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos>
<fld>(Min.)</fld> <def>A kind of feldspar commonly showing a
beautiful play of colors, and hence much used for ornamental
purposes. The finest specimens come from Labrador. See
<er>Feldspar</er>.</def>

<hw>La"bras</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n. pl.</pos>
<ety>[L.<ets>labrum</ets>; cf. It. <ets>labbro</ets>, pl.
<ets>labbra</ets>.]</ety> <def>Lips.</def> <mark>[Obs. &
R.]</mark>

<au>Shak.</au>

<hw>La"broid</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>a.</pos>
<ety>[<ets>Labrus</ets> + <ets>-oid</ets>.]</ety>
<fld>(Zo\'94l.)</fld> <def>Like the genus Labrus; belonging to
the family <spn>Labrid\'91</spn>, an extensive family of marine
fishes, often brilliantly colored, which are very abundant in the
Indian and Pacific Oceans. The tautog and cunner are American
examples.</def>

<hw>La"brose`</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>a.</pos> <ety>[L.
<ets>labrosus</ets>, fr. <ets>labrum</ets> lip.]</ety>
<def>Having thick lips.</def>

<hw>\'d8La"brum</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos>; <plu>pl. L.
<plw>Labra</plw> <pr>(#)</pr>, E. <plw>Labrums</plw>
<pr>(#)</pr></plu>. <ety>[L.]</ety> <sn>1.</sn> <def>A lip or
edge, as of a basin.</def>

<sn>2.</sn> <fld>(Zo\'94l.)</fld> <sd>(a)</sd> <def>An organ in
insects and crustaceans covering the upper part of the mouth, and
serving as an upper lip. See <xex>Illust</xex>. of
<er>Hymenoptera</er>.</def> <sd>(b)</sd> <def>The external margin
of the aperture of a shell. See <er>Univalve</er>.</def>

<hw>\'d8La"brus</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos>; <plu>pl.
<plw>Labri</plw> <pr>(-br<imac/)</pr></plu>. <ety>[L., a sort of
fish.]</ety> <fld>(Zo\'94l.)</fld> <def>A genus of marine fishes,
including the wrasses of Europe. See <er>Wrasse</er>.</def>

<hw>La*bur`nic</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>a.</pos> <def>Of,
pertaining to, or derived from, the laburnum.</def>

<hw>La-bur`nine</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos>
<fld>(Chem.)</fld> <def>A poisonous alkaloid found in the unripe
seeds of the laburnum.</def>

<hw>La*bur"num</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[L.]</ety>
<fld>(Bot.)</fld> <def>A small leguminous tree (<spn>Cytisus
Laburnum</spn>), native of the Alps. The plant is reputed to be
poisonous, esp. the bark and seeds. It has handsome racemes of
yellow blossoms.</def>

<note><hand/ Scotch laburnum (<spn>Cytisus alpinus</spn>) is
similar, but has smooth leaves; purple laburnum is <spn>C.
purpureus</spn>.

<hw>Lab"y*rinth</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[L.
<ets>labyrinthus</ets>, Gr. <grk>laby`rinthos</grk>: cf. F.
<ets>labyrinthe</ets>.]</ety> <sn>1.</sn> <def>An edifice or
place full of intricate passageways which render it difficult to
find the way from the interior to the entrance; <as>as, the
Egyptian and Cretan <ex>labyrinths</ex></as>.</def>
<-- said to be from from the ax symbol of the "labyrinth" at
Knossos, Crete -- a multistoried royal palace with labyrinthine
passages between rooms. -->

<sn>2.</sn> <def>Any intricate or involved inclosure; especially,
an ornamental maze or inclosure in a park or garden.</def>

<sn>3.</sn> <def>Any object or arrangement of an intricate or
involved form, or having a very complicated nature.</def>

<q>The serpent . . . fast sleeping soon he found,
In <qex>labyrinth</qex> of many a round self-rolled.</q>
<qau>Milton.</qau>

<q>The <qex>labyrinth</qex> of the mind.</q>
<qau>Tennyson.</qau>

<sn>4.</sn> <def>An inextricable or bewildering difficulty.</def>

<q>I' the maze and winding <qex>labyrinths o' the
world</qex>.</q>
<qau>Denham.</qau>

<sn>5.</sn> <fld>(Anat.)</fld> <def>The internal ear. See Note
under <er>Ear</er>.</def>

<sn>6.</sn> <fld>(Metal.)</fld> <def>A series of canals through
which a stream of water is directed for suspending, carrying off,
and depositing at different distances, the ground ore of a
metal.</def>

<au>Ure.</au>

<sn>7.</sn> <fld>(Arch.)</fld> <def>A pattern or design
representing a maze, -- often inlaid in the tiled floor of a
church, etc.</def>

<syn>Syn. -- Maze; confusion; intricacy; windings.</syn> <usage>
-- <er>Labyrinth</er>, <er>Maze</er>. <xex>Labyrinth</xex>,
originally; the name of an edifice or excavation, carries the
idea of design, and construction in a permanent form, while
<xex>maze</xex> is used of anything confused or confusing,
whether fixed or shifting.  <xex>Maze</xex> is less restricted in
its figurative uses than <xex>labyrinth</xex>. We speak of the
<xex>labyrinth</xex> of the ear, or of the mind, and of a
<xex>labyrinth</xex> of difficulties; but of the <xex>mazes</xex>
of the dance, the <xex>mazes</xex> of political intrigue, or of
the mind being in a <xex>maze</xex>.</usage>

<hw>Lab`y*rin"thal</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>a.</pos>
<def>Pertaining to, or resembling, a labyrinth; intricate;
labyrinthian.</def>

<hw>Lab`y*rin"thi*an</hw> <pr>(<?/)</pr>, <pos>a.</pos>
<def>Intricately winding; like a labyrinth; perplexed;
labyrinthal.</def>

<hw>Lab`y*rin"thi*branch</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>a.</pos>
<ety>[See <er>Labyrinth</er>, and <er>Branchia</er>.]</ety>
<fld>(Zo\'94l.)</fld> <def>Of or pertaining to the
Labyrinthici.</def> -- <def2><pos>n.</pos> <def>One of the
Labyrinthici.</def></def2>

<mhw>{ <hw>Lab`y*rin"thic</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>,
<hw>Lab`y*rin`thic*al</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, }</mhw> <pos>a.</pos>
<ety>[L. <ets>labyrinthicus</ets>: cf. F.
<ets>labyrinthique</ets>.]</ety> <def>Like or pertaining to a
labyrinth.</def>

<hw>\'d8Lab`y*rin"thi*ci</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n. pl.</pos>
<ety>[NL. See <er>Labyrinth</er>.]</ety> <fld>(Zo\'94l.)</fld>
<def>An order of teleostean fishes, including the Anabas, or
climbing perch, and other allied fishes.</def>

<note><hand/ They have, connected with the gill chamber, a
special cavity in which a labyrinthiform membrane is arranged so
as to retain water to supply the gills while the fish leaves the
water and travels about on land, or even climbs trees.</note>

<hw>Lab`y*rin"thi*form</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>a.</pos>
<ety>[<ets>Labyrinth</ets> + <ets>-form</ets>: cf. F.
<ets>labyrinthiforme</ets>.]</ety> <def>Having the form of a
labyrinth; intricate.</def>

<hw>Lab`y*rin"thine</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>a.</pos>
<def>Pertaining to, or like, a labyrinth; labyrinthal.</def>

<hw>Lab`y*rin"tho*don</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[Gr.
<?/ labyrinth + <?/, <?/, tooth.]</ety> <fld>(Paleon.)</fld>
<def>A genus of very large fossil amphibians, of the Triassic
period, having bony plates on the under side of the body. It is
the type of the order Labyrinthodonta. Called also
<spn>Mastodonsaurus</spn>.</def>

<hw>Lab`y*rin"tho*dont</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>a.</pos>
<fld>(Paleon.)</fld> <def>Of or pertaining to the
Labyrinthodonta.</def> -- <def2><pos>n.</pos> <def>One of the
Labyrinthodonta.</def></def2>

<hw>\'d8Lab`y*rin`tho*don"ta</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n. pl.</pos>
<ety>[NL. See <er>Labyrinthodon</er>.]</ety> <fld>(Paleon.)</fld>
<def>An extinct order of Amphibia, including the typical genus
Labyrinthodon, and many other allied forms, from the
Carboniferous, Permian, and Triassic formations. By recent
writers they are divided into two or more orders. See
<er>Stegocephala</er>.</def>

<mhw>{ <hw>Lac</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <hw>\'d8Lakh</hw>
<pr>(<?/)</pr> }</mhw>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[Hind. <ets>lak</ets>,
<ets>l\'bekh</ets>, <ets>l\'beksh</ets>, Skr. <ets>laksha</ets> a
mark, sign, lakh.]</ety> <def>One hundred thousand; also, a
vaguely great number; <as>as, a <ex>lac</ex> of
rupees</as>.</def> <altsp>[Written also <asp>lack</asp>.]</altsp>
<mark>[East Indies]</mark>

<hw>Lac</hw>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[Per. <ets>lak</ets>; akin to
Skr. <ets>l\'beksh\'be</ets>: cf. F. <ets>lague</ets>, It. & NL.
<ets>lacca</ets>. Cf. <er>Lake</er> a color, <er>Lacquer</er>,
<er>Litmus</er>.]</ety> <def>A resinous substance produced mainly
on the banyan tree, but to some extent on other trees, by the
<spn>Coccus lacca</spn><-- now Laccifer lacca -->, a scale-shaped
insect, the female of which fixes herself on the bark, and exudes
from the margin of her body this resinous substance.</def>

<note><hand/ <xex>Stick-lac</xex> is the substance in its natural
state, incrusting small twigs. When broken off, and the coloring
matter partly removed, the granular residuum is called
<xex>seed-lac</xex>. When melted, and reduced to a thin crust, it
is called <xex>shell-lac</xex> or <xex>shellac</xex>. Lac is an
important ingredient in sealing wax, dyes, varnishes, and
lacquers.</note>

<cs><col>Ceylon lac</col>, <cd>a resinous exudation of the tree
<xex>Croton lacciferum<xex>, resembling lac.</cd> -- <col>Lac
dye</col>, <cd>a scarlet dye obtained from stick-lac.</cd> --
<col>Lac lake</col>, <cd>the coloring matter of lac dye when
precipitated from its solutions by alum.</cd> -- <col>Mexican
lac</col>, <cd>an exudation of the tree <xex>Croton
Draco<xex>.</cd></cs>

<hw>Lac"cic</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>a.</pos> <ety>[Cf. F.
<ets>laccique</ets>.]</ety> <fld>(Chem.)</fld> <def>Pertaining to
lac, or produced from it; <as>as, <ex>laccic</ex>
acid</as>.</def>

<hw>Lac"cin</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[Cf. F.
<ets>laccine</ets>.]</ety> <fld>(Chem.)</fld> <def>A yellow
amorphous substance obtained from lac.</def>

<mhw>{ <hw>Lac"co*lite</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <hw>Lac"co*lith</hw>
<pr>(?)</pr>, }</mhw> <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[Gr. <?/ a cistern +
<ets>-lite</ets>, <ets>-lith</ets>.]</ety> <fld>(Geol.)</fld>
<def>A mass of igneous rock intruded between sedimentary beds and
resulting in a mammiform bulging of the overlying strata.</def>
-- <wordforms><wf>Lac`co*lit"ic</wf> <pr>(#)</pr>,
<pos>a.</pos></wordforms>

<hw>Lace</hw> <pr>(l\'bes)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[OE.
<ets>las</ets>, OF. <ets>laz</ets>, F. <ets>lacs</ets>, dim.
<ets>lacet</ets>, fr. L. <ets>laqueus</ets> noose, snare; prob.
akin to <ets>lacere</ets> to entice. Cf. <er>Delight</er>,
<er>Elicit</er>, <er>Lasso</er>, <er>Latchet</er>.]</ety>
<sn>1.</sn> <def>That which binds or holds, especially by being
interwoven; a string, cord, or band, usually one passing through
eyelet or other holes, and used in drawing and holding together
parts of a garment, of a shoe, of a machine belt, etc.</def>

<q>His hat hung at his back down by a <qex>lace</qex>.</q>
<qau>Chaucer.</qau>

<q>For striving more, the more in <qex>laces</qex> strong
Himself he tied.</q>
<qau>Spenser.</qau>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>A snare or gin, especially one made of
interwoven cords; a net.</def> <mark>[Obs.]</mark>

<au>Fairfax.</au>

<q>Vulcanus had caught thee [Venus] in his <qex>lace</qex>.</q>
<qau>Chaucer.</qau>

<sn>3.</sn> <def>A fabric of fine threads of linen, silk, cotton,
etc., often ornamented with figures; a delicate tissue of thread,
much worn as an ornament of dress.</def>

<q>Our English dames are much given to the wearing of
costly<qex>laces</qex>.</q>
<qau>Bacon.</qau>

<sn>4.</sn> <def>Spirits added to coffee or some other
beverage.</def> <mark>[Old Slang]</mark>

<au>Addison.</au>

<cs><col>Alencon lace</col>, <cd>a kind of point lace, entirely
of needlework, first made at Alencon in France, in the 17th
century. It is very durable and of great beauty and cost.</cd> --
<mcol><col>Bone lace</col>, <col>Brussels lace</col></mcol>,
<cd>etc. See under <er>Bone</er>, <er>Brussels</er>, etc.</cd> --
<mcol><col>Gold lace</col>, <or/ <col>Silver lace</col></mcol>,
<cd>lace having warp threads of silk, or silk and cotton, and a
weft of silk threads covered with gold (or silver), or with
gilt.</cd> -- <col>Lace leather</col>, <cd>thin, oil-tanned
leather suitable for cutting into lacings for machine belts.</cd>
-- <col>Lace lizard</col> <fld>(Zo\'94l.)</fld>, <cd>a large,
aquatic, Australian lizard (<spn>Hydrosaurus giganteus</spn>),
allied to the monitors.</cd> -- <col>Lace paper</col>, <cd>paper
with an openwork design in imitation of lace.</cd> -- <col>Lace
piece</col> <fld>(Shipbuilding)</fld>, <cd>the main piece of
timber which supports the beak or head projecting beyond the stem
of a ship.</cd> -- <mcol><col>Lace pillow</col>, <and/
<col>Pillow lace</col></mcol>. <cd>See under
<er>Pillow</er>.</cd></cs>

<hw>Lace</hw>, <pos>v. t.</pos> <wordforms>[<pos>imp. & p.
p.</pos> <er>Laced</er> <pr>(\'best)</pr>; <pos>p. pr. & vb.
n.</pos> <er>Lacing</er> <pr>(?)</pr>.]</wordforms> <sn>1.</sn>
<def>To fasten with a lace; to draw together with a lace passed
through eyelet holes; to unite with a lace or laces, or,
figuratively. with anything resembling laces.</def>

<au>Shak.</au>

<q>When Jenny's stays are newly <qex>laced</qex>.</q>
<qau>Prior.</qau>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>To adorn with narrow strips or braids of some
decorative material; <as>as, cloth <ex>laced</ex> with
silver</as>.</def>

<au>Shak.</au>

<sn>3.</sn> <def>To beat; to lash; to make stripes on.</def>
<mark>[Colloq.]</mark>

<q>I'll <qex>lace</qex> your coat for ye.</q>
<qau>L'Estrange.</qau>

<sn>4.</sn> <def>To add spirits to (a beverage).</def> <mark>[Old
Slang]</mark>

<hw>Lace</hw>, <pos>v. i.</pos> <def>To be fastened with a lace,
or laces; <as>as, these boots <ex>lace</ex></as>.</def>

<hw>La*cer"ta</hw>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[L. a lizard. See
<er>Lizard</er>.]</ety> <sn>1.</sn> <fld>(Zo\'94l.)</fld> <def>A
genus of lizards. See <er>Lizard</er>.</def>

<note><hand/ Formerly it included nearly all the known lizards.
It is now restricted to certain diurnal Old World species, like
the green lizard (<spn>Lacerta viridis</spn>) and the sand lizard
(<spn>L. agilis</spn>), of Europe.</note>

<sn>2.</sn> <fld>(Astron.)</fld> <def>The Lizard, a northern
constellation.</def>

<hw>La*cer"tian</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>a.</pos> <ety>[Cf. F.

<hw>\'d8Lac`er*til"i*a</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n. pl.</pos>
<ety>[NL., fr. L.<ets>lacertus</ets> a lizard.]</ety>
<fld>(Zo\'94l.)</fld> <def>An order of Reptilia, which includes
the lizards.</def>

<note><hand/ They are closely related to the snakes, and life the
latter, usually have the body covered with scales or granules.
They usually have eyelids, and most of then have well-formed
legs; but in some groups (amphisb\'91na, glass-snake, etc.) the
legs are wanting and the body is serpentlike. None are venomous,
unless <spn>Heloderma</spn> be an exception. The order includes
the chameleons, the <spn>Cionocrania</spn>, or typical lizards,
and the amphisb\'91nas. See <er>Amphisb\'91na</er>,
<er>Gecko</er>, <er>Gila monster</er>, and
<er>Lizard</er>.</note>

<hw>Lac`er*til"i*an</hw> <pr>(-an)</pr>, <pos>a. & n.</pos>
<def>Same as <er>Lacertian</er>.</def>

<hw>La*cer"ti*loid</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>a.</pos>
<ety>[<ets>Lacertilia</ets> + <ets>-oid</ets>.]</ety>
<fld>(Zo\'94l.)</fld> <def>Like or belonging to the
Lacertilia.</def>

<hw>La*cer"tine</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>a.</pos>
<fld>(Zo\'94l.)</fld> <def>Lacertian.</def>

<hw>\'d8La*cer"tus</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos>; <plu>pl.

the upper arm.]</ety> <fld>(Anat.)</fld> <def>A bundle or
fascicle of muscular fibers.</def>

<hw>Lace"wing`</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos>
<fld>(Zo\'94l.)</fld> <def>Any one of several species of
neuropterous insects of the genus <spn>Chrysopa</spn> and allied
genera. They have delicate, lacelike wings and brilliant eyes.
Their larv\'91 are useful in destroying aphids. Called also
<altname>lace-winged fly</altname>, and <altname>goldeneyed
fly</altname>.</def>

<hw>Lach`ry*ma"tion</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[L.
<ets>lacrimatio</ets>, from <ets>lacrimare</ets> to shed tears,
fr. <ets>lacrima</ets> tear.]</ety> <def>The act of shedding

<hw>Lach"ry*ma*to*ry</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos>; <plu>pl.
-<plw>ries</plw> <pr>(#)</pr></plu>. <ety>[Cf. F.
<ets>lacrymatoire</ets>.]</ety> <fld>(Antiq.)</fld> <def>A
\'bdtear-bottle;\'b8 a narrow-necked vessel found in sepulchers
of the ancient Romans; -- so called from a former notion that the
tears of the deceased person's friends were collected in it.
Called also <altname>lachrymal</altname> or
<altname>lacrymal</altname>.</def>

<hw>Lach"ry*mi*form</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>a</pos>,
<ety>[L.<ets>lacrima</ets> tear + <ets>-form</ets>; cf. F.
<ets>lacrymiforme</ets>.]</ety> <def>Having the form of a tear;
tear-shaped.</def>

<hw>Lach"ry*mose`</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>a.</pos> <ety>[L.
<ets>lacrymosus</ets>, better <ets>lacrimosus</ets>, fr.
<ets>lacrima</ets>, <ets>lacruma</ets> (also badly spelt
<ets>lachryma</ets>) a tear, for older <ets>dacrima</ets>, akin
to E. <ets>tear</ets>. See <er>Tear</er> the secretion.]</ety>
<def>Generating or shedding tears; given to shedding tears;
suffused with tears; tearful.</def>

<q>You should have seen his <qex>lachrymose</qex> visnomy.</q>
<qau>Lamb.</qau>

-- <wordforms><wf>Lach"ry*mose`ly</wf>,
<pos>adv.</pos></wordforms>

<-- p. 823 -->

<hw>La"cing</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <sn>1.</sn> <def>The
act of securing, fastening, or tightening, with a lace or
laces.</def>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>A lace; specifically <fld>(Mach.)</fld>, a thong
of thin leather for uniting the ends of belts.</def>

<sn>3.</sn> <def>A rope or line passing through eyelet holes in
the edge of a sail or an awning to attach it to a yard, gaff,
etc.</def>

<sn>4.</sn> <fld>(Bridge Building)</fld> <def>A system of bracing
bars, not crossing each other in the middle, connecting the
channel bars of a compound strut.</def>

<au>Waddell.</au>

process of the stipes on the maxill\'91 of insects.</def>

<hw>Lack</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[OE.
<ets>lak</ets>; cf. D. <ets>lak</ets> slander, <ets>laken</ets>
to blame, OHG. <ets>lahan</ets>, AS. <ets>le\'a0n</ets>.]</ety>
<sn>1.</sn> <def>Blame; cause of blame; fault; crime;
offense.</def> <mark>[Obs.]</mark>

<au>Chaucer.</au>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>Deficiency; want; need; destitution; failure;
<as>as, a <ex>lack</ex> of sufficient food</as>.</def>

<q>She swooneth now and now for <qex>lakke</qex> of blood.</q>
<qau>Chaucer.</qau>

<q>Let his <qex>lack</qex> of years be no impediment.</q>
<qau>Shak.</qau>

<hw>Lack</hw>, <pos>v. t.</pos> <wordforms>[<pos>imp. & p.
p.</pos> <er>Lacked</er> <pr>(?)</pr>; <pos>p. pr. & vb. n.</pos>
<er>Lacking</er>.]</wordforms> <sn>1.</sn> <def>To blame; to find
fault with.</def> <mark>[Obs.]</mark>

<q>Love them and <qex>lakke</qex> them not.</q>
<qau>Piers Plowman.</qau>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>To be without or destitute of; to want; to
need.</def>

<q>If any of you <qex>lack</qex> wisdom, let him ask of God.</q>
<qau>James i. 5.</qau>

<hw>Lack</hw>, <pos>v. i.</pos> <sn>1.</sn> <def>To be wanting;
often, impersonally, with <xex>of</xex>, meaning, to be less
than, short, not quite, etc.</def>

<q>What hour now ?
I think it <qex>lacks</qex> of twelve.</q>
<qau>Shak.</qau>

<q>Peradventure there shall <qex>lack</qex> five of the
fifty.</q>
<qau>Gen. xvii. 28.</qau>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>To be in want.</def>

<q>The young lions do <qex>lack</qex>, and suffer hunger.</q>
<qau>Ps. xxxiv. 10.</qau>

surprise.</def> <mark>[Prov. Eng.]</mark>

<au>Cowper.</au>

<hw>Lack"ey</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos>; <plu>pl.
<plw>Lackeys</plw> <pr>(#)</pr></plu>. <ety>[F.
<ets>laquais</ets>; cf. Sp. & Pg. <ets>lacayo</ets>; of uncertain

<q>Like a Christian footboy or a gentleman's
<qex>lackey</qex>.</q>
<qau>Shak.</qau>

<cs><col>Lackey caterpillar</col> <fld>(Zo\'94l.)</fld>, <cd>the
caterpillar, or larva, of any bombycid moth of the genus
<spn>Clisiocampa</spn>; -- so called from its party-colored
markings. The common European species (<spn>C. neustria</spn>) is
striped with blue, yellow, and red, with a white line on the
back. The American species (<spn>C. Americana</spn> and <spn>C.
sylvatica</spn>) are commonly called <altname>tent
caterpillars</altname>. See <cref>Tent caterpillar</cref>,under
<er>Tent</er>.</cd> -- <col>Lackey moth</col>
<fld>(Zo\'94l.)</fld>, <cd>the moth which produces the lackey
caterpillar.</cd></cs>

<hw>La*co"ni*an</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>a.</pos> <def>Of or
pertaining to Laconia, a division of ancient Greece;
Spartan.</def> -- <def2><pos>n.</pos> <def>An inhabitant of

<mhw>{ <hw>La*con"ic</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <hw>La*con"ic*al</hw>
<pr>(?)</pr>, }</mhw> <pos>a.</pos> <ety>[L. <ets>Laconicus</ets>
Laconian, Gr. <?/<?/, fr. <?/<?/ a Laconian, Laced\'91monian, or
Spartan: cf. F. <ets>laconique</ets>.]</ety> <sn>1.</sn>
<def>Expressing much in few words, after the manner of the
Laconians or Spartans; brief and pithy; brusque; epigrammatic. In
this sense <xex>laconic</xex> is the usual form.</def>

<q>I grow <qex>laconic</qex> even beyond laconicism; for
sometimes I return only yes, or no, to questionary or petitionary
epistles of half a yard long.</q>
<qau>Pope.</qau>

<q>His sense was strong and his style <qex>laconic</qex>.</q>
<qau>Welwood.</qau>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>Laconian; characteristic of, or like, the
Spartans; hence, stern or severe; cruel; unflinching.</def>

<q>His head had now felt the razor, his back the rod; all that
<qex>laconical</qex> discipline pleased him well.</q>
<qau>Bp. Hall.</qau>

<syn>Syn. -- Short; brief; concise; succinct; sententious;
pointed; pithy.</syn> <usage> -- <er>Laconic</er>,
<er>Concise</er>. <xex>Concise</xex> means without irrelevant or
superfluous matter; it is the opposite of <xex>diffuse</xex>.
<xex>Laconic</xex> means concise with the additional quality of
pithiness, sometimes of brusqueness.</usage>

<hw>La*con"ic</hw>, <pos>n.</pos> <def>Laconism.</def>
<mark>[Obs.]</mark>

<au>Addison.</au>

<hw>La*con"ic*al</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>a.</pos> <def>See
<er>Laconic</er>, <pos>a.</pos></def>

<hw>La*con"ic*al*ly</hw>, <pos>adv.</pos> <def>In a laconic
manner.</def>

<hw>La*con"I*cism</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <def>Same as
<er>Laconism</er>.</def>

<au>Pope.</au>

<hw>Lac"o*nism</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[Gr. <?/,
fr. <?/ to imitate Laced\'91monian manners, to speak laconically:
cf. F. <ets>laconisme</ets>.]</ety> <sn>1.</sn> <def>A vigorous,
brief manner of expression; laconic style.</def>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>An instance of laconic style or

<hw>Lac"o*nize</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>v. i.</pos>
<wordforms>[<pos>imp. & p. p.</pos> <er>Laconized</er>
<pr>(?)</pr>; <pos>p. pr. & vb. n.</pos> <er>Laconizing</er>
<pr>(?)</pr>.]</wordforms> <ety>[Gr. <?/. See
<er>Laconic</er>.]</ety> <def>To imitate the manner of the
Laconians, especially in brief, pithy speech, or in frugality and

<hw>Lac"quer</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[F.
<ets>lacre</ets> a sort of sealing wax, Pg. <ets>lacte</ets>, fr. 
<ets>laca</ets> lac. See <er>Lac</er> the resin.]</ety>
<altsp>[Written also <asp>lacker</asp>.]</altsp> <def>A varnish,
consisting of a solution of shell-lac in alcohol, often colored
with gamboge, saffron, or the like; -- used for varnishing
metals, papier-mach\'82, and wood. The name is also given to
varnishes made of other ingredients, esp. the tough, solid
varnish of the Japanese, with which ornamental objects are
made.</def>
<-- shell-lac = shellac; it is the prime spelling in this
dictionary, though not found in MW10! -->

<hw>La*crosse"</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[F. <ets>la
crosse</ets>, lit., the crosier, hooked stick. Cf.
<er>Crosier</er>.]</ety> <def>A game of ball, originating among
the North American Indians, now the popular field sport of
Canada, and played also in England and the United States. Each
player carries a long-handled racket, called a
\'bd<xex>crosse</xex>\'b8. The ball is not handled but caught
with the crosse and carried on it, or tossed from it, the object
being to carry it or throw it through one of the goals placed at
opposite ends of the field.</def>
