<hw>Li"bel*ous</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>a.</pos> <def>Containing
or involving a libel; defamatory; containing that which exposes
some person to public hatred, contempt, or ridicule; <as>as, a
<ex>libelous</ex> pamphlet</as>.</def> <altsp>[Written also
<asp>libellous</asp>.]</altsp> --
<wordforms><wf>Li"bel*ous*ly</wf>, <pos>adv.</pos></wordforms>

<hw>\'d8Li"ber</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[L. See
<er>Libel</er>.]</ety> <fld>(Bot.)</fld> <def>The inner bark of
plants, lying next to the wood. It usually contains a large
proportion of woody, fibrous cells, and is, therefore, the part
from which the fiber of the plant is obtained, as that of hemp,
etc.</def>

<cs><col>Liber cells</col>, <cd>elongated woody cells found in
the liber.</cd></cs>

<hw>Lib"er*al</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>a.</pos> <ety>[F.
<ets>lib\'82ral</ets>, L. <ets>liberalis</ets>, from
<ets>liber</ets> free; perh. akin to <ets>libet</ets>,
<ets>lubet</ets>,it pleases, E. <ets>lief</ets>. Cf.
<er>Deliver</er>.]</ety> <sn>1.</sn> <def>Free by birth; hence,
befitting a freeman or gentleman; refined; noble; independent;
free; not servile or mean; <as>as, a <ex>liberal</ex> ancestry; a
<ex>liberal</ex> spirit; <ex>liberal</ex> arts or
studies.</as></def> \'bd <xex>Liberal</xex> education.\'b8
<au>Macaulay</au>. \'bd A <xex>liberal</xex> tongue.\'b8

<au>Shak.</au>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>Bestowing in a large and noble way, as a
freeman; generous; bounteous; open-handed; <as>as, a
<ex>liberal</ex> giver</as>.</def> \'bd <xex>Liberal</xex> of
praise.\'b8

<au>Bacon.</au>

<q>Infinitely good, and of his good
As <qex>liberal</qex> and free as infinite.</q>
<qau>Milton.</qau>

<sn>3.</sn> <def>Bestowed in a large way; hence, more than
sufficient; abundant; bountiful; ample; profuse; <as>as, a
<ex>liberal</ex> gift; a <ex>liberal</ex> discharge of matter or
of water.</as></def>

<q>His wealth doth warrant a <qex>liberal</qex> dower.</q>
<qau>Shak.</qau>

<sn>4.</sn> <def>Not strict or rigorous; not confined or
restricted to the literal sense; free; <as>as, a <ex>liberal</ex>
translation of a classic, or a <ex>liberal</ex> construction of
law or of language</as>.</def>

<sn>5.</sn> <def>Not narrow or contracted in mind; not selfish;
enlarged in spirit; catholic.</def>

<sn>6.</sn> <def>Free to excess; regardless of law or moral
restraint; licentious.</def> \'bd Most like a <xex>liberal</xex>
villain.\'b8

<au>Shak.</au>

<sn>7.</sn> <def>Not bound by orthodox tenets or established
forms in political or religious philosophy; independent in
opinion; not conservative; friendly to great freedom in the
constitution or administration of government; having tendency
toward democratic or republican, as distinguished from
monarchical or aristocratic, forms; <as>as, <ex>liberal</ex>
thinkers; <ex>liberal</ex> Christians; the <ex>Liberal</ex>
party.</as></def>

<q>I confess I see nothing <qex>liberal</qex> in this \'bd order
of thoughts,\'b8 as Hobbes elsewhere expresses it.</q>
<qau>Hazlitt.</qau>

<note><hand/ <xex>Liberal</xex> has of, sometimes
<xex>with</xex>, before the thing bestowed, <xex>in</xex> before
a word signifying action, and <xex>to</xex> before a person or
object on which anything is bestowed; as, to be
<xex>liberal</xex> of praise or censure; <xex>liberal with</xex>
money; <xex>liberal in</xex> giving; <xex>liberal</xex> to the
poor.</note>

<cs><col>The liberal arts</col>. <cd>See under <er>Art</er>.</cd>
-- <col>Liberal education</col>, <cd>education that enlarges and
disciplines the mind and makes it master of its own powers,
irrespective of the particular business or profession one may
follow.</cd></cs>

<syn>Syn. -- Generous; bountiful; munificent; beneficent; ample;
large; profuse; free.</syn> <usage> -- <er>Liberal</er>,
<er>Generous</er>. <xex>Liberal</xex> is <xex>freeborn</xex>, and
<xex>generous</xex> is <xex>highborn</xex>. The former is opposed
to the ordinary feelings of a servile state, and implies
largeness of spirit in giving, judging, acting, etc. The latter
expresses that nobleness of soul which is peculiarly appropriate
to those of high rank, -- a spirit that goes out of self, and
finds its enjoyment in consulting the feelings and happiness of
others. <xex>Generosity</xex> is measured by the extent of the
sacrifices it makes; <xex>liberality</xex>, by the warmth of
feeling which it manifests.</usage>

<hw>Lib"er*al</hw>, <pos>n.</pos> <def>One who favors greater
freedom in political or religious matters; an opponent of the
established systems; a reformer; in English politics, a member of
the Liberal party, so called. Cf. <er>Whig</er>.</def>

<hw>Lib"er*al*ism</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[Cf. F.
<ets>lib\'82ralisme</ets>.]</ety> <def>Liberal principles; the
principles and methods of the liberals in politics or religion;
specifically, the principles of the Liberal party.</def>

<hw>Lib"er*al*ist</hw>, <pos>n.</pos> <def>A liberal.</def>

<hw>Lib`er*al*is"tic</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>a.</pos>
<def>Pertaining to, or characterized by, liberalism; <as>as,
<ex>liberalistic</ex> opinions</as>.</def>

<hw>Lib`er*al"i*ty</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos>; <plu>pl.
<plw>Liberalities</plw> <pr>(#)</pr></plu>. <ety>[L.
<ets>liberalitas</ets>: cf. F.
<ets>lib\'82ralit\'82</ets>.]</ety> <sn>1.</sn> <def>The quality
or state of being liberal; liberal disposition or practice;
freedom from narrowness or prejudice; generosity; candor;
charity.</def>

<q>That <qex>liberality</qex> is but cast away
Which makes us borrow what we can not pay.</q>
<qau>Denham.</qau>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>A gift; a gratuity; -- sometimes in the plural;
<as>as, a prudent man is not impoverished by his
<ex>liberalities</ex></as>.</def>

<hw>Lib`er*al*i*za"tion</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <def>The
act of liberalizing.</def>

<hw>Lib"er*al*ize</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>v. i.</pos>
<wordforms>[<pos>imp. & p. p.</pos> <er>Liberalized</er>
<pr>(?)</pr>; <pos>p. pr. & vb. n.</pos> <er>Liberalizing</er>
<pr>(?)</pr>.]</wordforms> <ety>[Cf. F.
<ets>lib\'82raliser</ets>.]</ety> <def>To make liberal; to free
from narrow views or prejudices.</def>

<q>To open and to <qex>liberalize</qex> the mind.</q>
<qau>Burke.</qau>

<hw>Lib"er*al*i`zer</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <def>One
who, or that which, liberalizes.</def>

<au>Emerson.</au>

<hw>Lib"er*al*ly</hw>, <pos>adv.</pos> <def>In a liberal
manner.</def>

<hw>Lib"er*ate</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>v. t.</pos>
<wordforms>[<pos>imp. & p. p.</pos> <er>Liberated</er>
<pr>(?)</pr>; <pos>p. pr. & vb. n.</pos> <er>Liberating</er>
<pr>(?)</pr>.]</wordforms> <ety>[L. <ets>liberatus</ets>, p. p.
of <ets>liberare</ets> to free, fr. <ets>liber</ets> free. See
<er>Liberal</er>, <pos>a.</pos>, and cf. <er>Deliver</er>.]</ety>
<def>To release from restraint or bondage; to set at liberty; to
free; to manumit; to disengage; <as>as, to <ex>liberate</ex> a
slave or prisoner; to <ex>liberate</ex> the mind from prejudice;
to <ex>liberate</ex> gases.</as></def>

<syn>Syn. -- To deliver; free; release. See
<er>Deliver</er>.</syn>

<hw>Lib`er*a"tion</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[L.
<ets>liberatio</ets>: cf. F. <ets>lib\'82ration</ets>. Cf.
<er>Livraison</er>.]</ety> <def>The act of liberating or the
state of being liberated.</def>

<q>This mode of analysis requires perfect <qex>liberation</qex>
from all prejudged system.</q>
<qau>Pownall.</qau>

<hw>Lib"er*a`tor</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[L.]</ety>
<def>One who, or that which, liberates; a deliverer.</def>

<hw>Lib"er*a*to*ry</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>a.</pos> <def>Tending,
or serving, to liberate.</def> <mark>[R.]</mark>

<hw>Lib`er*ta"ri*an</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>a.</pos> <ety>[See
<er>Liberty</er>.]</ety> <def>Pertaining to liberty, or to the
doctrine of free will, as opposed to the doctrine of
necessity.</def>

<hw>Lib`er*ta"ri*an</hw>, <pos>n.</pos> <def>One who holds to the
doctrine of free will.</def>

<hw>Lib`er*ta"ri*an*ism</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos>
<def>Libertarian principles or doctrines.</def>

<hw>Lib"er*ti*cide</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[L.
<ets>libertas</ets> liberty + <ets>caedere</ets> to kill: cf.
(for sense 2) F. <ets>liberticide</ets>.]</ety> <sn>1.</sn>
<def>The destruction of civil liberty.</def>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>A destroyer of civil liberty.</def>

<au>B. F. Wade.</au>

<hw>Lib"er*tin*age</hw> <pr>(?)</pr> <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[Cf. F.
<ets>libertinage</ets>. See <er>Libertine</er>.]</ety>
<def>Libertinism; license.</def> <mark>[R.]</mark>

<hw>Lib"er*tine</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[L.
<ets>libertinus</ets> freedman, from <ets>libertus</ets> one made
free, fr. <ets>liber</ets> free: cf. F. <ets>libertin</ets>. See
<er>Liberal</er>.]</ety> <sn>1.</sn> <fld>(Rom. Antiq.)</fld>
<def>A manumitted slave; a freedman; also, the son of a
freedman.</def>

<sn>2.</sn> <fld>(Eccl. Hist.)</fld> <def>One of a sect of
Anabaptists, in the fifteenth and early part of the sixteenth
century, who rejected many of the customs and decencies of life,
and advocated a community of goods and of women.</def>

<sn>3.</sn> <def>One free from restraint; one who acts according
to his impulses and desires; now, specifically, one who gives
rein to lust; a rake; a debauchee.</def>

<q>Like a puffed and reckless <qex>libertine</qex>,
Himself the primrose path of dalliance treads.</q>
<qau>Shak.</qau>

<sn>4.</sn> <def>A defamatory name for a freethinker.</def>
<mark>[Obsoles.]</mark>

<hw>Lib"er*tine</hw>, <pos>a.</pos> <ety>[L.
<ets>libertinus</ets> of a freedman: cf. F. <ets>libertin</ets>.
See <er>Libertine</er>, <pos>n.</pos> ]</ety> <sn>1.</sn>
<def>Free from restraint; uncontrolled.</def> <mark>[Obs.]</mark>

<q>You are too much <qex>libertine</qex>.</q>
<qau>Beau. & Fl.</qau>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>Dissolute; licentious; profligate; loose in
morals; <as>as, <ex>libertine</ex> principles or
manners</as>.</def>

<au>Bacon.</au>

<hw>Lib"er*tin*ism</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <sn>1.</sn>
<def>The state of a libertine or freedman.</def>
<mark>[R.]</mark>

<au>Hammond.</au>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>Licentious conduct; debauchery; lewdness.</def>

<sn>3.</sn> <def>Licentiousness of principle or opinion.</def>

<q>That spirit of religion and seriousness vanished all at once,
and a spirit of liberty and <qex>libertinism</qex>, of infidelity
and profaneness, started up in the room of it.</q>
<qau>Atterbury.</qau>

<hw>Lib"er*ty</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos>; <plu>pl.
<plw>Liberties</plw> <pr>(<?/)</pr>.</plu> <ety>[OE.
<ets>liberte</ets>, F. <ets>libert\'82</ets>, fr. L.
<ets>libertas</ets>, fr. <ets>liber</ets> free. See
<er>Liberal</er>.]</ety> <sn>1.</sn> <def>The state of a free
person; exemption from subjection to the will of another claiming
ownership of the person or services; freedom; -- opposed to
slavery, serfdom, bondage, or subjection.</def>

<q>But ye . . . caused every man his servant, and every man his
handmaid whom he had set at <qex>liberty</qex> at their pleasure,
to return, and brought them into subjection.</q>
<qau>Jer. xxxiv. 16.</qau>

<q>Delivered fro the bondage of corruption into the glorious
<qex>liberty</qex> of the sons of God.</q>
<qau>Bible, 1551. Rom. viii. 21.</qau>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>Freedom from imprisonment, bonds, or other
restraint upon locomotion.</def>

<q>Being pent from <qex>liberty</qex>, as I am now.</q>
<qau>Shak.</qau>

<sn>3.</sn> <def>A privilege conferred by a superior power;
permission granted; leave; <as>as, <ex>liberty</ex> given to a
child to play, or to a witness to leave a court, and the
like</as>.</def>

<sn>4.</sn> <def>Privilege; exemption; franchise; immunity
enjoyed by prescription or by grant; <as>as, the
<ex>liberties</ex> of the commercial cities of Europe</as>.</def>

<q>His majesty gave not an entire county to any; much less did he
grant . . . any extraordinary <qex>liberties</qex>.</q>
<qau>Sir J. Davies.</qau>

<sn>5.</sn> <def>The place within which certain immunities are
enjoyed, or jurisdiction is exercised.</def> <mark>[Eng.]</mark>

<q>Brought forth into some public or open place within the
<qex>liberty</qex> of the city, and there . . . burned.</q>
<qau>Fuller.</qau>

<sn>6.</sn> <def>A certain amount of freedom; permission to go
freely within certain limits; also, the place or limits within
which such freedom is exercised; <as>as, the <ex>liberties</ex>
of a prison</as>.</def>

<sn>7.</sn> <def>A privilege or license in violation of the laws
of etiquette or propriety; <as>as, to permit, or take, a
<ex>liberty</ex></as>.</def>

<q>He was repeatedly provoked into striking those who had taken
<qex>liberties</qex> with him.</q>
<qau>Macaulay.</qau>

<sn>8.</sn> <def>The power of choice; freedom from necessity;
freedom from compulsion or constraint in willing.</def>

<q>The idea of <qex>liberty</qex> is the idea of a power in any
agent to do or forbear any particular action, according to the
determination or thought of the mind, whereby either of them is
preferred to the other.</q>
<qau>Locke.</qau>

<q>This <qex>liberty</qex> of judgment did not of necessity lead
to lawlessness.</q>
<qau>J. A. Symonds.</qau>

<sn>9.</sn> <fld>(Manege)</fld> <def>A curve or arch in a bit to
afford room for the tongue of the horse.</def>

<sn>10.</sn> <fld>(Naut.)</fld> <def>Leave of absence; permission
to go on shore.</def>

<cs><col>At liberty</col>. <sd>(a)</sd> <cd>Unconfined;
free</cd>. <sd>(b)</sd> <cd>At leisure</cd>. -- <col>Civil
liberty</col>, <cd>exemption from arbitrary interference with
person, opinion, or property, on the part of the government under
which one lives, and freedom to take part in modifying that
government or its laws.</cd> -- <col>Liberty bell</col>. <cd>See
under <er>Bell</er>.</cd> -- <col>Liberty cap</col>. <sd>(a)</sd>
<cd>The Roman <xex>pileus<xex> which was given to a slave at his
manumission</cd>. <sd>(b)</sd> <cd>A limp, close-fitting cap with
which the head of representations of the goddess of liberty is
often decked. It is sometimes represented on a spear or a liberty
pole.</cd> -- <col>Liberty of the press</col>, <cd>freedom to
print and publish without official supervision.</cd> <col>Liberty
party</col></mcol>, <cd>the party, in the American Revolution,
which favored independence of England; in more recent usage, a
party which favored the emancipation of the slaves.</cd> --
<col>Liberty pole</col>, <cd>a tall flagstaff planted in the
ground, often surmounted by a liberty cap.</cd> <mark>[U.
S.]</mark> -- <col>Moral liberty</col>, <cd>that liberty of
choice which is essential to moral responsibility.</cd> --
<col>Religious liberty</col>, <cd>freedom of religious opinion
and worship.</cd></cs>

<syn>Syn. -- Leave; permission; license.</syn> <usage> --
<er>Liberty</er>, <er>Freedom</er>. These words, though often
interchanged, are distinct in some of of their applications.
<xex>Liberty</xex> has reference to previous restraint;
<xex>freedom</xex>, to the simple, unrepressed exercise of our
powers. A slave is set at <xex>liberty</xex>; his master had
always been in a state of <xex>freedom</xex>. A prisoner under
trial may ask <xex>liberty</xex> (exemption from restraint) to
speak his sentiments with <xex>freedom</xex> (the spontaneous and
bold utterance of his feelings), The <xex>liberty</xex> of the
press is our great security for <xex>freedom</xex> of
thought.</usage>

<hw>Li*beth"en*ite</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[From
<ets>Libethen</ets>, in Hungary, where it was first found.]</ety>
<fld>(Min.)</fld> <def>A mineral of an olive-green color,
commonly in orthorhombic crystals. It is a hydrous phosphate of
copper.</def>

<hw>Li"bra*ry</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos>; <plu>pl.

<hw>Li"brate</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>v. i.</pos>
<wordforms>[<pos>imp. & p. p.</pos> <er>Librated</er> <?/;
<pos>p. pr. & & vb. n.</pos> <er>Librating</er>.]</wordforms>
<ety>[L. <ets>libratus</ets>, p. p. of <ets>librare</ets> to
balance, to make even, fr. <ets>libra</ets>.Cf. <er>Level</er>,
<er>Deliberate</er>, <er>Equilibrium</er>.]</ety> <def>To vibrate

<hw>Li*bra"tion</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[L.
<ets>libratio</ets>: cf. F. <ets>libration</ets>.]</ety>
<sn>1.</sn> <def>The act or state of librating.</def>

<au>Jer. Taylor.</au>

<sn>2.</sn> <fld>(Astron.)</fld> <def>A real or apparent
libratory motion, like that of a balance before coming to
rest.</def>

<cs><col>Libration of the moon</col>, <cd>any one of those small
periodical changes in the position of the moon's surface
relatively to the earth, in consequence of which narrow portions
at opposite limbs become visible or invisible alternately. It
receives different names according to the manner in which it
takes place</cd>; as: <stype>(a)</stype> <xex>Libration in
longitude<xex>, that which, depending on the place of the moon in
its elliptic orbit, causes small portions near the eastern and
western borders alternately to appear and disappear each month.
(<stype>b</stype>) <xex>Libration in latitude<xex>, that which
depends on the varying position of the moon's axis in respect to
the spectator, causing the alternate appearance and disappearance
of either pole. (<stype>c</stype>) <xex>Diurnal<xex> or
<xex>parallactic libration<xex>, that which brings into view on
the upper limb, at rising and setting, some parts not in the
average visible hemisphere.</cd></cs>

<hw>Li"bra*to*ry</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>a.</pos> <def>Balancing;
moving like a balance, as it tends to an equipoise or
level.</def>

<hw>Li*bret"tist</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <def>One who

<hw>Li*bret"to</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos>; <plu>pl. E.

<pr>(#)</pr></plu>. <ety>[It., dim. of <ets>libro</ets> book, L.
<ets>liber</ets>. See <er>Libel</er>.]</ety> <fld>(Mus.)</fld>
<sd>(a)</sd> <def>A book containing the words of an opera or
extended piece of music.</def> <sd>(b)</sd> <def>The words
themselves.</def>

<hw>Li"cens*a*ble</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>a.</pos> <def>That can

<hw>Li"cense</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <altsp>[Written
also <asp>licence</asp>.]</altsp> <ety>[F. <ets>licence</ets>, L.
<ets>licentia</ets>, fr. <ets>licere</ets> to be permitted, prob.
orig., to be left free to one; akin to <ets>linquere</ets> to
leave. See <er>Loan</er>, and cf. <er>Illicit</er>,
<er>Leisure</er>.]</ety> <sn>1.</sn> <def>Authority or liberty
given to do or forbear any act; especially, a formal permission
from the proper authorities to perform certain acts or to carry
on a certain business, which without such permission would be
illegal; a grant of permission; <as>as, a <ex>license</ex> to
preach, to practice medicine, to sell gunpowder or intoxicating
liquors</as>.</def>

<q>To have a <qex>license</qex> and a leave at London to
dwell.</q>
<qau>P. Plowman.</qau>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>The document granting such permission.</def>

<au>Addison.</au>

<sn>3.</sn> <def>Excess of liberty; freedom abused, or used in
contempt of law or decorum; disregard of law or propriety.</def>

<q><qex>License</qex> they mean when they cry liberty.</q>
<qau>Milton.</qau>

<sn>4.</sn> <def>That deviation from strict fact, form, or rule,
in which an artist or writer indulges, assuming that it will be
permitted for the sake of the advantage or effect gained; <as>as,
poetic <ex>license</ex>; grammatical <ex>license</ex>,
etc.</as></def>

<syn>Syn. -- Leave; liberty; permission.</syn>

<-- p. 849 -->

<hw>Li*cen"ti*ate</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[LL.

<hw>Li*cen"tious</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>a.</pos> <ety>[L.

<hw>Lich</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos>

<pos>a.</pos>]</ety> <def>A dead body; a corpse.</def>

<cs><col>Lich fowl</col> <fld>(Zo\'94l.)</fld>, <cd>the European
goatsucker; -- called also <altname>lich owl</altname>.</cd> --
<col>Lich gate</col>, <cd>a covered gate through which the corpse
was carried to the church or burial place, and where the bier was
placed to await clergyman; a corpse gate. <mark>[Prov.
Eng.]</mark> <au>Halliwell</au>.</cd> -- <col>Lich wake</col>,
<cd>the wake, or watching, held over a corpse before burial.
<mark>[Prov Eng.]</mark> <au>Chaucer</au>.</cd> -- <col>Lich
wall</col>, <cd>the wall of a churchyard or burying ground.</cd>
-- <col>Lich way</col>, <cd>the path by which the dead are
carried to the grave. <mark>[Prov. Eng.]</mark></cd></cs>

<hw>Li"chen</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[L., fr. Gr.
<?/.]</ety> <sn>1.</sn> <fld>(Bot.)</fld> <def>One of a class of
cellular, flowerless plants, (technically called
<altname>Lichenes</altname>), having no distinction of leaf and
stem, usually of scaly, expanded, frond-like forms, but sometimes
erect or pendulous and variously branched. They derive their
nourishment from the air, and generate by means of spores. The
species are very widely distributed, and form irregular spots or
patches, usually of a greenish or yellowish color, upon rocks,
trees, and various bodies, to which they adhere with great
tenacity. They are often improperly called <xex>rock moss or tree
moss</xex>.</def>

<note><hand/ A favorite modern theory of lichens (called after
its inventor the <xex>Schwendener hypothesis</xex>), is that they
are not autonomous plants, but that they consist of ascigerous
fungi, parasitic on alg\'91. Each lichen is composed of white
filaments and green, or greenish, rounded cells, and it is argued
that the two are of different nature, the one living at the
expense of the other. See <er>Hyph\'91</er>, and
<er>Gonidia</er>.</note>

<sn>2.</sn> <fld>(Med.)</fld> <def>A name given to several
varieties of skin disease, esp. to one characterized by the
eruption of small, conical or flat, reddish pimples, which, if
unchecked, tend to spread and produce great and even fatal
exhaustion.</def>

<hw>Li"chened</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>a.</pos> <def>Belonging to,
or covered with, lichens.</def>

<au>Tennyson.</au>

<hw>Li*chen"ic</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>a.</pos> <def>Of,
pertaining to, or obtained from, lichens.</def>

<cs><col>Lichenic acid</col>. <sd>(a)</sd> <cd>An organic acid,
<chform>C14H24O3</chform> obtained from Iceland moss</cd>.
<sd>(b)</sd> <cd>An old name of fumaric acid.</cd></cs>

<hw>Li*chen"i*form</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>a.</pos> <def>Having
the form of a lichen.</def>

<hw>Li"chen*in</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos>
<fld>(Chem.)</fld> <def>A substance isomeric with starch,
extracted from several species of moss and lichen, esp. from
Iceland moss.</def>

<mhw>{ <hw>Li"chen*o*graph"ic</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>,
<hw>Li`chen*o*graph"ic*al</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, }</mhw>
<pos>a.</pos> <ety>[Cf. F. <ets>lich\'82nographique</ets>.]</ety>
<def>Of or pertaining to lichenography.</def>

<hw>Li`chen*og"ra*phist</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <def>One

<hw>Li`chen*og"ra*phy</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos>
<ety>[<ets>Lichen</ets> + <ets>-graphy</ets>: cf. F. 
<ets>lich\'82nographie</ets>.]</ety> <def>A description of
lichens; the science which illustrates the natural history of
lichens.</def>

<hw>Li`chen*ol"o*gist</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <def>One
versed in lichenology.</def>

<hw>Li`chen*ol"*gy</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos>
<ety>[<ets>Lichen</ets> + <ets>-logy</ets>.]</ety> <def>The
science which treats of lichens.</def>

pertaining to, or resembling, lichens; abounding in lichens;
covered with lichens.</def>

<au>G. Eliot.</au>

<hw>Lic"it</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>a.</pos>
<ety>[L.<ets>licitus</ets> permitted, lawful, from

<hw>Lick</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>v. t.</pos>
<wordforms>[<pos>imp. & p. p.</pos> <er>Licked</er> <pr>(?)</pr>;
<pos>p. pr. & vb. n.</pos> <er>Licking</er>.]</wordforms>
<ety>[AS. <ets>liccian</ets>; akin to OS. <ets>likk<?/n</ets>, D.
<ets>likken</ets>, OHG. <ets>lecch<?/n</ets>, G.
<ets>lecken</ets>, Goth. <ets>bi-laig<?/n</ets>, Russ.
<ets>lizate</ets>, L. <ets>lingere</ets>, Gr. <?/ , Skr.
<ets>lih</ets>, <ets>rih</ets>. <ets><?/</ets>. Cf.
<er>Lecher</er>, <er>Relish</er>.]</ety> <sn>1.</sn> <def>To draw
or pass the tongue over; <as>as, a dog <ex>licks</ex> his
master's hand</as>.</def>

<au>Addison.</au>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>To lap; to take in with the tongue; <as>as, a
dog or cat <ex>licks</ex> milk</as>.</def>

<au>Shak.</au>

<cs><col>To lick the dust</col>, <cd>to be slain; to fall in
battle. \'bdHis enemies shall <xex>lick the dust<xex>.\'b8 
<au>Ps. lxxii. 9</au>.</cd> -- <col>To lick into shape</col>,
<cd>to give proper form to; -- from a notion that the bear's cubs
are born shapeless and subsequently formed by licking.
<au>Hudibras</au>.</cd> -- <col>To lick the spittle of</col>,
<cd>to fawn upon.</cd> <au>South</au>. -- <col>To lick up</col>,
<cd>to take all of by licking; to devour; to consume
entirely.</cd> <au>Shak</au>. <au>Num. xxii. 4</au>.</cs>

<hw>Lick</hw>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[See <er>Lick</er>,
<pos>v.</pos>]</ety> <sn>1.</sn> <def>A stroke of the tongue in
licking.</def> \'bdA <xex>lick</xex> at the honey pot.\'b8

<au>Dryden.</au>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>A quick and careless application of anything, as
if by a stroke of the tongue, or of something which acts like a
tongue; <as>as, to put on colors with a <ex>lick</ex> of the
brush</as>. Also, a small quantity of any substance so
applied.</def> <mark>[Colloq.]</mark>

<q>A <qex>lick</qex> of court white wash.</q>
<qau>Gray.</qau>

<sn>3.</sn> <def>A place where salt is found on the surface of
the earth, to which wild animals resort to lick it up; -- often,
but not always, near salt springs.</def> <mark>[U. S.]</mark>
<-- = salt lick -->

<hw>Lick</hw>, <pos>v. t.</pos> <ety>[Cf. OSw.
<ets>l\'84gga</ets> to place, strike, prick.]</ety> <def>To
strike with repeated blows for punishment; to flog; to whip or
conquer, as in a pugilistic encounter.</def> <mark>[Colloq. or
Low]</mark><-- to defeat in a contest? -->

<au>Carlyle. Thackeray.</au>

<hw>Lick</hw>, <pos>n.</pos> <def>A slap; a quick
stroke.</def><mark>[Colloq.]</mark> \'bdA <xex>lick</xex> across
the face.\'b8

<au>Dryden.</au>

<hw>Lic"o*rice</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[OE.
<ets>licoris</ets>, though old French, fr. L.
<ets>liquiritia</ets>, corrupted fr. <ets>glycyrrhiza</ets>, Gr.
<?/; <?/ sweet + <?/ root. Cf. <er>Glycerin</er>,
<er>Glycyrrhiza</er>, <er>Wort</er>.]</ety> <altsp>[Written also
<asp>liquorice</asp>.]</altsp> <sn>1.</sn> <fld>(Bot.)</fld>
<def>A plant of the genus <spn>Glycyrrhiza</spn> (<spn>G.
glabra</spn>), the root of which abounds with a juice, and is
much used in demulcent compositions.</def>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>The inspissated juice of licorice root, used as
a confection and medicinal purposes.</def>

<cs><col>Licorice fern</col> <fld>(Bot.)</fld>, <cd>a name of
several kinds of polypody which have rootstocks of a sweetish
flavor.</cd> -- <col>Licorice sugar</col>. <fld>(Chem.)</fld>
<cd>See <er>Glycyrrhizin</er>.</cd> -- <col>Licorice weed</col>
<fld>(Bot.)</fld>, <cd>the tropical plant <spn>Scapania
aulcis</spn>.</cd> -- <col>Mountain licorice</col>
<fld>(Bot.)</fld>, <cd>a kind of clover (<spn>Trifolium
alpinum</spn>), found in the Alps. It has large purplish flowers
and a sweetish perennial rootstock.</cd> -- <col>Wild
licorice</col>. <fld>(Bot.)</fld> <sd>(a)</sd> <cd>The North
American perennial herb <spn>Glycyrrhiza lepidota</spn>.</cd>
<sd>(b)</sd> <cd>Certain broad-leaved cleavers (<spn>Galium
circ\'91zans</spn> and <spn>G. lanceolatum</spn>).</cd>
<sd>(c)</sd> <cd>The leguminous climber <spn>Abrus
precatorius</spn>, whose scarlet and black seeds are called
<xex>black-eyed Susans<xex>. Its roots are used as a substitute
for those of true licorice (<spn>Glycyrrhiza
glabra</spn>).</cd></cs>

<hw>Lic"tor</hw>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[L.]</ety> <fld>(Rom.
Antiq.)</fld> <def>An officer who bore an ax and fasces or rods,
as ensigns of his office. His duty was to attend the chief
magistrates when they appeared in public, to clear the way, and
cause due respect to be paid to them, also to apprehend and
punish criminals.</def>

<q><qex>Lictors</qex> and rods, the ensigns of their power.</q>
<qau>Milton.</qau>

<hw>Lid</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[AS.
<ets>hlid</ets>, fr. <ets>hl\'c6dan</ets> (in comp.) to cover,
shut; akin to OS. <ets>hl\'c6dan</ets> (in comp.), D.
<ets>lid</ets>, OHG. <ets>hlit</ets>, G. augen<ets>lid</ets>
eyelid, Icel. <ets>hli<?/</ets> gate, gateway. <?/.]</ety>

<sn>1.</sn> <def>That which covers the opening of a vessel or
box, etc. ; a movable cover; <as>as, the <ex>lid</ex> of a chest
or trunk</as>.</def>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>The cover of the eye; an eyelid.</def>

<au>Shak.</au>

<q>Tears, big tears, gushed from the rough soldier's
<qex>lid</qex>.</q>
<qau>Byron.</qau>

<sn>3.</sn> <fld>(Bot.)</fld> <sd>(a)</sd> <def>The cover of the
spore cases of mosses.</def> <sd>(b)</sd> <def>A calyx which
separates from the flower, and falls off in a single piece, as in
the Australian <spn>Eucalypti</spn>.</def> <sd>(c)</sd> <def>The
top of an ovary which opens transversely, as in the fruit of the
purslane and the tree which yields Brazil nuts.</def>

<hw>Lid"ded</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>a.</pos> <def>Covered with a
lid.</def>

<au>Keats.</au>

<hw>Lidge</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <def>Same
<er>Ledge</er>.</def><mark>[Obs.]</mark>

<au>Spenser.</au>

<hw>Lid"less</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>a.</pos> <def>Having no lid,
or not covered with the lids, as the eyes; hence, sleepless;
watchful.</def>

<q>A <qex>lidless</qex> watcher of the public weal.</q>
<qau>Tennyson.</qau>

<hw>Lie</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <def>See
<er>Lye</er>.</def>

<hw>Lie</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[AS.
<ets>lyge</ets>; akin to D. <ets>leugen</ets>, OHG.
<ets>lugi</ets>, <ets>G</ets>. <ets>l\'81ge</ets>,
<ets>lug</ets>, Icel. <ets>lygi</ets>, Dan. & Sw.
<ets>l\'94gn</ets>, Goth. <ets>liugn</ets>. See <er>Lie</er> to
utter a falsehood.]</ety> <sn>1.</sn> <def>A falsehood uttered or
acted for the purpose of deception; an intentional violation of
truth; an untruth spoken with the intention to deceive.</def>

<q>It is willful deceit that makes a <qex>lie</qex>. A man may
act a <qex>lie</qex>, as by pointing his finger in a wrong
direction when a traveler inquires of him his road.</q>
<qau>Paley.</qau>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>A fiction; a fable; an untruth.</def>

<au>Dryden.</au>

<sn>3.</sn> <def>Anything which misleads or disappoints.</def>

<q>Wishing this <qex>lie</qex> of life was o'er.</q>
<qau>Trench.</qau>

<cs><col>To give the lie to</col>. <sd>(a)</sd> <cd>To charge
with falsehood; <as>as, the man <ex>gave<ex> him <ex>the
lie<ex></as>.</cd> <sd>(b)</sd> <cd>To reveal to be false;
<as>as, a man's actions may <ex>give the lie to<ex> his
words</as>.</cd> -- <col>White lie</col>, <cd>a euphemism for
such lies as one finds it convenient to tell, and excuses himself
for telling.</cd></cs>

<syn>Syn. -- Untruth; falsehood; fiction; deception.</syn>
<usage> -- <er>lie</er>, <er>Untruth</er>. A man may state what
is <xex>untrue</xex> from ignorance or misconception; hence, to
impute an <xex>untruth</xex> to one is not necessarily the same
as charging him with a <xex>lie</xex>. Every <xex>lie</xex> is an
<xex>untruth</xex>, but not every <xex>untruth</xex> is a
<xex>lie</xex>. Cf. <er>Falsity</er>.</usage>

<hw>Lie</hw>, <pos>v. i.</pos> <wordforms>[<pos>imp. & p.
p.</pos> <er>Lied</er> <pr>(?)</pr>; <pos>p. pr. & vb. n.</pos>
<er>Lying</er> <pr>(?)</pr>.]</wordforms> <ety>[OE.
<ets>lien</ets>, <ets>li<?/en</ets>, <ets>le<?/en</ets>,
<ets>leo<?/en</ets>, AS. <ets>le\'a2gan</ets>; akin to D.
<ets>liegen</ets>, OS. &  OHG. <ets>liogan</ets>, G.
<ets>l\'81gen</ets>, Icel. <ets>lj<?/ga</ets>, Sw.
<ets>ljuga</ets>, Dan.<ets>lyve</ets>, Goth. <ets>liugan</ets>,
Russ. <ets>lgate</ets>.]</ety> <def>To utter falsehood with an
intention to deceive; to say or do that which is intended to
deceive another, when he a right to know the truth, or when
morality requires a just representation.</def>

<hw>Lie</hw>, <pos>v. i.</pos> <wordforms>[<pos>imp.</pos>
<er>Lay</er> <pr>(?)</pr>; <pos>p. p.</pos> <er>Lain</er>
<pr>(?)</pr>, (<er>Lien</er> <pr>(<?/)</pr>,
<mark>[Obs.]</mark>); <pos>p. pr. & vb. n.</pos>
<er>Lying</er>.]</wordforms> <ety>[OE. <ets>lien</ets>,
<ets>liggen</ets>, AS. <ets>licgan</ets>; akin to D.
<ets>liggen</ets>, OHG. <ets>ligen</ets>, <ets>licken</ets>, G.
<ets>liegen</ets>, Icel. <ets>liggja</ets>, Sw. <ets>ligga</ets>,
Dan. <ets>ligge</ets>, Goth.  <ets>ligan</ets>, Russ.
<ets>lejate</ets>, L. <ets>lectus</ets> bed, Gr. <?/ bed, <?/ to
lie. Cf. <er>Lair</er>, <er>Law</er>, <er>Lay</er>, <pos>v.
t.</pos>, <er>Litter</er>, <er>Low</er>, <ets>adj</ets>.]</ety>
<sn>1.</sn> <def>To rest extended on the ground, a bed, or any
support; to be, or to put one's self, in an horizontal position,
or nearly so; to be prostate; to be stretched out; -- often with
<ptcl>down</ptcl>, when predicated of living creatures; <as>as,
the book <ex>lies</ex> on the table; the snow <ex>lies</ex> on
the roof; he <ex>lies</ex> in his coffin.</as></def>

<q>The watchful traveler . . . 
<qex>Lay</qex> down again, and closed his weary eyes.</q>
<qau>Dryden.</qau>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>To be situated; to occupy a certain place;
<as>as, Ireland <ex>lies</ex> west of England; the meadows
<ex>lie</ex> along the river; the ship <ex>lay</ex> in
port.</as></def>

<sn>3.</sn> <def>To abide; to remain for a longer or shorter
time; to be in a certain state or condition; <as>as, to
<ex>lie</ex> waste; to <ex>lie</ex> fallow; to <ex>lie</ex> open;
to <ex>lie</ex> hid; to <ex>lie</ex> grieving; to <ex>lie</ex>
under one's displeasure; to <ex>lie</ex> at the mercy of the
waves; the paper does not <ex>lie</ex> smooth on the
wall.</as></def>

<sn>4.</sn> <def>To be or exist; to belong or pertain; to have an
abiding place; to consist; -- with <xex>in</xex>.</def>

<q>Envy <qex>lies</qex> between beings equal in nature, though
unequal in circumstances.</q>
<qau>Collier.</qau>

<q>He that thinks that diversion may not <qex>lie</qex> in hard
labor, forgets the early rising and hard riding of huntsmen.</q>
<qau>Locke.</qau>

<sn>5.</sn> <def>To lodge; to sleep.</def>

<q>Whiles I was now trifling at home, I saw London, . . . where I
<qex>lay</qex> one night only.</q>
<qau>Evelyn.</qau>

<q>Mr. Quinion <qex>lay</qex> at our house that night.</q>
<qau>Dickens.</qau>

<sn>6.</sn> <def>To be still or quiet, like one lying down to
rest.</def>

<q>The wind is loud and will not <qex>lie</qex>.</q>
<qau>Shak.</qau>

<sn>7.</sn> <fld>(Law)</fld> <def>To be sustainable; to be
capable of being maintained.</def> \'bdAn appeal <xex>lies</xex>
in this case.\'b8

<au>Parsons.</au>

<note><hand/ Through ignorance or carelessness speakers and
writers often confuse the forms of the two distinct verbs
<xex>lay</xex> and <xex>lie</xex>. <xex>Lay</xex> is a transitive
verb, and has for its preterit <xex>laid</xex>; as, he told me to
<xex>lay</xex> it down, and I <xex>laid</xex> it down.
<xex>Lie</xex> is intransitive, and has for its preterit
<xex>lay</xex>; as, he told me to <xex>lie</xex> down, and I
<xex>lay</xex> down.  Some persons blunder by using
<xex>laid</xex> for the preterit of <xex>lie</xex>; as, he told
me to <xex>lie</xex> down, and I <xex>laid</xex> down. So persons
often say incorrectly, the ship <xex>laid</xex> at anchor; they
<xex>laid</xex> by during the storm; the book was
<xex>laying</xex> on the shelf, etc. It is only necessary to
remember, in all such cases, that <xex>laid</xex> is the preterit
of <xex>lay</xex>, and not of <xex>lie</xex>.</note>

<cs><col>To lie along the shore</col> <fld>(Naut.)</fld>, <cd>to
coast, keeping land in sight.</cd> -- <col>To lie at the door
of</col>, <cd>to be imputable to; as, the sin, blame, etc.,
<xex>lies at your door<xex>.</cd> -- <col>To lie at the
heart</col>, <cd>to be an object of affection, desire, or
anxiety. <au>Sir W. Temple</au>.</cd> -- <col>To lie at the mercy
of</col>, <cd>to be in the power of.</cd> -- <col>To lie
by</col>. <sd>(a)</sd> <cd>To remain with; to be at hand; <as>as,
he has the manuscript <ex>lying by<ex> him</as></cd>.
<sd>(b)</sd> <cd>To rest; to intermit labor; as, we <xex>lay
by<xex> during the heat of the day.</cd> -- <mcol><col>To lie
hard</col> <or/ <col>heavy</col></mcol>, <cd>to press or weigh;
to bear hard.</cd> -- <col>To lie in</col>, <cd>to be in
childbed; to bring forth young.</cd> -- <col>To lie in one</col>,
<cd>to be in the power of; to belong to. \'bdAs much as
<xex>lieth in you<xex>, live peaceably with all men.\'b8 <au>Rom.
xii. 18</au>.</cd> -- <col>To lie in the way</col>, <cd>to be an
obstacle or impediment.</cd> -- <col>To lie in wait</col> ,
<cd>to wait in concealment; to lie in ambush.</cd> --
<mcol><col>To lie on</col> <or/ <col>upon</col></mcol>.
<sd>(a)</sd> <cd>To depend on; <as>as, his life <ex>lies on<ex>
the result</as></cd>. <sd>(b)</sd> <cd>To bear, rest, press, or
weigh on.</cd> -- <col>To lie low</col>, <cd>to remain in
concealment or inactive.</cd> <mark>[Slang]</mark> -- <col>To lie
on hand</col>, <col>To lie on one's hands</col>, <cd>to remain
unsold or unused; <as>as, the goods are still <ex>lying on his
hands<ex>; they have too much time <ex>lying on their
hands<ex></as>.</cd> -- <col>To lie on the head of</col>, <cd>to
be imputed to.</cd></cs>

<q>What he gets more of her than sharp words, let it <qex>lie on
my head</qex>.</q>
<qau>Shak.</qau>

-- <col>To lie over</col>. <sd>(a)</sd> <cd>To remain unpaid
after the time when payment is due, as a note in bank.</cd>
<sd>(b)</sd> <cd>To be deferred to some future occasion, as a
resolution in a public deliberative body.</cd> -- <col>To lie
to</col> <fld>(Naut.)</fld>, <cd>to stop or delay; especially, to
head as near the wind as possible as being the position of
greatest safety in a gale; -- said of a ship. Cf. <cref>To bring
to</cref>, under <er>Bring</er>.</cd> -- <col>To lie under</col>,
<cd>to be subject to; to suffer; to be oppressed by.</cd> --
<col>To lie with</col>. <sd>(a)</sd> <cd>To lodge or sleep
with.</cd> <sd>(b)</sd> <cd>To have sexual intercourse with</cd>.
<sd>(c)</sd> <cd>To belong to; <as>as, it <ex>lies with</ex> you
to make amends</as>.</cd></cs>

<hw>Lie</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <def>The position or way
in which anything lies; the lay, as of land or country.</def>

<au>J. H. Newman.</au>

<q>He surveyed with his own eyes . . . the <qex>lie</qex> of the
country on the side towards Thrace.</q>
<qau>Jowett (Thucyd.).</qau>

<hw>Lie"ber*k\'81hn</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[Named
after a German physician and instrument maker, <ets>J</ets>.
<pos>n.</pos> <ets>Lieberk\'81hn</ets>.]</ety>
<fld>(Optics)</fld> <def>A concave metallic mirror attached to
the object-glass end of a microscope, to throw down light on
opaque objects; a reflector.</def>

<hw>Lie"ber*k\'81hn's glands`</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>. <ety>[See
<er>Lieberk\'81hn</er>.]</ety> <fld>(Anat.)</fld> <def>The simple
tubular glands of the small intestines; -- called also
<altname>crypts of Lieberk\'81hn</altname>.</def>

<hw>\'d8Lied</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> ; <plu>pl.
<plw>Lieder</plw> <pr>(#)</pr></plu>. <ety>[G.]</ety>
<fld>(Mus.)</fld> <def>A lay; a German song. It differs from the
French <xex>chanson</xex>, and the Italian <xex>canzone</xex>,
all three being national.</def>

<q>The German <qex>Lied</qex> is perhaps the most faithful
reflection of the national sentiment.</q>
<qau>Grove.</qau>

<hw>\'d8Lie"der*ta`fel</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[G.,
lit., a song table.]</ety> <fld>(Mus.)</fld> <def>A popular name
for any society or club which meets for the practice of male part
songs.</def>

<hw>Lief</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <def>Same as
<er>Lif</er>.</def>

<hw>Lief</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>a.</pos> <altsp>[Written also
<asp>lieve</asp>.]</altsp> <ety>[OE. <ets>leef</ets>,
<ets>lef</ets>, <ets>leof</ets>, AS. <ets>le\'a2f</ets>; akin to
OS.<ets>liof</ets>, OFries. <ets>liaf</ets>, D. <ets>lief</ets>,
G. <ets>lieb</ets>, OHG. <ets>liob</ets>, Icel.
<ets>lj<?/fr</ets>, Sw.<ets>ljuf</ets>, Goth. <ets>liubs</ets>,
and E. <ets>love</ets>. <root/124. See <er>Love</er>, and cf.
<er>Believe</er>, <er>Leave</er>, <pos>n.</pos>,
<er>Furlough</er>, <er>Libidinous</er>.]</ety> <sn>1.</sn>
<def>Dear; beloved. <mark>[Obs., except in poetry.]</mark> \'bdMy
<xex>liefe</xex> mother.\'b8 <au>Chaucer</au>. \'bdMy
<xex>liefest</xex> liege.\'b8 <au>Shak.</au></def>

<q>As thou art <qex>lief</qex> and dear.</q>
<qau>Tennyson.</qau>

<sn>2.</sn> <note>(Used with a form of the verb <xex>to be</xex>,
and the dative of the personal pronoun.)</note> <def>Pleasing;
agreeable; acceptable; preferable. <mark>[Obs.]</mark> See
<er>Lief</er>, <pos>adv.</pos>, and <xex>Had as lief</xex>, under
<er>Had</er>.</def>

<q>Full <qex>lief</qex> me were this counsel for to hide.</q>
<qau>Chaucer.</qau>

<q>Death me <qex>liefer</qex> were than such despite.</q>
<qau>Spenser.</qau>

<sn>3.</sn> <def>Willing; disposed.</def> <mark>[Obs.]</mark>

<q>I am not <qex>lief</qex> to gab.</q>
<qau>Chaucer.</qau>

<q>He up arose, however <qex>lief</qex> or loth.</q>
<qau>Spenser.</qau>

<hw>Lief</hw>, <pos>n.</pos> <def>A dear one; a sweetheart.</def>
<mark>[Obs.]</mark>

<au>Chaucer.</au>

<hw>Lief</hw>, <pos>adv.</pos> <def>Gladly; willingly; freely; --
now used only in the phrases, <xex>had as lief</xex>, and
<xex>would as lief</xex>; <as>as, I had, or would, as
<ex>lief</ex> go as not</as>.</def>

<q>All women <qex>liefest</qex> would
Be sovereign of man's love.</q>
<qau>Gower.</qau>

<q>I had as <qex>lief</qex> the town crier spoke my lines.</q>
<qau>Shak.</qau>

<q>Far <qex>liefer</qex> by his dear hand had I die.</q>
<qau>Tennyson.</qau>

<note><hand/ The comparative <xex>liefer</xex> with <xex>had or
would</xex>, and followed by the infinitive, either with or
without the sign <xex>to</xex>, signifies <xex>prefer</xex>,
<xex>choose as preferable</xex>, <xex>would</xex> or <xex>had
rather</xex>. In the 16th century <xex>rather</xex> was
substituted for <xex>liefer</xex> in such constructions in
literary English, and has continued to be generally so used. See
<cref>Had as lief</cref>, <cref>Had rather</cref>, etc. , under
<er>Had</er>.</note>

<hw>Lief"some</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>a.</pos> <def>Pleasing;
delightful.</def> <mark>[Obs.]</mark>

<hw>Lieg"ance</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <def>Same as
<er>Ligeance</er>.</def>

<hw>Liege</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>a.</pos> <ety>[OE.
<ets>lige</ets>, <ets>lege</ets>, F. <ets>lige</ets>, LL.
<ets>ligius</ets>, <ets>legius</ets>, liege, unlimited, complete,
prob. of German origin; cf. G. <ets>ledig</ets> free from bonds
and obstacles, MHG. <ets>ledec</ets>, <ets>ledic</ets>,
<ets>lidic</ets>, freed, loosed, and Charta Ottonis de Benthem,
ann. <?/ , \'bd<ets>ligius homo</ets> quod Teutonic\'8a dicitur
<ets>ledigman</ets>,\'b8 i. e., uni soli homagio obligatus, free
from all obligations to others; influenced by L.<ets>ligare</ets>
to bind. G. <ets>ledig</ets> perh. orig. meant, free to go where
one pleases, and is perh. akin to E.<ets>lead</ets> to conduct.
Cf. <er>Lead</er> to guide.]</ety> <sn>1.</sn> <def>Sovereign;
independent; having authority or right to allegiance; <as>as, a
<ex>liege</ex> lord</as>.</def>

<au>Chaucer.</au>

<q>She looked as grand as doomsday and as grave;
And he, he reverenced his <qex>liege</qex> lady there.</q>
<qau>Tennyson.</qau>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>serving an independent sovereign or master;
bound by a feudal tenure; obliged to be faithful and loyal to a
superior, as a vassal to his lord; faithful; loyal; <as>as, a
<ex>liege</ex> man; a <ex>liege</ex> subject.</as></def>

<sn>3.</sn> <fld>(Old Law)</fld> <def>Full; perfect; complete;
pure.</def> <au>Burrill</au>.

<cs><col>Liege homage</col> <fld>(Feudal Custom)</fld>, <cd>that
homage of one sovereign or prince to another which acknowledged
an obligation of fealty and services.</cd> -- <col>Liege
poustie</col> <ety>[L. <ets>legitima potestas<ets>]</ety>
<fld>(Scots Law)</fld>, <cd>perfect, <it>i. e.</it>, legal,
power; specif., having health requisite to do legal acts.</cd> --
<col>Liege widowhood</col>, <cd>perfect, <it>i. e.</it>, pure,
widowhood. <mark>[Obs.]</mark></cd></cs>

<hw>Liege</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <sn>1.</sn> <def>A
free and independent person; specif., a lord paramount; a
sovereign.</def> <au>Mrs. Browning</au>.

<q>The anointed sovereign of sighs and groans,
<qex>Liege</qex> of all loiterers and malcontents.</q>
<qau>Shak.</qau>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>The subject of a sovereign or lord; a
liegeman.</def>

<q>A liege lord seems to have been a lord of a free band; and his
<qex>lieges</qex>, though serving under him, were privileged men,
free from all other obligations, their name being due to their
freedom, not to their service.</q>
<qau>Skeat.</qau>

<hw>Lieu</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[F., OF. also

<hw>Lieu*ten"an*cy</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <sn>1.</sn>
<def>The office, rank, or commission, of a lieutenant.</def>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>The body of lieutenants or subordinates.</def>
<mark>[Obs.]</mark>

<q>The list of the <qex>lieutenancy</qex> of our metropolis.</q>
<qau>Felton.</qau>

<hw>Lieu*ten"ant</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[F., fr.
<ets>lieu</ets> place + <ets>tenant</ets> holding, p. pr. of
<ets>tenir</ets> to hold, L. <ets>tenere</ets>. See
<er>Lieu</er>, and <er>Tenant</er>, and cf. <er>Locum
tenens</er>.]</ety> <sn>1.</sn> <def>An officer who supplies the
place of a superior in his absence; a representative of, or
substitute for, another in the performance of any duty.</def>

<q>The lawful magistrate, who is the vicegerent or
<qex>lieutenant</qex> of God.</q>
<qau>Abp. Bramhall.</qau>

<sn>2.</sn> <sd>(a)</sd> <def>A commissioned officer in the army,
next below a captain.</def> <sd>(b)</sd> <def>A commissioned
officer in the British navy, in rank next below a
commander.</def> <sd>(c)</sd> <def>A commissioned officer in the
United States navy, in rank next below a lieutenant
commander.</def>

<note><hand/ <xex>Lieutenant</xex> is often used, either
adjectively or in hyphened compounds, to denote an officer, in
rank next below another, especially when the duties of the higher
officer may devolve upon the lower one; as, <xex>lieutenant</xex>
general, or <xex>lieutenant-</xex>general; <xex>lieutenant</xex>
colonel, or <xex>lieutenant-</xex>colonel; <xex>lieutenant</xex>
governor, etc.</note>

<cs><col>Deputy lieutenant</col>, <cd>the title of any one of the
deputies or assistants of the lord lieutenant of a county.</cd>
<mark>[Eng.]</mark> -- <col>Lieutenant colonel</col>, <cd>an army
officer next in rank above major, and below colonel.</cd> --
<col>Lieutenant commander</col>, <cd>an officer in the United
States navy, in rank next below a commander and next above a
lieutenant.</cd> -- <col>Lieutenant general</col>. <cd>See in
Vocabulary.</cd> -- <col>Lieutenant governor</col>. <sd>(a)</sd>
<cd>An officer of a State, being next in rank to the governor,
and in case of the death or resignation of the latter, himself
acting as governor</cd>. <mark>[U. S.]</mark> <sd>(b)</sd> <cd>A
deputy governor acting as the chief civil officer of one of
several colonies under a governor general.
<mark>[Eng.]</mark></cd></cs>

<hw>Lieu*ten"ant gen"er*al</hw> <pr>(?)</pr><def>. An army
officer in rank next below a general and next above a major
general.</def>

<note><hand/ In the United States, before the civil war, this
rank had been conferred only on George Washington and (in brevet)
on Winfield Scott. In 1864 it was revived by Congress and
conferred on Ulysses S. Grant, and subsequently, by promotion, on
William T. Sherman and Philip H. Sheridan, each of whom was
advanced to the rank of <cref>general of the army</cref>. When
Sheridan was made general (in 1888) the rank of lieutenant
general was suffered to lapse. See <er>General</er>.</note>

<hw>Lieu*ten"ant*ry</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <def>See
<er>Lieutenancy</er>.</def> <mark>[Obs.]</mark>

<hw>Lieu*ten"ant*ship</hw>, <pos>n.</pos> <def>Same as
<er>Lieutenancy</er>, 1.</def>

<hw>Lieve</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>a.</pos> <def>Same as
<er>Lief</er>.</def>

<hw>Lif</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[Written also
<ets>lief</ets>.]</ety> <def>The fiber by which the petioles of
the date palm are bound together, from which various kinds of
cordage are made.</def>

<hw>Life</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos>; <plu>pl.
<plw>Lives</plw> <pr>(#)</pr></plu>. <ety>[AS. <ets>l<?/f</ets>;
akin to D. <ets>lijf</ets> body, G. <ets>leib</ets> body, MHG.
<ets>l<?/p</ets> life, body, OHG. <ets>l<?/b</ets> life, Icel.
<ets>l<?/f</ets>, life, body, Sw. <ets>lif</ets>, Dan.
<ets>liv</ets>, and E. <ets>live</ets>, v. <?/. See
<er>Live</er>, and cf. <er>Alive</er>.]</ety> <sn>1.</sn>
<def>The state of being which begins with generation, birth, or
germination, and ends with death; also, the time during which
this state continues; that state of an animal or plant in which
all or any of its organs are capable of performing all or any of
their functions; -- used of all animal and vegetable
organisms.</def>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>Of human being: The union of the soul and body;
also, the duration of their union; sometimes, the deathless
quality or existence of the soul; <as>as, man is a creature
having an immortal <ex>life</ex></as>.</def>

<q>She shows a body rather than a <qex>life</qex>.</q>
<qau>Shak.</qau>

<sn>3.</sn> <fld>(Philos)</fld> <def>The potential principle, or
force, by which the organs of animals and plants are started and
continued in the performance of their several and co\'94perative
functions; the vital force, whether regarded as physical or
spiritual.</def>

<sn>4.</sn> <def>Figuratively: The potential or animating
principle, also, the period of duration, of anything that is
conceived of as resembling a natural organism in structure or
functions; <as>as, the <ex>life</ex> of a state, a machine, or a
book; authority is the <ex>life</ex> of government.</as></def>

<sn>5.</sn> <def>A certain way or manner of living with respect
to conditions, circumstances, character, conduct, occupation,
etc.; hence, human affairs; also, lives, considered collectively,
as a distinct class or type; <as>as, low <ex>life</ex>; a good or
evil <ex>life</ex>; the <ex>life</ex> of Indians, or of
miners.</as></def>

<q>That which before us lies in daily <qex>life</qex>.</q>
<qau>Milton.</qau>

<q>By experience of <qex>life</qex> abroad in the world.</q>
<qau>Ascham.</qau>

<q><qex>Lives</qex> of great men all remind us
We can make our <qex>lives</qex> sublime.</q>
<qau>Longfellow.</qau>

<q>'T is from high <qex>life</qex> high characters are drawn.</q>
<qau>Pope</qau>

<sn>6.</sn> <def>Animation; spirit; vivacity; vigor;
energy.</def>

<q>No notion of <qex>life</qex> and fire in fancy and in
words.</q>
<qau>Felton.</qau>

<q>That gives thy gestures grace and <qex>life</qex>.</q>
<qau>Wordsworth.</qau>

<sn>7.</sn> <def>That which imparts or excites spirit or vigor;
that upon which enjoyment or success depends; <as>as, he was the
<ex>life</ex> of the company, or of the enterprise</as>.</def>

<sn>8.</sn> <def>The living or actual form, person, thing, or
state; <as>as, a picture or a description from, the
<ex>life</ex></as>.</def>

<sn>9.</sn> <def>A person; a living being, usually a human being;
<as>as, many <ex>lives</ex> were sacrificed</as>.</def>

<sn>10.</sn> <def>The system of animal nature; animals in
general, or considered collectively.</def>

<q>Full nature swarms with <qex>life</qex>.</q>
<qau>Thomson.</qau>

<sn>11.</sn> <def>An essential constituent of life, esp: the
blood.</def>

<q>The words that I speak unto you . . . they are
<qex>life</qex>.</q>
<qau>John vi. 63.</qau>

<q>The warm <qex>life</qex> came issuing through the wound.</q>
<qau>Pope</qau>

<sn>12.</sn> <def>A history of the acts and events of a life; a
biography; <as>as, Johnson wrote the <ex>life</ex> of
Milton</as>.</def>

<sn>13.</sn> <def>Enjoyment in the right use of the powers;
especially, a spiritual existence; happiness in the favor of God;
heavenly felicity.</def>

<sn>14.</sn> <def>Something dear to one as one's existence; a
darling; -- used as a term of endearment.</def>

<note><hand/ <xex>Life</xex> forms the first part of many
compounds, for the most part of obvious meaning; as,
<xex>life-</xex>giving, <xex>life-</xex>sustaining, etc.</note>

<cs><col>Life annuity</col>, <cd>an annuity payable during one's
life.</cd> -- <mcol><col>Life arrow</col>, <col>Life
rocket</col>, <col>Life shot</col></mcol>, <cd>an arrow, rocket,
or shot, for carrying an attached line to a vessel in distress in
order to save life.</cd> -- <col>Life assurance</col>. See
<cref>Life insurance</cref>, below. <-- no life boat?--> --
<col>Life buoy</col></mcol>. <cd>See <er>Buoy</er>.</cd> --
<col>Life car</col>, <cd>a water-tight boat or box, traveling on
a line from a wrecked vessel to the shore. In it person are
hauled through the waves and surf.</cd> -- <col>Life drop</col>,
<cd>a drop of vital blood. <au>Byron</au>.</cd> -- <col>Life
estate</col> <fld>(Law)</fld>, <cd>an estate which is held during
the term of some certain person's life, but does not pass by
inheritance.</cd> -- <col>Life everlasting</col>
<fld>(Bot.)</fld>, <cd>a plant with white or yellow persistent
scales about the heads of the flowers, as <spn>Antennaria</spn>,
and <spn>Gnaphalium</spn>; cudweed.</cd> -- <col>Life of an
execution</col> <fld>(Law)</fld>, <cd>the period when an
execution is in force, or before it expires.</cd> -- <col>Life
guard</col>. <fld>(Mil.)</fld> <cd>See under <er>Guard</er>.</cd>
-- <col>Life insurance</col>, <cd>the act or system of insuring
against death; a contract by which the insurer undertakes, in
consideration of the payment of a premium (usually at stated
periods), to pay a stipulated sum in the event of the death of
the insured or of a third person in whose life the insured has an
interest.</cd> -- <col>Life interest</col>, <cd>an estate or
interest which lasts during one's life, or the life of another
person, but does not pass by inheritance.</cd> -- <col>Life
land</col> <fld>(Law)</fld>, <cd>land held by lease for the term
of a life or lives.</cd> -- <col>Life line</col>. <sd>(a)</sd>
<fld>(Naut.)</fld> <cd>A line along any part of a vessel for the
security of sailors</cd>. <sd>(b)</sd> <cd>A line attached to a
life boat, or to any life saving apparatus, to be grasped by a
person in the water.</cd> -- <col>Life rate</col>, <cd>rate of
premium for insuring a life.</cd> -- <col>Life rent</col>,
<cd>the rent of a life estate; rent or property to which one is
entitled during one's life.</cd> -- <col>Life school</col>, <cd>a
school for artists in which they model, paint, or draw from
living models.</cd> -- <col>Lifetable</col>, <cd>a table showing
the probability of life at different ages.</cd> -- <col>To lose
one's life</col>, <cd>to die.</cd> -- <col>To seek the life
of</col>, <cd>to seek to kill.</cd> -- <col>To the life</col>,
<cd>so as closely to resemble the living person or the subject;
<as>as, the portrait was drawn <ex>to the
life<ex></as>.</cd></cs>

<qau>Swift.</qau>

<hw>Life"boat`</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <def>A strong,
buoyant boat especially designed for saving the lives of
shipwrecked people.</def>

<hw>Life"ful</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>a.</pos> <def>Full of
vitality.</def>

<au>Spenser.</au>

<hw>Life"-giv`ing</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>a.</pos> <def>Giving
life or spirit; having power to give life; inspiriting;
invigorating.</def>

<hw>Life"hold`</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <def>Land held by
a life estate.</def>

<hw>Life"less</hw>, <pos>a.</pos> <def>Destitute of life, or
deprived of life; not containing, or inhabited by, living beings
or vegetation; dead, or apparently dead; spiritless; powerless;
dull; <as>as, a <ex>lifeless</ex> carcass; <ex>lifeless</ex>
matter; a <ex>lifeless</ex> desert; a <ex>lifeless</ex> wine; a
<ex>lifeless</ex> story.</as></def> --
<wordforms><wf>Life"less*ly</wf>, <pos>adv.</pos> --
<wf>Life"less*ness</wf>, <pos>n.</pos></wordforms>

<syn>Syn. -- Dead; soulless; inanimate; torpid; inert; inactive;
dull; heavy; unanimated; spiritless; frigid; pointless; vapid;
flat; tasteless.</syn> <usage> -- <er>Lifeless</er>,
<er>Dull</er>, <er>Inanimate</er>, <er>Dead</er>. In a moral
sense, <xex>lifeless</xex> denotes a want of vital energy;
<xex>inanimate</xex>, a want of expression as to any feeling that
may be possessed; <xex>dull</xex> implies a torpor of soul which
checks all mental activity; <xex>dead</xex> supposes a
destitution of feeling. A person is said to be
<xex>lifeless</xex> who has lost the spirits which he once had;
he is said to be <xex>inanimate</xex> when he is naturally
wanting in spirits; one is <xex>dull</xex> from an original
deficiency of mental power; he who is <xex>dead</xex> to moral
sentiment is wholly bereft of the highest attribute of his
nature.</usage>

<hw>Life"like`</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>a.</pos> <ety>[Cf.
<er>Lively</er>.]</ety> <def>Like a living being; resembling
life; giving an accurate representation; <as>as, a
<ex>lifelike</ex> portrait</as>.</def> --
<wordforms><wf>Life"like`ness</wf>, <pos>n.</pos></wordforms>

<au>Poe.</au>

<hw>Life"long</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>a.</pos>

<hw>Lift</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos><ety>[AS.<ets>lyft</ets>

<hw>Lift</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>v. t.</pos>
<wordforms>[<pos>imp. & p. p.</pos> <er>Lifted</er>; <pos>p. pr.
& vb. n.</pos> <er>Lifting</er>.]</wordforms> <ety>[Icel.
<ets>lypta</ets>, fr. <ets>lopt</ets> air; akin to
Sw.<ets>lyfta</ets> to lift, Dan. <ets>l\'94fte</ets>, G.
<ets>l\'81ften</ets>; -- prop., to raise into the air. See
<er>Loft</er>, and cf. 1st <er>Lift</er>.]</ety> <sn>1.</sn>
<def>To move in a direction opposite to that of gravitation; to
raise; to elevate; to bring up from a lower place to a higher; to
upheave; sometimes implying a continued support or holding in the
higher place; -- said of material things; <as>as, to
<ex>lift</ex> the foot or the hand; to <ex>lift</ex> a chair or a
burden</as>.</def>

<-- p. 851 -->

<sn>2.</sn> <def>To raise, elevate, exalt, improve, in rank,
condition, estimation, character, etc.; -- often with
<xex>up</xex>.</def>

<q>The Roman virtues <qex>lift</qex> up mortal man.</q>
<qau>Addison.</qau>

<q>Lest, being <qex>lifted</qex> up with pride.</q>
<qau>I Tim. iii. 6.</qau>

<sn>3.</sn> <def>To bear; to support.</def> <mark>[Obs.]</mark>

<au>Spenser.</au>

<sn>4.</sn> <def>To collect, as moneys due; to raise.</def>

<sn>5.</sn> <ety>[Perh. a different word, and akin to Goth.
<ets>hliftus</ets> thief, <ets>hlifan</ets> to steal, L.
<ets>clepere</ets>, Gr. <?/. Cf. <er>Shoplifter</er>.]</ety>
<def>To steal; to carry off by theft (esp. cattle); <as>as, to
<ex>lift</ex> a drove of cattle</as>.</def>

<note><hand/ In old writers, <xex>lift</xex> is sometimes used
for <xex>lifted</xex>.</note>

<q>He ne'er <qex>lift</qex> up his hand but conquered.</q>
<qau>Shak.</qau>

<cs><col>To lift up</col>, <cd>to raise or elevate; in the
Scriptures, specifically, to elevate upon the cross. <au>John
viii. 28</au>.</cd> -- <col>To lift up the eyes</col>. <cd>To
look up; to raise the eyes, as in prayer. <au>Ps. cxxi.
1</au>.</cd> -- <col>To lift up the feet</col>, <cd>to come
speedily to one's relief. <au>Ps. lxxiv. 3</au>.</cd> -- <col>To
lift up the hand</col>. <sd>(a)</sd> <cd>To take an oath</cd>.
<au>Gen. xiv. 22</au>. <sd>(b)</sd> <cd>To pray.</cd> <au>Ps.
xxviii. 2</au>. <sd>(c)</sd> <cd>To engage in duty.</cd> <au>Heb.
xii. 12</au>.</cd> -- <col>To lift up the hand against</col>,
<cd>to rebel against; to assault; to attack; to injure; to
oppress. <au>Job xxxi. 21</au>.</cd> -- <col>To lift up one's
head</col>, <cd>to cause one to be exalted or to rejoice.
<au>Gen. xl. 13</au>. <au>Luke xxi. 28</au>.</cd> -- <col>To lift
up the heel against</col>, <cd>to treat with insolence or
unkindness. <au>John xiii.18</au>.</cd> -- <col>To lift up the
voice</col>, <cd>to cry aloud; to call out. <au>Gen. xxi.
16</au>.</cd></cs>

<hw>Lift</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>v. i.</pos> <sn>1.</sn> <def>To
try to raise something; to exert the strength for raising or
bearing.</def>

<q>Strained by <qex>lifting</qex> at a weight too heavy.</q>
<qau>Locke.</qau>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>To rise; to become or appear raised or elevated;
<as>as, the fog <ex>lifts</ex>; the land <ex>lifts</ex> to a ship
approaching it.</as></def>

<sn>3.</sn> <ety>[See <er>Lift</er>, <pos>v. t.</pos>, 5.]</ety>
<def>To live by theft.</def>

<au>Spenser.</au>

<hw>Lift</hw>, <pos>n.</pos> <sn>1.</sn> <def>Act of lifting;
also, that which is lifted.</def>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>The space or distance through which anything is
lifted; <as>as, a long <ex>lift</ex></as>.</def>

<au>Bacon.</au>

<sn>3.</sn> <def>Help; assistance, as by lifting; <as>as, to give
one a <ex>lift</ex> in a wagon</as>.</def> <mark>[Colloq.]</mark>

<q>The goat gives the fox a <qex>lift</qex>.</q>
<qau>L'Estrange.</qau>

<-- 3b. a ride in a vehicle, given by the vehicle's owner to
another person as a favor -- usually in "give a lift" or "got a
lift", as "Jack gave me a lift into town." -->

<sn>4.</sn> <def>That by means of which a person or thing lifts
or is lifted</def>; as: <sd>(a)</sd> <def>A hoisting machine; an
elevator; a dumb waiter</def>. <sd>(b)</sd> <def>An exercising
machine.</def>

<sn>5.</sn> <def>A rise; a degree of elevation; <as>as, the
<ex>lift</ex> of a lock in canals</as>.</def>

<sn>6.</sn> <def>A lift gate. See <cref>Lift gate</cref>,
below.</def> <mark>[Prov. Eng.]</mark>

<sn>7.</sn> <fld>(Naut.)</fld> <def>A rope leading from the
masthead to the extremity of a yard below; -- used for raising or
supporting the end of the yard.</def>

<sn>8.</sn> <fld>(Mach.)</fld> <def>One of the steps of a cone
pulley.</def>

<sn>9.</sn> <fld>(Shoemaking)</fld> <def>A layer of leather in
the heel.</def>

<sn>10.</sn> <fld>(Horology)</fld> <def>That portion of the
vibration of a balance during which the impulse is given.</def>

<au>Saunier.</au>

<cs><col>Dead lift</col>. <cd>See under <er>Dead</er>.
<au>Swift</au>.</cd> -- <col>Lift bridge</col>, <cd>a kind of
drawbridge, the movable part of which is lifted, instead of being
drawn aside.</cd> -- <col>Lift gate</col>, <cd>a gate that is
opened by lifting.</cd> -- <col>Lift hammer</col>. <cd>See
<er>Tilt hammer</er>.</cd> -- <col>Lift lock</col>, <cd>a canal
lock.</cd> -- <col>Lift pump</col>, <cd>a lifting pump.</cd> --
<col>Lift tenter</col> <fld>(Windmills)</fld>, <cd>a governor for
regulating the speed by adjusting the sails, or for adjusting the
action of grinding machinery according to the speed.</cd> --
<col>Lift wall</col> <fld>(Canal Lock)</fld>, <cd>the cross wall
at the head of the lock.</cd></cs>

<hw>Lift"a*ble</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>a.</pos><def>Such as can
be lifted.</def>

<hw>Lift"er</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <sn>1.</sn> <def>One
who, or that which, lifts.</def>

<sn>2.</sn> <fld>(Founding)</fld> <def>A tool for lifting loose
sand from the mold; also, a contrivance attached to a cope, to
hold the sand together when the cope is lifted.</def>

<hw>Lift"ing</hw>, <pos>a.</pos> <def>Used in, or for, or by,
lifting.</def>

<cs><col>Lifting bridge</col>, <cd>a lift bridge.</cd> --
<col>Lifting jack</col>. <cd>See 2d <er>Jack</er>, 5.</cd> --
<col>Lifting machine</col>. <cd>See <cref>Health lift</cref>,
under <er>Health</er>.</cd> -- <col>Lifting pump</col>.
<fld>(Mach.)</fld> <sd>(a)</sd> <cd>A kind of pump having a
bucket, or valved piston, instead of a solid piston, for drawing
water and lifting it to a high level</cd>. <sd>(b)</sd> <cd>A
pump which lifts the water only to the top of the pump, or
delivers it through a spout; a lift pump.</cd> -- <col>Lifting
rod</col>, <cd>a vertical rod lifted by a rock shaft, and
imparting motion to a puppet valve; -- used in the engines of
river steamboats.</cd> -- <col>Lifting sail</col>
<fld>(Naut.)</fld>, <cd>one which tends to lift a vessel's bow
out of water, as jibs and square foresails.</cd></cs>

<hw>Lig</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>v. i.</pos> <ety>[See

<au>Chaucer. Spenser.</au>

<hw>Lig"a*ment</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[L.
<ets>ligamentum</ets>, fr. <ets>ligare</ets> to bind; cf. f.
<ets>ligament</ets>. Cf. <er>Lien</er>, <pos>n.</pos>,
<er>Ligature</er>.]</ety> <sn>1.</sn> <def>Anything that ties or
unites one thing or part to another; a bandage; a bond.</def>

<au>Hawthorne.</au>

<q>Interwoven is the love of liberty with every
<qex>ligament</qex> of your hearts.</q>
<qau>Washington.</qau>

<sn>2.</sn> <fld>(Anat.)</fld> <sd>(a)</sd> <def>A tough band or
plate of dense, fibrous, connective tissue or fibrocartilage
serving to unite bones or form joints.</def> <sd>(b)</sd> <def>A
band of connective tissue, or a membranous fold, which supports
or retains an organ in place; <as>as, the gastrophrenic
<ex>ligament</ex>, connecting the diaphragm and
stomach</as>.</def>

<mhw>{ <hw>Lig`a*men"tal</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>,
<hw>Lig"a*men"tous</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, }</mhw> <pos>a.</pos>

<ex>ligamentous</ex> membrane</as>.</def>

<hw>Li"gan</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos><ety>[Cf. L.

<hw>Lig"a*ture</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[L.
<ets>ligatura</ets>, fr. <ets>ligare</ets>, <ets>ligatum</ets>,
to bind: cf. f. <ets>ligature</ets>. Cf. <er>Ally</er>,

<sn>3.</sn> <fld>(Surg.)</fld> <sd>(a)</sd> <def>A thread or
string for tying the blood vessels, particularly the arteries, to
prevent hemorrhage.</def> <sd>(b)</sd> <def>A thread or wire used
to remove tumors, etc.</def>

<sn>4.</sn> <def>The state of being bound or stiffened;
stiffness; <as>as, the <ex>ligature</ex> of a joint</as>.</def>

<sn>5.</sn> <def>Impotence caused by magic or charms.</def>
<mark>[Obs.]</mark>

<sn>6.</sn> <fld>(Mus.)</fld> <def>A curve or line connecting
notes; a slur.</def>

<sn>7.</sn> <fld>(Print.)</fld> <def>A double character, or a
type consisting of two or more letters or characters united, as
<it>\'91</it>, <it><filig/</it>, <it><ffllig/</it>.</def>

<fld>(Surg.)</fld> <def>To ligate; to tie.</def>

<hw>Lig"e</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>v. t. & i.</pos> <def>To lie;
to tell lies.</def> <mark>[Obs.]</mark>

<hw>Li"geance</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[OF.
<ets>ligeance</ets>, <ets>ligance</ets>. See
<er>Liege</er>.]</ety> <fld>(O. Eng. Law)</fld> <def>The
connection between sovereign and subject by which they were
mutually bound, the former to protection and the securing of

<altsp>[Written also <asp>ligeancy</asp> and

<hw>Lig"ger</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <sn>1.</sn> <def>A
