<sn>2.</sn> <def>See <er>Ledger</er>, 2.</def>

<hw>Light</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos>
<ety>[OE.<ets>light</ets>, <ets>liht</ets>, AS.
<ets>le\'a2t</ets>; akin to OS. <ets>lioht</ets>, D. & G.
<ets>licht</ets>, OHG. <ets>lioht</ets>, Goth. <ets>liuhap</ets>,
Icel. <ets>lj<?/s</ets>, L. <ets>lux</ets> light,
<ets>lucere</ets> to shine, Gr. <?/ white, Skr. <ets>ruc</ets> to
shine. <?/. Cf. <er>Lucid</er>, <er>Lunar</er>,
<er>Luminous</er>, <er>Lynx</er>.]</ety> <sn>1.</sn> <def>That
agent, force, or action in nature by the operation of which upon
the organs of sight, objects are rendered visible or
luminous.</def>

<note><hand/ <xex>Light</xex> was regarded formerly as consisting
of material particles, or corpuscules, sent off in all directions
from luminous bodies, and traversing space, in right lines, with
the known velocity of about 186,300 miles per second; but it is
now generally understood to consist, not in any actual
transmission of particles or substance, but in the propagation of
vibrations or undulations in a subtile, elastic medium, or ether,
assumed to pervade all space, and to be thus set in vibratory
motion by the action of luminous bodies, as the atmosphere is by
sonorous bodies. This view of the nature of light is known as the
<xex>undulatory or wave theory</xex>; the other, advocated by
Newton (but long since abandoned), as the <xex>corpuscular</xex>,
<xex>emission</xex>, or <xex>Newtonian theory</xex>. A more
recent theory makes light to consist in electrical oscillations,
and is known as the <xex>electro-magnetic theory</xex> of
light.</note>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>That which furnishes, or is a source of, light,
as the sun, a star, a candle, a lighthouse, etc.</def>

<q>Then he called for a <qex>light</qex>, and sprang in.</q>
<qau>Acts xvi. 29.</qau>

<q>And God made two great <qex>lights</qex>; the greater
<qex>light</qex> to rule the day, and the lesser <qex>light</qex>
to rule the night.</q>
<qau>Gen. i. 16.</qau>

<sn>3.</sn> <def>The time during which the light of the sun is
visible; day; especially, the dawn of day.</def>

<q>The murderer, rising with the <qex>light</qex>, killeth the
poor and needy.</q>
<qau>Job xxiv. 14.</qau>

<sn>4.</sn> <def>The brightness of the eye or eyes.</def>

<q>He seemed to find his way without his eyes;
For out o'door he went without their helps,
And, to the last, bended their <qex>light</qex> on me.</q>
<qau>Shak.</qau>

<sn>5.</sn> <def>The medium through which light is admitted, as a
window, or window pane; a skylight; in architecture, one of the
compartments of a window made by a mullion or mullions.</def>

<q>There were windows in three rows, and <qex>light</qex> was
against <qex>light</qex> in three ranks.</q>
<qau>I Kings vii.4.</qau>

<sn>6.</sn> <def>Life; existence.</def>

<q>O, spring to <qex>light</qex>, auspicious Babe, be born !</q>
<qau>Pope.</qau>

<sn>7.</sn> <def>Open view; a visible state or condition; public
observation; publicity.</def>

<q>The duke yet would have dark deeds darkly answered; he would
never bring them to <qex>light</qex>.</q>
<qau>Shak.</qau>

<sn>8.</sn> <def>The power of perception by vision.</def>

<q>My strength faileth me; as for the <qex>light</qex> of my
eyes, it also is gone from me.</q>
<qau>Ps. xxxviii. 10.</qau>

<sn>9.</sn> <def>That which illumines or makes clear to the mind;
mental or spiritual illumination; enlightenment; knowledge;
information.</def>

<q>He shall never know
That I had any <qex>light</qex> of this from thee.</q>
<qau>Shak.</qau>

<sn>10.</sn> <def>Prosperity; happiness; joy; felicity.</def>

<q>Then shall thy <qex>light</qex> break forth as the morning,
and thy health shall spring forth speedily.</q>
<qau>Is. lviii. 8.</qau>

<sn>11.</sn> <fld>(Paint.)</fld> <def>The manner in which the
light strikes upon a picture; that part of a picture which
represents those objects upon which the light is supposed to
fall; the more illuminated part of a landscape or other scene; --
opposed to <xex>shade</xex>. Cf. <er>Chiaroscuro</er>.</def>

<sn>12.</sn> <def>Appearance due to the particular facts and
circumstances presented to view; point of view; <as>as, to state
things fairly and put them in the right
<ex>light</ex></as>.</def>

<q>Frequent consideration of a thing . . . shows it in its
several <qex>lights</qex> and various ways of appearance.</q>
<qau>South.</qau>

<sn>13.</sn> <def>One who is conspicuous or noteworthy; a model
or example; <as>as, the <ex>lights</ex> of the age or of
antiquity</as>.</def>

<q>Joan of Are,
A <qex>light</qex> of ancient France.</q>
<qau>Tennyson.</qau>

<sn>14.</sn> <fld>(Pyrotech.)</fld> <def>A firework made by
filling a case with a substance which burns brilliantly with a
white or colored flame; <as>as, a Bengal
<ex>light</ex></as>.</def>

<note><hand/ <xex>Light</xex> is used figuratively to denote that
which resembles physical light in any respect, as illuminating,
benefiting, enlightening, or enlivening mankind.</note>

<cs><mcol><col>Ancient lights</col> <fld>(Law)</fld>,
<col>Calcium light</col>, <col>Flash light</col>, etc.</mcol>
<cd>See under <er>Ancient</er>, <er>Calcium</er>, etc.</cd> --
<col>Light ball</col> <fld>(Mil.)</fld>, <cd>a ball of
combustible materials, used to afford light; -- sometimes made so
as to fired from a cannon or mortar, or to be carried up by a
rocket.</cd> -- <col>Light barrel</col> <fld>(Mil.)</fld>, <cd>an
empty power barrel pierced with holes and filled with shavings
soaked in pitch, used to light up a ditch or a breach.</cd> --
<col>Light dues</col> <fld>(Com.)</fld>, <cd>tolls levied on
ships navigating certain waters, for the maintenance of
lighthouses.</cd> -- <col>Light iron</col>, <cd>a
candlestick.</cd> <mark>[Obs.]</mark> -- <col>Light keeper</col>,
<cd>a person appointed to take care of a lighthouse or
light-ship.</cd> -- <col>Light money</col>, <cd>charges laid by
government on shipping entering a port, for the maintenance of
lighthouses and light-ships.</cd> -- <col>The light of the
countenance</col>, <cd>favor; kindness; smiles.</cd></cs>

<q>Lord, lift thou up <qex>the light of thy countenance</qex>
upon us.</q>
<qau>Ps. iv. 6.</qau>

-- <col>Northern lights</col>. <cd>See <cref>Aurora
borealis</cref>, under <er>Aurora</er>.</cd> -- <col>To bring to
light</col>, <cd>to cause to be disclosed.</cd> -- <col>To come
to light</col>, <cd>to be disclosed.</cd> -- <col>To see the
light</col>, <cd>to come into the light; hence, to come into the
world or public notice; <as>as, his book never <ex>saw the
light</ex></as>.</cd><-- also, see the light of day; (b) to come
to understand (sometimes used ironically, said of a person who
professes to change his opinion after he has been convinced that
it will be in his own interest if the facts are different from
his initial beliefs) -->  -- <col>To stand in one's own
light</col>, <cd>to take a position which is injurious to one's
own interest.</cd></cs>

<hw>Light</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>a.</pos> <ety>[AS.
<ets>le\'a2ht</ets>. See <er>Light</er>, <pos>n.</pos>]</ety>
<wordforms>[<pos>Compar</pos>. <er>Lighter</er> <pr>(#)</pr>;
<pos>superl</pos>. <er>Lightest</er>.]</wordforms> <sn>1.</sn>
<def>Having light; not dark or obscure; bright; clear; <as>as,
the apartment is <ex>light</ex></as>.</def>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>White or whitish; not intense or very marked;
not of a deep shade; moderately colored; <as>as, a <ex>light</ex>
color; a <ex>light</ex> brown; a <ex>light</ex>
complexion.</as></def>

<hw>Light</hw>, <pos>v. t.</pos> <wordforms>[<pos>imp. & p.
p.</pos> <er>Lighted</er> <pr>(?)</pr> or <er>Lit</er> (<?/);
<pos>p. pr. & vb. n.</pos> <er>Lighting</er>.]</wordforms>
<ety>[AS. <ets>l<?/htan</ets>, <ets>l\'c6htan</ets>, to shine.
<?/. See <er>Light</er>, <pos>n.</pos>]</ety> <sn>1.</sn> <def>To
set fire to; to cause to burn; to set burning; to ignite; to
kindle; <as>as, to <ex>light</ex> a candle or lamp; to
<ex>light</ex> the gas</as>; -- sometimes with
<ptcl>up</ptcl>.</def>

<q>If a thousand candles be all <qex>lighted</qex> from one.</q>
<qau>Hakewill.</qau>

<q>And the largest lamp is <qex>lit</qex>.</q>
<qau>Macaulay.</qau>

<q>Absence might cure it, or a second mistress
<qex>Light</qex> up another flame, and put out this.</q>
<qau>Addison.</qau>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>To give light to; to illuminate; to fill with
light; to spread over with light; -- often with
<xex>up</xex>.</def>

<q>Ah, hopeless, lasting flames I like those that burn
To <qex>light</qex> the dead.</q>
<qau>Pope.</qau>

<q>One hundred years ago, to have <qex>lit</qex> this theater as
brilliantly as it is now <qex>lighted</qex> would have cost, I
suppose, fifty pounds.</q>
<qau>F. Harrison.</qau>

<q>The sun has set, and Vesper, to supply
His absent beams, has <qex>lighted</qex> up the sky.</q>
<qau>Dryden.</qau>

<sn>3.</sn> <def>To attend or conduct with a light; to show the
way to by means of a light.</def>

<q>His bishops lead him forth, and <qex>light</qex> him on.</q>
<qau>Landor.</qau>

<cs><col>To light a fire</col>, <cd>to kindle the material of a
fire.</cd></cs>

<hw>Light</hw>, <pos>v. i.</pos> <sn>1.</sn> <def>To become
ignited; to take fire; <as>as, the match will not
<ex>light</ex></as>.</def>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>To be illuminated; to receive light; to
brighten; -- with <xex>up</xex>; <as>as, the room <ex>light</ex>
up very well</as>.</def>

<hw>Light</hw>, <pos>a.</pos> <wordforms>[<pos>Compar.</pos>
<er>Lighted</er> <pr>(?)</pr>; <pos>superl.</pos>
<er>Lightest</er>.]</wordforms> <ety>[OE. <ets>light</ets>,
<ets>liht</ets>, AS. <ets>l\'c6ht</ets>, <ets>le\'a2ht</ets>;
akin to D. <ets>ligt</ets>, G. <ets>leicht</ets>,
OHG.<ets>l\'c6hti</ets>, Icel. <ets>l<?/ttr</ets>, Dan.
<ets>let</ets>, Sw. <ets>l\'84tt</ets>, Goth. <ets>leihts</ets>,
and perh. to L. <ets>levis</ets> (cf. <er>Levity</er>), Gr. <?/
small, Skr. <ets>laghu</ets> light. <?/. ]</ety> <sn>1.</sn>
<def>Having little, or comparatively little, weight; not tending
to be the center of gravity with force; not heavy.</def>

<q>These weights did not exert their natural gravity . . .
insomuch that I could not guess which was <qex>light</qex> or
heavy whilst I held them in my hand.</q>
<qau>Addison.</qau>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>Not burdensome; easy to be lifted, borne, or
carried by physical strength; <as>as, a <ex>light</ex> burden, or
load</as>.</def>

<q>Ye shall find rest unto your souls. For my yoke is easy, and
my burden is <qex>light</qex>.</q>
<qau>Matt. xi. 29. 30.</qau>

<sn>3.</sn> <def>Easy to be endured or performed; not severe; not
difficult; <as>as, a <ex>light</ex> affliction or
task</as>.</def>

<au>Chaucer.</au>

<q><qex>Light</qex> sufferings give us leisure to complain.</q>
<qau>Dryden.</qau>

<sn>4.</sn> <def>Easy to be digested; not oppressive to the
stomach; <as>as, <ex>light</ex> food</as>; also, containing
little nutriment.</def>

<sn>5.</sn> <def>Not heavily armed; armed with light weapons;
<as>as, <ex>light</ex> troops; a troop of <ex>light</ex>
horse.</as></def>

<sn>6.</sn> <def>Not encumbered; unembarrassed; clear of
impediments; hence, active; nimble; swift.</def>

<q>Unmarried men are best friends, best masters . . . but not
always best subjects, for they are <qex>light</qex> to run
away.</q>
<qau>Bacon.</qau>

<sn>7.</sn> <def>Not heavily burdened; not deeply laden; not
sufficiently ballasted; <as>as, the ship returned
<ex>light</ex></as>.</def>

<sn>8.</sn> <def>Slight; not important; <as>as, a <ex>light</ex>
error</as>.</def>

<au>Shak.</au>

<sn>9.</sn> <def>Well leavened; not heavy; <as>as, <ex>light</ex>
bread</as>.</def>

<sn>10.</sn> <def>Not copious or heavy; not dense; not
inconsiderable; <as>as, a <ex>light</ex> rain; a <ex>light</ex>
snow; <ex>light</ex> vapors.</as></def>

<sn>11.</sn> <def>Not strong or violent; moderate; <as>as, a
<ex>light</ex> wind</as>.</def>

<sn>12.</sn> <def>Not pressing heavily or hard upon; hence,
having an easy graceful manner; delicate; <as>as, a
<ex>light</ex> touch; a <ex>light</ex> style of
execution.</as></def>

<sn>13.</sn> <def>Easy to admit influence; inconsiderate; easily
influenced by trifling considerations; unsteady; unsettled;
volatile; <as>as, a <ex>light</ex>, vain person; a <ex>light</ex>
mind.</as></def>

<q>There is no greater argument of a <qex>light</qex> and
inconsiderate person than profanely to scoff at religion.</q>
<qau>Tillotson.</qau>

<sn>14.</sn> <def>Indulging in, or inclined to, levity; wanting
dignity or solemnity; trifling; gay; frivolous; airy;
unsubstantial.</def>

<q>Seneca can not be too heavy, nor Plautus too
<qex>light</qex>.</q>
<qau>Shak.</qau>

<q>Specimens of New England humor laboriously <qex>light</qex>
and lamentably mirthful.</q>
<qau>Hawthorne.</qau>

<sn>15.</sn> <def>Not quite sound or normal; somewhat impaired or
deranged; dizzy; giddy.</def>

<q>Are his wits safe? Is he not <qex>light</qex> of brain ?</q>
<qau>Shak.</qau>

<sn>16.</sn> <def>Easily bestowed; inconsiderately
rendered.</def>

<q>To a fair semblance doth <qex>light</qex> annex.</q>
<qau>Spenser.</qau>

<sn>17.</sn> <def>Wanton; unchaste; <as>as, a woman of <ex>light
character</ex></as>.</def>

<q>A <qex>light</qex> wife doth make a heavy husband.</q>
<qau>Shak.</qau>

<sn>18.</sn> <def>Not of the legal, standard, or usual weight;
clipped; diminished; <as>as, <ex>light</ex> coin</as>.</def>

<sn>19.</sn> <def>Loose; sandy; easily pulverized; <as>as, a
<ex>light</ex> soil</as>.</def>

<cs><mcol><col>Light cavalry</col>, <col>Light horse</col></mcol>
<fld>(Mil.)</fld>, <cd>light-armed soldiers mounted on strong and
active horses.</cd> -- <col>Light eater</col>, <cd>one who eats
but little.</cd> -- <col>Light infantry</col>, <cd>infantry
soldiers selected and trained for rapid evolutions.</cd> --
<col>Light of foot</col>. <sd>(a)</sd> <cd>Having a light
step.</cd> <sd>(b)</sd> <cd>Fleet.</cd> -- <col>Light of
heart</col>, <cd>gay, cheerful.</cd> -- <col>Light oil</col>
<fld>(Chem.<cd>)</fld>, the oily product, lighter than water,
forming the chief part of the first distillate of coal tar, and
consisting largely of benzene and toluene.</cd> -- <col>Light
sails</col> <fld>(Naut.)</fld>, <cd>all the sails above the
topsails, with, also, the studding sails and flying jib.
<au>Dana</au>.</cd> -- <col>Light sleeper</col>, <cd>one easily
wakened.</cd> -- <col>Light weight</col>, <cd>a prize fighter,
boxer, wrestler, or jockey, who is below a standard medium
weight. Cf. <cref>Feather weight</cref>, under
<er>Feather</er>.</cd> <mark>[Cant]</mark> -- <col>To make light
of</col>, <cd>to treat as of little consequence; to slight; to
disregard.</cd> -- <col>To set light by</col>, <cd>to undervalue;
to slight; to treat as of no importance; to despise.</cd></cs>

<-- p. 852 -->

<hw>Light</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>adv.</pos> <def>Lightly;
cheaply.</def>

<au>Hooker.</au>

<hw>Light</hw>, <pos>v. t.</pos> <ety>[See <er>Light</er> not
heavy, and cf. <er>Light</er> to alight, and <er>Lighten</er> to
make less heavy.]</ety> <def>To lighten; to ease of a burden; to
take off.</def> <mark>[Obs.]</mark>

<q>From his head the heavy burgonet did <qex>light</qex>.</q>
<qau>Spenser.</qau>

<hw>Light</hw>, <pos>v. i.</pos> <wordforms>[<pos>imp. & p.
p.</pos> <er>Lighted</er> <pr>(?)</pr> <or/ <er>Lit</er> (<?/);
<pos>p. pr. & vb. n.</pos> <er>Lighting</er>.]</wordforms>
<ety>[AS. <ets>l\'c6htan</ets> to alight orig., to relieve (a
horse) of the rider's burden, to make less heavy, fr.
<ets>l\'c6ht</ets> light. See <er>Light</er> not heavy, and cf.
<er>Alight</er>, <er>Lighten</er> to make light.]</ety>
<sn>1.</sn> <def>To dismount; to descend, as from a horse or
carriage; to alight; -- with <ptcl>from</ptcl>, <ptcl>off</ptcl>,
<ptcl>on</ptcl>, <ptcl>upon</ptcl>, <ptcl>at</ptcl>,
<ptcl>in</ptcl>.</def>

<q>When she saw Isaac, she <qex>lighted</qex> off the camel.</q>
<qau>Gen. xxiv. 64.</qau>

<q>Slowly rode across a withered heath,
And <qex>lighted</qex> at a ruined inn.</q>
<qau>Tennyson.</qau>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>To feel light; to be made happy.</def>
<mark>[Obs.]</mark>

<q>It made all their hearts to <qex>light</qex>.</q>
<qau>Chaucer.</qau>

<sn>3.</sn> <def>To descend from flight, and rest, perch, or
settle, as a bird or insect.</def>

<q>[The bee] <qex>lights</qex> on that, and this, and tasteth
all.</q>
<qau>Sir. J. Davies.</qau>

<q>On the tree tops a crested peacock <qex>lit</qex>.</q>
<qau>Tennyson.</qau>

<sn>4.</sn> <def>To come down suddenly and forcibly; to fall; --
with <ptcl>on</ptcl> or <ptcl>upon</ptcl>.</def>

<q>On me, me only, as the source and spring
Of all corruption, all the blame <qex>light</qex> due.</q>
<qau>Milton.</qau>

<sn>5.</sn> <def>To come by chance; to happen; -- with
<ptcl>on</ptcl> or <ptcl>upon</ptcl>; formerly with
<ptcl>into</ptcl>.</def>

<q>The several degrees of vision, which the assistance of glasses
(casually at first <qex>lit</qex> on) has taught us to
conceive.</q>
<qau>Locke.</qau>

<q>They shall <qex>light</qex> into atheistical company.</q>
<qau>South.</qau>

<q>And here we <qex>lit</qex> on Aunt Elizabeth,
And Lilia with the rest.</q>
<qau>Tennyson.</qau>

<hw>Light"a*ble</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>a.</pos> <def>Such as can
be lighted.</def>

<hw>Light"-armed`</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>a.</pos> <def>Armed
with light weapons or accouterments.</def>

<hw>Light"-boat`</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos>
<def>Light-ship.</def>

<hw>Light"e</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>obs. imp.</pos> <def>of
<er>Light</er>, to alight.</def>

<au>Chaucer.</au>

<hw>Light"en</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>v. i.</pos> <ety>[See
<er>Light</er> to alight.]</ety> <def>To descend; to light.</def>

<q>O Lord, let thy mercy <qex>lighten</qex> upon us.</q>
<qau>Book of Common Prayer [Eng. Ed.]</qau>

<hw>Light"en</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>v. i.</pos>
<wordforms>[<pos>imp. & p. p.</pos> <er>Lightened</er>
<pr>(?)</pr>; <pos>p. pr. & vb. n.</pos>
<er>Lightening</er>.]</wordforms> <ety>[OE. <ets>lightenen</ets>.
See <er>Light</er> to kindle, illuminate.]</ety> <sn>1.</sn>
<def>To burst forth or dart, as lightning; to shine with, or
like, lightning; to display a flash or flashes of lightning; to
flash.</def>

<q>This dreadful night,
That thunders, <qex>lightens</qex>, opens graves, and roars
As doth the lion.</q>
<qau>Shak.</qau>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>To grow lighter; to become less dark or
lowering; to brighten; to clear, as the sky.</def>

<hw>Light"en</hw>, <pos>v. t.</pos> <ety>[See <er>Light</er> to
illuminate.]</ety> <sn>1.</sn> <def>To make light or clear; to
light; to illuminate; <as>as, to <ex>lighten</ex> an apartment
with lamps or gas; to <ex>lighten</ex> the streets.</as></def>
<mark>[In this sense less common than <xex>light.</xex>]</mark>

<q>A key of fire ran all along the shore,
And <qex>lightened</qex> all the river with a blaze.</q>
<qau>Dryden.</qau>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>To illuminate with knowledge; to
enlighten.</def> <mark>[In this sense less common than
<xex>enlighten</xex>.]</mark>

<q><qex>Lighten</qex> my spirit with one clear heavenly ray.</q>
<qau>Sir J. Davies.</qau>

<sn>3.</sn> <def>To emit or disclose in, or as in, lightning; to
flash out, like lightning.</def>

<q>His eye . . . <qex>lightens</qex> forth
Controlling majesty.</q>
<qau>Shak.</qau>

<sn>4.</sn> <def>To free from trouble and fill with joy.</def>

<q>They looked unto him, were <qex>lightened</qex>.</q>
<qau>Ps. xxxiv. 5.</qau>

<hw>Light"en</hw>, <pos>v. t.</pos> <ety>[See <er>Light</er> not
heavy.]</ety> <sn>1.</sn> <def>To make lighter, or less heavy; to
reduce in weight; to relieve of part of a load or burden; <as>as,
to <ex>lighten</ex> a ship by unloading; to <ex>lighten</ex> a
load or burden.</as></def>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>To make less burdensome or afflictive; to
alleviate; <as>as, to <ex>lighten</ex> the cares of life or the
burden of grief</as>.</def>

<sn>3.</sn> <def>To cheer; to exhilarate.</def>

<q><qex>Lighens</qex> my humor with his merry jests.</q>
<qau>Shak.</qau>

<hw>Light"er</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <def>One who, or
that which, lights; <as>as, a <ex>lighter</ex> of
lamps</as>.</def>

<hw>Light"er</hw>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[D. <ets>ligter</ets>, fr.
<ets>ligt</ets> light. See <er>Light</er> not heavy.]</ety>
<fld>(Naut.)</fld> <def>A large boat or barge, mainly, used in
unloading or loading vessels which can not reach the wharves at
the place of shipment or delivery.</def>

<cs><col>Lighter screw</col> <fld>(Mach.)</fld>, <cd>a screw for
adjusting the distance between the stones in a grinding mill by
raising or lowering the bridgetree.</cd></cs>

<hw>Light"er</hw>, <pos>v. t.</pos> <def>To convey by a lighter,
as to or from the shore; <as>as, to <ex>lighter</ex> the cargo of
a ship</as>.</def>

<hw>Light"er*age</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <sn>1.</sn>
<def>The price paid for conveyance of goods on a lighter.</def>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>The act of unloading into a lighter, or of
conveying by a lighter.</def>

<hw>Light"er*man</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos>; <plu>pl.
<plw>Lightermen</plw> <pr>(<?/)</pr>.</plu> <def>A person
employed on, or who manages, a lighter.</def>

<hw>Light"-fin`gered</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>a.</pos>
<def>Dexterous in taking and conveying away; thievish; pilfering;
addicted to petty thefts.</def>

<au>Fuller.</au>

<mhw>{ <hw>Light"-foot`</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>,
<hw>Light"-foot`ed</hw>, }</mhw> <pos>a.</pos> <def>Having a
light, springy step; nimble in running or dancing; active;
<as>as, <ex>light-foot</ex> Iris</as>.</def>

<au>Tennyson.</au>

<hw>Light"ful</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>a.</pos> <def>Full of
light; bright.</def> <mark>[R.]</mark> \'bd<xex>Lightful</xex>
presence.\'b8

<au>Marston.</au>

<hw>Light"-hand`ed</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>a.</pos>
<fld>(Naut.)</fld> <def>Not having a full complement of men;
<as>as, a vessel <ex>light-handed</ex></as>.</def>

<hw>Light"-head`ed</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>a.</pos> <sn>1.</sn>
<def>Disordered in the head; dilirious.</def>

<au>Walpole.</au>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>Thoughtless; heedless; volatile; unsteady;
fickle; loose.</def> \'bd<xex>Light-headed</xex>, weak men.\'b8

<au>Clarendon.</au>

-- <wordforms><wf>Light"-head`ed*ness</wf>,
<pos>n.</pos></wordforms>

<hw>Light"-heart"ed</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>a.</pos> <def>Free
from grief or anxiety; gay; cheerful; merry.</def> --
<wordforms><wf>Light"-heart`ed*ly</wf>, <pos>adv.</pos> --
<wf>Light"-heart"ed*ness</wf>, <pos>n.</pos></wordforms>

<hw>Light"-heeled`</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>a.</pos> <def>Lively
in walking or running; brisk; light-footed.</def>

<hw>Light"-horse`man</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos>; <plu>pl.
<plw>-men</plw> <pr>(<?/)</pr>.</plu> <sn>1.</sn> <def>A soldier
who serves in the light horse. See under 5th
<er>Light</er>.</def>

<sn>2.</sn> <fld>(Zo\'94l.)</fld> <def>A West Indian fish of the
genus <spn>Ephippus</spn>, remarkable for its high dorsal fin and
brilliant colors.</def>

<hw>Light"house`</hw> <pr>(?)</pr> <pos>n.</pos>;
<plu>pl.<plw>Lighthouses</plw> <pr>(<?/)</pr>.</plu> <def>A tower
or other building with a powerful light at top, erected at the
entrance of a port, or at some important point on a coast, to
serve as a guide to mariners at night; a pharos.</def>

<hw>Light"ing</hw>, <pos>n.</pos> <fld>(Metal.)</fld> <def>A name
sometimes applied to the process of annealing metals.</def>

<hw>Light"-legged`</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>a.</pos> <def>Nimble;
swift of foot.</def>

<au>Sir P. Sidney.</au>

<hw>Light"less</hw>, <pos>a.</pos><def>Destitute of light;
dark.</def>

<au>Shak.</au>

<hw>Light"ly</hw>, <pos>adv.</pos> <sn>1.</sn> <def>With little
weight; with little force; <as>as, to tread <ex>lightly</ex>; to
press <ex>lightly</ex>.</as></def>

<q>Yet shall thy grave with rising flowers be drest,
And the green turf lie <qex>lightly</qex> on thy breast.</q>
<qau>Pope.</qau>

<q>Him thus intent Ithuriel with his spear
Touched <qex>lightly</qex>.</q>
<qau>Milton.</qau>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>Swiftly; nimbly; with agility.</def>

<q>So mikle was that barge, it might not <qex>lightly</qex>
sail.</q>
<qau>R. of Brunne.</qau>

<q>Watch what thou seest and <qex>lightly</qex> bring me
word.</q>
<qau>Tennyson.</qau>

<sn>3.</sn> <def>Without deep impression.</def>

<q>The soft ideas of the cheerful note,
<qex>Lightly</qex> received, were easily forgot.</q>
<qau>Prior.</qau>

<sn>4.</sn> <def>In a small degree; slightly; not severely.</def>

<q>At the first he <qex>lightly</qex> afflicted the land of
Zebulun . . . and afterward did more grievously afflict her.</q>
<qau>Is. ix. 1.</qau>

<sn>5.</sn> <def>With little effort or difficulty; easily;
readily.</def>

<q>That <qex>lightly</qex> come, shall <qex>lightly</qex> go.</q>
<qau>Old Proverb.</qau>

<q>They come <qex>lightly</qex> by the malt, and need not spare
it.</q>
<qau>Sir W. Scott.</qau>

<sn>6.</sn> <def>Without reason, or for reasons of little
weight.</def>

<q>Flatter not the rich, neither do thou willingly or
<qex>lightly</qex> appear before great personages.</q>
<qau>Jer. Taylor.</qau>

<sn>7.</sn> <def>Commonly; usually.</def> <mark>[Obs.]</mark>

<au>Bp. Fisher.</au>

<q>The great thieves of a state are <qex>lightly</qex> the
officers of the crown.</q>
<qau>B. Jonson.</qau>

<sn>8.</sn> <def>Without dejection; cheerfully.</def> \'bdSeeming
to bear it <xex>lightly</xex>.\'b8

<au>Shak.</au>

<sn>9.</sn> <def>Without heed or care; with levity; gayly;
airily.</def>

<q>Matrimony . . . is not by any to be enterprised, nor taken in
hand, unadvisedly, <qex>lightly</qex>, or wantonly.</q>
<qau>Book of Common Prayer [Eng. Ed.].</qau>

<sn>10.</sn> <def>Not chastely; wantonly.</def>

<au>Swift.</au>

<hw>Light"man</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> ; <plu>pl.
<plw>-men</plw> <pr>(<?/)</pr></plu> <def>A man who carries or
takes care of a light.</def>

<au>T. Brown.</au>

<hw>Light"-mind`ed</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>a.</pos>
<def>Unsettled; unsteady; volatile; not considerate.</def> --
<wordforms><wf>Light"-mind`ed*ness</wf>,
<pos>n.</pos></wordforms>

<hw>Light"ness</hw>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[From <er>Light</er> not
heavy.]</ety> <def>The state, condition, or quality, of being
light or not heavy; buoyancy; levity; fickleness; delicacy;
grace.</def>

<syn>Syn. -- Levity; volatility; instability; inconstancy;
unsteadiness; giddiness; flightiness; airiness; gayety;
liveliness; agility; nimbleness; sprightliness; briskness;
swiftness; ease; facility.</syn>

<hw>Light"ness</hw>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[From <er>Light</er>
bright.]</ety> <sn>1.</sn> <def>Illumination, or degree of
illumination; <as>as, the <ex>lightness</ex> of a
room</as>.</def>

<au>Chaucer.</au>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>Absence of depth or of duskiness in color;
<as>as, the <ex>lightness</ex> of a tint; <ex>lightness</ex> of
complexion.</as></def>

<hw>Light"ning</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[For
<ets>lightening</ets>, fr. <ets>lighten</ets> to flash.]</ety>
<sn>1.</sn> <def>A discharge of atmospheric electricity,
accompanied by a vivid flash of light, commonly from one cloud to
another, sometimes from a cloud to the earth. The sound produced
by the electricity in passing rapidly through the atmosphere
constitutes thunder.</def>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>The act of making bright, or the state of being
made bright; enlightenment; brightening, as of the mental
powers.</def> <mark>[R.]</mark>

<cs><col>Ball lightning</col>, <cd>a rare form of lightning
sometimes seen as a globe of fire moving from the clouds to the
earth.</cd> -- <col>Chain lightning</col>, <cd>lightning in
angular, zigzag, or forked flashes.</cd> -- <col>Heat
lightning</col>, <cd>more or less vivid and extensive flashes of
electric light, without thunder, seen near the horizon, esp. at
the close of a hot day.</cd> -- <col>Lightning arrester</col>
<fld>(Telegraphy)</fld>, <cd>a device, at the place where a wire
enters a building, for preventing injury by lightning to an
operator or instrument. It consists of a short circuit to the
ground interrupted by a thin nonconductor over which lightning
jumps. Called also <altname>lightning discharger</altname>.</cd>
-- <col>Lightning bug</col> <fld>(Zo\'94l.)</fld>, <cd>a luminous
beetle. See <er>Firefly</er>.</cd> -- <col>Lightning
conductor</col>, <cd>a lightning rod.</cd> -- <col>Lightning
glance</col>, <cd>a quick, penetrating glance of a brilliant
eye.</cd> -- <col>Lightning rod</col>, <cd>a metallic rod set up
on a building, or on the mast of a vessel, and connected with the
earth or water below, for the purpose of protecting the building
or vessel from lightning.</cd> -- <col>Sheet lightning</col>,
<cd>a diffused glow of electric light flashing out from the
clouds, and illumining their outlines. The appearance is
sometimes due to the reflection of light from distant flashes of
lightning by the nearer clouds.</cd></cs>

<hw>Light"ning</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>vb. n.</pos>
<def>Lightening.</def> <mark>[R.]</mark>

<hw>Light"-o'-love`</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <sn>1.</sn>
<def>An old tune of a dance, the name of which made it a
proverbial expression of levity, especially in love
matters.</def> <au>Nares</au>. \'bdBest sing it to the tune of
<xex>light-o'-love</xex>.\'b8

<au>Shak.</au>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>Hence: A light or wanton woman.</def>

<au>Beau. & Fl.</au>

<hw>Light"room`</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <def>A small
room from which the magazine of a naval vessel is lighted, being
separated from the magazine by heavy glass windows.</def>

<hw>lights</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n. pl.</pos> <ety>[So called
from their <ets>lightness</ets>.]</ety> <def>The lungs of an
animal or bird; -- sometimes coarsely applied to the lungs of a
human being.</def>

<hw>Light"-ship`</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos>
<fld>(Naut.)</fld> <def>A vessel carrying at the masthead a
brilliant light, and moored off a shoal or place of dangerous
navigation as a guide for mariners.</def>

<hw>Light"some</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>a.</pos> <sn>1.</sn>
<def>Having light; lighted; not dark or gloomy; bright.</def>

<q>White walls make rooms more <qex>lightsome</qex> than
black.</q>
<qau>Bacon.</qau>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>Gay; airy; cheering; exhilarating.</def>

<q>That <qex>lightsome</qex> affection of joy.</q>
<qau>Hooker.</qau>

-- <wordforms><wf>Light"some*ly</wf>, <pos>adv.</pos> --
<wf>Light"some*ness</wf>, <pos>n.</pos></wordforms>

<q>Happiness may walk soberly in dark attire, as well as dance
<qex>lightsomely</qex> in a gala dress.</q>
<qau>Hawthorne.</qau>

<hw>Light"-winged`</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>a.</pos> <def>Having
light and active wings; volatile; fleeting.</def>

<au>Shak.</au>

<hw>Light"wood`</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <def>Pine wood
abounding in pitch, used for torches in the Southern United
States; pine knots, dry sticks, and the like, for kindling a fire
quickly or making a blaze.</def>

<hw>Light"y</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>a.</pos>
<def>Illuminated.</def> <mark>[Obs.]</mark>

<au>Wyclif.</au>

<hw>Lign`-al"oes</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[OE.
<ets>ligne aloes</ets>, fr. L. <ets>lignum</ets> wood +
<ets>aloe</ets> aloe.]</ety> <sn>1.</sn> <def>Aloes wood, or
agallochum. See     <er>Agallochum</er>.</def>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>A fragrant tree mentioned in the Bible.</def>

<hw>Lig"ne*ous</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>a.</pos> <ety>[L.
<ets>ligneus</ets>, fr. <ets>lignum</ets> wood. Cf.
<er>Lignous</er>.]</ety> <def>Made of wood; consisting of wood;
of the nature of, or resembling, wood; woody.</def>

<q>It should be tried with shoots of vines and roots of red
roses; for it may be they, being of a more<qex>ligneous</qex>
nature, will incorporate with the tree itself.</q>
<qau>Bacon.</qau>

<cs><col>Ligneous marble</col>, <cd>wood coated or prepared so as
to resemble marble.</cd></cs>

<hw>Lig*nif`er*ous</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>a.</pos> <ety>[L.
<ets>lignifer</ets>; <ets>lignum</ets> wood + <ets>ferre</ets> to
bear: cf. F.  <ets>lignif\'8are</ets>.]</ety> <def>Yielding or
producing wood.</def>

<hw>Lig`ni*fi*ca"tion</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[Cf.
F. <ets>lignification</ets>. See <er>Lignify</er>.]</ety>
<fld>(Bot.)</fld> <def>A change in the character of a cell wall,
by which it becomes harder. It is supposed to be due to an
incrustation of lignin.</def>

<hw>Lig"ni*form</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>a.</pos> <ety>[L.
<ets>lignum</ets> wood + <ets>-form</ets>: cf. F.
<ets>ligniforme</ets>.]</ety> <def>Like wood.</def>

<hw>Lig"ni*fy</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>v. t.</pos>
<wordforms>[<pos>imp. & p. p.</pos> <er>Lignified</er>
<pr>(?)</pr>; <pos>p. pr. & vb. n.</pos> <er>Lignifying</er>
<pr>(?)</pr>.]</wordforms> <ety>[L. <ets>lignum</ets> wood +
<ets>-fy</ets>: cf. F. <ets>lignifier</ets>.]</ety>
<fld>(Bot.)</fld> <def>To convert into wood or into a ligneous
substance.</def>

<hw>Lig"ni*fy</hw>, <pos>v. i.</pos> <fld>(Bot.)</fld> <def>To
become wood.</def>

<hw>Lig"nin</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[L.
<ets>lignum</ets> wood: cf. F. <ets>lignine</ets>.]</ety>
<fld>(Bot.)</fld> <def>A substance characterizing wood cells and
differing from cellulose in its conduct with certain chemical
reagents.</def>

<note><hand/ Recent authors have distinguished four forms of this
substance, naming them <xex>lignose</xex>, <xex>lignin</xex>,
<xex>lignone</xex>, and <xex>lignireose</xex>.</note>

<hw>Lig`ni*per"dous</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>a.</pos> <ety>[L.
<ets>lignum</ets> wood + <ets>perdere</ets> to destroy: cf. F. 
<ets>ligniperde</ets>.]</ety> <fld>(Zo\'94l.)</fld>
<def>Wood-destroying; -- said of certain insects.</def>

<hw>Lig*nir"e*ose`</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos>
<fld>(Bot.)</fld> <def>See <er>Lignin</er>.</def>

<hw>Lig"nite</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[L.
<ets>lignum</ets> wood: cf. F. <ets>lignite</ets>.]</ety>
<fld>(Min.)</fld> <def>Mineral coal retaining the texture of the
wood from which it was formed, and burning with an empyreumatic
odor. It is of more recent origin than the anthracite and
bituminous coal of the proper coal series. Called also
<altname>brown coal</altname>, <altname>wood
coal</altname>.</def>

<hw>Lig*nit"ic</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>a.</pos> <def>Containing
lignite; resembling, or of the nature of, lignite; <as>as,
<ex>lignitic</ex> clay</as>.</def>

<cs><col>Lignitic group</col>. <cd>See <er>Laramie
group</er>.</cd></cs>

<hw>Lig`ni*tif"er*ous</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>a.</pos>
<ety>[<ets>Lignite</ets> + <ets>-ferous</ets>.]</ety>
<def>Producing or containing lignite; lignitic.</def>

<hw>Lig`no*cer"ic</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>a.</pos> <ety>[L.
<ets>lignum</ets> wood + <ets>cera</ets> wax.]</ety>
<fld>(Chem.)</fld> <def>Pertaining to, or designating, an acid of
the formic acid series, found in the tar, wax, or paraffine
obtained by distilling certain kinds of wood, as the beech.</def>

<hw>Lig"none`</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <fld>(Bot.)</fld>
<def>See <er>Lignin</er>.</def>

<mhw>{ <hw>Lig*nose`</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <hw>Lig"nous</hw>
<pr>(?)</pr>, }</mhw> <pos>a.</pos> <ety>[L. <ets>lignosus</ets>,
fr. <ets>lignum</ets> wood: cf. F. <ets>ligneux</ets>. Cf.
<er>Ligneous</er>.]</ety> <def>Ligneous.</def> <mark>[R.]</mark>

<au>Evelyn.</au>

<hw>Lig"nose`</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <sn>1.</sn>
<fld>(Bot.)</fld> <def>See <er>Lignin</er>.</def>

<sn>2.</sn> <fld>(Chem.)</fld> <def>An explosive compound of wood
fiber and nitroglycerin. See <er>Nitroglycerin</er>.</def>

<hw>\'d8Lig"num rho"di*um</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>. <ety>[NL., fr. L.
<ets>lignum</ets> wood + Gr. <?/ a rose.]</ety> <fld>(Bot.)</fld>
<def>The fragrant wood of several shrubs and trees, especially of
species of <spn>Rhodorhiza</spn> from the Canary Islands, and of
the West Indian <spn>Amyris balsamifera</spn>.</def>

<hw>\'d8Lig"num-vi"tae</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[L.,
wood of life; <ets>lignum</ets> wood + <ets>vita</ets>, genitive
<ets>vit\'91</ets>, life.]</ety> <fld>(Bot.)</fld> <def>A tree
(<spn>Guaiacum officinale</spn>) found in the warm latitudes of
America, from which the <xex>guaiacum</xex> of medicine is
procured. Its wood is very hard and heavy, and is used for
various mechanical purposes, as for the wheels of ships' blocks,
cogs, bearings, and the like. See <er>Guaiacum</er>.</def>

<note><hand/ In New Zealand the <spn>Metrosideros buxifolia</spn>
is called lignum-vit\'91, and in Australia a species of
<spn>Acacia</spn>. The bastard lignum-vit\'91 is a West Indian
tree (<spn>Sarcomphalus laurinus</spn>).</note>

<hw>Lig"ro*in</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <def>A trade name
applied somewhat indefinitely to some of the volatile products
obtained in refining crude petroleum. It is a complex and
variable mixture of several hydrocarbons, generally boils below
170<deg/ Fahr., and is more inflammable than safe kerosene. It is
used as a solvent, as a carburetant for air gas, and for
illumination in special lamps.</def>

<-- p. 853 -->

<hw>Lig"sam</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[Cf. D.
<ets>liggen</ets> to lie, E. <ets>lie</ets> to be prostrate, and
E. <ets>flotsam</ets>, <ets>jetsam</ets>, or
<ets>ligan</ets>.]</ety> <def>Same as <er>Ligan</er>.</def>

<au>Brande & C.</au>

<hw>\'d8Lig"u*la</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos>; <plu>pl. L.
<plw>Ligul\'91</plw> <pr>(#)</pr>, E. <plw>Ligulas</plw>
<pr>(#)</pr></plu>. <ety>[L., a little tongue. See
<er>Ligule</er>.]</ety> <sn>1.</sn> <fld>(Bot.)</fld> <def>See
<er>Ligule</er>.</def>

<sn>2.</sn> <fld>(Zo\'94l.)</fld> <sd>(a)</sd> <def>The central
process, or front edge, of the labium of insects. It sometimes
serves as a tongue or proboscis, as in bees. [See
<xex>Illust</xex>.  under <er>Labium</er>, and
<er>Hymenoptera</er>.]</def> <sd>(b)</sd> <def>A tongue-shaped
lobe of the parapodia of annelids. See <er>Parapodium</er>.</def>

<mhw>{ <hw>Lig"u*late</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <hw>Lig"u*la`ted</hw>
<pr>(?)</pr>, }</mhw> <pos>a.</pos> <ety>[Cf. F.
<ets>ligul\'82</ets>. See <er>Ligule</er>, and cf.
<er>Lingulate</er>.]</ety> <sn>1.</sn> <fld>(Bot.)</fld>
<def>Like a bandage, or strap; strap-shaped.</def>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>Composed of ligules.</def>

<cs><col>Ligulate flower</col>, <cd>a species of compound flower,
the florets of which have their corollets flat, spreading out
toward the end, with the base only tubular.</cd></cs>

<hw>Lig"ule</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos>
<ety>[L.<ets>ligula</ets>, little tongue, dim of
<ets>lingua</ets> tongue : cf. F. <ets>ligule</ets>.]</ety>
<sn>1.</sn> <fld>(Bot.)</fld> <sd>(a)</sd> <def>The thin and
scarious projection from the upper end of the sheath of leaf of
grass.</def> <sd>(b)</sd> <def>A strap-shaped corolla of flowers
of Composit\'91.</def>

<sn>2.</sn> <fld>(Anat.)</fld> <def>A band of white matter in the
wall of fourth ventricle of the brain.</def>

<hw>Lig`u*li*flo"rous</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>a.</pos>
<ety>[<ets>Ligule</ets> + L. <ets>flos</ets>, <ets>floris</ets>,
a flower.]</ety> <fld>(Bot.)</fld> <def>Bearing only ligulate
flowers; -- said of a large suborder of composite plants, such as
the dandelion, hawkweed, etc.</def>

<hw>Lig"ure</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[L.
<ets>ligurius</ets>, Gr. <?/ , <?/, <?/, <?/, equiv. to Heb.
<ets>leshem</ets>.]</ety> <def>A kind of precious stone.</def>

<q>The third row a <qex>ligure</qex>, an agate, and an
amethyst.</q>
<qau>Ex. xxviii. 19.</qau>

<hw>Li*gus"trin</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos>
<fld>(Chem.)</fld> <def>A bitter principle found in the bark of
the privet <fld>(Ligustrum vulgare)</fld>, and extracted as a
white crystalline substance with a warm, bitter taste; -- called
also <altname>ligustron</altname>.</def>

<hw>Lik"a*ble</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>a.</pos> <def>Such as can
be liked; such as to attract liking; <as>as, a <ex>likable</ex>
person</as>.</def>

<au>Thackeray.</au>

<hw>Like</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>a.</pos>
<wordforms>[<pos>Compar.</pos> <er>Liker</er> <pr>(?)</pr>;
<pos>superl.</pos> <er>Likest</er>.]</wordforms> <ety>[OE.
<ets>lik</ets>, <ets>ilik</ets>, <ets>gelic</ets>, AS.
<ets>gel\'c6c</ets>, fr. pref. <ets>ge-</ets> + <ets>l\'c6c</ets>
body, and orig. meaning, having the same body, shape, or
appearance, and hence, like; akin to OS. <ets>gil\'c6k</ets>, D.
<ets>gelijk</ets>, G. <ets>gleich</ets>, OHG.
<ets>gil\'c6h</ets>, Icel. <ets>l\'c6kr</ets>,
<ets>gl\'c6kr</ets>, Dan. <ets>lig</ets>, Sw. <ets>lik</ets>,
Goth. <ets>galeiks</ets>, OS. <ets>lik</ets> body, D.
<ets>lijk</ets>, G. <ets>leiche</ets>, Icel. <ets>l\'c6k</ets>,
Sw. <ets>lik</ets>, Goth. <ets>leik</ets>. The English adverbial
ending<ets>-ly</ets> is from the same adjective. Cf.
<er>Each</er>, <er>Such</er>, <er>Which</er>.]</ety> <sn>1.</sn>
<def>Having the same, or nearly the same, appearance, qualities,
or characteristics; resembling; similar to; similar; alike; --
often with <xex>in</xex> and the particulars of the resemblance;
<as>as, they are <ex>like</ex> each other in features,
complexion, and many traits of character</as>.</def>

<q>'The as <qex>like</qex> you
As cherry is to cherry.</q>
<qau>Shak.</qau>

<q><qex>Like</qex> master, <qex>like</qex> man.</q>
<qau>Old Prov.</qau>

<q>He giveth snow <qex>like</qex> wool; he scattereth the
hoar-frost <qex>like</qex> ashes.</q>
<qau>Ps. cxlvii. 16.</qau>

<note><hand/ <xex>To</xex>, which formerly often followed
<xex>like</xex>, is now usually omitted.</note>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>Equal, or nearly equal; <as>as, fields of
<ex>like</ex> extent</as>.</def>

<q>More clergymen were impoverished by the late war than ever in
the <qex>like</qex> space before.</q>
<qau>Sprat.</qau>

<sn>3.</sn> <def>Having probability; affording probability;
probable; likely. [<xex>Likely</xex> is more used now.]</def>

<au>Shak.</au>

<q>But it is <qex>like</qex> the jolly world about us will scoff
at the paradox of these practices.</q>
<qau>South.</qau>

<q>Many were not easy to be governed, nor like to conform
themselves to strict rules.</q>
<qau>Clarendon.</qau>

<sn>4.</sn> <def>Inclined toward; disposed to; <as>as, to feel
<ex>like</ex> taking a walk</as>.</def>

<cs><col>Had like</col> (followed by the infinitive), <cd>had
nearly; came little short of.</cd></cs>

<q><qex>Had like</qex> to have been my utter overthrow.</q>
<qau>Sir W. Raleigh</qau>

<q>Ramona <qex>had like</qex> to have said the literal truth, . .
. but recollected herself in time.</q>
<qau>Mrs. H. H. Jackson.</qau>

<cs><col>Like figures</col> <fld>(Geom.)</fld>, <cd>similar
figures.</cd></cs>

<note><hand/ <xex>Like</xex> is used as a suffix, converting
nouns into adjectives expressing resemblance to the noun; as,
man<xex>like</xex>, like a man; child<xex>like</xex>, like a
child; god<xex>like</xex>, like a god, etc. Such compounds are
readily formed whenever convenient, and several, as
<xex>crescentlike</xex>, <xex>serpentlike</xex>,
<xex>hairlike</xex>, etc., are used in this book, although, in
some cases, not entered in the vocabulary. Such combinations as
<xex>bell-like</xex>, <xex>ball-like</xex>, etc., are
hyphened.</note>

<hw>Like</hw>, <pos>n.</pos> <sn>1.</sn> <def>That which is equal
or similar to another; the counterpart; an exact resemblance; a
copy.</def>

<q>He was a man, take him for all in all,
I shall not look upon his <qex>like</qex> again.</q>
<qau>Shak.</qau>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>A liking; a preference; inclination; -- usually
in <pluf>pl.</pluf>; <as>as, we all have <ex>likes</ex> and
dislikes</as>.</def>

<hw>Like</hw>, <pos>adv.</pos> <ety>[AS. <ets>gel\'c6ce</ets>.
See <er>Like</er>, <pos>a.</pos>]</ety> <sn>1.</sn> <def>In a
manner like that of; in a manner similar to; <as>as, do not act
<ex>like</ex> him</as>.</def>

<q>He maketh them to stagger <qex>like</qex> a drunken man.</q>
<qau>Job xii. 25.</qau>

<note><hand/ <xex>Like</xex>, as here used, is regarded by some
grammarians as a preposition.</note>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>In a like or similar manner</def>.

<au>Shak.</au>

<q><qex>Like</qex> as a father pitieth his children, so the Lord
pitieth them that fear him.</q>
<qau>Ps. ciii. 13.</qau>

<sn>3.</sn> <def>Likely; probably.</def> \'bd<xex>Like</xex>
enough it will.\'b8

<au>Shak.</au>

<hw>Like</hw>, <pos>v. t.</pos> <wordforms>[<pos>imp. & p.
p.</pos> <er>Liked</er> <pr>(?)</pr>; <pos>p. pr. & vb. n.</pos>
<er>Liking</er>.]</wordforms> <ety>[OE. <ets>liken</ets> to
please, AS. <ets>l\'c6cian</ets>, <ets>gel\'c6cian</ets>,
fr.<ets>gel\'c6c</ets>. See <er>Like</er>, <pos>a.</pos>]</ety>
<sn>1.</sn> <def>To suit; to please; to be agreeable to.</def>
<mark>[Obs.]</mark>

<q>Cornwall him <qex>liked</qex> best, therefore he chose
there.</q>
<qau>R. of Gloucester.</qau>

<q>I willingly confess that it <qex>likes</qex> me much better
when I find virtue in a fair lodging than when I am bound to seek
it in an ill-favored creature.</q>
<qau>Sir P. Sidney.</qau>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>To be pleased with in a moderate degree; to
approve; to take satisfaction in; to enjoy.</def>

<q>He proceeded from looking to <qex>liking</qex>, and from
<qex>liking</qex> to loving.</q>
<qau>Sir P. Sidney.</qau>

<sn>3.</sn> <def>To liken; to compare.</def><mark>[Obs.]</mark>

<q><qex>Like</qex> me to the peasant boys of France.</q>
<qau>Shak.</qau>

<hw>Like</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>v. i.</pos> <sn>1.</sn> <def>To
be pleased; to choose.</def>

<q>He may either go or stay, as he best <qex>likes</qex>.</q>
<qau>Locke.</qau>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>To have an appearance or expression; to look; to
seem to be (in a specified condition).</def> <mark>[Obs.]</mark>

<q>You <qex>like</qex> well, and bear your years very well.</q>
<qau>Shak.</qau>

<sn>3.</sn> <def>To come near; to avoid with difficulty; to
escape narrowly; <as>as, he <ex>liked</ex> to have been too
late</as>. Cf. <xex>Had like</xex>, under <er>Like</er>,
<pos>a.</pos></def> <mark>[Colloq.]</mark>

<q>He probably got his death, as he <qex>liked</qex> to have done
two years ago, by viewing the troops for the expedition from the
wall of Kensington Garden.</q>
<qau>Walpole.</qau>

<cs><col>To like of</col>, <cd>to be pleased with.
<mark>[Obs.]</mark></cd></cs>

<au>Massinger.</au>

<hw>Like"hood</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos>
<def>Likelihood.</def> <mark>[Obs.]</mark>

<au>South.</au>

<hw>Like"li*hood</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos>
<ety>[<ets>Likely</ets> + <ets>-hood</ets>.]</ety> <sn>1.</sn>
<def>Appearance; show; sign; expression.</def>
<mark>[Obs.]</mark>

<q>What of his heart perceive you in his face
By any <qex>likelihood</qex> he showed to-day ?</q>
<qau>Shak.</qau>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>Likeness; resemblance.</def> <mark>[Obs.]</mark>

<q>There is no <qex>likelihood</qex> between pure light and black
darkness, or between righteousness and reprobation.</q>
<qau>Sir W. Raleigh.</qau>

<sn>3.</sn> <def>Appearance of truth or reality; probability;
verisimilitude.</def>

<au>Tennyson.</au>

<hw>Like"li*ness</hw>, <pos>n.</pos> <sn>1.</sn> <def>Likelihood;
probability.</def>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>Suitableness; agreeableness.</def>
<mark>[Obs.]</mark>

<hw>Like"ly</hw>, <pos>a.</pos> <wordforms>[<pos>Compar.</pos>
<er>Likelier</er> <pr>(?)</pr>; <pos>superl.</pos>
<er>Likeliest</er>.]</wordforms> <ety>[That is,
<ets>like-like</ets>. See <er>Like</er>, <pos>a.</pos>]</ety>
<sn>1.</sn> <def>Worthy of belief; probable; credible; <as>as, a
<ex>likely</ex> story</as>.</def>

<q>It seems <qex>likely</qex> that he was in hope of being busy
and conspicuous.</q>
<qau>Johnson.</qau>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>Having probability; having or giving reason to
expect; -- followed by the infinitive; <as>as, it is
<ex>likely</ex> to rain</as>.</def>

<sn>3.</sn> <def>Similar; like; alike.</def> <mark>[Obs.]</mark>

<au>Spenser.</au>

<sn>4.</sn> <def>Such as suits; good-looking; pleasing;
agreeable; handsome.</def>

<au>Shak. Milton.</au>

<sn>5.</sn> <def>Having such qualities as make success probable;
well adapted to the place; promising; <as>as, a <ex>likely</ex>
young man; a <ex>likely</ex> servant.</as></def>

<hw>Like"ly</hw>, <pos>adv.</pos> <def>In all probability;
probably.</def>

<q>While man was innocent he was <qex>likely</qex> ignorant of
nothing that imported him to know.</q>
<qau>Glanvill.</qau>

<hw>Like"-mind`ed</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>a.</pos> <def>Having a
like disposition or purpose; of the same mind.</def>

<au>Tillotson.</au>

<hw>Lik"en</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>v. t.</pos>
<wordforms>[<pos>imp. & p. p.</pos> <er>Likened</er>
<pr>(?)</pr>; <pos>p. pr. & vb. n.</pos>
<er>Likening</er>.]</wordforms> <ety>[OE. <ets>liknen</ets>. See
<er>Like</er>, <pos>a.</pos>]</ety> <sn>1.</sn> <def>To allege,
or think, to be like; to represent as like; to compare; <as>as,
to <ex>liken</ex> life to a pilgrimage</as>.</def>

<q>Whosoever heareth these sayings of mine, and doeth them, I
will <qex>liken</qex> him unto a wise man which built his house
upon a rock.</q>
<qau>Matt. vii. 24.</qau>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>To make or cause to be like.</def>
<mark>[R.]</mark>

<au>Brougham.</au>

<hw>Like"ness</hw>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[AS.
<ets>gel\'c6cnes</ets>.]</ety> <sn>1.</sn> <def>The state or
quality of being like; similitude; resemblance; similarity;
<as>as, the <ex>likeness</ex> of the one to the other is
remarkable</as>.</def>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>Appearance or form; guise.</def>

<q>An enemy in the <qex>likeness</qex> of a friend.</q>
<qau>L'Estrange.</qau>

<sn>3.</sn> <def>That which closely resembles; a portrait.</def>

<q>[How he looked] the <qex>likenesses</qex> of him which still
remain enable us to imagine.</q>
<qau>Macaulay.</qau>

<sn>4.</sn> <def>A comparison; parable; proverb.</def>
<mark>[Obs.]</mark>

<q>He said to them, Soothly ye shall say to me this
<qex>likeness</qex>, Leech, heal thyself.</q>
<qau>Wyclif (Luke iv. 23).</qau>

<syn>Syn. -- Similarity; parallel; similitude; representation;
portrait; effigy.</syn>

<mhw>{<hw>Lik"er*ous</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>a.</pos>,
<hw>Lik"er*ous*ness</hw>, <pos>n.</pos> }</mhw>
<mark>[Obs.]</mark> <def>See <er>Lickerish</er>,
<er>Lickerishness</er>.</def>

<au>Chaucer.</au>

<hw>Like"wise`</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>adv. & conj.</pos>
<ety>[See <er>Wise</er>, <pos>n.</pos>]</ety> <def>In like
manner; also; moreover; too. See <er>Also</er>.</def>

<q>Go, and do thou <qex>likewise</qex>.</q>
<qau>Luke x. 37.</qau>

<q>For he seeth that wise men die; <qex>likewise</qex> the fool
and the brutish person perish.</q>
<qau>Ps. xlix. 10.</qau>

<hw>Lik"ing</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>p. a.</pos> <def>Looking;
appearing; <as>as, better or worse <ex>liking</ex></as>. See
<er>Like</er>, to look.</def> <mark>[Obs.]</mark>

<au>Chaucer.</au>

<q>Why should he see your faces worse <qex>liking</qex> than the
children which are of your sort ?</q>
<qau>Dan. i. 10.</qau>

<hw>Lik"ing</hw>, <pos>n.</pos> <sn>1.</sn> <def>The state of
being pleasing; a suiting. See <cref>On liking</cref>,
below.</def> <mark>[Obs. or Prov. End.]</mark>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>The state of being pleased with, or attracted
toward, some thing or person; hence, inclination; desire;
pleasure; preference; -- often with <ptcl>for</ptcl>, formerly
with <ptcl>to</ptcl>; <as>as, it is an amusement I have no
<ex>liking</ex> for</as>.</def>

<q>If the human intellect hath once taken a <qex>liking</qex> to
any doctrine, . . . it draws everything else into harmony with
that doctrine, and to its support.</q>
<qau>Bacon.</qau>

<sn>3.</sn> <def>Appearance; look; figure; state of body as to
health or condition.</def> <mark>[Archaic]</mark>

<q>I shall think the worse of fat men, as long as I have an eye
to make difference of men's <qex>liking</qex>.</q>
<qau>Shak.</qau>

<q>Their young ones are in good <qex>liking</qex>.</q>
<qau>Job. xxxix. 4.</qau>

<cs><col>On liking</col>, <cd>on condition of being pleasing to
or suiting; also, on condition of being pleased with; as, to hold
a place of service <xex>on liking<xex>; to engage a servant
<xex>on liking<xex>. <mark>[Obs. or Prov. Eng.]</mark></cd></cs>

<q>Would he be the degenerate scion of that royal line . . . to
be a king <xex>on liking</xex> and on sufferance ?</q>
<qau>Hazlitt.</qau>

<hw>Li"lac</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <altsp>[Also
<asp>lilach</asp>.]</altsp> <ety>[Sp. <ets>lilac</ets>,
<ets>lila</ets>, Ar.<ets>l\'c6lak</ets>, fr. Per.
<ets>l\'c6laj</ets>, <ets>l\'c6lanj</ets>, <ets>l\'c6lang</ets>,
<ets>n\'c6laj</ets>, <ets>n\'c6l</ets>, the indigo plant, or from
the kindred <ets>l\'c6lak</ets> bluish, the flowers being named
from the color. Cf. <er>Anil</er>.]</ety> <sn>1.</sn>
<fld>(Bot.)</fld> <def>A shrub of the genus <spn>Syringa</spn>.
There are six species, natives of Europe and Asia.  <spn>Syringa
vulgaris</spn>, the common lilac, and <spn>S. Persica</spn>, the
Persian lilac, are frequently cultivated for the fragrance and
beauty of their purplish or white flowers. In the British
colonies various other shrubs have this name.</def>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>A light purplish color like that of the flower
of the purplish lilac.</def>

<cs><col>California lilac</col> <fld>(Bot.)</fld>, <cd>a low
shrub with dense clusters of purplish flowers (<spn>Ceanothus
thyrsiflorus</spn>).</cd></cs>

<hw>Lil"a*cin</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <fld>(Chem.)</fld>
<def>See <er>Syringin</er>.</def>

<hw>Lil`i*a"ceous</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>a.</pos> <ety>[L.
<ets>liliaceus</ets>, fr. <ets>lilium</ets> lily. See
<er>Lily</er>.]</ety> <fld>(Bot.)</fld> <sd>(a)</sd> <def>Of or
pertaining to a natural order of which the lily, tulip, and
hyacinth are well-known examples.</def> <sd>(b)</sd> <def>Like
the blossom of a lily in general form.</def>

<hw>Lil"i*al</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>a.</pos> <fld>(Bot.)</fld>
<def>Having a general resemblance to lilies or to liliaceous
plants.</def>

<hw>Lil"ied</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>a.</pos> <def>Covered with,
or having many, lilies.</def>

<q>By sandy Ladon's <qex>lilied</qex> banks.</q>
<qau>Milton.</qau>

<hw>Lill</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>v. i.</pos> <def>To loll.</def>
<mark>[Obs. or Prov.]</mark>

<au>Spenser.</au>

<hw>Lil`li*pu"tian</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <sn>1.</sn>
<def>One belonging to a very diminutive race described in Swift's
\'bdVoyage to Lilliput.\'b8</def>

<sn>2.</sn> Hence: <def>A person or thing of very small
size.</def>

<hw>Lil`li*pu"tian</hw>, <pos>a.</pos> <sn>1.</sn> <def>Of or
having to the imaginary island of <xex>Lilliput</xex> described
by Swift, or to its inhabitants.</def>

<sn>2.</sn> Hence: <def>Of very small size; diminutive;
dwarfed.</def>

<hw>Lil"ly-pil`ly</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos>
<fld>(Bot.)</fld> <def>An Australian myrtaceous tree
(<spn>Eugenia Smithii</spn>), having smooth ovate leaves, and
panicles of small white flowers. The wood is hard and
fine-grained.</def>

<hw>Lilt</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>v. i.</pos> <ety>[Cf. Norw.
<ets>lilla</ets>, <ets>lirla</ets>, to sing in a high
tone.]</ety> <sn>1.</sn> <def>To do anything with animation and
quickness, as to skip, fly, or hop.</def> <mark>[Prov.
Eng.]</mark>

<au>Wordsworth.</au>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>To sing cheerfully.</def> <mark>[Scot.]</mark>

<hw>Lilt</hw>, <pos>v. t.</pos> <def>To utter with spirit,
animation, or gayety; to sing with spirit and liveliness.</def>

<q>A classic lecture, rich in sentiment,
With scraps of thundrous epic <qex>lilted</qex> out
By violet-hooded doctors.</q>
<qau>Tennyson.</qau>

<hw>Lilt</hw>, <pos>n.</pos> <sn>1.</sn> <def>Animated, brisk
motion; spirited rhythm; sprightliness.</def>

<q>The movement, the <qex>lilt</qex>, and the subtle charm of the
verse.</q>
<qau>F. Harrison.</qau>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>A lively song or dance; a cheerful tune.</def>

<q>The housewife went about her work, or spun at her wheel, with
a <qex>lilt</qex> upon her lips.</q>
<qau>J. C. Shairp.</qau>

<hw>Lil"y</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos>; <plu>pl.
<plw>Lilies</plw> <pr>(#)</pr></plu>. <ety>[AS. <ets>lilie</ets>,
L. <ets>lilium</ets>, Gr. <?/. Cf.
<er>Flower-de-luce</er>.]</ety> <sn>1.</sn> <fld>(Bot.)</fld>
<def>A plant and flower of the genus <spn>Lilium</spn>,
endogenous bulbous plants, having a regular perianth of six
colored pieces, six stamens, and a superior three-celled
ovary.</def>

<note><hand/ There are nearly fifty species, all found in the
North Temperate zone. <spn>Lilium candidum</spn> and <spn>L.
longiflorum</spn> are the common white lilies of gardens; <spn>L.
Philadelphicum</spn> is the wild red lily of the Atlantic States.
<spn>L. Chalcedonicum</spn> is supposed to be the \'bdlily of the
field\'b8 in our Lord's parable; <spn>L. auratum</spn> is the
great gold-banded lily of Japan.</note>

<sn>2.</sn> <fld>(Bot.)</fld> <def>A name given to handsome
flowering plants of several genera, having some resemblance in
color or form to a true lily, as <spn>Pancratium</spn>,
<spn>Crinum</spn>, <spn>Amaryllis</spn>, <spn>Nerine</spn>,
etc.</def>

<sn>3.</sn> <def>That end of a compass needle which should point
to the north; -- so called as often ornamented with the figure of
a lily or fleur-de-lis.</def>

<q>But sailing further, it veers its <qex>lily</qex> to the
west.</q>
<qau>Sir T. Browne. </qau>

<cs><col>African lily</col> <fld>(Bot.)</fld>, <cd>the
blue-flowered <spn>Agapanthus umbellatus</spn>.</cd> --
<col>Atamasco lily</col> <fld>(Bot.)</fld>, <cd>a plant of the
genus <spn>Zephyranthes</spn> (<spn>Z. Atamasco</spn>), having a
white and pink funnelform perianth, with six petal-like divisions
resembling those of a lily. <au>Gray</au>.</cd> --
<col>Blackberry lily</col> <fld>(Bot.)</fld>, <cd>the
<spn>Pardanthus Chinensis</spn>, the black seeds of which form a
dense like a blackberry.</cd> -- <col>Bourbon lily</col>
<fld>(Bot.)</fld>, <cd><xex>Lilium candidum<xex>. See
<xex>Illust<xex>.</cd> -- <col>Butterfly lily</col>.
<fld>(Bot.)</fld> <cd>Same as <er>Mariposa lily</er>, in the
Vocabulary.</cd> -- <col>Lily daffodil</col> <fld>(Bot.)</fld>,
<cd>a plant of the genus <spn>Narcissus</spn>, and its
flower.</cd> -- <col>Lily encrinite</col> <fld>(Paleon.)</fld>,
<cd>a fossil encrinite, esp. <spn>Encrinus liliiformis</spn>. See
<er>Encrinite</er>.</cd> -- <col>Lily hyacinth</col>
<fld>(Bot.)</fld>, <cd>a plant of the genus
<spn>Hyacinthus</spn>.</cd> -- <col>Lily iron</col>, <cd>a kind
of harpoon with a detachable head of peculiar shape, used in
capturing swordfish.</cd>
<-- illustration: Lily Iron -->
 -- <col>Lily of the valley</col> <fld>(Bot.)</fld>, <cd>a low
perennial herb (<spn>Convallaria majalis</spn>), having a raceme
of nodding, fragrant, white flowers.</cd>
<-- illustration: Lily of the valley -->
 -- <col>Lily pad</col>, <cd>the large floating leaf of the water
lily. <mark>[U. S.]</mark> <au>Lowell</au>.</cd> -- <col>Tiger
lily</col> <fld>(Bot.)</fld>, <cd><spn>Lilium tigrinum</spn>, the
sepals of which are blotched with black.</cd> -- <col>Turk's-cap
lily</col> <fld>(Bot.)</fld> <cd><spn>Lilium Martagon</spn>, a
red lily with recurved sepals; also, the similar American lily,
<spn>L. superbum</spn>.</cd> -- <col>Water lily</col>
<fld>(Bot.)</fld>, <cd>the <spn>Nymph\'91a</spn>, a plant with
floating roundish leaves, and large flowers having many petals,
usually white, but sometimes pink, red, blue, or yellow. [See
<xex>Illust<xex>. of <er>Nymph\'91a</er>.]</cd></cs>

<hw>Lil"y-liv`ered</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>a.</pos>
<def>White-livered; cowardly.</def>

<hw>Li*ma"ceous</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>a.</pos> <ety>[L.
<ets>limax</ets>, <ets>limacis</ets>, slug, snail: cf. F.
<ets>limac\'82</ets>.]</ety> <fld>(Zo\'94l.)</fld>
<def>Pertaining to, or like, Limax, or the slugs.</def>

<hw>\'d8Lim`a*ci"na</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[NL.,
From L. <ets>limax</ets>, <ets>limacis</ets>, a slug.]</ety>
<fld>(Zo\'94l.)</fld> <def>A genus of small spiral pteropods,
common in the Arctic and Antarctic seas. It contributes to the
food of the right whales.</def>

<hw>\'d8Li`ma`<?/on"</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[F.
<ets>lima<?/on</ets>, lit., a snail.]</ety> <fld>(Geom.)</fld>
<def>A curve of the fourth degree, invented by Pascal. Its polar
equation is <xex>r = a</xex> cos <xex><?/</xex> +
<xex>b</xex>.</def>

<hw>Li"maille</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[F., fr.
<ets>limer</ets> to file. See <er>Limation</er>.]</ety>
<def>Filings of metal.</def> <mark>[Obs.]</mark> \'bdAn ounce . .
. of silver <xex>lymaille</xex>.\'b8

<au>Chaucer.</au>

<hw>Li"man</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[F.
<ets>limon</ets>, fr. L. <ets>limus</ets> slime.]</ety> <def>The
deposit of slime at the mouth of a river; slime.</def>

<hw>Li*ma"tion</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[L.
<ets>limatus</ets>, p. p. of <ets>limare</ets> to file, fr.
<ets>lima</ets> file : cf. F. <ets>limation</ets>.]</ety>
<def>The act of filing or polishing.</def>

<hw>Li"ma*ture</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[L.
<ets>limatura</ets>. See <er>Limation</er>.]</ety> <sn>1.</sn>
<def>The act of filing.</def>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>That which is filed off; filings.</def>

<au>Johnson.</au>

<hw>\'d8Li"max</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[L.]</ety>
<fld>(Zo\'94l.)</fld> <def>A genus of airbreathing mollusks,
including the common garden slugs. They have a small rudimentary
shell. The breathing pore is on the right side of the neck.
Several species are troublesome in gardens. See
<er>Slug</er>.</def>

<hw>Limb</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[OE.
<ets>lim</ets>, AS. <ets>lim</ets>; akin to Icel. <ets>limr</ets>
limb, <ets>lim</ets> branch of a tree, Sw. & Dan. <ets>lem</ets>
limb; cf. also AS. <ets>li<?/</ets>, OHG. <ets>lid</ets>,
<ets>gilid</ets>, G. <ets>glied</ets>, Goth. <ets>lipus</ets>.
Cf. <er>Lith</er>, <er>Limber</er>.]</ety> <sn>1.</sn> <def>A
part of a tree which extends from the trunk and separates into
branches and twigs; a large branch.</def>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>An arm or a leg of a human being; a leg, arm, or
wing of an animal.</def>

<q>A second Hector for his grim aspect,
And large proportion of his strong-knit <qex>limbs</qex>.</q>
<qau>Shak.</qau>

<sn>3.</sn> <def>A thing or person regarded as a part or member
of, or attachment to, something else.</def>

<au>Shak.</au>

<q>That little <qex>limb</qex> of the devil has cheated the
gallows.</q>
<qau>Sir W. Scott.</qau>

<sn>4.</sn> <def>An elementary piece of the mechanism of a
lock.</def>

<cs><col>Limb of the law</col>, <cd>a lawyer or an officer of the
law. <mark>[Colloq.]</mark></cd></cs>

<au>Landor.</au>

<hw>Limb</hw>, <pos>v. t.</pos> <sn>1.</sn> <def>To supply with
limbs.</def> <mark>[R.]</mark>

<au>Milton.</au>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>To dismember; to tear off the limbs of.</def>

<hw>Limb</hw>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[L. <ets>limbus</ets> border.
Cf. <er>Limbo</er>, <er>Limbus</er>.]</ety> <def>A border or
edge, in certain special uses.</def> <sd>(a)</sd>
<fld>(Bot.)</fld> <def>The border or upper spreading part of a
monopetalous corolla, or of a petal, or sepal; blade.</def>
<sd>(b)</sd> <fld>(Astron.)</fld> <def>The border or edge of the
disk of a heavenly body, especially of the sun and moon.</def>
<sd>(c)</sd> <def>The graduated margin of an arc or circle, in an
instrument for measuring angles.</def>

<hw>Lim"bat</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[Etymol.
uncertain.]</ety> <def>A cooling periodical wind in the Isle of
Cyprus, blowing from the northwest from eight o'clock, <sc>A.
M.</sc>, to the middle of the day or later.</def>

<hw>Lim"bate</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>a.</pos> <ety>[L.
<ets>limbatus</ets>, fr. <ets>limbus</ets> border, edge. See
<er>Limbus</er>.]</ety> <fld>(Bot. &  Zo\'94l.)</fld>
<def>Bordered, as when one color is surrounded by an edging of
another.</def>

<hw>Lim"bec</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[Abbrev. of
<ets>alembic</ets>.]</ety> <def>An alembic; a still.</def>
<mark>[Obs.]</mark>

<au>Spenser. Shak.</au>

<hw>Lim"bec</hw>, <pos>v. t.</pos> <def>To distill.</def>
<mark>[Obs.]</mark>

<au>Dryden.</au>

<hw>Limbed</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>a.</pos> <def>Having limbs; --
much used in composition; <as>as, large<ex>-limbed</ex>;
short<ex>-limbed</ex>.</as></def>

<q>Innumerous living creatures, perfect forms,
<qex>Limbed</qex> and full grown.</q>
<qau>Milton.</qau>

<hw>Lim"ber</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[For
<ets>limmer</ets>, Icel. <ets>limar</ets> branches, boughs, pl.
of <ets>lim</ets>; akin to E. <ets>limb</ets>. See <er>Limb</er>
a branch.]</ety> <sn>1.</sn> <pluf>pl.</pluf> <def>The shafts or
thills of a wagon or carriage.</def> <mark>[Prov. Eng.]</mark>

<sn>2.</sn> <fld>(Mil.)</fld> <def>The detachable fore part of a
gun carriage, consisting of two wheels, an axle, and a shaft to
which the horses are attached. On top is an ammunition box upon
which the cannoneers sit.</def>

<sn>3.</sn> <pluf>pl.</pluf> <fld>(Naut.)</fld> <def>Gutters or
conduits on each side of the keelson to afford a passage for
water to the pump well.</def>

<cs><col>Limber boards</col> <fld>(Naut.)</fld>, <cd>short pieces
of plank forming part of the lining of a ship's floor immediately
above the timbers, so as to prevent the limbers from becoming
clogged.</cd> -- <mcol><col>Limber box <or/ chest</col></mcol>
<fld>(Mil.)</fld>, <cd>a box on the limber for carrying
ammunition.</cd> -- <mcol><col>Limber rope</col>, <col>Limber
chain</col> <or/  <col>Limber clearer</col></mcol>
<fld>(Naut.)</fld>, <cd>a rope or chain passing through the
limbers of a ship, by which they may be cleared of dirt that
chokes them. <au>Totten</au>.</cd> -- <col>Limber strake</col>
<fld>(Shipbuilding)</fld>, <cd>the first course of inside
planking next the keelson.</cd></cs>

<hw>Lim"ber</hw> <pos>v. t.</pos> <wordforms>[<pos>imp. & p.
p.</pos> <er>Limbered</er> <pr>(?)</pr>; <pos>p. pr. & vb.
n.</pos> <er>Limbering</er>.]</wordforms> <fld>(Mil.)</fld>
<def>To attach to the limber; <as>as, to <ex>limber</ex> a
gun</as>.</def>

<cs><col>To limber up</col>, <cd>to change a gun carriage into a
four-wheeled vehicle by attaching the limber.</cd></cs>
<-- (b) to render limber, esp. to perform light exercises so as
to stretch the muscles and tendons gently in preparation for
vigorous activity (and thus to avoid straining the muscles by too
sudden exertion after prolonged inactivity) --> 

<hw>Lim"ber</hw>, <pos>a.</pos> <ety>[Akin to <ets>lim</ets>, a.
<?/ See <er>Limp</er>, <pos>a.</pos>]</ety> <def>Easily bent;
flexible; pliant; yielding.</def>

<au>Milton.</au>

<q>The bargeman that doth row with long and <qex>limber</qex>
oar.</q>
<qau>Turbervile.</qau>

<hw>Lim"ber</hw>, <pos>v. t.</pos> <def>To cause to become
limber; to make flexible or pliant.</def>

<au>Richardson.</au>

<hw>Lim"ber*ness</hw>, <pos>n.</pos> <def>The quality or state of
being limber; flexibleness.</def>

<au>Boyle.</au>

<hw>Limb"less</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>a.</pos> <def>Destitute of
limbs.</def>

<hw>Limb"meal`</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>adv.</pos> <ety>[See

<au>Shak.</au>

<mhw>{ <hw>Lim"bo</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <hw>Lim"bus</hw>
<pr>(?)</pr>, }</mhw> <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[L. <ets>limbus</ets>
border, edge <ets>in limbo</ets> on the border. Cf. <er>Limb</er>
border.]</ety> <sn>1.</sn> <fld>(Scholastic Theol.)</fld> <def>An
extramundane region where certain classes of souls were supposed
to await the judgment.</def>

<q>As far from help as <qex>Limbo</qex> is from bliss.</q>
<qau>Shak.</qau>

<q>A <qex>Limbo</qex> large and broad, since called
The Paradise of fools.</q>
<qau>Milton.</qau>

<note><hand/ The <xex>limbus patrum</xex> was considered as a
place for the souls of good men who lived before the coming of
our Savior. The <xex>limbus infantium</xex> was said to be a
similar place for the souls of unbaptized infants. To these was
added, in the popular belief, the <xex>limbus fatuorum</xex>, or
fool's paradise, regarded as a receptacle of all vanity and
nonsense.</note>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>Hence: Any real or imaginary place of restraint
or confinement; a prison; <as>as, to put a man in
<ex>limbo</ex></as>.</def>

<-- hence: a state of waiting, or uncertainty, in which final
judgment concerning the outcome of a decision is postponed,
perhaps indefinitely; neglect for an indefinite time -->

<sn>3.</sn> <fld>(Anat.)</fld> <def>A border or margin; <as>as,
the <ex>limbus</ex> of the cornea</as>.</def>

<-- 4. A West Indian dance contest, in which participants must
dance under a pole which is lowered successively until only one
participant can successfully pass under, without falling.
[MW10 <ety> Jamaican E limba to bend, fr. E. limber (1950)]. 
Often performed at celebrations, such as weddings. (1950-1996)
-->

<hw>Lim"bous</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>a.</pos> <ety>[See
<er>Limbus</er>.]</ety> <fld>(Anat.)</fld> <def>With slightly
overlapping borders; -- said of a suture.</def>

<hw>Lime</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[See <er>Leam</er>

<au>Halliwell.</au>

<hw>Lime</hw>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[Formerly <ets>line</ets>, for
earlier <ets>lind</ets>. See <er>Linden</er>.]</ety>
<fld>(Bot.)</fld> <def>The linden tree. See
<er>Linden</er>.</def>

<hw>Lime</hw>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[F. <ets>lime</ets>; of Persian
origin. See <er>Lemon</er>.]</ety> <fld>(Bot.)</fld> <def>A fruit
allied to the lemon, but much smaller; also, the tree which bears
it. There are two kinds; <spn>Citrus Medica</spn>, var.
<spn>acida</spn> which is intensely sour, and the sweet lime
(<spn>C. Medica</spn>, var. <spn>Limetta</spn>) which is only
slightly sour.</def>

<hw>Lime</hw>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[AS. <ets>l\'c6m</ets>; akin to
D. <ets>lijm</ets>, G. <ets>leim</ets>, OHG. <ets>l\'c6m</ets>,
L. <ets>limus</ets> mud, <ets>linere</ets> to smear, and E.
<ets>loam</ets>. <ets><?/</ets>. Cf. <er>Loam</er>,
<er>Liniment</er>.]</ety> <sn>1.</sn> <def>Birdlime.</def>

<q>Like the <qex>lime</qex>
That foolish birds are caught with.</q>
<qau>Wordsworth.</qau>

<sn>2.</sn> <fld>(Chem.)</fld> <def>Oxide of calcium; the white
or gray, caustic substance, usually called
<altname>quicklime</altname>, obtained by calcining limestone or
shells, the heat driving off carbon dioxide and leaving lime. It
develops great heat when treated with water, forming slacked
lime, <-- ##sic, and thus intended (see slack, v.t.), but now it
should be "slaked lime" -->and is an essential ingredient of
cement, plastering, mortar, etc.</def><-- <chform>CaO</chform>
-->

<note><hand/ Lime is the principal constituent of limestone,
marble, chalk, bones, shells, etc.</note>

<cs><col>Caustic lime</col>, <cd>calcium hydrate or slacked lime;
also, in a less technical sense, calcium oxide or
quicklime.</cd><-- Calcium hydroxide = slaked lime --> --
<col>Lime burner</col>, <cd>one who burns limestone, shells,
etc., to make lime.</cd> -- <col>Lime light</col>. <cd>See
<cref>Calcium light</cref> under <er>Calcium</er>.<-- as one
word, limelight means the center of public attention, esp. in the
phrase "in the limelight" --></cd> -- <col>Lime pit</col>, <cd>a
limestone quarry.</cd> -- <mcol><col>Lime rod</col>, <col>Lime
twig</col></mcol>, <cd>a twig smeared with birdlime; hence, that
which catches; a snare. <au>Chaucer</au>.</cd></cs>

<hw>Lime</hw>, <pos>v. t.</pos> <wordforms>[<pos>imp. & p.
p.</pos> <er>Limed</er> <pr>(?)</pr>; <pos>p. pr. & vb. n.</pos>
<er>Liming</er>.]</wordforms> <ety>[Cf. AS. <ets>gel\'c6man</ets>
to glue or join together. See <er>Lime</er> a viscous
substance.]</ety> <sn>1.</sn> </def>To smear with a viscous
substance, as birdlime.</def>

<q>These twigs, in time, will come to be <qex>limed</qex>.</q>
<qau>L'Estrange.</qau>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>To entangle; to insnare.</def>

<q>We had <qex>limed</qex> ourselves
With open eyes, and we must take the chance.</q>
<qau>Tennyson.</qau>

<sn>3.</sn> <def>To treat with lime, or oxide or hydrate of
calcium; to manure with lime; <as>as, to <ex>lime</ex> hides for
removing the hair; to <ex>lime</ex> sails in order to whiten
them.</as></def>

<q>Land may be improved by draining, marling, and
<qex>liming</qex>.</q>
<qau>Sir J. Child.</qau>

<sn>4.</sn> <def>To cement.</def> \'bdWho gave his blood to
<xex>lime</xex> the stones together.\'b8

<au>Shak.</au>

<-- Lime, lime-colored. adj. having a yellowish-green color like
that of the lime. -- n. the lime color. -->

sometimes contains also magnesium carbonate, and is then called
<xex>magnesian or dolomitic limestone</xex>. Crystalline
limestone is called <xex>marble</xex>.</def>

<hw>\'d8Li*mic"o*l\'91</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n. pl.</pos>

<hw>Lim"it</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[From L.
<ets>limes</ets>, <ets>limitis</ets>: cf. F.<ets>limite</ets>;
<ets>-or</ets> from E. <ets>limit</ets>, <er>v</er>. See
<er>Limit</er>, <pos>v. t.</pos>]</ety> <sn>1.</sn> <def>That
which terminates, circumscribes, restrains, or confines; the
bound, border, or edge; the utmost extent; <as>as, the
<ex>limit</ex> of a walk, of a town, of a country; the
<ex>limits</ex> of human knowledge or endeavor.</as></def>

<q>As eager of the chase, the maid
Beyond the forest's verdant <qex>limits</qex> strayed.</q>
<qau>Pope.</qau>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>The space or thing defined by limits.</def>

<q>The archdeacon hath divided it
Into three <qex>limits</qex> very equally.</q>
<qau>Shak.</qau>

<sn>3.</sn> <def>That which terminates a period of time; hence,
the period itself; the full time or extent.</def>

<q>The dateless <qex>limit</qex> of thy dear exile.</q>
<qau>Shak.</qau>

<q>The <qex>limit</qex> of your lives is out.</q>
<qau>Shak.</qau>

<sn>4.</sn> <def>A restriction; a check; a curb; a
hindrance.</def>

<q>I prithee, give no <qex>limits</qex> to my tongue.</q>
<qau>Shak.</qau>

<sn>5.</sn> <fld>(Logic & Metaph.)</fld> <def>A determining
feature; a distinguishing characteristic a differentia.</def>

<sn>6.</sn> <fld>(Math.)</fld> <def>A determinate quantity, to
which a variable one continually approaches, and may differ from
it by less than any given difference, but to which, under the law
of variation, the variable can never become exactly
equivalent.</def>

<cs><col>Elastic limit</col>. <cd>See under
<er>Elastic</er>.</cd> -- <col>Prison limits</col>, <cd>a
definite, extent of space in or around a prison, within which a
prisoner has liberty to go and come.</cd></cs>

<syn>Syn. -- Boundary; border; edge; termination; restriction;
bound; confine.</syn>

<hw>Lim"it</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>v. t.</pos>
<wordforms>[<pos>imp. & p. p.</pos> <er>Limited</er>; <pos>p. pr.
& vb. n.</pos> <er>Limiting</er>.]</wordforms> <ety>[F.
<ets>limiter</ets>, L. <ets>limitare</ets>, fr. 
<ets>limes</ets>, <ets>limitis</ets>, limit; prob. akin to
<ets>limen</ets> threshold, E. <ets>eliminate</ets>; cf. L.
<ets>limus</ets> sidelong.]</ety> <def>To apply a limit to, or
set a limit for; to terminate, circumscribe, or restrict, by a
limit or limits; <as>as, to <ex>limit</ex> the acreage of a crop;
to <ex>limit</ex> the issue of paper money; to <ex>limit</ex>
one's ambitions or aspirations; to <ex>limit</ex> the meaning of
a word.</as></def>

<cs><col>Limiting parallels</col> <fld>(Astron.)</fld>, <cd>those
parallels of latitude between which only an occultation of a star
or planet by the moon, in a given case, can occur.</cd></cs>

<hw>Lim"it</hw>, <pos>v. i.</pos> <def>To beg, or to exercise
functions, within a certain limited region; <as>as, a
<ex>limiting</ex> friar</as>.</def> <mark>[Obs.]</mark>

<hw>Lim"i*ta*ry</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>a.</pos>
<ety>[L.<ets>limitaris</ets>. See <er>Limit</er> , <pos>v.
t.</pos>]</ety> <sn>1.</sn> <def>Placed at the limit, as a
guard.</def> \'bdProud <xex>limitary</xex> cherub.\'b8

<au>Milton.</au>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>Confined within limits; limited in extent,
authority, power, etc.</def> \'bdThe <xex>limitary</xex>
ocean.\'b8

<au>Trench.</au>

<q>The poor, <qex>limitary</qex> creature calling himself a man
of the world.</q>
<qau>De Quincey.</qau>

<sn>3.</sn> <def>Limiting, or tending to limit;
restrictive.</def>

<q>Doctrines <qex>limitary</qex>, if not subversive of the papal
power.</q>
<qau>Milman.</qau>

<hw>Lim"i*ta*ry</hw>, <pos>n.</pos>; <plu>pl. <plw>-ries</plw>
<pr>(<?/)</pr>.</plu> <sn>1.</sn> <def>That which serves to
limit; a boundary; border land.</def> <mark>[Obs.]</mark>

<au>Fuller.</au>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>A limiter. See <er>Limiter</er>, 2.</def>

<hw>Lim"i*tate</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>a.</pos> <ety>[L.
<ets>limitatus</ets>, p. p. of <ets>limitare</ets> to limit. See
<er>Limit</er>, <pos>v. t.</pos> ]</ety> <def>Bounded by a
