<hw>Lim`i*ta"tion</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[L.
<ets>limitatio</ets>: cf. F. <ets>Limitation</ets>. See
<er>Limit</er>, <pos>v. t.</pos>]</ety> <sn>1.</sn> <def>The act
of limiting; the state or condition of being limited; <as>as, the
<ex>limitation</ex> of his authority was approved by the
council</as>.</def>

<q>They had no right to mistake the <qex>limitation</qex> . . .
of their own faculties, for an inherent <qex>limitation</qex> of
the possible modes of existence in the universe.</q>
<qau>J. S. Mill.</qau>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>That which limits; a restriction; a
qualification; a restraining condition, defining circumstance, or
qualifying conception; <as>as, <ex>limitations</ex> of
thought</as>.</def>

<q>The cause of error is ignorance what restraints and
<qex>limitations</qex> all principles have in regard of the
matter whereunto they are applicable.</q>
<qau>Hooker.</qau>

<sn>3.</sn> <def>A certain precinct within which friars were
allowed to beg, or exercise their functions; also, the time
during which they were permitted to exercise their functions in
such a district.</def>

<au>Chaucer. Latimer.</au>

<sn>4.</sn> <def>A limited time within or during which something
is to be done.</def>

<q>You have stood your <qex>limitation</qex>, and the tribunes
Endue you with the people's voice.</q>
<qau>Shak.</qau>

<sn>5.</sn> <fld>(Law)</fld> <sd>(a)</sd> <def>A certain period
limited by statute after which the claimant shall not enforce his
claims by suit.</def> <sd>(b)</sd> <def>A settling of an estate
or property by specific rules.</def> <sd>(c)</sd> <def>A
restriction of power; <as>as, a constitutional
<ex>limitation</ex></as>.</def>

<au>Wharton. Bouvier.</au>

<cs><col>To know one's own limitations</col>, <cd>to know the
reach and limits of one's abilities.</cd></cs>

<au>A. R. Wallace.</au>

<hw>Lim"it*ed</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>a.</pos> <def>Confined
within limits; narrow; circumscribed; restricted; <as>as, our
views of nature are very <ex>limited</ex></as>.</def>

<cs><col>Limited company</col>, <cd>a company in which the
liability of each shareholder is limited by the number of shares
he has taken, so that he can not be called on to contribute
beyond the amount of his shares. <mark>[Eng.]</mark> <au>Mozley &
W.</au></cd></cs>

limitation.</def>

<hw>lim"it*ed*ness</hw>, <pos>n.</pos> <def>The quality of being
limited.</def>

<def>One who, or that which, limits.</def>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>A friar licensed to beg within certain bounds,
or whose duty was limited to a certain district.</def>
<altsp>[Formerly written also <asp>limitour</asp>.]</altsp>

<au>Chaucer.</au>

<q>A <qex>limitour</qex> of the Gray Friars, in the time of his

<qau>Latimer.</qau>

<sn>2.</sn> <fld>(Zo\'94l.)</fld> <def>A mongrel, as a cross

<hw>Limn</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>v. t.</pos>
<wordforms>[<pos>imp. & p. p.</pos> <er>Limned</er> <pr>(?)</pr>;
<pos>p. pr. &  vb. n.</pos> <er>Limning</er>
<pr>(?)</pr>.]</wordforms> <ety>[OE. <ets>limnen</ets>, fr.
<ets>luminen</ets>, for <ets>enluminen</ets>, F.
<ets>enluminer</ets> to illuminate, to limn, LL.
<ets>illuminare</ets> to paint. <?/. See <er>Illuminate</er>,
<er>Luminous</er>.]</ety> <sn>1.</sn> <def>To draw or paint;
especially, to represent in an artistic way with pencil or
brush.</def>

<q>Let a painter carelessly <qex>limn</qex> out a million of
faces, and you shall find them all different.</q>
<qau>Sir T. Browne. </qau>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>To illumine, as books or parchments, with
ornamental figures, letters, or borders.</def>

<hw>Li*moges"</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <def>A city of
Southern France.</def>

<cs><col>Limoges enamel</col>, <cd>a kind of enamel ware in which
the enamel is applied to the whole surface of a metal plaque,
vase, or the like, and painted in enamel colors. The art was
brought to a high degree of perfection in Limoges in the 16th
century.</cd> -- <col>Limoges ware</col>. <sd>(a)</sd>
<cd>Articles decorated with Limoges enamel</cd>. <sd>(b)</sd>
<cd>Articles of porcelain, etc., manufactured at
Limoges.</cd></cs>

<hw>Li*mo"ni*ad</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[L.
<ets>limoniades</ets>, pl., Gr. <?/, fr. <?/ meadow.]</ety>
<fld>(Class. Myth.)</fld> <def>A nymph of the meadows; -- called
also <altname>Limniad</altname>.</def>

<hw>Li*mo"nin</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[From NL.

the lemon.]</ety> <fld>(Chem.)</fld> <def>A bitter, white,

<hw>Li"mon*ite</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[Gr. <?/ any
moist grassy place, a meadow : cf. F. <ets>limonite</ets>, G.
<ets>limonit</ets>.]</ety> <fld>(Min.)</fld> <def>Hydrous
sesquixoide of iron, an important ore of iron, occurring in
stalactitic, mammillary, or earthy forms, of a dark brown color,
yellowish brown powder. It includes bog iron. Also called
<altname>brown hematite</altname>.</def>

Gr. <?/. hunger.]</ety> <fld>(Med.)</fld> <def>A ravenous
appetite caused by disease; excessive and morbid hunger.</def>

<hw>Limp</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>v. i.</pos>
<wordforms>[<pos>imp. & p. p.</pos> <er>Limped</er> <pr>(?)</pr>;
<pos>p. pr. & vb. n.</pos> <er>Limping</er>.]</wordforms>
<ety>[Cf. AS. <ets>lemp</ets>healt lame, OHG. <ets>limphen</ets>
to limp, be weak; perh. akin to E. <ets>lame</ets>, or to
<ets>limp</ets>, a <?/.]</ety> <def>To halt; to walk lamely. Also
used figuratively.</def>

<au>Shak.</au>

<hw>Limp</hw>, <pos>n.</pos> <def>A halt; the act of
limping.</def>

<hw>Limp</hw>, <pos>n.</pos> <fld>(Ore Washing)</fld> <def>A
scraper for removing poor ore or refuse from the sieve.</def>

<hw>Limp</hw>, <pos>a.</pos> <ety>[Cf. Icel. <ets>limpa</ets>
limpness, weakness, and E.<ets>lap</ets>, <pos>n.</pos>,
<ets>lop</ets>, <pos>v. t.</pos> Cf. <er>Limber</er>,
<pos>a.</pos>]</ety> <sn>1.</sn> <def>Flaccid; flabby, as
flesh.</def>

<au>Walton.</au>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>Lacking stiffness; flimsy; <as>as, a
<ex>limp</ex> cravat</as>.</def>

<hw>Limp"er</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <def>One who
limps.</def>

<hw>Lim"pet</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[Prob. through
French fr. L. <ets>lepas</ets>, <ets>-adis</ets>, Gr. <?/,
<?/.]</ety> <fld>(Zo\'94l.)</fld> <sn>1.</sn> <def>In a general
sense, any hatshaped, or conical, gastropod shell.</def>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>Any one of many species of marine shellfish of
the order Docoglossa, mostly found adhering to rocks, between
tides.</def>

<note><hand/ The common European limpets of the genus
<spn>Patella</spn> (esp. <spn>P. vulgata</spn>) are extensively
used as food. The common New England species is <spn>Acm\'91a
testudinalis</spn>. Numerous species of limpets occur on the
Pacific coast of America, some of them of large size.</note>

<sn>3.</sn> <def>Any species of <spn>Siphonaria</spn>, a genus of
limpet-shaped Pulmonifera, living between tides, on rocks.</def>

<sn>4.</sn> <def>A keyhole limpet. See <er>Fissurella</er>.</def>

<hw>Lim"pid</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>a.</pos>
<ety>[L.<ets>limpidus</ets>; akin to Gr. <?/ to shine: cf. F.
<ets>limpide</ets>. Cf. <er>Lamp</er>.]</ety> <def>Characterized
by clearness or transparency; clear; <as>as, a <ex>limpid</ex>
stream</as>.</def>

<q>Springs which were clear, fresh, and <qex>limpid</qex>.</q>
<qau>Woodward.</qau>

<syn>Syn. -- Clear; transparent; pellucid; lucid; pure; crystal;
translucent; bright.</syn>

<hw>Limp"kin</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos>
<fld>(Zo\'94l.)</fld> <def>Either one of two species of wading
birds of the genus <spn>Aramus</spn>, intermediate between the
cranes and rails. The limpkins are remarkable for the great
length of the toes. One species (<spn>A. giganteus</spn>)
inhabits Florida and the West Indies; the other (<spn>A.
scolopaceus</spn>) is found in South America. Called also
<altname>courlan</altname>, and <altname>crying
bird</altname>.</def>

<hw>Limp"ness</hw>, <pos>n.</pos> <def>The quality or state of
being limp.</def>

<pos>a.</pos>, and cf. <ets>W</ets>. <ets>llymsi</ets> having a

<hw>\'d8Li"mu</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <fld>(Bot.)</fld>
<def>The Hawaiian name for seaweeds. Over sixty kinds are used as
food, and have species names, as <spn>Limu Lipoa</spn>, <spn>Limu
palawai</spn>, etc.</def>

<hw>Lim"ule</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[F.]</ety>
<fld>(Zo\'94l.)</fld> <def>A limulus.</def>

<hw>\'d8Lim`u*loi"de*a</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n. pl.</pos>
<ety>[NL. See <er>Limulus</er>, and <er>-oid</er>.]</ety>
<fld>(Zo\'94l.)</fld> <def>An order of Merostomata, including
among living animals the genus Limulus, with various allied
fossil genera, mostly of the Carboniferous period. Called also
<spn>Xiphosura</spn>.</def>

<note><hand/ There are six pairs of leglike organs, surrounding
the mouth, most of which terminate in claws; those of the first
pair (probably mandibles) are the smallest; the others have the
basal joints thickened and spinose, to serve as jaws, while the
terminal joints serve as legs. This group is intermediate, in
some characteristics, between crustaceans and certain arachnids
(scorpions), but the respiration is by means of lamellate gills
borne upon the five posterior abdominal appendages, which are
flat and united in pairs by their inner edges, and are protected
by the lidlike anterior pair, which also bear the genital
orifices.</note>

<hw>\'d8Lim"u*lus</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos>; <plu>pl.
<plw>Limuli</plw> <pr>(-l<imac/)</pr></plu>. <ety>[L., dim. of
<ets>limus</ets> sidelong, askance.]</ety> <fld>(Zo\'94l.)</fld>
<def>The only existing genus of Merostomata. It includes only a
few species from the East Indies, and one (<spn>Limulus
polyphemus</spn>) from the Atlantic coast of North America.
Called also <altname>Molucca crab</altname>, <altname>king
crab</altname>, <altname>horseshoe crab</altname>, and
<altname>horsefoot</altname>.</def>

<hw>Lim"y</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>a.</pos> <ety>[See 4th

consisting of, lime; viscous. \'bd<xex>Limy</xex> snares.'</def>

<au>Spenser.</au>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>Containing lime; <as>as, a <ex>limy</ex>
soil</as>.</def>

<sn>3.</sn> <def>Resembling lime; having the qualities of
lime.</def>

<hw>Lin"den</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[Orig. an adj.

<hw>Line</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[OE.
<ets>lin</ets>. See <er>Linen</er>.]</ety> <sn>1.</sn> <def>Flax;

<hw>Line</hw>, <pos>v. t.</pos> <wordforms>[<pos>imp. & p.
p.</pos> <er>Lined</er> <pr>(?)</pr>; <pos>p. pr. & vb. n.</pos>
<er>Lining</er>.]</wordforms> <sn>1.</sn> <def>To cover the inner
surface of; <as>as, to <ex>line</ex> a cloak with silk or fur; to
<ex>line</ex> a box with paper or tin.</as></def>

<q>The inside <qex>lined</qex> with rich carnation silk.</q>
<qau>W. Browne.</qau>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>To put something in the inside of; to fill; to
supply, as a purse with money.</def>

<q>The charge amounteth very high for any one man's purse, except
<qex>lined</qex> beyond ordinary, to reach unto.</q>
<qau>Carew.</qau>

<q>Till coffee has her stomach <qex>lined</qex>.</q>
<qau>Swift.</qau>

<sn>3.</sn> <def>To place persons or things along the side of for
security or defense; to strengthen by adding; to fortify; <as>as,
to <ex>line</ex> works with soldiers</as>.</def>

<q><qex>Line</qex> and new repair our towns of war
With men of courage and with means defendant.</q>
<qau>Shak.</qau>

<sn>4.</sn> <def>To impregnate; -- applied to brute
animals.</def>

<au>Creech.</au>

<cs><col>Lined gold</col>, <cd>gold foil having a lining of
another metal.</cd></cs>

<hw>Line</hw>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[OE. <ets>line</ets>, AS.
<ets>l\'c6ne</ets> cable, hawser, prob. from L. <ets>linea</ets>
a linen thread, string, line, fr. <ets>linum</ets> flax, thread,
linen, cable; but the English word was influenced by F.
<ets>ligne</ets> line, from the same L. word <ets>linea</ets>.
See <er>Linen</er>.]</ety> <sn>1.</sn> <def>linen thread or
string; a slender, strong cord; also, a cord of any thickness; a
rope; a hawser; <as>as, a fishing <ex>line</ex>; a <ex>line</ex>
for snaring birds; a clothes<ex>line</ex>; a
tow<ex>line</ex>.</as></def>

<q>Who so layeth <qex>lines</qex> for to latch fowls.</q>
<qau>Piers Plowman.</qau>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>A more or less threadlike mark of pen, pencil,
or graver; any long mark; <as>as, a chalk
<ex>line</ex></as>.</def>

<sn>3.</sn> <def>The course followed by anything in motion;
hence, a road or route; <as>as, the arrow descended in a curved
<ex>line</ex>; the place is remote from <ex>lines</ex> of
travel.</as></def>

<sn>4.</sn> <def>Direction; <as>as, the <ex>line</ex> sight or
vision</as>.</def>

<sn>5.</sn> <def>A row of letters, words, etc., written or
printed; esp., a row of words extending across a page or
column.</def>

<sn>6.</sn> <def>A short letter; a note; <as>as, a <ex>line</ex>
from a friend</as>.</def>

<sn>7.</sn> <fld>(Poet.)</fld> <def>A verse, or the words which
form a certain number of feet, according to the measure.</def>

<q>In the preceding <qex>line</qex> Ulysses speaks of
Nausicaa.</q>
<qau>Broome.</qau>

<sn>8.</sn> <def>Course of conduct, thought, occupation, or
policy; method of argument; department of industry, trade, or
intellectual activity.</def>

<q>He is uncommonly powerful in his own <qex>line</qex>, but it
is not the <qex>line</qex> of a first-rate man.</q>
<qau>Coleridge.</qau>

<sn>9.</sn> <fld>(Math.)</fld> <def>That which has length, but
not breadth or thickness.</def>

<sn>10.</sn> <def>The exterior limit of a figure, plat, or
territory; boundary; contour; outline.</def>

<q>Eden stretched her <qex>line</qex>
From Auran eastward to the royal towers
Of great Seleucia.</q>
<qau>Milton.</qau>

<sn>11.</sn> <def>A threadlike crease marking the face or the
hand; hence, characteristic mark.</def>

<q>Though on his brow were graven <qex>lines</qex> austere.</q>
<qau>Byron.</qau>

<q>He tipples palmistry, and dines
On all her fortune-telling <qex>lines</qex>.</q>
<qau>Cleveland.</qau>

<sn>12.</sn> <def>Lineament; feature; figure</def>. \'bdThe
<xex>lines</xex> of my boy's face.\'b8

<au>Shak.</au>

<sn>13.</sn> <def>A straight row; a continued series or rank;
<as>as, a <ex>line</ex> of houses, or of soldiers; a
<ex>line</ex> of barriers.</as></def>

<q>Unite thy forces and attack their <qex>lines</qex>.</q>
<qau>Dryden.</qau>

<sn>14.</sn> <def>A series or succession of ancestors or descand
ants of a given person; a family or race; <as>as, the ascending
or descending <ex>line</ex>; the <ex>line</ex> of descent; the
male <ex>line</ex>; a <ex>line</ex> of kings.</as></def>

<q>Of his lineage am I, and his offspring
By very <qex>line</qex>, as of the stock real.</q>
<qau>Chaucer.</qau>

<sn>15.</sn> <def>A connected series of public conveyances, and
hence, an established arrangement for forwarding merchandise,
etc. ; <as>as, a <ex>line</ex> of stages; an express
<ex>line</ex>.</as></def>

<sn>16.</sn> <fld>(Geog.)</fld> <sd>(a)</sd> <def>A circle of
latitude or of longitude, as represented on a map.</def>
<sd>(b)</sd> <def>The equator; -- usually called <xex>the
line</xex>, <xex>or equinoctial line</xex>; <as>as, to cross
<ex>the line</ex></as>.</def>

<sn>17.</sn> <def>A long tape, or a narrow ribbon of steel, etc.,
marked with subdivisions, as feet and inches, for measuring; a
tapeline.</def>

<sn>18.</sn> <fld>(Script.)</fld> <sd>(a)</sd> <def>A measuring
line or cord.</def>

<q>He marketh it out with a <qex>line</qex>.</q>
<qau>Is. xliv. 13.</qau>

<sd>(b)</sd> <def>That which was measured by a line, as a field
or any piece of land set apart; hence, allotted place of
abode</def>.

<q>The <qex>lines</qex> are fallen unto me in pleasant places;
yes. I have a goodly heritage.</q>
<qau>Ps. xvi. 6.</qau>

<sd>(c)</sd> <def>Instruction; doctrine</def>.

<q>Their <qex>line</qex> is gone out through all the earth.</q>
<qau>Ps. xix. 4.</qau>

<sn>19.</sn> <fld>(Mach.)</fld> <def>The proper relative position
or adjustment of parts, not as to design or proportion, but with
reference to smooth working; <as>as, the engine is in
<ex>line</ex> or out of <ex>line</ex> or out of
<ex>line</ex></as>.</def>

<sn>20.</sn> <def>The track and roadbed of a railway;
railroad.</def>

<sn>21.</sn> <fld>(Mil.)</fld> <sd>(a)</sd> <def>A row of men who
are abreast of one another, whether side by side or some distance
apart; -- opposed to <xex>column</xex>.</def> <sd>(b)</sd>
<def>The regular infantry of an army, as distinguished from
militia, guards, volunteer corps, cavalry, artillery, etc.</def>

<sn>22.</sn> <fld>(Fort.)</fld> <sd>(a)</sd> <def>A trench or
rampart.</def> <sd>(b)</sd> <pluf>pl.</pluf> <def>Dispositions
made to cover extended positions, and presenting a front in but
one direction to an enemy.</def>

<sn>23.</sn> <pluf>pl.</pluf> <fld>(Shipbuilding)</fld> <def>form
of a vessel as shown by the outlines of vertical, horizontal, and
obique sections.</def>

<sn>24.</sn> <fld>(Mus.)</fld> <def>One of the straight
horizontal and parallel prolonged strokes on and between which
the notes are placed.</def>

<sn>25.</sn> <fld>(Stock Exchange)</fld> <def>A number of shares
taken by a jobber.</def>

<sn>26.</sn> <fld>(Trade)</fld> <def>A series of various
qualities and values of the same general class of articles;
<as>as, a full <ex>line</ex> of hosiery; a <ex>line</ex> of
merinos, etc.</as></def>

<au>McElrath.</au>

<sn>27.</sn> <def>The wire connecting one telegraphic station
with another, or the whole of a system of telegraph wires under
one management and name.</def>

<sn>28.</sn> <pluf>pl.</pluf> <def>The reins with which a horse
is guided by his driver.</def> <mark>[U. S.]</mark>

<sn>29.</sn> <def>A measure of length; one twelfth of an
inch.</def>

<cs><col>Hard lines</col>, <cd>hard lot.</cd> <au>C.
Kingsley</au>. [See Def. 18.] -- <col>Line breeding</col>
<fld>(Stockbreeding)</fld>, <cd>breeding by a certain family line
of descent, especially in the selection of the dam or
mother.</cd> -- <col>Line conch</col> <fld>(Zo\'94l.)</fld>,
<cd>a spiral marine shell (<spn>Fasciolaria distans</spn>), of
Florida and the West Indies. It is marked by narrow, dark,
revolving lines.</cd> -- <col>Line engraving</col>. <sd>(a)</sd>
<cd>Engraving in which the effects are produced by lines of
different width and closeness, cut with the burin upon copper or
similar material; also, a plate so engraved</cd>. <sd>(b)</sd>
<cd>A picture produced by printing from such an engraving.</cd>
-- <col>Line of battle</col>. <sd>(a)</sd> <sd>(Mil
<xex>Tactics<xex>)</sd> <cd>The position of troops drawn up in
their usual order without any determined maneuver</cd>.
<sd>(b)</sd> <fld>(Naval)</fld> <cd>The line or arrangement
formed by vessels of war in an engagement.</cd> -- <col>Line of
battle ship</col>. <cd>See <cref>Ship of the line</cref>,
below.</cd> -- <col>Line of beauty</col> <fld>(Fine
Arts)</fld>,<cd>an abstract line supposed to be beautiful in
itself and absolutely; -- differently represented by different
authors, often as a kind of elongated <it>S<it> (like the one
drawn by Hogarth).</cd> -- <col>Line of centers</col>.
<fld>(Mach.)</fld> <sd>(a)</sd> <cd>A line joining two centers,
or fulcra, as of wheels or levers</cd>. <sd>(b)</sd> <cd>A line
which determines a dead center</cd>. See <cref>Dead
center</cref>, under <er>Dead</er>.</cd> -- <col>Line of
dip</col> <fld>(Geol.)</fld>, <cd>a line in the plane of a
stratum, or part of a stratum, perpendicular to its intersection
with a horizontal plane; the line of greatest inclination of a
stratum to the horizon.</cd> -- <col>Line of fire</col>
<fld>(Mil.)</fld>, <cd>the direction of fire.</cd> -- <col>Line
of force</col> <fld>(Physics)</fld>, <cd>any line in a space in
which forces are acting, so drawn that at every point of the line
its tangent is the direction of the resultant of all the forces.
It cuts at right angles every equipotential surface which it
meets. Specifically <fld>(Magnetism)</fld>, a line in proximity
to a magnet so drawn that any point in it is tangential with the
direction of a short compass needle held at that point.
<au>Faraday</au>.</cd> -- <col>Line of life</col>
<fld>(Palmistry)</fld>, <cd>a line on the inside of the hand,
curving about the base of the thumb, supposed to indicate, by its
form or position, the length of a person's life.</cd> --
<col>Line of lines</col>. <cd>See <er>Gunter's line</er>.</cd> --
<col>Line of march</col>. <fld>(Mil.)</fld> <sd>(a)</sd>
<cd>Arrangement of troops for marching</cd>. <sd>(b)</sd>
<cd>Course or direction taken by an army or body of troops in
marching.</cd> -- <col>Line of operations</col>, <cd>that portion
of a theater of war which an army passes over in attaining its
object. <au>H. W. Halleck</au>.</cd> -- <col>Line of sight</col>
<fld>(Firearms)</fld>, <cd>the line which passes through the
front and rear sight, at any elevation, when they are sighted at
an object.</cd> -- <col>Line tub</col> <fld>(Naut.)</fld>, <cd>a
tub in which the line carried by a whaleboat is coiled.</cd> --
<col>Mason and Dixon's line</col><-- also, the Mason-Dixon Line
-->, <cd>the boundary line between Pennsylvania and Maryland, as
run before the Revolution (1764-1767) by two English astronomers
named Charles Mason and Jeremiah Dixon. In an extended sense, the
line between the free and the slave States.</cd> -- <col>On the
line</col>, <cd>on a level with the eye of the spectator; -- said
of a picture, as hung in an exhibition of pictures.</cd><-- also,
at risk (dependent upon success) in a contest or enterprise, as
the survival of the company is on the line in this project --> --
<col>Right line a picture</col>, <cd>as hung in an exhibition of
pictures.</cd> -- <col>Right line</col>, <cd>a straight line; the
shortest line that can be drawn between two points.</cd> --
<col>Ship of the line</col>, <cd>formerly, a ship of war large
enough to have a place in the line of battle; a vessel superior
to a frigate; usually, a seventy-four, or three-decker; -- called
also <altname>line of battle ship</altname>.<-- eventually
abbreviated to "battleship" --> <au>Totten</au>.</cd> -- <col>To
cross the line</col>, <cd>to cross the equator, as a vessel at
sea.</cd> -- <col>To give a person line</col>, <cd>to allow him
more or less liberty until it is convenient to stop or check him,
like a hooked fish that swims away with the line.</cd> --
<col>Water line</col> <fld>(Shipbuilding)</fld>, <cd>the outline
of a horizontal section of a vessel, as when floating in the
water.</cd></cs>

<-- p. 856 -->

<hw>Line</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>v. t.</pos> <sn>1.</sn> <def>To
mark with a line or lines; to cover with lines; <as>as, to
<ex>line</ex> a copy book</as>.</def>

<q>He had a healthy color in his cheeks, and his face, though
<qex>lined</qex>, bore few traces of anxiety.</q>
<qau>Dickens.</qau>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>To represent by lines; to delineate; to
portray.</def> <mark>[R.]</mark> \'bdPictures fairest
<xex>lined</xex>.\'b8

<au>Shak.</au>

<sn>3.</sn> <def>To read or repeat line by line; <as>as, to
<ex>line</ex> out a hymn</as>.</def>

<q>This custom of reading or <qex>lining</qex>, <qex>or</qex>, as
it was frequently called \'bddeaconing' the hymn or psalm in the
churches, was brought about partly from necessity.</q>
<qau>N. D. Gould.</qau>

<sn>4.</sn> <def>To form into a line; to align; <as>as, to
<ex>line</ex> troops</as>.</def>

<cs><col>To line bees</col>, <cd>to track wild bees to their nest
by following their line of flight.</cd> -- <col>To line up</col>
<fld>(Mach.)</fld>, <cd>to put in alignment; to put in correct
adjustment for smooth running. See 3d <er>Line</er>,
19.</cd></cs>

<hw>Lin"e*age</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[OE.
<ets>linage</ets>, F. <ets>lignage</ets>, fr. L. <ets>linea</ets>
line. See 3d <er>Line</er>.]</ety> <def>Descent in a line from a
common progenitor; progeny; race; descending line of offspring or
ascending line of parentage.</def>

<q>Both the <qex>lineage</qex> and the certain sire
From which I sprung, from me are hidden yet.</q>
<qau>Spenser.</qau>

<hw>Lin"e*al</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>a.</pos> <ety>[L.
<ets>linealis</ets> belonging to a line, fr. <ets>linea</ets>
line: cf. F. <ets>lin\'82al</ets>. See 3d <er>Line</er>.]</ety>
<sn>1.</sn> <def>Descending in a direct line from an ancestor;
hereditary; derived from ancestors; -- opposed to
<xex>collateral</xex>; <as>as, a <ex>lineal</ex> descent or a
<ex>lineal</ex> descendant</as>.</def>

<q>The prime and ancient right of <qex>lineal</qex>
succession.</q>
<qau>Locke.</qau>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>Inheriting by direct descent; having the right
by direct descent to succeed (<ptcl>to</ptcl>).</def>

<q>For only you are <qex>lineal</qex> to the throne.</q>
<qau>Dryden.</qau>

<sn>3.</sn> <def>Composed of lines; delineated; <as>as,
<ex>lineal</ex> designs</as>.</def>

<sn>4.</sn> <def>In the direction of a line; of a line; of or
pertaining to a line; measured on, or ascertained by, a line;
linear; <as>as, <ex>lineal</ex> magnitude</as>.</def>

<cs><col>Lineal measure</col>, <cd>the measure of length; --
usually written <altname>linear measure</altname>.</cd></cs>

<hw>Lin`e*al"i*ty</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <def>The
quality of being linea<?/.</def>

<hw>Lin"e*al*ly</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>adv.</pos> <def>In a
lineal manner; <as>as, the prince is <ex>lineally</ex> descended
from the Conqueror</as>.</def>

<hw>Lin"e*a*ment</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[L.
<ets>lineamentum</ets>, fr. <ets>linea</ets> line: cf. F.
<ets>lin\'82ament</ets>. See 3d <er>Line</er>.]</ety> <def>One of
the outlines, exterior features, or distinctive marks, of a body
or figure, particularly of the face; feature; form; mark; --
usually in the <xex>plural</xex>.</def>  \'bdThe
<xex>lineaments</xex> of the body.\'b8 <au>Locke</au>.
\'bd<xex>Lineaments</xex> in the character.\'b8 <au>Swift</au>.

<q>Man he seems
In all his <qex>lineaments</qex>.</q>
<qau>Milton.</qau>

<hw>Lin"e*ar</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>a.</pos> <ety>[L.
<ets>linearis</ets>, <ets>linearius</ets> , fr. <ets>linea</ets>
line: cf. F. <ets>lin\'82aire</ets>. See 3d <er>Line</er>.]</ety>
<sn>1.</sn> <def>Of or pertaining to a line; consisting of lines;
in a straight direction; lineal.</def>

<sn>2.</sn> <fld>(Bot.)</fld> <def>Like a line; narrow; of the
same breadth throughout, except at the extremities; <as>as, a
<ex>linear</ex> leaf</as>.</def>

<cs><col>Linear differential</col> <fld>(Math.)</fld>, <cd>an
equation which is of the first degree, when the expression which
is equated to zero is regarded as a function of the dependent
variable and its differential coefficients.</cd> -- <col>Linear
equation</col> <fld>(Math.)</fld>, <cd>an equation of the first
degree between two variables; -- so called because every such
equation may be considered as representing a right line.<-- =
stright line! --></cd> -- <col>Linear measure</col>, <cd>the
measurement of length.</cd> -- <col>Linear numbers</col>
<fld>(Math.)</fld>, <cd>such numbers as have relation to length
only: such is a number which represents one side of a plane
figure. If the plane figure is square, the linear figure is
called a <xex>root<xex>.</cd> -- <col>Linear problem</col>
<fld>(Geom.)</fld>, <cd>a problem which may be solved
geometrically by the use of right lines alone.</cd> --
<col>Linear transformation</col> <fld>(Alg.)</fld>, <cd>a change
of variables where each variable is replaced by a function of the
first degree in the new variable.</cd></cs>

<hw>Lin"en</hw>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[Prop. an adj. from OE.
<ets>lin</ets>. flax, AS. <ets>l\'c6n</ets> flax, whence
<ets>l\'c6nen</ets> made of flax; akin to OS., Icel., & MHG.
<ets>l\'c6n</ets> flax and linen, G. <ets>lein</ets>,
<ets>leinen</ets>, linen, Sw. <ets>lin</ets> flax, Goth.
<ets>lein</ets> linen, L. <ets>linum</ets> flax, linen, Gr. <?/.
Cf. <er>Line</er>, <er>Linseed</er>.]</ety> <sn>1.</sn>
<def>Thread or cloth made of flax or (rarely) of hemp; -- used in
a general sense to include cambric, shirting, sheeting, towels,
tablecloths, etc.</def> \'bdIn <xex>linen</xex> white as
milk.\'b8

<au>Robert of Brunne.</au>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>Underclothing, esp. the shirt, as being, in
former times, chiefly made of linen.</def>

outer shell of the cylinder a space is left to form a steam

<hw>-ling</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>. <ety>[AS. <ets>-ling</ets>.]</ety>
<def>A noun suffix, commonly having a <xex>diminutive</xex> or a

<hw>Ling</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[OE.
<ets>lenge</ets>; akin to D. <ets>leng</ets>, G.
<ets>l\'84nge</ets>, Dan. <ets>lange</ets>, Sw.
<ets>l<?/nga</ets>, Icel. <ets>langa</ets>. So named from its
being <ets>long</ets>. See <er>Long</er>, <pos>a.</pos>]</ety>
<fld>(Zo\'94l.)</fld> <sd>(a)</sd> <def>A large, marine, gadoid
fish (<spn>Molva vulgaris</spn>) of Northern Europe and
Greenland. It is valued as a food fish and is largely salted and
dried. Called also <altname>drizzle</altname>.</def> <sd>(b)</sd>
<def>The burbot of Lake Ontario.</def> <sd>(c)</sd> <def>An
American hake of the genus <spn>Phycis</spn>.</def>
<mark>[Canada]</mark> <sd>(d)</sd> <def>A New Zealand food fish
of the genus <spn>Genypterus</spn>. The name is also locally
applied to other fishes, as the cultus cod, the mutton fish, and
the cobia.</def>

<hw>Ling</hw>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[Icel. <ets>lyng</ets>; akin to
Dan. <ets>lyng</ets>, Sw. <ets>ljung</ets>.]</ety>
<fld>(Bot.)</fld> <def>Heather (<spn>Calluna
vulgaris</spn>).</def>

<cs><col>Ling honey</col>, <cd>a sort of wild honey, made from
the flowers of the heather.</cd></cs>

<au>Holland.</au>

<hw>Lin"ger</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>v. i.</pos>
<wordforms>[<pos>imp. &  p. p.</pos> <er>Lingered</er>
<pr>(?)</pr>; <pos>p. pr. & vb. n.</pos>
<er>Lingering</er>.]</wordforms> <ety>[OE. <ets>lengen</ets> to
tarry, AS. <ets>lengan</ets> to prolong, put off, fr.
<ets>lang</ets> long. <?/. See <er>Long</er>,
<pos>a.</pos>]</ety> <def>To delay; to loiter; to remain or wait
long; to be slow or reluctant in parting or moving; to be slow in
deciding; to be in suspense; to hesitate.</def>

<q>Nor cast one longing, <qex>lingering</qex> look behind.</q>
<qau>Gray.</qau>

<q>Perhaps thou <qex>linger'st</qex>, in deep thoughts
detained.</q>
<qau>Milton.</qau>

<syn>Syn. -- To loiter; lag; saunter; delay; tarry; stop;
hesitate.</syn>

<hw>Lin"ger</hw>, <pos>v. t.</pos> <sn>1.</sn> <def>To protract;
to draw out.</def> <mark>[Obs.]</mark>

<q>She <qex>lingers</qex> my desires.</q>
<qau>Shak.</qau>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>To spend or pass in lingering manner; -- with
<xex>out</xex>; <as>as, to <ex>linger</ex> out one's days on a
sick bed</as>.</def>

<au>Dryden.</au>

<hw>Lin"ger*er</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <def>One who
lingers.</def>

<au>Guardian.</au>

<hw>Lin"ger*ing</hw>, <pos>a.</pos> <sn>1.</sn>
<def>Delaying.</def>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>Drawn out in time; remaining long; protracted;
<as>as, a <ex>lingering</ex> disease</as>.</def>

<q>To die is the fate of man; but to die with
<qex>lingering</qex> anguish is generally his folly.</q>
<qau>Rambler.</qau>

<hw>Lin"ger*ing*ly</hw>, <pos>adv.</pos> <def>With delay; slowly;
tediously.</def>

<hw>\'d8Lin"gua</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos>; <plu>pl.
<plw>Lingu\'91</plw> <pr>(#)</pr></plu>. <ety>[L., the
tongue.]</ety> <fld>(Zo\'94l.)</fld> <sd>(a)</sd> <def>A

at the under side of the mouth in insects, and serving as a

<hw>Lin*gua"cious</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>a.</pos> <ety>[L.
<ets>linguax</ets>, <ets>-acis</ets>, loquacious, fr.
<ets>lingua</ets> tongue.]</ety> <def>Given to the use of the
tongue; loquacious.</def> <mark>[Obs.]</mark>

<hw>Lin`gua*den"tal</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>a.</pos> <ety>[L.
<ets>lingua</ets> tongue + E. <ets>dental</ets>.]</ety>
<fld>(Phonetics)</fld> <def>Formed or uttered by the joint use of
the tongue and teeth, or rather that part of the gum just above
the front teeth; dentolingual, as the letters <xex>d</xex> and
<xex>t</xex>.</def>

<hw>Lin`gua*den"tal</hw>, <pos>n.</pos> <fld>(Phonetics)</fld>
<def>An articulation pronounced by the aid or use of the tongue
and teeth.</def>

<hw>Lin"gua Fran"ca</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>. <ety>[It., prop., language
of the Franks.]</ety> <def>The commercial language of the Levant,
-- a mixture of the language of the people of the region and
foreign traders.</def>

<hw>Lin"gual</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>a.</pos> <ety>[L.
<ets>lingua</ets> tongue: cf. F. <ets>lingual</ets>. See
<er>Tongue</er>, and cf. <er>Language</er>.]</ety> <def>Of or
pertaining to the tongue; uttered by the aid of the tongue;
glossal; <as>as, the <ex>lingual</ex> nerves; a <ex>lingual</ex>
letter.</as></def>

<cs><col>Lingual ribbon</col>. <fld>(Zo\'94l.)</fld> <cd>See
<er>Odontophore</er>.</cd></cs>

<hw>Lin"gual</hw>, <pos>n.</pos> <def>A consonant sound formed by
the aid of the tongue; -- a term especially applied to certain
articulations (as those of <xex>t</xex>, <xex>d</xex>,
<xex>th</xex>, and <xex>n</xex>) and to the letters denoting
them.</def>

<note><hand/ In Sanskrit grammar certain letters, as
<xex>t</xex>, <xex>th</xex>, <xex>d</xex>, <xex>dh</xex>,
<xex>n</xex>, are called linguals, cerebrals, or cacuminals. They
are uttered with the tip of the tongue turned up and drawn back
into the dome of the palate.</note>

<hw>Lin*gual"i*ty</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <def>The
quality of being lingual.</def>

<hw>\'d8Lin`gua*tu"li*da</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n. pl.</pos>
<ety>[NL., fr. L. <ets>lingua</ets> tongue.]</ety>
<fld>(Zo\'94l.)</fld> <def>Same as <er>Linguatulina</er>.</def>

<hw>\'d8Lin*guat`*u*li"na</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n. pl.</pos>
<ety>[NL., fr. L. <ets>lingua</ets> tongue.]</ety>
<fld>(Zo\'94l.)</fld> <def>An order of wormlike, degraded,
parasitic arachnids. They have two pairs of retractile hooks,
near the mouth. Called also
<altname>Pentastomida</altname>.</def>

<note><hand/ The adults of some species inhabit the nostrils and
nasal sinuses of dogs and other carnivores. The young, after
being swallowed by sheep, rabbits, etc., find their way to the
lungs and liver and become encysted. These, when eaten by
carnivores, develop into the adult forms.</note>

<hw>Lin`gui*den"tal</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>a. & n.</pos>
<def>Linguadental.</def>

<hw>Lin"gui*form</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>a.</pos> <ety>[L.
<ets>lingua</ets> tongue + <ets>-form</ets>:  cf. F. 
<ets>linguiforme</ets>.]</ety> <def>Having the form of the
tongue; tongue-shaped.</def>

<hw>Lin"guist</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[L.
<ets>lingua</ets> tongue, speech, language: cf. F. 
<ets>linguiste</ets>.]</ety> <sn>1.</sn> <def>A master of the use
of language; a talker.</def> <mark>[Obs.]</mark>

<q>I'll dispute with him;
He's a rare <qex>linguist</qex>.</q>
<qau>J. Webster.</qau>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>A person skilled in languages.</def>

<q>There too were Gibbon, the greatest historian, and Jones, the
greatest <qex>linguist</qex>, of the age.</q>
<qau>Macaulay.</qau>

<mhw>{ <hw>Lin*guis"tic</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>,
<hw>Lin*guis"tic*al</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, }</mhw> <pos>a.</pos>
<ety>[Cf. F. <ets>linguistique.</ets>]</ety> <def>Of or
pertaining to language; relating to linguistics, or to the
affinities of languages.</def>

<hw>Lin*guis"tic*al*ly</hw>, <pos>adv.</pos> <def>In a linguistic
manner; from the point of view of a linguist.</def>

<au>Tylor.</au>

<hw>Lin*guis"tics</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[Cf. F.
<ets>linguistique</ets>.]</ety> <def>The science of languages, or
of the origin, signification, and application of words;
glossology.</def>

<hw>\'d8Lin"gu*la</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos>; <plu>pl.
<plw>-l\'91</plw> <pr>(#)</pr></plu>. <ety>[L., a little
tongue.]</ety> <sn>1.</sn> <fld>(Anat.)</fld> <def>A tonguelike
process or part.</def>

<sn>2.</sn> <fld>(Zo\'94l.)</fld> <def>Any one of numerous
species of brachiopod shells belonging to the genus
<spn>Lingula</spn>, and related genera. See <er>Brachiopoda</er>,
and <xex>Illustration</xex> in Appendix.</def>

<cs><col>Lingula flags</col> <fld>(Geol.)</fld>, <cd>a group of
strata in the lower Silurian or Cambrian system of Wales, in
which some of the layers contain vast numbers of a species of
Lingula.</cd></cs>

<hw>Lin"gu*late</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>a.</pos> <ety>[L.
<ets>lingulatus</ets>, fr. <ets>lingula</ets> a little tongue.
Cf. <er>Ligulate</er>.]</ety> <def>Shaped like the tongue or a
strap; ligulate.</def>

<hw>Li*nig"er*ous</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>a.</pos> <ety>[L.
<ets>linum</ets> flax + <ets>-gerous</ets>.]</ety> <def>Bearing
flax; producing linen.</def>

<hw>Lin"i*ment</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[L.
<ets>linimentum</ets>, fr. <ets>linire</ets>, <ets>linere</ets>,
to besmear, anoint : cf. F. <ets>liniment</ets>. Cf.
<er>Letter</er>, <er>Lime</er> a viscous substance.]</ety> <def>A
liquid or semiliquid preparation of a consistence thinner than an
ointment, applied to the skin by friction, esp. one used as a
sedative or a stimulant.</def>

<hw>Lin"ing</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[See
<er>Line</er> to cover the in side.]</ety> <sn>1.</sn> <def>The
act of one who lines; the act or process of making lines, or of
inserting a lining.</def>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>That which covers the inner surface of anything,
as of a garment or a box; also, the contents of anything.</def>

<q>The <qex>lining</qex> of his coffers shall make coats
To deck our soldiers.</q>
<qau>Shak.</qau>

<hw>Link</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[Prob. corrupted
from <ets>lint</ets> and this for <ets>lunt</ets> a torch, match,
D. <ets>lont</ets> match; akin to G. <ets>lunte</ets>, cf. MHG.
<ets>l\'81nden</ets> to burn. Cf. <er>Lunt</er>,
<er>Linstock</er>.]</ety> <def>A torch made of tow and pitch, or
the like.</def>

<au>Shak.</au>

<hw>Link</hw>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[OE. <ets>linke</ets>, AS.
<ets>hlence</ets>; akin to Sw. <ets>l\'84nk</ets> ring of a
chain, Dan. <ets>l\'91nke</ets> chain, Icel. <ets>hlekkr</ets>;
cf. G. <ets>gelenk</ets> joint, link, ring of a chain,
<ets>lenken</ets> to bend.]</ety> <sn>1.</sn> <def>A single ring
or division of a chain.</def>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>Hence: Anything, whether material or not, which
binds together, or connects, separate things; a part of a
connected series; a tie; a bond.</def> \'bd<xex>Links</xex> of
iron.\'b8 <au>Shak</au>.

<-- p. 857 -->

<q>The <qex>link</qex> of brotherhood, by which
One common Maker bound me to the kind.</q>
<qau>Cowper.</qau>

<q>And so by double <qex>links</qex> enchained themselves in
lover's life.</q>
<qau>Gascoigne.</qau>

<sn>3.</sn> <def>Anything doubled and closed like a link; <as>as,
a <ex>link</ex> of horsehair</as>.</def>

<au>Mortimer.</au>

<sn>4.</sn> <fld>(Kinematics)</fld> <def>Any one of the several
elementary pieces of a mechanism, as the fixed frame, or a rod,
wheel, mass of confined liquid, etc., by which relative motion of
other parts is produced and constrained.</def>

<sn>5.</sn> <fld>(Mach.)</fld> <def>Any intermediate rod or piece
for transmitting force or motion, especially a short connecting
rod with a bearing at each end; specifically <fld>(Steam
Engine)</fld>, the slotted bar, or connecting piece, to the
opposite ends of which the eccentric rods are jointed, and by
means of which the movement of the valve is varied, in a
<xex>link motion</xex>.</def>

<sn>6.</sn> <fld>(Surveying)</fld> <def>The length of one joint
of Gunter's chain, being the hundredth part of it, or 7.92
inches, the chain being 66 feet in length. Cf. <er>Chain</er>,
<pos>n.</pos>, 4.</def>

<sn>7.</sn> <fld>(Chem.)</fld> <def>A bond of affinity, or a unit
of valence between atoms; -- applied to a unit of chemical force
or attraction.</def>

<sn>8.</sn> <pluf>pl.</pluf> <def>Sausages; -- because linked
together.</def> <mark>[Colloq.]</mark>

<-- 9. pl. A golf course. -->

<hw>Link</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>v. t.</pos>
<wordforms>[<pos>imp. & p. p.</pos> <er>Linked</er> <pr>(?)</pr>;
<pos>p. pr. & vb. n.</pos> <er>Linking</er>.]</wordforms> <def>To
connect or unite with a link or as with a link; to join; to
attach; to unite; to couple.</def>

<q>All the tribes and nations that composed it [the Roman Empire]
were <qex>linked</qex> together, not only by the same laws and
the same government, but by all the facilities of commodious
intercourse, and of frequent communication.</q>
<qau>Eustace.</qau>

<hw>Link</hw>, <pos>v. i.</pos> <def>To be connected.</def>

<q>No one generation could <qex>link</qex> with the other.</q>
<qau>Burke.</qau>

<hw>Link"age</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <sn>1.</sn>
<def>The act of linking; the state of being linked; also, a
system of links.</def>

<sn>2.</sn> <fld>(Chem.)</fld> <def>Manner of linking or of being
linked; -- said of the union of atoms or radicals in the
molecule.</def>

<sn>3.</sn> <fld>(Geom.)</fld> <def>A system of straight lines or
bars, fastened together by joins, and having certain of their
points fixed in a plane. It is used to describe straight lines
and curves in the plane.</def>

<mhw>{ <hw>Link"boy`</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <hw>Link"man</hw>
<pr>(?)</pr>, }</mhw> <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[See 1st
<er>Link</er>.]</ety> <def>A boy or man that carried a link or
torch to light passengers.</def><-- sic -->

<hw>Link" mo"tion</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>. <fld>(Steam Engine)</fld>
<def>A valve gear, consisting of two eccentrics with their rods,
giving motion to a slide valve by an adjustable connecting bar,
called the <xex>link</xex>, in such a way that the motion of the
engine can be reversed, or the cut-off varied, at will; -- used
very generally in locomotives and marine engines.</def>

<note><hand/ The illustration shows a link motion for a vertical
engine, <iref>c</iref> representing the shaft carrying two
eccentrics, <iref>a</iref> and <iref>b</iref>, for making the
engine run forward and backward, respectively, their rods
<iref>e</iref> and <iref>d</iref> being jointed to opposite ends
of the slotted link <iref>f</iref>, in the opening of which is a
pin <iref>g</iref> which is attached to the valve rod
<iref>h</iref>. The valve will receive the motion of the forward
eccentric when is in the position shown, and the motion of the
backward eccentric when the link is shifted so far to the right
as to bring <iref>e</iref> in line with <iref>h</iref>, or a
compound motion derived from both eccentrics when the link is
shifted to intermediate positions, the compound motion causing
the valve to cut off the steam at a point determined by the
position to which the link may have been shifted.</note>

<hw>Link"work`</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <sn>1.</sn>
<def>A fabric consisting of links made of metal or other material
fastened together; also, a chain.</def>

<q>And thou shalt make hooks of gold, and two chains of fine
gold; <qex>linkwork</qex> and wreathed.</q>
<qau>Udall.</qau>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>Mechanism in which links, or intermediate
connecting pieces, are employed to transmit motion from one part
to another.</def>

<hw>\'d8Lin*n\'91"a bo`re*a"lis</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>.
<ety>[NL.<ets>Linnaeus</ets> Linn\'91an + L. <ets>borealis</ets>
northern.]</ety> <fld>(Bot.)</fld> <def>The twin flower which
grows in cold northern climates.</def>

<mhw>{ <hw>Lin*n\'91"an</hw>, <hw>Lin*ne"an</hw>  }</mhw>
<pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>a.</pos> <def>Of or pertaining to
<xex>Linn\'91us</xex>, the celebrated Swedish botanist.</def>

<cs><col>Linnaean system</col> <fld>(Bot.)</fld>, <cd>the system
in which the classes are founded mainly upon the stamens, and the
orders upon the pistils; the artificial or sexual
system.</cd></cs>

<hw>Lin*n\'91"ite</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[See
<er>Linn\'91an</er>.]</ety> <fld>(Min.)</fld> <def>A mineral of
pale steel-gray color and metallic luster, occurring in isometric
crystals, and also massive. It is a sulphide of cobalt containing
some nickel or copper.</def>

<hw>Linne</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <def>Flax. See
<er>Linen</er>.</def> <mark>[Obs.]</mark>

<hw>Lin"net</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[F.
<ets>linot</ets>, <ets>linotte</ets>, from L. <ets>linum</ets>
flax; or perh. shortened from AS.<ets>l\'c6netwige</ets>, fr. AS.
<ets>l\'c6n</ets> flax; -- so called because it feeds on the
seeds of flax and hemp. See <er>Linen</er>.]</ety>
<fld>(Zo\'94l.)</fld> <def>Any one of several species of
fringilline birds of the genera <spn>Linota</spn>,
<spn>Acanthis</spn>, and allied genera, esp. the common European
species (<spn>L. cannabina</spn>), which, in full summer plumage,
is chestnut brown above, with the breast more or less crimson.
The feathers of its head are grayish brown, tipped with crimson.
Called also <altname>gray linnet</altname>, <altname>red
linnet</altname>, <altname>rose linnet</altname>, <altname>brown
linnet</altname>, <altname>lintie</altname>,
<altname>lintwhite</altname>, <altname>gorse thatcher</altname>,
<altname>linnet finch</altname>, and <altname>greater
redpoll</altname>. The American redpoll linnet (<spn>Acanthis
linaria</spn>) often has the crown and throat rosy. See
<er>Redpoll</er>, and <er>Twite</er>.</def>

<cs><col>Green linnet</col> <fld>(Zo\'94l.)</fld>, <cd>the
European green finch.</cd></cs>

<hw>Li*no"le*ate</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos>
<fld>(Chem.)</fld> <def>A salt of linoleic acid.</def>

<hw>Li*no"le*ic</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>a.</pos> <def>Pertaining
to, or derived from, linoleum, or linseed oil; specifically
<fld>(Chem.)</fld>, designating an organic acid, a thin yellow
oil, found combined as a salt of glycerin in oils of linseed,
poppy, hemp, and certain nuts.</def>

<hw>Li*no"le*um</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[L.
<ets>lin</ets>um flax + <ets>oleum</ets> oil.]</ety> <sn>1.</sn>
<def>Linseed oil brought to various degrees of hardness by some
oxidizing process, as by exposure to heated air, or by treatment
with chloride of sulphur. In this condition it is used for many
of the purposes to which India rubber has been applied.</def>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>A kind of floor cloth made by laying hardened
linseed oil mixed with ground cork on a canvas backing.</def>

<hw>Li*nox"in</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos>
<ety>[<ets>Lino</ets>leic + <ets>ox</ets>ygen.]</ety>
<fld>(Chem.)</fld> <def>A resinous substance obtained as an
oxidation product of linoleic acid.</def> <altsp>[Written also
<asp>linoxyn</asp>.]</altsp>

<hw>Lin*sang"</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos>
<fld>(Zo\'94l.)</fld> <def>Any viverrine mammal of the genus
<spn>Prionodon</spn>, inhabiting the East Indies and Southern
Asia. The common East Indian linsang (<spn>P. gracilis</spn>) is
white, crossed by broad, black bands. The Guinea linsang
(<spn>Porana Richardsonii</spn>) is brown with black spots.</def>

<hw>Lin"seed`</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[OE.
<ets>lin</ets> flax + <ets>seed</ets>. See <er>Linen</er>.]</ety>
<fld>(Bot.)</fld> <def>The seeds of flax, from which linseed oil
is obtained.</def> <altsp>[Written also
<asp>lintseed</asp>.]</altsp>

<cs><col>Linseed cake</col>, <cd>the solid mass or cake which
remains when oil is expressed.</cd> -- <col>Linseed meal</col>,
<cd>linseed cake reduced to powder.</cd> -- <col>Linseed
oil</col>, <cd>oil obtained by pressure from flaxseed.</cd></cs>

<hw>Lin"sey</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[See
<er>Linen</er>.]</ety> <def>Linsey-woolsey.</def>

<hw>Lin"sey-wool"sey</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <sn>1.</sn>
<def>Cloth made of linen and wool, mixed.</def>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>Jargon.</def> <mark>[Obs.]</mark>

<hw>Lin"sey-wool"sey</hw>, <pos>a.</pos> <def>Made of linen and
wool; hence, of different and unsuitable parts; mean.</def>

<au>Johnson.</au>

<hw>Lin"stock</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[Corrupt. fr.
<ets>luntstock</ets>, D. <ets>lonistok</ets>; <ets>lont</ets>
lunt + <ets>stok</ets> stock, stick. See <er>Link</er> a torch,

<asp>lintstock</asp>.]</altsp>

<hw>Lint</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[AS.
<ets>l\'c6net</ets> flax, hemp, fr. <ets>l\'c6n</ets> flax; or,
perh. borrowed fr. L. <ets>linteum</ets> a linen cloth, linen,
from <ets>linteus</ets> linen, a., fr. <ets>lineum</ets> flax,
lint. See <er>Linen</er>.]</ety> <sn>1.</sn> <def>Flax.</def>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>Linen scraped or otherwise made into a soft,
downy or fleecy substance for dressing wounds and sores; also,
fine ravelings, down, fluff, or loose short fibers from yarn or
fabrics.</def>

<cs><col>Lint doctor</col> <fld>(Calico-printing Mach.)</fld>,
<cd>a scraper to remove lint from a printing cylinder.</cd></cs>

<hw>Lin"tel</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[OE.

<ets>lintellus</ets>, for <ets>limitellus</ets>, a dim. fr. L.
<ets>limes</ets> limit. See <er>Limit</er>.]</ety>
<fld>(Arch.)</fld> <def>A horizontal member spanning an opening,

<hw>\'d8Li"num</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[L.,

<hw>Li"on</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[F.
<ets>lion</ets>, L. <ets>leo</ets>, <ets>-onis</ets>, akin to Gr.
<?/. Cf. <er>Chameleon</er>, <er>Dandelion</er>,
<er>Leopard</er>.]</ety> <sn>1.</sn> <fld>(Zo\'94l.)</fld> <def>A
large carnivorous feline mammal (<spn>Felis leo</spn>), found in
Southern Asia and in most parts of Africa, distinct varieties
occurring in the different countries. The adult male, in most
varieties, has a thick mane of long shaggy hair that adds to his
apparent size, which is less than that of the largest tigers. The
length, however, is sometimes eleven feet to the base of the
tail. The color is a tawny yellow or yellowish brown; the mane is
darker, and the terminal tuft of the tail is black. In one
variety, called the <stype>maneless lion</stype>, the male has
only a slight mane.</def><-- now Panthera leo -->

<sn>2.</sn> <fld>(Astron.)</fld> <def>A sign and a constellation;
Leo.</def>

<sn>3.</sn> <def>An object of interest and curiosity, especially
a person who is so regarded; <as>as, he was quite a <ex>lion</ex>
in London at that time</as>.</def>

<q>Such society was far more enjoyable than that of Edinburgh,
for here he was not a <qex>lion</qex>, but a man.</q>
<qau>Prof. Wilson.</qau>

<cs><col>American lion</col> <fld>(Zo\'94l.)</fld>, <cd>the puma
or cougar.</cd> -- <col>Lion ant</col> <fld>(Zo\'94l.)</fld>,
<cd>the ant-lion.</cd> -- <col>Lion dog</col>
<fld>(Zo\'94l.)</fld>, <cd>a fancy dog with a flowing mane,
usually clipped to resemble a lion's mane.</cd> -- <col>Lion
lizard</col> <fld>(Zo\'94l.)</fld>, <cd>the basilisk.</cd> --
<col>Lion's share</col>, <cd>all, or nearly all; the best or
largest part; -- from \'92sop's fable of the lion hunting in
company with certain smaller beasts, and appropriating to himself
all the prey.</cd></cs>

<hw>Li"on-heart`</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <def>A very

<hw>Li"on*ism</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <def>An attracting

<hw>Li"on*ize</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>v. t.</pos>
<wordforms>[<pos>imp. &  p. p.</pos> <er>Lionized</er>
<pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>p. pr. & vb. n.</pos> <er>Lionizing</er>
<pr>(<?/)</pr>.]</wordforms> <sn>1.</sn> <def>To treat or regard
as a lion or object of great interest.</def>

<au> J. D. Forbes.</au>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>To show the lions or objects of interest to; to
conduct about among objects of interest.</def>

<au>Macaulay.</au>

lion; brave as a lion.</def>

<hw>Li"on*ly</hw>, <pos>a.</pos> <def>Like a lion; fierce.</def>
<mark>[Obs.]</mark>

<au>Milton.</au>

<hw>Li"on's ear`</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>. <fld>(Bot.)</fld> <def>A name
given in Western South America to certain plants with shaggy
tomentose leaves, as species of <spn>Culcitium</spn>, and
<spn>Espeletia</spn>.</def>

<hw>Li"on's foot`</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>. <fld>(Bot.)</fld>
<sd>(a)</sd> <def> A composite plant of the genus
<spn>Prenanthes</spn>, of which several species are found in the
United States.</def> <sd>(b)</sd> <def>The edelweiss.</def>

<hw>Li"on*ship</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <def>The state of
being a lion.</def>

<hw>Li"on's leaf`</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>. <fld>(Bot.)</fld> <def>A
South European plant of the genus <spn>Leontice</spn> (<spn>L.
leontopetalum</spn>), the tuberous roots of which contain so much
alkali that they are sometimes used as a substitute for
soap.</def>

<hw>Li"on's tail`</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>. <fld>(Bot.)</fld> <def>A
genus of labiate plants (<spn>Leonurus</spn>); -- so called from
a fancied resemblance of its flower spikes to the tuft of a
lion's tail. <spn>L. Cardiaca</spn> is the common
<stype>motherwort</stype>.</def>

<hw>Li"on's tooth`</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>; <plu>pl. <plw>Lions'
teeth</plw> <pr>(<?/)</pr>.</plu> <fld>(Bot.)</fld> <def>See
<er>Leontodon</er>.</def>

<hw>Lip</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[OE.
<ets>lippe</ets>, AS. <ets>lippa</ets>; akin to D.
<ets>lip</ets>, G. <ets>lippe</ets>, <ets>lefze</ets>, OHG.
<ets>lefs</ets>, Dan. <ets>l\'91be</ets>, Sw. <ets>l\'84pp</ets>,
L. <ets>labium</ets>, <ets>labrum</ets>. Cf.
<er>Labial</er>.]</ety> <sn>1.</sn> <def>One of the two fleshy
folds which surround the orifice of the mouth in man and many
other animals. In man the lips are organs of speech essential to
certain articulations. Hence, by a figure they denote the mouth,
or all the organs of speech, and sometimes speech itself.</def>

<q>Thine own <qex>lips</qex> testify against thee.</q>
<qau>Jeb xv. 6.</qau>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>An edge of an opening; a thin projecting part of
anything; a kind of short open spout; <as>as, the <ex>lip</ex> of
a vessel</as>.</def>

<sn>3.</sn> <def>The sharp cutting edge on the end of an
auger.</def>

<sn>4.</sn> <fld>(Bot.)</fld> <sd>(a)</sd> <def>One of the two
opposite divisions of a labiate corolla.</def> (b) <def>The odd
and peculiar petal in the <spn>Orchis</spn> family. See
<er>Orchidaceous</er>.</def>

<sn>5.</sn> <fld>(Zo\'94l.)</fld> <def>One of the edges of the
aperture of a univalve shell.</def>

<cs><col>Lip bit</col>, <cd>a pod auger. See <er>Auger</er>.</cd>
-- <col>Lip comfort</col>, <cd>comfort that is given with words
only.</cd> -- <col>Lip comforter</col>, <cd>one who comforts with
words only.</cd> -- <col>Lip labor</col>, <cd>unfelt or insincere
speech; hypocrisy. <au>Bale</au>.</cd> -- <col>Lip reading</col>,
<cd>the catching of the words or meaning of one speaking by
watching the motion of his lips without hearing his voice.
<au>Carpenter</au>.</cd> -- <col>Lip salve</col>, <cd>a salve for
sore lips.</cd> -- <col>Lip service</col>, <cd>expression by the
lips of obedience and devotion without the performance of acts
suitable to such sentiments.</cd> -- <col>Lip wisdom</col>,
<cd>wise talk without practice, or unsupported by
experience.</cd> -- <col>Lip work</col>. <sd>(a)</sd>
<cd>Talk</cd>. <sd>(b)</sd> <cd>Kissing</cd>.
<mark>[Humorous]</mark> <au>B. Jonson</au>.</cd> -- <col>Lip make
a lip</col>, <cd>to drop the under lip in sullenness or contempt.
<au>Shak</au>.</cd> -- <col>To shoot out the lip</col>
<fld>(Script.)</fld>, <cd>to show contempt by protruding the
lip.</cd></cs>

<hw>Liq`ue*fa"cient</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[L.

<hw>Liq`ue*fac"tion</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[L.

pressure; <as>as, the <ex>liquefaction</ex> of oxygen or
hydrogen</as>.</def>

<hw>\'d8Li`queur"</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[F. See
<er>Liquor</er>.]</ety> <def>An aromatic alcoholic cordial.</def>

<note><hand/ Some <xex>liqueurs</xex> are prepared by infusing
certain woods, fruits, or flowers, in either water or alcohol,
and adding sugar, etc. Others are distilled from aromatic or
flavoring agents.</note>

<hw>Liq"uid</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>a.</pos> <ety>[L.
<ets>liquidus</ets>, fr. <ets>liquere</ets> to be fluid or
liquid; cf. Skr. <ets>r\'c6</ets> to <ets>ooze</ets>, drop,
<ets>l\'c6</ets> to melt.]</ety> <sn>1.</sn> <def>Flowing freely
like water; fluid; not solid.</def>

<q>Yes, though he go upon the plane and <qex>liquid</qex> water
which will receive no step.</q>
<qau>Tyndale.</qau>

<sn>2.</sn> <fld>(Physics)</fld> <def>Being in such a state that
the component parts move among themselves, but do not tend to
separate from each other as the particles of gases and vapors do;
neither solid nor a\'89riform; <as>as, <ex>liquid</ex> mercury,
in distinction from mercury solidified or in a state of
vapor</as>.</def>

<sn>3.</sn> <def>Flowing or sounding smoothly or without abrupt
transitions or harsh tones.</def> \'bd<xex>Liquid</xex>
melody.\'b8

<au>Crashaw.</au>

<sn>4.</sn> <def>Pronounced without any jar or harshness; smooth;
<as>as, <ex>l</ex> and <ex>r</ex> are <ex>liquid</ex>
letters</as>.</def>

<sn>5.</sn> <def>Fluid and transparent; <as>as, the
<ex>liquid</ex> air</as>.</def>

<sn>6.</sn> <def>Clear; definite in terms or
amount.</def><mark>[Obs.]</mark> \'bdThough the debt should be
entirely <xex>liquid</xex>.\'b8

<au>Ayliffe.</au>

<-- 7. (Finance) the quality of being readily convertible to
cash. -- said of assets, such as common stocks or bonds, tradable
on a major stock exchange -->

<cs><col>Liquid glass</col>. <cd>See <cref>Soluble glass</cref>,
under <er>Glass</er>.</cd></cs>

<hw>Liq"uid</hw>, <pos>n.</pos> <sn>1.</sn> <def>A substance
whose parts change their relative position on the slightest
pressure, and therefore retain no definite form; any substance in
the state of liquidity; a fluid that is not a\'89riform.</def>
<-- needs a better definition: e.g. a fluid with a definite
volume, but whose shape is determined by the container in which
it is contained.  Liquids, in contrast to gases, cannot expand
indefinitely to fill an expanding container, and are only
slightly compressible by application of pressure. -->

<note><hand/ <xex>Liquid</xex> and <xex>fluid</xex> are terms
often used synonymously, but <xex>fluid</xex> has the broader
signification. All liquids are fluids, but many fluids, as air
and the gases, are not liquids.</note>

<sn>2.</sn> <fld>(Phon.)</fld> <def>A letter which has a smooth,
flowing sound, or which flows smoothly after a mute; <as>as,
<ex>l</ex> and <ex>r</ex>, in <ex>bla</ex>, <ex>bra</ex></as>.
<xex>M</xex> and <xex>n</xex> also are called
<xex>liquids</xex>.</def>

<cs><col>Liquid measure</col>, <cd>a measure, or system of
measuring, for liquids, by the gallon, quart, pint, gill,
etc.</cd></cs>

<hw>Liq"uid*am`bar</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos>
<ety>[<ets>Liquid</ets> + <ets>amber</ets>.]</ety> <sn>1.</sn>
<fld>(Bot.)</fld> <def>A genus consisting of two species of tall
trees having star-shaped leaves, and woody burlike fruit.
<spn>Liquidambar styraciflua</spn> is the North American
<xex>sweet qum</xex>, and <spn>L. Orientalis</spn> is found in
Asia Minor.</def>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>The balsamic juice which is obtained from these
trees by incision. The liquid balsam of the Oriental tree is
<xex>liquid storax</xex>.</def>

<hw>Liq"uid*am`ber</hw>, <pos>n.</pos> <def>See
<er>Liquidambar</er>.</def>

<hw>Liq"ui*date</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>v. t.</pos>
<wordforms>[<pos>imp. & p. p.</pos> <er>Liquidated</er>
<pr>(?)</pr>; <pos>p. pr. & vb. n.</pos>
<er>Liquidating</er>.]</wordforms> <ety>[LL.
<ets>liquidatus</ets>, p. p. of <ets>liquidate</ets> to
liquidate, fr. L. <ets>liquidus</ets> liquid, clear. See
<er>Liquid</er>.]</ety> <sn>1.</sn> <fld>(Law)</fld> <def>To
determine by agreement or by litigation the precise amount of
(indebtedness); or, where there is an indebtedness to more than
one person, to determine the precise amount of (each
indebtedness); to make the amount of (an indebtedness); clear and
certain.</def>

<q>A debt or demand is <qex>liquidated</qex> whenever the amount
due is agreed on by the parties, or fixed by the operation of
law.</q>
<qau>15 Ga. Rep. 821.</qau>

<q>If our epistolary accounts were fairly <qex>liquidated</qex>,
I believe you would be brought in considerable debtor.</q>
<qau>Chesterfield.</qau>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>In an extended sense: To ascertain the amount,
or the several amounts, of , and apply assets toward the
discharge of (an indebtedness).</def>

<au>Abbott.</au>

<sn>3.</sn> <def>To discharge; to pay off, as an
indebtedness.</def>

<q>Friburg was ceded to Zurich by Sigismund to
<qex>liquidate</qex> a debt of a thousand florins.</q>
<qau>W. Coxe.</qau>

<sn>4.</sn> <def>To make clear and intelligible.</def>

<q>Time only can <qex>liquidate</qex> the meaning of all parts of
a compound system.</q>
<qau>A. Hamilton.</qau>

<sn>5.</sn> <def>To make liquid.</def> <mark>[Obs.]</mark>

<cs><col>Liquidated damages</col> <fld>(Law)</fld>, <cd>damages
the amount of which is fixed or ascertained.</cd></cs>

<au>Abbott.</au>

<ets>liquidation</ets>.]</ety> <def>The act or process of
liquidating; the state of being liquidated.</def>

<cs><col>To go into liquidation</col> <fld>(Law)</fld>, <cd>to
turn over to a trustee one's assets and accounts, in order that
the several amounts of one's indebtedness be authoritatively
ascertained, and that the assets may be applied toward their
discharge.</cd></cs>

<hw>Liq"uor</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[OE.
<ets>licour</ets>, <ets>licur</ets>, OF. <ets>licur</ets>, F.
<ets>liqueur</ets>, fr. L. <ets>liquor</ets>, fr.
<ets>liquere</ets> to be liquid. See <er>Liquid</er>, and cf.
<er>Liqueur</er>.]</ety> <sn>1.</sn> <def>Any liquid substance,
as water, milk, blood, sap, juice, or the like.</def>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>Specifically, alcoholic or spirituous fluid,
either distilled or fermented, as brandy, wine, whisky, beer,
etc.</def>

<sn>3.</sn> <fld>(Pharm.)</fld> <def>A solution of a medicinal
substance in water; -- distinguished from <xex>tincture</xex> and
<xex>aqua</xex>.</def>

<note><hand/ The U. S. Pharmacopoeia includes, in this class of
preparations, all <xex>aqueous</xex> solutions without sugar, in
which the substance acted on is wholly soluble in water,
excluding those in which the dissolved matter is gaseous or very
volatile, as in the aqu\'91 or waters.</note>

<au>U. S. Disp.</au>

<cs><col>Labarraque's liquor</col> <fld>(Old Chem.)</fld>, <cd>a
solution of an alkaline hypochlorite, as sodium hypochlorite,
used in bleaching and as a disinfectant.</cd> --
<mcol><col>Liquor of flints</col>, <or/ <col>Liquor
silicum</col></mcol> <fld>(Old Chem.)</fld>, <cd>soluble glass;
-- so called because formerly made from powdered flints. See

<col>Liquor of Libavius</col>. <fld>(Old Chem.)</fld> <cd>See
<cref>Fuming liquor of Libavius</cref>, under
<er>Fuming</er>.</cd> -- <col>Liquor sanguinis</col>
<pr>(<?/)</pr>, <fld>(Physiol.)</fld>, <cd>the blood plasma.</cd>
-- <col>Liquor thief</col>, <cd>a tube for taking samples of
liquor from a cask through the bung hole.</cd> -- <col>To be in
liquor</col>, <cd>to be intoxicated.</cd></cs>

<hw>Liq"uor</hw>, <pos>v. t.</pos> <wordforms>[<pos>imp. & p.
p.</pos> <er>Liquored</er> <pr>(?)</pr>; <pos>p. pr. & vb.
n.</pos> <er>Liquoring</er>.]</wordforms> <sn>1.</sn> <def>To

<hw>\'d8Lir`i*o*den"dron</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos>;
<plu>pl. <plw>Liriodendra</plw> <pr>(#)</pr></plu>. <ety>[NL.,
fr. Gr. <?/ lily + <?/ tree.]</ety> <fld>(Bot.)</fld> <def>A
genus of large and very beautiful trees of North America, having
smooth, shining leaves, and handsome, tuliplike flowers; tulip
tree; whitewood; -- called also <altname>canoewood</altname>.
<spn>Liriodendron tulipifera</spn> is the only extant species,
but there were several others in the Cretaceous epoch.</def>

<hw>Lisp</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>v. i.</pos>
<wordforms>[<pos>imp. & p. p.</pos> <er>Lisped</er> <pr>(?)</pr>;
<pos>p. pr. & vb. n.</pos> <er>Lisping</er>.]</wordforms>
<ety>[OE. <ets>lispen</ets>, <ets>lipsen</ets>, AS.
<ets>wlisp</ets> stammering, lisping; akin to D. & OHG.
<ets>lispen</ets> to lisp, G. <ets>lispeln</ets>, Sw.
<ets>l\'84spa</ets>, Dan. <ets>lespe</ets>.]</ety> <sn>1.</sn>
<def>To pronounce the sibilant letter <xex>s</xex> imperfectly;
to give <xex>s</xex> and <xex>z</xex> the sound of <xex>th</xex>;
-- a defect common among children.</def>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>To speak with imperfect articulation; to
mispronounce, as a child learning to talk.</def>

<q>As yet a child, nor yet a fool to fame,
I <qex>lisped</qex> in numbers came.</q>
<qau>Pope.</qau>

<sn>3.</sn> <def>To speak hesitatingly with a low voice, as if
afraid.</def>

<q>Lest when my <qex>lisping</qex>, guilty tongue should
halt.</q>
<qau>Drayton.</qau>

<hw>Lisp</hw>, <pos>v. t.</pos> <sn>1.</sn> <def>To pronounce
with a lisp.</def>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>To utter with imperfect articulation; to express
with words pronounced imperfectly or indistinctly, as a child
speaks; hence, to express by the use of simple, childlike
language.</def>

<q>To speak unto them after their own capacity, and to
<qex>lisp</qex>e words unto them according as the babes and
children of that age might sound them again.</q>
<qau>Tyndale.</qau>

<sn>3.</sn> <def>To speak with reserve or concealment; to utter
timidly or confidentially; <as>as, to <ex>lisp</ex>
treason</as>.</def>

<hw>Lisp</hw>, <pos>n.</pos> <def>The habit or act of lisping.
See <er>Lisp</er>, <pos>v. i.</pos>, 1.</def>

<q>I overheard her answer, with a very pretty <qex>lisp</qex>,
\'bdO! Strephon, you are a dangerous creature.\'b8</q>

<au>Tatler.</au>

<hw>Lisp"er</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <def>One who
lisps.</def>

<hw>Lisp"ing*ly</hw>, <pos>adv.</pos> <def>With a lisp; in a
lisping manner.</def>

<hw>List</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[F.
<ets>lice</ets>, LL. <ets>liciae</ets>, pl., from L.
<ets>licium</ets> thread, girdle.]</ety> <def>A line inclosing or
forming the extremity of a piece of ground, or field of combat;
hence, in the plural (<xex>lists</xex>), the ground or field
inclosed for a race or combat.</def>

<au>Chaucer.</au>

<q>In measured <qex>lists</qex> to toss the weighty lance.</q>
<qau>Pope.</qau>

<cs><col>To enter the lists</col>, <cd>to accept a challenge, or
engage in contest.</cd></cs>

<hw>List</hw>, <pos>v. t.</pos> <def>To inclose for combat;
<as>as, to <ex>list</ex> a field</as>.</def>

<hw>List</hw>, <pos>v. i.</pos> <ety>[See <er>Listen</er>.]</ety>
<def>To hearken; to attend; to listen. <mark>[Obs. except in
poetry.]</mark>

<q>Stand close, and <qex>list</qex> to him.</q>
<qau>Shak.</qau>

<hw>List</hw>, <pos>v. t.</pos> <def>To listen or hearken
to.</def>

<q>Then weigh what loss your honor may sustain,
If with too credent ear you <qex>list</qex> his songs.</q>
<qau>Shak.</qau>

<hw>List</hw>, <pos>v. i.</pos> <ety>[OE. <ets>listen</ets>,
<ets>lusten</ets>, AS. <ets>lystan</ets>, from <ets>lust</ets>
pleasure. See Lust.]</ety> <sn>1.</sn> <def>To desire or choose;
to please.</def>

<q>The wind bloweth where it <qex>listeth</qex>.</q>
<qau>John iii. 8.</qau>

<q>Them that add to the Word of God what them
<qex>listeth</qex>.</q>
<qau>Hooker.</qau>

<q>Let other men think of your devices as they
<qex>list</qex>.</q>
<qau>Whitgift.</qau>

<sn>2.</sn> <fld>(Naut.)</fld> <def>To lean; to incline; <as>as,
the ship <ex>lists</ex> to port</as>.</def>

<hw>List</hw>, <pos>n.</pos> <sn>1.</sn> <def>Inclination;
desire.</def> <mark>[Obs.]</mark>

<au>Chaucer.</au>

<sn>2.</sn> <fld>(Naut.)</fld> <def>An inclination to one side;
<as>as, the ship has a <ex>list</ex> to starboard</as>.</def>

<hw>List</hw>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[AS. <ets>l\'c6st</ets> a list
of cloth; akin to D. <ets>lijst</ets>, G. <ets>leiste</ets>, OHG.
<ets>l\'c6sta</ets>,Icel. <ets>lista</ets>, <ets>listi</ets>, Sw.
<ets>list</ets>, Dan. <ets>liste</ets>. In sense 5 from F.
<ets>liste</ets>, of German origin, and thus ultimately the same
word.]</ety> <sn>1.</sn> <def>A strip forming the woven border or
selvedge of cloth, particularly of broadcloth, and serving to
strengthen it; hence, a strip of cloth; a fillet.</def> \'bd
Gartered with a red and blue <xex>list</xex>. \'b8

<-- p. 859 -->

<au>Shak.</au>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>A limit or boundary; a border.</def>

<q>The very <qex>list</qex>, the very utmost bound,
Of all our fortunes.</q>
<qau>Shak.</qau>

<sn>3.</sn> <def>The lobe of the ear; the ear itself.</def>
<mark>[Obs.]</mark>

<au>Chaucer.</au>

<sn>4.</sn> <def>A stripe.</def> <mark>[Obs.]</mark>

<au>Sir T. Browne.</au>

<sn>5.</sn> <def>A roll or catalogue, that is row or line; a
record of names; <as>as, a <ex>list</ex> of names, books,
articles; a <ex>list</ex> of ratable estate.</as></def>

<q>He was the ablest emperor of all the <qex>list</qex>.</q>
<qau>Bacon.</qau>

<sn>6.</sn> <fld>(Arch.)</fld> <def>A little square molding; a
fillet; -- called also <altname>listel</altname>.</def>

<sn>7.</sn> <fld>(Carp.)</fld> <def>A narrow strip of wood, esp.
sapwood, cut from the edge of a plank or board.</def>

<sn>8.</sn> <fld>(Rope Making)</fld> <def>A piece of woolen cloth
with which the yarns are grasped by a workman.</def>

<sn>9.</sn> <fld>(Tin-plate Manuf.)</fld> <sd>(a)</sd> <def>The
first thin coat of tin.</def> <sd>(b)</sd> <def>A wirelike rim of
tin left on an edge of the plate after it is coated.</def>

<cs><col>Civil list</col> (<mark>Great Britain & U.S.</mark>),
<cd>the civil officers of government, as judges, ambassadors,
secretaries, etc. Hence, the revenues or appropriations of public
money for the support of the civil officers. More recently, the
<xex>civil list</xex>, in England, embraces only the expenses of
the reigning monarch's household.</cd> <col>Free
list</col></mcol>. <sd>(a)</sd> <cd>A list of articles admitted
to a country free of duty</cd>. <sd>(b)</sd> <cd>A list of
persons admitted to any entertainment, as a theater or opera,
without payment, or to whom a periodical, or the like, is
furnished without cost.</cd></cs>

<syn>Syn. -- Roll; catalogue; register; inventory;
schedule.</syn> <usage> -- <er>List</er>, <er>Boll</er>,
<er>Catalogue</er>, <er>Register</er>, <er>Inventory</er>,
<er>Schedule</er>. A<xex>list</xex> is properly a simple series
of names, etc., in a brief form, such as might naturally be
entered in a narrow strip of paper. A <xex>roll</xex> was
originally a list containing the names of persons belonging to a
public body (as Parliament, etc.), which was <xex>rolled</xex> up
and laid aside among its archives. A <xex>catalogue</xex> is a
list of persons or things arranged in order, and usually
containing some description of the same, more or less extended. A
<xex>register</xex> is designed for record or preservation. An
<xex>inventory</xex> is a list of articles, found on hand in a
store of goods, or in the estate of a deceased person, or under
similar circumstances. A <xex>schedule</xex> is a formal list or
inventory prepared for legal or business purposes.</usage>

<hw>List</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>v. t.</pos>
<wordforms>[<pos>imp. & p. p.</pos> <er>Listed</er>; <pos>p. pr.
& vb. n.</pos> <er>Listing</er>.]</wordforms> <ety>[From
<ets>list</ets> a roll.]</ety> <sn>1.</sn> <def>To sew together,
as strips of cloth, so as to make a show of colors, or form a
border.</def>

<au>Sir H. Wotton.</au>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>To cover with list, or with strips of cloth; to
put list on; <as>as, to <ex>list</ex> a door</as>; to stripe as
if with list.</def>

<q>The tree that stood white-<qex>listed</qex> through the
gloom.</q>
<qau>Tennyson.</qau>

<sn>3.</sn> <def>To enroll; to place or register in a list.</def>

<q><qex>Listed</qex> among the upper serving men.</q>
<qau>Milton.</qau>

<sn>4.</sn> <def>To engage, as a soldier; to enlist.</def>

<q>I will <qex>list</qex> you for my soldier.</q>
<qau>Sir W. Scott.</qau>

<sn>5.</sn> <fld>(Carp.)</fld> <def>To cut away a narrow strip,
as of sapwood, from the edge of; <as>as, to <ex>list</ex> a
board</as>.</def>

<cs><col>To list a stock</col> <fld>(Stock Exchange)</fld>,
<cd>to put it in the list of stocks called at the meeting of the
board.</cd></cs><-- to put it on a list of stocks which may be
traded on a specific stock exchange -->

<hw>List</hw>, <pos>v. i.</pos> <def>To engage in public service
by enrolling one's name; to enlist.</def>

<hw>List"el</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[F.
<ets>listel</ets>, dim. of <ets>liste</ets> fillet, list. See
<er>List</er> the edge.]</ety> <fld>(Arch.)</fld> <def>Same as
<er>List</er>, <pos>n.</pos>, 6.</def>

<hw>Lis"ten</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>v. i.</pos>
<wordforms>[<pos>imp. & p. p.</pos> <er>Listened</er>
<pr>(?)</pr>; <pos>p. pr. & vb. n.</pos>
<er>Listening</er>.]</wordforms> <ety>[OE. <ets>listnen</ets>,
<ets>listen</ets>, <ets>lustnen</ets>, <ets>lusten</ets>, AS.
<ets>hlystan</ets>; akin to <ets>hlyst</ets> hearing, OS.
<ets>hlust</ets>, Icel. <ets>hlusta</ets> to listen,
<ets>hlust</ets> ear, AS. <ets>hlosnian</ets> to wait in
suspense, OHG. <ets>hlos\'c7n</ets> to listen, Gr. <?/, and E.
<ets>loud</ets>. <root/41. See <er>Loud</er>, and cf.
<er>List</er> to listen.]</ety> <sn>1.</sn> <def>To give close
attention with the purpose of hearing; to give ear; to hearken;
to attend.</def>

<q>When we have occasion to <qex>listen</qex>, and give a more
particular attention to same sound, the tympanum is drawn to a
more than ordinary tension.</q>
<qau>Holder.</qau>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>To give heed; to yield to advice; to follow
admonition; to obey.</def>

<q><qex>Listen</qex> to me, and by me be ruled.</q>
<qau>Tennyson.</qau>

<cs><col>To listen after</col>, <cd>to take an interest in.
<mark>[Obs.]</mark></cd></cs>

<q>Soldiers note forts, armories, and magazines; scholars
<qex>listen after</qex> libraries, disputations, and
professors.</q>
<qau>Fuller.</qau>

<syn>Syn. -- To attend; hearken. See <er>Attend</er>.</syn>

<hw>Lit"a*ny</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos>; <plu>pl.
<plw>Litanies</plw> <pr>(#)</pr></plu>. <ety>[OE.
<ets>letanie</ets>, OF. <ets>letanie</ets>, F.
<ets>litanie</ets>, L. <ets>litania</ets>, Gr. <?/, fr. <?/ to
pray, akin to <?/, <?/, to pray, <?/ prayer.]</ety> <def>A solemn
form of supplication in the public worship of various churches,
in which the clergy and congregation join, the former leading and
the latter responding in alternate sentences. It is usually of a
penitential character.</def>

<q>Supplications . . . for the appeasing of God's wrath were of
the Greek church termed <qex>litanies</qex>, and rogations of the
Latin.</q>
<qau>Hooker.</qau>

<hw>Li"tchi`</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <fld>(Bot.)</fld>
<def>The fruit of a tree native to China (<spn>Nephelium
Litchi</spn>). It is nutlike, having a rough but tender shell,
containing an aromatic pulp, and a single large seed. In the
dried fruit which is exported the pulp somewhat resembles a
raisin in color and form.</def> <altsp>[Written also
<asp>lichi</asp>, and <asp>lychee</asp>.]</altsp>
