<mhw>{ <hw>Li"ter</hw>, <hw>Li"tre</hw>  }</mhw> <pr>(?)</pr>,
<pos>n.</pos> <ety>[F. <ets>litre</ets>, Gr. <?/ a silver
coin.]</ety> <def>A measure of capacity in the metric system,
being a cubic decimeter, equal to 61.022 cubic inches, or 2.113
American pints, or 1.76 English pints.</def>

<hw>Lit"er*a*cy</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <def>State of
being literate.</def>

<hw>Lit"er*al</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>a.</pos> <ety>[F.
<ets>lit\'82ral</ets>, <ets>litt\'82ral</ets>, L.
<ets>litteralis</ets>, <ets>literalis</ets>, fr.
<ets>littera</ets>, <ets>litera</ets>, a letter. See
<er>Letter</er>.]</ety> <sn>1.</sn> <def>According to the letter
or verbal expression; real; not figurative or metaphorical;
<as>as, the <ex>literal</ex> meaning of a phrase</as>.</def>

<q>It hath but one simple <qex>literal</qex> sense whose light
the owls can not abide.</q>
<qau>Tyndale</qau>.

<sn>2.</sn> <def>Following the letter or exact words; not
free.</def>

<q>A middle course between the rigor of <qex>literal</qex>
translations and the liberty of paraphrasts.</q>
<qau>Hooker.</qau>

<sn>3.</sn> <def>Consisting of, or expressed by, letters.</def>

<q>The <qex>literal</qex> notation of numbers was known to
Europeans before the ciphers.</q>
<qau>Johnson.</qau>

<sn>4.</sn> <def>Giving a strict or literal construction;
unimaginative; matter-of fast; -- applied to persons.</def>

<cs><col>Literal contract</col> <fld>(Law)</fld>, <cd>contract of
which the whole evidence is given in writing.
<au>Bouvier</au>.</cd> -- <col>Literal equation</col>
<fld>(Math.)</fld>, <cd>an equation in which known quantities are
expressed either wholly or in part by means of letters; --
distinguished from a <xex>numerical equation<xex>.</cd></cs>

<hw>Lit"er*al</hw>, <pos>n.</pos> <def>Literal meaning.</def>
<mark>[Obs.]</mark> <au>Sir T. Browne</au>.

<hw>Lit"er*al*ism</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <sn>1.</sn>
<def>That which accords with the letter; a mode of interpreting
literally; adherence to the letter.</def>

<sn>2.</sn> <fld>(Fine Arts)</fld> <def>The tendency or
disposition to represent objects faithfully, without abstraction,
conventionalities, or idealization.</def>

<hw>Lit"er*al*ist</hw>, <pos>n.</pos> <def>One who adheres to the
letter or exact word; an interpreter according to the
letter.</def>

<hw>Lit`er*al"ty</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[Cf. F.
<ets>litt\'82ralit\'82</ets>.]</ety> <def>The state or quality of
being literal.</def>

<au>Sir T. Browne.</au>

<hw>Lit`er*al*i*za"tion</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <def>The
act of literalizing; reduction to a literal meaning.</def>

<hw>Lit"er*al*ize</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>v. t.</pos>
<wordforms>[<pos>imp. & p. p.</pos> <er>Literalized</er>
<pr>(?)</pr>; <pos>p. pr. & vb. n.</pos> <er>Literalizing</er>
<pr>(?)</pr>.]</wordforms> <def>To make literal; to interpret or
put in practice according to the strict meaning of the words; --
opposed to <xex>spiritualize</xex>; <as>as, to
<ex>literalize</ex> Scripture</as>.</def>

<hw>Lit"er*al*i`zer</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <def>A
literalist.</def>

<hw>Lit"er*al*ly</hw>, <pos>adv.</pos> <sn>1.</sn> <def>According
to the primary and natural import of words; not figuratively;
<as>as, a man and his wife can not be <ex>literally</ex> one
flesh</as>.</def>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>With close adherence to words; word by
word.</def>

<q>So wild and ungovernable a poet can not be translated
<qex>literally</qex>.</q>
<qau>Dryden.</qau>

<hw>Lit"er*al*ness</hw>, <pos>n.</pos> <def>The quality or state
of being literal; literal import</def>.

<hw>Lit"er*a*ry</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>a.</pos> <ety>[L.
<ets>litterarius</ets>, <ets>literarius</ets>,fr.
<ets>littera</ets>, <ets>litera</ets>, a letter: cf. F.
<ets>litt\'82raire</ets>. See <er>Letter</er>.]</ety>

<sn>1.</sn> <def>Of or pertaining to letters or literature;
pertaining to learning or learned men; <as>as, <ex>literary</ex>
fame; a <ex>literary</ex> history; <ex>literary</ex>
conversation.</as></def>

<q>He has long outlived his century, the term commonly fixed as
the test of <qex>literary</qex> merit.</q>
<qau>Johnson.</qau>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>Versed in, or acquainted with, literature;
occupied with literature as a profession; connected with
literature or with men of letters; <as>as, a <ex>literary</ex>
man</as>.</def>

<q>In the <qex>literary</qex> as well as fashionable world.</q>
<qau>Mason.</qau>

<cs><col>Literary property</col>. <sd>(a)</sd> <cd>Property which
consists in written or printed compositions</cd>. <sd>(b)</sd>
<cd>The exclusive right of publication as recognized and limited
by law.</cd></cs><--- e.g. a copyright -->

<hw>Lit"er*ate</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>a.</pos> <ety>[L.
<ets>litteratus</ets>, <ets>literatus</ets>. See
<er>Letter</er>.]</ety> <def>Instructed in learning, science, or
literature; learned; lettered.</def>

<q>The <qex>literate</qex> now chose their emperor, as the
military chose theirs.</q>
<qau>Landor.</qau>

<hw>Lit"er*ate</hw>, <pos>n.</pos> <sn>1.</sn> <def>One educated,
but not having taken a university degree; especially, such a
person who is prepared to take holy orders.</def>
<mark>[Eng.]</mark>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>A literary man.</def>

<hw>\'d8Lit`e*ra"ti</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n. pl.</pos>
<ety>[See <er>Literatus</er>.]</ety> <def>Learned or literary
men. See <er>Literatus</er>.</def>

<q>Shakespearean commentators, and other <qex>literati</qex>.</q>
<qau>Craik.</qau>

<hw>\'d8Lit`e*ra"tim</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>adv.</pos>
<ety>[LL., fr. L.<ets>litera</ets>, <ets>litera</ets>,
letter.]</ety> <def>Letter for letter.</def>

<hw>Lit`er*a"tion</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[L.
<ets>littera</ets>, <ets>litera</ets>, letter.]</ety> <def>The
act or process of representing by letters.</def>

<hw>Lit"er*a`tor</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[L.
<ets>litterator</ets>, <ets>literator</ets>. See
<er>Letter</er>.]</ety> <sn>1.</sn> <def>One who teaches the
letters or elements of knowledge; a petty schoolmaster.</def>

<au>Burke.</au>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>A person devoted to the study of literary
trifles, esp. trifles belonging to the literature of a former
age.</def>

<q>That class of subjects which are interesting to the regular
<qex>literator</qex> or black-letter \'bd bibliomane,\'b8 simply
because they have once been interesting.</q>
<qau>De Quincey.</qau>

<sn>3.</sn> <def>A learned person; a literatus.</def>

<au>Sir W. Hamilton.</au>

<hw>Lit"er*a*ture</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[F.
<ets>litt\'82rature</ets>, L. <ets>litteratura</ets>,
<ets>literatura</ets>, learning, grammar, writing,
fr.<ets>littera</ets>, <ets>litera</ets>, letter. See
<er>Letter</er>.]</ety> <sn>1.</sn> <def>Learning; acquaintance
with letters or books.</def>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>The collective body of literary productions,
embracing the entire results of knowledge and fancy preserved in
writing; also, the whole body of literary productions or writings
upon a given subject, or in reference to a particular science or
branch of knowledge, or of a given country or period; <as>as, the
<ex>literature</ex> of Biblical criticism; the
<ex>literature</ex> of chemistry.</as></def>

<sn>3.</sn> <def>The class of writings distinguished for beauty
of style or expression, as poetry, essays, or history, in
distinction from scientific treatises and works which contain
positive knowledge; belles-lettres.</def>

<sn>4.</sn> <def>The occupation, profession, or business of doing
literary work.</def>

<au>Lamp.</au>

<syn>Syn. -- Science; learning; erudition; belles-lettres.</syn>
<usage> See <er>Science</er>. -- <er>Literature</er>,
<er>Learning</er>, <er>Erudition</er>. <xex>Literature</xex>, in
its widest sense, embraces all compositions in writing or print
which preserve the results of observation, thought, or fancy; but
those upon the positive sciences (mathematics, etc.) are usually
excluded. It is often confined, however, to
<xex>belles-lettres</xex>, or works of taste and sentiment, as
poetry, eloquence, history, etc., excluding abstract discussions
and mere erudition. A man of <xex>literature</xex> (in this
narrowest sense) is one who is versed in
<xex>belles-lettres</xex>; a man of <xex>learning</xex> excels in
what is taught in the schools, and has a wide extent of
knowledge, especially, in respect to the past; a man of
<xex>erudition</xex> is one who is skilled in the more recondite
branches of learned inquiry.</usage>

<q>The origin of all positive science and philosophy, as well as
of all <qex>literature</qex> and art, in the forms in which they
exist in civilized Europe, must be traced to the Greeks.</q>
<qau>Sir G. Lewis.</qau>

<q><qex>Learning</qex> thy talent is, but mine is sense.</q>
<qau>Prior.</qau>

<q>Some gentlemen, abounding in their university
<qex>erudition</qex>, fill their sermons with philosophical
terms.</q>
<qau>Swift.</qau>

<hw>\'d8Lit`e*ra"tus</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos>; <plu>pl.
<plw>Literati</plw> <pr>(#)</pr></plu>. <ety>[L.
<ets>litteratus</ets>, <ets>literatus</ets>.]</ety> <def>A
learned man; a man acquainted with literature; -- chiefly used in
the <xex>plural</xex>.</def>

<q>Now we are to consider that our bright ideal of a
<qex>literatus</qex> may chance to be maimed.</q>
<qau>De Quincey.</qau>

<hw>Lith"arge</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[OE.
<ets>litarge</ets>, F. <ets>litharge</ets>, L.
<ets>lithargyrus</ets>, Gr. <?/ the scum or foam of silver; <?/
stone + <?/ silver. Litharge is found in silverbearing lead
ore.]</ety> <fld>(Chem.)</fld> <def>Lead monoxide; a yellowish
red substance, obtained as an amorphous powder, or crystallized
in fine scales, by heating lead moderately in a current of air or
by calcining lead nitrate or carbonate. It is used in making
flint glass, in glazing earthenware, in making red lead minium,
etc. Called also <altname>massicot</altname>.</def>

<hw>\'d8Li*thar"gy*rum</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[NL.
See <er>Litharge</er>.]</ety> <fld>(Old Chem.)</fld>
<def>Crystallized litharge, obtained by fusion in the form of
fine yellow scales.</def>

<asp>lithiate</asp>.]</altsp>

<hw>Lith"i*um</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[NL., from
Gr.<?/ of stone, fr. <?/ stone.]</ety> <fld>(Chem.)</fld> <def>A
metallic element of the alkaline group, occurring in several
minerals, as petalite, spodumene, lepidolite, triphylite, etc.,
and otherwise widely disseminated, though in small
quantities.</def>

<note><hand/ When isolated it is a soft, silver white metal,
tarnishing and oxidizing very rapidly in the air. It is the
lightest solid element known, specific gravity being 0.59. Symbol
Li. Atomic weight 7.0 So called from having been discovered in a
mineral.</note>

<hw>Lith"o*cyst</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos>

<hw>Lith"o*dome</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos>

<spn>Lithodomus</spn>.</def>

<hw>Li*thod"o*mous</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>a.</pos>

<hw>\'d8Li*thod"o*mus</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[NL.
See <er>Lithodome</er>.]</ety> <fld>(Zo\'94l.)</fld> <def>A genus
of elongated bivalve shells, allied to the mussels, and
remarkable for their ability to bore holes for shelter, in solid
limestone, shells, etc. Called also
<altname>Lithophagus</altname>.</def>

<note><hand/ These holes are at first very small and shallow, but
are enlarged with the growth of the shell, sometimes becoming two
or three inches deep and nearly an inch diameter.</note>

<hw>Lith"o*fel"lic</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>a.</pos>

designating, a crystalline, organic acid, resembling cholic acid,

<hw>Lith"o*graph</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>v. t.</pos>
<wordforms>[<pos>imp. & p. p.</pos> <er>Lithographed</er>
<pr>(?)</pr>; <pos>p. pr. & vb. n.</pos> <er>Lithographing</er>
<pr>(?)</pr>.]</wordforms> <ety>[<ets>Litho-</ets> +
<ets>-graph</ets>: cf. F. <ets>lithographier</ets>.]</ety>
<def>To trace on stone by the process of lithography so as to
transfer the design to paper by printing; <as>as, to
<ex>lithograph</ex> a design; to <ex>lithograph</ex> a painting.
See <er>Lithography</er>.</as></def>

<hw>Lith"o*graph</hw>, <pos>n.</pos> <def>A print made by
lithography.</def>

<hw>Li*thog"ra*pher</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <def>One who

<mhw>{ <hw>Lith`o*graph"ic</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>,
<hw>Lith`o*graph"ic*al</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, }</mhw> <pos>a.</pos>
<ety>[Cf. F. <ets>lithographique</ets>.]</ety> <def>Of or

<cs><col>Lithographic limestone</col> <fld>(Min.)</fld>, <cd>a
compact, fine-grained limestone, obtained largely from the Lias
and O\'94lite, esp. of Bavaria, and extensively used in
lithography.</cd></cs>

-- <wordforms><wf>Lith`o*graph"ic*al*ly</wf>,
<pos>adv.</pos></wordforms>

<hw>Li*thog"ra*phy</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[Cf. F.
<ets>lithographie</ets>.]</ety> <def>The art or process of
putting designs or writing, with a greasy material, on stone, and
of producing printed impressions therefrom. The process depends,
in the main, upon the antipathy between grease and water, which
prevents a printing ink containing oil from adhering to wetted
parts of the stone not covered by the design. See
<cref>Lithographic limestone</cref>, under
<er>Lithographic</er>.</def><-- now used for a similar process
using any flat surface, such as a metal plate, for a similar
purpose. (b) The process of producing patterns on semiconductor
crystals by exposing photosensitive coatings on a matrix, such as
silicon, to light patterns in the form desired for the circuit,
and subsequently treating (e.g., chemically) the patterns thus
formed in such a way as to create integrated semiconductor
circuits with the desired properties.  This is the principle
method  (1990's) to create the high-density integrated circuits
used in the digital computers on which you are reading this. -->

<mhw>{ <hw>Lith"oid</hw> <pr>(?)</pr> <hw>Li*thoid"al</hw>

<mhw>{ <hw>Lith`o*log"ic</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>,
<hw>Lith`o*log"ic*al</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, }</mhw> <pos>a.</pos>

mineral contents.</def>

stratum <ex>lithologically</ex></as>.</def>

is skilled in lithology.</def>

<hw>Li*thol"o*gy</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos>
<ety>[<ets>Litho-</ets> + <ets>-logy</ets>: cf. F.
<ets>lithologie</ets>.]</ety> <sn>1.</sn> <def>The science which
treats of rocks, as regards their mineral constitution and
classification, and their mode of occurrence in nature.</def>

<sn>2.</sn> <fld>(Med.)</fld> <def>A treatise on stones found in
the body.</def>

<hw>Li*thoph"a*gous</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>a.</pos>

<hw>Lith"o*physe</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos>
<ety>[<ets>Litho-</ets> + Gr. <?/ a flatus, air bubble.]</ety>
<fld>(Min.)</fld> <def>A spherulitic cavity often with concentric
chambers, observed in some volcanic rocks, as in rhyolitic lavas.
It is supposed to be produced by expanding gas, whence the
name.</def>

<hw>Lith"o*phyte</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos>
<ety>[<ets>Litho-</ets> + Gr. <?/ plant: cf. F.
<ets>lithophyte</ets>.]</ety> <fld>(Zo\'94l.)</fld> <def>A hard,
or stony, plantlike organism, as the gorgonians, corals, and
corallines, esp. those gorgonians having a calcareous axis. All
the lithophytes except the corallines are animals.</def>

<hw>Li*ti"gious</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>a.</pos> <ety>[L.
<ets>litigiosus</ets>, fr. <ets>litigium</ets> dispute, quarrel,

<q>Soldiers find wars, and lawyers find out still
<qex>Litigious</qex> men, who guarrels move.</q>
<qau>Donne.</qau>

controvertible; debatable; doubtful; precarious.</def>

<au>Shak.</au>

<q>No fences, parted fields, nor marks, nor bounds,
Distinguished acres of <qex>litigious</qex> grounds.</q>
<qau>Dryden.</qau>

<sn>3.</sn> <def>Of or pertaining to legal disputes.</def>

<q>Nor brothers cite to the <qex>litigious</qex> bar.</q>
<qau>Young.</qau>

<hw>Lit"mus</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[D.
<ets>lakmoes</ets>; <ets>lak</ets> lacker + <ets>moes</ets> a
thick preparation of fruit, pap, prob. akin to E.
<ets>meat</ets>: cf. G. <ets>lackmus</ets>. See <er>Lac</er> a
resinous substance.]</ety> <fld>(Chem.)</fld> <def>A dyestuff
extracted from certain lichens (<spn>Roccella tinctoria</spn>,
<spn>Lecanora tartarea</spn>, etc.), as a blue amorphous mass
which consists of a compound of the alkaline carbonates with
certain coloring matters related to orcin and orcein.</def>

<note><hand/ Litmus is used as a dye, and being turned red by
acids and restored to its blue color by alkalies, is a common
indicator or test for acidity and alkalinity.</note>

<cs><col>Litmus paper</col> <fld>(Chem.)</fld>, <cd>unsized paper
saturated with blue or red litmus, -- used in testing for acids
or alkalies.</cd></cs>
<-- litmus test, (Fig.) a test for a single factor, which has
only two outcomes, positive or negative; (Politics) For voters
concerned predominantly by a single issue, the question of
whether a candidate is for or against their position on that
issue. -->

<hw>\'d8Li"to*tes</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[NL., fr.
Gr. <?/, from <?/ plain, simple.]</ety> <fld>(Rhet.)</fld> <def>A
diminution or softening of statement for the sake of avoiding
censure or increasing the effect by contrast with the moderation
shown in the form of expression; <as>as, \'bd a citizen of no
mean city,\'b8 that is, of an illustrious city</as>.</def>

<hw>Li*tran"e*ter</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[Gr.
<grk>li`tra</grk> + <ets>-meter</ets>. See <er>Liter</er>]</ety>
<def>An instrument for ascertaining the specific gravity of
liquids.</def>

<hw>Li"tre</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[F.]</ety>
<def>Same as <er>Liter</er>.</def>

<hw>Lit"ter</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[F.
<ets>liti\'8are</ets>, LL. <ets>lectaria</ets>, fr. L.
<ets>lectus</ets> couch, bed. See <er>Lie</er> to be prostrated,
and cf. <er>Coverlet</er>.]</ety> <sn>1.</sn> <def>A bed or
stretcher so arranged that a person, esp. a sick or wounded
person, may be easily carried in or upon it.</def>

<q>There is a <qex>litter</qex> ready; lay him in 't.</q>
<qau>Shak.</qau>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>Straw, hay, etc., scattered on a floor, as
bedding for animals to rest on; also, a covering of straw for
plants.</def>

<q>To crouch in <qex>litter</qex> of your stable planks.</q>
<qau>Shak.</qau>

<q>Take off the <qex>litter</qex> from your kernel beds.</q>
<qau>Evelyn.</qau>

<sn>3.</sn> <def>Things lying scattered about in a manner
indicating slovenliness; scattered rubbish.</def>

<q>Strephon, who found the room was void.
Stole in, and took a strict survey
Of all the <qex>litter</qex> as it lay.</q>
<qau>Swift.</qau>

<sn>4.</sn> <def>Disorder or untidiness resulting from scattered
rubbish, or from thongs lying about uncared for; <as>as, a room
in a state of <ex>litter</ex></as>.</def>

<sn>5.</sn> <def>The young brought forth at one time, by a sow or
other multiparous animal, taken collectively. Also Fig.</def>

<q>A wolf came to a sow, and very kindly offered to take care of
her <qex>litter</qex>.</q>
<qau>D. Estrange.</qau>

<q>Reflect upon numerous <qex>litter</qex> of strange, senseless
opinions that crawl about the world.</q>
<qau>South.</qau>

<hw>Lit"ter</hw>, <pos>v. t.</pos> <wordforms>[<pos>imp. & p.
p.</pos> <er>Littered</er> <pr>(?)</pr>; <pos>p. pr. & vb.
n.</pos> <er>Littering</er>.]</wordforms> <sn>1.</sn> <def>To
supply with litter, as cattle; to cover with litter, as the floor
of a stall.</def>

<q>Tell them how they <qex>litter</qex> their jades.</q>
<qau>Bp. Hacke<?/.</qau>

<q>For his ease, well <qex>littered</qex> was the floor.</q>
<qau>Dryden.</qau>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>To put into a confused or disordered condition;
to strew with scattered articles; <as>as, to <ex>litter</ex> a
room</as>.</def>

<q>The room with volumes <qex>littered</qex> round.</q>
<qau>Swift.</qau>

<sn>3.</sn> <def>To give birth to; to bear; -- said of brutes,
esp. those which produce more than one at a birth, and also of
human beings, in abhorrence or contempt.</def>

<q>We might conceive that dogs were created blind, because we
observe they were <qex>littered</qex> so with us.</q>
<qau>Sir T. Browne.</qau>

<q>The son that she did <qex>litter</qex> here,
A freckled whelp hagborn.</q>
<qau>Shak.</qau>

<-- p. 861 -->

<hw>Lit"ter</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>v. i.</pos> <sn>1.</sn>
<def>To be supplied with litter as bedding; to sleep or make
one's bed in litter.</def> <mark>[R.]</mark>

<q>The inn
Where he and his horse <qex>littered</qex>.</q>
<qau>Habington.</qau>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>To produce a litter.</def>

<q>A desert . . . where the she-wolf still
<qex>littered</qex>.</q>
<qau>Macaulay.</qau>

<hw>\'d8Lit`te`ra`teur"</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos>
<ety>[F.]</ety> <def>One who occupies himself with literature; a
literary man; a literatus.</def> \'bd Befriended by one
kind-hearted <xex>litt\'82rateur</xex> after another.\'b8

<au>C. Kingsley.</au>

<hw>Lit"ter*y</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>a.</pos> <def>Covered or
encumbered with litter; consisting of or constituting
litter.</def>

<hw>Lit"tle</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>a.</pos> <wordforms>[The
regular comparative of this word is wanting, its place being
supplied by <it>less</it>, or, rarely, <it>lesser</it>. See
<er>Lesser</er>. For the superlative <it>least</it> is used, the
regular form, <it>littlest</it>, occurring very rarely, except in
some of the English provinces, and occasionally in colloquial
language. \'bd Where love is great, the <qex>littlest</qex>
doubts are fear.\'b8 <au>Shak</au>.]</wordforms> <ety>[OE.
<ets>litel</ets>, <ets>lutel</ets>, AS. <ets>l<?/tel</ets>,
<ets>l\'c6tel</ets>, <ets>l<?/t</ets>; akin to OS.
<ets>littil</ets>, D. <ets>luttel</ets>, LG. <ets>l\'81tt</ets>,
OHG. <ets>luzzil</ets>, MHG. <ets>l\'81tzel</ets>; and perh. to
AS. <ets>lytig</ets> deceitful, <ets>lot</ets> deceit, Goth.
<ets>liuts</ets> deceitful, <ets>lut<?/n</ets> to deceive; cf.
also Icel. <ets>l\'c6till</ets> little, Sw. <ets>liten</ets>,
Dan. <ets>liden</ets>, <ets>lille</ets>, Goth.
<ets>leitils</ets>, which appear to have a different root
vowel.]</ety> <sn>1.</sn> <def>Small in size or extent; not big;
diminutive; -- opposed to <xex>big</xex> or <xex>large</xex>;
<as>as, a <ex>little</ex> body; a <ex>little</ex> animal; a
<ex>little</ex> piece of ground; a <ex>little</ex> hill; a
<ex>little</ex> distance; a <ex>little</ex> child.</as></def>

<q>He sought to see Jesus who he was; and could not for the
press, because he was <qex>little</qex> of stature.</q>
<qau>Luke xix. 3.</qau>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>Short in duration; brief; <as>as, a
<ex>little</ex> sleep</as>.</def>

<q>Best him enough: after a <qex>little</qex> time,
I'll beat him too.</q>
<qau>Shak.</qau>

<sn>3.</sn> <def>Small in quantity or amount; not much; <as>as, a
<ex>little</ex> food; a <ex>little</ex> air or water.</as></def>

<q>Conceited of their <qex>little</qex> wisdoms, and doting upon
their own fancies.</q>
<qau>Barrow.</qau>

<sn>4.</sn> <def>Small in dignity, power, or importance; not
great; insignificant; contemptible.</def>

<q>When thou wast <qex>little</qex> in thine own sight, wast thou
not made the head of the tribes?</q>
<qau>I Sam. xv. 17.</qau>

<sn>5.</sn> <def>Small in force or efficiency; not strong; weak;
slight; inconsiderable; <as>as, <ex>little</ex> attention or
exertion;<ex>little</ex> effort; <ex>little</ex> care or
diligence.</as></def>

<q>By sad experiment I know
How <qex>little</qex> weight my words with thee can find.</q>
<qau>Milton.</qau>

<sn>6.</sn> <def>Small in extent of views or sympathies; narrow;
shallow; contracted; mean; illiberal; ungenerous.</def>

<q>The long-necked geese of the world that are ever hissing
dispraise,
Because their natures are <qex>little</qex>.</q>
<qau>Tennyson.</qau>

<cs><col>Little chief</col>. <fld>(Zo\'94l.)</fld> <cd>See
<er>Chief hare</er>.</cd> -- <col>Little finger</col>, <cd>the
fourth and smallest finger of the hand.</cd> -- <col>Little
go</col> <fld>(Eng. Universities)</fld>, <cd>a public examination
about the middle of the course, which as less strict and
important than the final one; -- called also
<altname>smalls</altname>. Cf. <xex>Great go<xex>, under
<er>Great</er>. <au>Thackeray</au>.</cd> -- <col>Little
hours</col> <fld>(R. C. Ch.)</fld>, <cd>the offices of prime,
tierce, sext, and nones. Vespers and compline are sometimes
included.</cd> -- <col>Little ones</col>, <cd>young
children.</cd></cs>

<q>The men, and the women, and the <qex>little ones</qex>.</q>
<qau>Deut. ii. 34.</qau>

<hw>Lit"tle</hw>, <pos>n.</pos> <sn>1.</sn> <def>That which is
little; a small quantity, amount, space, or the like.</def>

<q>Much was in <qex>little</qex> writ.</q>
<qau>Dryden.</qau>

<q>There are many expressions, which carrying with them no clear
ideas, are like to remove but <qex>little</qex> of my
ignorance.</q>
<qau>Locke.</qau>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>A small degree or scale; miniature.</def> \'bd
His picture in <xex>little</xex>.\'b8

<au>Shak.</au>

<q>A little, to or in a small degree; to a limited extent;
somewhat; for a short time. \'bd Stay a
<qex>little</qex>.\'b8</q>

<au>Shak.</au>

<q>The painter flattered her a <qex>little</qex>.</q>
<qau>Shak.</qau>

-- <mcol><col>By little and little</col>, <or/ <col>Little by
little</col></mcol>, <cd>by slow degrees; piecemeal;
gradually.</cd>

<hw>Lit"tle</hw>, <pos>adv.</pos> <def>In a small quantity or
degree; not much; slightly; somewhat; -- often with a preceding
it.</def> \'bd The poor sleep <xex>little</xex>.\'b8

<au>Otway.</au>

<au>Latimer.</au>

<syn>Syn. -- Smallness; slightness; inconsiderableness;

<hw>Lit"to*ral</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>a.</pos> <ety>[L.

<sn>2.</sn> <fld>(Biol.)</fld> <def>Inhabiting the seashore, esp.

<hw>\'d8Lit"to*ri"na</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[NL.
See <er>Littoral</er>.]</ety> <fld>(Zo\'94l.)</fld> <def>A genus
of small pectinibranch mollusks, having thick spiral shells,
abundant between tides on nearly all rocky seacoasts. They feed
on seaweeds. The common periwinkle is a well-known example. See
<er>Periwinkle</er>.</def>

<hw>Lit"ur*gy</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos>; <plu>pl.
<plw>Liturgies</plw> <pr>(#)</pr></plu>. <ety>[F.
<ets>liturgie</ets>, LL. <ets>liturgia</ets>, Gr. <?/ a public
service, the public service of God, public worship; (assumed)
<?/, <?/, belonging to the people, public (fr. <?/, <?/, the
people) + the root of <?/ work. See <er>Lay</er>, <pos>a.</pos>,
and <er>Work</er>.]</ety> <def>An established formula for public
worship, or the entire ritual for public worship in a church
which uses prescribed forms; a formulary for public prayer or
devotion. In the Roman Catholic Church it includes all forms and
services in any language, in any part of the world, for the
celebration of Mass.</def>

<hw>\'d8Lit"u*us</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos>; <plu>pl.
<plw>Litui</plw> <pr>(#)</pr></plu>. <ety>[L.]</ety> <sn>1.</sn>
<fld>(Rom. Antig.)</fld> <sd>(a)</sd> <def>A curved staff used by
the augurs in quartering the heavens.</def> <sd>(b)</sd> <def>An
instrument of martial music; a kind of trumpet of a somewhat
curved form and shrill note.</def>

<sn>2.</sn> <fld>(Math.)</fld> <def>A spiral whose polar equation
is <mathex>r<exp>2</exp><theta/ = a</mathex>; that is, a curve
the square of whose radius vector varies inversely as the angle
which the radius vector makes with a given line.</def>

<hw>Liv"a*ble</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>a.</pos> <sn>1.</sn>
<def>Such as can be lived.</def>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>Such as in pleasant to live in; fit or suitable
to live in.</def> <mark>[Colloq.]</mark>

<q>A more delightful or <qex>livable</qex> region is not easily
to be found.</q>
<qau>T. Arnold.</qau>

<hw>Live</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>v. i.</pos>
<wordforms>[<pos>imp. & p. p.</pos> <er>Lived</er> <pr>(?)</pr>;
<pos>p. pr. & vb. n.</pos> <er>Living</er>.]</wordforms>
<ety>[OE. <ets>liven</ets>, <ets>livien</ets>, AS.
<ets>libban</ets>, <ets>lifian</ets>; akin to OS.
<ets>libbian</ets>, D. <ets>leven</ets>, G. <ets>leben</ets>,
OHG. <ets>leb</ets><?/<ets>n</ets>, Dan. <ets>leve</ets>, Sw.
<ets>lefva</ets>, Icel. <ets>lifa</ets> to live, to be left, to
remain, Goth. <ets>liban</ets> to live; akin to E.
<ets>leave</ets> to forsake, and <ets>life</ets>, Gr. <?/ to
persist, <?/ oily, shining, sleek, <?/ fat, lard, Skr.
<ets>lip</ets> to anoint, smear; -- the first sense prob. was, to
cleave to, stick to; hence, to remain, stay; and hence, to
live.]</ety> <sn>1.</sn> <def>To be alive; to have life; to have,
as an animal or a plant, the capacity of assimilating matter as
food, and to be dependent on such assimilation for a continuance
of existence; <as>as, animals and plants that <ex>live</ex> to a
great age are long in reaching maturity</as>.</def>

<q>Thus saith the Lord God unto these bones; Behold, I will . . .
lay sinews upon you, and will bring up flesh upon you, and cover
you with skin, and put breath in you, and ye shall
<qex>live</qex>.</q>
<qau>Ezek. xxxvii. 5, 6.</qau>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>To pass one's time; to pass life or time in a
certain manner, as to habits, conduct, or circumstances; <as>as,
to <ex>live</ex> in ease or affluence; to <ex>live</ex> happily
or usefully.</as></def>

<q>O death, how bitter is the remembrance of thee to a man that
<qex>liveth</qex> at rest in his possessions!</q>
<qau>Ecclus. xli. 1. </qau>

<sn>3.</sn> <def>To make one's abiding place or home; to abide;
to dwell; to reside.</def>

<q>Jacob <qex>lived</qex> in the land of Egypt seventeen
years.</q>
<qau>Gen. xlvii. 28.</qau>

<sn>4.</sn> <def>To be or continue in existence; to exist; to
remain; to be permanent; to last; -- said of inanimate objects,
ideas, etc.</def>

<q>Men's evil manners <qex>live</qex> in brass; their virtues
We write in water.</q>
<qau>Shak.</qau>

<sn>5.</sn> <def>To enjoy or make the most of life; to be in a
state of happiness.</def>

<q>What greater curse could envious fortune give
Than just to die when I began to <qex>live</qex>?</q>
<qau>Dryden.</qau>

<sn>6.</sn> <def>To feed; to subsist; to be nourished or
supported; -- with <xex>on</xex>; <as>as, horses <ex>live</ex> on
grass and grain</as>.</def>

<sn>7.</sn> <def>To have a spiritual existence; to be quickened,
nourished, and actuated by divine influence or faith.</def>

<q>The just shall <qex>live</qex> by faith.</q>
<qau>Gal. iii. ll.</qau>

<sn>8.</sn> <def>To be maintained in life; to acquire a
livelihood; to subsist; -- with <xex>on</xex> or <xex>by</xex>;
<as>as, to <ex>live</ex> on spoils</as>.</def>

<q>Those who <qex>live</qex> by labor.</q>
<qau>Sir W. Temple.</qau>

<sn>9.</sn> <def>To outlast danger; to float; -- said of a ship,
boat, etc.; <as>as, no ship could <ex>live</ex> in such a
storm</as>.</def>

<q>A strong mast that <qex>lived</qex> upon the sea.</q>
<qau>Shak.</qau>

<cs><col>To live out</col>, <cd>to be at service; to live away
from home as a servant.</cd> <mark>[U. S.]</mark> -- <col>To live
with</col>. <sd>(a)</sd> <cd>To dwell or to be a lodger
with</cd>. <sd>(b)</sd> <cd>To cohabit with; to have intercourse
with, as male with female.</cd></cs>

<hw>Live</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>v. t.</pos> <sn>1.</sn> <def>To
spend, as one's life; to pass; to maintain; to continue in,
constantly or habitually; <as>as, to <ex>live</ex> an idle or a
useful life</as>.</def>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>To act habitually in conformity with; to
practice.</def>

<q>To <qex>live</qex> the Gospel.</q>
<qau>Foxe.</qau>

<cs><col>To live down</col>, <cd>to live so as to subdue or
refute; as, <xex>to live down<xex> slander.</cd></cs>

<hw>Live</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>a.</pos> <ety>[Abbreviated from
<ets>alive</ets>. See <er>Alive</er>, <er>Life</er>.]</ety>
<sn>1.</sn> <def>Having life; alive; living; not dead.</def>

<q>If one man's ox hurt another's, that he die; then they shall
sell the <qex>live</qex> ox, and divide the money of it.</q>
<qau>Ex. xxi. 35.</qau>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>Being in a state of ignition; burning; having
active properties; <as>as, a <ex>live</ex> coal; <ex>live</ex>
embers.</as></def> \'bd The <xex>live</xex> ether.\'b8

<au>Thomson.</au>

<sn>3.</sn> <def>Full of earnestness; active; wide awake;
glowing; <as>as, a <ex>live</ex> man, or orator</as>.</def>

<sn>4.</sn> <def>Vivid; bright.</def> \'bd The <xex>live</xex>
carnation.\'b8

<au>Thomson.</au>

<sn>5.</sn> <fld>(Engin.)</fld> <def>Imparting power; having
motion; <as>as, the <ex>live</ex> spindle of a lathe</as>.</def>

<-- 6. (Elec.) connected to a voltage source, as a live wire.
  7. (Broadcasting) being transmitted instantaneously, as events
occur, in contrast to recorded.
  8. (Sport) still in active play -- as a live ball.
  9. pertaingin to an entertainment event which was performed
(and possibly recorded) in front of an audience; contrasted to
performances recorded in a studio without an audience -->

<cs><col>Live birth</col>, <cd>the condition of being born in
such a state that acts of life are manifested after the extrusion
of the whole body. <au>Dunglison</au>.</cd> -- <col>Live
box</col>, <cd>a cell for holding living objects under
microscopical examination. <au>P. H. Gosse</au>.</cd> --
<col>Live feathers</col>, <cd>feathers which have been plucked
from the living bird, and are therefore stronger and more
elastic.</cd> -- <col>Live gang</col>. <fld>(Sawing)</fld>
<cd>See under <er>Gang</er>.</cd> -- <col>Live grass</col>
<fld>(Bot.)</fld>, <cd>a grass of the genus
<spn>Eragrostis</spn>.</cd> -- <col>Live load</col>
<fld>(Engin.)</fld>, <cd>a suddenly applied load; a varying load;
a moving load; as a moving train of cars on a bridge, or wind
pressure on a roof.</cd> <col>Live oak</col> <fld>(Bot.)</fld>,
<cd>a species of oak (<spn>Quercus virens</spn>), growing in the
Southern States, of great durability, and highly esteemed for
ship timber. In California the <spn>Q. chrysolepis</spn> and some
other species are also called <ex>live oaks<ex>.</cd> --
<col>Live ring</col> <fld>(Engin.)</fld>, <cd>a circular train of
rollers upon which a swing bridge, or turntable, rests, and which
travels around a circular track when the bridge or table
turns.</cd> -- <col>Live steam</col> , <cd>steam direct from the
boiler, used for any purpose, in distinction from <contr>exhaust
steam</contr>.</cd> -- <col>Live stock</col>, <cd>horses, cattle,
and other domestic animals kept on a farm.  whole body.</cd></cs>
<-- live wire (a) (Elec.) a wire connected to a power source,
having a voltage potential; -- used esp. of a power line with a
high potential relative to ground, capable of harming a person
who touches it. (b) [MW10] (Fig.) "an alert, active, or
aggressive person." -->

<hw>Live"li*hed</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <def>See

<hw>Live"li*hood</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[OE.
<ets>livelode</ets>, <ets>liflode</ets>, prop., course of life,
life's support, maintenance, fr. AS. <ets>l\'c6f</ets> life +
<ets>l\'bed</ets> road, way, maintenance. Confused with
<ets>livelihood</ets> liveliness. See <er>Life</er>, and
<er>Lode</er>.]</ety> <def>Subsistence or living, as dependent on
some means of support; support of life; maintenance.</def>

<q>The opportunities of gaining an honest
<qex>livelihood</qex>.</q>
<qau>Addison.</qau>

<q>It is their profession and <qex>livelihood</qex> to get their
living by practices for which they deserve to forfeit their
lives.</q>
<qau>South.</qau>

<hw>Live"li*hood</hw>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[<ets>Lively</ets> +
<ets>-hood</ets>.]</ety> <def>Liveliness; appearance of
life.</def> <mark>[Obs.]</mark>

<au>Shak.</au>

<hw>Live"li*ly</hw>, <pos>adv.</pos> <def>In a lively
manner.</def> <mark>[Obs.]</mark>

<au>Lamb.</au>

<hw>Live"li*ness</hw>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[From
<er>Lively</er>.]</ety> <sn>1.</sn> <def>The quality or state of
being lively or animated; sprightliness; vivacity; animation;
spirit; <as>as, the <ex>liveliness</ex> of youth, contrasted with
the gravity of age</as>.</def>

<au>B. Jonson.</au>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>An appearance of life, animation, or spirit;
<as>as, the <ex>liveliness</ex> of the eye or the countenance in
a portrait</as>.</def>

<sn>3.</sn> <def>Briskness; activity; effervescence, as of
liquors.</def>

<syn>Syn. -- Sprightliness; gayety; animation; vivacity;
smartness; briskness; activity. -- <er>Liveliness</er>,
<er>Gayety</er>, <er>Animation</er>, <er>Vivacity</er>.
<xex>Liveliness</xex> is an habitual feeling of life and
interest; <xex>gayety</xex> refers more to a temporary excitement
of the animal spirits; <xex>animation</xex> implies a warmth of
emotion and a corresponding vividness of expressing it, awakened
by the presence of something which strongly affects the mind;
<xex>vivacity</xex> is a feeling between liveliness and
animation, having the permanency of the one, and, to some extent,
the warmth of the other. <xex>Liveliness</xex> of imagination;
<xex>gayety</xex> of heart; <xex>animation</xex> of countenance;
<xex>vivacity</xex> of gesture or conversation.</syn>

<hw>Live"lode`</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[See 1st
<er>Livelihood</er>.]</ety> <def>Course of life; means of
support; livelihood.</def> <mark>[Obs.]</mark>

<hw>Live"long`</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>a.</pos> <ety>[For
<ets>lifelong</ets>. Cf. <er>Lifelong</er>.]</ety> <sn>1.</sn>
<def>Whole; entire; long in passing; -- used of time, as day or
night, in adverbial phrases, and usually with a sense of
tediousness.</def>

<q>The obscure bird
Clamored the <qex>livelong</qex> night.</q>
<qau>Shak.</qau>

<q>How could she sit the <qex>livelong</qex> day,
Yet never ask us once to play?</q>
<qau>Swift.</qau>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>Lasting; durable.</def> <mark>[Obs.]</mark>

<q>Thou hast built thyself a <qex>livelong</qex> monument.</q>
<qau>Milton.</qau>

<hw>Live"ly</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>a.</pos>
<wordforms>[<pos>Compar.</pos> <er>Livelier</er> <pr>(?)</pr>;
<pos>superl.</pos> <er>Liveliest</er>.]</wordforms> <ety>[For
<ets>lifely</ets>. Cf. <er>Lifelike</er>.]</ety> <sn>1.</sn>
<def>Endowed with or manifesting life; living.</def>

<q>Chaplets of gold and silver resembling <qex>lively</qex>
flowers and leaves.</q>
<qau>Holland.</qau>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>Brisk; vivacious; active; <as>as, a
<ex>lively</ex> youth</as>.</def>

<q>But wherefore comes old Manoa in such haste,
With youthful steps ? Much <qex>livelier</qex> than erewhile
He seems.</q>
<qau>Milton.</qau>

<sn>3.</sn> <def>Gay; airy; animated; spirited.</def>

<q>From grave to gay, from <qex>lively</qex> to severe.</q>
<qau>Pope.</qau>

<sn>4.</sn> <def>Representing life; lifelike.</def>
<mark>[Obs.]</mark>

<q>I spied the <qex>lively</qex> picture of my father.</q>
<qau>Massinger.</qau>

<sn>5.</sn> <def>Bright; vivid; glowing; strong; vigorous</def>.

<q>The colors of the prism are manifestly more full, intense, and
<qex>lively</qex> that those of natural bodies.</q>
<qau>Sir I. Newton.</qau>

<q>His faith must be not only living, but <qex>lively</qex>
too.</q>
<qau>South.</qau>

<cs><col>Lively stones</col> <fld>(Script.)</fld>, <cd>saints, as
being quickened by the Spirit, and active in holiness.</cd></cs>

<syn>Syn. -- Brisk; vigorous; quick; nimble; smart; active;
alert; sprightly; animated; spirited; prompt; earnest; strong;
energetic; vivid; vivacious; blithe; gleeful; airy; gay;
jocund.</syn>

<hw>Live"ly</hw>, <pos>adv.</pos> <sn>1.</sn> <def>In a brisk,
active, or animated manner; briskly; vigorously.</def>

<au>Hayward.</au>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>With strong resemblance of life.</def>
<mark>[Obs.]</mark>

<q>Thou counterfeitest most <qex>lively</qex>.</q>
<qau>Shak.</qau>

<hw>Liv"er</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <sn>1.</sn> <def>One
who, or that which, lives.</def>

<q>And try if life be worth the <qex>liver's</qex> care.</q>
<qau>Prior.</qau>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>A resident; a dweller; <as>as, a <ex>liver</ex>
in Brooklyn</as>.</def>

<sn>3.</sn> <def>One whose course of life has some marked
characteristic (expressed by an adjective); <as>as, a free
<ex>liver</ex></as>.</def>

<cs><col>Fast liver</col>, <cd>one who lives in an extravagant
and dissipated way.</cd> -- <mcol><col>Free liver</col>,
<col>Good liver</col></mcol>, <cd>one given to the pleasures of
the table.</cd> -- <col>Loose liver</col>, <cd>a person who lives
a somewhat dissolute life.</cd></cs>

<hw>Liv"er</hw>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[AS. <ets>lifer</ets>; akin
to D. <ets>liver</ets>, G. <ets>leber</ets>, OHG.
<ets>lebara</ets>, Icel. <ets>lifr</ets>, Sw. <ets>lefver</ets>,
and perh. to Gr. <?/ fat, E. <ets>live</ets>, v.]</ety>
<fld>(Anat.)</fld> <def>A very large glandular and vascular organ
in the visceral cavity of all vertebrates.</def>

<note><hand/ Most of the venous blood from the alimentary canal
passes through it on its way back to the heart; and it secretes
the bile, produces glycogen, and in other ways changes the blood
which passes through it. In man it is situated immediately
beneath the diaphragm and mainly on the right side. See
<er>Bile</er>, <er>Digestive</er>, and <er>Glycogen</er>.  The
liver of invertebrate animals is usually made up of c\'91cal
tubes, and differs materially, in form and function, from that of
vertebrates.</note>

<cs><col>Floating liver</col>. <cd>See <cref>Wandering
liver</cref>, under <er>Wandering</er>.</cd> -- <mcol><col>Liver
of antimony</col>, <col>Liver of sulphur</col></mcol>. <fld>(Old
Chem.)</fld> <cd>See <er>Hepar</er>.</cd> -- <mcol><col>Liver
brown</col>, <col>Liver color</col></mcol>, <cd>the color of
liver, a dark, reddish brown.</cd> -- <col>Liver shark</col>
<fld>(Zo\'94l.)</fld>, <cd>a very large shark (<spn>Cetorhinus
maximus</spn>), inhabiting the northern coasts both of Europe and
North America. It sometimes becomes forty feet in length, being
one of the largest sharks known; but it has small simple teeth,
and is not dangerous. It is captured for the sake of its liver,
which often yields several barrels of oil. It has gill rakers,
resembling whalebone, by means of which it separates small
animals from the sea water.</cd> Called also <altname>basking
shark</altname>, <altname>bone shark</altname>,
<altname>hoemother</altname>, <altname>homer</altname>, and
<altname>sailfish</altname><-- sometimes referred to as 'whale
shark', but that name is more commonly used for the Rhincodon
typus, which grows even larger -->. -- <col>Liver spots</col>,
<cd>yellowish brown patches or spots of chloasma.</cd></cs>

<-- p. 862 -->

<def>The glossy ibis (<spn>Ibis falcinellus</spn>); -- said to
have given its name to the city of Liverpool.</def>

white-<ex>livered</ex></as>.</def>

enlarged liver.</def>

<au>Dunglison.</au>

<q>The <qex>liveried</qex> servants wait.</q>
<qau>Parnell.</qau>

sausage made of liver or pork.</def> <mark>[Obs.]</mark>

<au>Chapman.</au>

<hw>Liv"er*leaf`</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos>
<fld>(Bot.)</fld> <def>Same as <er>Liverwort</er>.</def>

<hw>Liv"er*wort`</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos>
<fld>(Bot.)</fld> <sn>1.</sn> <def>A ranunculaceous plant
(<spn>Anemone Hepatica</spn>) with pretty white or bluish flowers
and a three-lobed leaf; -- called also <altname>squirrel
cups</altname>.</def>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>A flowerless plant (<spn>Marchantia
polymorpha</spn>), having an irregularly lobed, spreading, and
forking frond.</def>

<note><hand/ From this plant many others of the same order
(<spn>Hepatic\'91</spn>) have been vaguely called liverworts,
esp. those of the tribe <spn>Marchantiace\'91</spn>. See
<xex>Illust</xex>. of <er>Hepatica</er>.</note>

<hw>Liv"er*y</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos>; <plu>pl.
<plw>Liveries</plw> <pr>(#)</pr></plu>. <ety>[OE.
<ets>livere</ets>, F. <ets>livr\'82e</ets>, formerly, a gift of
clothes made by the master to his servants, prop., a thing
delivered, fr. <ets>livrer</ets> to deliver, L.
<ets>liberare</ets> to set free, in LL., to deliver up. See
<er>Liberate</er>.]</ety> <sn>1.</sn> <fld>(Eng. Law)</fld>
<sd>(a)</sd> <def>The act of delivering possession of lands or
tenements.</def> <sd>(b)</sd> <def>The writ by which possession
is obtained.</def>

<note><hand/ It is usual to say, <xex>livery of seizin</xex>,
which is a feudal investiture, made by the delivery of a turf, of
a rod, or twig, from the feoffor to the feoffee. In the United
States, and now in Great Britain, no such ceremony is necessary,
the delivery of a deed being sufficient.</note>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>Release from wardship; deliverance.</def>

<q>It concerned them first to sue out their <qex>livery</qex>
from the unjust wardship of his encroaching prerogative.</q>
<qau>Milton.</qau>

<sn>3.</sn> <def>That which is delivered out statedly or
formally, as clothing, food, etc.</def>; especially: <sd>(a)</sd>
<def>The uniform clothing issued by feudal superiors to their
retainers and serving as a badge when in military service.</def>
<sd>(b)</sd> <def>The peculiar dress by which the servants of a
nobleman or gentleman are distinguished; <as>as, a claret-colored
<ex>livery</ex></as>.</def> <sd>(c)</sd> <def>Hence, also, the
peculiar dress or garb appropriated by any association or body of
persons to their own use; <as>as, the <ex>livery</ex> of the
London tradesmen, of a priest, of a charity school, etc.</as>;
also, the whole body or company of persons wearing such a garb,
and entitled to the privileges of the association; <as>as, the
whole <ex>livery</ex> of London</as>.</def>

<q>A Haberdasher and a Carpenter,
A Webbe, a Dyer, and a Tapicer,
And they were clothed all in one <qex>livery</qex>
Of a solempne and a gret fraternite.</q>
<qau>Chaucer.</qau>

<q>From the periodical deliveries of these characteristic
articles of servile costume (blue coats) came our word
<qex>livery</qex>.</q>
<qau>De Quincey.</qau>

<sd>(d)</sd> <def>Hence, any characteristic dress or outward
appearance</def>. \'bd April's <xex>livery</xex>.\'b8  <au>Sir P.
Sidney.</au>

<q>Now came still evening on, and twilight gray
Had in her sober <qex>livery</qex> all things clad.</q>
<qau>Milton.</qau>

<sd>(e)</sd> <def>An allowance of food statedly given out; a
ration, as to a family, to servants, to horses, etc.</def>

<q>The emperor's officers every night went through the town from
house to house whereat any English gentleman did repast or lodge,
and served their <qex>liveries</qex> for all night: first, the
officers brought into the house a cast of fine manchet [white
bread], and of silver two great post, and white wine, and
sugar.</q>
<qau>Cavendish.</qau>

<sd>(f)</sd> <def>The feeding, stabling, and care of horses for
compensation; boarding; <as>as, to keep one's horses at
<ex>livery</ex></as></def>.

<q>What <qex>livery</qex> is, we by common use in England know
well enough, namely, that is, allowance of horse meat, as to keep
horses at <qex>livery</qex>, the which word, I guess, is derived
of livering or delivering forth their nightly food.</q>
<qau>Spenser.</qau>

<q>It need hardly be observed that the explanation of
<qex>livery</qex> which Spenser offers is perfectly correct, but
. . . it is no longer applied to the ration or stated portion of
food delivered at stated periods.</q>
<qau>Trench.</qau>

<sd>(g)</sd> <def>The keeping of horses in readiness to be hired
temporarily for riding or driving; the state of being so
kept</def>.

<q>Pegasus does not stand at <qex>livery</qex> even at the
largest establishment in Moorfields.</q>
<au>Lowell.</au>

<sn>4.</sn> <def>A low grade of wool.</def>

<cs><col>Livery gown</col>, <cd>the gown worn by a liveryman in
London.</cd></cs>

<hw>Liv"er*y</hw>, <pos>v. t.</pos> <def>To clothe in, or as in,
livery.</def>

<au>Shak.</au>

<hw>Liv"er*y*man</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos>; <plu>pl.
<plw>Liverymen</plw> <pr>(<?/)</pr>.</plu>

<sn>1.</sn> <def>One who wears a livery, as a servant.</def>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>A freeman of the city, in London, who, having
paid certain fees, is entitled to wear the distinguishing dress
or <xex>livery</xex> of the company to which he belongs, and also
to enjoy certain other privileges, as the right of voting in an
election for the lord mayor, sheriffs, chamberlain, etc.</def>

<sn>3.</sn> <def>One who keeps a livery stable.</def>

<hw>Liv"er*y sta`ble</hw> <pr>(?)</pr><def>. A stable where
horses are kept for hire, and where stabling is provided. See
<er>Livery</er>, <pos>n.</pos>, 3 <sd>(e)</sd> <sd>(f)</sd> &
<sd>(g)</sd>.</def>

<hw>Lix*iv"i*al</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>a.</pos> <ety>[L.

<cs><col>Lixivial salts</col> <fld>(Old Chem.)</fld>, <cd>salts

<mhw>{ <hw>Lix*iv"i*ate</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <hw>Lix*iv"i*`ted</hw>

<hw>Lix*iv"i*ate</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>v. t.</pos>
<wordforms>[<pos>imp. & p. p.</pos> <er>Lixiviated</er>
<pr>(?)</pr>; <pos>p. pr. & vb. n.</pos> <er>Lixiviating</er>
<pr>(?)</pr>.]</wordforms> <def>To subject to a washing process

<hw>Lix*iv`i*a"tion</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[Cf. F.

<hw>\'d8Li"za</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos>

<hw>Liz"ard</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[OE.
<ets>lesarde</ets>, OF. <ets>lesarde</ets>, F.
<ets>l\'82zard</ets>, L. <ets>lacerta</ets>, <ets>lacertus</ets>.
Cf. <er>Alligator</er>, <er>Lacerta</er>.]</ety>

<sn>1.</sn> <fld>(Zo\'94l.)</fld> <def>Any one of the numerous
species of reptiles belonging to the order Lacertilia; sometimes,
also applied to reptiles of other orders, as the Hatteria.</def>

<note><hand/ Most lizards have an elongated body, with four legs,
and a long tail; but there are some without legs, and some with a
short, thick tail. Most have scales, but some are naked; most
have eyelids, but some do not. The tongue is varied in form and
structure. In some it is forked, in others, as the chameleons,
club-shaped, and very extensible. See <er>Amphisb\'91na</er>,
<er>Chameleon</er>, <er>Gecko</er>, <er>Gila monster</er>,
<er>Horned toad</er>, <er>Iguana</er>, and <er>Dragon</er>,
6.</note>

<sn>2.</sn> <fld>(Naut.)</fld> <def>A piece of rope with thimble
or block spliced into one or both of the ends.</def>

<au>R. H. Dana, Ir.</au>

<sn>3.</sn> <def>A piece of timber with a forked end, used in
dragging a heavy stone, a log, or the like, from a field.</def>

<cs><col>Lizard fish</col> <fld>(Zo\'94l.)</fld>, <cd>a marine
scopeloid fish of the genus <spn>Synodus</spn>, or
<spn>Saurus</spn>, esp. <spn>S. f\'d2tens</spn> of the Southern
United States and West Indies; -- called also <altname>sand
pike</altname>.</cd> -- <col>Lizard snake</col>
<fld>(Zo\'94l.)</fld>, <cd>the garter snake (<spn>Eut\'91nia
sirtalis</spn>).</cd> -- <col>Lizard stone</col>
<fld>(Min.)</fld>, <cd>a kind of serpentine from near Lizard
Point, Cornwall, England, -- used for ornamental
purposes.</cd></cs>

<hw>Liz"ard's tail`</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>. <fld>(Bot.)</fld> <def>A
perennial plant of the genus <spn>Saururus</spn> (<spn>S.
cernuus</spn>), growing in marshes, and having white flowers
crowded in a slender terminal spike, somewhat resembling in form
a lizard's tail; whence the name.</def>

<au>Gray.</au>

<hw>Lla"ma</hw>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[Peruv.]</ety>
<fld>(Zo\'94l.)</fld> <def>A South American ruminant
(<spn>Auchenia llama</spn>), allied to the camels, but much
smaller and without a hump. It is supposed to be a domesticated
variety of the guanaco. It was formerly much used as a beast of
burden in the Andes.</def>

<hw>Llan*dei"lo group`</hw>. <fld>(Geol.)</fld> <def>A series of
strata in the lower Silurian formations of Great Britain; -- so
named from <ets>Llandeilo</ets> in Southern Wales. See
<xex>Chart</xex> of <er>Geology</er>.</def>

<hw>\'d8Lla*ne"ro</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[Sp.
Amer.]</ety> <def>One of the inhabitants of the llanos of South
America.</def>

<hw>Lla"no</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos>; <plu>pl.
<plw>Llanos</plw> <pr>(#)</pr></plu>. <ety>[Sp., plain even,
level. See <er>Plain</er>.]</ety> <def>An extensive plain with or
without vegetation.</def> <mark>[Spanish America]</mark>

<hw>Lloyd's</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <sn>1.</sn> <def>An
association of underwriters and others in London, for the
collection and diffusion of marine intelligence, the insurance,
classification, registration, and certifying of vessels, and the
transaction of business of various kinds connected with
shipping.</def>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>A part of the Royal Exchange, in London,
appropriated to the use of underwriters and insurance brokers; --
called also <altname>Lloyd's Rooms</altname>.</def>

<note><hand/ The name is derived from <xex>Lloyd's</xex> Coffee
House, in Lombard Street, where there were formerly rooms for the
same purpose. The name <xex>Lloyd</xex> or <xex>Lloyd's</xex> has
been taken by several associations, in different parts of Europe,
established for purposes similar to those of the original
association.</note>

<cs><col>Lloyd's agents</col>, <cd>persons employed in various
parts of the world, by the association called Lloyd's, to serve
its interests.</cd> -- <col>Lloyd's list</col>, <cd>a publication
of the latest news respecting shipping matters, with lists of
vessels, etc., made under the direction of Lloyd's.</cd>
<au>Brande & C.</au> -- <col>Lloyd's register</col>, <cd>a
register of vessels rated according to their quality, published
yearly.</cd></cs>

<hw>Lo</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>interj.</pos> <ety>[OE.
<ets>lo</ets>, <ets>low</ets>; perh. akin to E. <ets>look</ets>,
v.]</ety> <def>Look; see; behold; observe.</def> \'bd Lo, here is
Christ.\'b8 <au>Matt. xxiv. 23</au>. \'bd Lo, we turn to the
Gentiles.\'b8 <au>Acts xiii. 46</au>.

<hw>Loach</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[OE.
<ets>loche</ets>, F. <ets>loche</ets>.]</ety>
<fld>(Zo\'94l.)</fld> <def>Any one of several small, fresh-water,
cyprinoid fishes of the genera <spn>Cobitis</spn>,
<spn>Nemachilus</spn>, and allied genera, having six or more
barbules around the mouth. They are found in Europe and Asia. The
common European species (<spn>N. barbatulus</spn>) is used as a
food fish.</def>

<hw>Load</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[OE.
<ets>lode</ets> load, way; properly the same word as
<ets>lode</ets>, but confused with <ets>lade</ets>,
<ets>load</ets>, v. See <er>Lade</er>, <er>Lead</er>,
<pos>v.</pos>, <er>Lode</er>.]</ety> <sn>1.</sn> <def>A burden;
that which is laid on or put in anything for conveyance; that
which is borne or sustained; a weight; <as>as, a heavy
<ex>load</ex></as>.</def>

<q>He might such a <qex>load</qex>
To town with his ass carry.</q>
<qau>Gower.</qau>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>The quantity which can be carried or drawn in
some specified way; the contents of a cart, barrow, or vessel;
that which will constitute a cargo; lading.</def>

<sn>3.</sn> <def>That which burdens, oppresses, or grieves the
mind or spirits; <as>as, a <ex>load</ex> of care</as>.</def> \'bd
A . . . <xex>load</xex> of guilt.\'b8 <au>Ray</au>. \'bd Our
life's a <xex>load</xex>.\'b8

<au>Dryden.</au>

<sn>4.</sn> <def>A particular measure for certain articles, being
as much as may be carried at one time by the conveyance commonly
used for the article measured; <as>as, a <ex>load</ex> of wood; a
<ex>load</ex> of hay</as>; specifically, five quarters.</def>

<sn>5.</sn> <def>The charge of a firearm; <as>as, a <ex>load</ex>
of powder</as>.</def>

<sn>6.</sn> <def>Weight or violence of blows.</def>
<mark>[Obs.]</mark>

<au>Milton.</au>

<sn>7.</sn> <fld>(Mach.)</fld> <def>The work done by a steam
engine or other prime mover when working.</def>

<cs><mcol><col>Load line</col>, <or/ <col>Load water
line</col></mcol> <fld>(Naut.)</fld>, <cd>the line on the outside
of a vessel indicating the depth to which it sinks in the water
when loaded.</cd></cs>

<syn>Syn. -- Burden; lading; weight; cargo. See
<er>Burden</er>.</syn>

<hw>Load</hw>, <pos>v. t.</pos> <wordforms>[<pos>imp. & p.
p.</pos> <er>Loaded</er>; <pos>p. pr. & vb. n.</pos>
<er>Loading</er>. <xex>Loaden</xex> is obsolete, and
<xex>laden</xex> belongs to <xex>lade</xex>.]</wordforms>
<sn>1.</sn> <def>To lay a load or burden on or in, as on a horse
or in a cart; to charge with a load, as a gun; to furnish with a
lading or cargo, as a ship; hence, to add weight to, so as to
oppress or embarrass; to heap upon.</def>

<q>I strive all in vain to <qex>load</qex> the cart.</q>
<qau>Gascoigne.</qau>

<q>I have <qex>loaden</qex> me with many spoils.</q>
<qau>Shak.</qau>

<q>Those honors deep and broad, wherewith
Your majesty <qex>loads</qex> our house.</q>
<qau>Shak.</qau>

<-- p. 863 -->

<sn>2.</sn> <def>To adulterate or drug; <as>as, to <ex>load</ex>
wine</as>.</def> <mark>[Cant]</mark>

<sn>3.</sn> <def>To magnetize.</def><mark>[Obs.]</mark>

<au>Prior.</au>

<cs><col>Loaded dice</col>, <cd>dice with one side made heavier
than the others, so that the number on the opposite side will
come up oftenest.</cd></cs>

<hw>Load"er</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <def>One who, or
that which, loads; a mechanical contrivance for loading, as a
gun.</def>

<hw>Load"ing</hw>, <pos>n.</pos> <sn>1.</sn> <def>The act of
putting a load on or into.</def>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>A load; cargo; burden.</def>

<au>Shak.</au>

}</mhw>, <pos>n.</pos> <def>Pilotage; skill of a pilot or

<mhw>{ <hw>Load"star`</hw>, <hw>Lode"star`</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>

<hw>Loam</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[AS.
<ets>l\'bem</ets>; akin to D. <ets>leem</ets>, G.
<ets>lehm</ets>, and E. <ets>lime</ets>. See 4th
<er>Lime</er>.]</ety> <sn>1.</sn> <def>A kind of soil; an earthy
mixture of clay and sand, with organic matter to which its
fertility is chiefly due.</def>

<q>We wash a wall of <qex>loam</qex>; we labor in vain.</q>
<qau>Hooker.</qau>

<sn>2.</sn> <fld>(Founding)</fld> <def>A mixture of sand, clay,
and other materials, used in making molds for large castings,
often without a pattern.</def>

<cs><col>Loam mold</col> <fld>(Founding)</fld>, <cd>a mold made
with loam. See <er>Loam</er>, <pos>n.</pos>, 2.</cd> -- <col>Loam
molding</col>, <cd>the process or business of making loam
molds.</cd> <col>Loam plate</col>, <cd>an iron plate upon which a
section of a loam mold rests, or from which it is suspended.</cd>
-- <col>Loam work</col>, <cd>loam molding or loam
molds.</cd></cs>

<hw>Loath</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>a.</pos> <ety>[OE.
<ets>looth</ets>, <ets>loth</ets>, AS. <ets>l\'be<?/</ets>
hostile, odious; akin to OS. <ets>l<?/<?/</ets>, G.
<ets>leid</ets>, Icel. <ets>lei<?/r</ets>, Sw. <ets>led</ets>, G.
<ets>leiden</ets> to suffer, OHG. <ets>l\'c6dan</ets> to suffer,

odious; disliked.</def> <mark>[Obs.]</mark>

<au>Chaucer.</au>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>Filled with disgust or aversion; averse;
unwilling; reluctant; <as>as, <ex>loath</ex> to part</as>.</def>

<q>Full <qex>loth</qex> were him to curse for his tithes.</q>
<qau>Chaucer</qau>.

<q>Why, then, though <qex>loath</qex>, yet must I be content.</q>
<qau>Shak.</qau>

<hw>Loathe</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>v. t.</pos>
<wordforms>[<pos>imp. & p. p.</pos> <er>Loathed</er>
<pr>(?)</pr>; <pos>p. pr. & vb. n.</pos>
<er>Loathing</er>.]</wordforms> <ety>[AS. <ets>l\'be<?/ian</ets>
to hate. See <er>Loath</er>.]</ety> <sn>1.</sn> <def>To feel

<q><qex>Loathing</qex> the honeyed cakes, I Ionged for bread.</q>
<qau>Cowley.</qau>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>To dislike greatly; to abhor; to hate.</def>

<qau>Waller.</qau>

<q>She <qex>loathes</qex> the vital sir.</q>
<qau>Dryden.</qau>

<syn>Syn. -- To hate; abhor; detest; abominate. See
<er>Hate</er>.</syn>

<mhw>{ <hw>Lo"bate</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <hw>Lo"ba*ted</hw>
<pr>(?)</pr>, }</mhw> <pos>a.</pos> <ety>[See
<er>Lobe</er>.]</ety> <sn>1.</sn> <fld>(Bot.)</fld>
<def>Consisting of, or having, lobes; lobed; <as>as, a
<ex>lobate</ex> leaf</as>.</def>

<sn>2.</sn> <fld>(Zo\'94l.)</fld> <sd>(a)</sd> <def>Having lobes;
-- said of the tails of certain fishes having the integument
continued to the bases of the fin rays.</def> <sd>(b)</sd>
<def>Furnished with membranous flaps, as the toes of a coot. See
<xex>Illust</xex>. <iref>(m)</iref> under <er>Aves</er>.</def>

<hw>Lob"bish</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>a.</pos> <def>Like a lob;
consisting of lobs.</def>

<au>Sir. P. Sidney.</au>

<hw>Lob"by</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos>; <plu>pl.
<plw>Lobbies</plw> <pr>(#)</pr></plu>. <ety>[LL.
<ets>lobium</ets>, <ets>lobia</ets>, <ets>laubia</ets>, a covered
portico fit for walking, fr. OHG.<ets>louba</ets>, G.
<ets>laube</ets>, arbor. See <er>Lodge</er>.]</ety> <sn>1.</sn>
<fld>(Arch.)</fld> <def>A passage or hall of communication,
especially when large enough to serve also as a waiting room. It
differs from an <xex>antechamber</xex> in that a <xex>lobby</xex>
communicates between several rooms, an <xex>antechamber</xex> to
one only; but this distinction is not carefully preserved.</def>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>That part of a hall of legislation not
appropriated to the official use of the assembly; hence, the
persons, collectively, who frequent such a place to transact
business with the legislators; any persons, not members of a
legislative body, who strive to influence its proceedings by
personal agency<-- = lobbyist -->.</def> <mark>[U.S.]</mark>

<sn>3.</sn> <fld>(Naut.)</fld> <def>An apartment or passageway in
the fore part of an old-fashioned cabin under the
quarter-deck.</def>

<sn>4.</sn> <fld>(Agric.)</fld> <def>A confined place for cattle,
formed by hedges. trees, or other fencing, near the
farmyard.</def>

<cs><col>Lobby member</col>, <cd>a lobbyist. <mark>[Humorous
cant, U. S.]</mark></cd></cs>

<hw>Lob"by</hw>, <pos>v. i.</pos> <wordforms>[<pos>imp. & p.
p.</pos> <er>Lobbied</er> <pr>(?)</pr>; <pos>p. pr. & vb.
n.</pos> <er>Lobbying</er>.]</wordforms> <def>To address or
solicit members of a legislative body in the lobby or elsewhere,
with the purpose to influence their
votes.</def><mark>[U.S.]</mark>

<au>Bartlett.</au>

<hw>Lob"by</hw>, <pos>v. t.</pos> <def>To urge the adoption or
passage of by soliciting members of a legislative body; <as>as,
to <ex>lobby</ex> a bill</as>.</def> <mark>[U.S.]</mark>

<hw>Lob"by*ist</hw>, <pos>n.</pos> <def>A member of the lobby; a
person who solicits members of a legislature for the purpose of

<hw>Lobe</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[F.
<ets>lobe</ets>, Gr. <?/.]</ety> <def>Any projection or division,
especially one of a somewhat rounded form</def>; as: <sd>(a)</sd>
<fld>(Bot.)</fld> <def>A rounded projection or division of a
leaf</def>. <au>Gray</au>. <sd>(b)</sd><fld>(Zo\'94l.)</fld>
<def>A membranous flap on the sides of the toes of certain birds,
as the coot</def>. <sd>(c)</sd> <fld>(Anat.)</fld> <def>A round
projecting part of an organ, as of the liver, lungs, brain, etc.
See <xex>Illust.</xex> of <er>Brain</er>.</def> <sd>(b)</sd>
<fld>(Mach.)</fld> <def>The projecting part of a cam wheel or of
a non-circular gear wheel.</def>

<cs><col>Lobe of the ear</col>, <cd>the soft, fleshy prominence
in which the human ear terminates below. See. <xex>Illust<xex>.
of <er>Ear</er>.</cd></cs><-- = earlobe -->

<hw>Lo*be"li*a</hw> <pr>(?; 106)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[NL. So
called from <ets>Lobel</ets>, botanist to King James I.]</ety>
<fld>(Bot.)</fld> <def>A genus of plants, including a great
number of species. <spn>Lobelia inflata</spn>, or Indian tobacco,
is an annual plant of North America, whose leaves contain a
poisonous white viscid juice, of an acrid taste. It has often
been used in medicine as an emetic, expectorant, etc. <spn>L.
cardinalis</spn> is the cardinal flower, remarkable for the deep
and vivid red color of its flowers.</def>

<hw>Lo*be`li*a"ceous</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>a.</pos>
<fld>(Bot.)</fld> <def>Of or pertaining to a natural order of
plants of which the genus <spn>Lobelia</spn> is the type.</def>

<hw>Lo*be"lin</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <fld>(Med.)</fld>
<def>A yellowish green resin from <spn>Lobelia</spn>, used as an
emetic and diaphoretic.</def>

<hw>Lo*be"line</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos>
<fld>(Chem.)</fld> <def>A poisonous narcotic alkaloid extracted
from the leaves of Indian tobacco (<spn>Lobelia inflata</spn>) as
a yellow oil, having a tobaccolike taste and odor.</def>

<hw>Lo"bi*ped</hw>, <pos>a.</pos> <ety>[<ets>Lobe</ets> + L.
<ets>pes</ets>, <ets>pedis</ets>, foot.]</ety>
<fld>(Zo\'94l.)</fld> <def>Having lobate toes, as a coot.</def>

<hw>Lob"lol`ly</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[Etymol.
uncertain.]</ety> <def>Gruel; porridge; -- so called among
seamen.</def>

<cs><col>Loblolly bay</col> <fld>(Bot.)</fld>, <cd>an elegant
white-flowered evergreen shrub or small tree, of the genus
<spn>Gordonia</spn> (<spn>G. Lasianthus</spn>), growing in the
maritime parts of the Southern United States. Its bark is
sometimes used in tanning. Also, a similar West Indian tree
(<spn>Laplacea h\'91matoxylon</spn>).</cd> -- <col>Loblolly
boy</col>, <cd>a surgeon's attendant on shipboard.
<au>Smollett</au>.</cd> -- <col>Loblolly pine</col>
<fld>(Bot.)</fld>, <cd>a kind of pitch pine found from Delaware
southward along the coast; old field pine (<spn>Pinus
T\'91da</spn>). Also, <spn>P. Bahamensis</spn>, of the West
Indies.</cd> -- <col>Loblolly tree</col> <fld>(Bot.)</fld>, <cd>a
name of several West Indian trees, having more or less leathery
foliage, but alike in no other respect; as <spn>Pisonia
subcordata</spn>, <spn>Cordia alba</spn>, and <spn>Cupania
glabra</spn>.</cd></cs>

<hw>\'d8Lo*bo"sa</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n. pl.</pos> <ety>[NL.
See <er>Lobe</er>.]</ety> <fld>(Zo\'94l.)</fld> <def>An order of
Rhizopoda, in which the pseudopodia are thick and irregular in
form, as in the <xex>Am\'d2ba</xex>.</def>

<hw>Lob"scouse`</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[Written
also <ets>lobscourse</ets> from which <ets>lobscouse</ets> is

<hw>Lobs"pound`</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos>

<hw>Lob"ster</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[AS.
<ets>loppestre</ets>, <ets>lopystre</ets> prob., corrupted fr. L.
<ets>locusta</ets> a marine shellfish, a kind of lobster, a
locust. Cf. <er>Locust</er>.]</ety> <fld>(Zo\'94l.)</fld>
<def>Any large macrurous crustacean used as food, esp. those of
the genus <spn>Homarus</spn>; as the American lobster (<spn>H.
Americanus</spn>), and the European lobster (<spn>H.
vulgaris</spn>). The Norwegian lobster (<spn>Nephrops
Norvegicus</spn>) is similar in form. All these have a pair of
large unequal claws. The spiny lobsters of more southern waters,
belonging to <spn>Palinurus</spn>, <spn>Panulirus</spn>, and
allied genera, have no large claws. The fresh-water crayfishes
are sometimes called <xex>lobsters</xex>.</def>

<cs><col>Lobster caterpillar</col> <fld>(Zo\'94l.)</fld>, <cd>the
caterpillar of a European bombycid moth (<spn>Stauropus
fagi</spn>); -- so called from its form.</cd> <col>Lobster
louse</col> <fld>(Zo\'94l.)</fld>, <cd>a copepod crustacean
(<spn>Nicotho\'89 astaci</spn>) parasitic on the gills of the
European lobster.</cd></cs>

<ets>lobulaire</ets>.]</ety> <def>Like a lobule; pertaining to a
lobule or lobules.</def>

<pr>(?)</pr>, }</mhw> <pos>a.</pos> <def>Made up of, or divided

<hw>Lo"cal</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>a.</pos> <ety>[L.
<ets>localis</ets>, fr. <ets>locus</ets> place: cf. F.
<ets>local</ets>. See <er>Lieu</er>, <er>Locus</er>.]</ety>
<def>Of or pertaining to a particular place, or to a definite
region or portion of space; restricted to one place or region;
<as>as, a <ex>local</ex> custom</as>.</def>

<q>Gives to airy nothing
A <qex>local</qex> habitation and a name.</q>
<qau>Shak.</qau>

<cs><col>Local actions</col> <fld>(Law)</fld>, <cd>actions such
as must be brought in a particular county, where the cause
arises; -- distinguished from <xex>transitory actions<xex>.</cd>
-- <col>Local affection</col> <fld>(Med.)</fld>, <cd>a disease or
ailment confined to a particular part or organ, and not directly
affecting the system.</cd> -- <col>Local attraction</col>
<fld>(Magnetism)</fld>, <cd>an attraction near a compass, causing
its needle to deviate from its proper direction, especially on
shipboard.</cd> -- <col>Local battery</col> <fld>(Teleg.)</fld>,
<cd>the battery which actuates the recording instruments of a
telegraphic station, as distinguished from the battery furnishing
a current for the line.</cd> -- <col>Local circuit</col>
<fld>(Teleg.)</fld>, <cd>the circuit of the local battery.</cd>
-- <col>Local color</col>. <sd>(a)</sd> <fld>(Paint.)</fld>
<cd>The color which belongs to an object, and is not caused by
accidental influences, as of reflection, shadow, etc.</cd> 
<sd>(b)</sd> <fld>(Literature)</fld> <cd>Peculiarities of the
place and its inhabitants where the scene of an action or story
is laid.</cd> -- <col>Local option</col>, <cd>the right or
obligation of determining by popular vote within certain
districts, as in each county, city, or town, whether the sale of
alcoholic beverages within the district shall be
allowed.</cd></cs>

<hw>Lo"cal</hw>, <pos>n.</pos> <sn>1.</sn> <fld>(Railroad)</fld>
<def>A train which receives and deposits passengers or freight
along the line of the road; a train for the accommodation of a
certain district.</def> <mark>[U.S.]</mark>
<-- a train or bus which stops at all stations along a line, as
contrasted with an express, which stops only at certain stations
designated as express stops -->

<sn>2.</sn> <def>On newspaper cant, an item of news relating to
the place where the paper is published.</def> <mark>[U.S.]</mark>

<hw>\'d8Lo`cale"</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[F.
<ets>local</ets>.]</ety> <sn>1.</sn> <def>A place, spot, or
location.</def>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>A principle, practice, form of speech, or other
thing of local use, or limited to a locality.</def>

<hw>Lo"cal*ism</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <sn>1.</sn>
<def>The state or quality of being local; affection for a
particular place.</def>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>A method of speaking or acting peculiar to a
certain district; a local idiom or phrase.</def>

<hw>Lo*cal"i*ty</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos>; <plu>pl.
<plw>Localitiees</plw> <pr>(<?/)</pr>.</plu> <ety>[L.
<ets>localitas</ets>: cf. F. <ets>localit\'82</ets>.]</ety>
<sn>1.</sn> <def>The state, or condition, of belonging to a
definite place, or of being contained within definite
limits.</def>

<q>It is thought that the soul and angels are devoid of quantity
and dimension, and that they have nothing to do with grosser
<qex>locality</qex>.</q>
<qau>Glanvill.</qau>

<-- p. 864 -->

<sn>2.</sn> <def>Position; situation; a place; a spot; esp., a
geographical place or situation, as of a mineral or plant.</def>

<sn>3.</sn> <def>Limitation to a county, district, or place;
<as>as, <ex>locality</ex> of trial</as>.</def>

<au>Blackstone.</au>

<sn>4.</sn> <fld>(Phren.)</fld> <def>The perceptive faculty
concerned with the ability to remember the relative positions of
places.</def>

<hw>Lo`cal*i*za"tion</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[Cf.
F. <ets>localisation</ets>.]</ety> <def>Act of localizing, or
state of being localized.</def>

<cs><col>Cerebral localization</col> <fld>(Physiol.)</fld>,
<cd>the localization of the control of special functions, as of
sight or of the various movements of the body, in special regions
of the brain.</cd></cs>

<hw>Lo"cal*ize</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>v. t.</pos>
<wordforms>[<pos>imp. & p. p.</pos> <er>Localized</er>
<pr>(?)</pr>; <pos>p. pr. & vb. n.</pos> <er>Localizing</er>
<pr>(?)</pr>.]</wordforms> <ety>[Cf. F. <ets>localiser</ets>. See
<er>Local</er>.]</ety> <def>To make local; to fix in, or assign
to, a definite place.</def>

<au>H. Spencer. Wordsworth.</au>

<hw>Lo"cal*ly</hw>, <pos>adv.</pos> <def>With respect to place;
in place; <as>as, to be <ex>locally</ex> separated or
distant</as>.</def>

<hw>Lo"cate</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>v. t.</pos>

<er>Locating</er>.]</wordforms> <ety>[L. <ets>locatus</ets>, p.

<qau>B. F. Westcott.</qau>

limits of; <as>as, to <ex>locate</ex> a public building; to
<ex>locate</ex> a mining claim; to <ex>locate</ex> (the land
granted by) a land warrant.</as></def>

<qex>located</qex>.</q>

<hw>Lock</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[AS.
<ets>locc</ets>; akin to D. <ets>lok</ets>, G. <ets>locke</ets>,
OHG. loc, Icel. <ets>lokkr</ets>, and perh. to Gr. <?/ to bend,
twist.]</ety> <def>A tuft of hair; a flock or small quantity of
wool, hay, or other like substance; a tress or ringlet of
hair.</def>

<q>These gray <qex>locks</qex>, the pursuivants of death.</q>
<qau>Shak.</qau>

<hw>Lock</hw>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[AS. <ets>loc</ets> inclosure,
an inclosed place, the fastening of a door, fr.
<ets>l<umac/can</ets> to lock, fasten; akin to OS.
<ets>l<umac/kan</ets> (in comp.), D. <ets>luiken</ets>, OHG.
<ets>l<umac/hhan</ets>, Icel. <ets>l<?/ka</ets>, Goth.
<ets>l<umac/kan</ets> (in comp.); cf. Skr. <ets>ruj</ets> to
break. Cf. <er>Locket</er>.]</ety> <sn>1.</sn> <def>Anything that
fastens; specifically, a fastening, as for a door, a lid, a
trunk, a drawer, and the like, in which a bolt is moved by a key
so as to hold or to release the thing fastened.</def>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>A fastening together or interlacing; a closing
of one thing upon another; a state of being fixed or
immovable.</def>

<q>Albemarle Street closed by a <qex>lock</qex> of carriages.</q>
<qau>De Quincey.</qau>

<sn>3.</sn> <def>A place from which egress is prevented, as by a
lock.</def>

<au>Dryden.</au>

<sn>4.</sn> <def>The barrier or works which confine the water of
a stream or canal.</def>

<sn>5.</sn> <def>An inclosure in a canal with gates at each end,
used in raising or lowering boats as they pass from one level to
another; -- called also <altname>lift lock</altname>.</def>

<sn>6.</sn> <def>That part or apparatus of a firearm by which the
charge is exploded; <as>as, a match<ex>lock</ex>,
flint<ex>lock</ex>, percussion <ex>lock</ex>, etc.</as></def>

<sn>7.</sn> <def>A device for keeping a wheel from turning.</def>

<sn>8.</sn> <def>A grapple in wrestling.</def>

<au>Milton.</au>

<cs><col>Detector lock</col>, <cd>a lock containing a contrivance
for showing whether it as has been tampered with.</cd> --
<col>Lock bay</col> <fld>(Canals)</fld>, <cd>the body of water in
a lock chamber.</cd> -- <col>Lock chamber</col>, <cd>the inclosed
space between the gates of a canal lock.</cd> -- <col>Lock
nut</col>. <cd>See <cref>Check nut</cref>, under
<er>Check</er>.</cd> -- <col>Lock plate</col>, <cd>a plate to
which the mechanism of a gunlock is attached.</cd> -- <col>Lock
rail</col> <fld>(Arch.)</fld>, <cd>in ordinary paneled doors, the
rail nearest the lock.</cd> <col>Lock rand</col>
<fld>(Masonry)</fld>, <cd>a range of bond stone.
<au>Knight</au>.</cd> -- <col>Mortise lock</col>, <cd>a door lock
inserted in a mortise.</cd> -- <col>Rim lock</col>, <cd>a lock
fastened to the face of a door, thus differing from a
<cref>mortise lock</cref>.</cd></cs>

<hw>Lock</hw>, <pos>v. t.</pos> <wordforms>[<pos>imp. & p.
p.</pos> <er>Locked</er> <pr>(?)</pr>; <pos>p. pr. & vb. n.</pos>
<er>Locking</er>.]</wordforms> <sn>1.</sn> <def>To fasten with a
lock, or as with a lock; to make fast; to prevent free movement
of; <as>as, to <ex>lock</ex> a door, a carriage wheel, a river,
etc.</as></def>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>To prevent ingress or access to, or exit from,
by fastening the lock or locks of; -- often with <ptcl>up</ptcl>;
<as>as, to <ex>lock</ex> or <ex>lock up</ex>, a house, jail,
room, trunk</as>. etc.</def>

<sn>3.</sn> <def>To fasten in or out, or to make secure by means
of, or as with, locks; to confine, or to shut in or out -- often
with <ptcl>up</ptcl>; <as>as, to <ex>lock</ex> one's self in a
room; to <ex>lock</ex> up the prisoners; to <ex>lock</ex> up
one's silver; to <ex>lock</ex> intruders out of the house; to
<ex>lock</ex> money into a vault; to <ex>lock</ex> a child in
one's arms; to <ex>lock</ex> a secret in one's breast.</as></def>

<sn>4.</sn> <def>To link together; to clasp closely; <as>as, to
<ex>lock</ex> arms</as>.</def> \'bd <xex>Lock</xex> hand in
hand.\'b8

<au>Shak.</au>

<sn>5.</sn> <fld>(Canals)</fld> <def>To furnish with locks; also,
to raise or lower (a boat) in a lock.</def>

<sn>6.</sn> <fld>(Fencing)</fld> <def>To seize, as the sword arm
of an antagonist, by turning the left arm around it, to disarm
him.</def>

<hw>Lock</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>v. i.</pos> <def>To become fast,
as by means of a lock or by interlacing; <as>as, the door
<ex>locks</ex> close</as>.</def>

<q>When it <qex>locked</qex> none might through it pass.</q>
<qau>Spenser.</qau>

<cs><col>To lock into</col>, <cd>to fit or slide into; <as>as,
they <ex>lock into<ex> each other</as>.</cd></cs>

<au>Boyle.</au>

<hw>Lock"age</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <sn>1.</sn>
<def>Materials for locks in a canal, or the works forming a lock

<sn>2.</sn> <def>Toll paid for passing the locks of a

<q>The entire <qex>lock</qex> will be about fifty feet.</q>
<qau>De Witt Clinton.</qau>

<hw>Lock"et</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[F.
