<hw>Lock" hos"pi*tal</hw> <pr>(?)</pr><def>. A hospital for the
treatment of venereal diseases.</def> <mark>[Eng.]</mark>

<hw>Lock"jaw`</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <fld>(Med.)</fld>
<def>A contraction of the muscles of the jaw by which its motion
is suspended; a variety of tetanus.</def>

<hw>Lock"less</hw>, <pos>a.</pos> <def>Destitute of a lock.</def>

<hw>Lock"man</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <def>A public
executioner.</def> <mark>[Scot.]</mark>

<hw>Lock"out`</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <def>The closing
of a factory or workshop by an employer, usually in order to
bring the workmen to satisfactory terms by a suspension of
wages.</def>

<hw>Lock"ram</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[F.
<ets>locrenan</ets>, <ets>locronan</ets>; from
<ets>Locronan</ets>, in Brittany, where it is said to have been
made.]</ety> <def>A kind of linen cloth anciently used in
England, originally imported from Brittany.</def>

<au>Shak.</au>

<hw>Lock"smith`</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <def>An
artificer whose occupation is to make or mend locks.</def>

<hw>Lock" step`</hw> <pr>(?)</pr><def>. A mode of marching by a
body of men going one after another as closely as possible, in
which the leg of each moves at the same time with the
corresponding leg of the person before him.</def>

<hw>Lock" stitch`</hw> <pr>(?)</pr><def>. A peculiar sort of
stitch formed by the locking of two threads together, as in the
work done by some sewing machines. See <er>Stitch</er>.</def>

<hw>Lock"up`</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <def>A place where
persons under arrest are temporarily locked up; a
watchhouse.</def>

<hw>Lock"-weir`</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <def>A waste
weir for a canal, discharging into a lock chamber.</def>

<hw>Lock"y</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>a.</pos> <def>Having locks or
tufts.</def> <mark>[R.]</mark>

<au>Sherwood.</au>

<hw>\'d8Lo"co</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>adv.</pos> <ety>[It.]</ety>
<fld>(Mus.)</fld> <def>A direction in written or printed music to
return to the proper pitch after having played an octave
higher.</def>

<hw>Lo"co</hw>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[Sp. <ets>loco</ets>
insane.]</ety> <fld>(Bot.)</fld> <def>A plant (<spn>Astragalus
Hornii</spn>) growing in the Southwestern United States, which is
said to poison horses and cattle, first making them insane. The
name is also given vaguely to several other species of the same
genus. Called also <altname>loco weed</altname>.</def>

<hw>Lo`co*fo"co</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[Of
uncertain etymol.; perh. for L. <ets>loco foci</ets> instead of
fire; or, according to Bartlett, it was called so from a
self-lighting cigar, with a match composition at the end,
invented in 1834 by John Marck of New York, and called by him
<ets>locofoco cigar</ets>, in imitation of the word
<ets>locomotive</ets>, which by the uneducated was supposed to
mean, self-moving.]</ety> <sn>1.</sn> <def>A friction
match.</def> <mark>[U.S.]</mark>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>A nickname formerly given to a member of the
Democratic party.</def> <mark>[U.S.]</mark>

<note><hand/ The name was first applied, in 1834, to a portion of
the Democratic party, because, at a meeting in Tammany Hall, New
York, in which there was great diversity of sentiment, the
chairman left his seat, and the lights were extinguished, for the
purpose of dissolving the meeting; when those who were opposed to
an adjournment produced <xex>locofoco</xex> matches, rekindled
the lights, continued the meeting, and accomplished their
object.</note>

<hw>Lo`co*mo"tion</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[L.
<ets>locus</ets> place +  <ets>motio</ets> motion: cf. F.
<ets>locomotion</ets>. See <er>Local</er>, and
<er>Motion</er>.]</ety> <sn>1.</sn> <def>The act of moving from
place to place. \'bd Animal <xex>locomotion</xex>.\'b8
<au>Milton.</au></def>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>The power of moving from place to place,
characteristic of the higher animals and some of the lower forms
of plant life.</def>

<-- 3. the name of a song and a dance, briefly popular in the
1960's -->

<hw>Lo"co*mo`tive</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>a.</pos> <ety>[Cf. F.
<ets>locomotif</ets>. See <er>Locomotion</er>.]</ety> <sn>1.</sn>
<def>Moving from place to place; changing place, or able to
change place; <as>as, a <ex>locomotive</ex> animal</as>.</def>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>Used in producing motion; <as>as, the
<ex>locomotive</ex> organs of an animal</as>.</def>

<hw>Lo"co*mo`tive</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <def>A
locomotive engine; a self-propelling wheel carriage, especially
one which bears a steam boiler and one or more steam engines
which communicate motion to the wheels and thus propel the
carriage, -- used to convey goods or passengers, or to draw
wagons, railroad cars, etc. See <xex>Illustration</xex> in
Appendix.</def>

<cs><col>Consolidation locomotive</col>, <cd>a locomotive having
four pairs of connected drivers.</cd> -- <col>Locomotive
car</col>, <cd>a locomotive and a car combined in one vehicle; a
dummy engine.</cd> <mark>[U.S.]</mark> -- <col>Locomotive
engine</col>. <cd>Same as <er>Locomotive</er>, above.</cd> --
<col>Mogul locomotive</col>. <cd>See <er>Mogul</er>.</cd></cs>

<cs><mcol><col>Locomotor ataxia</col>, <or/ <col>Progressive

<hw>Loc"u*la*ment</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[L.

<hw>Loc"u*lus</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos>; <plu>pl.
<plw>Loculi</plw> <pr>(#)</pr></plu>. <ety>[L., little place, a

<hw>\'d8Lo"cum te"nens</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>. <ety>[L., holding the

<hw>Lo"cus</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos>; <plu>pl.
<plw>Loci</plw> <pr>(#)</pr>, & <plw>Loca</plw>
<pr>(#)</pr></plu>. <ety>[L., place. Cf. <er>Allow</er>,
<er>Couch</er>, <er>Lieu</er>, <er>Local</er>.]</ety> <sn>1.</sn>
<def>A place; a locality.</def>

<sn>2.</sn> <fld>(Math.)</fld> <def>The line traced by a point
which varies its position according to some determinate law; the
surface described by a point or line that moves according to a
given law.</def>

<cs><col>Plane locus</col>, <cd>a locus that is a straight line,
or a circle.</cd> -- <col>Solid locus</col>, <cd>a locus that is
one of the conic sections.</cd></cs>

<hw>Lo"cust</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[L.
<ets>locusta</ets> locust, grasshopper. Cf.
<er>Lobster</er>.]</ety> <sn>1.</sn> <fld>(Zo\'94l.)</fld>
<def>Any one of numerous species of long-winged, migratory,
orthopterous insects, of the family <spn>Acridid\'91</spn>,
allied to the grasshoppers; esp., (<spn>Edipoda, <or/ Pachytylus,
migratoria</spn>, and <spn>Acridium perigrinum</spn>, of Southern
Europe, Asia, and Africa. In the United States the related
species with similar habits are usually called
<altname>grasshoppers</altname>. See <er>Grasshopper</er>.</def>

<note><hand/ These insects are at times so numerous in Africa and
the south of Asia as to devour every green thing; and when they
migrate, they fly in an immense cloud. In the United States the
harvest flies are improperly called <xex>locusts</xex>. See
<er>Cicada</er>.</note>

<cs><col>Locust beetle</col> <fld>(Zo\'94l.)</fld>, <cd>a
longicorn beetle (<spn>Cyllene robini\'91</spn>), which, in the
larval state, bores holes in the wood of the locust tree. Its
color is brownish black, barred with yellow. Called also
<altname>locust borer</altname>.</cd> -- <col>Locust bird</col>
<fld>(Zo\'94l.)</fld> <cd>the rose-colored starling or pastor of
India. See <er>Pastor</er>.</cd> -- <col>Locust hunter</col>
<fld>(Zo\'94l.)</fld>, <cd>an African bird; the
beefeater.</cd></cs>

<sn>2.</sn> <ety>[Etymol. uncertain.]</ety> <fld>(Bot.)</fld>
<def>The locust tree. See <er>Locust Tree</er> (definition, note,
and phrases).</def>

<cs><col>Locust bean</col> <fld>(Bot.)</fld>, <cd>a commercial
name for the sweet pod of the carob tree.</cd></cs>

<hw>Lo*cus"ta</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[NL.: cf.
<ets>locuste</ets>.]</ety> <fld>(Bot.)</fld> <def>The spikelet or
flower cluster of grasses.</def>

<au>Gray.</au>

<hw>Lo`cus*tel"la</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[NL., fr.
L. <ets>locusta</ets> a locust.]</ety> <fld>(Zo\'94l.)</fld>
<def>The European cricket warbler.</def>

<hw>Lo*cus"tic</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>a.</pos>
<fld>(Chem.)</fld> <def>Pertaining to, or derived from, the
locust; -- formerly used to designate a supposed acid.</def>

<hw>Lo"cust*ing</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>p. a.</pos> <def>Swarming
and devastating like locusts.</def> <mark>[R.]</mark>

<au>Tennyson.</au>

<hw>Lo"cust tree`</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>. <ety>[Etymol.
uncertain.]</ety> <fld>(Bot.)</fld> <def>A large North American
tree of the genus <spn>Robinia</spn> (<spn>R. Pseudacacia</spn>),
producing large slender racemes of white, fragrant,
papilionaceous flowers, and often cultivated as an ornamental
tree. In England it is called <altname>acacia</altname>.</def>

<note><hand/ The name is also applied to other trees of different
genera, especially to those of the genus <spn>Hymen\'91a</spn>,
of which <spn>H. Courbaril</spn> is a lofty, spreading tree of
South America; also to the carob tree (<spn>Ceratonia
siliqua</spn>), a tree growing in the Mediterranean
region.</note>

<cs><col>Honey locust tree</col> <fld>(Bot.)</fld>, <cd>a tree of
the genus <spn>Gleditschia</spn> ) <spn>G. triacanthus</spn>),
having pinnate leaves and strong branching thorns; -- so called
from a sweet pulp found between the seeds in the pods. Called
also simply <altname>honey locust</altname>.</cd> -- <col>Water
locust tree</col> <fld>(Bot.)</fld>, <cd>a small swamp tree
(<spn>Gleditschia monosperma</spn>), of the Southern United
States.</cd></cs>

<hw>Lo*cu"tion</hw>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[L. <ets>locutio</ets>,

<au>G. Eliot.</au>

<q>I hate these figures in <qex>locution</qex>,
These about phrases forced by ceremony.</q>
<qau>Marston.</qau>

conversation; especially, a room in monasteries, where the monks
were allowed to converse.</def>

<hw>Lod"de</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <fld>(Zo\'94l.)</fld>
<def>The capelin.</def>

<hw>Lode</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[AS.
<ets>l\'bed</ets> way, journey, fr. <ets>l\'c6\'eban</ets> to go.
See <er>Lead</er> to guide, and cf. <er>Load</er> a
burden.]</ety> <sn>1.</sn> <def>A water course or way; a reach of
water.</def>

<q>Down that long, dark <qex>lode</qex> . . .  he and his brother
skated home in triumph.</q>
<qau>C. Kingsley.</qau>

<sn>2.</sn> <fld>(Mining)</fld> <def>A metallic vein; any regular
vein or course, whether metallic or not.</def>

<hw>Lode"man*age</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[OE.
<ets>lodemenage</ets>. <ets>Chaucer</ets>.]</ety>
<def>Pilotage.</def> <mark>[Obs.]</mark>

<hw>Lode"*ship`</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <def>An old name
for a pilot boat.</def>

<hw>Lodes"man</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <def>Same as
<er>Loadsman</er>.</def> <mark>[Obs.]</mark>

<hw>Lode"stone`</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos>

<hw>Lodge</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[OE.
<ets>loge</ets>, <ets>logge</ets>, F. <ets>loge</ets>, LL.
<ets>laubia</ets> porch, gallery, fr. OHG. <ets>louba</ets>, G.
<ets>laube</ets>, arbor, bower, fr. <ets>lab</ets> foliage. See
<er>Leaf</er>, and cf. <er>Lobby</er>, <er>Loggia</er>.]</ety>
<sn>1.</sn> <def>A shelter in which one may rest; as:
<sd>(a)</sd> A shed; a rude cabin; a hut; <as>as, an Indian's
<ex>lodge</ex></as>.</def> <au>Chaucer</au>.

<q>Their <qex>lodges</qex> and their tentis up they gan bigge [to
build].</q>
<qau>Robert of Brunne.</qau>

<q>O for a <qex>lodge</qex> in some vast wilderness!</q>
<qau>Cowper.</qau>

<sd>(b)</sd> <def>A small dwelling house, as for a gamekeeper or
gatekeeper of an estate.</def> <au>Shak</au>. <sd>(c)</sd> <def>A
den or cave.</def> <sd>(d)</sd> <def>The meeting room of an
association; hence, the regularly constituted body of members
which meets there; as, a masonic <xex>lodge</xex>.</def>
<sd>(c)</sd> <def>The chamber of an abbot, prior, or head of a
college</def>.

<sn>2.</sn> <fld>(Mining)</fld> <def>The space at the mouth of a
level next the shaft, widened to permit wagons to pass, or ore to
be deposited for hoisting; -- called also
<altname>platt</altname>.</def>

<au>Raymond.</au>

<sn>3.</sn> <def>A collection of objects lodged together.</def>

<q>The Maldives, a famous <qex>lodge</qex> of islands.</q>
<qau>De Foe.</qau>

<sn>4.</sn> <def>A family of North American Indians, or the
persons who usually occupy an Indian lodge, -- as a unit of
enumeration, reckoned from four to six persons; <as>as, the tribe
consists of about two hundred <ex>lodges</ex>, that is, of about
a thousand individuals</as>.</def>

<cs><col>Lodge gate</col>, <cd>a park gate, or entrance gate,
near the lodge. See <er>Lodge</er>, <pos>n.</pos>, 1
<sd>(b)</sd>.</cd></cs>

<hw>Lodge</hw>, <pos>v. i.</pos> <wordforms>[<pos>imp. & p.
p.</pos> <er>Lodged</er> <pr>(?)</pr>; <pos>p. pr. & vb. n.</pos>
<er>Lodging</er> <pr>(?)</pr>.]</wordforms> <sn>1.</sn> <def>To
rest or remain a lodge house, or other shelter; to rest; to stay;
to abide; esp., to sleep at night; <as>as, to <ex>lodge</ex> in
York Street</as>.</def>

<au>Chaucer.</au>

<q>Stay and <qex>lodge</qex> by me this night.</q>
<qau>Shak.</qau>

<q>Something holy <qex>lodges</qex> in that breast.</q>
<qau>Milton</qau>.

<sn>2.</sn> <def>To fall or lie down, as grass or grain, when
overgrown or beaten down by the wind.</def>

<au>Mortimer.</au>

<sn>3.</sn> <def>To come to a rest; to stop and remain; <as>as,
the bullet <ex>lodged</ex> in the bark of a tree</as>.</def>

<hw>Lodge</hw>, <pos>v. t.</pos> <ety>[OE. <ets>loggen</ets>, OF.
<ets>logier</ets>, F. <ets>loger</ets>. See <er>Lodge</er>,
<pos>n.</pos> ]</ety> <sn>1.</sn> <def>To give shelter or rest
to; especially, to furnish a sleeping place for; to harbor; to
shelter; hence, to receive; to hold.</def>

<q>Every house was proud to <qex>lodge</qex> a knight.</q>
<qau>Dryden.</qau>

<q>The memory can <qex>lodge</qex> a greater stone of images that
all the senses can present at one time.</q>
<qau>Cheyne.</qau>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>To drive to shelter; to track to covert.</def>

<q>The deer is <qex>lodged</qex>; I have tracked her to her
covert.</q>
<qau>Addison.</qau>

<sn>3.</sn> <def>To deposit for keeping or preservation; <as>as,
the men <ex>lodged</ex> their arms in the arsenal</as>.</def>

<sn>4.</sn> <def>To cause to stop or rest in; to implant.</def>

<q>He <qex>lodged</qex> an arrow in a tender breast.</q>
<qau>Addison.</qau>

<sn>5.</sn> <def>To lay down; to prostrate.</def>

<q>Though bladed corn be <qex>lodged</qex>, and trees blown
down.</q>
<qau>Shak.</qau>

<cs><col>To lodge an information</col>, <cd>to enter a formal
complaint.</cd></cs>

<hw>Lodge"a*ble</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>a.</pos> <ety>[Cf. F.
<ets>logeable</ets>.]</ety> <sn>1.</sn> <def>That may be or can
be lodged; <as>as, so many persons are not <ex>lodgeable</ex> in
this village</as>.</def>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>Capable of affording lodging; fit for lodging
in.</def> <mark>[R.]</mark> \'bd The <xex>lodgeable</xex> area of
the earth.\'b8

<au>Jeffrey.</au>

<hw>Lodged</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>a.</pos> <fld>(Her.)</fld>
<def>Lying down; -- used of beasts of the chase, as
<xex>couchant</xex> is of beasts of prey.</def>

<hw>Lodg"er</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <def>One who, or
that which, lodges; one who occupies a hired room in another's
house.</def>

<hw>Lodg"ing</hw>, <pos>n.</pos> <sn>1.</sn> <def>The act of one
who, or that which, lodges.</def>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>A place of rest, or of temporary habitation;
esp., a sleeping apartment; -- often in the plural with a
singular meaning.</def>

<au>Gower.</au>

<q>Wits take <qex>lodgings</qex> in the sound of Bow.</q>
<qau>Pope.</qau>

<sn>3.</sn> <def>Abiding place; harbor; cover.</def>

<q>Fair bosom . . . the <qex>lodging</qex> of delight.</q>
<qau>Spenser.</qau>

<cs><col>Lodging house</col>, <cd>a house where lodgings are
provided and let.</cd> -- <col>Lodging room</col>, <cd>a room in
which a person lodges, esp. a hired room.</cd>

<hw>Lodg"ment</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <altsp>[Written
also <asp>lodgement</asp>.]</altsp> <ety>[Cf. F.
<ets>logement</ets>. See <er>Lodge</er>, <pos>v.</pos>]</ety>
<sn>1.</sn> <def>The act of lodging, or the state of being
lodged.</def>

<q>Any particle which is of size enough to make a
<qex>lodgment</qex> afterwards in the small arteries.</q>
<qau>Paley.</qau>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>A lodging place; a room.</def>
<mark>[Obs.]</mark>

<sn>3.</sn> <def>An accumulation or collection of something
deposited in a place or remaining at rest.</def>

<sn>4.</sn> <fld>(Mil.)</fld> <def>The occupation and holding of
a position, as by a besieging party; an instrument thrown up in a
captured position; <as>as, to effect a
<ex>lodgment</ex></as>.</def>

<hw>Lod"i*cule</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[L.
<ets>lodicula</ets>. dim, of <ets>lodix</ets>,

<ets>lodicule</ets>.]</ety> <fld>(Bot.)</fld> <def>One of the two
or three delicate membranous scales which are next to the stamens

<hw>Loel"ling*ite</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[So
called from <ets>L\'94lling</ets>, in Austria.]</ety>
<fld>(Min.)</fld> <def>A tin-white arsenide of iron, isomorphous
with arsenopyrite.</def>

<hw>Loess</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[G.

<hw>Loft</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[Icel.
<ets>lopt</ets> air, heaven, loft, upper room; akin to AS.
<ets>lyft</ets> air, G. <ets>luft</ets>, Dan. <ets>loft</ets>
loft, Goth. <ets>luftus</ets> air. Cf. <er>Lift</er>,
<pos>v.</pos> & <pos>n.</pos> ]</ety> <def>That which is lifted
up; an elevation.</def> Hence, especially: <sd>(a)</sd> <def>The
room or space under a roof and above the ceiling of the uppermost
story.</def> <sd>(b)</sd> <def>A gallery or raised apartment in a
church, hall, etc.; <as>as, an organ <ex>loft</ex></as>.</def>
<sd>(c)</sd> <def>A floor or room placed above another; a
story.</def>

<q>Eutychus . . . fell down from the third <qex>loft</qex>.</q>
<qau>Acts xx. 9.</qau>

<mark>[Obs.]</mark></cd></cs>

<hw>Log</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[Heb.
<ets>l<omac/g</ets>.]</ety> <def>A Hebrew measure of liquids,
containing 2.37 gills.</def>

<au>W. H. Ward. </au>

<hw>Log</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[Icel.
<ets>l\'beg</ets> a felled tree, log; akin to E. <ets>lie</ets>.
See <er>Lie</er> to lie prostrate.]</ety> <sn>1.</sn> <def>A
bulky piece of wood which has not been shaped by hewing or
sawing.</def>

<sn>2.</sn> <ety>[Prob. the same word as in sense 1; cf. LG.
<ets>log</ets>, <ets>lock</ets>, Dan. <ets>log</ets>, Sw.
<ets>logg</ets>.]</ety> <fld>(Naut.)</fld> <def>An apparatus for
measuring the rate of a ship's motion through the water.</def>

<note><hand/ The <xex>common log</xex> consists of the
<xex>log-chip</xex>, or <xex>logship</xex>, often exclusively
called the <xex>log</xex>, and the <xex>log line</xex>, the
former being commonly a thin wooden quadrant of five or six
inches radius, loaded with lead on the arc to make it float with
the point up. It is attached to the log line by cords from each
corner. This line is divided into equal spaces, called
<xex>knots</xex>, each bearing the same proportion to a mile that
half a minute does to an hour. The line is wound on a reel which
is so held as to let it run off freely. When the log is thrown,
the log-chip is kept by the water from being drawn forward, and
the speed of the ship is shown by the number of knots run out in
half a minute. There are improved logs, consisting of a piece of
mechanism which, being towed astern, shows the distance actually
gone through by the ship, by means of the revolutions of a fly,
which are registered on a dial plate.</note>

<sn>3.</sn> <def>Hence: The record of the rate of ship's speed or
of her daily progress; also, the full nautical record of a ship's
cruise or voyage; a log slate; a log book.</def>

<sn>4.</sn> <def>A record and tabulated statement of the work
done by an engine, as of a steamship, of the coal consumed, and
of other items relating to the performance of machinery during a
given time.</def>

<sn>5.</sn> <fld>(Mining)</fld> <def>A weight or block near the
free end of a hoisting rope to prevent it from being drawn
through the sheave.</def>

<cs><col>Log board</col> <fld>(Naut.)</fld>, <cd>a board
consisting of two parts shutting together like a book, with
columns in which are entered the direction of the wind, course of
the ship, etc., during each hour of the day and night. These
entries are transferred to the log book. A folding slate is now
used instead.</cd> -- <mcol><col>Log book</col>, <or/
<col>Logbook</col></mcol> <fld>(Naut.)</fld>, <cd>a book in which
is entered the daily progress of a ship at sea, as indicated by
the log, with notes on the weather and incidents of the voyage;
the contents of the log board.</cd> <mcol><col>Log cabin</col>,
<col>Log house</col></mcol>, <cd>a cabin or house made of
logs.</cd> -- <col>Log canoe</col>, <cd>a canoe made by shaping
and hollowing out a single log.</cd><-- = dugout canoe --> --
<col>Log glass</col> <fld>(Naut.)</fld>, <cd>a small sandglass
used to time the running out of the log line.</cd> -- <col>Log
line</col> <fld>(Naut.)</fld>, <cd>a line or cord about a hundred
and fifty fathoms long, fastened to the log-chip. See Note under
2d <er>Log</er>, <pos>n.</pos>, 2.</cd> -- <col>Log perch</col>
<fld>(Zo\'94l.)</fld>, <cd>an ethiostomoid fish, or darter
(<spn>Percina caprodes</spn>); -- called also
<altname>hogfish</altname> and <altname>rockfish</altname>.</cd>
-- <col>Log reel</col> <fld>(Naut.)</fld>, <cd>the reel on which
the log line is wound.</cd> -- <col>Log slate</col>.
<fld>(Naut.)</fld> <cd>See <cref>Log board</cref> (above).</cd>
-- <col>Rough log</col> <fld>(Naut.)</fld>, <cd>a first draught
of a record of the cruise or voyage.</cd> -- <col>Smooth
log</col> <fld>(Naut.)</fld>, <cd>a clean copy of the rough log.
In the case of naval vessels this copy is forwarded to the proper
officer of the government.</cd> -- <col>To heave the log</col>
<fld>(Naut.)</fld>, <cd>to cast the log-chip into the water;
also, the whole process of ascertaining a vessel's speed by the
log.</cd></cs>

<hw>Log</hw>, <pos>v. i.</pos> <wordforms>[<pos>imp. & p.
p.</pos> <er>Logged</er> <pr>(?)</pr>; <pos>p. pr. & vb. n.</pos>
<er>Logging</er> <pr>(?)</pr>.]</wordforms>
<fld>(Naut.)</fld><def>, To enter in a ship's log book; <as>as,
to <ex>log</ex> the miles run</as>.</def>

<au>J. F. Cooper.</au>

business of cutting or transporting logs for timber; to get out
logs.</def> <mark>[U.S.]</mark>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>To move to and fro; to rock.</def>
<mark>[Obs.]</mark>

<au>Gwill.</au>

<hw>Log`a*\'d2d"ic</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>a.</pos> <ety>[Gr.
<?/; <?/ discourse, prose + <?/ song.]</ety> <fld>(Gr.
Pros.)</fld> <def>Composed of dactyls and trochees so arranged as
to produce a movement<-- ? ve illegible --> like that of ordinary

<hw>Log"a*rithm</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[Gr. <?/
word, account, proportion + <?/ number: cf. F.
<ets>logarithme</ets>.]</ety> <fld>(Math.)</fld> <def>One of a
class of auxiliary numbers, devised by John Napier, of
Merchiston, Scotland (1550-1617), to abridge arithmetical
calculations, by the use of addition and subtraction in place of
multiplication and division. <note>The relation of
<xex>logarithms</xex> to common numbers is that of numbers in an
arithmetical series to corresponding numbers in a geometrical
series, so that sums and differences of the former indicate
respectively products and quotients of the latter; thus</def>

<table>
<row>0    1    2     3      4       Indices or logarithms</row>
<row>1   10   100  1000  10,000     Numbers in geometrical
progression</row>
</table>

Hence, the logarithm of any given number is the exponent of a
power to which another given invariable number, called the
<xex>base</xex>, must be raised in order to produce that given
number. Thus, let 10 be the base, then 2 is the logarithm of 100,
because <mathex>10<exp>2</exp> = 100</mathex>, and 3 is the
logarithm of 1,000, because <mathex>10<exp>3</exp> =
1,000</mathex>.

<cs><col>Arithmetical complement of a logarithm</col>, <cd>the
difference between a logarithm and the number ten.</cd> --
<col>Binary logarithms</col></mcol>. <cd>See under
<er>Binary</er>.</cd> -- <mcol><col>Common logarithms</col>, <or/
<col>Brigg's logarithms</col></mcol>, <cd>logarithms of which the
base is 10; -- so called from Henry <xex>Briggs<xex>, who
invented them.</cd> -- <col>Gauss's logarithms</col>, <cd>tables
of logarithms constructed for facilitating the operation of
finding the logarithm of the sum of difference of two quantities
from the logarithms of the quantities, one entry of those tables
and two additions or subtractions answering the purpose of three
entries of the common tables and one addition or
subtraction.</cd> They were suggested by the celebrated German
mathematician Karl Friedrich <xex>Gauss</xex> (died in 1855), and
are of great service in many astronomical computations. --
<mcol><col>Hyperbolic, <or/ Napierian</col>,
<col>logarithms</col><-- usually called 'natural logarithms'
--></mcol>, <cd>those logarithms (devised by John Speidell, 1619)
of which the base is 2.7182818; -- so called from
<xex>Napier<xex>, the inventor of logarithms.</cd> --
<mcol><col>Logistic</col> <or/
<col>Proportionallogarithms.</col></mcol>, <cd>See under
<er>Logistic</er>.</cd></cs>

<mhw>{ <hw>Log`a*rith*met"ic</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>,
<hw>Log"a*rith*met"ic*al</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, }</mhw> <pos>a.</pos>
<def>See <er>Logarithmic</er>.</def>

<hw>Log`a*rith*met"ic*al*ly</hw>, <pos>adv.</pos>
<def>Logarithmically.</def>

<mhw>{ <hw>Log`a*rith"mic</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>,
<hw>Log`a*rith"mic*al</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, }</mhw> <pos>a.</pos>
<ety>[Cf. F. <ets>logarithmique</ets>.]</ety> <def>Of or
pertaining to logarithms; consisting of logarithms.</def>

<cs><col>Logarithmic curve</col> <fld>(Math.)</fld>, <cd>a curve
which, referred to a system of rectangular co\'94rdinate axes, is
such that the ordinate of any point will be the logarithm of its
abscissa.</cd> -- <col>Logarithmic spiral</col>, <cd>a spiral
curve such that radii drawn from its pole or eye at equal angles
with each other are in continual proportion. See
<er>Spiral</er>.</cd></cs>

logarithms.</def>

<hw>Log"ic</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[OE.
<ets>logike</ets>, F. <ets>logi</ets>q<ets>ue</ets>, L.
<ets>logica</ets>, <ets>logice</ets>, Gr. <?/ (sc. <?/), fr. <?/
belonging to speaking or reason, fr. <?/ speech, reason, <?/ to
say, speak. See <er>Legend</er>.]</ety> <sn>1.</sn> <def>The
science or art of exact reasoning, or of pure and formal thought,
or of the laws according to which the processes of pure thinking
should be conducted; the science of the formation and application
of general notions; the science of generalization, judgment,
classification, reasoning, and systematic arrangement; correct
reasoning.</def>

<-- p. 866 -->

<q><qex>Logic</qex> is science of the laws of thought, as that
is, of the necessary conditions to which thought, considered in
itself, is subject.</q>
<qau>Sir W. Hamilton.</qau>

<note><hand/ <xex>Logic</xex> is distinguished as <xex>pure</xex>
and <xex>applied</xex>. \'bd <xex>Pure logic</xex> is a science
of the form, or of the formal laws, of thinking, and not of the
matter. <xex>Applied logic</xex> teaches the application of the
forms of thinking to those objects about which men do think.
\'b8</note>

<au>Abp. Thomson.  </au>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>A treatise on logic; <as>as, Mill's
<ex>Logic</ex></as>.</def>

<hw>Log"ic*al</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>a.</pos> <ety>[Cf. F.
<ets>logique</ets>, L. <ets>logicus</ets>, Gr. <?/.]</ety>

<as>as, <ex>logical</ex> subtilties</as>.</def>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>According to the rules of logic; <as>as, a
<ex>logical</ex> argument or inference; the reasoning is
<ex>logical</ex>.</as></def>

<au>Prior.</au>

<sn>3.</sn> <def>Skilled in logic; versed in the art of thinking
and reasoning; <as>as, he is a <ex>logical</ex>
thinker</as>.</def>

<au>Addison.</au>

<mhw>{ <hw>Lo*gis"tic</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <hw>Lo*gis"tic*al</hw>

<cs><mcol><col>Logistic</col>, <or/ <col>Proportional</col>,
<col>logarithms</col></mcol>, <cd>certain logarithmic numbers
used to shorten the calculation of the fourth term of a
proportion of which one of the terms is a given constant
quantity, commonly one hour, while the other terms are expressed
in minutes and seconds; -- not now used.</cd></cs>

<hw>Lo*gis"tics</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <sn>1.</sn>

<mhw>{ <hw>Log`o*graph"ic</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>,
<hw>Log`o*graph"ic*al</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, }</mhw> <pos>a.</pos>
<ety>[Gr. <?/ of writing speeches: cf. F.
<ets>logographique</ets>.]</ety> <def>Of or pertaining to

<hw>Lo*gog"ra*phy</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[Gr. <?/
a writing of speeches; <?/ word, speech + <?/ to write: cf. F.
<ets>logographie</ets>.]</ety> <sn>1.</sn> <def>A method of
printing in which whole words or syllables, cast as single types,
are used.</def>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>A mode of reporting speeches without using
shorthand, -- a number of reporters, each in succession, taking
down three or four words.</def>

<au>Brande & C.</au>

<hw>Log"o*griph</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[Gr. <?/
word + <?/ a fishing net, a dark saying, a riddle: F.
<ets>logogriphe</ets>.]</ety> <def>A sort of riddle in which it
is required to discover a chosen word from various combinations
of its letters, or of some of its letters, which form other
words; -- thus, to discover the chosen word <xex>chatter</xex>
form <xex>cat</xex>, <xex>hat</xex>, <xex>rat</xex>,
<xex>hate</xex>, <xex>rate</xex>, etc.</def>

<au>B. Jonson.</au>

<hw>Lo*gom"a*chist</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[See
<er>Logomachy</er>.]</ety> <def>One who contends about
words.</def>

<hw>Lo*gom"a*chy</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[Gr. <?/;
<?/ word + <?/ fight, battle, contest: cf. F.
<ets>logomachie</ets>.]</ety> <sn>1.</sn> <def>Contention in
words merely, or a contention about words; a war of words.</def>

<q>The discussion concerning the meaning of the word \'bd
justification\'b8 . . . has largely been a mere
<qex>logomachy</qex>.</q>
<qau>L. Abbott.</qau>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>A game of word making.</def>

word, ratio + <?/ measure.]</ety> <fld>(Chem.)</fld> <def>Serving
to measure or ascertain chemical equivalents;
stoichiometric.</def> <mark>[R.]</mark>

<hw>Log"roll`ing</hw>, <pos>n.</pos> <sn>1.</sn>
<fld>(Logging)</fld> <def>The act or process of rolling logs from
the place where they were felled to the stream which floats them
to the sawmill or to market. In this labor neighboring camps of
loggers combine to assist each other in turn.</def>
<au>Longfellow.</au> <mark>[U.S.]</mark>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>Hence: A combining to assist another in
consideration of receiving assistance in return; -- sometimes
used of a disreputable mode of accomplishing political schemes or
ends.</def> <mark>[Cant, U.S.]</mark><-- "You scratch my back,
I'll scratch yours." -->

<er>Log</er>, <pos>n.</pos>, 2.</def>

<hw>Log"wood`</hw> <pr>(?)</pr> <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[So called
from being imported in <ets>logs</ets>.]</ety> <def>The heartwood
of a tree (<spn>H\'91matoxylon Campechianum</spn>), a native of
South America, It is a red, heavy wood, containing a crystalline
substance called <xex>h\'91matoxylin</xex>, and is used largely
in dyeing. An extract from this wood is used in medicine as an
astringent. Also called <altname>Campeachy wood</altname>, and
<altname>bloodwood</altname>.</def>

<hw>Loin</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[OE.
<ets>loine</ets>, OF. <ets>logne</ets>, F. <ets>longe</ets>, from
(assumed) LL. <ets>lumbea</ets>, L. <ets>lumbus</ets> join. Cf.

<def>That part of a human being or quadruped, which extends on
either side of the spinal column between the hip bone and the
false ribs. In human beings the loins are also called the reins.
See <xex>Illust</xex>. of <er>Beef</er>.</def>

<hw>Loi"ter</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>v. i.</pos>

<qau>Rogers.</qau>

<au>Spenser.</au>

<syn>Syn. -- To linger; delay; lag; saunter; tarry.</syn>

<hw>Loll</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>v. i.</pos>
<wordforms>[<pos>imp. & p. p.</pos> <er>Lolled</er> <pr>(?)</pr>;
<pos>p. pr. & vb. n.</pos> <er>Lolling</er>.]</wordforms>
<ety>[Cf. Icel. <ets>lolla</ets> to act lazily, <ets>loll</ets>,
<ets>lolla</ets>, laziness, OD. <ets>lollen</ets> to sit over the
fire, and E. <ets>lull</ets>. Cf. <er>Lill</er>,
<er>Lull</er>.]</ety> <sn>1.</sn> <def>To act lazily or
indolently; to recline; to lean; to throw one's self down; to lie
at ease.</def>

<q>Void of care, he <qex>lolls</qex> supine in state.</q>
<qau>Dryden.</qau>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>To hand extended from the mouth, as the tongue
of an ox or a log when heated with labor or exertion.</def>

<q>The triple porter of the Stygian seat,
With <qex>lolling</qex> tongue, lay fawning at thy feet.</q>
<qau>Dryden</qau>.

<sn>3.</sn> <def>To let the tongue hang from the mouth, as an ox,
dog, or other animal, when heated by labor; <as>as, the ox stood
<ex>lolling</ex> in the furrow</as>.</def>

<hw>Loll</hw>, <pos>v. t.</pos> <def>To let hang from the mouth,
as the tongue.</def>

<q>Fierce tigers couched around and <qex>lolled</qex> their
fawning tongues.</q>
<qau>Dryden.</qau>

<hw>Lol"lard</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[LL.
<ets>Lollardi</ets>, <ets>Lullardi</ets>, from Walter
<ets>Lolhardus</ets>, a German; cf. LG. & D. <ets>lollen</ets> to
mumble, to hum, sing in a murmuring strain; hence, OD.
<ets>lollaerd</ets> a mumbler, <ets>i</ets>. <ets>e</ets>., of
prayers or psalms, which was prob. the origin of the name. See
<er>Loll</er>, <er>Lull</er>.]</ety> <fld>(Eccl. Hist.)</fld>
<sd>(a)</sd> <def>One of a sect of early reformers in
Germany.</def> <sd>(b)</sd> <def>One of the followers of Wyclif

called from Walter Lollardus, one of their teachers in
Germany.</q>
<qau>Fuller.</qau>

<hw>Lom"bard</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>a.</pos> <def>Of or

for banks and the offices of note brokers; hence, the money

<hw>Lone</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <def>A lane. See
<er>Loanin</er>.</def> <mark>[Prov. Eng.]</mark>

<hw>Lone</hw>, <pos>a.</pos> <ety>[Abbrev. fr.
<ets>alone</ets>.]</ety> <sn>1.</sn> <def>Being without a
companion; being by one's self; also, sad from lack of
companionship; lonely; <as>as, a <ex>lone</ex> traveler or
watcher</as>.</def>

<q>When I have on those pathless wilds a appeared,
And the <qex>lone</qex> wanderer with my presence cheered.</q>
<qau>Shenstone.</qau>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>Single; unmarried, or in widowhood.</def>
<mark>[Archaic]</mark>

<q>Queen Elizabeth being a <qex>lone</qex> woman.</q>
<qau>Collection of Records (1642).</qau>

<q>A hundred mark is a long one for a poor <qex>lone</qex> woman
to bear.</q>
<qau>Shak.</qau>

<sn>3.</sn> <def>Being apart from other things of the kind; being
by itself; also, apart from human dwellings and resort; <as>as, a
<ex>lone</ex> house</as>.</def> \'bd A <xex>lone</xex> isle.\'b8

<au>Pope.</au>

<q>By a <qex>lone</qex> well a <qex>lonelier</qex> column
rears.</q>
<qau>Byron.</qau>

<sn>4.</sn> <def>Unfrequented by human beings; solitary.</def>

<q>Thus vanish scepters, coronets, and balls,
And leave you on <qex>lone</qex> woods, or empty walls.</q>
<qau>Pope.</qau>

<hw>Lone"li*ness</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <sn>1.</sn>
<def>The condition of being lonely; solitude; seclusion.</def>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>The state of being unfrequented by human beings;
<as>as, the <ex>loneliness</ex> of a road</as>.</def>

<sn>3.</sn> <def>Love of retirement; disposition to
solitude.</def>

<q>I see
The mystery of your <qex>loneliness</qex>.</q>
<qau>Shak.</qau>

<sn>4.</sn> <def>A feeling of depression resulting from being
alone.</def>

<syn>Syn. -- Solitude; seclusion. See <er>Solitude</er>.</syn>

<hw>Lone"ly</hw>, <pos>a.</pos> <wordforms>[<pos>Compar.</pos>
<er>Lonelier</er> <pr>(?)</pr>; <pos>superl.</pos>
<er>Loneliest</er>.]</wordforms> <ety>[Shortened fr.
<ets>alonely</ets>.]</ety> <sn>1.</sn> <def>Sequestered from
company or neighbors; solitary; retired; <as>as, a
<ex>lonely</ex> situation; a <ex>lonely</ex> cell.</as></def>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>Alone, or in want of company; forsaken.</def>

<q>To the misled and <qex>lonely</qex> traveler.</q>
<qau>Milton.</qau>

<sn>3.</sn> <def>Not frequented by human beings; <as>as, a
<ex>lonely</ex> wood</as>.</def>

<sn>4.</sn> <def>Having a feeling of depression or sadness
resulting from the consciousness of being alone; lonesome.</def>

<q>I am very often alone. I don't mean I am
<qex>lonely</qex>.</q>
<qau>H. James.</qau>

<syn>Syn. -- Solitary; lone; lonesome; retired; unfrequented;
sequestered; secluded.</syn>

<hw>Lone"ness</hw>, <pos>n.</pos> <def>Solitude; seclusion.</def>
<mark>[Obs.]</mark>

<au>Donne.</au>

<hw>Lone"some</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>a.</pos>
<wordforms>[<pos>Compar.</pos> <er>Lonesomer</er> <pr>(?)</pr>;
<pos>superl.</pos> <er>Lonesomest</er>.]</wordforms> <sn>1.</sn>
<def>Secluded from society; not frequented by human beings;
solitary.</def>

<q>Like one that on a <qex>lonesome</qex> road
Doth walk in fear and dread.</q>
<qau>Coleridge</qau>.

<sn>2.</sn> <def>Conscious of, and somewhat depressed by,
solitude; <as>as, to feel <ex>lonesome</ex></as>.</def>

-- <wordforms><wf>Lone"some*ly</wf>, <pos>adv.</pos> --
<wf>Lone"some*ness</wf>, <pos>n.</pos></wordforms>

<hw>Long</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>a.</pos>
<wordforms>[<pos>Compar.</pos> <er>Longer</er> <pr>(?)</pr>;
<pos>superl.</pos> <er>Longest</er> <pr>(?)</pr>.]</wordforms>
<ety>[AS. <ets>long</ets>, <ets>lang</ets>; akin to OS, OFries.,
D., & G. <ets>lang</ets>, Icel. <ets>langr</ets>, Sw.
<ets>l\'86ng</ets>, Dan. <ets>lang</ets>, Goth. <ets>laggs</ets>,
L.<ets>longus</ets>. <root/125.  Cf. <er>Length</er>,
<er>Ling</er> a fish, <er>Linger</er>, <er>Lunge</er>,
<er>Purloin</er>.]</ety> <sn>1.</sn> <def>Drawn out in a line, or
in the direction of length; protracted; extended; <as>as, a
<ex>long</ex> line; -- opposed to <ex>short</ex>, and
distinguished from <ex>broad</ex> or <ex>wide</ex>.</as></def>

<-- p. 867 -->

<sn>2.</sn> <def>Drawn out or extended in time; continued through
a considerable tine, or to a great length; <as>as, a
<ex>long</ex> series of events; a <ex>long</ex> debate; a
<ex>long</ex> drama; a <ex>long</ex> history; a <ex>long</ex>
book.</as></def>

<sn>3.</sn> <def>Slow in passing; causing weariness by length or
duration; lingering; <as>as, <ex>long</ex> hours of
watching</as>.</def>

<sn>4.</sn> <def>Occurring or coming after an extended interval;
distant in time; far away.</def>

<q>The we may us reserve both fresh and strong
Against the tournament, which is not <qex>long</qex>.</q>
<qau>Spenser.</qau>

<sn>5.</sn> <def>Extended to any specified measure; of a
specified length; <as>as, a span <ex>long</ex>; a yard
<ex>long</ex>; a mile <ex>long</ex>, that is, extended to the
measure of a mile, etc.</as></def>

<sn>6.</sn> <def>Far-reaching; extensive.</def> \'bd
<xex>Long</xex> views.\'b8

<au>Burke.</au>

<sn>7.</sn> <fld>(Phonetics)</fld> <def>Prolonged, or relatively
more prolonged, in utterance; -- said of vowels and syllables.
See <er>Short</er>, <pos>a.</pos>, 13, and <xex>Guide to
Pronunciation</xex>, <sect/<sect/ 22, 30.</def>

<note><hand/ <xex>Long</xex> is used as a prefix in a large
number of compound adjectives which are mostly of obvious
meaning; as, <xex>long-</xex>armed, <xex>long-</xex>beaked,
<xex>long-</xex>haired, <xex>long-</xex>horned,
<xex>long-</xex>necked, <xex>long-</xex>sleeved,
<xex>long-</xex>tailed, <xex>long-</xex> worded, etc.</note>

<cs><col>In the long run</col>, <cd>in the whole course of things
taken together; in the ultimate result; eventually.</cd> --
<col>Long clam</col> <fld>(Zo\'94l.)</fld>, <cd>the common clam
(<spn>Mya arenaria</spn>) of the Northern United States and
Canada; -- called also <altname>soft-shell clam</altname> and
<altname>long-neck clam</altname>. See <er>Mya</er>.</cd> --
<col>Long cloth</col>, <cd>a kind of cotton cloth of superior
quality.</cd> -- <col>Long clothes</col>, <cd>clothes worn by a
young infant, extending below the feet.</cd> -- <col>Long
division</col>. <fld>(Math.)</fld> <cd>See
<er>Division</er>.</cd> -- <col>Long dozen</col>, <cd>one more
than a dozen; thirteen.</cd> -- <col>Long home</col>, <cd>the
grave.</cd> -- <mcol><col>Long measure</col>, <col>Long
mater</col></mcol>. <cd>See under <er>Measure</er>,
<er>Meter</er>.</cd> -- <col>Long Parliament</col> <fld>(Eng.
Hist.)</fld>, <cd>the Parliament which assembled Nov. 3, 1640,
and was dissolved by Cromwell, April 20, 1653.</cd> -- <col>Long
price</col>, <cd>the full retail price.</cd> -- <col>Long
purple</col> <fld>(Bot.)</fld>, <cd>a plant with purple flowers,
supposed to be the <spn>Orchis mascula</spn>. <au>Dr.
Prior</au>.</cd> -- <col>Long suit</col> <fld>(Whist)</fld>,
<cd>a suit of which one holds originally more than three cards.
<au>R. A. Proctor</au>.</cd> -- <col>Long tom</col>. <sd>(a)</sd>
<cd>A pivot gun of great length and range, on the dock of a
vessel</cd>. <sd>(b)</sd> <cd>A long trough for washing
auriferous earth</cd>. <mark>[Western U.S.]</mark> <sd>(c)</sd>
<fld>(Zo\'94l.)</fld> <cd>The long-tailed titmouse.</cd> --
<col>Long wall</col> <fld>(Coal Mining)</fld>, <cd>a working in
which the whole seam is removed and the roof allowed to fall in,
as the work progresses, except where passages are needed.</cd> --
<col>Of long</col>, <cd>a long time. <mark>[Obs.]</mark>
<au>Fairfax</au>.</cd> -- <mcol><col>To be</col>, <or/
<col>go</col>, <col>long of the market</col>, <col>To be on the
long side of the market</col></mcol>, etc. <fld>(Stock
Exchange)</fld>, <cd>to hold stock for a rise in price, or to
have a contract under which one can demand stock on or before a
certain day at a stipulated price; -- opposed to <xex>short<xex>
in such phrases as, <xex>to be short of stock<xex>, <xex>to sell
short<xex>, etc. <mark>[Cant]</mark> See <er>Short</er>.</cd> --
<col>To have a long head</col>, <cd>to have a farseeing or
sagacious mind.</cd></cs>

<hw>Long</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <sn>1.</sn>
<fld>(Mus.)</fld> <def>A note formerly used in music, one half
the length of a large, twice that of a breve.</def>

<sn>2.</sn> <fld>(Phonetics)</fld> <def>A long sound, syllable,
or vowel.</def>

<sn>3.</sn> <def>The longest dimension; the greatest extent; --
in the phrase, <xex>the long and the short of it</xex>, that is,
the sum and substance of it.</def>

<au>Addison.</au>

<hw>Long</hw>, <pos>adv.</pos> <ety>[AS. <ets>lance</ets>.]</ety>
<sn>1.</sn> <def>To a great extent in apace; <as>as, a
<ex>long</ex> drawn out line</as>.</def>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>To a great extent in time; during a long
time.</def>

<q>They that tarry <qex>long</qex> at the wine.</q>
<qau>Prov. xxiii. 30.</qau>

<q>When the trumpet soundeth <qex>long</qex>.</q>
<qau>Ex. xix. 13.</qau>

<sn>3.</sn> <def>At a point of duration far distant, either prior
or posterior; <as>as, not <ex>long</ex> before; not <ex>long</ex>
after; <ex>long</ex> before the foundation of Rome; <ex>long</ex>
after the Conquest.</as></def>

<sn>4.</sn> <def>Through the whole extent or duration.</def>

<q>The bird of dawning singeth all night <qex>long</qex>.</q>
<qau>Shak.</qau>

<sn>5.</sn> <def>Through an extent of time, more or less; -- only
in question; as, how <xex>long</xex> will you be gone?</def>

<hw>Long</hw>, <pos>prep.</pos> <ety>[Abbreviated fr.
<ets>along</ets>. See 3d <er>Along</er>.]</ety> <def>By means of;
by the fault of; because of. <mark>[Obs.]</mark> See <cref>Along
of</cref>, under 3d <er>Along</er>.</def>

<hw>Long</hw>, <pos>v. i.</pos> <wordforms>[<pos>imp. &  p.
p.</pos> <er>Longed</er> <pr>(?)</pr>; <pos>p. pr. & vb. n.</pos>
<er>Longing</er>.]</wordforms> <ety>[AS. <ets>langian</ets> to
increase, to lengthen, to stretch out the mind after, to long, to
crave, to belong to, fr. <ets>lang</ets> long. See <er>Long</er>,
<pos>a.</pos>]</ety> <sn>1.</sn> <def>To feel a strong or morbid
desire or craving; to wish for something with eagerness; --
followed by an infinitive, or by <ptcl>after</ptcl> or
<ptcl>for</ptcl>.</def>

<q>I <qex>long</qex> to see you.</q>
<qau>Rom. i. 11.</qau>

<q>I have <qex>longed</qex> after thy precepts.</q>
<qau>Ps. cxix. 40.</qau>

<q>I have <qex>longed</qex> for thy salvation.</q>
<qau>Ps. cxix. 174.</qau>

<q>Nicomedes, <qex>longing</qex> for herrings, was supplied with
fresh ones . . . at a great distance from the sea.</q>
<qau>Arbuthnot.</qau>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>To belong; -- used with <ptcl>to</ptcl>,
<ptcl>unto</ptcl>, or <ptcl>for</ptcl>.</def> <mark>[Obs.]</mark>

<q>The labor which that <qex>longeth</qex> unto me.</q>
<qau>Chaucer.</qau>

<hw>Lon"gan</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <fld>(Bot.)</fld>
<def>A pulpy fruit related to the litchi, and produced by an
evergreen East Indian tree (<spn>Nephelium Longan</spn>).</def>

<hw>Lon`ga*nim"i*ty</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[L.
<ets>longanimitas</ets>; <ets>longus</ets> long +

<hw>Long"boat`</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos>
<fld>(Naut.)</fld> <def>Formerly, the largest boat carried by a

vessel.</def>

<hw>Long"bow`</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <def>The ordinary
bow, not mounted on a stock; -- so called in distinction from the
<xex>crossbow</xex> when both were used as weapons of war. Also,
sometimes, such a bow of about the height of a man, as
distinguished from a much shorter one.</def>

<cs><col>To draw the longbow</col>, <cd>to tell large
stories.</cd></cs>

<hw>Long"-breathed`</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>a.</pos> <def>Having
the power of retaining the breath for a long time;
long-winded.</def>

<hw>Long"-drawn`</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>a.</pos> <def>Extended
to a great length.</def>

<q>The cicad\'91 hushed their <qex>long-drawn</qex>,
ear-splitting strains.</q>
<qau>G. W. Cable.</qau>

<hw>Long"-horned`</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>a.</pos>
<fld>(Zo\'94l.)</fld> <mark>[Obs.]</mark> <def>Having a long horn

(<spn>Longicornia</spn>).</def>

<hw>Lon"gi*corn</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>a.</pos> <ety>[L.

<hw>\'d8Lon`gi*cor"ni*a</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n. pl.</pos>
<ety>[NL., fr. L. <ets>longus</ets> long + <ets>cornu</ets>
horn.]</ety> <fld>(Zo\'94l.)</fld> <def>A division of beetles,
including a large number of species, in which the antenn\'91 are
very long.  Most of them, while in the larval state, bore into
the wood or beneath the bark of trees, and some species are very
destructive to fruit and shade trees. See <stype>Apple
borer</stype>, under <er>Apple</er>, and <stype>Locust
beetle</stype>, under <er>Locust</er>.</def>

<hw>Lon`gi*lat"er*al</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>a.</pos> <ety>[L.
<ets>longus</ets> long + <ets>lateralis</ets> lateral, fr.
<ets>latus</ets> side.]</ety> <def>Having long sides especially,
having the form of a long parallelogram.</def>

<q>Nineveh . . . was of a <qex>longilateral</qex> figure,
ninety-five furlongs broad, and a hundred and fifty long.</q>
<qau>Sir T. Browne.</qau>

<hw>\'d8Lon`gi*ros"tres</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n. pl.</pos>
<ety>[NL., fr. L. <ets>longus</ets> long + <ets>rostrum</ets>
beak.]</ety> <fld>(Zo\'94l.)</fld> <def>A group of birds
characterized by having long slender bills, as the sandpipers,
curlews, and ibises. It is now regarded as an artificial
division.</def>

<hw>Long"ish</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>a.</pos> <def>Somewhat long;
moderately long.</def>

<hw>Lon"gi*tude</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[F., fr. L.
<ets>longitudo</ets>, fr. <ets>longus</ets> long.]</ety>
<sn>1.</sn> <def>Length; measure or distance along the longest
line; -- distinguished from <xex>breadth</xex> or
<xex>thickness</xex>; <as>as, the <ex>longitude</ex> of a
room</as>; rare now, except in a humorous sense.</def>

<au>Sir H. Wotton.</au>

<q>The <qex>longitude</qex> of their cloaks.</q>
<qau>Sir. W. Scott.</qau>

<q>Mine [shadow] spindling into <qex>longitude</qex> immense.</q>
<qau>Cowper.</qau>

<sn>2.</sn> <fld>(Geog.)</fld> <def>The arc or portion of the
equator intersected between the meridian of a given place and the
meridian of some other place from which longitude is reckoned, as
from Greenwich, England, or sometimes from the capital of a
country, as from Washington or Paris. The longitude of a place is
expressed either in degrees or in time; <as>as, that of New York
is 74<deg/ or 4 h. 56 min. west of Greenwich.</as></def>

<sn>3.</sn> <fld>(Astron.)</fld> <def>The distance in degrees,
reckoned from the vernal equinox, on the ecliptic, to a circle at
right angles to the ecliptic passing through the heavenly body
whose longitude is designated; <as>as, the <ex>longitude</ex> of
Capella is 79<deg/</as>.</def>

<cs><col>Geocentric longitude</col> <fld>(Astron.)</fld>, <cd>the
longitude of a heavenly body as seen from the earth.</cd> --
<col>Heliocentric longitude</col>, <cd>the longitude of a
heavenly body, as seen from the sun's center.</cd> --
<col>Longitude stars</col>, <cd>certain stars whose position is
known, and the data in regard to which are used in observations
for finding the longitude, as by lunar distances.</cd></cs>

<hw>Lon`gi*tu"di*nal</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>a.</pos> <ety>[Cf.
F. <ets>longitudinal</ets>.]</ety> <sn>1.</sn> <def>Of or
pertaining to longitude or length; <as>as, <ex>longitudinal</ex>
distance</as>.</def>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>Extending in length; in the direction of the
length; running lengthwise, as distinguished from
<xex>transverse</xex>; <as>as, the <ex>longitudinal</ex> diameter
of a body</as>.</def>

<au>Cheyne.</au>

<hw>Lon`gi*tu"di*nal</hw>, <pos>n.</pos> <def>A railway sleeper
lying parallel with the rail.</def>

<hw>Lon`gi*tu"di*nal*ly</hw>, <pos>adv.</pos> <def>In the
direction of length.</def>

they are a <ex>longlived</ex> family; <ex>long-lived</ex>

<au>Shak.</au>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>For a long time; hence, wearisomely.</def>

<hw>Long"mynd rocks"</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>. <fld>(Geol.)</fld>
<def>The sparingly fossiliferous conglomerates, grits, schists,
and states of Great Britain, which lie at the base of the
Cambrian system; -- so called, because typically developed in the
<xex>Longmynd</xex> Hills, Shropshire.</def>

<hw>Long"ness</hw>, <pos>n.</pos> <def>Length.</def>

primer</xex>.</note>

<hw>Long"shore`</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>a.</pos> <ety>[Abbrev.

or a seaport; along and on the shore.</def>
\'bd<xex>Longshore</xex> thieves.\'b8

<au>R. Browning.</au>

<hw>Long"shore`man</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos>; <plu>pl.
<plw>Longshoremen</plw> <pr>(#)</pr></plu>. <ety>[Abbrev. fr.
<ets>alongshoreman</ets>.]</ety> <def>One of a class of laborers
employed about the wharves of a seaport, especially in loading
and unloading vessels.</def>

<hw>Long"-sight</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos>
<def>Long-sightedness</def>

<au>Good.</au>

<hw>Long"-sight`ed</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>a.</pos> <sn>1.</sn>
<def>Able to see objects at a great distance; hence, having great
foresight; sagacious; farseeing.</def>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>Able to see objects distinctly at a distance,
but not close at hand; hypermetropic.</def>

<hw>Long"-sight`ed*ness</hw>, <pos>n.</pos> <sn>1.</sn> <def>The
state or condition of being long-sighted; hence, sagacity;
shrewdness.</def>

<sn>2.</sn> <fld>(Med.)</fld> <def>See
<er>Hypermetropia</er>.</def>

<hw>Long"some</hw> <pr>(?)</pr> <pos>a.</pos> <ety>[AS.
<ets>langsum</ets>.]</ety> <def>Extended in length;
tiresome.</def> <mark>[Obs.]</mark> <au>Bp. Hall</au>.
<au>Prior</au>. -- <wordforms><wf>Long"some*ness</wf>,
<pos>n.</pos> <mark>[Obs.]</mark> <au>Fuller</au>.</wordforms>

<hw>Long"spun`</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>a.</pos> <def>Spun out, or
extended, to great length; hence, long-winded; tedious.</def>

<q>The <qex>longspun</qex> allegories fulsome grow,
While the dull moral lies too plain below.</q>
<qau>Addison.</qau>

<hw>Long"spur`</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[So called
from the length of the hind claw.]</ety> <fld>(Zo\'94l.)</fld>
<def>Any one of several species of fringilline birds of the genus
<spn>Calcarius</spn> (or <spn>Plectrophanes</spn>), and allied
genera. The Lapland longspur (<spn>C. Lapponicus</spn>), the
chestnut-colored longspur (<spn>C. ornatus</spn>), and other
species, inhabit the United States.</def>

<hw>Long"-stop`</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos>
<fld>(Cricket)</fld> <def>One who is set to stop balls which pass
the wicket keeper.</def>

<hw>Long"-suf`fer*ance</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos>
<def>Forbearance to punish or resent.</def>

<hw>Long"-suf`fer*ing</hw>, <pos>n.</pos> <def>Bearing injuries
or provocation for a long time; patient; not easily
provoked.</def>

<q>The Lord God, merciful and gracious,
<qex>long-suffering</qex>, and abundant in goodness and
truth.</q>
<qau>Ex. xxxiv. 6.</qau>

<hw>Long"-suf`fer*ing</hw>, <pos>n.</pos> <def>Long patience of
offense.</def>

<q>Despisest thou the riches of his goodness and forbearance and
<qex>long-suffering</qex>?</q>
<qau>Rom. ii. 4. </qau>

<hw>Long"tail`</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <def>An animal,
particularly a log, having an uncut tail. Cf. <er>Curtail</er>.
<er>Dog</er>.</def>

<note><hand/ A <xex>longtail</xex> was a gentleman's dog, or the
dog of one qualified to bunt, other dogs being required to have
their tails cut.</note>

<cs><col>Cut and longtail</col>, <cd>all, gentlefolks and others,
as they might come.</cd></cs>

<au>Shak.</au>

<hw>Long"-tongue`</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos>
<fld>(Zo\'94l.)</fld> <def>The wryneck.</def>

<def>Having a long tongue.</def>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>Talkative; babbling; loquacious.</def>

<au>Shak.</au>

<ets>longus</ets> long + <ets>-lie</ets>.]</ety>

<hw>Long"-waist`ed</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>a.</pos> <sn>1.</sn>

coat</as>.</def>

<hw>Loo</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[For older
<ets>lanterloo</ets>, F. <ets>lanturelu</ets>,
<ets>lanturlu</ets>, name of the game; orig., the refrain of a
vaudeville.]</ety> <sd>(a)</sd> <def>An old game played with
five, or three, cards dealt to each player from a full pack. When
five cards are used the highest card is the knave of clubs or (if
so agreed upon) the knave of trumps; -- formerly called
<altname>lanterloo</altname>.</def> <sd>(b)</sd> <def>A
modification of the game of \'bdall fours\'b8 in which the
players replenish their hands after each round by drawing each a
card from the pack.</def>

<-- p. 868 -->

<cs><col>Loo table</col>, <cd>a round table adapted for a circle
of persons playing loo.</cd></cs>

<hw>Loo</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>v. t.</pos> <wordforms>[<pos>imp.
& p. p.</pos> <er>Looed</er> <pr>(?)</pr>; <pos>p. pr. & vb.
n.</pos> <er>Looing</er>.]</wordforms> <def>To beat in the game
of loo by winning every trick.</def> <altsp>[Written also
<asp>lu</asp>.]</altsp>

<au>Goldsmith.</au>

from tin ore in dressing.</def>

<er>Looby</er>.]</ety> <def>Loobylike; awkward.</def>

<hw>Loof</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[See
<er>Luff</er>.]</ety> <altsp>[Also written
<asp>luff</asp>.]</altsp> <fld>(Naut.)</fld> <sd>(a)</sd>
<def>Formerly, some appurtenance of a vessel which was used in
changing her course; -- probably a large paddle put over the lee
bow to help bring her head nearer to the wind</def>. <sd>(b)</sd>
<def>The part of a ship's side where the planking begins to curve
toward bow and stern.</def>

<er>Luff</er>.</def>

<hw>Look</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>v. i.</pos>
<wordforms>[<pos>imp. & p. p.</pos> <er>Looked</er> <pr>(?)</pr>;
<pos>p. pr. & vb. n.</pos> <er>Looking</er>.]</wordforms>
<ety>[OE. <ets>loken</ets>, AS. <ets>l<omac/cian</ets>; akin to
G. <ets>lugen</ets>, OHG. <ets>luog<emac/n</ets>.]</ety>
<sn>1.</sn> <def>To direct the eyes for the purpose of seeing
something; to direct the eyes toward an object; to observe with
the eyes while keeping them directed; -- with various
prepositions, often in a special or figurative sense. See Phrases
below.</def>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>To direct the attention (to something); to
consider; to examine; <as>as, to <ex>look</ex> at an
action</as>.</def>

<sn>3.</sn> <def>To seem; to appear; to have a particular
appearance; <as>as, the patient <ex>looks</ex> better; the clouds
<ex>look</ex> rainy.</as></def>

<q>It would <qex>look</qex> more like vanity than gratitude.</q>
<qau>Addison.</qau>

<q>Observe how such a practice <qex>looks</qex> in another
person.</q>
<qau>I. Watts.</qau>

<sn>4.</sn> <def>To have a particular direction or situation; to
face; to front.</def>

<q>The inner gate that <qex>looketh</qex> to north.</q>
<qau>Ezek. viii. 3.</qau>

<q>The east gate . . . which <qex>looketh</qex> eastward.</q>
<qau>Ezek. xi. 1.</qau>

<sn>5.</sn> <def>In the imperative: see; behold; take notice;
take care; observe; -- used to call attention.</def>

<q><qex>Look</qex>, how much we thus expel of sin, so much we
expel of virtue.</q>
<qau>Milton.</qau>

<note><hand/ <xex>Look</xex>, in the imperative, may be followed
by a dependent sentence, but <xex>see</xex> is oftener so
used.</note><-- See spot run? in 1990, the reverse is true -->

<q><qex>Look</qex> that ye bind them fast.</q>
<qau>Shak.</qau>

<q><qex>Look</qex> if it be my daughter.</q>
<qau>Talfourd.</qau>

<sn>6.</sn> <def>To show one's self in looking, as by leaning out
of a window; <as>as, <ex>look</ex> out of the window while I
speak to you</as>. Sometimes used figuratively.</def>

<q>My toes <qex>look</qex> through the overleather.</q>
<qau>Shak.</qau>

<sn>7.</sn> <def>To await the appearance of anything; to expect;
to anticipate.</def>

<q><qex>Looking</qex> each hour into death's mouth to fall.</q>
<qau>Spenser.</qau>

<cs><col>To look about</col>, <cd>to look on all sides, or in
different directions.</cd> -- <col>To look about one</col>,
<cd>to be on the watch; to be vigilant; to be circumspect or
guarded.</cd> -- <col>To look after</col>. <sd>(a)</sd> <cd>To
attend to; to take care of; as, <xex>to look after<xex>
children</cd>. <sd>(b)</sd> <cd>To expect; to be in a state of
expectation.</cd>

<q>Men's hearts failing them for fear, and for <qex>looking
after</qex> those things which are coming on the earth.</q>
<qau>Luke xxi. 26.</qau>

<sd>(c)</sd> <cd>To seek; to search</cd>.

<q>My subject does not oblige me <qex>to look after</qex> the
water, or point forth the place where to it is now retreated.</q>
<qau>Woodward.</qau>

-- <col>To look at</col>, <cd>to direct the eyes toward so that
one sees, or as if to see; <as>as, <ex>to look at</ex> a
star</as>; hence, to observe, examine, consider; <as>as, <ex>to
look at</ex> a matter without prejudice</as>.</cd> -- <col>To
look black</col>, <cd>to frown; to scowl; to have a threatening
appearance.</cd>

<q>The bishops thereat repined, and <qex>looked black</qex>.</q>
<qau>Holinshed.</qau>

-- <mcol><col>To look down on</col> <or/ <col>upon</col></mcol>,
<cd>to treat with indifference or contempt; to regard as an
inferior; to despise.</cd> -- <col>To look for</col>.
<sd>(a)</sd> <cd>To expect; <as>as, <ex>to look for</ex> news by
the arrival of a ship</as>. \'bd<xex>Look</xex> now
<xex>for</xex> no enchanting voice.\'b8 <au>Milton</au>.
<sd>(b)</sd> <cd>To seek for; to search for; <as>as, <ex>to look
for</ex> lost money, or lost cattle</as>.</cd> -- <col>To look
forth</col>. <sd>(a)</sd> <cd>To look out of something, as from a
window.</cd> <sd>(b)</sd> <cd>To threaten to come out</cd>.
<au>Jer. vi. 1. (Rev. Ver.)</au>. -- <col>To look into</col>,
<cd>to inspect closely; to observe narrowly; to examine; <as>as,
<ex>to look into</ex> the works of nature; <ex>to look into</ex>
one's conduct or affairs</as>.</cd> -- <col>To look on</col>.
<sd>(a)</sd> <cd>To regard; to esteem.</cd>

<q>Her friends would <qex>look on</qex> her the worse.</q>
<qau>Prior.</qau>

<sd>(b)</sd> <cd>To consider; to view; to conceive of; to think
of.</cd>

<q>I <qex>looked on</qex> Virgil as a succinct, majestic
writer.</q>
<qau>Dryden.</qau>

<sd>(c)</sd> <cd>To be a mere spectator</cd>.

<q>I'll be a candleholder, and <qex>look on</qex>.</q>
<qau>Shak.</qau>

-- <col>To look out</col>, <cd>to be on the watch; to be careful;
as, the seaman <xex>looks out</xex> for breakers.</cd> -- <col>To
look through</col>. <sd>(a)</sd> <cd>To see through.</cd>
<sd>(b)</sd> <cd>To search; to examine with the eyes</cd>. --
<mcol><col>To look to</col> <or/ <col>unto</col></mcol>.
<sd>(a)</sd> <cd>To watch; to take care of.</cd>
\'bd<xex>Look</xex> well <xex>to</xex> thy herds.\'b8 <au>Prov.
xxvii. 23</au>. <sd>(b)</sd> <cd>To resort to with expectation of
receiving something; to expect to receive from; as, the creditor
may <xex>look to</xex> surety for payment.</cd> \'bd<xex>Look
unto</xex> me, and be ye saved.\'b8 <au>Is. xlv. 22</au>. --
<col>To look up</col>, <cd>to search for or find out by looking;
as, <xex>to look up</xex> the items of an account.</cd> --
<col>To look up to</col>, <cd>to respect; to regard with
deference.</cd></cs>

<hw>Look</hw>, <pos>v. t.</pos> <sn>1.</sn> <def>To look at; to
turn the eyes toward.</def>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>To seek; to search for.</def>
<mark>[Obs.]</mark>

<q><qex>Looking</qex> my love, I go from place to place.</q>
<qau>Spenser.</qau>

<sn>3.</sn> <def>To expect.</def> <mark>[Obs.]</mark>

<au>Shak.</au>

<sn>4.</sn> <def>To influence, overawe, or subdue by looks or
presence as, to <xex>look</xex> down opposition.</def>

<q>A spirit fit to start into an empire,
And <qex>look</qex> the world to law.</q>
<qau>Dryden.</qau>

<sn>5.</sn> <def>To express or manifest by a look.</def>

<q>Soft eyes <qex>looked</qex> love to eyes which spake
again.</q>
<qau>Byron.</qau>

<cs><col>To look daggers</col>. <cd>See under
<er>Dagger</er>.</cd> -- <col>To look in the face</col>, <cd>to
face or meet with boldness or confidence; hence, sometimes, to
meet for combat.</cd> -- <col>To look out</col>, <cd>to seek for;
as, prudent persons <xex>look out<xex> associates good
reputation.</cd></cs>

<hw>Look</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <sn>1.</sn> <def>The
act of looking; a glance; a sight; a view; -- often in certain
phrases; <as>as, to have, get, take, throw, or cast, a
<ex>look</ex></as>.</def>

<q>Threw many a northward <qex>look</qex> to see his father
Bring up his powers; but he did long in vain.</q>
<qau>Shak.</qau>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>Expression of the eyes and face; manner; <as>as,
a proud or defiant <ex>look</ex></as>.</def> \'bdGentle
<xex>looks</xex>.\'b8

<au>Shak.</au>

<q>Up ! up! my friends, and clear your <qex>looks</qex>.</q>
<qau>Wordsworth.</qau>

<sn>3.</sn> <def>Hence; Appearance; aspect; <as>as, the house has
a gloomy <ex>look</ex>; the affair has a bad
<ex>look</ex>.</as></def>

<q>Pain, disgrace, and poverty have frighted
<qex>looks</qex>.</q>
<qau>Locke.</qau>

<q>There was something that reminded me of Dante's Hell in the
<qex>look</qex> of this.</q>
<qau>Carlyle.</qau>

<hw>Look"down`</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos>
<fld>(Zo\'94l.)</fld> <def>See <er>Moonfish</er>
<sd>(b)</sd>.</def>

<hw>Look"er</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <def>One who
looks.</def>

<cs><col>Looker-on</col>, <cd>a spectator; one that looks on, but
has no agency or part in an affair.</cd></cs>

<q>Did not this fatal war affront thy coast,
Yet sattest thou an idle <qex>looker-on</qex> ?</q>
<qau>Fairfax.</qau>

<hw>Look"ing</hw>, <pos>a.</pos> <def>Having a certain look or
appearance; -- often compounded with adjectives; <as>as,
good<ex>-looking</ex>, grand<ex>-looking</ex>, etc.</as></def>

<hw>Look"ing</hw>, <pos>n.</pos> <sn>1.</sn> <def>The act of one
who looks; a glance.</def>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>The manner in which one looks; appearance;
countenance; face.</def> <mark>[Obs.]</mark>

<q>All dreary was his cheer and his <qex>looking</qex>.</q>
<qau>Chaucer.</qau>

<cs><col>Looking for</col>, <cd>anticipation; expectation. \'bdA
certain fearful <xex>looking for<xex> of judgment.\'b8</cd></cs>

<au>Heb. x. 27.</au>

<hw>Look"ing-glass`</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <def>A
mirror made of glass on which has been placed a backing of some
reflecting substance, as quicksilver.</def>

<q>There is none so homely but loves a
<qex>looking-glass</qex>.</q>
<qau>South.</qau>

<hw>Look"out`</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <sn>1.</sn> <def>A
careful looking or watching for any object or event.</def>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>The place from which such observation is
made.</def>

<sn>3.</sn> <def>A person engaged in watching.</def>

<sn>4.</sn> <def>Object or duty of forethought and care;
responsibility.</def> <mark>[Colloq.]</mark>

<hw>Lool</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <fld>(Metal.)</fld>
<def>A vessel used to receive the washings of ores of
metals.</def>

<hw>Loom</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <fld>(Zo\'94l.)</fld>
<def>See <er>Loon</er>, the bird.</def>

<hw>Loom</hw>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[OE. <ets>lome</ets>, AS.
<ets>gel<?/ma</ets> utensil, implement.]</ety>

<sn>1.</sn> <def>A frame or machine of wood or other material, in
which a weaver forms cloth out of thread; a machine for
interweaving yarn or threads into a fabric, as in knitting or
lace making.</def>

<q>Hector, when he sees Andromache overwhelmed with terror, sends
her for consolation to the <qex>loom</qex> and the distaff.</q>
<qau>Rambler.</qau>

<sn>2.</sn> <fld>(Naut.)</fld> <def>That part of an oar which is
near the grip or handle and inboard from the rowlock.</def>

<au>Totten.</au>

<hw>Loom</hw>, <pos>v. i.</pos> <wordforms>[<pos>imp. & p.
p.</pos> <er>Loomed</er> <pr>(?)</pr>; <pos>p. pr. & vb. n.</pos>
<er>Looming</er>.]</wordforms> <ety>[OE. <ets>lumen</ets> to
shine, Icel. <ets>ljoma</ets>; akin to AS. <ets>le\'a2ma</ets>
light, and E. <ets>light</ets>; or cf. OF. <ets>lumer</ets> to
shine, L. <ets>luminare</ets> to illumine, <ets>lumen</ets>
light; akin to E. <ets>light</ets>. <?/ See <er>Light</er> not
dark.]</ety> <sn>1.</sn> <def>To appear above the surface either
of sea or land, or to appear enlarged, or distorted and
indistinct, as a distant object, a ship at sea, or a mountain,
esp. from atmospheric influences; <as>as, the ship <ex>looms</ex>
large; the land <ex>looms</ex> high.</as></def>

<q>Awful she <qex>looms</qex>, the terror of the main.</q>
<qau>H. J. Pye.</qau>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>To rise and to be eminent; to be elevated or
ennobled, in a moral sense.</def>

<q>On no occasion does he [Paul] <qex>loom</qex> so high, and
shine so gloriously, as in the context.</q>
<qau>J. M. Mason.</qau>

<hw>Loom</hw>, <pos>n.</pos> <def>The state of looming; esp., an
unnatural and indistinct appearance of elevation or enlargement
of anything, as of land or of a ship, seen by one at sea.</def>

<hw>Loom"-gale`</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <def>A gentle
gale of wind.</def>

<hw>Loom"ing</hw>, <pos>n.</pos> <def>The indistinct and
magnified appearance of objects seen in particular states of the
atmosphere. See <er>Mirage</er>.</def>

<hw>Loon</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[Scot.
<ets>loun</ets>, <ets>lown</ets>, <ets>loon</ets>; akin to OD.
<ets>loen</ets> a stupid man; prob. for an older <ets>lown</ets>,
and akin to E. <ets>lame</ets>.]</ety> <def>A sorry fellow; a
worthless person; a rogue.</def>

<hw>Loon</hw>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[For older <ets>loom</ets>,
Icel. <ets>l<?/mr</ets>; akin to Dan. & Sw.
<ets>lom</ets>.]</ety> <fld>(Zo\'94l.)</fld> <def>Any one of
several aquatic, wed-footed, northern birds of the genus
<spn>Urinator</spn> (formerly <spn>Colymbus</spn>), noted for
their expertness in diving and swimming under water. The common
loon, or great northern diver (<spn>Urinator imber</spn>, or
<spn>Colymbus torquatus</spn>), and the red-throated loon or
diver (<spn>U. septentrionalis</spn>), are the best known
species. See <er>Diver</er>.</def>

<hw>Loon"y</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>a.</pos> <def>See
<er>Luny</er>.</def>

<hw>Loop</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[G.
<ets>luppe</ets> an iron lump. Cf. <er>Looping</er>.]</ety>
<fld>(Iron Works)</fld> <def>A mass of iron in a pasty condition
gathered into a ball for the tilt hammer or rolls.</def>
<altsp>[Written also <asp>loup</asp>.]</altsp>

<hw>Loop</hw>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[Cf. Ir. & Gael. <ets>lub</ets>
loop, noose, fold, thong, bend, <ets>lub</ets> to bend,
incline.]</ety> <sn>1.</sn> <def>A fold or doubling of a thread,
cord, rope, etc., through which another thread, cord, etc., can
be passed, or which a hook can be hooked into; an eye, as of
metal; a staple; a noose; a bight.</def>

<q>That the probation bear no hinge, nor <qex>loop</qex>
To hang a doubt on.</q>
<qau>Shak.</qau>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>A small, narrow opening; a loophole.</def>

<q>And stop all sight-holes, every <qex>loop</qex> from whence
The eye of Reason may pry in upon us.</q>
<qau>Shak.</qau>

<sn>3.</sn> <def>A curve of any kind in the form of a loop.</def>

<sn>4.</sn> <fld>(Telegraphy)</fld> <def>A wire forming part of a
main circuit and returning to the point from which it
starts.</def>

<sn>5.</sn> <fld>(Acoustics)</fld> <def>The portion of a
vibrating string, air column, etc., between two nodes; -- called
also <altname>ventral segment</altname>.</def>

<cs><col>Loop knot</col>, <cd>a single knot tied in a doubled
cord, etc. so as to leave a loop beyond the knot. See
<xex>Illust<xex>. of <er>Knot</er>.</cd></cs>

<hw>Loop</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>v. t.</pos>
<wordforms>[<pos>imp. & p. p.</pos> <er>Looped</er> <pr>(?)</pr>;
<pos>p. pr. & vb. n.</pos> <er>Looping</er>.]</wordforms> <def>To
make a loop of or in; to fasten with a loop or loops; -- often
with <xex>up</xex>; <as>as, to <ex>loop</ex> a string; to
<ex>loop</ex> up a curtain.</as></def>

<hw>Looped</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>a.</pos> <sn>1.</sn>
<def>Bent, folded, or tied, so as to make a loop; <as>as, a
<ex>looped</ex> wire or string</as>.</def>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>Full of holes.</def> <mark>[Obs.]</mark>

<au>Shak.</au>

<hw>Loop"er</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <sn>1.</sn> <def>An
instrument, as a bodkin, for forming a loop in yarn, a cord,
etc.</def>

<sn>2.</sn> <fld>(Zo\'94l.)</fld> <def>The larva of any species
of geometrid moths. See <er>Geometrid</er>.</def>

<hw>Loop"hole`</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <sn>1.</sn>
<fld>(Mil.)</fld> <def>A small opening, as in the walls of
fortification, or in the bulkhead of a ship, through which small
arms or other weapons may be discharged at an enemy.</def>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>A hole or aperture that gives a passage, or the
means of escape or evasion.</def>

<-- 3. (Fig.) (Law) An amibiguity or unintended omission in a
law, rule, or contract which allows a party to circumvent the
intent of the text and avoid its obligations under certain
circumstances. -- used usually in a negative sense; --
distinguished from "escape clause" in that the latter usually is
included to deliberately allow evasion of obligation under
certain specified and foreseen circumstances. -->

<hw>Loose</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>a.</pos>
<wordforms>[<pos>Compar.</pos> <er>Looser</er> <pr>(?)</pr>;
<pos>superl.</pos> <er>Loosest</er>.]</wordforms> <ety>[OE.
<ets>loos</ets>, <ets>lous</ets>, <ets>laus</ets>, Icel.
<ets>lauss</ets>; akin to OD. <ets>loos</ets>, D. los, AS.
<ets>le\'a0s</ets> false, deceitful, G. <ets>los</ets>, loose,
Dan. &  Sw. <ets>l\'94s</ets>, Goth. <ets>laus</ets>, and E.
<ets>lose</ets>. <?/  See <er>Lose</er>, and cf. <er>Leasing</er>
falsehood.]</ety> <sn>1.</sn> <def>Unbound; untied; unsewed; not
attached, fastened, fixed, or confined; <as>as, the
<ex>loose</ex> sheets of a book</as>.</def>

<q>Her hair, nor <qex>loose</qex>, nor tied in formal plat.</q>
<qau>Shak.</qau>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>Free from constraint or obligation; not bound by
duty, habit, etc. ; -- with <xex>from or of</xex>.</def>

<q>Now I stand
<qex>Loose</qex> of my vow; but who knows Cato's thoughts ?</q>
<qau>Addison.</qau>

<sn>3.</sn> <def>Not tight or close; <as>as, a <ex>loose</ex>
garment</as>.</def>

<sn>4.</sn> <def>Not dense, close, compact, or crowded; <as>as, a
cloth of <ex>loose</ex> texture</as>.</def>

<q>With horse and chariots ranked in <qex>loose</qex> array.</q>
<qau>Milton.</qau>

<sn>5.</sn> <def>Not precise or exact; vague; indeterminate;
<as>as, a <ex>loose</ex> style, or way of reasoning</as>.</def>

<q>The comparison employed . . . must be considered rather as a
<qex>loose</qex> analogy than as an exact scientific
explanation.</q>
<qau>Whewel.</qau>

<sn>6.</sn> <def>Not strict in matters of morality; not rigid
according to some standard of right.</def>

<q>The <qex>loose</qex> morality which he had learned.</q>
<qau>Sir W. Scott.</qau>

<sn>7.</sn> <def>Unconnected; rambling.</def>

<q>Vario spends whole mornings in running over <qex>loose</qex>
and unconnected pages.</q>
<qau>I. Watts.</qau>

<sn>8.</sn> <def>Lax; not costive; having lax bowels.</def>

<au>Locke.</au>

<sn>9.</sn> <def>Dissolute; unchaste; <as>as, a <ex>loose</ex>
man or woman</as>.</def>

<q><qex>Loose</qex> ladies in delight.</q>
<qau>Spenser.</qau>

<sn>10.</sn> <def>Containing or consisting of obscene or unchaste
language; <as>as, a <ex>loose</ex> epistle</as>.</def>

<au> Dryden.</au>

<cs><col>At loose ends</col>, <cd>not in order; in confusion;
carelessly managed.</cd> -- <col>Fast and loose</col>. <cd>See
under <er>Fast</er>.</cd> -- <col>To break loose</col>. <cd>See
under <er>Break</er>.</cd> -- <col>Loose pulley</col>.
<fld>(Mach.)</fld> <cd>See <cref>Fast and loose pulleys</cref>,
under <er>Fast</er>.</cd> -- <col>To let loose</col>, <cd>to free
from restraint or confinement; to set at liberty.</cd></cs>

<hw>Loose</hw>, <pos>n.</pos> <sn>1.</sn> <def>Freedom from
restraint.</def> <mark>[Obs.]</mark>

<au>Prior.</au>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>A letting go; discharge.</def>

<au>B. Jonson.</au>

<cs><col>To give a loose</col>, <cd>to give freedom.</cd></cs>

<q>Vent all its griefs, and <qex>give a loose</qex> to
sorrow.</q>
<qau>Addison.</qau>

<hw>Loose</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>v. n.</pos>
<wordforms>[<pos>imp. & p. p.</pos> <er>Loosed</er> <pr>(?)</pr>;
<pos>p. pr. & vb. n.</pos> <er>Loosing</er>.]</wordforms>
<ety>[From <er>Loose</er>, <pos>a.</pos>]</ety> <sn>1.</sn>
<def>To untie or unbind; to free from any fastening; to remove
the shackles or fastenings of; to set free; to relieve.</def>

<q>Canst thou . . . <qex>loose</qex> the bands of Orion ?</q>
<qau>Job. xxxviii. 31.</qau>

<q>Ye shall find an ass tied, and a colt with her;
<qex>loose</qex> them, and bring them unto me.</q>
<qau>Matt. xxi. 2.</qau>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>To release from anything obligatory or
burdensome; to disengage; hence, to absolve; to remit.</def>

<q>Art thou <qex>loosed</qex> from a wife ? seek not a wife.</q>
<qau>1 Cor. vii. 27.</qau>

<q>Whatsoever thou shalt <qex>loose</qex> on earth shall be
<qex>loosed</qex> in heaven.</q>
<qau>Matt. xvi. 19.</qau>

<sn>3.</sn> <def>To relax; to loosen; to make less strict.</def>

<q>The joints of his loins were <qex>loosed</qex>.</q>
<qau>Dan. v. 6.</qau>

<sn>4.</sn> <def>To solve; to interpret.</def>
<mark>[Obs.]</mark>

<au>Spenser.</au>

<hw>Loose</hw>, <pos>v. i.</pos> <def>To set sail.</def>
<mark>[Obs.]</mark>

<au>Acts xiii. 13.</au>

<hw>Loose"ly</hw>, <pos>adv.</pos> <def>In a loose manner.</def>

<hw>Loos"en</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>v. t.</pos>
<wordforms>[<pos>imp. & p. p.</pos> <er>Loosened</er>
<pr>(?)</pr>; <pos>p. pr. & vb. n.</pos>
<er>Loosening</er>.]</wordforms> <ety>[See <er>Loose</er>,
<pos>v. t.</pos>]</ety> <sn>1.</sn> <def>To make loose; to free
from tightness, tension, firmness, or fixedness; to make less
dense or compact; <as>as, to <ex>loosen</ex> a string, or a knot;
to <ex>loosen</ex> a rock in the earth.</as></def>

<q>After a year's rooting, then shaking doth the tree good by
<qex>loosening</qex> of the earth.</q>
<qau>Bacon.</qau>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>To free from restraint; to set at
liberty..</def>

<q>It <qex>loosens</qex> his hands, and assists his
understanding.</q>
<qau>Dryden.</qau>

<sn>3.</sn> <def>To remove costiveness from; to facilitate or
increase the alvine discharges of.</def>

<au>Bacon.</au>

<hw>Loos"en</hw>, <pos>v. i.</pos> <def>To become loose; to
become less tight, firm, or compact.</def>

<au>S. Sharp.</au>

<hw>Loos"en*er</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <def>One who, or
that which, loosens.</def>

<hw>Loose"ness</hw>, <pos>n.</pos> <def>The state, condition, or
quality, of being loose; <as>as, the <ex>looseness</ex> of a
cord; <ex>looseness</ex> of style; <ex>looseness</ex> of morals
or of principles.</as></def>

<hw>\'d8Lo*phi"o*mys</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[NL.,
