<hw>Lord</hw>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[OE. <ets>lord</ets>,
<ets>laverd</ets>, <ets>loverd</ets>, AS. <ets>hl\'beford</ets>,
for <ets>hl\'befweard</ets>, i. e., bread keeper;
<ets>hl\'bef</ets> bread, loaf + <ets>weardian</ets> to look
after, to take care of, to ward. See <er>Loaf</er>, and
<er>Ward</er> to guard, and cf. <er>Laird</er>,
<er>Lady</er>.]</ety> <sn>1.</sn> <def>One who has power and
authority; a master; a ruler; a governor; a prince; a proprietor,
as of a manor.</def>

<q>But now I was the <qex>lord</qex>
Of this fair mansion.</q>
<qau>Shak.</qau>

<q>Man over men
He made not <qex>lord</qex>.</q>
<qau>Milton.</qau>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>A titled nobleman., whether a peer of the realm
or not; a bishop, as a member of the House of Lords; by courtesy;
the son of a duke or marquis, or the eldest son of an earl; in a
restricted sense, a boron, as opposed to noblemen of higher
rank.</def> <mark>[Eng.]</mark>

<sn>3.</sn> <def>A title bestowed on the persons above named; and
also, for honor, on certain official persons; <as>as,
<ex>lord</ex> advocate, <ex>lord</ex> chamberlain, <ex>lord</ex>
chancellor, <ex>lord</ex> chief justice, etc.</as></def>
<mark>[Eng.]</mark>

<sn>4.</sn> <def>A husband.</def> \'bdMy <xex>lord</xex> being
old also.\'b8

<au>Gen. xviii. 12.</au>

<q>Thou worthy <qex>lord</qex>
Of that unworthy wife that greeteth thee.</q>
<qau>Shak.</qau>

<sn>5.</sn> <fld>(Feudal Law)</fld> <def>One of whom a fee or
estate is held; the male owner of feudal land; <as>as, the
<ex>lord</ex> of the soil; the <ex>lord</ex> of the
manor.</as></def>

<sn>6.</sn> <def>The Supreme Being; Jehovah.</def>

<note><hand/ When <xex>Lord</xex>, in the Old Testament, is
printed in small capitals, it is usually equivalent to
<xex>Jehovah</xex>, and might, with more propriety, be so
rendered.</note>

<sn>7.</sn> <def>The Savior; Jesus Christ.</def>

<cs><col>House of Lords</col>, <cd>one of the constituent parts
of the British Parliament, consisting of the lords spiritual and
temporal.</cd> -- <mcol><col>Lord high chancellor</col>,
<col>Lord high constable</col></mcol>, <cd>etc. See
<er>Chancellor</er>, <er>Constable</er>, etc.</cd> -- <col>Lord
justice clerk</col>, <cd>the second in rank of the two highest
judges of the Supreme Court of Scotland.</cd> -- <mcol><col>Lord
justice general</col>, <or/ <col>Lord president</col></mcol>,
<cd>the highest in rank of the judges of the Supreme Court of
Scotland.</cd> -- <col>Lord keeper</col>, <cd>an ancient officer
of the English crown, who had the custody of the king's great
seal, with authority to affix it to public documents. The office
is now merged in that of the chancellor.</cd> -- <col>Lord
lieutenant</col>, <cd>a representative of British royalty: the
<stype>lord lieutenant of Ireland</stype> being the
representative of royalty there, and exercising supreme
administrative authority; the <stype>lord lieutenant of a
county</stype> being a deputy to manage its military concerns,
and also to nominate to the chancellor the justices of the peace
for that county.</cd> -- <col>Lord of misrule</col>, <cd>the
master of the revels at Christmas in a nobleman's or other great
house. <au>Eng. Cyc</au>.</cd> -- <col>Lords spiritual</col>,
<cd>the archbishops and bishops who have seats in the House of
Lords.</cd> -- <col>Lords temporal</col>, <cd>the peers of
England; also, sixteen representative peers of Scotland, and
twenty-eight representatives of the Irish peerage.</cd> --
<col>Our lord</col>, <cd>Jesus Christ; the Savior.</cd> --
<col>The Lord's Day</col>, <cd>Sunday; the Christian Sabbath, on
which the Lord Jesus rose from the dead.</cd> -- <col>The Lord's
Prayer</col>, <cd>the prayer which Jesus taught his disciples.
<au>Matt. vi. 9-13</au>.</cd> -- <col>The Lord's Supper</col>.
<sd>(a)</sd> <cd>The paschal supper partaken of by Jesus the
night before his crucifixion</cd>. <sd>(b)</sd> <cd>The sacrament
of the eucharist; the holy communion.</cd> -- <col>The Lord's
Table</col>. <sd>(a)</sd> <cd>The altar or table from which the
sacrament is dispensed</cd>. <sd>(b)</sd> <cd>The sacrament
itself.</cd></cs>

<hw>Lord</hw>, <pos>v. t.</pos> <sn>1.</sn> <def>To invest with
the dignity, power, and privileges of a lord.</def>
<mark>[R.]</mark>

<au>Shak.</au>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>To rule or preside over as a lord.</def>
<mark>[R.]</mark>

<hw>Lord</hw>, <pos>v. i.</pos> <wordforms>[<pos>imp. & p.
p.</pos> <er>Lorded</er>; <pos>p. pr. & vb. n.</pos>
<er>Lording</er>.]</wordforms> <def>To play the lord; to
domineer; to rule with arbitrary or despotic sway; -- sometimes
with <ptcl>over</ptcl>; and sometimes with <ptcl>it</ptcl> in the
manner of a transitive verb.</def>

<q>The whiles she <qex>lordeth</qex> in licentious bliss.</q>
<qau>Spenser.</qau>

<q>I see them <qex>lording</qex> it in London streets.</q>
<qau>Shak.</qau>

<q>And <qex>lorded</qex> over them whom now they serve.</q>
<qau>Milton.</qau>

<hw>Lord"ing</hw>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[<ets>Lord</ets> +
<ets>-ing</ets>, 3.]</ety> <sn>1.</sn> <def>The son of a lord; a
person of noble lineage.</def> <mark>[Obs.]</mark>

<au>Spenser.</au>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>A little lord; a lordling; a lord, in contempt
or ridicule.</def> <mark>[Obs.]</mark>

<au>Swift.</au>

<note><hand/ In the plural, a common ancient mode of address
equivalent to \'bdSirs\'b8 or \'bdMy masters.\'b8</note>

<q>Therefore, <qex>lordings</qex> all, I you beseech.</q>
<qau>Chaucer.</qau>

<hw>Lord"kin</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <def>A little
lord.</def>

<au>Thackeray.</au>

<hw>Lord"like`</hw>, <pos>a.</pos> <ety>[2d <ets>lord +
like</ets>. Cf. <er>Lordly</er>.]</ety>

<sn>1.</sn> <def>Befitting or like a lord; lordly.</def>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>Haughty; proud; insolent; arrogant.</def>

<hw>Lord"li*ness</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[From
<er>Lordly</er>.]</ety> <def>The state or quality of being
lordly.</def>

<au>Shak.</au>

<hw>Lord"ling</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos>
<ety>[<ets>Lord</ets> + <ets>-ling</ets>.]</ety> <def>A little or
insignificant lord.</def>

<au>Goldsmith.</au>

<hw>Lord"ly</hw>, <pos>a.</pos> <wordforms>[<pos>Compar.</pos>
<er>Lordlier</er> <pr>(?)</pr>; <pos>superl.</pos>
<er>Lordliest</er>.]</wordforms> <ety>[<ets>Lord</ets> +
<ets>-ly</ets>. Cf. <er>Lordlike</er>.]</ety> <sn>1.</sn>
<def>Suitable for a lord; of or pertaining to a lord; resembling
a lord; hence, grand; noble; dignified; honorable.</def>

<q>She brought forth butter in a <qex>lordly</qex> dish.</q>
<qau>Judges v. 25.</qau>

<q><qex>Lordly</qex> sins require <qex>lordly estates to support
them</qex>.</q>
<qau>South.</qau>

<q>The maidens gathered strength and grace
And presence, <qex>lordlier</qex> than before.</q>
<qau>Tennyson.</qau>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>Proud; haughty; imperious; insolent.</def>

<q>Lords are <qex>lordliest</qex> in their wine.</q>
<qau>Milton.</qau>

<syn>Syn. -- Imperious; haughty; overbearing; tyrannical;
despotic; domineering; arrogant. See <er>Imperious</er>.</syn>

<hw>Lord"ly</hw>, <pos>adv.</pos> <def>In a lordly manner.</def>

<hw>Lord*ol"a*try</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos>
<ety>[<ets>Lord</ets> + <ets>-olatry</ets>, as in
<ets>idolatry</ets>.]</ety> <def>Worship of, or reverence for, a
lord as such.</def> <mark>[Jocose]</mark>

<q>But how should it be otherwise in a country where
<qex>lordolatry</qex> is part of our creed ?</q>
<qau>Thackeray.</qau>

<hw>\'d8Lor*do"sis</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[NL.,
fr. Gr. <?/ , fr. <?/ bent so as to be convex in front.]</ety>
<fld>(Med.)</fld> <sd>(a)</sd> <def>A curvature of the spine
forwards, usually in the lumbar region.</def> <sd>(b)</sd>
<def>Any abnormal curvature of the bones.</def>

<hw>Lords" and La"dies</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>. <fld>(Bot.)</fld>
<def>The European wake-robin (<spn>Arum maculatum</spn>), --
those with purplish spadix the lords, and those with pale spadix
the ladies.</def>

<au>Dr. Prior.</au>

<hw>Lord"ship</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <sn>1.</sn>
<def>The state or condition of being a lord; hence (with
<xex>his</xex> or <xex>your</xex>), a title applied to a lord
(except an archbishop or duke, who is called <xex>Grace</xex>) or
a judge (in Great Britain), etc.</def>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>Seigniory; domain; the territory over which a
lord holds jurisdiction; a manor.</def>

<q>What lands and <qex>lordships</qex> for their owner know
My quondam barber.</q>
<qau>Dryden.</qau>

<sn>3.</sn> <def>Dominion; power; authority.</def>

<q>They which are accounted to rule over the Gentiles exercise
<qex>lordship</qex> over them.</q>
<qau>Mark x. 42.</qau>

<hw>Lore</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[F.
<ets>lore</ets>, L. <ets>lorum</ets> thong.]</ety>
<fld>(Zo\'94l.)</fld> <sd>(a)</sd> <def>The space between the eye
and bill, in birds, and the corresponding region in reptiles and
fishes.</def> <sd>(b)</sd> <def>The anterior portion of the
cheeks of insects.</def>

<hw>Lore</hw>, <pos><mark>obs.</mark> imp. & p. p.</pos> of
<er>Lose</er>. <ety>[See <er>Lose</er>.]</ety> <def>Lost.</def>
<-- irregular pos-ety-def format -->

<q>Neither of them she found where she them <qex>lore</qex>.</q>
<qau>Spenser.</qau>

<hw>Lore</hw>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[OE. <ets>lore</ets>,
<ets>lare</ets>, AS. <ets>l\'ber</ets>, fr. <ets>l<?/ran</ets> to
teach; akin to D. <ets>leer</ets> teaching, doctrine, G.
<ets>lehre</ets>, Dan. <ets>l\'91re</ets>, Sw.
<ets>l\'84ra</ets>. See <er>Learn</er>, and cf. <er>Lere</er>,
<pos>v. t.</pos>]</ety> <sn>1.</sn> <def>That which is or may be
learned or known; the knowledge gained from tradition, books, or
experience; often, the whole body of knowledge possessed by a
people or class of people, or pertaining to a particular subject;
<as>as, the <ex>lore</ex> of the Egyptians; priestly
<ex>lore</ex>; legal <ex>lore</ex>; folk<ex>lore</ex>.</as></def>
\'bdThe <xex>lore</xex> of war.\'b8

<au>Fairfax.</au>

<q>His fair offspring, nursed in princely <qex>lore</qex>.</q>
<qau>Milton.</qau>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>That which is taught; hence, instruction;
wisdom; advice; counsel.</def>

<au>Chaucer.</au>

<q>If please ye, listen to my <qex>lore</qex>.</q>
<qau>Spenser.</qau>

<sn>3.</sn> <def>Workmanship.</def> <mark>[Obs.]</mark>

<au>Spenser.</au>

<hw>\'d8Lo`rette"</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos>
<ety>[F.]</ety> <def>In France, a name for a woman who is
supported by her lovers, and devotes herself to idleness, show,
and pleasure; -- so called from the church of Notre Dame de
<xex>Lorette</xex>, in Paris, near which many of them
resided.</def>

<hw>Lo`ret*tine"</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <fld>(R. C.
Ch.)</fld> <def>One of a order of nuns founded in 1812 at
<ets>Loretto</ets>, in Kentucky. The members of the order (called
also <altname>Sisters of Loretto</altname>, or <altname>Friends
of Mary at the Foot of the Cross</altname>) devote themselves to
the cause of education and the care of destitute orphans, their
labors being chiefly confined to the Western United States.</def>

<hw>Lor`gnette"</hw> <pr>(?)</pr> <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[F.]</ety>
<def>An opera glass</def>; <pluf>pl.</pluf> <def>elaborate double

<hw>Lo*ri"ca</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos>; <plu>pl.
<plw>Loric\'91</plw> <pr>(#)</pr></plu>. <ety>[L., lit., a
corselet of thongs, fr. <ets>lorum</ets> thong.]</ety>
<sn>1.</sn> <fld>(Anc. Armor)</fld> <def>A cuirass, originally of
leather, afterward of plates of metal or horn sewed on linen or
the like.</def>

<sn>2.</sn> <fld>(Chem.)</fld> <def>Lute for protecting vessels
from the fire.</def>

<sn>3.</sn> <fld>(Zo\'94l.)</fld> <def>The protective case or
shell of an infusorian or rotifer</def>.

<hw>\'d8Lor`i*ca"ta</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n. pl.</pos>

<hw>Lor"i*cate</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>v. t.</pos>
<wordforms>[<pos>imp. & p. p.</pos> <er>Loricated</er>
<pr>(?)</pr>; <pos>p. pr. & vb. n.</pos> <er>Loricating</er>
<pr>(?)</pr>.]</wordforms> <ety>[L. <ets>loricatus</ets>, p. p.
of <ets>loricare</ets> to clothe in mail, to cover with
plastering, fr. <ets>lorica</ets> a leather cuirass, a
plastering, fr. <ets>lorum</ets> thong.]</ety> <def>To cover with

<hw>Lor"i*cate</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>a.</pos> <ety>[See
<er>Loricate</er>, <pos>v.</pos>]</ety> <def>Covered with a shell
or exterior made of plates somewhat like a coat of mail, as in

<hw>Lor"i*cate</hw>, <pos>n.</pos> <fld>(Zo\'94l.)</fld> <def>An
animal covered with bony scales, as crocodiles among reptiles,
and the pangolins among mammals.</def>

<hw>Lor`i*ca"tion</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[L.
<ets>loricatio</ets>.]</ety> <def>The act of loricating; the

<hw>Lor"i*keet</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos>
<fld>(Zo\'94l.)</fld> <def>Any one numerous species of small
brush-tongued parrots or lories, found mostly in Australia, New
Guinea and the adjacent islands, with some forms in the East
Indies. They are arboreal in their habits and feed largely upon
the honey of flowers. They belong to <spn>Trichoglossus</spn>,
<spn>Loriculus</spn>, and several allied genera.</def>

<mhw>{ <hw>Lor"i*mer</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <hw>Lor"i*ner</hw>
<pr>(?)</pr>, }</mhw> <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[OF. <ets>lormier</ets>,
<ets>loremier</ets>, fr. LL. <ets>loranum</ets> bridle, L.

<hw>Lo"ri*ot</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[F., fr. OF.

<hw>Lo"ris</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos>
<ety>[<ets>Loris</ets>, or <ets>lori</ets>, the indigenous East
Indian name.]</ety> <fld>(Zo\'94l.)</fld> <def>Any one of several
species of small lemurs of the genus <spn>Stenops</spn>. They
have long, slender limbs and large eyes, and are arboreal in
their habits. The slender loris (<spn>S. gracilis</spn>), of
Ceylon, in one of the best known species.</def> <altsp>[Written
also <asp>lori</asp>.]</altsp>

<hw>Lorn</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>a.</pos> <ety>[Strong p. p. of
<er>Lose</er>. See <er>Lose</er>, <er>Forlorn</er>.]</ety>
<sn>1.</sn> <def>Lost; undone; ruined.</def>
<mark>[Archaic]</mark>

<q>If thou readest, thou art <qex>lorn</qex>.</q>
<qau>Sir W. Scott.</qau>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>Forsaken; abandoned; solitary; bereft; <as>as, a
lone, <ex>lorn</ex> woman</as>.</def>

<mhw>{ <hw>Lor"rie</hw>, <hw>Lor"ry</hw>  }</mhw> <pr>(?)</pr>,
<pos>n.</pos>; <plu>pl. <plw>Lorries</plw> <pr>(#)</pr></plu>.
<ety>[Prob. from <ets>lurry</ets> to pull or lug.]</ety> <def>A
small cart or wagon, as those used on the tramways in mines to
carry coal or rubbish; also, a barrow or truck for shifting
baggage, as at railway stations.</def><-- (Brit.) now a motorized
vehicle, esp. a large one, for transporting freight, called
"truck" in the U.S. -->

<hw>Lo"ry</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos>; <plu>pl.
<plw>Lories</plw> <pr>(#)</pr></plu>. <ety>[Hind. & Malay.
<ets>l\'d4r\'c6</ets>, <ets>n\'d4r\'c6</ets>.]</ety>
<fld>(Zo\'94l.)</fld> <def>Any one of many species of small
parrots of the family Trichoglossid\'91, generally having the
tongue papillose at the tip, and the mandibles straighter and
less toothed than in common parrots. They are found in the East
Indies, Australia, New Guinea, and the adjacent islands.  They
feed mostly on soft fruits and on the honey of flowers.</def>

<note><hand/ The lory, or louri, of South Africa is the
white-crested plantain eater or turacou. See
<er>Turacou</er>.</note>

<hw>Los</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <def>Praise. See
<er>Loos</er>.</def> <mark>[Obs.]</mark>

<au>Chaucer.</au>

<hw>Los"a*ble</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>a.</pos> <def>Such as can
be lost.</def>

<hw>Los"ange</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <def>See
<er>Lozenge</er>.</def>

<hw>Lose</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>v. t.</pos>
<wordforms>[<pos>imp. & p. p.</pos> <er>Losing</er>
<pr>(?)</pr>.]</wordforms> <ety>[OE. <ets>losien</ets> to loose,
be lost, lose, AS. <ets>losian</ets> to become loose; akin to OE.
<ets>leosen</ets> to lose, p. p. <ets>loren</ets>,
<ets>lorn</ets>, AS. <ets>le\'a2san</ets>, <ets>p. p. loren</ets>
(in comp.), D. ver<ets>liezen</ets>, G. ver<ets>lieren</ets>,
Dan. for<ets>lise</ets>, Sw. f\'94r<ets>lisa</ets>,
f\'94r<ets>lora</ets>, Goth. fra<ets>liusan</ets>, also to E.
<ets>loose</ets>, a & v., L. <ets>luere</ets> to loose, Gr. <?/,
Skr. <ets>l<?/</ets> to cut. <root/127. Cf. <er>Analysis</er>,
<er>Palsy</er>, <er>Solve</er>, <er>Forlorn</er>,
<er>Leasing</er>, <er>Loose</er>, <er>Loss</er>.]</ety>

<sn>1.</sn> <def>To part with unintentionally or unwillingly, as
by accident, misfortune, negligence, penalty, forfeit, etc.; to
be deprived of; <as>as, to <ex>lose</ex> money from one's purse
or pocket, or in business or gaming; to <ex>lose</ex> an arm or a
leg by amputation; to <ex>lose</ex> men in battle.</as></def>

<q>Fair Venus wept the sad disaster
Of having <qex>lost</qex> her favorite dove.</q>
<qau>Prior.</qau>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>To cease to have; to possess no longer; to
suffer diminution of; <as>as, to <ex>lose</ex> one's relish for
anything; to <ex>lose</ex> one's health.</as></def>

<q>If the salt hath <qex>lost</qex> his savor, wherewith shall it
be salted ?</q>
<qau>Matt. v. 13.</qau>

<sn>3.</sn> <def>Not to employ; to employ ineffectually; to throw
away; to waste; to squander; <as>as, to <ex>lose</ex> a day; to
<ex>lose</ex> the benefits of instruction.</as></def>

<q>The unhappy have but hours, and these they
<qex>lose</qex>.</q>
<qau>Dryden.</qau>

<sn>4.</sn> <def>To wander from; to miss, so as not to be able to
and; to go astray from; <as>as, to <ex>lose</ex> one's
way</as>.</def>

<q>He hath <qex>lost</qex> his fellows.</q>
<qau>Shak</qau>

<sn>5.</sn> <def>To ruin; to destroy; as destroy; <as>as, the
ship was <ex>lost</ex> on the ledge</as>.</def>

<q>The woman that deliberates is <qex>lost</qex>.</q>
<qau>Addison.</qau>

<sn>6.</sn> <def>To be deprived of the view of; to cease to see
or know the whereabouts of; <as>as, he <ex>lost</ex> his
companion in the crowd</as>.</def>

<q>Like following life thro' creatures you dissect,
You <qex>lose</qex> it in the moment you detect.</q>
<qau>Pope</qau>.

<sn>7.</sn> <def>To fail to obtain or enjoy; to fail to gain or
win; hence, to fail to catch with the mind or senses; to miss;
<as>as, I <ex>lost</ex> a part of what he said</as>.</def>

<q>He shall in no wise <qex>lose</qex> his reward.</q>
<qau>Matt. x. 42.</qau>

<q>I fought the battle bravely which I <qex>lost</qex>,
And <qex>lost</qex> it but to Macedonians.</q>
<qau>Dryden.</qau>

<sn>8.</sn> <def>To cause to part with; to deprive of.</def>
<mark>[R.]</mark>

<q>How should you go about to <qex>lose</qex> him a wife he loves
with so much passion ?</q>
<qau>Sir W. Temple.</qau>

<sn>9.</sn> <def>To prevent from gaining or obtaining.</def>

<q>O false heart ! thou hadst almost betrayed me to eternal
flames, and <qex>lost</qex> me this glory.</q>
<qau>Baxter.</qau>

<cs><col>To lose ground</col>, <cd>to fall behind; to suffer
gradual loss or disadvantage.</cd> -- <col>To lose heart</col>,
<cd>to lose courage; to become timid. \'bdThe mutineers <xex>lost
heart<xex>.\'b8 <au>Macaulay</au>.</cd> -- <col>To lose one's
head</col>, <cd>to be thrown off one's balance; to lose the use
of one's good sense or judgment.</cd></cs>

<q>In the excitement of such a discovery, many scholars <qex>lost
their heads</qex>.</q>
<qau>Whitney.</qau>

-- <col>To lose one's self</col>. <sd>(a)</sd> <cd>To forget or
mistake the bearing of surrounding objects; as, <xex>to lose
one's self</xex> in a great city.</cd> <sd>(b)</sd> <cd>To have
the perceptive and rational power temporarily suspended; <as>as,
we <ex>lose ourselves</ex> in sleep</as></cd>. -- <col>To lose
sight of</col>. <sd>(a)</sd> <cd>To cease to see; as, <xex>to
lose sight of</xex> the land.</cd> <sd>(b)</sd> <cd>To overlook;
to forget; to fail to perceive; <as>as, he <ex>lost sight of</ex>
the issue</as></cd>.

<hw>Lose</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>v. i.</pos> <def>To suffer loss,
disadvantage, or defeat; to be worse off, esp. as the result of
any kind of contest.</def>

<q>We 'll . . . hear poor rogues
Talk of court news; and we'll talk with them too,
Who <qex>loses</qex> and who wins; who's in, who's out.</q>
<qau>Shak.</qau>

<hw>Los"el</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[From the root
of <ets>lose</ets>, <ets>loss</ets>. <?/. Cf.
<er>Lorel</er>.]</ety> <def>One who loses by sloth or neglect; a
worthless person; a lorel.</def> <mark>[Archaic]</mark>

<au>Spenser.</au>

<q>One sad <qex>losel</qex> soils a name for aye.</q>
<qau>Byron.</qau>

<hw>Los"el</hw>, <pos>a.</pos> <def>Wasteful; slothful.</def>

<hw>Los"en*ger</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[OF.
<ets>losengier</ets>, <ets>losengeor</ets>, fr.
<ets>losengier</ets> to deceive, flatter, <ets>losenge</ets>,
flattery, Pr. <ets>lauzenga</ets>, fr. L. <ets>laus</ets> praise.
Cf. <er>Lozenge</er>.]</ety> <def>A flatterer; a deceiver; a
cozener.</def> <mark>[Obs.]</mark>

<au>Chaucer.</au>

<q>To a fair pair of gallows, there to end their lives with
shame, as a number of such other <qex>losengers</qex> had
done.</q>
<qau>Holinshed.</qau>

<ety>[OF.]</ety> <def>Flattery; deceit; trickery.</def>

<au>South.</au>

<hw>Lo"sing</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>a.</pos> <ety>[See

<q>Amongst the many simoniacal that swarmed in the land, Herbert,
Bishop of Thetford, must not be forgotten; nick-named
<qex>Losing</qex>, that is, the Fratterer.</q>

<hw>Los"ing</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>a.</pos> <ety>[See

<qau>Herbert.</qau>

<hw>Loss</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[AS.
<ets>los</ets> loss, losing, fr. <ets>le\'a2san</ets> to lose.
<?/. See <er>Lose</er>, <pos>v. t.</pos>]</ety> <sn>1.</sn>
<def>The act of losing; failure; destruction; privation; <as>as,
the <ex>loss</ex> of property; <ex>loss</ex> of money by gaming;
<ex>loss</ex> of health or reputation.</as></def>

<q>Assured <qex>loss</qex> before the match be played.</q>
<qau>Shak.</qau>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>The state of losing or having lost; the
privation, defect, misfortune, harm, etc., which ensues from
losing.</def>

<q>Though thou repent, yet I have still the <qex>loss</qex>.</q>
<qau>Shak</qau>

<sn>3.</sn> <def>That which is lost or from which one has parted;
waste; -- opposed to <xex>gain</xex> or <xex>increase</xex>;
<as>as, the <ex>loss</ex> of liquor by leakage was
considerable</as>.</def>

<sn>4.</sn> <def>The state of being lost or destroyed;
especially, the wreck or foundering of a ship or other
vessel.</def>

<sn>5.</sn> <def>Failure to gain or win; <as>as, <ex>loss</ex> of
a race or battle</as>.</def>

<sn>6.</sn> <def>Failure to use advantageously; <as>as,
<ex>loss</ex> of time</as>.</def>

<sn>7.</sn> <fld>(Mil.)</fld> <def>Killed, wounded, and captured
persons, or captured property.</def>

<sn>8.</sn> <fld>(Insurance)</fld> <def>Destruction or diminution
of value, if brought about in a manner provided for in the
insurance contract (as destruction by fire or wreck, damage by
water or smoke), or the death or injury of an insured person;
also, the sum paid or payable therefor; <as>as, the
<ex>losses</ex> of the company this year amount to a million of
dollars</as>.</def>

<cs><col>To bear a loss</col>, <cd>to make a loss good; also, to
sustain a loss without sinking under it.</cd> -- <col>To be at a
loss</col>, <cd>to be in a state of uncertainty.</cd></cs>

<syn>Syn. -- Privation; detriment; injury; damage.</syn>

<hw>Loss"ful</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>a.</pos>
<def>Detrimental.</def> <mark>[Obs.]</mark>

<au>Bp. Hall.</au>

<hw>Loss"less</hw>, <pos>a.</pos> <def>Free from loss.</def>
<mark>[Obs.]</mark>

<au>Milton.</au>

<hw>Lost</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>a.</pos> <ety>[Prop. p. p. of
OE. <ets>losien</ets>. See <er>Lose</er>, <pos>v. t.</pos>]</ety>
<sn>1.</sn> <def>Parted with unwillingly or unintentionally; not
to be found; missing; <as>as, a <ex>lost</ex> book or
sheep</as>.</def>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>Parted with; no longer held or possessed;
<as>as, a <ex>lost</ex> limb; <ex>lost</ex> honor.</as></def>

<sn>3.</sn> <def>Not employed or enjoyed; thrown away; employed
ineffectually; wasted; squandered; <as>as, a <ex>lost</ex> day; a
<ex>lost</ex> opportunity or benefit.</as></def>

<sn>5.</sn> <def>Having wandered from, or unable to find, the
way; bewildered; perplexed; <as>as, a child <ex>lost</ex> in the
woods; a stranger <ex>lost</ex> in London.</as></def>

<sn>6.</sn> <def>Ruined or destroyed, either physically or
morally; past help or hope; <as>as, a ship <ex>lost</ex> at sea;
a woman <ex>lost</ex> to virtue; a <ex>lost</ex> soul.</as></def>

<sn>7.</sn> <def>Hardened beyond sensibility or recovery;
alienated; insensible; <as>as, <ex>lost</ex> to shame;
<ex>lost</ex> to all sense of honor.</as></def>

<sn>8.</sn> <def>Not perceptible to the senses; no longer
visible; <as>as, an island <ex>lost</ex> in a fog; a person
<ex>lost</ex> in a crowd.</as></def>

<sn>9.</sn> <def>Occupied with, or under the influence of,
something, so as to be insensible of external things; <as>as, to
be <ex>lost</ex> in thought</as>.</def>

<cs><col>Lost motion</col> <fld>(Mach.)</fld>, <cd>the difference
between the motion of a driver and that of a follower, due to the
yielding of parts or looseness of joints.</cd></cs>

<hw>Lot</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[AS.
<ets>hlot</ets>; akin to <ets>hle\'a2tan</ets> to cast lots, OS.
<ets>hl<?/t</ets> lot, D. <ets>lot</ets>, G. <ets>loos</ets>,
OHG. <ets>l<?/z</ets>, Icel. <ets>hlutr</ets>, Sw.
<ets>lott</ets>, Dan. <ets>lod</ets>, Goth. <ets>hlauts</ets>.
Cf. <er>Allot</er>, <er>Lotto</er>, <er>Lottery</er>.]</ety>

<sn>1.</sn> <def>That which happens without human design or
forethought; chance; accident; hazard; fortune; fate.</def>

<q>But save my life, which <qex>lot</qex> before your foot doth
lay.</q>
<qau>Spenser.</qau>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>Anything (as a die, pebble, ball, or slip of
paper) used in determining a question by chance, or without man's
choice or will; <as>as, to cast or draw <ex>lots</ex></as>.</def>

<q>The <qex>lot</qex> is cast into the lap, but the whole
disposing thereof is of the Lord.</q>
<qau>Prov. xvi. 33.</qau>

<q>If we draw <qex>lots</qex>, he speeds.</q>
<qau>Shak.</qau>

<sn>3.</sn> <def>The part, or fate, which falls to one, as it
were, by chance, or without his planning.</def>

<q>O visions ill foreseen! Each day's <qex>lot's</qex>
Enough to bear.</q>
<qau>Milton.</qau>

<q>He was but born to try
The <qex>lot</qex> of man -- to suffer and to die.</q>
<qau>Pope.</qau>

<sn>4.</sn> <def>A separate portion; a number of things taken
collectively; <as>as, a <ex>lot</ex> of stationery</as>; --
colloquially, sometimes of people; <as>as, a sorry <ex>lot</ex>;
a bad <ex>lot</ex>.</as></def>

<q>I, this winter, met with a very large <qex>lot</qex> of
English heads, chiefly of the reign of James I.</q>
<qau>Walpole.</qau>

<sn>5.</sn> <def>A distinct portion or plot of land, usually
smaller than a field; <as>as, a building <ex>lot</ex> in a
city</as>.</def>

<q>The defendants leased a house and <qex>lot</qex> in the city
of New York.</q>
<qau>Kent.</qau>

<sn>6.</sn> <def>A large quantity or number; a great deal;
<as>as, to spend a <ex>lot</ex> of money; <ex>lots</ex> of people
think so.</as></def> <mark>[Colloq.]</mark>

<q>He wrote to her . . . he might be detained in London by a
<qex>lot</qex> of business.</q>
<qau>W. Black.</qau>

<sn>7.</sn> <def>A prize in a lottery.</def> <mark>[Obs.]</mark>

<au>Evelyn.</au>

<cs><col>To cast in one's lot with</col>, <cd>to share the
fortunes of.</cd> -- <col>To cast lots</col>, <cd>to use or throw
a die, or some other instrument, by the unforeseen turn or
position of which, an event is by previous agreement
determined.</cd> -- <col>To draw lots</col>, <cd>to determine an
event, or make a decision, by drawing one thing from a number
whose marks are concealed from the drawer.</cd> -- <col>To pay
scot and lot</col>, <cd>to pay taxes according to one's ability.
See <er>Scot</er>.</cd></cs>

<hw>Lot</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>v. t.</pos> <wordforms>[<pos>imp.
& p. p.</pos> <er>Lotted</er> <pr>(?)</pr>; <pos>p. pr. & vb.
n.</pos> <er>Lotting</er> <pr>(?)</pr>.]</wordforms> <def>To
allot; to sort; to portion.</def> <mark>[R.]</mark>

<cs><mcol><col>To lot on</col> <or/ <col>upon</col></mcol>,
<cd>to count or reckon upon; to expect with pleasure.
<mark>[Colloq. U. S.]</mark></cd></cs>

<fld>(Bot.)</fld> <def>A large tree (<spn>Celtis
australis</spn>), found in the south of Europe. It has a hard
wood, and bears a cherrylike fruit. Called also <altname>nettle
tree</altname>.</def>

<au>Eng. Cyc.</au>

<hw>\'d8Lo*toph"a*gi</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n. pl.</pos>

<hw>Lo"tos</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[NL.]</ety>

<hw>Lot"ter*y</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos>; <plu>pl.
<plw>Lotteries</plw> <pr>(#)</pr></plu>. <ety>[<ets>Lot</ets> +
<ets>-ery</ets>, as in brewe<ets>ry</ets>,
bind<ets>ery</ets>.]</ety> <sn>1.</sn> <def>A scheme for the
distribution of prizes by lot or chance; esp., a gaming scheme in
which one or more tickets bearing particular numbers draw prizes,
and the rest of tickets are blanks. Fig. : An affair of
chance.</def>

<note><hand/ The laws of the United States and of most of the
States make lotteries illegal.</note><-- except those conducted
by the states themselves -->

<sn>2.</sn> <def>Allotment; thing allotted.</def>
<mark>[Obs.]</mark>

<au>Shak.</au>

<hw>Lot"to</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[F. <ets>loto
or</ets> It. <ets>lotto</ets>, prop., a lot; of German origin.
See <er>Lot</er>.]</ety> <def>A game of chance, played with
cards, on which are inscribed numbers, and any contrivance (as a
wheel containing numbered balls) for determining a set of numbers
by chance. The player holding a card having on it the set of
numbers drawn from the wheel takes the stakes after a certain
percentage of them has been deducted for the dealer. A variety of
<xex>lotto</xex> is called <stype>keno</stype>.</def>
<altsp>[Often written <asp>loto</asp>.]</altsp>

<hw>Lo"ture</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[L.
<ets>lotura</ets>. See <er>Lotion</er>.]</ety> <def>See
<er>Lotion</er>.</def> <mark>[Obs.]</mark>

<au>Holland.</au>

<hw>Lo"tus</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[L.
<ets>lotus</ets>, Gr. <?/. Cf. <er>Lote</er>.]</ety> <sn>1.</sn>
<fld>(Bot.)</fld> <sd>(a)</sd> <def>A name of several kinds of
water lilies; as <spn>Nelumbium speciosum</spn>, used in
religious ceremonies, anciently in Egypt, and to this day in
Asia; <spn>Nelumbium luteum</spn>, the American lotus; and
<spn>Nymph\'91a Lotus</spn> and <spn>N. c\'91rulea</spn>, the
respectively white-flowered and blue-flowered lotus of modern
Egypt, which, with <spn>Nelumbium speciosum</spn>, are figured on
its ancient monuments.</def> <sd>(b)</sd> <def>The
<xex>lotus</xex> of the <xex>lotuseaters</xex>, probably a tree
found in Northern Africa, Sicily, Portugal, and Spain
(<spn>Zizyphus Lotus</spn>), the fruit of which is mildly sweet.
It was fabled by the ancients to make strangers who ate of it
forget their native country, or lose all desire to return to
it.</def> <sd>(c)</sd> <def>The lote, or nettle tree. See
<er>Lote</er>.</def> <sd>(d)</sd> <def>A genus (<spn>Lotus</spn>)
of leguminous plants much resembling clover.</def>
<altsp>[Written also <asp>lotos</asp>.]</altsp>

<cs><col>European lotus</col>, <cd>a small tree (<spn>Diospyros
Lotus</spn>) of Southern Europe and Asia; also, its rather large
bluish black berry, which is called also the <altname>date
plum</altname>.</cd></cs>

<-- p. 871 -->

<sn>2.</sn> <fld>(Arch.)</fld> <def>An ornament much used in
Egyptian architecture, generally asserted to have been suggested
by the Egyptian water lily.</def>

<q>The mild-eyed melancholy <qex>Lotos-eaters</qex>.</q>

<hw>Loud</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>a.</pos>
<wordforms>[<pos>Compar.</pos> <er>Louder</er> <pr>(?)</pr>;
<pos>superl.</pos> <er>Loudest</er>.]</wordforms> <ety>[OE.
<ets>loud</ets>, <ets>lud</ets>, AS. <ets>hl<?/d</ets>; akin to
OS. <ets>hl<?/d</ets>, D. <ets>luid</ets>, OHG. <ets>l<?/t</ets>,
G. <ets>laut</ets>, L. <ets>-clutus</ets>, in
in<ets>clutus</ets>, in<ets>clitus</ets>, celebrated, renowned,
<ets>cluere</ets> to be called, Gr. <?/ heard, loud, famous, <?/
to hear, Skr. <ets><?/ru</ets>. <?/. Cf. <er>Client</er>,
<er>Listen</er>, <er>Slave</er> a serf.]</ety> <sn>1.</sn>
<def>Having, making, or being a strong or great sound; noisy;
striking the ear with great force; <as>as, a <ex>loud</ex> cry;
<ex>loud</ex> thunder.</as></def>

<q>They were instant with <qex>loud</qex> voices, requiring that
he might be crucified.</q>
<qau>Luke xxiii. 23.</qau>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>Clamorous; boisterous.</def>

<q>She is <qex>loud</qex> and stubborn.</q>
<qau>Prov. vii. 11.</qau>

<sn>3.</sn> <def>Emphatic; impressive; urgent; <as>as, a
<ex>loud</ex> call for united effort</as>.</def>
<mark>[Colloq.]</mark>

<sn>4.</sn> <def>Ostentatious; likely to attract attention;
gaudy; <as>as, a <ex>loud</ex> style of dress; <ex>loud</ex>
colors.</as></def> <mark>[Slang]</mark>

<syn>Syn. -- Noisy; boisterous; vociferous; clamorous;
obstreperous; turbulent; blustering; vehement.</syn>

<hw>Lounge</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>v. i.</pos>
<wordforms>[<pos>imp. & p. p.</pos> <er>Lounged</er>
<pr>(?)</pr>; <pos>p. pr. & vb. n.</pos> <er>Lounging</er>
<pr>(?)</pr>.]</wordforms> <ety>[OE. <ets>lungis</ets> a tall,
slow, awkward fellow, OF. <ets>longis</ets>, <ets>longin</ets>,
said to be fr. <ets>Longinus</ets>, the name of the centurion who
pierced the body of Christ, but with reference also to L.
<ets>longus</ets> long. Cf. <er>Long</er>, <pos>a.</pos>]</ety>
<def>To spend time lazily, whether lolling or idly sauntering; to
pass time indolently; to stand, sit, or recline, in an indolent
manner.</def>

<q>We <qex>lounge</qex> over the sciences, dawdle through
literature, yawn over politics.</q>
<qau>J. Hannay.</qau>

<hw>Lounge</hw>, <pos>n.</pos> <sn>1.</sn> <def>An idle gait or
stroll; the state of reclining indolently; a place of
lounging.</def>

<q>She went with Lady Stock to a bookseller's whose shop <?/erved
as a fashionable <qex>lounge</qex>.</q>
<qau>Miss Edgeworth.</qau>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>A piece of furniture resembling a sofa, upon
which one may lie or recline.</def>

<hw>Loun"ger</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <def>One who
lounges; ar idler.</def>

<def>See 1st <er>Loop</er>.</def>

<hw>\'d8Loup"-cer`vier"</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[F.
Cf. <er>Lusern</er>.]</ety> <fld>(Zo\'94l.)</fld> <def>The Canada
lynx. See <er>Lynx</er>.</def>

<hw>Loups</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n. pl.</pos>; <sing>sing.

<hw>\'d8Lour</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[Native

<hw>Louse</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos>; <plu>pl.
<plw>Lice</plw> <pr>(#)</pr></plu>. <ety>[OE. <ets>lous</ets>,
AS. <ets>l<?/s</ets>, pl. <ets>l<?/s</ets>; akin to D.
<ets>luis</ets>, G. <ets>laus</ets>, OHG. <ets>l<?/s</ets>, Icel.
<ets>l<?/s</ets>, Sw. <ets>lus</ets>, Dan. <ets>luus</ets>; perh.
so named because it is destructive, and akin to E.
<ets>lose</ets>, <ets>loose</ets>.]</ety> <fld>(Zo\'94l.)</fld>
<sn>1.</sn> <def>Any one of numerous species of small, wingless,
suctorial, parasitic insects belonging to a tribe
(<spn>Pediculina</spn>), now usually regarded as degraded
Hemiptera. To this group belong of the lice of man and other
mammals; <as>as, the head <ex>louse</ex> of man (<spn>Pediculus
capitis</spn>), the body <ex>louse</ex> (<spn>P.
vestimenti</spn>), and the crab <ex>louse</ex> (<spn>Phthirius
pubis</spn>), and many others</as>. See <cref>Crab louse</cref>,
<cref>Dog louse</cref>, <cref>Cattle louse</cref>, etc., under
<er>Crab</er>, <er>Dog</er>, etc.</def>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>Any one of numerous small mandibulate insects,
mostly parasitic on birds, and feeding on the feathers. They are
known as Mallophaga, or bird lice, though some occur on the hair
of mammals. They are usually regarded as degraded
Pseudoneuroptera. See <er>Mallophaga</er>.</def>

<sn>3.</sn> <def>Any one of the numerous species of aphids, or
plant lice. See <er>Aphid</er>.</def>

<sn>4.</sn> <def>Any small crustacean parasitic on fishes. See
<er>Branchiura</er>, and <er>Ichthvophthira</er>.</def>

<note><hand/ The term is also applied to various other parasites;
as, the whale <xex>louse</xex>, bee<xex>louse</xex>, horse
<xex>louse</xex>.</note>

<cs><col>Louse fly</col> <fld>(Zo\'94l.)</fld>, <cd>a parasitic
dipterous insect of the group Pupipara. Some of them are
wingless, as the bee louse.</cd> -- <col>Louse mite</col>
<fld>(Zo\'94l.)</fld>, <cd>any one of numerous species of mites
which infest mammals and birds, clinging to the hair and feathers
like lice. They belong to <spn>Myobia</spn>,
<spn>Dermaleichus</spn>, <spn>Mycoptes</spn>, and several other
genera.</cd></cs>

<hw>Louse</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>v. t.</pos> <def>To clean from
lice.</def> \'bdYou sat and <xex>loused</xex> him.\'b8

<au>Swift.</au>

<hw>Louse"wort`</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos>
<fld>(Bot.)</fld> <def>Any species of <spn>Pedicularis</spn>, a
genus of perennial herbs. It was said to make sheep that fed on
it lousy.</def>

<cs><col>Yellow lousewort</col> , <cd>a plant of the genus
<spn>Rhinanthus</spn>.</cd></cs>

<er>Lousy</er>.]</ety> <def>In a lousy manner; in a mean, paltry
manner; scurvily.</def> <mark>[Vulgar]</mark>

<hw>Lous"i*ness</hw>, <pos>n.</pos> <def>The state or quality of
being lousy.</def>

<hw>Lous"y</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>a.</pos> <sn>1.</sn>
<def>Infested with lice.</def>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>Mean; contemptible; <as>as, <ex>lousy</ex>
knave</as>.</def> <mark>[Vulgar]</mark><-- informal but
common(1950-96) -->

<q>Such <qex>lousy</qex> learning as this is.</q>
<qau>Bale.</qau>

<-- 3. very bad [RH2: "wretchedly bad"]. To feel lousy; to do a
lousy job. -->

<hw>Lout</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>v. i.</pos> <ety>[OE.

<hw>\'d8Lou*tou"</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[Native

<mhw>{ <hw>Lou"ver</hw>, <hw>Lou"vre</hw>  }</mhw> <pr>(?)</pr>,
<pos>n.</pos> <ety>[OE. <ets>lover</ets>, OF. <ets>lover</ets>,
<ets>lovier</ets>; <ets>or l'ouvert</ets> the opening, fr.
<ets>overt</ets>, <ets>ouvert</ets>, p. p. of <ets>ovrir</ets>,
<ets>ouvrir</ets>, to open, F. <ets>ouvrir</ets>. Cf.
<er>Overt</er>.]</ety> <fld>(Arch.)</fld> <def>A small lantern.
See <er>Lantern</er>, 2 (a)</def> <altsp>[Written also
<asp>lover</asp>, <asp>loover</asp>, <asp>lovery</asp>, and
<asp>luffer</asp>.]</altsp>

<-- 2. same as louver boards; (b) a set of slats resembling
louver boards, arranged in a vertical row and attached at each
slat end to a frame inserted in a door or window; the slats may
be made of wood, plastic, or metal, and the angle of inclination
of the slats may be adjustable simultaneously, to allow more or
less light or air into the enclosure.  -->

<cs><mcol><col>Louver boards</col> <or/
<col>boarding</col></mcol>, <cd>the sloping boards set to shed
rainwater outward in openings which are to be left otherwise
unfilled; as belfry windows, the openings of a louver, etc.</cd>
-- <col>Louver work</col>, <cd>slatted work.</cd></cs>

<hw>Lov"a*ble</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>a.</pos> <def>Having
qualities that excite, or are fitted to excite, love; worthy of
love.</def>

<q>Elaine the fair, Elaine the <qex>lovable</qex>,
Elaine, the lily maid of Astolat.</q>
<qau>Tennyson.</qau>

<hw>Lov"age</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[F.
<ets>liv\'8ache</ets>, fr. L. <ets>levisticum</ets>,
<ets>ligusticum</ets>, a plant indigenous to Liguria, lovage,
from <ets>Ligusticus</ets> Ligustine, Ligurian,
<ets>Liguria</ets> a country of Cisalpine Gaul.]</ety>
<fld>(Bot.)</fld> <def>An umbelliferous plant (<spn>Levisticum
officinale</spn>), sometimes used in medicine as an aromatic
stimulant.</def>

<hw>Love</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[OE.
<ets>love</ets>, <ets>luve</ets>, AS. <ets>lufe</ets>,
<ets>lufu</ets>; akin to E.<ets>lief</ets>, <ets>believe</ets>,
L. <ets>lubet</ets>, <ets>libet</ets>,it pleases, Skr.
<ets>lubh</ets> to be lustful. See <er>Lief</er>.]</ety>
<sn>1.</sn> <def>A feeling of strong attachment induced by that
which delights or commands admiration; pre\'89minent kindness or
devotion to another; affection; tenderness; <as>as, the
<ex>love</ex> of brothers and sisters</as>.</def>

<q>Of all the dearest bonds we prove
Thou countest sons' and mothers' <qex>love</qex>
Most sacred, most Thine own.</q>
<qau>Keble.</qau>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>Especially, devoted attachment to, or tender or
passionate affection for, one of the opposite sex.</def>

<q>He on his side
Leaning half-raised, with looks of cordial <qex>love</qex>
Hung over her enamored.</q>
<qau>Milton.</qau>

<sn>3.</sn> <def>Courtship; -- chiefly in the phrase <it>to make
love</it>, i. e., to court, to woo, to solicit union in
marriage.</def>

<q>Demetrius . . . 
Made <qex>love</qex> to Nedar's daughter, Helena,
And won her soul.</q>
<qau>Shak.</qau>

<sn>4.</sn> <def>Affection; kind feeling; friendship; strong
liking or desire; fondness; good will; -- opposed to
<xex>hate</xex>; often with <xex>of</xex> and an object.</def>

<q><qex>Love</qex>, and health to all.</q>
<qau>Shak.</qau>

<q>Smit with the <qex>love</qex> of sacred song.</q>
<qau>Milton.</qau>

<q>The <qex>love</qex> of science faintly warmed his breast.</q>
<qau>Fenton.</qau>

<sn>5.</sn> <def>Due gratitude and reverence to God.</def>

<q>Keep yourselves in the <qex>love</qex> of God.</q>
<qau>Jude 21.</qau>

<sn>6.</sn> <def>The object of affection; -- often employed in
endearing address.</def> \'bdTrust me, <xex>love</xex>.\'b8

<au>Dryden.</au>

<q>Open the temple gates unto my <qex>love</qex>.</q>
<qau>Spenser.</qau>

<sn>7.</sn> <def>Cupid, the god of love; sometimes, Venus.</def>

<q>Such was his form as painters, when they show
Their utmost art, on naked <qex>Lores</qex> bestow.</q>
<qau>Dryden.</qau>

<q>Therefore do nimble-pinioned doves draw <qex>Love</qex>.</q>
<qau>Shak.</qau>

<sn>8.</sn> <def>A thin silk stuff.</def> <mark>[Obs.]</mark>

<au>Boyle.</au>

<sn>9.</sn> <fld>(Bot.)</fld> <def>A climbing species of Clematis
(<spn>C. Vitalba</spn>).</def>

<sn>10.</sn> <def>Nothing; no points scored on one side; -- used
in counting score at tennis, etc.</def>

<q>He won the match by three sets to <qex>love</qex>.</q>
<qau>The Field.</qau>

<note><hand/ <xex>Love</xex> is often used in the formation of
compounds, in most of which the meaning is very obvious; as,
<xex>love-</xex>cracked, <xex>love-</xex>darting,
<xex>love-</xex>killing, <xex>love-</xex>linked,
<xex>love-</xex>taught, etc.</note>

<cs><col>A labor of love</col>, <cd>a labor undertaken on account
of regard for some person, or through pleasure in the work
itself, without expectation of reward.</cd> -- <col>Free
love</col>, <cd>the doctrine or practice of consorting with one
of the opposite sex, at pleasure, without marriage. See <er>Free
love</er>.</cd> -- <col>Free lover</col>, <cd>one who avows or
practices free love.</cd> -- <col>In love</col>, <cd>in the act
of loving; -- said esp. of the love of the sexes; <as>as, to be
<ex>in love<ex>; to fall <ex>in love<ex></as>.</cd> -- <col>Love
apple</col> <fld>(Bot.)</fld>, <cd>the tomato.</cd> -- <col>Love
bird</col> <fld>(Zo\'94l.)</fld>, <cd>any one of several species
of small, short-tailed parrots, or parrakeets, of the genus
<spn>Agapornis</spn>, and allied genera. They are mostly from
Africa. Some species are often kept as cage birds, and are
celebrated for the affection which they show for their
mates.</cd> -- <col>Love broker</col>, <cd>a person who for pay
acts as agent between lovers, or as a go-between in a sexual
intrigue. <au>Shak</au>.</cd> -- <col>Love charm</col>, <cd>a
charm for exciting love. <au>Ld. Lytton</au>.</cd> -- <col>Love
child</col>. <cd>an illegitimate child. <au>Jane
Austen</au>.</cd> -- <col>Love day</col>, <cd>a day formerly
appointed for an amicable adjustment of differences.
<mark>[Obs.]</mark> <au>Piers Plowman</au>.
<au>Chaucer</au>.</cd> -- <col>Love drink</col>, <cd>a love
potion; a philter. <au>Chaucer</au>.</cd> -- <col>Love
favor</col>, <cd>something given to be worn in token of
love.</cd> -- <col>Love feast</col>, <cd>a religious festival,
held quarterly by some religious denominations, as the Moravians
and Methodists, in imitation of the <xex>agap\'91<xex> of the
early Christians.</cd> -- <col>Love feat</col>, <cd>the gallant
act of a lover. <au>Shak</au>.</cd> -- <col>Love game</col>,
<cd>a game, as in tennis, in which the vanquished person or party
does not score a point.</cd> -- <col>Love grass</col>. <ety>[G.
<ets>liebesgras</ets>.]</ety> <fld>(Bot.)</fld> <cd>Any grass of
the genus <spn>Eragrostis</spn>.</cd> --
<col>Love-in-a-mist</col>. <fld>(Bot.)</fld> <sd>(a)</sd> <cd>An
herb of the Buttercup family (<spn>Nigella Damascena</spn>)
having the flowers hidden in a maze of finely cut bracts</cd>.
<sd>(b)</sd> <cd>The West Indian <spn>Passiflora f\'d2tida</spn>,
which has similar bracts.</cd> -- <col>Love-in-idleness</col>
<fld>(Bot.)</fld>, <cd>a kind of violet; the small
pansy.</cd></cs>

<q>A little western flower,
Before milk-white, now purple with love's wound;
And maidens call it <qex>love-in-idleness</qex>.</q>
<qau>Shak.</qau>

-- <col>Love juice</col>, <cd>juice of a plant supposed to
produce love.</cd> <au>Shak</au>. -- <col>Love knot</col>, <cd>a
knot or bow, as of ribbon; -- so called from being used as a
token of love, or as a pledge of mutual affection.
<au>Milman</au>.</cd> -- <col>Love lass</col>, <cd>a
sweetheart.</cd> -- <col>Love letter</col>, <cd>a letter of
courtship. <au>Shak</au>.</cd> -- <col>Love-lies-bleeding</col>
<fld>(Bot.)</fld>, <cd>a species of amaranth (<spn>Amarantus
melancholicus</spn>).</cd> -- <col>Love match</col>, <cd>a
marriage brought about by love alone.</cd> -- <col>Love
potion</col>, <cd>a compounded draught intended to excite love,
or venereal desire.</cd> -- <col>Love rites</col>, <cd>sexual
intercourse.</cd> <au>Pope</au> -- <col>Love scene</col>, <cd>an
exhibition of love, as between lovers on the stage.</cd> --
<col>Love suit</col>, <cd>courtship. <au>Shak</au>.</cd> --
<col>Of all loves</col>, <cd>for the sake of all love; by all
means. <mark>[Obs.]</mark> \'bdMrs. Arden desired him <xex>of all
loves</xex> to come back again.\'b8 <au>Holinshed</au>.</cd> --
<mcol><col>The god of love</col>, <or/ <col>Love
god</col></mcol>, <cd>Cupid.</cd> -- <col>To make love to</col>,
<cd>to express affection for; to woo. \'bdIf you will marry,
<xex>make</xex> your <xex>loves to</xex> me.\'b8
<au>Shak</au>.</cd> -- <col>To play for love</col>, <cd>to play a
game, as at cards, without stakes. \'bdA game at piquet <xex>for
love</xex>.\'b8 <au>Lamb</au>.</cd></cs>

<syn>Syn. -- Affection; friendship; kindness; tenderness;
fondness; delight.</syn>

<hw>Love</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>v. t.</pos>
<wordforms>[<pos>imp. & p. p.</pos> <er>Loved</er> <pr>(?)</pr>;
<pos>p. pr. & vb. n.</pos> <er>Loving</er>.]</wordforms>
<ety>[AS. <ets>lufian</ets>. <?/. See <er>Love</er>,
<pos>n.</pos>]</ety> <sn>1.</sn> <def>To have a feeling of love
for; to regard with affection or good will; <as>as, to
<ex>love</ex> one's children and friends; to <ex>love</ex> one's
country; to <ex>love</ex> one's God.</as></def>

<q>Thou shalt <qex>love</qex> the Lord thy God with all thy
heart, and with all thy soul, and with all thy mind.</q>
<qau>Matt. xxii. 37.</qau>

<q>Thou shalt <qex>love</qex> thy neighbor as thy self.</q>
<qau>Matt. xxii. 39.</qau>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>To regard with passionate and devoted affection,
as that of one sex for the other.</def>

<sn>3.</sn> <def>To take delight or pleasure in; to have a strong
liking or desire for, or interest in; to be pleased with; to
like; <as>as, to <ex>love</ex> books; to <ex>love</ex>
adventures.</as></def>

<q>Wit, eloquence, and poetry.
Arts which I <qex>loved</qex>.</q>
<qau>Cowley.</qau>

<hw>Love</hw>, <pos>v. i.</pos> <def>To have the feeling of love;
to be in love.</def>

<qau>Spectator.</qau>

<hw>Love"lock`</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <def>A long lock
of hair hanging prominently by itself; an earlock; -- worn by men
of fashion in the reigns of Elizabeth and James I.</def>

<au>Burton.</au>

<q>A long <qex>lovelock</qex> and long hair he wore. <qex>Sir
W</qex>. <qex>Scott</qex>.</q>

<hw>Love"lorn`</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>a.</pos> <def>Forsaken by
one's love.</def>

<q>The <qex>lovelorn</qex> nightingale.</q>
<qau>Milton.</qau>

<hw>Love"ly</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>a.</pos>
<wordforms>[<pos>Compar.</pos> <er>Lovelier</er> <pr>(?)</pr>;
<pos>superl.</pos> <er>Loveliest</er>.]</wordforms> <ety>[AS.
<ets>luflic</ets>.]</ety> <sn>1.</sn> <def>Having such an
appearance as excites, or is fitted to excite, love; beautiful;
charming; very pleasing in form, looks, tone, or manner.</def>
\'bd<xex>Lovely</xex> to look on.\'b8 <au>Piers Plowman</au>.

<q>Not one so fair of face, of speech so <qex>lovely</qex>.</q>
<qau>Robert of Brunne.</qau>

<q>If I had such a tire, this face of mine
Were full as <qex>lovely</qex> as is this of hers.</q>
<qau>Shak.</qau>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>Lovable; amiable; having qualities of any kind
which excite, or are fitted to excite, love or friendship.</def>

<q>A most <qex>lovely</qex> gentlemanlike man.</q>
<qau>Shak.</qau>

<sn>3.</sn> <def>Loving; tender.</def> <mark>[Obs.]</mark> \'bdA
<xex>lovely</xex> kiss.\'b8

<au>Shak.</au>

<q>Many a <qex>lovely</qex> look on them he cast.</q>
<qau>Chaucer.</qau>

<sn>4.</sn> <def>Very pleasing; -- applied loosely to almost
anything which is not grand or merely pretty; <as>as, a
<ex>lovely</ex> view; a <ex>lovely</ex> valley; a <ex>lovely</ex>
melody.</as></def>

<q>Indeed these fields
Are <qex>lovely</qex>, <qex>lovelier</qex> not the Elysian
lawns.</q>
<qau>Tennyson.</qau>

<syn>Syn. -- Beautiful; charming; delightful; delectable;
enchanting; lovable; amiable.</syn>

<hw>Lov"er</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <sn>1.</sn> <def>One
who loves; one who is in love; -- usually limited, in the
singular, to a person of the male sex.</def>

<au>Gower.</au>

<q>Love is blind, and <qex>lovers</qex> can not see
The pretty follies that themselves commit.</q>
<qau>Shak.</qau>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>A friend; one strongly attached to another; one
who greatly desires the welfare of any person or thing; <as>as, a
<ex>lover</ex> of his country</as>.</def>

<q>I slew my best <qex>lover</qex> for the good of Rome.</q>
<qau>Shak.</qau>

<sn>3.</sn> <def>One who has a strong liking for anything, as
books, science, or music.</def> \'bdA <xex>lover</xex> of
knowledge.\'b8 <au>T. Burnet</au>.

<-- p. 872 -->

<qau>Dryden.</qau>

love.</def>

<hw>Low</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>v. i.</pos> <wordforms>[<pos>imp.
& p. p.</pos> <er>Lowed</er> <pr>(?)</pr>; <pos>p. pr. & vb.
n.</pos> <er>Lowing</er>.]</wordforms> <ety>[OE.
<ets>lowen</ets>, AS. <ets>hl<?/wan</ets>; akin to D.
<ets>loeijen</ets>, OHG. <ets>hl<?/jan</ets>,
<ets>hluojan</ets>.]</ety> <def>To make the calling sound of cows
and other bovine animals; to moo.</def>

<q>The <qex>lowing</qex> herd wind slowly o'er the lea.</q>
<qau>Gray.</qau>

<hw>Low</hw>, <pos>n.</pos> <def>The calling sound ordinarily
made by cows and other bovine animals.</def>

<q>Talking voices and the <qex>law</qex> of herds.</q>
<qau>Wordsworth.</qau>

<hw>Low</hw>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[AS. <ets>hl\'bew</ets>; akin to
Goth. <ets>hlaiw</ets> a grave, <ets>hlains</ets> a hill, and to
E. <ets>lean</ets> to incline.]</ety> <def>A hill; a mound; a
grave.</def> <mark>[Obs. except in place names.]</mark>

<au>Skeat.</au>

<hw>Low</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[Icel.
<ets>log</ets>, <ets>logi</ets>; akin to E. <ets>light</ets>,
<pos>n.</pos>]</ety> <def>Fire; a flame; a light.</def>
<mark>[Scot. & Prov. Eng.]</mark>

<hw>Low</hw>, <pos>v. i.</pos> <def>To burn; to blaze.</def>
<mark>[Prov. Eng. & Scot.]</mark>

<au>Burns.</au>

<hw>Low</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>a.</pos>
<wordforms>[<pos>Compar.</pos> <er>Lower</er> <pr>(?)</pr>;
<pos>superl.</pos> <er>Lowest</er>.]</wordforms> <ety>[OE.
<ets>low</ets>, <ets>louh</ets>, <ets>lah</ets>, Icel.
<ets>l\'begr</ets>; akin to Sw. <ets>l</ets>\'86<ets>g</ets>,
Dan. <ets>lav</ets>, D.  <ets>laag</ets>, and E. <ets>lie</ets>.
See <er>Lie</er> to be prostrate.]</ety>

<sn>1.</sn> <def>Occupying an inferior position or place; not
high or elevated; depressed in comparison with something else;
<as>as, <ex>low</ex> ground; a <ex>low</ex> flight.</as></def>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>Not rising to the usual height; <as>as, a man of
<ex>low</ex> stature; a <ex>low</ex> fence.</as></def>

<sn>3.</sn> <def>Near the horizon; <as>as, the sun is
<ex>low</ex> at four o'clock in winter, and six in
summer</as>.</def>

<sn>4.</sn> <def>Sunk to the farthest ebb of the tide; <as>as,
<ex>low</ex> tide</as>.</def>

<sn>5.</sn> <def>Beneath the usual or remunerative rate or
amount, or the ordinary value; moderate; cheap; <as>as, the
<ex>low</ex> price of corn; <ex>low</ex> wages.</as></def>

<sn>6.</sn> <def>Not loud; <as>as, a <ex>low</ex> voice; a
<ex>low</ex> sound.</as></def>

<sn>7.</sn> <fld>(Mus.)</fld> <def>Depressed in the scale of
sounds; grave; <as>as, a <ex>low</ex> pitch; a <ex>low</ex>
note.</as></def>

<sn>8.</sn> <fld>(Phon.)</fld> <def>Made, as a vowel, with a low
position of part of the tongue in relation to the palate; <as>as,
<?/ (<?/m), <?/ (all)</as>. See <xex>Guide to
Pronunciation</xex>, <sect/<sect/ 5, 10, 11.</def>

<sn>9.</sn> <def>Near, or not very distant from, the equator;
<as>as, in the <ex>low</ex> northern latitudes</as>.</def>

<sn>10.</sn> <def>Numerically small; <as>as, a <ex>low</ex>
number</as>.</def>

<sn>11.</sn> <def>Wanting strength or animation; depressed;
dejected; <as>as, <ex>low</ex> spirits; <ex>low</ex> in
spirits.</as></def>

<sn>12.</sn> <def>Depressed in condition; humble in rank; <as>as,
men of <ex>low</ex> condition; the <ex>lower</ex>
classes.</as></def>

<q>Why but to keep ye <qex>low</qex> and ignorant ?</q>
<qau>Milton.</qau>

<sn>13.</sn> <def>Mean; vulgar; base; dishonorable; <as>as, a
person of <ex>low</ex> mind; a <ex>low</ex> trick or
stratagem.</as></def>

<sn>14.</sn> <def>Not elevated or sublime; not exalted or
diction; <as>as, a <ex>low</ex> comparison</as>.</def>

<q>In comparison of these divine writers, the noblest wits of the
heathen world are <qex>low</qex> and dull.</q>
<qau>Felton.</qau>

<sn>15.</sn> <def>Submissive; humble.</def> \'bd<xex>Low</xex>
reverence.\'b8

<au>Milton.</au>

<sn>16.</sn> <def>Deficient in vital energy; feeble; weak;
<as>as, a <ex>low</ex> pulse; made <ex>low</ex> by
sickness.</as></def>

<sn>17.</sn> <def>Moderate; not intense; not inflammatory;
<as>as, <ex>low</ex> heat; a <ex>low</ex> temperature; a
<ex>low</ex> fever.</as></def>

<sn>18.</sn> <def>Smaller than is reasonable or probable; <as>as,
a <ex>low</ex> estimate</as>.</def>

<sn>19.</sn> <def>Not rich, high seasoned, or nourishing; plain;
simple; <as>as, a <ex>low</ex> diet</as>.</def>

<note><hand/ <xex>Low</xex> is often used in the formation of
compounds which require no special explanation; as,
<xex>low-</xex>arched, <xex>low-</xex> browed,
<xex>low-</xex>crowned, <xex>low-</xex>heeled,
<xex>low-</xex>lying, <xex>low-</xex>priced,
<xex>low-</xex>roofed, <xex>low-</xex>toned,
<xex>low-</xex>voiced, and the like.</note>

<cs><col>Low Church</col>. <cd>See <cref>High Church</cref>,
under <er>High</er>.</cd> -- <col>Low Countries</col>, <cd>the
Netherlands.</cd> -- <mcol><col>Low German</col>, <col>Low
Latin</col></mcol>, <cd>etc. See under <er>German</er>,
<er>Latin</er>, etc.</cd> -- <col>Low life</col>, <cd>humble
life.</cd> -- <col>Low milling</col>, <cd>a process of making
flour from grain by a single grinding and by siftings.</cd> --
<col>Low relief</col>. <cd>See <er>Bas-relief</er>.</cd> --
<col>Low side window</col> <fld>(Arch.)</fld>, <cd>a peculiar
form of window common in medi\'91val churches, and of uncertain
use. Windows of this sort are narrow, near the ground, and out of
the line of the windows, and in many different situations in the
building.</cd> -- <col>Low spirits</col>, <cd>despondency.</cd>
-- <col>Low steam</col>, <cd>steam having a low pressure.</cd> --
<col>Low steel</col>, <cd>steel which contains only a small
proportion of carbon, and can not be hardened greatly by sudden
cooling.</cd> -- <col>Low Sunday</col>, <cd>the Sunday next after
Easter; -- popularly so called.</cd> -- <col>Low tide</col>,
<cd>the farthest ebb of the tide; the tide at its lowest point;
low water.</cd> -- <col>Low water</col>. <sd>(a)</sd> <cd>The
lowest point of the ebb tide; a low stage of the in a river,
lake, etc.</cd>  <sd>(b)</sd> <fld>(Steam Boiler)</fld> <cd>The
condition of an insufficient quantity of water in the
boiler.</cd> -- <mcol><col>Low water</col> <col>alarm <or/
indicator</col></mcol> <fld>(Steam Boiler)</fld>, <cd>a
contrivance of various forms attached to a boiler for giving
warning when the water is low.</cd> -- <col>Low water mark</col>,
<cd>that part of the shore to which the waters recede when the
tide is the lowest. <au>Bouvier</au>.</cd> -- <col>Low
wine</col>, <cd>a liquor containing about 20 percent of alcohol,
produced by the first distillation of wash; the first run of the
still; -- often in the plural.</cd></cs>

<hw>Low</hw>, <pos>n.</pos> <fld>(Card Playing)</fld> <def>The
lowest trump, usually the deuce; the lowest trump dealt or
drawn.</def>

<hw>Low</hw>, <pos>adv.</pos> <sn>1.</sn> <def>In a low position
or manner; not aloft; not on high; near the ground.</def>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>Under the usual price; at a moderate price;
cheaply; <as>as, he sold his wheat <ex>low</ex></as>.</def>

<sn>3.</sn> <def>In a low mean condition; humbly; meanly.</def>

<sn>4.</sn> <def>In time approaching our own.</def>

<q>In that part of the world which was first inhabited, even as
<qex>low</qex> down as Abraham's time, they wandered with their
flocks and herds.</q>
<qau>Locke.</qau>

<sn>5.</sn> <def>With a low voice or sound; not loudly; gently;
<as>as, to speak <ex>low</ex></as>.</def>

<au>Addison.</au>

<q>The . . . odorous wind
Breathes <qex>low</qex> between the sunset and the moon.</q>
<qau>Tennyson.</qau>

<sn>6.</sn> <def>With a low musical pitch or tone.</def>

<q>Can sing both high and <qex>low</qex>.</q>
<qau>Shak.</qau>

<sn>7.</sn> <def>In subjection, poverty, or disgrace; <as>as, to
be brought <ex>low</ex> by oppression, by want, or by
vice</as>.</def>

<au>Spenser.</au>

<sn>8.</sn> <fld>(Astron.)</fld> <def>In a path near the equator,
so that the declination is small, or near the horizon, so that
the altitude is small; -- said of the heavenly bodies with
reference to the diurnal revolution; <as>as, the moon runs
<ex>low</ex>, that is, is comparatively near the horizon when on
or near the meridian</as>.</def>

<hw>Low</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>v. t.</pos> <def>To depress; to
lower.</def> <mark>[Obs.]</mark>

<au>Swift.</au>

<hw>Low"bell`</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos>
<ety>[<ets>Low</ets> a flame + <ets>bell</ets>.]</ety>
<sn>1.</sn> <def>A bell used in fowling at night, to frighten
birds, and, with a sudden light, to make them fly into a
net.</def>

<q>The fowler's <qex>lowbell</qex> robs the lark of sleep.</q>
<qau>King.</qau>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>A bell to be hung on the neck of a sheep.</def>

<q>A <qex>lowbell</qex> hung about a sheep's . . . neck.</q>
<qau>Howell.</qau>

<hw>Low"bell`</hw>, <pos>v. t.</pos> <def>To frighten, as with a
lowbell.</def>

<hw>Low"born`</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>a.</pos> <def>Born in a low
condition or rank; -- opposed to <xex>highborn</xex>.</def>

<hw>Low"bred`</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>a.</pos> <def>Bred, or like
one bred, in a low condition of life; characteristic or
indicative of such breeding; rude; impolite; vulgar; <as>as, a
<ex>lowbred</ex> fellow; a <ex>lowbred</ex> remark.</as></def>

<hw>Low"-church`</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>a.</pos> <def>Not
placing a high estimate on ecclesiastical organizations or forms;
-- applied especially to Episcopalians, and opposed to
<xex>high-church</xex>. See <cref>High Church</cref>, under
<er>High</er>.</def>

<hw>Low"-church`ism</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <def>The
principles of the low-church party.</def>

<hw>Low"-church`man</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos>; <plu>pl.
<plw>-men</plw> <pr>(<?/)</pr>.</plu> <def>One who holds
low-church principles.</def>

<hw>Low"-church`man*ship</hw>, <pos>n.</pos> <def>The state of

<hw>Low"er</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>a.</pos>
<def><pos>Compar.</pos> <it>of</it> <er>Low</er>,
<pos>a.</pos></def>
<-- irregular format -->

<hw>Low"er</hw>, <pos>v. t.</pos> <wordforms>[<pos>imp. & p.
p.</pos> <er>Lowered</er> <pr>(?)</pr>; <pos>p. pr. & vb.
n.</pos> <er>Lowering</er>.]</wordforms> <ety>[From <er>Low</er>,
<pos>a.</pos>]</ety> <sn>1.</sn> <def>To let descend by its own
weight, as something suspended; to let down; <as>as, to
<ex>lower</ex> a bucket into a well; to <xex>lower</xex> a sail
or a boat</as>; sometimes, to pull down; <as>as, to
<ex>lower</ex> a flag</as>.</def>

<q><qex>Lowered</qex> softly with a threefold cord of love
Down to a silent grave.</q>
<qau>Tennyson.</qau>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>To reduce the height of; <as>as, to
<ex>lower</ex> a fence or wall; to <ex>lower</ex> a chimney or
turret.</as></def>

<sn>3.</sn> <def>To depress as to direction; <as>as, to
<ex>lower</ex> the aim of a gun</as>; to make less elevated as to
object; <as>as, to <ex>lower</ex> one's ambition, aspirations, or
hopes</as>.</def>

<sn>4.</sn> <def>To reduce the degree, intensity, strength, etc.,
of; <as>as, to <ex>lower</ex> the temperature of anything; to
<ex>lower</ex> one's vitality; to <ex>lower</ex> distilled
liquors.</as></def>

<sn>5.</sn> <def>To bring down; to humble; <as>as, to
<ex>lower</ex> one's pride</as>.</def>

<sn>6.</sn> <def>To reduce in value, amount, etc. ; <as>as, to
<ex>lower</ex> the price of goods, the rate of interest,
etc.</as></def>

<hw>Low"er</hw>, <pos>v. i.</pos> <def>To fall; to sink; to grow
less; to diminish; to decrease; <as>as, the river
<ex>lowered</ex> as rapidly as it rose</as>.</def>

<hw>Low"er</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>v. i.</pos>
<wordforms>[<pos>imp. & p. p.</pos> <er>Lowered</er>
<pr>(?)</pr>; <pos>p. pr. & vb. n.</pos>
<er>Lowering</er>.]</wordforms> <ety>[OE. <ets>lowren</ets>,
<ets>luren</ets>; cf. D. <ets>loeren</ets>, LG. <ets>luren</ets>.
G. <ets>lauern</ets> to lurk, to be on the watch, and E.
<ets>leer</ets>, <ets>lurk</ets>.]</ety> <sn>1.</sn> <def>To be
dark, gloomy, and threatening, as clouds; to be covered with dark
and threatening clouds, as the sky; to show threatening signs of
approach, as a tempest.</def>

<q>All the clouds that <qex>lowered</qex> upon our house.</q>
<qau>Shak.</qau>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>To frown; to look sullen.</def>

<q>But sullen discontent sat <qex>lowering</qex> on her face.</q>
<qau>Dryden.</qau>

<hw>Low"er</hw>, <pos>n.</pos> <mark>[Obs.]</mark> <sn>1.</sn>
<def>Cloudiness; gloominess.</def>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>A frowning; sullenness.</def>

capitals and small capitals. See the Note under 1st

<hw>Low"land</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <def>Land which is

country; -- opposed to <xex>highland</xex>.</def>

<cs><col>The Lowlands</col>, <cd>Belgium and Holland; the
Netherlands; also, the southern part of Scotland.</cd></cs>

<hw>Low"land*er</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <def>A native or
inhabitant of the Lowlands, especially of the Lowlands of
Scotland, as distinguished from <xex>Highlander</xex>.</def>

<mhw>{ <hw>Low"li*hood</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <hw>Low"li*head</hw>
<pr>(?)</pr>, }</mhw> <pos>n.</pos> <def>A lowly state.</def>

<au>Tennyson.</au>

<hw>Low"li*ly</hw>, <pos>adv.</pos> <def>In a lowly place or
manner; humbly.</def> <mark>[Obs. or R.]</mark>

<q>Thinking <qex>lowlily</qex> of himself and highly of those
better than himself.</q>
<qau>J. C. Shairp.</qau>

<hw>Low"li*ness</hw>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[From
<er>Lowly</er>.]</ety> <sn>1.</sn> <def>The state or quality of
being lowly; humility; humbleness of mind.</def>

<q>Walk . . . with all <qex>lowliness</qex> and meekness.</q>
<qau>Eph. iv. 1, 2.</qau>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>Low condition, especially as to manner of
life.</def>

<q>The <qex>lowliness</qex> of my fortune has not brought me to
flatter vice.</q>
<qau>Dryden.</qau>

<hw>Low"-lived`</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>a.</pos>
<def>Characteristic of, or like, one bred in a low and vulgar
condition of life; mean dishonorable; contemptible; <as>as,
<ex>low-lived</ex> dishonesty</as>.</def>

<hw>Low"ly</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>a.</pos>
<wordforms>[<pos>Compar.</pos> <er>Lowlier</er> <pr>(?)</pr>;
<pos>superl.</pos> <er>Lowliest</er>.]</wordforms>
<ety>[<ets>Low</ets>, <pos>a.</pos> + <ets>-ly</ets>.]</ety>
<sn>1.</sn> <def>Not high; not elevated in place; low.</def>
\'bd<xex>Lowly</xex> lands.\'b8

<au>Dryden.</au>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>Low in rank or social importance.</def>

<q>One common right the great and <qex>lowly</qex> claims.</q>
<qau>Pope.</qau>

<sn>3.</sn> <def>Not lofty or sublime; humble.</def>

<q>These rural poems, and their <qex>lowly</qex> strain.</q>
<qau>Dryden.</qau>

<sn>4.</sn> <def>Having a low esteem of one's own worth; humble;
meek; free from pride.</def>

<q>Take my yoke upon you, and learn of me, for I am meek and
<qex>lowly</qex> in heart.</q>
<qau>Matt. xi. 29.</qau>

<hw>Low"ly</hw>, <pos>adv.</pos> <sn>1.</sn> <def>In a low
manner; humbly; meekly; modestly.</def> \'bdBe <xex>lowly</xex>
wise.\'b8

<au>Milton.</au>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>In a low condition; meanly.</def>

<q>I will show myself highly fed, and <qex>lowly</qex>
taught.</q>
<qau>Shak.</qau>

<hw>Low"-mind`ed</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>a.</pos> <def>Inclined
in mind to low or unworthy things; showing a base mind.</def>

<q><qex>Low-minded</qex> and immoral.</q>
<qau>Macaulay.</qau>

<q>All old religious jealousies were condemned as
<qex>low-minded</qex> infirmities.</q>
<qau>Bancroft.</qau>

<hw>Low"-mind`ed*ness</hw>, <pos>n.</pos> <def>The quality of
being lowminded; meanness; baseness.</def>

<cs><col>Low-pressure steam engine</col>, <cd>a steam engine in

even when steam at high pressure is used. See <er>Steam
engine</er>.</cd></cs>

<hw>Lox`o*drom"ic</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>a.</pos> <ety>[Gr. <?/
slanting, oblique + <?/ a running, course; cf. F.
<ets>loxodromique</ets>.]</ety> <def>Pertaining to sailing on
rhumb lines; <as>as, <ex>loxodromic</ex> tables</as>.</def>

<cs><mcol><col>Loxodromic curve</col> <or/ <col>line</col></mcol>
<fld>(Geom.)</fld>, <cd>a line on the surface of a sphere, which
always makes an equal angle with every meridian; the rhumb line.
It is the line on which a ship sails when her course is always in
the direction of one and the same point of the compass.</cd></cs>

<hw>Lox`o*drom"ics</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <def>The art
or method of sailing on the loxodromic or rhumb line.</def>

<hw>Lox*od"re*mism</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <def>The act
or process of tracing a loxodromic curve; the act of moving as if
in a loxodromic curve.</def>

<hw>Lox*od"ro*my</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[Cf. F.
<ets>loxodromic</ets>.]</ety> <def>The science of
loxodromics.</def> <mark>[R.]</mark>

<hw>Loy</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <def>A long, narrow

<hw>Loy"al</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>a.</pos> <ety>[F.
<ets>loyal</ets>, OF. <ets>loial</ets>, <ets>leial</ets>, L.
<ets>legalis</ets>, fr. <ets>lex</ets>, <ets>legis</ets>, law.
See <er>Legal</er>, and cf. <er>Leal</er>.]</ety>

<sn>1.</sn> <def>Faithful to law; upholding the lawful authority;
faithful and true to the lawful government; faithful to the
prince or sovereign to whom one is subject; unswerving in
allegiance.</def>

<q>Welcome, sir John ! But why come you in arms ? -
 To help King Edward in his time of storm,
As every <qex>loyal</qex> subject ought to do.</q>
<qau>Shak.</qau>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>True to any person or persons to whom one owes
fidelity, especially as a wife to her husband, lovers to each
other, and friend to friend; constant; faithful to a cause or a
principle.</def>

<q>Your true and <qex>loyal</qex> wife.</q>
<qau>Shak.</qau>

<q>Unhappy both, but <qex>loyal</qex>their loves.</q>
<qau>Dryden.</qau>

<hw>Loy"al*ist</hw>, <pos>n.</pos> <def>A person who adheres to
his sovereign or to the lawful authority; especially, one who
maintains his allegiance to his prince or government, and defends
his cause in times of revolt or revolution.</def>

<hw>Loy"al*ly</hw>, <pos>adv.</pos> <def>In a loyal manner;
faithfully.</def>

<hw>Loy"al*ness</hw>, <pos>n.</pos> <def>Loyalty.</def>
<mark>[R.]</mark>

<au>Stow.</au>

<hw>Loy"al*ly</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[Cf. F.
<ets>loyaute</ets>. See <er>Loyal</er>, and cf.
<er>Legality</er>.]</ety> <def>The state or quality of being
loyal; fidelity to a superior, or to duty, love, etc.</def>

<q>He had such <qex>loyalty</qex> to the king as the law
required.</q>
<qau>Clarendon.</qau>

<q>Not withstanding all the subtle bait
With which those Amazons his love still craved,
To his one love his <qex>loyalty</qex> he saved.</q>
<qau>Spenser.</qau>

<note><hand/ \'bd<xex>Loyalty</xex>  . . . expresses, properly,
that fidelity which one owes according to law, and does not
necessarily include that attachment to the royal person, which,
happily, we in England have been able further to throw into the
word.\'b8</note>

<au>Trench.</au>

<syn>Syn. -- Allegiance; fealty. See <er>Allegiance</er>.</syn>

<hw>Loz"enge</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[F.
<ets>lozange</ets>, <ets>losange</ets>; perh. the same as OF.
<ets>losenge</ets>f flattery, praise, the heraldic sense being
the oldest (cf. E. <ets>hatchment</ets>, <ets>blazon</ets>). Cf.
<er>Losenger</er>, <er>Laudable</er>.]</ety> <sn>1.</sn>
<fld>(Her.)</fld> <sd>(a)</sd> <def>A diamond-shaped figure
usually with the upper and lower angles slightly acute, borne
upon a shield or escutcheon. Cf. <er>Fusil</er>.</def>
<sd>(b)</sd> <def>A form of the escutcheon used by women instead
of the shield which is used by men.</def>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>A figure with four equal sides, having two acute
and two obtuse angles; a rhomb.</def>

<sn>3.</sn> <def>Anything in the form of lozenge.</def>

<sn>4.</sn> <def>A small cake of sugar and starch, flavored, and
often medicated. -- originally in the form of a lozenge.</def>

<cs><col>Lozenge coach</col>, <cd>the coach of a dowager, having
her coat of arms painted on a lozenge. <mark>[Obs.]</mark>
<xex>Walpole<xex>.</cd> -- <col>Lozenge-molding</col>
<fld>(Arch.)</fld>, <cd>a kind of molding, used in Norman
architecture, characterized by lozenge-shaped
ornaments.</cd></cs>

<-- p. 873 -->

<au>Swift.</au>

<hw>Lub"ber</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[Cf. dial. Sw.
<ets>lubber</ets>. See <er>Looby</er>, <er>Lob</er>.]</ety>
<def>A heavy, clumsy, or awkward fellow; a sturdy drone; a
clown.</def>

<q>Lingering <qex>lubbers</qex> lose many a penny.</q>
<qau>Tusser.</qau>

<cs><col>Land lubber</col>, <cd>a name given in contempt by
sailors to a person who lives on land.</cd> -- <col>Lubber
grasshopper</col> <fld>(Zo\'94l.)</fld>, <cd>a large, stout,
clumsy grasshopper; esp., <spn>Brachystola magna</spn>, from the
Rocky Mountain plains, and <spn>Romalea microptera</spn>, which
is injurious to orange trees in Florida.</cd> -- <col>Lubber's
hole</col> <fld>(Naut.)</fld>, <cd>a hole in the floor of the
\'bdtop,\'b8 next the mast, through which sailors may go aloft
without going over the rim by the futtock shrouds. It is
considered by seamen as only fit to be used by lubbers.
<au>Totten</au>.</cd> -- <mcol><col>Lubber's line</col>,
<col>point</col>, <or/ <col>mark</col></mcol>, <cd>a line or
point in the compass case indicating the head of the ship, and
consequently the course which the ship is steering.</cd></cs>

clumsy.</def>

<qau>Shak.</qau>

awkwardly.</def>

<hw>Lu"bri*cant</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>a.</pos> <ety>[L.
<ets>lubricans</ets>, p. pr. of <ets>lubricare</ets>, See
<er>Lubricate</er>.]</ety> <def>Lubricating.</def>

<hw>Lu"bri*cant</hw>, <pos>n.</pos> <def>That which lubricates;
specifically, a substance, as oil, grease, plumbago, etc., used
for reducing the friction of the working parts of
machinery.</def>

<hw>Lu"bri*cate</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>v. t.</pos> <ety>[L.
<ets>lubricatus</ets>, p. p. of <ets>lubricare</ets> to
lubricate. See <er>Lubric</er>.]</ety> <sn>1.</sn> <def>To make
smooth or slippery; <as>as, mucilaginous and saponaceous remedies
<ex>lubricate</ex> the parts to which they are
applied</as>.</def>

<au>S. Sharp.</au>

<q>Supples, <qex>lubricates</qex>, and keeps in play,
The various movements of this nice machine.</q>
<qau>Young.</qau>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>To apply a lubricant to, as oil or tallow.</def>

<hw>Lu`bri*ca"tion</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <def>The act
of lubricating; the act of making slippery.</def>

<hw>Lu*bric"i*ty</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[L.

<sn>1.</sn> <def>Smoothness; freedom from friction; also,

<au>Ray.</au>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>Slipperiness; instability; <as>as, the

image is thrown upon a plate of ground glass connected with the

<hw>\'d8Lu`cer*na"ri*a</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos>

margin. It attaches itself by a sucker at the base of the

<hw>Lu"cid</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>a.</pos> <ety>[L.
<ets>lucidus</ets>, fr. <ets>lux</ets>, <ets>lucis</ets>, light.
See <er>Light</er>, <pos>n.</pos>]</ety> <sn>1.</sn>
<def>Shining; bright; resplendent; <as>as, the <ex>lucid</ex>
orbs of heaven</as>.</def>

<q><qex>Lucid</qex>, like a glowworm.</q>
<qau>Sir I. Newton.</qau>

<q>A court compact of <qex>lucid</qex> marbles.</q>
<qau>Tennyson.</qau>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>Clear; transparent.</def> \'bd <xex>Lucid</xex>
streams.\'b8

<au>Milton.</au>

<sn>3.</sn> <def>Presenting a clear view; easily understood;
clear.</def>

<q>A <qex>lucid</qex> and interesting abstract of the debate.</q>
<qau>Macaulay.</qau>

<sn>4.</sn> <def>Bright with the radiance of intellect; not
darkened or confused by delirium or madness; marked by the
regular operations of reason; <as>as, a <ex>lucid</ex>
interval</as>.</def>

<syn>Syn. -- Luminous; bright; clear; transparent; sane;
reasonable. See <er>Luminous</er>.</syn>

<hw>Lu*cid"i*ty</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[Cf. F.
