<hw>Lu"ci*fer</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[L., bringing
light, <pos>n.</pos>, the morning star, fr. <ets>lux</ets>,
<ets>lucis</ets>, light + <ets>ferre</ets> to bring.]</ety>

<sn>1.</sn> <def>The planet Venus, when appearing as the morning
star; -- applied in Isaiah by a metaphor to a king of
Babylon.</def>

<q>How art thou fallen from heaven, O <qex>Lucifer</qex>, son of
the morning ! how art thou cut down to the ground which didst
weaken the nations !</q>
<qau>Is. xiv. 12.</qau>

<q>Tertullian and Gregory the Great understood this passage of
Isaiah in reference to the fall of Satan; in consequence of which
the name <qex>Lucifer</qex> has since been applied to, Satan.</q>
<qau>Kitto.</qau>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>Hence, Satan.</def>

<q>How wretched
Is that poor man that hangs on princes' favors! . . . 
When he falls, he falls like <qex>Lucifer</qex>,
Never to hope again.</q>
<qau>Shak.</qau>

<sn>3.</sn> <def>A match made of a sliver of wood tipped with a
combustible substance, and ignited by friction; -- called also
<altname>lucifer match</altname>, and
<altname>locofoco</altname>. See <er>Locofoco</er>.</def>

<sn>4.</sn> <fld>(Zo\'94l.)</fld> <def>A genus of free-swimming
macruran Crustacea, having a slender body and long
appendages.</def>

<hw>Lu`ci*fe"ri*an</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>a.</pos> <sn>1.</sn>
<def>Of or pertaining to Lucifer; having the pride of Lucifer;
satanic; devilish.</def>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>Of or pertaining to the Luciferians or their
leader.</def>

<hw>Lu`ci*fe"ri*an</hw>, <pos>n.</pos> <fld>(Eccl. Hist.)</fld>
<def>One of the followers of Lucifer, bishop of Cagliari, in the
fourth century, who separated from the orthodox churches because
they would not go as far as he did in opposing the Arians.</def>

<hw>Lu*cif"er*ous</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>a.</pos> <ety>[See
<er>Lucifer</er>.]</ety> <def>Giving light; affording light or
means of discovery.</def>

<au>Boyle.</au>

<hw>Lu*cif"er*ous*ly</hw>, <pos>adv.</pos> <def>In a luciferous
manner.</def>

<hw>Lu*cif"ic</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>a.</pos> <ety>[L.
<ets>lucificus</ets>; <ets>lux</ets>, <ets>lucis</ets>, light +
<ets>facere</ets> to make.]</ety> <def>Producing light.</def>

<au>Grew.</au>

<hw>Lu"ci*form</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>a.</pos> <ety>[L.
<ets>lux</ets>, <ets>lucis</ets>, light =
<ets>-form</ets>.]</ety> <def>Having, in some respects, the
nature of light; resembling light.</def>

<au>Berkeley.</au>

<hw>Lu*cif"ri*an</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>a.</pos>
<def>Luciferian; satanic.</def> <mark>[Obs.]</mark>

<au>Marston.</au>

<hw>Lu*cim"e*ter</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[L.
<ets>lux</ets>, <ets>lucis</ets>, light +
<ets>-meter</ets>.]</ety> <def>an instrument for measuring the
intensity of light; a photometer.</def>

<hw>Luck</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[Akin to D.
<ets>luk</ets>, <ets>geluk</ets>, G. <ets>gl\'81ck</ets>, Icel.
<ets>lukka</ets>, Sw. <ets>lycka</ets>, Dan. <ets>lykke</ets>,
and perh. to G. <ets>locken</ets> to entice. Cf. 3d
<er>Gleck</er>.]</ety> <def>That which happens to a person; an
event, good or ill, affecting one's interests or happiness, and
which is deemed casual; a course or series of such events
regarded as occurring by chance; chance; hap; fate; fortune;
often, one's habitual or characteristic fortune; <as>as, good,
bad, ill, or hard <ex>luck</ex></as>. <xex>Luck</xex> is often
used for <xex>good luck</xex>; <as>as, <ex>luck</ex> is better
than skill</as>.</def>

<q>If thou dost play with him at any game,
Thou art sure to lose; and of that natural <qex>luck</qex>,
He beats thee 'gainst the odds.</q>
<qau>Shak.</qau>

<cs><col>Luck penny</col>, <cd>a small sum given back for luck to
one who pays money.</cd> <mark>[Prov. Eng.]</mark> -- <col>To be
is luck</col></mcol>, <cd>to receive some good, or to meet with
some success, in an unexpected manner, or as the result of
circumstances beyond one's control; to be fortunate.</cd></cs>

<hw>Luck"i*ly</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>adv.</pos> <ety>[From
<er>Lucky</er>.]</ety> <def>In a lucky manner; by good fortune;
fortunately; -- used in a good sense; <as>as, they
<ex>luckily</ex> escaped injury</as>.</def>

<hw>Luck"i*ness</hw>, <pos>n.</pos> <sn>1.</sn> <def>The state or
quality of being lucky; <as>as, the <ex>luckiness</ex> of a man
or of an event</as>.</def>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>Good fortune; favorable issue or event.</def>

<au>Locke.</au>

<hw>Luck"less</hw>, <pos>a.</pos> <def>Being without luck;
unpropitious; unfortunate; unlucky; meeting with ill success or
bad fortune; <as>as, a <ex>luckless</ex> gamester; a
<ex>luckless</ex> maid.</as></def>

<q>Prayers made and granted in a <qex>luckless</qex> hour.</q>
<qau>Dryden.</qau>

-- <wordforms><wf>Luck"less*ly</wf>, <pos>adv.</pos> --
<wf>Lock"less*ness</wf>, <pos>n.</pos></wordforms>

<hw>Luck"y</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>a.</pos>
<wordforms>[<pos>Compar.</pos> <er>Luckier</er> <pr>(?)</pr>;
<pos>superl.</pos> <er>Luckiest</er>.]</wordforms> <sn>1.</sn>
<def>Favored by luck; fortunate; meeting with good success or
good fortune; -- said of persons; <as>as, a <ex>lucky</ex>
adventurer</as>.</def> \'bd <xex>Lucky</xex> wight.\'b8

<au>Spenser.</au>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>Producing, or resulting in, good by chance, or
unexpectedly; favorable; auspicious; fortunate; <as>as, a
<ex>lucky</ex> mistake; a <ex>lucky</ex> cast; a <ex>lucky</ex>
hour.</as></def>

<q>We doubt not of a fair and <qex>lucky</qex> war.</q>
<qau>Shak.</qau>

<syn>Syn. -- Successful; fortunate; prosperous; auspicious.</syn>

<hw>Luck`y proach"</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>. <fld>(Zo\'94l.)</fld>
<def>See <er>Fatherlasher</er>.</def>

<hw>Lu"cra*tive</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>a.</pos> <ety>[L.
<ets>lucrativus</ets>, fr. <ets>lucrari</ets> to gain, fr.
<ets>lucrum</ets> gain: cf. F. <ets>lucratif</ets>. See
<er>Lucre</er>.]</ety>

<sn>1.</sn> <def>Yielding lucre; gainful; profitable; making
increase of money or goods; <as>as, a <ex>lucrative</ex> business
or office</as>.</def>

<q>The trade of merchandise being the most <qex>lucrative</qex>,
may bear usury at a good rate.</q>
<qau>Bacon.</qau>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>Greedy of gain</def> <mark>[Obs.]</mark>

<q>Such diligence as the most part of our <qex>lucrative</qex>
lawyers do use, in deferring and prolonging of matters and
actions from term to term.</q>
<qau>Latimer.</qau>

<hw>Lu"cra*tive*ly</hw>, <pos>adv.</pos> <def>In a lucrative
manner.</def>

<hw>Lu"cre</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[F.
<ets>lucre</ets>, L. <ets>lucrum</ets>.]</ety> <def>Gain in money
or goods; profit; riches; -- often in an ill sense.</def>

<q>The lust of <qex>lucre</qex> and the dread of death.</q>
<qau>Pope.</qau>

profitable.</def> <mark>[Obs.]</mark>

<hw>Lu"cu*brate</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>v. i.</pos>
<wordforms>[<pos>imp. & p. p.</pos> <er>Lucubrated</er>
<pr>(?)</pr>; <pos>p. pr. & vb. n.</pos> <er>Lucubrated</er>
<pr>(?)</pr>.]</wordforms> <ety>[L. <ets>lucubratus</ets>, p. p.
of <ets>lucubrare</ets> to work by lamplight, fr. <ets>lux</ets>
light. See <er>Light</er>, <pos>n.</pos>]</ety> <def>To study by
candlelight or a lamp; to study by night.</def>

<hw>Lu"cu*brate</hw>, <pos>v. t.</pos> <def>To elaborate,
perfect, or compose, by night study or by laborious
endeavor.</def>

<hw>Lu`cu*bra"tion</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[l.
<ets>lucubratio</ets>;cf. F. <ets>lucubration</ets>.]</ety>
<sn>1.</sn> <def>The act of lucubrating, or studying by
candlelight; nocturnal study; meditation.</def>

<q>After long <qex>lucubration</qex> I have hit upon such an
expedient.</q>
<qau>Goldsmith.</qau>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>That which is composed by night; that which is
produced by meditation in retirement; hence (loosely) any
literary composition.</def>

<q>Thy <qex>lucubrations</qex> have been perused by several of
our friends.</q>
<qau>Tatler.</qau>

<hw>Lu"cu*bra`tor</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <def>One who
studies by night; also, one who produces lucubrations.</def>

<hw>Lu"cu*bra*to*ry</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>a.</pos> <ety>[L.
<ets>lucubratorius</ets>.]</ety> <def>Composed by candlelight, or
by night; of or pertaining to night studies; laborious or
painstaking.</def>

<au>Pope.</au>

<hw>Lu"cule</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[Dim. fr. L.
<ets>lux</ets>, <ets>lucis</ets>, light.]</ety>
<fld>(Astron.)</fld> <def>A spot or fleck on the sun brighter
than the surrounding surface.</def>

<hw>Lu"cu*lent</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>a.</pos> <ety>[L.

<mark>[Obs.]</mark>

<qau>B. Jonson.</qau>

<hw>Lu"cu*lent*ly</hw>, <pos>adv.</pos> <def>In a luculent

<hw>Lu*cul"lite</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[From
<ets>Lucullus</ets>, a Roman consul, famous for his great wealth

<def>A variety of black limestone, often polished for ornamental
purposes.</def>

<hw>\'d8Lu*cu"ma</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos>
<fld>(Bot.)</fld> <def>An American genus of sapotaceous trees
bearing sweet and edible fruits.</def>

<note><hand/ <xex>Lucuma mammosum</xex> is called <xex>natural
marmalade</xex> in the West Indies; L. <xex>Caimito</xex>, of
Peru, furnishes a delicious fruit called <xex>lucuma</xex> and
<xex>caimito</xex>.</note>

<hw>Lud"dite</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <def>One of a
number of riotous persons in England, who for six years (1811-17)
tried to prevent the use of labor-saving machinery by breaking
it, burning factories, etc.; -- so called from Ned
<xex>Lud</xex>, a half-witted man who some years previously had
broken stocking frames.</def>

<au>J. &  H. Smith. H. Martineau.</au>

<hw>Lu*dib"ri*ous</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>a.</pos> <ety>[L.
<ets>ludibrium</ets> mockery, derision, from <ets>ludere</ets> to
play, sport.]</ety> <def>Sportive; ridiculous; wanton.</def>
<mark>[Obs.]</mark>

<au>Tooker.</au>

<hw>Lu"di*bund</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>a.</pos> <ety>[L.
<ets>ludibundus</ets>.]</ety> <def>Sportive.</def>
<mark>[Obs.]</mark> -- <wordforms><wf>Lu"di*bund*ness</wf>,
<pos>n.</pos> <mark>[Obs.]</mark></wordforms>

<au>Dr. H. More.</au>

<hw>Lu"di*crous</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>a.</pos> <ety>[L.
<ets>ludicrus</ets>, or <ets>ludicer</ets>, from <ets>ludus</ets>
play, sport, fr. <ets>ludere</ets> to play.]</ety> <def>Adapted
to excite laughter, without scorn or contempt; sportive.</def>

<au>Broome.</au>

<q>A chapter upon German rhetoric would be in the same
<qex>ludicrous</qex> predicament as Van Troil's chapter on the
snakes of Iceland, which delivers its business in one summary
sentence, announcing, that snakes in Iceland -- there are
none.</q>
<qau>De Quincey.</qau>

<syn>Syn. -- Laughable; sportive; burlesque; comic; droll;
ridiculous.</syn> <usage> -- <er>Ludicrous</er>,
<er>Laughable</er>, <er>Ridiculous</er>. We speak of a thing as
<xex>ludicrous</xex> when it tends to produce laughter; as
<xex>laughable</xex> when the impression is somewhat stronger; as
<xex>ridiculous</xex> when more or less contempt is mingled with
the merriment created.</usage>

-- <wordforms><wf>Lu"di*crous*ly</wf>, <pos>adv.</pos> --
<wf>Lu"di*crous*ness</wf>, <pos>n.</pos></wordforms>

<hw>Lud"lam*ite</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[Named
after Mr. <ets>Ludlam</ets>, of London.]</ety> <fld>(Min.)</fld>
<def>A mineral occurring in small, green, transparent, monoclinic

<hw>Lud"low group`</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>. <fld>(Geol.)</fld> <def>A
subdivision of the British Upper Silurian lying below the Old Red
Sandstone; -- so named from the <xex>Ludlow</xex>, in Western
England. See the <xex>Chart</xex> of <er>Geology</er>.</def>

<hw>Lud"wig*ite</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[Named

<def>A borate of iron and magnesia, occurring in fibrous masses
of a blackish green color.</def>

<hw>\'d8Lu"es</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[L.]</ety>

<hw>Luff</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[OE.
<ets>lof</ets>, prob. a sort of timber by which the course of a
ship was directed, perh. a sort of paddle; cf. D. <ets>loef</ets>
luff, <ets>loeven</ets> to luff. The word is perh. akin to E.
<ets>glove</ets>. Cf. <er>Aloof</er>.]</ety> <fld>(Naut.)</fld>
<sd>(a)</sd> <def>The side of a ship toward the wind</def>.
<sd>(b)</sd> <def>The act of sailing a ship close to the
wind</def>. <sd>(c)</sd> <def>The roundest part of a ship's
bow</def>. <sd>(d)</sd> <def>The forward or weather leech of a
sail, especially of the jib, spanker, and other fore-and-aft
sails.</def>

<cs><col>Luff tackle</col>, <cd>a purchase composed of a double
and single block and fall, used for various purposes.
<xex>Totten<xex>.</cd> -- <col>Luff upon luff</col>, <cd>a luff
tackle attached to the fall of another luff tackle.</cd> <au>R.
H. Dana, Jr. </au></cs>

<hw>Luff</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>v. i.</pos>
<wordforms>[<pos>imp. & p. p.</pos> <er>Luffed</er> <pr>(?)</pr>;
<pos>p. pr. & vb. n.</pos> <er>Luffing</er>.]</wordforms>
<fld>(Naut.)</fld> <def>To turn the head of a vessel toward the
wind; to sail nearer the wind; to turn the tiller so as to make
the vessel sail nearer the wind.</def>

<cs><mcol><col>To luff round</col>, <or/ <col>To luff
alee</col></mcol>, <cd>to make the extreme of this movement, for
the purpose of throwing the ship's head into the wind.</cd></cs>

<hw>Lug</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[Sw.
<ets>lugg</ets> the forelock.]</ety> <sn>1.</sn> <def>The ear, or
its lobe.</def> <mark>[Scot. & Prov. Eng.]</mark>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>That which projects like an ear, esp. that by
which anything is supported, carried, or grasped, or to which a
support is fastened; an ear; <as>as, the <ex>lugs</ex> of a
kettle; the <ex>lugs</ex> of a founder's flask; the <ex>lug</ex>
(handle) of a jug.</as></def>

<sn>3.</sn> <fld>(Mach.)</fld> <def>A projecting piece to which
anything, as a rod, is attached, or against which anything, as a
wedge or key, bears, or through which a bolt passes, etc.</def>

<sn>4.</sn> <fld>(Harness)</fld> <def>The leather loop or ear by
which a shaft is held up.</def>

<sn>5.</sn> <fld>(Zo\'94l.)</fld> <def>The lugworm.</def>

<cs><col>Lug bolt</col> <fld>(Mach.)</fld>, <cd>a bolt
terminating in a long, flat extension which takes the place of a
head; a strap bolt.</cd></cs>

<hw>Lug</hw>, <pos>v. i.</pos> <wordforms>[<pos>imp. & p.
p.</pos> <er>Lugged</er> <pr>(?)</pr>; <pos>p. pr. & vb. n.</pos>
<er>Lugging</er> <pr>(?)</pr>.]</wordforms> <ety>[OE.
<ets>luggen</ets>, Sw. <ets>lugga</ets> to pull by the hair, fr.
<ets>lugg</ets> the forelock.]</ety> <def>To pull with force; to
haul; to drag along; to carry with difficulty, as something heavy
or cumbersome.</def>

<au>Dryden.</au>

<q>They must divide the image among them, and so <qex>lug</qex>
off every one his share.</q>
<qau>Collier.</qau>

<hw>Lug</hw>, <pos>v. i.</pos> <def>To move slowly and
heavily.</def>

<ex>lug</ex></as>.</def><mark>[Colloq.]</mark>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>Anything which moves slowly.</def>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>A measure of length, being 16<frac12/ feet; a

<au>Spenser.</au>

<cs><mcol><col>Chimney lug</col>, <or/ <col>Lug

<au>Whittier.</au>

<hw>Lug"gage</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[From 4th
<er>Lug</er>.]</ety> <def>That which is lugged; anything cumbrous
and heavy to be carried; especially, a traveler's trunks,
baggage, etc., or their contents.</def>

<q>I am gathering up my <qex>luggage</qex>, and preparing for my

<q>What do you mean,
To dote thus on such <qex>luggage</qex>!</q>

<hw>Lu*gu"bri*ous</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>a.</pos> <ety>[L.

<hw>Lug"worm`</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[<ets>1st
lug</ets> + <ets>worm</ets>.]</ety> <fld>(Zo\'94l.)</fld> <def>A
large marine annelid (<spn>Arenicola marina</spn>) having a row
of tufted gills along each side of the back. It is found
burrowing in sandy beaches, both in America and Europe, and is
used for bait by European fishermen. Called also
<altname>lobworm</altname>, and
<altname>baitworm</altname>.</def>

<hw>Luke</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>a.</pos> <ety>[Prob. fr.
<ets>lew</ets>, perh. influenced by AS. <ets>wl\'91c</ets> warm,
lukewarm, remiss. Cf. Lew.]</ety> <def>Moderately warm; not hot;
tepid.</def> -- <wordforms><wf>Luke"ness</wf>, <pos>n.</pos>
<mark>[Obs.]</mark></wordforms><-- = lukewarm.  Why not
synonymous? -->

<q>Nine penn'orth o'brandy and water <qex>luke</qex>.</q>
<qau>Dickens.</qau>

<hw>Luke"warm`</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>a.</pos> <ety>[See
<er>Luke</er>.]</ety> <def>Moderately warm; neither cold nor hot;
tepid; not ardent; not zealous; cool; indifferent.</def> \'bd
<xex>Lukewarm</xex> blood.\'b8 <au>Spenser</au>. \'bd
<xex>Lukewarm</xex> patriots.\'b8

<au>Addison.</au>

<q>An obedience so <qex>lukewarm</qex> and languishing that it
merits not the name of passion.</q>
<qau>Dryden.</qau>

<hw>Lull</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>v. t.</pos>
<wordforms>[<pos>imp. & p. p.</pos> <er>Lulled</er> <pr>(?)</pr>;
<pos>p. pr. & vb. n.</pos> <er>Lulling</er>.]</wordforms>
<ety>[Akin to OD. <ets>lullen</ets> to sing to sleep, G.
<ets>lullen</ets>, Dan. <ets>lulle</ets>, Sw. <ets>lulla</ets>;
all of imitative origin. Cf. <er>Loll</er>,
<er>Lollard</er>.]</ety> <def>To cause to rest by soothing
influences; to compose; to calm; to soothe; to quiet.</def> \'bd
To <xex>lull</xex> him soft asleep.\'b8

<au>Spenser.</au>

<q>Such sweet compulsion doth in music lie,
To <qex>lull</qex> the daughters of necessity.</q>
<qau>Milton.</qau>

<hw>Lull</hw>, <pos>v. i.</pos> <def>To become gradually calm; to
subside; to cease or abate for a time; <as>as, the storm
<ex>lulls</ex></as>.</def>

<hw>Lull</hw>, <pos>n.</pos> <sn>1.</sn> <def>The power or
quality of soothing; that which soothes; a lullaby.</def>
<mark>[R.]</mark>

<au>Young.</au>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>A temporary cessation of storm or
confusion.</def>

<hw>lull"a*by</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[From
<er>Lull</er>, <pos>v. t.</pos> ]</ety> <sn>1.</sn> <def>A song
to quiet babes or lull them to sleep; that which quiets.</def>

<au>Shak.</au>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>Hence: Good night; good-by.</def>
<mark>[Obs.]</mark>

<au>Shak.</au>

<hw>Lull"er</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <def>One who, or
that which, lulls.</def>

<hw>Lull"ing*ly</hw>, <pos>adv.</pos> <def>In a lulling manner;
soothingly.</def>

<hw>Lum</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[W.

Eng. & Scot.]</mark>

<au>Burns.</au>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>A ventilating chimney over the shaft of a

<sn>3.</sn> <def>A woody valley; also, a deep pool.</def>

<mhw>{ <hw>Lu"ma*chel</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>,
<hw>\'d8Lu`ma*chel"la</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, }</mhw> <pos>n.</pos>
<ety>[F. <ets>lumachelle</ets>, It. <ets>lumachella</ets>, fr.
<ets>lamachella</ets> a little snail, dim. of <ets>lumaca</ets> a
snail, fr. L. <ets>limax</ets>, <ets>-acis</ets>.]</ety>
<fld>(Min.)</fld> <def>A grayish brown limestone, containing
fossil shells, which reflect a beautiful play of colors. It is
also called <altname>fire marble</altname>, from its fiery
reflections.</def>

<hw>Lum*bag"i*nous</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>a.</pos> <def>Of or
pertaining to lumbago.</def>

<hw>Lum*ba"go</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[L., fr.
<ets>lumbus</ets> loin. See <er>Lumbar</er>.]</ety>
<fld>(Med.)</fld> <def>A rheumatic pain in the loins and the
small of the back.</def>

<mhw>{ <hw>Lum"bar</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <hw>Lum"bal</hw>
<pr>(?)</pr>, }</mhw> <pos>a.</pos> <ety>[L. <ets>lumbus</ets>
loin. See <er>Loin</er>.]</ety> <fld>(Anat.)</fld> <def>Of,
pertaining to, or near, the loins; <as>as, the <ex>lumbar</ex>
arteries</as>.</def>

<cs><col>Lumbar region</col> <fld>(Anat.)</fld>, <cd>the region
of the loin; specifically, a region between the hypochondriac and
ilias regions, and outside of the umbilical region.</cd></cs>

<hw>Lum"ber</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[Prob. fr.
<ets>Lombard</ets>, the Lombards being the money lenders and
pawnbrokers of the Middle Ages. A <ets>lumber</ets> room was,
according to Trench, originally a <ets>Lombard</ets> room, or
room where the Lombard pawnbroker stored his pledges. See
<er>Lombard</er>.]</ety> <sn>1.</sn> <def>A pawnbroker's shop, or
room for storing articles put in pawn; hence, a pledge, or
pawn.</def> <mark>[Obs.]</mark>

<q>They put all the little plate they had in the
<qex>lumber</qex>, which is pawning it, till the ships came.</q>
<qau>Lady Murray.</qau>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>Old or refuse household stuff; things cumbrous,
or bulky and useless, or of small value.</def>

<sn>3.</sn> <def>Timber sawed or split into the form of beams,
joists, boards, planks, staves, hoops, etc.; esp., that which is
smaller than heavy timber.</def> <mark>[U.S.]</mark>

<cs><col>Lumber kiln</col>, <cd>a room in which timber or lumber
is dried by artificial heat.</cd> <mark>[U.S.]</mark> --
<col>Lumber room</col>, <cd>a room in which unused furniture or
other lumber is kept.</cd> <mark>[U.S.]</mark> -- <col>Lumber
wagon</col>, <cd>a heavy rough wagon, without springs, used for
general farmwork, etc.</cd></cs>

<hw>Lum"ber</hw>, <pos>b. t.</pos> <wordforms>[<pos>imp. & p.
p.</pos> <er>Lumbered</er> <pr>(?)</pr>; <pos>p. pr. & vb.
n.</pos> <er>Lumbering</er>.]</wordforms> <sn>1.</sn> <def>To
heap together in disorder.</def> \'bd Stuff <xex>lumbered</xex>
together.\'b8

<au>Rymer.</au>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>To fill or encumber with lumber; <as>as, to
<ex>lumber</ex> up a room</as>.</def>

<hw>Lum"ber</hw>, <pos>v. i.</pos> <sn>1.</sn> <def>To move
heavily, as if burdened.</def>

<sn>2.</sn> <ety>[Cf. dial. Sw. <ets>lomra</ets> to
resound.]</ety> <def>To make a sound as if moving heavily or
clumsily; to rumble.</def>

<au>Cowper.</au>

<sn>3.</sn> <def>To cut logs in the forest, or prepare timber for
market.</def> <mark>[U.S.]</mark>

<hw>Lum"ber*er</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <def>One employed
in lumbering, cutting, and getting logs from the forest for
lumber; a lumberman.</def> <mark>[U.S.]</mark>

<q><qex>Lumberers</qex> have a notion that he (the woodpecker) is
harmful to timber.</q>
<qau>Lowell.</qau>

<hw>Lum"ber*ing</hw>, <pos>n.</pos> <def>The business of cutting
or getting timber or logs from the forest for lumber.</def>
<mark>[U.S.]</mark>

<hw>Lum"ber*man</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos>; <plu>pl.
<plw>Lumbermen</plw> <pr>(<?/)</pr>.</plu> <def>One who is
engaged in lumbering as a business or employment.</def>
<mark>[U.S.]</mark>

<hw>Lum`bo*sa"cral</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[L.
<ets>lumbus</ets> loin + E. <ets>sacral</ets>.]</ety>
<fld>(Anat.)</fld> <def>Of or pertaining to the loins and sacrum;
<as>as, the <ex>lumbosacral</ex> nerve, a branch of one of the
lumber nerves which passes over the sacrum</as>.</def>

<hw>Lum"bric</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[L.
<ets>lumbricus</ets>.]</ety> <fld>(Zo\'94l.)</fld> <def>An
earthworm, or a worm resembling an earthworm.</def>

<hw>Lum"bric*al</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>a.</pos> <ety>[Cf. F.
<ets>lombrical</ets>. See <er>Lumbric</er>.]</ety>
<fld>(Anat.)</fld> <def>Resembling a worm; <as>as, the
<ex>lumbrical</ex> muscles of the hands of the hands and
feet</as>.</def> -- <def2><pos>n.</pos> <def>A lumbrical
muscle.</def></def2>

<hw>Lum*bric"i*form</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>a.</pos> <ety>[L.
<ets>lumbricus</ets> worm + <ets>-form</ets>.]</ety>
<fld>(Zo\'94l.)</fld> <def>Resembling an earthworm;
vermiform.</def>

<hw>Lum"bri*coid</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>a.</pos>
<ety>[<ets>Lumbricus</ets> + <ets>-oid</ets>.]</ety>
<fld>(Zo\'94l.)</fld> <def>Like an earthworm; belonging to the
genus Lumbricus, or family <xex>Lumbricid\'91</xex>.</def>

<hw>\'d8Lum"bri*cus</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[L. See
<er>Lumbric</er>.]</ety> <fld>(Zo\'94l.)</fld> <def>A genus of

common earthworms. See <er>Earthworm</er>.</def>

<hw>Lu"mi*nant</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>a.</pos>
<def>Luminous.</def> <mark>[R.]</mark>

<hw>Lu"mi*na*ry</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos>; <plu>pl</plu>.
<plw>Luminaries</plw> <pr>(#)</pr>, <ety>[F.
<ets>luminaire</ets>, L. <ets>luminare</ets> a light or lamp,
which was lighted in the churches, a luminary, fr.
<ets>lumen</ets>, <ets>luminis</ets>, light, fr.
<ets>lucere</ets> to be light, to shine, <ets>lux</ets>,
<ets>lucis</ets>, light. See <er>Light</er>.]</ety>

<sn>1.</sn> <def>Any body that gives light, especially one of the
heavenly bodies.</def> \'bd Radiant <xex>luminary</xex>.\'b8

<au>Skelton.</au>

<q>Where the great <qex>luminary</qex> . . . 
Dispenses light from far.</q>
<qau>Milton.</qau>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>One who illustrates any subject, or enlightens
mankind; <as>as, Newton was a distinguished
<ex>luminary</ex></as>.</def>

<hw>Lu"mi*nate</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>v. t.</pos> <ety>[L.
<ets>luminatus</ets>, p. p. of <ets>luminare</ets> to illumine,
fr. <ets>lumen</ets> light. See <er>Limn</er>.]</ety> <def>To
illuminate.</def> <mark>[Obs.]</mark>

<hw>Lu`mi*na"tion</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos>
<def>Illumination.</def> <mark>[Obs.]</mark>

<hw>Lu"mine</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>v. i.</pos> <def>To
illumine.</def> <mark>[Obs.]</mark>

<au>Spenser.</au>

<hw>Lu`mi*nif"er*ous</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>a.</pos> <ety>[L.
<ets>lumen</ets> light + <ets>-ferous</ets>.]</ety>
<def>Producing light; yielding light; transmitting light; <as>as,
the <ex>luminiferous</ex> ether</as>.</def>

<hw>Lu`mi*nos"i*ty</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <def>The
quality or state of being luminous; luminousness.</def>

<hw>Lu"mi*nous</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>a.</pos> <ety>[L.
<ets>luminosus</ets>, fr. <ets>lumen</ets> light: cf. F.
<ets>lumineux</ets>. See <er>Luminary</er>,
<er>Illuminate</er>.]</ety>

<sn>1.</sn> <def>Shining; emitting or reflecting light;
brilliant; bright; <as>as, the is a <ex>luminous</ex> body; a
<ex>luminous</ex> color.</as></def>

<q>Fire burneth wood, making it . . . <qex>luminous</qex>.</q>
<qau>Bacon.</qau>

<q>The mountains lift . . . their lofty and <qex>luminous</qex>
heads.</q>
<qau>Longfellow.</qau>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>Illuminated; full of light; bright; <as>as, many
candles made the room <ex>luminous</ex></as>.</def>

<q>Up the staircase moved a <qex>luminous</qex> space in the
darkness.</q>
<qau>Longfellow.</qau>

<sn>3.</sn> <def>Enlightened; intelligent; also, clear;
intelligible; <as>as, a <ex>luminous</ex> mind</as>.</def> \'bd
<xex>Luminous</xex> eloquence.\'b8 <au>Macaulay</au>. \'bd A
<xex>luminous</xex> statement.\'b8

<au>Brougham.</au>

<cs><col>Luminous paint</col>, <cd>a paint made up with some
phosphorescent substance, as sulphide of calcium, which after
exposure to a strong light is luminous in the dark for a
time.</cd></cs>

<syn>Syn. -- Lucid; clear; shining; perspicuous.</syn>

<wf>Lu"mi*nous*ness</wf>, <pos>n.</pos></wordforms>

<hw>Lum"mox</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <def>A fat,

<hw>Lump</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[Cf. OD.
<ets>lompe</ets> piece, mass. Cf. <er>Lunch</er>.]</ety>
<sn>1.</sn> <def>A small mass of matter of irregular shape; an
irregular or shapeless mass; <as>as, a <ex>lump</ex> of coal; a
<ex>lump</ex> of iron ore.</as></def>  \'bd A <xex>lump</xex> of
cheese.\'b8 <au>Piers Plowman</au>. \'bd This <xex>lump</xex> of
clay.\'b8

<au>Shak.</au>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>A mass or aggregation of things.</def>

<sn>3.</sn> <fld>(Firearms)</fld> <def>A projection beneath the
breech end of a gun barrel.</def>

<cs><col>In the lump</col>, <col>In a lump</col>, <cd>the whole
together; in gross.</cd>

<q>They may buy them <qex>in the lump</qex>.</q>
<qau>Addison.</qau>

-- <col>Lump coal</col>, <cd>coal in large lumps; -- the largest
size brought from the mine.</cd> -- <col>Lump sum</col>, <cd>a
gross sum without a specification of items; as, to award a
<xex>lump sum</xex> in satisfaction of all claims and
damages.</cd> <-- (b) a single sum paid once in satisfaction of a
claim, as contrasted with the alternate choice of several
payments over a period of time.--></cs>

<hw>Lump</hw>, <pos>v. i.</pos> <wordforms>[<pos>imp. & p.
p.</pos> <er>Lumped</er> <pr>(?)</pr>; <pos>p. pr. & vb. n.</pos>
<er>Lumping</er>.]</wordforms> <sn>1.</sn> <def>To throw into a
mass; to unite in a body or sum without distinction of
particulars.</def>

<q>The expenses ought to be <qex>lumped</qex> together.</q>
<qau>Ayliffe.</qau>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>To take in the gross; to speak of
collectively.</def>

<q>Not forgetting all others, . . . whom for brevity, but out of
no resentment you, I <qex>lump</qex> all together.</q>
<qau>Sterne.</qau>

<sn>3.</sn> <def>To get along with as one can, although
displeased; <as>as, if he does n't like it, he can <ex>lump</ex>
it</as>.</def> <mark>[Law]</mark>

<-- lump together. v. combine (various items) and treat them as a
unit. -->

<-- lumpenproletariat -->

<hw>Lump"er</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[Cf. <er>Lamper
eel</er>.]</ety> <fld>(Zo\'94l.)</fld> <def>The European eelpout;
-- called also <altname>lumpen</altname>.</def>

<hw>Lump"er</hw>, <pos>n.</pos> <sn>1.</sn> <def>One who
lumps.</def>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>A laborer who is employed to load or unload
vessels when in harbor.</def>

<hw>Lump"fish`</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[From
<er>Lump</er>, on account of its bulkiness: cf. G. & D.
<ets>lump</ets>, F. <ets>lompe</ets>.]</ety>
<fld>(Zo\'94l.)</fld> <def>A large, thick, clumsy, marine fish
(<spn>Cyclopterus lumpus</spn>) of Europe and America. The color
is usually translucent sea green, sometimes purplish. It has a
dorsal row of spiny tubercles, and three rows on each side, but
has no scales. The ventral fins unite and form a ventral sucker
for adhesion to stones and seaweeds. Called also
<altname>lumpsucker</altname>, <altname>cock-paddle</altname>,
<altname>sea owl</altname>.</def>

<hw>Lump"ing</hw>, <pos>a.</pos> <def>Bulky; heavy.</def>

<au>Arbuthnot.</au>

<hw>Lump"ish</hw>, <pos>a.</pos> <def>Like a lump; inert; gross;
heavy; dull; spiritless.</def> \'bd <xex>Lumpish</xex>, heavy,
melancholy.\'b8

<au>Shak.</au>

-- <wordforms><wf>Lump"ish*ly</wf>, <pos>adv.</pos> --
<wf>Lump"ish*ness</wf>, <pos>n.</pos></wordforms>

<hw>Lump"suck`er</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos>
<fld>(Zo\'94l.)</fld> <def>The lumprish.</def>

<hw>Lump"y</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>a.</pos>
<wordforms>[<pos>Compar.</pos> <er>Lumpier</er> <pr>(?)</pr>;
<pos>superl.</pos> <er>Lumpiest</er>.]</wordforms> <def>Full of
lumps, or small compact masses.</def>

<hw>\'d8Lu"na</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[L.; akin to
<ets>lucere</ets> to shine. See <er>Light</er>, <pos>n.</pos>,
and cf. <er>Lune</er>.]</ety> <sn>1.</sn> <def>The moon.</def>

<sn>2.</sn> <fld>(Alchemy)</fld> <def>Silver.</def>

<cs><col>Luna cornea</col> <fld>(Old Chem.)</fld>, <cd>horn
silver, or fused silver chloride, a tough, brown, translucent
mass; -- so called from its resemblance to horn.</cd> <col>Luna
moth</col></mcol> <fld>(Zo\'94l.)</fld>, <cd>a very large and
beautiful American moth (<spn>Actias luna</spn>). Its wings are
delicate light green, with a stripe of purple along the front
edge of the anterior wings, the other margins being edged with
pale yellow. Each wing has a lunate spot surrounded by rings of
light yellow, blue, and black. The caterpillar commonly feeds on
the hickory, sassafras, and maple.</cd></cs>

<-- Fig. of Luna moth -->

<hw>Lu"na*cy</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos>; <plu>pl.
<plw>Lunacies</plw> <pr>(#)</pr></plu>. <ety>[See
<er>Lunatic</er>.]</ety> <sn>1.</sn> <def>Insanity or madness;
properly, the kind of insanity which is broken by intervals of
reason, -- formerly supposed to be influenced by the changes of
the moon; any form of unsoundness of mind, except idiocy; mental
derangement or alienation.</def>

<au>Brande. Burrill.</au>

<q>Your kindred shuns your house
As beaten hence by your strange <qex>lunacy</qex>.</q>
<qau>Shak.</qau>

<sn>2.</sn> A morbid suspension of good sense or judgment, as
through fanaticism.<pluf>

<au>Dr. H. More.</au>

<syn>Syn. -- Derangement; craziness; mania. See
<er>Insanity</er>.</syn>

<-- p. 875 -->

<hw>Lu"nar</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>a.</pos> <ety>[L.
<ets>lunaris</ets>, fr. <ets>luna</ets> the moon. See
<er>Luna</er>, and cf. <er>Lunary</er>.]</ety> <sn>1.</sn>
<def>Of or pertaining to the moon; <as>as, <ex>lunar</ex>
observations</as>.</def>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>Resembling the moon; orbed.</def>

<au>Dryden.</au>

<sn>3.</sn> <def>Measured by the revolutions of the moon; <as>as,
a <ex>lunar</ex> month</as>.</def>

<sn>4.</sn> <def>Influenced by the moon, as in growth, character,
or properties; <as>as, <ex>lunar</ex> herbs</as></def>.

<au>Bacon.</au>

<cs><col>Lunar caustic</col> <fld>(Med. Chem.)</fld>, <cd>silver
nitrate prepared to be used as a cautery; -- so named because
silver was called <xex>luna<xex> by the ancient alchemists.</cd>
-- <col>Lunar cycle</col>. <cd>Same as <cref>Metonic
cycle</cref>. See under <er>Cycle</er>.</cd> -- <col>Lunar
distance</col>, <cd>the angular distance of the moon from the
sun, a star, or a planet, employed for determining longitude by
the <cref>lunar method</cref>.</cd> -- <col>Lunar method</col>,
<cd>the method of finding a ship's longitude by comparing the
local time of taking (by means of a sextant or circle) a given
lunar distance, with the Greenwich time corresponding to the same
distance as ascertained from a nautical almanac, the difference
of these times being the longitude.</cd> -- <col>Lunar
month</col>. <cd>See <er>Month</er>.</cd> -- <col>Lunar
observation</col>, <cd>an observation of a lunar distance by
means of a sextant or circle, with the altitudes of the bodies,
and the time, for the purpose of computing the longitude.</cd> --
<col>Lunar tables</col>. <sd>(a)</sd> <fld>(Astron.)</fld>
<cd>Tables of the moon's motions, arranged for computing the
moon's true place at any time past or future</cd>. <sd>(b)</sd>
<fld>(Navigation)</fld> <cd>Tables for correcting an observed
lunar distance on account of refraction and parallax.</cd> --
<col>Lunar year</col>, <cd>the period of twelve lunar months, or
354 days, 8 hours, 48 minutes, and 34.38 seconds.</cd></cs>

<hw>Lu"nar</hw>, <pos>n.</pos> <sn>1.</sn> <fld>(Astron.)</fld>
<def>A lunar distance.</def>

<sn>2.</sn> <fld>(Anat.)</fld> <def>The middle bone of the
proximal series of the carpus; -- called also
<altname>semilunar</altname>, and
<altname>intermedium</altname>.</def>

<hw>Lu*na"ri*an</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[See
<er>Lunar</er>, <er>Luna</er>.]</ety> <def>An inhabitant of the
moon.</def>

<hw>Lu"na*ry</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>a.</pos> <ety>[Cf. F.
<ets>lunaire</ets>. See <er>Lunar</er>.]</ety> <def>Lunar.</def>
<mark>[Obs.]</mark>

<au>Fuller.</au>

<hw>Lu"na*ry</hw>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[Cf. F.
<ets>lunaire</ets>.]</ety> <fld>(Bot.)</fld> <sd>(a)</sd>
<def>The herb moonwort or \'bdhonesty\'b8.</def> <sd>(b)</sd>
<def>A low fleshy fern (<spn>Botrychium Lunaria</spn>) with
lunate segments of the leaf or frond.</def>

<mhw>{ <hw>Lu"nate</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <hw>Lu"na*ted</hw>
<pr>(?)</pr>, }</mhw> <pos>a.</pos> <ety>[L. <ets>lunatus</ets>
crescent-shaped, p. p. of <ets>lunare</ets> to bend like a
crescent, fr. <ets>luna</ets> the moon.]</ety>
<def>Crescent-shaped; <as>as, a <ex>lunate</ex> leaf; a
<ex>lunate</ex> beak; a <ex>lunated</ex> cross.</as></def>

<au>Gray.</au>

<hw>Lu"na*tic</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>a.</pos> <ety>[F.
<ets>lunatique</ets>, L. <ets>lunaticus</ets>, fr.
<ets>luna</ets> the moon. See <er>Lunar</er>.]</ety> <sn>1.</sn>
<def>Affected by lunacy; insane; mad.</def>

<q>Lord, have mercy on my son; for he is lunatic.</q>
<qau>Wyclif (Matt. xvii. 15).</qau>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>Of or pertaining to, or suitable for, an insane
person; evincing lunacy; <as>as, <ex>lunatic</ex> gibberish; a
<ex>lunatic</ex> asylum.</as></def>

<hw>Lu"na*tic</hw>, <pos>n.</pos> <def>A person affected by
lunacy; an insane person, esp. one who has lucid intervals; a
madman; a person of unsound mind.</def>

<q>The <qex>lunatic</qex>, the lover, and the poet,
Are of imagination all compact.</q>
<qau>Shak.</qau>

<hw>Lu*na"tion</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[Cf.
<er>Lunated</er>.]</ety> <def>The period of a synodic revolution
of the moon, or the time from one new moon to the next; varying
in length, at different times, from about 29<frac14/ to
29<frac56/ days, the average length being 29 d., 12h., 44m.,
2.9s.</def>

<hw>Lunch</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[Of uncertain
etymol. Cf. Prov. Eng. <ets>nunc</ets> a lump.]</ety> <def>A
luncheon; specifically, a light repast between breakfast and
dinner.</def>

<hw>Lunch</hw>, <pos>v. i.</pos> <wordforms>[<pos>imp. & p.
p.</pos> <er>Lunched</er> <pr>(?)</pr>; <pos>p. pr. & vb.
n.</pos> <er>Lunching</er>.]</wordforms> <def>To take
luncheon.</def>

<au>Smart.</au>

<hw>Lunch"eon</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[Prov. E.
<ets>luncheon</ets>, <ets>lunchion</ets>, <ets>lunshin</ets>, a
large lump of food, fr. <ets>lunch</ets>. See
<er>Lunch</er>.]</ety>

<sn>1.</sn> <def>A lump of food.</def> <mark>[Prov. Eng.]</mark>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>A portion of food taken at any time except at a
regular meal; an informal or light repast, as between breakfast
and dinner.</def>

<hw>Lunch"eon</hw>, <pos>v. i.</pos> <def>To take luncheon.</def>

<au>Beaconsfield.</au>

<hw>Lune</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[L.
<ets>luna</ets> moon: cf. F. <ets>lune</ets>. See
<er>Luna</er>.]</ety> <sn>1.</sn> <def>Anything in the shape of a
half moon.</def> <mark>[R.]</mark>

<sn>2.</sn> <fld>(Geom.)</fld> <def>A figure in the form of a
crescent, bounded by two intersecting arcs of circles.</def>

<sn>3.</sn> <def>A fit of lunacy or madness; a period of frenzy;
a crazy or unreasonable freak.</def> <mark>[Obs.]</mark>

<q>These dangerous, unsafe <qex>lunes</qex> i' the king.</q>
<qau>Shak.</qau>

<hw>Lu"net</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[See
<er>Lunette</er>.]</ety> <def>A little moon or satellite.</def>
<mark>[Obs.]</mark>

<au>Bp. Hall.</au>

<hw>Lu*nette"</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[F., dim. of
<ets>lune</ets> moon, L.<ets>luna</ets>. See <er>Lune</er> a
crescent.]</ety> <sn>1.</sn> <fld>(Fort.)</fld> <def>A fieldwork
consisting of two faces, forming a salient angle, and two
parallel flanks. See <er>Bastion</er>.</def>

<sn>2.</sn> <fld>(Far.)</fld> <def>A half horseshoe, which wants
the sponge.</def>

<sn>3.</sn> <def>A kind of watch crystal which is more than
ordinarily flattened in the center; also, a species of
convexoconcave lens for spectacles.</def>

<sn>4.</sn> <def>A piece of felt to cover the eye of a vicious
horse.</def>

<sn>5.</sn> <fld>(Arch.)</fld> <def>Any surface of semicircular
or segmental form; especially, the piece of wall between the
curves of a vault and its springing line.</def>

<sn>6.</sn> <def>An iron shoe at the end of the stock of a gun
carriage.</def>

<cs><col>Lunette window</col> <fld>(Arch.)</fld>, <cd>a window
which fills or partly fills a lunette.</cd></cs>

<hw>Lung</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[OE.
<ets>lunge</ets>, AS. <ets>lunge</ets>, pl. <ets>lungen</ets>;
akin to D. <ets>long</ets>, G. <ets>lunge</ets>, Icel. & Sw.
<ets>lunga</ets>, Dan. <ets>lunge</ets>, all prob. from the root
of E. <ets>light</ets>. <ets><?/</ets> See <er>Light</er> not
heavy.]</ety> <fld>(Anat.)</fld> <def>An organ for a\'89rial
respiration; -- commonly in the plural.</def>

<q>My <qex>lungs</qex> began to crow
like chanticleer.</q>
<qau>Shak.</qau>

<-- Insert: Illustration of lungs with description. -->

<note><hand/ In all air-breathing vertebrates the lungs are
developed from the ventral wall of the esophagus as a pouch which
divides into two sacs. In amphibians and many reptiles the lungs
retain very nearly this primitive saclike character, but in the
higher forms the connection with the esophagus becomes elongated
into the windpipe and the inner walls of the sacs become more and
more divided, until, in the mammals, the air spaces become
minutely divided into tubes ending in small air cells, in the
walls of which the blood circulates in a fine network of
capillaries. In mammals the lungs are more or less divided into
lobes, and each lung occupies a separate cavity in the thorax.
See <er>Respiration</er>.</note>

<cs><col>Lung fever</col> <fld>(Med.)</fld>, <cd>pneumonia.</cd>
-- <col>Lung flower</col> <fld>(Bot.)</fld>, <cd>a species of
gentian (<spn>G. Pneumonanthe</spn>).</cd> -- <mcol><col>Lung
lichen</col> <fld>(Bot.)</fld>, <cd>tree lungwort.</cd> See under
<er>Lungwort</er>. <col>Lung sac</col> <fld>(Zo\'94l.)</fld>,
<cd>one of the breathing organs of spiders and snails.</cd></cs>

<hw>Lunge</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[Also spelt
<ets>longe</ets>, fr. <ets>allonge</ets>. See <er>Allonge</er>,
<er>Long</er>.]</ety> <def>A sudden thrust or pass, as with a
sword.</def>

<hw>Lunge</hw>, <pos>v. i.</pos> <wordforms>[<pos>imp. & p.

<hw>\'d8Lun"goor</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[Hind.
<ets>lang<umac/r</ets>.]</ety> <fld>(Zo\'94l.)</fld> <def>A

<hw>Lung"worm`</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos>
<fld>(Zo\'94l.)</fld> <def>Any one of several species of
parasitic nematoid worms which infest the lungs and air passages
of cattle, sheep, and other animals, often proving fatal. The
lungworm of cattle (<spn>Strongylus micrurus</spn>) and that of
sheep (<spn>S. filaria</spn>) are the best known.</def>

<hw>Lung"wort`</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <fld>(Bot.)</fld>
<sd>(a)</sd> <def>An herb of the genus <spn>Pulmonaria</spn>
(<spn>P. officinalis</spn>), of Europe; -- so called because the
spotted appearance of the leaves resembles that of a diseased
lung.</def> <sd>(b)</sd> <def>Any plant of the genus
<spn>Mertensia</spn> (esp. <spn>M. Virginica</spn> and <spn>M.
Sibirica</spn>) plants nearly related to <spn>Pulmonaria</spn>.
The American lungwort is <spn>Mertensia Virginica</spn>, Virginia
cowslip.</def>

<au>Gray.</au>

<cs><col>Cow's lungwort</col> <cd>mullein.</cd> -- <col>Sea
lungwort</col>, <cd><spn>Mertensia maritima</spn>, found on the
seacoast of Northern Europe and America.</cd> -- <col>Tree
lungwort</col>, <cd>a lichen (<spn>Sticta pulmonacea</spn>)
growing on trees and rocks. The thallus is lacunose, and in
appearance somewhat resembles the lungs, for diseases of which it
was once thought a remedy.</cd></cs>

<hw>Lu"ni*cur"rent</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>a.</pos> <ety>[L.

<hw>Lu"ni*form</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>a.</pos> <ety>[L.

<hw>Lu"ni*so"lar</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>a.</pos> <ety>[L.
<ets>luna</ets> moon + E. <ets>solar</ets>: cf. F.
<ets>lunisolaire</ets>.]</ety> <def>Resulting from the united
action, or pertaining to the mutual relations, of the sun and
moon.</def>

<cs><col>Lunisolar precession</col> <fld>(Astron.)</fld>,
<cd>that portion of the annual precession of the equinoxes which
depends on the joint action of the sun and moon.</cd> --
<col>Lunisolar year</col>, <cd>a period of time, at the end of
which, in the Julian calendar, the new and full moons and the
eclipses recur on the same days of the week and month and year as
in the previous period. It consists of 532 common years, being
the least common multiple of the numbers of years in the cycle of
the sun and the cycle of the moon.</cd></cs>

<hw>Lu"ni*stice</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[L.
<ets>luna</ets>. moon + <ets>sistere</ets> to cause to stand. Cf.
<er>Solstice</er>.]</ety> <fld>(Astron.)</fld> <def>The farthest
point of the moon's northing and southing, in its monthly
revolution.</def> <mark>[Obs.]</mark>

<hw>Lu"ni*tid`al</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>a.</pos> <def>Pertaining

<hw>Lu"pine</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[L.

<fld>(Bot.)</fld> <def>A leguminous plant of the genus

species of the Eastern United States is <spn>L. perennis</spn>.
There are many species in California.</def>

<hw>Lu"pu*lin</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[Cf. F.
<ets>lupulin</ets>. See <er>Lupuline</er>.]</ety> <sn>1.</sn>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>The fine yellow resinous powder found upon the

<asp>lupuline</asp>.]</altsp>

<hw>Lu"pu*line</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[NL.

<hw>Lu`pu*lin"ic</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>a.</pos>

<hw>\'d8Lu"pus</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[L., a wolf.
See <er>Wolf</er>.]</ety> <sn>1.</sn> <fld>(Med.)</fld> <def>A
cutaneous disease occurring under two distinct forms.</def>

<note><hand/ <xex>Lupus erythematosus</xex> is characterized by
an eruption of red patches, which become incrusted, leaving
superficial scars. <xex>L. vulgaris</xex> is marked by the
development of nodules which often ulcerate deeply and produce
great deformity. Formerly the latter was often confounded with
cancer, and some varieties of cancer were included under
Lupus.</note>
<-- systemic lupus erythematosus is an inflammatory disease -->

<sn>2.</sn> <fld>(Astron.)</fld> <def>The Wolf, a constellation
situated south of Scorpio.</def>

<hw>Lur*ca"tion</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[See its
<er>Lurch</er>.]</ety> <def>Gluttony; gormandizing.</def>
<mark>[Obs.]</mark>

<hw>Lurch</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>v. i.</pos> <ety>[L.
<ets>lurcare</ets>, <ets>lurcari</ets>.]</ety> <def>To swallow or
eat greedily; to devour; hence, to swallow up.</def>
<mark>[Obs.]</mark>

<q>Too far off from great cities, which may hinder business; too
near them, which <qex>lurcheth</qex> all provisions, and maketh
everything dear.</q>
<qau>Bacon.</qau>

<hw>Lurch</hw>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[OF. <ets>lourche</ets> name
of a game; as adj., deceived, embarrassed.]</ety> <sn>1.</sn>
<def>An old game played with dice and counters; a variety of the
game of tables.</def>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>A double score in cribbage for the winner when
his adversary has been left in the <xex>lurch</xex>.</def>

<q>Lady --- has cried her eyes out on losing a
<qex>lurch</qex>.</q>
<qau>Walpole.</qau>

<cs><col>To leave one in the lurch</col>. <sd>(a)</sd> <cd>In the
game of cribbage, to leave one's adversary so far behind that the
game is won before he has scored thirty-one</cd>. <sd>(b)</sd>
<cd>To leave one behind; hence, to abandon, or fail to stand by,
a person in a difficulty.</cd> <au>Denham.</au>

<q>But though thou'rt of a different church,
I will not <qex>leave thee in the lurch</qex>.</q>
<qau>Hudibras.</qau>
</cs>

<hw>Lurch</hw>, <pos>v. t.</pos> <sn>1.</sn> <def>To leave in the
lurch; to cheat.</def> <mark>[Obs.]</mark>

<q>Never deceive or <qex>lurch</qex> the sincere communicant.</q>
<qau>South.</qau>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>To steal; to rob.</def> <mark>[Obs.]</mark>

<q>And in the brunt of seventeen battles since
He <qex>lurched</qex> all swords of the garland.</q>
<qau>Shak.</qau>

<hw>Lurch</hw>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[Cf. W. <ets>llerch</ets>,
<ets>llerc</ets>, a frisk, a frisking backward or forward, a
loitering, a lurking, a lurking, <ets>llercian</ets>,
<ets>llerciaw</ets>, to be idle, to frisk; or perh. fr. E.
<ets>lurch</ets> to lurk.]</ety> <def>A sudden roll of a ship to
one side, as in heavy weather; hence, a swaying or staggering
movement to one side, as that by a drunken man. Fig.: A sudden
and capricious inclination of the mind.</def>

<-- p. 876 -->

<hw>Lurch</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>v. i.</pos>
<wordforms>[<pos>imp. & p. p.</pos> <er>Lurched</er>
<pr>(?)</pr>; <pos>p. pr. & vb. n.</pos>
<er>Lurching</er>.]</wordforms> <def>To roll or sway suddenly to
one side, as a ship or a drunken man.</def>

<hw>Lurch</hw>, <pos>v. i.</pos> <ety>[A variant of
<ets>lurk</ets>.]</ety> <sn>1.</sn> <def>To withdraw to one side,
or to a private place; to lurk.</def>

<au>L'Estrange.</au>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>To dodge; to shift; to play tricks.</def>

<q>I . . . am fain to shuffle, to hedge, and to
<qex>lurch</qex>.</q>
<qau>Shak.</qau>

<hw>Lurch"er</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[See
<er>Lurch</er> to lurk.]</ety> <sn>1.</sn> <def>One that lurches
or lies in wait; one who watches to pilfer, or to betray or
entrap; a poacher.</def>

<sn>2.</sn> <fld>(Zo\'94l.)</fld> <def>One of a mongrel breed of
dogs said to have been a cross between the sheep dog, greyhound,
and spaniel. It hunts game silently, by scent, and is often used
by poachers.</def>

<hw>Lurch"er</hw>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[L. <ets>lurco</ets>,

<hw>Lure</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[OF.
<ets>loire</ets>, <ets>loirre</ets>, <ets>loerre</ets>, F.
<ets>leurre</ets> lure, decoy; of German origin; cf. MHG.
<ets>luoder</ets>, G. <ets>luder</ets> lure, carrion.]</ety>
<sn>1.</sn> <def>A contrivance somewhat resembling a bird, and
often baited with raw meat; -- used by falconers in recalling

<au>Shak.</au>

prospect of advantage or pleasure; a decoy.</def>

<au>Milton.</au>

brush.</def>

<au>Knight.</au>

<hw>Lure</hw>, <pos>v. t.</pos> <wordforms>[<pos>imp. & p.
p.</pos> <er>Lured</er> <pr>(?)</pr>; <pos>p. pr. & vb. n.</pos>
<er>Luring</er>.]</wordforms> <ety>[OF. <ets>loirer</ets>,
<ets>loirier</ets>, F. <ets>leurrer</ets>. See <er>Lure</er>,
<pos>n.</pos>]</ety> <def>To draw to the lure; hence, to allure

advantage; to entice; to attract.</def>

<q>I am not <qex>lured</qex> with love.</q>
<qau>Piers Plowman.</qau>

<q>And various science <qex>lures</qex> the learned eye.</q>
<qau>Gay.</qau>

<hw>Lure</hw>, <pos>v. i.</pos> <def>To recall a hawk or other
animal.</def>

<hw>Lurg</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <fld>(Zo\'94l.)</fld>
<def>A large marine annelid (<spn>Nephthys c\'91ca</spn>),
inhabiting the sandy shores of Europe and America. It is whitish,
with a pearly luster, and grows to the length of eight or ten
inches.</def>

<hw>Lu"rid</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>a.</pos> <ety>[L.
<ets>luridus</ets>.]</ety> <sn>1.</sn> <def>Pale yellow; ghastly
pale; wan; gloomy; dismal.</def>

<q>Fierce o'er their beauty blazed the <qex>lurid</qex>
flame.</q>
<qau>Thomson.</qau>

<q>Wrapped in drifts of <qex>lurid</qex> smoke
On the misty river tide.</q>
<qau>Tennyson.</qau>

<sn>2.</sn> <fld>(Bot.)</fld> <def>Having a brown color tonged
with red, as of flame seen through smoke.</def>

<sn>3.</sn> <fld>(Zo\'94l.)</fld> <def>Of a color tinged with
purple, yellow, and gray.</def>

<hw>Lurk</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>v. i.</pos>
<wordforms>[<pos>imp. & p. p.</pos> <er>Lurked</er> <pr>(?)</pr>;
<pos>p. pr. & vb. n.</pos> <er>Lurking</er>.]</wordforms>
<ety>[OE. <ets>lurken</ets>, <ets>lorken</ets>, prob. a dim. from
the source of E. <ets>lower</ets> to frown. See <er>Lower</er>,
and cf. <er>Lurch</er>, a sudden roll, <er>Lurch</er> to
lurk.]</ety> <sn>1.</sn> <def>To lie hid; to lie in wait.</def>

<q>Like wild beasts, <qex>lurking</qex> in loathsome den.</q>
<qau>Spenser.</qau>

<q>Let us . . . <qex>lurk</qex> privily for the innocent.</q>
<qau>Prov. i. 11.</qau>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>To keep out of sight.</def>

<q>The defendant <qex>lurks</qex> and wanders about in Berks.</q>
<qau>Blackstone.</qau>

<hw>Lurk"er</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <sn>1.</sn> <def>One
who lurks.</def>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>A small fishing boat.</def> <mark>[Prov.
Eng.]</mark>

<hw>Lur"ry</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[W.
<ets>llwry</ets> precipitant, a provision.]</ety> <def>A confused
heap; a throng, as of persons; a jumble, as of sounds.</def>
<mark>[Obs.]</mark>

<q>To turn prayer into a kind of <qex>lurry</qex>.</q>
<qau>Milton.</qau>

<hw>Lus"cious</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>a.</pos> <ety>[Prob. for
<ets>lustious</ets>, fr. <ets>lusty</ets>, or perh. a corruption
of <ets>luxurious</ets>. Cf. <er>Lush</er>,
<er>Lusty</er>.]</ety>

<sn>1.</sn> <def>Sweet; delicious; very grateful to the taste;
toothsome; excessively sweet or rich.</def>

<q>And raisins keep their <qex>luscious</qex>, native taste.</q>
<qau>Dryden.</qau>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>Cloying; fulsome.</def>

<q>He had a tedious, <qex>luscious</qex> way of talking.</q>
<qau>Jeffrey.</qau>

<sn>3.</sn> <def>Gratifying a depraved sense; obscene.</def>
<mark>[R.]</mark>

<au>Steele.</au>

<hw>Lust</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[AS.
<ets>lust</ets>, <ets>lust</ets>, pleasure, longing; akin to OS.,
D., G., & Sw. <ets>lust</ets>, Dan. & Icel. <ets>lyst</ets>, Goth
<ets>lustus</ets>, and perh. tom Skr. <ets>lush</ets> to desire,
or to E. <ets>loose</ets>. Cf. <er>List</er> to please,
<er>Listless</er>.]</ety> <sn>1.</sn> <def>Pleasure</def>
<mark>[Obs.]</mark> \'bd Lust and jollity.\'b8

<au>Chaucer.</au>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>Inclination; desire.</def> <mark>[Obs.]</mark>

<q>For little <qex>lust</qex> had she to talk of aught.</q>
<qau>Spenser.</qau>

<q>My <qex>lust</qex> to devotion is little.</q>
<qau>Bp. Hall.</qau>

<sn>3.</sn> <def>Longing desire; eagerness to possess or enjoy;
-- in a had sense; <as>as, the <ex>lust</ex> of gain</as>.</def>

<q>The <qex>lust</qex> of reigning.</q>

<au>Milton.</au>

<sn>4.</sn> <def>Licentious craving; sexual appetite.</def>

<au>Milton.</au>

<sn>5.</sn> <def>Hence: Virility; vigor; active power.</def>
<mark>[Obs.]</mark>

<au>Bacon.</au>

<hw>Lust</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>v. i.</pos>
<wordforms>[<pos>imp. & p. p.</pos> <er>Lusted</er>; <pos>p. pr.
& vb. n.</pos> <er>Lusting</er>.]</wordforms> <ety>[AS.
<ets>lystan</ets>. See <er>Lust</er>, <pos>n.</pos>, and cf. List
to choose.]</ety> <sn>1.</sn> <def>To list; to like.</def>
<mark>[Obs.]</mark> <au>Chaucer</au>. \'bd Do so if thou
<xex>lust</xex>. \'b8

<au>Latimer.</au>

<note><hand/ In earlier usage <xex>lust</xex> was impersonal.

<q>In the water vessel he it cast
When that him <qex>luste</qex>.</q>
<qau>Chaucer.</qau>
</note>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>To have an eager, passionate, and especially an
inordinate or sinful desire, as for the gratification of the
sexual appetite or of covetousness; -- often with
<ptcl>after</ptcl>.</def>

<q>Whatsoever thy soul <qex>lusteth</qex> after.</q>
<qau>Deut. xii. 15.</qau>

<q>Whosoever looketh on a woman to <qex>lust</qex> after her,
hath committed adultery with her already in his heart.</q>
<qau>Matt. v. 28.</qau>

<q>The spirit that dwelleth in us <qex>lusteth</qex> to envy.</q>
<qau>James iv. 5. </qau>

<hw>Lust"er</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <def>One who
lusts.</def>

<hw>Lus"ter Lus"tre</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[L.
<ets>lustrum</ets>: cf. F. <ets>lustre</ets>.]</ety> <def>A
period of five years; a lustrum.</def>

<q>Both of us have closed the tenth <qex>luster</qex>.</q>
<qau>Bolingbroke.</qau>

<mhw>{ <hw>Lus"ter</hw>, <hw>Lus"tre</hw>, }</mhw> <pos>n.</pos>
<ety>[F. <ets>lustre</ets>; cf. It. <ets>lustro</ets>; both fr.
L. <ets>lustrare</ets> to purify, go about (like the priests at
the lustral sacrifice), traverse, survey, illuminate, fr.
<ets>lustrum</ets> a purificatory sacrifice; perh. akin to E.
<ets>loose</ets>. But <ets>lustrare</ets> to illuminate is perh.
a different word, and akin to L. <ets>lucere</ets> to be light or
clear, to shine. See <er>Lucid</er>, and cf.
<er>Illustrious</er>, <er>Lustrum</er>.]</ety>

<sn>1.</sn> <def>Brilliancy; splendor; brightness; glitter.</def>

<q>The right mark and very true <qex>luster</qex> of the
diamond.</q>
<qau>Sir T. More.</qau>

<q>The scorching sun was mounted high,
In all its <qex>luster</qex>, to the noonday sky.</q>
<qau>Addison.</qau>

<note><hand/ There is a tendency to limit the use of
<xex>luster</xex>, in this sense, to the brightness of things
which do not shine with their own light, or at least do not blaze
or glow with heat. One speaks of the <xex>luster</xex> of a
diamond, or of silk, or even of the stars, but not often now of
the <xex>luster</xex> of the sun, a coal of fire, or the
like.</note>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>Renown; splendor; distinction; glory.</def>

<q>His ancestors continued about four hundred years, rather
without obscurity than with any great <qex>luster</qex>.</q>
<qau>Sir H. Wotton.</qau>

<sn>3.</sn> <def>A candlestick, chandelier, girandole, or the
like, generally of an ornamental character.</def>

<au>Pope.</au>

<sn>4.</sn> <fld>(Min.)</fld> <def>The appearance of the surface
of a mineral as affected by, or dependent upon, peculiarities of
its reflecting qualities.</def>

<note><hand/ The principal kinds of luster recognized are:
<xex>metallic</xex>, <xex>adamantine</xex>, <xex>vitreous</xex>,
<xex>resinous</xex>, <xex>greasy</xex>, <xex>pearly</xex>, and
<xex>silky</xex>. With respect to intensity, <xex>luster</xex> is
characterized as <xex>splendent</xex>, <xex>shining</xex>,
<xex>glistening</xex>, <xex>glimmering</xex>, and
<xex>dull</xex>.</note>

<sn>5.</sn> <def>A substance which imparts luster to a surface,
as plumbago and some of the glazes.</def>

<sn>6.</sn> <def>A fabric of wool and cotton with a lustrous
surface, -- used for women's dresses.</def>

<cs><col>Luster ware</col>, <cd>earthenware decorated by applying
to the glazing metallic oxides, which acquire brilliancy in the
process of baking.</cd></cs>

<mhw>{ <hw>Lus"ter</hw>, <hw>Lus"tre</hw>, }</mhw> <pos>v.
t.</pos> <wordforms>[<pos>imp. & p. p.</pos> <er>Lustred</er>
<pr>(?)</pr>; <pos>p. pr. & vb. n.</pos> <er>Lustering</er>, <or/
<er>Lustring</er>.]</wordforms> <def>To make lustrous.</def>
<mark>[R. & Poetic]</mark>

<q>Flooded and <qex>lustered</qex> with her loosened gold.</q>
<qau>Lowell.</qau>

<hw>Lus"ter*ing</hw>, <pos>n.</pos> <sn>1.</sn> <def>The act or
process of imparting a luster, as to pottery.</def>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>The brightening of a metal in the crucible when
it becomes pure, as in certain refining processes.</def>

<mhw>{ <hw>Lus"ter*less</hw>, <hw>Lus"tre*less</hw>, }</mhw>
<pos>a.</pos> <def>Destitute of luster; dim; dull.</def>

<hw>Lust"ful</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>a.</pos> <sn>1.</sn>
<def>Full of lust; excited by lust</def>

<au>Spenser. Tillotson.</au>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>Exciting lust; characterized by lust or
sensuality.</def> \'bd <xex>Lustful</xex> orgies.\'b8

<au>Milton.</au>

<sn>3.</sn> <def>Strong; lusty.</def> <mark>[Obs.]</mark> \'bd
<xex>Lustful</xex> health.\'b8

<au>Sackville.</au>

<syn>Syn. -- sensual; fleshly; carnal; inordinate; licentious;
lewd; unchaste; impure; libidinous; lecherous.</syn>

<hw>Lus"trate</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>v. t.</pos>
<wordforms>[<pos>imp. & p. p.</pos> <er>Lustrated</er>

<hw>Lus"tring</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[F.

<hw>Lus"trous</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>a.</pos> <ety>[Cf. F.

<hw>Lus"trum</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos>; <plu>pl. E.
<plw>Lustrums</plw> <pr>(#)</pr>, L. <plw>Lustra</plw>
<pr>(#)</pr></plu>. <ety>[L. Cf. 2d & 3d <er>Luster</er>.]</ety>
<def>A lustration or purification, especially the purification of
the whole Roman people, which was made by the censors once in
five years. Hence: A period of five years.</def>

<hw>Lust"wort`</hw> <pos>n.</pos> <fld>(Bot.)</fld> <def>See
<er>Sundew</er>.</def>

<hw>Lust"y</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>a.</pos>
<wordforms>[<pos>Compar.</pos> <er>Lustier</er> <pr>(?)</pr>;
<pos>superl.</pos> <er>Lustiest</er>.]</wordforms> <ety>[From
<er>Lust</er>. See <er>Lust</er>, and cf.
<er>Luscious</er>.]</ety>

<sn>1.</sn> <def>Exhibiting lust or vigor; stout; strong;
vigorous; robust; healthful; able of body.</def>

<q>Neither would their old men, so many as were yet vigorous and

<sn>2.</sn> <def>Beautiful; handsome; pleasant.</def>

sometimes, pregnant.</def> <mark>[Obs. or Prov.]</mark>

<sn>4.</sn> <def>Lustful; lascivious.</def> <mark>[Obs.]</mark>

<au>Milton.</au>

<hw>Lu*ta"tion</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[L.
<ets>lutare</ets>, <ets>lutatum</ets>, to bedaub with mud, fr.

<hw>Lute</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[L.
<ets>lutum</ets> mud, clay: cf. OF. <ets>lut</ets>.]</ety>

<sn>1.</sn> <fld>(Chem.)</fld> <def>A cement of clay or other
tenacious infusible substance for sealing joints in apparatus, or
the mouths of vessels or tubes, or for coating the bodies of
retorts, etc., when exposed to heat; -- called also
<altname>luting</altname>.</def>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>A packing ring, as of rubber, for fruit jars,
etc.</def>

<sn>3.</sn> <fld>(Brick Making)</fld> <def>A straight-edged piece
of wood for striking off superfluous clay from mold.</def>

<hw>Lute</hw>, <pos>v. t.</pos> <wordforms>[<pos>imp. & p.
p.</pos> <er>Luted</er>; <pos>p. pr. & vb. n.</pos>
<er>Luting</er>.]</wordforms> <def>To close or seal with lute;
<as>as, to <ex>lute</ex> on the cover of a crucible; to
<ex>lute</ex> a joint.</as></def>

<hw>Lute</hw>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[OF. <ets>leut</ets>, F.
<ets>luth</ets>; skin to Pr. <ets>la\'a3t</ets>, It.
<ets>li\'a3to</ets>, <ets>le\'a3to</ets>, Sp. <ets>la\'a3d</ets>,
Pg. <ets>alaude</ets>; all fr. Ar. <ets>al'<?/d</ets>;
<ets>al</ets> the + <ets>'<?/d</ets> wood, timber, trunk or
branch of a tree, staff, stick, wood of aloes, lute or
harp.]</ety> <fld>(Mus.)</fld> <def>A stringed instrument
formerly much in use. It consists of four parts, namely, the
table or front, the body, having nine or ten ribs or
\'bdsides,\'b8 arranged like the divisions of a melon, the neck,
which has nine or ten frets or divisions, and the head, or cross,
in which the screws for tuning are inserted. The strings are
struck with the right hand, and with the left the stops are
pressed.</def>

<hw>Lute</hw>, <pos>v. i.</pos> <def>To sound, as a lute.
<xex>Piers Plowman</xex>. <xex>Keats</xex>.</def>

<hw>Lute</hw>, <pos>v. t.</pos> <def>To play on a lute, or as on
a lute.</def>

<q>Knaves are men
That <qex>lute</qex> and flute fantastic tenderness.</q>
<qau>Tennyson.</qau>

<hw>Lute"-backed`</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>a.</pos> <def>Having a
curved spine.</def>

<hw>Lu*te"ic</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>a.</pos> <fld>(Chem.)</fld>
<sd>(a)</sd> <def>Pertaining to, or derived from, weld
(<spn>Reseda luteola</spn>).</def> <sd>(b)</sd> <def>Pertaining
to, or designating, an acid resembling luteolin, but obtained
from the flowers of <spn>Euphorbia cyparissias</spn>.</def>

<hw>Lu"te*in</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[From corpus
<ets>lute</ets>um.]</ety> <fld>(Physiol. Chem.)</fld> <def>A
substance of a strongly marked yellow color, extracted from the
yelk of eggs, and from the tissue of the corpus luteum.</def>

<hw>Lut"e*nist</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <def>Same as
<er>Lutanist</er>.</def>

<hw>Lu"te*o-</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>. <ety>[L.
<ets>luteus</ets>.]</ety> <fld>(Chem.)</fld> <def>A combining
form signifying <xex>orange yellow</xex> or <xex>brownish
yellow</xex>.</def>

<hw>Lu"te*o*co*balt"ic</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>a.</pos>
<fld>(Chem.)</fld> <def>Pertaining to, or designating, certain
compounds of cobalt having a yellow color. Cf.
<er>Cobaltic</er>.</def>

<cs><col>Luteocobaltic chloride</col> <fld>(Chem.)</fld>, <cd>a
brilliant reddish yellow crystalline compound,
<chform>Co2Cl6(NH3)12</chform>, obtained by the action of
ammonium chloride on an ammoniacal solution of cobaltic
chloride.</cd></cs>

<hw>Lu"ti*dine</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[From
<ets>toluidine</ets>, by transposition.]</ety> <fld>(Chem.)</fld>
<def>Any one of several metameric alkaloids,
<chform>C5H3N.(CH3)2</chform>, of the pyridine series, obtained
from bone oil as liquids, and having peculiar pungent odors.
These alkaloids are also called respectively <altname>dimethyl
pyridine</altname>, <altname>ethyl pyridine</altname>, etc.</def>
<-- most commonly 2,6-lutidine = 2,6-dimethyl pyridine -->

<-- p. 877 -->

<hw>Lux*u"ri*ant</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>a.</pos> <ety>[L.

<def>Exuberant in growth; rank; excessive; very abundant; <as>as,
a <ex>luxuriant</ex> growth of grass; <ex>luxuriant</ex>
foliage.</as></def>

<q>Prune the <qex>luxuriant</qex>, the uncouth refine.</q>
<qau>Pope.</qau>

<cs><col>Luxuriant flower</col> <fld>(Bot.)</fld>, <cd>one in
which the floral envelopes are overdeveloped at the expense of
the essential organs.</cd></cs>

<hw>Lux*u"ri*ant*ly</hw>, <pos>adv.</pos> <def>In a luxuriant
manner.</def>

<hw>Lux*u"ri*ate</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>v. i.</pos>
<wordforms>[<pos>imp. & p. p.</pos> <er>Luxuriated</er>
<pr>(?)</pr>; <pos>p. pr. & vb. n.</pos>
<er>Luxuriating</er>.]</wordforms> <ety>[L.
<ets>luxuriatus</ets>, p. p. of <ets>luxuriari</ets>,
<ets>-are</ets>, to luxuriate. See <er>Luxury</er>.]</ety>

<sn>1.</sn> <def>To grow exuberantly; to grow to superfluous
abundance.</def> \'bd Corn <xex>luxuriates</xex> in a better
mold.\'b8

<au>Burton.</au>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>To feed or live luxuriously; <as>as, the herds
<ex>luxuriate</ex> in the pastures</as>.</def>

<sn>3.</sn> <def>To indulge with unrestrained delight and
freedom; <as>as, to <ex>luxuriate</ex> in description</as>.</def>

<hw>Lux"u*ry</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos>; <plu>pl.
<plw>Luxuries</plw> <pr>(#)</pr></plu>. <ety>[L.
<ets>luxuria</ets>, fr. <ets>luxus</ets>: cf. F.
<ets>luxure</ets>.]</ety> <sn>1.</sn> <def>A free indulgence in
costly food, dress, furniture, or anything expensive which
gratifies the appetites or tastes.</def>

<q>Riches expose a man to pride and <qex>luxury</qex>.</q>
<qau>Spectator.</qau>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>Anything which pleases the senses, and is also
costly, or difficult to obtain; an expensive rarity; <as>as,
silks, jewels, and rare fruits are <ex>luxuries</ex>; in some
countries ice is a great <ex>luxury</ex>.</as></def>

<q>He cut the side of a rock for a garden, and, by laying on it
earth, furnished out a kind of <qex>luxury</qex> for a
hermit.</q>
<qau>Addison.</qau>

<sn>3.</sn> <def>Lechery; lust.</def> <mark>[Obs.]</mark>

<au>Shak.</au>

<q><qex>Luxury</qex> is in wine and drunkenness.</q>
<qau>Chaucer.</qau>

<sn>4.</sn> <def>Luxuriance; exuberance.</def>
<mark>[Obs.]</mark>

<au>Bacon.</au>

<syn>Syn. -- Voluptuousness; epicurism; effeminacy; sensuality;
lasciviousness; dainty; delicacy; gratification.</syn>

<hw>Ly*ce"um</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos>; <plu>pl. E.

<hw>\'d8Lych"nis</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[L., a
kind of red flower, Gr. <grk>lychni`s</grk>; cf.
<grk>ly`chnos</grk> a lamp.]</ety> <fld>(Bot.)</fld> <def>A genus
of Old World plants belonging to the Pink family
(<spn>Caryophyllace\'91</spn>). Most of the species have
brilliantly colored flowers and cottony leaves, which may have
anciently answered as wicks for lamps. The botanical name is in
common use for the garden species. The corn cockle (<spn>Lychnis
Githago</spn>) is a common weed in wheat fields.</def>

<cs><col>Lycopodium powder</col>, <cd>a fine powder or dust
composed of the spores of Lycopodium, and other plants of the
order <spn>Lycopodiace\'91</spn>. It is highly inflammable, and
is sometimes used in the manufacture of fireworks, and the
artificial representation of lightning.</cd></cs>

<hw>Lyd"i*an</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>a.</pos> <ety>[L.
<ets>Lydius</ets>, fr. <ets>Lydia</ets>, Gr. <?/.]</ety> <def>Of

of the ancient Greek modes or keys, the music in which was of a
soft, pathetic, or voluptuous character.</def>

<hw>Lye</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <altsp>[Written also

ornament, inhabits shaded and moist grassy places, from
Massachusetts to Virginia and Kentucky, and sparingly
southwards.</note>

<hw>Lymph</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[L.
<ets>lympha</ets>: cf. F. <ets>lymphe</ets>.]</ety> <sn>1.</sn>
<def>A spring of water; hence, water, or a pure, transparent
liquid like water.</def>

<q>A fountain bubbled up, whose <qex>lymph</qex> serene
Nothing of earthly mixture might distain.</q>
<qau>Trench.</qau>

<sn>2.</sn> <fld>(Anat.)</fld> <def>An alkaline colorless fluid,
contained in the lymphatic vessels, coagulable like blood, but
free from red blood corpuscles. It is absorbed from the various
tissues and organs of the body, and is finally discharged by the
thoracic and right lymphatic ducts into the great veins near the
heart.</def>

<sn>3.</sn> <fld>(Med.)</fld> <def>A fibrinous material exuded
from the blood vessels in inflammation. In the process of healing
it is either absorbed, or is converted into connective tissue
binding the inflamed surfaces together.</def>

<cs><col>Lymph corpuscles</col> <fld>(Anat.)</fld>, <cd>finely
granular nucleated cells, identical with the colorless blood
corpuscles, present in the lymph and chyle.</cd> -- <col>Lymph
duct</col> <fld>(Anat.)</fld>, <cd>a lymphatic.</cd> --
<col>Lymph heart</col>. <cd>See Note under <er>Heart</er>,
<pos>n.</pos>, 1.</cd></cs>

<hw>\'d8Lym`pha*de*ni"tis</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos>
<ety>[NL. See <er>Lymph</er>, and <er>Adenitis</er>.]</ety>
<fld>(Med.)</fld> <def>Inflammation of the lymphatic glands; --
called also <altname>lymphitis</altname>.</def>

<hw>\'d8Lym`pha*de*no"ma</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos>
<ety>[NL. See <er>Lymph</er>, <er>Aden-</er>, and
<er>-oma</er>.]</ety> <fld>(Med.)</fld> <def>See
<er>Lymphoma</er>.</def>

<hw>\'d8Lym*phan`ge*i"tis</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos>
<ety>[NL., from L. <ets>lympha</ets> lymph + Gr. <?/ vessel +
<ets>-itis</ets>.]</ety> <fld>(Med.)</fld> <def>Inflammation of
the lymphatic vessels.</def> <altsp>[Written also
<asp>lymphangitis</asp>.]</altsp>

<hw>Lym*phan"gi*al</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>a.</pos> <ety>[See
<er>Lymphangeitis</er>.]</ety> <fld>(Anat.)</fld> <def>Of or
pertaining to the lymphatics, or lymphoid tissue;
lymphatic.</def>

<mhw>{ <hw>Lymph"ate</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <hw>Lymph"a*ted</hw>
<pr>(?)</pr>, }</mhw> <pos>a.</pos> <ety>[L.
<ets>lymphatus</ets>, p. p. of <ets>lymphare</ets> to water,
dilute with water, to drive out of one's senses, to make
mad.]</ety> <def>Frightened into madness; raving.</def>
<mark>[Obs.]</mark>

<hw>Lym*phat"ic</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>a.</pos> <ety>[L.
<ets>lymphaticus</ets> distracted, frantic: cf. F.
<ets>lymphatique</ets>]</ety> <def>pertaining to, containing, or
conveying lymph.</def>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>Madly enthusiastic; frantic. <mark>[Obs.]</mark>
\'bd <xex>Lymphatic</xex> rapture. \'b8 <au>Sir T. Herbert</au>.
<ety>[See <er>Lymphate</er>.]</ety>

<cs><col>Lymphatic gland</col> <fld>(Anat.)</fld>, <cd>one of the
solid glandlike bodies connected with the lymphatics or the
lacteals; -- called also <altname>lymphatic ganglion</altname>,
and <altname>conglobate gland</altname>.</cd> -- <col>Lymphatic
temperament</col> <fld>(Old Physiol.)</fld>, <cd>a temperament in
which the lymphatic system seems to predominate, that is, a
system in which the complexion lacks color and the tissues seem
to be of loose texture; hence, a temperament lacking energy,
inactive, indisposed to exertion or excitement. See
<er>Temperament</er>.</cd></cs>

<hw>Lym*phat"ic</hw>, <pos>n.</pos> <sn>1.</sn>
<fld>(Anat.)</fld> <def>One of the lymphatic or absorbent
vessels, which carry lymph and discharge it into the veins; lymph
duct; lymphatic duct.</def>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>A mad enthusiast; a lunatic.</def>
<mark>[Obs.]</mark>

<hw>\'d8Lym*phi"tis</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos>
<ety>[NL.]</ety> <fld>(Med.)</fld> <def>See
<er>Lymphadenitis</er>.</def>

<hw>Lym`pho*gen"ic</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>a.</pos>
<ety>[<ets>Lymph</ets> + root of L. <ets>gignere</ets> to
produce.]</ety> <fld>(Physiol.)</fld> <def>Connected with, or
formed in, the lymphatic glands.</def>

<hw>Lym*phog"ra*phy</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos>
<ety>[<ets>Lymph</ets> + <ets>-graphy</ets>.]</ety> <def>A
description of the lymphatic vessels, their origin and
uses.</def>

<hw>Lymph"oid</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>a.</pos>
<ety>[<ets>Lymph</ets> + <ets>-oid</ets>.]</ety>
<fld>(Anat.)</fld> <def>Resembling lymph; also, resembling a
lymphatic gland; adenoid; <as>as, <ex>lymphoid</ex>
tissue</as>.</def>

<hw>\'d8Lym*pho"ma</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[NL. See
<er>Lymph</er>, and <er>-oma</er>.]</ety> <fld>(Med.)</fld>
<def>A tumor having a structure resembling that of a lymphatic
gland; -- called also <altname>lymphadenoma</altname>.</def>

<cs><col>Malignant lymphoma</col>, <cd>a fatal disease
characterized by the formation in various parts of the body of
new growths resembling lymphatic glands in structure.</cd></cs>

<hw>Lymph"y</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>a.</pos> <def>Containing, or
like, lymph.</def>

<hw>Lyn</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <def>A waterfall. See

<hw>Lyn*ce"an</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>a.</pos> <ety>[See
<er>Lynx</er>.]</ety> <fld>(Zo\'94l.)</fld> <def>Of or pertaining
to the lynx.</def>

<hw>Lynch</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>v. t.</pos>
<wordforms>[<pos>imp. & p. p.</pos> <er>Lynched</er>
<pr>(?)</pr>; <pos>p. pr. & vb. n.</pos>
<er>Lynching</er>.]</wordforms> <ety>[See Note under <er>Lynch
law</er>.]</ety> <def>To inflict punishment upon, especially
death, without the forms of law, as when a mob captures and hangs
a suspected person. See <er>Lynch law</er>.</def>

<hw>Lynch"er</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <def>One who
assists in lynching.</def>

<hw>Lynch" law`</hw> <pr>(?)</pr><def>. The act or practice by
private persons of inflicting punishment for crimes or offenses,
without due process of law.</def>

<note><hand/ The term <xex>Lynch law</xex> is said to be derived
from a Virginian named Lynch, who took the law into his own
hands. But the origin of the term is very doubtful.</note>

<mhw>{ <hw>Lynde</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <hw>Lyn"den</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>
}</mhw>, <pos>n.</pos> <def>See <er>Linden</er>.</def>

<hw>Lyne</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <def>Linen.</def>

<au>Spenser.</au>

<hw>Lynx</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[L.
<ets>lynx</ets>, <ets>lyncis</ets>, Gr. <?/; akin to AS.
<ets>lox</ets>, G. <ets>luchs</ets>, prob. named from its sharp
sight, and akin to E. <ets>light</ets>. See <er>Light</er>,
<pos>n.</pos>, and cf. <er>Ounce</er> an animal.]</ety>
<sn>1.</sn> <fld>(Zo\'94l.)</fld> <def>Any one of several species
of feline animals of the genus <spn>Felis</spn>, and subgenus
<spn>Lynx</spn>. They have a short tail, and usually a pencil of
hair on the tip of the ears.</def>

<-- p. 878 -->

<note><hand/ Among the well-known species are the European lynx
(<spn>Felis borealis</spn>); the Canada lynx or loup-cervier
(<spn>F. Canadensis</spn>); the bay lynx of America (<spn>F.
rufa</spn>), and its western spotted variety (<spn>var.
maculata</spn>); and the pardine lynx (<spn>F. pardina</spn>) of
Southern Europe.</note>

<sn>2.</sn> <fld>(Astron.)</fld> <def>One of the northern
constellations.</def>

<hw>Lynx"-eyed`</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>a.</pos> <def>Having
acute sight.</def>

<hw>Ly`on`naise"</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>a.</pos> <ety>[F.
<ets>lyonnaise</ets>, fem. of <ets>lyonnais</ets> of
Lyons.]</ety> <fld>(Cookery)</fld> <def>Applied to boiled
potatoes cut into small pieces and heated in oil or butter. They
are usually flavored with onion and parsley.</def>

<hw>\'d8Ly`o*po"ma*ta</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n. pl.</pos>
<ety>[NL., fr. Gr. <?/ to loose + <?/, <?/, a lid.]</ety>
<fld>(Zo\'94l.)</fld> <def>An order of brachiopods, in which the
valves of shell are not articulated by a hinge. It includes the
Lingula, Discina, and allied forms.</def> <altsp>[Written also
<asp>Lyopoma</asp>.]</altsp>

<hw>\'d8Ly"ra</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[L.
<ets>lyra</ets>, Gr. <?/. See <er>Lyre</er>.]</ety> <sn>1.</sn>
<fld>(Astron.)</fld> <def>A northern constellation, the Harp,
containing a white star of the first magnitude, called <xex>Alpha
Lyr\'91</xex>, <xex>or Vega</xex>.</def><-- has-member -->

<sn>2.</sn> <fld>(Anat.)</fld> <def>The middle portion of the
ventral surface of the fornix of the brain; -- so called from the
arrangement of the lines with which it is marked in the human
brain.</def>

<hw>Ly"ra*id</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos>
<fld>(Astron.)</fld> <def>Same as <er>Lyrid</er>.</def>

<mhw>{ <hw>Ly"rate</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <hw>Ly"ra*ted</hw>
<pr>(?)</pr>, }</mhw> <pos>a.</pos> <ety>[NL. <ets>lyratus</ets>.
See <er>Lyre</er>.]</ety> <sn>1.</sn> <fld>(Bot.)</fld>
<def>Lyre-shaped, or spatulate and oblong, with small lobes
toward the base; <as>as, a <ex>lyrate</ex> leaf</as>.</def>

<sn>2.</sn> <fld>(Zo\'94l.)</fld> <def>Shaped like a lyre, as the
tail of the blackcock, or that of the lyre bird.</def>

<hw>Lyre</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[OE.
<ets>lire</ets>, OF. <ets>lyre</ets>, L. <ets>lyra</ets>, Gr.
<?/. Cf. <er>Lyra</er>.]</ety> <sn>1.</sn> <fld>(Mus.)</fld>
<def>A stringed instrument of music; a kind of harp much used by
the ancients, as an accompaniment to poetry.</def>

<note><hand/ The lyre was the peculiar instrument of Apollo, the
tutelary god of music and poetry. It gave name to the species of
verse called lyric, to which it originally furnished an
accompaniment</note>

<sn>2.</sn> <fld>(Astron.)</fld> <def>One of the constellations;
Lyra. See <er>Lyra</er>.</def>

<cs><col>Lyre bat</col> <fld>(Zo\'94l.)</fld>, <cd>a small bat
(<spn>Megaderma lyra</spn>), inhabiting India and Ceylon. It is
remarkable for the enormous size and curious shape of the nose
membrane and ears.</cd> -- <col>Lyre turtle</col>
<fld>(Zo\'94l.)</fld>, <cd>the leatherback.</cd></cs>

<hw>Lyre" bird`</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>. <fld>(Zo\'94l.)</fld> <def>Any
one of two or three species of Australian birds of the genus
<spn>Menura</spn>. The male is remarkable for having the sixteen
tail feathers very long and, when spread, arranged in the form of
a lyre. The common lyre bird (<spn>Menura superba</spn>),
inhabiting New South Wales, is about the size of a grouse. Its
general color is brown, with rufous color on the throat, wings,
tail coverts and tail. Called also <altname>lyre
pheasant</altname> and <altname>lyre-tail</altname>.</def>

<mhw>{ <hw>Lyr"ic</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <hw>Lyr"ic*al</hw>
<pr>(?)</pr>, }</mhw> <pos>a.</pos> <ety>[L. <ets>lyricus</ets>,
Gr. <?/: cf. F. <ets>lyrique</ets>. See <er>Lyre</er>.]</ety>
<sn>1.</sn> <def>Of or pertaining to a lyre or harp.</def>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>Fitted to be sung to the lyre; hence, also,
appropriate for song; -- said especially of poetry which
expresses the individual emotions of the poet.</def> \'bdSweet
<xex>lyric</xex> song.\'b8

<au>Milton.</au>

<hw>Lyr"ic</hw>, <pos>n.</pos> <sn>1.</sn> <def>A lyric poem; a
lyrical composition.</def>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>A composer of lyric poems.</def>
<mark>[R.]</mark>

<au>Addison.</au>

<sn>3.</sn> <def>A verse of the kind usually employed in lyric
poetry; -- used chiefly in the <xex>plural</xex>.</def>

<au>Gray.</au>

<hw>Ly"rid</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <fld>(Astron.)</fld>
<def>One of the group of shooting stars which come into the air
in certain years on or about the 19th of April; -- so called
because the apparent path among the stars the stars if produced
back wards crosses the constellation <xex>Lyra</xex>.</def>

<hw>Ly"rie</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[Icel.
<ets>hl<?/ri</ets> a sort of fish.]</ety> <fld>(Zo\'94l.)</fld>
<def>A European fish (<spn>Peristethus cataphractum</spn>),
having the body covered with bony plates, and having three spines
projecting in front of the nose; -- called also
<altname>noble</altname>, <altname>pluck</altname>,
<altname>pogge</altname>, <altname>sea poacher</altname>, and
<altname>armed bullhead</altname>.</def>

<hw>Ly*rif"er*ous</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>a.</pos>
<ety>[<ets>Lyre</ets> + <ets>-ferous</ets>.]</ety>
<fld>(Zo\'94l.)</fld> <def>Having a lyre-shaped shoulder girdle,
as certain fishes.</def>

<hw>Lyr"ism</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[Cf. Gr.
<?/.]</ety> <def>The act of playing on a lyre or harp.</def>

<au>G. Eliot.</au>

<hw>Lyr"ist</hw>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[L. <ets>lyristes</ets>, Gr.
<?/: cf. F. <ets>lyriste</ets>.]</ety> <def>A musician who plays
on the harp or lyre; a composer of lyrical poetry.</def>

<au>Shelley.</au>

<hw>Ly*sim"e*ter</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[Gr. <?/ a
loosing + <ets>-meter</ets>.]</ety> <def>An instrument for
measuring the water that percolates through a certain depth of
soil.</def>

<au>Knight.</au>

<hw>\'d8Ly"sis</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[NL., fr.
Gr. <?/.]</ety> <fld>(Med.)</fld> <def>The resolution or
favorable termination of a disease, coming on gradually and not
marked by abrupt change.</def>

<note><hand/ It is usually contrasted with <xex>crisis</xex>, in
which the improvement is sudden and marked; as, pneumonia ends by
<xex>crisis</xex>, typhoid fever by <xex>lysis</xex>.</note>

<hw>\'d8Lys"sa</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[NL. See
<er>Lytta</er>.]</ety> <fld>(Med.)</fld> <def>Hydrophobia.</def>

<note><hand/ The plural (<xex>Lyss\'91</xex>) has been used to
signify the pustules supposed to be developed under the tongue in
hydrophobia.</note>

<hw>Ly*te"ri*an</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>a.</pos> <ety>[Gr. <?/
healing, fr. <?/ a deliverer, fr. <?/ to loosen.]</ety>
<fld>(Med.)</fld> <def>Termination a disease; indicating the end
of a disease.</def>

<hw>Lythe</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <fld>(Zo\'94l.)</fld>
<def>The European pollack; -- called also
<altname>laith</altname>, and <altname>leet</altname>.</def>
<mark>[Scot.]</mark>

<er>Lithe</er>, <pos>a.</pos>]</ety> <def>Soft; flexible.</def>

<hw>\'d8Lyt"ta</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos>; <plu>pl.
<plw>Lytt\'91</plw> <pr>(#)</pr></plu>. <ety>[L., a worm said to
